https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/15/busin.snippet: Economics of chartering one's yacht discussed; photo (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/15/busin.body_text: **********BREATHES there a sailor who has not heard the siren song of the charter programs? ''Get paid for owning a boat,'' the ads read, quite a temptation for anyone contemplating the purchase of a yacht. But like any offer that sounds too good to be true, these programs require careful scrutiny. **********Placing a yacht in charter has long been a way of offsetting the cost of ownership, especially with the rising prices of sailboats. By yacht, most charter programs mean a 30-  to 50-foot sailboat, typically with an inboard diesel motor. From major manufacturers like Beneteau S.A., Catalina Yachts or the Hunter Marine Corporation, such boats sell new for $75,000 to $375,000, up about 75 percent from 10 years ago. **********Charter programs maintain a fleet of sailboats owned by private individuals and chartered to qualified sailors by the day or week. It is a bit like owning a vacation home and renting it out to help pay the mortgage, but the charter programs do most of the work and keep part of the revenue. In some cases, the programs also pay for insurance, maintenance and dock fees, which can amount to a few thousand dollars a year, although the programs then take a larger slice of the charter income. **********Clearly, such plans can generate revenue for boat owners, but can they bring in enough money to match or exceed the cost of ownership? Can the programs turn a sailboat from an indulgence to an investment? The answers are maybe, and probably not. In many cases, the buyer's motivations and expectations are as important as the provisions of any program. **********''If one tries to analyze this for return on investment, you wouldn't analyze for very long,'' said Jean Larroux, vice president of yacht sales for the Moorings, one of the oldest and largest charter operators with more than 650 boats in service. ''There has to be some emotional involvement,'' he said. ''The revenue stream we provide is certainly real, but it's not that compelling.'' **********Some programs are multinational, with fleets across the Caribbean, the South Pacific and other exotic locales, while others are regional, in California, Florida and Texas. Although there are charter clubs in the Northeast and Midwest, short sailing seasons mean smaller revenues. **********Based in Clearwater, Fla., the Moorings has fleets in the Bahamas, the Caribbean, Mexico, Tahiti, Tonga, Fiji, Vanuatu, New Zealand, France, Turkey and Greece. All boats are sold new by the Moorings and are custom-configured by the manufacturer, Beneteau, for charter use. The Moorings pays owners 25 percent of charter revenues and picks up all other costs. **********Some programs promise a certain income, typically enough to cover mortgage payments. Others offer projections. The buyer of a new Moorings 382, the custom version of a Beneteau 380, a 38 1/2-foot boat, would pay $164,500. With 25 percent, or $41,125 down, and an interest rate of 8.75 percent, monthly payments come to $1,233. The Moorings estimates that the boat would generate $1,708 a month in charter revenue the first year, rising to $1,978 a month the fourth year, as charter rates increase. At the end of the four-year program, the owner would still owe $70,038 if all of the income were applied to the mortgage. **********In addition to the potential income, boat owners at the Moorings receive four to six weeks of owner's time, in which they can sail their own or other comparable boats, and pay a service charge of $350 a week. This allows them to sail in different parts of the world for far less than the usual $2,200 to $3,800 weekly charter cost of a boat like the 382, depending on the season. **********Although the Moorings does not account for depreciation, many charter programs do. Owners often reduce their income taxes by claiming depreciation on their boats. Tax advisers say such deductions are legitimate, but that the subject is one of great complexity and considerable litigation, so  owners should get professional advice. **********Boat owners say charter programs can be a good deal, but only for the right person: someone who could afford the boat without the charter income, which may fall well short of expectations; who can get four to six weeks of vacation a year, and who can afford to fly often. **********''You're not going to pay for the boat by chartering it out,'' said John Hakemian, a chief financial officer for a company in Manhattan, who has a boat in the Moorings fleet in the British Virgin Islands. ''The very best you can hope for is to pay off a significant fraction, one-third to one-half.'' **********''This is not an investment,'' he said. ''This is either a way to acquire a vessel at reduced cost, or more importantly, participate in a sailing program at reduced cost.'' **********JOHN WHITE, a Silicon Valley computer engineer, has had mixed results. He and his wife, Patti, have one boat in the British Virgin Islands with the Moorings and another on San Francisco Bay with Club Nautique in Alameda, Calif. Their Moorings 352, a $116,000 boat with about $850 a month in mortgage payments, has generated several thousand dollars a year in income. But their Calibre 40, which cost more than $200,000, has not earned enough revenue to pay the $1,550 monthly mortgage payment. **********''I couldn't have afforded a boat like this at all, to just put it in a marina and let it sit,'' Mr. White said. He expects the Calibre to break even next year and begin to generate income in 1998. ''I'm really going for positive cash flow with this thing,'' he said. **********Boats that are purchased from charter programs often cost more than a comparable boat bought from a dealer. Last week a dealer quoted the Beneteau 380 at $139,500, $25,000 less than the Moorings 382, the customized version of the 380. Charter companies are less willing to haggle than dealers, and typically load boats with special fittings and fixtures, which tend to have high profit margins and add little to resale value. **********So why not just buy the boat from a dealer? Because many charter programs only accept boats purchased from them. The Moorings and Club Nautique are two such programs. **********''We want the boats we want, and we want them the way we want them,'' said Don Durant, president of Club Nautique, which sells and charters boats made by Hunter. ''Our 30-footers go out 150 days a year. The reason we can do that is we standardize; we are a warranty station; we have spare parts. The typical off-the-shelf boat needs some modification for charter use.'' **********Used boats may make a better investment. Some clubs accept late-model used boats, and this is a way to increase the return on investment and reduce the cost of ownership. Because boats depreciate so rapidly, a typical 34-footer that sells new for $100,000 can be bought three years old for $50,000, yet both boats would command $300 a day in charter fees. **********''We recommend first, buy a good used boat,'' said Anthony Sandberg, president of OCSC, a charter club in Berkeley, Calif. ''Now there's some chance of making money.'' **********Hugh Devlin, a computer consultant in Chicago who bought a new 40-footer in the Moorings fleet almost four years ago, is still waiting to make money. **********''We haven't experienced any income in the Bahamas,'' Mr. Devlin said. ''Every year we've had to make up a difference between what the Moorings paid us and the mortgage. The only way I can view it as anything other than an insane act is to remember the great sailing time I've had.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/20/busin.print_headline: TORO TO ACQUIRE IRRIGATION PRODUCTS SUPPLIER
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/20/busin.body_text: **********The Toro Company, the lawn-care products concern, said yesterday that it would acquire James Hardie Irrigation Group, a unit of James Hardie Industries Ltd. of Australia, for $130 million. James Hardie Irrigation, based in Laguna Niguel, Calif., provides irrigation products to residential and commercial customers. In addition to its lawn mowers and snow blowers, Toro makes irrigation sprinkler heads. Toro, based in Minneapolis, said the price could be adjusted based on a final review of the unit's balance sheet. The company said that it expected the acquisition would reduce its per-share earnings slightly in the first year after the transaction was completed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/22/busin.print_headline: Ad Spending Rises In Gay Publications
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/22/busin.body_text: **********Advertising spending in publications aimed at gay and lesbian consumers rose significantly during the last year, an annual survey reported. **********The survey, by Mulryan/Nash, an agency in New York that specializes in marketing to homosexuals, found that spending from April 1, 1995, through March 31, 1996, rose 19.6 percent from the year-earlier period, to $73.7 million from $61.6 million. Among consumer products and services that increased spending in the publications surveyed were the America Online computer service, Subaru automobiles and Tanqueray gin. **********The study surveyed 138 local and national newspapers and 11 local and national magazines. For the third consecutive year, the two largest ad categories were bars and clubs and telephone services. Travel products and services rose to 6th place from 14th.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/03/world.body_text: **********Britain and Ireland are expected to appoint George J. Mitchell, the former Democratic Senator from Maine and chairman of an international commission on disarmament of paramilitary groups in Northern Ireland, to a major post in the peace talks that start on June 10, British officials said today. **********The commission's recommendation in January on how to handle disarmament provided grounds for a compromise that the Irish and British Governments incorporated into the process that led to the talks, which are intended to reach a political settlement of the fighting between groups representing the Protestant majority and the Roman Catholic minority in the British province of Ulster. **********The officials said that Mr. Mitchell's precise role had not yet been decided, but added that it was possible that he would be chairman of the talks,  assisted by the two other members of the disarmament commission, Gen. John de Chastelain of Canada and Harri Holkeri, a former Prime Minister of Finland.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/13/busin.body_text: **********The European Parliament voted yesterday to allow the biggest corporate users of electricity in the European Union to buy from generators anywhere in the 15-nation group starting in 1999 as a first step to opening the electricity market. The parliament, made up of lawmakers from each country, endorsed draft legislation approved by European Union governments in June. **********European Union governments are expected to agree within days to make the directive law in their countries by 1999. In 1999, only companies that use 100 gigawatt-hours of electricity a year may choose their suppliers. That limit will be lowered to 40 gigawatt-hours over nine years. (Bloomberg Business News)

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/08/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Russian Shepherd of Mutual Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/08/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Russian Shepherd of Mutual Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/08/busin.body_text: **********When Dmitri V. Vasiliev was a student of Marxist economics, he was taught that the stock market was a casino for the super-rich. **********"They stressed it served a narrow circle and was not in the interests of the  broad masses of people," Mr. Vasiliev recalled with a smile. **********Today, with an eye on those broad masses, he has a new passion: creating Russia's first mutual funds. **********As the 32-year-old head of Russia's version of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the former Marxist is now an unabashed advocate of free markets. And he sees mutual funds as the key to building capitalism, energizing the anemic stock market and helping Russia raise the money that is badly needed for investment. **********With many Russians deeply distrustful of investment schemes and the stock market experiencing growing pains, Mr. Vasiliev has his work cut out. But the potential payoff, he insists, is great. **********According to Government estimates, Russians are sitting on at least $20 billion in household savings. And Mr. Vasiliev figures that if 10 percent or so  could be drawn into the stock market, this could help the economy exceed foreign investment in Russia last year. **********"There is a huge supply of money, including hard currency, for which there is no use," Mr. Vasiliev said. "It is money kept under the pillow or bed, as we say." **********With his banker's business suit and studious manner, Mr. Vasiliev looks out of place in Russia's cut-throat political scene. By his own admission, it has been a long, strange trip. **********As a student in St. Petersburg, Mr. Vasiliev was a confirmed Marxist. But as  the cold war wound down, he began to study Western economics on his own. **********Mr. Vasiliev served as a key aide to Anatoly B. Chubais, the free-market advocate, who rose to the rank of first deputy prime minister before being ousted in January by President Boris N. Yeltsin. **********When Russia established its Federal Commission on Securities and the Capital  Market in 1994, Mr. Vasiliev became the deputy chairman and executive director under Mr. Chubais, who served as chairman. **********Now, with the Communists riding high in the polls, this is not the most auspicious time to be an economic reformer. Mr. Yeltsin's attempt to distance himself from controversial economic changes, and Mr. Chubais's departure, have led some to wonder if Mr. Vasiliev will be among the next casualties in Russia's political wars. **********Still, he soldiers on. "I can say that my work was and is supported by the Prime Minister," Mr. Vasiliev said. **********Even without the political considerations, his task would not be easy. With a capitalization of about $20 billion, the Russian stock market is tiny compared with that of major markets in the United States. **********Mr. Vasiliev's commission completed a plan in December to protect investors'  rights, which is still awaiting Mr. Yeltsin's signature. Some key elements, such as the strengthening of the law on securities fraud, require legislative approval. **********Another big problem is attracting money from small Russian investors. Not only do they face prohibitively expensive brokerage fees and red tape, but also  pyramid schemes -- like the one at the investment company MMM, have made investing synonymous with scandal for many Russians. **********"The capital market today is imbalanced," said Bernard Sucher, managing director of Troika Dialog, an investment bank and brokerage dealer. "If you are  a small Russian investor, there is no way of accessing the securities market here." **********The scarcity of Russians willing to take the risks has made the market overly dependent on wary foreign investors. **********"The market in Russia today moves on foreign money deciding to come or leave," said Christopher Smart, director of research for Pioneer First Voucher,  which is planning to start a mutual fund. "Economically, the real long-term hope for this market lies in mobilizing domestic capital." **********And this is where mutual funds come in. Last summer, Mr. Yeltsin signed a decree authorizing the creation of the funds, leaving Mr. Vasiliev to create the regulatory structure. Mr. Vasiliev hopes to issue licenses for the first mutual  funds before the country's presidential election in June. **********The funds are to be of two types: open, meaning that they are required to redeem shares within 15 days of a request, and interval, which will be obliged to redeem shares at least once a year. Foreigners will be able to invest in the funds. **********Among the companies planning to set up mutual funds are Pioneer First Voucher, in which the Boston-based Pioneer Group has a controlling interest. **********Other applicants include Russian investment groups like Asko-Kapital as well  as Dubna, whose management includes former nuclear scientists. Major Russian banks and brokerage companies, like Troika Dialog, also plan to set up funds. **********Mr. Vasiliev hopes to rehabilitate failed investment schemes and turn them into respectable mutual funds. But his commission has received only five applications from such unlicensed companies, and only one, Russki Dom Selengo, has been given temporary permission to proceed. **********Some skeptics say the Government has been moving too slowly. **********"There has been a lot of noise around this idea of mutual funds, but no result so far," said Sergei Skatershchikov, president of Skate Press, a financial data and research company. "In the short period, I do not really expect this industry to develop." **********But other specialists argue that Russian stocks are undervalued and that Russians do not have a lot of investment alternatives. Even so, much may depend  on politics. **********"If the Communists win, I think Western investors will treat Russia quite cautiously, and there will be less domestic investment," Mr. Vasiliev said. "Our Communists are not Polish Communists. They are worse." **********But, characteristically bullish, he quickly moved away from that thought. "If the elections have success, and I believe in Yeltsin's victory, we can expect a  significant development of the market in the fall of 1996," Mr. Vasiliev said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/09/busin.snippet: Securities and Exchange Commission is set to consider staff proposal that would force disclosure of ways companies are using and abusing Regulation S, 1990 rule aimed at making it easier for American firms to sell securities abroad; rule exempts f...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/09/busin.main_headline: The S.E.C. is set to undo a rule that was an invitation to abuse.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/09/busin.print_headline: The S.E.C. is set to undo a rule that was an invitation to abuse.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/09/busin.body_text: **********IT may be the worst regulation ever passed by the Securities and Exchange Commission, in terms of the invitation to abuse that it presented, but back in 1990 no one foresaw the problems. Now the S.E.C. is finally ready to force disclosure of the ways companies are using -- and misusing -- a rule meant to make it easier for American companies to sell securities overseas. **********The commission today will consider a staff proposal to require companies that make use of Regulation S to disclose the terms of any overseas offerings of stock sold under the regulation, which exempts foreign offerings from disclosure. **********Under Regulation S, American companies may sell securities overseas without any American disclosure. The rule says the overseas buyers may not sell the securities in the American market for 40 days, but otherwise sets no restrictions. **********When the rule was adopted, deregulation was a buzzword in Washington, and the view was that the commission was doing something to help companies raise foreign capital. **********The kind of companies that were expected to take advantage of the rule were major ones selling bonds in Europe. Why, the argument went, should the S.E.C. try to regulate the sale of securities when there were no American investors involved? And if the securities were to be resold in the United States, they would have to be registered anyway, so investors would be protected. **********What was not anticipated was the use of the rule by some small companies to sell stock, not bonds. The shares have often been sold at deep discounts to market value, with the buyers sometimes putting up no cash but instead providing only promissory notes. When the shares are resold in the United States, the proceeds are used to pay off the note and, assuming the stock has not collapsed, provide a tidy return for the buyers of the stock. **********In some cases, the S.E.C. has said in civil complaints, the buyers were not really foreigners at all, merely fronts that took advantage of the rule. In a criminal indictment announced in Brooklyn last week, Federal prosecutors said that six men had inflated the value of two stocks and used Rule S to secretly issue stock to allies who then sold it without disclosure. **********Just how much Regulation S has been used, or abused, is unclear because the rule does not require companies to disclose that they have used the rule to issue stock. The only way shareholders could deduce that stock was sold was when the next quarterly report came out, showing an increase in the number of shares outstanding. But even then, there was no way of knowing on what terms the shares were issued. **********The plan to be voted on by the S.E.C. calls for companies to disclose all Regulation S sales within five to 15 days of the sale of stock, including all relevant facts, such as the price and the nature of the compensation received by the company. **********It is expected that the rule will also cover private placements of stock in this country, although there have been fewer abuses in that area. In cases of those sales, the details would not need to be released until the company's next quarterly report was filed with the S.E.C. **********''If this rule is adopted, it should cure much of the problem, because of the sunlight brought through disclosure,'' said Brian J. Lane, the director of the S.E.C.'s division of corporation finance. **********But it will not cure all problems. Another favorite way for securities law violators to issue stock, according to both S.E.C. enforcement personnel and Federal prosecutors, is to use Form S-8, which requires minimal disclosure and is used to register stock distributed to employees and consultants, such as through employee stock purchase plans. The S.E.C. is thinking about making modifications to that, but has not yet taken any action. **********And more action is likely on Regulation S, although a precise proposal is at least a few months away. The S.E.C. staff is considering such questions as whether the period during which resale in the United States is barred should be lengthened from the current 40 days. Another issue is whether to ban the purchase of Regulation S securities with nonrecourse notes -- effectively freeing the buyer from paying if the stock price collapses before the shares are resold. **********Such moves may be necessary. But letting investors know that a company is selling stock at a big discount to market value will itself be a warning that something odd is going on. It is long overdue.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/10/world.snippet: Stray bullets from guns of drug traffickers are taking increasing toll among innocent bystanders in Rio de Janeiro; candidates in mayoral election campaign across city, even as rival drug gangs carry on parallel war for control of underworld; esti...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/10/world.main_headline: Drug War Forces Rio To Dodge Its Bullets
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/10/world.print_headline: Drug War Forces Rio To Dodge Its Bullets
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/10/world.body_text: **********The victims were standing at bus stops, attending university classes, chatting with friends on a balmy night or watching a circus. They have included a baby in his father's arms, children playing in front of their houses and a visitor to the Government tourist agency. Some of them have the most fashionable addresses in the city. **********All have had their play, their sleep or their lives shattered by stray bullets, a growing problem as heavy, long-range weapons have become part of the basic equipment of drug traffickers here. **********As candidates for a mayoral election this Friday blanket Rio with their pictures, flags and placards, rival drug gangs have been engaged in their own parallel war for control  -- of the city's underworld. Many of the victims have been hit in shootouts between rival drug gangs firing across the hillside slums that snake through Rio, or by police shooting it out with drug traffickers on the hills. **********For many, the decline in public safety was crystallized last month in the image of a 9-month-old baby, Lucas Cabral Albano, who was shot in his right arm at the circus while he slept in his father's arms. A week later, the circus cut short its engagement and left town. **********State security officials here estimate that 18 people were hit by stray bullets in the last two years and that 5 of them died. But Silas Diniz, who is coordinating a special police unit set up to confiscate the long-range firearms, said the official definition of stray bullets refers only those that are fired into the air and fall down far from their mark. No figures were available for people caught in the crossfire of drug wars, he said. **********But one Rio newspaper, the Jornal do Brasil, is keeping a running count. According to its tally, there has been a 50 percent increase in injuries and deaths from stray bullets over the last two years. In 1995, the newspaper said, 41 people were shot. This year, the figure had already reached 51 by early this month. **********While crime has long been an inescapable feature of life in Rio, where apartments cost more than houses largely because they are considered safer, the more recent violence has spilled over into some of the city's most expensive neighborhoods. From most streets in Ipanema and many in Copacabana, explosions and prolonged gunfire in the middle of the night are becoming a weekly occurrence. **********''When the shooting starts, I take my pillow and sleep in the living room,'' said Hilda Martins, 65, who lives on a street between Copacabana and Ipanema called Sa Ferreira. Mrs. Martins' bedroom window faces the hillside slum of Pavao-Pavaozinho, where four straight nights of gunfire a few months ago forced slum dwellers to abandon their homes and sleep at the foot of the hill out of fear they might be caught in the crossfire. **********In the penthouse apartment in Mrs. Martins' building, a bullet had come through the window and hit the wall. ''I live just under that apartment,'' she said. One doorman on the block, who refused to identify himself for fear of retaliation by the drug traffickers, said 35 apartments on Sa Ferreira were for sale. **********While the gunfire has been disturbing the sleep and security of Rio's wealthy, the most direct casualties of the heightened violence have remained those who share the city's poorest neighborhoods with the drug dealers. **********In a clinic bed in Botafogo, a 6-year-old, Clecio de Souza Farias, fell in and out of tears, 24 hours after a bullet pierced his thigh. The same bullet went on to hit the ribs of his 5-year-old friend, Rafael de Siqueira Silva, who lay in a hospital across town. The two children were playing in front of Clecio's grandmother's house in the Rio Comprido neighborhood when the gunfire started. All the children ran for cover, but Clecio and his friend fell to the ground wounded. **********''They used to avoid shooting kids, but now they don't even care,'' said Clecio's father, Cleber de Souza Farias. The traffickers are younger and younger these days, and they fight without rules or reservations, he said. ''A lot of them, the majority, are children themselves -- 12, 13, 14 years old.'' **********On Wednesday, the Mayor of Rio, Cesar Maia, proposed lowering property taxes, in some areas by as much as 46 percent, to reflect the fall in property values in areas affected by the gunfire. **********Rubem Cesar Fernandez, who heads Viva Rio, a nonprofit civic group, said that many of the heavy weapons were being smuggled in from the United States. Last year, shipments were also seized at the airport in Rio and coming in from Paraguay. **********Mr. Fernandez said that, in addition to cracking down on arms trafficking, the police should establish a permanent presence in the slums to heighten overall security. The current policy of conducting raids for specific operations ''always ends in gunfire,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/10/world.snippet: Prime Ministers of Ireland and Britain say efforts to achieve peace in Northern Ireland have been set back, but not extinguished, by bombing of British Army base near Ulster by Irish Republican Army; Prime Mins John Bruton and John Major insist pe...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/10/world.main_headline: British and Irish Premiers Say Ulster Talks Are Still On
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/10/world.print_headline: British and Irish Premiers Say Ulster Talks Are Still On
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/10/world.body_text: **********The Prime Ministers of Ireland and Britain said today that efforts to achieve peace in Northern Ireland were certainly damaged, but not extinguished, by the I.R.A. attack on a British Army base in Ulster. **********Prime Ministers John Bruton of Ireland and John Major of Britain both insisted that the peace talks would go forward without Sinn Fein, the political wing of the I.R.A., which has been excluded until the I.R.A. resumes its cease-fire. But no cease-fire is likely, according to Sinn Fein officials, until the outlawed organization's political group, has representatives sitting at the negotiation table in Belfast. **********The I.R.A. car-bombing attack in Lisburn, south of Belfast, wounded 21 soldiers and 10 civilians and was the first attack in Northern Ireland acknowledged by the I.R.A. since it declared a cease-fire on Sept. 1, 1994. **********The overwhelmingly Roman Catholic group had already broken its general cease-fire with bombings in England beginning in February. The car-bombing at the British base on Monday caused widespread pessimism and fear that regular incidents of violence might soon resume in Northern Ireland and here in the Irish Republic. **********The anxiety is aggravated by the fact that the political talks that began June 10 in Belfast, the Northern Ireland capital, have in recent weeks slipped deeper into deadlock beween Catholic and Protestant politicians and officials of the Irish and British Governments. **********Protestant paramilitary groups, whose own cease-fire began on Oct. 13, 1994, are widely feared to be considering retaliation for the renewal of violence in Northern Ireland. Protestant paramilitary leaders have said that if they resume attacks, they will include Dublin and other Irish cities. **********The reasons for the near-collapse of the peace talks and the prospect of new fighting are complicated by the tangled history of violence and mistrust on both sides. They involve, according to officials and others close to the negotiations, a nettle of political strategies and face-saving measures, the same combination of factors that have kept the predominantly Protestant British province in turmoil for most of the last 27 years. **********The prospect of a peaceful settlement is also clouded by a split between hard-liners and moderates within the I.R.A. as well as by the general elections coming in Britain and Ireland next year. **********The political situation increases the determination of Protestant leaders in Northern Ireland to put off any accommodation with the I.R.A. and Sinn Fein. **********''The present peace process has taken us virtually nowhere,'' said Paul Arthur, a politics professor at Ulster University in Belfast. ''Both the Irish and British Governments have produced a mantra that the peace process is still in existence. In effect the peace process has been a sham for some time. The talks have not moved to substantive issues. It now comes down to whether the Governments can move things forward again.'' **********A British official said: ''Look, we have established a process that wasn't there before. If things collapse, and they might, the two Governments just have to sit down again and try to come up with something.'' **********In the Irish Parliament today, Mr. Bruton compared the I.R.A. to Nazis. **********Mr. Major, at the Conservative Party conference in England, accused Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein leader, of seeking to join the peace talks while knowing that the I.R.A. was planing to detonate two car bombs at the army base.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/26/world.main_headline: U.N. Council Criticizes Israel, But Half Its Members Abstain
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/26/world.print_headline: U.N. Council Criticizes Israel, But Half Its Members Abstain
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/26/world.body_text: **********Recovering some of the diplomatic ground they lost last week in the Security  Council, Arab nations forced a resolution through an emergency session of the General Assembly today condemning Israel's continuing assault on southern Lebanon. **********But the resolution, passed 64 to 2, with the United States and Israel opposed and 65 members abstaining, was slightly more moderate than the one the Council had rejected last week when 11 of the 15 members abstained. **********The General Assembly version "condemns the Israeli military attacks against  the civilian population in Lebanon" as violations of international humanitarian  law, whereas last week's resolution in the Security Council had "strongly" condemned them. It also calls upon Israel to cease such attacks, withdraw its forces from southern Lebanon and pay compensation for damage. **********Neither version had any specific criticism of the Islamic militiamen who have been firing rockets into northern Israel from Lebanon. **********But as the price for voting in favor of today's resolution, Russia succeeded  in amending the original text to affirm the right of all states in the region "to live in peace and security within their internationally recognized borders." **********The Arabs also failed to win any support from industrial countries: Canada, Japan, the members of the European Union, the nations of Eastern Europe and several Latin American countries all abstained.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/04/world.main_headline: U.S. Seeking to Strengthen Nuclear Agency
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/04/world.print_headline: U.S. Seeking to Strengthen Nuclear Agency
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/04/world.body_text: **********After the Persian Gulf war, when international inspectors got a better opportunity to look around a defeated Iraq, they discovered that President Saddam Hussein had secretly been developing nuclear weapons. **********To deter such an ominous possibility from threatening the world again, Washington wants to strengthen the powers of the International Atomic Energy Agency, which is responsible for guarding against the diversion of nuclear material to bomb-making. **********But the effort has run into determined resistance, not from rogue states bent on acquiring nuclear arsenals, but from two allies -- Germany and Japan --  that fear a new burden on their flourishing nuclear power industries. **********While expressing commitment to nonproliferation, diplomats from each country, in separate interviews today, said the expanded powers that Washington is seeking for the atomic energy agency would place unfair economic and financial burdens on the owners of nuclear power plants. **********Next week, the atomic energy agency's 35-member board of governors will meet  in Vienna, where a majority of the nations will seek to persuade the Germans and Japanese to change their positions. The board operates by consensus, and the determined opposition of any member could scuttle the changes. **********In broad terms, the new powers would require nuclear installations to provide more detailed reports about domestic nuclear activity and about the imports and exports of material that can be used to make nuclear weapons. Agency inspectors would also acquire more sweeping search authority. **********"I'm in favor of it," said Gary Milhollin, director of the nonprofit Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control, about the agency's proposed new powers. But, he added, "there are some simple things the agency could do now on  its own, to increase their credibility and effectiveness." Foremost, he said, the agency should make public much of what it now keeps confidential, such as the amount of nuclear material a country has. **********Currently, the agency inspectors have authority to inspect only the nuclear plants that a government has declared exist. The agency strives to safeguard against the enrichment of uranium or production of plutonium, which can be used  in nuclear warheads. **********In Iraq, which is a member of the atomic energy agency, the inspectors had access to President Hussein's declared installations. But within the same compound, Iraq was developing nuclear weapons, in "undeclared" installations, which were off limits to the inspectors. **********More recently, in North Korea, the Government had no problems with allowing the atomic energy agency to inspect declared sites. But when inspectors sought to look at sites the Government had not declared, but which American intelligence said were nuclear installations, the North Koreans balked, effectively confirming that they were developing their own nuclear weapons. **********In principle, the German Government agrees that steps must be taken to stop these nations from getting nuclear weapons, said a senior German diplomat here. **********But he said the expanded powers as now being sought for the agency would give inspectors from the international agency more legal rights to search private property than a German police officer has. **********Concern about the economic and financial burden on operators of the nuclear installations is also at the foundation of Japanese objections to expanding the  atomic energy agency's power, said Makoto Yamanaka, a senior diplomat at the Japanese mission to the United Nations organizations in Vienna. **********Mr. Yamanaka said the burden of atomic energy inspections is already greater  on Japan than on other countries, because of its large nuclear industry. **********The American representative to the United Nations here, John B. Ritch 3d, agreed that Germany and Japan will bear a greater burden than other countries, including the United States. **********But, he added, "the enormous benefits to global security from deterring, or at least detecting, a future Saddam Hussein, overwhelm the modest burdens involved."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/09/world.main_headline: TV Station In Bosnia Feeds Serbs Propaganda
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/09/world.print_headline: TV Station In Bosnia Feeds Serbs Propaganda
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/09/world.body_text: **********Pale Television, broadcast from a small ocher-colored building on the rutted  street that slices through the heart of this shabby former ski resort, recently  began its evening broadcast with another world exclusive. **********"NATO forces," the news announcer intoned, "used low-intensity nuclear weapons when they conducted air strikes on Serb positions around Sarajevo, Gorazde and Majevica last August and September." **********The announcer said that experts from Serbia had examined ethnic Serbs living near the areas that were attacked by NATO warplanes, in strikes carried out to force the Bosnian Serbs to stop shelling Sarajevo and make peace, and "had concluded that some people showed signs of being contaminated by radiation." **********The report, however incredulously received by those outside the self-styled Republic of Srpska and its "capital" in Pale, 10 miles east of Sarajevo, is typical of the steady diet of propaganda and questionable information that the Bosnian Serb-controlled station feeds its viewers. And while outsiders might scoff, its reports exert a powerful influence over many Bosnian Serbs, who remain deeply distrustful of the outside world and fearful that their Muslim opponents are out to destroy them. **********The Bosnian Muslims and Croats are also guilty of distorting events to suit their political agendas in their news reports, but the Serbs' fabrications are the most extravagant. **********The Vienna-based Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe and the  office of the High Representative overseeing civilian implementation of the Bosnia peace accord are raising money to set up an independent radio and television network in Sarajevo, to be named Open Broadcast News. The station, which should be in place this summer in advance of national elections scheduled  for September, will provide equal time for all political parties and candidates, as well as news coverage free of political coloring. **********But, for now, the impact of Pale Television, the only Bosnian Serb station available throughout Bosnia, is immense. **********"It keeps the political atmosphere fetid," said Michael Maclay, the chief spokesman for the High Representative, Carl Bildt. "It prevents daylight and oxygen from getting through. In the last couple of weeks it has become worse, as Stalinist as any of the old Communist regimes." **********Several themes are hammered home each night, but the most important one is the duty of Serbs to defend Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb political leader, and Gen. Ratko Mladic, the military commander, both of whom were indicted on war crimes charges by the United Nations tribunal at The Hague. **********"By taking away our leaders they wish to control us," one recent commentator  said. **********In late May, Pale Television carried what it said were the last words of the  Bosnian Serb Gen. Djordje Djukic, an indicted war criminal who was released by The Hague because he was suffering from terminal cancer. The television station  reported that Gen. Djukic, who died in Belgrade last month, had been tortured while a prisoner in The Hague. **********"As he struggled for life, he condemned Chief Justice Goldstone as a hater of Serbs, a murderer with a child's face," Pale Television said, referring to the war crimes tribunal's chief prosecutor, Richard Goldstone. "And he beseeched the Serb people to protect Mr. Karadzic and Mr. Mladic." **********When a United Nations spokesman, Alexander Ivanko, held a news conference in  Pale recently and condemned the Bosnian Serb police for beating and torturing seven Muslim prisoners, the news report not only skipped over these details but, showing a silent frame of Mr. Ivanko, told its viewers that the United Nations official had declared that the captured Muslims were "terrorists." **********Pale Television repeatedly shows footage from the Srebrenica enclave last summer, when some 4,000 Muslims are believed to have been rounded up and killed  by Bosnian Serb troops. **********The Muslims are shown boarding buses and being treated well by Bosnian Serb soldiers. Bosnian Serbs often cite the pictures as proof that the charges of genocide leveled against their soldiers are Bosnian Muslim propaganda. **********The station also features a program called "Genocide," in which Serbs tell of abuse by Muslims, while the more melodramatic passages from Carl Orff's "Carmina Burana" play in the background. **********As Bosnia prepares for elections, the station has begun broadcasting its own  voter-awareness programs. **********"The international community will try to intervene in the forthcoming elections," Borvivoje Sendic, the deputy chairman of Dr. Karadzic's Serb Democratic Party, told viewers a couple of days ago. "But the Serbian people will not allow themselves to be cheated this time out of respect for all the victims who have fallen in the Republic of Srpska."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/02/world.body_text: **********A bus crossed into oncoming traffic and rammed another bus head on in northern Mexico today, killing 26 people and injuring at least 22. Six of the dead were children. **********It was not clear what caused the bus to drift into the opposite lane outside  Sonoita, about 12 mles from the United States border. It was also not clear what nationalities many of the victims were. **********The Sonoran State prosector, Vicky Salazar, said several passengers had noticed brake problems, but their complaints were ignored. **********The two buses were carrying a total of 52 passengers, according to the Mexican news agency Notimex. **********Sonoita police said one of the buses was traveling from the border city of Tijuana to Guadalajara in west-central Mexico, and the other was going from Mexico City to Tijuana. **********A van crash two hours later in the same area involving a California family caused some confusion because victims of both accidents were flown to some of the same Arizona hospitals.
