https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/25/world.main_headline: In France, Socialized Medicine Meets Gallic Version of H.M.O.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/25/world.print_headline: In France, Socialized Medicine Meets Gallic Version of H.M.O.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/25/world.body_text: **********The French Government today announced sweeping changes in the national health care system that are intended to curb spending and help tame the budget deficit. The new measures, among other things, will use computers to monitor every patient's costs and penalize doctors who surpass budgets for the care and prescriptions they provide. **********The changes announced today, which have been under public discussion since last fall, are almost sure to pass Parliament in the coming weeks and then would take effect immediately. They amount to the most far-reaching changes in 50 years for the state-run health care system here, and reflect the same struggle to rein in health costs seen in other countries like Britain, Germany and the United States. **********They involve, in a sense, an effort to impose on a national scale some of the controls on spending and practices that are applied by private insurers in the United States under the label of managed care. **********French Government officials denied the charge made by some doctors that these measures would constitute rationing of what has until now been considered the universal right of French citizens to unlimited health care, with practically no questions asked of doctors or patients. But they are intended to curb spending not only by limiting payments to doctors but also by controlling visits to specialists. **********The measures introduced today would require patients to consult general practitioners before going to specialists or receiving diagnostic tests. Richard Bouton, the head of the MG-France Association, the largest doctors' group, observed, "General practitioners have much more to gain in this reform than to lose." **********But specialists -- surgeons, psychiatrists and others -- may find their incomes sharply reduced, and some doctors, especially from specialist-dominated  smaller unions, closed their offices today in protest. Some doctors warned that  this was a step toward rationing and low-quality care, but there has been little public reaction so far. **********Advocates of the right of privacy questioned whether there were adequate safeguards on individual health records, which patients now carry around in paper folders that in the future may be accessible to anyone who passes a patient's electronic care card through a scanner. **********"In 1995, urban medical spending grew by close to 5 percent," said Social Affairs Minister Jacques Barrot, adding that the immediate goal of the new measures was to keep medical bills from rising this year by more than 2.1 percent. **********Prime Minister Alain Juppe's earlier attempts to rein in the French welfare system by tightening the rules for pensions for Government employees set off a monthlong transportation strike last winter. **********Mr. Juppe eventually had to withdraw plans to increase the retirement age for Government employees and trim the sprawling national rail system to halt deficits that were running at a combined $15 billion last year. This year, he hoped to keep the health system from running more than $3.3 billion in the red,  but Government predictions now project its deficit at up to $9.2 billion because of rising costs and slow growth of payroll taxes. **********The French system allows people to pick their own doctors and reimburses them for most of the cost of treatment, hospitalization, and medicine. The new French plan would track individual doctors through the new computerized health-care identity cards that all French health-care users will be getting. It would cut back the doctors' reimbursements if they overspend the budgets set for them.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/30/busin.main_headline: For a Former Corporate Raider, Act II Is Tough
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/30/busin.print_headline: For a Former Corporate Raider, Act II Is Tough
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/30/busin.body_text: **********ON a recent mid-May morning, several vice presidents at the headquarters of Watkins Inc. here are being politely but enthusiastically queried by Irwin L. Jacobs, their chief executive. **********First he focuses on the army of salespeople who work out of their homes taking orders for Watkins's food, health and home-care products. Shouldn't the thousands who sign on each year be invited to company headquarters soon after they enlist, he asks, for training that will encourage them to stick with it? He also wants to know if prospective partners in Korea have been sent a fax of the  detergent ingredient lists they had asked for. Later he moves on to packaging costs, wondering why Watkins isn't pushing suppliers harder for new contracts now that paper prices have fallen. **********I want to be the nicest guy in town, but I don't want to be the nicest because I'm the stupidest," he says. **********Wait a minute. Is this the Irwin L. Jacobs, the fabled corporate raider who became conspicuously wealthy during the 1980's by buying huge chunks of troubled companies like Kaiser Steel, Walt Disney and Castle & Cooke (the parent of Dole  Foods), threatening them with takeovers or management changes, and then selling  out to higher bidders? Is this the man dubbed "Irv the Liquidator" for the way he dismantled companies that he did manage to buy, like the industrial and leisure-goods giant AMF Inc.? Wasn't Irwin Jacobs known for pestering powerful chief executives like Rand Araskog of ITT, whose conglomerate he wanted to break up, not underlings at obscure companies like Watkins, about what they are doing to build the business? **********Well, yes, it is he. To understand why he is so busy these days with the details of running Watkins, a privately held company that had revenues last year of about $100 million-- about what Wal-Mart Stores rang up in half a day -- one  has to look at how both Mr. Jacobs, 54, and the times have changed. **********"It's some of each," said Mr. Jacobs, a gregarious and disarmingly casual bear of a man. "I wouldn't buy more than 5 percent of a company today unless I was taking it over, and even then I wouldn't do it in a hostile situation." **********Corporate raiders are not quite extinct. There's Bennett S. LeBow, for instance, still pursuing his plans to break off the food business of RJR Nabisco Holdings from the tobacco operations and then combine the latter with Liggett, his own tobacco company. Then there is Carl C. Icahn, the New York financier best known for acquiring control in 1985 of Trans World Airlines, at the time the nation's fourth-largest airline. Until recently, he was an ally with Mr. LeBow in the assault on RJR. And there's Kirk Kerkorian, who failed in his attempt to gain control of Chrysler's board but may still make hundreds of millions of dollars from his investment. **********But, Mr. Jacobs said, the number of flabby or overdiversified companies that  are undervalued has fallen sharply because top managers and directors are now much quicker to whip their companies into shape at the first sign of trouble. "Look at how AT&T and all these other companies are breaking up without being forced to," he said. **********Moreover, when the companies themselves have been slow to act, many pension funds and other institutional shareholders that once reflexively backed management are now routinely challenging corporate strategies without the prodding of freelance flame throwers like Mr. Jacobs. Their restiveness had a lot to do with Mr. Araskog's announcement last year that ITT would split up, just as Mr. Jacobs had urged in 1985. **********"If we could have patented our suggestions, we could be suing Araskog right now for infringement," said Daniel Lindsay, a lawyer for Mr. Jacobs's holding company and a longtime partner in his deals. **********Raiding investors are also rarer because of the loss of their easiest source  of funds, the high-interest-rate loans provided by the giant leveraged-buyout machines run by the likes of Michael R. Milken of Drexel Burnham Lambert. The junk-bond financiers who survive have become much more cautious because of the bankruptcies and other struggles faced by many of the highly indebted companies  their deals created. **********Finally, as Mr. Jacobs and other raiders who gained control of companies have learned, running them can be a drain on the investors' time, their reputations and even their financial power. For every success like Ronald O. Perelman, who built a business empire around his acquisition of Revlon, many others have stumbled. Some, like T. Boone Pickens, who eventually settled down to run Mesa Inc., find themselves vilified by other investors as the same kind of self-interested corporate insiders they were once famous for attacking. Mr. Pickens stepped down this month as Mesa's chairman and chief executive at the request of a financier he had brought in to defend the company from hostile shareholders. **********Mr. Icahn flew TWA into bankruptcy in 1992. Under Asher B. Edelman, Datapoint, a once-leading-edge producer of computer networking equipment, collapsed. **********Mr. Jacobs has certainly accumulated his share of bitter lawsuits and critics. "I lost all my respect for him," said Marc Kozberg, a longtime Minneapolis investment-fund manager. Mr. Kozberg profited from many deals involving Mr. Jacobs, but was dismayed by the latter's failure to shield fellow  investors caught in the collapse of an investment holding company called MEI Diversified. Mr. Jacobs says that there was nothing he could do to save MEI and  that he was among the biggest losers. **********Mr. Jacobs is the first to acknowledge that his portfolio's diversity strained his expertise and drained his energy, in part because he made a more serious stab than many raiders did at running parts of his empire. "No one could spread themselves as thin as I did in the 80's," Mr. Jacobs said. "It was profitable, but it could have been a whole lot better." **********Not the contemplative sort, Mr. Jacobs does not spend much time fretting about how much better it could have been. While continuing to buy and sell large chunks of stock, he stays below the 5 percent level that would require him to notify the Securities and Exchange Commission of his presence and intentions. Mostly, he tries to stay focused on improving the performance of what he already owns to the point where he will be comfortable stepping away. **********"My wife asked if we could ever take a month off," he said. "I may never do it, but I've reached the point where I want to know I could." **********But he still jumps at what he perceives as bargains, though. In 1994, he snapped up Canterbury Downs, a shuttered racetrack in a Minneapolis suburb, Shakopee, for $7 million, about a tenth of the cost of building it. But the payoff he was hoping for never materialized. After he ignited a controversy by suggesting that the track could enjoy a renaissance if other forms of gambling were authorized there, he unloaded the property at a modest profit. **********"Deals are in our blood," mused Carl C. Pohlad, the 80-year-old Minneapolis banker who has been Mr. Jacobs's backer and partner in numerous ventures over the last 22 years. "We could say, 'Never again,' but it's only until the right thing comes along." **********BY the mid-1980's Mr. Jacobs had assembled the bulk of the business portfolio -- and the headaches -- that keep him busy these days. There is no common thread to explain why he has kept some businesses and discarded scores of others, but the centerpiece of what is left is clearly Genmar Holdings, a privately held collection of boat companies acquired since 1977. With sales last year of $552.7 million, they make up the nation's third-largest leisure-boat manufacturer, after Brunswick and Outboard Marine. **********Mr. Jacobs, who keeps three powerboats at his lakeside mansion outside Minneapolis, has long played an active role in managing his boat businesses. But that involvement was overshadowed in the 1980's when his other investment forays were grabbing headlines and generating the profits that allowed him to load up on the trappings of success, including a vacation home in Palm Beach, Fla., and  a succession of Rolls-Royces. **********"He knows and loves the marine business," said James Chapman, the former chairman and chief operating officer of Outboard Marine, a supplier of engines to Genmar as well as a competitor in boat sales. "When we negotiated our long-term engine contract several years ago, it was Irwin across the table from  me." **********But Mr. Jacobs's management skills appeared to be nothing special when Genmar sales collapsed in 1989, along with the rest of the boating industry's. Burdened by the heavy debts accumulated to allow Mr. Jacobs and others to take cash out of the company, Genmar escaped bankruptcy only because Mr. Jacobs injected new capital, recruited new investors and negotiated new terms with lenders. Genmar's sales began rebounding three years ago, with total revenue up 25 percent in 1994 and 11 percent last year. Operating cash flows remain uncomfortably weak because of rising expenses -- both Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investors Service downgraded their ratings on $100 million of outstanding junk bonds in December -- but Mr. Jacobs is confident of a third consecutive year of operating profits  and is even talking cautiously about the possibility of returning to the black for the first time since 1989. **********"We are managing this for the long haul," he said, adding that his main role  at this point was developing new marketing strategies. **********For example, he recently negotiated an arrangement to allow Genmar dealers to display some of their more inexpensive boats in Wal-Mart parking lots, an exposure that he hopes will attract a broad new range of potential customers to  showrooms. **********Mr. Jacobs is delving much more deeply into Watkins, a 128-year-old company that was once a giant in direct sales. Watkins helped pioneer the technique of multilevel marketing, in which sales representatives are paid commissions not just on their own sales but on the business generated by people they recruit. Such pyramid-like marketing strategies have been a frequent source of business fraud, but when run legitimately they have allowed tens of thousands of Americans to create independent home-based businesses with little investment up  front.    THE founding Watkins family had mismanaged the company into bankruptcy when Mr. Jacobs acquired it for $4.6 million in 1978. A succession of professional managers he installed turned the business around, but after an early period of fast growth, annual revenues stalled a few years ago at around $100 million. **********The slowdown frustrated Mr. Jacobs, who believed the company's marketing structure made it an ideal refuge for workers threatened by corporate downsizing who were hungry for opportunities to build independent sources of income. **********His dismay deepened, he said, when Russ Hall, then the president, raised the  cost of the starter kit for new sales representatives from $81 to $99, with disastrous results. Instead of bolstering revenue by attracting more committed people, as Mr. Hall had anticipated, the move dampened sales, made new recruiting tougher and infuriated star sales representatives who earned six-figure incomes, Mr. Jacobs said. **********Mr. Hall was dismissed, Mr. Jacobs says, and after a meeting in Minneapolis in January with the top 100 salespeople that Mr. Jacobs calls "the best learning experience of my career," a new starter kit costing $29.95 was introduced. Mr. Hall could not be reached for comment. **********Mr. Jacobs is now spending at least a day a week in Winona with a new management team, plunging into activities like negotiating the recent partnership with Jinro, a huge Korean conglomerate, to expand Watkins's reach into South Korea. **********The silver lining in Watkins's troubles for Mr. Jacobs is that they attracted the interest of Mark, his 32-year-old son. **********The only son in a close-knit family that includes four daughters, Mark had been pursuing an acting career that had resulted in bit roles in several movies. He can be seen getting beaten up in "Goodfellas." Mark moved back to Minnesota this spring and recently became vice president in charge of marketing at Watkins. He and his father talk several times a day. One of Mark's sisters, Tricia, is developing a line of cosmetic products for Watkins, but the three others are not currently involved in Mr. Jacobs's businesses. **********MR. JACOBS said he hoped Genmar and Watkins would both be prosperous enough to take public within a year. But investors might be wary based on the track record of Insty-Print, a franchise chain of 325 printing shops in which Mr. Jacobs and an investment group retain a 70 percent stake after a 1994 public offering. The thinly traded shares of I.P.I. Inc., the publicly traded holding company, are at $4, just where they started trading in May 1994, having been left behind during one of the greatest market rallies in history. **********The problem, according to some investment managers, is Mr. Jacobs. They say I.P.I. told investors it planned to grow through acquisitions, but Mr. Jacobs's  reluctance to buy at anything other than bargain prices has resulted in no action and slow growth. That quest for a discount is unlikely to change, say those who know Mr. Jacobs best. **********"He firmly believes that you make your money when you make your buy," said Dennis Mathiesen, a Jacobs lieutenant and investing partner in the 1980's, who has since built a mini-empire of his own around the Mountain Parks Financial Corporation, a publicly traded bank holding company. **********One business where Mr. Jacobs's passion for bargains is unlikely to hold him  back is his Jacobs Trading Company and the closely related WGD Inc., which specialize in buying cut-rate goods and reselling them to wholesalers, retailers and consumers. These descendants of Mr. Jacobs's original business, the close-out merchandising deals he began putting together as a teen-ager, aim to capitalize on retailers' growing problems with handling the billions of dollars  of goods that come back to them under liberal return policies that consumers have come to take for granted. **********Jacobs Trading sells a variety of returned goods picked up from mass merchandisers like Wal-Mart, manufacturers and other sources, marketing them to  other retailers or directly to consumers through its small but growing chain of  retail outlets in the upper Midwest. WGD, which stands for "World's Greatest Deal," is attempting to expand the same concept into electronic marketing (and its home on the Internet is www.wgdeal.com). **********Critics, though, say Mr. Jacobs's search for the cheapest deal has led him down a questionable road. To expand the range of returned goods they handle, the trading companies last year began marketing electronic goods and other items that have been rebuilt by convicts at a state prison in Appleton, Wis. **********Unions decry the practice as a grab for cheap labor that they say was approved by Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin as a quid pro quo for campaign contributions. The Governor has denied the allegations, and Mr. Jacobs describes the plan as a public service that allows the state to recoup some of its costs of running the prisons and trains prisoners to do jobs that will help them stay  out of prison once they are released. **********Mr. Jacobs said it was never an exclusive deal, adding that he did not see it as essential to the success of Jacobs Trading. Indeed, the experiment is still so small-scale that his interest in it might surprise anyone whose impressions of Mr. Jacobs are based on his more widely publicized ventures of the 1980's. **********But Mr. Jacobs says he does not mourn the loss of the national spotlight, and those who know him believe him. Bill Nicholson, the former chief operating officer of Amway, whom Mr. Jacobs lured out of retirement to run WGD, said, "He  loves the art of business at any level."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/14/world.main_headline: U.N. and Iraq Report Progress in Talks to Allow Limited Oil Sales
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/14/world.print_headline: U.N. and Iraq Report Progress in Talks to Allow Limited Oil Sales
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/14/world.body_text: **********Talks between Iraq and the United Nations that could lead to limited Iraqi oil sales for the first time since the Persian Gulf war neared the end of an initial round today, with diplomats saying that the two sides are as close as they have ever been to an agreement. **********United States officials said they thought the talks would recess late today,  but the United Nations spokeswoman, Sylvana Foa, said the two sides planned another meeting on details for Wednesday. **********As the talks proceeded, the Security Council today discussed a new and separate resolution on Iraq that would tighten monitoring of Iraqi imports in general and stiffen requirements on exports to Iraq from all countries. **********As new disclosures of secret Iraqi weapons programs have emerged in recent months, Council members have decided to act now to "close loopholes," an official said. **********The resolution, which could be passed this week, would not only tighten monitoring now as limited oil sales become a possibility but would also put in place a web of restrictions before broader sanctions against Iraq are lifted at  some future date. **********[Reuters reported from Vienna on Tuesday that the International Atomic Energy Agency said its investigation into Iraq's weapons programs found that about a dozen Western companies had sold to Baghdad equipment it used in its nuclear program before the gulf war. An agency spokesman said Iraq bought items "bit by bit," making the equipment difficult to trace.] **********Rolf Ekeus, the Swedish diplomat who is in charge of monitoring Iraqi programs for the United Nations, said he has found a pattern of Iraq buying from different suppliers in other arms projects. As late as the end of last year, United Nations monitors found missile gyroscopes that had been hastily dumped in a Baghdad canal to avoid detection. **********The talks this week between Iraq and the United Nations are about a 1995 Council resolution that would allow the Iraqis to sell up to $2 billion worth of oil over renewable six month periods to pay for shortages of food and medicine that have been caused in large part by an international embargo. **********The broader embargo, imposed in 1990 after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, is not  being negotiated. Iraq will not qualify to have sanctions lifted until it meets  the requirements of other resolutions calling for the destruction of all weapons of mass destruction, a full accounting of people still missing after the invasion of Kuwait and restitution of Kuwaiti property. **********The first round of current talks, which began on Feb. 6, has focused on how food and other goods would be imported and distributed. The 1995 resolution requires that about $150 million of each $1 billion in oil sales be spent on aid to the Kurds in northern Iraq, now effectively an autonomous region under Western protection. **********Diplomats say that the Iraqis would like to be in charge of that distribution, but the United Nations has proposed giving the job to relief agencies. The United Nations is also required to conduct assessments everywhere  in Iraq to be sure that the emergency supplies are reaching the neediest people. **********Even if these issues are quickly resolved, as Iraqis apparently believe they  will be, there remain big questions about how the oil sales will be conducted and the money collected and disbursed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/25/busin.snippet: Obstacles to financial success in child care business are substantial, quandary that reflects both problematic economics of day care and a cultural failure to adjust to consequences of expecting mothers with young children to work; care of the sor...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/25/busin.main_headline: Parents Most in Need May Have the Least Access
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/25/busin.print_headline: Parents Most in Need May Have the Least Access
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/25/busin.body_text: **********It's 10 A.M., and the parents of some 90 infants, toddlers and preschoolers in this white-collar suburb about an hour's drive southwest of Manhattan know exactly where their children are. **********Life within the cheerful, pristine confines of Kindercare's ''learning center'' is safe, cozy and, above all, predictable. On this sunny, not-too-chilly morning, the older children are busy attacking the plastic playground equipment, while inside the 3-year-olds are puzzling over cut-paper shapes and the babies are snoozing in their green and white cribs. In the kitchen, the cook is preparing pizza-like ''Italian dippers'' with broccoli for lunch from a four-week rotation that runs from meat loaf to toasted cheese. **********If Kindercare Learning Centers' new owner, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, has its way, tens of thousands more preschoolers will soon be sampling the menu. While Kohlberg Kravis, the leveraged buyout specialist, declined to discuss its plans for Kindercare until the formalities are completed next month, Clifton Roberts, a general partner, has made no secret of the firm's wish to capitalize on Kindercare's good will. **********''K.K.R. intends to support the expansion of Kindercare through internal growth and acquisitions while continuing to promote industry-leading education and quality standards,'' Mr. Roberts explained in the Oct. 3 announcement of the buyout. And despite a tangled financial past, Kindercare is probably better positioned to expand than its rivals. It has long experience in operating a nationwide network and a strong reputation in the upper-middle end of the day care market. **********But the obstacles to success in the child care business are substantial, a quandary that reflects both the problematic economics of day care and a cultural failure to adjust to the consequences of expecting mothers with young children to work. **********There are several reasons. Care of the sort provided by Kindercare's Clark center -- $150 to $205 a week -- is out of financial reach of many families. And many others do not want it: though experts say preschoolers benefit from the social context and stimulation of quality day care, many working parents prefer to re-create, with a mother-surrogate, a more traditional setting, even if it offers little more than baby-sitting. **********''Parents and developmental psychologists disagree about what is best for children,'' said David Blau, an economist at the University of North Carolina, who has studied child care providers. ''And many parents just don't want to pay for what the psychologists want.'' **********Quality Care Comes at a Price **********Two-thirds of American women with preschool children now work, including half the women with infants under a year old. Yet a survey of 400 day care centers in four states, conducted in 1995 by a team led by Susan Helburn, an economist at the University of Colorado, rated the quality ''poor'' to ''mediocre'' in six out of seven centers. While most centers ''meet children's basic health and safety needs,'' she concluded that few help to develop language, math and social skills, leaving even the children of America's middle class inadequately prepared for less sheltered environments. **********Less is known about ''family'' child care -- care in other people's homes. For while friends, grandparents and neighbors are the ones who most often must provide a safe, stimulating environment for preschoolers, the average quality varies widely from the most nurturing to the most neglectful. **********For many parents, its great advantage is cost: full-time child care in this largely unregulated part of the market runs $40 to $100 a week, just half the cost of unsubsidized care in a group center. **********But it is group day care centers to which more and more American families are necessarily turning. **********Today, just 3 percent of preschoolers with working mothers are left at home with nannies, according to Barbara Willer, a consultant to the National Association for the Education of Young Children. That is down from 15 percent in 1965. And of the 20 million children now under kindergarten age, some 6 million spend at least part of the day in one of America's 100,000 group day care centers. **********Indeed, Roger Neugeberger, publisher of the Child Care Information Exchange, an industry newsletter, reports that virtually all growth in the market has been in the centers. **********For years, the accepted wisdom has been that any solution to the day care problem would require a big injection of Government cash. Roger Brown, the president of Bright Horizons, a company that manages 125 up-market day care centers for corporate and government clients, offers the most common view. ''It's much like a famine in the midst of a well-fed world,'' he said. ''Good day care is out there, but the average person simply can't afford it.'' **********Margins Are Thin; Mergers Are Sparse **********But while more money to subsidize day care is clearly necessary to meet the needs of lower-income families and welfare mothers who are going to be required to work under the new welfare law, no level of government is likely to aim much money in the direction of Kindercare and others that cater to the middle class. **********Moreover, investors, like Kohlberg Kravis, that are looking to make a profit in child care must contend with the willingness of small-scale entrepreneurs to enter the business with operations that run on razor-thin margins. Of the roughly 35,000 centers run as businesses designed to make a profit, 29,000 are little more than a single operation -- often a converted house or a storefront. And in contrast to many other service industries, there is no clear trend to consolidation. **********Mr. Brown of Bright Horizons thinks he knows why: economies of scale in the business are modest. While chains can save a bit on supplies, training, insurance, real estate and marketing, most of the cost is in labor. The chains have some hiring advantages in being able to offer group fringe benefits and opportunities for promotion. ''We can get quality employees for $2 less in hourly wages,'' said Miriam Liggett, a regional vice president of Kindercare, who started as an assistant teacher. **********But the chains face disadvantages, too, in competing directly with the ''mom-and-pop'' centers whose owners impute little cost to their own long hours on the job. **********And there seems to be limited value to brand recognition. While parents may be relieved to find the same Big Mac in Pittsburgh or Prague, they have mixed emotions about the assembly line image in child care. ''There is some brand-name premium'' for chains that contract to manage centers for others, Mr. Brown concluded. But the contract business represents a small part of the commercial market. **********Kindercare clearly wants to break out of the slow-growth mold. The company, which was founded in 1969, stumbled badly in the late 1980's after it was saddled with a huge debt in a buyout engineered by Drexel Burnham Lambert. It spent part of 1992 and 1993 in Chapter 11. But Kohlberg Kravis, which agreed to pay stockholders $467 million, has pledged to provide $175 million in new equity capital, plus a $300 million line of bank credit. **********Market and Mandate Determine Costs **********But can that injection overcome the inherent difficulties of running day care centers at a return high enough to provide money for further expansions? **********A look at the finances shows just how hard it will be. Sandra Scarr, the president of Kindercare, who previously led a research program in developmental psychology at the University of Virginia, would not reveal the actual budget for the Clark center. But she provided enough detail to piece one together. Most of Clark's costs, it seems, are dictated by a combination of competition in the labor market and the State of New Jersey, which regulates health and safety at day care centers and sets minimum staffing ratios for each age group served. **********Every classroom at the Clark center has a full-time lead teacher earning $9 to $12 an hour, including benefits, along with enough full-time $8-  to $10-an-hour assistants and part-time $6-  to $8-an-hour assistants to satisfy the state. New Jersey requires one staff member for every 4 infants, one for every 7 toddlers and one for every 10 children between 2 1/2 and 4. With a mix that requires roughly one worker for 7 children at an average cost of $9 an hour, classroom labor runs a bit less than $1.30 an hour for each child. **********Clark is open from 6:30 A.M. to 6:30 P.M., or 60 hours a week -- a necessity, said Kristy Sugg, director of the Clark center, because ''most of our parents drop them off early on the way to work and pick them up late.'' Presumably, a full complement of workers is not needed across the entire day. Figure full staffing for just 50 hours a week, and the direct labor cost alone comes to $65 a child. **********Each Kindercare center has a director and an assistant director. In a relatively high wage area like Clark, the two earn a total of $60,000 to $80,000, including health benefits and virtually free child care. Figure supervisory costs (including regional and national management) at a minimum of $10 weekly a child when the center is running at 80 percent of its full capacity of 200. **********Then there is real estate. Kindercare designs and builds its own centers for about $1.9 million in high-cost areas like suburban New Jersey. It probably takes at least 15 percent a year for capital and maintenance, or $285,000. Assuming the center runs at 80 percent of capacity, the weekly cost for each child is about $35. Food (breakfast, lunch, two snacks), insurance, cleaning, classroom supplies and marketing costs are harder to pin down, but $50 a week is conservative. **********All told, then, Kindercare needs revenues of about $160 a week from each child for a spanking new, high-cost center like Clark to break even at 80 percent capacity. Currently, the fees run $205 for infants, $180 for toddlers, $165 for 2 1/2 to 3 years and $150 for 4 and above. This leaves only modest room for profit, ''but it is all the market can bear,'' said Susan Liddy, the New York regional coordinator for Kindercare. **********In lower-wage regions and states that permit lower staffing levels, Kindercare can break even for as little as $130 a week from each child, Dr. Scarr said. She added that the company is considering centers with fewer amenities, but doesn't expect that costs could be cut by more than 10 to 20 percent without compromising features that Kindercare considers important. ''Shiny playground equipment and hot lunches just aren't much of the bill,'' she explained. **********Looking at Life Through '57 Glasses **********At a minimum, high-quality day care -- with the higher staffing levels and wages that Mr. Brown of Bright Horizons said were needed -- would cost $9,000 a year. But even Kindercare's bare-bones $130 a week comes to $6,500 for a 50-week year, or a bit more than 10 percent of the median income of a family with two adults employed full-time. Perhaps it's no surprise, then, that the average center charges less than $5,000, with consequently lower care. Indeed, fully 40 percent of the centers in the Helburn study were rated ''inadequate'' for infants and toddlers. **********What seems clearest in the decidedly murky world of day care is that progress will be piecemeal. In part, this follows from the cost: the tens of billions of dollars needed annually to assure first-class care for all preschool children will not be easily found in family budgets. And the Federal Government, cutting back everywhere else, is certainly not about to fill the gap. **********Perhaps the largest impediment to change is Americans' failure to acknowledge, for better and worse, that the 1950's world of ''Leave It To Beaver,'' and ''Father Knows Best,'' is history and that Mom is working outside the home for good. Until attitudes reflect the reality, day care is likely to remain the latch-key kid of public policy. Meanwhile, Roger Brown concluded, ''the people who need good child care most are the people least likely to get it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/06/news/.print_headline: But Intelligence Unit Is Said to Stay Behind In Kurdish Region: U.S. Sees Expanded Zone as Permanent (folo)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/06/news/.body_text: **********Washington—                     Brian Knowlton of the International Herald Tribune reportedfrom Washington: **********The extension of the southern flight-exclusion zone in Iraq, from the 32d Parallel to the 33d, about 95 kilometersfarther north, is now considered permanent, Pentagon officials said Thursday. **********The State Department reacted obliquely to an announcement thatthe French governmentwould resume its air patrols over the old flight-exclusion zone in southern Iraq on Monday, but that its planes would not fly in the expanded portion of the zone. **********The State Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, said Washington would pursue its goals in Iraq regardless of the allies' stance."We are accomplishing our objectives," he said. "If we have to do it alone, or alone with the British, we will do it."Britain has strongly endorsed the U.S. moves to punish Mr. Saddam for his moves into the north. **********But the U.S. air strikes against Iraq drew blunt criticism Thursday from the Russian security chief, Alexander Lebed.The Interfax news agency quoted him as having said:"There is one big strong master who spits on everybody. That master is behaving like a bull in a china shop." **********Unconfirmed reports of newfactional fighting in Iraq,including heavy clashesnear Degala, reported by UN personnel and foreign aid workers, came a day after President Bill Clintonpronounced himself satisfied with the results of missile attacks against 15 air-control targets. Pentagon officials said two-thirds of the targets had beenseverely damaged, the remainder less so.The damage, they said, was sufficient to make skies in the expanded no-flight zone relatively safe. **********The Pentagon appeared Thursday to be starting to step down from its emergency footing. Defense Secretary William Perry, who had canceled a visit to Portsmouth,Virginia, has decided to make the trip after all.For the moment, further U.S. military action appeared unlikely, barring new provocation by Mr. Saddam, Pentagon officials said. **********The UN Security Council failed Wednesday to agree on a common response to the crisis and Britain said it would revise a draft resolution thatcondemned Iraq for its incursion into the north.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/04/world.snippet: Defense Sec William Perry tells Senate panel that up to 7,500 American troops will remain in Bosnia until mid-March of 1997, for primary purpose of assisting in withdrawal of US forces; rejects Republican charge that Clinton Administration is dela...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/04/world.main_headline: 7,500 G.I.'s Staying in Bosnia to Next Spring, Perry Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/04/world.print_headline: 7,500 G.I.'s Staying in Bosnia to Next Spring, Perry Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/04/world.body_text: **********Up to 7,500 American troops will remain in Bosnia until mid-March, Defense Secretary William J. Perry told a Senate panel today. He insisted to Republican Senators that this did not represent the beginning of an extended American military presence in Bosnia. **********The new figure is about half the  current number of American peacekeepers in Bosnia, whose one-year  mission is to end on Dec. 20. Both Mr. Perry and Gen. John Shalikashvili, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today that a new contingent of 5,000 troops would leave for Bosnia soon for a six-month tour with the primary purpose of assisting in the withdrawal. **********Mr. Perry acknowledged that America's NATO allies largely favored a so-called follow-on force to be installed after the current mission ends. **********But he repeated before the Senate Armed Services Committee today  that neither he nor President Clinton had made any decision on a follow-on force. **********Mr. Perry rejected a charge by skeptical Republicans that the Administration was simply delaying until after the Presidential election a decision to deploy more American troops to Bosnia for an extended period. **********Senator John McCain of Arizona and the committee chairman, Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, chastised Mr. Perry and General Shalikashvili for announcing the new deployment without first informing the panel or seeking authorization. **********''I've never seen anything like it before: a press report that we're going to keep 5,000 men and women overseas without any consultation with Congress,'' Mr. McCain said. ''The credibility gap between you and Congress is as wide as the Grand Canyon.'' **********Mr. Thurmond complained: ''Notification and policy by press release does not constitute consultation with the Congress.'' **********But Mr. Perry and General Shalikashvili argued that they were remaining within the 20,000-troop ceiling authorized by the Senate, that they had moved in soldiers to replace others in Bosnia before, and that the new 5,000-troop deployment was only a ''cover force'' to insure a safe and thorough withdrawal during a period of expected bad weather. **********As the United States had put in a larger ''enabling force'' to set up in Bosnia, General Shalikashvili argued, the military was putting in a cover force to pack up and get out. **********Therefore authorization was not necessary, Mr. Perry said. He did say that committee leaders should have been informed by letter. **********A senior Administration official said that Mr. Clinton and Mr. Perry had no ulterior motive and that the 5,000 troops were the minimum the Pentagon required to leave Bosnia in good order. **********''You don't know how the Pentagon works,'' the official said. ''They think in big units. It's like atomic particles: what is the smallest unit in which troops come? I'm amazed the number isn't higher.'' **********A decision to postpone municipal elections in Bosnia from September to late November, Mr. Perry said, meant a slower withdrawal of American troops than had been planned. But he said the schedule would not slip further, even if municipal elections are again delayed. **********NATO defense ministers have ordered Gen. George A. Joulwan, commander of NATO forces in Europe, to study options for a follow-on force in Bosnia, which range from zero to a heavily armed force like the current one, in which American troops predominate. They make up some 15,000 of a total of 52,000, down from 19,000 and 60,000 respectively. **********Mr. Perry said he found three options most plausible: complete withdrawal, without a follow-on force; a force able to deter the renewal of serious fighting, but relying on air power, without the use of ground troops, and a force able to deter new fighting and provide freedom of movement for Bosnians, which would require ground troops. **********While he said the second of these options ''is attractive, if it could be done,'' most American officials think the last option is most likely. NATO diplomats agree.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/15/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;GENERAL RE PLANS ITS EIGHTH BUYBACK OF SHARES
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/15/busin.body_text: **********The General Re Corporation said yesterday that its board had authorized the repurchase of up to $300 million of the company's common stock, the eighth such  move under a longstanding plan. Since 1987, General Re has repurchased about 22.7 million shares, leaving 81.7 million shares outstanding at the end of 1995. The company's shares fell 87.5 cents yesterday, to $148.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. Based on that price, the authorization will cover the repurchase of about two million common shares. The reinsurer, based in Stamford, Conn., also raised its quarterly dividend by 4 percent, to 51 cents a share, from 49 cents. General Re will pay the new dividend on March 29 to stock of record on March 21.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/10/busin.body_text: **********Vallicorp Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it was in preliminary talks for a possible merger with an undisclosed banking company. Vallicorp, a banking company based in Fresno, Calif., which has $1.3 billion in assets, said its board was evaluating all options, including remaining an independent company. It said it could not predict the terms or timing of any possible transaction or whether current discussions would result in a deal.
