https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/11/busin.main_headline: Magellan Fund Adds Stocks In Energy and Cuts Technology
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/11/busin.print_headline: Magellan Fund Adds Stocks In Energy and Cuts Technology
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/11/busin.body_text: **********The Fidelity Magellan Fund likes energy, and continues to shy away from technology. **********Fidelity Investments reported yesterday that the Magellan Fund, the nation's  largest mutual fund, with $56 billion in assets, increased the percentage of energy stocks in the fund to 10.7 percent in March. That was up from 6.3 percent a month earlier and from nothing six months before. **********By contrast, the fund's stake in technology stocks was down to 3.6 percent of assets at the end of March, compared with 5 percent a month earlier and 40.2  percent last September. Jeffrey N. Vinik, the fund's manager, had been a leading proponent of technology stocks, but he began to sell them late last year. **********The Magellan Fund has trailed most major stock funds this year in large part  because it made a big bet on bonds, which have fallen in price as interest rates have risen. The new report shows that bet was not reduced in March, with the percentage of bonds in the portfolio at 19.2 percent, just down from 19.4 percent a month earlier. But cash was cut to 10.1 percent from 15.6 percent. **********The Fidelity report also showed some substantial changes in March in some funds that got new portfolio managers that month. Harry Lange, the new manager of the $1.7 billion Capital Appreciation Fund, initiated a 9.5 percent stake in  technology stocks in March. The fund's holding of energy stocks fell to 12.9 percent from 20 percent. **********Richard Fentin, who took over the $6.7 billion Value Fund, raised its energy  stake to 11.4 percent from 6.2 percent and increased its position in basic industries to 12.5 percent from 9.4 percent. Its stake in retail and wholesale companies was raised to 9.3 percent from from nothing, while its position in financial companies was slashed to 7.7 percent from 20.7 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/01/busin.snippet: Two influential pension funds send letter to shareholders of Archer Daniels Midland Co, criticizing company's steps toward creating more independent board as 'shallow'; letter calls on shareholders to support proposed rule that would hold Archer D...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/01/busin.main_headline: 2 Big Pension Funds Complain To Archer About Board Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/01/busin.print_headline: 2 Big Pension Funds Complain To Archer About Board Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/01/busin.body_text: **********In a letter to the shareholders of the Archer Daniels Midland Company, two influential pension funds yesterday criticized the company's steps toward creating a more independent board as ''shallow.'' **********The letter, from the heads of the California Public Employees Retirement System and the State Board of Administration of Florida, called on shareholders to support a proposed rule that would hold Archer Daniels to a strict standard requiring that the majority of its directors be independent. **********During the last year, institutional investors have waged a campaign to break the control exercised over Archer Daniels by its longtime chairman, Dwayne O. Andreas. Many of those investors have said that they are angry at what they describe as years of being ignored by the company's senior officers. **********That anger was made all the worse in June 1995, when the company and a number of its executives were served with search warrants in what has since become one of the most broad-reaching price-fixing investigations in years. The investigation was begun after Mark Whitacre, a former company executive, served as a secret informant for the Government for two years. **********The company is now negotiating a settlement with the Government of criminal charges. People involved in the situation said that some broad terms of the settlement had been agreed upon, though the two sides still had some way to go before any deal was complete. **********Since the disclosure of the investigation, the institutional investors have complained that the company has done little to respond to their concerns about the inquiry. Some large investors have put the problem on the close personal, professional and financial ties between Mr. Andreas and many of the company's directors. **********In its joint letter yesterday, the two pension funds attacked efforts by Archer Daniels to change its board makeup, which the company has said will increase the independence of directors. There are nine incumbents and three new nominees who hope to be elected to the board at its annual meeting in October. **********''The company's definition of independence is too shallow,'' the letter states. ''Eight of the incumbents are 'insiders' with material ties to the company; two of the three new nominees are bound to 'insiders' by friendship or blood relation.'' **********An Archer Daniels spokesman did not return a telephone call.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/28/busin.main_headline: With Partners Like These, Who Needs Rivals?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/28/busin.print_headline: With Partners Like These, Who Needs Rivals?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/28/busin.body_text: **********FOR people whose knowledge of Government securities is limited to a beach-towel session with Tom Wolfe's "Bonfire of the Vanities," B. Gerald Cantor is not a household name. If they know Mr. Cantor at all, it is as a generous art patron whose private collection of Rodin sculpture is unsurpassed. **********Wall Street knows Mr. Cantor, who is nearly 80 and goes by his nickname, Bernie, as the pioneering founder of Cantor Fitzgerald L.P., one of the largest Government bond brokers in the country, with a blue-chip institutional customer list that includes the nation's biggest banks, pension funds, mutual fund managers and corporate treasurers. **********But in the tidy files of the Court of Chancery in Wilmington, Del., Mr. Cantor is known simply and sadly as a figure in Case No. 14887: Cantor Fitzgerald L.P. and CF Group Management v. Cantor Fitzgerald Inc. **********The confusingly similar names give the impression that Cantor Fitzgerald is suing itself -- and in a larger sense, it is. Indeed, some advisers to family businesses say the Delaware case could scar the firm, its partners and its prospects for years to come. However the firm's troubles turn out, they are a textbook example of the difficulties of providing for the next generation of leadership at a company whose success has been tied closely to a powerful founding figure. **********Cantor Fitzgerald Inc., the defendant, is a Cantor family entity, owned by Bernie Cantor and his second wife, Iris. It is one of two general partners of Cantor Fitzgerald L.P., the business that Wall Street knows and one of the plaintiffs in the case. The other general partner, and the other plaintiff, is CF Group Management, owned by Howard Lutnick, Mr. Cantor's 34-year-old protege and, for at least three years, his designated successor at the firm. **********In human terms, then, Howard Lutnick and the firm he has managed for five years are suing Iris and Bernie Cantor, who control about 55 percent of the firm. At issue is who should run the house that Bernie built, now that Mr. Cantor himself is gravely ill. **********Mr. Cantor, a diabetic, has required regular kidney dialysis since 1990 and has lost much of his eyesight to retinal bleeding. He experienced a medical crisis in late December and was hospitalized in New York for several weeks. He is now being treated at his home in the Los Angeles area, with occasional hospital visits, according to court records. **********A spokesman for Mrs. Cantor would not comment on her husband's current physical and mental condition; Mr. Lutnick's lawyers, in court papers, contend that Mr. Cantor is still too ill to run the business and lacks "sufficient mental capacity" to understand the legal steps being taken in his name. Doctors hired by lawyers for the firm are scheduled to examine Mr. Cantor  today. **********In any event, on Jan. 2, just days after Mr. Cantor's medical crisis began, Mr. Lutnick took steps to implement the partnership's succession plan, which transferred to Mr. Lutnick the role of "managing general partner" previously held by Mr. Cantor's family partnership. That step, which left the Cantor family entity with very limited powers despite its majority ownership stake, immediately provoked Mrs. Cantor's opposition. The move, she said in court papers, was premature and disrespectful to her husband. **********By early March, the wounded feelings on both sides had congealed into icy arguments between teams of lawyers. To the firm and Mr. Lutnick, Mrs. Cantor was undermining the clear wishes of Mr. Cantor, was acting improperly in his name and was derailing the smooth transfer of power that Mr. Cantor desired. **********To Mrs. Cantor, Mr. Lutnick had taken advantage of Mr. Cantor's medical crisis to stage a "palace coup," as one of her advisers described it, and had therefore betrayed Mr. Cantor's trust and forfeited his role as successor. **********On March 7, Mr. Lutnick and the firm filed suit in Delaware, the partnership's legal home, to enforce the succession plan. A few weeks later, Mrs. Cantor countersued, to evict Mr. Lutnick from office. She charged that an incapacity ruling, which set off the succession plan, was invalidly obtained from a special committee of the firm and that Mr. Lutnick had breached his fiduciary duties to the Cantor family by unilaterally amending the partnership agreement on March 5 to make it harder to remove him as managing general partner. Vice Chancellor Jack B. Jacobs, who will try the case in Wilmington starting on May 6, will determine the winner. **********But "winner" is an elusive concept in this laceratingly bitter litigation. **********Even if Mr. Lutnick wins in court, he has already lost the companionship and  guidance of Mr. Cantor and the trust of Mrs. Cantor, who is wealthy enough to hire lawyers to torment Mr. Lutnick and the firm for years. And even if the Cantors win, Mr. Cantor has lost his dream of a smooth succession at his firm and, further, has lost his fatherlike relationship with Mr. Lutnick and other young senior executives who have supported Mr. Lutnick in the fight. **********The firm itself may face the biggest losses, regardless of the decision. **********Although Mr. Lutnick has pushed Cantor Fitzgerald into foreign markets and expanded its role in the domestic equity markets, the dispute tarnishes that successful image by revealing an office culture that makes Oliver Stone's vision of "Wall Street" look beatific by comparison. Battle lines have cut through office friendships and family ties. Management time and attention has already been diverted by depositions and other legal tasks. And, say people allied with  Mr. Lutnick, angry partners are vowing future legal action against Mrs. Cantor that could extend far into the future. **********WILL the feud unsettle the firm's sophisticated clients and leave it vulnerable in a highly competitive business? Absolutely not, Mr. Lutnick said in an interview Thursday night. "Our operating business is far removed from the battles of the executive suite," he said. Other partners said the firm's customers are "very relaxed" about the dispute, while the firm's bankers, accountants and regulators see it as a "ho hum" matter. **********With nearly $200 million in capital, Cantor Fitzgerald is financially secure, the partners said, but they declined to provide other details about the private  firm's finances. One measure of the partnership's profitability, however, is an  estimate by Financial World magazine that Mr. Cantor alone drew out about $50 million from the firm in 1995. **********But if the fight drags on -- as partisans on both sides say it will -- many talented people may be loathe to build their careers in a war zone, family business experts say. **********"It is O.K. for two people with a lot of power to disagree -- but they have to find a way to co-exist or it will tear the organization apart," said Mark Rubin, founder of the Metropolitan Group, a consulting firm in Leonia, N.J., that specializes in closely held and family businesses. "If not, say I'm a Harvard M.B.A. who can work anywhere. Will I pick this company or pick a competitor? You know the answer to that." **********Samuel P. Starr, a tax partner with Coopers & Lybrand in Washington, agreed that battles this bitter could have devastating consequences. "Without commenting on the merits in this case, any succession plan is ultimately about human relationships," Mr. Starr said. "It is that simple. Any time you end up with a 'cram down' solution through litigation, you will have soured the relationships sufficiently as to really raise the question of whether the organization can survive." **********Mr. Lutnick said he did not fear that the fight would hurt the firm. "But what it does do," he added after a moment, "is -- well, it's got to be hurting Iris Cantor. And it certainly is hurting me, emotionally." **********Bernie Cantor is a seminal figure on Wall Street. He founded his firm in Los  Angeles in 1945 as Cantor & Company -- it took its current name from the addition of a partner, John Fitzgerald, who died in 1964. The firm now employs 1,800 people in Los Angeles, New York and other North American cities, and in Europe and East Asia. **********At first, the firm designed sophisticated tax strategies for Hollywood stars  like Kirk Douglas, Zsa Zsa Gabor and Clint Eastwood. Later, Mr. Cantor's clients included Meshulam Riklis and other brash conglomerate-builders of the 1960's. **********But in 1972, Mr. Cantor acquired a controlling stake in the Telerate information service and started to post public price quotes for Treasury securities on Telerate's computer screens. This pierced the secrecy that had traditionally veiled trading in Treasury securities, and allowed Mr. Cantor to widen his customer base sharply. In 1981, he sold Telerate to Exco International for about $100 million, more than 30 times his original investment, retaining an exclusive contract to provide broker prices to the service. (Telerate is now owned by Dow Jones & Company.) **********Two years later, Mr. Cantor hired a young trainee, Howard Lutnick, a high-school tennis star who was just one year out of Haverford College. For about 18 months, Mr. Lutnick moved from one sector of the firm to another, learning the ropes and gathering information. The last stop on his orientation tour was a desk in the corner of Mr. Cantor's office, where the boss frequently  interrogated the young man about what he found in his travels around the firm. **********"I would tell him something that the executive or manager of the unit hadn't  told him, and the next thing you know, Bernie would be on the phone yawping to the guy," Mr. Lutnick recalled. "I was aggressively lectured by every executive  who walked out of his office. But hey, my theory was that the guy whose name was on the door was the one who mattered." **********Mr. Lutnick was then assigned to a tiny unit that managed Mr. Cantor's personal investments and those of a few of his friends. With Mr. Cantor's nod, he brought in additional clients and transformed the unit into one of the firm's most profitable. **********His personal relationship with Mr. Cantor deepened. Mr. Lutnick, who said his parents died before he left college, choked with emotion recounting how Mr. Cantor had talked him out of leaving the firm to get an M.B.A. by promising him  "private lessons." **********The legacy that Bernie Cantor was preparing for Howard Lutnick was not pristine: Cantor Fitzgerald is known as a very sharp-elbowed firm, and occasionally it has cut corners too close for the comfort of Wall Street's regulators. **********The firm, without admitting or denying wrongdoing, was disciplined by the Securities and Exchange Commission in 1994 for record-keeping violations in connection with investigations stemming from the Treasury auction scandal at Salomon Brothers. And Mr. Cantor raised some eyebrows by hiring Peter DaPuzzo, who in June 1992 had paid $100,000 and agreed to a brief suspension to settle a  New York Stock Exchange complaint arising from the manipulation of the price of  Conagra shares in 1990 while he was at Shearson Lehman Brothers. Mr. DaPuzzo neither admitted nor denied any wrongdoing. **********A WIDELY known investment manager, S. Jay Goldinger, had a serious run-in with regulators while he was employed at Cantor Fitzgerald: in 1991, he and four others, including two at Cantor Fitzgerald, were accused by the S.E.C. of insider trading. A Federal District Court judge in Los Angeles has dismissed the case, but the S.E.C. is appealing the ruling. (Mr. Goldinger later struck out on his own and, early this year, filed for bankruptcy after being sued over his derivatives-driven investment strategies.) **********As far back as 1974, Cantor Fitzgerald paid $265,000 -- a substantial amount  in that era -- to settle an S.E.C. case charging that it had participated in a scheme that defrauded investors of $9 million through a mutual fund. The firm denied wrongdoing, saying it settled the case to avoid the expense of litigation. **********Outside the office, though, Mr. Cantor, whose net worth was estimated at more than $400 million in 1992 by Forbes magazine, moved in a very different world. A genial and generous benefactor of medical institutions and museums since the late 1960's, he and Mrs. Cantor have made major gifts to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, the Brooklyn Museum and the Los Angeles County Art Museum. Driven by a single-minded passion for Auguste Rodin, he helped polish the reputation of the turn-of-the-century French sculptor through study grants and exhibitions. **********Perhaps his best-known effort was the casting, at his expense, of Rodin's original and powerfully disturbing designs for a massive bronze work, "The Gates of Hell," which was permanently installed at Stanford University in 1985. **********Those gates would have made an appropriate entry into the executive suite at  Cantor Fitzgerald, where seething political battles among rivals for Mr. Cantor's approval were common though the 1980's. Former and current executives tell their war stories with great relish -- indeed, Mr. Lutnick himself attributes his own elevation in the firm to a former competitor's fatal effort to fire him on Aug. 13, 1990. The rival, the firm's president, was forced out, Mr. Lutnick said; his position, though not his title, fell to Mr. Lutnick, who managed the firm from that point on. **********It was in this environment that Mr. Cantor dropped, in 1992, his original plan to leave the ownership of Cantor Fitzgerald to his charitable foundation and decided, for tax reasons, to convert the firm from a corporation to a partnership. The next spring, the firm admitted 75 employees as its first limited partners and added a succession plan. **********"A key issue for them is, who will run the partnership if something happened  to Bernie," Mr. Lutnick said. "He decided, well, I would run it -- but if he chose to change his mind, he could do so. My deal with Bernie was, as long as he was around, I would work for him, and if he wasn't around, I would run the company." **********IF the deal were indeed that simple, the litigation now scorching its way through the Delaware courts would never have been ignited. **********For one thing, according to supporters of Mr. Lutnick, Mrs. Cantor's legal advisers had raised questions as early as mid-1993 about how she would be treated after Mr. Lutnick took control. Mr. Cantor responded with a side agreement that insured her a substantial stream of income after a change in management. Mrs. Cantor declined to be interviewed for this article. **********And last fall, after an earlier scare about Mr. Cantor's health, Mrs. Cantor  was approached by Mr. Lutnick about selling her stake in the firm, supporters of both sides said, although people familiar with Mrs. Cantor's case said the approach was "very tentative" and was declined without rancor. **********Missing from the overall partnership plan, family partnership experts said, was any requirement for mediation of disputes that might arise over such sensitive issues as succession and the powers of the Cantor family entity as the non-managing general partner. **********Moreover, while the partnership agreement does indeed call for Mr. Lutnick to become managing general partner in the event of Mr. Cantor's death, it also allows a shift if Mr. Cantor is deemed to be "incapacitated" by a five-member panel he appointed. But the partnership agreement does not define "incapacity,"  nor does it specify how this committee is to operate or whether its vote must be unanimous. **********As of December, this panel consisted of Mrs. Cantor; Stuart Fraser, her nephew and an executive at the firm; Rod A. Fisher, her niece's husband and an executive at another family firm; Philip Ginsberg, another executive of the firm, and Dr. Peter S. Bing, a Stanford University trustee and longtime friend of the family. **********The committee was thrust into the spotlight when Mr. Cantor was rushed to New York Hospital in late December. On Jan. 1, he aspirated fluid into his lungs and was put on a respirator. Family members gathered in great distress, advisers to  both sides confirm. **********The next day, according to court papers filed by both sides, Mr. Lutnick approached three members of the incapacity committee -- Mr. Fraser, Mr. Fisher and Mr. Ginsberg -- and solicited their opinion that Mr. Cantor was incapacitated under the terms of the partnership agreement. All three initially  agreed, and Mr. Lutnick thus activated the succession plan, according to the court records. **********It may now seem unwise for Mr. Lutnick to have acted on the succession plan in the midst of an emotional crisis in the Cantor family. But people who support Mr. Lutnick insist that senior partners had been concerned about Mr. Cantor's physical and mental health since the fall of 1995, when he had been unable to complete a deposition in an unrelated lawsuit. With the firm preparing to offer  new partnership units to employees in March 1996, these partners pushed to have  the management situation clarified. **********In any case, Mrs. Cantor was shaken and enraged by the action, according to documents filed in court on her behalf. "She believed that Mr. Cantor's illness  no more interfered with the successful carrying out of the partnership's business than it had theretofore," her counterclaim asserted. Any incapacity declaration, her complaint continued, "was inappropriate, unnecessary, disrespectful and demeaning to Mr. Cantor." **********Her lawyers argue, indeed, that the committee vote is invalid and Mr. Lutnick thus has not lawfully assumed the role of managing general partner. Their argument is based on the lack of a formal committee meeting, on misrepresentations that Mr. Lutnick was accused of making to Mr. Fisher in soliciting his vote and on Mr. Fisher's own subsequent decision to revoke his support for the ruling of incapacity. That change of heart was noted in a letter he sent to the firm on March 4, a day before Mr. Lutnick amended the partnership agreement to make it more difficult for him to be removed as managing general partner. **********Mrs. Cantor's lawyers further challenge the validity of earlier partnership amendments in 1994 and 1995 that reduced the powers of the non-managing general  partner; they were initiated by Mr. Lutnick, they charge, in violation of the fiduciary duty he owed the Cantors. **********The level of anger in the case escalated when the firm refused to recognize as valid the powers of attorney that Mrs. Cantor submitted when she attempted to retrieve artwork owned by her husband from the firm's Los Angeles office on March 8, the day after Mr. Lutnick and the firm filed their lawsuit in Delaware. The result was an ugly scene; Mrs. Cantor has since been barred from the firm's  premises. Mr. Lutnick's supporters defend these steps as necessary to prevent Mrs. Cantor from using what the firm's lawyers say are "bogus powers of attorney" to undermine Mr. Cantor's wishes. Mrs. Cantor's advisers cite the incident as an example of the churlish treatment she has received from Mr. Lutnick. **********The refusal by Mr. Fraser, Mrs. Cantor's nephew, to join Mr. Fisher in retracting support for the incapacity ruling has caused more pain and division among the families that overlap the Cantor Fitzgerald executive suite. **********Mrs. Cantor has removed both Mr. Fraser and his mother, Enid Fraser, who is Mrs. Cantor's sister, from the board of the Cantor family partnership, along with Mr. Lutnick. The firm and Mr. Lutnick dispute her authority to effect those changes, however, under their general position that she is acting without Mr. Cantor's authority. **********Mr. Fisher, besides being married to Mr. Fraser's sister, is also a first cousin to Stephen Merkel, general counsel of Cantor Fitzgerald, said by many partners to be the architect of Mr. Lutnick's legal strategy in implementing the succession plan in January. **********On Saturday, April 6, partners at the firm received a letter signed "B. Gerald Cantor," with a shaky scrawled signature, announcing that Mr. Lutnick had been dismissed and that he and Mrs. Cantor were looking for a new management team. **********"As you all know by now," the typed letter said, "Howard Lutnick has betrayed the trust I placed in him" by "taking advantage of my current medical condition" to "declare himself the sole managing general partner" of the firm. "I am actively reclaiming our company and ask for your support," the note continued. "I will protect and restore our company, and your help will be forever appreciated." **********An accompanying typed letter, bearing the names of both Bernie and Iris Cantor, accused Mr. Lutnick of an "unauthorized attempt to seize control," and added, "This is not the succession plan we intended nor envisioned." **********Mr. Lutnick responded with a letter to the firm's partners on Monday, April 8: "Those letters did not come from Bernie," he wrote. "His physical and mental  condition rob him of the capacity to understand what is in them; his name is being misused by the one person who above all should honor it." Business would continue as usual, he continued, with him at the helm. "Our management team remains intact and is performing superbly," he wrote. **********There matters stand as the case speeds toward trial on an expedited basis in  Wilmington next week. Armies of lawyers have been engaged on both sides. **********The Los Angeles firm of Munger, Tolles & Olson, best known for its links to the investment guru Warren Buffett, is representing Mrs. Cantor, with the help of Morris, Nichols, Arsht & Tunnell in Wilmington and the Kekst & Company public relations firm in New York. President Clinton's former legal counsel, Bernard Nussbaum of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, is leading Mr. Lutnick's team, along with the Delaware firm of Young, Conaway, Stargatt & Taylor. **********Several dozen people -- doctors, nurses, household help, Cantor family lawyers, partners at the firm -- have been summoned to give depositions in the case; boxes of legal documents, partnership records and correspondence have been demanded on both sides. **********Lately, there have been a few whispers among Mr. Lutnick's advisers about possible settlement talks, involving some deal for the other partners to buy Mrs. Cantor's stake in the firm. But the parties have not been able to agree on  a simple plan to maintain the status quo at the firm until the judge reaches a decision, so a truce in the core dispute seems like a long shot. **********So far, neither side has proposed bringing in an independent professional mediator who could perhaps turn down the emotional heat under this cauldron and  achieve a negotiated peace -- an approach that several family business specialists endorsed. "That would be the ideal way to resolve something like this," said Mr. Starr of Coopers & Lybrand. **********What lies ahead for Cantor Fitzgerald? Any decision in the Delaware action is certain to be appealed, advisers on both sides agree. Given the various jurisdictions involved in the dispute -- the Cantor family partnership is registered in Nevada, Mr. Lutnick's company is incorporated in New York and the  Cantors live mainly in California -- new battles can be waged in other places after the Delaware action is concluded. "We'll fight until Iris Cantor comes to  her senses," one of Mr. Lutnick's supporters said. **********While the battle for control of Cantor Fitzgerald may be an extreme example,  such fights are common at large, complicated partnerships -- and several consultants see the case as a cautionary tale for all family businesses that have not yet tackled the sensitive and potentially divisive issue of succession. **********But for those who assert devotion to Bernie Cantor but who are waging war on  each other in his name, the lesson to be drawn from the case may simply be that  the gates of hell, once opened, are not easily closed again.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/24/busin.main_headline: Saks and Isetan Plan to Bid for Barney's
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/24/busin.print_headline: Saks and Isetan Plan to Bid for Barney's
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/24/busin.body_text: **********The suitors for Barneys New York are beginning to flirt openly. **********Saks Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it had joined the Isetan Company of Japan to create a proposed plan of reorganization for Barney's Inc., which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in January. Isetan is the partner of Barney's, the parent of Barneys New York, the luxury apparel chain. **********But Saks, the holding company for Saks Fifth Avenue, has yet to sign a confidentiality agreement with the Blackstone Group, Barney's financial adviser, and other potential investors might still have one leg up on Saks, a person with knowledge of the bankruptcy case said yesterday. **********Isetan and Barney's have been embroiled in a dispute over the retailer's future since it filed for Chapter 11. **********In response to an article on Tuesday in The Wall Street Journal, Saks, which  is controlled by the Investcorp Bank of Bahrain, issued a rough outline of what  it envisioned such a joint agreement would look like. **********Saks and Isetan executives propose that Saks, which operates 66 retail and outlet stores in the United States, would gain control of Barneys stores. Isetan, which paid for the costly construction of three Barneys stores in New York, Chicago and Beverly Hills, Calif., would lease these stores to Saks and continue to use the Barneys Asian trademark. **********"We've been talking for quite a time in terms of the possible synergies of a  relationship together and decided there obviously are some," Philip B. Miller, the chairman of Saks, said in a telephone interview. **********Barney's executives yesterday seemed deeply displeased with the idea, issuing this statement: "We are outraged that Isetan has entered into an agreement with  Saks that interferes with Barney's negotiations with Saks and other prospective  investors during the company's exclusive period." The exclusive period is the time given to companies in Chapter 11 to devise their own reorganization plans. **********The person with knowledge of the bankruptcy case, who spoke on the condition  of anonymity, said yesterday that while Saks may be more open about its intentions, other retailers have also expressed interest in Barney's. Among them are Canadian and Parisian companies, as well as Dickson Concepts Holdings Ltd.,  a Hong Kong-based retailer, that have already gone to Blackstone to sign a confidentiality agreement. **********"There are a host of people interested in making an investment," this person  said. "Dickson is the furthest along on the curve." Dickson executives have been circumspect about their true intentions, but do not deny their interest. **********Saks could be a good fit for Barneys, if it were able to keep the two stores  distinguishable. Such a retail merger could also offer economies of scale and operational consolidations that would benefit Saks. And Barneys, which is best known for its excellent merchandise team, could gain from Investcorp's long history of fixing up luxury merchants. **********"What Barneys says are its sales and gross margin are great," said Lisa Stern, an analyst at M. J. Whitman, which specializes in distressed securities.  "With financial and operational discipline, you can have a fabulous business." **********There is the question of how Saks, which went public just this spring with $945 million in long-term debt, would pay for Barney's. "I don't think we have the answer to how to pay for it," Mr. Miller said. "Obviously, the main issue for us is that this adds value to the Saks enterprise and for our shareholders.  We have not determined what the currency will be." He said that some amount could be paid for in Saks stock. **********But the biggest unanswered question is what, if any, role Bob and Gene Pressman, the brothers who share the title of chief executive of Barney's, would play in a new company. **********"The view in the market is that somebody else is going to end up with this company," Ms. Stern said. "On the one hand, you don't need the Pressmans as operators because they are terrible at that, but do you need them as merchants?  Maybe now the vision has been created, maybe others can follow it through now. Who knows?"

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/13/world.snippet: Prospects for smooth election in Bosnia do not look good; United Nations police monitors have spent most of last week planning how to move refugees to voting places; of Bosnia's nearly three million potential voters, as many as 150,000 are expecte...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/13/world.body_text: **********Prospects for a smooth election on Saturday did not look good today. **********Those dim prospects were reflected in the eyes of perplexed refugees jammed together in the rain outside a government building, hoping someone inside could tell them where to vote. **********The same prediction was evident in the frustration wrinkling the brows of supervisors for United Nations police monitors who have spent most of the last week planning how to move refugees to voting places. **********''The only way we can escape disaster is if my prayers are answered and we have enough bad weather to keep people at home,'' one monitor said. **********Of Bosnia's nearly three million potential voters, as many as 150,000 are expected to cross former battle lines to vote in the areas from which they were expelled during the war. And perhaps as many as 138,000 more refugees could be coming in from Serbia and Croatia. **********The estimates may be daunting, and possibly too high, but officials say these are the numbers being planned for, if indeed preparation is possible. **********''What we heard this morning is to get ready for about 1,200 buses coming in from Yugoslavia,'' a foreign election official said on Wednesday, her eyes wide at the prospect. ''How do we get ready for that?,'' **********One United Nations official added, ''I don't believe there are enough buses with working engines left in this country to do the job.'' **********So far, foreign officials are setting the rules, but trying to make Bosnian officials responsible for carrying them out. **********In charge of the election overall is the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe. NATO officers say they are deploying troops to monitor the voting, but getting people to the right polling places and making sure that they are not attacked along the way is supposed to be in the hands of local authorities. **********''We think that is going to be enough; maybe I should say we hope it is,'' said an American officer. ''We're counting on everyone to act responsibly, and maybe we're counting on too much.'' **********Most of Bosnia is still essentially in three pieces, each controlled by a single ethnic group that wants to keep out refugees from other groups. It was difficult, foreign diplomats said, to force local officials to plan for refugees to vote in the places from which they were expelled during the war. **********With the cancellation of local elections, fewer voters are expected to travel, since they can use absentee ballots in the national election. **********This week Bosnian officials decided on a plan to allow many people to vote in their home counties, without having to actually go to the town or village from which they fled or were driven . **********In many places, especially those in areas where emotions are the highest, refugees will vote in ballot booths just inside the boundaries of their county. **********An elaborate system is being devised to use buses to pick up refugees in one part of Bosnia and take them to polling place in their own county. **********Some highways have been barred to all traffic except for buses to be used in transporting voters. **********Even if the system works, it will take a long time to vote. A Muslim refugee from Srebrenica, for instance, will have to somehow get to the Muslim town of Kladanj, then wait for a bus ride to the outskirts of Srebrenica, well over an hour away. **********The round trip, and the time waiting to vote, will take nearly five hours, according to United Nations officials. Then the voter will have to somehow get home again. **********There had been considerable concern by foreign officials that once some voters were taken near their former homes, they would try to stay. **********Even though the peace agreement gives people the right to move freely in Bosnia, most people have not been able to go home, and voters using the buses will be required to leave as soon as they have voted. **********In a few towns, Muslim refugees will be voting very near to where Serbian refugees are being brought in from Yugoslavia. **********The confusion, and the fear of violence may keep the number of voters low, especially refugee voters. **********With refugees clamoring for information at the front door to his building, an Bosnian official, Fuad Ekmecic, opened today's newspaper looking for help. **********''I have nothing official, no information,'' he said. ''And there's nothing reliable in the paper. Maybe many people will just stay home.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/07/busin.main_headline: You Saved, but They Didn't. So Now What?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/07/busin.print_headline: You Saved, but They Didn't. So Now What?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/07/busin.body_text: **********HERE'S the nightmare. You've socked away every stray penny in retirement accounts, resisting the temptation to live it up, in order to accumulate a comfy nest egg. Now it's payoff time: Hawaii beckons. But all the aging spendthrifts -- the folks who bought fishing boats instead of mutual funds -- persuade Congress to tax your savings and slash your Social Security checks in order to spread the wealth. **********A far-fetched prospect in the home of the free and the land of the 401(k)? Don't be so sure. For while the baby boom generation's slowly building retirement crisis could be resolved in a variety of ways, punishing the thrifty  will always be a tempting option in a world of too many old people chasing too few condos in the sun. **********At one extreme, Washington might resolve the conflict between the boomers' expectations and the nation's fiscal realities by reneging on the promises of retirement benefits that it cannot easily underwrite. If it does, it might start by limiting benefits or raising taxes and financial penalties on those who have  saved significant amounts. At the other extreme, the baby boomers may gang up on the next generation of workers, heavily increasing taxes to sustain Social Security and Medicare. Conceivably, though, a middle ground could be found that  encourages or forces most Americans to save more and thereby softens the blow to both generations. **********The truly affluent will always be able to fend for themselves, and poor retirees will probably be protected -- few people, after all, are prepared to let granny eat Gravy Train. "It's the retirees in the middle who are most vulnerable" to falling short of their expectations, argues Sylvester Schieber, an economist at Watson Wyatt Worldwide, a pension consulting firm, "the people with incomes between $50,000 and $100,000." **********Practically everybody has an inkling that the retirement of the big generation born in the first two decades after World War II will strain the nation's resources. But the magnitude of the problem has yet to sink in. Between 1990 and 2030 the number of Americans over 65 will double, while the working-age population will grow by just 25 percent. Hence just 2.8 workers will be around to produce the goods and services consumed by each 65-plus retiree, compared with 4.8 workers today. **********Gilding this poisonous lily, the elderly population will be, on average, considerably older than it is today, and a greater percentage will need custodial care. **********Not every analyst paints the boomers' retirement prospects in shades of black. Three years ago a Congressional Budget Office study concluded that the baby boomers were actually a bit ahead of their parents' generation in accumulating assets for retirement. But for William Beeman, director of economic studies at the Committee for Economic Development, a policy group financed by business, any sense of relief disappeared after a look at the fine print. **********For one thing, he said, the boomers have a higher living standard -- and, presumably, higher expectations for retirement -- than their parents did in midlife. So merely saving on their parents' track will not take the boomers as far as they want to go. For another, the study assumed that today's workers would enjoy the Social Security and Medicare benefits provided under the current law. But that is hardly likely: projecting current tax and spending policies into the future, another, more recent C.B.O. study estimates that the budget deficit will rise from 2.2 percent of gross domestic product in 1995 to an astonishing 37 percent in 2030. **********Douglas Bernheim, an economist at Stanford University and consultant to Merrill Lynch, offers sobering confirmation. Each year he constructs an index of retirement-savings adequacy based on Merrill Lynch's survey of 2,000 baby-boom households. The latest, based on the November 1995 survey, puts the index at just 36, where 100 would be sufficient to sustain the living standard the boomers are expected to enjoy in their last working years. **********Wait -- it gets worse. The figure assumes that taxes will not go up and Social Security benefits will not go down. But if income taxes were raised by 63 percent in 2009 -- and that is what it would take to balance the Federal budget  through raising taxes alone from then on, according to an estimate by Lawrence Kotlikoff of Boston University and Alan Auerbach of the University of California at Berkeley -- the retirement index slips to 27. Alternatively, if the fiscal accounts were balanced exclusively through a 70 percent across-the-board cut in  Social Security benefits, the index would fall to just 15. **********These numbers are averages, reflecting the inadequacy of the entire generation's savings. Those who are prudent or lucky can expect to do much better. Using data from Watson Wyatt's own survey of corporate pension plans, Mr. Schieber calculated that workers covered for 30 years by both traditional "defined benefit" pension plans of average generosity and 401(k)-style "defined  contribution" plans can expect to retire with incomes equal to about 60 percent  of their preretirement wage. That, plus Medicare, Social Security and modest personal savings, should be sufficient to sustain their preretirement living standard. **********The catch, apart from the problematic nature of Government entitlements and the risk of higher taxes down the road, is that relatively few workers can boast of such belt-and-suspenders security. According to the Employee Benefit Research Institute, only about half of all private-sector employees aged 30 to 50 participated in any sort of retirement plan in 1993. What is more, while the percentage of the work force with some retirement coverage has remained roughly the same, there has been a sharp shift in the last decade from traditional-pension to 401(k)-style plans. **********In theory, there is nothing wrong with retirement accounts that give workers  discretion to invest their own assets instead of having their employers do it. In practice, though, they tend to invest far too conservatively to take advantage of the gains from investing in the stock market over the long haul. **********And a variety of rules, imposed by Congress in recent years in the scramble to limit revenue loss so that tax rates would not have to be raised, limit the amounts that can be socked away. Worse, many workers in 401(k)-style plans give  in to temptation and spend the money before they need it in retirement. **********While the laws of politics suggest that Washington will duck Social Security  and Medicare finance issues as long as possible, the laws of arithmetic guarantee a day of reckoning. Just how the chips will fall from this multitrillion-dollar collision between expectations and reality is anyone's guess. But a handful of possibilities are now being debated, some of them in Washington and some only in ivory towers. **********You Did Well, So You Lose! **********The trustees of the Social Security System estimate that revenues will fall short of scheduled outlays by about 30 percent between 2019 and 2043. Mr. Schieber argues that this projection is optimistic; he reckons that it will take a 40 percent across-the-board cut in outlays to balance the books without tax increases. **********Cuts would not necessarily be across the board. More likely, retirees who had saved more would take a bigger hit in order to keep those near the bottom out of poverty. This could be done directly by limiting or eliminating Social Security  benefits for those with more than a certain income. Or it could be done indirectly by taxing more heavily the nonwage income, like interest and dividends, of affluent retirees. Or it could be done by lowering the amount that can be withdrawn annually from retirement-plan savings without financial penalty. Even today, people who have accumulated large amounts in their retirement accounts and who make excessive withdrawals (currently $155,000 a year) pay penalties to the Government. The levels that constitute an excess amount could be reduced, or at least not allowed to rise with inflation, punishing the people who have saved to help those who have not. **********Those who expect this soak-the-prudent strategy could presumably sustain their living standards by redoubling their savings effort. But to make up for a 60 percent cut in Social Security, Mr. Schieber calculates, middle-income workers would have to save an extra 4 percent of their income over 30 years -- an astoundingly high figure, given that the average family saves less than 5 percent of its income today. **********So Washington will likely seek other ways to cut the system's liabilities. Of these, Mr. Beeman reckons that raising the age of eligibility for full pension benefits is "the least unpalatable." After all, the life expectancy of 65-year-olds has risen by five years in the last 50 years, and the number of extra years Americans can expect to enjoy in good health has risen at least in proportion. **********But under the 1983 amendments to the Social Security law that promised to guarantee the system's solvency for three-quarters of a century, many boomers already face an increase in the age of eligibility for full benefits, to 66 in the year 2020 and 67 in the year 2030. In any case, the very idea bucks the trend toward ever-earlier retirement in wealthy industrialized countries. **********Mr. Bernheim points to a less noticed but more important obstacle: Keeping older workers on the job for the extra years needed to ease the retirement squeeze would increase workplace tensions. It is customary to increase pay as workers' tenure rises, he notes, even though their productivity typically begins to fall in their 50's. That explains why many employers are eager to ease out employees by their early 60's, and why they would resist efforts to solve the retirement-finance problem by keeping aging workers on the job a few years more. "Just because somebody wants to work doesn't mean they will be able to," Mr. Bernheim argued. **********Delaying retirement does not require a mandate from Washington. When 65-year-olds discover they cannot afford full-time leisure, they may cling to their jobs or look for others. It already seems to be happening in the Sun Belt, where 60-somethings are returning to the labor force in increasing numbers. But  the free-market fix will not make everyone happy. **********"Many of these 'second careers' are flipping hamburgers," Mr. Schieber noted. **********The most serious objection to reducing or delaying Government benefits may be the disincentive to personal saving. Until 1991 Australia relied on a national pension system that used a stiff means test to sort retirees in need from those  who could pay their own way. But the system's cost ballooned under the weight of a perverse incentive to depend on the state. "It became fashionable to spend down your personal savings to become eligible for a public pension," Mr. Schieber said, much as it has become commonplace in America for the elderly to give away their wealth in order to become eligible for nursing-home care under the means-tested Medicaid program. **********Just Shift the Burden **********The boomers are, in effect, paying for the retirement of their parents by keeping Social Security and Medicare afloat with their payroll taxes. Why not ask their children to do the same for them? For that matter, why ask? Why not just use the weight of boomers' votes to force them? **********That approach has a certain realpolitik appeal, but there are problems. For starters, the tax increases needed to cover the costs would probably be enormous. Mr. Schieber estimates that it would take a 40 percent increase in payroll taxes, starting now, to square Social Security's accounts without reducing benefits. If Congress waits -- a sure bet -- the numbers would quickly  become staggering. **********How staggering? **********Mr. Kotlikoff and Mr. Auerbach calculate the extreme case. Under current law, they estimate, Americans who are now working will pay about 34 percent of their  lifetime wages in taxes. If, however, everyone alive in 1993 were exempted from  the extra taxes needed to pay for currently mandated services, the hapless people born after 1993 would have to pay 84 percent of their wages in taxes. **********One way to soften the blow would be to invite more young, taxpaying immigrants to join the American work force. But Mr. Beeman notes that to get much bang from an extra green card the immigration laws would have to be made more selective, admitting more working-age immigrants with lots of earning power and few dependents. **********And the numbers would have to be huge to make a material difference. The Committee for Economic Development calculates that in 2030, some 110 million workers would have to be added to a projected labor force of 160 million to restore the worker-retiree ratio to 1990 levels. "Immigration could be part of the answer," Mr. Beeman concluded, "but not much of it." **********Saved by the Savings **********This is the handy-dandy, all-purpose solution for those eager to avoid a showdown between the generations. **********Savings translates into bricks and mortar and productivity-enhancing machines. So if savings were higher -- everybody's savings, not just the boomers' -- national income would eventually grow faster and the sacrifice required to support the elderly in the style they see as their due would shrink. But wishing won't make it happen. "There's a lot of talk, but I don't see any basis for believing that savings is rising," said Barry Bosworth, an economist at the Brookings Institution. **********The Committee for Economic Development offers a laundry list of regulatory changes that could made a difference. High on the list is a reduction in the cost of administering defined-benefit contribution pension plans, which according to the Pension Benefit Guarantee Corporation now run to $455 a year per employee for small companies. If that cost were cut sharply, maybe more companies would offer such plans. **********The pension consultants are also enthusiastic about the simplest of fixes, namely more aggressive efforts by employers to inform midcareer workers of the pressing need to save for retirement. "Education does work -- especially one-on-one counseling," Mr. Bernheim said. **********Tax incentives to save -- in particular, liberalized retirement savings accounts -- are also perennial favorites. But Robert Litan, director of economic studies at Brookings, points to the Achilles' heel of virtually all these tax carrots. A substantial portion of the money going into tax-sheltered accounts, he argues, would have been saved anyway. And even if the incentive to save is relatively effective it still reduces tax revenue, which in turn makes it more difficult to reduce the budget deficit. **********Mr. Litan has proposed a novel way around this problem: requiring middle- and upper-income families to save a minimum percentage of their income, with severe  tax penalties for noncompliance. But he acknowledges that this is a political nonstarter. **********There are subtler means, though, toward this same end. Since 1991 Australia has had a mandatory retirement-saving system, to which employers and employees will eventually be required to contribute a total of 12 percent of wages. The savings accounts, which work much the way 401(k) plans do, are portable from job to job. **********Edward M. Gramlich, an economist at the University of Michigan who heads the  Social Security system's advisory commission, wants to try something similar in  the United States, supplementing the existing Social Security system with mandatory individual retirement savings accounts financed by an additional few percentage points of payroll tax. "The attraction," Mr. Litan noted, "is that workers would identify the money as their own," rather than just another tax that disappears into the black hole of Social Security. **********Every proposed solution to the retirement-finance crisis would meet objections, and for good reason: someone must pay. But one way or another, the cupboard must be replenished or the next generation of retirees must learn to do without. Once this message really gets across, perhaps sweet reason will prevail. "Attitudes could change," Mr. Bernheim concluded, "as people become more desperate."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/21/world.main_headline: The Battle Cry 'Reform!' Rocks the House of Lords
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/21/world.print_headline: The Battle Cry 'Reform!' Rocks the House of Lords
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/21/world.body_text: **********From time to time something goes wrong with the clock that rings Big Ben, perhaps some humidity that slows the aging mechanism or a spasm of wind that speeds it up. Then a workman appears with a pocket full of thick one-penny copper coins. He deftly dangles from a railing and carefully adds or subtracts a penny from a tiny pile on top of the 13-foot pendulum, thereby gaining or losing two-fifths of a second over the course of 24 hours. **********Down below, the Houses of Parliament run much the same way as the clock. Nothing fancy, nothing digital, and when something needs fixing give it a rap on the knuckles or a smidgeon of oil. After all, it has been working for 731 years. **********So it's a bit surprising that the Labor Party, flexing its muscles as it contemplates winning an election within the next year, is preparing to tackle one of the most delicate and intractable political issues in Britain: reforming  the House of Lords. **********"It's bizarre that we are the only legislature anywhere in the world in which there is a substantial number of people who are hereditary peers, the vast majority of whom are Conservative, that are entitled to vote just on the basis of birth," Tony Blair, the party leader, said in an interview. "And from time to time they have considerable impact on legislation." **********As every schoolchild knows, the House of Lords has been gradually emasculated over the years, leading Gilbert and Sullivan to pen the saucy line that it "did  nothing in particular and did it very well." Its vestigial power lies in the capacity to delay bills passed by the House of Commons for one year. But in practice it operates as a revising body, reworking the raw bills from the lower  chamber and filling in the details and closing the loopholes. **********"The Commons is not superlative when it comes to nuts and bolts," remarked Ivor Richard, a life baron who is the Lords Labor leader. **********The upper chamber includes hereditary peers, who inherit the right to sit there along with their titles; life peers (appointed by the Queen on the recommendation of the Prime Minister), and 26 bishops and archbishops from the Church of England. **********It has long attracted humorous jibes. Lord Beaverbrook, the statesman and newspaper magnate, called it "the house of make-believe." And Winston Churchill, in his fiery younger days, said it was "filled with old doddering peers, cute financial magnates, clever wirepullers, big brewers with bulbous noses." **********Since 1968, when Labor's last big push to undermine the symbolic seat of privilege went down to ignominious defeat, some 34 bills to change the Lords have died at various stages. But this time Labor says it is serious. The first step, according to Mr. Blair, is to take away voting rights from the hereditary  peers who make up about three-fifths of the active body. **********But Mr. Blair is vague when it comes to talking about the second stage of reform, turning the Lords into an elected body. Backtracking from more radical pledges, Labor now says that this is a project for the far future, that it is a  subject that needs consensus and perhaps even a royal commission to sort it out. **********Since the middle of the last century, the occasional reformist gust has swept through Westminister's fabled upper house. There have been some notable advances, like the 1958 law that created life peerages, which cannot be passed on to descendants, and that also allowed women to take seats. But more often than not the winds of change dissipate into nothingness as they blow through the ornately carved Gothic chamber with its statues, frescoes and stained-glass windows. **********Through it all, the House of Lords endures, something of a cross between a genteel debating society and a well-appointed gentlemen's club, the bane of constitutional modernizers, the only feudal remnant in Europe in which an octogenarian can dine, snooze on television and vote because an ancestor won the king's favor back in the 13th century. **********Everyone except the most dyed-in-the-wool Tory will acknowledge privately that things must change. After all, the anomaly is striking of a legislature that debates the Maastricht Treaty on European Union one minute and the next tries to untangle the tricky question of who should succeed Lord Moynihan, who died five years ago while running a string of massage parlors in the Philippines -- his half-brother, an Olympic rower, or the 5-year-old boy who is said to be his son by a belly dancer? **********The problem is in agreeing upon what the House of Lords should change into. Few people seem to want a one-chamber Parliament. But if the upper chamber is retained and democratically elected, how should its members be chosen? By regions? By countries -- meaning England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland?  What is to prevent it from rivaling the House of Commons? **********Each new proposal to change it only reveals how deeply embedded it is in the  fabric of national government, a jigsaw puzzle piece that can't be rearranged without disturbing those around it. **********Boosters of the Lords -- and there are many -- say it functions as a sort of  legislative pause for a rethinking. They point out that its debates are elegant, non-adversarial and informative and sometimes lead to significant amendments. They insist that many of the life peers have a depth of expertise from earlier careers and that a number of the hereditary peers have eclectic backgrounds surpassing those of the homogeneous lawyers and other professionals that crowd the Commons. **********In fact, they are a varied lot. The roll call has the occasional ring of history: there is the 13th Lord Byron (a solicitor) and the 9th Lord Nelson (a retired police detective sergeant). Some of the once aristocratic families have  fallen on hard times and others use their wealth to pursue private passions. One lord was a shelf-stuffer in a supermarket and another was a bus driver (he is on the transportation committee). A third, who has gone off to Australia, lists his occupation as "rabbit salesman, used-car dealer and encyclopedia salesman." One  lady is a fortune-teller named Lady Strange, who is given to reciting poetry in  her speeches, which sometimes refer to supernatural phenomena. **********Bankruptcy is ground for losing the right to attend -- a prospect two lords are currently facing -- though other misdeeds seem to be tolerated. Scandal is not unknown in the chamber. But the house is not looking forward to the day when it will get a specialist in prisons -- the Marquess of Blandford, who has a lengthy record of committing forgery, assaulting policemen, possessing cocaine and failing to pay child support, and will be entitled to wear the ermine collar of a lord as the 12th Duke of Marlborough. **********Altogether there are 1,199 lords, including 151 who have never taken up office or are on leave. Of the rest, 400 are life peers, 622 are hereditary peers and 26 are "lords spiritual," archbishops and bishops of the Church of England. The body tends to be Conservative, because so many of the hereditary peers (332) are Conservative and so few (13) are Labor. A significant number of  the lords -- 287 -- are "cross benchers," without party affiliation. **********The tilt to the right shows up in the voting record. During years when the Conservatives are in power, the Lords almost always vote with the Government, and when Labor is in power they usually vote against it. **********As an example of their impact on legislation, Mr. Blair cited the poll tax pushed through by the Thatcher Government in 1988, a community charge for local  services. The Lords, who are empowered only to delay bills for up to a year, were considering tacking on an amendment that would have varied the tax by income. But the Government called out the "backwoodsmen" -- peers who usually do not attend -- and got the unpopular legislation through unchanged. It led to riots in the streets and was eventually dumped. **********Mr. Blair's proposals are unsettling to many. "The Lords is an anachronism and hard to defend," said Valerian Freyberg, a 25-year-old baron and sculptor. "The only thing is, it works. And people are nervous about replacing it with anything else."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/07/busin.snippet: Dow Jones industrial average rises 52.90 points, to 5,659.86, with S&P 500-stock index keeping pace, up 6.24 points at 655.68; table (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/07/busin.main_headline: Dow Gains 52.90 as Fears Over Rate Rise Are Eased
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/07/busin.print_headline: Dow Gains 52.90 as Fears Over Rate Rise Are Eased
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/07/busin.body_text: **********Stocks bounded higher yesterday, following the release of August nonfarm payroll data that eased investor fears that corporate profits would be hurt by a Federal Reserve decision to raise interest rates. **********The stock market had been nervous that strong payroll data would have spurred the Fed to tighten monetary policy to slow growth and control inflation. In doing so, corporate profits most likely would have been hurt, and higher interest rates would make bonds more attractive, taking funds away from the stock market. **********The Dow Jones industrial average rose 52.90 points, to 5,659.86, with the S.& P. 500-stock index keeping pace, up 6.24 points at 655.68. The Dow tripped the New York Stock Exchange's circuit-breakers, which limit certain kinds of computerized trading, at 12:22 P.M. **********Because the jobs data showed only slightly more strength in the economy than expected, they allayed market fears that the central bank would raise interest rates by half a percentage point at the Sept. 24 meeting of the Fed's Open Market Committee. It was those fears that sent the Dow skidding 50 points on Thursday and had kept stocks depressed for the last couple of weeks. **********New York Stock Exchange volume was 348.7 million, with gainers topping decliners, 1,652 to 705. **********John H. Shaughnessy, senior vice president and director of research at Advest Inc., said yesterday's jobs report was consistent with the theme that the economy was growing faster than the Fed would like in the second half of the year. ''The market entered the day in a high degree of stress, fearing the worst,'' he said. **********''From what I saw, there must have been a significant number of short positions in both stocks and bonds for the rally to take off the way it did,'' Mr. Shaughnessy said. ''From a profile of the action, the Dow, S.& P. 500 and Nasdaq were all up about 1 percent, with the strength pretty much spread across the board. **********''I think what is happening is that the market is basically resigned to the fact that Fed will bump rates significantly, and by as much as 50 basis points on Sept. 24. My own conclusion is that it may not be such a bad thing, because it keeps inflation fears in check, and secondly it may turn out to be the last hike needed this year. Also it may lay to rest the continuing fears that have gripped the market all year because of fears on when, and to what extent, the Fed will be raising rates.'' **********Oil stocks and paper stocks were strong, while shares of Ford Motor and General Motors fell in reaction to August sales reports. **********Elsewhere, shares of Boise Cascade Office Products fell 5 1/2, to 17 1/4, after a J. P. Morgan analyst, Mark Husson, lowered his third-quarter earnings estimate. Shares of Genovese Drug traded up 1 1/8, to 13 3/8, after hitting a 52-week high of 13 3/4 on a Business Week article that quoted an analyst who said Genovese could be a buyout target. Gene Wexler, the company's vice president and general counsel, said the drugstore chain was not involved in merger talks with any company. The article mentioned J. C. Penney's Thrift Drug unit as a good fit. **********A day after it acquired the rights to a new drug that tests show may make chemotherapy more effective, shares of Bristol-Myers Squibb gained 2 1/4, to 90 3/8.
