https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/13/your-.main_headline: Does EMU Spell Boom or Bust for Hedge Funds?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/13/your-.print_headline: Does EMU Spell Boom or Bust for Hedge Funds?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/13/your-.body_text: **********CALL it fame, call it infamy, call it what you will. One thing at least is certain: Hedge fund managers in the 1990s have made a name for themselves in the financial markets and the wider world. **********That the epithets applied to them are not always polite is partly because of the great European Exchange Rate Mechanism spree of 1992.In the autumn of that year, the foreign exchange markets — with hedge funds in the vanguard — — went on a gigantic spree at the expense of the ERM. Today, some observers are asking whether the political and technical problems facing European Monetary Union — the merging of European currencies, and the next step forward from the ERM — will provide too tempting a target. **********During the ERM debacle a succession of European currencies were either forced out of the grid of exchange rate parities (the British pound and the Italian lire) or were forced to "realign" themselves by devaluing and trying to hold a lower rate (the Spanish peseta and the Irish punt). **********One prominent hedge fund manager, George Soros, made some dollars 1.5 billion by using aggressive derivatives positions to bet on a sharp fall in the value of the pound. The question now being asked is whether something similar will occur to the French franc's value against the Deutsche mark before 1999, when the currencies participating in the ERM are expected to join in the single European currency. **********If the franc and the Deutsche mark were not to be joined in what is to be called the Euro, it is generally accepted that EMU would be less of a union of currencies than a"mark zone," including the Dutch guilder and the Belgian franc, which are closely associated with the Deutsche mark. **********Individuals, therefore, who are thinking about a hedge fund investment and are impressed by the clever hedge fund management of 1992 and 1993 (when, among other things, the markets had a summer run against the French franc) should ask themselves a few questions: **********First, is there a general perception that the French franc — or other significant currencies within the EMU core — is vulnerable to sustained selling? **********If so, and EMU is thereby effectively prevented from occurring, what will be the major financial consequences? **********Finally, how important is the role of the hedge funds? Specifically, do hedge fund managers exert such influence — directly through their buying power, or indirectly through their reputations — to influence the markets simply by advertising their investment decisions? **********Will the markets sell the franc? **********"There is a growing possibility that the French administration has done it. They've survived all the major political storms of 1995, in particular the December strike," said Nick Knight, head of strategy at Nomura Research Institute Europe. "Before selling pressure builds, the markets will need to see a greater visibility of failure to deliver on the budget deficit limits as specified in the Maastricht treaty." **********Ciaran O'Hagan, an analyst at J.P. Morgan in Paris, argued that the French government had "for the moment, at least, got away with it.The resolution of the December strike had minimal budgetary implications for 1996 or 1997." **********Michael Goldman, London-based managing director of Momentum Asset Management, which has 10 diverse hedge funds under management, added that he did not believe the franc was in imminent danger of coming under attack: "People are long of German government bonds and several have been buying the mark and shorting the franc. But those are long-term positions that have been held for some months." **********Mr. Goldman cited the gold, oil and dollar-yen rate markets as the most active among hedge fund managers. **********But from January 1996 to January 1999 is an eternity in the volatile currency markets, and few can rule out a speculative attack on the franc in that time. **********Mr. Knight at Nomura identified an aura of returning confidence about the hedge fund industry that might lead to more aggressive strategies in the medium-term future: "Hedge funds had a great 1993, a very poor 1994, and quite a few enjoyed 1995, especially the second half. So self-confidence is returning, and we may see hedge funds as a more potent force in 1996 and after that they begin to throw their weight around again." **********What will be the likely financial consequences? **********The Zurich-based Bank Julius Baer published a booklet, "Scenarios for European Monetary Union," at the end of last year in which it rated the likelihood of EMU's not going ahead at 30 percent. The bank argued that if EMU did not occur or were to be postponed for several years, European interest rates generally would fall, with "significantly greater devaluation in the soft currency countries." **********By "soft currencies" the bank means denominations such as the Spanish peseta, the Portuguese escudo and the Greek drachma. Its assumptions are predicated on its assertion that EMU "stands or falls on the Frenco-German axis." If the unlikely occurs, therefore, a significant fall in the value of the franc should also be assumed. **********Mr. O'Hagan at J.P. Morgan also regarded the achievement of EMU as more likely than not: "EMU has two chances in three of occurring. Partly because, little by little, the European Commission is beginning to work out a consensus on the legal difficulties involved." **********Mr. O'Hagan cautioned against the automatic assumption that the proposed Euro currency would instantly take over as a unit of account from the ECU basket of currencies. Although this positive development seemed likely in Germany, he said that the replacement of one unit by the other was one of many legal problems yet to be solved. **********How important are the hedge funds? **********Acting with typical alacrity, a Congressional committee hearing was called into the activities of hedge funds on hearing of Mr. Soros' successful sterling play in the fall of 1992. Mr. Soros was asked to give evidence before the committee in April 1994, at which time he argued that hedge funds were a stabilizing force in the market, since they tended to bet against irrational investment decisions and erratic capital flows. He also argued that, in the overall context of the market, hedge funds were simply too small to have a major impact on currency rates. **********This point of view is, by implication, shared by Charles R. Taylor in a paper on currency and option intervention published in October by the London-based Center for the Study of Financial Innovation. Mr. Taylor argues that derivatives — the favorite securities of the hedge fund managers — are really a form of insurance, and that governments seeking to protect an exchange rate would be well-advised to make use of these instruments themselves. **********Mr. Goldman at Momentum agreed that the effect of hedge funds was generally overrated, but he added that once a hedge fund manager had a following in the market, his decisions would be copied and their effect multiplied by the "herd mentality." Nevertheless, it was difficult to envisage hedge funds leading an assault on a currency so as to derail EMU.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/18/busin.main_headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Crude Oil Prices Settle Higher Despite Speculation on Iraq Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/18/busin.print_headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Crude Oil Prices Settle Higher Despite Speculation on Iraq Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/18/busin.body_text: **********Crude oil prices settled higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, after plunging early in the day, as traders bet that stockpiles are so low that even a limited oil sale by Iraq would be absorbed by the world market. **********On other markets, corn prices also rebounded from an early dip, and coffee rose. **********Speculation that Iraq was close to an agreement with the United Nations that would allow it to sell as much as $2 billion of crude oil over six months sent crude prices plunging on Tuesday and early yesterday. While many traders still expect an agreement, intended to help Iraq buy food and medicine, demand from refineries to replenish inventories that are close to their lowest since 1977 stalled the decline. **********"There is pent-up demand from refiners and the market needs" the Iraqi oil, said Liz Gall, head of crude oil marketing at Enterprise Oil P.L.C., Britain's largest independent oil company. **********After dropping as low as $23.20 a barrel, crude oil for May delivery rose 20  cents, to $24.67 a barrel. **********A smaller-than-expected decline in gasoline stockpiles reported by the American Petroleum Institute pushed gasoline prices lower. May gasoline fell 1.33 cents, to 68.12 cents a gallon. **********With demand for gasoline expected to rise by 2 percent this summer, traders are betting oil prices will rebound even if the Iraqi sale is announced. **********"I think the market can absorb the oil, it's just that the panic will take prices down at first," said Tom Bentz, energy services director at ING Derivatives Clearing Inc. **********Corn also rebounded from an early decline as a steady stream of export sales  showed soaring prices have yet to curb demand. **********Japan, the largest customer for American corn, bought 107,696 metric tons of  the grain for delivery after Sept. 1, the Agriculture Department said. **********The announcement came after corn prices tumbled on Tuesday from a record high on Monday. May corn settled 4 cents higher yesterday at $4.485 a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade. **********May coffee rose 1.7 cents, to $1.173 a pound, on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa  Exchange in New York.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/11/world.snippet: Russian Pres Boris Yeltsin formally hands over authority for national security and law enforcement to Prime Min Viktor S Chernomyrdin as he prepares to undergo heart surgery; will retain authority over nation's nuclear forces; ministers of defense...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/11/world.main_headline: Yeltsin, Preparing for Surgery, Yields Authority to Premier
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/11/world.print_headline: Yeltsin, Preparing for Surgery, Yields Authority to Premier
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/11/world.body_text: **********President Boris N. Yeltsin, on vacation and resting up for heart surgery, formally handed over authority today for national security and law enforcement to his Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin. **********Mr. Yeltsin will still hold onto the nuclear button, the President's spokesman, Sergei Yastrzhembsky, said. But in a move that seemed partly aimed at curbing the ambitions of the national security adviser, Aleksandr I. Lebed, the ministers of defense, foreign affairs, intelligence and the interior, who normally report to the President, will now report to Mr. Chernomyrdin. **********As the ailing Mr. Yeltsin, 65, prepares for bypass surgery this month, the Kremlin is struggling to lock in the chain of command and contain a power struggle that picked up steam when Mr. Yeltsin acknowledged last week that he would undergo heart surgery. **********The Russian Constitution says that  if the President dies or is incapacitated, the Prime Minister takes over as Acting President until new elections are held within three months. **********While the decision today confirmed that Mr. Chernomyrdin will run things if Mr. Yeltsin cannot, it did not settle who, if anyone, will receive Mr. Yeltsin's blessing to run in the next presidential race, which given his health could occur well before his term ends in the year 2000. **********As Mr. Yeltsin has receded from public view, the three men most likely to compete to succeed him have suddenly sprung up all over the place, doing things that look eerily like the first steps of a presidential campaign. **********Mr. Lebed is seeking peace in Chechnya by noisily declaring war on vested interests in the Kremlin. **********The powerful Mayor of Moscow, Yuri Luzhkov, has recently begun voicing strong views on foreign policy and national security matters, and vividly attacked Mr. Lebed last week, denouncing his peace plan for Chechnya as ''capitulation to armed bandits.'' **********And the stiff, buttoned-down Mr. Chernomyrdin suddenly left Moscow last week to attend the opening of a newly restored Russian Orthodox Church in his home village, Chorny Otrog, accompanied by the Patriarch Aleksy II. Mr. Chernomyrdin, wearing a tie and a borrowed workman's jacket, also drove a harvester and talked about his log cabin roots. **********Russians are suddenly talking openly about political life after Yeltsin, weighing scenarios and evaluating the various candidates' chances. **********''Now, when the President's illness is known and nobody knows when the next presidential campaign will be, the question of who will be the next President has become legitimate,'' said Vyacheslav A. Nikonov, a political consultant who worked on Mr. Yeltsin's re-election campaign this year. **********But he warned that unless or until Mr. Yeltsin anoints someone as his chosen successor, ''they will also start running against each other -- and create enough division and chaos for a Communist revanche.'' **********The decision today reined in Mr. Lebed, who had received and asserted sweeping powers over a wide range of national security issues. Mr. Lebed, who has brokered a controversial peace agreement in the secessionist republic of Chechnya, is Mr. Chernomyrdin's main rival for influence inside the Kremlin -- and in the next presidential race. **********Mr. Lebed will continue to report directly to the President, according to the Kremlin. But Mr. Chernomyrdin, who usually oversees the economy and social issues, was given additional authority to decide national security and military matters. **********The Kremlin did not give any details about how long Mr. Chernomyrdin will be in charge or whether he will take over in full during the actual operation. Mr. Yastrzhembsky did not even say exactly when the operation would take place. **********Mr. Yeltsin, who for a long time fiercely resisted any talk of undergoing heart surgery, does not seem eager to contemplate a political landscape stripped of his presence. Today he did not anoint Mr. Chernomyrdin as his chosen successor -- he mainly seemed intent on temporarily lending his power to someone he could trust to return it. **********''Chernomyrdin is loyal,'' an official close to the Kremlin said. ''The President trusts Chernomyrdin, he can be secure that while he is in hospital, Mr. Chernomyrdin will not use the pause in his functioning to become a de facto president.'' **********Mr. Chernomyrdin proved his loyalty today by refusing to view himself as an acting president. ''For me this means that he will remain President even during the operation and during the entire course of medical treatment,'' Mr. Chernomyrdin told reporters. He described a transfer of power as ''far-fetched and tactless.'' **********Mr. Lebed did not comment on the transfer today, and it was not clear how informed he was of the decision ahead of time. His spokesman said  the National Security Council's press service learned of the decision only when it was announced by the news agencies. **********When Mr. Yeltsin announced that he would undergo a major heart operation, many politicians began demanding that he formally transfer his responsibilities to the Prime Minister during the operation and until he recovers. **********Mr. Lebed was among the most vehement. He seemed mostly worried that without such a formal transfer, the President's chief of staff, Anatoly B. Chubais, would in effect run the Kremlin. **********Mr. Chubais has not hid his coolness toward Mr. Lebed, who has not hidden his intention to run for the presidency as soon as he gets a chance. Mr. Chubais is too unpopular with voters to run for President, but he is very popular with the bankers and financiers who bankrolled Mr. Yeltsin's re-election effort; his support would be essential to any establishment candidate seeking to succeed Mr. Yeltsin. **********Kremlin aides say the chief of staff's relationship with Mr. Chernomyrdin has so far been fairly smooth and conciliatory, but Mr. Chubais has been careful to not appear totally in the Prime Minister's pocket. Last week Mr. Chubais told reporters that Mr. Luzhkov might soon be granted an audience with Mr. Yeltsin, who has remained secluded at a Government hunting lodge 60 miles from Moscow. **********Mr. Chubais's relationship with Mr. Luzhkov has been stormy. When Mr. Chubais headed the Government's privatization program, the Mayor rejected it and devised one of his own for Moscow. **********Political experts in Moscow interpreted the invitation to Mr. Luzhkov as an attempt to repair Mr. Chubais's relations with the powerful Mayor, who is close to influential Russian bankers and businessmen. **********Some suspected that Mr. Chernomyrdin's future prospects were enhanced by today's decision. ''He's getting presidential experience,'' Mr. Nikonov said. ''No one else has that.'' **********The Communists, who had vehemently demanded that Mr. Yeltsin identify a constitutional successor, have also kept a close eye on the political maneuvering on the other side of the aisle. **********''In Russia, it is unethical to talk about a presidential race when the President is sick,'' said Aleksandr Shabanov, the chief ideologist of the Communist Party. ''But there are figures who are acting publicly like politicians, which is natural under the circumstances.'' **********Mr. Shabanov said his party would not identify its future candidate until elections are announced. But he said that Gennadi A. Zyuganov, Mr. Yeltsin's unsuccessful Communist challenger in the presidential election, ''is the only and recognized leader of the opposition.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/05/busin.main_headline: S.&L.'s Post Loss After Insurance Fund Fee
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/05/busin.print_headline: S.&L.'s Post Loss After Insurance Fund Fee
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/05/busin.body_text: **********The United States savings and loan industry posted a loss of $505 million in the third quarter after paying a one-time fee to replenish its deposit insurance fund, the Office of Thrift Supervision said today. **********Nevertheless, the industry remains healthy. If the $2.1 billion fee for the fund that insures their deposits had not been needed, savings institutions would have earned $1.6 billion in the third quarter, the office said. In the second quarter, the industry earned $1.89 billion. **********After years of poor earnings hampered by bad loans, the institutions are enjoying healthy loan growth -- especially in California, which is recovering from a recession. **********In return for the one-time insurance fund contribution, the savings and loans will pay lower premiums to the Savings Association Insurance Fund, which will help earnings in subsequent quarters. **********Third-quarter savings and loan profits were unchanged from the third quarter of last year, when savings and loans also posted $1.6 billion in earnings, the agency said. **********The number of problem institutions continued to drop. The agency listed only 31 savings and loans as troubled in the third quarter, down from 33 in the second quarter and 49 at the end of the third quarter of 1995. **********Delinquent loans and other troubled assets were $9.3 billion, the same as in the second quarter. **********The agency was regulating 1,378 institutions as of Sept. 30, down from 1,397 at the end of the second quarter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/09/busin.body_text: **********In the face of yesterday's selloff of stocks and bonds, market analysts are counseling investors to remain focused on the long term, rather than on wild one-day swings. **********Many consider the surprising employment report that jolted the markets to be  more of a fluke than an indicator of an overheating economy. Moreover, since stocks have pushed to dizzying heights in recent months, analysts say investors  should have been prepared for just this sort of sharp pullback. **********As such, few analysts are ready to predict an end to the bull market in stocks, although they do caution investors to be prepared for inevitable future  upsets. **********News Analysis, page 35.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/20/busin.main_headline: Uncovered Short Sales Decline On the Big Board and the Amex
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/20/busin.print_headline: Uncovered Short Sales Decline On the Big Board and the Amex
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/20/busin.body_text: **********Despite the stock market's recent gyrations, bearish investors have been trimming their bets a bit, based on the open positions of short sales reported yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange. **********The Big Board reported that open short-sale positions on its stocks totaled 2.3 billion shares as of July 15, which includes actual trades through July 10.  That reflects a decline of one-half of a percent from the June figure, which was revised to 2.31 billion shares. **********On the American exchange, the decline in short sales was a bit larger. Traders held open short positions of 124.9 million shares as of the July settlement date, down 1.4 percent from the June figure. **********In a short sale, an investor borrows shares from a brokerage firm and sells them, hoping the shares will decline in price. If they do, the investor can buy  them back at a lower price, return them to the lender, and make a profit. If the shares rise in price, the investor faces a loss. Open short sales are those in which the investor has not yet returned the borrowed shares to the lender. **********Some analysts see a high short position as a sign of investor pessimism, while others say that it is a source of future purchases as short-sellers must buy to return their borrowed shares. And many factors -- a pending merger, a stock swap, a derivative-driven trading strategy -- can result in short sales that offer no clues to market sentiment. **********The Kmart Corporation had the largest open short position on the Big Board, with 49.7 million shares sold short, slightly fewer than in the prior period. The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, which last month announced a $3.9 billion purchase of Infinity Broadcasting, registered the largest increase in short sales on the Big Board, to 27.4 million shares from 8.5 million in the June period. **********On the Amex, the open short position in the Atari Corporation increased by more than 60 percent, to 4.1 million shares.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/22/world.main_headline: Ex-Hamas Group Forms Nonviolent Party With Arafat Backing
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/22/world.print_headline: Ex-Hamas Group Forms Nonviolent Party With Arafat Backing
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/22/world.body_text: **********A group of Islamic militants formerly associated with Hamas announced today that they had formed a new political party that shares Hamas's broad ideology but rejects the use of violence. **********The party, the Islamic National Salvation Party, was formed with the active support of Yasir Arafat, president of the Palestinian Authority, who has tried and failed before to foster an Islamic opposition that would function openly within the authority. **********The timing, when Hamas and Islamic militants are under pressure after the wave of suicide bombings in Israel, suggested an attempt by Islamic leaders opposed to Hamas's violence to avoid being swept up in the general crackdown. **********It also appeared to be an attempt by Mr. Arafat to give Muslims a channel of  political expression other than Hamas, and to demonstrate that his crackdown on  Hamas is not a general war on Islamic activities. Despite pressures from Israel  to eradicate Hamas, Mr. Arafat has not moved against social services run by the  movement. **********Mr. Arafat also probably hoped to demonstrate to Israel that his general strategy of co-opting moderate elements of the Islamic movement and isolating the armed wings is bearing fruit. **********The new party was proclaimed at a news conference held by 19 members of the "political office." The chairman, Ismail Abu Shanab, an engineer by training, has been in an Israeli jail since 1989, and most of those at the conference had  served time in Israeli prisons for taking part in Hamas activities. Two of the leaders, in a marked departure from usual Islamic practice, were women. **********The program they presented generally followed the militant Islamic line, rejecting the "unjust" Israeli-Palestinian treaties, declaring Palestine to be an "Islamic, Arab and Palestinian" land with Jerusalem as its capital, and proclaiming Islam as the "solution for all problems." **********But the party also declared that its means for achieving its ends was "legal  political struggle," and that it acknowledges religious, cultural and political  pluralism. **********The statement concluded by saying, "Our compliments are to the chairman Arafat and to everyone who has financially and spiritually supported the establishment of our party." **********Mr. Arafat is expected to give the party representation on his executive committee, or Cabinet, and the party is certain to run in municipal elections expected in summer or fall. **********There was no way to predict how much support the new party might attract. But the potential was large because Islam is strong in Gaza, while Hamas has lost standing since Mr. Arafat has taken charge. Hamas also is currently in disarray, with most of its political leaders in jail and its international sources of financing threatened. **********At today's session of the Palestinian Legislative Council, there was speculation among deputies that Mr. Arafat would channel money to the party to enhance its standing, and thus further isolate Hamas. **********There was no immediate comment on the new party in Israel. **********-------------------- **********More Suicide Bombs Threatened **********BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 21 (AP) -- The Party of God's "human bombs battalion" will carry out more suicide bombings to force Israeli troops from southern Lebanon, the leader of the Iranian-backed group said today. **********The leader, Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, spoke a day after a suicide bomber charged into an Israeli Army convoy in southern Lebanon, killing an Israeli captain along with himself, and wounding seven others.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/07/busin.snippet: Microsoft Corp and its computer-industry allies lobby Federal Communications Commission, seeking to block or modify planned technical standards for advanced digital television broadcasting, the next generation of television; equipment makers and b...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/07/busin.main_headline: Microsoft Pushing To Alter Standard For Digital TV
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/07/busin.print_headline: Microsoft Pushing To Alter Standard For Digital TV
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/07/busin.body_text: **********A last-minute lobbying push by the Microsoft Corporation, seeking to block or modify the planned technical standards for the next generation of television, has goaded members of the Federal Communications Commission into a search for a way to accommodate the software giant and its computer-industry allies. **********While the compromise most likely to emerge from Microsoft's efforts could be no more than a promise to re-evaluate the standards after a fixed number of years, the lobbying effort -- by a $6 billion company with a reputation for take-no-prisoners competitiveness -- has been watched with a mixture of fascination and anger by the parties on the other side of the dispute. **********The issue of technical standards is one close to the hearts of the powerful broadcast and consumer electronics industries, who have put television sets in living rooms across the nation and beamed programming for half a century. Equipment makers and broadcasters worked for eight years to develop a new standard for advanced digital television broadcasting. **********As recently as early summer, it appeared assured that the F.C.C. would adopt both the resulting ''Grand Alliance'' technical standard and the allocation of spectrum to broadcasters, the two prerequisites to move the country toward digital broadcasting. **********Enter Microsoft. Arguing that the standard under consideration could hinder the computer industry's future use of broadcast spectrum, Microsoft set about making its objections clear to the Clinton Administration, Congress and the F.C.C. The television industry quickly retorted that the standard would advance the computer industry's entry into broadcasting by digitizing transmissions and allowing data to be sent while video is played. **********Microsoft organized around a July 11 counterproposal by the Computer Industry Coalition on Advanced Television Service, a group backed by Apple Computer Inc., the Intel Corporation and the Compaq Computer Corporation, as well as Microsoft. The coalition proposed a video system technology now used by the computer industry, which is not wholly compatible with current broadcasting systems. The proposal also abandoned the superior high-definition picture quality that was the original goal of advanced television. **********At the end of July, Microsoft joined the three high-technology companies and several film industry organizations, including Dreamworks SKG, the Directors Guild of America and the International Photographers Guild, in a new lobbying organization called Americans for Better Digital TV. **********In one of the group's first press releases, William H. Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, said, ''The standard being considered by the F.C.C. would stand in the way of future innovation and force consumers to use inferior technology over time.'' **********Craig Mundie, Microsoft's senior vice president for consumer platforms, said: ''A few months ago people said this train was coming down the track and couldn't be stopped. Now you could say it has slowed down and is approaching a switch. No one will predict when it will arrive at its originally planned station.'' **********As evidence, he points to a Sept. 27 speech by an F.C.C. commissioner, Susan Ness, one of the four people who will vote on the standard. In the speech, she reiterated her calls for setting a standard and then said, ''I have asked all the parties to sit down together to see if a joint recommendation can be made to the commission that will benefit all.'' **********Ms. Ness, through a spokesman, said that her words were not intended as a nod to Microsoft's position, but simply a plea for any discussions that could lead to speedy resolution of differences. **********In an interview on Friday, Ms. Ness's fellow commissioner, Rachelle B. Chong, offered another compromise: adoption of the ''Grand Alliance'' standard as it was proposed by the F.C.C. in May and then setting a time ''in the future to relook at the standard -- a technological reality checkpoint.'' **********Even Richard E. Wiley, who is in effect the godfather of the currently proposed standard because it evolved under his eight-year stewardship of the F.C.C.'s advisory committee on advanced television, has urged compromise, pointing out that television is an international business and that time-consuming squabbles among industries in this country give an advantage to overseas competitors. **********''This religious war should not continue to delay the establishment of a new standard,'' Mr. Wiley said in a speech recently. ''As we debate the issue in the United States, TV systems developed in Europe and elsewhere are being promoted in China, Latin America and other developing world markets.'' **********Television standards being promoted abroad are incompatible with the needs of the computer industry. Widespread adoption of these standards would foreclose opportunities for the United States computer industry overseas. **********The last delays on the standard had seemed to be over earlier this year, but two letters from officials in the Clinton Administration, in effect urging the F.C.C. to adopt the ''Grand Alliance'' standard, led to objections by Microsoft and its allies in the computer industry. **********Technically the issue is whether the 18 video formats specified in the standard should be retained. These include 14 formats in ''progressive'' scanning used in computers, in which lines are painted continuously down the screen, and 4 formats in ''interlaced'' scanning used in television today. Broadcasters insist that all these formats can be included in new digital receivers at minimal added cost. The computer industry wants fewer specifications for video, to leave room for other potential uses. **********Dozens of companies and laboratories spent an estimated $500 million testing systems for eight years to produce the ''Grand Alliance'' standard. Some of those who contributed to this effort were computer companies -- I.B.M. in particular. **********Ms. Ness and Ms. Chong, along with their colleague James H. Quello, have long publicly favored the ''Grand Alliance'' standard reflected in the Federal Register's notice of proposed rules. The commission chairman, Reed E. Hundt, who alone has the power to bring the issue up for a vote, has appeared ambivalent. **********In an interview last week, Mr. Hundt said if a standard were ''nonproprietary, dynamic and not static, and inclusive not exclusive, then I'd consider sprinkling regulatory holy water on it.'' **********''I wouldn't stand in the way of a vote,'' he continued, adding that his goal was ''to get it done by the end of the year, yes.'' **********The final lobbying push by Microsoft and its allies is infuriating some of the broadcasters. **********''Their counterproposal doesn't meet the needs of broadcasters; it doesn't provide full high-definition television capability on day one, nor is it based on a proven, tested system,'' said Robert Graves, chairman of the Advanced Television Systems Committee, an industry-wide group of the broadcast and consumer-electronics industries that had reviewed the standard and filed a brief supporting it with the F.C.C. **********''The television industry needs both to move ahead, and their proposal provides neither,'' Mr. Graves added. **********The continuing argument, long after the issue was to have been settled, has frustrated some Administration officials. ''People have been talking around each other and not to each other,'' said Larry Irving of the Commerce Department's National Telecommunications and Information Administration. **********''I've sat through six hours with representatives of all industries and dozens of hours with other players,'' he said, ''and we're still trying to get them to work together. The Administration has said repeatedly that we need an industry compromise.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/15/busin.main_headline: SUMITOMO'S HUGE LOSS;In 1991, Agencies Were Told Of Letter on Sumitomo Trader
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/15/busin.print_headline: SUMITOMO'S HUGE LOSS;In 1991, Agencies Were Told Of Letter on Sumitomo Trader
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/15/busin.body_text: **********On Dec. 6, 1991, The Wall Street Journal reported in its commodities roundup  that regulatory officials had been informed of allegations regarding the trading practices of Yasuo Hamanaka, the Sumitomo Corporation's chief copper trader. Following is an excerpt from that report: **********COPPER: Futures prices fell sharply on reports that a U.S. copper trader had  sent a letter to the London Metal Exchange and to the Commodity Exchange in New  York raising questions about Sumitomo Corp.'s powerful chief copper trader, Yasuo Hamanaka. David L. Threlkeld, a U.S. metals trader based in Vermont, confirmed in an interview yesterday that he had sent the letter. **********In the letter, a copy of which was obtained by The Wall Street Journal, Mr.  Threlkeld wrote that Mr. Hamanaka had asked him to provide a letter confirming certain trades. Mr. Threlkeld said in the letter that Mr. Hamanaka "informed me  that we would find no record of the trades." Mr. Threlkeld said he declined to "confirm details of nonexistent trades." **********Sumitomo offices in New York and London declined to comment, as did the London Metal Exchange. The Securities & Investment Board, a U.K. regulatory authority, said it had received the letter from the London exchange and was "aware" of the allegations. The Commodity Exchange acknowledged it had received  correspondence from Mr. Threlkeld but wouldn't say whether it was looking into the matter. **********In Tokyo, Mr. Hamanaka expressed his surprise at Mr. Threlkeld's action, saying, "We are puzzled at the letter since we can't understand" why Mr. Threlkeld wrote it. But he declined to comment for now, saying, "we don't know yet what's going on." **********Copper for December delivery ended 2.05 cents a pound lower at 98.5 cents; the actively traded March contract fell 1.15 cents to 98.45 cents. The possibility of increased regulatory and public scrutiny of Mr. Hamanaka led traders to believe his trading activity -- which many believed had held up copper prices recently -- would be curtailed for a while.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/02/busin.snippet: Makers of equipment for new wireless voice and data networks known as personal communications services (PCS) are finding out what it is like to sell on credit; in few, if any, other industries must small companies make such large capital investmen...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/02/busin.main_headline: Layaway Plan Helps Finance a New Generation of P.C.S. Wireless Services
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/02/busin.print_headline: Layaway Plan Helps Finance a New Generation of P.C.S. Wireless Services
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/02/busin.body_text: **********When Sprint Spectrum wanted huge amounts of sophisticated electronic equipment to build a new national wireless telephone network, it went to the telecommunications equipment titans Lucent Technologies and Northern Telecom Ltd. Little surprise there. **********But when the venture needed billions of dollars to pay for the equipment, it did not get the money from the bond market, or commercial banks or even its owners -- Sprint and the large cable television operators Tele-Communications Inc., Comcast and Cox Enterprises. Instead, the company turned to Lucent and Northern Telecom, which this spring committed up to $3.1 billion in financing to help Sprint Spectrum buy their products. **********Think of it as a layaway plan for a corporate giant. Vendor financing is well known to consumers, who get car loans from auto companies and ''no payments till June'' offers from discount furniture stores. Airplane makers have helped finance corporate customers for years. Now makers of equipment for the new wireless voice and data networks known as personal communications services, or P.C.S., are finding out what it is like to sell on credit. In few, if any, other industries must small companies make such large capital investments to get off the ground. **********Having spent billions for airwave space, many small P.C.S. operators are spurned by traditional lenders and have nowhere to turn for equipment financing but their suppliers. (Equipment, in this case, is rarely the handsets consumers buy but the software and base stations that are the backbone of wireless networks.) **********Taking advantage of rivalries among competing vendors, larger P.C.S. operators like Sprint Spectrum are demanding generous financing. **********And the equipment manufacturers are discovering that in the battle for market share, balance sheets can be as potent a weapon as technology -- but one that must be wielded carefully. In underwriting their customers, P.C.S. equipment makers put their own credit ratings on the line. **********It is not a risk all are willing to take. Motorola, another large wireless manufacturer, has hung back. But Lucent, Northern Telecom and Ericsson have financed aggressively, as have fledging P.C.S. equipment providers like Nokia and Hughes Electronics, a unit of General Motors. While lending to a potential nationwide operator like Sprint Spectrum appears a sure bet to many, equipment makers often wager on small start-up companies whose success is far from assured. **********Lucent now carries at least $2.3 billion in vendor financing obligations for P.C.S. equipment on its books as contingent liabilities, more than half the value of the new wireless sales contracts announced this year. Northern Telecom's potential exposure is almost $2 billion. Ericsson reported about $400 million in potential equipment financing losses last year; that figure has at least doubled. The plans of every equipment maker call for spinning off North American P.C.S. financing obligations to traditional lenders. So far there are no takers. **********Vendor financing is ''clearly something that people can get carried away with,'' said Gregory S. Geiling, a telecommunications equipment analyst at J. P. Morgan. ''Investors need to know when they're buying that stock that they're buying some P.C.S. risk. But at least so far the reward has outweighed the risk.'' **********Only two major builders of P.C.S. networks have been able to manage without vendor financing: AT&T Wireless and Primeco Personal Communications, a cash-laden consortium of Nynex, Bell Atlantic, U S West and Airtouch Communications. **********Most experts estimate the cost of building a P.C.S. network at around $25 for each resident of the coverage area. Building a traditional cellular telephone system for a city of two million people costs about $8 million, while a P.C.S. network there could cost as much as $60 million, according to John W. Stanton, chief executive of the midsized wireless operator Western Wireless, which has a $200 million financing agreement with Northern Telecom. **********Charles A. DiSanza, an analyst at Gerard Klauer Mattison & Company, said P.C.S. providers ''need to build a very expensive infrastructure for many, many customers before they get even a single customer.'' **********Pocket Communications, a privately held company based in Washington, has financing agreements with Northern Telecom and Ericsson to provide equipment for P.C.S. networks in Las Vegas, Nev., and Honolulu, respectively. ''We're a start-up company; we don't have any revenue,'' said Bill Getch, a Pocket spokesman. ''It's a reality in the market that you need these kinds of agreements.'' **********The equipment makers recognize that, but are not happy about it. ''Of course we'd prefer not to have to finance these customers,'' said Lucent's treasurer, Meg Walsh. **********But they do, because even Sprint Spectrum, with its deep pockets, required it. ''We could have bought the equipment straight out,'' said Robert E. Sleet, treasurer of Sprint Spectrum. ''We were looking for an opportunity for the vendor to be tied closely to us, in terms of them having a stake in the game.'' Robert J. O'Brien, a Northern Telecom spokesman, added, ''It would be irresponsible for us not to pursue an opportunity like Sprint Spectrum with vigor.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/22/busin.snippet: Market Place column on Montedison, Italian chemicals and energy producer, in light of SEC's filing of civil suit against Montedison over company's payment of bribes to Italian officials several years ago (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/22/busin.main_headline: If you must pay a bribe, don't let it distort the accounting
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/22/busin.print_headline: If you must pay a bribe, don't let it distort the accounting
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/22/busin.body_text: **********THE Securities and Exchange Commission wants to send a message to companies, particularly foreign ones: If you pay bribes, either disclose the practice or make sure that they do not distort your financial statements. **********Yesterday, the S.E.C. filed a civil suit against Montedison, the Italian chemicals and energy producer, over the company's payment of bribes to Italian officials several years ago. **********The facts in the Montedison case are not in dispute. The company has admitted paying bribes, and concealing them in its financial statements. In some cases, it paid bribes and described them as loans made, creating an asset on its balance sheet. In another case, Montedison overstated real estate values to conceal other bribes. **********All told, the S.E.C. said, those maneuvers overstated the company's earnings, assets and net worth by at least $400 million until it wrote off the fictitious assets in 1993. The company's reports had been inaccurate from 1988 through 1992, the commission said. **********Given that the disclosure has already been made, why file the suit? The S.E.C. seems to be trying to send a message, particularly to foreign companies that choose to trade in the United States. ''If they are going to sell their securities in this market,'' said Paul Gerlach, the S.E.C.'s associate director of enforcement, ''then they are going to be held to the same disclosure requirements, and the same books and records obligations as other issuers.'' **********Montedison, in a statement, emphasized that the facts in the case had been disclosed, and that it had new management. It said its only arguments with the commission were whether it was appropriate for a Federal judge to issue an injunction barring future violations of securities laws, and over how large a monetary penalty was appropriate. The S.E.C. did not disclose how large a payment it was seeking. **********The commission's action does not mean that any company paying bribes now has to disclose that, or face securities law penalties in addition to whatever criminal penalties might apply. **********Indeed, , there are judicial decisions that point to the Fifth Amendment protection from self-incrimination against forcing companies to disclose criminal conduct, notwithstanding the risk that committing a crime involves a potential liability if it is detected and prosecuted. **********But the S.E.C. takes the position that this does not mean that inaccurate financial statements may be filed. **********Had the bribes that were paid been so small that they were immaterial to the company's financial statements, then there would presumably have been no case. But while the standard for immateriality varies with size -- a $1 million payment might be highly material for a small company but immaterial for a company the size of Exxon or General Electric -- there are no companies for whom $400 million is immaterial. **********And had Montedison hidden the bribes by classifying them as another type of expense -- say, as consultant's fees or salaries -- then the commission would have had a more difficult time making a case. While the specifics would have been inaccurate, the overall picture painted by the financial statements would not have been meaningfully misleading. **********In this case, however, Montedison hid the payments not as other expenses, but as payments for assets. When an asset is bought, the books record that as substituting one asset (cash) for another one (here, a loan that was owed to the company, or real estate). And that has no effect on the income statement. **********As a result, Montedison's net worth was overstated, and so was its profit. And the company, which has suffered greatly in recent years in part because of the bribery disclosures, will suffer one more loss when the financial penalty is determined. **********In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, Montedison's American depository receipts, which sold for $25 in 1989 while the books were being falsified, fell 25 cents, to $6.875. Each A.D.R. represents 10 ordinary shares.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/24/busin.body_text: **********The Bankers Trust New York Corporation gave its former chief executive, Charles Sanford, a $2 million payment after he retired in April. In exchange, Mr. Sanford agreed not to criticize his former employer. **********Mr. Sanford left amid problems in Bankers Trust's derivatives trading, as clients like Gibson Greetings and Procter & Gamble said it had misled them about their investments. **********Bankers Trust, the seventh-biggest American banking company, disclosed the payment in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. It also discussed details of the severance package it gave Timothy Yates, who resigned as chief financial officer when Mr. Sanford left. He received $330,303. **********Both former executives agreed not to ''publicly or privately disparage'' Bankers Trust, and the company made a similar promise about Mr. Yates and Mr. Sanford. All agreed that the two men would not testify in court or cooperate with Government investigations of the company. Mr. Sanford is required to return the $2 million if he violates the agreement within a year. **********Mr. Yates also agreed not to raid Bankers Trust's ranks for employees on behalf of any competitor in the year ending April 1997.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/19/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;A Rainbow Coalition of sorts can be found in a wider range of campaigns than ever before.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/19/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;A Rainbow Coalition of sorts can be found in a wider range of campaigns than ever before.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/19/busin.body_text: **********MARKETERS who have long painted portraits of consumers in shades of white are adding colors to their palettes as campaigns increasingly present multiracial, multi-ethnic images -- and even interracial couples. **********In some instances, such mosaic or rainbow advertising supplements a larger campaign dominated by traditional representations of America as the land of the  free and the home of the Bradys. But often, ads that blend actors, models and actual customers of disparate racial and ethnic backgrounds are the sole pitches an advertiser is making. **********Occasionally, mosaic advertising can be a publicity gimmick. And the campaigns can be counterproductive if they alienate consumers whose attitudes are less Brown v. Board of Education and more Plessy v. Ferguson. **********Yet considering that as recently as 1967, 18 states prohibited intermarriage  -- and that a year later a sponsor withdrew from an NBC television special because Petula Clark touched Harry Belafonte -- the changes are profound. **********"We're featuring a variety of people because of the diversified and changing  family structure today," said Linda Sawyer, executive vice president and account management director at Deutsch Inc. in New York. "It's part of a more realistic  depiction of where America is." **********In a television commercial by Deutsch for the American unit of Inter Ikea Systems B.V., the home furnishings retailer, actors portray an interracial couple discussing efforts to conceive a child. Bob Garfield, critic for the trade publication Advertising Age, praised it as an "advertising breakthrough." **********As indicated by Ikea, a Swedish company, this trend is in large part attributable to the penchant of multinational corporations to leap borders with  messages of inclusion. **********"We sell products in 76 countries, so our advertising is international," said Diana Loguzzo, media director in New York for the Diesel USA unit of the Italian fashion marketer Diesel, which is running print ads about a Don Juan who marries brides of all races. "We might have an Italian advertising director and a Swedish photographer -- and they usually shoot in Miami Beach." **********Posters for Club Monaco, a chain of 115 apparel stores in Canada, Japan, South Korea and the United States, show an interracial couple in an affectionate pose. "We try to have a modern, stylish approach, reflecting modern, stylish people," said Christine Ralphs, vice president for marketing and store design at the Club Monaco unit of Dylex Ltd. in Toronto. **********The trend is also motivated by the substantial demographic shifts remaking America. The Census Bureau last month released projections that by 2050, 53 percent of the population will be non-Hispanic whites compared with 74 percent now. **********"We wanted to use real people you can identify with," said David Roth, associate publisher of the Fodor's Travel Publications produced by the Random House unit of Advance Publications in New York. A print and outdoor campaign by  Spot Design in New York to introduce "Fodor's Gay Guide to the USA" in May will  include a gay interracial couple, David Reese and Ron Anderson, who run a jewelry design company. **********The appearance of interracial couples, straight or gay, can raise eyebrows, as Mr. Garfield noted in Advertising Age, among "racists of both major complexions." Ms. Sawyer disputed a suggestion the Ikea spot was "waving a flag  to get attention." Rather, she said, it was "about a varied portrayal of America." **********Michael Toth, chairman and creative director at Toth Design and Advertising in Concord, Mass., and New York, which creates multiracial campaigns for the apparel lines marketed by the Tommy Hilfiger Corporation, agreed with Ms. Sawyer that such ads were "not a ploy." **********"The idea is showing people getting along and enjoying themselves," he said.  "We don't want to force anything because the moment the campaign starts to look  contrived is the moment Tommy starts to lose what he has." **********As the examples above indicate, many rainbow ads are for products aimed at so-called niche markets or for "badge brands" sold through perceptions they are  hip or trendy. For instance, a print campaign by Jordan Hamilton in New York for Naya water, marketed by Nora Beverages Inc., includes everyone from white heterosexuals to drag queens. **********"You create an identity for water," said Gunnar Jordan, creative director at  Jordan Hamilton, "and Naya is identifying with the ultimate aspiration of a desire for equality." **********Yet mainstream advertisers are taking part, too. A print ad by the Euro RSCG Tatham unit of Havas Advertising in Chicago for Head & Shoulder shampoo -- marketed by the staid Procter & Gamble Company -- features a mosaic of men and women who are thisclose together. **********"The ad shows a group of friends from different racial backgrounds, which is  particularly fitting because more people use Head & Shoulders than any other dandruff shampoo in the world," said Don Tassone, a spokesman for P.& G. in Cincinnati. **********"We have been running the ad about six months," he added, "and it's working.  Sales of Head & Shoulders are up." **********So perhaps someday soon, Ms. Clark and Mr. Belafonte will rejoin for a duet of "The best part of waking up is Folgers in your cup."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/01/world.main_headline: Clinton Leads Two Memorials For Victims of Saudi Bombing
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/01/world.print_headline: Clinton Leads Two Memorials For Victims of Saudi Bombing
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/01/world.body_text: **********President Clinton led two memorial services today for the 19 airmen killed on Tuesday in a bombing in Saudi Arabia, telling their families, "America stands with you in your sorrow and in your outrage," and vowing that "we will not rest" until their killers are caught. **********"There is a passage in Isaiah in which God wonders, 'Whom shall I send, and who will go for us?' " the President told 4,500 friends and colleagues of the fallen airmen this morning at Eglin Air Force Base, in the Florida panhandle. **********Isaiah answers: 'Here am I, Lord. Send me,' " Mr. Clinton continued. "These men we honor today said to America, 'Send me.' " **********Mr. Clinton cut short a visit to France at the end of the annual summit meeting of the seven largest industrial democracies to attend the services today. As he did throughout the summit meeting, which ended in Lyons, France, on Saturday, Mr. Clinton vowed today that those who killed the airmen would be hunted down. **********"They were taken before their time," the President repeated in identical language at the separate services, "felled by the hands of hatred in an act whose savagery is matched only by its cowardice. We will not rest in our effort  to capture, prosecute and punish those who committed this evil deed." **********Today's eulogies were the latest of several services in which Mr. Clinton has taken on a role of the nation's chief mourner: for Commerce Secretary Ronald H.  Brown, who was killed in a plane crash in Croatia; for Adm. Jeremy M. Boorda, the Chief of Naval Operations, who committed suicide, and at the one-year anniversary of Oklahoma City bombing. **********While none of these have been political events, Mr. Clinton's advisers often  comment that they make use of Mr. Clinton's best oratorical skills -- mixing the role of empathetic national pastor and that of national leader in a time of a new type of threat. **********Mr. Clinton met today, at both Eglin and Patrick Air Force Bases, with the families of each of the men who died, and later said he found them "incredibly strong." At one point one relative said the President "needed to think about this when you see your daughter, Chelsea." **********"One day your children are there and the next they are gone," an Administration official who saw the encounter recalled hearing. "And it's very difficult to know why." **********Several times the President hugged the children whose fathers had died. **********The grandparents of one of the dead, Master Sgt. Michael G. Heiser, a 35-year-old communications specialist, gave Mr. Clinton a picture of their grandson with the President last year at Ramstein Air Base in Germany. Sergeant  Heiser had given the President a small medal with the insignia of his unit -- Mr. Clinton keeps a display of such medals behind his desk in the Oval Office -- and the photograph of their meeting had been on the mantelpiece in the grandparents' home. **********The first service today took place on the sprawling Eglin Air Force Base, where 12 of the 19 men had been based. In the front row of a huge air hangar were 11 men who survived the bombing. They came to the service on foot, in wheelchairs, and in a few cases on hospital beds that were wheeled into the huge space. **********"Our Nomads have ceased their wandering," Mr. Clinton said, a reference to the nickname of the 33rd Fighter Wing at Eglin, which is responsible for keeping planes serviced and flying. "They have come home. May God embrace their souls. And may God bless America's mission of peace and freedom, for which they gave the last full measure of their devotion." **********Mr. Clinton steered clear today of any comment about security at the base in  Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, or about reports that the Saudi Government had not cooperated when the United States asked for a wider perimeter around the base. **********But a survivor of the explosion, Master Sgt. William Sine, 39, said he thought security was "extra tight" compared with his previous visits to the base. He added that he "had heard some talk" about expanding the security perimeter before the explosion. **********Sergeant Sine, a large man who wore a red beret to today's service here, said he had escaped with minor injuries because he had just left his suite in the building and was a few steps from the elevator. **********Air Force officials said Saturday that in a case of mistaken identity in the  chaos after the bombing, they had initially told the family of one airman who had been killed that he was alive, but seriously injured, in a hospital in Dhahran. **********The mistake involved Airman 1st Class Christopher B. Lester of Pineville, W.  Va.. Air Force officials said members of Mr. Lester's unit had incorrectly believed that an injured airman, Paul A. Blais, was Mr. Lester. Mr. Blais's whereabouts had been listed as "unknown" since the explosion. The confusion was  not sorted out until Friday evening, more than three days after the blast. **********"The Air Force sincerely regrets all hardship and pain caused to both families," the Pentagon said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/11/world.main_headline: For Abused Saint, the Last Straw: Santa Weighs In
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/11/world.print_headline: For Abused Saint, the Last Straw: Santa Weighs In
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/11/world.body_text: **********A cluster of small children was serenading St. Nicholas, the European ancestor of Santa Claus, when a group of teen-agers rushed up to him, knocked off his bishop's miter and ripped off his beard. The incident forced the holy man to flee by car, when everyone knows he travels by horse. **********''It was really a sad moment,'' said St. Nicholas, who when not dressed for the part is a schoolteacher named Johan. He had recovered his nerve, donned the robes and miter, and was back out on the street, touring a neighborhood in Amsterdam. ''Joking is fine, but such attacks in front of children, that's going too far.'' **********Sinterklaas, as he is known here, has been a fixture of Dutch culture since the Middle Ages, and in Amsterdam he is the patron saint. His feast day, Dec. 6, is a national event, and the the celebrations, songs and parades in his honor start as early as mid-November, when the saint arrives by boat from Spain, along with his white horse and black pageboy. **********He appears in every town, stopping in schools, hospitals and even homes and, like Santa, he delivers presents. But being a bishop, he is a bit more solemn than Santa, and often carries a big book with notes about the naughty habits of some children. **********The attack on St. Nicholas in Amsterdam is unusual, but lately, other irreverent residents have lampooned him and mocked him in cartoons. Some have even yelled in his presence that he is a fake. In fact, the holy man has been the object of such fierce deconstruction that some of his followers wonder if he will make it into the next millennium. **********Animal lovers have criticized Sinterklaas because his character sometimes wears a mantle with white furry trim. One critic wrote in a published letter that ''removing the fur would make a better, more animal-friendly impression.'' **********Some feminists have said they regret that the yearly ritual involving the bishop and his pageboys remains an all-male event. Just before the feast day this year, an historian, a man, wrote in a local newspaper that by now the saint should be aware of the spirit of our time and include a woman in his entourage. **********And an intense debate has sprung up about the racism of Sinterklaas because his chief assistant, known as Zwarte Piet, or Black Pete, is supposed to be Moorish and traditionally stains his face black. **********An anti-discrimination group has tried launching alternative Pete characters whose faces are painted blue or green, but the change has not caught on. **********According to the Amsterdam Sinterklaas foundation, a kind of rent-a-saint center, it is the white Dutch who are self-conscious about the color issue. An employee at the center said that immigrants from Suriname, a former Dutch colony where many of the people are descended from African slaves, often try to get a Black Pete job and ask to have their faces painted even blacker. **********''Here's a white bishop with a black servant and this looks like something from the time of slavery,'' said Peter-Paul Spanjaard, a student. But he said that after talking things over with his friends, they agreed the issue was not that clear-cut, because Black Pete was not subservient and in fact was the more sympathetic character. **********''Zwarte Piet gave you sweets,'' said Mr. Spanjaard, now 18 and wiser. ''He comforted you when you cried. He could climb on the roof like an acrobat. Black Pete was my hero. Sinterklaas is frightening. He has the big book, he knows everything.'' **********The travails of St. Nicholas reflect other changes in the once-homogeneous Dutch social landscape. **********Sinterklaas, alias Johan, said the teen-agers who had ripped off his beard the other day were the sons of Moroccan immigrants. He said the boys were wedged between two cultures. Their school, like every Dutch school, celebrates the St. Nicholas feast day with songs, presents and a visit from the holy man. But at home, their Muslim parents dismiss the festivities as nonsense. **********The more humiliating change for the ancient bishop, though, may be the growing competition from a young upstart, the American figure of Santa Claus. In the past few years, Santa has been gaining ground here, a development that suggests the closing of a curious historical circle as he crosses back over the Atlantic. **********The historical St. Nicholas lived in the fourth century, and was a beloved bishop of Myra, in today's Turkey. After astonishing miracles were attributed to him around the Mediterranean his bones were taken to Italy. Later his fame crossed the Alps and spread over Northern Europe. Dutch settlers took their Sinterklaas tradition to America, where he merged with the English Father Christmas and became Santa Claus. **********Images of the jolly American figure have now been making their way into the shops, along with ''Jingle Bells'' and other seasonal tunes popular in the United States, helping to turn Christmas into more of an occasion for gift-giving and inevitably stealing some of the allure of St. Nicholas Day three weeks earlier. **********Many adult Dutch, who remember Christmas as a strictly religious event, are scandalized. Just a generation ago, the Dutch regarded the more commercial Christmas spirit of the English-speaking world as a profanity. **********This shift has become a topic for sociologists, who theorize that the invasion of Santa Claus is part of the globalization of cultural images, or that the Dutch have become less religious, or that Sinterklaas is essentially for children and people have fewer or no children, or that they are perhaps lazier, because Sinterklaas gifts must be accompanied by satirical or clever rhyming verses. **********One recent market study said the Christmas hype of the past few years was set off by the large garden centers outside the big cities because they have nothing to sell in winter. It said that these stores started imitating their American cousins, stocking Christmas trees, avalanches of decorations and Santa figures, and that other stores followed. **********Some people are upset about the competing versions of the same character. The city of Assen has even decided to keep St. Nicholas and Santa Claus apart. City fathers have told shopkeepers to wait with Santa Claus motifs until after the departure of St. Nicholas, Dec. 6, even posting signs at the city limits: the image of a fat Santa, crossed out with a large red X.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/27/world.body_text: **********President Clinton asked Congress today to grant $40 million in tax relief to  20,000 American troops serving with the NATO-led peacekeeping force in the Balkans. **********Mr. Clinton said in a statement that such tax breaks were normally set aside  for American troops serving in a "combat zone." **********The proposed legislation, similar to bills already pending in Congress, would exempt the pay of American enlisted personnel and warrant officers serving in Bosnia, Croatia and Macedonia from federal income taxes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/04/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;$3 Billion Later, Japan Financier Is Bankrupt
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/04/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;$3 Billion Later, Japan Financier Is Bankrupt
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/04/busin.body_text: **********Shinkyoto Shinpan, a Japanese finance company, filed for bankruptcy today, under the weight of $3.24 billion in debts. **********The bankruptcy is Japan's seventh largest since the end of World War II, according to Teikoku Data Bank, a research company specializing in bankruptcy analysis. **********The bankruptcy heightened concern about the stability of the Japanese banking industry, which has slowly been trying to dispose of mountains of bad debt. Shares of Japanese financial institutions tumbled here today. **********Institutions like Skinkyoto Shinpan lend money borrowed from banks and other  financial companies, and take no deposits. Shinkyoto Shinpan's primary business  was housing loans. It borrowed 120.2 billion yen, or $1.1 billion, from 35 financial institutions, including Sanwa Bank, the Industrial Bank of Japan, Nippon Credit Bank, Hokkaido Takushoku Bank, Daiwa Bank, Fuji Bank, Mitsubishi Bank, Sumitomo Bank, Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank and Tokai Bank. **********The bankruptcy comes as Japanese banks, already ailing under their own bad loans, are moving to withdraw support from financially troubled affiliated borrowers. **********The nation's governing coalition expects to secure the passage of legislation by next week providing a legal framework to close indebted financial institutions. **********That could set the stage for a new wave of bankruptcies, said Brian Waterhouse, a senior banking analyst at James Capel Pacific Ltd. **********In February, two Tokyo-based independent lenders went out of business. The Aichi Corporation failed with 182 billion yen in bad loans, and the Equion Company collapsed with 311 billion yen in liabilities. **********According to the Finance Ministry, Japan has about 20,000 nonbanking financial lenders with 80 trillion yen in outstanding loans. Experts say as much as half of their loans have turned sour. **********In addition, major banks have extended loans to their own nonbanking affiliates. The banks set up such lenders during the economic boom of the late 1980's to expand real estate financing beyond a limit imposed by the Government. The end of the property boom in 1990 left trillions of yen in bad loans at the nonbanking lenders. Japan's top 21 banks have lent a combined 31.4 trillion yen  to affiliates, of which 7.1 trillion yen is troubled, the Finance Ministry says.
