https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/01/busin.main_headline: Wood Pulp Prices Off 40% Since Autumn
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/01/busin.print_headline: Wood Pulp Prices Off 40% Since Autumn
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/01/busin.body_text: **********The prices of North American wood pulp have fallen 40 percent since last fall, one of the sharpest price reversals in the history of the industry, and consumers of many paper products, from tissues and paper towels to stationery and envelopes, are expected to find lower prices. **********Surging inventories and slower growth in paper consumption worldwide are behind the price cuts, which have dropped the price of northern bleached softwood kraft pulp, a bellwether grade, from $985 a metric ton in November to $575 in mid-March, the lowest level since 1991. The decline, however, followed big increases over the last several years. **********I would think there would be even more slippage as producers compete on price," said Harold Cody, director of a forecasting service for Pulp and Paper magazine, a trade journal. Pulp is made from wood chips and other residue at lumber mills. **********Mr. Cody estimated that prices of some grades of printing papers at the wholesale level were down 20 to 30 percent. Linerboard, which is used for boxes  and cartons, has been under similar pressure. **********The Procter & Gamble Company said last week that it was cutting list prices for its facial tissues, bath tissues and paper towels by 4.8 to 8.6 percent, citing the lower pulp prices. **********Competitors are expected to make comparable cuts. **********Though many newsprint producers have their own integrated pulp mills and do not buy pulp on the open market, the weakness in pulp prices has been a factor in their recent decisions to cancel price increases for newsprint. **********Canada is the world's largest supplier of pulp. In the first two months of this year, shipments fell 18 percent, according to the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association. **********As producers increased prices in 1995, pulp on hand at mills in Canada, the United States and the Nordic countries, the principal supply points, shot up to  2 million tons from 1.1 million, the fastest rise in inventory levels since the  mid-1970's. **********Struggling to get inventories down to more manageable levels, North American  mills have announced extensive shutdowns. MacMillan Bloedel Ltd., a giant producer in British Columbia, is closing its lumber and sawmill operations until May 4, affecting 1,250 workers. **********Crestbrook Forest Industries, Slocan Forest Products and Repap Enterprises are among other Canadian companies that have announced temporary shutdowns. Georgia-Pacific idled 14 lumber mills from Maine to Arkansas in the last two weeks of December. **********After price weakness and the severe winter, which has also affected bottom lines, analysts expect that first-quarter earnings of many paper companies will  take a dive. **********"In the first quarter we'll see virtually every company with far lower earnings and further deterioration in the second quarter based on the sharp drop that's already occurred in pricing," said Mark Rogers, paper industry analyst for Prudential Securities in New York. **********Yet some analysts expect a turnaround later this year. Patricia Mohr, a vice  president of economics at the Toronto headquarters of the Bank of Nova Scotia, pointed to the "relatively favorable" underlying demand for most paper products. "This is a big inventory correction but it will come to an end over the next few months," she predicted. **********And Sam Magid, an analyst with Salman Partners of Vancouver, British Columbia, said that as mills go through temporary shutdowns to reduce pulp, they also reduce supplies of lumber, a commodity that has recently had rising prices. Since the fourth quarter, the producer price of a bellwether grade of two-by-fours has risen to $295 for 1,000 board feet from $244. "The death of the pulp market," Mr. Magid said, "brings with it breaths of life to the lumber market."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/03/busin.body_text: **********Calgene Inc.'s genetically engineered Flavr Savr tomato does not infringe patents held by Enzo Biochem Inc., a Federal judge ruled today. **********The ruling by Federal District Judge Joseph J. Farnan also held that the patents that Enzo had contended were being infringed were invalid. **********Calgene, a biotechnology company based in Davis, Calif., is seeking a patent on its process for growing tomatoes with a longer-than-normal shelf life. **********Enzo Biochem of Farmingdale, L.I., sued Calgene, saying that the Flavr Savr infringed three of its bioengineering patents. Calgene filed a counterclaim, contending the patents were invalid. **********Calgene's stock was up 50 cents today, to $6.875, in Nasdaq trading.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/10/world.main_headline: Yeltsin's Uncertain Health Leaves a Question in the Minds of RussianVoters
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/10/world.print_headline: Yeltsin's Uncertain Health Leaves a Question in the Minds of RussianVoters
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/10/world.body_text: **********In his frenetic pursuit of re-election, Boris N. Yeltsin plans 16 campaign trips this month. In April the 65-year-old Russian President's punishing schedule sent him from Moscow to Norway and then across the Asian continent to China. In between, he presided over a hectic summit meeting held for the leaders of the world's richest nations. **********"I do not have any time to remember my illnesses," Mr. Yeltsin wrote this week in response to a series of personal questions submitted by voters. "I work  from 5 in the morning until late each night." **********But with little more than a month before the Russian people must almost certainly choose between Mr. Yeltsin and a return to Communist rule, the President's often precarious health -- and the drastic choices that would remain should he die or become seriously ill for the third time in a year -- has become for many voters a central issue. **********Whatever else a vote for Mr. Yeltsin means, it will be a vote for a man with  a long history of health problems, including two heart "ailments" last year that kept him hospitalized and often totally inaccessible for weeks. It will mean a vote for a man who has already lived seven years beyond the current average life expectancy for a Russian man. And it will mean a vote for a man whose past problems with alcohol have been so obvious to the average Russian that Mr. Yeltsin felt the need this week to comment on them. **********"To say that I abuse alcohol would be untrue," he wrote in a response to a question from a voter. "To say that I do not drink would not be convincing. People would doubt it and say: 'What kind of Russian man are you if you cannot drink?' " **********Doctors here and in the United States insist that there is no real way to assess with certainty the severity of Mr. Yeltsin's heart problems or predict what they will mean in the future. But most of those interviewed agreed that, based on what is known about Mr. Yeltsin and based on general information about  the health of men his age in Russia, the picture is unlikely to be bright. **********"I cannot speak directly about the President's health," said Dr. Mikhail Alshibai, one of Russia's foremost heart surgeons, who has never treated Mr. Yeltsin. "But in our country men that age with heart problems are dying at rates that it is almost impossible to believe. It is one of our worst social problems." **********Mr. Yeltsin has had many illnesses and his physical condition vacillates wildly. He has a long history of sudden and prolonged absences from public view. He has acknowledged occasional spells of depression. He was, by many accounts, including those of close aides, so drunk on a 1994 stop at Shannon Airport in Ireland that he was unable to leave the plane to meet the Irish Prime Minister,  Albert Reynolds. **********Mr. Yeltsin's principal opponent, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, the 51-year-old Communist leader, wastes no opportunity to speak about Mr. Yeltsin's drinking. **********"A bus driver cannot go to work without a medical examination," Mr. Zyuganov  says in his standard stump speech, referring to the tests for alcohol that are supposed to be administered to all public transportation workers before they take the wheel. "But now, a person can rule the entire country in any condition." **********Polls show that while Mr. Yeltsin's drinking may not bother many people, his  age and his recent health problems do. **********Yet to the degree that the future of Russian reform relies on the victory of  Mr. Yeltsin -- and most political analysts increasingly agree it relies heavily  on such an outcome -- there is a lot riding on the President's continued good health. **********Russia has no vice president. If Mr. Yeltsin were to die or become incapacitated before the June election, his Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, would temporarily take over the Government. But neither he nor any other political ally could run for President in Mr. Yeltsin's place because the  law does not permit it. **********Even for a Russian leader, Mr. Yeltsin has been particularly vague about the  nature of his heart ailment and about the treatment he received during his many  weeks of convalescence last year. **********The Kremlin did not respond to written requests seeking information about Mr. Yeltsin's health and permission to speak with his doctors. Nobody who knows will say whether Mr. Yeltsin had two heart attacks last year or whether his ailments  were less severe. **********And although Mr. Yeltsin is clearly running as energetically as Mr. Zyuganov, who has no such history of serious illness, even his strongest supporters entertain constant worries about his health. **********"I think he looks extremely vigorous," said Igor B. Malashenko, the president of Russia's Independent Television Network, who has become a senior media adviser to the President's campaign. "But nobody really wants to think about what would happen if President Yeltsin were to become unable to do his job. It is a problem in our system that we need to work out." **********Last July 11 Mr. Yeltsin was admitted to the Central Clinical Hospital in Moscow with chest pains that officials attributed to ischemia of the heart. He was admitted again in October. But ischemia is really a symptom of an illness, not the illness itself. Ischemia means that oxygen-rich blood is not getting where it needs to go, in this case to the heart. **********It can be minor -- millions of people suffer from some level of ischemia because of blocked arteries and many do not know it -- or it can be bad enough to cause a major heart attack. It depends how serious the blockages are -- again something easy to discover but something nobody has reported about Mr. Yeltsin. **********Because the Kremlin said there was angina, or pain, associated with the ischemia, most doctors interviewed agree that the chances of the episodes having been minor are not good, particularly the second one, which hospitalized him from late October to mid-December. **********"Heart ischemia can indicate very serious problems, particularly if it is repeated," said Valery Shumakov, director of the Research Center of Surgery in Moscow, who has performed more heart transplants than any other Russian surgeon. **********Like all those interviewed, Dr. Shumakov stressed that he had no personal knowledge of Mr. Yeltsin's case, and therefore could not know what shape his heart is in. **********"Everyone is different," he said. "It depends on the state of the blood vessels. Obviously though, your age, your weight, your level of physical activity and the amount of stress you have in your life all contribute to any diagnosis and any prognosis." **********Mr. Yeltsin appears overweight.  He is far less physically active than he used to be, and few people could have a more stressful life. **********"I will tell you this," said Dr. Norman D. Anderson, who runs what is often regarded as the most successful American executive fitness program, at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. "I never worry about my executives as long as they are in charge. But the greatest stress is when events control their lives and they are not in charge." **********Mr. Yeltsin seems to know what the doctor is talking about. **********"My family reproaches me for taking everything to my heart," he said in his written comments this week, the first time he has commented so fully about his health in more than a year. "This is not noticeable at first, but when concerns  accumulate, the load makes itself felt. Large emotional and physical stresses brought me to the hospital last year but the doctors put me right." **********Mr. Yeltsin also noted that all his grandfathers and great-grandfathers lived until they were 90 or older. Genetics, experts agree, play a significant role in life expectancy and in the development of heart disease. Nor does he smoke. **********Still, if looked at solely on a statistical basis, Mr. Yeltsin's prognosis would not be comforting. Russia has by far the highest death rate from cardiovascular illness in the world, according to the American Heart Association. The total death rate is also the highest of countries that keep records. **********In 1994, the last year for which full statistics are available, the death rate from cardiovascular illness was 1,318 for every 100,000 Russian men between the ages of 35 and 74. The total death rate in that age group was 2,940 men per 100,000. **********That is nearly 10 times the heart disease death rate of Japan, which is the lowest in the world. But it is also about three times the rate for the United States, where heart disease kills 460 of people for every 100,000 men of that age range. **********One of the largest unanswered questions about Mr. Yeltsin's health is what medication he takes, if any. **********"We have offered more than once to help in any way we could," said a senior American diplomat who spoke on condition of anonymity. "The Russians have always said no thanks. He looks better these days, of course. But we cannot even say for certain what the problem is. Obviously there is a problem, however, and of course it worries us a lot." **********Rumors swirl constantly about Mr. Yeltsin. If he stumbles, people wonder if it's from alcohol or from drugs. The Russian leader was in a very rough emergency helicopter landing in 1990 and may still take painkillers, but again there is no way to be certain. **********"I have been in accidents with nearly every kind of vehicle," Mr. Yeltsin noted. "Planes, helicopters, cars, a train and once, when I was a child, a horse." So far he has managed to shake them all off. **********"Seeing Yeltsin very often now I could say that he is now in really good shape," said Anatoly B. Chubais, who is working for Mr. Yeltsin's re-election although he was recently dismissed by the President from the post in which he led Russia's industrial privatization effort. **********"It could be seen on television that his activity is very energetic in the same way he looked in 1991-92," Mr. Chubais said. "So in this situation we need  to hope for the best and investigate the worst scenario after it happens. As the Russian proverb says, let's cope with the problems when they come."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/19/world.snippet: Canadian leaders press to keep alive international aid mission to rescue Rwandan refugees as support dwindles among allied nations and resistance grows at home (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/19/world.main_headline: Canadians Keep Pressing for African Aid Mission
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/19/world.print_headline: Canadians Keep Pressing for African Aid Mission
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/19/world.body_text: **********As support dwindled among allied nations and resistance grew at home, Canadian leaders tried today to keep alive the international aid mission they planned to lead in Central Africa. **********''It is much too early to say the crisis is over,'' said Doug Young, Canada's Minister of Defense, before  Parliament today. ''Canadian forces continue to prepare for possible deployment.'' **********Some troops are already there, along with transport planes and advance units of a disaster response team that can provide medical care, electricity and pure water for large numbers of people. **********Canada is still prepared to send as many as 1,500 troops, Mr. Young said, if the African Governments in the region agree to the presence of a multinational force. **********But when the first 34 Canadian troops arrived in Kigali on Sunday, they were not exactly welcomed by the Rwandan Government, which detained them at the airport most of the day. **********As tens of thousands of refugees filed out of the Zairian camps, the United States and other allies were reconsidering the need for the kind of military intervention that Canada had first proposed and the United Nations sanctioned last week. **********In Ottawa today, Anthony Lake, the United States national security adviser, met with Canadian leaders, including Foreign Minister Lloyd Axworthy, and committed $140 million from Washington for immediate and short-term relief in the region. The Canadians have already said that they would contribute $11.3 million. The United States will also contribute logistical support to move supplies from Europe to Uganda and into Rwanda. **********Members of the international coalition are to decide at a meeting on Thursday in Stuttgart, Germany, what form any mission would take.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/23/busin.main_headline: COMPANY NEWS;SETTLEMENT ACCEPTED ON LOUISIANA-PACIFIC HOME SIDING
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/23/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;SETTLEMENT ACCEPTED ON LOUISIANA-PACIFIC HOME SIDING
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/23/busin.body_text: **********A Federal judge accepted the settlement yesterday of a class-action lawsuit that had accused the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation of producing defective siding for homes. After chastising lawyers last week for a proposal he said inadequately compensated homeowners, Judge Robert Jones of the Federal District  Court in Portland, Ore., approved a modified deal. Louisiana-Pacific agreed to pay $275 million, and has an option to add $50 million more to the fund in each of years six and seven of the settlement. The company agreed to pay administrative costs and arbitrators' awards from funds outside the settlement pool. The siding in question, known as Inner Seal, resembles cedar, but it can soak up moisture, resulting in swelling and cracking. It was installed on an estimated 800,000 homes nationwide. Louisiana-Pacific has maintained that up to  90 percent of the problems with the siding can be traced to improper installation and maintenance.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/20/busin.snippet: CSX Corporation and its rival, Norfolk Southern Corp, increase their bids for control of Conrail and rail freight traffic in Northeast; CSX raises its friendly cash-and-stock bid for Conrail by $870 million, to $9.3 billion; Conrail directors agre...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/20/busin.main_headline: Rival Bidders Raise Offers For Conrail
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/20/busin.print_headline: Rival Bidders Raise Offers For Conrail
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/20/busin.body_text: **********The CSX Corporation and its rival, the Norfolk Southern Corporation, traded body blows yesterday in an increasingly expensive battle for control of Conrail and rail freight traffic in the Northeast. **********CSX opened the day by raising its friendly stock-and-cash bid for Conrail by $870 million, to $9.3 billion, as Conrail directors agreed not to consider a takeover proposal from any other company until 1999. **********But last evening, Norfolk Southern, which is unwilling to give up its bitter two-month fight for the railroad that has a virtual monopoly over freight traffic in the Northeast, fired back with its own revised bid: $10.5 billion cash, or $115 share. **********Norfolk Southern also filed suit in United States District Court in Philadelphia, seeking to dismantle the lockup provision that binds Conrail to CSX for the next two years. A hearing is scheduled for Jan. 9, and the company said it was convinced the court would not approve the Conrail board's ''wholesale abrogation of its fiduciary duties to all of its constituencies.'' **********Most analysts and investors say that Norfolk Southern must win the court battle, otherwise the monetary value of its offer will decline over the two years it must wait, making the bid less enticing for shareholders. In that case, CSX would most likely proceed to the next stage in the merger process: regulatory approval. **********''It makes a lot of sense for Norfolk to raise its bid in conjunction with trying to smash the lockup provision,'' Anthony Hatch, an analyst at NatWest Securities, said. ''Both tactics must work for this to succeed. But if they can't break the lockup provision, $115 a share is not enough for people to wait until 1999. I think we're finally coming to the end of the game.'' **********Whatever the outcome, Conrail shares continued to climb, gaining $1.75 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday to close at $100.75. The stock price for the once-troubled railroad has climbed a giddy $29.75, or 42 percent, since the bidding war began on Oct. 15 with the announcement of a friendly, $8.1 billion agreement between Conrail and CSX. CSX stock, however, fell $1.50 on the Big Board, closing at $43.75, while Norfolk, which did not announce its new offer until after the stock market had closed, gained $2.125, to $87.375. **********Conrail shareholders gave yesterday's events mixed reviews, with some anxious to grab CSX's new offer and run, while others continued to favor Norfolk Southern's sweeter bid. The lockup provision and various anti-takeover statutes in Pennsylvania, however, provide CSX and Conrail with a formidable defense against Norfolk Southern's hostile bid. **********Until yesterday, many shareholders had complained bitterly about CSX's failure to close the $1.5 billion gap between the offers. CSX would have almost certainly lost a shareholder vote next Monday on a proposal to allow the company to buy more than 20 percent of Conrail stock. Yesterday, Conrail moved that meeting to Jan. 17, allowing CSX more time to assuage stockholders with its new offer. CSX also agreed to provide stockholders with cash or stock early next year, rather than waiting until after the merger receives regulatory approval. **********''It's a three-pronged attack on Norfolk Southern, and I think it'll be successful,'' said Thomas R. Angers, vice president of the Glenmede Trust Company in Philadelphia, which has 10,000 shares of Conrail. ''The gap between the two offers has narrowed significantly.'' **********John Snow, chairman of CSX, said he was optimistic that the bloodletting was finally over. ''We're hopeful that by increasing our offer and by extending the no-solicitation period to the end of December 1999 that we'll be able to move to the next phase of the merger,'' Mr. Snow said. **********But not everyone has been won over. CSX, which already owns 20 percent of Conrail stock, is offering $110 cash for another 20 percent. But it is offering a stock swap for the remaining 40 percent that values Conrail at $102.34 a share, based on yesterday's closing price. In contrast, Norfolk Southern is offering $115 cash for all shares. **********''It's heartening to see that CSX raised its offer after figuring out that they couldn't win the vote on Monday,'' said Ann Yerger, research director at the Council of Institutional Investors, which represents 100 private and public sector pension funds and has been critical of the CSX offer. ''But it's clear that no serious consideration has been given to Norfolk, whose offer is still higher than CSX.'' **********Institutional investors hold about 40 percent of Conrail stock, and arbitragers, who by no means favor CSX, have another 20 percent. ''The CSX offer is unfair and onerous,'' Eric Longmire, an arbitrager at Wyser Pratte, said. ''This is extremely abusive of shareholders. It prevents us from getting the best value for our stock.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/12/world.main_headline: Discovering Generosity As a Long-Distance Joy

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/12/world.body_text: **********As Johnny Suzuki knows, you do not have to live in New York to support The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Mr. Suzuki, who lives in Japan, had his contribution in the mail days after the drive began last November, writing, somewhat ambiguously, that his overseas gift was "for fellow American folks who  need help and who helped us in time of need." **********His was not the only donation from Asia. Michael R. March wrote: "As I sit transfixed by the incessant activity in Hong Kong harbor and marvel at the general sense of optimism and boundless prosperity throughout Asia, it is nevertheless easy to recall the pervasive gloom that continues to haunt a substantial number of my former neighbors in New York City." **********Mr. March gave $2,500, his single largest contribution to the fund. **********Yet another long-distance gift from Raymond and Betty Kaplan in Jerusalem, whose contribution of $72 was made in memory of their son, Kenneth Max Kaplan. **********The Neediest Cases Fund has provided direct aid to the poor for 84 years. All donations to the fund go directly to the charities since The Times pays administrative costs. Three weeks before this year's campaign closes, the total  has reached $4,257,773.62. Last year at this time, the total was $3,903,535.29.  Most contributions come from local readers, but but each year, a number of them  stand out for their foreign or long-distance postmarks. **********Charles W. Tait sent $115 and a note from Seattle, Wash., touching on a theme that has echoed through many letters this year. https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/04/world.main_headline: Vatican Says Sudan Forced Priest to Confess to Bomb Plot
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/04/world.print_headline: Vatican Says Sudan Forced Priest to Confess to Bomb Plot
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/04/world.body_text: **********The Pope's representative in the Sudan accused the Khartoum Government today  of using torture and death threats to force a priest to confess to plotting a bombing campaign. **********The Vatican said that its envoy in the Sudan, the Archbishop Erwin Joseph Ender, made the accusations in a letter to Sudan's Interior Minister and in notes to diplomats in Khartoum, the Sudanese capital. **********The Vatican said that the Archbishop, in a letter dated Jan. 25, denied that the priest, the Rev. P. Mark Lotede, or anyone else from the Roman Catholic Church had plotted against the Government. **********Sudanese rebels, most of them Christians or followers of tribal faiths, have  fought the Muslim-dominated Government in Khartoum since 1983. **********The Sudanese news agency said the priest had confessed to recruiting rebels and plotting bombing attacks. He was arrested in late December and released on Jan. 16, the news agency said. **********The Archbishop also contended that a second person, a student, was also tortured, intimidated and threatened with death to force him to accuse the priest of wrongdoing. **********Quoting from the archbishop's letter, the Vatican said that the Archbishop protested "the cynical decision to invite the Pope's representative to show up Jan. 16, 1996, for the pantomime of the public confession of the two victims of  the violence of state." **********The Archbishop said that Sudan's actions went against "all the declarations of good will, openness to dialogue, mutual understanding and tolerance between church and government."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/26/busin.main_headline: House Resales Fell by 1.5% In October
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/26/busin.print_headline: House Resales Fell by 1.5% In October
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/26/busin.body_text: **********Sales of existing houses dropped by 1.5 percent in October, the fifth consecutive monthly drop, the National Association of Realtors said today, providing further evidence that the housing market is slowing. **********The association said house resales declined to an annual rate of 3.97 million in October, and it revised its figure for September to 2.7 percent. The October figures were lower than expected; analysts had predicted a drop of three-tenths of 1 percent last month. **********The figures reflect actual closings. **********Even though mortgage rates are falling, the housing market for 1997 is not expected to sustain the big contribution it made to the economy this year, analysts said. ''Housing has gone as far as it will go for now,'' Jim Glassman, senior economist at Chase Securities Inc. in New York, said. **********Despite the decline in resales, John Tuccillo, the chief economist with the association, said the average of monthly resales would set a record of more than four million this year. ''It's been a banner year for housing,'' he said. ''Next year, while it will be a good year, probably will be off 5 percent.'' **********Even if the housing market slows, many economists still think the economy will sustain its moderate growth and low inflation through next year. That is the view of the National Association of Business Economists, which released a forecast today by 44 corporate economists, saying that the economy will grow at a 2.3 percent average annual pace in 1997 and that the Consumer Price Index would rise 2.9 percent. **********That is in line with expectations of the Federal Reserve, which decided last month to leave the overnight lending rate for banks unchanged at 5.25 percent. **********Resales of houses fell 1 percent in the Midwest, to an annual rate of 1.02 million, the National Association of Realtors said, and 5.8 percent in the South, to an annual rate of 1.45 million. In the Northeast, resales rose 3.3 percent, to an annual rate of 620,000, and in the West they rose 3.5 percent, to an annual rate of 880,000. **********The strong resales rate in the West is chiefly the result of activity in the San Francisco Bay area, where resales rose 15.4 percent last month from October 1995, a real estate information service said last week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/01/busin.main_headline: MEDIA: TELEVISION;With a fenetic debut, CNN's Business network plays catch-up. And there's more to come.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/01/busin.print_headline: MEDIA: TELEVISION;With a fenetic debut, CNN's Business network plays catch-up. And there's more to come.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/01/busin.body_text: **********MAYOR RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI was on hand to announce: "Live, from New York, it's CNNFN!" So was Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, who waited patiently to make an appearance. CNN's new financial news network even recruited a psychic, the Amazing Kreskin, to predict the direction  of the stock market in 1996 (down, sharply). **********About the only thing missing from the Dec. 29 start of CNNFN was Ted Turner himself. **********Mr. Turner, who founded the original CNN, was in Florida on a hunting trip, said a spokeswoman for Turner Broadcasting System. But if Mr. Turner was not there in person last week, his spirit was everywhere in the network's freewheeling and frantic debut. **********On Thursday evening, 12 hours before the new financial news service signed on, workers were still hurriedly tacking up posters and running cables through the studio. They had just finished repairing the ceiling, which had been damaged earlier in the week by a fire on the floor above the newsroom. **********Nerves were so frayed that Lou Dobbs, the executive vice president of CNN and head of the new network, hired a string quartet and a massage therapist to soothe employees as they rushed to gather material to fill the network's 12-hour daily schedule by 7 A.M. Friday. **********"It's been a crazy week," said a weary Mr. Dobbs, as he squatted on a stepladder in the middle of the crowded newsroom. **********The last-minute improvisation and cheerful chaos was eerily reminiscent of CNN's debut 15 years ago. But the birth of CNN-pere represented something genuinely new in television -- round-the-clock news -- and quickly became a worldwide phenomenon. **********Last week's debut of CNN-fils seemed more like a game of catch-up. NBC already has an all-business-news channel, and companies like Bloomberg Business  News, the ITT Corporation, and Dow Jones & Company are getting into business news. **********The question for CNN is: How many channels can survive by reporting on the daily swings of the Dow or the occasional pronouncements of the Fed? **********"The whole audience for all-news is minuscule," said Porter Bibb, an investment banker at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company who specializes in the media  industry. "CNN is only jumping into this because it will help extend its brand name." **********With a staff of 170 journalists and a 26,000-square-foot newsroom and studio  in midtown Manhattan, CNNFN clearly aims to be the leading business news channel on television. But to do so, the network must overtake CNBC, which now has 56 million subscribers in the United States and roughly 120 million subscribers worldwide. **********Turner's new service is starting out with only 5.5 million subscribers. And three million of those are getting it via rooftop and backyard satellite dishes, an audience that is less attractive to advertisers. (It will begin broadcasting  in New York City tomorrow on Time Warner Cable.) **********The new service will benefit from CNN's strong reputation for news gathering. And Turner Broadcasting has potent ties to Time Warner, the nation's second-largest cable operator. Nevertheless, it will be difficult for CNN's financial news network to match the distribution of CNBC. **********"The big question is when will cable operators be willing to carry two channels in the same category?" said Larry Gerbrandt, a cable analyst at Paul Kagan Associates. **********Beyond rival business news services, Turner's fledgling network faces future  competition from two other all-news cable networks: one from NBC and the Microsoft Corporation, the other from Capital Cities/ ABC. NBC and Microsoft also intend to distribute their network, which goes by the initials MSNBC, on Microsoft's on-line service. **********Executives at Turner are quick to note that CNNFN will have an even wider multimedia distribution than MSNBC. In addition to cable, it is being distributed through a site on the World Wide Web (http:// www.cnn.com); on desktop computers via CNN at Work, a joint venture of CNN and the Intel Corporation, and through the AT&T Business Network, an on-line service. **********And while NBC and ABC plan to roll out their services in 1996 and 1997, respectively, CNN's network is already up and running. "They talk the talk, we walk the walk," Mr. Dobbs said. **********Mr. Dobbs, who anchors CNN's daily business news program, "Moneyline," in addition to his corporate duties, is proud that his troops designed and built the service from scratch in six months. The network is also a classic example of how Turner squeezes more from less: It has kept its payroll down by using digital production and editing equipment and by doing without scripts for its anchors, which reduces the need for writers. **********As a result, Turner has been able to start his financial news network with an upfront investment of less than $50 million. NBC and Microsoft, by contrast, plan to spend about $200 million to start MSNBC. **********But ingenuity alone does not guarantee success. In particular, CNN must still solve the riddle of making business news watchable. For all its success, CNBC remains essentially an electronic trade magazine for the individual investor --  complete with a stock tape scrolling across the bottom of the television screen  giving the latest information on market activity. **********To attract a broad viewership, CNN's network is consciously striking a slicker pose than CNBC. In a decision that was opposed by many staff members, Mr. Dobbs persuaded Mr. Turner to do without the stock tape. The network's sprawling newsroom is painted in soft hues of green and turquoise, and looks like a cross between a Wall Street trading pit and a Southwestern cantina. And its programs have names like "Digital Jam," "Biz Buzz" and "Street Sweep." **********CNNFN has some indisputable advantages. CNN's 29 news bureaus will enable it  to offer comprehensive global coverage. And if its first day was any indication, the network will have no trouble attracting A-list guests. In addition to Mr. Levitt, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and the Presidential candidate Malcolm S. Forbes Jr. appeared on the network. **********In the end, though, the success of CNN's financial news network will hinge on its ability to make the quotidian events of business interesting. As Mr. Gerbrandt noted, "There's only so far you can take a story about rising interest rates, or what the Hang Seng index closed at."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/22/busin.snippet: US Bureau of Labor Statistics says average of 17 people die daily in US because of the work they do; that amounted to 6,210 job-related deaths in 1995, almost exactly the number (6,217) recorded in 1992, the year the bureau its conducted its first...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/22/busin.main_headline: One Day's Death Toll on the Job
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/22/busin.print_headline: One Day's Death Toll on the Job
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/22/busin.body_text: **********STATE HIGHWAY 84 parallels the Mississippi River as it cuts through northwestern Illinois and the flat cornfields north of Cordova. The land along the road looks untouched by the 20th century except for the Rock Island Nuclear Power Station, which squats heavily on the ice-crusted river bank amid a spider's web of transmission lines. **********Every workday Rick Risdal, 29, pedaled his bicycle past the plant and turned off the two-lane blacktop into the driveway of the Xylen Company, a far less imposing compound crowded with pungent heaps of shredded tree bark, large sheds and twin rows of parked tractor-trailer trucks. **********His $6-an-hour job required no special skills. He loaded large plastic bags with bark chips and wood shavings destined to be sold as mulch or landscaping materials to suburban shoppers at garden stores around the nation. **********Two months ago, on Oct. 21, he reported to work for the last time. At approximately 10:15 A.M., he was operating a forklift when it skidded on gravel, overturned and pinned him underneath. He died before an ambulance arrived. **********Within the same hour, a former deli owner who worked part time as a courier was fatally crushed beneath the wheels of a van in Wilmington, Del., a day laborer in El Paso died in a construction accident and an Indiana man who was being paid to drive a used car to an auto auction was killed when he lost control and the vehicle flipped over. **********By day's end, at least nine more people were killed or fatally injured on the job in the United States. **********It was an extraordinary day only for the victims, their families, friends and co-workers. Few of the deaths got more attention than several paragraphs in the local newspaper. **********Indeed, an average of 17 people die daily in the United States because of the work they do, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. **********That amounted to 6,210 job-related deaths in 1995, almost exactly the number (6,217) recorded in 1992, the year the bureau conducted its first 50-state census of work fatalities. The figure covers accidents, homicides and suicides on the job, but not deaths from natural causes. **********As big as those numbers are, they are a mark of progress, even after taking into account the somewhat fuzzy and haphazard data-gathering that went on in previous years. A half-century ago, in 1947, some 17,000 job-related deaths were estimated to have occurred in a work force that was less than half the size of today's. **********Fatalities in manufacturing and the construction trades have fallen sharply over the years because of mandated safety measures and education programs, officials of the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration and state agencies say. **********''One clear success story of governmental vigilance over workplace safety is the steady reduction of fatalities even as the work force has grown,'' Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said in an interview. **********Still, as the overall numbers have gone down, new areas of concern have appeared. The danger has shifted from the factory floor to service industries and outdoor occupations, areas more difficult to regulate or supervise, safety experts acknowledged. **********And workplace violence -- a category not even counted before 1992 -- is now responsible for one of every six job-related deaths, roughly the same proportion that is attributed to accidents with machinery and equipment. (Transportation-related mishaps, a category that includes everything from jackknifed trailer trucks to school crossing guards hit by a car, accounted for most of the rest.) **********Violence -- whether inflicted by robbers, co-workers or estranged spouses -- is so prevalent that it is now the leading cause of job-related deaths for women, who make up a sizable proportion of the work force at convenience stores and other retail outlets that are favorite targets of criminals. **********Joseph A. Dear, Assistant Labor Secretary for OSHA, observed that those who wrote Federal job safety regulations in years past ''would probably be surprised to see how our focus of concern has changed to workplace violence, repetitive motion and nursing home injuries.'' **********Proposed OSHA guidelines offered earlier this year to lower the risk of violence to millions of retail clerks and cashiers met stiff resistance from the fast food and convenience store industries. A modified set of guidelines is expected to be proposed in 1997 after consideration of industry objections. **********Critics of these and other efforts to expand safety guidelines say the cost and time spent in dealing with Federal and state agencies place a burden on employers far out of proportion to any gains in safety. **********OSHA, Mr. Reich said, ''remains a lightning rod for highly contentious disputes over how much death or injury is preventable.'' **********Last year, in addition to the 6,210 people who died, some 3.6 million Americans suffered disabling work injuries, according to the National Safety Council, which placed the cost at $119 billion in lost wages, employer expenses and medical care. **********The list of workplace deaths on Oct. 21 was put together with the assistance of OSHA and a number of state safety offices and state and local police agencies. Almost certainly, additional deaths occurred that day that have not yet been tallied; it will take more than a year for the Bureau of Labor Statistics to compile the complete figures for 1996. **********The 13 known deaths that day were unusual only in the fact that none involved intentional violence. In other respects they fit well within the sudden and traumatic dimensions of workplace fatalities. **********Some of the accidents were cases of simple bad luck -- of being in the wrong place at the wrong time when a piece of machinery failed. Others appeared to be the product of a misstep here, a loss of concentration there, a failure to take simple precautions because the task had been done a thousand times without a mishap. And alcohol was a factor in at least one death. Experts note that drugs and alcohol play an incalculable role in workplace accidents. **********The human toll of the deaths that occurred on Oct. 21 was also familiar. Many of those who died were of modest means and in the prime of their working lives. For financial sustenance, their survivors now have to look to workers' compensation, Social Security and the possibility of litigation. **********No one day, of course, produces a list that meets a precise ''average'' based on a year's toll. Each day is special, marked by the individuality of the men and women who died in the course of their labor. Here is a look at those who reported to work for the last time on Oct. 21. **********The Metals Worker **********The first of the group to die that day was Thomas Fishback, who lived with his wife and four small children in a modest rented house in Turtle Lake, Wis., a town of 900 more than an hour's drive northeast of Minneapolis. **********Mr. Fishback, 39, worked the graveyard shift at the American Steel and Industrial Supply Company, one of a patchwork of scrap metal yards hugging the banks of the Mississippi River just north of downtown Minneapolis. **********''That meant they didn't get to mix much socially,'' a Turtle Lake neighbor, Greg Greschner, said of the Fishbacks. ''But they liked the town and were shopping around for a house to buy.'' **********All those plans ended at 2:39 that morning. Mr. Fishback and a co-worker were standing on a platform about 30 feet above a concrete floor inside a company shed, trying to adjust steel arms that held supplies in place, the police reported. As Mr. Fishback tightened an arm, he lost his balance and fell backward to the floor below. He was dead by the time an ambulance arrived. **********Within days, Mr. Fishback's widow and children left Turtle Lake, moving in with relatives in Minnesota. **********''One minute he's working and the next minute he's dead,'' Mr. Greschner said. ''The only good thing is, they never had a chance to buy that house and be stuck with a big mortgage now that he's gone.'' **********Mr. Greschner also conceded that he was  now more safety-conscious at his own job in a local window factory. ''If I go up on an elevated platform now, I make sure the safety rails are up,'' he said. **********The Oil Rigger **********Danny Gilchrist, 46, died in the early-morning hours after an accident in the oilfields 17 miles east of Artesia in southeastern New Mexico. **********A mechanical failure in an oil rig caused a piece of equipment to crush him against a control panel, the Eddy County sheriff's office reported. His employer and co-workers could not be reached for comment. **********The Ironworker **********Dereck Bridges, 42, came from a family of ironworkers near Florence, in the Tennessee River Valley of northwestern Alabama, where playing hard is as much a part of a man's life as working hard. **********''He rode Harley-Davidson motorcycles,'' said one of his two ironworker brothers, Kent. ''That was his only hobby, that and work, and he did both pretty hard.'' **********Keith Michaels, an ironworker who was with Dereck Bridges on the morning he died, agreed that his co-worker was a character. **********''Many didn't like him at first because they didn't know how to take him,'' Mr. Michaels said. ''He was that type of fellow. **********''But once they got to know him, he was a lot of laughs. He was always cutting up.'' **********They were employed by the B & H Craig Construction Company, a Florence contractor hired by the Reynolds Metals Company to dismantle the roof of a mill located across the river near Muscle Shoals. The mill is part of a huge factory that has produced aluminum since World War II. It is Reynolds's largest plant in the world, employing about 2,000 workers. **********At 8:40 A.M., Mr. Bridges was removing rivetlike fasteners that locked 12-foot-long roof panels in place when one panel apparently gave way beneath him and he plunged 44 feet to his death, investigators said. **********Mr. Bridges was wearing a body harness at the time, but for unexplained reasons was not hooked to a secured safety rope, a measure that might have saved the life of a man who also didn't care much for wearing a helmet when he skimmed along back-country roads on his prized Harley Heritage Soft Tail. **********The Maintenance Man **********The job was routine but the circumstances were not. **********Anthony Marks, 34, was preparing to perform maintenance work near a steam boiler in a municipal water plant in Cleveland when it blew up at about 10 A.M. and killed him. **********City water officials said the boiler automatically shut down over the weekend when it malfunctioned for unknown reasons. It was restarted Monday morning at 8:15, but safety devices shut it down again 20 minutes later, they reported. **********''No one was attempting to do anything at the time of the explosion,'' explained Ron Schwarzwalder, assistant water commissioner. **********Mr. Schwarzwalder added that Mr. Marks was the first worker at the city water department to die on the job in at least 20 years. **********The Deliveryman **********Howard G. Cohen had been a deliveryman for only a few months. **********Until June he had operated a sandwich shop and restaurant, All That Food, in northeastern Wilmington, Del., and before that a kosher meat market. Businessmen favored the hefty pastrami and corned beef sandwiches and flirted with a pretty waitress from West Virginia named Betty. **********Things went well for Mr. Cohen and his wife, Deborah, until the last few years. First, the state tore up the road in front of the shopping strip where the restaurant was located, blocking easy access for an extended period, and then another takeout deli moved in next door. **********The competition and the aggravation were too much, friends said, and Mr. Cohen closed the restaurant and took a part-time job with Brooks Courier Service of Wilmington. His new job, at age 64, was delivering packages, commercial papers and nonnegotiable financial materials, said Robert Williams, a Brooks vice president. **********About 11 A.M., residents of a street named Todds Lane heard cries for help. Mr. Cohen, who had stopped his van to make a delivery, was pinned under a wheel. There were no witnesses to the accident. The police said later that he had apparently fallen and the van had rolled over him. **********Paramedics rushed Mr. Cohen to Christiana Hospital and he was able to talk to doctors after his arrival. But he soon became unconscious and died a short time later. **********The Driver **********The day's assignment was a short run for George C. Philpot, 50, a down-on-his-luck man with a thirst for strong drink who ferried cars for an auto auction company. **********Drivers like Mr. Philpot are not paid by the hour, but receive a set sum for a trip. That places a premium on driving fast. ''On some jobs, you make less than the minimum wage if a car breaks down or a battery needs jumping,'' said Mary Napier, Mr. Philpot's 52-year-old companion and fellow driver. **********She said he had worked 20 years as a casket maker in Richmond, Ind., where they lived, was divorced and had four grown children. **********''He was a fun-loving guy,'' she recalled, ''a big guy, 6-foot-1 and weighing maybe 220, a guy everyone liked.'' **********According to Ms. Napier, Mr. Philpot had downed two pints of vodka late the night before but did not appear drunk when they drove across the state line that morning to report to work in Franklin, Ohio. ''It was a perfect day,'' she recalled. ''We stopped at McDonald's and had biscuits and eggs for breakfast.'' They were among eight drivers carried in vans to a Buick dealership about seven miles to the north, where each was assigned a used car to transport to Franklin. **********Mr. Philpot's car was a green 1994 Pontiac Firebird. ''I told him to be careful with that performance car,'' Ms. Napier said. ''I drove one just like it two weeks before and it got away from me.'' **********Mr. Philpot made it only halfway back to Franklin. **********On a southbound ramp connecting Interstates 675 and 75, the Firebird suddenly fishtailed off a curve in the road and Mr. Philpot, trailing Ms. Napier's car, struggled to regain control. **********''I caught sight of him in my rear-view mirror,'' she said. ''I could see the look on his face. He knew he had lost it. It was such a horrible look.'' **********She watched the green car roll down an embankment, tumbling end over end and ejecting Mr. Philpot before coming to rest. ''He lived maybe 15 minutes,'' she said. **********Sterling Cockerham, 66, another driver in the group, told Ohio Highway Patrol investigators that the Firebird had passed him traveling 70 to 75 miles an hour before entering the ramp. **********''He passed me pretty good,'' the police accident report quoted Mr. Cockerham as saying. ''I remember thinking, 'Why is he going so fast for $4.75 an hour?' '' **********The Montgomery County Coroner's office reported later that the dead man's alcohol blood level was .270, nearly three times the legal standard for drunken driving. **********The Wood-Chip Bagger **********It had not been an easy 29 years for Rick Risdal. He had a drinking problem ''because he was so unhappy,'' said his mother, Sharon Risdal of Boone, Iowa, a custodial employee at Iowa State University. His girlfriend had moved back to Michigan with his children, Mrs. Risdal explained, ''and his heart was dripping with blood because he couldn't see his kids.'' **********Drinking led to drunken driving convictions, she said, and after the fourth one he served two years in an Iowa prison. When he got out last year, he moved to the Cordova area to be near his divorced father, who was in declining health, Mrs. Risdal explained. **********Rick's mother continued: ''He was a good-looking guy, with brilliant steel-gray eyes, and he loved working on cars. I still have a classic '78 Buick sitting out back, with a bucket of bolts and engine parts, that he never finished.'' **********Mrs. Risdal said she thought about a possible lawsuit against the bark-processing plant where her son died, but she said she was confused about her legal standing in the matter and doubted she could afford a retainer to hire a lawyer. **********''I was told the seat belt on that forklift didn't work,'' she said, referring to the vehicle her son was operating when it turned over on him. ''They should make damn sure those things work.'' **********Charles Dornfeld, Mr. Risdal's employer, said he would not comment on the accident because he had been told there might be lawsuits stemming from it. **********Willie Ziegler, a 19-year-old co-worker of Mr. Risdal who witnessed the accident, held out another version. **********''We had finished loading trucks and had some down time when Rick made some skidding turns coming out of the shed pretty fast,'' Mr. Ziegler said. ''It was pretty much horsing around. **********''Anyway, he hit some loose gravel and skidded off the pavement and flipped. He tried to jump out, but hit his head on the cage and fell to the ground with the forklift on top of him.'' **********Mrs. Risdal was notified about the accident at work and drove with a daughter across Iowa without knowing his fate. ''I wept all the way out there,'' she murmured. ''I knew he was going to die and I wanted to say goodbye.'' **********The Day Laborer **********It was Ismeal Acero's first day on the job and few of the other workers at a high school construction site on the south side of El Paso knew his name. **********''I believe his family lives in Juarez,'' said Roberta Cordova, secretary-treasurer of the El Paso Crane and Rigging Company, the outfit that hired him. Ciudad Juarez is just across the border from El Paso, where west Texas drives a pointed wedge deep into the sandy wastes of the Chihuahuan desert. **********''He seemed like a nice young man,'' Ms. Cordova continued. ''His in-laws said he worked at any job he could find.'' **********Because of El Paso's promixity to the border, and to cheap Mexican labor, hourly pay for men like Mr. Acero, who was 23, runs from the minimum wage to $7. **********Mr. Acero had earned about $10 by the time he was killed shortly before 10 A.M. Those present said later that they were not sure what went wrong. It was perhaps a language problem or just a misunderstanding, they said, or someone else goofed. It wasn't clear. **********Workers had erected concrete wall panels, some weighing more than 15,000 pounds, in the locker area of the school gymnasium, Ms. Cordova said. Mr. Acero's job was to move tools out of the way as other men worked, she continued, and somehow he removed or knocked away an unbolted brace supporting one of the panels. **********''It was a smaller panel with a big opening for a door built into it,'' she explained. ''But seven tons are going to get you every time.'' **********His back was turned to the wall when it tipped over and fell on him, she added. By the time other workers maneuvered a forklift truck to raise the slab from Mr. Acero's body, they could find no pulse. **********In the next few days, Ms. Cordova met with his young widow, Belinda, who is left with an infant girl, to offer assistance in filing workers' compensation and Social Security death claims. **********''She said she was O.K.,'' Ms. Cordova recalled. ''Things were fine. She didn't need help.'' The widow said her family would take care of the forms. **********Ms. Cordova paused, and a wry but not unsympathetic thought struck her. **********''As a widow, she and the baby may receive more money a month in benefits than Ismeal could earn while he was alive,'' she said. **********The Painter **********Bogdan Modrzejewski, 56, was a Polish immigrant who spoke little English but was handy with a paintbrush. He and Jacob Olkiewicz, 29, were painting soffits at 11:20 A.M. on the third-floor roof of an expensive house undergoing renovations in Winnetka, Ill., a well-to-do suburb of Chicago. **********''I couldn't see him from where I was working,'' Mr. Olkiewicz later said. ''I just heard him shout, and a crash.'' **********The police said Mr. Modrzejewski apparently fell through a plastic-covered opening in the roof that was being prepared for a skylight and landed in the basement three floors below. He died of head injuries 10 days later in an Evanston hospital. **********The Lineman **********Power company linemen spend much of their working time just inches from death -- dangerously close to cables or wires alive with thousands of volts of electricity. The challenge is to guard against the casual or accidental move that closes the distance. **********That moment arrived for Michael Pitts at about 2:30 P.M. that day. He was part of a three-man Duke Power Company crew installing a cross arm to a new electrical pole in a remote, forested section of western South Carolina, near Lake Keowee. After 17 years on the job, Mr. Pitts had a good work record and was conscientious about safety. He relished having an outdoor job that carried him up and down the Blue Ridge Mountains, where he had lived all his 40 years. **********He was raising himself and the cross arm in the cherrypicker-like bucket of the company truck when contact with a 7,200-volt primary line produced a crackling pop and a smoking flash that startled his co-workers on the ground. His shoulder touched the line, a company spokesman later said, and by the time the others lowered the bucket he was beyond help. **********''Just the month before, he paid off the mortgage on his home in Westminster,'' said his father, Ray E. Pitts, in a shaken voice. **********He was buried in the Coneross Baptist Church cemetery in Westminster, leaving behind a widow and two sons. **********A Working Woman **********Every year, Beryl Rockwell, 65, and her male companion of 49 years, Ora Hardy, escaped the hard winters of northern Maine by renting a place in Ocala, Fla. Watching her play shuffleboard, she might be mistaken for the retirees on the court, basking in the golden years. **********In fact, the 5-foot-3 Ms. Rockwell -- Brownie to her friends -- was a hard-driving working woman who could do the labor of a man half her age. **********''She was soft-spoken but tough,'' her niece, Diana Rockwell, said with pride. ''Whether it was driving a gravel dump truck, bulldozing or running a jackhammer, nothing fazed her.'' **********''Just two weeks before she died,'' Ms. Rockwell added, ''she cut half her thumb off on a job and drove 35 miles by herself to get to a hospital.'' **********Brownie and Mr. Hardy -- who is in his 70's -- lived together in Merrill, a township in rural Aroostook County, which forms the sparsely populated crown of Maine. The couple also worked together, the niece said, and their specialty was laying water and sewer pipes. **********On that Monday afternoon, they went to the trailer home of Lisa Condon in nearby Smyrna Mills to put in a well. ''It was the kind of job they must've done a thousand times,'' Ms. Rockwell said. **********The only difference this time was that it had been raining hard for two days, and the ground was heavy with mud. **********Mr. Hardy operated a backhoe to dig a trench 83 feet long, 3 feet wide and 7 feet deep. Brownie worked behind him, setting water pipe in the trench. **********''Ora's back was to her and he didn't see what happened,'' Ms. Rockwell said. ''Something made Brownie get down into the ditch. Probably a rock was in the way and the pipe wouldn't lay flat.'' **********It was a few minutes past 3. **********''Ora turned around and saw the trench wall had caved in on her,'' the niece continued. ''The only part of her not covered was hair on the top of her head.'' **********Mr. Hardy scrambled frantically to claw the earth and gravel away to allow her to breathe. Neighbors came running to help while the police and rescue squad were summoned. But they were too late. **********Winter now grips the north woods and the ground is frozen, too hard for even the steel teeth of a backhoe to gouge. Yet friends say Ora Hardy won't make the long trip to Florida this year by himself, preferring to spend this hard winter, as the past 49, close to his Brownie. **********The Insurance Man **********The same rains that made the earth unstable in Maine also made driving conditions wretched in the coastal section of New Hampshire. **********On I-95 near Hampton, Philip Fitzpatrick of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., pulled his car onto the shoulder of the southbound lanes at about 6:40 P.M. He had spent the day attending a training course in Dover, N.H., put on by his employer, the Liberty Mutual insurance group, and told others in his class he was off to see someone. **********No one knows why Mr. Fitzpatrick, a claims adjuster, pulled over, turned off his lights and got out of the car. All the police know is what the driver of an 18-wheel tractor-trailer with a load of frozen French fries told them. **********He said he spotted the reflector lights of the parked car and made out the dim outline of a man crouched down in the darkness near the front fender. He could see the man's face in his headlights, he told investigators. **********''Suddenly he feels an impact, brakes and pulls over,'' said Trooper Peter Gould of the State Police. **********Mr. Fitzpatrick, 36, was hurled more than 200 feet, the officer said, and was dead at the scene. **********''We checked the parked car and everything was operational and did not appear to be disabled in any way,'' Trooper Gould reported. ''It wasn't out of fuel, didn't have a flat tire, wasn't flooded out -- nothing.'' **********And somehow, he continued, the victim was struck by the center grille of the truck in the middle of the lane. ''It was odd and raised some real big questions that we haven't figured out,'' the trooper said. **********What was even stranger, in a creepy way, was the name hand-lettered on the side of the truck's door. **********''It was 'Fitzpatrick,' '' the officer said. **********Neal Comer, a White Plains lawyer representing the Fitzpatrick family in a possible lawsuit growing out of the accident, said Mr. Fitzpatrick had complained before his death about a loose bolt in the engine mount of his car that made the vehicle shake uncontrollably when driven. **********The Teen-Ager **********The last of the group to die was also the youngest, Rex Kim Lester, 17, of Salt Lake City. **********Since June, he had worked for his father's contracting business, and that evening, around 9:45, the teen-ager and his father were digging an 8-foot-deep trench for a sewer line in Riverton, a suburb. **********Investigators said the father, who was operating a backhoe, told them the earth wall collapsed on his son after he jumped into it to retrieve a surveying tool. It took 30 minutes of digging to uncover the youth's lifeless body, investigators said. **********Until last June the teen-ager had lived with his mother, Jackie Cook, in Green River, Wyo., before moving to Utah to work for his dad. The couple had divorced when Rex was a small boy. **********''He had a 3.8 grade point average in high school here,'' Mrs. Cook said the other day. ''He needed just one more English course to graduate and then he planned to go to technical college in Colorado.'' **********Mrs. Cook said her Mormon family had been in Utah since the 19th century. ''My great-grandfather on my mother's side helped settle Lehi in Utah,'' Mrs. Cook, who is assistant manager of a Subway sandwich shop, said with a note of pride. **********Lehi, like Riverton, lies in the early morning shadow of the snow-capped Wasatch Mmountains, a range he crossed on Oct. 18 to visit his mother back in Green River. **********''His older brother gave him a used van and he was real proud of it,'' she said. ''He fixed it up and wanted to show it off to his high-school buddies.'' **********When he left for the return trip to Utah the next day, a snowstorm was blowing down from the mountains. Mrs. Cook, who had lost 2 of her 10 children to childhood illnesses, wanted him to delay the return trip. When he persisted and told her not to worry, she prepared an Italian sub sandwich for the ride. **********Then she watched as the van went down the road and was swallowed up by the swirling snow.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/22/world.body_text: **********In a vivid demonstration of the problems afflicting this country's once-proud space program, Russia has been without photo-reconnaissance satellites for nearly two months, Russian and Western scientists say. **********It is the first time since the early 1960's that the Russian military has been without the satellite pictures modern armies deem essential for detecting threats and conducting combat for more than a brief period. **********Russia's last operable photo satellite burned up on re-entry to the atmosphere on Sept. 28, and since then, Russian and Western experts say, the Russian military has lacked up-to-date imagery of such potential flashpoints as Afghanistan and the Russia-China border. **********''This is the consequence of continued underfinancing of the space program, particularly in the military sector,'' said Maxim Tarasenko, a space analyst at Moscow's Institute for Physics and Technology. **********Russia's military and intelligence services are not completely without surveillance, the experts said, since other types of satellites that could detect ballistic missile attacks and track electronic emissions from military warships are still working. **********''In the heyday of the cold war, it would have been unthinkable for them to go for an extended period without a recon bird up,'' said Lieut. Gen. James R. Clapper Jr., former head of the Defense Intelligence Agency. ''It shows how much the Russians have turned inwards.'' **********A senior American official who requested anonymity said the nearly two months without satellite pictures also ''shows the incredible depths to which the Soviet military has fallen.'' **********This official said Russian military officers may feel less need for satellite photos than their American counterparts, in part because the threats Russia faces are regional rather than global. ''They really don't care when Brazil puts its navy out to sea,'' he said. ''We do.'' **********Russia, the United States and France are the only countries with significant capabilities for photographing the Earth from outer space. China's program for satellite reconnaissance is in its infancy. **********Although it never lost all of its photo satellites, the American reconnaissance program was stretched thin by the 32-month grounding that followed the 1986 explosion of the space shuttle Challenger. **********During the cold war, the Pentagon nervously watched as the Kremlin extended its reach into space. **********The Soviet Union deployed spy satellites to eavesdrop on communications and to intercept electronic emissions from the armada that accompanies American aircraft carriers. It launched satellites that provide advance warning of ballistic missile attacks and transmit messages to military units. **********It also managed an ambitious program of photo-reconnaissance satellites. Between 1962 and 1994, Moscow launched more than 800 photo-reconnaissance satellites into orbit, making up for their lack of durability with quantity. Over time, the Soviet satellites became more sophisticated and longer-lived. **********With the end of the cold war and the collapse of the Soviet Union, the number of Russian photo satellites orbiting the earth sharply declined. In 1993 and 1994, the Russians launched only seven photo-reconnaissance satellites, according to Nicholas L. Johnson, an expert on orbital debris at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. **********Russia generally had two or more photo-reconnaissance satellites in space during that time, but this year Moscow ran into problems. **********On June 11, Kosmos 2331, one of two Russian photo-reconnaissance satellites in space, reached the end of its operational life and fell out of orbit. Nine days later, the Russians tried to launch a replacement satellite into orbit. But the mission failed within seconds when the rocket crashed a few miles from the launch site. That left the Russians with a single photo satellite, Kosmos 2320. It fell out of orbit on Sept. 28, and the Russians have yet to launch a replacement. **********Public concern arose here only last week when the newspaper Izvestia reported that the Russian military was been left without a single photo-reconnaissance satellite. **********Along with this week's dramatic failure of Russia's $300 million Mars mission, the photo-reconnaissance gap is embarrassing for a nation that sent the first man into space. **********The setbacks in Russia's space programs have experienced other embarrassing signs of financial strain. Because of budget cutbacks, Moscow had to turn to the Americans for help in tracking the errant Mars spacecraft. **********Russia has also postponed bringing astronauts from its Mir space station back to Earth because of delays in building the necessary rockets. To raise badly needed cash, the Russians allowed Pepsi-Cola to use the Mir space station as a prop in the company's campaign to advertise its new blue soda cans.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/18/busin.main_headline: Suit Over Restrictions on Encryption Software Clears Early Hurdle
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/18/busin.print_headline: Suit Over Restrictions on Encryption Software Clears Early Hurdle
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/18/busin.body_text: **********Ruling that software code is speech that deserves First Amendment protection, a Federal judge has refused a request by the Government to dismiss a mathematician's lawsuit accusing it of wrongly blocking him from freely publishing and exporting his computer program. **********The ruling, by Judge Marilyn Hall Patel of Federal District Court in San Francisco, comes at a preliminary stage of what is expected to be a long courtroom struggle over the Government's policy of restricting the export and publishing of encryption software. It also comes as some members of Congress are preparing legislation that would relax the policy. **********The mathematician, Daniel J. Bernstein, sued the Justice Department in February 1995, when he was a doctoral candidate at the University of California  at Berkeley, after he was told that he would have to register as an international weapons dealer if he wanted to publish his encryption software or  discuss it at academic conferences, where foreigners might be in attendance. **********Under Government arms regulations, encryption software is classified as a weapon, along with bombs and jet fighters. The Government has restricted the export of some kinds of encryption software on the grounds that it can be used to conceal illegal activities. **********The penalties for violating the restrictions can include up to 10 years in prison and fines of as much as $1 million. **********Mr. Bernstein, who now teaches mathematics at the University of Illinois-Chicago, and the Electronic Freedom Foundation, a group promoting civil liberties in electronic communication, contended in the suit that the Government controls were an unconstitutional prior restraint of his freedom of speech. **********Lawyers for the Justice Department had asked the judge to dismiss the suit, arguing that the courts had no jurisdiction over national security policy and that computer software was not speech. **********In her ruling this week, Judge Patel disagreed, saying that the suit was about free speech and not national security. "This court can find no meaningful  difference between a computer language," she wrote, "and German or French." She  also ruled that while the court could not interfere with case-by-case rulings by the State Department, it could address the broader issue of whether encryption software could be restricted. **********Justice Department attorneys declined to comment on the case, which now heads into the discovery phase, when lawyers gather additional information. No trial date has been set. **********Mr. Bernstein's lawyer, Cindy A. Cohn, said the judge's ruling exceeded her expectations. But she added, "We expect a long, hard fight ahead." In a similar case last month, Judge Charles R. Richey of Federal District Court in Washington, D.C., ruled that the author of a book on cryptography could export the printed book, which contained the source code for an encryption program, but not an accompanying computer disk that contained the same source code in digital form.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/08/busin.body_text: **********Months of intense and bitter wrangling between Eurotunnel and its banks appeared Monday to have left both sides bloodied and neither in a position to claim victory. **********An announcement of details of the complex preliminary deal made last week between the British-French operator of the Channel Tunnel and its bankers clarified little beyond the essential point that the company will not go under. **********The compromise reached by a committee of 24 banks and Eurotunnel's board restructures the company's £8.7 billion ($13.37 billion) in short-term bank debt. A year ago, when that debt stood at £8.2 billion, Eurotunnel announced that it was suspending interest payments and seeking a restructuring of its obligations. **********Under the deal, Eurotunnel's banks will take £1 billion of what is owed them and convert it into shares in the company. That swap will instantly give them 45.5 percent of the tunnel operator's equity. In seven years they have the option to convert a second £1 billion of debt to equity. **********If Eurotunnel does well commercially — in other words, if it can raise its fares and its share of the cross-Channel market despite competition from ferry companies — existing shareholders could yet end up with as much as 55 percent of the shares. **********If, on the other hand, the current cross-Channel fare wars continue, Eurotunnel's banks, which would get less cash out and more shares for their debt, could end up holding as much as 75 percent of the company. **********The deal must win the unanimous endorsement of the company's 225 banks and that of the majority of its 750,000 shareholders. Those approvals are expected by late March. **********Sir Alastair Morton, co-chairman of Eurotunnel, said the deal would leave the company "in a position to endure enormous pressures for years to come." **********Freely acknowledging the deal's complexity, however, Sir Alastair characterized it as containing a series of interlocking conditions where "every-thing is dependent on something and nothing is protected from everything." **********What is clear is that the deal gives the company a variety of financial options that could help it through difficult commercial conditions without having to ask for fresh assistance, analysts said. **********"I think their No. 1 priority was a reconstruction that was seen to work, to ensure that there would be no chance of the company coming back for another refinancing in three more years," said Jeff Summers, head of research at the debt-trading concern Klesch & Co. in London. **********Among those options are such complex instruments as the stabilization notes that Eurotunnel can "pay" to its banks should it not have enough cash to pay them interest on debt. Over the next nine years the company has the right to issue £1.8 billion of this paper, on which it will pay no interest. These notes, too, may be converted to more shares. **********Analysts pointed to hopeful signs for Eurotunnel, including the merger announced last week of the cross-channel operations of the two largest ferry operators, P&O and Stena Line, which holds the promise of less competition and higher prices. Other analysts were pessimistic, however, suggesting that Eurotunnel's shares would fall when trading resumed Tuesday after being suspended Sept. 30 pending details of the company's debt deal. **********Analysts warned that steep drops in Eurotunnel shares could make it difficult to win the approval of the banks, who are being asked to replace billions of pounds worth of their loans with stock. **********Richard Hannah of Union Bank of Switzerland said all the talk about who would be left with how much equity verged on the irrelevant, since by his calculations Eurotunnel's debts may still exceed its so-called enterprise value. **********"You are talking about the icing on a cake, when it is likely that there will be no cake," he said.
