https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/15/busin.main_headline: Tapping the Power of Satellite TV;3 Broadcasters Aim for Arabic Speakers Around the World
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/15/busin.print_headline: Tapping the Power of Satellite TV;3 Broadcasters Aim for Arabic Speakers Around the World
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/15/busin.body_text: **********Karim Abdallah, who was working as an executive at the Cable News Network during the Persian Gulf war, remembers vividly the thirst of the Arab world for  the kind of minute-by-minute news coverage that CNN provided during that conflict. He remembers, too, how eagerly local broadcasters in Egypt and Bahrain agreed, when given the chance in the early days of the war, to pass the  network's satellite feed to their viewers. **********The lesson -- if, indeed, they needed it at all -- was not lost on some influential and wealthy Saudi businessmen interested both in an investment opportunity and in gaining some measure of control over the distribution of information and entertainment to 300 million Arabic speakers across the Middle East and North Africa. **********This triggered people's interest in the power of satellite television," Mr. Abdallah said in a recent interview. Indeed, over the last five years, three privately owned satellite broadcasting companies have begun targeting people around the world who speak Arabic. Borne aloft by several billion dollars of Saudi investments, together they are transmitting 26 channels, most to the Middle East and North Africa but also to Europe and the United States. **********So it was hardly surprising that, at the same time as CNN's ghostly images of aerial bombs or Scud missiles exploding were appearing on television sets in Cairo, a group of investors led by a Saudi businessman named Walid al-Ibrahim -- a brother-in-law of King Fahd -- was starting the Middle Eastern Broadcasting Center, or MBC. Using Arabsat satellites operated by a consortium of Arab state television companies, MBC started broadcasting news, sports and entertainment from London in 1991. **********The early broadcasts of MBC and the Egyptian Government's satellite channel were the beginning. Eventually, Arabic-language broadcasts could reach 16 million households with television sets in the Middle East and 10 million more in North Africa. In the process they are beginning to provide a homogenous -- and decidedly secular -- cultural experience in a region most known for cultural and political divisions. At a time when Muslim fundamentalism, with its deep distrust of foreign and secular influences, is challenging governments across the region, satellite television is opening the region to the rest of the world. **********In 1993, Arab Radio and Television, or ART, began broadcasting in Arabic and  English from its headquarters in Fucino, a town in central Italy. It has added two new channels a year since then, with films, children's shows and sports programs. Mr. Abdallah left CNN to become ART's executive vice president. **********In 1994, another station that is based in Italy, Orbit Satellite Television and Radio Network, began transmitting 19 television channels to the Middle East. Two are Arabic-language channels, the rest use either English or French. **********These private satellite businesses, along with government-owned satellite broadcasting systems already running or being readied in a number of countries including Egypt, Jordan, Qatar and Saudi Arabia, are developing in tandem. Sometimes they work together -- Orbit carries Jordan's state-run service -- but  more often they are engaging in lively competition. "The next five years will bring very tough competition," said Mustafa Karkouti, an executive at MBC in London. **********The Saudi-backed private satellite broadcasters receive revenue from a combination of advertising and subscriber fees, but thus far none is profitable. Advertising rates are extremely low by American standards; MBC typically charges between $2,140 and $3,780 for a 30-second advertisement in prime evening viewing hours. By comparison, the cheapest such ad costs $80,000 in the United States, while a 30-second spot on NBC's perennial hit "Seinfeld" costs $490,000. **********The Saudis' biggest government-supported rival is the Egyptian Satellite Channel, or ESC,which, according to the president of the Egyptian Radio and Television Union -- the equivalent of a government ministry for broadcasting --  brings in $5 million annually in advertising revenues and subscriber fees. The groups under the E.R.T.U. that are responsible for producing programs are equally profitable, said the E.R.T.U.'s president, Amin Bassiouny. **********Viewer fees for the new services -- the equivalent of the monthly rates paid  by subscribers to cable or direct satellite broadcasts in the United States -- vary widely. **********In addition to broadcasting over ESC, the E.R.T.U. joined with private investors in 1992 to start Cable Network Egypt, which charges subscribers a flat $90 monthly rate for a package of services including CNN, MTV and three other channels. Private stations like Orbit are more sophisticated. Orbit's Cyprus-based automatic booking system allows subscribers to phone in and change  the number and choice of channels on a monthly basis. They are then billed accordingly. **********While none of the executives of these private concerns believe that profit is possible before 1998 at the earliest -- and some in the business say it will take far longer -- the size of the potential audience, makes them believe it is  worth the wait. In Egypt alone, the E.R.T.U.'s president contends there is an audience of at least a million people for ESC. **********The three commercial networks -- MBC, Orbit and ART -- are also vying to gain sizable audiences by securing rights to material like the Turner Broadcasting System's CNN and Walt Disney's ESPN International sports channel, which Orbit broadcasts, or N.C.A.A. basketball, which is featured on ART. **********And the commercial broadcasters are also producing fresh Arab-language programs. ART, for instance, produces soap operas, talk shows and children's programs at studios in the Middle East and Western Europe. This growing market for Arabic material has spawned new television production centers and revived old ones. In Cairo, the traditional hub of the Arab-language film and entertainment industry, the Government is building a new, $300 million production center. **********But despite the Egyptian origin of most programming, the gush of Saudi Arabian money behind the satellite television revolution is still raising concerns that the popular new channels could exert a dominant influence. For if  Egyptian tastes, accents and slang has predominated until now, producers are increasingly attentive to more conservative Saudi attitudes in such matters as the way women are attired and how they speak and behave. **********"Many movies cater to Saudi tastes," said Selim Hussein, a Cairo civil engineer who two years ago banded together with 12 other tenants in his apartment house to buy five fixed satellite dishes. Each tenant chipped in $1,200. Satellite broadcasts, he suggested, might be the antidote as well as the ailment. "With open skies, at the end, you have a choice," he said. **********And the sometimes prohibitive cost of the hardware required to receive these  broadcasts -- which has meant the viewers of satellite broadcasts tend to come from the wealthy and Western-educated slice of the Arab world -- is slowly coming down. In Cairo, Samsung sells a package of a fixed dish, receiver and television set for about $740. **********The broadcasters themselves are in the market for hardware and services. Orbit, according to the network's spokesman Thomas Kington, gets its satellite decoders from Scientific Atlanta, a satellite equipment maker in Georgia. **********Though all three private stations began by using the Arabsat satellites, Orbit and ART have switched to commercial satellites. Orbit's broadcasts are sent via an Intelsat satellite that hovers in a geostationary orbit over the Mediterranean Sea. This spring, ART will begin using a new Panamsat satellite over the Indian Ocean. And the Egyptian Government has signed a $180 million contract with France's Matra Marconi and Alcatel Espace to build and launch on a French rocket Egypt's own broadcast satellite. **********So, while the state-owned terrestrial broadcasters still are the sole source  of television in most cities like Cairo, the number of satellite dishes grows daily. Executives for all three companies are reticent about numbers. Orbit says it has 80,000 subscribers, up from 56,000 in December. The other Saudi-backed businesses send their signals for free, so they have as yet no way to make accurate estimates of how many viewers they have. **********Some broadcasters offer decoders capable of filtering out selected material,  a feature that is proving popular. "What you would call PG-13, I would call PG-18," said Ghada Shahbander, a marketing consultant who is Mr. Hussein's wife. They have four children. **********Orbit's chief executive, Alexander B. Zilo, an American who once did the same job at Rupert Murdoch's Star TV has described Orbit's viewers as "college-educated, usually having studied abroad," and "nostalgic for the American sort of life style." **********Orbit was put together two years ago with about $1 billion in investments by  the Saudi-controlled Mawarid Group, one of the largest private conglomerates in  the Middle East. ART, which began about a year earlier, was started by one of the original MBC investors, Saleh Abdullah Kamel, another Saudi executive. He sold his stake in MBC for $60 million, added to this from his own substantial personal resources and formed another group of investors to get the new project  started. **********The Saudi-backed companies chose to base their operations in Italy and Britain to ease satellite links and tap a reservoir of European and American technicians -- and, possibly, to avoid political pressure from Arab governments. **********Indeed, the reaction of Arab governments to the private commercial broadcasts has not always been cordial. In 1994, Orbit contracted with the British Broadcasting Corporation's Arabic service to provide newscasts, and an early BBC program featured interviews with Saudi Arabian dissidents. **********[Last week, Orbit abruptly announced it was ending the contract with the BBC  in outrage over a recent report by a Panorama news program on capital punishment in Saudi Arabia. **********In a statement that appeared dictated by Orbit's Saudi owners, Mr. Zilo attacked the report as a "sneering and racist attack on Islamic law and culture." Panorama had shown preparations for a public execution in Saudi Arabia and interviewed a Filipino woman who described how she had been flogged for breaching Saudi law by appearing in public with male companions. **********The BBC's contract with Orbit required Panorama to "take account of local sensitivities," Mr. Zilo's statement said. "This they did not do," he added. **********A BBC spokesman, Phil Johnstone, said the contract with Orbit gave it "full editorial control," and said the BBC was satisfied it had complied with its obligations "as to editorial standards, content, quality, and local sensitivities."]

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/20/world.main_headline: For Israeli Settlers, a Dream Revived
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/20/world.print_headline: For Israeli Settlers, a Dream Revived
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/20/world.body_text: **********For nearly three years, Yaldena Nawi and her young family have gazed wistfully at a house that stands empty in this remote Jewish settlement on a rock-strewn hillside surrounded by Palestinian villages. **********Built by the last Likud Government, the house was locked shut before it became a home, declared off-limits by a Labor Government that tried to curb Jewish colonization of occupied Arab lands. **********But now that Israel's pendulum has swung to the right again, emboldened advocates are calling for the steel doors and iron bars here and across the West Bank and Gaza to be flung open as part of a surge that would allow Jewish settlers like the Nawis to move to the house they call their own. **********"We've had enough of the trailer," said Mrs. Nawi, who with her husband and two children took refuge there rather than abandon a plan to settle here. "But of course we wanted Netanyahu to win, and now we can have some hope." **********With the United States and the Palestinians warning darkly against erecting new obstacles to the quest for peace, Israel's new Prime Minister has not yet said whether he shares his supporters' vision of a doubling or tripling of the ranks of Jewish settlers in Arab lands in the next four years. **********But the Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, has made clear that he is not willing to force new settlement to a halt, and it is a fair bet that his first step will be to lift the restrictions that have left some 3,000 housing units like the ones in Nili vacant. **********That prospect alone outrages Palestinian leaders and some on the Israeli left, who say that an Israeli Government serious about peace should be preparing to evacuate Jewish settlements, not expand or build new ones. **********"This is the clearest sign that the new Government is regressing to four years back," David Zucker, a member of Parliament from the leftist Meretz party, said of the notion of unlocking latched doors. "This is the end of the drying-out period for the settlements, and the beginning of their rebirth." **********Nili, established 15 years ago, is one among a chain of Jewish settlements originally intended as a barrier to a widening of Palestinian autonomy in the West Bank. Unlike settlements closer to Jerusalem endorsed by Labor and Likud leaders alike, the more far-flung community is among those seen by critics as staking a claim on Arab lands too vast to be compatible with any final peace settlement. **********On his visit to Washington last week, Mr. Netanyahu pointed to what he called the "natural growth" of settlements in the last four years. During that period,  the number of settlers increased from about 98,000 to 145,000. **********But under Yitzhak Rabin and Shimon Peres, most of that increase took place in the outskirts of Jerusalem, and Mr. Netanyahu's policy will not be measured by the magnitude of further settlement alone, but also by where it takes place. **********With a population that stands now at just 500, Nili may prove to be a telling gauge. **********One-third of its 120 families live in trailers, unable to build or buy houses of their own. While costly private construction has gone forward, the Government has not begun work on a new unit since July 1992, when Mr. Rabin and his Labor Party took power and called a halt to the huge building campaign in the settlements that was begun by Ariel Sharon, the last Likud housing minister. **********Of the projects then under way in Nili, only five prefabricated duplexes -- each housing a pair of mirror-image units -- were permitted to be completed. **********Mrs. Nawi, then 30, had fully expected that she and her husband would buy one of the 600-square-foot homes priced at $45,000 when they planned their move here with an infant son in August 1993. They had even picked a favorite. **********Their timing proved unfortunate. By the time the Nawis were ready to buy, the Government had tightened its restrictions, barricading the four houses that remained unsold in a ban that Phineas Wallerstein, chairman of the influential Judea and Samaria Settlements Council, still scorns as Labor's "decree from the  skies." **********Like others whose hopes were dashed, the couple stayed in Nili, squeezed into a modest trailer they rent for $100 a month. Their presence, they believe, helped to reinforce Jewish claims to biblical lands. **********In conversations here, Mrs. Nawi and others said they recognized that the opening of the closed houses could have broad consequences. The trailers that would be vacated would be filled by new settlers, swelling Nili's population, they said, as would a parallel ruling easing restrictions on towing new trailers to the settlement. **********But Mrs. Nawi, who will turn 33 next month, said she was inclined to think more personally, about the weeds that have grown and walls that have leaked as her intended home and those nearby remain untended. **********"Three thousand houses -- well, maybe that's a matter of policy," she said, holding her son Nimrod in her arms. "But four houses -- that's just being stubborn."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/05/world.snippet: Romanian Pres Ion Iliescu faces runoff election on Nov 17 against Emil Constantinescu; with 50 percent of votes counted in Nov 3 Presidential election, Iliescu reportedly has 33 percent and Constantinescu 28 percent (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/05/world.main_headline: Incumbent in Romania, a Leftist, Faces a Runoff
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/05/world.print_headline: Incumbent in Romania, a Leftist, Faces a Runoff
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/05/world.body_text: **********A third term for President Ion Iliescu, who has led Romania on a leftist course since the collapse of Communism, seemed uncertain today after partial results from the presidential election on Sunday were announced. **********Mr. Iliescu, 66, faces a runoff on Nov. 17 against Emil Constantinescu, an academic and centrist politician. **********With 50 percent of the votes counted, Pro-TV, a private television station, reported tonight that Mr. Iliescu had about 33 percent, with Mr. Constantinescu at 28 percent and Petre Roman, a former reformist Prime Minister, at 21 percent. Candidates from smaller parties won the rest. **********The runoff outcome may depend on how Mr. Roman steers his voters. **********Mr. Iliescu's governing party, the Party of Social Democracy, which is composed of former Communists, lost the parliamentary elections also held on Sunday. Analysts said Mr. Constantinescu's Centrist Democratic Convention would seek to form a coalition government with Mr. Roman's Union for Social Democracy. **********The voting showed deep disillusion with Mr. Iliescu's policies, which have resulted in lower standards of living for many Romanians since the overthrow and execution of Nicolae Ceausescu in 1989. **********Mr. Iliescu, afraid of alienating constituents, held back on market reforms. **********A new coalition government with the Democratic Convention and the Union for Social Democracy would speed up economic reforms by making the ownership of private property easier and dismantling some of the failing state industries. Both parties vowed to clean up the wide-scale corruption that they accused Mr. Iliescu's party of fostering. **********Romania has been trying to become one of the first former Eastern bloc countries to join NATO, but Western diplomats said Romania's chances were slim and would probably not be much affected by elections.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/05/world.main_headline: To Retain Momentum, Peres May Call Israeli Elections by May
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/05/world.print_headline: To Retain Momentum, Peres May Call Israeli Elections by May
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/05/world.body_text: **********Israel's major newspapers all reported today that Prime Minister Shimon Peres had all but decided to advance national elections to May and that he would make  the announcement within two weeks. **********Mr. Peres evidently reached the decision at an international economic meeting in Davos, Switzerland, after concluding that no breakthrough was imminent in the talks with Syria and that his chances of victory would diminish with time. **********The coordinated leak of the early elections came with another visit here by  Secretary of State Warren Christopher for more shuttling between Israel and Syria, suggesting that Mr. Peres may be trying to put new pressure on President  Hafez al-Assad of Syria to agree to a meeting. **********Senior officials in Mr. Peres's Labor party have said that such a meeting, which would mark a breakthrough in the Israeli-Syrian dealings, was the one factor that would still persuade Mr. Peres to delay elections till October. But  the slow progress of the American-brokered talks in Maryland has now left little chance of such a meeting. **********Though there was no public comment from Washington on the likelihood of early elections, there was speculation in the Israeli press that the Clinton Administration was probably unhappy that the latest talks would be effectively suspended even if meetings continued. **********The more immediate political problem is accusations by the Likud opposition and its leader, Benjamin Netanyahu, that Mr. Peres is seeking to capitalize on the assassination of Yitzhak Rabin. In the days after the assassination last Nov. 4, Mr. Peres said he would not hold elections until the term of Mr. Rabin's Government ran out in October. **********Asked about the accusations in a television interview Saturday, Mr. Peres said: "The Likud has always said that we have no mandate, that this Government is not legitimate, that we have no majority, and we have no right to decide. So  how come he has suddenly changed his mind?" **********The Likud party has been acting for some time now as if the decision to move  up the vote is definite, and major papers today carried Likud party advertisements attacking the Government as if the campaign had begun. **********Labor leaders have advanced several other reasons to hurry up the vote. **********The main one is that Mr. Peres is continuing to show a strong lead over Mr. Netanyahu in public opinion polls. The latest poll in the daily Yediot Ahronot showed Mr. Peres ahead by 46 percent to 30 percent. **********The Labor party also expects that the Palestinian elections, and the anticipation that Yasir Arafat will soon lift portions of the Palestinian covenant calling for the destruction of Israel, will convince voters that Labor's peace policies are working. **********Mr. Peres is also said to believe that he would be better able to negotiate with Mr. Arafat and Mr. Assad with a strong mandate. **********Labor Party leaders said the exact date of the election was not yet settled,  although the consensus was focusing on May 21. Then if a runoff vote was required, it could be held on June 18. **********Under new election rules, Israelis will vote directly for a Prime Minister as well as for new members of Parliament. In the past, the Prime Minister was chosen by the party or coalition with the most votes. **********That will pit Mr. Peres directly against Mr. Netanyahu, who suffered considerable political damage after Mr. Rabin's assassination when he was accused of contributing to, or at least not controlling, the violence of the political opposition. Since then, Mr. Netanyahu has rallied, but he still trails Mr. Peres in all polls.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/04/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene;Paying to pollute: a free market solution that's yet to be tested.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/04/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene;Paying to pollute: a free market solution that's yet to be tested.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/04/busin.body_text: **********THE 1990 amendments to the Clean Air Act give electric power companies the right to pay to pollute, much the way sinners bought indulgences in the Middle Ages. Yet although the trading of sulfur emissions between utilities is now permitted, there is not much activity in this market, and prices of marketable permits are far below initial projections. Does that mean the system is not working -- that free market environmentalism is being sabotaged by myopic corporate executives or hostile state regulators? **********According to the latest studies, the answer is both cheerier and more complicated. So far, it seems, trading among utilities has not been needed to meet Federal standards. Indeed, A. Denny Ellerman, director of the Center for Energy and Environmental Policy at M.I.T., argues that thanks to the plunging price of low-sulfur coal "compliance has been essentially free" in some parts of the country. **********It is not yet known, though, whether the utilities will exploit the advantages of trading when pollution controls are tightened in coming years. "The issue has yet to be tested," says Daniel J. Dudek of the Environmental Defense Fund. **********Federal law requires utilities to limit the sulfur emissions from the country's 110 dirtiest plants -- all of them coal-fired -- to 2.5 pounds for every million British thermal units of energy generated. In 2000, the limit will be extended to all power plants and maximum sulfur emissions will be pared to 1.2 pounds to a million B.T.U.'s. (A million B.T.U.'s is enough heat to make about 100 kilowatt-hours of electricity, a little less than the typical American household uses in a week). **********Unlike earlier legislation, the Clean Air Act of 1990 applies to the corporate emissions average: a utility may exceed the limit on one plant by running a very clean operation at another. What's more, it allows individual utilities to buy permits from other power producers, or to bank excess compliance for future use. **********In 1990 the Environmental Protection Agency estimated that the right to emit  of ton of sulfur would be worth about $750. The figure represented the agency's  best guess about the cost of the alternatives -- shutting dirty plants, switching fuels and adding catalytic sulfur scrubbers. But permits have generally run below $150 a ton, and organized trading on the Chicago Board of Trade has been far lighter than expected. Just one utility in six is using the market to comply with the law. **********One explanation is that the market has been sabotaged. If, for example, state regulators allow utilities to earn a guaranteed return on outlays for expensive  scrubbers, but don't allow them to profit from skillful emissions trading, there would not be much demand for marketable permits. **********In fact, there has not been much trading because utilities have taken advantage of their newly won flexibility to offset emissions by cleaning up other plants within their own systems. "Two-thirds of gains have come through intra-utility trading," said Robert N. Stavins of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. **********One key has been access to cheap, clean fuel. Increased competition among railroads, made possible by rail deregulation, has sharply reduced the price of  low-sulfur coal mined in the Plains states for delivery to the Midwest and the South. That allows utilities to burn coal in some plants with as little as a half-pound of sulfur in each million B.T.U.'s, reducing overall utility emissions to the allowable tonnage at little or no cost. **********Dallas Burtraw, an economist at Resources for the Future, also notes that new technology has lowered the cost of meeting the sulfur standard. Fuel blending -- mixing low- and high-sulfur coal -- has proved easier than expected. And the price of scrubbing sulfur from smokestacks has fallen by half since 1989. **********What's yet to be determined, though, is whether utilities will use the market when pollution requirements tighten and the economic advantages of emissions trading emerge. A number of states are putting pressure on power producers to buy high-sulfur coal from local mines. Indeed, last year a Federal appeals court struck down Illinois legislation that would have required utilities to install scrubbers -- and thus become a captive market for high-sulfur coal. **********Even the states without such parochial agendas are sending out mixed signals. Some environmental groups are still ready to cheer on local regulators who frown on utilities that choose to "pay to pollute." And no state has ruled that utilities with the foresight to buy marketable permits cheaply will be allowed to keep the benefits. **********Perhaps the best hope is that the wave of electric utility deregulation will  end the states' will or capacity to micromanage environmental fixes. If states forgo the right to dictate who sells power at what price -- if electricity is sold in a national market -- competition will force producers to minimize costs. "At least a billion dollars a year in savings" is on the line, Mr. Burtraw says.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/26/world.main_headline: Despite Doubts, Official Gives Go-Ahead to Bosnian Vote
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/26/world.print_headline: Despite Doubts, Official Gives Go-Ahead to Bosnian Vote
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/26/world.body_text: **********The European diplomat in charge of organizing national elections in Bosnia said today that although conditions had not been met for free and fair elections, the vote should nevertheless go ahead in September as scheduled. **********Under the Balkan peace plan the official, Flavio Cotti, as chairman of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, was supposed to certify that conditions in Bosnia will allow fair elections before setting a date and supervising the vote. But Mr. Cotti, who is also the Swiss Foreign Minister, came under intense pressure from the United States and Europe to give the go-ahead to the elections despite the serious misgivings he and other diplomats  had expressed about the wisdom of proceeding. **********The Americans have argued that elections to form a national legislature and  presidency in Bosnia are needed to begin the process of reuniting the warring ethnic factions. They also argue that the elections should be held while NATO troops are still in the country to keep peace, and that if elections are not held soon, the entire Dayton peace effort could unravel. **********But human rights groups and many observers in Bosnia fear that without freedom of refugees to return to their homes, and without press freedoms, elections now will only give legitimacy to ethnic separation. **********In his statement today giving the sought-after approval, Mr. Cotti made it clear he did so reluctantly. **********He said holding elections this fall had "extremely high risks." He warned that if the international community did not succeed in opening up genuine political debate within the three ethnic enclaves of Bosnia, the vote would only consolidate the power of nationalist Croats, Muslims and Serbs. **********Speaking in Vienna to a meeting of the organization -- which has 53 members including European countries, Russia and other former Soviet states and the United States and Canada -- Mr. Cotti called on foreign countries to take vigorous action to insure conditions for a free vote, including the arrest of indicted war criminals such as the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic. **********"If no actions are undertaken right now against the indicted war criminals,"  Mr. Cotti said, "it can be taken for granted that the elections will very quickly give way to developments diametrically opposed to those which they are expected to yield. There exists the most serious danger that they then degenerate into a pseudo-democratic legitimization of extreme nationalist power  structures and ethnic cleansing. Instead of the peaceful evolution in keeping with the peace agreement, the elections would lead to further dramatic tensions." **********Western diplomats here said they were encouraged by reports from Belgrade that suggest that Dr. Karadzic will not, as many feared, attempt to run in the elections. Under the Dayton accord he is banned from holding office. **********The Serbian press agency said the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, informed Bosnian Serb envoys on Monday that they must remove Dr. Karadzic from office and appoint an acting President to replace him. **********Diplomats here said Mr. Milosevic threatened the Bosnian Serbs with reprisals unless Dr. Karadzic steps aside and the elections go ahead without interference. American and European diplomats have issued stern warnings to Mr. Milosovic that Serbia risks renewed sanctions unless Mr. Karadzic is pushed aside. Mr. Milosovic represented the Bosnian Serbs at the Dayton talks. **********While Western officials say they still want to see Mr. Karadzic arrested, they have privately made it clear they will settle for now with seeing him out of office and out of the limelight. **********The Clinton Administration, which wants to stick to the timetable set out in  the peace agreement reached last November in Dayton, Ohio, has mounted a vigorous campaign to hold the elections as scheduled, with support from other O.S.C.E. members. The Swiss Foreign Minister, who has made five trips to the region, said today that the conditions stipulated in the Dayton agreement for free and fair elections remain elusive. His decision to certify the vote was, he said, based on the possibility that a delay "could heighten political uncertainty and political division even more." **********He urged that the next two-and-a-half months before the September 14 vote be  used to create conditions for a legitimate vote. **********"This period must be employed in order to improve the framework conditions,"  he said. "This is absolutely imperative for us all." **********The Dayton agreement requires that "the parties shall insure a politically neutral environment without fear and intimidation, one which insures human rights and fundamental freedoms." The agreement calls for freedom of movement, freedom of expression, freedom of press and freedom of association, including for political parties. **********Mr. Cotti said today that, in his view, none of these requirements have been  achieved. He said there were continued "police controls, incidents of intimidation and aggression," as well as "discrimination and violence against minorities." He also cited the lack of a free press and the inability of people  to travel freely. And he noted that only 70,000 of the some two million refugees and displaced people in Bosnia had been able to go home, and in most cases those who returned went back to areas where their ethnic group was in the majority. **********But Mr. Cotti added that one of the aims of the vote, designed to create a three-person presidency and a Parliament representing all three ethnic groups, was to build joint institutions that would prevent Bosnia from being partitioned along ethnic lines. And he said that it would be riskier to hold elections after the withdrawal of NATO peacekeeping forces, scheduled for year's end. He called  the presence of the force "indispensable" to the election process. **********"If we delayed for some months," he told reporters following the speech, "it  might not make the situation better, but possibly worse." **********"After carefully weighing all factors, I have come to the conclusion that there are no convincing alternatives on the holding of elections," he told the body.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/25/busin.snippet: Calenergy Inc of US claims victory in its 923 million pound, or $1.55 billion, hostile takeover offer for Northern Electric PLC (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/25/busin.main_headline: Calenergy Bid For Utility Is Victorious
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/25/busin.print_headline: Calenergy Bid For Utility Is Victorious
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/25/busin.body_text: **********Calenergy Inc. of the United States claimed victory today in its $:923 million, or $1.55 billion, hostile takeover offer for Northern Electric P.L.C., a British regional electricity supplier. **********A spokesman for CE Electric, a partnership between Calenergy and Peter Kiewit Sons' Inc. that is making the bid, said the final tally of shares tendered gave the bidder 50.3 percent of Northern Electric's shares. **********Calenergy, a producer of geothermal energy based in Omaha, thus became the fourth American buyer of a British electricity supplier in the last two years. **********The British utility market has consolidated rapidly since it was deregulated. Of the 12 regional electricity companies created in 1995, only two will begin 1997 as independent concerns: Yorkshire Electricity P.L.C. and Southern Electric P.L.C. **********The takeover battle was one of the fiercest in Britain since the last time Northern Electric was being sought, by Trafalgar House P.L.C. The outcome was in doubt until the very end. **********By the original deadline last Friday, Calenergy's offer had been accepted by holders of 49.77 percent of Northern Electric's shares, not enough to give it control. But Britain's Takeover Panel extended the deadline to today. **********That decision came after the panel learned that Barclays de Zoete Wedd, an investment bank that was advising Northern Electric, had been offered a $:250,000 performance fee in conjunction with its business on behalf of Northern. Calenergy asserted that the fee amounted to a bribe to get the investment bank to buy Northern Electric shares on the open market and block the hostile bid. Barclays de Zoete Wedd denied this. **********The Takeover Panel extended the offering period to look at the matter. **********By Sunday, Calenergy had received acceptances for more than 50 percent of the company. But on Monday, the Prudential Corporation, Britain's biggest insurance company and a key Northern Electric shareholder, offered to match Calenergy's $:6.50-a-share offer, if other Northern Electric holders would revoke their acceptances of the bid. **********A document released by the London Stock Exchange today showed that Prudential had bought more than 700,000 shares on the open market during the session in an effort to block the bid. But a Calenergy spokesman said enough new acceptances came in for the hostile bidder to maintain control of the target company. **********''It was really close,'' the spokesman said. ''You're talking about 300,000 shares here.'' **********Prudential had been an outspoken opponent of Calenergy, repeatedly saying that the company was trying to buy Northern Electric too cheaply. **********The London stock market was already closed for the Christmas break by the time Calenergy announced its victory. During today's session, Northern Electric fell 4 pence, to $:6.37, below the offering price. **********On the New York Stock Exchange today, Calenergy rose 75 cents, to $30.50.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/22/busin.main_headline: TECHNOLOGY: DIGITAL COMMERCE;Adapt karaoke for CD-ROM and what do you have? A copyright problem, it seems.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/22/busin.print_headline: TECHNOLOGY: DIGITAL COMMERCE;Adapt karaoke for CD-ROM and what do you have? A copyright problem, it seems.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/22/busin.body_text: **********AS they careen into the information age, the media are increasingly becoming  the butts of their own jokes. **********The Internet is awash in spoof press releases (some may recall the classic, "Microsoft Buys Catholic Church"). The comedian Dana Carvey simultaneously blisters and bows to the gods of advertising on his new television series. The hilarious cable television show "Mystery Science Theater 3000," now a feature film, provides acidic yet affectionate commentary on movies and pop culture via  two robots and a guy who sit in the front row of a theater and wisecrack their way through stunningly bad films. **********And considering today's preoccupation with all things interactive, it's not  surprising that a couple of Hollywood multimedia types would find a way to stir  technology into today's irreverent media attitude. The result is a CD-ROM title, still in development, that they call Movieoke. **********The Movieoke concept is derived from the karaoke sing-along, a popular pastime in Japan that has been moderately successful in the United States as well. Karaoke companies license the rights to record a popular song from a music publishing company. Then they record the sound track, without vocals, mix it with some video, and print song lyrics along the bottom of the video screen. **********Karaoke happens when a normally thoughtful human being gets up on a stage, usually in a bar and after a certain amount of imbibing, and proceeds to sing the song, accompanied by aforementioned sound track and video. Fun is had all around. **********Public humiliation, however, is not a requisite of Movieoke, which can be performed in the comfort and privacy of your computer nook. O.K.? There, the disk plays scenes from classic movies -- the demonstration version uses scenes from "Casablanca" and "Young Frankenstein" -- strips out the dialogue, and allows you to dub your voice in place of, say, Humphrey Bogart's or Madeline Kahn's. **********Speaking into your PC's microphone, you can read the real movie script as it  scrolls along your computer screen -- whether in your own voice, your best Bogie or, say, an imitation of Mr. Ed, the talking horse. As with karaoke, this provokes much hilarity. And you can save the dubbed dialogue to a hard disk or diskette so you can replay it for the amusement of your friends and family, or to send along to other Movieoke players. **********Who knows if there's a mass market for such a toy, but the developers -- Harry Marks and Jim Lambert -- have interesting resumes. Mr. Marks, a former television vice president and creative director for both ABC and CBS, is now a multimedia graphic designer and senior adviser to the American Film Institute's  Advanced Technology Program. Mr. Lambert, a multimedia author who developed the  recently released Hot Wheels Computer Cars for the Mattel Corporation, also just shipped three CD-ROM's -- "Cine*Noir," "Bimbo Movie Bash"and "Sci-Fi Movie Machine" -- that enable users to splice together their own movies using clips from different B-grade genres. **********Mr. Marks and Mr. Lambert, who've been working on the project since January 1995, want to ship Movieoke's dubbing software, along with 10 movie scenes, on the first Movieoke CD-ROM. Later versions would bundle the dubbing software with scenes from specific genres like noir, romance and action adventure. **********Movie studios are lining up for the opportunity to participate, right? After  all, most Hollywood studios became involved with interactive media in the first  place because they saw it as a way to "repurpose" existing assets and recoup a few more dollars from material they had already paid to produce. **********But as it turns out, Hollywood doesn't have much of a sense of humor when it  comes to sacred cash cows like "Casablanca." Mr. Marks and Mr. Lambert have found they can't finish Movieoke, even though the technical guts of the program  are completed, because they can't buy the rights to use the classic movie scenes that everyone recognizes. **********"Because amateur performers could make a mockery of the film, on an ongoing basis rather than a one-shot parody, this kind of usage could damage its value," said Mickey Kapp, a music industry consultant and former Warner Music executive who has dealt extensively with copyright issues. He said that parody writers in the music world have been successfully sued for "damaging a copyright" if they changed the interpretation of the original material. **********Because of this, Mr. Kapp said, he finds it unlikely that the film studios would want to risk such damage by issuing licenses for Movieoke. **********This situation isn't necessarily curtains for Movieoke. Though dubbing a B-movie doesn't have the same cachet as intoning your own "Hasta la vista, baby," as Arnold Schwarzenegger glowers from your monitor, the purveyors of B-grade footage are usually more than willing to license for laughs. And if Movieoke were to incorporate the requisite software tools so that folks with their own video and computer equipment could create their own Movieokes, then there still may be a business in the technology. **********But whether or not Movieoke ever makes it out of development, the larger issues it raises are worth pondering. Garry Hare, the president of Fathom Pictures, a multimedia developer in Sausalito, Calif., likes to tell the story of a baseball CD-ROM title he wanted to create in the early 1990's. By the time  he toted up what he would need to pay to the players to use their likenesses, and to Major League Baseball, and to music publishers -- and on and on -- Mr. Hare said he would actually be paying out more in licensing fees than he could recoup from any reasonable retail price for the disk. **********The artistic and intellectual property issues of media re-use are important,  in an era when digital technology is making replication instantaneous and infinite -- with or without the permission of the copyright holder. **********But whether or not they choose to play along with new-media pranksters like Movieoke, entertainment companies may need to begin rethinking their old-media notions of copyright sanctity. Otherwise, they may end up copyrighting themselves right out of the few potentially lucrative markets in multimedia.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/11/busin.main_headline: Need to Cut Costs? Order Out;Outsourcing Saves Money, but Labor Is Frustrated
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/11/busin.print_headline: Need to Cut Costs? Order Out;Outsourcing Saves Money, but Labor Is Frustrated
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/11/busin.body_text: **********The anti-lock brake systems look out of place as they slide by almost silently on conveyor belts at the ITT Industries factory here. From the spotless white floors to the cool, filtered air to the young workers in white hair nets and white plastic laboratory coats, the factory seems more suited to the production of computer components than auto parts. **********Far different are the cavernous buildings in Dayton, Ohio, filled with endless rows of clanking, roaring machinery, where the General Motors Corporation makes brakes for nearly all its cars and trucks. A few rusting fans  hang from the exposed support beams, the only relief when temperatures soar above 100 degrees in the summer. The floors are concrete painted black, and the  air smells of oil and sweat. The workers, mostly graying men in their 40's and 50's, wear greasy orange jump suits or blue jeans -- and nobody has a hairnet. **********Across America, executives at big companies like G.M. are looking at their less efficient operations with dismay and trying to find ways to buy more parts  from low-cost outside vendors like ITT. By buying more of their parts, executives can save money and keep their businesses competitive; for them, the difference between G.M.'s factories in Dayton and ITT's plant here is the difference between yesterday and tomorrow. **********But for many workers, the executives' tomorrow is a frightening prospect. G.M.'s unionized employees in Dayton earn about $19 an hour, and when they get sick they can go to almost any doctor, paying no deductible and a minuscule co-payment. ITT's nonunion workers earn $9.90 an hour and choose their doctors from the lists of two health maintenance organizations. **********The contrast between the two brake plants makes stark the logic that has compelled so many manufacturers to shift jobs to low-cost, outside suppliers over the last decade, as well as the uphill -- if not quixotic -- resistance from labor unions. **********Because of the United Automobile Workers union's success in driving up wages  and benefits at the Big Three auto makers, the savings from buying outside parts are especially large in the auto industry. Wages and fringe benefits at the average auto parts factory are only a third of what the Big Three pay their unionized workers. As a result, the parts industry has become a front line in the battle between management and labor over corporate downsizing. **********But outsourcing is a prime cost-saving strategy throughout the economy, from  the insurance company that replaces its security guards and cafeteria workers with outside contractors to manufacturing giants like the Boeing Company, which  buys airplane parts from factories in Japan, Mexico and Xian, China, that its own employees once fabricated in the United States. **********With the most to lose, labor unions have fought a largely unsuccessful rear guard action against the shifting of jobs to outside contractors. In settling a  strike last year, Boeing pledged only to look for other jobs for workers displaced by foreign parts purchases and to notify its union of future plans for the purchase of outside parts. **********Similarly, the 17-day strike last month at G.M.'s Dayton brake factories stemmed largely from worker objections to four G.M. contracts to buy outside brake parts. G.M. settled the strike with a pledge to hire 417 more workers in Dayton and inform the union about future plans for parts purchases; the four contracts remain in place. **********Indeed, Timothy D. Leuliette, the president of ITT Industries' automotive operations, declared in a speech earlier this year that it was inevitable that auto makers would buy more parts from outside suppliers, because the public was  demanding affordable cars. "Fighting to defend higher-cost jobs in an industry undergoing strategic restructuring ultimately can have little success," Mr. Leuliette said. **********The U.A.W. contends that the problem lies with corporations that would rather turn to outside vendors than invest the money in their old factories. **********"They're fooling themselves when they say we've got to compete with other factories that have the best techniques, that have the best manufacturing processes," said Richard Shoemaker, the U.A.W. vice president who oversees relations with G.M. "They have an obligation to put money in the plants." **********The issues are seldom drawn as clearly as by comparing ITT's factory here with G.M.'s two brake plants in Dayton. **********Morale is high at the ITT factory, partly because of a collegial relationship between managers and the nonunionized workers. Walk the immaculate factory floor here and the cheerfulness is unmistakable. **********"I like it a lot," said Deanna Cayton, a 26-year-old worker who paused as she assembled brake valves. "The people are great, the work's not hard; it's clean,  very clean." **********W. Steve Dickerson, the plant manager here, dresses much like his workers, wearing a short-sleeve green polo shirt on one recent day and putting on a hairnet and white plastic laboratory coat before going on the factory floor. He  knows the workers by name and talks easily with them about their families.    ITT manufactures brakes for all the Big Three auto makers. When the factory won a Ford Motor Company quality award last year, ITT spent $50,000 on a lavish  party in which Mr. Dickerson and other managers dressed in tuxedos and served roast beef to the 900 workers. **********Yet ITT's intentions in throwing the party were not just philanthropic. "In the next two weeks, we picked up $200,000 in productivity," Mr. Dickerson said. **********Even before last month's strike, morale was terrible in Dayton. Some workers  there refer to the factories as the "state prison." They labor under the watchful eye of security guards and foremen. Few workers smile or wave as Daniel E. Warrell, the factory manager, strides by in his dark blue pin stripe suit. **********The floors in Dayton are filthy, with oily slime in spots. When an aide to Mr. Warrell reached down recently to pick up an oil-sodden, crushed cardboard box in an aisle, the factory manager waved him away. "That's O.K.," he said. He  later apologized for his factory's dirty appearance, for which he blamed the need to bring production back to normal quickly after the strike. **********Another reason is that Dayton factories do produce some mechanical parts not  made in Asheville, contributing to difference in noise and dirt between the factories. **********While the Dayton factories had a cookout last year, there were no parties or  big staff gatherings when the strike ended. "Management had meetings," Mr. Warrell said, but relied on the foremen to talk to the assembly workers. **********The sheer complexity of the union work rules agreed to by management over the years at the G.M. factories make management's own job much more difficult. Partly because the Dayton factories produce a wider range of parts, but mostly because of the work rules, the G.M. brake operations have 35 different categories of semiskilled workers, including those who work on the assembly line. There are also 16 categories of skilled workers, like electricians. **********ITT has only two categories of semiskilled workers in Asheville, and skilled  workers are on salary. The company buys most of its equipment from outside vendors and asks employees to change work assignments frequently, partly to keep their jobs interesting. "We never get into 'It's not my job,' " Mr. Dickerson said. **********The difference in labor-management relations is particularly striking when it comes to the sharing of information. **********In Dayton, one of the strikers' demands was that G.M. begin telling them more about future brake plans.  But in Asheville, without strikes or union contracts, Mr. Dickerson makes monthly presentations to assembly line workers. He provided  a detailed appraisal in late March of the factory's contracts and business plans for the next several years, even discussing a $650 million Ford contract that ITT did not disclose publicly until the following week. **********But while the Asheville factory may offer a much more pleasant, open work environment, the pay and benefits are considerably inferior to G.M.'s. Workers in Dayton earn an average of $69,000 a year, including close to $30,000 in overtime from working six- and seven-day weeks. ITT's workers earn around $20,000 a year, with little overtime available. **********Yet the workers here have few complaints about their pay. One of the reasons  is a basic shift in American society: the young, married employees typically have working spouses, so they have two incomes to support their households. By contrast, many U.A.W. workers in Dayton still support their families on a single paycheck. **********But the bigger reason for workers' acceptance of lower pay here is that the burden of history weighs much less heavily on Asheville, where pay scales have long been much lower than in the industrial Midwest. **********The Asheville factory stands on land that used to belong to the Biltmore Estate, which surrounds the 250-room French chateau built in 1895 by George Vanderbilt as a bucolic summer retreat. ITT was the first big auto parts company to build a factory in the area, setting up operations in 1989. The main competitor then for industrial workers was a Burlington Industries textile factory that paid $7.50 an hour and closed in 1991. At $9.90 an hour, the wages  at ITT seem generous. **********"The pay is great," said Malina Mcasee, a 39-year-old former Burlington worker, as she used tweezers to insert a pin into each anti-lock brake passing on the assembly line.  The health care benefits are also the best in the area, said Ms. Cayton, who is expecting a baby in mid-May. **********The burden of history is very different at G.M.'s factories. Dayton has been  a high-wage, unionized town of skilled industrial workers for generations. One of the G.M. plants bears a small historical marker noting that the Wright Brothers built some of their first commercial airplanes at the site. **********In the late 1980's, G.M. was a pioneer in making anti-lock brakes, and the units turned out by the Dayton factories rely more on mechanical parts than the  electronic gear at the heart of ITT's slightly less expensive but equally reliable brakes. **********Now, G.M. plans to install a "clean room" production line for highly sophisticated electronic brakes inside one of the Dayton plants by 1998. And while that will not eliminate the differences between the Dayton and Asheville operations, it likely means more U.A.W. members will be wearing hairnets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/03/world.main_headline: Soweto Journal;Dreamer With a Bookstore Wakes to Fiscal Facts
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/03/world.print_headline: Soweto Journal;Dreamer With a Bookstore Wakes to Fiscal Facts
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/03/world.body_text: **********Soweto's first bookstore is now one year old. It is still the only bookstore  in this immense black township. That probably won't be true for long. **********If its owner, Solomon Sikakane, is right, there may be three in local townships soon. If his wife, Edith, is right, soon there will be none. **********Mr. Sikakane, a retired school administrator, says that his Imfundo Thuto bookstore in the new Dobsonville Mall here is a labor of love. "I'm not looking  at this on a profit basis," he said at the opening last year. "I'm looking at it as the social upliftment of my people." **********Still, a book lover has to eat. The Sikakanes are barely able to pay the $450 monthly rent on the store. **********The small store has few shelves, and a lot of air between the books.  Many are simply samples of what can be ordered. Even the impulse buys -- the daily papers -- are in very short stacks. The store has a handsome display stand for Nelson Mandela's autobiography, "Long Walk to Freedom," but no copies. **********"Even today, someone will ask for it -- Mandela, Mandela, Mandela," said Mrs. Sikakane from behind the counter one recent morning. "But we have no capital, and the publisher will not give them in advance." **********Mr. Sikakane has great dreams. Developers planning the first malls in nearby  Kagiso and Tembisa townships have asked about franchising the name Imfundo Thuto, which means Education, Education in Nguni and Sotho, the country's two African language groups. A New York office supply company is talking about a partnership printing school stationery -- if he can find interested schools and  build a printing plant. A Denver bookstore owner wants to distribute books about black Americans through him -- if he can build a customer base. **********But all these things take capital, which Mr. Sikakane, like many would-be businessmen in South Africa's black townships, does not have.  He lacks the retail experience to qualify for bank loans. He is applying for small-business grants from the World Bank and the United States Agency for International Development, but grant-writing is a skill that is foreign to him, so he has an American friend helping him with that. **********Suddenly, the police are at the door. Mr. Sikakane brightens at the sight of  one of his best customers, Tiro Matshoe, a trainee patrolman with the Soweto Traffic Department.  His request almost too perfectly illustrates the store's predicament. **********Officer Matshoe wants the complete works of William Shakespeare.  "To expand  my knowledge," he explains. "I meet members of the public, and I want to be able to quote from Shakespeare. Because I think of being a leader someday." **********Virtually any other South African bookstore would have the book, which costs  about $15 wholesale. Mr. Sikakane does not, and it is a mark of Officer Matshoe's loyalty that he is willing to wait a week for the order. **********He is followed by Gugu Ngema, who heads adult education at Funda Community College here. As part of his desire to "build a culture of learning" in Soweto,  Mr. Ngema wants to order his textbooks through Mr. Sikakane's store instead of sending students to stores "that really cater for the needs of white people." But, he said, he faces resistance from a surprising source. **********"A lot of my colleagues are still worried about whether you can get quality service from a fellow African," Mr. Ngema said. "I have to use my powers to convince them -- and to be ready to fight." **********When he started a year ago, Mr. Sikakane had no retailing experience.  He met his former partner, a white housewife named Barbara Malk, through a group trying to start a library in Soweto, where 80 percent of adults read below seventh-grade level. In February, Mrs. Malk remarried and moved to Cape Town, withdrawing from the partnership. **********Imfundo Thuto is in the first real shopping mall in this virtually all-black  city, which may be home to as many as four million people. Under apartheid laws, blacks were mot allowed to own businesses, though there were spazzas -- informal living-room stores. Even now, black enterprise is in its infancy: several of the mall's shops are Indian-owned, and the larger ones are chain stores. Fortunately for Mr. Sikakane, neither of the country's two large bookstore chains has yet taken a chance on the malls slowly springing up in black townships. **********Although the store just had its first birthday, Mr. Sikakane is delaying the  celebration until October because that is when Clara Villarosa, the owner of the Hue-Man Experience African-American Bookstore in Denver, Colo., is supposed to arrive.  She has promised to ship him hundreds of used children's books, which will be collected by African-American bookstores in the States from their customers. Mr. Sikakane wants to give them to children here. **********Ms. Villarosa met Mr. Sikakane last year on a trade mission by black American entrepreneurs. She came hoping to sell new books. Now she is collecting used ones to give away. **********"Everybody else found business opportunities," she said. "I found a philanthropic mission. You do what you have to do. I like that old man."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/12/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;New Credit Line For Deutsche Babcock
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/12/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;New Credit Line For Deutsche Babcock
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/12/busin.body_text: **********Deutsche Babcock A.G. said yesterday that its banks had agreed to provide 600 million marks ($393 million) in a new credit line for a drastic reorganization of the company, an unprofitable German factory builder and machinery maker. The  reorganization includes plans to sell the company's special machinery unit, Schumag A.G. **********"Details of the restructuring concept of the 'new' Babcock will be released  in coming weeks," the company said. Deutsche Babcock expects a loss in 1996 of 400 million marks. It attributes the loss primarily to the costs of reorganization and losses at some noncore units.   (Bloomberg Business News)

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/21/busin.main_headline: COMPANY NEWS;MANHATTAN BAGEL REPORTS ACCOUNTING IRREGULARITIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/21/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;MANHATTAN BAGEL REPORTS ACCOUNTING IRREGULARITIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/21/busin.body_text: **********The Manhattan Bagel Company said yesterday that it had found improper accounting at its I& J West Coast unit and would have to restate its financial results for the first quarter. Manhattan Bagel, a chain of bagel shops that is based in Eatontown, N.J., said it would also investigate other possible financial irregularities. The company will reduce its first-quarter earnings per share to 9 cents from the 12 cents previously reported. The announcement was made after the markets closed. Earlier, the company's shares fell $4.875, to $21.25, in Nasdaq trading.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/20/world.snippet: Two Israeli border policemen are arrested and denounced by Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu as unfit to serve after amateur videotape shows them beating and kicking Palestinians near checkpoint outside Jerusalem; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/20/world.main_headline: A Tape Shows Israeli Police Beating Arabs
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/20/world.print_headline: A Tape Shows Israeli Police Beating Arabs
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/20/world.body_text: **********Captured on an amateur videotape as they beat and kicked Palestinians near a checkpoint outside Jerusalem, two Israeli border policemen were arrested today and denounced by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as unfit to serve in the Israeli security forces. **********The beating was filmed by a Palestinian onlooker and shown on national television on Monday night, raising concerns that it was part of a broader pattern of violence against Arabs by police officers and soldiers. **********The images of the officers assaulting six West Bank men who had tried to enter Israel without work permits prompted a swift response today from police and Government officials. The officers were ordered held for 48 hours and questioned, and face possible charges of aggravated assault and abuse of authority. **********Mr. Netanyahu said the officers, Yitzhak Shmaaya and David Ben-Abu, had acted ''in a criminal fashion'' toward the Palestinians. **********''These two soldiers, who acted the way they did, unraveled a norm that is accepted by all army soldiers,'' the Prime Minister told reporters. ''We are not prepared to accept it. I'm not prepared to tolerate it. And people who behave like that are not fit to be in our security forces.'' **********Public Security Minister Avigdor Kahalani said he was shocked by the beating, adding that it required a thorough examination of the sources of such violence. ''This is a culture I don't know,'' he said. ''It is really something very exceptional.'' **********Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, said in Gaza, ''It was shameful, and I hope the Israeli Government will take measures and steps against this crime.'' **********The officers, stationed on the border between the West Bank and the northern outskirts of Jerusalem, were videotaped on Oct. 10 by a Palestinian who saw them from an apartment window, much like the amateur cameraman who filmed Los Angeles police officers beating the motorist Rodney King in 1991. **********The Palestinian, Azzam Maraka, said that although he had been beaten himself several times and wanted the pictures broadcast, he had initially held them back because he did not think they would produce results. ''It happens a lot, and I said what good will it do,'' Mr. Maraka said in a television interview. **********In his videotape the officers are seen kicking the Palestinians in the head and in the groin, forcing them to do pushups and slapping them as they sat bent forward, their hands behind their heads. Mr. Maraka said he had taped the scene for an hour. **********''This is not an isolated case,'' the chief of the border police, Yisrael Sadan, acknowledged after a talk with the officers' unit. ''It is an isolated case that was photographed.'' **********Palestinians crossing Israeli checkpoints often complain of beatings and humiliation by Israeli soldiers and border policemen. **********The problem of lenient punishment emerged in sharp relief on Sunday, when a military court fined four members of an army undercover unit the equivalent of one-third of a cent for killing a Palestinian at a checkpoint in the West Bank in 1993. **********Although they convicted the soldiers of violating firing orders, the judges ruled that they could not have acted differently under the circumstances. The soldiers said they had shot at a suspicious-looking car when it backed away from their checkpoint at night. The Palestinian driver said he had stopped at the checkpoint before the car was fired on. The military prosecutor's office said it would appeal the sentence.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/22/world.body_text: **********Leaders of the European Union's 15 member countries agreed today to a plan that would gradually allow the British to resume exporting beef. In response, Britain ended its monthlong disruption of the union's decision-making. **********But exports would resume only after experts from all 15 countries certified to its Executive Commission in Brussels that the meat was free of contamination  from the so-called mad cow disease, a fatal brain disease that has undermined consumer confidence in all beef. Consumption of meat from infected animals has been tentatively linked to a fatal brain disease in humans. **********Prime Minister John Major and his ministers said their tough tactics had forced the Europeans to give in on the ban on British beef exports. But the agreement laid down no dates for when the ban might be lifted, and it left key decisions firmly in the hands of the Brussels bureaucrats who are the nemesis of the rebellious anti-European wing of Mr. Major's Conservative Party. **********Mr. Major will thus have some convincing to do in Parliament when he presents the plan on Monday. **********Foreign Minister Malcolm Rifkind said the Prime Minister would try to give Parliament an idea of when exports of grass-fed veal and other beef products thought to be least risky might resume. **********Mr. Rifkind also said the European leaders had agreed to let Britain sell beef to non-European countries if anybody wanted to buy it before the general embargo was lifted. But only South Africa, he conceded, had expressed any interest. **********But he appeared to be grasping at a bare bone, an ambiguous, nonbinding statement by Prime Minister Romano Prodi of Italy saying the Executive Commission would ask its experts for advice on requests by third countries to buy British beef. The experts would be extremely unlikely to let the British sell beef to others before it was certified safe for consumption by Europeans. **********"The two objectives that were indicated by my Prime Minister as far as noncooperation is concerned have now been achieved," Mr. Rifkind said. He was referring to a European decision this month to let Britain resume exporting gelatin, tallow and semen from cattle, and today's proposal for lifting the rest of the ban; both decisions came after Britain had vetoed close to 100 routine European Union actions in the last month. **********Most of the blocked measures were technical ones, or statements of policy like support for anti-corruption measures. Britain did make some exceptions, like allowing Slovenia to conclude an association agreement with the European Union. **********"Our policy of noncooperation now ceases, as of now," Mr. Rifkind said, ending the most vigorous display of sovereign cantankerousness in Europe since France tried a similar tactic three decades ago. **********European leaders repeatedly denounced the British tactic as unworthy, and the president of the European Parliament, Klaus Hansch of Germany, urged the leaders, meeting in Macchiavelli's hometown, to live up to his dictum that princes should solve problems before public emotions made them unsolvable. **********The British have challenged the beef embargo in the European Court of Justice as an illegal ganging up of 14 members against one, and expect a ruling within weeks. **********But the worst of the crisis appears to be over, allowing leaders to turn to other pressing problems, like the 10 percent unemployment rate besetting the continent and disarray in their attempt to revise decision-making procedures to  prepare for an influx of new Central European members in the next century. **********The Executive Commission imposed the worldwide ban on British beef exports on March 27, a week after the British Government disclosed that scientists had concluded that a link between a degenerative brain disease that has afflicted more than 100,000 head of cattle in the United Kingdom and a similar disease in  people could not be ruled out. **********That statement seemed to make nonsense of years of previous British Government assertions that mad cow disease, bovine spongiform encephalopathy, was nothing to worry about. Suddenly it seemed possible that Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease, which destroys the human brain, could be contracted from eating meat or meat products from cows with the bovine disease. **********At least 11 young adults in Britain and 1 in France have come down with Creutzfeldt-Jakob since the mad cow outbreak started in Britain in the late 1980's. In the past, most people who contracted the rare disease have been elderly. **********The source of the bovine disease is thought to be animal feed from processed  offal and other parts of slaughtered sheep, which are susceptible to a degenerative brain disorder known as scrapies. Britain banned the use of such feeds for cattle in 1990, but did not totally ban the use of meat and bonemeal in all animal feeds until last March. **********To get today's European agreement to lift the embargo on beef exports, the British have also agreed to immediate culling of up to 147,000 head of cattle that scientists have identified as being at particularly high risk of the disease, if Parliament will agree to the slaughter. **********The British have also agreed not to sell beef to anyone from animals over 30  months old, the ones most likely to have come into direct or indirect contact with other infected animals or the infected feeds, and will slaughter a million  such animals over the next year, according to the Government. **********The European plan, adopted in the context of what it called "considerable misgiving about the effectiveness of past actions taken by the U.K.," requires the British to submit evidence that the cattle disease has been eliminated from  the various classes of beef they want to start exporting. **********Step by step, after consulting its experts, the Executive Commission can then recommend governments a gradual relaxation of the ban. **********"Such decisions will be taken only and exclusively on the basis of public health and objective scientific criteria and of the judgment of the commission that these criteria have been satisfied," leaders here agreed. **********But it is consumers who will determine how much British beef will be sold abroad, and millions of them right now will not even buy beef that butchers swear does not even have distant relatives across the Channel. One sign of the crisis for farmers is that the leaders also agreed today to stock a relief fund  with more than $1 billion.

At the same time, Norfolk reaffirmed its all-cash $100-a-share offer for Conrail. On Oct. 23, Norfolk Southern announced a hostile offer intended at upending a friendly merger between CSX and Conrail.
