https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/19/world.main_headline: Peres and Arafat, After Talks, Agree to Revive Peace Efforts
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/19/world.print_headline: Peres and Arafat, After Talks, Agree to Revive Peace Efforts
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/19/world.body_text: **********Under the shadow of the fighting in Lebanon, Prime Minister Shimon Peres and  the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat agreed today to revive their peace efforts,  which had been suspended after a spate of suicide bombings in Israel by Palestinian militants. **********The two leaders, in their first meeting since the bombings, held talks at the Erez checkpoint on the northern edge of the Gaza Strip. They emerged after two hours to announce that they would move forward with the agreements on Palestinian self-rule signed by Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization in 1993 and last September. **********The meeting took place before either leader had learned of today's disaster, in which Israeli forces shelled a United Nations base crowded with Lebanese refugees, killing scores. **********"We have agreed to go ahead and fulfill the different parts of the agreement," Mr. Peres said right after their meeting, adding that talks on a permanent peace settlement would begin on schedule on May 4. The talks are supposed to cover such difficult issues as the future of Jerusalem, Jewish settlements and Palestinian refugees. **********Mr. Peres had suspended contacts with the Palestinians and delayed an army withdrawal from most of Hebron after the suicide attacks, demanding that Mr. Arafat crack down on Islamic militants. Mr. Peres indicated today that he was satisfied with Mr. Arafat's efforts. **********Mahmoud Abbas, a senior P.L.O. official who joined Mr. Arafat at the meeting, told Reuters that the two sides had agreed on a withdrawal in Hebron before the  Israeli national elections on May 29. **********Mr. Arafat said that the P.L.O.'s policy-making body, the Palestine National  Council, would meet on Monday to change the organization's charter, which calls  for Israel's destruction. **********The National Council will meet for two days, Mr. Arafat said, "to fulfill what had been promised from our side concerning the covenant." Under the accords with Israel, clauses calling for its destruction in the P.L.O. charter, known as the Palestinian National Covenant, must be changed by May 7. A senior aide to Mr. Arafat predicted this week that the charter would be replaced by a new document. **********In preparation for the planned meeting in Gaza, Israel has allowed council members from abroad, including leaders of militant P.L.O. factions, to return to the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Leila Khaled, who gained notoriety as an airplane  hijacker, crossed into the West Bank today from Jordan. She has vowed to vote against any change in the charter. **********Mr. Arafat needs a two-thirds majority in the National Council to amend the charter, but may encounter resistance from opposition factions and other council members critical of his policies. **********"We will do our best without harming democracy," Mr. Arafat said. "I am committed to what I have agreed. I will call the P.N.C. between April 22 and 24  but I cannot guarantee. It is our democracy." **********The two leaders announced that Israeli-Palestinian committees would resume meetings on a range of issues, including the pullback in Hebron, economic concerns and travel by Palestinians through Israel between the West Bank and Gaza Strip. **********Mr. Arafat said he had briefed Mr. Peres on his efforts to combat Islamic militant groups responsible for four suicide attacks in February and March that  killed 63 people, including the four bombers. Hundreds of members of the Hamas and Islamic Holy War groups were arrested by Mr. Arafat's security forces in the wake of the bombings. **********Mr. Peres said that the Palestinian Authority had "begun really to fight the  terror which is a common danger to the Palestinians, to us and to peace." **********"No doubt the Palestinian Authority has prevented a few cases of infiltration into Israel, and it undoubtedly jailed some of the leaders of Hamas," Mr. Peres  added. "I got the impression that the Palestinian Authority is making very serious efforts to track down those who have not yet been caught." **********On issues of security, Mr. Peres concluded, Israel and the Palestinians "see  eye to eye."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/18/world.main_headline: Ex-Premier Goes on Trial In Milan For Bribery
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/18/world.print_headline: Ex-Premier Goes on Trial In Milan For Bribery
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/18/world.body_text: **********Former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi went on trial in Milan today on charges of corruption that he says were fabricated to destroy his political career. **********The accusations against the media baron-turned-politician -- that companies he owns paid large bribes to Government tax inspectors in exchange for favorable audits -- grew out of the investigations into scandals in Italy that discredited a generation of political and business leaders, and haunt their successors. **********Mr. Berlusconi, 59, appeared at Milan's Palace of Justice with three other defendants, all Government tax officials. Six other defendants, including Mr. Berlusconi's younger brother, Paolo, availed themselves of the right not to appear. **********Mr. Berlusconi has publicly acknowledged that units of his company, Fininvest, paid bribes, but he says they were extorted. **********"It's a question of seeing whether they were the fruit of intentional force,  of intentional extortion, or not," he told reporters today. **********Moreover, while admitting the illegal payments, his defense is built around the contention that he never authorized or was informed of them. **********"Either there is testimonial and documentary proof by which they can succeed  in demonstrating that I authorized these payments, or there is not," he said. "If there is not, the rest is mere conjecture." **********According to the prosecution, officers of four companies in the Fininvest group paid tax inspectors $240,000 in bribes. **********Mr. Berlusconi built Fininvest, a $7 billion-a-year media conglomerate, in the 1980's on a combination of hard work and political cronyism. In 1994, he left the company in the hands of old friends and business associates to enter politics. **********He swept to victory in 1994 national elections, but his government lasted only seven months before his coalition came apart and he was forced to resign. Since then, Mr. Berlusconi has issued repeated battle cries for fresh national elections. That eventuality grew nearer last week, after his successor, Lamberto Dini, was also forced to resign. **********Mr. Berlusconi has repeatedly asserted that the investigations into supposed  corrupt practices at Fininvest are part of political moves by Italy's left wing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/27/busin.snippet: Treasury securities prices are mixed; 30-year bond falls 7/32, to 100 26/32, to yield 6.44%; graph (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/27/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury securities turned mixed yesterday, gaining early on signs that consumer confidence is not rising and that the economy is not growing rapidly, only to fall as some traders began to take profits. **********Analysts said market participants began unloading securities after the price on the benchmark Treasury bond had risen enough to push its yield down to 6.37 percent, the lowest since March 4 and a key resistance level for technical traders. **********The 30-year bond finished the New York session down 7/32, to a price of 100 26/32 to yield 6.44 percent, up from 6.42 percent on Monday, but still down near its eight-month-low levels. **********The Conference Board's November reading of consumer confidence was unchanged at 107.3 from October's reading. Market reaction to the data was minimal, with early buying caused by the report drying up quickly. However, prices of Treasury securities remained firm in thin trading as the market next reacted favorably to a report by the Philadelphia Federal Reserve that economists it had surveyed expected slower growth in the fourth quarter. Market watchers also noted that there was year-end portfolio squaring by some dealers, which gave the market some of that early support, as money managers bought securities with longer maturities. **********Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said that although the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index for November was unchanged, consumer confidence was still quite buoyant, and certainly created a conducive environment for a favorable Christmas shopping season. He expects to see more evidence of that in today's release of the University of Michigan's Consumer Sentiment Index. **********Other economic statistics are to be released today, but Mr. Fine does not anticipate that any of them will change the market's psyche. Third- quarter G.D.P. is expected to be revised downward, mainly as a result of lower inventory levels. The Chicago Purchasing Managers Index is expected to show only modest gains in that region's industrial sector, and a decline in October durable goods orders is foreseen. **********''But all the recent data are very much in line with what the great preponderance of economic statistics have been indicating for some time,'' Mr. Fine said, ''a moderating economy, but one that is certainly not faltering.'' He added, ''Neither is the economy growing quickly enough to warrant fear about an overheating that could produce inflationary pressures.'' **********The yield curve, Mr. Fine said, is likely to remain in a neutral Fed position. ''At the same time the long end seems bounded by the continued sustainable growth of the economy setting a floor on yields in one hand, while on the other hand, the lack of inflationary pressures puts a cap on how high yields can go,'' he continued. **********Analysts noted also that the long end of the government securities market was being pressured by issuance of corporate debt, which competes for investor dollars. **********Stephen W. Carter, an analyst at MCM Corporate Watch, said about $1.56 billion of fresh investment- grade corporate debt was priced yesterday, including $750 million of 30-year capital securities issued by JPM Capital Trust I, a financing vehicle of J. P. Morgan & Company. **********The bank capital notes, as they are called, are a new debtlike trust preferred stock.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/10/busin.main_headline: ECONOMIC SCENE : Asia Looks to Norway for Oil Diversity
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/10/busin.print_headline: ECONOMIC SCENE : Asia Looks to Norway for Oil Diversity
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/10/busin.body_text: **********When Marcel P. Kramer, president and corporate representative for the Asia-Pacific region of Statoil, Norway's national oil company, called a meeting earlier this year of regional refiners to discuss prospects for sales of Norwegian oil, he was pleasantly surprised by the turnout and initial results. **********Asia's voracious appetite for oil to fuel its rapid economic growth and industrialization is prompting countries in the area to turn to increasingly distant sources of supply, partly to offset their heavy dependence on the volatile Gulf. **********With Asia-Pacific oil production lagging way behind demand, the region's net oil imports reached 10.3 million barrels per day in 1995, up 45 percent from 1990. **********About 60 percent of East Asia's oil consumption is imported, nearly all of it from the Middle East. If demand continues to grow as expected, the region's oil dependence on the Gulf will increase from 55 percent in 1995, to 59 percent in the year 2000, and to 61 percent in 2005. **********"Most Asian countries will become increasingly dependent on imported oil in the next 15 years, and the major source of supply will be a small number of countries in the politically fragile Middle East," said John P. Ferriter, deputy executive director of the International Energy Agency in Paris. "Supply diversity adds to oil security." **********A couple of years ago, East Asia started to tap West African production. Imports of West African oil are expected to average about 400,000 barrels per day in 1996, up from about 80,000 in 1994, when the first sustained shipments began. **********Fereidun Fesharaki, director of the program on resources at the East-West **********Center in Hawaii, said he expected to see East Asia begin importing "substantial amounts of North Sea oil in the next year or two because the demand is there." **********Many Asian refineries are not equipped to process Middle East oil and prefer to avoid making expensive modifications by importing oil that is low in sulfur and high in gasoline content. North Sea and West African oil meets those requirements. **********Some 40 firms, representing about 16 million barrels per day in oil refining capacity, showed up at the Singapore meeting convened by Norway's Statoil in March. **********They account for the great majority of the oil that is refined to make gasoline, jet fuel, diesel, naphtha and other products for Asia's transportation, power, manufacturing and petrochemical industries. **********Despite the fact that it takes more than three times as long and costs twice as much to ship oil from the North Sea to Singapore as it does from the Middle East, Taiwan's China Petroleum Development Corp. has started to buy Norwegian oil on a regular basis. **********Mr. Fesharaki said that other Asian refiners were expected to follow as West African oil production and prices peaked, making the economics of North Sea supply attractive. **********Statoil says it takes a large tanker from the North Sea 38 days to reach Singapore at a cost of $1.10 per barrel of oil, compared to 30 days at 95 cents from West Africa. **********Norway is one of the world's largest oil exporters. Statoil sells 2 million barrels per day, mainly to European refineries. But up to 600,000 barrels per day are exported to the United States and Canada. **********"If we can get a return at least equal to North America, we would be happy to sell to Asian customers," Mr. Kramer said. "We are not interested in subsidized sales, but we are trying to expand our market in places where it makes economic sense."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/15/busin.main_headline: Agency Tests a New Kind of Public Hearing
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/15/busin.print_headline: Agency Tests a New Kind of Public Hearing
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/15/busin.body_text: **********In a nationwide multimedia experiment that redefined the limits of a public hearing, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission linked its new World Wide Web site with the video conferencing system of four Kinko's copy shops around the country on Jan. 5 for a session on fire protection rules at nuclear power plants. The session married two media: the Web, in a real-time dialogue, and the video conferencing at Kinko's, whichallowed people in different cities to see and hear each other and interact. It was an experiment that the commission was not committed to repeating, but which it had hoped would be a milestone for a new way to conduct business. **********No matter the outcome of the experiment, commission officials said that it could only be an improvement over the current system. William J. Olmstead, the commission's associate general counsel who served as master of ceremonies at the video conference, said that when he was a law student in Topeka, Kan., he was frustrated by not being able to attend hearings in Washington on affirmative action rules. **********The new program, he said, "allows you to go to the public meeting anywhere in the U.S." **********Top commission officials left their headquarters in Rockville, a suburb of Washington, for a Kinko's across the street, to address agency officials and members of the public who had gathered at Kinko's in Atlanta, Chicago and Philadelphia and in a Sprint video conference room in Irving, Tex. **********More agency officials had gathered at a video conference room at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, in Livermore, Calif. With them was a court reporter who produced a transcription of the proceedings with a delay of less than two minutes, so that anyone on the Web could monitor the discussions and send in questions. **********And off in a corner of the Kinko's in Rockville, a Sprint employee kept an open phone line to the room at Lawrence Livermore to make sure it all stayed connected. **********It did, sort of. **********People on the Web could send messages to Lawrence Livermore, where a conference facilitator would read them aloud to the video participants. But many comments he got merely complained that the transcript had stopped scrolling across the screen. **********"Press 'more' at the bottom of your screen," the facilitator, John Helie, advised, speaking to the camera. The comment was put on the Web. "Of course," he added, "they'll probably have to click on 'more' in order to get that information." **********The conference was scheduled to last an hour but with only two substantive questions coming in over the Web, it was adjourned after 52 minutes. Dr. Shirley Jackson, the commission's chairwoman, said the experiment might be repeated, depending on what happened on the agency's "Rulenet" Web page, which is available through the commission's home page. **********The commission is using the page to gather comment before it drafts a new rule on fire protection. Normally, public comments solicited as part of rule-making are submitted in writing and those submitting them cannot see the comments of others; on Rulenet they can read each other's postings and reply to  one and all. **********Mr. Helie said he would draft statements, post them for at least 24 hours and ask participants to vote, by clicking on a scale of one to six, ranging from agreement to strenuous objection. Then, he said in the video conference, he would refine the statements and call for a ballot vote. **********The statements, votes, comments and everything else submitted to the page are to be used by the commission staff in drafting a new rule.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/17/busin.main_headline: Kerkorian Group Plans to Buy MGM Studio for $1.3 Billion
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/17/busin.print_headline: Kerkorian Group Plans to Buy MGM Studio for $1.3 Billion
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/17/busin.body_text: **********Kirk Kerkorian is back in show business. Mr. Kerkorian, the wily billionaire  who bought and sold Metro Goldwyn Mayer Inc. twice before, is buying it one more time. **********The French bank Credit Lyonnais, which owns the ailing film company, said yesterday that it had accepted a $1.3 billion offer from an investment group led by Mr. Kerkorian's holding company, the Tracinda Corporation. **********The Kerkorian group includes MGM's chairman, Frank Mancuso; Seven Network Group Ltd., an Australian broadcasting company that is 15 percent owned by the News Corporation, and J. P. Morgan & Company. **********The group beat out rival offers from Polygram N.V., a subsidiary of Philips Electronics N.V., and the film company Morgan Creek Productions. **********The News Corporation was initially an independent bidder, but executives familiar with the negotiations said it was not willing to spend more than $1 billion for the studio. **********Under Mr. Mancuso, who was brought in by Credit Lyonnais in 1993, MGM has cut its losses, but the company has still been running out of cash in recent months. **********Tracinda will put up $650 million of the purchase price, with $250 million coming from Seven Network. J. P. Morgan will provide $800 million in financing. **********Mr. Kerkorian was a latecomer to the bidding for MGM, having become involved  last week. But he has a long history with MGM, having originally bought the company in 1969 and then sold it to the Turner Broadcasting System in 1986. He subsequently bought back much of the company, only to resell it in 1990 to Giancarlo Parretti, the Italian financier who later lost it to Credit Lyonnais. **********Mr. Kerkorian and other members of his group did not comment. **********The 79-year-old Mr. Kerkorian had known Mr. Mancuso from the days when Mr. Mancuso ran Paramount Pictures and Mr. Kerkorian owned MGM. The two companies jointly owned United International Pictures, which distributed their films overseas. **********In the recent round of bids, the Kerkorian group had an advantage because it  has no other film production companies. MGM has an agreement to distribute the home video versions of its films through Warner Brothers, and other bidders like Polygram were concerned that Warner might insist on distributing their films as  well. **********That issue was particularly crucial for Polygram, a large film producer that  already has alternative distribution agreements, and it was apparently a factor  in the News Corporation's reluctance to pursue a bid; it owns the 20th Century Fox studio. **********Morgan Creek already distributes its films through Warner Brothers. **********In recent years, Mr. Kerkorian has added to his fortune by investing heavily  in the Chrysler Corporation. He owns 13.75 percent of Chrysler, a stake that has a market value of $2.9 billion. He also owns 72 percent of the MGM Grand hotel-casino company, with a value of $1.4 billion. He has homes in Las Vegas, Nev., where he spends most of his time, and in Beverly Hills, Calif. **********Credit Lyonnais gained control of MGM in 1992 after Mr. Parretti defaulted on his loan payments to the bank. The bank is believed to have invested nearly $2 billion in MGM, according to The Associated Press, meaning that it is taking a significant loss on the sale. **********Mr. Kerkorian's relationship with Credit Lyonnais has often been bitter. In 1992, Credit Lyonnais sued Mr. Kerkorian in a Los Angeles court, contending that he had left MGM in a financial shambles when he sold it to Mr. Parretti. That suit was settled last year. **********MGM is not in good financial shape. Last year, it reported a net loss of $159.3 million on revenues of $860.9 million, according to documents that were circulated to potential buyers. The bulk of that loss, $102 million, was from operations. But it also included $66 million in interest payments on bank loans. **********Still, those losses were barely a third of MGM's losses in 1993, when Mr. Mancuso took charge. Under his direction, MGM/UA has been on the rebound. Not only has it released a flurry of hits in the last 18 months, but it has also rejuvenated its television operations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/13/busin.main_headline: Siemens Plans To Cut 6,000 More Workers
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/13/busin.print_headline: Siemens Plans To Cut 6,000 More Workers
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/13/busin.body_text: **********Siemens A.G. of Germany, which has made big cuts in its work force, said today that it would dismiss 6,000 more employees in an effort to return to earnings growth in the 1998 fiscal year. **********Siemens, a diversified electronics and engineering giant, said it would  shed about 3 percent of its 203,000 workers in Germany, where labor costs are the highest in the world. **********The cuts will come mostly at its computer manufacturer, Siemens-Nixdorf Informationssysteme A.G., and its plant engineering and power generator units, both of which saw comparable staff cuts last year, the chief financial officer, Karl-Hermann Baumann, said. Jobs will also be lost in the medical engineering unit. **********Heinrich von Pierer, the chief executive, repeated a forecast that profit at Siemens would be unchanged in the current fiscal year as  earnings in its semiconductor business continue to decline. **********''Although we don't anticipate increased earnings in the current year in light of the underlying situation, we expect significant earnings growth again in fiscal 1998,'' Mr. von Pierer said. **********The company surprised investors last month by saying net profit for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30, 1997, would not exceed that of 1996, when its net rose 20 percent, to 2.491 billion marks ($1.617 billion), not including one-time gains. **********That forecast prompted Siemens shares to drop sharply at the time, but today the price rose 15 pfennigs, or two-tenths of 1 percent, to close at 72.8 marks. **********In addition to the problems in its semiconductor business, Siemens is trying to turn around its unprofitable industrial and building systems group. It also expects losses as it reorganizes its medical engineering unit, Mr. von Pierer said. **********''This year is a little bit more difficult, because we don't expect such an upturn of the economy in Germany,'' Mr. von Pierer said in an interview. ''We suffer from recession in the chip market. So I think it would for us be a success if we can keep the high level of profits for this year.'' **********The company will also continue to sell businesses that do not make enough money or do not fit into the organization, Mr. von Pierer said, with the proceeds reinvested in profitable units. Siemens recently sold its high-performance printing unit.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/13/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;COMCAST BUYS NEXTEL STAKE FOR $100 MILLION
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/13/busin.body_text: **********The Comcast Corporation exercised its right to acquire 8.2 million shares of  the wireless telecommunications concern Nextel Communications Inc. for about $100 million, Nextel said yesterday. Comcast's share purchase, which represents  about a 4 percent stake in Nextel, is related to Nextel's $357 million acquisition of Dial Page Inc., which was completed late last month.  Comcast had a right to buy up to 9.7 million Nextel shares initially, but that number was lowered to 8.2 million shares after taking into account the number of shares actually issued in connection with the Dial Page acquisition. Comcast was one of Nextel's first big investors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/09/world.main_headline: South Korea Asks Countries to Press The North on Border
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/09/world.print_headline: South Korea Asks Countries to Press The North on Border
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/09/world.body_text: **********The South Korea Government is asking Japan, China and Russia and other countries, to bring pressure to bear on North Korea to prevent further incursions by North Korean troops into its sensitive border area, a spokesman for South Korea's Foreign Ministry said today. He also said that Seoul is considering bringing the matter to the United Nations Security Council. **********Nevertheless, there was relative calm tonight along the so-called joint security area at the border village of Panmunjon and South Koreans, feeling little threat, mainly went about their normal routines today. **********Bae Ie Dong, executive director of the Federation of Korean Industries, a powerful group representing large South Korean companies, predicted the crisis will be resolved soon. "Some response will have to be made by the South Koreans  and the United States, and the Japanese as well," he said. **********Right now, some elements of the government of South Korea might be happy to let the situation remain as it is, at least until Thursday, when there will be nationwide elections for the National Assembly. **********That is because South Korea's governing party, headed by President Kim, is expected to benefit by appealing to a public desire for stability at a time of crisis. **********Until a few days ago, most analysts assumed that the governing New Korea Party would lose its majority in the legislature because of Mr. Kim's sagging popularity. But now, thanks to North Korea, the election outcome is more difficult to predict. **********A cartoon in one South Korean newspaper portrayed North Korean troops as Kim  Young Sam campaign workers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/28/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Sony, Getting Into PC's, Is Planning a Software Operating System
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/28/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Sony, Getting Into PC's, Is Planning a Software Operating System
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/28/busin.body_text: **********In what would be an audacious move for a Japanese company, the Sony Corporation is planning to develop a new software operating system, officials said today. Such operating systems, the fundamental software controlling computers and some other electronic machines, have been dominated by American companies. **********The officials said Sony did not intend to compete directly with the Microsoft Corporation in personal computer operating systems, but was aiming at the expected market for products that combine computing with audio, video and networking capabilities. **********We would like to develop an operating system that is ideally suited for audiovisual applications," Nobuyuki Idei, Sony's president, said at a news conference called to discuss changes in Sony's corporate structure announced in  January. **********Minoru Morio, Sony's executive deputy president and chief technology officer, said, "As the PC merges with traditional audiovisual products, the office-oriented operating system is not necessarily the best one." The Internet  will also provide opportunities for new operating systems, executives said. **********Sony is entering the personal computer market in the fall, with help from the Intel Corporation. Its first machines will be fairly standard and will use Microsoft's operating system, but the company hopes to introduce more innovative machines, with rich audio and video capabilities, early next year. **********Sony officials did not give details of the operating system but it appeared that it might be based on Apertos, an operating system that Sony has been developing as a research project for several years. Kunitake Ando, president of  Sony's information technology company, said Sony wanted to market Apertos as quickly as possible and would make an announcement about that this year. **********Apertos has a core that requires very little memory to store, which makes it  suitable for consumer electronic devices. But other modules, known as objects, can be added over a network. For instance, the basic software needed to reproduce high- quality sound can be downloaded to a computer or television set  top box just when the consumer wants to receive a broadcast of a concert. Sony has said Apertos would be ideal for video on demand applications. **********But Sony has its work cut out for it. Microsoft, Apple Computer and others are developing operating software for handling audio and video. Sun Microsystems' Java looks as if it will do what Sony hopes its system will do over networks. **********Apertos was developed at Sony's Computer Science Laboratory, which is the company's attempt to duplicate, on a small scale, the free-wheeling atmosphere of the Xerox Corporation's Palo Alto Research Center, which originated many computer concepts. The Sony lab, with about 18 researchers, is free from many of the company's usual rules and hires people on a contract basis. **********Japanese companies have long been frustrated that American companies dominate two key pieces of computing -- microprocessors and operating system. A project called TRON, started in the 1980's by Tokyo University and Japanese companies to develop microprocessors and operating systems, did not come up with successful products.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/04/world.main_headline: Ally of Yeltsin And Reformer Out as Mayor
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/04/world.print_headline: Ally of Yeltsin And Reformer Out as Mayor
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/04/world.body_text: **********The Mayor of St. Petersburg, a liberal who was an early, close ally of Boris  N. Yeltsin and remains a symbol of Russia's reform movement, narrowly lost his bid for re-election on Sunday to his former deputy. **********But the preliminary results, which were released today, did not signal voters' rejection of free market reform and democratic rule. The Mayor, Anatoly  Sobchak, and his successor, Vladimir Yakovlev, both support economic reform and  President Yeltsin's re-election bid. Mostly, the voting suggested that St. Petersburg residents had tired of their famous, charismatic but increasingly unpopular Mayor. **********St. Petersburg is one of Russia's few pro-reform strongholds, and Communist  and nationalist challengers there were shut out in the first round of voting on  May 19. The municipal election turned out to be mostly a referendum on Mr. Sobchak's tenure. Weary of five years of drastic economic changes, shrinking services and corruption scandals, voters chose a fresh face. **********In his campaign, Mr. Yakovlev capitalized on citizens' concerns about shrinking social services, unemployment and ailing industries.  He cast himself  as a hands-on manager, and attacked his rival for courting the West and neglecting municipal problems. **********Mr. Sobchak, 58, a former law professor who rose to prominence by challenging the Soviet system in the late 1980's and siding with Mr. Yeltsin during the aborted hard-line Communist coup of August 1991, was regarded as a possible presidential candidate when he became Mayor in 1991. But early in his tenure, he began distancing himself from the Russian President, sharply criticizing the strategy and details of the Kremlin's economic and political reforms. **********And almost as early, he also began alienating the intelligentsia who had brought him to power by encouraging business interests and controversial development deals. His popularity ebbed as reform's promise of prosperity dwindled. **********In the second round, Mr. Yakovlev, 51, fused a broad coalition and said he would not rule out including Communists in his administration as long as they were competent. **********After his victory, he moved quickly to assure the public that his election would not signal a break with economic reform. **********In his concession speech, Mr. Sobchak, who is not known for modesty, likened  his defeat to that of Winston Churchill after World War II. "People who got sick and tired of hard living and who came to believe the promises of his competitors rejected Churchill, the savior of the country, the symbol of victory," he said. **********He vowed that he would not leave politics and warned that his defeat might be a harbinger for the presidential election this month. "If the presidential election follows the pattern of the St. Petersburg election," he said, "I have serious worries about Russia's future." **********Mr. Yeltsin did not appear to share Mr. Sobchak's fears that the St. Petersburg election was a testing ground for his own political future. The President did not endorse his onetime ally during the campaign.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/02/your-.main_headline: Short-Term Investors Find No Free Parking
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/02/your-.print_headline: Short-Term Investors Find No Free Parking
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/02/your-.body_text: **********FINDING a secure short-term, high-income "parking space" for money that has been earmarked for future use is not easy. At today's interest rates, peace of mind tends to be incompatible with healthy returns. **********The exceptions are Italian banks, currently offering 9.6 percent for three month deposits, 9.5 percent for six months and 9.4 percent for one year. **********But for non-Italian investors unwilling to swap their currencies for lire , historically low interest rates make local savings accounts look decidedly unappealing. **********"[U.S.] interest rates are falling so far that investors will be lucky to get three to four percent on short term deposits," said Paul Diesel, a director at Bank of Boston's private banking division. "Choosing among federal, state or municipal instruments depends on the investor's tax position, but rates are so low on all of these that it's hardly worth it." **********U.S. bank certificates of deposit can generate a slightly higher return **********up to five percent or so, said Mr. Diesel. But the resulting tax liability may offset the benefit, he said. **********Japanese savers have even better cause to gripe. Interest rates, as determined by government-backed short-term bonds, are 0.8 percent for three-month deposits, 0.62 percent for six months and 0.87 percent for one year. Karl Hancock, an analyst at stockbrokers County NatWest in London, attributed the particularly low six-month figure to a lack of money supply for that period, which is pushing the price up and the rate down. **********In Britain, the prospects for short-term savers are only marginally brighter. According to MoneyFacts, a monthly guide to investment and mortgage rates published in Norfolk, bank and building society money-market rates on £50,000 ($77,000) deposited in February for three, six or 12 months ranged between 3.75 percent and 6.25 percent. **********Offshore accounts pay slightly better returns: up to seven percent for £50,000 deposited in a two-month notice account and 5.25 percent for $50,000 in dollars. **********"Investors with more than £50,000 should consider approaching banks with bespoke services," said Stephen Renals, a director at stockbrokers Kleinwort Benson's private banking division in London. These can access interbank market rates, or the rate at which banks and financial institutions lend to each other. Currently, the interbank rate on sterling is about 6.3 percent. **********For the totally risk-averse investor, that is the end of the story. But caution doesn't have been thrown entirely to the winds to obtain the prospect of a far higher return on short-term investments. **********One possibility is a hybrid savings products, such as Kleinwort Benson's Investors Deposit Account, which pays a return linked to the performance of the FT-SE 100 index, rather than a rate of interest. **********This account, which requires a minimum deposit of £2,500, pays the investor 70 percent of the index's average return over a three-month deposit period, 95 percent for six months and 121 percent for 12 months. If the market declines, the original deposit remains unscathed. Therefore, the most an investor stands to lose is the interest he or she would have made from a more traditional savings product. **********Another option is a money market fund, including single currency or managed currency funds. These generate higher rates of interest than retail accounts because, like the customized services, they are able to tap into the wholesale rates available to very large depositors. **********Currency funds also offer more competitive foreign exchange rates and generally make no charge for switching currencies, an added attraction for investors moving abroad or with liabilities in more than one country. **********Cash and currency management funds account for more than $800 billion in the U.S. market alone. **********"Managed currency funds can be very volatile so they are really better for investors with a four-year time frame," cautioned Mogens Kjoller-Petersen, chairman of Northstar Fund Mangers (Cayman) Ltd. "Single currency funds are better for short-term deposits." **********In fact, short-term depositors probably do better to avoid most money market funds: The average return of the 631 funds tracked by Micropal for the past 12 months was 6.82 percent, hardly better than retail bank interest.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/28/world.main_headline: Critic of Arafat, Free Now, Says He'll Keep Speaking Out
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/28/world.print_headline: Critic of Arafat, Free Now, Says He'll Keep Speaking Out
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/28/world.body_text: **********A Palestinian human rights advocate who was jailed after he was quoted as criticizing Yasir Arafat's self-rule administration said today that he planned to continue speaking out. **********Dr. Eyad R. Sarraj, a psychiatrist who is the leader of the Palestinian Independent Commission for Citizens Rights, was released Sunday night after spending nine days in a Gaza City jail. **********The Palestinian Attorney General, Khaled Kidreh, said that Dr. Sarraj's release was ordered by Mr. Arafat, and that Dr. Sarraj could still be tried on charges of libel, incitement, and harming the public interest. **********"The file is not closed," Mr. Kidreh said today. **********Dr. Sarraj said that Mr. Arafat's administration had a poor human rights record, "and I will keep up my criticisms." **********"Torture is still going on," he said. "People are still intimidated. There is a terrible mixing between legal and executive authorities." **********He went on: "Everybody knows that there is mishandling of authority, there is confusion and there are no respect to laws. Unfortunately, only very few can speak out." **********Dr. Sarraj was arrested on May 18 after he was quoted as calling the Palestinian Authority "corrupt, dictatorial and oppressive" in a May 6 column by Anthony Lewis on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times. **********He also had been quoted as saying that the Palestinian Authority made arbitrary arrests and tortured suspects. **********He also said he was "100 times freer" during Israel's occupation of Gaza to speak out in the local press. That remark, in particular, seemingly rankled Palestinian officials. **********"We revere freedom of opinion, but he has gone beyond that," Mr. Kidreh said. **********Dr. Sarraj's jailing provoked an outcry from local and international human rights groups, which he credited for his release. **********"My detention hurt the Palestinian Authority," he said. **********Several days before his release, Dr. Sarraj wrote a letter to Mr. Arafat in which he said he had not attacked Mr. Arafat or any figure in the Palestinian Authority, but gave only "constructive criticism" of the government. **********"I said I was sorry if my criticism had caused personal pain to the president," Dr. Sarraj said today. "This does not mean I am abandoning my previous positions and my principles against any violations of human rights." **********Dr. Sarraj said the police made him sign a document promising to respect Palestinian laws, but he added a clause in his own handwriting that he has the right to express his opinions to the news media. **********Dr. Sarraj said he had been asked to come to the police station on May 18 "to have a cup of coffee" with the commander. Once there, the commander and Mr. Kidreh accused him of libeling the Palestinian Authority in The New York Times article, he said. **********He said he was confined by himself in a jail cell but was never interrogated. **********He appeared on May 23 in a military court, which extended his detention for 15 days. His lawyer was not told about the court hearing and he was allowed no other representation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/14/busin.body_text: **********Is there another Dun & Bradstreet out there, a big company with a laundry hamper full of businesses that Wall Street would like better if they were spun off into simple piles? It is not an idle questions. When the publishing company  announced Tuesday that it would reorganize into three publicly owned companies,  its stock price rose from $63.5 to $65. **********Nor was that stock jump unusual. While there are no guarantees, betting on spinoffs can pay off handsomely in both strong and weak mearkets, said Barbara Goodstein, an analyst at Rothschild Inc. who has studied their performance. **********And there are indeed many future Dun & Bradstreets, say the experts. Look for a company with desirable assets, disgruntled investors or a chief executive  who may be willing to consider a spinoff. **********Here are the results of Ms. Goodstein's study, along with some future spinoff candidates.   ANTHONY RAMIREZ

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/25/busin.body_text: **********The chairman of the General Motors Corporation offered an olive branch today  to the United Automobile Workers union, seeking to mend a relationship strained  by two bitter strikes this year, a lawsuit and G.M.'s dismissal of an influential shop steward. **********John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, called for the company and the union to work together to improve G.M.'s competitive position "in an atmosphere of trust and mutual respect, and with a spirit of cooperation." **********At the auto maker's annual shareholder meeting, in Wilmington, Del., Mr. Smith tried to reassure employees and the union about the intentions of the world's largest auto maker as it prepared for negotiations this summer on a three-year national labor contract. "I've frequently read in the papers that G.M.'s management and board have become labor hawks," Mr. Smith said. "It is not true, and I do not want our employees, the U.A.W. and other unions or the public to think it is true." **********Mr. Smith added, "We have more in common than in conflict," a phrase made popular in the auto industry 32 years ago by Walter Reuther, the legendary labor leader who built the U.A.W. in the 1930's and 1940's. **********G.M., the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation have each been lobbying the U.A.W. in the last several weeks to be chosen as the union's primary negotiating target. Because the U.A.W. tries to reach broadly similar labor agreements with each of the Big Three auto makers, the first company to reach a deal can try to negotiate contract details that hold down its costs while increasing costs for its rivals. **********Mr. Smith said at a news conference here on Monday that G.M. wanted the U.A.W. to choose it for the pattern-setting talks. "We would prefer to go first  -- I think all companies would prefer to determine their own fate," he said. **********Mr. Smith took a step further today. "It is our sincere objective to reach a  satisfactory agreement with the U.A.W. and all of our unions this fall," he said. "I hope peace and productivity will mark the months ahead. We do not want  a long-term strike; we want a long-term partnership." **********Frank Joyce, the U.A.W.'s chief spokesman, declined to respond specifically to Mr. Smith's remarks today but said, "The U.A.W. also looks forward to a problem-solving environment for the negotiations." **********Craig M. Brown, a labor lawyer in the Cleveland offices of Duvin, Cahn & Hutton, said that Mr. Smith's remarks today appeared to be aimed at wooing the U.A.W. to choose G.M. for the negotiations. "I don't think it'll happen, but I think he may be attempting to persuade them," Mr. Brown said. **********Longtime observers of auto industry labor relations say that the U.A.W. still seems more likely to choose Chrysler, which has not been the target since 1973.  Chrysler is highly profitable and selling mini-vans and sport utility vehicles as fast as it can build them, which might make the company more willing to make  concessions to avoid a strike. **********The current national labor contract expires on Sept. 14 and talks will begin  in June. The U.A.W. has traditionally chosen its primary target just around Labor Day, after talks with all three companies over the summer. **********G.M. has lately pursued a good-cop, bad-cop approach to labor negotiations. Harry J. Pearce, a 53-year-old lawyer who is G.M.'s vice chairman and Mr. Smith's heir apparent, spoke strongly of the need to make G.M. more competitive  during a 17-day strike in March at two brake factories in Dayton, Ohio. Mr. Smith, who was traveling in Europe during part of the strike, was silent then. **********When workers at an assembly plant in Lordstown, Ohio, went on strike a month  ago to protest the dismissal of their popular shop steward, Mr. Pearce played a  role in G.M.'s decision to seek a court order forcing workers to return to work  immediately. G.M. also issued a statement then accusing the shop steward of fraudulently putting in for overtime, an accusation that local union officials said was untrue. **********Mr. Pearce took a slightly more conciliatory tone in talking with reporters at the end of the meeting today. "I guess you could call us competitiveness hawks, and I guess we all ought to be that," he said. "That's the way you secure those jobs."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/10/busin.main_headline: Market Place;Swiss banking, too, encounters the ethos of the bottom line.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/10/busin.print_headline: Market Place;Swiss banking, too, encounters the ethos of the bottom line.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/10/busin.body_text: **********THE Swiss have been celebrated and envied for their banking skills for centuries. But even they are not immune from the competitive pressures and lackluster profits that are forcing big banks almost everywhere to consolidate as a way to cut costs and increase revenue. **********And despite the illustrious banking history, the nation's big three bank companies, Union Bank of Switzerland, CS Holding and the Swiss Bank Corporation, have recently lagged behind many of their big American and European competitors  in profitability. In the decades after World War II -- when loyal, perhaps insular, Swiss investors provided the capital -- that might not have mattered so much. **********But in today's truly international capital markets, where investors move money quickly to improve their returns, the Swiss banks are being pressed to improve their performance. All three have been struggling to build world-class investment banking franchises to increase earnings. **********Union Bank is also battling Martin Ebner, a powerful and restive shareholder  who wants to see the bank substantially increase its returns. These are the forces behind yesterday's announcement that the Union Bank of Switzerland and CS Holding are considering a merger -- to be discussed at Union Bank's stockholder  meeting. **********Whether this particular merger happens or not, analysts think that the pressure for more consolidation is inevitable. **********"The logic of mergers is inexorable and global in reach," said Robert B. Albertson, United States bank research director at Goldman, Sachs. "We just created our biggest bank two weeks ago with the Chase-Chemical merger. The cost  savings and productivity impact are enormous, and in the modern age of commercial and consumer banking round the world, the name of the game is using sophisticated technology and marketing. And there, big is good." **********There would be many potential benefits in a merger of these giants, analysts  and bankers said yesterday. If these companies, two of the three largest Swiss banking institutions, merged, the combined institution would replace Deutsche Bank as Europe's biggest and best-capitalized bank, and be a behemoth that would tower over all American banks, including the new combination of Chase Manhattan  and Chemical. Only the recently merged Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Ltd. would be larger. **********The new Swiss giant would almost certainly command an AAA credit rating, something that no American bank has managed to retain. **********But there would be difficulties, too, at least in the initial years. **********Such a merger would probably lead to the layoff of many thousands of employees. These would fall particularly hard in Switzerland, where a weak economy is struggling to cope with the strength of the Swiss franc, and unemployment, particularly among young people, is matter of growing national concern. **********And the big Swiss banks, while they have been huge employers, have been rapidly shedding jobs of late. A number of large institutions, such as Bank Leu  and Swiss Volksbank, have been swallowed up. **********Also, big mergers depend on the personalities leading each institution and the willingness of each to set aside some of their ambition to make sure that a  merger can be completed and made to work. Yesterday, some Wall Street investment bankers said that the Union Bank team was more likely to take the top management jobs, and those who know Rainer Gut, the forceful chairman of CS Holding, speculated that he might not be ready to take a back seat to insure that a merger went ahead. **********"I am not sure that Gut will really like it," said a Wall Street banking specialist who declined to be named. "A lot of it will depend on that." **********Union Bank's capital may be as much as 50 percent greater than that of CS Holding, and that is why this banker surmised that its top managers would have to play the leading role in a combined institution. **********There also could be a negative reaction to such a deal in Switzerland, where  mergers have been rare. In recent weeks, Switzerland witnessed a huge merger in  another of its hallmark businesses: pharmaceuticals. Ciba-Geigy and Sandoz, both world leaders, announced that they would merge, sending ripples through Swiss business. **********"That has already shaken up the Swiss financial community," a senior CS employee in London said yesterday. Interestingly, the two drug companies were each advised by American investment banks -- J. P. Morgan and Morgan Stanley. **********And the bank merger, if it goes ahead, may not pan out so well for many of the investment bankers who work for either institution in world financial centers -- like Wall Street, London, Tokyo and Singapore. These high-paid employees would probably be among the first to be culled by a management eager to cut costs. **********This would indeed be a reversal. The big three Swiss banks have been buying investment banking talent and institutions in London and New York in recent years. Swiss Bank Corporation, for example, late last year paid more than $1 billion to acquire the venerable S. G. Warburg merchant bank of London. **********For some investment bankers at Union Bank's New York unit, such a merger might prove an eerie experience, as it would put them back to work with colleagues they only just left. In recent months, several investment bankers, including John Costas, a managing director in charge of much of the firm's debt  business and Thomas Hanley, a leading bank analyst, have switched jobs from CS First Boston to Union Bank's Wall Street unit. Neither Mr. Hanley nor Mr. Costas could be reached late yesterday. **********On Wall Street, CS Holding has an established presence with its CS First Boston subsidiary, while Union Bank has in the last two years spent hundreds of  millions trying to build a world-class investment bank. The overlap would be substantial, leading to hundreds, if not thousands, of expected layoffs. **********"The North American investment banking businesses would be decimated," an employee at one of the two banks' Wall Street businesses said yesterday. "It's lucky that a lot of firms are still hiring." **********Wall Street has been rife with jokes about the high salaries that Union Bank  paid to entice top talent. Its top executives' guaranteed pay packages of $2 million for four years, or $3 million for five years, have become known as 2-by-4's and 3-by-5's, prompting Wall Street wags to nickname the UBS investment bank "the lumber yard."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/04/busin.main_headline: STREET SMARTS;A Lesson From the Playground
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/04/busin.print_headline: STREET SMARTS;A Lesson From the Playground
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/04/busin.body_text: **********THE tiny tots who run, jump and play at Discovery Zone have a lot of experience with the company's slides. There's the bouncy foam-rubber one. There's another made up of wooden rods. And, of course, don't forget that old favorite, the covered tunnel slide. **********Still, there's yet one more slide that the kiddies might not know, even though the company's investors sure do. It's called the sickening slide. **********That's what the share price of Discovery Zone has been on for years. After being one of the hottest stocks on Wall Street, Discovery Zone started tumbling  more than a gymnast. Last week came the final indignity: The company announced that it might have to file for bankruptcy protection, and its shares hit the mat, dropping 50 percent in one day. By Friday, Discovery Zone shares closed at  87.5 cents in over-the-counter trading. **********How could such a disastrous fall happen? A better question might be: How could it not? Indeed, the story of Discovery Zone offers investors a pointed example of the dangers of fad stocks. **********The Discovery Zone concept is simple. The company owns and franchises what are effectively indoor playgrounds, made up of a series of tubes, slides, trampolines and ball bins for children. With the company's stress on fun and fitness, parents who took their children to Discovery Zone could easily have walked out with the mistaken impression that this was a company with an incredibly profitable idea. **********Apparently, it was a common thought. In June 1993, when the child-recreation  company went public, it quickly became one of Wall Street's hottest offerings. On the first day of trading, shares of Discovery Zone jumped 61.4 percent from their offering price of $22, to close at $35.50. (Prices have since been adjusted to account for new shares.) Making the stock even more attractive was the identity of a 20 percent shareholder: Blockbuster Entertainment, which had made its video-store chain one of the most successful stocks of the 1980's. **********Then, just a year later, more good news. Blockbuster increased its holdings in Discovery Zone to more than 50 percent of the outstanding shares. On the same day, Discovery Zone announced it would buy its only national competitor, Leaps & Bounds Inc., from the McDonald's Corporation for more than $100 million in stock. Then, a few months after that, Discovery Zone purchased about 60 facilities that were owned by affiliates of Blockbuster. **********With no big competitors, and two of the most successful companies in America  betting on it, Discovery Zone seemed destined for success. But from that point on, Discovery Zone flopped at every opportunity. **********Its rapid expansion -- building up from eight play centers to almost 350 in just a few years -- proved far too costly to make any money. In 1993, Discovery Zone had $3 million in profits on $61 million in revenue. By 1994, revenues had tripled, but profits had vanished, and the company lost $25 million. **********Last year, with things falling apart, Blockbuster took control. But the hemorrhaging got worse: In the first nine months of 1995, Discovery Zone lost an eye-popping $114 million. **********Now, shareholders might have avoided these troubles if, back when Discovery Zone was the Wunderkind of Wall Street, they had asked one question: Exactly what is it that this company is offering that anybody else couldn't copy? Think  about it. Nobody can patent slides or ball bins or trampolines -- the main attractions at Discovery Zone. So if the company proved to be the moneymaker that Wall Street so clearly hoped for, every two-bit operator could open a competitor down the street. And they would be able to avoid whatever mistakes Discovery Zone made along the way as an industry trailblazer. **********In other words, if it was successful, Discovery Zone was destined to be swamped with competitors. And if it wasn't, well, then it wouldn't succeed. **********Last week offered the latest evidence that Discovery Zone is failing. It has  moved to the brink of bankruptcy due to high real-estate costs from its excessive expansion, and its inability to negotiate more credit from its banks.  But savvy investors suspected from the start that trouble, one way or another, was likely. **********True, there was one possible path to success for a company like this -- but Discovery Zone did not take it. The company might have been rigorous in creating a brand identity, just as Blockbuster has done with video stores. But, in fact,  the centers differ widely in construction, supervision, security and even in what foods are offered. **********A result is that local operators of competing play centers have just as much  chance of attracting children as does Discovery Zone. Meanwhile, other companies, like Ikea and even McDonald's, have hit upon the idea of setting up slides and ball bins in their stores.  That offers something Discovery Zone does not: an attraction for parents like the chance to shop or have a decent lunch. And, after all, it is the parents who decide where the tots will play. **********Any doubters of the flaws in Discovery Zone should have been convinced in 1994, when McDonald's sold the company its indoor-playground business.  While it was true that the deal meant Discovery Zone had no national competitors, investors should have asked: What does McDonald's know that I don't? **********Most corporations don't walk away from big moneymakers. In essence, the stock deal with Discovery Zone allowed McDonald's the best of both worlds: If the concept took off, McDonald's would profit from its Discovery Zone shares. If it  didn't, the losses would be limited to its investment. **********In the end, while Discovery Zone doesn't offer much profit, at least it provides an important lesson for investors: Companies that offer something readily copied should have plenty of playmates in the same business.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/03/busin.snippet: Anecdotes on consultants' impact on companies; drawings (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/03/busin.main_headline: When the Consultant's Cure Is Worse Than the Ailment
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/03/busin.print_headline: When the Consultant's Cure Is Worse Than the Ailment
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/03/busin.body_text: **********Guess who has an image problem? Could it be those busybodies known as consultants? So the recent mail would indicate. But not to worry. Surely someone out there knows how to restore their tarnished image. All that consultants need is some advice from a good consultant. As to how some consultants earned their reputations, read on. **********Like many managers, this boss hoped the consultant he hired would deliver the magic elixir: a way to cut expenses, increase sales, attract new customers. **********So, recalls Lia Moskowitz of Brooklyn, the boss made the consultant privy to all his business records and transactions. **********Flash forward a year. **********The boss has filed for bankruptcy. The company has been sold by a bankruptcy court. **********The new owner? Funny you should ask. **********The consultant, of course. **********While going through the corporate records, it seems, the consultant came upon some questionable transactions the boss made. Being a noble soul, the consultant reported them to the appropriate authorities. The result was a fine. When the boss could not afford to pay it, the company went bankrupt. **********As the old saying goes, it's an ill wind that blows no good. **********In October 1994, Jim Gialamas of Manhattan was put in charge of a production group of 30 people at the Wall Street subsidiary of a Fortune 500 company. ''Somewhere, behind the scenes, the firm hired a consultant to scale down the operating environment,'' Mr. Gialamas writes. The two had met before. **********Mr. Gialamas remembered him as a man who spoke aggressively, belittled anyone without seniority, armed himself with incomprehensible jargon and shielded himself from criticism behind recent articles from PC Magazine. ''A combination of ill-humor and conceit earned him credibility,'' Mr. Gialamas writes. **********Before long, Mr. Gialamas's group was reduced to half. New work stations would enable each of the survivors to do the work of two, he was told, but the technology never materialized. When the consultant discussed the department's software, he got its name wrong. Morale withered. Work quality deteriorated. Those who remained -- terrified that they would lose their jobs -- worked overtime without pay. Another revamping followed. The consultant even replaced Mr. Gialamas's boss. **********Mr. Gialamas soon quit. **********''Eventually, an old colleague forwarded me an E-mail announcing the consultant's resignation as managing director,'' Mr. Gialamas writes. ''In a desperate act of vanity, the departing director wrote, 'I am choosing a new career path in order to succeed elsewhere. . . . ' As far as I know, he's still consulting. **********''As for me, I work out of my home now. When I invoice clients, they ask if my title is 'consultant.' **********''I respond, ' ''vendor'' will be fine.' '' **********''It was the dry cleaning bills that irked us,'' writes Helen S. Paxton of Montclair, N.J. **********''We were low-paid employees in a medium-size nonprofit organization, and he was the consultant from the Midwest who wore very nice suits and impeccable shirts.'' He had been brought in to develop a new plan for the organization, including a campaign to raise significant endowment funds. The hope was that the board, the executive director and the staff could execute the plan and put the organization on a stable footing for the first time in its history. **********''But then someone discovered that the dry cleaning bills for the consultant's shirts were being reimbursed by our financially strapped nonprofit organization,'' Ms. Paxton writes. ''A small rebellion ensued.'' **********Soon the consultant was back in the Midwest, leaving behind the fund-raising plan his assistant had typed so beautifully. **********''Fund raising is more than writing a fancy document,'' Ms. Paxton says. ''It's about people connecting with people, about the chemistry that happens between the askers and the givers. Plans give you perspective and hope, and that's pretty important, too. Eventually, through a lot of hard work and chemistry making, the organization began to realize some of the goals that the consultant had helped us to articulate. **********''If you look at this through the capitalist lens, he came out the winner. We were the chemistry makers who brought our lunch to work and shopped for bargain-basement deals on nice shirts. **********''His fees allowed him to buy fancy shirts, he didn't have to budget for dry cleaning and he never got his hands dirty in the chemistry lab, either.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/14/busin.main_headline: Deals in Digital TV: A Matter of Necessity
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/14/busin.print_headline: Deals in Digital TV: A Matter of Necessity
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/14/busin.body_text: **********Americans may soon see a major expansion in their hitherto spotty diet of BBC programs. A senior official of Flextech, the largely U.S.-owned television-program packager, said Tuesday that he hoped by the end of the month to wrap up a deal with the British Broadcasting Corporation to create up to six new theme-television channels for distribution around the world. **********Stanislas Yassukovich, Flextech's chairman, predicted that an agreement would be reached by September. "This partnership will bring our financing capability together with the BBC's library and its ability to commission new programming," he said in an interview. **********He said he expected the half dozen new channels to each contain a mixture of fresh programming and so-called time-warp material — programs from the BBC's vast warehouse of previously broadcast dramas, documentaries and more. **********Behind the new joint venture is an expected growth in the need for programs with the arrival of digital television. Among other things, digital technology will enable broadcasters to squeeze far more channels onto the same band width. **********"Distribution capacity is growing far faster than the available content," said Mr. Yassukovich. "The big challenge is to produce and package program content to fill that new capacity." **********"No one can cover all the bases in all the markets by themselves," said Mr. Yassukovich, referring to recent combinations of European forces to gain market niches. "It is a business now based on complex, some might say incestuous, relationships." **********Should talks with Flextech founder, for instance, experts say the BBC would have little choice but to seek an alternative partner. **********Analysts point out that in the past the BBC has had difficulty in finding the money to expand its still relatively tiny for-profit activities. **********Flextech, which is 50.8 percent owned by Tele-Communications Inc., could significantly advance the BBC's plans on two fronts. As the largest cable-television operator in the United States, Denver-based TLC can offer the BBC distribution in the world's richest English-speaking market. Furthermore, it has the financial muscle that the BBC sorely lacks. **********Andrea Kirkby, an analyst with the Daiwa Institute of Research, offers a third explanation as to why the deal might be attractive for the BBC. "The BBC is good at general-interest programming, but it has never run a special-interest or niche channel in its life. It does not know how to, because it has never had to do so."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/06/busin.main_headline: Roll Over, Pearl Jam, Classical Radio Lives
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/06/busin.print_headline: Roll Over, Pearl Jam, Classical Radio Lives
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/06/busin.body_text: **********Before radio had formats or ratings, before drive time, before pop, or rock,  or talk or shock jocks, it had classical music. And just as radio has found a quiet place for itself in the cacophony of technological revolutions since 1906, classical music is doing quite nicely in the Arbitron-driven world of radio today. **********The American Radio Systems Corporation's recent agreement to pay $66.5 million for two of Marlin Broadcasting Inc.'s radio stations -- and to retain their classical music format -- is only the latest sign that a tradition as old  as radio can survive. **********But classical music broadcasters say patience and hard work are required. "If you track the performance of classical over the past five years, you'll see  a steady increase of shares across the country," said Steven Dodge, the chairman and chief executive of American Radio, which is based in Boston and owns, or has agreements to acquire, a total of 63 stations -- none of the others with classical music. "There are so many formats in radio that when you're in a niche format like this, it's a good place to be." **********While many popular-music stations bounce up and down in the ratings as they tinker with their formats, classical programming remains a stable moneymaker with a virtually guaranteed audience that is demographically attractive to advertisers. **********"We just agreed to advertise on classical music broadcasts for the first time in a long time," said Dan Haughton, director of marketing services at Merrill Lynch. "We're doing this to show our support for the arts, and we feel it's a good way to reach a very affluent client base." Merrill Lynch is sponsoring "Evening at the Pops With Skitch Henderson," which the Concert Music Network, a  national satellite network, transmits to 35 affiliates. **********Robert Unmacht of M Street Journal, an industry newsletter, said the number of commercial stations playing classical music had remained fairly steady over the last five years -- currently 39, including WQRS-FM in Detroit and WFLN-FM in Philadelphia, the stations that American Radio bought from Marlin. The number of noncommercial stations with such programming has decreased somewhat, he said. **********Few cities have more than one commercial classical station. Chicago and San Francisco each have two, while Boston and the Portland, Me., area each have three. In New York City, the only commercial station playing classical music is  WQXR-FM, owned by the New York Times Company. The audience is also served by WNYC-FM, a noncommercial station which plays more than a dozen hours of classical music a day, and blocks of music on smaller stations. **********"If you go classical, you need a marketing strategy, you need to be in it for a long haul, you need to go after the better advertisers," said Mr. Unmacht. "It's much easier to tell an agency, 'Here's how many bodies we have ages 25 to  54. Send us the Ford spot, and the check.' " **********Peter Newman, the general manager and program director of one of the most successful classical stations, KING-FM, in Seattle, said: "If you look at where  the big advertising money is, it is usually in beer and soft drinks. Classical owners have to consider how much money this format, with its bias, will be worth in a given market." **********The programming format, meanwhile, is not monolithic. "We run our radio like  a Top 40 station," said Howard Tanger, the president and chief executive of Marlin Broadcasting. "It must be entertainment." Mr. Tanger said Marlin stations run contests, golf tournaments and Beethoven birthday parties. **********Marlin sold the two stations to American Radio "to provide liquidity for myself and my other stockholders," Mr. Tanger said. The company, which is based  in Boston, is repurchasing WTMI-FM, a classical station in the Miami area, for $18 million. **********Mr. Tanger's father, Alexander M. Tanger, owns and operates a classical station, WBQQ, in Kennebunkport, Me.; his brother Doug has WBOQ-FM in Gloucester, Mass. Many other stations were founded in the 1940's and 1950's, with relatively small investments, by individuals dedicated to classical music. **********Classical music on the air predates commercial radio, back to when Enrico Caruso sang from the Metropolitan Opera House in a live broadcast in 1910. During the 1930's, concerts were common, and in 1937 NBC formed its own symphony, led by Arturo Toscanini. **********But as prices for stations have surged, many owners have been tempted to seek a more mainstream audience. **********In New York City, for example, WNCN-FM, a classical music station, had a 1.7  share of the radio audience and could not crack the top 20 among adults 25-54. Now, as hard rock station WAXQ, it recently scored an Arbitron rating of 6.2 among men 18-34, which places it third in the market, and its revenues are about 50 percent higher, said Randy Bongarten, the general manager. The station was owned by GAF Broadcasting during the makeover. On March 15, GAF sold it for $90  million to a small company that in turn traded it to Viacom Inc. for three stations in Seattle. Owners of classical stations have learned that they have to market the buying power of their audiences and persuade media buyers to look beyond the ratings. "If you're strictly buying the numbers you're not doing the job properly," said  Richard Cotter, regional broadcast manager at J. Walter Thompson.    KING-FM, which is owned by Classical Radio Inc., is one of the country's most successful classical stations, averaging about a 4 share over the last five years in Seattle, a city that has emerged as a leader in pop music. **********But the most profitable classical station in the country is WGMS-FM in Washington, said James Duncan Jr., the publisher of Duncan's American Radio, a trade paper. The station has pretax earnings of close to $3 million on revenues  of about $7.5 million. It is owned by Colfax Communications Inc. **********WQXR, in New York, and KKGO-FM, which broadcasts in Los Angeles and is owned  by Mount Wilson FM Broadcasters Inc., have similar revenues, he said, but higher marketing costs. **********Mr. Newman in Seattle said his approach was to keep the programming clean and simple, concentrating on the music, without wine ratings and business reports. **********The station has three tiers of music: about 200 well-known pieces that are broadcast once each month, a second tier of less-well-known fare and a third of  programming that is "pleasant but without a strong presence." **********"I have a 40-minute Brahms symphony, but I'm not going to play it at 8 in the morning," Mr. Newman said. "In the morning we play shorter, lighter things, as we do in the afternoon drive." **********Generally classical stations are optimistic. As baby boomers age, classical programmers are hoping that their tastes will turn toward Bach and away from the Beatles, Mr. Newman said. **********The classical broadcasters are also testing the syndicated market. Marlin hopes to offer a worldwide classical music service. Sony Worldwide Networks has  signed six affiliates since August, when it offered a classical format. **********"It is slow going," said Susan Solomon, the president and chief executive.
