https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/19/world.main_headline: Tension in Asia Over Wealth Under the Sea
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/19/world.print_headline: Tension in Asia Over Wealth Under the Sea
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/19/world.body_text: **********In the seas between Japan and China are potential oil reserves, fishing grounds, mineral deposits and a few specks of rock that together amount to prime international real estate. **********The disputes about who owns the resources are becoming more serious, for Japan, China and South Korea will soon be tussling over competing claims under the Law of the Sea Treaty. No one expects war any time soon, but some diplomats  and government officials warn that in the long term, the disagreements could become a source of major conflict. **********I think there's a potential here for more than just diplomatic wrangling,"  said Kent E. Calder, a Princeton University scholar who has just published a book, "Pacific Defense," (William Morrow & Company), about security risks in the region. "Beyond that, the disputed areas are part of a larger danger of tensions between China and Japan. **********"This will be a central issue in Sino-Japanese security for the next 5 to 10  years and perhaps beyond." **********The backdrop is the growing unease in Japan about the military implications of the rise of China. Japanese Government officials often say that in the long run, the most important external issue facing their country is China. **********Just this month five Chinese research ships conducted sonar exploration of what Japan regards as its seabed. Last fall a Chinese ship searched for oil on what Japan considers its side of the dividing line in the seas between them. **********Japan occasionally scrambles its fighter aircraft when Chinese warplanes approach the Senkaku Islands, a few uninhabited islets that both countries claim. But some Japanese officials acknowledge that their warplanes and warships are a bit like dogs chasing cars, and that if the Chinese ever fired a missile,  the Japanese forces would beat a hasty retreat. **********One complication is oil, for the East China Sea bears promising geological formations that some experts say resemble those of the North Sea, with its huge  oil reserves. Japan is acutely aware of its vulnerability on imported oil, and China has been a net oil importer since 1993. So both sides are dazzled by estimates that the East China Sea may contain 10 billion to 100 billion barrels  of oil. **********China's oil exploration in the disputed area last fall may be a sign that it  will try to exploit reserves in the sea. So far Japan's Foreign Ministry has discouraged Japanese oil companies from drilling in the area, but if China goes  ahead there would be strong political pressure for Japan to do so as well. **********Sadayuki Hayashi, Deputy Foreign Minister of Japan, said in an interview that it was important to work toward finding common boundaries under the Law of the Sea Treaty. But he added that Japan would draw its exclusive economic zone on the basis that the Senkakus are a part of Japan. **********"It is very clear that this is part of Japan," Mr. Hayashi said. He noted that China had not much contested Japan's sovereignty until reports surfaced that the area includes a lot of oil. **********The issue has arisen because Asia, like most of the world, is moving to the Law of the Sea Treaty as the new framework for determining who controls the ocean's resources. South Korea ratified the treaty late last year, China did so  on Wednesday, and Japan is expected to do so in the coming month. **********The treaty allows nations to establish 200-mile "exclusive economic zones" in adjacent waters -- but the problem is that China and Japan and South Korea are less than 400 miles apart. This means that they have to figure out how to draw the line dividing their zones. **********China's claims are raising anxieties to its south as well as its east. On Friday the Philippines and Vietnam reportedly denounced Beijing's claims under the Law of the Sea Treaty to a vast stretch of water in the South China Sea. **********Japan proposes drawing the line at the halfway mark, although for this purpose it conveniently ignores a sometimes-submerged island off the Chinese coast. China, on the other hand, makes a sweeping claim to "inviolable sovereignty" over its continental shelf, which it argues juts into the ocean most of the way to Japan. **********China also has disputes about maritime boundaries with South and North Korea. Although North Korea and China often hail their friendship, North Korean gunboats are said to have fired on Chinese fishing boats that stray into what North Korea regards as its waters. **********Ji Guoxing, a Chinese scholar in Shanghai who has written extensively about maritime disputes in the seas around China, said it would take China some time after it ratifies the Law of the Sea Treaty to fix its exclusive economic zones. Mr. Ji added that while disagreements may be difficult to resolve, a war is unlikely. **********"This may be an area of potential conflict, but I don't see a real battle there," he said. "Both Japan and China will exercise restraint while sticking to their own claims." **********To solve the disputes, the parties could refer the matter to the International Court of Justice or seek mediation or arbitration. **********For now, though, the countries have been taking the alternative approach of bolstering their navies. China and South Korea have been pouring money into their navies in recent years, and Japan, which already has a very credible navy, is considering whether to upgrade it further.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/16/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;U.S. Issues Strong Warning To China About Copyrights
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/16/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;U.S. Issues Strong Warning To China About Copyrights
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/16/busin.body_text: **********The Clinton Administration has delivered a sharp warning in private to Chinese leaders that China's failure to comply with a 1995 agreement on copyright piracy of American products is undercutting the Administration's credibility in Congress and will force tariff sanctions on up to $2 billion in Chinese imports sometime next month, Westerners who were briefed by the Administration said. **********The ultimatum was delivered by Charlene Barshefsky, the acting United States  trade representative, who held two days of talks here last week and then left Beijing without public comment. **********Ms. Barshefsky was said to have conveyed the prevailing view in the Clinton  Administration that the President will not be able to credibly push for the annual renewal of China's most-favored-nation trade privileges if Beijing continues to tolerate the rampant trade in pirated American music, films and computer software. **********Mr. Clinton must make his recommendation to renew China's low-tariff trade privileges by June 3. Some members of Congress have signaled that they intend to challenge China's "most favored nation" trade status in retaliation for China's  military intimidation of Taiwan, China's poor human rights record and failure to live up to previous trade agreements. **********In this campaign season Mr. Clinton's advisers are said to be concerned that  he maintain a firm stance on China, particularly on its obligations under the protocol signed in February 1995. That agreement called for a "special enforcement period" of a year to close down 29 pirate compact disk factories that were producing as many as 45 million disks annually without license, trademark or royalty agreements with the copyright holders in the United States  and other countries. **********"Mickey Kantor believes that the Administration has to hit China with a big stick to fend off Congress," said one Westerner who was briefed by Administration officials on the current trade talks. "So they are coming at it from the standpoint of, 'To save M.F.N., what do you do?' " **********Ms. Barshefsky was said to have presented the Chinese with a detailed "plan of action" that requires Beijing to either shut down or bring into compliance with copyright laws the majority of the pirate factories still operating in China. **********"The plan of action does not require that they shut all of them down immediately," a Western business executive said, "but rather it was shut these down, license these and these others we can live with. But it was a very specific plan of action and I hear the Chinese reaction was extremely negative." **********The Clinton Administration is also weighing sanctions in a separate dispute involving China's sale of nuclear technology to Pakistan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/04/busin.snippet: Stocks of all independent radio companies have retreated since Justice Dept blocked American Radio Systems Corp's purchase of two radio stations; radio executives are upset about seeming inconsistency of recent decisions regarding radio acquisitio...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/04/busin.main_headline: It's a time of uncertainty: just how much merger can the industry get away with?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/04/busin.print_headline: It's a time of uncertainty: just how much merger can the industry get away with?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/04/busin.body_text: **********OF you are looking for Wall Street analysts who follow radio, you can find them hanging from window ledges all over New York,'' said Jeff Smulyan, chairman of the Emmis Broadcasting Corporation, one of the nation's largest radio station companies. **********Analysts may not have gone quite that far, but they have reason to be depressed. In the wake of last week's decision by the Justice Department to block the American Radio Systems Corporation's purchase of two radio stations, ''the radio industry is in free fall,'' Mr. Smulyan said. The purchase would have given American Radio control over 64 percent of the radio advertising revenues in Rochester. **********Stocks of virtually all the independent radio companies -- including American Radio, Emmis Broadcasting, Jacor Communications Inc. and the Evergreen Media Corporation -- have been retreating in recent weeks after hitting 52-week highs earlier, and several fell sharply after the American Radio decision. **********''Wall Street hates uncertainty, and the new Justice Department rulings raise the specter of increasing uncertainty in the industry,'' said one radio industry executive who insisted on not being identified. **********Since the Telecommunications Act of 1996 allowed radio companies to own as many as eight stations in a single market -- though not more than five on either the AM or FM band -- the Justice Department has started looking assiduously at the antitrust implications of mergers. In a speech on Thursday, Lawrence Fullerton, an official in the department's antitrust division, said the department was investigating about 20 radio mergers around the country. **********What has riled radio executives is the seeming inconsistency of recent decisions. In August, the Justice Department said Jacor could not proceed with an acquisition that would have given it control over 50 percent of the radio advertising revenues in Cincinnati. As a result, Jacor agreed to buy only one of the two stations it had planned to acquire. **********''When the Jacor decision came out, it was seen as a one-time event,'' said John Reidy, an analyst who follows radio companies at Smith Barney. ''But the Justice Department moved way up on the radar screen last week when it requested revisions in the American Radio deal.'' **********To some people, the Justice Department's direction is unclear. Edward Henneberry, who specializes in antitrust law at the law firm of Howrey & Simon, said: ''The Justice Department does not really seem to know where it is going. It is feeling its way.'' **********David Turetsky, Deputy Assistant Attorney General for the antitrust division, disagreed with that assessment. ''With the explosion of transactions, it is necessary and natural that we investigate their impact,'' he said. ''We have actually given quite a lot of guidance in a very short time.'' He said the department had been concerned in the Rochester case because there were a limited number of stations with strong signals and because American Radio would have owned six of the eight there. **********The stricter rules certainly limit the flexibility of the radio industry, but it is still too early to measure the mergers' benefits. Indeed, Mr. Smulyan contends that one reason radio stocks have come under pressure is that the industry has exaggerated how much such concentration can increase profitability. **********To be sure, even without merger benefits, the radio industry is extremely healthy. Advertising revenues have been growing at about 7 percent a year. **********But what has really driven the stocks for the last two years has been mergers and acquisitions activity,  Dennis H. Leibowitz, an analyst at  Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said. **********''Historically, stations had sold at 9 to 12 times cash flow,'' Mr. Smulyan of Emmis Broadcasting said. ''When CBS bought Infinity Broadcasting, it paid 20 times cash flow.'' **********Not only are flagging stock prices nagging at radio industry executives, but also there is the uncertainty about what the Justice Department will do next, since it has not laid out absolute guidelines. ''After the American Radio decision, people are assuming that you can't go over 40 percent,'' Mr. Leibowitz said. ''But as a result of all the mergers, some companies are already that high, and they are bumping up against a wall.'' **********The Justice Department has said it will make market-by-market decisions. And in addition to future mergers, it may also disqualify existing joint sales agreements, which are arrangements in which one station agrees to sell the advertising time for another station. **********The Justice Department is worried that such agreements, like mergers, give companies too much influence with advertisers. Measuring the absolute percentage of advertising dollars a single company controls in a single market is not the only issue. **********The Justice Department is also raising questions about single companies controlling too many stations with the same or similar formats in a single market. It may let an owner retain control of a number of stations if they have widely different formats, like classical music and rock music, that do not attract similar advertisers. But if a company has formats that give it a lock on a single target advertising market, the Justice Department may be more inclined to intervene. **********Radio industry executives contend that radio does not get its fair share of advertising dollars, considering the time people spend listening to it. They note that radio advertising revenues account for only 7 percent of all advertising sold in all media. **********For now, it looks like the Justice Department is putting a bit of a damper on the radio merger frenzy. As a result radio stocks are cooling, at least slightly. But the trend is still toward mergers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/12/busin.main_headline: SPENDING IT;Only a Will Can Insure That Thy Will Be Done
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/12/busin.print_headline: SPENDING IT;Only a Will Can Insure That Thy Will Be Done
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/12/busin.body_text: **********ABRAHAM LINCOLN died without one. **********So did Presidents Andrew Johnson, Ulysses S. Grant and James A. Garfield. **********Pablo Picasso, D. H. Lawrence and Howard Hughes, unconventional until the end, didn't bother to leave one behind, either. **********All went to their graves without writing wills, the granddaddy of all mistakes in estate planning. In the worst-case possibilities, the lack of a will can turn potential heirs against each other as lawyers feast on diminishing assets of the deceased. **********The need for a will has grown ever more important in American society as people live longer and become more affluent because of various retirement plans, rising real estate and stock values, experts say. **********Nevertheless, an estimated two out of three Americans die without a will, or  "intestate" in legal parlance. Many of these people have few worldly possessions, or they own property like bank accounts, houses and cars that pass  directly to a spouse or other joint owner outside probate, a system by which an  estate's debts are paid and assets distributed under court supervision. Life insurance and retirement fund benefits also bypass probate court. **********For anyone with substantial assets, though, an updated, valid and properly witnessed will is essential. It should designate an executor, who will administer the estate and see to it that debts are paid and assets distributed according to the wishes expressed in the will. **********Dying without a will is the biggest but not the only blunder made by people who fail to organize their finances before succumbing to infirmity and death. **********Many people who die with valid wills leave their families scrambling to find  the documents. A Manhattan widow, for example, left her will in the freezer for  safekeeping, reckoning -- incorrectly as it turned out -- that her family would  want ice cubes for a drink at her wake. **********The preparation of the will itself sometimes causes a problem. When people draw up their own wills or use standard forms, some of them generated on computers, certain mistakes can make the will invalid in New York and many other states: typing in provisions instead of writing them in longhand or having beneficiaries like children witness the signature. **********Because handling the affairs of a deceased family member often means dealing  with complicated issues and finances at a time of emotional distress, people should conduct a frank discussion with their heirs well before the onset of illness and death. **********But there is a reluctance on both sides of the generational divide to discuss death and personal finances when parents enjoy good health. Also, changes in American society have reduced opportunities for quiet exchanges of information around the dinner table. Divorce, remarriage and the mobility of retired parents and adult children often fracture family alliances, weaken bonds and open gaping emotional and geographic distances. **********"There is great reluctance and discomfort about bringing up unmentionable things like dying," said Judy Pollatsek, a clinical therapist in Washington and  a lecturer on death and grief. "Both parents and children may be in denial about death. **********"And asking parents where the safe deposit key is or how much they own can create guilt about prying, an invasion of privacy second only to asking your parents what they do in bed," she said. **********Ms. Pollatsek speaks from experience. When she asked her mother, who lives in California and has suffered several strokes, about her assets, she was cut short and told it was none of her business, she recalled. **********"There are so many things an adult child who doesn't live near a parent needs to know in case of death," she added. "But here I was, a professional who counsels others on dealing with emotions, and I'm reduced to tears because my mother is a couple of thousand miles away and being unreasonable." **********The fears of some parents are not baseless. Greed on the part of relatives anticipating an inheritance can reveal itself before and after a death. "I had a client who divulged her net worth to a daughter who then became very agitated and demanded part of inheritance right away," recalled Vincent J. Russo, a lawyer in Westbury, L.I., who specializes in wills and estates. **********Protracted court battles between family members who contest wills are growing in number, state court officials say. **********"You are dealing with people fighting over money in one of the most difficult periods of their lives," said A. Gail Prudenti of Suffolk County, one of the 63  Surrogate Court judges in New York State who supervise estates, trusts and contested wills. **********In Westchester County, Surrogate Judge Albert J. Emanuelli agreed. "Heirs today are much more prone to litigate than they were just a few years ago," he observed. "Any latent hostility that existed during mom and dad's lifetime rises in full bloom.  The children don't have to worry about mom and dad's feelings any more and they really take it out on each other." **********Some court fights concern emotional issues rather than money, he said. Disputes over relatively inexpensive heirlooms last for years and result in legal fees that add up to many times the value of the items. **********Divorce and remarriage spawn the most bitter legal battles, Judge Emanuelli said. "I think the 10 years I spent in private practice specializing in matrimonial law has been the best preparation for this job," the judge said with a sigh. **********These battles fall into a category that Prof. Thomas J. Reed of the Widener School of Law in Wilmington, Del., calls "David and Bathsheba" after the Biblical king and his second wife. **********Professor Reed was co-author of "Will Contests" (Clark Boardman Callahan) with Eunice L. Ross, a Pennsylvania Court of Common Pleas judge; in the book, they used literary and cultural allusions to label the most common reasons why wills are contested. Others are "Uriah Heep," after the clerk in Dickens's "David Copperfield," a symbol of a person who abuses his position of trust; "Judge Pyncheon," from Hawthorne's "House of Seven Gables," who exerts undue influence to share in an estate; "Esau and Jacob," based on the Old Testament brothers who represent the issues of sibling rivalry and parental favoritism, and "Mary Worth," the comic strip protagonist who represents the kindly old busybody named chief beneficiary in a neighbor's will. **********Trying to arrange one's final affairs with a trust, either to avoid estate taxes or probate, does not eliminate the potential problems of not having a will. A will is still needed to cover items not transferred to the trust, said Ernie Wruck Jr., an estate and trust lawyer in Patchogue, L.I. **********"There are a lot of do-it-yourselfers out there right now who are drawing up  living trusts to avoid probate," Mr. Wruck said. "Nine out of 10 times they are  going to forget to put all of their assets into the trust. We have one guy with  a $15 million estate who neglected to include another $2 million he owned. That  sum goes to probate, and unless he has a will naming beneficiaries, the court will distribute it according to a state formula, not necessarily the people he intended it to go to." **********Putting One's Affairs in Order **********Dying without a will is considered the biggest of all estate-planning mistakes. But even if you have a will, you should take these precautions to make sure there is no confusion among your heirs. *********** Make sure the will is properly witnessed and otherwise valid, is up to date and is placed in safekeeping. It should name an executor to handle the distribution of assets and other essential legal tasks. *********** If you move to another state, have your will reviewed by a lawyer there. *********** Apart from the will, create a folder marked "open in case of death" and put in it the names, addresses and phone numbers of an executor, lawyers and financial planners and the location of the will. Family or close friends should  be informed in writing where the folder can be found. *********** In the folder, keep a list of property, along with the names and account numbers of bank accounts, insurance policies, stocks, bonds, retirement and pension funds, veterans benefits and all other sources of income. Note your personal debts and include copies of recent state and Federal income tax returns. *********** Also in the folder, list your preferences on burial versus cremation, funeral  versus memorial services. This will spare mourners a wrenching debate. List the  names and addresses of a preferred church or clergyman, and cemetery or cremation service.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/22/world.main_headline: France's Army Keeps Grip in African Ex-Colonies
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/22/world.print_headline: France's Army Keeps Grip in African Ex-Colonies
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/22/world.body_text: **********Week in and week out for years, French sentries have manned the lookout towers at a military base here, and French soldiers have drilled behind high concrete walls topped with barbed wire. **********Despite such vigilance, France's military outpost here, 3,300 miles from Paris, is not guarding some hostile border or protecting against a foreign threat. **********Instead, to judge from the base's setting, hard against one of Africa's most extravagant presidential mansions, among Paris's top priorities here is protecting Gabon's autocratic leader, Omar Bongo, who was installed with French  help in 1968. **********With the end of the cold war, France has begun the difficult process of wrestling with the future size and shape of its large standing army.  Earlier this year President Jacques Chirac announced sweeping reforms that would alter longstanding French deployments in Europe and gradually introduce an all-volunteer force. **********Left unchanged, at least for now, however, are African commitments like these that date to independence 36 years ago. Besides Gabon, French troops are based in the Ivory Coast, Cameroon, Senegal, Central African Republic, Chad, Djibouti  and the Indian Ocean islands of Reunion and Mayotte. **********In addition to the countries where it has troops, France has military cooperation agreements with Mauritania, Mali, Burkina Faso, Benin, Togo, Equatorial Guinea, Congo, Zaire, Rwanda and Burundi. **********Since its 1964 intervention in Gabon, France has intervened militarily on the continent every other year on average. Paris has repeatedly sent troops into action in Chad, flown in paratroopers to rescue French and Belgian nationals in  Zaire and help put down an insurrection there, and used its forces to replace political leaders in the Central African Republic. **********[France said May 21 that it was trying to arrange a settlement to an army uprising in the Central African Republic, Reuters reported. French troops had been patrolling the capital, Bangui, at the Government's request, but most of the troops retreated to their bases, witnesses said, as fighting and looting continued. **********[A French military plane flew out with 138 French nationals, and an American  military plane was used to evacuate 13 Americans as American marines arrived to  help. French troops were flown from Gabon and Chad to reinforce those already in the Central African Republic.] **********In response to worried appeals by clients across the continent over rumors of an impending cutback of French troops, Mr. Chirac's Government pledged that Paris's military presence in Africa, totaling some 8,700 soldiers, would not be  reduced. **********If the announcement soothed Paris's main political allies , however, it has also stirred a public debate in Africa's increasingly free press and among opposition parties about France's mission on the continent. **********Late last year, France's Minister for Foreign Assistance, Jacques Godfrain, explained the sense of his country's continuing military presence in Africa in terms of stabilizing democracies. Paris "will intervene each time an elected democratic power is overthrown by a coup d'etat if a military cooperation agreement exists," he said. **********Given that France had never done such a thing and that most of its African-based troops are billeted in countries of dubious democratic credentials, Mr. Godfrain's remarks unleashed a storm of skeptical commentary throughout West and Central Africa. **********The skepticism turned to derision when Niger's first democratically elected Government fell to a military coup in February. At the time, France, which has a defense treaty with Niger, said it regretted the development but would not intervene. **********"What justifies this kind of presence?" asked an editorialist in the Ivory Coast daily Le Jour. "An external threat? Nothing could be less certain." For the Ivorian newspaper, and for commentators throughout this region, France's presence here has more to do with perpetuating Paris's predominance in an area that it has long considered its "natural" zone of influence. **********"Only the African continent gives France the illusion of being a great power," another Ivorian editorialist wrote, under the headline "France Comes to  the Rescue of Dictators," in response to Mr. Godfrain's remarks. **********Some countries where French troops are stationed, like the Ivory Coast and Gabon, represent rich markets for France or, like Niger and Chad, are current or potentially important sources of strategic resources such as uranium and oil. **********For many experts on African affairs, the history of France's military role in post-colonial Africa can be neatly condensed in the experience of Gabon, where Paris launched the first of many full-fledged interventions in 1964. **********When Gabon's first President, Leon M'ba, was overthrown in a broadly popular  military coup in 1964, French paratroopers were flown in to reinstate Mr. M'ba,  whose devotion to France was legendary. **********Mr. M'ba was soon weakened by illness, and by France's promotion of a young aide, Omar Bongo, to near figurehead status. Jacques Foccart, the chief adviser  on Africa to the French President at the time, Charles de Gaulle, wrote in his memoirs that Paris literally auditioned Mr. Bongo for the role of head of state, which he assumed in 1968 upon Mr. M'ba's death. **********Shortly after taking office, Mr. Bongo banned opposition parties in Gabon, and ruled unchallenged until a democratic reform movement began sweeping much of Africa in 1990. With his huge mansions throughout Gabon and around the world, diplomats say Mr. Bongo has used the country's large oil revenues to become one  of the continent's wealthiest leaders. **********Diplomats say corporations and businessmen from France, which retains an unusually high degree of influence here, even by the standards of its former colonies, have also done well by Gabon's oil-based economy. **********To protect that investment, from their bases in Gabon, the 600 or so French troops here have intervened twice, in 1990 and 1994, to help put down civil disturbances directed against Mr. Bongo's rule. **********A second wave of riots occurred after Mr. Bongo declared himself the winner of an election that international observers called "a very flawed exercise," with 51 percent of the vote. **********These days, Mr. Bongo, who is also protected by Moroccan security units and privately hired former French military officers, never goes anywhere without first closing off nearby streets to traffic. **********"There is no threat to Gabon other than the disaffection of the population towards its leader," said one Gabonese businessman who is sympathetic to the opposition. "When someone needs this kind of protection, that should tell you immediately that something is badly wrong." **********For diplomats of other Western nations, France's high-profile security role in countries like Gabon has more to do with preserving Paris's privileged access to business opportunities than it does with questions of democracy. **********"You could talk about the French presence for hours and hours, but it comes down to two things: prestige and business," said a Western diplomat here. "And they are absolutely determined not to let go of either." **********Though more and more Africans have begun to openly criticize France leveraging its military presence and tight network of political ties in Africa to maintain a commercial grip on its foreign colonies, French officials have been frankly unapologetic. **********"When we aid a country, we must have a minimum in return," said Bernard Debre, a former minister of foreign assistance, in an interview with the Paris-based magazine Jeune Afrique. "For France, Africa is also a market. Not a  captive market, certainly, but not a sieve either."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/17/world.print_headline: U.S. Cites Cuban Retraction on Shootdown
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/17/world.body_text: **********A display of American intelligence data apparently persuaded Cuba to drop its claim that the two unarmed civilian planes it shot down last month were in its airspace, Administration officials said today. **********A national security official at the White House said that during a New York City meeting in late February, senior officials of the Central Intelligence Agency showed Cuban intelligence officers "evidence that the shootdown did take  place in international airspace." **********Similar evidence had been presented earlier at the United Nations, but members of the Cuban delegation said they could not properly interpret it and asked that it be shown to their Government's intelligence experts. **********Following the Feb. 24 downing, the Cuban Foreign Minister, Roberto Robaina, repeatedly contended that the civilian planes had been over Cuban waters. **********The downing of the planes killed two pilots and two other members of a Cuban-American exile group, Brothers to the Rescue. It led to a tightening of the American embargo against Cuba. **********The Washington Post reported today that Cuba might have overreacted to statements by Jose Basulto, the leader of the exile group and the pilot of a third light aircraft, that he had previously violated Cuban airspace to buzz Havana and drop propaganda leaflets. **********These statements may have led Cuban officials to believe that Brothers to the Rescue would do so again, the newspaper said, and angered Fidel Castro.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/04/busin.body_text: **********Jobless Rate Eased in April, Despite Steady Payrolls The Government reported that the job market was lackluster in April, a day after reporting unexpectedly sharp growth in the economy in the first quarter. But even signs of modest growth failed to dissipate the inflation fears that rattled the financial markets on Thursday. The nation's unemployment rate eased to 5.4 percent in April from 5.6 percent in March and was at the lowest level in 14 months, even though there was no growth in business payrolls. **********The results reduced chances that the Federal Reserve would find it necessary  to tighten monetary policy soon. [Page 1.] **********Car Sales Cool Down  Car and truck sales weakened in April to an annual pace of 14.6 million, seasonally adjusted, down from a sizzling 15.9 million in March. The slowdown reflected surprisingly weak sales at Ford and some shortages of General Motors autos, which were slow getting to dealers because of the strike. Ford sales dropped 2 percent below April 1995. [35.] **********Merger to Form Insurance Giant  Royal Insurance and Sun Alliance plan to merge, forming Britain's second-largest publicly traded insurer and largest general insurer. The merger will result in annual savings of at least $262 million by 1998 for the combined company. [34.] **********Viacom Earnings Firm  Viacom turned in a better performance than expected, helped in large part by its alliance with the Kirch Group of Germany. While earnings fell 61 percent, Viacom avoided the loss that Wall Street had forecast. Viacom, the owner of Paramount Pictures and Blockbuster Video, earned $27.8 million in the quarter, and cash flow was stronger than expected. [37.] Mexico Power Plant to Serve U.S. Mexico is ready to begin building a $647 million electric power generating plant 30 miles south of El Paso, having resolved complex financing issues. Construction is to begin within a month, according to the Government, which called the step a breakthrough for the economy. The plant will serve not only Ciudad Juarez, a city of a million residents and more than 300 factories, but also American customers. [34.] **********Upjohn Operating Profit Up  Pharmacia & Upjohn said first-quarter operating earnings rose 8 percent, which was less than expected, on slow growth in pharmaceutical sales. Profits from operations increased to $229 million, but a big charge for integrating the two companies reduced net income to $50 million. [36.] **********New Chief at National Semi  National Semiconductor named Brian Halla as its chairman, chief executive and president, succeeding Gilbert Amelio, who left in February to head Apple Computer. Mr. Halla, 49, had been executive vice president of LSI Logic. His appointment came a week after National Semiconductor warned of disappointing earnings because of decreasing sales of its electronic parts. [43.] Transit Programs Halted in China Qingdao, China, a port city eager to attract foreign investment, had planned to  build a subway system, cross-harbor tunnel and a 10-mile bridge. But now all the projects have been suspended for lack of financing. Throughout China, basic transportation projects are being canceled or truncated. [3.] **********Anger at British Cow Slaughter  Britain began slaughtering cows that are at risk of contracting mad cow disease  but so far, the program has been a disaster for the beef industry: farmers are unsure of how they will get their backlog of animals slaughtered, and the $6.5-billion-a-year industry remains devastated by the export ban. [5.] **********Strike Threat Lifts Oil Prices  Crude oil prices rose on a strike threat in Norway and tight supplies. Crude oil for June delivery climbed 32 cents, to $21.18. [32.] **********Dollar Advances Against Yen  The dollar rebounded against the yen but fell against other leading currencies in a quiet session. The dollar rose to 105.05 yen, from 104.35 yen Thursday, while the British pound climbed to $1.5070, from $1.5025. [32.]

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/19/busin.main_headline: Fidelity Shifts Policy on Distressed Securities Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/19/busin.print_headline: Fidelity Shifts Policy on Distressed Securities Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/19/busin.body_text: **********Fidelity Investments, which in the last five years has dominated such high-profile bankruptcy cases as those involving Federated Department Stores and R. H. Macy & Company, abruptly announced yesterday that it was "discontinuing its aggressive style" of investing in the stocks, bonds and bank debt of weak and insolvent companies. **********"Today, aggressive investing can require a large ownership position and involvement in the reorganization process, including sitting on boards of directors and seeking to effect management changes," said Perry Chlan, a Fidelity spokesman. "Those are not consistent with our approach to investment management." **********In the future, he said, Fidelity will limit itself to smaller, "value-oriented" holdings "consistent with our mutual fund investment practices." **********The unexpected policy shift, which could jolt the thinly traded market for bankruptcy-linked securities, was confirmed by Mr. Chlan after Fidelity, the nation's largest mutual fund company and a unit of the FMR Corporation, announced the resignation of three key figures in its bankruptcy investing team: the money managers David J. Breazzano and Dan Harmetz, and the legal specialist  Judy K. Mencher. **********Mr. Breazzano was until yesterday the manager of the $2.3 billion Fidelity Capital and Income Fund, a substantial investor in the distressed securities market. Mr. Harmetz and Ms. Mencher were the dominant figures in the Macy bankruptcy in 1994, which led to Macy being merged into Federated Department Stores. In addition, Mr. Harmetz has managed three private investment partnerships, similar to highly leveraged hedge funds, with investments estimated at $750 million, largely in distressed securities. **********According to Fidelity, Mr. Breazzano's spot at the Capital and Income Fund will be taken by David L. Glancy, who now manages the Spartan High Income Fund.  That fund, in turn, will be taken over by Thomas T. Soviero, who had been managing private high-income accounts since 1994. **********Mr. Glancy, an accountant by training, worked for three years as a bond analyst before joining Fidelity in 1990. Mr. Soviero had four years' experience  as a bond and equity analyst before Fidelity hired him as an analyst in 1989. **********While both are described by colleagues and competitors as extremely intelligent, neither man has the reputation of Mr. Breazzano, who was a well-regarded bankruptcy investment manager at T. Rowe Price in Baltimore before he joined Fidelity in November 1990, or Mr. Harmetz, whose pre-Fidelity experience included managing the junk-bond portfolio of Columbia Savings and Loan in California. **********Nor have either Mr. Glancy or Mr. Soviero been deeply involved in the troubled companies in which Fidelity is currently playing an important role: Harrah's Jazz Company, Merry-Go-Round Enterprises and the El Paso Electric Company. **********All three have been substantial headaches -- and major disappointments -- for Fidelity. Harrah's Jazz collapsed into bankruptcy in November, barely a year after selling nearly $500 million worth of bonds to develop a casino and hotel complex in New Orleans. Since the bankruptcy filing, Fidelity has emerged as an  aggressive creditor -- it has already filed litigation against various figures involved in the case. **********In addition, Ms. Mencher has been playing a substantial role in the efforts of Merry-Go-Round, the retailing chain, to emerge from bankruptcy. The company's plan for reorganization, which was expected to be approved by last June, has been delayed amid continuing losses and weak sales. **********And while Fidelity successfully negotiated a reorganization for El Paso Electric, the result was an embarrassing regulatory bind: Fidelity stood to own  nearly 30 percent of the reorganized company, a stake so large that the mutual fund company could have been deemed to be a "public utility holding company" under Federal securities laws. To avoid that designation, which would have radically limited the fund group's investment options, it had to obtain an S.E.C. exemption from the Federal statutes. **********Asked about how Fidelity would deal with these on-going situations, Fidelity's spokesman, Mr. Chlan, said that Fidelity expected all three departing executives "to work with us to help us meet our obligations to all our clients." He said the specific terms of their future involvement with Fidelity had not yet been determined. **********The three were the core of Fidelity's high-income division, which manages about $8 billion through four public mutual funds and at least three private investment partnerships. Besides the Capital and Income Fund, the public mutual  funds managed by this unit include the Fidelity Spartan High-Income Fund, the Fidelity Advisor Strategic Income Fund and the Fidelity Advisor High Yield Fund. The three private partnerships managed by Mr. Harmetz are the Belmont Fund, the  Copernicus Fund and the Galileo Fund. **********None of the three departing executives returned calls made to their offices yesterday, but according to Fidelity, they intend to unite to form an independent asset management company specializing in distressed securities. With their Fidelity track record, all could reasonably expect to easily raise money from private investors -- indeed, Donald J. Trump, who knows Mr. Harmetz from his own dealings with Fidelity, is said to be among the investors lined up  for the new firm. **********Wall Street has always been home to so-called vulture investors -- people who buy the bonds and other securities of insolvent companies for pennies on the dollar, and then push for corporate changes that could make those securities more valuable. But public mutual funds did not enter the field in large numbers  until the late 1980's, when major junk-bond issuers started to collapse into bankruptcy. **********While many junk bond funds thus became "accidental vultures," Fidelity quickly expanded its presence and increased its power in the field. In December  1990, it officially converted its former junk-bond fund, renamed the Capital and Income Fund, into a fund specializing in both junk bonds and distressed securities. **********Since then, it has been an active player in dozens of important cases, including several of the Trump casino bankruptcies, the Bally's Grand casino-hotel case and, most visibly, the Macy bankruptcy reorganization.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/01/busin.main_headline: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF CHIP MAKER LSI LOGIC FALL FOR A SECOND DAY

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/01/busin.body_text: **********The stock of the LSI Logic Corporation fell again yesterday, a day after it joined other computer chip makers in warning of disappointing profits. The shares fell $3.875, to $27.625, in trading of more than 17 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock dropped $4 a share on Wednesday. Analysts had predicted first-quarter revenues of $350 million, unchanged from the fourth quarter of 1995, and earnings of 46 cents a share.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/14/world.main_headline: U.S. Sending Envoys to Seek Peace in Armenian-Held Region
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/14/world.print_headline: U.S. Sending Envoys to Seek Peace in Armenian-Held Region
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/14/world.body_text: **********The Clinton Administration has begun an unusually high-level effort to settle the bitter war over Nagorno-Karabakh, a disputed enclave of ethnic Armenians in  Azerbaijan, and to help make the region safe for oil development, American officials said today. **********The deputy national security adviser, Sandy Berger, and the Deputy Secretary  of State, Strobe Talbott, have been dispatched to Azerbaijan and Armenia for talks this week. **********A short-term goal is to encourage President Gaidar Aliyev of Azerbaijan and  President Levon Ter-Petrossyan of Armenia to come to Moscow next month for talks with senior American and Russian officials. **********President Clinton is to come to Moscow in mid-April for a summit meeting on nuclear issues. The hope is to use the Moscow meeting to stimulate progress on such thorny questions as how Nagorno-Karabakh might gain autonomy and how to resettle refugees. **********The longer-term goal is to deprive Iran of an opportunity to extend its influence in the region. **********The United States also wants to ease the harvesting of the vast reserves of oil in the Caspian Sea by an international consortium. Several oil pipelines are being planned, including one through Georgia and Turkey, thus depriving Moscow of a monopoly on oil shipments. But the pipeline to Turkey would pass near Nagorno-Karabakh, and fighting in the area would discourage oil production. **********A senior American official drew a direct link between the exploitation of oil resources in the Caspian Basin and prospects for stability. "Yes, they are linked," the official told reporters. "That is their road out, if you will. But  you can't get there from here, absent some kind of settlement in Nagorno-Karabakh." **********Predominantly Christian Armenia has forceably linked the ethnic Armenian enclave to its own territory; Azerbaijan wants to recover territory lost to Armenia and is particularly concerned about the fate of one city in the enclave  where the mostly Muslim Azeris are a majority. **********Further complicating matters is Russia's concern about American diplomacy in  an area that Moscow deems to be within its sphere of influence. To ease such fears, the Clinton Administration has stressed its cooperation with Moscow. **********Paul Goble, a former State Department expert, has advocated a swap of territory, in which Nogorno-Karabakh would go to Armenia. A senior American official declined today to address land exchanges.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/14/busin.snippet: Government securities trade higher on strength of weak economic data and firm dollar; table (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/14/busin.main_headline: Treasury Securities Higher As Firm Dollar Aids Bonds
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/14/busin.print_headline: Treasury Securities Higher As Firm Dollar Aids Bonds
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/14/busin.body_text: **********Government securities traded higher yesterday, aided by weak economic data and a firm dollar. **********Shorter maturities attracted investors who were shifting from the stock market, while a strong dollar, which makes United States investments more attractive to foreign investors, helped underpin bond prices. **********The 30-year bond rose 21/32 , to a price of 993/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, slipped to 6.57 percent, from 6.62 percent on Thursday. **********For the last few sessions, the market has largely ignored economic data, with technical factors dominating trade. But yields declined yesterday after the Government reported that business inventories in October had increased a larger-than-expected half-percent -- matching the gain in July. While inventory buildups can help the economy in the short term, they threaten an economic slowdown if not matched by sales. **********Investors also reacted to a University of Michigan survey that indicated consumer sentiment fell in December to 98.8 from 99.2 in November. Most had expected a rise of two-tenths of 1 percent. **********James Padinha, an economist with MMS International in San Francisco, said that consumer expectations had been rising for a long time and that the University of Michigan index was indicating ''there was not much of a slowdown in the economy.'' **********''The inventory increase,'' he added, ''on the other hand is stronger than expected, but not threatening.'' **********Steven Landis, director of fixed- income investments at Bull and Bear Advisors Inc., said he saw value in the market. ''All of the news this week has been market friendly,'' he said, ''and the market has reached levels where you will be glad you bought securities.'' **********He said the Treasury auction of two-year and five-year notes next week, along with coupon payments and payments on maturing issues, would put about $4.5 billion in cash back into the market by the time the year is out. **********Mr. Landis attributed the positive ending to the market's week to short- covering by dealers and overseas buying spurred by a strong dollar. **********''The dollar firmed,'' he said ''on news that the European Union finance ministers had reached agreement on penalties to protect the future European common currency from being wrecked by excessive borrowing by national governments. And the agreement seems to have clout behind it.'' **********Next week, the Federal Reserve's monetary policy arm will meet on Tuesday for a one-day meeting; few expect the central bank to adjust interest rates in the last meeting of the year. On Wednesday and Thursday, the Treasury will auction $30.75 billion of new two-year and five-year notes. **********In when-issued trading, the two-year note is being offered at a price to yield 5.74 percent and the five-year at a price to yield 6.05 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/13/busin.main_headline: Orange County: Hard Lesson in Safety of Municipal Debt
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/13/busin.print_headline: Orange County: Hard Lesson in Safety of Municipal Debt
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/13/busin.body_text: **********When Orange County, Calif., emerged from bankruptcy yesterday, ending an 18-month cliffhanger over the fate of this wealthy enclave south of Los Angeles, there was a Hollywood ending: Worried bondholders got paid in full, taxpayers did not have to raise a dime to pay off a $1.6 billion loss and the municipal market, after being burned once by the county, eagerly lent it $800 million more. **********But the neat resolution to the crisis, the largest municipal bankruptcy in United States history, could not hide the fact that the most fundamental tenet of municipal finance had been shaken -- the once ironclad belief that municipalities always pay their debts. **********This shared value, the underpinning of the $1.5 trillion market, ultimately  prevailed in Orange County. Yet many worry that the market could well be lulled  into complacency when it should instead be concerned about the red flags raised  by Orange County since it filed for bankruptcy in December 1994. **********"Things that were once unthinkable are now being thought of," said Joe Mysak, editor of Grant's Municipal Bond Observer, a trade publication. "This wasn't like nothing happened. This was a big deal. Yet I don't think people appreciate  the risks that this crisis revealed, because they haven't been touched by them yet. There's just a lot less security in municipal finance. This is a seismic event. Yet it will take a while to measure the reverberations." **********Unlike the corporate bond markets, in which risk is scrutinized from a variety of angles and security holders know that they could lose most of their money, the municipal markets have always been viewed as sleepier and less risky. There has been less scrutiny of the underlying risk of municipal deals, of the creditworthiness of municipalities and the risk of default, because investors have always been assured that municipalities would raise taxes to pay off their  borrowings -- and if they did not, the state would step in to help. That, in fact, is how financial crises in New York, Philadelphia and Cleveland were resolved. **********In Orange County, not only did the county do the unthinkable -- make its creditors fight it out with the county in bankruptcy court -- but it did not raise taxes to cover its debts. And the State of California made it clear that it would not step in to help. **********"The municipal system did receive some interesting tests," said Paul S. Maco, head of the Securities and Exchange Commission's office of municipal securities. "The edges of the envelope were tested." **********In the end, the crisis was resolved when Orange County engineered an elaborate plan, dubbed Project Robin Hood, to divert funds coming into some of the county's agencies and use them instead to repay bondholders. In addition, some Orange County municipalities agreed to accept only 80 cents on the dollar for claims they had against the county from the losses in the county's investment pool, with the rest to be made up from any proceeds of litigation filed by the county against its former financial advisers. **********"Investors will interpret the resolution of Orange County as an affirmation that there is no risk in municipal debt," said Chris Varelas, an adviser to the  county at Salomon Brothers. "But Orange County proves that the safeguards to investors may not be there. We've recalculated risk. What does 'full faith and credit' mean when you have no ability to raise taxes and you have a community with high antitax sentiment. Does it mean you will be paid in full?" **********He added: "The risk was always there. But people's perception of risk was not calibrated with the actuality of it." **********Orange County exposes the risks inherent in municipal finance: that municipalities can file for bankruptcy, that their elected officials may not be  responsible or right-thinking, that default is possible and that financially pressed municipalities may have neither the resources nor the willingness to always honor their obligations. Especially in an era of taxpayer revolt and the  shifting of the burden for costly health and welfare services from the Federal Government to cash-short local governments, these issues are expected to come into play even more in the future, experts say. **********"Orange County gave us a fundamental lesson that wasn't there before," said Jeremy Ragus, a municipal portfolio manager for Scudder, Stevens & Clark, a mutual fund company. "Before, the willingness of any major voting group to pay was never in question. There are now limits of what you can do with taxes -- you just can't raise them." **********In addition, Orange County's bankruptcy was the catalyst for several other trends. There is some debate about whether the apparently successful resolution  will encourage more municipalities to seek bankruptcy protection. **********Some argue that it has given the S.E.C. a broad platform to make its case for greater financial accountability by public officials and more prudence in the investment of public funds. And there may well be a shift in the type of borrowing used by municipalities -- more toward project finance, with limited protection given to borrowers, and away from general obligation bonds and their  unlimited promise to repay investors. **********At least two groups are thinking about proposing amendments to the Federal Bankruptcy Code to make it more difficult for municipalities to seek bankruptcy  protection. As this goes on, some say that Orange County has moved municipal bankruptcy from the unthinkable to a possible financial tool. Others say that the pain and disruption that resulted in Orange County show how costly a tool this is. **********Bankruptcy, after all, does not reduce the payment of obligations, it only slows it down. In Orange County's case, the county has $800 million more in long-term debt than when it filed for bankruptcy, and services to many of its citizens, mainly the poor, are being drastically cut. **********With some Orange County officials facing civil and criminal charges over their roles in the county's $1.6 billion loss, a warning shot has been fired against poor public oversight. "There's a great level of fear and concern among  local officials over the S.E.C. enforcement actions," said Robert Dean Pope, a bond attorney with Hunton & Williams, a Richmond firm. **********James Spiotto, a lawyer with Chapman & Cutler in Chicago, added: "It won't be amateur hour any more. The professionals and the officials will be required by the S.E.C. and by the market to know and stand by their product." **********One market analyst, who insisted that he not be named, said: "Orange County was a near miss. Every time this happens, all bets are off. Before, the market got used to municipalities doing what they promised for bondholders and then more. Now municipalities may well just do what they promised -- and no more."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/11/busin.snippet: General Electric Co says third-quarter earnings increased 11 percent over period last year; sales were up more than 15 percent, to $20 billion; actual earnings were $1.788 billion, up 11 percent over corresponding quarter last year; table (L)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/11/busin.main_headline: G.E. Reports 11% Increase In Third-Quarter Earnings
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/11/busin.print_headline: G.E. Reports 11% Increase In Third-Quarter Earnings
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/11/busin.body_text: **********The General Electric Company announced yesterday that third-quarter earnings increased 11 percent over the period last year. **********''It was a truly solid quarter,'' said  Ann M. Schwetje of Smith Barney.  Nicholas P. Heymann, a NatWest Securities analyst who is among the most bullish of G.E.'s fans, readily agreed. ''It shows everything is A-O.K. and on track there,'' he said. **********Indeed it is. G.E., a conglomeration of 12 disparate businesses, has always been well hedged -- a sluggish European market can always be offset by a boom in Asia, while one good sweeps week at NBC can make up for a badly timed entry into on-line information markets. And lately, only G.E.'s smallest businesses, like transportation and information systems, have been hiccupping. Indeed, the company's sales were up more than 15 percent, to $20 billion. **********''One of the joys is that our largest divisions, like GE Capital, power systems and NBC, led the record growth,'' said Bruce Bunch, a G.E. spokesman. **********G.E. has been cutting costs across the company. Its manufacturing divisions are chasing service and spare parts contracts, far less capital-intensive businesses than equipment manufacturing. And all its businesses are trying to sell more to existing customers, which is less expensive than trying to woo new ones. **********The cost improvements have freed up a staggering amount of cash. So far this year G.E. has generated $5.4 billion in cash, compared with just $2.4 billion in the first nine months of last year. Much of that money has been used to increase dividends and to buy back stock. In fact, the stock buybacks were in part responsible for raising earnings to $1.08 a share. The gain over the third quarter last year was 13 percent a share, exactly what analysts had predicted. Actual earnings were $1.788 billion, up 11 percent over the corresponding quarter last year. **********Both the sales and earnings reflect a nonrecurring bonanza from last summer's Olympics, which analysts say tacked $650 million onto NBC's sales numbers and added close to $60 million in profits to the company's  coffers. The sluggish economy in Europe, an area that accounts for about a fifth of G.E.'s sales (a quarter, counting exports from the United States), reined in some sales. **********Still, the good news far outweighed the bad. G.E.'s major appliances, despite a flat market, saw sales increase about 4 percent, as G.E. continued to grab share away from Whirlpool, Maytag and other makers of washers, dryers and the like. **********G.E. plastics and silicones did well, despite soaring chemical costs, primarily because demand was high and no new capacity came on stream. **********G.E.'s power systems division, which has had technological problems with some of its newer turbines as well as a flat market from American utilities, got a tremendous boost when Nuovo Pignone, the Italian company it purchased in late 1993, received a $1 billion contract to supply compressors to Gazprom, Russia's huge natural gas company. Power system's sales were up 30 percent and its profits up 35 percent for the quarter. **********Even G.E.'s nuclear businesses are enjoying a turnaround, as more utilities hire the company to manage existing nuclear power plants.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/26/world.main_headline: East German Ex-Activists Continue as a Force in West
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/26/world.print_headline: East German Ex-Activists Continue as a Force in West
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/26/world.body_text: **********When Chancellor Helmut Kohl dropped by to visit the human rights advocate Barbel Bohley in her small Berlin apartment recently, a storm of controversy erupted. **********Ms. Bohley helped organize the mass protests that brought down East Germany's Communist Government in 1989, and many of her former comrades felt she was betraying their cause by sipping tea with someone who epitomizes the political establishment as completely as Chancellor Kohl. Left-leaning journals condemned  her with headlines like "Former Dissident Makes Peace With Power." **********The criticism did not seem to bother Ms. Bohley, who has spent much of her life as an outsider. But when a satirical magazine devoted its cover to a photomontage in which she appeared to be having sex with the Chancellor, she sued. A judge is now considering the case. **********That such a furor should erupt around Ms. Bohley's political choices reflects the influence that leaders of the East German revolution still have here. Although very few have moved into positions of power in the united Germany, they still have a call on the nation's conscience. They join demonstrations, sign petitions, write articles and preach sermons. Whatever they say or do, people in both east and west take note. **********"These people play a very interesting role in our society," said Peter Schneider, the Berlin novelist and screenwriter. "We naturally admire them for their courage, but there's also another side to it. Some people resent them because they are living proof that the individual can resist evil. Many Germans  are uncomfortable facing that truth, because we've built a national myth out of  the belief that there is no alternative to submitting to tyrants." **********The former dissidents often attract large audiences when they speak in western Germany, and they are regularly quoted in newspapers throughout the country. Leading politicians compete to honor them. A few months ago, President  Roman Herzog awarded 28 of them the Federal Merit Cross, Germany's highest civilian award. Chancellor Kohl has met with them several times and is planning  to be a co-sponsor of a new lobby group that will represent victims of repression in East Germany. **********"We have the greatest respect and admiration for the men and women whose courage in the face of tyranny made this peaceful revolution possible," Mr. Kohl said recently in Leipzig. "The civil rights movement played a crucial role in the collapse of the Communist dictatorship." **********What is odd about this flow of tributes is that they honor a small group of people whose views about unified Germany are far from uniformly positive. In a series of interviews, several complained that the country they helped create is  too materialistic and that easterners have not been given a fair voice. **********Instinctively critical of capitalism but also acutely aware of the importance of freedom, the 1989 leaders today weigh the success of their movement against what they see as its failure to create a caring, idealistic society. **********"The most important success is that we now have democratic freedoms, which is something I will never undervalue," said the Rev. Friedrich Schorlemmer, a Lutheran minister based in Wittenberg who runs several social projects in addition to his parish responsibilities. "It's also great that in this region where everything was falling apart, so much is being done to rebuild schools and roads and other things we need. **********"But two things have gone very wrong. The first is that although we have escaped from the tyranny of ideology, we fell into the tyranny of money. The way wealth is distributed in this society is something I find very hard to take. **********"The second thing is that we easterners lost our feeling of dignity, because  the west ignored all of our suggestions for change. They didn't take our experience seriously. Looking back at it now, I see that a true unification was  not possible. The west was too big and powerful, and we were too small and poor." **********An even stronger critique came from another Lutheran pastor, the Rev. Christian Fuhrer. His church in Leipzig was a hotbed of dissent during the Communist era, and a new film about his exploits in those days has renewed his aura of heroism. He speaks bitterly about unification. **********"I feel a sense of disillusion, of dreams falling away," Pastor Fuhrer said in his cluttered parish office. "You have to remember that we East Germans had no real picture of what life was life in the west. We had no idea how competitive it would be. The whole system was unknown. **********"The chance to renew Germany was not taken. A very conscious decision was made not to create a new Germany. People in the west simply do not believe that  their system needs any change. Unification was like a marriage in which one partner expects the other to do everything his way, but doesn't make that clear  until after the wedding." **********Not all veterans of the 1989 movement hold such regrets. One who offered a more positive view was Ulrike Poppe, who was a co-founder of one of East Germany's first dissident groups in 1983 and who helped plan many anti-Government protests in and around Berlin. **********"I had hoped for more from unification, something more than just a reaffirmation of the West German political system," said Ms. Poppe, who now organizes seminars on human rights and social issues. "I thought there would be  a little more in the way of reform. But fundamentally, we got what we wanted. We live in a state of law. The conditions of life allow us to pursue our own goals." **********Like several other former East German dissidents, Ms. Poppe turned down chances to pursue a political career. One who made the opposite choice is Joachim Gauck, a Lutheran clergyman from the northern city of Rostock. Mr. Gauck now holds one of Germany's most sensitive jobs: He runs the agency charged with  holding, analyzing and releasing the vast archives left behind by the Stasi, the East German secret police. **********During the tumultuous days following the collapse of the Berlin wall in November 1989, Mr. Gauck strongly urged quick German unification. He rejected the view, held by Ms. Bohley and others, that East Germany should remain apart and try to build a new society of its own. Today he is certain he was right. **********"I'm more pleased with the results of unification than a lot of other people  who were active in the East German opposition," Mr. Gauck said. "As I see it, we now have just about everything we fought for. We won. Naturally I'm not pleased to be living in a society where 10 percent of the people are unemployed. But we have basic freedoms, and that gives us the power to build whatever kind of society we want." **********The failings that many easterners see in unification, Mr. Gauck asserted, are partly their own fault. **********"I wish easterners would participate more in public life," he said.  "We aren't used to doing that, because we grew up under dictatorship. The idea of active participation was bred out of us over 40 years. Now we want to enjoy freedom, but we don't understand what it is. We don't realize that it takes work."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/08/world.body_text: **********Pinhas Menachem Alter, one of Israel's rigorously Orthodox rabbis, died today in Jerusalem. He was 69. **********Rabbi Alter was found dead at his home. He was not known to be ill, and no cause of death was immediately announced. **********Born in Poland, he headed the Gerrer or Gur community, one of the most influential Hasidic groups in Israel. The Gur dynasty of rabbis was founded at Gora Kalwaria, near Warsaw, in 1859. **********Rabbi Alter was instrumental in preventing the entry of the ultra-Orthodox United Torah Judaism bloc into Israel's present Labor-led Government. **********Menachem Friedman, an expert on Hasidic Jewry at Bar-Ilan University, said Rabbi Alter never forgave Prime Minister Shimon Peres for forming a coalition with the left-wing secular Meretz bloc. **********"For him, the name of Shulamit Aloni was like a red rag to a bull," Mr. Friedman said, referring to the Meretz leader. **********Rabbi Alter is survived by a wife, four sons and a daughter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/10/busin.main_headline: Channel Operator Also Says Loss Narrowed : Eurotunnel Nears a Deal To Restructure Its Debt
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/10/busin.print_headline: Channel Operator Also Says Loss Narrowed : Eurotunnel Nears a Deal To Restructure Its Debt
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/10/busin.body_text: **********After almost a year of intense negotiations, Eurotunnel, the operator of the Channel Tunnel, said Monday a deal to restructure its nearly £9 billion ($14.04 billion) of debt might be achieved within weeks, or perhaps days. **********"We have only got eight hours of serious negotiations left," said Sir Alastair Morton, the company's co-chairman, "so I am allowing eight weeks to get the job done." **********Sir Alastair, who had pledged to stay on until his last task — putting Eurotunnel on a sound financial footing — was done, said that he would leave the company by the end of October, but he did not rule out last-minute delays dragging the refinancing negotiations deeper into the autumn. **********In August, Eurotunnel obtained an extension to Sept. 30 for mediation on debt restructuring after the British-French company was unable to reach a deal with its creditors. **********Having last year embraced the idea that banks would convert some of the debt into Eurotunnel shares, Sir Alastair said Monday that such a transaction had to have limits, as Eurotunnel's 750,000 shareholders would not be willing to face an indefinite dilution of their stakes. **********"This will not be an 'Anglo-Saxon creditor takes all' kind of deal," Sir Alastair said. **********He said any deal negotiated between the company and its 225 creditor banks would require the approval of 75 percent of voting shareholders.Even if a refinancing were agreed this month, shareholders would not vote on it until next spring or summer because of the complexities involved in preparing the papers and ironing out details, analysts said. **********Even though Eurotunnel's problem remains its debt burden, it reported Monday that its first-half loss narrowed as revenue more than doubled. The company's loss shrank 20 percent from a year earlier, to £372 million, as its revenue more than doubled to £224 million from £105 million in the first half of 1995, when the company was still in the early stages of operations. **********"The numbers are as bad as ever, and they don't matter anyway," Richard Hannah, an analyst with UBS Ltd., told Bloomberg Business News. "What matters is what the banks will agree to in the refinancing of the debt." **********Eurotunnel's London-traded units rose 3.1 percent, to 100.5 pence.. Its Paris-listed shares closed up 3.2 percent to 8.10 francs. **********The real crunch for Eurotunnel will come in March, when it must begin paying interest on its debt. It suspended those payments in September 1995, a right that, under its loan agreements, runs for 18 months. By most accounts, even in the best of commercial conditions, Eurotunnel's revenue next year is expected to service no more than £4.5 billion in debt. That leaves a similar amount of debt to be swapped for shares, written off or, more likely, a combination of the two. **********Company executives said shareholders and creditors were locked in a bitter battle to see who gets what share of Eurotunnel's cash flow over the 56 years remaining in its license to run the tunnel between England and France. The Japanese banks are expected to be the toughest negotiators; they hold a quarter of Eurotunnel's debts and are trying to resolve domestic loan losses. **********Jeff Summers, head of research at Klesch & Co., estimated that a straight conversion of Eurotunnel's excess debt into shares at Monday's price would leave the banks owning 85 percent of the company.
