https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/24/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Russia and De Beers Sign Diamond Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/24/busin.body_text: **********Russia signed a diamond marketing agreement yesterday with De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd. of South Africa that paves the way for a three-year sales deal, the two sides said. The agreement gives Russia a significantly larger quota for direct exports of uncut stones, according to a senior official  at Russia's diamond exporting company. **********A memorandum of understanding was signed yesterday by Russia's Finance Minister, Vladimir Panskov, and Nicky Oppenheimer, the deputy chairman of De Beers, an affiliate of the Anglo American Corporation. The company said a formal sales deal would be signed "as soon as possible." The two sides have been negotiating since 1994 on renewing the previous deal. Under that accord, Russia  sells 95 percent of its exports of rough gem diamonds to the De Beers cartel.   (AP)

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/09/busin.main_headline: Market Place;Labor Desires May Threaten Northwest Air
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/09/busin.print_headline: Market Place;Labor Desires May Threaten Northwest Air
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/09/busin.body_text: **********Life is pretty good these days at Northwest Airlines. Of the largest carriers, Northwest faces perhaps the least competition from feisty low-cost airlines. With the help of an industry recovery, Northwest's stock has risen from an initial offering price of $13 in 1994 to yesterday's close of $49.625 a  share. **********And to reward its senior managers, Northwest disclosed last week that it was  seeking to raise the number of shares available for bonuses to five million from two million. **********This quiet prosperity, though, may be disrupted this fall when Northwest's union contracts expire. **********At the very minimum, the unions will get so-called snapbacks to return their  annual wages to what they were before they gave up about $280 million in wages.  In return for those concessions, the unions got almost a third of the company's  stock and three seats on the 15-member board. **********But union leaders say they will be looking for far more than simply a return  to old wage levels. Rather, they want to reap rewards above and beyond an appreciating stock price. Just how hard they will negotiate represents a question that many investors do not fully appreciate. **********"The market hasn't fully factored in the uncertainty surrounding the snapbacks and the accompanying labor negotiations this fall," said Jeffrey Long, an analyst at J. P. Morgan. **********Grumbling from organized labor prior to contract talks is to be expected. But warnings from Northwest's union leaders cannot be easily dismissed. Of the big airline employee-ownership deals in recent years, including one at United Airlines, Northwest Airlines benefited the most from swapping stock for wage concessions -- the move that helped it avert a bankruptcy filing. **********"Their rescue was the deepest," said Joseph R. Blasi, a professor of management-labor relations at Rutgers University. **********That fact is not lost on Northwest's labor leaders. "Now is the day of reckoning," said Marvin Sandrin, president of the International Association of Machinists local that represents Northwest mechanics. "If we are going to take a chance on the downside, we sure as hell want a part of the profits on the upside." **********Bruce Retrum, president of the teamsters' local that represents Northwest flight attendants, added that he, too, would be asking for something above and beyond the snapbacks. "Northwest is a revitalized company, much to the credit of the hard work of its employees," he said. "It has been a difficult three years for our members," whose wages were cut 12 to 13 percent. **********Although John H. Dasburg, the president, gave back a $750,000 bonus he earned in 1994, he more than made up for it last year by cashing in on stock options worth $8.7 million. The company's proxy statement also disclosed that Northwest    will also grant him the cash equivalent of 100,000 shares in August, around the  time the union contracts expire. In addition, he will have the chance to earn, depending on his and the airline's performance, the equivalent of 400,000 shares through the year 2004. **********Mr. Dasburg's jump in overall pay mirrors the increases for many other top executives. According to compensation experts, chief executives at some of the nation's largest corporations earned pay packages last year that grew at a rate  far quicker than for most American workers. **********The Air Line Pilots Association, which represents Northwest pilots, is bothered less by Mr. Dasburg's incentive pay. After all, a representative of the union sits on the board's compensation committee. In addition, said Paul Omodt,  a spokesman for the union, the pilots felt that Mr. Dasburg had put a good team  in place and was keeping the airline on firm footing, making an incentive package necessary to keep him. **********"It is," Mr. Omodt said, "one of the realities of business today." **********Kevin C. Murphy, an airline analyst at Morgan Stanley, said he believed that  productive management-labor relations at Northwest in recent years would continue to protect the gains reflected in Northwest's stock price. **********Mr. Murphy also characterized Mr. Dasburg's incentive pay as a bargain, considering the rise in Northwest's stock price. **********"Any time you're creating enormous value," he said, "you're worth $8.7 million."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/13/news/.main_headline: China Reassures Hong Kong's Many Holders of Foreign Passports
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/13/news/.print_headline: China Reassures Hong Kong's Many Holders of Foreign Passports
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/13/news/.body_text: **********HONG KONG—                     Moving on Friday to allay serious concerns about Beijing's stance on nationality laws and residency rights in Hong Kong after July 1, 1997, a senior Chinese official ruled out unequal treatment for local residents holding foreign passports. **********In his first public statements to a city wracked by new doubts about life under Chinese rule, Lu Ping, the visiting head of Beijing's Hong Kong and Macau Affairs office, described China's views on the complex issue as "pragmatic and flexible." **********China, in effect, does not care what other passports Hong Kong residents now hold, Mr. Lu said, citing detailed examples and scenarios, provided they do not ask for consular protection from their adoptive countries and seek Chinese nationality at the same time. **********Hong Kong residents who choose to declare their foreign nationality on entering the territory after the 1997 handover will lose automatic rights to vote and seek employment, Mr. Lu said, but most will be treated like other foreigners and will be granted conditional residency and work rights. **********Although China disagreed with recent British efforts to grant additional passports to local people, a program that saw more than 200,000 people apply in one recent week alone, Mr. Lu said, "No registration, examination or any special arrangements will need to be adopted toward these people." **********And if Hong Kong residents choose to travel abroad on non-Chinese documents without notifying local authorities, that will be acceptable also. That would be a departure from Beijing's normal stance, which does not recognize dual nationality. **********"It makes things much clearer and easier to understand," said a local Chinese businessman who heard Mr. Lu's address. He spoke at a seminar on Hong Kong's economic future that was organized by a local business lobby. **********"There were quite serious worries that Beijing might force people to choose between local residency and foreign nationality," said the businessman, the holder of a foreign passport. **********But while Mr. Lu's speech is likely to reassure the estimated 700,000 to 1 million people in Hong Kong with foreign passports, he said nothing to diffuse tensions in rapidly polarizing local political circles. **********Mr. Lu's visit coincides with a meeting of the Preparatory Committee, a group appointed by Beijing to decide a host of key transition matters. **********It also comes when many local residents, particularly those who are active politically, are expressing grave fears about China's plans to stifle dissent. **********Beijing's decision to press forward with plans to abolish Hong Kong's first fully elected legislature and replace it with an appointed body that will begin its work six months before the handover has quickly opened a chasm between groups that support and oppose this decision. **********China says it was forced to do this in retaliation for a unilateral decision by Britain to reform rules for the elections held last September. **********The Hong Kong and British governments decry Beijing's plans and refuse to cooperate with any gestures that might legitimize the provisional body. **********A senior Chinese official's demands earlier this month that top-level Hong Kong bureaucrats openly support the coming provisional legislature has badly shaken a largely apolitical civil service. **********At the same time, the refusal by the Preparatory Committee to meet with any local community groups that question the legality of China's plans for a provisional legislature suggests that open political debate in Hong Kong could be endangered, some politicians said. **********"Hong Kong people seem to be trapped like a bird in a cage now," a local legislator, Cheung Man-kwong, told Reuters. **********"I'd rather become a small bird flying free than a canary in a cage only singing those songs that a master likes to hear," said Mr. Cheung, who was barred from the consultations with the Preparatory Committee earlier this week because he opposed China's plan to appoint the legislature.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/29/world.body_text: **********A gunman methodically killed at least 32 people at and near a popular tourist site on Sunday. The police captured him today when he bolted in flames from a guest cottage, which he had set afire with three hostages inside. **********The gunman, whom police described as a 29-year-old with a history of psychological problems, had opened fire with an semiautomatic rifle on Sunday afternoon on tourists at the ruins of a colonial prison on Tasmania. **********It was the worse shooting massacre in Australia in this century. **********The police indicated that they expected to find the bodies of three more victims inside the guest cottage, where the gunman took three hostages and held  the police at bay for 12 hours. **********Witnesses said the incident began at about 1:30 P.M. on Sunday, when the blond man drove up to the prison in a Volkswagen with a surfboard strapped on its top and talked casually with some of the 500 people outside. **********"He said, 'There's a lot of WASP's around today; there's not many Japs here,  are there?' and then started muttering to himself," an unidentified survivor told the Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio. **********The man then walked into a cafe, pulled the rifle from a tennis bag, and methodically started shooting. **********"He wasn't going bang-bang-bang-bang," a witness, Phillip Milburn, told the Australian radio. "It was 'bang,' and then he'd pick someone else out and line them up and shoot them." **********[An account by Reuters, quoting Deputy Police Commissioner Richard McCreadie  at a news conference in Hobart, the capital, gave this sequence of events: The gunman first opened fire with a high-powered rife in the crowded cafe, killing 20 people.  [He moved on among the ruins, shooting three people dead outside the cafe. He got back into his car and drove to the entrance to the ruins, where he  killed a 3-year-old girl and 6-year-old girl and their mother. He shot dead all  four occupants of a car, which he then drove to a nearby service station, killing a woman there -- his 31st victim. Mr. McCreadie did not account for the  32d victim. **********[The gunman also kidnapped a man and stowed him in the trunk of the stolen car, then drove to the nearby Seascape guest house, where he holed up with the hostages.] **********The bed-and-breakfast cottage was owned by a couple who apparently were friends of the gunman's late father. The Age newspaper of Melbourne identified them as David and Sally Martin. **********By early today, more than 200 local and special police units had surrounded the guest house. **********The police tried to negotiate by phone with the gunman, who fired two heavy-caliber military-type rifles at them and at helicopters airlifting out the dead and wounded. He demanded a helicopter for himself. **********When he set the cottage on fire, flames finally drove him from the building.  He threw his rifle aside. **********"His clothing was on fire, and he started taking his clothing off," said Police Superintendent Bob Fielding. **********Exploding ammunition in the burning house prevented officers from rapidly searching it to learn the fate of the three hostages. "It doesn't look very good," Mr. Fielding said. **********The police said 25 of those killed in the shooting spree were Australians, but the dead also included two Malaysians and a victim who appeared to be Indian. Four people were not identified. **********One American and two Canadians were wounded along with 15 others. The police  said only that the American man, from Washington state, was not badly hurt. **********One Melbourne woman told the Australian Associated Press that she survived by hiding under a table at the cafe. **********"There were people just sitting there in their chairs where they'd been eating -- dead," she said. "There was a weird sort of calm, as if no one could believe what they were seeing." **********Wendy Scurr, who worked at the front desk at the historic site, said the gunman had left "shooting as he went, shooting everybody he could see." She said she "ran for my life along with hundreds of other people at the site." **********Another witness, Karen Jones, told the Australian radio that as the gunman kept firing at fleeing tourists and at tourist buses outside the cafe, "the guy  that we were with had to go and help take a stretcher in, and the mother was saying, 'You have to get my baby to the hospital, quick, quick.' But it was already dead." **********The old Port Arthur prison colony is on the Tasman Peninsula, connected to Tasmania's mainland by one road on a narrow isthmus. The police closed off the road into Port Arthur, the landing site of some of the toughest convicts England sent into Australian exile in the 1800's. **********State gun laws vary in Australia, but it is fairly easy for a person without  a criminal record to buy a rifle or shotgun. Pistols are less commonly owned. **********Tasmania has one of the most lax gun laws in the nation. Until recent law changes, almost anyone could buy any kind of weapon, even a machine gun.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/10/busin.snippet: Boeing Co wins Air Force contract valued at $540 million for sale and maintenance of four C-32A planes; Boeing says planes will be delivered in early 1998 and it will provide support for them through 2005 (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/10/busin.body_text: **********The Boeing Company said today that it had won an Air Force contract valued at $540 million for the sale and maintenance of four C-32A planes, used mostly to transport Government executives, including the Vice President. **********The planes will be delivered in early 1998, and Boeing will provide support for them through 2005, the company said. **********The Air Force said the planes would be powered by engines made by Pratt & Whitney, which is a unit of the United Technologies Corporation. **********The value of that contract was not disclosed. **********The planes are modified versions of the twin-engine 757-200, which is a medium-size commercial plane that can fly long distances. **********They will replace four Boeing C-137 jets that the Air Force has used to transport Government executives since the late 1950's.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/15/busin.main_headline: RISCORP CONSIDERS A SALE OF THE COMPANY
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/15/busin.print_headline: RISCORP CONSIDERS A SALE OF THE COMPANY
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/15/busin.body_text: **********Riscorp Inc. said yesterday that it would consider a sale of the company in light of a recent plunge in its stock price and disappointing earnings. The company, a provider of health care services in workers' compensation cases, formed a committee to consider its options, including its sale, to improve its share price. The move comes as Riscorp reported lower-than-expected third-quarter earnings and warned that it would probably fail to meet fourth-quarter estimates. It also comes amid an investigation of political contributions by top executives. Shares of Riscorp, based in Sarasota, Fla., dropped $2, to $4.375, giving the company a current market capitalization of $163 million. The company's shares traded as high as $24.50 in May.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/02/busin.snippet: Robertson, Stephens & Co, brokerage firm involved in dispute with its client, Xylan Corp, suspends its analyst, Paul Johnson, for allegedly leaking news to certain institutional clients about resignation of Xylan's chief financial officer, C Steph...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/02/busin.body_text: **********Robertson, Stephens & Company, the San Francisco brokerage firm involved in a dispute with a client, the Xylan Corporation, suspended the analyst at the center of the controversy yesterday. **********Executives at Xylan accused Robertson, Stephens, its investment banker, on Wednesday of having leaked news to certain institutional clients that the company's chief financial officer, C. Stephen Cordial, had resigned before the company officially announced the resignation. Xylan's shares fell about 12 percent on the disclosure; they have since rebounded. **********In a statement released yesterday by the Robertson, Stephens chief executive, Michael G. McCaffery, the firm said the analyst, Paul Johnson, had been suspended without pay pending the conclusion of an internal investigation into the matter. **********''It is this firm's policy to insure that confidential information be maintained by every employee of this firm as confidential,'' the statement said. **********Xylan makes high-band switching systems designed to improve the performance of local area computer networks and ease the transition to the next generation of networking technology. **********Shares of Xylan, listed on the Nasdaq, rose $4.50 yesterday, to $42. **********John Mazzaferro, a Xylan spokesman, said yesterday, ''We thought the matter was handled inappropriately.''

Vyacheslav Tikhomirov, the ITAR-Tass news agency said. It said that discussions centered on 26 Russian soldiers the rebels captured on Saturday in the Nozhai-Yurt region southeast of Grozny and on 10 Chechens taken prisoner  by the Russians a day earlier in Shali. **********Mr. Guldimann was also to meet the rebels' military chief, Aslan Maskhadov.  The Interfax news agency reported that Mr. Maskhadov was also in contact with Russia's military command.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/26/busin.body_text: **********The chemical company BASF A.G. has joined Daimler-Benz A.G. in a challenge to labor as they cut sick pay for 264,000 German employees. **********Shares in Daimler, which has 220,000 employees, rose today by 75 pfennigs a share, to 34.45 marks ($22.50), after it announced on Tuesday that it would cut sick pay to 80 percent of gross income as of Oct. 1, when a new law lowers the minimum sick pay level. BASF followed today, saying it planned to reduce sick pay for its 44,000 German employees. **********Unions threatened strikes and court action to fight the reductions, which top a list of deregulatory measures that industry and government say are needed to increase Germany's appeal to business. **********Germany's largest industrial company announced the move on Tuesday, just one day after Chancellor Helmut Kohl called on German industry to hold to labor contracts until questions could be sorted out. **********Daimler said it was within its rights in imposing the new sick pay minimum, one of the key elements in a package pushed by Mr. Kohl and passed by the Parliament Sept. 13.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/14/your-.print_headline: A Career and Children: Have It All, at a Price
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/14/your-.body_text: **********In theory, most women no longer have to make the stark choice between having a career or having children. In many countries, laws exist that require employers to give women maternity leave and keep their jobs open, sometimes for years after they give birth. **********But the reality for women trying to continue their careers and raise children is often quite different.One of the biggest stumbling blocks is finding and paying for adequate child care. **********In Europe, covering the gap between the end of maternity pay benefits — usually after three months — and the beginning of school — at the earliest usually three years later — can involve searching out private care. **********As cash-strapped governments rein in welfare spending, there are fewer state-backed child-care options. **********For one British mother, Helen Westwell, there was never any doubt that she would return to her job in advertising as soon as her five-month, partially paid maternity leave ended and her son, Oscar, was old enough to attend a nursery.She also knew that she would have to find private child care. **********Although state-run nurseries exist in Britain, many have been closed down because of funding problems and there is enormous competition for places at those remaining. **********In North London, Ms. Westwell foundplenty of good private nurseries. But the cheapest she found charges fees of £530 ($850) a month.So she has to pay £6,360 a year in order to stay at work. **********"I suppose I'm lucky in that I had a choice," she said. "For many mothers on smaller salaries that choice doesn't exist."Child benefits are paid to all British parents regardless of income, she said, but the amount falls far short of most child-care costs. **********France is at the other end of the scale, offering a broad range of state benefits for working mothers.The state nursery system is overburdened by demand, with waits of up to a year at some nurseries, but there are several state-supported alternatives. **********Mothers using registered care-givers get part of their monthly outlay reimbursed. This includes the social costs they incur as employers. **********InItaly and Spain, the problem working mothers face is one of tradition. These countries are developing child-care systems but still lean heavily on the family. **********Expatriates in Italy with no local family ties often turn to babysitting services thatcharge a minimum of 12,000 lira an hour ($8) **********Spanish maternity benefits are less generous than in France, but are still good compared to many other countries, said Alice Corson, who is based in Barcelona and has a 4-year-old son. **********Working mothers get 16 weeks fully paid maternity leave and up to three years of unpaid leave.But the dependence on families to provide care for children has left the private as well as the public sector underdeveloped. **********Even so, private care is relatively cheap. Ms. Corson paid about 35,000 pesetas ($270) a month until her son started school. **********Japan, despite its economic problems, is supportive of working mothers, said Misako Sakamoto, the mother of a 3-year-old, in Tokyo. Although there are only 230 state-run kindergartens throughout the city, taking less than 25 children each, parents turning to the private sector are subsidized by the government. **********Ms. Sakamoto said that a state kindergarten costs about 5,000 yen ($45) per month.Her son's private kindergarten costs 20,000 yen a month, but more than half is reimbursed by the state. **********The only drawback is that private kindergartens often cram up to 50 children in a single class.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/30/news/.main_headline: French Company Controls Subsidiaries From India to New Zealand : Danone Nurtures a Pan-Asian Empire
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/30/news/.print_headline: French Company Controls Subsidiaries From India to New Zealand : Danone Nurtures a Pan-Asian Empire
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/30/news/.body_text: **********HONG KONG—                     Ten years ago, France's Group Danone had no businesses in Asia outside Japan, even though it had already been searching for opportunities in China for at least three years. **********But Danone, Europe's third-largest food company, now controls nine companies in China alone, and several others stretching from New Zealand to India. **********The company's move into Asia was in step with the international food industry's mushrooming interest in the region, as rising personal incomes and busier, urbanized lifestyles brought dramatic changes in the way many Asian consumers eat and drink. **********Throughout Asia, curiosity about meals from other cultures and concern about nutrition and food quality — and the wealth to pay for them — have opened up tremendous opportunities to local and global food groups alike. **********Yet, while burgeoning demand for food in the developing region is a given, executives and analysts agree, there is no certain way for businesses to proceed in a market that has become more crowded and competitive in a hurry. **********When Danone first tried to set up shop in China 12 years ago, after the company president visited as an official guest, the obstacles to efficient commerce were daunting. **********"There were no planes, no faxes, no hotels.How could you imagine that China would ever be the market of the century?" said Yannick Vivarel, vice president for Danone's corporate growth and communications for Asia and the Pacific. **********"It took us two years to find our market entry, and then it took six months to find aluminum foil for our yogurt packaging," said Mr. Vivarel, who has been involved with Danone's Asian expansion from its start after the company's chairman visited China as an official guest. **********"But the game has changed since in China and everywhere else in Asia," he said. **********Too busy at work to shop once or twice a day in traditional fresh food markets, Asians are turning more to packaged and processed foods, a trend that augurs well for companies likeDanone, whose total sales in Asia were about $1 billionin 1995, but whose hunger for expansion throughout the region in its core product line-up of dairy products, biscuits, sauces and beer has by no means been sated. **********In Bangkok, commuters, who leave home early to beat the city's hellish traffic jams, spend up to 70 billion baht (about $2.8 billion) a year on breakfasts eaten on the go, a recent survey by the Thai Farmers Bank found. **********Throughout Asia, the food industry is moving quickly to take advantage of this trend by openingmore modern, larger-scale manufacturing plants. At the same time, new product development and marketing are becoming increasingly important to profitability in newly liberalized markets. **********The changing landscape favors the multinational food groups, but the enormity and diversity of the Asian markets is forcing the big foreign players to adapt their strategies to local conditions, according to Mr. Vivarel of Danone. **********"Multinationals have changed their ways. Once they bought 100 percent control and told the old management to get out," Mr. Vivarel said. "Now many start out as minority partners and slowly build up their positions. It's more cooperation these days than mergers and acquisitions." **********The competition is changing, too. **********"We are facing three types of competition now," Mr. Vivarel said. "The classical contest between Western multinationals; strong local groups like the Salim group in Indonesia and President Foods of Taiwan; a new third type, unexpected, groups of local businessmen joining together to diversify into food businesses." **********While multinational groups such as Danone, Nestlé SA, Kraft Foods, H.J. Heinz Co. and Unilever are busy scouring the region for opportunities to buy out existing family-run businesses or form joint ventures with them, a handful of Asian entrepreneurs have begun looking abroad for products and brands to bring back into Asia. **********National Foods Ltd., one of Australia's largest milk, ice cream and yogurt producers, has become the target of interest by groups based in Hong Kong and Singapore.National is only one of several Australian food firms that are being eyed in recent months as possible takeover candidates. **********Both Camerlin Pte. Ltd., a joint venture between Malaysian, Indonesian and Singapore interests, and Mingly Corp., better known as a Hong Kong property developer, have taken stakes in National Foods, attracted by the company's potential to profit from Asia. **********Butfood groups are divided on the relative benefits of buying existing brands and manufacturing operations versus starting from the ground up with new facilities and products. **********For example, Hong Kong-based Dharmala Holdings Ltd., ultimatelycontrolled by Indonesia's Gondokusomo family, decided a few years ago to turn its experience in trading Chinese agricultural commodities into a chicken-raising operation. **********If managed properly, Dharmala believes, the move from handling grains to producing chickens and, later, operating fried chicken restaurants, should prove more lucrative than commodity trading, where profit margins have narrowed in recent years. **********Starting in 1994, Dharmala has established four joint ventures centered in China's northern Shandong Province that produced 50,000 metric tons of frozen chickenlast year. **********By 1997, Dharmala expects production to triple, increasing exports to Japan and enlarging distribution in China. **********"We are looking for more opportunities to go downstream," said Bernard Pouliot, Dharmala's group managing director. "We're looking at selling by-products, developing a brand name and expanding our distribution chain throughout China." **********Profit margins on chicken, however, have been squeezed by unexpected rises in the price of corn or maize feed because China allowed corn prices to be liberalized as part of the country's opening up and its effort to raise rural incomes. **********Despite the short-term difficulties, Dharmala and dozens of other companies are pouring resources into the Chinese market. **********President Enterprises of Taiwan, for example, has set itself the goal of becoming the world's largest food manufacturer, based on its plans to expand its range of products into China. **********In that country, a report by SBC Warburg says,"more than in any other industries, the food processing industry represents a golden opportunity for foreign companies." **********"The market is already sufficiently developed to afford its products, rather (as is often the case) being a potential market," said the report. "The domestic competition often lacks the strength to compete, and consumers are receptive to foreign products." **********- **********KEVIN MURPHY writes from Hong Kong for the International Herald Tribune.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/01/world.body_text: **********An American citizen holding a high-ranking United Nations position in Geneva  has been accused of forgery and embezzling as much as $500,000 from the agency where he works, the Secretary General's spokeswoman said today. **********The American official, who was not named by the United Nations or the United  States mission here, is being investigated by Swiss authorities and by the United Nations inspector general, Karl Theodor Paschke, who arrived in Geneva today. **********The spokeswoman, Sylvana Foa, said that the American, who is an official of  the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, is on sick leave and faces suspension on his return to the agency. **********There were reports in Geneva that the American official had dropped from sight after an active investigation began on charges of fraud and the falsification of documents going back several years. **********The Clinton Administration and Congress have been critical of the agency, known as Unctad, which helps poorer nations to develop their economies through trade and have demanded reforms.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/07/busin.body_text: **********The Italian Government said yesterday that it would sell its remaining stake in Stet S.p.A., the telecommunications company, next February or March, after selling or spinning off its telephone equipment and publishing units. At current market prices, the Government's stake is worth 16 trillion lire, or $10.5 billion. **********A Treasury official said that before the sale, Stet would sell or spin off SEAT, its yellow page publishing unit; Sirti S.p.A., which develops telecommunications and other systems, and Italtel S.p.A., a maker of telecommunications equipment. The main assets remaining will be the majority stakes held by Stet in Telecom Italia S.p.A., Italy's near-monopoly telephone company, and in Telecom Italia Mobile S.p.A., the  largest cellular telephone company in Europe.   (Bloomberg Business News)

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/04/busin.main_headline: The Siskel and Ebert of Telecom Investing
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/04/busin.print_headline: The Siskel and Ebert of Telecom Investing
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/04/busin.body_text: **********JACK GRUBMAN and Dan Reingold say they like each other. You'd never know it from the hand grenades they toss back and forth. **********In a new report, Mr. Grubman, a prominent telecommunications analyst at Salomon Brothers, said any analyst who would recommend the stocks of regional Bell telephone companies was "starry eyed," "bull headed" and "nuts." Mr. Grubman acknowledged that this was a reference to Mr. Reingold, his equally prominent counterpart at Merrill Lynch & Company. **********For his part, Mr. Reingold said Mr. Grubman was "intuitive and gut-oriented." Explaining how he differs from that approach, he said, "Before making conclusions, I try to do the work." **********Such verbal fisticuffs would not be remarkable in the rough-and-tumble world  of stock picking, except that Mr. Reingold and Mr. Grubman are the Hertz and Avis of telecommunications analysts. Mr. Reingold is ranked first, and Mr. Grubman second, in the annual ranking of telecommunications analysts by Institutional Investor magazine. Both also began their careers in the industry they now track -- Mr. Grubman at AT&T and Mr. Reingold at MCI. **********For all their similarities, the two men now have diametrically opposed views  of the industry. The gap between them underscores just how murky the outlook for telecommunications has become as it faces deregulation and no-holds-barred competition. It also smacks of an old-fashioned ego battle between two highly paid, closely followed industry seers. **********"These are two of the most competitive people I have ever met," said Peter Crawford, the executive director of investor relations for the Bell Atlantic Corporation. "They are both intensely driven by recognition and success." **********As fun as it is to watch, the rivalry raises a sober question: Whom should investors listen to as they place bets on a vital industry in the grip of dizzying change? AT&T, GTE and the seven Baby Bells are among the 15 most widely held issues on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Mr. Reingold contends that the Bells will be the big winners from the telecommunications bill, which Congress passed on Thursday, because the legislation would free the companies to compete in the $70 billion long-distance telephone market. Mr. Grubman says that even after President Clinton signs the bill into law, the Bells stand to gain precious little. **********Mr. Reingold is recommending that investors buy the shares of the seven Baby  Bells; Mr. Grubman is steering his clients away. **********"You have two guys who have looked at the same issue, and one guy sees it flat while the other guy sees it round," said Robert M. Kavner, a former top executive at AT&T who now advises Tele-TV, an entertainment programming company  owned by three Baby Bells. **********One prominent fund manager, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said investors should not take either analyst's warnings too seriously. He noted that his fund had large stakes in both local and long-distance companies. **********"The investment community likes to have black-and-white winners and losers,"  the manager said. Yet, odds are, both analysts' favorite stocks will do fine, he said. "If this was going to be a blood bath, we probably wouldn't own these stocks." **********What gives the Grubman-Reingold debate an extra dash of theater is that the two analysts play their respective roles to the hilt. **********Mr. Grubman, 43, is the swashbuckler, who boasts about his close ties to the  chief executives of the big telephone companies and whose research reports sometimes read more like polemics than dispassionate studies. Mr. Reingold, 42,  is the Wall Street wonk, who cultivates a network of contacts in Washington to gauge the direction of legislation, and who showers his clients with a stream of briefings and updates. **********"I bet you that in college, Dan was prepared for every test, while I was cramming at the last minute," Mr. Grubman said. **********Mr. Grubman and Mr. Reingold did not always disagree so vociferously. Seven months ago, they were equally skeptical about the Bells. In fact, Mr. Reingold upbraided the companies in several reports for plowing hundreds of millions of dollars into interactive television ventures that he argued had an uncertain payoff, at best. **********"I mean, those guys really hated me," he said. **********Then, in July, Mr. Reingold suddenly changed his tune and began promoting the Bells. He said he was swayed after reading the fine print in the telecommunications bill, which made it clear that the companies would be allowed into the long-distance market at roughly the same time AT&T and MCI would gain entry into the local market. **********Mr. Reingold contends that the Bells have two big advantages as they enter long distance. They have large networks that can easily be retrofitted to carry  long-distance calls in their home regions. And because the Bells handle such a huge volume of traffic, they can demand reduced rates from AT&T and MCI to carry calls for them outside their regions. **********Given these strengths, Mr. Reingold predicted that the Bells would grab 25 percent of the long-distance market within seven years. Because much of that revenue will come without significant capital investment, he said the earnings growth of the Bells as a group should accelerate -- to an average rate of 10 percent a year, compared with 7 percent in 1994. **********Wall Street has embraced Mr. Reingold's rosy outlook. With the exception of the Pacific Telesis Group, the shares of the Bells have outperformed the Standard & Poor's 500 index since July. All told, the telecommunications business is growing more quickly than the economy as a whole. **********When Mr. Reingold first came out with his new opinion, he acknowledged that some of his clients reacted angrily. "It's very embarrassing to say you made the wrong assumptions," he said, "It's much easier to say, 'The market is reading this wrong,' and dig in your heels." **********Mr. Grubman makes exactly that argument. He said that for the Baby Bells to realize the kind of profits from long distance that Mr. Reingold predicts, they  would have to gang up to demand bulk discounts from AT&T and MCI for carrying their long-distance calls. **********Moreover, he said, the Baby Bells would have to use hardball tactics to keep  the long-distance carriers out of their local monopolies. **********"If you believe Dan on the ability of the Bells to collude and conspire," Mr. Grubman said, "the C.E.O.'s of these companies will all be sharing a cell at Leavenworth in five years." **********Both analysts agree that it will be difficult for AT&T and MCI to make huge inroads into the local franchises of the Bells, because they are left negotiating in each market with the one company that owns the lines running into homes. But Mr. Grubman, unlike Mr. Reingold, says the Bells will have similarly  little luck in cracking the long-distance market. **********In his new report, Mr. Grubman said that the battle for long-distance customers would be won by the companies with the strongest brand names and the most aggressive marketing. He contends that AT&T and MCI are still better on both counts than their Baby Bell rivals. **********Not surprisingly, Mr. Grubman now draws barbed remarks from executives at some of the Bell companies. "Dan has done a better job of identifying, crisply and succinctly, the changes in our industry," said Mr. Crawford of Bell Atlantic. **********Several Bell executives said Mr. Grubman's pessimism about the local phone industry stemmed from his background. He was at AT&T for eight years and worked  in its Federal regulatory department. **********Mr. Grubman left AT&T in 1985 to join Paine Webber as an analyst. Salomon lured him in 1994 with a salary and bonus that some industry executives said he  had told them is worth $1 million a year. **********Despite his long-distance pedigree, Mr. Grubman noted that he stopped recommending AT&T's stock a year ago and chided the company for its ill-fated foray into the computer business. He said he had also clashed with MCI, though he is currently recommending the stock. **********"There was a time when Bert Roberts didn't talk to me," he said, referring to the chairman and chief executive of MCI. **********Moreover, as Mr. Grubman pointed out, Mr. Reingold spent six years as a corporate planner at MCI before starting on Wall Street in 1989 as an analyst with Morgan Stanley. He switched to Merrill Lynch in 1993 to develop a global research effort for telecommunications. **********Industry executives said Mr. Reingold had put Merrill on the map in telecommunications research. But his strong views can cause headaches for his employer; executives at Merrill acknowledge that his recommendations have occasionally cost the firm lucrative investment banking business. That said, Merrill just won an assignment from AT&T to co-manage a giant stock offering for its new equipment-manufacturing company -- despite Mr. Reingold's qualms about AT&T's broader prospects. **********As for their rivalry, Mr. Reingold and Mr. Grubman say they are not obsessed  with each other. Mr. Grubman says he does not read Mr. Reingold's reports or those of any other analyst. Mr. Reingold says he studiously avoids referring to  Mr. Grubman in his work. He even declined to pose for a photograph with him for  this article. **********Mr. Grubman said he and Mr. Reingold often had friendly encounters in distant outposts like Jakarta, Indonesia, or Lima, Peru, where analysts and investment bankers from Merrill Lynch and Salomon turn up to compete for assignments from state-owned telephone companies that want to issue equity or debt. **********Back home, though, both analysts keep a sharp eye on the Institutional Investor rankings, which are based on extensive surveys of the research directors and chief investment officers at money management firms. **********In the latest survey, published in October, Mr. Reingold unseated Mr. Grubman as the top-rated telecommunications analyst for the first time. **********Not to be outdone, Mr. Grubman noted that the year before, he surpassed the pre-eminent analyst in the field at the time, Robert Morris 3d of Goldman, Sachs & Company, who had ranked first for nine consecutive years. In that survey, Mr.  Reingold ranked third. **********"There are precious few analysts who can look eyeball-to-eyeball with the C.E.O. and take away an intangible feel for the company," Mr. Grubman said. **********For all their bravura, Mr. Grubman and Mr. Reingold both recognize that fame  on Wall Street can be fleeting. As Oren Shaffer, the chief financial officer of  Ameritech, noted, stock picking is an unforgiving profession. "The selection of  winners and losers is going to become more complex as the volatility of this industry increases," he said. **********And unless each analyst keeps picking winners, their great debate over the future of telephones will exist simply between themselves, with no one else listening in.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/03/busin.main_headline: Forte Moves To Thwart Granada Bid
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/03/busin.print_headline: Forte Moves To Thwart Granada Bid
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/03/busin.body_text: **********Forte P.L.C., the British hotel company, began a further, aggressive effort today to thwart a hostile takeover bid by the Granada Group. **********Forte, which is resisting a bid valued at L3.3 billion, or $5.1 billion, said it would raise its dividend for the first time in five years, buy back shares worth L800 million and spin off its stake in the Savoy hotels of London. **********While Granada dismissed the Forte defense as "nothing more than a quick fix," investors on the London Stock Exchange reacted favorably. Shares closed 12.5 pence higher at 343 pence, remaining above Granada's offer price. Granada's shares fell 3 pence to close at 642 pence. **********"We think it's quite a radical departure," said Paul Slattery, an analyst with Kleinwort Benson Securities. "It's more like a prospectus for a new company than a defense document." **********Analysts said they expected that Granada would have to increase its bid before Jan. 9, the last day it can change its offer, to win the support of Forte's shareholders. On Nov. 22, Granada offered four shares and L23.25 in cash for each Forte share. A bitter battle has followed. **********"The question now is what Granada is going to pull out of the bag," said Jason Crisp, an analyst with SGST Securities. **********In its final defense document before Granada's offer closes on Jan. 23, Forte pledged to shareholders that it would raise its dividend by at least 20 percent each year for the next three years, provided they rejected Granada's offer. **********Forte, Britain's largest hotel company, also said it would spend L800 million to buy back about 20 percent of its shares outstanding. And Forte plans to spin  off its 68 percent stake in the Savoy luxury hotel group, owner of the namesake  Savoy, Berkeley and Claridges to shareholders in proportion to their holdings in Forte. **********Granada, which operates television franchises and owns Britain's third-largest caterer, dismissed the Forte defense proposals. **********Granada's chief executive, Gerry Robinson, said they were "nothing more than  a quick fix which fails to address the key issues." Meeting Forte's dividend targets could require the company to double its profits in three years, he said. **********"This is a tall order for a management which has conspicuously failed to deliver profits, earnings and dividends in the past," Mr. Robinson said in a statement. **********Forte also announced today a strategy to expand its international chain of Meridien hotels, which were bought from Air France in 1994. **********Forte said it would add 50 new Meridien hotels in the next three years and increase its Posthouse three-star chain to 14,500 rooms. **********In addition, the company said it was negotiating to obtain about 20 management contracts for its Meridien brand and planned to dispose of some of its luxury hotels as "the market continues to strengthen." **********Under British takeover rules, Forte is barred from releasing new information  or defense documents from today until the close of the bid. **********Last week, Forte agreed to sell its restaurant division and British budget hotels to Whitbread P.L.C. for L1.05 billion cash, assuming Granada's bid failed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/17/busin.body_text: **********JANE D. SCHWARTZ was excited when she learned that the Federal Government had authorized a new kind of plan for her retirement investing. ''I think our investment choices are too conservative now,'' she said. ''I haven't been able to take full advantage of the bull market.'' **********Ms. Schwartz is the executive director of the Paul Rapoport Foundation, an organization in New York City involved in gay and lesbian issues. And the law that has raised her hopes will allow most nonprofit employers, like the foundation, to set up 401(k) accounts, the popular tax-deferred vehicle of the for-profit sector. Until now, most nonprofits have been restricted to the tax-deferred plans known as 403(b)'s. **********The statute, which was signed by President Clinton in August, will expand the retirement possibilities for some nine million nonprofit workers, who have already invested $300 billion in 403(b) plans. The new provisions, to take effect on Jan. 1, are contained in the minimum-wage law. **********The new law does not guarantee that Ms. Schwartz and others will benefit -- nonprofit employers may balk at the cost of setting up a new plan. But 401(k)'s have many attractions that may lead nonprofit employees to push for them. **********For example, there are more investment options available in 401(k) plans than in 403(b)'s. While the law limits 403(b) investments to mutual funds and annuities, 401(k) plans can have those options as well as  guaranteed investment contracts, individual equities -- often the company' stock -- and other instruments. **********''In a 401(k) you can literally have any investments other than tangible collectibles,'' said Peter Gold, a principal at Buck Consultants in New York. **********Practically speaking, the investment choices in specific 403(b) plans are often  few and conservative. ''People who choose to work in the nonprofit sector generally are not as motivated by money and on average are older'' than other workers, Mr. Gold said. ''For these reasons, they tend to be more conservative investors.'' **********Moreover, all 401(k)'s fall under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, known as Erisa, which requires the employer to be prudent and vigilant in selecting, maintaining and reviewing plan investments. But 403(b) plans are covered by Erisa only if the  administrator chooses to be; only about half do so, though the number is growing. That means the rest are subject just to state-law  protections. Perhaps more important, employers' matching contributions -- a common feature of 401(k)'s -- are not permitted in non-Erisa 403(b)'s. **********Moreover, at least until 1999, when the new law will end the practice, retired workers who take a lump-sum distribution from their 401(k)'s can spread their tax payments over five years. Not so with 403(b)'s; investors must pay all the taxes at once. **********But just because 401(k)'s have attractions for workers does not mean they look good to employers. One potential drawback  concerns ''discrimination testing,'' an annual process by which employers with 401(k) plans make sure that the contributions of highly paid employees are not unacceptably high compared with those of other workers. Employers may chafe at the testing, an annual chore that experts say can be costly and time-consuming, while highly paid workers may balk at the discrimination rules themselves, which can limit their retirement contributions. (Beginning in 1999, certain 401(k) plans will be exempt from discrimination testing.) **********Many nonprofit groups are also put off by the idea of setting up a new plan. ''It's a no-brainer,'' said Nancy Palazzolo, director of retirement services at the Daughters of Charity National Health System, a hospital group in St. Louis. ''The start-up costs of a 401(k) would be too high for us, and, I would assume, for most nonprofits.'' **********Also, there is no provision in the new law that allows 403(b) money to be rolled over to a 401(k). Thus, the many nonprofit organizations that already have 403(b)'s -- like Ms. Palazzolo's -- must maintain two retirement plans if they elect to start a 401(k). **********Cherith Harrison, vice president of Diversified Investment Advisors, a consulting firm in Purchase, N.Y., said, ''Many employers we're dealing with say they're not going to do the two plans because it's a communications nightmare.'' **********Despite the strong feelings among both workers and employers, the 401(k) decision is not always clear-cut. While 401(k)'s have many advantages, 403(b)'s also have features that may appeal to some workers. Both 401(k)'s and 403(b)'s allow investors to contribute up to $9,500 a year, for instance. But only 403(b)'s let some participants play catch-up by contributing up to $12,500 a year for five years. **********To muddy matters a bit more, 403(b)'s are evolving. The minimum-wage law, for instance, authorizes 403(b) plans to let their participants change their contribution amounts as often as they wish each year.  The law has always given 401(k)'s this flexibility, but it imposed a once-a-year limit on 403(b)'s. (Individual plans may put their own restrictions on such changes, of course; a common one is once a quarter.) **********And according to a recent survey of 147 nonprofit organizations by Buck Consultants, employees are pushing hard to get  more investment options in their 403(b)'s.  About 46 percent of the employers surveyed, in fact, said they planned to increase the number of mutual funds they offer. **********''It doesn't cost employers anything to expand offerings in 403(b)'s and the administrative work is minimal,'' Mr. Gold said. **********That may give Ms. Schwartz a nice fallback position. If she cannot get her board to start a 401(k), she said, ''I'm going to fight for more funds in my 403(b).''

Ayer & Partners in New York, has opened a creatively focused agency in New York named Door #2. **********The shop opens with one client, Charles Schwab & Company, the national discount brokerage firm in San Francisco. Door #2 will handle the broadcast creative account for Schwab, with billings estimated at $20 million; that assignment had previously been divided between an in-house team at Schwab and Rubin Postaer & Associates in Santa Monica, Calif., which continues to handle the media portion of the account. **********Ms. Kraus, 37, had overseen Ayer's creative output with Patrick Cunningham,  vice chairman and chief creative officer, until both left Ayer in June. https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/27/world.main_headline: Guerrillas in Peru Release One of Six Hostage Envoys
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/27/world.print_headline: Guerrillas in Peru Release One of Six Hostage Envoys
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/27/world.body_text: **********Hours after a mysterious explosion rocked the besieged Japanese Ambassador's residence early today, the Marxist rebels holding more than 100 hostages released one of six captive senior diplomats, the Ambassador of Guatemala. **********Red Cross officials said it appeared that an animal, probably a cat, had tripped a booby trap or land mine planted by the guerrillas after they stormed a diplomatic cocktail party at the residence on Dec. 17. Though no one was injured by the  blast, which occurred at 1:45 A.M., local police officers and diplomats expressed concern that more unstable explosives could be set off by mistake, potentially with more deadly results. **********Diplomats and Red Cross workers have said they believed that the rebels laid the booby traps in the gardens surrounding the residence to help avert a counterattack by government forces. These officials say some released hostages have also  reported that the guerrillas are keeping reserves of booby traps and other explosives as well. **********Despite the early specter of danger, and few signs of concrete advances toward breaking the standoff, there were some tantalizing signs of movement. Bishop Juan Luis Cipriani of Ayacucho, who visited the  hostages on Christmas Day for six hours, ostensibly to celebrate Mass, suggested that a peaceful solution was possible. **********''Little by little we need to understand each other,'' Bishop Cipriani, a conservative ally of President Alberto K. Fujimori, told reporters staking out the compound this afternoon. ''With a little help from Mary, hopefully we'll see more gestures, not little gestures but bigger gestures.'' **********Bishop Cipriani said he was not a mediator. But a Western diplomat monitoring the hostage-taking noted, ''That was a long Mass all right.'' **********The diplomat added: ''The Bishop is well respected and he does have the confidence of Fujimori. When the President visits Ayacucho, he always calls on the Bishop.'' **********President Fujimori has not budged from his demand that the 20 guerrillas occupying the residence release every remaining hostage and drop their arms before safe passage might be considered. The Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement has clung to its original demand that 300 or more of its members be freed from Peruvian prisons, and the rebels have sporadically released more than 400 people since they  stormed the residence. **********But while today's release was insignificant in number, the rebels appeared to make a symbolically rich gesture by liberating Jose Maria Argueta, the Ambassador of Guatemala. Mr. Argueta said that his release ''was an acknowledgement of the historical accomplishments of Guatemala reaching a peace agreement to be signed on Dec. 29'' that will end a 40-year-old guerrilla war. **********Several freed hostages have said that the guerrillas, in conversations with them, spoke of longing to integrate into Peru's political system, the way the Guatemalan guerrillas and so many other rebel groups have done around Latin America in recent years. The freeing of Ambassador Argueta without any other hostages seemed to highlight that desire. **********Gustavo Gorriti, a leading Peruvian journalist, said he believed the  objective of the rebels was to negotiate a new role in Peruvian society after years of military defeats and the capture of most of their leaders and members. But he said that before they could negotiate a settlement with the Government, ''they must show force or otherwise no one will be willing to concede them anything.'' **********Ambassador Argueta looked fit as he left the compound, wearing a gray suit and walking slowly but erectly.  He leaves behind the Ambassadors of Japan, Malaysia, Bolivia, Honduras and the Dominican Republic, along with five Peruvian generals, two Cabinet ministers, several supreme court judges and congressmen, and scores of Japanese and Peruvian businessmen. **********Through diplomatic channels to the Governments in Peru and Japan, the United States continues to offer  help and repeat its view that there should be no concession made in negotiations with terrorists, officials said today. So far, Peru has not accepted the American offer of assistance. But with the release of seven American hostages, and with no other Americans believed to be held in the residence, the United States has slipped further into the background. **********The special task force created at the State Department when the crisis began has been disbanded, although officials in Washington and at the embassy in Lima continue to watch developments closely, officials said today. **********''We're no longer directly involved in this,'' one official said. **********The official also said that United States authorities had debriefed the released Americans, but that they had not ''shed any great light on the motives or the intentions of the terrorists.'' **********While the United States remained in the background, Malaysia's Foreign Minister, Abdullah Badawi, arrived in Lima today and kept to a private schedule, leading to speculation that he might be trying to negotiate a separate settlement to obtain  the release of Malaysia's Ambassador to Peru, Ahmad Mokhtar. **********Rumors are swirling in the Peruvian press and among diplomats that several countries may be trying to make deals as Uruguay apparently did to free its Ambassador earlier this week. **********Japan joined Peru today in sharply criticizing Uruguay for undercutting President Fujimori by releasing two Tupac Amaru guerrillas held in Uruguayan jails for violations of immigration laws. Bolivian Government officials said today that they would not trade the handful of Tupac Amaru prisoners they hold in exchange for their captive ambassador. **********A few hours before the guerrillas freed Tabare Bocalandro Yapeyu, the Uruguayan Ambassador, on Tuesday, an Uruguayan appeals court released Sonia Silvia Gora Rivera and Luis Alberto Miguel Samaniego, who was arrested last December while entering Uruguay carrying false passports. **********According to the Peruvian security forces, Ms. Gora had been responsible for renting safe houses where the Tupac Amaru rebels kept several  captives. Mr. Samaniego, according to security sources, was a senior member of the group's ruling executive committee. **********The two have been accused of masterminding the kidnapping of Samuel Doria Medina, Bolivia's former Economy Minister, last year before releasing him for $200,000 ransom. Nestor Cerpa Cartolini, the same Tupac Amaru commander who negotiated that ransom agreement, is now leading the rebels who are occupying the Japanese diplomatic residence.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/12/busin.print_headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Heating Oil Prices Keep Rising As Cold Weather Persists in East
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/12/busin.body_text: **********Heating oil and natural gas drove commodity prices higher yesterday for the fourth consecutive session, as unseasonably cold weather in the Eastern United States suggested increased demand at a time of low inventories. **********Crude oil prices also rose, bolstered by increased speculation that Iraq and  the United Nations would not agree soon on a proposal to allow limited Iraqi sales of oil for the purchase of food and medicine. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 17 commodities gained 1.1 points, to 246.47. On other commodities markets, pork bellies rose. **********Below-normal temperatures are forecast for most of this week and the early part of next week in parts of the Northeast and the Midwest, according to Weather Services Corporation of Lexington, Mass. The cold weather follows a report by American Petroleum Institute showing that American inventories of heating oil and distillate fuels were 18 percent less than those of the corresponding period last year. **********"We have a late-season cold snap coming and the market is taking off," said Jerry Samuels, managing director of ARB Oil in Los Angeles. "Everyone's living hand-to-mouth with heating oil. Because of the low stock levels, traders are paying up." **********On the New York Mercantile Exchange, heating oil for April delivery surged 1.71 cents, to 55.15 cents a gallon. April natural gas jumped 8.3 cents, to $2.178 for 1,000 cubic feet. The April crude oil contract gained 30 cents, to $19.91 a barrel. **********Crude oil prices were helped by news of a standoff between United Nations weapons inspectors and Iraqi authorities at an installation south of Baghdad. The inspectors were allowed in late yesterday. Still, it was the second confrontation in four days. The standoff suggested to traders that the United Nations and Iraq were far apart on a plan to allow Iraq to sell as much as $2 billion of crude oil over six months. **********"The talk of a second standoff helped boost the crude market," said Drew Dickson, director of oil trading at the GSC Energy Corporation in Atlanta. "There's a perception growing that we're just a long way off before we see Iraqi crude." **********Pork-belly prices jumped to a five-year high on signs that rising demand for  American pork from Japan and Eastern European countries was drawing down stockpiles.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/01/busin.snippet: Deborah Stead reviews The Media Equation: How People Treat Computers, Television, and News Media as Real People and Places, by Byron Reeves and Clifford Nass; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/01/busin.main_headline: Sex, Lies and Semiconductors: The Human Links
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/01/busin.print_headline: Sex, Lies and Semiconductors: The Human Links
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/01/busin.body_text: **********PRESCHOOLERS looking at a bag of popcorn on a television screen are likely to predict that it will spill if the TV set is turned upside down. Adults, of course, know better. But just how much better? Do we, too, confuse the media world with the real one? **********We do. At least that's the conclusion reached by Byron Reeves and Clifford Nass, two Stanford professors who studied people's reactions to computers and television at the university's Center for the Study of Language and Information. The results, some of them pretty astonishing, are engagingly reported in their just-published book, ''The Media Equation: How People Treat Computers, Televisions, and New Media as Real People and Places'' (Cambridge University Press, $27.95). **********The book's thesis is that on some level we can't help equating media with real life. ''People are not evolved to 20th-century technology,'' the authors say, to explain why the subjects in their studies tried to protect a computer's feelings or were aglow with self-esteem after an electronic gush of flattery. **********To us confused homo sapiens, it turns out, media that communicate with words or pictures seem to be doing something social. In our brains, that adds up to human behavior, and we respond in kind. (Of course, it can occasionally work the other way, as well. A friend of mine used to be married to someone who, when he was tired of arguing, would grab the remote and try to click her off.) **********Even relatively hip technological types are at the mercy of their human instincts. Most of the 35 or so studies that form the basis of ''The Media Equation'' used subjects who were experienced computer users. But despite their stated views that computers were just machines, they responded in ways usually reserved for human interaction. **********In testing their hypotheses, the authors looked for earlier psychological studies that show some rule about human-to-human interaction and then repeated them -- substituting media for one of the humans. **********So what did they find? To start with, people are polite to computers when forced to rate them, uh, face-to-face. That mirrors the psychological rule in human relations: People give a more positive -- and less honest -- evaluation to someone who asks about himself than they do when someone else asks about that individual's performance. **********In the professors' experiment, subjects worked on a computer tutoring exercise, after which the same computer asked half of the 44 subjects how it performed, offering them a choice of adjectives. The other 22 subjects went on to a second computer, which asked them to rate the performance of the first. **********Bingo. The face-to-face evaluators were polite, rating their computer tutors as ''accurate,'' ''fair'' and ''friendly'' much more often than did the students who confided their ratings to another computer. **********And this was all done with text -- no voice, no graphics. ''People don't need much of a cue to respond socially,'' the authors conclude. **********The dynamics of human flattery also worked in the computer realm. When flattered, people usually rate their own performances more favorably. And they tend to bestow praise upon the flatterer -- whether or not they believe the praise is warranted. (Embarrassing, isn't it?) Well, it happened just like that when a computer flashed flattery about a user's performance. Subsequent tests showed that the users lapped it up, felt better and loved the little praise machines. **********The authors, who have consulted for Microsoft, say computer designers should learn a lesson from this. Imagine, they say, a spelling program that points out an especially fine spelling job, along with the errors. Or an electronic Web browser that praises its users for finding unusual sites. Of course, that lesson might never be learned. As one computer designer told the authors: ''I got into engineering because I didn't know any social rules.'' **********Another human frailty -- stereotyping -- was applied to the computers, too. Participants in this experiment worked with identical software, but with different computer audio voices -- some male, some female. The results? Evaluations from male-voiced computers were taken more seriously. And -- get this -- the ''female'' computers were rated as more ''knowledgeable'' about the software content related to love and relationships. All this, even though the subjects were told beforehand that the same programmer -- a man -- had created the software. **********''The Media Equation'' also reports that given the slightest encouragement, people perceive a personality in computers. By designing software with verbal styles that are psychologically linked to various behaviors, the authors created dominant, submissive, friendly and unfriendly computers. Over all, their subjects described the various machines in just this way. They liked best the dominant-plus-friendly ones. That's how it is in life, too, the authors say, adding, in an especially delicious phrase, that this helps explain the popularity of media figures ''from the anchors on the evening news to Mickey Mouse.'' **********The experiment also showed that people who were ''dominant,'' according to psychological tests, preferred dominant computers, and that submissive folks preferred more passive machines. This apparently holds in relationships between humans, too, despite the folk wisdom about opposites attracting. **********Naturally, software designers can't tailor a machine's personality to each user, the authors say, but programmers might eventually create computers that ''offer multiple personalities.'' Who knows, maybe Hollywood could get Joanne Woodward to do ''The Three Interfaces of Eve.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/16/busin.snippet: Time Warner Inc is taking its cable-television feud with Rupert Murdoch's News Corp to the skies; Time Warner pres Richard D Parsons, in letter to FCC, urges commission to withhold approval of MCI Communications' application for satellite license ...

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/16/busin.print_headline: Time Warner-Murdoch Feud Entangles MCI Satellite Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/16/busin.body_text: **********Time Warner Inc. is taking its cable-television feud with Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation to the skies. **********In a letter yesterday to the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, Time Warner urged the commission to withhold approval of MCI Communications' application for a satellite license because MCI was being acquired by a foreign company, British Telecommunications. **********The letter, which was signed by Time Warner's president, Richard D. Parsons, said the F.C.C. would open the door to a ''foreign ownership violation'' if it granted the license to MCI. **********The real target of Time Warner's request -- according to several executives familiar with the situation -- was not MCI, but its partner, the News Corporation. It and MCI are equal owners of a direct-broadcast television service that plans to use MCI's high-powered satellite. If the F.C.C. withheld its approval of the license, it would deal a blow to Mr. Murdoch's ambitions to get into satellite television in the United States. **********Time Warner has been enmeshed in a rancorous battle with the News Corporation over Time Warner's refusal to carry the Fox News Channel on its cable systems in New York City. The dispute escalated when the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani tried unsuccessfully to carry the Fox channel on one of the five public-affairs and educational channels it controls. **********The chairman of the F.C.C., Reed E. Hundt, said yesterday that he had not yet read Time Warner's letter and could not comment on it. **********But a former F.C.C. official, who declined to be identified, said the commission was ''most unlikely'' to withhold MCI's license because of its pending merger with British Telecom. MCI has already asked the F.C.C. to allow British Telecom to buy 100 percent of MCI. **********This person said the F.C.C. would probably grant MCI its satellite license and take up the foreign ownership issue as part of its overall consideration of the merger. Indeed, it may issue the license as soon as Monday or Tuesday, according to people familiar with the F.C.C. **********Time Warner's complaint comes as the the News Corporation-MCI alliance may be unraveling on its own. MCI has said it wants to dilute its ownership in the satellite service to less than 20 percent. The News Corporation, however, must retain some relationship with MCI to have access to a high-powered satellite in the United States. **********In his letter, Mr. Parson said the company was objecting to the license because it would mean that the nation's last available slot for a high-powered direct-broadcast satellite would be in the hands of one foreign-controlled company, MCI, and another company, the News Corporation, based in Sydney, Australia. **********The News Corporation and MCI plan to start their direct-broadcast satellite service, which is called A Sky B, at the end of 1997. **********MCI and the News Corporation both attributed Time Warner's request to its continuing battle over the Fox channel. ''First, Time Warner tried to censor the Fox News Channel from competing with CNN, and now they are trying to censor A Sky  B's satellite competition to their cable systems,'' Preston Padden, chairman of A Sky B, said in a statement. **********Tod Hullin, a spokesman for Time Warner, denied that the company was motivated by its clash with the News Corporation. ''We are interested in all forms of distribution for our programming,'' he said. ''And we in the satellite business, through our Prime Star subsidiary.'' **********Despite Time Warner's latest volley, Mr. Parsons said on Thursday that Time Warner and the News Corporation could still work out their differences. In order for the companies to begin a discussion, he said that Mr. Murdoch, who is News Corporation's chairman, would have to ask Mr. Giuliani to remove himself from the dispute.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/16/busin.body_text: **********SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. said yesterday that it had eliminated a dual share  structure in effect since the 1989 merger of the SmithKline Beckman Corporation  of the United States and Beecham Group P.L.C. of Britain. SmithKline announced the share structure change on Feb. 20. SmithKline's class A and class B shares are being merged into one class of common shares. Preference shares are being redeemed at a total cost of about $295 million. **********SmithKline formerly had two classes of shares. Each equity unit contained a  combination of preference shares and common shares and traded in London and New  York.   (Bloomberg Business News)
