https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/20/busin.print_headline: The Interpublic Group is linking up with an Internet broadcaster in a new media expansion.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/20/busin.body_text: **********THE Interpublic Group of Companies is expanding its interests in new media by going into the interactive advertising business with a client of one of its agencies. **********Interpublic, the world's third-largest agency company, with billings of $16.1 billion, is forming a joint venture with the Ifusion Com Corporation, which is developing a so-called Internet broadcasting system named Arrive. Terms of the deal with Ifusion, which is a client of the Interpublic agency Gotham Inc., were not disclosed. **********The purpose of Arrive, which is scheduled to begin a rollout in January, is to deliver customized information -- including advertising -- directly to computer users, relieving them of the need to search through the overwhelming amounts of data available on the Internet. Ifusion (http://www.ifusion.com) joins companies like Pointcast Inc., Backweb Technologies and Intermind in producing ''push delivery'' systems that are being likened to broadcast television channels. **********Interpublic has been exploring the realm of cybercommunications in two ways. One is by helping to finance and support the in-house efforts by the agencies it owns, which besides Gotham include Ammirati Puris Lintas, Lowe Group and McCann-Erickson Worldwide. The other is by investing in independent companies like CKS Group, in which Interpublic owns a minority interest. **********''We've been championing our agencies' development of their own skills,'' Barry R. Linsky, senior vice president for planning and business development at Interpublic in New York, said yesterday, ''and looking beyond that, where appropriate, by taking a stake in companies specializing in this arena. **********''We see a value in being involved in several platforms,'' he added, ''in order to maximize our learning.'' **********Interpublic and Ifusion, which has been working with Gotham since February, will each own 50 percent of the company, to be called Really Perceptive Interactive Advertising L.L.C. It will start with about 10 employees at an office in New York; its mission is to develop interactive advertising that is more precisely aimed at specific consumers as well as more compelling than present offerings like banners -- those signs adorning Web sites urging viewers to ''click here.'' **********''Banners are boring,'' said Martin J. Smith, 53, vice chairman of Gotham in New York, who will also serve as president of Really Perceptive, ''and don't offer high enough value to advertisers.'' **********''This is all about content,'' he added. ''We're hoping to create advertising that really gets people involved with the products.'' **********As an example, Mr. Smith cited an interactive game on the Arrive system that Ifusion is demonstrating this week at Comdex, the big computer trade show in Las Vegas, Nev. The game, with an ice hockey motif, advertises the Mennen Speed Stick deodorant brand marketed by the Colgate-Palmolive Company. **********''It's really fun to play, and it's addictive,'' Michael Recanati, chief executive at Ifusion in New York, said in a telephone interview from Comdex. ''And that's the point of an interactive ad: the more time you spend on the screen, the more time you spend with the product.'' **********Gotham has billings of $250 million from clients that include, in addition to Ifusion, the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, the Dial Corporation and Maybelline Inc. **********Soon after Ifusion executives began working with Gotham executives, Mr. Recanati said, it became apparent ''very early on that they really understood'' what Ifusion was seeking to accomplish. **********''They've been so instrumental in developing the idea'' of Arrive, he added, ''we felt we needed to bring in'' Interpublic as a partner. **********''Interpublic is a large company,'' Mr. Recanati said, ''and we were somewhat concerned we would not be able to get through all the layers. But they've responded extraordinarily well.'' Executives from both Interpublic and Ifusion will serve on the board of Really Perceptive. **********Ifusion, founded last year, has offices in San Francisco and Vienna, Va., in addition to its headquarters in New York. The company has announced agreements with eight ''content providers'' for Arrive, Mr. Recanati said, that include CNNFN, the cable television network owned by Time Warner Inc.; Golfweb, a golf Web site (http://www.golfweb.com); the Showtime Networks of Viacom Inc.; USA Today, published by the Gannett Company; the Weather Channel, the cable network owned by Landmark Communications, and Yahoo Inc., which operates an Internet search engine (http://www.yahoo.com). USA Today is also a client of Gotham. **********By coincidence, Ifusion and Really Perceptive are in the same Manhattan office building that once housed the New York office of Chiat/Day, now the TBWA Chiat/Day unit of Omnicom Group. **********''I was just in Jay Chiat's kitchen the other day,'' Mr. Smith said, laughing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/17/busin.main_headline: Patents;A little box holds out the enticing promise of the lowest long-distance rate every time you call.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/17/busin.print_headline: Patents;A little box holds out the enticing promise of the lowest long-distance rate every time you call.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/17/busin.body_text: **********ON your last long-distance call, did you engage in mathematical calculations? In the seconds between picking up the receiver and punching the last number, did you sift through the hundreds of rates -- based on time zones, time of day and miles crossed -- to find the best deal? **********A Smithtown, L.I., telecommunications company says you don't have to: It has  patented a computerized processor and a method of loading it with data so that the resulting system can weigh all the options for you and choose the cheapest carrier for each long-distance call you make. **********Rates Technology Inc., has two patents -- the first for a microprocessor that is inserted between the phone and the wall jack, and the second for the system of updating the device with current rate information from up to hundreds  of long-distance carriers. **********"The first one we call the plug patent," said Sal Barcia, the company's vice  president of information systems, of the 6-by-4-inch box. **********"The device is loaded with all the rate information from many carriers -- technically we have the ability to carry information for all 867 carriers nationwide right now," he said. "As the phone call is being made, the device looks at the rates of all the carriers, finds the cheapest one, and routes the call through that carrier." **********The number dialed is loaded into a buffer in the microprocessor while the calculation is finishing. Once the device has chosen the cheapest long-distance carrier, it dials that carrier's access code and then the phone number you've just given it. **********The second patent covers "the method by which the device keeps up to date with carrier rates," Mr. Barcia said. The company maintains a central data base  of long-distance rates. Once a month each microprocessor automatically calls the central computer and downloads the updated rate information. The call is made on the company's 900 number, and it charges $1.80 for each update. **********The system uses data compression software developed at Rates Technology. The  company collects rate data from tariff services, phone companies and long-distance carriers. The service charge appears on the consumer's phone bill. After collecting the money, the phone company then pays Rates Technology. **********Mr. Barcia said his company hoped to offer the device through phone companies and in catalogues, where it might sell for about $70. The company received patents 5,519,769 and 5,425,085. **********A New Approach To Text-Telephone **********For anyone with a hearing loss, using a telephone typically requires a text-telephone device -- a keyboard with a display screen that allows callers either to speak or to type what they want to say and then receive text replies from the person they've called. If the other person does not have a keyboard device, the call can be placed through a relay operator who will type the replies and transmit them to the deaf person's screen. **********But that system did not work well for Alan Aronow, who suffered a major hearing loss at the age of 42. Unlike many people who are deaf from birth, Mr. Aronow was able and willing to do his own talking. The vast majority of his business clients, friends and family did not have special equipment, since they  had no hearing problems. **********"The major obstacle is the poorly designed text-telephone interface," Mr. Aronow said in a telephone interview conducted through a relay operator. "It's really a modernized version of an old-fashioned teletype machine designed to allow two people to type messages back and forth." **********So Mr. Aronow set out to design an alternative and came up with a device he calls Look-Hear. **********The unit is about the size of a small clock-radio, with a front taken up almost entirely by a screen that can show several lines of text. It plugs into a standard phone jack and functions as a telephone with a microphone and speaker.  It also has a large, illuminated button on top that automatically dials the relay operator's 800-number. **********After plugging in the Look-Hear, a user would hit the automatic dial button to reach the relay operator and then, speaking into the microphone, ask the operator to dial a specific number. When someone answers that line, his words would be typed by the relay operator and appear on the Look-Hear screen. At the  end of a conversation, the device resets itself to record text messages or make  another outgoing call. **********Mr. Aronow is talking to phone companies, relay services and communications manufacturers about producing his invention. He received patent 5,521,960. Patents are available by number for $3 from the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/04/world.main_headline: With Placards and Slogans, Palestinians Face the Unknown: An Election
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/04/world.print_headline: With Placards and Slogans, Palestinians Face the Unknown: An Election
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/04/world.body_text: **********After many last-minute changes and much confusion, the Palestinian election commission today declared the campaign open to elect the first legislature and president the Palestinians have ever had. **********In the hilly streets of the West Bank's second largest city, the announcement went almost unnoticed -- not because of apathy, but because the campaign has already been going at full steam for almost two months, since Yasir Arafat set Jan. 20 as the date of the elections. **********The 55 contenders for the eight Council seats in Nablus have transformed every downtown wall and lamppost into a patchwork of posters with the red, green, black and white colors of the Palestinian flag and, with rare exceptions, portraits of male candidates sporting the mandatory Palestinian mustaches. **********The scene is much the same throughout the Palestinian cities and villages that have emerged from Israeli occupation over the past two years. Some 700 candidates from a bewildering array of blocs and parties have each anted up the  $1,000 registration fee to compete for the ballots of 1,013,235 newly registered voters, most of whom have never voted before. **********For both Palestinians and Israelis, the election of a Council marks a major step on the journey of West Bank Palestinians from an occupied people to full self-rule, in which the Palestinians will have a legitimate government of their  own, with a legislature, executive council and president. **********The elections are part of the agreements between the Israelis and Palestinians signed in the last two years under which the elected Palestinian legislative council and president will form an executive authority, and together they will govern the Palestinians until the end of the century, when a final peace settlement is to be concluded. **********By any measure, the elections do not make a democracy. The domination of the  race by Mr. Arafat and his Fatah movement, uncertainty about the powers of the legislature, continuing disputes with Israel, and Mr. Arafat's failure to bring  the Islamic opposition, Hamas, into the race, have cast shadows over the voting. **********International monitors have complained about the haste and improvisation of the election. The election commission was appointed only two weeks ago, and only last week the number of seats in the Council was increased by presidential decree from 83 to 88. **********During the Palestinian-Israeli talks, neither side could agree on whether the Palestinian chief executive would be known as the President, Mr. Arafat's choice, or Chairman, the Israeli choice. So they settled on "Ra'ees," an Arabic  word that can be translated either way. **********Only one candidate has challenged Mr. Arafat for that office -- Samiha Khalil, a 72-year-old woman known for her ardent left-wing social and political  views, and who pledges to annul the Israeli-Palestinian agreements if elected. **********There is no question that Mr. Arafat will defeat her soundly. He has drawn tens of thousands of Palestinians to victory rallies over the past two months as Israeli soldiers have pulled out of one West Bank city after another, and he is  still a national icon to most Palestinians. **********By contrast, Mrs. Khalil attracted about 200 curious Palestinians, plus several dozen reporters and observers, to a meeting this afternoon at the Al-Qasr Hotel in Nablus, where she declared, "What drove me to stand for a candidate to the presidency is my wish to lift the burden of oppression from the shoulders of the Palestinian people." **********The real action has been in the Council race. In the crush since he announced the election date, Mr. Arafat has failed to issue a law regulating political parties, so candidates have banded together in dozens of parties and blocs. Even the Samaritans, a sect whose approximately 400 adherents live near Nablus, have  fielded three candidates for their one guaranteed seat. **********In the scramble to win votes, many candidates have been using the tricks of more mature democracies. One rich candidate even took over a Nablus coffee shop  for the duration of the campaign, offering free coffee to all comers. **********At the headquarters of the "Freedom and Independence Bloc," a pair of bare rooms in a downtown office building, the bloc's leader, Khair al-Din Barham, sat under a large sheet with a hand-painted seal of his association, "The Palestinian Association of Revolutionary Ex-Warriors," featuring crossed assault rifles. **********As befits a Palestinian of stature, his office was filled with supporters smoking and sipping sugary coffee. As they looked on, Mr. Barham answered questions of a group of observers from the European Union. **********How did his bloc differ from any other, asked one monitor. "We want to help the people," Mr. Barham explained to the approving nods from his supporters. "If elected we will fight for social issues and economic help." **********The observer jotted down the answer, but it was not immediately apparent how  the program Mr. Barham outlined differed from any described on the posters and ads plastering the West Bank and Gaza Strip. **********Out in the street, a poster promoting Fawzi al-Araj, an architect and engineer, featured his photo under the slogan, "There's no difference between independence and economic development." **********Next to it was a picture of Tahseen al-Fares with the message, "No development without cooperation, no cooperation without development." Kamel Afghani, opting for poetic impact, pledged that those who struggled for Palestinian liberation would "leave their horses only on the fields of Jerusalem." **********The only portrait of a woman was that of Mihaya al-Saqa, one of only 20 women who have registered as candidates although women account for 49 percent of registered voters. She pledged to "create real unity," to resolve the issue of refugees, to free all political prisoners, to support farmers and workers and to defend women. **********In the absence of traditional parties apart from Fatah, and with few differences on issues, the campaign has focused on individuals. The qualification most frequently cited is resistance to Israeli occupation, with candidates proudly listing how many times they were imprisoned, beaten or -- most prestigious -- deported. **********Most candidates are from Fatah, the oldest Palestinian movement extant, though democracy has sharply divided its ranks. Initially, Mr. Arafat held primaries within Fatah to select a single slate, but when the results came in he put them aside and announced his own list of candidates, setting aside many veteran guerrillas in favor of men with entrepreneurial or legal skills, as well as a broader representation from villages and refugee camps. **********In Nablus, Mr. Arafat tapped Mayor Ghassan Shaka, scion of a powerful local clan and head of the West Bank lawyers' association, to head his slate. Sitting  in his storefront office among coffee-sipping supporters, Mr. Shaka, 53, said he had resigned the mayoralty to run for the Council because "this is the most important moment of Palestinian history -- the building of a state." **********The most yawning gap in the campaign is the absence of Hamas, the Islamic opposition group that has the strongest backing among Palestinians. Mr. Arafat opened talks on Dec. 20 with Hamas in hopes of persuading them to join the election. **********Evidently expecting Hamas to do so, Mr. Arafat issued a presidential decree adding five seats to the Council and extended the registration deadline. But Hamas refused to participate and ordered three moderate members in Gaza who had registered as independent candidates to drop out. Mr. Arafat's only gain was that Hamas tacitly agreed not to call for a general boycott of the vote and not  to mount terrorist attacks during the campaign. **********Mr. Arafat's attempt to attract Hamas through last-minute changes in the size of the Council and the rules of the campaign drew a sharp rebuke from European Union election observers. **********In a statement titled "Enough is Enough," the head of the team, Carl Lidbom,  complained that extending the deadline for registering shortened the campaign to 14 days, and that Mr. Arafat did not have the authority to change the rules. **********"Over all, the events of the past few days have created confusion and uncertainty, and give the impression of the arbitrary use of power to redesign the electoral architecture," Mr. Lidbom declared in a press release, though he did not note that the intention was actually to make place for the opposition. **********Mr. Arafat has made sure that the Palestinian Christian minority will be in the Council, making them the only minority aside from the Samaritans to have guaranteed seats. Though the Christians comprise only 3 percent of the population, Mr. Arafat granted them six seats, recognizing their disproportionate wealth and influence among Palestinians, especially in Jerusalem. **********The race for Jerusalem's two Christian seats drew a number of prominent Palestinians, including Hanan Ashwari, a former peace negotiator; Hanna Siniora, a publisher and head of the Palestinian-European Chamber of Commerce, and Jonathan Kuttab, a lawyer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/22/busin.main_headline: G.O.P. Bill Would Extend Pensions in Small Business
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/22/busin.print_headline: G.O.P. Bill Would Extend Pensions in Small Business
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/22/busin.body_text: **********House Republicans plan to pass legislation on Wednesday that would make it easier for small businesses to offer retirement savings plans for their 36 million workers. And in a break from decades of pension policy, the bill would let owners reap tax benefits for themselves even if their workers do not participate. **********The retirement provisions are part of a $7.5 billion bill filled with changes sought by owners of small businesses to simplify tax, pension and other rules that bedevil companies with fewer than 100 workers. **********For example, over seven years the bill would increase to $25,000 from $17,500 the value of equipment purchases that can be deducted immediately, instead of being depreciated over several years. The bill would also phase out tax breaks for companies that build factories in Puerto Rico and reinvest the profits on the island, using the increased revenues to offset the small business tax breaks. **********These provisions will provide political cover for Republicans who oppose another aspect of the bill, increasing the minimum wage by 90 cents an hour over two years, to $5.15. Polls have shown that raising the minimum wage is widely popular despite concerns expressed by small-business owners and many economists  that it would cost jobs. **********Republicans, citing a rising public concern about retirement income and the safety of nest eggs, sought to focus attention today on changes to pension law. **********Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said the proposals would help workers in small business by "making it easier to get a secure pension and by providing increased security for existing retirement accounts." And he said all 120 million working  Americans stood to benefit from one or more of the two dozen pension changes in  the bill. **********Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich called the bill "a watered down version of what President Clinton has already proposed." And he noted that it did not require accountants or other professionals who find indications that retirement  savings are being embezzled to report their suspicions to the Government. **********But the centerpiece of the bill is what the Republicans call a Simple pension plan for small businesses, which is short for "savings incentive match plan for  employees." **********Companies with fewer than 100 workers at any time during a year could create  a sort of mini-401(k) plan in which workers could save up to $6,000, compared with $9,500 under existing 401(k) plans. **********Existing 401(k)'s require expensive and complex tests comparing the contributions of highly paid and low-wage workers to insure that tax benefits do not flow only to the highly paid. In Simple plans, these tests would not be necessary if the employer either deposited 2 percent of each employee's pay into the employee's account or matched dollar-for-dollar the first 3 percent that employees saved. Employers who choose the matching option could reduce the match in two of every five years if they fell on hard times. **********Under the bill, the owner of a small business could save $6,000 on tax-deferred basis and match the savings with another $6,000, even if none of his or her employees participated in the Simple plan. **********A critic of existing pension laws, Karen Ferguson, co-author of "The Pension  Book," called the bill "a radical departure from decades of pension policy requiring that lower-paid workers get benefits as a condition of owners and managers' getting tax breaks." **********"This is shortsighted, crazy and foodhardy," she said. **********Republican staff members said they were confident that millions of workers, even those earning modest wages, would leap at the chance to save money on a tax-advantaged basis for retirement, especially when their money would be matched by their employers. **********Mr. Reich noted that the President's proposal would require small- business owners to contribute at least 1 percent of their workers' wages to a retirement  savings plan before their own contributions could be tax-deferred. **********Another provision of the bill would allow the one in six workers who are employed by nonprofit organizations to have 401(k) accounts. Currently, workers  at nonprofit organizations are limited to less generous 403(b) plans. **********The bill would also protect the assets of state and local government pension  plans from creditors, putting them on the same footing as business and nonprofit pension plans. This provision was added in response to the bankruptcy filing by  Orange County, Calif., which focused attention on the disparate treatment of government and business plans. **********The bill would also protect truck drivers, carpenters and others who participate in pension plans paid for by groups of employers by making retirement benefits mandatory after five years, the same as the law requires of  plans provided by a single employer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/09/world.main_headline: After NATO Overtures, France Is Ready to Resume Military Role
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/09/world.print_headline: After NATO Overtures, France Is Ready to Resume Military Role
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/09/world.body_text: **********President Jacques Chirac said today that France would rejoin all the military structures of NATO from which it pulled out in 1966 if the alliance's decision this week to give European countries a stronger leadership role was fully carried out. **********French officials said it would take about a year for NATO nations to draw up  detailed contingency plans for the new command procedures on which its foreign ministers agreed last Monday in Berlin, and that Mr. Chirac could then make the  decision to end France's 30-year estrangement. **********The NATO foreign ministers approved plans to give a European defense organization, the Western European Union, the ability to use NATO command structures, heavy transport aircraft and other assets in European-led military operations in regional crises even when the United States did not become involved. **********"The decision, to the extent that it becomes reality, opens the way to full and complete French participation in the structures of an alliance whose principles and operating procedures will have been profoundly transformed," Mr.  Chirac said in a major defense policy speech today. **********American officials have welcomed the French moves, even while insisting that  they find it hard to imagine any NATO military operation that the United States  would not want to join. **********Abandoning the go-it-alone policy adopted by Charles de Gaulle 30 years ago,  Mr. Chirac has committed France to developing a European defense strategy within the American-led alliance rather than outside it. **********France announced last December that it would take part in meetings of NATO defense ministers and military chiefs of staff, in which it had not participated since 1966, on condition that the alliance transform itself to reflect changes since the cold war ended, including a diminished American military presence in Europe. **********Mr. Chirac has also started changes to make the French armed forces all-volunteer and reduce their numbers from 500,000 to 350,000 over the next decade, with the ability to send large units quickly to trouble spots like Bosnia. **********NATO sent a 60,000-member peacekeeping force into Bosnia late last year only  after the United States agreed to lead the operation. **********"Success in Berlin was not guaranteed in advance on a subject where the temptation to resist was strong on both sides of the Atlantic," Mr. Chirac told  an audience of high military officers and strategists at the Institute of Advanced National Defense Studies here. **********French defense officials said one obstacle was the reluctance of the alliance's American commander, Gen. George A. Joulwan, to accept the idea that NATO subordinate commanders could be designated for separate all-European operations that NATO would not command. **********The allied foreign ministers agreed on Monday that NATO and the Western European Union would work hand-in-hand in their separate European missions. **********"We have to put an end to what the world sees as European impotence," Mr. Chirac told his audience. **********Rejoining the alliance's integrated military structures would put French officers permanently back into NATO's subordinate military commands and into the Military Committee, the alliance's highest military authority, now consisting of the chiefs of staffs of the 15 member countries besides France. **********France also does not now take part in NATO's nuclear planning group or its defense planning committee, both of which were set up after France limited its participation to the political level in 1966.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/31/busin.snippet: Heating oil prices tumble on New York Mercantile Exchange after report that showed sharp gain in inventories; corn and soybeans fall, while copper rises (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/31/busin.main_headline: Heating Oil Price Plunges On Report of Jump in Supply
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/31/busin.print_headline: Heating Oil Price Plunges On Report of Jump in Supply
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/31/busin.body_text: **********Heating oil prices tumbled on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday after a report that showed a sharp gain in inventories. **********On other markets, corn and soybeans fell, while copper rose. **********After the market closed on Tuesday, the American Petroleum Institute reported that the refinery output of heating oil and other distillate fuels rose by 3 percent last week, to 3.8 million barrels a day. **********The report eased concern that inventories were perilously low at the start of the winter heating season. **********''The inventory builds have increased sizably,'' said Richard Watov, vice president for trading at the American Agip Company in New York. ''We won't see prices move up until we get colder weather.'' **********Heating oil for November delivery fell 1.37 cents, to 68.46 cents a gallon, on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the lowest price since September. That followed Tuesday's drop of 1.63 cents on forecasts of mild weather in the East. December crude oil fell 6 cents yesterday, to $24.28 a barrel. **********Corn and soybeans fell as ideal weather forecast for next week should allow farmers to harvest their late-planted crops without delay. **********Normal to below-normal rainfall is expected in the Midwest growing region next week, forecasters said. Unhindered by rain, farmers will make up for planting that was delayed by rain this spring. **********December corn fell 4.25 cents, to $2.7025 a bushel, on the Chicago Board of Trade. November soybeans dropped 9 cents, to $6.895 a bushel. **********Copper prices rose, rebounding from a 5.3 percent plunge on Tuesday, as traders judged stockpiles to be low, even if some of the recent withdrawals are returned to exchange warehouses. **********Prices had tumbled on speculation that a sharp drop in London Metal Exchange copper stocks was an attempt to inflate prices and not a sign of demand from manufacturers. **********''It's a very difficult market to work in,'' said Joseph Drosdick, copper manager at American Iron and Metal in Verona, N.J. **********December copper rose 2.4 cents, to 92.8 cents a pound, at the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/08/busin.snippet: End-of-year charitable contributions can make good financial sense for taxpayers who itemize deductions; Internal Revenue Service says charitable giving is the second most frequently claimed deduction, showing up on a quarter of all individual tax...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/08/busin.main_headline: A Warm Glow, and Perhaps a Nice Deduction
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/08/busin.print_headline: A Warm Glow, and Perhaps a Nice Deduction
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/08/busin.body_text: **********CHARITY springs from the heart, but it also makes sense to engage the financial-savvy regions of the brain. That way you can maximize your giving. **********The Internal Revenue Service says charitable giving is the second most frequently claimed deduction, showing up on a quarter of all individual tax returns. The average amount claimed is about $2,400. **********To be deductible, a donation must be made to a ''qualified'' organization. Most churches, schools, and familiar charities, like the Red Cross, qualify, though not all nonprofits do. Club dues do not, nor do gifts to specific individuals. Gifts to governments qualify, such as land for a town park. **********First and foremost in any donor's mind is usually the hope of doing some good. So if you have settled on a cause that you care about, it may pay to spend a little time looking at the group's finances. Good signs are when a charity spends a big portion of its budget on program services, or good works, and a small portion on fund-raising and administration. This way, the chances are greater that your money will wind up in the right hands, whether a hungry child or a cancer researcher. **********If you are planning to make a really big donation, you may find that a foundation or a trust allows you more control and to direct gifts for years. You may even get something in return. **********Of course, the timing of a donation can be important from a tax standpoint. If your tax bracket is higher this year than you expect it to be next year, that's a good reason to give before the year is out. And if you are giving late in December, how you pay can be important. A check made out to a charity is considered to be given on the day you mail it. A contribution charged on a credit card is deductible in the year you make the charge, regardless of when you pay the bill. A pledge is a gift once it is honored. **********To get a tax benefit, you must itemize on your Federal return. A single person with more than $4,000 in deductions and a married couple with more than $6,700 will find that itemizing makes sense. The general rule is to deduct the full value of cash gifts, the current value of appreciated securities and the market value of other donated property, like real estate or used clothes. **********Record-keeping is a little tricky. A canceled check, an account statement or a simple receipt is generally fine for gifts of cash or property worth less than $250. For bigger gifts, you need a more detailed written receipt, including how much you gave, what, if anything, you received in return and what it is worth. **********Charities also have to provide a written statement if you give more than $75 and get something significant in return, like a dinner. You can take a deduction only for the difference in the two amounts. **********If a gift of property is worth more than $5,000, you generally need a professional appraisal for tax purposes. **********And if you give of your time, some out-of-pocket expenses, like travel to and from events, are also deductible. Confused by it all? The rules are spelled out in I.R.S. Publication 526, Charitable Contributions. **********Finally, take note of two I.R.S. limits. **********The amount of your deduction may be limited if your gifts exceed 20 percent of income. Whether the limit is 20 percent, 30 percent or 50 percent of your adjusted gross income depends on whether a gift is cash or property, what type of organization receives it and what terms and conditions are attached to the gift. (Excess deductions can be carried forward to future years.) **********Second, like all other deductions, charitable ones are phased out for high-income taxpayers. Big donors may want to consult a tax adviser.   JOHN H. CUSHMAN JR.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/28/busin.snippet: Federal judge refuses to dismiss lawsuit against IRS brought by 737 former IBM employees who contend that part of their severance payments should not have been taxed; decision allows lawsuit to proceed; case reviewed (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/28/busin.main_headline: Ex-I.B.M. Workers' Suit Against I.R.S. Gains
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/28/busin.print_headline: Ex-I.B.M. Workers' Suit Against I.R.S. Gains
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/28/busin.body_text: **********A Federal judge refused today to dismiss a lawsuit against the I.R.S. brought by 737 former I.B.M. employees who contend that part of their severance payments should not have been taxed. **********The decision by Judge Thomas J. McAvoy of the Federal District Court here to reject a motion from the Internal Revenue Service allows the unusual lawsuit to proceed. It also allows the employees to subpoena company documents and executives. The suit contends  that a portion of the employees' severance payments was not wages, which are taxable, but settlements of potential personal injury claims for emotional distress and other wrongs. **********Alan M. Shapiro, a Justice Department lawyer representing the I.R.S., had argued that if the lawsuit went ahead, it could create a precedent amounting to billions of dollars in lost tax revenues. The suit, he said, ''gives special treatment to downsized employees and burdens taxpayers.'' **********Mr. Shapiro said he did not dispute that downsized employees suffered distress, as the suit contends, like insomnia, weight gain, headaches, hypertension and heart trouble. **********But in arguing for the suit's dismissal, he said the severance payments by I.B.M. were to ease its workers into retirement or new careers, not to pre-empt lawsuits, as the plaintiffs argued. **********Judge McAvoy said I.B.M.'s real intent was ambiguous, and said it would be premature to dismiss the suit before the plaintiffs had an opportunity to collect evidence. **********The judge also disclosed that he and his wife worked for the International Business Machines Corporation from 1961 to 1962, and that he has two sons-in-law who are worried about their jobs at the company. **********More than 120,000 former I.B.M. employees who paid $2.3 billion in taxes may be eligible to join the lawsuit if they file refund claims with the I.R.S., said James T. McDermott, a lawyer with Ball Janik of Portland, Ore., which filed the suit on behalf of the former employees. **********''This is a tremendous victory,'' Mr. McDermott's partner, Neil Kimmelfield, said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/18/world.main_headline: Balkan Chiefs Air Problems Of Peace Plan In Rome Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/18/world.print_headline: Balkan Chiefs Air Problems Of Peace Plan In Rome Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/18/world.body_text: **********In an effort to prevent the unraveling of the Balkan peace accord, officials  of the United States and its NATO allies began a two-day meeting here today with the Presidents of Bosnia, Croatia and Serbia. **********As the meeting began this afternoon at the Italian Foreign Ministry, Assistant Secretary of State Richard C. Holbrooke underscored the problems by quoting words used by Churchill just before the Allied invasion in Normandy in World War II. "I don't argue the difficulties," Mr. Holbroke said. "They will argue for themselves." **********It was the first time since the accord was signed in Paris in December that  the three Presidents -- Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, Franjo Tudjman of Croatia, and Alija Izetbegovic of Bosnia -- had met. **********After brief statements by several participants, the delegates, including officials of France, Germany, Britain and Russia, which along with the United States formed the so-called "contact group" on the Balkans, began closed sessions. The basic issues involve mounting evidence that all sides are flouting the accords on refugee and prisoner exchanges, the departure of foreign military volunteers, pledges to apprehend suspected war criminals, and growing tensions in the Muslim-Croat federation. **********Mr. Holbrooke has said his goal at the talks is "a recommitment to Dayton." The accord signed in Paris was reached in talks near Dayton, Ohio, in November. **********"It is really going to be pretty thorough," he said before the meeting. "Not  just on one or two issues." Officials said the meeting was expected to end Sunday with a clear pledge by all sides to recommit to full compliance with the  peace agreement. **********In an opening statement today, the European Union mediator, Carl Bildt, said  the meeting should send out "one clear message -- that the peace process is still on course in Bosnia." **********Addressing the three Presidents, Mr. Bildt said: "We can help from the side of the international community. But in the end, it is your country, your peace,  your future." **********The United States led the talks in 1994 that produced the accord, which calls for the Muslim-Croat federation to govern roughly half of Bosnia, with the Bosnian Serbs getting the rest. Tens of thousands of NATO soldiers are in the country to try to assure compliance with the accord. **********Mr. Holbrooke was accompanied by NATO's supreme commander in Europe, Gen. George Joulwan, and Adm. Leighton Smith, the NATO commander in Bosnia. In an interview today with CNN, Mr. Holbrooke said that General Joulwan and Admiral Smith would "give a no-holds-barred, straight-from-the-shoulder statement" on conditions in Bosnia. "The good, the bad, the ugly," he said. **********The three Presidents gave a peace gesture before the meeting, exchanging handshakes to general applause. Seeking to play down the air of crisis, Mr. Tudjman was quoted as saying earlier today: "Dayton is not in a crisis. It wasn't realistic to expect that everything would go smoothly." **********Mr. Tudjman will certainly be asked about the failure of Croats in Bosnia to  accept the Muslim-Croat federation foreseen by the peace plan. Earlier this month, Croats in the Bosnian city of Mostar rebelled against plans drawn up by a European Union administrator, Hans Koschnick, for the reunification of the city, which is divided between Croats and Muslims. For several hours, angry crowds blocked Mr. Koschnick in his car. **********Mr. Milosevic, the Serbian President, who met privately with Mr. Holbrooke this morning, will presumably be asked about the refusal until Friday of senior  Bosnian Serb military commanders to meet or talk to NATO officials. **********The Bosnian Serb boycott against the meetings came as a protest against the extradition to The Hague of two Bosnian Serb military officers by the Bosnian Government as suspected war criminals. **********On Friday, as a first sign of reduced tension, several contacts between Bosnian Serb and NATO officers took place, including one between Lieut. Gen. Sir Michael Walker, the commander of NATO ground forces in Bosnia, and Gen. Zdravko  Tolimir, the Bosnian Serb army's deputy commander. **********Mr. Izetbegovic, the Bosnian President, will presumably face questioning about NATO charges that a building near Sarajevo raided by NATO on Thursday was  a terrorist training center, run with the aid of the Muslim-led Bosnian Government, and that the operation was conducted by the Bosnian Army with the help of foreign experts, including some from Iran.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/11/your-.snippet: FINDING a new home abroad while adjusting to an unfamiliar culture can be a bewildering experience. Fortunately, there are plenty of companies able to help expatriates find the right home away from home..Orientation tours, house hunting, and movin...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/11/your-.main_headline: Home Away from Home? Call a Professional
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/11/your-.print_headline: Home Away from Home? Call a Professional
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/11/your-.body_text: **********FINDING a new home abroad while adjusting to an unfamiliar culture can be a bewildering experience. Fortunately, there are plenty of companies able to help expatriates find the right home away from home. **********Orientation tours, house hunting, and moving and storage are some of the services being offered. Some companies will even assist clients in obtaining driver's licenses and a place for their children at the top of a school waiting list. Others throw in home management, rental services and cultural assimilation programs. **********None of this comes cheap, of course. Home-search companies charge between 1 percent and 2 percent of the purchase price, or about a month's rent. Charges mount as the services become more complex: Managers at London-based PRIcoa Relocation reckon that one international relocation can cost a company as much as five times an employee's annual salary. **********Companies like their employees to be able to hit the ground running. A "do it yourself" move can be both time-consuming and demoralizing. **********Settler International, part of medical evacuation giant Europ Assistance, is among the largest of these consultants. The Paris-based group has offices in all European Union countries and representation in another 40 capital cities around the globe. All told, it operates on behalf of about 140 companies, of which about 40 percent are American. **********"We can help someone find a house in Harare," said Attilio Batilia, Settler International's sales and marketing director. **********"A third of our business is within Europe, another third are people coming to Europe and the remainder are people moving from Europe to other countries. We select, pre-visit and then present the right house." **********In Britain, the Brighton-based Association of Relocation Agents publishes a directory of its 140-member home search and relocation companies. Tad Zurlinden, the association's chief executive, said that the service has become much more professional in recent years as demand has risen. **********"Ten years ago there were more companies offering home search, but the ones around today are much better, whether they operate on behalf of individuals or companies," he said. "The nature of the work means that most still tend to be regional, however." **********A narrow focus may mean a more comprehensive search, but it can also be a drawback to an expatriate who may be entirely unfamiliar with the area. For example, subtle differences among New York City neighborhoods and among the surrounding suburbs of New York State, Connecticut and New Jersey will not be readily apparent to a new arrival from Tokyo. **********That said, house-hunting in the United States is much easier than in Europe or Asia because most real estate agents have access to all available properties in their area. This so-called multiple listing service means that a prospective buyer or renter only need contact one agent. **********"Multiple listings mean that any real estate agent's firm in the U.S. is in the home-search business," said Chris Collie, executive vice president of the Employee Relocation Council in Washington, D.C. "About 50 companies work exclusively in relocation and home search but most of these are regional." **********The few national relocation companies in America include PHH Relocation Services, Coldwell Banker Relocation Services and Prudential Resources Management. **********"Sometimes the expatriate just gets an allowance and a week's holiday to go find a place," said Mr. Batilia. "But more and more of these services are being offered and to more people. They used to be reserved for top management but now everyone from middle management on up is getting some help."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/15/busin.snippet: Rite Aid Corp, second-largest druggist in the country, in an acceleration of the wave of consolidation sweeping the drugstore industry, says it will acquire Thrifty Payless Holdings Inc, 1,007-store West Coast chain, for $1.3 billion in stock and ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/15/busin.main_headline: Rite Aid to Buy Thrifty Payless for $1.3 Billion
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/15/busin.print_headline: Rite Aid to Buy Thrifty Payless for $1.3 Billion
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/15/busin.body_text: **********In an acceleration of the wave of consolidation sweeping the drugstore industry, the Rite Aid Corporation, the second-largest druggist in the country, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Thrifty Payless Holdings Inc., a 1,007-store West Coast chain, for $1.3 billion in stock, plus the assumption of debt. **********The new entity would create a national chain of 3,816 drugstores and annual revenue of more than $10 billion, second by a slim margin to the Walgreen Company. Prior to the deal, Rite Aid had about half the revenue of Walgreen, though Rite Aid had more stores than Walgreen, even before the acquisition. **********''This industry will continue to consolidate and we plan on being a consolidator,'' said Martin Grass, chairman and chief executive of Rite Aid, which is based in Camp Hill, Pa. ''We want to be a player in markets with a strong market share. The acquisition of the West Coast's largest drugstore chain enables us to extend our geographic reach and provide more opportunities in higher growth areas.'' **********Rite Aid stores are primarily in the East and Midwest. Thrifty Payless, based in Wilsonville, Ore., near Portland, was formed by the 1994 merger of the Thrifty and Payless chains and operates stores in 10 Western states under the Thrifty and Payless names. The deal was first reported in The Wall Street Journal yesterday. **********Under the terms of the stock-swap deal, Rite Aid is to pay 0.65 share of its stock for each Thrifty Payless share. Using yesterday's closing stock price, the deal totals $1.32 billion. Rite Aid will also assume $890 million of debt, much of it incurred when the Thrifty and Payless chains merged. **********Rite Aid's acquisition plans are also a boon for Thrift Drug, a division of the J. C. Penney Company, which is to buy 200 stores in North and South Carolina from Rite Aid for an undisclosed price. Rite Aid was running a distant fourth in the South, so it decided to abandon the market and plans to sell other stores in the region. **********Thrift Drug has also been expanding. On Friday, Thrift completed a $285 million acquisition of Fay's Inc., a chain of 272 stores in New York, Pennsylvania, Vermont and New Hampshire. **********Indeed, Rite Aid and Thrift Drug are only the latest chains caught in the merger wave. Revco D.S. Inc. of Twinsburg, Ohio, whose bid to merge with Rite Aid earlier this year foundered on antitrust issues, is pursuing Big B Inc., a chain of 387 drugstores based in Alabama, with an offer of $330 million. **********The merger trend of the last few years has been spurred by managed health care plans and the shift by consumers to third-party prescription coverage that provides lower reimbursement rates to drugstores. The chains have sought to grow to increase efficiency and spread costs over a bigger base of stores in the face of declining profit margins. **********Analysts estimate that chains of fewer than 20 drugstores account for about 40 percent of the industry's $65 billion in sales. But, they say, the small competitors find it increasingly hard to survive in a cost-conscious environment in which they cannot bargain for better prices from either the third-party providers or the pharmaceutical companies. **********Some critics have contended that the consolidation among drugstores will lead to higher prices, but Mr. Grass at Rite Aid said the merger could benefit consumers. **********''Consolidation may mean lower prices for consumers because we'll be the most efficient provider in the marketplace,'' he said. ''We're in a great position to become a preferred provider for a lot of these H.M.O,'s. To do that, we have to give them the most competitive price.'' **********The merger, however, will eliminate all but a few dozen of the 740 administrative posts at the Thrifty Payless headquarters The company is providing a severance package, Mr. Grass said, ''for everyone from the chairman down to the janitor.'' **********Rite Aid also plans to divest itself of Thrifty Payless's Bi-Mart operation, a chain of 44 membership discount drugstores. But only 2.5 percent of Thrifty Payless's 31,000 employees will be laid off, Mr. Grass said, with Rite Aid retaining store employees and supervisors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/10/busin.main_headline: Ford, in a Shift, Is Offering Rebates to Increase Sales
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/10/busin.print_headline: Ford, in a Shift, Is Offering Rebates to Increase Sales
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/10/busin.body_text: **********The Ford Motor Company said today that it had started offering $600 rebates and discount financing on nearly all its vehicles in an acknowledgment that it had miscalculated the strength of the market. **********Wall Street analysts also said that the rebates reflected the strong reluctance of consumers to pay higher prices for cars. "The market in general has been very sticker sensitive," said Nicholas Lobaccaro, an analyst at S. G. Warburg & Company. For Ford, he added, "the first half of the year is really locked in to be pretty disappointing." **********Ford said that it would offer rebates or discount interest rates of 4.8 percent over four years on most 1996 models sold through April 2. Typical interest rates on four-year auto loans are now twice that level. **********No discounts were offered on Lincolns or several Ford models, including the Explorer, the popular sport utility vehicle; the subcompact Aspire, and the 1997 F-150 pickup, which goes on sale this month. The Bronco sport utility vehicle will offer a $2,000 rebate or the 4.8 percent interest rate. **********Analysts generally agreed that Ford had missed the mark in its strategy to add as standard equipment some previously optional features and charge nearly $19,150 for the most basic of its Taurus models. That would be a 5.6 percent increase from the price of the stripped-down 1995 model, which came with a $1,000 rebate last summer. By contrast, the Chevrolet Lumina, a comparable sedan, starts at $16,355, while a Dodge Intrepid from Chrysler starts at $18,445 plus a $1,000 rebate. **********Ford's rebates amount to "a recognition that the company has recently overproduced," said Scott F. Merlis, an independent automotive researcher based  in Westport, Conn. "Sales were strong, but production was even stronger." He said Ford's per-vehicle incentive costs would probably rise $50 in the first quarter, to about $950. **********The announcement came a week after Alexander Trotman, Ford's chairman and chief executive, had insisted that the company's vehicles were fairly priced and did not need the incentives recently introduced by the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation on selective models. He stressed then that Ford would not offer discounts on its flagship car, the Taurus, despite its disappointing sales in the fall. **********Ross H. Roberts, Ford division general manager, insisted in an interview today that Mr. Trotman, "told you right last week; we had made up our mind to not put any incentives on it." **********But then came the results of a test of incentives that Ford conducted last month in the Midwest. The test bolstered sales so much that Ford decided to offer incentives nationally. **********In Cincinnati, one of the test cities, sales of selected vehicles jumped 22 percent and Taurus sales climbed 34 percent over the November sales. **********The incentives are an embarrassing acknowledgment that Ford misjudged the family-sedan market, where the Taurus has been a best seller for years. Sales in the fall lagged behind 1994 levels, a downturn that Ford attributed to its decision to sell fewer Tauruses to rental fleets. But both customers and dealers have complained about the extensive redesign of the car. **********Mr. Roberts said Ford had not misjudged the market. "We are just responding the way that other manufacturers have," with incentives, he said, adding that the Taurus was the industry's best-selling car in the fourth quarter. **********The problem is that "the size of the pie" has been shrinking, he said, adding: "The car market has just not been that strong. We are getting a bigger piece of the pie than we had." **********Mr. Lobaccaro, the stock analyst, said that on Wednesday he would probably lower his estimate for Ford's 1996 profits to $2.25 a share, from the $3.20 he had estimated in recent weeks and the $3.70 figure he had assigned in the autumn. "The earnings are clearly depressed due to launch costs" associated with the introduction of the new Taurus, Escort and F-150 pickup truck designs, he said. **********As for Ford dealers, they praised the new sales incentives today, although several said Ford should have offered $1,000 rebates. Nevertheless, Doug Barbour, sales manager at Capitol Ford in Raleigh, N.C., said that even the $600 discount "should spur car sales significantly."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/20/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;An Inquiry On Metals By Britain
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/20/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;An Inquiry On Metals By Britain
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/20/busin.body_text: **********Responding to the Sumitomo Corporation's copper trading scandal, British regulators put the entire London-based metal market under scrutiny today. **********The Securities and Investment Board said it would conduct a six-month inquiry into trading on the London Metal Exchange, a leading international market, as well as off-exchange dealing. **********The board is already investigating whether British dealers were involved in  trades with Yasuo Hamanaka, Sumitomo's top copper trader, who acknowledged losing $1.8 billion as a result of unauthorized trades over 10 years. **********The investigation could result in tighter regulation by the British Government of off-exchange trading, which has been vulnerable to fraud. **********Details of the copper trading losses emerged last week when Sumitomo dismissed Mr. Hamanaka.  In Tokyo today, Sumitomo said that it would set aside cash and other assets worth $1.5 billion to help cover the losses and that it had suspended $1.1 million in executive bonuses and canceled a share buyback plan. **********Criminal investigations in Britain were begun last week by the Serious Fraud  Office; a Federal grand jury in New York is also to examine the case. **********Copper prices rose today after the chairman of the London Metal Exchange, Raj Bagri, said clearing and trading arrangements had absorbed the major shocks of the affair. "We have not melted down, and we are not going to," he said. **********Copper on the London Metal Exchange gained more than $25, to $2,025 a metric  ton. At the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange, copper for delivery in July rose 2.2 cents, settling at 97.2 cents a pound. **********Andrew Large, head of the Securities and Investment Board, said the agency's  review would cover the entire metals market as well as unregulated deals outside the London Metal Exchange. **********The board will work with the United States Commodities Futures Trading Commission, the American agency in charge of futures markets. Over the years, the American commodities industry has sought tighter supervision of London trading. **********In New York, Daniel Rappaport, the chairman of the New York Mercantile Exchange, told the Dow Jones News Service that he expected that regulatory changes in the aftermath of the Sumitomo losses would benefit the Comex division and its copper contract. He said Congress was likely to amend the Commodity Exchange Act to force foreign exchanges with delivery points in the United States to abide by American regulations on commodities trading. **********Futures contracts on the London Metal Exchange form a benchmark for world prices. But the exchange has said it cannot supervise or regulate deals struck off the exchange among traders, like Sumitomo, that are not exchange members. **********The board said events had "demonstrated the potentially damaging impact nonmember and nonregulated firms can have on the metals market." **********Traders say Mr. Hamanaka's strategy of controlling supplies for nearby delivery seemed to prop up the London Metal Exchange's copper prices when other  metals weakened in the early 1990's. **********Investigators are also re-examining Chinese losses in the exchange's copper trading and a 1995 scandal involving Chile's state producer Codelco, which lost  $170 million on unauthorized trading. One of Codelco's former top traders has denied fraud charges in Chile.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/02/busin.body_text: **********PT Dharmala Sakti Sejahtera of Indonesia has settled a dispute over $69 million in losses on derivatives it bought from the Bankers Trust New York Corporation. **********The Indonesian financial services company agreed today to pay part of the $69 million it owed the New York bank for interest rate swaps, or bets on the direction of interest rates, that went awry in 1994, a Bankers Trust spokesman said in New York. **********Dharmala agreed to drop suits in Indonesia and London contending that Bankers Trust had misrepresented the risks of the swaps and had promised to replace them free if the company lost money. **********"The suits and countersuits by both parties have been dropped," said Sanjeev  Chatrath, Dharmala's vice president for finance and planning. **********The company and the Bankers Trust spokesman in New York declined to disclose  details of the settlement. **********The agreement settles one of the last major disputes by customers of Bankers  Trust over losses on derivatives that piled up after interest rates began to rise unexpectedly in 1994.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/28/world.snippet: US Defense Sec William Perry denies committing American peacekeeping troops to Bosnia through 1997 (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/28/world.main_headline: Perry Denies Pledging to Keep U.S. Troops in Bosnia in 1997
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/28/world.print_headline: Perry Denies Pledging to Keep U.S. Troops in Bosnia in 1997
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/28/world.body_text: **********Defense Secretary William J. Perry has not indicated an American commitment to retain peacekeeping troops in Bosnia through 1997, his spokesman said yesterday. **********Mr. Perry has said that the United States ''would be prepared to consider a NATO proposal to commit ground troops to Bosnia next year,'' said the spokesman, Kenneth Bacon. ''But he has given no hint that the U.S. would agree to such a proposal.'' **********''At no point has Secretary Perry signaled U.S. commitment to station U.S. ground troops in Bosnia,'' Mr. Bacon said, ''and it would be premature to do so until NATO authorities reach their decision and until President Clinton has reached his.'' **********NATO officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, told The New York Times last week that Mr. Perry and other American officials had ''essentially signaled'' that the United States was committed to retaining ground troops in Bosnia. **********They were quoted in an article published on Saturday saying that while no formal American decision had been made -- and none was expected before the American Presidential election because of political sensitivity -- both American and NATO plans were now predicated on a NATO force of at least 15,000 troops through next year, including at least 5,000 Americans. **********In a statement issued on Saturday, Mr. Perry described the report as ''misleading.'' **********One NATO official, contacted yesterday, repeated that Mr. Perry had strongly indicated to his NATO counterparts that the United States would be part of a successor force in Bosnia. **********''The more private the meetings, the more forthcoming he was,'' the official said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/24/world.main_headline: World News Briefs;Many Tributes as Tutu Leaves Archbishop Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/24/world.print_headline: World News Briefs;Many Tributes as Tutu Leaves Archbishop Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/24/world.body_text: **********Kings, presidents and clergy celebrated Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu and his struggle against apartheid at a service today that marked his retirement as head of the Anglican Church in South Africa. **********After a decade as Anglican Primate of South Africa, he will now devote himself to leading a commission formed by the country's first black-led Government to investigate apartheid-era crimes. **********The first black Archbishop of Cape Town, he rose to international prominence during the 1980's as the voice of the antiapartheid struggle, winning the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize. **********"His laughter ringing out has given courage and confidence to a downtrodden people," the Archbishop of Canterbury, George Carey, said at the ceremony.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/22/busin.snippet: Kobrand Corp, importer and marketer of alcoholic beverages, puts its advertising account in review; account had been handled by Angotti, Thomas, Hedge (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/22/busin.body_text: **********The Kobrand Corporation in New York, an importer and marketer of alcoholic beverages, has placed its account in review. With billings estimated at $2 million, the account had been handled for seven years by Angotti, Thomas, Hedge in New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, until that agency and Kobrand parted ways last month. **********Cathleen Burke, marketing director at Kobrand, said the company was seeking a ''highly creative boutique'' with strategic planning skills to handle Maison Louis Jadot wines, Taittinger champagne and Alize de France, a passion-fruit and cognac beverage. A decision is expected Oct. 1, she added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/03/busin.main_headline: Smart Phone' Makers Seek Cheaper and Easier Way to Reach the Internet
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/03/busin.print_headline: Smart Phone' Makers Seek Cheaper and Easier Way to Reach the Internet
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/03/busin.body_text: **********Despite the considerable attention being paid to the development of the network computer, the gateway to the Internet may not be a $500 PC but a $250 telephone -- or both. **********In recent months, several of the nation's telephone manufacturers have announced plans to market sophisticated screen phones that will let consumers perform a variety of sales transactions like banking or bill-paying, receive documents over the Internet and grab bits of information from Web sites or other information services. **********This week, Philips Home Services, the interactive services unit of Philips Electronics N.V., will begin selling a phone that can send and receive mail over the Internet using software from the Oracle Corporation, the same company that has hyped the idea of the network computer. **********Telephones that provide Internet access look much like ordinary screen phones, which are currently being marketed to take advantage of new services like caller ID. But with additional intelligence, often larger screens, and more often small keyboards, these so-called smart, or enhanced, phones are taking on  some of the attributes of personal computers. In recent demonstrations, in fact, Oracle has been describing a version of the network computer that is actually a  smart phone. **********The three dominant competitors in this new market -- Northern Telecom, a unit of BCE Inc.; Philips, and the combined development forces of U.S. Order and the  Colonial Data Technologies Corporation -- along with a host of smaller players are now lining up partners among the regional Bell companies. The idea is to use the partnerships to distribute the phones and create additional services for them. **********Cidco Inc., a leading maker of phone terminals, announced recently it had licensed the i-phone, an Internet-oriented smart phone designed by the National  Semiconductor Corporation and Infogear, a start-up company based in Woodside, Calif. **********As the market heats up, each company is taking a slightly different approach, adding features like voice recognition, specialized interfaces and touch screens. But the makers of the enhanced phones are quick to point out that their devices are not intended to replace PC's or compete head-to-head with network computers as Web-surfing tools, at least not any time soon. **********It may be just as well. In their current incarnations, they are ill-suited to such competition. For one thing, their mostly text-only black-and-white screens  are typically a quarter of the size of a standard PC monitor, or smaller. So, at least initially, the smart phones will be best suited to performing transactions, such as banking and making airline reservations, and for communication, such as sending and receiving E-mail. Their beauty lies in ease of use. Connecting to the bank, for example, can be a one-button operation, far  simpler than starting up a computer, launching an application and connecting with a modem. **********While the vision of the network computer being promoted by Oracle, I.B.M. and others is something of an inexpensive device used by the whole family for education and entertainment on the Internet, the new phones are decidedly utilitarian appliances. Some models, such as the Telesmart 4000 from Colonial Data, even include a credit card swipe. **********"The screen phone is certainly not a PC, but a very useful device that serves multiple applications, providing access to information services and transactions," said Joseph W. Cline, executive vice president of sales and marketing for Colonial Data. "And it can display information in a very easy to use way." **********"People are going to buy a smart phone because it's the natural next phone you're going to have in your home," said John Backus, president and chief operating officer of U.S. Order, in Herndon, Va. **********Instead of having one device or the other, the manufacturers expect that consumers will have a personal computer in the office or a network computer in the den attached to the television set and an enhanced phone in the kitchen, where it will replace the conventional family phone. **********As Mr. Backus envisions it, the products will have very different uses. If you wanted to use the Web to research sport utility vehicles, for example, you would use a PC to browse auto makers' Web sites, download reviews from car magazines and perhaps compare dealer prices. But if you wanted to check the school lunch menu for your 8-year-old, you could probably find out more quickly  using a smart phone. **********Gerrit Schipper, the president and chief executive of Philips Home Services,  says the company's research has shown that consumers are not interested in using a telephone for Internet browsing. **********Berge Ayvazian, a senior vice president at the Yankee Group, a consulting company, said people underestimate the inherent advantages of using an enhanced  phone to connect to the Web compared with using a network computer. **********"The smart phone has a small screen, but the phone is a multifunction device, while the network computer is a narrow device, only for surfing the Web," Mr. Ayvazian said. And, he said, "The guys that are trying to keep the perceived price of the network computer under $500 are stripping out all but the most necessary and assuming you want to use your television, and want to pay for a modem, which is also separate." **********But the new phones are still a long way from becoming the preferred low-cost  Internet access device. Providing a means of translating Web documents into information that can be viewed on the small screens of smart phones is one of the biggest hurdles facing manufacturers. Initially, users will dial in to intermediary servers to provide the translation. Eventually, however, translation will take place in the phone, Mr. Ayvazian said. **********For example, Northern Telecom, or Nortel, a telecommunications company based  in Dallas, is developing a sophisticated phone that will use Sun Microsystems' Java language to translate Web pages into information that can be read on the phone's small screen. **********At least one more cycle of price reductions is expected. Enhanced phones today typically cost $400 to $500, though a few are already much cheaper (Philips sells an Internet phone in the Netherlands for about $350), and the phones can be leased for a few dollars a month. **********The price of smart phones will have to come down to around $250, analysts predict, before most consumers would readily embrace them as alternatives to conventional phones, which can cost less than $20. Nortel's phone is expected to sell for $500 when it released next year, but the company hopes eventually to sell it for about $300, said Rock Faletti, president of Nortel Multimedia Communications Systems. **********"It is not at all clear yet how these services are going to be packaged and priced," Mr. Ayvazian said. **********Philips has been testing its phones in Garden City, L.I., where it delivered  $4 million worth of smart phones to the town's 7,500 households. Initially, residents will use the phones to retrieve local information stored in Philips' own information service which will include supermarket specials and school events. And while they will not be able to browse the Web, they will be able to  send E-mail to friends on the system or over the Internet. **********The project builds upon Philips' early foray into phone-based financial services, which it began in late 1994 with Citibank. Through the Garden City test, Philips hopes to determine just what the demand is for broader information services delivered through the phone, and how much such services will cost.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/04/busin.main_headline: COMPANY NEWS;INTERNATIONAL PAPER PLANS TO ELIMINATE 1,300 JOBS
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/04/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;INTERNATIONAL PAPER PLANS TO ELIMINATE 1,300 JOBS
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/04/busin.body_text: **********The International Paper Company said yesterday that it would cut 1,300 jobs in the United States and Europe, resulting in a $70 million pretax charge against fourth-quarter earnings. The eliminated jobs represent 1.9 percent of International Paper's 70,000 employees at the end of 1994. George Adler, an analyst at Smith Barney Inc. in New York, said the moves by International Paper, the world's largest forest-products company, might be a response to reduced demand and lower prices for paper and cardboard boxes. The charge will reduce earnings by 17 cents a share, according to the company, which is based in Purchase, N.Y. A survey of 14 analysts by Zacks Investment Research before the announcement estimated that International Paper would earn $1.22 a share in the  quarter.
