https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/08/busin.main_headline: Several New Reports Give A Mixed View of Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/08/busin.print_headline: Several New Reports Give A Mixed View of Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/08/busin.body_text: **********Several new statistics gave a mixed reading on the economy today, as economists awaited the Labor Department's employment report on Friday. **********Despite the January blizzard in the Northeast, consumers added to installment debt at a hefty annual pace of 12.1 percent in January, the Federal Reserve reported. This compared with a rate of 11.6 percent in December, revised upward  from a 9.3 percent rate estimated a month ago. **********The Conference Board, a business research group in New York, calculated that its index designed to signal turning points in the business cycle dropped five-tenths of 1 percent in January as the blizzard shrank the length of the average workweek to its lowest point in more than 12 years. **********Still another report found that first-time claims for unemployment insurance  climbed 6,000 in the week ended Saturday, retracing about a quarter of the preceding week's improvement. **********Analysts said the latest data provided little solid information about the state of the economy, which they said seemed to be grinding out further meager gains. **********"They suggest to me that we're still in the doldrums, especially the manufacturing sector," commented Evelina M. Tainer, chief economist at Indosuez  Carr Futures in Chicago. "We're going to have a soft, sluggish first half and a  rebound in the second half," she predicted, with total output expanding an average of 1.3 percent at an annual rate through mid-year and 2.8 percent thereafter. **********The installment debt compilation, once regarded as a quite useful indicator of consumer behavior, is now denigrated by many analysts because of the rise of  home equity loans, which are not included, and the increased use of credit cards for convenience rather than as a means to borrow. Moreover, the series does not  show extensions or repayments, only the net change in the amount outstanding. **********Still, analysts said, the economy is unlikely to be at risk of a significant  downturn so long as installment debt continues to rise at double-digit annual rates. Revolving, or credit card, debt rose at a 16.1 percent pace in January, the fastest since June, today's report showed, while automobile credit slowed to a 9.3 percent rate of increase from 14.4 percent in December. **********Interest rates on new car loans averaged 9.74 percent, down sharply from 10.52 in December. **********The category of "other" debt, which includes loans for boats, college or vacations, expanded at a 9.8 percent pace compared with 2.1 percent in December, the Fed reported. **********"The consumer's balance sheet is not yet as overextended as it was in the late 1980's," Joseph Liro, economist at Wood Gundy, advised clients last Friday. "Therefore we believe the consumer can sustain at least a moderate pace of spending through 1996." **********The sizable decline in the recently privatized index of leading indicators, which has also lost esteem over the last several years, had little effect today  not only because most of its components have been previously reported but also because of the blizzard's overwhelming effect in shrinking the workweek. **********Excluding the workweek item, the index would have edged up one-tenth of 1 percent instead of falling five-tenths of 1 percent, the Conference Board said.  Nonetheless, the index has moved lower in four of the latest five months and eight of the latest 12. **********After the workweek, negative impacts were generated by lower building permits, a decline in consumer expectations, a rise in first-time jobless claims, quicker deliveries by suppliers and lower stock prices. **********Positive contributions came from a rise in unfilled factory orders for durable goods (also reflecting the blizzard), higher prices for materials particularly sensitive to the business cycle, higher contracts and orders for new plant and equipment, more orders to factories for consumer goods and a slightly expanded money supply. **********The companion index of coincident indicators fell three-tenths of 1 percent in January after rising that much in December, while the index of indicators that tend to move only after the economy at large was unchanged in January after rising three-tenths of 1 percent in December. **********The Labor Department's report on jobless claims listed 363,000 last week, up  from 357,000 in the Feb. 24 week, with the four-week average inching down by 1,000 to stand at 370,750. Some analysts found signs of marginal labor market improvement in recent claims figures but there was little correlation between them and the monthly figures to be published Friday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/16/world.main_headline: U.S. Helps to Start Negotiations To End the Fighting in Lebanon
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/16/world.print_headline: U.S. Helps to Start Negotiations To End the Fighting in Lebanon
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/16/world.body_text: **********Israeli planes and artillery hammered Lebanon for the fifth day today, but Israeli and American officials said intensive contacts had begun in an effort to end the fighting, possibly by week's end. **********A White House spokesman said Secretary of State Warren Christopher, en route  to East Asia, opened a round of extensive talks today with Syrian, Lebanese and  Israeli officials. At the same time, Israeli radio reported that the Iranian Foreign Minister would visit Syria and Lebanon within the next two days. **********The dance has begun; we hope the time is ripe," an Israeli official said, confirming that Mr. Christopher held long telephone talks today with Prime Minister Shimon Peres and Foreign Minister Ehud Barak of Israel, as well as Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa of Syria and Prime Minister Rafik al-Hariri of Lebanon. **********In other diplomatic moves, the French Foreign Minister, Herve de Charette, met in Israel today with Mr. Peres and Mr. Barak, though Israeli commentators put little stock in his initiative. Mr. de Charette reportedly asked the Iranian Foreign Minister, Ali Akbar Velayati, to join in the efforts to halt the fighting. **********The Jordanian Prime Minister, Abdul Karim al-Kabariti, is also expected in Israel, on Tuesday, to help mediate. **********Israeli officials said they believed that a cease-fire agreement could be reached within two or three days, in time for residents who had fled from threatened regions of northern Israel to return to their homes by the national holiday on April 22. **********Mr. Peres has not spelled out the goals of attacks in Lebanon, which began last Thursday and have sent hundreds of thousands of Lebanese civilians fleeing  from cities and villages south of Beirut. But Israeli officials have made clear  that the primary objective is to mount enough pressure on Lebanon and Syria to force them to curb attacks by Hezbollah, or the Party of God, a militant Shiite  Muslim organization supported by Iran. **********Once the point was driven home with the combined pressure of the large exodus and incessant air and artillery attacks, including select strikes on Beirut, the plan was for the United States to step in and broker a new cease-fire arrangement, much as Mr. Christopher did after a similar Israeli operation in 1993, which lasted seven days. **********Hezbollah has been fighting a guerrilla war for 11 years against the Israeli  occupation of a nine-mile-wide buffer zone in southern Lebanon. Israel launched  the attacks asserting that the guerrillas had escalated their attacks beyond the limits set in 1993, both inside the zone and against northern Israel. **********Though there was no indication yet what arrangements the United States was discussing, Israeli officials said that as in 1993, there would be no written agreement. The Israelis said the minimum they expected to gain was firm commitments from the Lebanese and Syrian Governments that Hezbollah would not attack inside Israel, either with Katyusha rockets or infiltrations. **********Beyond that, the Israelis said they hoped that Syria would agree to clamp down on Hezbollah, a commitment Israel had been seeking from Syria before their  peace talks were suspended last month. Those talks were broken off in the political crisis that followed a wave of suicide bombings in Israel. **********An American official said Washington was pressing Syria to restrain Hezbollah, which derives much of its support from Iran but which is dependent in southern Lebanon on Syrian tolerance. "We want the Katyushas to stop," one American official said, expressing hope that a cease-fire -- "for a long-term period, not a week or 10 days" -- could be established within 48 hours. **********The official American position is that the current violence is a direct result of Hezbollah's firing rockets into Israel. But as the Israeli military response continued, Mr. Christopher decided to try to stop the violence. **********"His engagement was spurred by the continuing violence, as the rocket attacks continued and Israel responded in a very muscular fashion, and the whole situation became more tenuous and dangerous," an American official said. **********Mr. Christopher is to attend a meeting of foreign ministers of 29 countries and organizations in Luxembourg on April 22, designed to be a follow-up to the antiterrorism commitments made in Sharm el-Sheik, Egypt, on March 13, a summit meeting called to help Israel overcome the suicide bombings. **********The Syrians and the Lebanese, who refused to go there, have been invited to Luxembourg. American officials hope that if a cease-fire can be arranged in southern Lebanon with Syrian help, Damascus may be willing to send Mr. Sharaa to Luxembourg. Lebanon, a client state of Syria, would follow suit. **********Any agreement ending Katyusha rocket attacks on northern Israel is bound to bolster Mr. Peres's chances in the Israeli elections on May 29. After the suicide bombings that took 63 lives in late February and early March, his ratings took a steep dive because of the popular impression that he was dovish on security. A successful Lebanon operation, commentators agreed, would go a long way to reverse that image. **********But prolonged negotiations, or failure to secure a halt to the rocketing of northern Israel, could turn against Mr. Peres by raising questions about the wisdom and execution of an operation that has attracted considerable censure around the world for using attacks against civilian areas. **********The secretary general of Amnesty International, Pierre Sane, issued a statement asserting that the Israeli declaration of areas of Lebanon as a free-fire zone was "tantamount to a death threat against almost half a million civilians." He continued, "In what is becoming a major humanitarian crisis, innocent people are being punished in a massive reprisal for attacks on Israeli  civilians by Hezbollah." **********Even as the diplomatic contacts gained momentum, the pounding of Lebanon continued unabated. **********Israeli planes struck a power station five miles northeast of Beirut, further reducing electricity to the capital after a strike on a transformer station on Sunday. The Israeli command said the strikes were in retaliation for Katyusha rockets that cut electricity in the northern Israeli city of Qiryat Shemona. **********Once again, Israeli helicopters flew in from the Mediterranean Sea to fire missiles into southern suburbs where Hezbollah has its strongholds. The Israelis said their target was the offices of Hezbollah's consultative council. **********[Three Israeli helicopter gunships rocketed Lebanon's largest Palestinian refugee camp on Tuesday, The Associated Press reported. Lebanese police officials said six rockets were fired into the Ein el-Hilweh camp on the outskirts of Sidon before dawn, hitting the house of a dissident Palestinian guerrilla leader, Col. Munir Makdah, who survived the attack unscathed. Two bodyguards and one of their wives were wounded, the police said. **********[Israeli aircraft and artillery struck elsewhere in southern Lebanon at daybreak on Tuesday, hitting suspected guerrilla bases of Hezbollah after they fired more rockets into northern Israel.] **********The Lebanese Army fired antiaircraft guns at the Israeli planes, but none of  the aircraft were reported hit, and the Israelis did not strike back at the Lebanese. **********Israel also warned another seven villages in southern Lebanon that it intended to shell them, adding more civilians to the stream of people fleeing north. About 100 towns and villages have now been vacated after Israeli warnings, and their residents, said to number more than 400,000 now, are becoming a major problem both for the Lebanese Government and for Syria, which has considerable control over Lebanon by virtue of its 35,000 troops stationed there. **********Israeli planes and artillery continued to hit targets across southern Lebanon, including four strikes near the port city of Tyre and barrages on the town of Nabatiye, northeast of Tyre. **********According to Lebanese tallies, the death toll in Lebanon has remained under 30, and no Israelis have been killed. **********On its side, Hezbollah maintained a steady barrage of Katyusha rockets into northern Israel, though no serious injuries were reported. Though Israeli commanders have asserted over the last two days that the fire was becoming more  sporadic and less accurate, they also acknowledged that their shelling of suspected guerrilla bases was not likely to stop the Katyushas. **********There was no indication that Israel intended to order an infantry sweep outside its security zone. **********Leaders of Hezbollah continued to issue threats of reprisals, including suicide bombings against Israeli and Jewish targets around the world. **********Despite Israeli attacks and pressures in the past, Syria and its Lebanese allies have rejected demands to crack down on Hezbollah, arguing that as a Lebanese militia it has the right to fight against Israeli occupation. **********Seeking support for his country in Paris, Prime Minister Hariri of Lebanon reiterated his argument that, "If there were no occupation, there would be no reason for Hezbollah to exist." **********He also rejected Israeli demands that Lebanon disarm the guerrillas. "Israel  knows very well that this is impossible," he said. The Israelis, he added, "are  occupying part of our country." **********"What they want us to do is make the occupation easy," he said. "We cannot do this."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/07/news/.main_headline: AMERICAN TOPICS : British Stewardess Saves Fishermen From Aloft
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/07/news/.print_headline: AMERICAN TOPICS : British Stewardess Saves Fishermen From Aloft
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/07/news/.body_text: **********A British Airways stewardess who spotted black smoke in the Atlantic Ocean helped save three American fishermen whose boat was burning. **********"It was literally luck," Joanne Savage said on returning to London. "I'm thrilled to bits that all the fishermen are all right." **********Miss Savage, 31, said the Boeing 747 was flying over the Atlantic Thursday at 34,000 feet (10,000 meters), en route to New York from London, when she looked out the window. **********"There was a moment when the clouds parted and I saw black smoke on the water," she said. "Twenty seconds later there was a complete cover of cloud again, so I wouldn't have seen it." **********Cabin crew are trained to report anything unusual, and Miss Savage told the head steward, Terry Mills, about the smoke. **********He alerted the captain, Dave Cobley, who switched to the aircraft's emergency channel and picked up a signal from an automatic SOS beacon. He then contacted American authorities. **********A helicopter that was filming whales in the in the area, about 100 miles (160 kilometers) northeast of Cape Cod, rescued the fishermen from a life raft and flew them to safety in Boston.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/02/busin.body_text: **********The Toyota Motor Corporation will centralize supervision of its North American manufacturing operations at a new site in northern Kentucky, company and state officials said today. **********The Kentucky Economic Development Finance Authority approved an incentive package that could be worth up to $13.3 million in tax credits for the company in the coming decade. **********A Toyota spokeswoman, Frances Champion, said Toyota would centralize supervision of purchasing, engineering and administration in northern Kentucky.  She said sales, marketing and research would remain separate. **********Reports here estimate that 500 or more employees will eventually work at the  headquarters, which will be in the northern Kentucky suburbs of Cincinnati. An exact site has not yet been chosen. **********Toyota makes passenger cars in Georgetown, Ky., and Cambridge, Ontario. It has a joint venture auto plant in Fremont, Calif., with General Motors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/07/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;IP TIMBERLANDS IN $905 MILLION DEAL WITH R-H TIMBER
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/07/busin.body_text: **********IP Timberlands Ltd. said yesterday that one of its subsidiaries had agreed to sell a general partnership interest to the R-H Timber Company for $905 million.  IP Timberlands, a subsidiary of the International Paper Company, owns 300,000 acres of forest lands in Oregon and Washington. R-H Timber is a new company formed by the Roseburg Forest Products Company and the Hampton Company. Roseburg dropped out of negotiations to buy three wood-product factories and 600,000 acres of Oregon timberlands from the Weyerhaeuser Company last month. International Paper said it would record a gain of about $335 million, or $1.25  a share, on the sale.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/05/world.print_headline: Israel Air Force Not for Her
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/05/world.body_text: **********An Israeli woman who won the right to become an air force pilot in a landmark court case has failed qualification exams for flight training, a military spokesman said today. **********The Supreme Court ruled in November that the woman, Alice Miller, a 23-year-old aeronautical engineer, could take the exams, lifting a ban that on women as air force pilots. But she failed the medical tests after getting high grades on the aptitude test.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/11/busin.body_text: **********Linda Wachner, the top executive of the Warnaco Group, the apparel maker, was paid about $10 million last year in cash and stock. And she was given stock options that could be worth an additional $10.3 million, assuming the stock appreciates 5 percent annually over the next nine years, the company said yesterday. **********Warnaco, which is based in New York, said it had paid Ms. Wachner a salary of $2.4 million, a bonus of $1.3 million, other annual compensation of $361,805, a  restricted stock award the company valued at $6 million and on top of that, options to buy one million shares of Warnaco stock. **********Ms. Wachner's compensation at Warnaco is not the only pay she received. As chairman and chief executive of Authentic Fitness, she earned a salary of $975,000 in the fiscal year ended July 1, 1995, and was granted options to buy 250,000 shares of Authentic Fitness stock, with a potential realizable value of  $6 million assuming 10 percent annual appreciation for the option term. **********Under her employment agreement with Warnaco, Ms. Wachner is permitted to spend "reasonable" time managing the business of Authentic Fitness, which until  1990 was Warnaco's active-wear division.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/28/busin.snippet: Edward Rothstein column on importance of metaphors developing around the Internet, as discussed in book Internet Dreams: Archetypes, Myths, and Metaphors by Mark Stefik; Stefik is principal scientist at Xerox reserch center that 20 years ago creat...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/28/busin.main_headline: The Internet needs technological innovation and social transformation.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/28/busin.print_headline: The Internet needs technological innovation and social transformation.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/28/busin.body_text: **********''WHEN I get starry-eyed,'' one scientist recently wrote, ''I think of the Web as an information analog of the medieval cathedrals -- something the whole culture contributes to and participates in.'' **********But Mark Stefik, author of a book to be published next week, ''Internet Dreams: Archetypes, Myths, and Metaphors'' (M.I.T. Press), warns that getting starry-eyed about the Net can be a problem. It creates metaphors -- like the medieval cathedral -- which are not just innocent flights of fancy. In any new technology, he suggests, our conception of an invention shapes the way it evolves and the way it is used. And the Internet now is in just such an infancy, awaiting the imprinting of our metaphors and archetypes. **********This is a fascinating assertion about a technology that sometimes risks getting the sort of effusive acclaim once reserved for life-saving medicine. Mr. Stefik prescribes caution and analysis, but the enthusiasm and optimism poke through as he comments on a series of papers about Internet metaphors, arguing that if the Net ever becomes as profound as he thinks it will, part of the reason will be that we are using the right metaphors to describe it. **********Mr. Stefik knows whereof he speaks. He is a principal scientist at the Xerox Palo Alto Research Center, the same organization that, nearly 20 years ago, created the metaphor of windows for organizing data on a computer screen -- an idea that didn't catch on until the Macintosh was introduced and now, through its marketing, seems self-evident. **********As an example of a limiting metaphor, Mr. Stefik discusses the most popular: the Information Superhighway. The image suggests that like the national highway system, the Internet will allow fast, fluent transport of information, increasing prosperity and commerce. But it is deceptive, for the Internet is not centralized, its pathways are not fixed, and the image does not begin to suggest its potential impact. As Mr. Stefik points out, no one would think of describing the effects of the telephone system on business and private life by referring to a voice superhighway. **********Instead, Mr. Stefik suggests four interrelated and familiar, but resonant, images to describe the possibilities of the Internet: the library, the mail system, the marketplace and the idea of alternative worlds. These are so important, he argues, partly because they invoke primal personality archetypes described by the psychoanalyst Carl Jung: the digital library awakes the Keeper of Knowledge within us; E-mail appeals to the Communicator archetype; the marketplace invokes the Trader or Trickster, and playing with virtual reality attracts the Adventurer. **********This is getting as fanciful as the medieval cathedral metaphor, but luckily, archetypes are superfluous to the argument. They really become themes, as Mr. Stefik reprints essays that illumine their possibilities and ambiguities. Can digital libraries be free and survive? What sort of copyright protection and royalty system will protect digital books? Will the electronic marketplace of the future, with its break-down of geographic and logistical boundaries, change corporate culture? How does the Net change social interaction? **********The past is not irrelevant to the metaphors guiding these questions. The book includes an essay written in 1945 for the Atlantic Monthly by Vannevar Bush, who was director of the Federal Office of Scientific Research and Development. It is reprinted on the Web (www.isg.sfu.ca/duchier/misc/vbush/). **********Mr. Bush suggested that one of the big problems in ordinary libraries was that the indexing system was marred by ''artificiality.'' Libraries made it difficult to follow an ''associative trail,'' in which one piece of information raised questions that led to a search for another. **********He believed that a desk sized device he called a memex might be developed -- a personal library of microfilm equipped with a screen and a keyboard. Each bit of stored information would be instantly accessible and would contain references to other sources. He suggested there would be ''new forms of encyclopedias'' with ''a mesh of associative trails running through them.'' **********This was an extraordinarily prescient imagining of a (nondigital) PC and the possibilities of hypertext. But this vision was not a matter of random fantasy. The shaping of the future came about through finding a resonant image in the present: the memex was a researcher's dream, an icon for a Keeper of Knowledge. **********So, Mr. Stefik would suggest, the technology did not create the dream; the dream of what research could be helped prepare the way for a successful technology. The repeated message is that technology does not drive society on its own; it is not a force independent from our expectations or the context we create for it. **********In a very suggestive historical essay, for example, Scott D.N. Cook, a philosopher and researcher at Xerox Palo Alto Research Center, argues that we have completely misunderstood this idea, even when thinking about the impact of moveable type. The Gutenberg Bible did not create a revolutionary change; the new technology did not have a rapid and far-reaching effect on literacy and social institutions. In fact, Mr. Cook, argues, the famous Bible took years of hand work to produce; paper was extraordinarily expensive, and illiteracy in the year 1500 ran at about 90 percent. It did not reach 50 percent until the turn of the last century. **********Moveable type did not by itself create a revolution; it took later inventions along with the transformation of society to allow the technological revolution to take place. Something similar, Mr. Stefik argues, must happen with the Internet. The pace of the transformation is much faster than it was in Gutenberg's day, but still much must take place before the technology has a significant impact. Trade on the Net is still crude; access still awkward; influence, outside the media, relatively negligible. The evolution of the Internet will require not just technological innovation but also social transformation. And, who knows, by then archetypes might be as irrelevant for the Net as they are for the telephone.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/13/busin.main_headline: Cox Cable Systems to Carry NBC-Microsoft Channel
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/13/busin.print_headline: Cox Cable Systems to Carry NBC-Microsoft Channel
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/13/busin.body_text: **********NBC said yesterday that Cox Communications Inc.'s cable television systems, with nearly 3.3 million subscribers, would carry MSNBC, the new all-news cable channel being started by NBC and the Microsoft Corporation. **********About 1.7 million Cox subscribers will receive MSNBC when it starts up July 15, bringing the total initial subscriber base for the new channel to approximately 22 million. That would be one of the best start-ups for any recent cable channel. The remaining Cox subscribers would be added by the end of 1997. **********David Zaslav, the president of cable distribution for NBC, a unit of the General Electric Company, said the deal would likely encourage other cable operators to sign with MSNBC. "I expect to be announcing several other deals in  the next weeks and months," he said. **********The financial terms of the deal with Cox, a unit of Cox Enterprises Inc., were not disclosed. **********The deal is significant because Cox, the nation's fourth-largest cable operator, specifically wanted MSNBC. Other cable operators are taking the channel because of existing agreements to carry America's Talking, NBC's all-talk cable channel that is being converted into MSNBC next month. **********In addition, Cox executives had no reservations about the conversion of the channel's format. Because of the change, some other cable operators have questioned whether they would add MSNBC. **********In recent weeks, some large cable operators, including Continental Cablevision and Comcast, have opposed the switch by NBC of its cable channel to  an all-news format, saying the move violates existing contracts. **********But Ajit M. Dalvi, the senior vice president of marketing and programming for Cox Communications, said he did not understand that opposition. **********"MSNBC is a big step up from America's Talking, which had a format that wasn't working," he said. "If I can get it for the same license fee, why shouldn't I?" **********Mr. Dalvi said he was impressed that the new channel would offer on-line linkups being devised by Microsoft. More importantly, he said, he welcomed MSNBC because -- unlike its rival, the Turner Broadcasting System's Cable News Network -- the new channel would feature well-known news personalities. **********"CNN is a channel driven by its format, not by its personalities," he said. "That's the exact opposite of the network-news philosophy." NBC has said it plans to include its news personalities, such as Tom Brokaw, Katie Couric and Bryant Gumble, in MSNBC programming; this week it said that Jane Pauley would also have a regular show on the channel. **********Mr. Dalvi did not have nearly as encouraging a forecast for another competing all-news cable competitor being planned by Fox Inc., the television arm of the News Corporation. **********"If what I read is true and Mr. Murdoch is offering to pay $10 per subscriber in exchange for a 20-cent license fee, that is not too compelling an offer," Mr. Dalvi said, referring to Rupert Murdoch, the News Corporation chairman. **********"This is about providing a quality service. Nobody knows what Fox News is going to be. It has no news service, no staff, no studio, and no organization. I'm not doing my customers any service by putting that $10 in my pocket."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/16/world.main_headline: Yeltsin, Seeking a Second Term, Points to Communism as the Foe
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/16/world.print_headline: Yeltsin, Seeking a Second Term, Points to Communism as the Foe
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/16/world.body_text: **********Casting himself as Russia's best hope for protecting democracy and market reforms from a lurch back to the past, President Boris N. Yeltsin announced today that he would seek a second term in the presidential election in June. **********His declaration amounted to the formal opening of a campaign that, according  to every measure of public opinion, could well bring back to power the Communists Mr. Yeltsin ousted five years ago. **********His voice croaking with hoarseness after a rash of campaign appearances in his hometown of Yekaterinburg, Mr. Yeltsin -- himself once a member of the Communist Politburo -- told supporters that he alone could head off a Communist  victory and continue Russia's political and economic reforms. **********He also promised a solution within months to the hugely unpopular war in Chechnya, without suggesting what it might be. **********Even as Mr. Yeltsin spoke, the Communists were lampooning him as a weak rival and celebrating the nomination of their standard bearer, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, at their party congress in Moscow. **********Presenting a gentler version of Communism that has left the West wondering if he is really a Social Democrat or a true believer, Mr. Zyuganov spoke vaguely of limiting privatization of the economy and restoring Russia as a great power. **********Other Communist speakers, however, made no secret of their hostility toward the West. **********The dual announcements today marked the start of what promises to be a bitterly fought, raucous campaign over the future of economic and political reforms. **********The growing field also includes Grigory A. Yavlinsky, an economic reformer, and Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, a strident nationalist. Other possible candidates include Aleksandr I. Lebed, a retired general, and possibly Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the former Soviet President, whose popularity in Russia is minuscule. **********To qualify, each candidate must collect at least one million signatures before April 14. The election itself is expected to be a two-phase process, with a run-off in late June between the two top contenders. **********Securing a place in the run-off would be no mean accomplishment for Mr. Yeltsin, whose poll ratings are dismally low. Many reformers, in fact, were hoping that he would retire, opening the way for a potentially more electable candidate, such as Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin. But in recent weeks that has seemed highly unlikely. **********Yegor T. Gaidar, the economic reformer and leader of Russia's Choice, predicted today that Mr. Yeltsin's candidacy would benefit the Communists, who came in first in parliamentary elections in December with 22 percent of the vote. **********But Andrei V. Kozyrev, the pro-Western former Foreign Minister, said Mr. Yeltsin could win re-election by strongly backing reforms and, thus, underscoring his differences with the Communists. **********Mr. Yeltsin "has an opportunity before him to defend the reform cause and not to yield any further to anti-reformist pressure," Mr. Kozyrev said in an interview. **********In recent weeks, however, Mr. Yeltsin has delivered a mixed message, praising reform while replacing his Government's leading free-market advocate, Anatoly B. Chubais. **********"I am for reforms, but not at any price," Mr. Yeltsin said today. "I am for correcting the course, not for backtracking on it." **********And tonight, the President showed his sensitivity to unflattering news coverage by dismissing the head of Russian State Television, Oleg Poptsov, because the station's coverage of Chechnya was too negative. Its coverage of Chechnya has drawn fire from hard-line advisers to Mr. Yeltsin. **********The city of Yekaterinburg, where the 65-year-old Mr. Yeltsin was born and served as a Communist Party boss in the 1970's and 1980's, was selected to get his re-election effort off to an auspicious start. **********Sergei A. Filatov, Mr. Yeltsin's former chief of staff who is now involved in Mr. Yeltsin's campaign, told Russian television tonight the voters would decide  the election on three main issues: delayed wages and pensions, corruption and the war in Chechnya. **********Not surprisingly, Mr. Yeltsin today addressed all three: He vowed to end delays in wage payments. He cited efforts to fight corruption. He promised a fast end to the Chechen war. **********"Elsewhere in the world such conflicts sometimes take decades to resolve," he said. "We are obliged to untangle the Chechen knot much more quickly -- within months." **********But Mr. Yeltsin also ruled out an immediate troop withdrawal. And his recent  statements that Dzhokhar Dudayev, the rebel Chechen leader, should be executed,  do not suggest a quick political solution. **********Beyond that, Mr. Yeltsin tried to assure voters that the most painful part of Russia's journey to a capitalist economy was behind them. And he warned that the Communists could reverse hard-won gains and restore totalitarian controls, a development he warned could lead to "possible upheavals, including a civil war." **********"Today political freedoms are taken for granted," Mr. Yeltsin warned. "But how tenuous is the line that separates us from the suffocating yesterday." **********At today's Communist meeting, the 51-year old Mr. Zyuganov read his speech to 208 delegates at a lectern bearing his party's symbol, a hammer and sickle over  an open book. He spoke in a stentorian voice but with little emotion, and received tepid applause from the party faithful. **********He complained that privatization had gone too far. He urged a strengthened union of Russian and former Soviet republics -- a popular theme among the delegates. Reflecting nostalgia for the old Soviet Union, a Ukrainian delegate gave Mr. Zyuganov a piece of Crimean earth. Mr. Zyuganov also promised to protect Russia against the insiduous influence of foreign television. **********"People in Russia only have three rights," Mr. Zyuganov complained. "The right to steal. The right to get drunk. And the right to have no responsiblity for anything." **********Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, a Prime Minister under Mikhail Gorbachev and a supporter  of Mr. Zyuganov, said it would be a mistake to count Mr. Yeltsin out because he  has the authority of the presidency at his disposal and knows how to use it. **********"He is definitely not the same Yeltsin I used to know," Mr. Ryzhkov said, alluding to the President's declining health and low standing in the polls. "But he still has power."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/28/world.main_headline: Libyan Troops Clash With Foes After Jailbreak
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/28/world.print_headline: Libyan Troops Clash With Foes After Jailbreak
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/28/world.body_text: **********Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has sent troops to northeastern Libya, apparently to  stamp out unrest, diplomats and opposition groups said today. **********The clashes began last week after a prison break near the port of Benghazi. As many as 400 prisoners, many of them Government opponents and Islamic militants, escaped into nearby mountains and valleys, opposition groups said. **********Fighting reportedly broke out between security forces and the fugitives, prompting the Government to start a sweeping crackdown in the region, an opposition stronghold. Neither diplomats nor opposition figures could provide details on the number of wounded or arrested. Previous reports said 16 guards died in the prison break. **********Similar clashes erupted in June and September between armed militants fighting to impose Islamic law and the police in Benghazi and other towns in eastern Libya, according to diplomats and witnesses. The death toll was put as high as 110, and hundreds were said to have been arrested. **********The unrest this month did not appear to pose a threat to Colonel Qaddafi, who has held power for 27 years by keeping firm control of the army, intelligence services and police. **********But Libya sent a statement to Egypt's state-run news agency on Wednesday denouncing reports of a rebellion in the northeast as "lies and ill-intended rumors." **********The statement from Libya's official news agency said the police had broken up "a large drug trafficking network," killing several smugglers, and confiscating  weapons, hashish and heroin. **********Diplomats in Tripoli said army troops and security forces had sealed off the  coastal towns of Derna and Al Bayda, both east of Benghazi. Travelers arriving in Egypt reported that water supplies and electricity had been cut in Derna. **********The latest trouble appeared to be a sign of significant anti-Government sentiment in eastern Libya.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/12/world.snippet: Interview with Maria Rosa Henson, Filipino who has accepted Japanese reparation payment and apology for being forced to serve in brothel by Japanese forces in Pacific during World War II; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/12/world.main_headline: Inside a Wartime Brothel: The Avenger's Story
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/12/world.print_headline: Inside a Wartime Brothel: The Avenger's Story
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/12/world.body_text: **********Years later, asleep in the arms of her husband, Maria Rosa Henson would sometimes cry out the name of the Japanese Army officer who had imprisoned her in a brothel in the Philippines for nine months in World War II. **********''Who is this Tanaka?'' her husband would ask, waking her, but Mrs. Henson said she never told him, afraid that if he knew of the abuse she had suffered he would reject her. **********There was another, perhaps even sadder, reason for her reticence: She was grateful to Captain Tanaka. **********''He was good to me,'' Mrs. Henson said in an interview, recalling the occasional cups of tea and kind looks he offered her during the months he forced her, at the age of 15, to provide sex to 10 or 20 or 30 Japanese soldiers a day. **********''I was always asking him, 'Let me go, Tanaka,' but he answered: 'I cannot do that. It is against my Emperor,' '' Mrs. Henson said, without bitterness. ''I realized that the vow of Tanaka to his Emperor was very great, greater than my plea.'' **********Still grateful for small favors, Mrs. Henson, now 68, recently became the first woman in the region to accept a Japanese reparation payment for her suffering in the brothels. The payments have been rejected as inadequate by all but half a dozen of the 500 surviving victims, widely known as ''comfort women,'' who have come forward in the Philippines, South Korea and Taiwan. **********After receiving her payment of about $19,000 and a letter of apology from Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan in August, Mrs. Henson said, she wrote to the Prime Minister to thank him. **********Most of the other women, now in their 60's and 70's, have joined in rejecting the payments because they come from a private fund organized by the Japanese Government rather than from the Government itself. **********Until recently, the Government had denied any involvement in the wartime brothels, which historians say victimized as many as 200,000 women and teen-age girls throughout Asia. Its offer of payments now from what it calls the Asian Women's Fund is in part an effort to avoid opening the door to hundreds of lawsuits from survivors of various wartime atrocities. **********''The victims oppose the private fund principally because it cannot be a substitute for official legal compensation,'' said Nelia Sancho, a spokeswoman for a Philippine support group for the women. **********Demonstrating in front of the Japanese Embassy in August, one of the victims, Gertrudes Balisalisa, said she was rejecting both the payment and Prime Minister Hashimoto's expression of ''most sincere apologies and remorse.'' **********''I would be a hypocrite if I said I didn't need the money, but I need my dignity and honor more,'' Mrs. Balisalisa said. ''I want the money to come from the Japanese Government.'' **********Mrs. Henson said she accepted the money, quite simply, because she needs it. She needs medical care and she wants to provide for her three children and their families after working for most of her life in a tobacco factory. **********And in any case, she said, ''I cannot restore any more my dignity for what happened 50 years ago.'' **********''No amount of money -- even a mountain of money -- can repay the horror of the war.'' **********Mrs. Henson may feel gratitude for small kindnesses, but she has kept her anger alive. Rather than trying to forget her trauma, she said, she has clung to her sanity over the years by remembering everything. **********And she has found a powerful way to avenge her humiliation: she is telling her story. **********After revealing her long-held secret in 1992, as the first of the women  to speak out in public, Mrs. Henson sat down to write about her experiences. The result is a short, blunt book published here and in Japan this year, titled ''Comfort Woman: Slave of Destiny'' (Philippine Center for Investigative Journalism). **********''I am telling my story so that they will feel humiliated,'' Mrs. Henson said. ''It is true: I am an avenger of the dead.'' **********Every day from 2 P.M. until 10 P.M., she recalls in the book, she and five other women in the brothel were forced to have sex with scores of soldiers who lined up noisily outside their small, curtained rooms. **********The women were given four days of rest each month during menstruation, except for Mrs. Henson, who had not yet begun to have her period. **********''We began the day with breakfast, after which we swept and cleaned our rooms,'' she wrote. ''Then we went to the bathroom downstairs to wash the only dress we had and to bathe. The bathroom did not even have a door, so the soldiers watched us. We were all naked, and they laughed at us.'' **********And she wrote: ''When the soldiers raped me, I felt like a pig. Sometimes they tied up my right leg with a waistband or belt and hung it to a nail on the wall as they violated me. I was angry all the time.'' **********Even the Japanese Army doctor who checked the women for venereal disease raped her, she wrote. Even when she was shaking with the fever and chills of malaria she was raped. **********Sometimes Captain Tanaka, who had also raped her, seemed to feel compassion for her, stroking her hair and kissing her cheek. **********''He would hold my face and look straight into my eyes,'' she wrote. ''Sometimes I pitied him.'' **********In January 1944 the camp where she was being held came under attack by Philippine guerrillas and Mrs. Henson and the other women were rescued. **********For months afterward, she wrote, she was so severely traumatized that her mother thought she had gone mad. **********Overcome with shame and guilt, she wrote, ''I kept muttering to myself: 'Why did I not escape? Because they might kill me.' '' **********During this period, she overheard a Philippine doctor saying she might never be able to function or to recover her memory. **********''I told myself, no, I cannot lose my sanity; I will fight,'' Mrs. Henson said in the interview. ''I tried to work my mind all the time, night and day. I did not let my brain stop thinking. Always thinking and thinking. I learned to remember everything, to remember always, so that I will not go mad.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/30/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Kirin Brewery Posts 11% Drop in Profit
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/30/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Kirin Brewery Posts 11% Drop in Profit
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/30/busin.body_text: **********The Kirin Brewery Company, the biggest brewer in Japan, said yesterday that its pretax profit for the first half of the year fell 11.5 percent, to 27.5 billion yen ($254.9 million). Sales declined two-tenths of 1 percent, to 612 billion yen ($5.67 billion). Revenue from beer was not sufficient to offset rising promotional expenses, falling prices for Kirin's line of drugs and meager returns on financial investments because of Japan's record low interest rates, the company said. **********While Kirin still boasts the biggest share of Japan's beer market, its position is slipping. Last year, Kirin's market share dropped below the 50 percent level, to 49.3 percent, from a peak of 64 percent in 1976.   (Bloomberg  Business News)

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/26/world.snippet: News analysis of Pres Jacques Chirac's six-day trip through Mideast in quest of greater role for Europe, specifically France, in US-dominated peace efforts; Chirac's goal is to win back leverage that France used to have among Arab countries (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/26/world.body_text: **********Pressing for a greater role for Europe in the American-dominated Middle East peace negotiations, President Jacques Chirac of France showed during a six-day trip through the region this week that Europe might not be ready to be a player, but that France was -- as an outspoken advocate of Arab causes. **********Mr. Chirac, whose deficit-cutting economic policies have made him deeply unpopular at home, flew back to France today to both criticism and praise. **********Some of the accolades were almost as warm as those he got earlier in the week after calling on Israelis to recognize the Palestinians' right to a nation-state of their own and facing down zealous Israeli security guards during his visit to East Jerusalem. **********It was a performance that some saw as worthy of de Gaulle, whose mantle had been looking uncomfortably loose and large on Mr. Chirac's shoulders since his election as President in May 1995. **********''Jacques Chirac, in the purest Gaullist tradition, has said no,'' Sami Nair, a professor of political science at the University of Paris, said in Le Monde today. ''He has underlined that Europe must refuse the rule of imperial law in the region that enables the American-Israeli axis to impose just about anything it wants on impotent Arab states.'' **********Winning back the leverage that France used to have among the Arab countries of the Middle East but lost to the United States over the years has been a prime goal of Mr. Chirac's since he took office, and there seemed little doubt that he had made progress on that goal this week. **********Whether his foreign policy play can help him win back lost popularity at home is another question. Only 32 percent of French voters view him favorably now, according to a poll published in the weekly Le Point taken just before his trip. **********By appealing to Arab and Muslim moderation in the Middle East, Mr. Chirac may also have been trying to head off frustration among the millions of Muslim immigrants living in France, frustration that French officials fear could lead to the spread of terrorism here. **********There is nothing they fear more.  Bombs believed to have been planted by terrorists from Algeria killed several people in Paris and wounded hundreds in several cities around France last year, until the police gunned down the ringleaders. **********So some diplomats who know him well believe that Mr. Chirac was also trying on this trip to support people he sees as bulwarks against fundamentalism -- not only Yasir Arafat,  but also King Hussein of Jordan and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt. **********And maybe also President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, whom Mr. Chirac, then the Prime Minister, welcomed to Paris in 1975 as ''my personal friend.'' Mr. Chirac's conservative Government, and subsequent Socialist ones, sold enough arms to Baghdad to make France its biggest foreign creditor. **********In 1981 Israeli planes bombed a French-supplied nuclear reactor that the Iraqis were apparently planning to use to make atomic bombs, and in 1991 France sided with the United States and its allies in the Persian Gulf war to get Iraq out of Kuwait. **********But Mr. Chirac did not support the American missile strikes on Iraq early last month, and in Jordan on Thursday he appealed to the United Nations to lift a ban on limited oil sales to let Iraq to pay for food and medicine for its suffering population. **********The United Nations was about to let Iraq sell $2 billion worth of oil for this purpose in September, but held up the sale after Iraq moved forces into Iraqi Kurdish territory and set off the American military reaction. It is probably not coincidental that two French oil companies, Elf and Total, are expected to be the main foreign conduits for the Iraqi oil. **********Like de Gaulle, Mr. Chirac also has ambitions to lead Europe to a greater world role, and he consulted his European Union partners before undertaking this trip. But it was not ''Europe'' trying to get its foot in the negotiating door in Israel and Syria so much as France, which has found little support outside the Arab world in calling for a European negotiator to help the United States put some steam back into the peace effort. **********''The conditions aren't there yet,'' Sir Leon Brittan, vice president of the European Union's executive Commission, said on Thursday of the prospects for a more visible European role. ''If we manage to work together and we abstain from any independent actions, then we will have the ability to work with the United States in this region.'' **********Though French officials insisted that Mr. Chirac's suggestions were aimed at complementing American  policy in the Middle East, not competing with it, American officials accepted that claim with increasingly tight smiles. **********''I salute the U.S. role, but I see the peace process running short of breath because of the loss of trust,'' Mr. Chirac said. ''I see the European and French role in building more trust.'' **********He was careful to stress that he saw Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel as a ''friend.'' But his trip did little to cement French-Israeli friendship, always tenuous, and it might also do more harm than good to the improvement in French relations with the United States that he achieved in his first year in office.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/10/world.snippet: Chinese authorities sentence without trial pro-democracy activist, Liu Xiaobo, to three years in labor camp after he called on Communist Party to honor promises to allow freedom of speech and assembly and right to form political parties (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/10/world.main_headline: Champion of Democracy in China Draws 3-Year Sentence
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/10/world.print_headline: Champion of Democracy in China Draws 3-Year Sentence
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/10/world.body_text: **********The authorities sentenced without trial a pro-democracy activist, Liu Xiaobo, to three years in a labor camp today after he called on the Communist Party to honor promises to allow freedom of speech and assembly and the right to form political parties. **********Mr. Liu's wife, Liu Xia, reported her husband's arrest after the couple's Beijing apartment was searched on Tuesday and Mr. Liu was led away by Public Security policemen. She told Reuters that she was notified of the sentencing early today. ''I feel he hasn't done anything,'' she told the news agency.  ''Citizens have freedom of speech to write articles and say things.'' **********Mr. Liu and another dissident, Wang Xizhe of Guangzhou, drafted a protest letter last month that carried harsh criticism of President Jiang Zemin, including an assertion that he should be impeached for asserting that China's military forces are under the authority of the Communist Party, as opposed to the state. **********Wang Xizhe, also a veteran democracy campaigner, could not be located today and it was feared that he too had been sent to a labor camp. **********Western human rights organizations voiced new concerns this week over the fate of Wang Dan, the former student leader of the Tiananmen Square pro-democracy demonstrations in 1989. Mr. Wang has been detained without charge since May 1995, and reports began to circulate here this week that he would soon be  sentenced to a new prison term. **********''These reports, if true, would be one more demonstration of China's conviction that it has nothing to fear from locking up its critics,'' said Sidney Jones, the executive director of Human Rights Watch, based in New York. **********Mr. Wang served four years in prison and was released in 1993 in a gesture to the Bush Administration, which was applying trade pressure against China to force the release of political prisoners taken during the Tiananmen uprising. **********This strategy is gradually being abandoned by the Clinton Administration. Many rights activists believe that is leading to a new era of repression, even as many Chinese say they have more liberties than at any time in this century to pursue economic prosperity. **********In recent weeks, the family of China's best-known political prisoner, Wei Jingsheng, has expressed concern about his prison treatment. Wei Shanshan, Mr. Wei's sister, who lives in Hamburg, Germany, has told  rights organizations that Mr. Wei, who is suffering from heart trouble,  is in a cell where the lights are on 24 hours a day with six inmates whose role seems to be to taunt Mr. Wei. **********''I believe the Chinese are very good at slow torture to break somebody down in a way that eventually makes a person either useless or kills them,'' Robert L. Bernstein, chairman of Human Rights Watch, said in a statement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/24/busin.main_headline: SPENDING IT;The Price of Your Nonrefundable Ticket Just Fell? Don't Despair.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/24/busin.print_headline: SPENDING IT;The Price of Your Nonrefundable Ticket Just Fell? Don't Despair.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/24/busin.body_text: **********ON a harsh winter morning when your car was covered in snow and the local weatherman predicted six more inches the next day, you booked a spring trip to Florida. Giving two months' notice, you figured the advance airfare was a good deal and paid for a nonrefundable airline ticket. **********Now, just two weeks before departure, newspaper ads suggest that a ticket on  the same flight is available for $75 less. It just doesn't seem fair. **********We advise people to purchase tickets as soon as possible when they know they are going to be traveling," said Steve Loucks, a spokesman for the American Society of Travel Agents, because of the discounts awarded for advance purchases. "But you may see your fare drop after you buy your ticket. So you're  damned if you do and damned if you don't." **********Maybe not. Although some tickets cannot be refunded or exchanged, a nonrefundable ticket, the type most often sold by airlines, can be exchanged for travel at a later date, a credit voucher or a ticket at a lower fare. **********"I think people are surprised to find out that they can get a refund or exchange on a nonrefundable ticket," said Lee Gemlich, a reservations analyst at Northwest Airlines. Nonrefundable simply means you cannot get your money back if you decide not to travel. **********At Northwest, travelers can choose to take a credit that can be applied to the purchase of another ticket. There is no charge for that service. **********They can also exchange the ticket and pocket the savings. The big hitch is that the savings must be substantial to make this effort worthwhile, since Nothwest charges a $50 administrative fee for any change on a nonrefundable ticket. **********Many airlines do not permit credits and charge $50 for any exchange, meaning  the fare has to be much lower to bother. Todd Clay, a spokesman for Delta Air Lines, said, "There are time and resources utilized in changing the ticket, so we have to charge for it." **********Another way for fliers to fight back is to buy the price-guarantee programs that some travel agencies have begun to offer. All About Travel, in Kansas City, Mo., added the Worry Free Price Guarantee about a year ago, and said that almost all its clients now used the service. After a ticket is bought, the agency's computer continues to search for a better fare until the day of the flight. The  guarantee costs $10 a person or $20 a family, and if the fare drops, the customer receives a refund of the difference, minus any airline administrative fee. **********"We feel that this is a much better gamble for the customer," said Kathy Sudeikis, a vice president at All About Travel, which has annual revenue of $25 million. "If a crazy fare war breaks out, we will get you on the flight with the lower fare." **********Some tickets cannot be exchanged or applied to future travel. These tickets do not have a specific name, but are often issued in conjunction with special sales. They usually must be bought at the time of booking. **********With any advertised sale, travelers need to act quickly if they want to buy a new ticket or exchange an old one, because few discount seats may be available on the flights desired. And with oil prices rising in the last couple of weeks,  airlines are expected to limit their discounted seats while their profits are under pressure.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/19/busin.snippet: Price wars, currency devaluations and an enduring recession drove profit down 45 percent at PSA Peugeot Citroën SA last year, Europe's third-largest carmaker reported Thursday.. France's largest automaker said net profit dropped to 1.7 billion fra...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/19/busin.main_headline: Peugeot Feels Pinch Of Strong Franc: Earnings Fall 45%
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/19/busin.print_headline: Peugeot Feels Pinch Of Strong Franc: Earnings Fall 45%
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/19/busin.body_text: **********Price wars, currency devaluations and an enduring recession drove profit down 45 percent at PSA Peugeot Citroën SA last year, Europe's third-largest carmaker reported Thursday. **********France's largest automaker said net profit dropped to 1.7 billion francs ($331.8 million) in 1995 from 3.1 billion francs in 1994. Its operating margin shrank to 2.3 percent of sales from 4.4 percent, while debt jumped nearly 30 percent. **********The company said it would cut its dividend to 5 francs a share from 6 francs, and Peugeot's shares fell 14 francs, or 1.9 percent, to 731. **********"The drop in earnings wasn't a surprise, but the cut in dividend was a message to the market that 1996 won't be great," Gerard Ewenczyk, an analyst at SAFE, a Paris brokerage concern, told Bloomberg Business News. **********Peugeot's chairman, Jacques Calvet, described the results as "disappointing, given expectations and the effort made by the staff." **********Peugeot, which also makes Citroën vehicles and does most of its business in Europe, with 37.5 percent of it in France, had a declining share of a European market that itself showed sluggish growth over the past year. **********In the year ended in March, new-car registrations in Europe grew 3.1 percent, but Peugeot's market share in Europe dropped to 12 percent from 12.8 percent. **********Mr. Calvet said part of the problem was the French franc's strength against other European currencies, as "competitive devaluations" by other governments eroded the carmaker's earnings. **********Peugeot's consolidated sales were fairly stable, at 164.2 billion francs, compared with 166.2 billion francs in 1994, but its operating profit was cut nearly in half, to 3.75 billion francs from 7.29 billion francs, partly because of the strength of the franc. As a case in point, he said Italy's currency lost 6 percent of its value in 1995, making it possible for French shoppers to buy a Peugeot in Italy for far less than its French price. **********While Peugeot raised prices an average of 4.1 percent in France in 1995, the company said, it had to reduce prices in Italy, Spain and Britain to compete with carmakers in those countries benefiting from the weakness of their currencies. Currency fluctuations alone, Mr. Calvet said, cost Peugeot 1.3 billion francs in 1995. **********The carmaker's results also suffered from strikes that crippled transportation in France in November and December, paralyzing its distribution of new automobiles to dealers and keeping nervous consumers from investing in expensive items such as cars. **********Mr. Calvet predicted only tepid growth for 1996. **********In Europe, he said the company was counting on no more than 3 percent growth in car sales. He said Peugeot would try to offset Europe's sluggishness by expanding operations in South America and Central Europe and was continuing to study the North American market. Peugeot, he said, hoped to get 25 percent of its sales from outside Europe by 2000, compared with 12.2 percent now. **********James Rosenstein, a spokesman for the European Automobile Manufacturers Association, said European carmakers, including Peugeot, were making the best of a bad situation. **********"Europe is a mature market," he said. "Most purchases are renewal purchases, the population is getting older, and there are fewer new car buyers. At the same time, unemployment is higher, and real income levels are lower." **********The European car market collapsed, he said, after South Korean and Japanese imports arrived en masse in 1993, causing prices to fall as much as 16 percent.
