The Swissair Associated Companies, a hotel and catering unit of the Swiss airline, then offered L160 million ($247 million) for Allders International through the investment banker SBC Warburg. **********Allders, which also owns department stores, confirmed that "such an offer has been received." It said a further announcement would be made "as soon as possible."   (Bloomberg Business News)

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/22/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Japan to Conduct Study of Trade Practices in Film Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/22/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Japan to Conduct Study of Trade Practices in Film Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/22/busin.body_text: **********Japan's Fair Trade Commission said today that it would conduct a survey of the Japanese photographic film and paper market. **********The commission, which made the announcement just two days before Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto visits the United States, said it would conduct the study because of the "considerable interest" generated by the trade dispute between the Eastman Kodak Company and the Fuji Photo Film Company over each other's business practices. **********The commission also recognized in a statement the "oligopolistic structures" and "long-term business relationships" of the film and photo paper market in Japan. **********Mr. Hashimoto is to meet with President Clinton on Friday in California, but  the commission said the unexpected announcement had nothing to do with that visit, or with an investigation by the Office of the United States Trade Representative. **********Kodak filed a complaint with the trade representative's office in July, contending that Fuji was blocking access to the Japanese film and photo paper market through anticompetitive practices. Fuji has denied the complaint. **********[George M. C. Fisher, the chairman of Kodak, criticized the commission's decision on Wednesday, calling it a denial by the Japanese Government that its film markets are closed. Reuters reported that in a speech in Arizona, Mr. Fisher urged the United States Government to take action against Japan for the nation's refusal to negotiate an end to the dispute. **********["The Japanese Government is testing the resolve of the U.S. Government to deal effectively with market access issues," Mr. Fisher said.] **********Under United States trade law, the Government has one year, or until July 3,  1996, to decide whether to impose sanctions on Japan. **********Fuji has about a 70 percent share of the Japanese film market and Kodak has about 10 percent. In the United States, those shares are reversed. **********Mr. Fisher said the company had not directly approached the Japanese trade commission because it believed foreign companies had little standing in front of the organization. **********Mr. Fisher said he felt it was better to have the two Governments resolve the issue, partly because Kodak had accused the Japanese Government of helping Fuji  to create an exclusive distribution system that would keep Kodak out of Japan. **********The Fair Trade Commission typically studies one to three industries a year. For the year that ends in March, the commission conducted studies of the housing and construction materials markets. **********The commission said the new study would begin in April and end by March 1997. **********Fuji said in a statement that it would cooperate with the commission and that it was confident that the study would "prove that the film and paper markets in  Japan are completely open to free and fair competition." **********Fuji said it was also important to investigate business practices in the American and European markets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/03/world.main_headline: World News Briefs;Fireworks Explosion Kills 36 in China
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/03/world.print_headline: World News Briefs;Fireworks Explosion Kills 36 in China
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/03/world.body_text: **********An explosion at a firecracker factory in southwestern China has killed at least 36 workers and passers-by, local officials and state news media said today. **********The explosion, which happened Saturday, also injured 52 people, including three who were in critical condition with serious burns, an official said by telephone. **********Authorities had shut down the plant in April for safety reasons, but it had  reopened without authorization June 23, said an official of the nearby town of Hefang. **********The factory was in the village of Piya in Sichuan province. **********The death toll was unclear because some workers at the privately run factory  were from elsewhere in China with no relatives nearby to report them missing, a  police officer said. **********Fireworks, considered by many Chinese an essential part of traditional celebrations, are said to kill or injure 60,000 people a year, with many of the  casualties caused by accidents during production or transport.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/31/world.snippet: Russsia, without clear explanation to US, reportedly backs away from signing agreement on non-strategic missile defenses allowed under 1972 Antiballistic Misile Treaty (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/31/world.main_headline: Russia Will Put Off Signing Agreement on Missile Systems
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/31/world.print_headline: Russia Will Put Off Signing Agreement on Missile Systems
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/31/world.body_text: **********Without a clear explanation to the United States, Russia has backed away from signing an agreement on non-strategic missile defenses allowed under the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, senior Administration officials said today. **********In New York last month, Foreign Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov of Russia and Secretary of State Warren Christopher announced agreement on lower-velocity anti-missile systems, with negotiations to open on higher-velocity systems that the United States is developing. **********But on Friday, senior American officials said, Russian officials informed the Americans that Moscow now wanted to make the agreement on lower-velocity systems dependent on the conclusion of an agreement covering higher-velocity systems. The first part was to be signed in Geneva this week, but that signing will not go ahead, the officials said. **********The new Russian hesitation was first reported in The Washington Times today. Administration officials said today that they were puzzled by the late change in a position that Presidents Clinton and Boris N. Yeltsin had agreed to last April, at their Moscow meeting, and that was confirmed on Sept. 23 by Mr. Primakov to Mr. Christopher. Mr. Christopher then called the agreement ''a milestone'' in relations. **********''This is of course a disappointment and a glitch, and we're working the problem,'' one American official said. But he said American work on non-strategic missile defense systems would continue, including work on the only higher-speed American system, known as the Navy Upper Tier Area Defense System. **********All six American and NATO systems, including the Upper Tier, comply with the ABM treaty in the American view, the officials said, and Congress has been notified of that view. ''In the absence of an agreement that clarifies the line between antiballistic missile defenses and these theater missile defenses, it remains each country's responsibility to decide what complies, and we've decided that Upper Tier complies,'' the official said. **********The Administration has rejected Republican criticism that it is slowing or halting theater-missile development because of the ABM treaty and Russian complaints. **********The five lower-velocity systems include two that are already deployed, most famously the Patriot system used in the Persian Gulf war. Updated systems are nearly ready for deployment, while development work continues on the others, as it does on the Upper Tier system. **********The Americans argue that while the Upper Tier missile has enough velocity to knock out a strategic missile, it is based on fast warships that cannot house a radar big enough to track strategic missiles. **********Another Administration official said he assumed the Russians had decided that it was not in their interest to show partial progress with Washington now, and that it would not hurt them to wait until an agreement could be reached on higher-velocity systems. **********The negotiations have been going on for some three years. On Tuesday, in a speech in New York, Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott warned the Russians not to ''overindulge their misplaced suspicions that we want to keep them down,'' suggesting that partnership and cooperation could become synonyms in the domestic Russian debate for ''appeasement, subservience and humiliation at the hands of the West.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/30/busin.main_headline: CURRENCY MARKETS;Absence of Buying by Japan Weakens Dollar Against Yen
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/30/busin.print_headline: CURRENCY MARKETS;Absence of Buying by Japan Weakens Dollar Against Yen
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/30/busin.body_text: **********The dollar fell against the yen yesterday, hurt by speculation that the Bank  of Japan might soon raise interest rates. **********The dollar was also weakened as currency traders took advantage of a national holiday in Japan to sell dollars, believing the Bank of Japan would not intervene to support the dollar against the yen. While Japanese markets were closed yesterday for the holiday, Greenery Day, the Bank of Japan might have left orders with other central banks to buy dollars for yen on its behalf. But such orders did not materialize in the market. **********On Friday, the Japanese central bank bought an estimated $200 million to $500 million for yen, traders said. **********"By its absence, the Bank of Japan created a very negative sentiment for the  dollar," said Thomas Lapinski, chief dealer at MTB Bank. **********The dollar has been weak against the yen since Friday, when a Japanese newspaper reported that the central bank would soon push interest rates up. **********Although the report was denied by Bank of Japan officials, the yen rally has  not lost any steam. Higher rates would bolster the value of the yen by making deposits denominated in the Japanese currency more attractive. **********In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 104.67 yen, down from 105.55 yen on Friday. The dollar fell to 1.5265 marks from 1.5284 marks. The British pound fell to $1.5069 from $1.5130. **********Despite two days of declines, many currency traders and analysts remained bullish on the dollar. **********"We would not regard this as any change in direction for the dollar," said John de Beer, who oversees $2 billion in foreign bonds at Loomis, Sayles & Company in Boston. "We still think the general trend for the dollar is up." **********While Japan's bond yields and money-market rates have risen as the economy emerges from a four-year economic slowdown, it may be too early to bet on an increase in rates by the Bank of Japan, traders said. **********The country's banking system remains under pressure from an estimated $400 billion of bad loans, and several false starts by the economy in the last three  years should make the central bank cautious about raising rates, traders said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/26/world.main_headline: 3 More Prisoners Die in Turkish Hunger Strike
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/26/world.print_headline: 3 More Prisoners Die in Turkish Hunger Strike
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/26/world.body_text: **********Three more prisoners died today in a nationwide hunger strike by nearly 2,000 inmates in Turkey's jails, bringing the death toll to six. **********The inmates, who say they are protesting beatings, inadequate medical care and forced transfers to remote places, have seized control of three large prisons. More than 50 prisoners were in critical condition in some 33 jails around the nation. **********Nearly 2,000 people gathered today in front of Istanbul's main courthouse to protest the deaths. But Turkey's new Islamic-oriented Government said it would not make any concessions to end the 67-day strike or force the strikers to eat or drink. **********"We will show them the state's authority by doing whatever is necessary at the right time," Justice Minister Sevket Kazan said today as he returned to Istanbul. **********Earlier, he said it was "inevitable that further unfortunate incidents will occur" if authorities try to take prisoners to the hospital by force. **********Prisoners armed with metal sticks cut from bed frames remained in control of  wards in the Bayrampasa and Umraniye prisons in Istanbul and the Buca prison in  Izmir, the Government said. The prisons hold about 1,600 inmates. **********"If the soldiers try to go in, the resistance will be tough and bloody," a former Bayrampasa inmate, Aynur Cihan, said. **********The protests are being organized from Bayrampasa in Istanbul, where prisoners have smuggled in cellular telephones and fax machines, Mr. Kazan said. **********The prisoners who died today were identified as Ali Ayata, 31, in Bursa; Huseyin Demircioglu, 36, in Ankara; and Mujdat Yanat, 37, in Aydin. All three had been convicted of membership in an outlawed leftist group. The first three deaths occurred in Istanbul prisons. **********Inmates, most of them accused or convicted members of the outlawed Revolutionary People's Salvation Party-Front, have refused solid food. About 275 of them are refusing even sugared water, and 56 reportedly are in critical condition. **********"The strikers were so weak and close to death, I felt I was in a ghost town," said Ali Dizdar, a lawyer for the prisoners. He said several had lost consciousness or their eyesight, or were vomiting blood. **********Other inmates are refusing to allow authorities to treat the starving prisoners, the Government said. **********Wednesday night, gunmen killed a police officer in Gebze, a small town 15 miles east of Istanbul. Suspicion fell on left-wing groups who have carried out  similar attacks. **********In the eastern city of Erzurum, two inmates tried to burn themselves to death to protest the Government's stance, Turkish news reports said. **********The hunger strike began after the previous Government ordered large-scale transfers of prisoners to remote parts of the country and canceled visiting rights for political prisoners. **********The new Islamic-led Government that came to power last month has eased some of the restrictions, including scaling back the transfers and allowing visitation rights. But Mr. Kazan, the Justice Minister, said the prisons are too crowded and that some transfers are still necessary.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/16/busin.snippet: Fusion Systems Corp agrees to sell its ultraviolet curing systems unit to Fairey Group PLC for $126 million in cash (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/16/busin.main_headline: FUSION TO SELL ULTRAVIOLET BUSINESS TO FAIREY GROUP
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/16/busin.print_headline: FUSION TO SELL ULTRAVIOLET BUSINESS TO FAIREY GROUP
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/16/busin.body_text: **********Hoping to burnish its image with investors by concentrating on semiconductor-making tools, the Fusion Systems Corporation agreed yesterday to sell an unrelated business to the Fairey Group P.L.C. of Britain for $126 million in cash. Fairey, a maker of electronic and other equipment, would buy Fusion's ultraviolet curing systems unit. The unit's technology is used to dry photosensitive coatings and adhesives. Fusion said the division, which had sales of $51.1 million last year, had been undervalued by investors. Shares of Fusion, based in Rockville, Md., rose 37.5 cents yesterday, to $19.625.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/24/busin.body_text: **********The Nynex Corporation reported yesterday that its profit jumped 19 percent in the fourth quarter because of an increased number of customers and more telephone calls. **********The regional Bell company, based in New York, made $235.6 million, or 55 cents a share. In the fourth quarter of 1994, Nynex had a profit of $198.3 million, or 47 cents a share. **********Revenue was $3.304 billion, down from $3.391 billion a year ago, chiefly because Nynex's cellular operation, which was combined last year with Bell Atlantic's operation, was not included in the recent quarter. **********The results included adjustments for changes in accounting practices, a continued pension offer and charges related to combining the cellular operations. **********Without the adjustments, Nynex would have made $387.7 million, or 88 cents a  share, compared with $339.1 million, or 80 cents a share, a year earlier before  pension-related charges. **********The results were slightly higher than Wall Street analysts' expectations. **********Call volume rose 10.4 percent, with nearly 60 percent of the gain in residential service from existing customers who wanted second lines. **********For the year, Nynex lost $1.85 billion, or $4.34 a share, compared with a 1994 full-year profit of $792.6 million, or $1.89 a share. Revenue for the year  was $13.4 billion, up from $13.3 billion in 1994.   (AP)

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/18/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Jackson Says He'll Expand Boycott Against Mitsubishi
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/18/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Jackson Says He'll Expand Boycott Against Mitsubishi
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/18/busin.body_text: **********The Rev. Jesse Jackson vowed today to step up a boycott against the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation and to extend it eventually to other Japanese car  companies if they do not expand opportunities for members of minorities to become executives and to own dealerships in the United States. **********"We're going to expand the boycott," Mr. Jackson said outside Mitsubishi headquarters here, after emerging from a 90-minute meeting with company executives that he labeled "not very productive." He said he would call on black Americans and other members of minorities to go "car line by car line and challenge the automotive industry." **********Mitsubishi is already the target of a boycott by Mr. Jackson's National Rainbow Coalition, the National Organization for Women and other groups because  of a lawsuit filed earlier this year by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission that contends there has been widespread sexual harassment at the company's factory in Normal, Ill. **********Mitsubishi announced on Tuesday in Chicago its first set of steps for improving the treatment of women at the Normal factory and for expanding opportunities for minorities. **********Mr. Jackson said the Chicago announcement was a "pre-emptive strike" made before his visit and that members of minorities were not involved enough in drawing up the plan, which lacked "goals, targets and timetables." **********Mitsubishi denied that the announcement was timed to the visit. **********The issues being raised by Mr. Jackson are longstanding ones. It is generally acknowledged that Japanese companies offer fewer opportunities for promotion to  foreigners than American and European companies do. There have been numerous race and sex discrimination suits brought against Japanese companies by American employees. **********Only 22 of the 505 Mitsubishi dealerships in the United States, 4.3 percent,  are owned by members of minorities, including three owned by blacks, according to company figures. Mr. Jackson said, minority members make up about 22 percent  of the buyers of Mitsubishi's cars. "We cannot be loyal consumers and second-class employees," he said. **********Mitsubishi's figures on minority dealerships, however, appear to be higher than those for other Japanese companies and even some American ones. **********Mr. Jackson said that the Honda Motor Company, which showed "gross insensitivity" about the issue of minority dealers, would be the next boycott target.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/20/world.snippet: Thailand's opposition attacks Prime Min Banharn Silpaarcha in marathon no-confidence session intended to oust him after just 14 months in power; Thais have been riding high on export-led economic boom for more than decade, and have overlooked corr...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/20/world.main_headline: A Chorus of Critics in Thailand Is Trying to Oust Premier
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/20/world.print_headline: A Chorus of Critics in Thailand Is Trying to Oust Premier
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/20/world.body_text: **********''I used to strut the streets in foreign countries, so proud to be Thai,'' said Chatichai Choonhavan, a former Prime Minister who is now an opposition member of Parliament. ''Now I hate to tell people where I'm from.'' **********Hyperbole, invective and expressions of angst are thick in the air this week as Thailand's opposition attacks Prime Minister Banharn Silpa-archa in a marathon no-confidence session intended to oust him after just 14 months in power. **********This is a time of discontent for Thailand, which has been riding high on an export-led economic boom for more than a decade. Corruption, military coups, urban chaos and growing social inequities have been overlooked as living standards soared and shopping malls, factories and luxury cars proliferated. **********But a series of economic setbacks this year have shaken the nation's confidence and prompted calls for political change. **********Export growth has tumbled from about 24 percent last year to 3.8 percent. The overall economic growth rate has slipped from 8.6 percent last year to a projected 7 percent in 1996. There is talk of devaluing the baht, the Thai currency.  Last week Moody's Investor Service, the American credit-rating agency, lowered the country's short-term credit standing, and the stock market plunged to its lowest point in three years. **********''Remember the days when our pockets were full?'' Mr. Chatichai said, warming to his hyperbole. ''Not money from within our country but from abroad. We used to go out and get rich with foreign money. Now look at the golf courses, the condos and housing estates that go dark at night because nobody lives there.'' **********The country's unhappiness has focused on its Prime Minister, an old-style rural politician known popularly as the Walking ATM for his generosity with constituents. He is seen by Bangkok's elite as a throwback to a deep-rooted tradition of the politics of greed. **********Not only opposition politicians but also a growing number of business executives, political commentators, economic analysts and public opinion polls are calling for his ouster. **********''Premier Has to Go if Thailand Is to Survive,'' read the headline on an editorial this week in the English-language daily The Nation. **********Mr. Banharn, 64, denies wrongdoing and has vowed to fight back, exclaiming recently to journalists, ''What have I done wrong?'' **********His tenuous six-party coalition, which holds 209 seats in the 391-seat legislature, has said it plans to hold together to defeat the no-confidence motion, though many of its members have joined the criticisms of him. **********Even if he survives the vote, expected on Saturday, some press reports suggest that his coalition partners will force him to step down. Mr. Banharn also has the option of dissolving Parliament and calling new elections, which would be held within three months. **********But he has stated his ambition to be the first Thai Prime Minister ever to serve out a full four-year term, uninterrupted by coups or the political collapse of a government. **********The three-day parliamentary session that began on Wednesday, in which two dozen legislators have lined up to castigate Mr. Banharn, is being watched avidly on live television. When Wednesday's broadcast was cut short for the evening news at 9 P.M., the Government station was deluged with protests, The Bangkok Post reported today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/10/world.main_headline: A Ghost of Maoist Fervor Lives On in Disgrace
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/10/world.print_headline: A Ghost of Maoist Fervor Lives On in Disgrace
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/10/world.body_text: **********For 10 years, Wang Li worked side by side with Mao and then became one of the most ardent firebrands of the early Cultural Revolution, helping to topple scores of Communist Party elders, some of whom survived to rule again. **********Now at age 75, he lives impoverished in a tiny apartment in western Beijing,  where he is ailing from stomach cancer. Since emerging in 1982 from prison, where he was held for 15 years, he has sent 104 petitions to the Chinese leadership seeking rehabilitation, but it has never come. **********In the minds of current party leaders, Mr. Wang, one of the last surviving leaders of the Cultural Revolution, personifies some of the most violent excesses of the onset of China's most tumultuous political upheaval since Mao's  Communists took power in Beijing in 1949. **********Though he regards himself as a scapegoat for much of the chaos that Mao loosed from 1966 to 1976, he continues to praise the party that has shunned him  for nearly 30 years. **********He also praises Mao, who he says was a misunderstood visionary who wanted China to grow closer to the United States and to learn from American successes in agriculture and industry. **********"I have no regrets about my actions," Mr. Wang said in the only interview with a foreign journalist he has given since his release from prison. "I made mistakes. It was all right to make mistakes in those times, as long as you corrected them. **********"But I became the scapegoat for the whole party. They said that I caused the  chaos throughout the country." **********Prison, he said, "was the most painful period for me." **********"I was not allowed to use pen and paper until 1980," he said. **********Like an old ghost from a bygone era, Mr. Wang seems weighted down by the chains he forged in life. The party has yet to forgive him, even though he asserts that luminaries like Deng Xiaoping, the country's paramount leader, and  Wang Guangmei, the widow of former President Liu Shaoqi, have had nothing but good things to say about him. Liu and Deng were purged as China's two leading "capitalist roaders" during the Cultural Revolution. **********But perhaps because Mr. Wang and his comrades incited so much violence by their calls to "bombard the headquarters" -- attack party leaders -- on Mao's behalf, some revolutionary elders who survived those years are unable to forget. **********"Wang Li is a classic scapegoat of the extremism of the early Cultural Revolution," said Geremie R. Barme, a China scholar at the Australian National University. "This is not to say that he was not a willing participant and an opportunist, but you have to remember that Wang Li and people like him were empowered by full sessions of the Central Committee of the Communist Party, including Deng Xiaoping and others. **********"We know that Wang Li was persecuted for crimes against numerous leaders, but we also know that lurking behind his excesses were instructions from Mao and Zhou Enlai, and these may surface if the party archives are ever opened." **********For now, the party leaders feel "there is no need to rehabilitate him," Mr. Barme said, adding that Mr. Wang "can safely be blamed" for the "war crimes" of  the Cultural Revolution. **********In 1966, as a propagandist drafted by Mao from the Communist Party's Red Flag magazine, Mr. Wang rose to become a member of the Leading Group of the Cultural  Revolution, a body at times more powerful than the party's Politburo. **********To be known as a leader of the May 16th Brigade, as Mr. Wang was, inspired fear and awe among the millions of Red Guards roaming the country. It was a time when all of China seemed riveted on the unfolding events of the Cultural Revolution. **********To Westerners, these episodes, if they were ever understood, have dimmed from memory, but for someone who was at the epicenter of history with Mao, they burn  as if they occurred yesterday. **********"I worked side by side with Mao Zedong for 10 years," from 1957 to 1967, "and Deng Xiaoping was there during that time, too," said Mr. Wang, as the wisps of his white hair caught the morning sunlight that splashed across his wooden desk  littered with writings, calligraphy brushes and his pain. **********"He was not a god," Mr. Wang said of Mao. "He was just an ordinary man and he made mistakes, and he had a bad temper sometimes." **********The chaos of the Cultural Revolution included riots and mass rallies at which leaders, university presidents, teachers and literary figures were hauled out for political "struggle" that often turned into beatings and torture. **********Countless thousands were killed or hounded into suicide, while museums, libraries and priceless cultural relics were sacked or destroyed. **********On Aug. 22, 1967, at the height of the violence, mobs of Red Guards set ablaze the British Chancery building in Beijing with gasoline bombs and then beat the fleeing diplomats. **********Some of China's most revered leaders, like President Liu and Marshal Chen Yi, then the Foreign Minister, were thrown into prisons where they languished without medical attention and later died. **********Mr. Wang, who delivered a fiery speech at the Foreign Ministry on Aug. 7, 1967, was blamed for inciting the violent takeover of the ministry building that month and the rampage of Red Guards through foreign embassy areas. **********Today, Mr. Wang denies taking part in any of the violence at the ministry, but he admits that his speech was "somewhat excessive at certain points," and thus may have incited the violence. He adds that Mao read his speech in advance. **********"I was one of the initiators of the so-called theory to 'continue the revolution under the proletarian dictatorship,' " Mr. Wang said. This call to unceasing class struggle was the call to anarchy that became the party's "basic  line," which Mao exploited to purge his rivals from the party. **********In that first year of the Cultural Revolution, from 1966 to 1967, Mr. Wang said, "I took part in almost all of the drafting of important decisions, circulars and commentaries from the party's Central Committee." **********"Most of them, in today's point of view, are wrong," he continued, "and although I did these things according to Mao Zedong's instructions, I, as a writer of these documents, had major responsibilities for the mistakes." **********Mr. Wang's meeting with a foreign reporter was arranged at the third-floor walk-up apartment that the Communist Party has assigned to him and his wife, Wang Bingquan. **********Seated in his unheated study, where he has written his memoirs, he seemed a pale reflection of the firebrand who in July 1967 stood atop the Gate of Heavenly Peace overlooking a rally of one million Red Guards in Tiananmen Square as he was declared the "hero" who had stood up for Mao during the bloody confrontation in the central city of Wuhan earlier that month. **********In Wuhan, competing revolutionary bands had declared war on each other, and hundreds died in the skirmishing. Mr. Wang himself was taken hostage by a band of 200 partisans armed with guns, knives and spears. **********"Both of my legs were broken," he says. Mao was forced to flee the city, and  Mr. Wang only escaped with the help of Zhou Enlai, the Prime Minister. **********Mr. Wang sighed and chuckled as he remembered that "triumphant" return to Beijing. Mao's wife, Jiang Qing -- the top leader of the Cultural Revolution after Mao himself -- escorted him to the parapet of power overlooking Tiananmen  Square. **********"She told me, 'This whole show is not for you.' " In fact, Mr. Wang said, she added: "I don't care if you had been beaten to death in Wuhan. This show is for  Mao, for his reputation." **********Raising his delicate hands from the arms of his chair, Mr. Wang said, "That was when I was raised up to heaven, and it was not long before I was plunged into hell." **********Referring to his arrest and imprisonment a month later for the excesses at the Foreign Ministry and the attack on the British Embassy, he said, "I realized then that I would have a short political life and, as the brightest star of China, I would soon disappear." **********Never charged with specific crimes, the imprisoned Mr. Wang took a sizable share of the blame for inciting much of the violence of 1967. **********If Mr. Wang wished he could rewrite any chapter in history, it would be the long estrangement between China and the United States. **********And the greatest lesson of the Cultural Revolution, he said, was the abuse of power. "There should be the means to control personal power," he said, "to prevent any individual from abusing power and from making great mistakes."
