Voice Control said the purchase price included four million of its shares, which fell 12.5 cents, to $10.125, in Nasdaq trading. Shareholders of Voice Processing, based in Cambridge, Mass., will own about 30 percent of the combined company's fully diluted shares after the transaction. Dallas-based Voice Control supplies speech-recognition and speaker-verification technology.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/09/world.main_headline: Whatever Happened to Venezuela's Middle Class?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/09/world.print_headline: Whatever Happened to Venezuela's Middle Class?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/09/world.body_text: **********The snapshot that emerged from Luis Sandoval's pocket showed the 34-year-old  former administrator for a manufacturer of heavy machinery standing in a driveway by his sparkling white Chevrolet Impala, his wife and daughter by his side. **********Now, years later, when Government exchange controls have crippled business and squeezed him out of his job, the family car has become another of Caracas's  rattle-trap taxis, and Mr. Sandoval's livelihood. The car's right headlight is gone, and the alignment is so bad the car seems to ski down the streets, trailing a spume of black smoke. **********There are two children now, who get by on the same amount of milk one used to drink, diluted to go twice as far. Last Christmas, Mr. Sandoval, a graduate of Venezuela's most prestigious university, could only afford to buy a single toy for the two of them. There is three months' rent due at the end of the week, and this one-time paragon of the prosperous middle class has become desperate. **********"We're living hand to mouth," Mr. Sandoval said. **********At a time when the rest of South America is paring down public spending and opening up markets in the quest for foreign investment, Venezuela stands as a peculiarly enduring throwback to an age of excessive government economic intervention, and a reminder of its perils. **********This Caribbean country of 24 million people, blessed with the world's largest oil reserves outside the Persian Gulf, last year became the largest foreign supplier of oil to the United States. But its economy is in a shambles and its public payroll so bloated that hospitals cannot afford to buy medicine or equipment, while the Government remains unable -- or unwilling -- to trim its work force. **********The country is entering its fourth year of recession, and the inflation rate, at 54 percent last year, is the highest in South America. Venezuela's middle class, once accustomed to shopping sprees in Miami, has been reduced to near-poverty. **********"The middle class is disappearing," said Andres Serbin, president of the Venezuelan Institute for Social and Political Studies, a private research institute. "Now you have a clear polarization between the people who have and the people who don't have." **********Juan Carlos Navarro, coordinator of the Center for Public Policy at the Institute for Advanced Administrative Studies, agreed. "People feel that every day they're getting poorer, and they're right," he said. **********At the start of the 1990's, Venezuela appeared to be well on its way toward the free-market economic reforms that other parts of Latin America have since embraced. But austerity measures that were endured elsewhere in the continent proved too difficult an adjustment for Venezuelans who, thanks to a $10-billion-a-year cushion of oil revenues, had grown accustomed to government largess. **********The backlash against the free-market reforms instituted by Carlos Andres Perez, who was then President, included looting and two attempted military coups in 1992. Although the coups failed, they proved fatal to the economic policies and to the presidency of Mr. Perez, who was impeached in 1993 and charged with stealing $17 million in public funds. He remains under house arrest. **********As the country awaited Mr. Perez's reaction to the second 1992 coup attempt in a televised message from Congress, Rafael Caldera, a former president, unexpectedly took the microphone to voice understanding for the frustrations of  the military men who led the coup attempts. **********Swept back into the presidency by a mass yearning for less corrupt, more generous past, Mr. Caldera pledged to restore the kind of state-financed populism that had marked his administration in the 1970's, but he did not address the country's ability to finance such grand promises in the economy of the 1990's **********His measures have failed to check Venezuela's economic slide. **********According to a recent report by Data Information Resources to the Venezuelan-American Chamber of Commerce, in the last 25 years the share of household income spent on food has shot up to 72 percent, from 28 percent. The middle class has shrunk by a third. An estimated 53 percent of jobs are now classified as "informal" -- in the underground economy -- as compared with 33 percent in the late 1970's. **********Economists complain that the country has functioned under Mr. Caldera without a coherent and consistent economic program, relying instead on emergency measures. The latest is a plan to compensate working people for rising prices with a system of modified indexation, which will raise wages every few months to help keep up with inflation. In Brazil, this approach led from double- to triple-digit inflation before it was abandoned in 1994. **********The country is struggling back from a banking crisis that was five times the  size of the savings and loan collapse in the United States, in terms of the percentage of gross national product. No sooner had Venezuela won plaudits for coming through the banking debacle, however, than it had to confront a scandal involving the system of severance payments for public employees, in which billions of dollars contributed to the system have disappeared. **********That is one reason the Government has not concentrated on trimming the public sector, although Labor Minister Juan N. Carrido, and most analysts of Venezuela, agree the need is strong. **********"The question of where you're going to get the money for severance payments is relevant only if you do the layoffs," said Fernando Egana, the Government spokesman. "Reduction of the public sector," he added pointedly, "is very much related to the growth of the private sector." **********Although Mr. Caldera came into office denouncing the austerity measures that  were imposed by Mr. Perez (partly to conform with directives from the International Monetary Fund), his own administration has been negotiating for a  $3 billion loan from the I.M.F. since last year. Economists here say Venezuela does not need the money as much as it needs the credibility that such a loan would convey. The country has also been negotiating a second loan of undisclosed size to ease the social impact of any hardships imposed by an I.M.F. agreement. **********Politically, President Caldera's reputation for personal honesty has brought  the Government some measure of credibility, and pulling back from the austerity measures of his predecessor has helped build stability. A slew of state and local elected offices, created over the last half-dozen years, have also provided the country with a fresh crop of potential national leaders, like  the highly popular Irene Saez, a former Miss Universe recently re-elected mayor  of Chacao, a neighborhood in Caracas. **********Another promising sign was the opening last month of the oil sector to private investment -- by the same President who nationalized it 20 years earlier. Industry executives flocked to Caracas to bid on exploration rights in  10 regions, using a formula that guarantees Venezuela at least 85 percent of the profits. But Juan Szabo, who put together the opening, said it would probably be three to four years before the country sees any revenues from privatization. **********"I don't think Venezuela's problem is really one of income," said Mr. Szabo.  "It's getting the housekeeping done and getting the economic process in line." **********Paradoxically, some here feel the oil revenues will only delay the day of reckoning for President Caldera, putting off further the tough decisions he has  been avoiding. The trouble, they say, is that while oil revenues give the President a reprieve, the money is never used "to accumulate capital and develop social programs that are not politically motivated," said Mr. Serbin, of the Institute for Social and Political Studies. **********As Monsignor Baltazar Porros, vice president of Venezuela's Episcopal Confederation, prepares for the arrival of Pope John Paul II, he says the crisis Venezuelans are encountering is as much emotional and spiritual as economic. **********The 1950's to 1980's, he said, were marked by "a kind of looting of the oil wealth, so young people have never lived in hard times." The loss of prosperity  is more shattering than never having known it at all, he said. "Now, we see that our lives are the same as in any other country in Latin America."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/27/busin.body_text: **********The Quaker Oats Company will spend about $50 million to build a new beverage  plant and distribution center near Atlanta, the company said today. The Chicago-based food and beverage concern said the plant would produce Gatorade and Snapple teas and juice drinks and would employ about 150 people. The start of production is set for January 1997. The Atlanta plant will be the seventh company-owned beverage plant.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/15/busin.snippet: Richard Hyse letter on Alabama's lures to Mercedes; suggests it would have been more cost-efficient to just pay off welfare recipients, creating instant middle class
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/15/busin.main_headline: Can a State Go Too Far In Courting Business?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/15/busin.print_headline: Can a State Go Too Far In Courting Business?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/15/busin.body_text: **********''O Governor, Won't You Buy Me a Mercedes Plant?'' (Sept. 1), by Allen R. Myerson, examined the debate over how Alabama attracted the German auto maker and 1,500 new jobs at a cost approaching $300 million in tax breaks and other subsidies. The article drew these responses from readers: **********To the Editor: **********In these days of ending welfare as we know it, would it not have been more cost-efficient to pay $100,000 directly to each of 3,000 welfare recipients, thereby creating an instant substantial middle class with some spending and investment possibilities in Alabama, instead of routing these funds through a long chain of bureaucratic red tape to Mercedes-Benz at a cost of $200,000 each for only 1,500 recipients? **********RICHARD HYSE **********Oswego, N.Y., Sept. 2

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/06/busin.body_text: **********GREENWICH BUYING AVIALL'S ENGINE SERVICES UNIT Greenwich Air Services Inc. signed a letter of intent yesterday to purchase Aviall Inc.'s Commercial Engine Services division for an estimated price of $260 million to $280 million. Shares of both companies surged yesterday. The acquisition will make Greenwich the world's largest company in the business of engine repair, maintenance and overhaul. The purchase includes Aviall's operations in Dallas, Fort Worth and Prestwick, Scotland, as well as its components business in McAllen, Tex. Greenwich shares rose $5, or 22 percent, to close at $27.75 in Nasdaq trading; Aviall shares rose $1.25, or 23.3 percent, to close at $6.625 on the New York Stock Exchange. (Reuters) **********BRODERBUND PREDICTS EARNINGS BELOW EXPECTATIONS Shares of Broderbund Software Inc. fell sharply yesterday in after-hours trading after the company announced that earnings for the second quarter, which ends on  Feb. 29, would fall short of analysts' estimates. After rising $3, to $53.125, in regular Nasdaq trading, Broderbund shares fell to $49. Broderbund, based in Novato, Calif., said it expected revenues in the quarter of $44 million to $49 million, compared with $45.2 million in the corresponding period last year. (Reuters) **********TWO MORE EXECUTIVES DEPART LOTUS DEVELOPMENT Two executives announced their departures from the Lotus Development Corporation yesterday, joining the exodus of upper management since I.B.M. bought the company last summer. Jeffrey Beir, 38, senior vice president in charge of applications software for desktop computers, resigned to pursue an "entrepreneurial opportunity," according to a Lotus spokesman. Separately, Russell Campanello, 39, the head of human resources, announced his departure to  pursue other interests. Neither was available for comment. Mr. Beir will be succeeded by John Throckmorton, who is in charge of the development of desktop applications programs. A successor to Mr. Campanello has not been named. **********AT&T NAMES A UNIT IT PLANS TO SPIN OFF The AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it had given the name Lucent Technologies to the equipment business it plans to spin off this year. AT&T said it was registering with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of 15 percent of Lucent shares. It also named seven members to the new Lucent board. By the end of 1996, AT&T will divide into three companies: the AT&T Corporation, a telephone company; Lucent Technologies, and the NCR Corporation, a maker of large computers. Analysts said that Lucent would have the potential to be a big money maker, perhaps doubling its revenue within five  years. AT&T shareholders will receive one share of each of the new companies for each AT&T share. (Bloomberg Business News) **********HOSPITALITY PROPERTIES SIGNS DEALS FOR 45 HOTELS Hospitality Properties Trust, a real estate investment trust in Newton, Mass., said yesterday that it had signed letters of intent to acquire 45 hotels and to  lease them back to the sellers or to other parties. Hospitality will acquire 11  Wyndham Gardens hotels for $136 million from an affiliate of the Dallas-based Wyndham Hotel Company and will lease them to another Wyndham affiliate. In a second deal, Hospitality will buy 18 Residence Inn hotels from an affiliate of the Host Marriott Corporation for $172.2 million and will lease them to a Hospitality affiliate. Hospitality will also acquire 16 Courtyard by Marriott hotels for $176.4 million and will lease them to Host Marriott affiliates.   Hospitality will own 82 hotels in 26 states after the transactions close. (Reuters) **********JACOR COMMUNICATIONS TO BUY NOBLE BROADCAST GROUP Jacor Communications Inc., a radio and cable television holding company in Cincinnati, said yesterday that it would acquire Noble Broadcast Group Inc. from Conseco Inc. for about $152 million. The deal will make Jacor the nation's fifth-largest radio company. Jacor said it had received credit commitments of $300 million from a group of banks for the purchase and for future acquisitions. Noble's 12 radio stations serve Denver, St. Louis, San Diego and Toledo, Ohio. Conseco, a financial services holding company based in Carmel, Ind., acquired a  75 percent equity stake in San Diego-based Noble in August in return for providing it with $37 million of subordinated debt financing. (Reuters) **********HARTE-HANKS AND DIMARK IN DEAL WORTH $155 MILLION Harte-Hanks Communications Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Dimark Inc., a provider of marketing and data base services, for about $155 million in stock. Harte-Hanks, a direct marketing and media company in San Antonio, will exchange 0.656 share for each share of Dimark, which would value Dimark shares about $15 each. Shares of Dimark, which is based in Langhorne, Pa., fell 62.5 cents yesterday, to $14.125, on the American Stock Exchange; shares of   Harte-Hanks fell 37.5 cents, to $22.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. (Dow Jones) **********VARITY DROPS BID FOR REMAINING STAKE IN HAYES WHEELS The Varity Corporation said yesterday that it had withdrawn its offer for the remaining 54 percent stake in Hayes Wheels International Inc. Varity, an industrial company based in Buffalo, announced in September that it planned to buy the Hayes shares for $25 each, or about $236 million. Along with its 46 percent stake in Hayes, Varity owns Kelsey Hayes, a supplier of brake products,  and Dayton Walther, a maker of wheel and brake parts for heavy-duty trucks and trailers. Hayes, based in Romulus, Mich., makes aluminum and steel automotive wheels. Its shares fell $4.625, or 19 percent, to $19.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. (Dow Jones) **********MARVEL NAMES EXECUTIVE FOR NEW SOFTWARE DIVISION The Marvel Entertainment Group has chosen Scott Marden to be chief executive of  a new division, Marvel Software. Mr. Marden, 41, had been the president and chief executive of Philips Media, a unit of Philips Electronics. Mr. Marden said he hoped to propel Marvel into electronic publishing by developing on-line  services and Web sites. Marvel, which owns comic-book titles like Spider-Man and the X-Men, has been somewhat haphazard in licensing those characters to multimedia outlets, he said. "It has become increasingly clear that the future of the company was going to be tied to electronic delivery," Mr. Marden said. At Philips, Mr. Marden established a multimedia publishing division and oversaw the company's cable TV holdings. **********McDONALD'S DISCONTINUES ITS REDUCED-FAT BURGER The McDonald's Corporation will discontinue its reduced-fat hamburger, McLean Deluxe, after it did little to improve the company's bottom line. The company will also discontinue its chef's salad and side salads, said Malesia Webb-Dunn,  a McDonald's spokeswoman. McDonald's introduced McLean Deluxe about five years ago. It has 10 grams of fat compared with 21 grams of fat in a Quarter Pounder.  Sales of the reduced-fat hamburger did not justify keeping it on the menu, said  Mark Miller, an analyst at CS First Boston, especially as McDonald's opened smaller restaurants and satellite sites with limited menus. (Bloomberg Business News) **********FLEXTRONICS INTERNATIONAL LTD., San Jose, Calif., a maker of electronic components, purchased Astron Group Inc. for $35 million in cash, stock and promissory notes. **********TEXTRON INC., Providence, R.I., acquired Xact Products Inc. of Brooklyn, Mich.,  which makes fasteners, clips and other metal parts, primarily for the automobile industry, in a stock and cash transaction valued at $8 million to $10 million. **********MEDCATH INC., Charlotte, N.C., which provides cardiology and cardiovascular services to the medical industry, acquired Mid-Atlantic Medical Specialists Inc. of Galax, Va. Terms were not disclosed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/05/busin.main_headline: Bringing Up Baby With Its Parents On the Sideline
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/05/busin.print_headline: Bringing Up Baby With Its Parents On the Sideline
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/05/busin.body_text: **********IN the 1987 movie "Baby Boom," Diane Keaton played a big-city management consultant who moved to small-town Vermont, cooked up homemade baby food, then fended off corporate America's attempt to take over her thriving enterprise. **********In real life, things don't always work that way: Witness Ron and Arnie Koss,  45-year-old twin brothers who moved from New York State to Vermont and developed an organic baby food wholesome enough for their own children. Despite the upstart brand's growing sales, the brothers lost control of their baby to venture capitalists and a hotshot professional manager who they say didn't even  return their phone calls. **********Then, this March, H. J. Heinz, the Pittsburgh food-processing giant, bought  the company, Earth's Best, for about $30 million. While it promises to stick to  the founders' principle of purity, it made no written guarantees when the deal was done. What is more, Heinz is considering a move to capitalize on the Earth's Best reputation for quality by attaching its new company's name to everything from pacifiers to soups for grown-ups. And all this from a company whose main brand of baby food has been knocked by one influential consumer group as being "nutritionally inferior." **********The brothers wish they had been able to hold onto their company. Still, they  realize that Heinz can do big things for the brand name they nursed for so long. "My brother and I got into this because we wanted to see this food available to  children," Ron Koss said. **********The Kosses' inability to hold onto their company shows how easy it is for starry-eyed idealists to get waylaid by the earthy realities of American capitalism. All too frequently, beginning entrepreneurs learn an old truth the hard way: No matter how brilliant your concept, it probably won't succeed without marketing know-how and plenty of capital to get you through the bumpy ride of the early years. And the people with the money and the expertise they need -- venture capitalists and big corporations -- are forever on the prowl to  make cheap acquisitions of start-up companies with first-rate products and inexperienced managers. **********Ron and Arnie Koss certainly fit the mold of budding entrepreneurs with no money, a hot idea and only the vaguest notion of how to turn it into a marketable product. They got their brainstorm in the mid-1970's while working as clerks in natural-food stores in upstate New York. They noticed that in the cornucopia of health merchandise for adults there was nary a spoonful of organic anything for babies. **********It wasn't just that they had found an opening for a niche product that big companies had overlooked. Both men felt drawn to the all-natural precepts of the environmental movement. Ron Koss, a vegetarian, remembers reading Rachel Carson's book, "Silent Spring," which describes the dangers of pesticides to animals, and "imagining that children would be especially sensitive to pesticides, just as the eggs of bald eagles were." **********"I am an environmentalist," he added. "I started Earth's Best because I have  a connection to this planet, and I have a love of nature." **********Even so, years passed before the brothers acted on their inspiration. Ron took a job managing a Ronald McDonald house for seriously ill children and their parents in Burlington, Vt. Arnie, who was more entrepreneurial, started a tiny company in the same town that produced handmade brooms in the style of old-time  Shaker communities. **********In 1984, the time seemed right to revive their long-dormant dream. Ron Koss's first son, Gabriel, had been born the previous year, giving the twins their first taste-tester. And, unbelievable to them, a decade after they began to talk about it, nobody else had yet hit hard on the notion of selling organic food to  parents. **********First, they had to find some start-up capital. Arnie sold his business, but that wasn't nearly enough. They hit pay dirt with Ray Pecor, a local businessman who now owns the minor league Vermont Expos baseball team. Mr. Pecor took an immediate liking to Arnie and signed a bank loan for $25,000. "I was impressed with his enthusiasm and his work ethic," Mr. Pecor says of the curly haired man  who appeared in his office in blue jeans. "This was a love affair with a product for him, rather than a business venture." **********That initial cash infusion enabled the Kosses to do some nutritional and product research. But it wasn't enough to lease a factory, buy equipment, purchase organic fruits and vegetables and hire workers. So off they went, knocking on doors of banks and private investors. "We looked like a couple of curly haired flakes" and endured lots of rejections, Arnie Koss said. "But we didn't go away." **********They managed to raise $1.3 million, enough to get them started. In December 1987, in a small concrete building on Pond Lane in Middlebury, Vt., with a view  of the Green Mountains, they watched the first jars of Earth's Best bump off the production line. **********"They were filled with organic apple puree," Arnie Koss recalled proudly. **********That moment of glory was short-lived. Like millions of entrepreneurs before them, the Koss brothers soon discovered an unforgiving reality of the marketplace: making a great product is no guarantee that it sold at a profit. **********Within months, Earth's Best was out of money. The Kosses were forced to lay off the 60 workers they had just hired and began a desperate search for more financing. What went wrong? "Baby food is capital-intensive," Arnie Koss explained. Perishable ingredients like blueberries and plums must be bought a year in advance, when they are in season, then frozen. Competition for grocery shelf space is so fierce that some stores charge for it. "Large amounts of money disappear quickly," Mr. Koss said. **********The two partners finally raised an additional $300,000 but went through it quickly as they rehired laid-off workers, bought produce, built inventory and marketed their goods. But sales were zooming, from about $1.5 million in 1988 to about $3.5 million in 1989. **********Finally, in late 1989, they made the fateful decision to seek money from venture-capital firms. These firms specialize in buying equity interests in promising but troubled companies, turning them around and selling them at a big  profit. The brothers got a huge infusion of cash -- more than $6 million -- but  their success was bittersweet. The venture-capital industry is notorious for negotiating tough terms, and many entrepreneurs put off seeking their help as long as possible. But the Kosses were desperate, and in the end they made a huge sacrifice: to save Earth's Best, they gave up a controlling interest in it. **********"My No. 1 priority was to protect the company and the employees of the company and not my own position," Arnie Koss said. "Ron and I knew before we even raised a penny that we were getting into something that was so big that loss of control was a very high probability." **********The new majority stockholders included firms run by Gregory Peters, general partner of North Atlantic Venture Funds and the Venture Capital Fund, both of Burlington, and four other venture capital firms around the Northeast. And the Koss brothers were quick to realize that the price of their financial deliverance was more than just losing control. They were turning over a product  born of idealism to the number crunchers who viewed it as a commodity, not a way to help build a better world. **********"At some level they believed in the product in terms of its value to society," Arnie Koss said of his new partners. But, he added, "They were making  an investment because they thought there was a huge windfall to be made." **********Mr. Peters said the venture capitalists were attracted to Earth's Best in part because of its product. "We saw a company committed to providing high-quality, healthy foods to infants," he said. He declined to comment on whether the venture capitalists were too obsessed with the bottom line. **********One of the first things the new owners demanded was that Arnie Koss step down as president of the money-losing company. "It became a condition of the investment," Arnie Koss said. "They just decided they wanted their own guy there." Both brothers stayed on until mid-1990 as executive vice presidents, then left for good. **********"Those guys didn't have a clue who Ron and I were and what we were capable of," Arnie Koss said. "Ron and I weren't cut out of the M.B.A. mold." **********An entrepreneur's loss of control over the company he or she created is a common tale in American capitalism. Bob Iverson, the founder of Kiwi International Airlines, was ousted as chief executive last year. In 1993, Kendall Square Research, a Boston maker of supercomputers, dismissed its founder, Henry Burkhardt 3d, and in the previous year the Compaq Computer Corporation eased out its founder, Joseph R. Canion. **********Some of the departing founders go down fighting and remain bitter; others prefer dignified exits. Usually, though, the business world concludes that the entrepreneurs have outlived their usefulness. In this case, even the Kosses' original backer, Mr. Pecor, approved the venture capitalists' decision. Arnie Koss "didn't have the background to manage a millions-of-dollars-a-year business," he said. "The next step needed professional management." **********Earth's Best went through two professional managers in two years, the first replacing Arnie and the second coming on board a few months after Arnie left. But the company was still losing money. Then, in November 1991, it hired Jay G.  Shoemaker, who had left Whitman's Chocolates as president after its sales were disappointing and had worked as a manager at General Mills Inc. Mr. Shoemaker, who received an M.B.A. degree at Harvard, makes no pretense that organic baby food has a special place in his heart. For him, business is all about selling; what he sells is secondary. "I'm not really a product guy," he said. "I don't really come in and say, 'I really love this product so I'm going to buy the business.' It has more to do with strategic opportunity." **********ARNIE KOSS has a low opinion of businessmen with such theories. "They just had one thing on their mind, and that was how to make the most money in the shortest amount of time," he said. **********In the fiscal year of Mr. Shoemaker's arrival, Earth's Best had revenue of $8 million -- and losses of $7 million. Despite that huge deficit, there was a bright side: The company had survived four years in a competitive market that had mashed other organic baby foods made by later entries into the field. Mr. Shoemaker diagnosed Earth's Best's problem as poor management and figured he was just the man to turn it around. "Anytime you can see a business that is succeeding despite itself, then obviously you can come in there and clean up the problems," he said. "Then you're removing the impediments to real growth and to  real earnings." **********In January 1992, Mr. Shoemaker thought nothing of moving the company's headquarters from Middlebury, where it all started, to Boulder, Colo. In May, he shut down the Middlebury factory and laid off about 50 workers, farming out production to a California company. Then he turned to the investment arm of SunAmerica Inc., the large insurance and investment company based in Los Angeles, for a $5 million loan. **********The next year, SunAmerica invested another $1.8 million and eventually became the company's largest stockholder, followed by Orien Ventures, an Oregon venture capital firm. Together, they held majority control, with more than 200 other shareholders bringing up the rear. By then, the twins held only warrants to purchase stock that would in the end entitle them to only eight-tenths of 1 percent of the company they founded. **********Slowly but surely, Earth's Best pulled out of the doldrums. With so much money and management expertise behind it, it approached the black for the first  time in the 1995 fiscal year, earning $200,000 before interest payments on $23.8 million in sales. (It lost $800,000 after interest was deducted.) **********Enter H. J. Heinz. The $8 billion food behemoth had been eyeing Earth's Best  since 1988. In 1991, it toyed with the notion of making a bid to acquire it. But like many big corporations, it wanted to wait for the small company to prove it  was viable before striking. **********"The reason we walked away from it back then is because we thought it could be a fad," said Al Banisch, senior product manager for infant feeding at Heinz U.S.A. Also, Heinz wasn't sure that it should be moving into the organic-food business, which by definition requires a steady supply of organic produce. In its early years, Earth's Best was plagued with shortages that resulted in the sudden disappearance and then reappearance of varieties from store shelves -- a  forgivable lapse for a small company but not for a household name like Heinz. **********Still, with sales of organic foods growing more than 20 percent a year recently, other big companies had already embraced health food. In 1989, the J.  M. Smucker Company acquired Santa Cruz Natural (now Santa Cruz Organic), a maker of organic fruit juices. The next year, Welch Foods Inc. bought a controlling interest in Cascadian Farms, which produces organic foods in jars and frozen form. **********LAST year, Heinz had a change of heart. It began in July when a senior executive, Brian Ruder, was named president of Heinz U.S.A.'s retail division, with responsibilities for both baby food and ketchup. Mr. Ruder had seen organic baby food in Europe while serving as a vice president in charge of developing Heinz's worldwide baby-food business. And his own brother, who lived in Boston,  fed his infant son Earth's Best instead of Heinz. **********Within two weeks of his promotion, Mr. Ruder called Mr. Shoemaker. Less than  eight months later, the two had worked out a deal for the sale of the company for around $30 million. Earth's Best's board, controlled by venture capitalists, quickly approved the transaction. **********The Koss brothers, their stake now reduced to less than 1 percent, got less than $300,000. **********Arnie Koss doesn't try to hide his disappointment about the way the agreement was consummated. "Of course I would have preferred that Earth's Best had remained independent," he said. "My opinion was not sought. I did call Jay Shoemaker and he did not return my call." Mr. Shoemaker, who was chief executive of Earth's Best at the time, says he doesn't recall getting the call. **********Mr. Ruder, the Heinz executive now in charge of Earth's Best, is already thinking about ways to exploit its name. He says he hopes to expand the Earth's  Best line to everything from adult foods like soups and sauces to, perhaps, accessories like pacifiers and baby bottles -- all "made in an environmentally sensitive way." **********"The Earth's Best trademark has become a Good Housekeeping seal of approval for organics," he said enthusiastically. "We think there's very strong brand equity and it's extendable to other categories." **********But is there a danger that Heinz, in attaching the name to new products, will water down the brand's appeal? After all, one reason for the success of Earth's  Best was the homey image of two brothers stewing apples in Ron Koss's kitchen and taste-testing them on his six-month-old. The consuming public's perception of such dedication to quality contrasts sharply with its suspiciousness toward an industry with a checkered history of mass-producing baby food. **********In 1989, for example, back when Beech-Nut was owned by Nestle S.A., Niels L.  Hoyvald, Beech-Nut's former president, pleaded guilty to selling sugar water disguised as apple juice for babies. He was sentenced to six months of community service and five years' probation. Nestle sold the Beech-Nut brand to Ralston Purina in late 1989. More recently, Nestle pulled its Libby's Juicy Juice apple  juice out of warehouses because of concerns that what it thought was pure apple  concentrate imported from European suppliers was in fact spiked with high-fructose syrup. **********Heinz's record is free of such scandals. But when making its own baby food, Heinz does allow the traces of pesticides commonly found in nonorganic fruits and vegetables, as do the two other major brands, Gerber and Beech-Nut. (As the  companies point out, the levels of the chemicals that show up in the final product are far below those that the Food and Drug Administration deems unsafe.) **********Also, a 1995 report by the Center for Science in the Public Interest criticized both Heinz and Gerber for adding water and fillers to its little jars of fruits and vegetables. "Not only are those products a monetary rip-off, they  are also nutritionally inferior to similar products made without fillers," said  the report, "Cheating Babies, Nutritional Quality and Cost of Commercial Baby Food." **********"When I heard about their purchase of Earth's Best, I thought, 'Isn't it interesting: The company that makes the worst variety of baby food is buying the company that makes among the best baby foods," said Michael F. Jacobson, one of  the report's authors, referring to a banana-tapioca product. Heinz responds that what the center calls fillers is actually food. Deborah S. Magness, a Heinz spokeswoman, called its accusations "false" and "misleading." The tapioca in the criticized bananas-and-tapioca mixture is food that babies like, she said. "We stand behind that particular variety, as well as all our varieties," she said. **********Elaine Lipson, a spokeswoman for Mothers and Others for a Livable Planet, a New York City group that focuses on the purity of baby food and other products,  said she was concerned by all the takeovers of little companies like Earth's Best by large corporations. "We're not sure what will happen. Earth's Best has been a wonderful company," she said. But, she added, if the buyouts result in wider availability of organic foods, "that's a plus." **********EARTH'S BEST, of course, isn't about to monopolize the attention of top Heinz executives. Its $30 million in annual sales are less than one-half of one percent of Heinz's revenues, small potatoes compared with the $240 million in annual retail sales of Heinz ketchup -- the company's top-selling single product -- in America alone. Even dog food and cat food accounts for more; products like 9-Lives and Kibbles 'n Bits fetch more than $1 billion in annual sales. **********Heinz's worldwide stable of baby food brings nearly $1 billion in sales annually -- an amount equal to the entire United States market. Its Heinz brand  retails for about 27 cents less than Earth's Best, at 32 cents versus 59 cents for a 4-ounce jar at many groceries. Organically grown fruits and vegetables cost more, and 100 percent fruit is more expensive than fruit cut with sweeteners or tapioca. **********So is there a danger that Heinz will adulterate Earth's Best products with unnatural ingredients? After all, it made no written commitment to keep them 100 percent organic or to refrain from adding sugar, salt or refined starches when it bought the company. **********No Federal regulations define "organic," although 11 states have standards and the United States Department of Agriculture is developing national guidelines. The department is debating whether to allow the use of certain synthetic chemicals in food processing or as pesticides, said Harold Ricker, program manager of the department's national organic program. **********So why not tamper a bit with Earth's Best if it lowers the cost? **********Mr. Ruder says that just won't happen. "Are we going to bastardize it?" he asks. "The answer is 'no' -- unequivocally.It's not something you play around   with. When we bought into the company, we bought into the concept of the company." **********No matter how the company feels about organic food, retaining the Earth's Best purity makes marketing sense, he added. After all, it carries a higher price tag and complements the cheaper, mainstream Heinz baby foods, he said. **********"It's what we call the bookbinder approach," Mr. Banisch, the Heinz product manager, explained. Increased sales for Earth's Best would likely come at the expense of more costly competitors or from parents switching from homemade food, Heinz executives say. **********Indeed, Heinz values the Earth's Best name so much that it has decided to keep its corporate logo off the company's products lest it dilute their upscale  image. **********That doesn't prevent it from manufacturing the organic food at its sprawling  complex across the Allegheny River from downtown Pittsburgh, where it has been making some Earth's Best products under contract since fall 1994. It plans to move most production into the plant by next month. Inside, stainless steel pipes curl 2,600 feet in the main cooking area and the contents of 1,000-gallon tanks  are monitored by computer. Going full speed, Heinz figures it could crank out enough Earth's Best food in 20 days to meet a year's demand. **********What do the Koss brothers make of all this? While they feel mistreated by the venture capitalists, they have no complaints with Heinz, figuring it is in that  company's interest to protect Earth's Best's integrity. **********Indeed, Heinz is taking steps to maintain the products' standards. It is paying an outside quality-control organization to monitor suppliers' compliance  to organic-farming specifications. And it has added several Earth's Best executives to its payroll or taken them on as consultants. One of these is Marty Illick, who stirs up new Earth's Best varieties in the kitchen of her pre-Civil  War home in Charlotte, Vt., then taste-tests them at the walnut table that was a wedding present to her grandmother. **********"They're a little perplexed as to how you can make baby food in your house,"  Ms. Illick said of her new bosses. "You're talking about two different cultures." **********Arnie now lives in Hawaii and Ron in Washington state. They have started a new company, Great Circles Inc., to develop environmentally responsible food and agricultural products. They do not plan to make baby food. **********The brothers say they wish Heinz well and hope the big company can make the baby food more widely available. "I pray for it," Ron Koss said of the company he started. "I pray that they understand Earth's Best and that they take care of it as I think a parent would want their child to be taken care of."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/23/world.snippet: Pope John Paul II winds up trip to France that was test of his health and his popular appeal; many are surprised by his stamina despite busy schedule; major anti-Pope demonstration held in Paris, sponsored by leftist and anti-clerical groups, draw...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/23/world.main_headline: Pope Is Showing Stamina on His French Visit
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/23/world.print_headline: Pope Is Showing Stamina on His French Visit
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/23/world.body_text: **********Winding up a trip that was a test of his health and his popular appeal, Pope John Paul II showed today that he still has the stamina to meet the demands of his flock. **********Before a crowd of more than 200,000 people, the Pope celebrated an open-air Mass commemorating the 1,500th anniversary of the baptism of Clovis, a fifth-century Frankish king. The Pope's trip to France and his plan to commemorate Clovis's baptism prompted a monthlong debate about the role of the Catholic Church in French history and society. **********But for all the vehemence of the debate, the major anti-Pope demonstration held today in Paris, sponsored by leftist and anti-clerical groups, drew only about 5,000 people. **********''The people of France have more sense than those who speak in their name,'' Jean-Marie Cardinal Lustiger, Archbishop of Paris, said at a news conference today. ''This was an artificial debate.'' **********The preoccupation with the health of the Pope, who is 76 and due to undergo surgery next month to remove what his doctors say is an inflamed appendix, subsided somewhat after he celebrated three open-air Masses, made 18 other public appearances and delivered 12 speeches in the course of a four-day visit. **********Still, his slow gait and speech, now viewed as normal by those who follow him, came as a surprise to many French Catholics who remember his vigorous appearance on four previous visits here. **********Two French cardinals who accompanied him during much of the trip told reporters today that the had come terms with his infirmities. **********''He talks of his death freely and with a smile,'' Cardinal Lustiger said. ''There is no fear in the face of the void.'' **********Pierre Cardinal Eyt, Archbishop of Bordeaux, also noted the Pope's view of his health problems, saying,  ''He gives the feeling that when the day comes when he has to lie down, he will lie down, but that it is Jesus Christ who will tell him when that day comes by taking him into the other world.'' **********In his remarks today, the Pope avoided the disputes over the baptism of Clovis that had been seized on by rightists, particularly the nationalist politician Jean-Marie Le Pen, to celebrate the traditions of French conservatism and bolster their campaign against immigrants. **********On the first day of his trip to France, which began Thursday in Tours, the Pope signaled that he had come here as a ''pilgrim'' to visit the majority Catholic people and had no intention of challenging the secularist French state. At other stops, the Pope appealed for greater compassion for those marginalized by modern society, including the poor, invalids and immigrants from developing countries. **********By staking his distance from Mr. Le Pen's anti-immigrant stance, the Pope hoped to steer the church away from the nationalist message that had threatened to envelop today's commemoration.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/03/busin.main_headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Prices Rise On Treasury Securities
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/03/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Prices Rise On Treasury Securities
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/03/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday, bolstered by reports that suggested the economy was not growing at a fast enough pace to accelerate inflation. **********One report, on leading economic indicators, showed a gain that was stronger than expected. But the market viewed the improvements as recoveries from sharp weather-related setbacks and not indicative of a trend that could keep the Federal Reserve from cutting short-term interest rates in the coming months. Bond prices were also supported by a weekly survey of retail sales that showed weakness and by a firm dollar. **********Still, the rise in bond prices came on light volume, with many market participants reluctant to take positions ahead of the March employment report due to be released on Friday. **********"In front of the employment report it would be unwise if not irresponsible for anyone to make big bets," said David Ader, managing fixed-income anlayst at  Technical Data in Boston, **********The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 15/32, to 92 9/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.59 percent from  6.64 percent on Monday. **********The Conference Board reported yesterday that the monthly index of leading indicators rose 1.3 percent in February, exceeding the market's expectations for a gain of 1.1 percent. But traders and analysts viewed the gain as a rebound from a setback in January caused by a blizzard. **********"As with much of the other weather-related spikes we've seen, the leading indicators will fail to produce a clear indication of economic activity until more data is offered from this series in the coming months," said Marilyn Schaja of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. **********Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisers Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, estimated that about 60 percent of the jump in the indicators reflected a weather-related recovery in the manufacturing workweek. The report, he said, "merely confirmed the market-friendly scenario of moderate growth ahead." **********The Commerce Department yesterday released its revised estimate of the gross  domestic product in the fourth quarter, and that also fell short of expectations. The report said the economy grew at an annual pace of five-tenths  of 1 percent in the last three months of 1995, down from an earlier estimate of  nine-tenths of 1 percent. Some analysts had been expecting a revision of seven-tenths of 1 percent. The Commerce Department report suggested that the economy was weaker than many had thought last year. **********Weakness was also seen in the Johnson Redbook survey, released in the afternoon, which showed a decline of seven-tenths of 1 percent in retail sales last week. **********Bond prices received additional support yesterday from expectations that the  Federal Reserve would soon conduct a coupon pass, in which the Fed enters the market to buy certain maturities to add cash to the banking system. It is used to address seasonal shortages of reserves, and is not a signal of any change in  monetary policy. Traders say the coupon pass gives dealers an opportunity to sell Treasury securities piling up in inventory to a ready buyer. **********At yesterday's Treasury auctions of short-term maturities, the Treasury sold  $14 billion of 15-day cash management bills at an average rate of 5.29 percent,  and $11.1 billion of 22-day bills at 5.25 percent. **********Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auctions of new one-year bills and 15-day and 22-day cash management bills: **********(000 omitted in dollar figures) **********Average Price . . . 94.773 Discounted Rate . . . 5.17% Coupon Yield . . . 5.46% High Price . . . 94.793 Discounted Rate . . . 5.15% Coupon Yield . . . 5.43% Low Price . . . 94.773 Discounted Rate . . . 5.17% Coupon Yield . . . 5.46% Accepted at low price . . . 46% Total applied for . . . $56,035,579 Accepted . . . $18,937,179 Noncompetitive . . . $1,142,429 **********The one-year bills mature on April 3, 1997. **********(000 omitted in dollar figures) **********Average Price . . . 99.780 Discounted Rate . . . 5.29% Coupon Yield . . . 5.37% High Price . . . 99.780 Discounted Rate . . . 5.27% Coupon Yield . . . 5.37% Low Price . . . 99.779 Discounted Rate . . . 5.31% Coupon Yield . . . 5.39% Accepted at low price . . . 69% Total applied for . . . $41,567,200 Accepted . . . $14,008,000 Noncompetitive . . . $0 **********The 15-day cash management bills mature April 18, 1996. **********(000 omitted in dollar figures) **********Average Price . . . 99.679 Discounted Rate . . . 5.25% Coupon Yield . . . 5.34% High Price . . . 99.680 Discounted Rate . . . 5.23% Coupon Yield . . . 5.33% Low Price . . . 99.679 Discounted Rate . . . 5.25% Coupon Yield . . . 5.34% Accepted at low price . . . 97% Total applied for . . . $39,871,500 Accepted . . . $11,062,155 Noncompetitive . . . $0 **********The 22-day cash management bills mature April 25, 1996.

EA Industries, based in West Long Branch, N.J., acquired 596,927 Aydin shares, for about $18 each. https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/09/busin.main_headline: Rockwell Agrees to Pay Fine Of $6.5 Million in Explosion
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/09/busin.print_headline: Rockwell Agrees to Pay Fine Of $6.5 Million in Explosion
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/09/busin.body_text: **********The Rockwell International Corporation agreed today to pay a $6.5 million fine in connection with an explosion that killed two men at its rocket engine subsidiary. **********As part of the settlement, which must be approved by a Federal judge, the company pleaded guilty to three counts of improper storage and disposal of a hazardous material. **********Federal prosecutors said the fine was the maximum allowed and the biggest criminal environmental fine in California history. **********The settlement is part of the attempt by Rockwell to put a tarnished environmental record behind it. The company has agreed to cooperate with further investigations and will turn over its interviews with witnesses, as well as files on the case, to Federal authorities. **********The settlement does not protect individuals from prosecution for crimes in connection with the blast or Rockwell from civil liability under Federal law. Investigations are continuing, said Nora Manella, the United States Attorney in  Los Angeles. . **********The explosion, at a field laboratory in the Santa Susana Mountains northwest  of Los Angeles, occurred on July 26, 1994, touching off a brush fire. Otto K. Heiney, 53, and Larry A. Pugh, 51, two scientists at Rocketdyne, a Rockwell division, died while trying to burn up small batches of a propellant so dangerous that the explosion of a single dust particle can fracture a finger, Ms. Manella said. **********In addition, Lee Wells, 62, a test technician, was seriously injured. **********Rocketdyne executives at first said the two scientists were conducting an experiment. But the state's Occupational Safety and Health Administration said the blasts appeared to be "a disguise for destroying waste explosive material" and levied more than $200,000 in fines. **********Rockwell's chairman, Donald R. Beall, said rules for storing, handling and disposing of hazardous materials were broken and "went undetected within a small department of Santa Susana" but that the company must accept accountability. **********The company has since strengthened its emphasis on safety procedures and management accountability, he said. **********Shares of Rockwell fell $3.125 today, to $56.125, amid a broad selloff on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/21/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;New Internet Search Engine Said to Ease Hunt for Sites
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/21/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;New Internet Search Engine Said to Ease Hunt for Sites
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/21/busin.body_text: **********As anyone who has gone foraging on the Internet knows, the best way to find anything useful or amusing is to know where you are headed from the outset. Get  the precise address, or URL (uniform resource locator), and go directly to the World Wide Web site you want. **********Without the Internet address, the chances of getting lost in cyberspace are high indeed. Today's guides are Web sites like Yahoo, Infoseek and Alta Vista, which are Internet directories or catalogues, and they are crude tools at best.  Tap in a key word or two for an Internet search and the result is often hundreds of Web sites, most of them useless, ranked in no apparent order. **********And the fact that search sites, like Yahoo and Infoseek, are among the most  heavily trafficked locales on the Web suggests what people spend much of their time doing on the Internet -- searching, half blind, for something worthwhile. **********The latest entry in the quest for a better search engine is Hotbot, which went up on the Web last night (http://www.hotbot.com). The new search tool is the result of a collaboration between Hotwired, the Internet arm of Wired magazine, and a start-up company, the Inktomi Corporation. Hotwired is contributing design skills, user research and marketing, while Inktomi is supplying the technology. **********Named after a mythological spider of the Indian tribes of the Great Plains, Inktomi was founded by an assistant professor of computer science at the University of California at Berkeley, Eric Brewer, and a former graduate student, Paul Gauthier. They were in the news last fall for warning of security flaws in Netscape's browser program. But yesterday, they had to delay the release of Hotbot until the evening hours for some last-minute tightening of security in their search site. **********Inktomi claims to bring innovative technology, called hive computing, to the  search-engine market. The idea is to link several work stations into a network,  and have each machine work on part of a problem. Inktomi researchers say the result is a system that can mimic a supercomputer, at a fraction of the cost and can be easily scaled up to keep pace with the explosive growth of the Web. **********Thus, Inktomi says it can search the entire Web, more than 50 million pages,  while other search engines can handle only about 25 million. **********Still, people are far less likely to complain of a shortage of information on the Web than to lament that what they find there is of little interest -- personal home pages, company billboards and so on. **********To address the problem, Hotbot enables users to tailor their inquiries not only by several words in categories like "must include" or "should include," but also by date of the site posting, domain groups like .edu and .com and other characteristics. **********It is these search innovations that most impress industry analysts who have sampled test versions of Hotbot. "In the future, search engines are going to succeed or fail because of usefulness and usability," said Greg Wester, director of Internet research at the Yankee Group in Boston. "And Hotbot seems to have some nice features for refining searches." **********Yet analysts also agree that Hotbot and the other search tools still have a long way to go. They speak of searching software with "semantic intelligence" or "intelligent agent" features that will someday hone inquiries according to word  relationships as well as personal preferences and interests. "The next step is to bring really relevant materials to individuals instead of having to spend a lot of time wading though pages you don't want," said Torrey Byles, an analyst for Giga Information Group, a research company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/17/busin.main_headline: Fleet Chairman to Resign In Wake of Banks' Merger
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/17/busin.print_headline: Fleet Chairman to Resign In Wake of Banks' Merger
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/17/busin.body_text: **********Joel A. Alvord, the chairman of the Fleet Financial Group, announced late last night that he would step down at the end of the year. **********Mr. Alvord had been chairman of the Shawmut National Corporation, which merged with Fleet last year. Terrence Murray, 56, who had been the chairman of Fleet, gave up that title in the merger, but remained chief executive and president. **********Mr. Alvord had been scheduled to remain chairman until November 1998, but he said he wanted to pursue other interests and would announce his plans to step down at the annual meeting today. **********"I will be 58 in November, and life's too short to have my obituary read, 'Banker dies,' " he said. Mr. Alvord said he saw great opportunities in companies that create insurance and other products to sell through banks. **********He said he had wanted to remain chairman long enough to make sure that Shawmut executives were guaranteed jobs in the combined bank, a task that he said was largely complete. He added that he had no conflicts with Mr. Murray. **********"Terry and I have known each other for 25 years, and we get along beautifully," Mr. Alvord said. **********Last year's wave of mergers left a number of big banks with two former chairmen sharing the executive suite, an arrangement that is often unstable. **********Last week, Samuel A. McCullough said he would step down as president of the Corestates Financial Corporation, only three months after its acquisition of Meridian Bancorp, which Mr. McCullough had run for 18 years. **********Mr. McCullough said that he chose to vacate the presidency in favor of a one-year consulting contract because he could not reach a satisfactory division  of duties with Terrence A. Larsen, Corestates' chairman. **********Banking analysts have wondered how long other former bank chiefs in the same  situation will last. These include Anthony P. Terracciano, who was chairman of the First Fidelity Bancorporation and now is the president of the First Union Corporation; Garry J. Scheuring, former chairman of the Midlantic Corporation, and now vice chairman of the PNC Bank Corporation, and William Crozier Jr., the  chairman of Bay Banks Inc., who will be chairman but not chief executive of the  Bank of Boston Corporation after their pending merger is completed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/31/world.main_headline: World News Briefs;2 More Fled North Korea, Authorities in South Say
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/31/world.print_headline: World News Briefs;2 More Fled North Korea, Authorities in South Say
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/31/world.body_text: **********A scientist and a writer from North Korea have defected and are seeking political asylum in South Korea, South Korean authorities said today. **********News reports here said the two sought asylum separately through the South Korean Embassy in Beijing and were transferred to two different Southeast Asian  countries for their final journey to Seoul. **********The defections were made public a week after a North Korean pilot flew his MIG-19 jet across the Korean border to seek asylum in South Korea. He was the first North Korean air force pilot to defect in 13 years. **********Cho Won Il, a spokesman for the South Korean Foreign Ministry, said the latest two North Korean defectors were safe and were expected to arrive in Seoul "sooner or later." China's Foreign Ministry comment. **********Officials in Seoul identified the scientist as Chung Gap Yul, 45, director of North Korea's research institute for sound equipment. He sought asylum in Beijing on May 7, they said. **********Authorities identified the other defector only as a broadcast scriptwriter. KBS television in South Korea gave his name as Kim Young Hwan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/26/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********Re "Life of a Cold Caller: Riding on a Smile and a Thick Skin" (March 24): **********The stress experienced by telemarketers accurately reflects their unwelcomeness in the vast majority of homes. The damage inflicted upon the recipients of these calls through disruption of activities, loss of privacy, inability to relax, etc., is enormous, especially in a society that is already grappling with stimulus overload. **********I have no doubt that Alexander Graham Bell is rolling over in his grave at how his invention is being used. **********I recommend that all cold callers be required to gain access to one's home telephone only by passing through a T-chip.
