https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/14/busin.snippet: With international bonds from high-risk emerging countries running at flood levels — and the prospect of more, with Russia poised for its first offering — the leading underwriters of new issues have agreed to ignore an official request to mod
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/14/busin.body_text: **********With international bonds from high-risk emerging countries running at flood levels — and the prospect of more, with Russia poised for its first offering — the leading underwriters of new issues have agreed to ignore an official request to modify contracts to facilitate a rescheduling of the debt, should it ever be needed. **********The request was formulated by the Group of Ten, made up of major industrialized countries, in April. As a follow-up to the official bailout of private holders of Mexican debt in 1995, finance ministers and central bank governors suggested changes in contract terms that would make it possible for sovereign borrowers to suspend debt payments "in certain exceptional cases" to resolve a financial crisis. **********As international bonds are typically bearer instruments, which do not entail identification of the holder, the officials recommended that contracts provide for collective representation of debtholders in the event of a crisis and that qualified majority voting replace the now standard unanimous vote needed to alter contract conditions. **********It is this very difficulty in identifying holders of bearer paper and the improbability of ever getting unanimous agreement that enabled bondholders to emerge unscathed from the debt crisis of the early 1980s that savaged international banks. But in emerging from that crisis, developing countries have transformed the bulk of their debt into bonds, making it virtually certain that any future payments crisis will require the approval of bondholders. **********As the April recommendation from the Group of Ten stated, the "evolution of contractual arrangements between sovereign borrowers and their creditors needs to be a market-led process." **********But the International Primary Market Association, the organization represent- **********ing banks that arrange and underwrite new issues and oversee the contract language, says its members oppose any change in wording that would enhance the possibility of a borrower defaulting. The association's chairman, Jean-Pierre Wellens of Banque Bruxelles Lambert, said in an interview that adding such contract language could only "destabilize what is now a flourishing market." **********In the first three-quarters of this year, borrowers from developing countries sold a record $65 billion of international bonds. In a low-inflation environment where high-grade medium-term government and corporate debt yields barely more than 6 percent, investors striving to maximize income have lowered risk standards in return for coupon payments that are several percentage points above benchmark rates. **********For example, the Russian issue, expected to be as large as $500 million and with a maturity possibly as long as five years, is expected to pay about 400 basis points, or four percentage points, more than comparably dated U.S. government notes. Russia last week was rated Ba-2 by Moody's, two levels below investment grade, and BB-minus by Standard & Poor's, three rungs below investment grade, but both ratings were higher than many had expected. **********After the central government, the Moscow municipality is also expected to come to the market for as much as $300 million, then St. Petersburg. Other expected new borrowers include Pakistan and Croatia. **********Mr. Wellens said underwriters agreed that requiring unanimous consent to modify a contract was unrealistic and that no single investor should have the power to block a renegotiation of terms. But he said bankers were unable to agree on what amount should constitute the qualified majority sought by the Group of Ten. **********Summarizing the bankers' view concerning an allowance for renegotiation, Mr. Wellens said: **********"We believe that when a borrower signs a contract, he commits himself to repay the full amount. We believe we shouldn't introduce a major weakness into a flourishing market."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/13/world.body_text: **********The first Japanese troops to serve in a full peacekeeping role formally joined United Nations forces in the Golan Heights today. **********The 45 armed Japanese newcomers arrived at this camp, 35 miles west of Damascus, to join the troops serving as a buffer between Israeli and Syrian troops since 1974. **********The Japanese will serve in a logistics unit within the 1,040-member force. **********The Japanese soldiers will replace a Canadian unit that is completing its mission this month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/26/busin.main_headline: Unit of B.A.T. Plans to Sell 6 Cigarette Lines
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/26/busin.print_headline: Unit of B.A.T. Plans to Sell 6 Cigarette Lines
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/26/busin.body_text: **********The Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed  to sell six discount cigarette brands and a North Carolina factory to a small maker of off-price cigarettes. **********Brown & Williamson, a unit of B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. of Britain, must obtain approval from the Federal Trade Commission for the sale to closely held Commonwealth Brands Inc. of Bowling Green, Ky.  B.A.T. said it would not disclose the price until it won approval. **********In April, the F.T.C. rejected a proposed sale of the six brands, to the Loews Corporation, saying Loews did not have experience with low-price brands and that the transaction would not foster competition in the industry. **********The agency originally required the sale of the Montclair, Malibu, Riviera, Crowns, Special Tens and Bull Durham brands when B.A.T. bought American Brands Inc.'s cigarette business in the United States for $1 billion in 1994. **********As part of a settlement, the F.T.C. also suggested the sale of three full-price brands. **********A Brown & Williamson spokesman could not be reached for comment. A receptionist at Commonwealth said no one was available. **********Owned by a tobacco warehouse operator, Brad Kelley, Commonwealth has pledged  to keep the plant, in Reidsville, N.C., open. It now sells such brands as Maui,  Raven and Canada Goose in at least 18 states, mostly in the Southeast and Midwest. **********The proposed sale includes domestic rights to the six brands, with Brown & Williamson keeping the international rights. **********The F.T.C. rejected B.A.T.'s sale to Loews, the fourth-biggest United States  cigarette company, after objections by Brooke Group Ltd., the discount cigarette maker controlled by the financier Bennett S. LeBow. **********The F.T.C. and Brooke Group had no immediate comment on the proposed sale to  Commonwealth. **********American depository receipts of B.A.T. rose 6.25 cents, to $15.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. Each A.D.R. represents two ordinary shares of the company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/09/world.main_headline: Isolated and Corrupt, Serbia's Economy Stagnates
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/09/world.print_headline: Isolated and Corrupt, Serbia's Economy Stagnates
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/09/world.body_text: **********You can still buy a small, boxy Yugo car here, but you have to wait for months. When cars are finally delivered, the more fortunate buyers find they are missing mirrors, upholstery panels or ash trays. The unfortunate ones must clank their way to the nearest garage, where work immediately begins under the hood. **********"As soon as I drove away, I had a leak in the fuel hose," Branislav Cuckovic, 23, said of his Yugo. "A week later the brakes failed, the window handles broke  off and the transmission went. I've spent all my money just to keep it going." **********The stripped-down car, with a Fiat engine, was once the pride of Yugoslavia. The huge Zastava Yugo Automobile plant in Kragujevac rolled out 200,000 vehicles a year beforecivil war broke out five years ago. The cars, which cost about $5,000, were exported to other Eastern European countries and the United States. **********But the plight of Zastava, where production has fallen to 3,500 cars in the first six months of this year, is indicative of the deep economic and political  crisis brewing in Yugoslavia, which now comprises only two republics, Serbia and Montenegro. **********The break-up of Yugoslavia in 1991 destroyed its industrial sector as large manufacturing centers in Serbia were cut off from their suppliers and outlets. International sanctions imposed because of Belgrade's support for the Bosnian Serbs, together with the refusal by the Government to relinquish its grip on state industries, contributed to the withering of manufacturing. (The sanctions, imposed in June 1992, were lifted in January of this year.) **********The central bank's hard currency is almost gone, bringing enormous pressure on the Yugoslav Government to print more money to pay salaries and keep businesses open, but so far officials have resisted increasing the money supply. Once that begins, economists say, the days of hyperinflation are not far away. **********If things do not improve soon -- and there are few signs they will -- the president of Serbia, Slobodan Milosevic, could face "serious political unrest within six to nine months," according to United States intelligence reports. Union leaders, who led a series of strikes this spring, have given the Yugoslav  Government until September to raise salaries and create new jobs, or face renewed nationwide protests. **********As many people in Belgrade remind visitors, the war in the former Yugoslavia  was as much about the control of diminishing resources, jobs and industries as about nationalist ideologies peddled to whip up popular support. **********An economic disaster here could spell real trouble in flash points like the Kosovo region, where ethnic Albanians, who make up more than 90 percent of the population, are under the thumb of repressive Serbian police and officials sent  from Belgrade. **********"Foreign companies come in here, take one look at what is going on and pack up and leave," a Western diplomat said. "We don't even bring in trade delegations now; it's no use." **********Dragoslav Avramovic recently lost his job as governor of the central bank after criticizing the Government for economic mismanagement and its failure to reform the economy -- a failure that has seen Yugoslavia shunned by every major  international lending institution. Mr. Avramovic, 76, a former World Bank official, now warns that catastrophe looms. **********"The Government has two ways left to manage the deficit," he said. "Either print more money or stop paying the bills. I am not sure which is worse. The Government has stopped, for now, paying its bills, but we are running into trouble. The Government does not generate any savings. It is barely able to pay  pensions." **********The country's infrastructure is crumbling: Belgrade's bus fleet is down to 750, from 900, because of the need to cannibalize vehicles for spare parts. There are increasing power failures. The rail system, with 50 engines that are more than five decades old running on hundreds of miles of poorly kept track, can no longer haul products reliably. The water system works sporadically. **********Salaries are paid months late, if at all. The average wage, rural or urban, is about $100 a month, a drop of 80 percent in the last decade. **********"I earn $140 dollars a month, and even then my check comes three months late," said Milanka Bojanovic, 44, who works for the port authority. "I have neighbors who have not been paid for six months." **********Institutional Investor, the trade magazine, recently ranked Yugoslavia Number 129 of 137 countries as a prospect for foreign investment. Among the countries rated less attractive were Libya, the Sudan, Zaire and Afghanistan. **********There never were many foreign companies here. Those that have looked into investment say the import-export process is cumbersome, with many bureaucratic restrictions and paperwork. The Government makes it tough to get hard currency.  Taxes and fees, piled one on the other, are also barriers to doing business. Nor was there much direct foreign investment; most foreign companies here handled only sales and distribution. **********And there is a powerful lobby, built up in the last five years, that vigorously opposes economic reform, despite the threat of political upheaval. **********"Milosevic's power is based, as it was under Communism, on nepotism," an American businessman said. "Those who support him get rich, really rich. Those who do not, starve. The middle class is being wiped out, and a new, powerful oligarchy rules this place like a feudal estate." **********Nearly every major state industry is now headed by a senior government official. Prime Minister Mirko Marjanovic is the director of Progres, the oil-importing company; the Deputy Prime Minister, Slobodan Radulovic, runs the largest chain of supermarkets. **********Given the political and economic muscle the state-run corporations wield, local rivals are easily squashed. New businesses that find a niche are quickly absorbed in the maw of government-run monopolies. **********For example, when farmers began to make money by selling raspberries to Germany, trade that was not permitted under the sanctions, the farms were simply taken over by government officials or their cronies, or growers were forced to sell to the state. Not a raspberry leaves this country now without the profits going to one of the huge agricultural conglomerates, including Pik Takovo, which is run by the Agriculture Minister, Ivko Djonovic. **********"A large proportion of the so-called socially owned firms, or government-owned firms, are losing money," Mr. Avramovic said. "These are very inefficient industries. Companies constantly raise prices to keep up, and this has been one of the major causes of inflation." **********The latest row, between wheat farmers and the Government, has many in the countryside seething and could lead to unrest this fall. **********Wheat farmers, many of whom cut back on the number of acres they planted this year because they are being forced to sell their harvests at below-market prices to state-run export companies, warn that they are being pushed over the brink. **********"Never have I seen such anger," said Momir Crnogorac, 32, a farmer from Vojvodina, the major wheat-producing region. "Milosevic, who got away during the war by blaming all this on sanctions, is now playing a very dangerous game. People no longer believe him. They are fed up with being robbed."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/12/world.snippet: Report predicting attacks on European targets by Islamic groups from Algeria was reportedly completed by French intelligence services on November 19, two weeks before bomb exploded on Paris commuter train killing four persons (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/12/world.main_headline: 2 Weeks Before Paris Blast, French Report Predicted New Attacks
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/12/world.print_headline: 2 Weeks Before Paris Blast, French Report Predicted New Attacks
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/12/world.body_text: **********A report predicting attacks on European targets by  militant Islamic groups from Algeria was completed by French intelligence services on Nov. 19, two weeks before a bomb exploded at a Paris rail station, killing four people. **********The report, disclosed today by Le Monde, was titled ''Algeria, Toward the Exporting of Violence?'' Based on investigations in Algeria, it concluded that ''all the indications gathered on the ground'' suggested that European targets would be picked because they would provide ''a resonance that no longer exists in Algeria.'' **********The Defense Ministry issued a statement today saying an investigation had been ordered into ''the reasons that led to the divulging of parts'' of a ''note for reflection'' destined for ''internal use.'' **********The ministry, which oversees the Directorate General for External Security, denied Le Monde's report that President Jacques Chirac and Prime Minister Alain Juppe had been informed of the findings of the intelligence services in mid-November. **********The bombing at the Port-Royal commuter station -- using a gas canister filled with nails -- recalled precisely the methods used by the Armed Islamic Group, an Algerian organization, in a wave of attacks in France last year that killed 8 people and wounded more than 160. No arrests have yet been made in connection with the recent bombing. **********But Said Lahlali, a representative in France of the Islamic Salvation Front, the party that appeared set to win elections in Algeria in 1992 before they were canceled by the army, said today that a senior party official, Anouar Haddam, had been arrested in the United States. **********The detention of Mr. Haddam, who has lived mainly in the United States for the last three years, would appear to mark a distinct shift in American policy. **********Elected to Parliament in Algeria in late 1991, Mr. Haddam has acted as an interlocutor between the Islamic Salvation Front and the State Department. **********In 1995 he represented his party at a conference in Rome that tried to establish a platform for peace in Algeria by rejecting ''violence to gain or maintain power,'' recognizing a multiparty system and accepting the alternation of political office. Earlier, however, he had appeared to endorse the Armed Islamic Group, the most radical and ruthless of the factions that emerged from Islamic Salvation Front after it was banned in Algeria in 1992. **********More than a week after the attack on the train station, a state of high alert continues in Paris, with soldiers deployed in the city, all garbage cans on the subway sealed to prevent the concealing of a bomb, widespread signs urging people to be vigilant, and almost daily bomb scares in department stores or train stations. **********The report from the French intelligence services argued that a blocked military and political situation in Algeria made it more likely that violence would be ''exported'' by increasingly splintered and marginalized groups of Islamic militants in Algeria. Tens of thousands of people have been killed in Algeria since a faction of the Islamic Salvation Front began a campaign of violence to protest the cancellation of elections in 1992. In the latest of a series of attacks in the Blida area south of Algiers, Islamic insurgents slit the throats of 20 passengers on an overnight bus early today, the Algerian Government said. **********More than 60 people have been killed in Blida Province in the last week. Reprisals by security forces are often fierce, and the insurgents  assert that many killings attributed to them are the work of the army.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/24/busin.snippet: Germany and European Commission fail to resolve dispute concerning state aid payments to Volkswagen AG, Europe's biggest auto company, making it likely deadlock will have to be broken in court (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/24/busin.main_headline: Dispute Continues On Aid to Volkswagen
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/24/busin.print_headline: Dispute Continues On Aid to Volkswagen
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/24/busin.body_text: **********Germany and the European Commission failed to resolve a dispute concerning state aid payments to Volkswagen A.G., Europe's biggest auto company, making it likely the deadlock will have to be broken in court. **********The clash began in June when the commission, the executive agency of the European Union, blocked 240.7 million marks ($155 million) in aid to Volkswagen on the ground that it contravened antitrust rules. The government of Saxony said it would make part of the payment regardless. The German Economics Minister, Gunter Rexrodt, and the European Union's Competition Commissioner, Karel van Miert, met in an attempt to settle the dispute.   (Bloomberg Business News)

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/18/busin.main_headline: U.S. Trade Gap Narrowed Again in October
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/18/busin.print_headline: U.S. Trade Gap Narrowed Again in October
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/18/busin.body_text: **********The nation's trade deficit fell to $8.04 billion last October, the lowest level in 10 months and the fourth straight monthly decline, the Commerce Department said today in a delayed report. **********The numbers solidified a view among economists that the trade deficit had peaked, but the latest figures also raised new concerns about the nation's trade with Japan and highlighted a lack of progress in opening parts of China's vast market more widely to American goods. **********And some economists cautioned that these and other problems, including growing United States trade imbalances with Canada and Mexico and a slowdown in  Europe's economy, could keep the country's overall trade deficit from dropping significantly next year. **********In its report, which was delayed at least a month by the Government shutdown, the Commerce Department said the trade deficit decreased 2.5 percent in October  from $8.25 billion in September. That marked the fourth straight monthly fall since the deficit hit $11.39 billion last June. **********But even with those gains, several private economists projected that the 1995 deficit would total $150 billion to $165 billion, making it one of the highest in history. **********Still, Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said the overall trend "is obviously helpful." He added that the trade total, fueled by strong United States exports, "have been moving inextricably in the right direction over the last several months. **********"I perceive that is going to continue, but how strongly I can't tell," he said. **********Several economists said they were troubled by a jump in the United States trade deficit with Japan, which rose 11.1 percent in October to $4.79 billion from $4.31 billion in September, ending a seven-month stretch of declines. **********But Mr. Kantor said in an interview that the overall trade deficit with Japan had dropped 4 percent in the first 10 months of 1995 over the same period in 1994. **********He said he was more concerned about trade with China. Hinting that the Administration may seek to reimpose trade sanctions against China next month, Mr. Kantor said: "Things are not going in the correct direction with China. We have focused on China with some intensity, and we intend to be even more intense over the next several months. This goes beyond trade rules to the rule of law. We expect them to live up to their agreements." **********Last February, the Clinton Administration suspended $1 billion in tariffs on  imports from China to encourage the Chinese Government to crack down on piracy of American movies and computer software and to halt other discriminatory trade  practices. **********But some trade experts contended that China has not changed many of its practices, and the Commerce report showed that America's deficit with China climbed to $29.09 billion in the first 10 months of 1995 from $24.59 billion in  the same period in 1994. **********Mr. Kantor and several economists said new trade agreements with other countries and a renewed competitiveness by American companies had helped to increase exports. But, noting that exports dipped slightly in October, they also said that any strengthening in the dollar's value, making United States goods more expensive, and the sluggish nature of the Japanese and European economies,  could choke out some of that growth. **********Gary C. Hufbauer, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington, said the latest trade numbers were "slightly better than one might have expected," and he said he expected a continued decline in the overall deficit. **********But he also said that "the bigger story is the softness of the U.S. economy," which is improving the balance of trade by slowing purchases of imports by American consumers. **********Indeed, the Commerce Department report showed that while exports of American  goods and services rose from $64.68 billion last June to $66.75 billion in October, imports dropped from $76.06 billion to $74.79 billion over the same period. **********Others, such as Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., a former Commerce Department official and a critic of some of Japan's trading practices, said they found the  Commerce Department report to be "discouraging" because it showed that the United States deficits were still growing with several of its leading trading partners. **********Besides the problems with Japan and China, the report showed that trade deficits had worsened with both Canada and Mexico, the country's partners in the North American Free Trade Agreement. **********In addition, America's trade deficit with Western Europe jumped to $1.15 billion in October from $125 million in September, possibly reflecting Europe's growing economic woes. **********Commerce Department officials cautioned that such figures could be misleading because the total trade deficit is adjusted for seasonal variations in economic  activity, but the country-by-country figures are not. **********But Mr. Prestowitz, now president of the Economic Strategy Institute in Washington, said he was concerned by the numbers. **********"Mexico's economy is slowing," he said, "and the forecast is that it will not be robust and Europe will not be robust." In addition, he said, "We have a chronic, big trade deficit with Canada." **********Among industrial sectors, some of the biggest declines in October occurred in exports of autos and auto parts, which slipped to $4.77 billion in October from  $5.6 billion in September. Imports dropped even more, to $9.51 billion from $10.42 billion. **********Imports of foreign oil also declined, to $4.25 billion in October from $4.78  billion in September. **********Given the delay in releasing the October figures, economists expect the Commerce Department to follow in early February with the November totals, bringing the trade picture more up to date. **********The Japanese Government is expected to report its 1995 trade figures soon, and most experts believe they will show that Japan's huge trade surplus shrank for the first time in five years. If that is so, it could ease trade tensions between Japan and the United States and help keep the dollar strong.

Meridian, which is based in Santa Fe Springs, Calif., has annual sales of about  $200 million. Along with two subsidiaries, Atlantic Meridian and Gulf Meridian,  it supplies seafood worldwide. https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/23/busin.main_headline: COMPANY NEWS;WATKINS-JOHNSON STOCK FALLS ON LOWER PROFIT OUTLOOK
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/23/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;WATKINS-JOHNSON STOCK FALLS ON LOWER PROFIT OUTLOOK
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/23/busin.body_text: **********The stock of the Watkins-Johnson Company fell 14 percent yesterday after the  company, a maker of computer chip manufacturing equipment and electronic products, said its earnings for the second quarter and the full year would not meet expectations on Wall Street. The concern, based in Palo Alto, Calif., cited lower-than-expected orders and requests by customers to extend delivery times. It noted that demand for chips had slowed and that prices for some popular chips had fallen sharply. As a result, the company said that shipments for the second half of 1996 were likely to be below those of the first six months and that it would have to cut costs. The stock fell by $5.125, to $29.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/26/world.snippet: Pope John Paul II uses Christmas message to appeal for more aid to victims of violence in Central Africa and for a quickening of efforts to achieve lasting peace in Middle East (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/26/world.main_headline: Pope Appeals for Aid for African Refugees and Peace in Mideast
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/26/world.print_headline: Pope Appeals for Aid for African Refugees and Peace in Mideast
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/26/world.body_text: **********Pope John Paul II delivered a Christmas appeal today for more aid to victims of violence in Central Africa, and for a quickening of efforts to achieve lasting peace in the Middle East. **********The Pope issued the plea in his annual Christmas message, ''Urbi et Orbi'' -- ''To the City and to the World'' -- and he later offered brief season's greetings in 55 languages. **********As usual, the Pope spoke from the central balcony of St. Peter's Basilica, overlooking thousands of people who crowded under rainy skies into the immense square. They were only a fraction of the Pope's audience, for his remarks were carried in direct or delayed broadcasts to television viewers in 70 countries. **********In the 18 years that he has led the world's 960 million Roman Catholics, John Paul's Christmas words have struck varying themes. He has been political, pastoral, often mystical. Today, his comments contained much poetry, but also stern political admonition. **********'' 'God is born; power trembles,' '' he said, quoting the words of an 18th-century Polish poet, Franciszek Karpinski, that have become a popular Christmas carol in the Pope's homeland. '' 'The Lord of Heaven is naked; fire congeals; glare darkens; he who is infinite, has boundaries. The scorned one is covered with glory; the mortal one is a king for centuries.''' **********The Pope said such melodies had now brought peace to places like Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as Guatemala, where after years of war the guns had fallen silent. **********''But the echo of the songs of Christmas must travel much farther,'' he continued. ''It must resound beyond walls where the clash of arms is still heard, shattering the spell of peace brought by this holy day. I am thinking of Bethlehem and all the Holy Land, where Jesus was born and lived: the land which he loved, the land where hope must not die, despite provocations and profound differences.'' **********Moving to another area of turmoil, Africa, John Paul assailed what he called international apathy toward the fate of refugees, saying: ''At its very heart, in the region of the Great Lakes, this young continent is experiencing, amid the general indifference of the international community, one of the cruelest human tragedies of its history.'' **********''Thousands and thousands of people -- our brothers and sisters -- wander, displaced, victims of fear, hunger and disease,'' he said. ''They,  alas, will not be able to feel the joy of Christmas.'' **********The Pope has appealed repeatedly for international aid to help ease the sufferings of a million or more displaced Rwandan refugees who have returned from neighboring Zaire and Tanzania over the last month. **********But the theme of Middle East peace between Israel and the Palestinians also weighed heavily. On Friday, the Roman Catholic Patriarch of Jerusalem, the Very Rev. Michel Sabbah, cautioned the Israeli authorities in a strongly worded Christmas message that they were pursuing ''a path of violence.'' In January, the Pope is expected to deliver similar urgings to Israel's Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, when he comes to Rome on a visit. **********The Pope, looking rested, had forgone the public celebration of the third of three Masses he ordinarily celebrates on Christmas. John Paul, 76, has suffered health problems in recent years, and though he took part in the long liturgy of Christmas midnight Mass, he heeded the advice of physicians to conserve his strength, limiting his activities today to services after dawn in his private chapel and the Christmas address.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/17/busin.main_headline: A Double Standard In Health Coverage
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/17/busin.print_headline: A Double Standard In Health Coverage
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/17/busin.body_text: **********TO most of its employees, the Gannett Company makes no excuses for economizing on health care. Those who want to pick their own doctors and hospitals instead of sticking with the cut-rate Communicare Choice network, a company brochure warns, face high deductibles, low payments and, potentially, thousands of dollars of added expense. **********All for a good cause, Gannett vouches. Communicare Choice, the brochure says, "addresses the dilemma facing most businesses today -- how to continue to provide good health-care coverage and keep costs in check." **********A quandary it may be, but not one so serious that Gannett's top executives have to confront it personally. Under their separate plan, the company shows more flexibility in covering deductibles and other payments no matter which doctors they see. **********Gannett is hardly alone. As companies herd their employees into managed care, limiting their choices to doctors and hospitals that have agreed to cut their charges, the chiefs of many of the nation's largest corporations -- including Atlantic Richfield; Charles Schwab; RJR Nabisco; SBC Communications, the parent  of Southwestern Bell, and Gannett -- are leading more by precept than example. According to recent Securities and Exchange Commission filings and the companies themselves, the executives have medical coverage more bountiful than what their  employees enjoyed even before their companies began economizing. **********These perks, worth perhaps a few thousand dollars for a typical chief executive, might seem trivial compared with executive-compensation packages that can total millions of dollars. But in an era of mass layoffs, the special treatment rankles workers and could provide grist for politicians who rail against corporate greed. **********Some executive-compensation specialists wonder how bosses can justify full coverage for themselves while insisting that their workers accept cutbacks. "Unfortunately," said Judith Fischer, a managing director at Executive Compensation Services, a newsletter and research firm in Fairfax Station, Va., "what is good for the rank and file is not always good enough for executives." **********Although companies with executive health plans are in a minority, as many others have done away with them, these companies say the benefits are necessary  to recruit and keep qualified leaders. "SBC has an outstanding record of retaining its managers, and it's a competitive marketplace," said Robert Ferguson, a company spokesman. SBC's executive plan eliminates the deductibles and co-payments for visits to doctors and hospitals that ordinary employees have to pay, up to a limit that Mr. Ferguson said he could not specify. **********For employees of SBC, and of most other companies, traditional coverage with  no restrictions on choice is virtually dead. SBC workers are limited to health maintenance organizations or Prudential's Customcare program. Customcare, chosen by 90 percent, penalizes SBC employees who want to choose their own doctors and hospitals by imposing a $1,215 annual deductible for a family of three and paying only 80 percent of most hospital costs. Employees who limit themselves tomembers of the Customcare network have no deductibles and 100 percent hospital coverage. **********For workers, the lack of choice can be a hardship. Managed-care plans force many people to abandon doctors who have cared for them and their families for years. They also limit the ability of members to shop for the best hospitals and specialists to treat afflictions like cancer or heart disease. **********The restrictions are painful enough, but the realization that they don't apply to the higher-ups hurts worker morale, said Vic Crawley, an official with  the Communications Workers of America who represents workers at SBC. "They have  no limitations," Mr. Crawley said of the top managers' coverage. That inequity "builds up anger," he said, adding, "I think you have to can those kinds of perks." **********When the union brought up the executive benefits in negotiations, Mr. Crawley said, management wanted no part of the workers' managed-care plan. "We may not like it, but it's not the kind of issue you go to war over," he said. **********Mr. Ferguson of SBC said that most other large companies probably have similar executive coverage. But in fact, SBC belongs to a shrinking minority in  assigning a higher value to upper-management life, organ and limb. Towers Perrin, the compensation-and-benefits consulting firm, said that only 12 percent of the nation's largest corporations offered executives special medical perks today, down from 18 percent 20 years ago. **********Companies that have eliminated special health coverage for executives in recent years, according to S.E.C. filings and checks with the corporations, include Western Digital, Time Warner, Wisconsin Electric, Carter-Wallace and Walt Disney. **********DISNEY used to pay $4,000 a year to give each top executive full insurance coverage for expenses not paid by the standard employee plan. The only limit on  benefits was an improbable 20 percent of annual salary -- or hundreds of thousands of dollars, or perhaps even millions, for the likes of Michael D. Eisner, the chief executive who is famous for making $203 million in 1993, most  of it from cashing in stock options. **********Last year, Disney decided that such favoritism sent the wrong signal and dropped the special coverage. "All employees have the same choice with the same financial commitment, from the guy in the mail room to a senior executive," said Ken Green, a spokesman for Disney. "It was just believed to be the most equitable." **********Many compensation specialists have reached the same conclusion. They say the  slight benefit of full coverage to an executive earning hundreds of thousands of dollars or more doesn't justify risking a corporate black eye that even a spin doctor would have trouble treating. **********"In an atmosphere where companies are installing managed-care programs, cutting back on the benefits they are paying to everybody else, it would be indefensible to employees," said Don Sullivan, a Towers Perrin vice president. "Hey, how can we eat at Le Cirque when we're insisting on employees' going to McDonald's?" **********BUT some executives still prefer mignonettes de boeuf to Big Macs. "We look at competitive practices, and that's justification," said Albert Greenstein, a spokesman for Atlantic Richfield. In its 1995 proxy statement, the company, known as ARCO, reported that the cost of the executive medical plan the year before had been $8,554 for Mike R. Bowlin, the chief executive, and the same for each of the company's five other top managers. **********Even some companies that have adopted a uniform program for all employees slip in extras for top management, like thorough annual checkups that can cost $1,000 or more. Consolidated Edison, the giant New York City utility, abandoned  the most generous features of its executive plan years ago, but it still gives the bosses eyeglasses twice a year and lets them have private hospital rooms, with no limits on coverage. Unionized employees are reimbursed for a single pair of glasses every two years and shared rooms, with a lifetime maximum of $1 million, depending on their plan. **********executives beyond what other employees receive is a payment of up to $500 each for comprehensive annual checkups, plus as much as $500 for some specialized tests. **********At some companies, the health care largess heaped on senior executives knows  no bounds. W. R. Grace & Company spent $271,000 for what it called "private nursing and related expenses" for J. Peter Grace, the chief executive, in the two years before he retired at the end of 1992. It then doled out an additional  $351,000 in the next two years. **********The company's failure until last April, 10 days before Mr. Grace died, to disclose the costs of these and other perks, which included a private chef and the use of a company jet, has prompted a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation. The company said recently that the investigation remained open. **********Grace hasn't been the only company to pay five- or six-figure medical bills for current or former executives. Winn-Dixie paid $101,782 for A. D. Davis, a retired vice chairman, in 1994, the year before he died. Also in 1994, Aflac, an insurance company, paid medical expenses of $45,063 for Paul Amos, its chairman. **********But for most workers, frugality rules. A survey by the benefits and health care consulting company Foster Higgins showed that in 1995, 71 percent of employees with company health insurance belonged to managed-care plans, up from  48 percent in 1992. **********These programs limit costs by steering patients to doctors and hospitals that have agreed to fixed, usually discounted charges, and by forcing them to pay some or all of the bills if they go to health care providers outside the network. Partly as a result, corporate medical expenses fell by 1 percent in 1994, the first decline in a decade, and rose just 2.1 percent last year, less than the inflation rate. **********At the Charles Schwab Corporation, the drive for medical savings has spared top management. Senior executives, including Mr. Schwab, the founder and chairman, have supplemental coverage up to a limit that Tom Taggart, a company spokesman, declined to specify. **********Mr. Schwab hardly needs the cushion. Last year, the company lifted a $2.5 million cap on his compensation and awarded him a $7.8 million bonus, more than  tripling his total pay of the year before, to $8.6 million. But, the spokesman said, it's the principle of the thing. "They are executives," he said. "Executives get perks." **********Other employees' choices are limited to a health maintenance organization, which generally restricts them to member doctors and hospitals, and to other plans that expose them to thousands of dollars of expense unless they stick with providers in a Prudential network. Primary-care physicians, or PCP's, as a Schwab booklet calls them, also serve as cost cops who alone can open the doors  to the networks' specialists or hospitals. **********The Schwab health plan guide treats such restrictions as opportunities. "Look at how much you can save by using your PCP and other network physicians, rather  than non-network doctors," it declares. **********Open-ended health care opportunities for bosses became popular in the 1970's  and early 1980's as executives' salaries ballooned and their perks multiplied. "If you have five neurotic children, all with bad teeth, you have a real benefit," said Graef S. Crystal, an expert on executive compensation. Corporate  lobbyists turned back an attempt in the early 1980's to tax benefits that were not extended to other employees, although Congress did tighten the terms somewhat for making these benefits tax-free. **********Most companies are reluctant to discuss these perks. At RJR Nabisco Inc., the 1995 proxy statement tersely mentions supplemental health benefits for top executives. Linda Elkes, a spokeswoman, said that a plan covering executives' deductibles and co-payments was still in effect, but she would not provide further details. **********When it comes to employee health plans, however, the companies are downright  effusive. Gannett promotes its plan to employees as a smart investment. By using doctors and hospitals in the Communicare Choice network, an in-house brochure says, "You and Gannett spend health care dollars more effectively." **********The company steers employees toward this plan by holding maximum expenses for a family of three to $3,750 (not counting some co-payments) and imposing no deductibles. But for those who stray outside the Communicare network, the maximum nearly triples to $10,500, including a $1,500 deductible. **********GANNETT executives, however, enjoy more choice than Communicare Choice offers, and they exercise it under what the company's 1995 proxy statement calls a medical reimbursement plan. While the document lumps medical reimbursements with those for taxes on other perks, it reported that in 1994 Gannett paid John  J. Curley, the chief executive, $14,737; Douglas H. McCorkindale $19,681; Gary L. Watson, the president of the newspaper division, $16,878, and Thomas Curley,  the publisher of USA Today, who is not related to the chief executive, $5,760. **********Mr. McCorkindale said that senior executives often used doctors recommended to them when the company moved its headquarters to Arlington, Va., from Rochester in 1985, and that many of these doctors became part of the Communicare network. So, while top executives see some of the same doctors as their underlings, these executives have more flexibility to go outside the network. **********Mr. McCorkindale and Thomas Curley said they did not know the details of their health coverage or how much of the amounts listed on the proxy statement were for medical costs. Mr. McCorkindale referred further questions to Richard L. Clapp, a senior vice president responsible for benefits. Mr. Clapp declined to comment. **********Mr. Watson and John Curley did not return calls seeking comment.  Thomas Curley said that the management health plan appeared to give him more latitude to choose doctors outside the network without paying more. **********"I think we have more flexibility," he said, adding that his own doctor turned out to be in the Communicare network. **********For top executives, he said, heavier duties justify greater privileges. "You  may have some entitlements that go beyond" what employees receive, he said, "but we're still responsible for bringing in the revenue and making the profits."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/13/world.body_text: **********Former President Lech Walesa, who says money problems drove him back to his old job at the Gdansk shipyard, may finally be granted a pension by the Polish Government. **********The Parliament today voted for a pension law that would give him and future  presidents a pension of $2,600 a month, plus $1,600 a month to run their offices. Average monthly pay in Poland is about $350. Mr. Walesa's salary at the shipyard is $260.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/25/busin.main_headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Texas Drought Sends Cotton Up As Wheat and Copper Decline
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/25/busin.print_headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Texas Drought Sends Cotton Up As Wheat and Copper Decline
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/25/busin.body_text: **********Cotton futures prices rose yesterday on concerns that a drought in West Texas, where almost 20 percent of the American crop is grown, could cut production. **********Rainfall in the Texas highlands surrounding Lubbock has been less than two inches since October, according to the Weather Services Corporation, compared with more than seven inches normally. **********This is one of their worst droughts ever,"said Dave Taylor, meteorologist with Weather Services in Lexington, Mass., **********In other futures markets, wheat and copper fell. **********While farmers have planted cotton successfully up until July 1, heavy rains are needed soon, or as much as 10 percent of the 15 million acres planted with cotton this year could be lost, traders said. **********Peter Egli, vice president with Volkhart International in Phoenix, said: "They need three, four, five inches of rain. Half an inch won't do it." **********Cotton for July delivery rose 0.96 cent, to 82.55 cents a pound, at the New York Cotton Exchange. **********Mr. Egli said that cotton fields in other parts of the country were in excellent condition. "Don't write off Texas yet," he added. "And even if we lose that acreage, the rest of the nation is looking so good that we might make it up through higher yields." **********Wheat prices fell as the hot, dry weather in Texas and Oklahoma allowed farmers to press ahead with the hard red winter wheat harvest. **********As of Sunday, the Texas wheat harvest was in its early stages with only 2 percent complete, although beneficial weather this week has allowed combines to  roll. With wheat prices reaching record levels this year, farmers are eager to sell what is left of their drought-damaged crop quickly, traders said. **********"These prices are great," said Steve Freed, research director at ADM Investor Services in Chicago, adding that as much as 80 percent of the wheat being harvested now would be sold immediately. **********Hard red winter wheat for July delivery, the variety grown in the Plains and  used for bread, fell 15.25 cents, to $6.275 a bushel, on the Kansas City Board of Trade, the lowest in more than a month. **********Copper sank as rising stockpiles in London Metal Exchange warehouse stockpiles signaled weaker demand from European manufacturers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/20/world.main_headline: Lawyer Says Defending A Bosnia Serb Is No Easy Job
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/20/world.print_headline: Lawyer Says Defending A Bosnia Serb Is No Easy Job
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/20/world.body_text: **********There may be few jobs less appealing than defending one of Bosnia's suspected war criminals. Yet representing Dusan Tadic, the first man to be tried by a new  international tribunal here, is a distinguished Dutch law professor who could be doing far more lucrative work. **********Michail Wladimiroff, 51, also a partner in a high-powered law firm in The Hague, usually defends large companies involved in tax or environmental disputes, charging hefty fees. But he has spent much of the past year in the mountains of northern Bosnia, searching for evidence and witnesses. The indictment of the United Nations tribunal for the former Yugoslavia says that his client, a Bosnian Serb, killed, beat and mutilated Muslims in 1992 at the start of the Serbian onslaught. **********By the standards of his firm, Wladimiroff and Spong, he is paid very modestly by the tribunal. Mr. Wladimiroff has called his work here, thousands of miles from the scene of the crime, frustrating and difficult. **********So why did Mr. Wladimiroff agree to take on such an unpopular case?  "This is an historical trial," he said in an interview. "This is the first case that involves discussing a new body of international law. For a jurist, being part of this process is extremely fascinating." **********While the war crimes tribunal at The Hague follows in the footsteps of the trials at Nuremberg and Tokyo after World War II, there are many differences. New conventions and treaties on the rules of war have since been developed and widely accepted. But those new laws have never been applied to individuals in an international court. **********Mr. Wladimiroff said the tribunal asked him to take on the defense when Mr. Tadic arrived in The Hague in April 1995 from a German prison. "His German lawyer did not want to handle the case," Mr. Wladimiroff said. **********The son of Russian parents who fled Communism, he speaks Russian, which helps him understand his client's Serbo-Croatian. But more to the point, as a board member of several Dutch lawyers' associations, he had previously helped the tribunal draw up rules for its relations with defense lawyers. "I guess the tribunal remembered my name," he said. **********As so much else that was touched by the brutal conflict in Bosnia, matters did not work out as originally expected. "The tribunal thought the case would be a matter of three months," Mr. Wladimiroff recalled. But it has already taken more than a year and the trial, which began on May 7, is expected to last months. **********For prosecutors, hunting down those accused of atrocities has been very difficult, and the tribunal has complained of a shortage of money and a lack of  cooperation from NATO forces in the field. "The defense has been even more handicapped," Mr. Wladimiroff said. "Countries other than former Yugoslavia are  cooperating well with the prosecution, but not with the defense," he said. **********He and members of his team have already made seven trips to Bosnia, mainly to the Prijedor region where Mr. Tadic lived. It was the scene of some of the worst atrocities and the most notorious Serbian-run detention camps for Muslim civilians. The lawyer said he will prove that his client was not involved. **********Most difficult, he said, has been finding witnesses and getting them to talk. The prosecution has announced it will call more than 80 witnesses, the defense says it will have 36, of whom 16 will tesify by satellite. Conditions for the two sides are very unequal, Mr. Wladimiroff said, because all of the prosecution's witnesses are outside Bosnia, but all the defense witnesses are in the Serbian part of Bosnia. **********"There authorities blocked not only the investigation by the prosecution, but also by the defense," he said. "People could not or would not talk to us." People were afraid they too would face war crime charges or they feared the local bosses, he added, because to the local authorities, any cooperation, even  in defense of Bosnian Serbs would mean recognizing the tribunal. **********The tribunal's rules are a hybrid of Anglo-Saxon common law and of the Napoleonic code, which is widely used in Europe. The defense team is also a mix: Mr. Wladimiroff is assisted by Alphons Orie, a Dutch colleague from his own law  firm and by Steven Kay, a British barrister, who resigned from his job as Secretary of the Criminal Bar Association in Britain to come to The Hague. Their goal, the lawyer has insisted over and over again, is to secure a fair trial, despite all the limitations. "This tribunal has not been established to satisfy  only the victims but to bring justice to all, including the accused," he told the court in his opening statement. **********With respected legal scholars as judges, prosecutors and defense counsels, Mr. Tadic's chances for a fair trial would seem strong. Yet Mr. Wladimiroff said he had serious misgivings and as the trial opened he told the court he doubted that a fair trial was possible at all. **********He said the great suffering of the war had made the need for revenge and for  finding a scapegoat very pervasive, and, he added, victims' recollections are inevitably tainted by deep emotion, by hearsay and by extensive news coverage of the war. **********Besides, he said, the tribunal's legal procedures are still plagued by "novelties that are yet to be sorted out." Even though the trial is now under way, the court still needs to establish exactly what evidence will be admitted.  Both defense and prosecution, he said, have asked the judges to define more precisely what constitutes an offense. It would be wrong to use his defendent as a guinea pig, the lawyer said. **********He told the court, "This is the first case which the tribunal has to try, but the experiment should not be conducted at the expense of the defendent." In the  interview, Mr. Wladimiroff went further: "This is not a normal court, but if accepted standards of fairness are violated, we will file for a mistrial."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/30/busin.body_text: **********Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that its Southern Progress Corporation unit had bought Weight Watchers magazine from the H. J. Heinz Company. The price was  not disclosed. Southern Progress will not be involved with the Weight Watchers weight-loss centers or with other operations of Weight Watchers International. Nor will it be involved with the Weight Watchers Food Company, another Heinz unit. Weight Watchers magazine has a circulation of one million and readership of five million. It has editions for North America, Italy, Australia and Britain.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/03/world.main_headline: Elliot Lake Journal;Snug Retiree Haven Where Uranium Mine Stood
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/03/world.print_headline: Elliot Lake Journal;Snug Retiree Haven Where Uranium Mine Stood
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/03/world.body_text: **********Uranium miners' children used to kick soccer balls and ride two- and three-wheelers around the garden plots where Eileen Porter, 83, and Ingeborg Boone, 57, now tend the fresh plantings of their carrots, beans, peppers, strawberries and rhubarb. **********The women are neighbors in the eight-story apartment house out back, built some four decades ago for miners in what was then known as the uranium capital of the world. **********Most of the miners have long gone. The town, on the site of an old Ojibwa village, owes its existence to the postwar uranium boom. Yet today it has only half of the 25,000 residents it had in the late 1950's. **********Reduced military demand, nagging problems with nuclear-generated electrical power and cheaper uranium extraction elsewhere, like Saskatchewan, have resulted in the shutdown of all but one Elliot Lake pit. And that last one, the Stanleigh mine, will deliver up its final ton of rock in June, throwing 600 people out of  work. **********But as one chapter closes for this isolated community in the southern reaches of the Canadian Shield, a rocky, forested area that makes up much of the nation, a new one has already opened. Mrs. Porter and Mrs. Boone are among the 4,000 people who in the last half-dozen years have given Elliot Lake a new feather in  its cap as the "Retirement Living Capital" of Canada. **********The retirees and their spouses, mainly from southern Ontario, have been drawn by the low-cost apartments and houses vacated by the miners, the scenic views and the prospect of easy, comfortable, even stimulating small-town living. **********The uranium bust set the conditions for the town's rebirth. The mining companies built thousands of homes for miners they never hired. To cut losses -- for example from real estate taxes owed even if nobody lived there -- the companies decided to tear the homes down. **********But municipal leaders and one of the company vice presidents, Claire Dimock,  66, who retired here herself, had another idea. They obtained seed money for a nonprofit company that bought up the houses from the companies, made needed improvements and began marketing the properties as a retirement getaway. **********"We made an industry of the seniors," recalled Ms. Dimock, who added that their stable incomes "strengthened the local economy." **********The tax base was restored. New businesses were started, some even by the retirees themselves, like a craft shop, a fish and chips shop and a tea room. "We're now investing in our infrastructure," said Dianna Bratina, the town's economic development officer. "Telecommunications, roads, various things that mean more business." **********Auto dealers like the three-term Mayor, George Farkouh, 48, who runs the Chrysler distributorship, and his brother, Fawzi, 60, who owns the General Motors franchise, say business has never been better. "We crashed in 1990 but have been coming back ever since," the Mayor said. **********Although uranium has been mined in the area for years, city officials insist  that radioactivity registers no higher here than in Toronto or New York. Residents say it has never concerned them. The mining companies, with the Government looking hard over their shoulders, disposed of the mine wastes in a lake, to which access is barred. **********Mrs. Porter was born in Vancouver, married her husband, Newton, an Anglican clergyman who has since died, in England, and lived in Ontario and Quebec for years before finally settling in a two-bedroom apartment with her three cats. She has three children but prefers to live independently. Her rent is $348 a month. "It would be easily three or four times that in Toronto," she said, smoothing the soil around her beans. **********Mrs. Boone was born in Berlin, worked as a banking supervisor in Toronto and  moved up here with her husband, Fred, a former railroad maintenance worker, whose hip ailment kept him out of the garden. They live in a two-bedroom unit for the same $348 monthly rent. Fifteen minutes away they fish for brown and speckled trout. **********In spring and summer the green is spectacular, but winters are cruel and uniformly white. Temperatures drop well below zero, and snow is heavy. Yet many  of the residents say they love winters as much as summers. **********Henry Shapiro, 88, was born in Brooklyn and moved here with his wife, Dorothy, 79, only last November. **********"We decided if we could last out the winter we'd stay, and it really wasn't too difficult for us," he said. Neither drives. They took the bus everywhere, paying $10 for a three-month pass. **********One negative is the prevalence of black flies in the summer. But residents slough this off as a minor inconvenience. "Black flies, you've got those everywhere," said Maye Conway, 64, a retired General Motors worker from Oshawa,  near Toronto. "They're little itty-bitty things, mostly around the woods and in the swampy areas. They don't bother us." **********She and her friend Diana Richardson, 56, a photographer, have just paid $77,000 for a three-bedroom split-level that in the Toronto area would cost more than $200,000. **********For recreation, people meet at a former union hall now called the Renaissance Center, where activities include shuffleboard, line-dancing and tai chi. As half of the residents are single, romance is often in the air. **********"This is the second wind you hear," wrote Basil Jesshope, 74, a retired government economist, in a poem he prepared for his Elliot Lake creative writing class. "Its softened whisper lessens fear."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/10/busin.main_headline: Gruntal Agrees To Fraud Fine As U.S. Indicts Former Official
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/10/busin.print_headline: Gruntal Agrees To Fraud Fine As U.S. Indicts Former Official
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/10/busin.body_text: **********A former senior executive at Gruntal & Company, the brokerage firm, was indicted yesterday in the latest charges to come out of an embezzlement scandal  that has already led to guilty pleas by two other former Gruntal employees. **********As part of the investigation, Gruntal agreed yesterday to pay $6.2 million in fines and $5.5 million in customer restitution. The fines are among the biggest  ever paid on Wall Street. **********Edward Bao, who was executive vice president at Gruntal until December 1994  and a director, was indicted by a Federal grand jury in Manhattan as part of a continuing investigation into an embezzlement scheme that prosecutors said had eluded auditors and regulators for more than 10 years. **********"It's safe to say that we plan to contest these charges," Steven Reiss, a lawyer who represents Mr. Bao, said. "These allegations took place a long time ago. And nothing in there says that Mr. Bao profited personally." **********As part of the same investigation, Gruntal agreed to the fines and restitution to resolve investigations by the Securities and Exchange Commission, New York Stock Exchange and National Association of Securities Dealers. **********"It's a disturbing set of events that occurred here over a period of time," said Robert P. Rittereiser, Gruntal's president and chief executive. "I'm sorry  that it happened. But we're dealing with these issues and we hope to move the company along." The company, which handles trading for individual accounts and institutions, has 29 offices. **********What is amazing about the Gruntal scandal, prosecutors said, is how the participants eluded Federal regulators for 10 years. According to Mary Jo White, the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, Mr. Bao, along with Charles Meizoso, Gruntal's director of operations; Waseem Ahmad, the company's cashier, and Eugene McCloskey, the firm's internal audit manager,  began an elaborate scheme to embezzle money in July 1984 and continued until Mr. Ahmed died of a heart attack in October 1994. **********"The setup was really impressive," said Thomas C. Newkirk, associate director, division of enforcement for the S.E.C. "There was little chance of them getting caught. Everyone involved with the scam were the same people charged with guarding the hen house, so to speak." **********According to the indictment filed yesterday, Mr. Bao and his colleagues diverted unclaimed customer dividends, dividend overages, and uncashed customer  or vendor checks into Gruntal accounts. To hide these transactions, the three routinely transferred money into fictitious accounts. After it was safely hidden, the money was either used to pay the company's expenses, thereby increasing Gruntal's profits. **********According to the S.E.C., the group managed to steal $14 million. Mr. Meizoso  and Mr. McCloskey were accused of stealing $6 million personally, the agency said. On top of that, Mr. Ahmed stole $3 million more. **********The scheme, which had apparently worked smoothly for 10 years, finally ran amok when Mr. Ahmed died in October 1994. According to prosecutors, the company  called in an outside auditor, prompting Mr. Meizoso and Mr. McCloskey to flee to Ireland. Gruntal officials discovered the embezzlement and contacted the S.E.C., the New York Stock Exchange and the United States Attorney's Office. **********On Aug. 11, 1995, Mr. Meizoso and Mr. McCloskey pleaded guilty to two charges of conspiracy: one to divert more than $5 million of funds and property under Gruntal's custody and control and another to embezzle $5 million in funds and property. Both men face a maximum sentence on each count of five years in prison and a fine of $250,000. **********If convicted, Mr. Bao faces a maximum sentence of five years in prison and a  fine of $250,000. **********Even should the scandal be resolved, it will not be business as usual at Gruntal for some time. Some of the $6.2 million in fines is going to settle other improprieties in the firm's trading and managed account divisions. **********The National Association of Securities Dealers fined Gruntal $250,000 yesterday for trading ahead of its customers' limit orders, late reporting of trades and lack of supervision in this area. And the S.E.C. fined Gruntal $1 million yesterday for several infractions since 1993, including billing its fee-only customers a commission. As restitution for these offenses, Gruntal was  ordered to hire an independent consultant to look into these businesses and identify customers who may have lost money. **********Indeed, Gruntal is no stranger to controversy. In December 1994, Gruntal's former head of fixed income filed a wrongful dismissal suit against Howard Silverman, the firm's former chief executive, accusing him of bilking retail customers by having his own traders buy municipal bonds at less than market cost, then sell them to Mr. Silverman and Barry Richter, a Gruntal executive vice president. At the time, Gruntal spokesman said the allegations were without merit.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/05/busin.snippet: Television Production Partners, a consortium of 10 giant advertisers that was formed in 1992 to produce programming for members to sponsor, has been disbanded, though its efforts may continue on ad hoc basis (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/05/busin.body_text: **********Television Production Partners, a consortium of 10 giant advertisers that was formed in 1992 to produce programming for members to sponsor, has been disbanded, though its efforts may continue on an ad hoc basis. **********''We found that it involved taking more risks than was palatable with very uncertain long-term returns,'' said Jack Myers, chairman and chief executive of the consortium, which produced several programs including an award-winning documentary, ''Hank Aaron: Chasing the Dream.'' The problems, he added, included ratings, costs and the time periods available for the programs. **********Some of the consortium's efforts may continue under the aegis of Myers Communications, a consulting company in Parsippany, N.J., where Mr. Myers is chairman; those include a series of television movies that the consortium was to produce with the Paramount Television unit of Viacom Inc. for the Fox Broadcasting Company division of the News Corporation. There is ''also a potential opportunity,'' Mr. Myers said, to work with the agencies that handle the accounts of the consortium's members. **********The consortium was founded by the AT&T Corporation, the Campbell Soup Company, the Clorox Company, the Coca-Cola Company, the Adolph Coors Company, the General Motors Corporation, Mastercard International, the McDonald's Corporation, Reebok International Ltd. and Sears, Roebuck & Company. **********At the same time some advertisers withdraw from program production, others are moving to embrace it further. For instance, the American Honda Motor Company is producing comedy and game shows along with partners that include Rubin Postaer & Associates in Santa Monica, Calif., the agency for Honda vehicles. And the Procter & Gamble Company helped Paramount Television to develop two fall series for the ABC-TV network owned by the Walt Disney  Company.
