https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/17/busin.snippet: From Wall Street to board rooms around the country, business executives praise Bob Dole for displaying energy, decisiveness and even youthfulness in his speech accepting Republican Presidential nomination; but many question whether his economic pr...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/17/busin.main_headline: Dole's Speech Wins Praise Of Executives
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/17/busin.print_headline: Dole's Speech Wins Praise Of Executives
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/17/busin.body_text: **********From Wall Street to board rooms around the country, business executives praised Bob Dole yesterday for displaying energy, decisiveness and even youthfulness in his speech accepting the Republican Presidential nomination. But many questioned whether his economic program could work. **********''Given the concerns about his age, I think one of the enduring impressions will be the energy level and intensity that he brought to the speech,'' said Peter Peterson, chairman of the Blackstone Group, an investment banking firm, and a former Commerce Secretary in the Nixon Administration. ''That will be very reassuring to the public.'' **********The Dole tax cut proposals drew high marks from most of the executives -- just the tonic needed, they said, to bring the economy to a higher level of growth than it has been able to achieve during President Clinton's tenure. But most of the bottom-line-oriented executives saw balancing the budget as equally important and wondered whether a Dole Administration -- or any Administration -- could manage the necessary spending cuts to offset those tax reductions. **********''He has captured the spirit of much of the country in saying that we have to have a less intrusive Government,'' said Joseph T. Gorman, chief executive of TRW Inc., a large and diverse manufacturing company based in Cleveland. But ''if Dole's not going to change Medicare, Medicaid or Social Security,'' he added, ''then it is going to be very difficult to find the spending cuts.'' **********Mr. Dole's convention speech on Thursday in San Diego included a call for support of his economic plan, which was first announced on Aug. 5. The main proposals -- lower income and capital-gains taxes, less regulation of business and a balanced budget by 2002 -- have drawn relatively little public comment from the nation's chief executives over the last two weeks. **********On Wall Street, there was concern that the tax cuts could be inflationary if they were not offset by spending reductions. **********''Right now we are close to full employment in a strong economy,'' said Henry Kaufman, chairman of Henry Kaufman & Company, a money management firm, ''And,'' he added, ''if you cut taxes you run the risk of overheating the economy with too much stimulus, bringing on inflation. That concerns the financial markets.'' **********Mr. Peterson has been arguing for years that spending programs for the elderly must be restrained to avoid a ballooning of the Federal deficit to crisis levels when the baby-boom generation retires in the next century. Mr. Dole promised not to change these programs before 2002, Mr. Peterson noted, ''but I hope the Republicans don't say anything that would tie their hands on entitlement reform after that date.'' **********Others, like Sanford Robertson, president of Robertson, Stephens & Company, a San Francisco-based investment bank that is a major backer of several Silicon Valley enterprises, praised Mr. Dole for promising to lower the capital-gains tax. ''I wouldn't be surprised if the Democrats respond with something similar,'' said Mr. Robertson, a lifelong Republican who supported Mr. Clinton in 1992 and still backs the President. He complained, however, that Mr. Dole's program harked ''back to the Reagan era, a little bit more of the 'trickle-down' stuff,'' adding, ''I don't think there's any great inspiration there.'' **********T. J. Rodgers, the outspoken chief executive of the Cypress Semiconductor Corporation, a major chip maker in San Jose, Calif., said Mr. Dole's best move was to name Jack Kemp as his running mate. ''They're going to cut taxes and give money back to the American people,'' he said. ''Kemp is going to be the spark plug of this campaign.'' **********Whatever their political leanings, corporate executives were encouraged that Mr. Dole had put the issue of economic growth at the top of the nation's agenda. Several business leaders have been arguing that the right policies could foster a greater output of the economy without higher inflation than the 2.5 percent growth rate now considered the upper limit by many economists. **********Stanley C. Gault, the recently retired chairman of Goodyear Tire and Rubber, praised Mr. Dole for offering policies that Mr. Gault said would promote more growth than the Clinton Administration has considered possible. ''Dole has taken a bold move, one that he and his people have been thinking about and analyzing for many months,'' Mr. Gault said in an interview after Mr. Dole outlined his economic program but before the speech. **********And not everybody on Wall Street is spooked by faster growth. **********''I fall into the growth camp,'' said Elizabeth R. Bramwell, president of Bramwell Capital Management Inc., a money management firm, insisting that Mr. Dole's tax cut proposals are the right avenue to lifting the economy. **********For Tracy O'Rourke, chairman of Varian Associates, a health care and semiconductor equipment company, Bob Dole has upstaged Bill Clinton on the economy. ''Clinton's policies have locked us into a 2 percent to 2.5 percent growth rate,'' said Mr. O'Rourke, a Republican. ''The key thing about the Dole growth plan is that it is a balance of cutting taxes, reducing the regulatory burden and trying to balance the budget.'' **********But many of the executives expressed concern, before and after Mr. Dole's speech Thursday night, that his proposed spending cuts were too vague, and his goal of balancing the budget might be undermined, not only by leaving Social Security and Medicare untouched, but by increasing military spending, as Mr. Dole said he would do. **********''His tax cuts are viable and good,'' said Douglas Durst, who heads the Durst Organization, a New York real estate developer. ''But I don't see any reason to increase defense spending. What enemy do we have that we need a large army to fight against?'' **********Social issues steer Roger McNamee, general partner of Integral Capital Partners, a venture capital firm, away from the Republican camp. ''I have a really hard time reconciling Bob Dole the individual with the increasingly extreme social program of the Republican Party,'' Mr. McNamee, a Democrat, said. ''As appealing as the words are that Bob Dole uses to describe his economic program, that meat comes in the wrong sandwich bread.'' **********For Paul O'Neill, chairman of the Aluminum Corporation of America, neither Democratic nor Republican economic proposals offer the central reason for selecting one candidate over the other. ''Three years from now, you don't know what events will be on the table,'' he said. ''Therefore my vote will go to the candidate I trust and that is Mr. Dole. Trust is the issue.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/30/world.main_headline: U.N., Pressing for Restraint, Delays Its Action on Burundi
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/30/world.print_headline: U.N., Pressing for Restraint, Delays Its Action on Burundi
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/30/world.body_text: **********After weeks of warnings from Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali and relief agencies that Burundi was on the brink of a civil war, the Security Council passed a resolution today calling for restraint, reconciliation and the  rule of law. But it put off any international action on the crisis until late next month at the earliest. **********The lack of movement in the Security Council in part reflects the unwillingness of any major power to take the lead in pushing for a stronger measures. At the same time, the delay is providing Burundi's military leaders time to harden their position against outside involvement, threatening to erode  what leverage the United Nations may have there. **********Burundi's envoy to the United Nations, Nsanze Terence, tried today to derail voting on the resolution by objecting to wording that leaves open the possibility of a future arms embargo and sanctions "against those leaders in Burundi who continue to encourage violence." His unusual interruption was ruled  out of order by this month's Council president, Sir John Weston of Britain. **********"It is important that Burundians take the message seriously," said Botswana's representative, Legwaila J. Legwaila, asking that sanctions be considered sooner rather than later. **********But unable to agree on any formula for immediate action in a country that Madeleine K. Albright, the United States representative, has described as teetering "on the verge of national suicide," the Security Council asked Mr. Boutros-Ghali to study possible preventive measures and report back on Feb. 20. **********Led by the United States, the Council had earlier rejected the Secretary General's suggestions that a quick-reaction force be stationed on Burundi's borders although it is still considering his proposal that United Nations guards be deployed in the country to protect international relief operations. **********Mr. Boutros-Ghali is also being asked to encourage talks between between rival factions in Burundi, with the help of African leaders and the organization of African Unity. Diplomats hope that Julius Nyerere, a former President of neighboring Tanzania, who has been drawn into talks on Burundi, will take a larger role in mediating a solution. Only if diplomacy fails will sanctions be discussed. **********The response of the Council has redoubled pleas for action from international relief organizations caring for thousands of refugees and displaced people in Burundi, many from neighboring Rwanda, where similar tensions between a Hutu majority and a Tutsi minority led to a slaughter of hundreds of thousands of Tutsi and moderate Hutu in 1994. **********"The lack of leadership by any major member of the Council to move real-time  solutions forward is extremely distressing," said Lionel Rosenblatt, president of Refugees International and a founder of the year-old Burundi Policy Forum, an umbrella group of concerned organizations. **********"We seem not to have learned the lesson of Kigali in the spring of 1994," he  said in an interview today, referring to the massacres in the Rwandan capital. "We have before us that graphic example of what happens when you wait." **********Mr. Rosenblatt said that his group has recommended protection for Burundi's embattled civilian President, Sylvestre Ntibantunganya, a Hutu, who appealed for help on a visit to Washington in October. The Burundi President, whose two predecessors were assassinated, is believed to be a possible target of soldiers  in the Tutsi-led army as well as Hutu guerrillas battling the military. **********Life in Burundi's capital, Bujumbura, has been sharply curtailed by violence, some of it politically inspired terrorism, some common criminality. In the countryside, thousands have been killed in attacks on towns and camps. At least  115 international relief workers are reported to have lost their lives since 1992. **********In a letter to President Clinton on Jan. 19, InterAction, an association of American private voluntary organizations, said that recent assaults on aid workers in Burundi seemed designed to "force the departure of foreigners whose presence inhibits ethnic violence." **********"After World War II, the international community committed itself to seeing that genocide never again disgraced the human race," Andrew Natsios, a former United States Government emergency aid coordinator in Africa, wrote on behalf of InterAction. Referring to the massacres of civilians in Bosnia and Rwanda, Mr. Natsios said: "Some could credibly claim to have been caught by surprise. No responsible figure will be able to feign surprise if genocide erupts in Burundi." **********Mrs. Albright, who recently returned from a visit to Burundi, Rwanda, Liberia and Angola, said that the Clinton Administration is prepared to assist in transporting an international force or equipment to Africa, but would not be prepared to send American troops. **********The French, who sent their own force to Rwanda in reaction to the massacres there in 1994, say they do not want to be alone in the field again this time. They are accused by other diplomats and some United States officials of deliberately stalling United Nations action while keeping their own options open. **********The European Union will meet soon to begin framing a common policy on Burundi and appoint a special representative to the country.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/08/world.main_headline: Quebec's Premier Softens His Stance on Independence
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/08/world.print_headline: Quebec's Premier Softens His Stance on Independence
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/08/world.body_text: **********He has stopped his furious assaults on the federal Government and hardly mentions Quebec independence. Instead, Premier Lucien Bouchard now speaks of the "shared values" of French- and English-speakers and quotes the Quebec-born, English-language writer Joyce Marshall, who said it is "the rub and bite of difference that keeps us alert and alive." **********On the night of Oct. 30, after the separatists narrowly lost the independence referendum, Mr. Bouchard suggested that another vote could come as early as 1996. Now, he tells Quebecers, he will call one only when he is sure of winning  and in any case not before the next provincial election, which must come before  September 1999. **********Premier for the last 10 weeks, Mr. Bouchard, who galvanized the referendum campaign with his stirring vision of Quebec as a proud new country, is now concentrating on trying to rehabilitate a province with Canada's highest unemployment (more than 11 percent) and widest budget deficit ($2.9 billion). **********The shift seems to have been welcomed in the province and the rest of the country, giving time to heal fractures from the referendum and perhaps to germinate fresh proposals for keeping Canada together. **********Although recent opinion polls indicate that many Quebecers think separatism is inevitable, more than twice as many say they prefer a new arrangement within  Canada than say they would like the province to go its own way. **********In any event, pollsters say, the last thing Quebecers now want is a new referendum. "We have gone to the ballot box four times in the past four years, and people are tired of all the politicking," said Jean-Marc Leger, president of Groupe Leger & Leger of Montreal. "Our first priority is economic recovery, and  Mr. Bouchard, who still has a tremendous reserve of popularity in the province,  recognizes this." **********The business community, most of whose members oppose separation, also welcomes the respite. "Since the arrival of Mr. Bouchard and his government," said Ghislain Dufour, head of the Quebec big-business organization known as the  Conseil du Patronat, "all the efforts of the government have been devoted to the expenses of the government, the creation of jobs, and that's the kind of speech  that pleases us." **********Is this Bouchard II? the Premier was asked in a recent interview. "It might be a different angle of myself that people are seeing now," Mr. Bouchard replied. "I am a frugal man. I was brought up in a modest family where everything was paid for in cash. My father would never, never borrow money." **********Mr. Bouchard, 57, sat at a conference table dunking chocolate chip cookies into a coffee mug in an office complex, jocularly known as the "bunker," across the street from the Quebec legislature. **********He has refused to take the opulent mansion at 1080 Avenue des Braves that briefly served as the official residence of his predecessor, Jacques Parizeau, who resigned after a diatribe against "money and the ethnic vote" on the night of the referendum. **********The Premier, who has returned his $10,500 annual housing allowance to the treasury, usually spends weekday nights in a specially fitted bedroom in the "bunker," and weekends at the family home in the Montreal suburb of Outremont, with his American-born wife, Audrey Best, and their two young sons. **********His frugal side has come out as well with the government's plans, announced last month, to cut $750 million from spending in the current fiscal year. Schools, hospitals, welfare recipients and civil servants are on the block. The  government also said it will close 13 of its 19 foreign delegations. Only Quebec offices in New York City, Mexico City, Tokyo, Paris, London and Brussels are to  remain open. **********After meeting with business and labor leaders, Mr. Bouchard now has a target  year -- 2000 -- for achieving a balanced budget. **********While the government-union-business consensus could prove fragile, the threat of a downgrade from credit-rating agencies, which would raise the cost of Quebec's borrowed money and further strain the economy, may keep the accord intact. **********But if the Bouchard timetable for budget balancing is firm, nothing is fixed  about a new referendum. "My terms are fluid ones," he said in the interview. "But they are stemming from very material restraints. First I would like to launch a new era of financial and economic responsibility and prosperity for Quebec." **********Mr. Bouchard said that while his "fundamental priority" remains sovereignty,  his long-term one is the economy. "This government should be more active in business and the economy and not talk so much about sovereignty first hand -- if there is a question, O.K., you answer the question -- but let's talk business. Business is the best way to forge binds." **********Although Mr. Bouchard is by far the most popular politician in the country, with a favorable rating exceeding 70 percent, the highest for any Quebec leader  in 50 years, words like that hardly endear him to the faithful of the Parti Quebecois, which has carried the separatist banner for the last three decades and would probably implode if deprived of its central ideological drive. **********"Many hard-liners don't trust him," said Guy Laforest, political scientist and separatist at Laval University in Quebec. "Remember six years ago this fellow was a member of the Federal Cabinet." **********Mr. Bouchard, who had been a friend and Laval law school classmate of former  Progressive Conservative Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, broke with Mr. Mulroney  and the Tories over Quebec strategy in 1987. Mr. Bouchard then formed the Bloc Quebecois, a political party representing sovereignty supporters in Ottawa. He came from the Bloc, now Canada's second largest political party after the governing Liberals, to head the provincial government. **********If supporters may be uneasy, so are some members of the English-speaking minority in Quebec. **********"Where's our representation in the Cabinet?" asked Tom Velk, a McGill University economics professor, referring to the language law that promotes French at the expense of English. "The old Bouchard has just put on a new mask."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/16/world.print_headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Saudis Bar Some Africans As Health Risk to Mecca
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/16/world.body_text: **********Saudi Arabia has banned Muslims from four African countries from making this  year's pilgrimage to Mecca because of an outbreak of meningitis in Nigeria, Mali, Niger and Burkina Faso. **********Saudi Arabia's official news agency, in a report late Sunday, quoted a Health Ministry official as saying the decision was made on the basis of information provided by the World Health Organization. **********The ban is aimed at protecting 2 million Muslims expected to converge on Mecca month. The annual pilgrimage reaches a peak in the last week of April. **********Since January, there have been more meningitis cases reported in Africa than  in any year since 1989. Of nearly 74,000 cases and 9,000 deaths reported this year, more than 95 percent come from Burkina Faso, Mali, Niger and Nigeria.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/02/busin.main_headline: ECONOMIC SCENE/ Guest Commentary : In Global Arena, Euro Faces a Test of Strength
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/02/busin.print_headline: ECONOMIC SCENE/ Guest Commentary : In Global Arena, Euro Faces a Test of Strength
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/02/busin.body_text: **********It's no longer a question of whether European monetary union will happen, but whether the Euro will be a weak or strong currency. The Euro is likely to start out strong, but it will end up weak. **********How is that? When the Euro is finally born, central banks can cut their currency reserves because they will only need to keep a safe proportion of around 15 percent of foreign currency-denominated imports in the vaults. Because intra-European trade would be in Euros, at least for EMU countries, foreign-currency trade would shrink after the birth of the Euro. That reduces the amount of reserves that need to be held. **********Also, international demand for Euros could grow disproportionately. Big trading countries such as the United States and Japan tend to have a greater proportion of international reserves than their share of international trade. Because the new EMU area would be like a large trading country, the demand for Euros as a global transaction and reserve currency could rise. **********European bureaucrats and politicians want a strong Euro. The alternative of a weak Euro to achieve growth and jobs through devaluation is not really an option. A weak Euro would not work economically, either, because high interest rates would kill domestic growth, and export markets outside a large EMU area would be too small to compensate. **********But there are many reasons to doubt the Euro's long-term strength. No other currency in Europe matches the quality of the Deutsche mark. So substituting the Euro for it, which will include weaker currencies, is swapping good money for bad — unless the other member countries match Germany's economic management as a result of being in EMU. **********But that will not happen because monetary union fails to address some key issues — the size of government in Europe, the lack of an automatic financial transfer mechanism and the impact of diverging real exchange rates under a single currency. **********The job of shrinking the economic size of European governments has only just begun. European governments still swallow up a greater share of economic resources than those of the United States, Japan or the so-called Asian tigers. So budget stabilizations cannot stop with the Euro's creation. That will expose the real economic divergence within EMU-Europe, namely the difference between the mind-set that wants small government and that which tries to preserve le Grand Etat. **********EMU has another fatal flaw. It lacks an EU-level compensatory fiscal mechanism for regional disparities and curtails existing national ones, but it imposes a common exchange rate and monetary policy. Take the United States as a successful common-currency area. If California has a boom and Texas a recession, there are no political roars out of Texas to leave the monetary union, devalue, re-establish independent monetary and fiscal policy and go for growth. **********The first reason for this stoic endurance of recession in Texas is because of the automatic federal fiscal stabilizers that kick in to help Texas. In the United States, booming California pays its federal taxes, which get transferred to slumping Texas as employment benefits. In Europe, there is not, and will not be, any such mechanism. **********Second, the American union does not break up because the U.S. work force is mobile. It moves to where there is work. Such labor mobility is out of the question in Europe's culturally divided and rigid labor markets. **********A single European currency does not mean that the real exchange rate of Italy will equal that of Germany. The real exchange-rate value is the value of a country's currency after accounting for the relative inflation rates of a country's trading partners. Germany's real exchange rate will not vary much from its nominal one because the inflation impact of a weak Euro will be controlled culturally, and domestic inflation will stay low. That will not be so in Italy. Rising imports prices will get passed on much more in higher domestic prices and rising wage claims. So Italy's industrial competitiveness will be weakened. **********The answer would be for real wage rates to fall in the poor periphery of Europe. But politically that is explosive and probably only achievable with higher inflation. **********The result could be for social and political instability because of joblessness between regions and countries. A weak European Central Bank would be forced to follow a higher inflation policy to allow for changes in real wages. As this happened, the Euro would progressively weaken. **********World investors would seek to diversify out of the Euro into other sound currencies such as the yen and dollar. In Europe, the refuge currency would be the Swiss franc. But the Swiss franc cannot be pegged to the Euro any more than diamonds can be pinned to dirt. The world currency order will be reversed. The yen will re-emerge as the strongest, the Euro will be the weakest and the dollar will be a feeble currency in the middle. **********- **********Mr. Roche is global strategist at Independent Strategy Ltd., a London-based investment research firm.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/17/busin.main_headline: Supreme Court Deadlocks In Key Case on Software
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/17/busin.print_headline: Supreme Court Deadlocks In Key Case on Software
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/17/busin.body_text: **********A closely watched Supreme Court case that was expected to define the boundaries of copyright protection for computer software fizzled today as the eight Justices who heard the case last week deadlocked 4 to 4. **********As a result, the Court automatically affirmed a 1995 decision by the Federal  appeals court in Boston that the Lotus Development Corporation was not entitled  to copyright protection for the system of menus and commands used in its pioneering Lotus 1-2-3 spreadsheet program. **********The Court issued no opinion and set no precedent for future cases, leaving behind dashed expectations and a state of heightened uncertainty. As a legal matter, the effect was as if the Court had simply never agreed last September to hear Lotus's appeal of the ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the  First Circuit. The one difference is that the Court has now broadcast how deeply split it is. **********Lawyers knowledgeable about the software industry said today that the Court would almost certainly need to address the issue in a subsequent case, although  with technology having moved on, the copyright dispute will probably have a different focus than the "user interface" at issue in the six-year-old litigation between Lotus and Borland International Inc. **********Following the Court's practice when a case results in a tie vote, the Justices on either side were not identified. The missing Justice was John Paul Stevens, who earlier had taken himself out of the case for reasons he did not explain. **********Based on his most recent financial disclosure form, Justice Stevens does not  appear to own any stock that could be affected by the case, a common reason for  a Justice not to participate. He perhaps has a family connection to one of the several companies involved. Lotus was acquired last summer by I.B.M., and in 1994 Borland sold Quattro Pro, the spreadsheet program that was at issue in the  case, to Novell Inc. **********Henry B. Gutman, who argued the appeal for Lotus, said today that he and his  client were "disappointed both in the outcome and in the fact that the Supreme Court did not take an opportunity that would have clarified the law both for the lower courts and for the industry." **********Lotus sued Borland for copyright infringement in 1990, seeking $100 million in damages because the Quattro Pro program copied the system of menus and commands used in Lotus 1-2-3, thus letting users benefit from their hard-won expertise with operating the Lotus program rather than having to learn a new set of codes and keystrokes. **********To Lotus, this menu and command system, also known as the user interface, was a form of original expression falling squarely within the protection of the Copyright Act. Judge Robert E. Keeton of the United States District Court in Boston agreed in a 1993 decision, which Borland appealed. **********But to the appeals court, the command structure was not a form of expression  but a "method of operation," which is explicitly excluded from copyright protection under the law. One of the appeals court judges, Judge Michael Boudin, drew an analogy to the familiar QWERTY arrangement of keys on a typewriter keyboard. All typists "would be the captive of anyone who had a monopoly on the  production of such a keyboard" if copyright protection were available, Judge Boudin said. **********Esther Roditti, editor of Computer Law and Tax Report, said today that neither Congress nor judicial decisions had yet provided a workable definition of "method of operation" in the context of computer software. **********"I don't think anyone has a clear idea of what it means," she said in an interview. "There is no bright line." **********For that reason, Ms. Roditti said, cases exploring the "dichotomy between expression and ideas will inevitably come up again," with judges growing in sophistication as they encounter more such cases.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/21/your-.main_headline: Quick and Easy Money Transfers?Where There's a Wire, There's a Way
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/21/your-.print_headline: Quick and Easy Money Transfers?Where There's a Wire, There's a Way
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/21/your-.body_text: **********RUNNING LATE on that Christmas present? Need to send cash to another country for yourchild's travel plans? Or just plain ran out of cash in a foreign country and your credit cards are maxed out? **********The solution may lie in one of thebanking transactions most frequently used around the world: wire transfers, which seem to be increasingly popular with banks and customers alike. Along with that comes a variety of other ways of sending money via wire, including Western Union, its competitor MoneyGram and your credit union or other commercial outlets in the currency-exchange or wire-transfer business. **********For a variety of reasons, wire transfers handily beat checks. When postal strikes hit England last summer, for example, wire transfers were the way to go. They also eliminate the wait on checks clearing, since transfers arrive as cash.Generally, the transactions are quick and simple, typically taking one or two days for an overseas operation. **********Two areas of growth in wire transfers are between the United States and China and the United States and Mexico. In a new service started Nov. 20, a joint venture betweenKeyBank of Cleveland, Ohio, and ChinaWire Corp. began improved wire-transfer availability between China and the West Coast of the United States. **********Mexico has also grown as a market for immigrants to the United States who wire money back home, so the systems there are increasingly accustomed to handling such transfers. **********Although almost any amount of money can be transferred, there is a fee that varies depending onthe sending institution. Who pays the fee — the sender or the receiver — can also vary. **********Among the biggest wire transactions on record was Texaco Inc.'s 1988 transfer of $3 billion to Pennzoil Co. to settle a lawsuit in the United States over the disputed acquisition of Getty Oil Co. The money had to be sent in three chunks because the sum was too big for the banking system to handle. **********Banks around the world have the capacity to send and receive wire transfers. To do so, they have corresponding bank relationships with one another. Big banks can have thousands of these relationships around the world, so when arranging a transfer it is important to verify that the banks on each end are correspondents. This streamlines the operation byeliminating the need for a go-between bank. **********Understandably, banks are loath to give out information about specific accounts and transfers, unless of course they are yours, so it was hard to track down users of transfers to assess consumer satisfaction. **********But one New York bank customer, who recently was awaiting a several-hundred-dollar transfer from a British bank, recounted a string of mistakes and red tape that left him scrambling. **********First, the sending bank left out the account number. Then, the receiving bank did not inform the customer that the money was in a holding pattern, awaiting a follow-up response from the sending bank as to the account number. Finally, after several days of back-and-forth correspondence, the receiving bank credited the transfer to the customer's account. **********The anecdote shows that a transfer can only work if all the information is available. To properly process the operation, the sending bank needs to know the amount to be transferred and in what currency it is being sent and received; the recipient's name and account number; the receiving bank's name,address, and routing, or ABA, number; when the funds should be payable to the recipient's account, and who is to pay the transfer fee. If this informationis not in order, there can be a problem. **********Generally, once the wire is credited to the recipient's account, his or her bank sends a notice in the mail confirming receipt. Among the information on the form are the sending bank's branch and reference numbers. One such number includes the phrase SWIFT, which is a method of payment for transfers. These numbers can be used to sort out any eventual problems or discrepancies. **********ONE OF THE BIGGEST banks in the wire-transfer business is, naturally, also one of the biggest banks in the world, The Chase Manhattan Bank in New York. **********Patricia Boyce and Robert Blackburn,who are in charge of Chase's wire-transfer operations, described wire transfers as "painless." **********About 87 percent go straight through, automatically, but should there be problems, a staff of 50 people worksto fix them. Such miscues can include a wrong or missing account number, or even a missing name. In that case, the receiving bank has to contact the sending bank and find out what went wrong. **********The bank's wire-transfer operationis in a Chase officein New York City. It looks like a typical big office, with computers, work stations and dividers. Off to the side behind a glass panel is a control room of sorts that monitors a wider range of Chase transactions. **********Thousands of transfers move through Chase's system daily, and there are even more on the day after a holiday. The bank moves an average of$900 billion a day in wire transfers, with the average transfer ranging from $5 million to $6 million. **********The high average is due to the large number of corporate transactions, although many individual wire transfers of far smaller amounts also go through the Chase Manhattan wire-transfer system. **********As in most financial transactions, it pays to shop around and keep an eye on the fees. The KeyBank-ChinaWire venture, which first connected the Seattle area and 30,000 post offices and postal banks in China, allows for wires of up to $10,000 to be sent. Each transaction has a fee; for $100, the fee is $10 **********The service, which is faster than previous transfer methods to much of the Chinese market, is to be expanded on the U.S. end to other states and then will be aimed at other Asian countries, said the ChinaWire president, Gilles Struckor. **********"Our system is safe, reliable and simple to use for Chinese and English speakers alike," he said. "Our system is equipped to handle transfers of any size, from a few dollars to large corporate purchases and payrolls." **********The wire traffic between the United States and Mexico, estimated to be in the billions of dollars, has also given rise to competition between banks and MoneyGram and Western Union, giving consumers a choice of services and fees. **********For members of credit unions, such asthe United Nations Federal Credit Union, fees can be lower than at banks. They are $8 for domestic U.S. transfers and $17 for international transfers. Discounts are available on off-peak days. On the 5th, 10th, 20th and 25th days of the month, fees are $6 for domestic wires and $15 for international **********A RANGE OF FEE and service options are also available in Europe and Asia, depending on whether you use a bank or MoneyGram or Western Union. **********These two operators are owned by the same company, followingthe merger of First Data Corp. and First Financial Management Corp. But under a 1995 Federal Trade Commission consent decree, one of the services has to be divested. **********Both companies have thousands of locations worldwide for transfers, but unlike with banks, which send the money to an account, the receiving party must pick up the money at the receiving outlets. Fees range as high as 10 percent of the total amount. **********Many of the Western Union and MoneyGram offices around the world are in banks or American Express offices. **********MoneyGram used to be owned by American Express and its office in Estonia, for example, is in an American Express affiliate. And Western Union has three offices in Indonesia at branches of Bank Internasional Indonesia. **********One way to find out which banks offer which services overseas is to contact the U.S. Embassy in a given country. In Moscow, for example, the embassy has a list detailing which banks in Russia offer wire-transfer services. **********In most places around the world, and no matter which operator is used, wire transfers are available the same day or within one or two days. There may be exceptions, such as in a remote region of China, where even with the new KeyBank-ChinaWire service a transfer can take as long as three days to arrive. **********If all this is still too low-tech for you, do not fret. Chase Manhattan and other banks are working on taking wire transfers to the next logical step: In the near future, wire transfers will be available via the Internet. **********For information about ChinaWire, call 1 206 684 6475, or in the United States, 800 862 4462.Information also is available at KeyBank's web site: www.keybank.com. **********To view the U.S. Embassy's list of banks in Russia that offer wire transfers, access its web site at www.iep.doc.gov/bisnis/cables/cable.html. **********Information about MoneyGram is available at the following Internet addresses:www.estravel.ee/#eng andwww.ftc.gov/opa/9509/fdfin.htm. In the United States, call 800 926 9400. Check local directories in other countries. **********Information about Western Union is available on the World Wide Web atwww.westernunion.com. In the United States call 800 325 6000. Check local directories in other countries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/12/world.main_headline: El Mozote Journal;Where Countless Died in '81, Horror Lives On in Salvador
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/12/world.print_headline: El Mozote Journal;Where Countless Died in '81, Horror Lives On in Salvador
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/12/world.body_text: **********Even after 14 years, it is clear something terrible once happened here. Shards of bone no longer protrude from the earth, but the church just off the plaza is still in ruins and stained with smoke, and munitions cartridges and bullet casings still litter the ground. **********To the side of the dusty main square, a "Wall of Lamentations" and a simple memorial, showing a man and woman holding the hands of two small children, explain what happened. "They have not died," a plaque proclaims. "They are with  us, with you, and with all mankind. El Mozote, December 11, 1981." **********In a burst of calculated destruction that day, soldiers from the American-trained and American-armed Atlacatl Battalion of the Salvadoran Armed Forces killed hundreds of unarmed peasants they suspected of being guerrilla sympathizers. The exact number, perhaps as many as a thousand people, can never  be known because animals consumed some bodies and relatives returned to bury others. **********El Salvador was immersed in civil war then, a conflict that became part of the larger cold war because of Cuban and Nicaraguan support of the guerrillas of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front and American patronage for the Salvadoran military. Though fighting would continue for another decade, resulting in the deaths of 75,000 people, the massacre here in the mountains of  Morazan Province still stands as the single most horrifying episode in the conflict. **********But now the people of El Mozote, or rather the lucky few who happened to be away at market or visiting relatives elsewhere that day, are returning. **********Casting aside bitter memories of loss and lingering fears of their Government, they have begun building new houses of wood, wattle, mud or brick on the sites of their former homes, burned and razed by rampaging soldiers. "We are people raised in the countryside," said Jose Socorro Chicas, 72, a beekeeper who lost 6 children and 17 grandchildren in the massacre. "We can't adapt to life in the city. We had our lands here, which have always belonged to us. This is our place, and we always knew we had to come back." **********Not Rufina Amaya, though. The only known survivor of the massacre, she saw her husband, Domingo Claros, bound, blindfolded and shot before she managed to slip off into the bush, where she listened helplessly as soldiers bayoneted four of her children while her 9-year-old son, Cristino, screamed: "Mama Rufina, help me! They're killing us!" **********Today she lives a few miles south of here, in a settlement called Quebrachos, with a new husband and a 10-year-old daughter, eking out a meager living from the corn and bananas they grow. She still owns a house and a small plot of land  here, but rents them to others because she cannot bring herself to visit, much less move back. **********"God saved me because He needed someone to tell the story of what happened,"  she said, sifting through a pile of beans on the front porch of the wood cabin that is her new home. "I wish He hadn't, though, because it is very painful to have to think of it all the time. There are so many things that I remember, and  I tell them, but I just cannot stand to be there." **********It is now thought that "El Mozote may well have been the largest massacre in  modern Latin American history," as Mark Danner put it in his 1994 book "The Massacre at El Mozote: A Parable of the Cold War" (Vintage Books). But the immediate aftermath of the massacre found the Reagan Administration, echoing its allies in the Salvadoran military, repeatedly challenging and casting doubt on every aspect of the killing, from the number of dead to their political sympathies. **********In fact, the guerrillas considered El Mozote anything but a stronghold, in part because "so many of the people who live there belong to Protestant evangelical sects" that were notoriously anti-Communist, Joaquin Villalobos, a commander of the dominant rebel group in the area, said in an interview last year. "That was not fertile ground for us." **********After formal exhumations began in 1992 and a United Nations-sponsored Truth Commission pieced together the sequence of events, Secretary of State Warren Christopher ordered an internal investigation. "U.S. statements on the case were wrong," the State Department's final report on the matter, published in 1993, flatly stated. **********Now that a rebuilding effort is under way here, the United States is seeking  to help. The American Ambassador to El Salvador, Alan J. Flanigan, has donated more than $10,000 from his discretionary fund to aid in rebuilding the local elementary school, and United States Government money is also being used for road construction and in well-digging and latrine projects. **********"Funds donated by the people and Government of the United States," proclaims  a shiny metal plaque on a well in the hamlet's ramshackle central square. On Feb. 12, Mr. Flanigan is scheduled to stop in El Mozote in what Embassy officials call a trip to monitor the progress of American-financed projects. **********Since May of last year, Peace Corps volunteers have also been working in the  Morazan area. "I found an M-16 rifle up there not long ago and I've heard the stories, but I can't even imagine what it must have been like here before," one  of them, Kevin Mitchell, a 24-year-old from Oregon, said. **********Some people who live and work here regard this sudden infusion of American aid and support as a belated apology and a tacit admission of guilt on the part  of Washington, which gave billions of dollars in aid to the Salvadoran military  during the war. But in San Salvador, officials at the American Embassy say no, that they are focused on the future, not the past. **********"The embassy believes that national reconstruction and reconciliation in El Salvador face their sternest tests in those regions of the country, like Morazan, which were the most conflictive during the war," said Chris Midura, an  embassy spokesman. "The long-term success of the accords depends to a large extent on insuring that the benefits of peace," including American-financed development projects, "reach the residents of these zones." **********Mindful of the suffering that occurred here, foreign religious and solidarity groups have also donated money and materials for reconstruction and resettlement. The amounts are not large, but they are more than the Salvadoran Government has offered, residents say. **********"Neither the army nor the Government has helped us rebuild," said Maria Luisa Guevara, head of the local chapter of the Committee of Mothers, a Roman Catholic Church group. "We have asked, but they have given us nothing." Her neighbor Mr. Chicas, the beekeeper, added, "Not even a nickel or a sheet of plastic." **********After the United Nations documented the massacre and fixed the blame on the Salvadoran Armed Forces, returning residents put all that and other information  together in a formal request for a pension. Soldiers who fought in the civil war, including many who may have committed human rights abuses, get such a monthly payment, but after two years the people of El Mozote still do not have a response from their Government. **********"They have never even come to ask our pardon," Rufina Amaya said. "They have  never come to explain why they did what they did, or in any way ever accepted the responsibility for what happened here, and until they do, there cannot be true reconciliation or a just peace here."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/14/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Reed Elsevier's Profit Surged 19% Last Year
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/14/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Reed Elsevier's Profit Surged 19% Last Year
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/14/busin.body_text: **********Reed Elsevier N.V.'s shift from print to electronic media helped to fuel a 19 percent profit gain last year, and the company says it wants to back that strategy with more than $1 billion in additional acquisitions. **********The British-Dutch publisher and information provider said its 1995 pretax profit was L723 million ($1.1 billion), excluding one-time items, up from L620 million in 1994. There was also a one-time gain of L751 million from selling British and Dutch newspapers and United States consumer magazines. The company said it would use the cash to buy more companies, mainly in the United States and Europe, as part of its shift away from print media. Reed Elsevier's 1995 sales rose 20 percent, to L3.7 billion from L3.04 billion.   (Bloomberg Business News)

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/31/busin.body_text: **********The Italian Cabinet has approved a widely expected package of incentives intended to increase car sales, the Ansa news wire reported yesterday, citing unidentified people in the Government. The incentives are intended to encourage people owning cars more than 10 years old to turn them in and acquire a new one. **********The Italian Government has been considering car sales incentives since early September. Italian car sales have declined or have been little changed for four consecutive years.   (Bloomberg Business News)

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/01/busin.snippet: Conrail, nearly moribund six years ago, has prospered and become increasingly valuable piece of nation's freight transportation system; railroad deregulation, new technology and shifting patterns of world trade are factors leading to resurgence of...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/01/busin.main_headline: Global Trade, High Tech Lift Railroad 'Basket Case'
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/01/busin.print_headline: Global Trade, High Tech Lift Railroad 'Basket Case'
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/01/busin.body_text: **********Derided as ''a basket of basket cases'' when the Government created it from the ruins of six bankrupt railroads two decades ago, today Conrail Inc. is a corporate jewel at the heart of the biggest railroad merger battle ever. Conrail has worked hard to modernize, but a visit to Port Elizabeth underscores that the railroad itself is only part of this Cinderella story. **********Day after day, Conrail freight trains bring hundreds of truck-size containers filled with products for export to a mammoth dock on Newark Bay here. Unloading is so rapid that some containers are on ships on their way out to the Atlantic within hours. And each day, a similar mountain of containers recently plucked by cranes from ships arriving from Europe, Asia, Africa and Latin America, ride Conrail trains back into the American heartland, filled with clothing, beer, electronics, toys and other goods. **********Express Rail, as the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey calls the transfer service, handles only a small part of the cargo here at the East Coast's busiest port. It also is just a sliver of Conrail's multi-billion-dollar operations. **********But Express Rail did not exist at all six years ago. Its rapid growth is a product of railroad deregulation, new technology and shifting patterns of world trade -- the same factors that have made Conrail an increasingly valuable piece of the nation's freight transportation system. **********The dollar value of Conrail's near monopoly on freight transport over tracks that run as far west as Chicago and as far south as Maryland is not settled. Conrail's preferred merger partner is CSX, the giant rail and shipping company based in Richmond that recently offered more than $8 billion in cash and stock. Norfolk Southern, which is both wooing and suing to win Conrail away from CSX, has offered $9 billion. **********Conrail, formally known as the Consolidated Rail Corporation, was created by the Government in a multibillion-dollar bailout of the bankrupt Penn Central and other Northeastern railroads two decades ago. The Chessie System merged with the Seaboard Coast Line Railroad to form CSX. **********The contest for Conrail comes on the heels of the Union Pacific Railroad's $5.4 billion marriage to the Southern Pacific, itself a response to the merger of the Burlington Northern and Santa Fe railroads in 1995. The deals are defended as necessary to increase efficiency and profits, but, as Express Rail shows, railroads have not relied on consolidation alone. **********''The railroads have snuck up on people,'' said J. Ganson Evans, a Conrail marketing executive who courts customers for Express Rail and other Conrail terminals near the port that also handle container traffic. ''People are surprised at what we are doing today.'' **********What Conrail and other lines are doing is slowing, and in some cases reversing, a decades-long loss of business to the trucking industry. While the public perception is that railroads are crumbling because passenger service is notoriously bad compared with other countries, freight shippers say the American rail network is the best and most efficient in the world. **********Railroads' share of freight traffic, measured by tonnage and distance carried, rose to 40.6 percent last year, from 36.4 percent in 1985, according to Mercer Management, a transportation consulting firm based in Lexington, Mass. **********The recovery has its roots in deregulation of the industry in 1980, four years after the Government began pouring billions into the dying Penn Central and five other lines to replace dilapidated track and rolling stock. Deregulation allowed railroads to drop costly branch lines that generated little traffic, and to quickly add new services to make better use of main lines like those Conrail uses to move goods from here to Chicago, Detroit and other inland hubs. It also freed them to rapidly change prices to meet competition from the far more flexible and reliable truckers. **********''The key is, unlike anywhere else in the world, you have the opportunity to have truly commercial railroads,'' said William Rennicke, a rail specialist at Mercer Management. ''Our productivity is 2 or 3 times greater than in Western Europe and 10 or 20 times that in other parts of the world.'' **********Express Rail is just one of many new services contributing to the freight railroads' slow but unmistakable renaissance. In the West, 110-car trains ferry a single valuable product, low-sulfur coal, from the Powder River basin of Wyoming to distant power plants. **********On the East Coast, CSX transports a million gallons of Tropicana orange juice from Bradenton, Fla., to Philadelphia three times a week on 65-car trains that it turns over to Conrail for a last leg to Kearny, N.J. **********Many services like Express Rail -- called intermodal because they use two or more modes of transportation -- exploit the huge cost advantage that railroads have over long distance trucking by carrying truck trailers that can be attached to cabs near their final destination and containers that can go on either ships or trucks. **********''Intermodal has been growing because railroads continue to bring their costs down and improve the reliability of their service,'' said Donald Schneider, president of Schneider National Inc. The Green Bay, Wis., trucking giant has seen its intermodal business with railroads grow 30 percent a year. **********Huge productivity gains have come from relatively straightforward improvements like raising road overpasses and enlarging tunnels enough to stack containers two high. As the improvements were completed, it became cheaper and faster to land goods pouring out of booming factories in Japan and Korea at West Coast ports and ship them across the country by rail than to ship them to the East Coast via the Panama Canal. **********Conrail spent $64 million on such improvements in Pennsylvania alone to create an eastbound container route south of its main line across New York. West Coast container services then could reach terminals around Harrisburg, the Port of Philadelphia, and, with a handoff to the Norfolk Southern in Hagerstown, Md., cities further south. **********The rail bridge from California grew at the expense of East Coast ports like the Port of New York and New Jersey. But now, with manufacturing moving to Southeast Asia, the same improvements to the rail network are making it attractive to ship containerized goods from there to New York via the Suez Canal and then into the Midwest by rail. **********The benefits of increased global trade have been enhanced by investments in a variety of new technologies. Conrail and others are buying a new generation of locomotives powerful enough to do the work of two of their predecessors. Computerized dispatch centers control traffic more efficiently; satellites are used to pinpoint and repair breakdowns more quickly. **********The railroads' economic revival cost 270,000 railroad employees their jobs from 1980 to 1995, about 60 percent of the total. Conrail's work force was cut to 23,500 from 96,000. **********On the other hand, the railroads' comeback has revived locomotive and rail car manufacturing, saved shippers billions of dollars a year, stimulated world trade and influenced many domestic activities in ways the average citizen might not realize, like allowing utilities to meet clean air regulations by switching to low-sulfur Western coal instead of installing expensive scrubbers. Rail revenue, meanwhile, rose to $32.28 billion last year, from $28.26 billion in 1980. Operating profits doubled to $2.86 billion. **********''The railroads, which were laid out a century ago to serve passengers, have finally found their niche serving commerce,'' said Robert Voltman, director of policy for the National Industrial Transportation League, a Washington-based trade group of manufacturers and other major shippers. ''They are now in a battle to expand that niche.'' **********The battle is tough because many customers are moving targets that are easier for truckers to hit. Railroads typically figure they are on schedule if they pick up and deliver within 24 hours of when they are expected, a big improvement from the days when the window was several days at least. But truckers generally show up within 15 minutes of the time they promise. That is a huge advantage in the just-in-time era, when manufacturers do not want materials until they are ready to process them, and retailers do not want products delivered before they are needed on the shelves. **********''We use rail shipping from plants to our own warehouses, but our customers are now specifying what time of day we have to deliver,'' said Thomas Weikart, director of global logistics for Owens Corning, which spends about $380 million a year shipping Fiberglas insulation and other goods. ''Intermodal is getting very reliable, but if I have to go 500 miles and it has to be there tomorrow, I still use trucks. I'll pay a 5 percent to 10 percent premium to get them.'' **********The biggest problem for the railroads may be overcoming their reputation for indifference, even arrogance, in dealing with many customers. Until deregulation, they paid little attention to selling themselves. **********Conrail, by virtue of its monopoly position, has generally received lower marks than most lines on that score, but those working with it say the situation has improved. Port Authority executives, for instance, say they had to lobby hard to convince Conrail that Express Rail would bring new business to both of them. But once Conrail made the commitment, it became a responsive partner, they say. **********Big customers with a choice of carriers naturally see the biggest improvements. Transportation executives at the Ford Motor Company say Norfolk Southern participated in designing a new vehicle distribution system that is expected to cut inventory costs. **********The railroad is setting up new yards where Ford will send vehicles from several factories, allowing trains to be filled and dispatched to dealers more quickly. And both Norfolk Southern and CSX have asked to be included in planning new methods for handling incoming components to Ford plants. **********''They recognize they have to be more than just movers of goods,'' said Wade Deal, director of supply chain management for Ford. ''Their share of our business could grow substantially.'' **********But many more customers say railroads are still run by people who care more about convenient operations than customers. And retailing experts agree. **********''I still haven't seen the rail industry come up with clever service ideas,'' said Robert Sabath, a retailing expert in Mercer Management's Chicago office. ''It's been their customers pushing them. They used to be one on a one-to-10 scale of customer service. Now they are a 3.'' **********Wall Street, although nervous about whether Norfolk Southern or CSX will end up overpaying for Conrail, has generally been pleased. Rising profits and the prospect of still more mergers as Conrail and its rivals jockey for leverage with customers have lifted rail stocks more than 12 percent in the last year. **********But with just four railroads controlling 95 percent of interstate rail traffic once Conrail is married off, customers and other participants in  the transportation system are increasingly anxious. Many fear price increases or service cuts. Even those anticipating improvements, like the Port of New York and New Jersey, worry that the railroads' efforts to be more competitive could shift business away from them, just as new shipping routes shifted cargo away from it before. **********''What seems to be a modest improvement in the price or service a railroad offers to a particular destination can have a huge impact on where cargo goes,'' said Joseph Curnyn, the facility supervisor at the Port Authority's New Jersey marine terminal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/16/busin.main_headline: AT&T May Cut Fewer Jobs Than It Initially Estimated
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/16/busin.print_headline: AT&T May Cut Fewer Jobs Than It Initially Estimated
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/16/busin.body_text: **********Not three months after it stunned Main Street and delighted Wall Street by estimating that it would cut 40,000 jobs over two to three years, the AT&T Corporation is now predicting fewer reductions. **********AT&T has made no official statement about the smaller numbers. For now, it is sticking with its original estimate, given in January. But queries from news organizations over the last few weeks have disclosed that the composition of the numbers is changing, and that the overall number may come down. **********At the time it made its announcement, AT&T expected that 30,000 people would be forced to give up their jobs, and that 10,000 would accept buyouts. **********So far, however, the buyouts have exceeded expectations. Moreover, internal demand in some areas has been strong enough so that employees who might leave one job are finding work in another part of the company. **********"Our latest best estimate of people who will have to be involuntarily let go  is about 18,000," said Adele Ambrose, an AT&T spokeswoman. "But that number could go up. None of these figures are hard and firm. The good news is that more people than we originally estimated have taken the buyout offer." **********Ms. Ambrose said that 7,500 employees had accepted buyouts, and she estimated that 4,500 others would do the same. **********In addition, growth in AT&T's wireless business, as well as intensified preparations for the company's re-entry into the local telephone service and the introduction of an Internet-access service have generated a previously unseen need for jobs. **********"We are finding we may be successful in finding jobs for 5,000 or 6,000 people, either through the normal attrition process or in areas that are growing," Ms. Ambrose said. "But those figures are an aspiration. It is not a done deal by any means." **********Analysts said they were not surprised that as time passed the company was finding that its initial estimates might need some tuning. **********"The 40,000 figure was always an estimate," said Frank J. Governali, an analyst at CS First Boston. "But I don't believe this has altered their game plan for restructuring the business, and I don't think Pat Buchanan is altering  their human resources requirements." AT&T has been criticized by Mr. Buchanan and other politicians for the cuts. **********The updated information on what is going on inside AT&T comes in a week when  the company placed full-page ads in newspapers across the country seeking jobs for the workers it is laying off. **********The revamping of AT&T, which will split the company into three entities, begins next month, when its $20 billion network equipment business is spun off as an independent company called Lucent Technologies. **********The two other companies will be AT&T, which will provide communications services, and NCR, a computer division. **********Ms. Ambrose said that if the company was successful in finding jobs for 6,000 employees within the restructured AT&T, the $2.6 billion in reserves the company set aside to cover the cost would be reduced accordingly. **********AT&T shares, which jumped in price after the restructuring was announced, closed yesterday at $61.375, down 12.5 cents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/25/world.main_headline: Drug Traffickers Smuggling Tons of Cash From U.S. Through Mexico
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/25/world.print_headline: Drug Traffickers Smuggling Tons of Cash From U.S. Through Mexico
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/25/world.body_text: **********Under cover of darkness in the northern desert, a tramp Caravelle 727 set down hard on the sand 30 miles outside Hermosillo a few minutes past midnight last March 11. **********On board were 2.5 tons of Colombian cocaine. But the equally important mission was to pick up money, possibly several tons of $5, $10 and $20 bills totaling as much as $20 million in proceeds from street corner drug sales in the United States that were to be brought back to Colombia. **********When the wheels of the old jet got mired in the desert sand, the mission was scuttled. The money, the crew and the cocaine disappeared. **********On April 17, police agents at Benito Juarez International Airport here opened 12 boxes containing new air conditioners bound for Bogota, Colombia. Stuffed inside the Arctic Air window units was $6.2 million in small American bills. **********On Oct. 11, a plane landed near a dam just south of Tepic, in Nayarit state.  Mexican soldiers grew suspicious when they saw the pilot and crew carrying pistols as they left the plane. An army patrol moved in and seized the pilot and the aircraft and six large suitcases filled with more than $12 million in American bills. **********These incidents were signs of a major new problem facing Latin American drug  lords: how to smuggle tons of dollars home, a task that is in some ways even more daunting than smuggling cocaine into the United States. For many years, the cartels relied on financial wizards and manipulation of the banking system to send much of their drug profits home electronically. **********But, American and Mexican drug officials say, since the United States tightened reporting requirements in the early 1990's and pressed legitimate banks to steer clear of money-laundering schemes, traffickers have had to rely more heavily on shipping money in bulk. **********So the drug traffickers are faced with the thorny challenge of physically repatriating their profits. Smuggling out mountains of bills from sales in the United States poses an extraordinary logistical problem. **********Besides overstuffing suitcases and overtaxing aging jets, the gangs get the money home by slipping the bills through tunnels under the border, exporting to  Colombia refrigerators and washing machines bought in the United States with drug proceeds, and exploiting small and mostly unregulated Mexican dollar exchange houses and even legitimate Mexican banks to launder the cash. **********Under Mexican law, the banks and exchange houses do not have to report large  transactions -- as they would in the United States -- and no one knows for certain what goes where. And money-laundering is not a criminal offense in Mexico, but a tax violation. **********Officials of both countries are worried that the flood of narcotics money may also have been used by drug lords like Juan Garcia Abrego, who was arrested by Mexican authorities last week and expelled to the United States, where he faces  drug-trafficking and money-laundering charges, to buy hotels, restaurants, transportation companies and airlines in Mexico. There are even suspicions, voiced by American officials, that laundered drug money may have found its way into the purchases of important Government businesses under the previous administration. **********Raul Salinas de Gortari, the older brother of former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, is being investigated by the Swiss authorities on money-laundering allegations involving more than $100 million he has in secret Swiss accounts. **********The Swiss have so far been unable to prove the money came from drug traffickers or bribes from businessmen, but a report in Money Laundering Alert,  a monthly magazine published in Miami, said that Raul Salinas may be charged with money laundering in the United States. **********While millions of dollars are also laundered through off-shore banks in Panama and electronic transfer operations in other countries, the bulk shipments of money across the Rio Grande are powerful symbols of the growing strength of Mexican drug traffickers who, despite recent blows by the Mexican and American Governments, still maintain a firm hold on parts of Mexico. **********"These organizations are now in a position where they have the money, resources and influence to affect not only the internal political stability in segments of the Mexican countryside but are increasingly responsible for the propagation of violence in their homeland," United States Drug Enforcement Agency officials wrote in a confidential document. **********The drug trade is essentially a cash-only business in which high value goods, produced by a few dominant suppliers, are sold in countless small enterprises spread out over a huge area. Laundering is necessary for the suppliers to return their profits home without being detected. **********The illicit drug trade amounts to hundreds of billions of dollars -- all in cash -- around the world. The small bills used in the illegal transactions weigh more than the equivalent amount of drugs. A kilogram, or 2.2 pounds, of cocaine  brings around $20,000 retail on the streets of New York. Based on an estimate that about 450 paper bills weigh a pound, drug traffickers have to figure out a  way to get around three pounds of $10 and $20 bills back home for every kilo of  cocaine they sell. **********Of course, it is easier to use banking conveniences like electronic transfers to move money around. But in the United States banks have strict reporting requirements that make it possible for government agents to trace the path of such money and bring charges against those involved. **********Ronald K. Noble, American Under Secretary of the Treasury for Enforcement, said that by making the money-laundering process complicated, the Government forces drug gangs to find other methods that leave them more open to discovery. **********"The more intricate money laundering becomes, the more people are involved and the greater are the chances of somebody making a mistake or of our getting an informant," Mr. Noble said. **********Mexico does not have the same kind of reporting requirements as the United States. American officials say it is fairly easy, although risky, to conceal large amounts of illicit cash inside cars and tractor trailers, often packed inside legitimate merchandise, and get it across busy border crossing sites. **********Once inside Mexico, there are several ways the drug gangs send the money back home, laundered and untraced. One is through currency exchange firms. **********A 1991 change in Mexican law forced foreign exchange shops to increase their  capital or stop using the name "casas de cambio," or exchange houses. About 47 big operations met the new requirements and are overseen by banking authorities. More than 2,000 others did not and simply dropped the term and call themselves money centers or exchange centers. They are no longer supervised by fiscal authorities and instead are treated like any other small business in Mexico. **********Jose Antonio Ramirez, director general of the Mexican Association of Casasmselves money centers or exchange centers. They are no longer supervised by fiscal authorities and instead are treated like any other small business in Mexico. **********Jose Antonio Ramirez, director general of the Mexican Association of Casas de Cambio, the regulated group, said it is common for gang members to show up at the unregulated money centers with suitcase stuffed with cash. The money centers either write money orders or transfer the cash to banks, which wire the money to Colombia. **********But that process carries dangers. "One of the trends we're seeing is a reluctance on the part of gangs to wire transport their money because it can be  traced," said an American official familiar with the Mexican drug trade. Since 1993, Mexico has been freely exchanging financial informaiton with the United States that helps track the flow of money, although not as closely as law enforcement officials would like. **********In November 1994, the American Express Bank International, a subsidiary of American Express, agreed to pay a $7 million civil penalty and forfeit more than $25 million in deposits that were made by Juan Garcia Abrego, the Mexican drug lord now in custody in Houston. **********The current indictment presented against Mr. Garcia Abrego is filled with charges that gang members hid money in cars and trucks to get the "data," as it  is referred to in intercepted conversations, across the border. In several cases the trail reached as far as New York City. **********On Feb. 2, 1989, an American named Bill Hoffman went to Queens to pick up a Chevrolet Suburban with New York license plates that was filled with an unknown  portion of $18 million Mr. Garcia Abrego's gang had warehoused. He drove to Brownsville, Tex., and left the Suburban there. It was then driven across the International Bridge into Matamoros, Mexico, the base of Mr. Garcia Abrego's operations. **********Two months later, the indictment says, Mr. Hoffman was again driving south from New York, this time in a 1986 Tioga camper loaded with "documents," and "receipts," which are believed to be code words for cash. He later allegedly traveled back and forth from Texas to New York several times in the recreational vehicle, bringing cocaine north and money south. **********Officials say that after money crosses the border, it is stored at a safe house until enough is accumulated to warrant a flight to South America. That is  what was supposed to take place in the Sonora Desert nearly a year ago. **********According to local police reports and information from American sources, Mexican agents in Sonora's capital, Hermosillo, received their first call just before midnight on March 11, 1994, that a Caravelle jet from Colombia had landed in a remote area of the desert called Campo San Rafael. **********"But they gave us no coordinates and to get there we had to cross mountains and search through desert," said a Mexican official familiar with the case. The  agents arrived at 6 the next morning. **********By then they found the abandoned Caravelle, sunk to its axle in sand. Inside  the ragged interior the police said they found a small bit of cocaine in a briefcase, but nothing else. **********But it turned out that a special crime-fighting force of the Mexican Government had flown over the landing site at night, and with an infra-red camera, filmed the frantic activity on the ground. **********The Mexican authorities would not show the recording, but Mexican and American officials who have seen it said it shows a half dozen pickup trucks and even a tanker truck, probably filled with jet fuel, come up to the jet. The blurry images show several people involved in what the officials believe was the transfer of the cocaine off the jet. Then it shows the pilot trying to rock the  jet out of the sand, unsuccessfully. **********A day after the landing, the police found many of the vehicles. And a day after that they captured a 30-year-old Colombian, Mario Hernando Rendon Cuellar, who was arrested for taking part in the delivery. **********It was Mr. Rendon Cuellar who told the police that the jet had come in to pick up "a few tons" of money, and that the cocaine had been loaded at the last minute before leaving Colombia. **********It has been rumored that it was police agents who were filmed unloading the drugs from the disabled jet but both Mexican and American authorities insist that is not true. **********Mexico realizes it has created a haven for drug money laundering and may try  to change its laws to make it a crime instead of a tax violation. **********But although the Attorney General and Congressional leaders have talked about passing a tough new organized crime bill, so far they have not formally begun the debate. There is resistance from some Mexican business leaders who fear that reporting requirements for money exchanges of over $10,000, as proposed, would be a first step toward currency controls, which would limit their ability to move legitimate money. **********Based on their past experiences with the Government, they also are worried that the information they give to agents may somehow be used against them.
