https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/25/world.snippet: Epidemic of suicides is plaguing Kaiowa Indians of Brazil, whose lands and traditions are being lost to colonization; wave of suicides has prompted other tribes to gather in Dourados, offering prayers and share of their crop; colonists are blockin...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/25/world.main_headline: Indians in Brazil Wither in an Epidemic of Suicide
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/25/world.print_headline: Indians in Brazil Wither in an Epidemic of Suicide
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/25/world.body_text: **********Haunted by memories of the elderly aunt, the nephew and the cousins who have killed themselves, Valerio Vera Goncalves dances hard over the earth and chants to the heavens. He wears a crown of pink feathers, and his entreaties mix with the roar of a nearby tractor on the edge of this boom town: ''Go find a good road; chase away the evil spirits,'' he calls out. **********For Mr. Goncalves, who runs the Kaiowa Indians' house of worship here, prayer is the only defense against an epidemic of suicides that have plagued his people during the last few years. **********''We have to dance very hard and pray,'' said Mr. Goncalves, 48. ''I feel as if I'm losing pieces of myself.'' **********During the last 10 years, some 200 Kaiowa are thought to have killed themselves in this southern region near the border with Paraguay, and anthropologists say they are now seeing suicides among other tribes. While the general rate of suicide among Brazilians is roughly 1 in 28,000, last year as many as 56 of the 28,000 Kaiowa in this region died in what are presumed to be suicides. **********For the Kaiowa, a subgroup of the Guarani Indians, the suicides seem to be tied to their estrangement from the land, on which their traditional life of fishing, farming and worship depended. A peaceful people who tend to withdraw from confrontation, the Kaiowa have, in the span of 75 years, suffered the kind of losses of land, people and culture that have characterized the Indian encounter with Europeans for 500 years. **********When Europeans arrived here, Brazil was home to an estimated five million Indians. At the start of this century, their number had fallen to one million. Now, there are 230,000. **********Since 1945, the Kaiowa have watched their land shrink from 25,000 square miles -- roughly the size of West Virginia -- to 172, and their language and their rituals disappear with the arrival of white colonists and the increase in the number of religious missionaries. In Bororo, which is near Dourados and the center of the surge in suicides, some 6,000 Kaiowa live on 10 acres. **********The wave of suicides has prompted other tribes to gather here, offering prayers and shares of their crops. Government agencies have promised food and seeds, but so far, the Indians here say, Government help has not reached them. **********Late last year, Justice Minister Nelson Jobim pledged to return nearly 4,000 acres to the Kaiowa. But signaling the explosiveness of the contest for land here, federal and military police protected Mr. Jobim as he announced the areas to be turned over. The 40 colonists whose land was earmarked have vowed not to leave; no land has been returned. **********Although the Government Indian protection agency is conducting a census that aims to return the Kaiowa to some of their historic lands, that goal has become more unlikely under a decree that President Fernando Henrique Cardoso signed in January. The decree allows non-Indians to challenge pending and future allocations of land to Indians. Since it was issued, there have been six challenges to Kaiowa lands here. **********The Kaiowa live on the margins of Dourados, an agribusiness center started in the 1940's with a land redistribution that gave each colonist family 75 acres to farm. Now, grain silos and neatly planted fields stretch for miles, while the Kaiowa go hungry, unable to eke out a living on less than an acre per person. **********As a result, the Kaiowa men leave for work in distant sugar cane fields and distilleries. The women, left behind, clean houses, sell trinkets, beg and sometimes turn to prostitution. The most common suicide tales begin with husbands who became alcoholics while away returning home and fighting with their wives. **********''Land is much more than simply a means of subsistence,'' wrote Alcida Ramos, in his book ''Indigenous Societies.'' ''It is the support for a social life that is directly linked to their system of belief and knowledge.'' **********With missionary churches springing up to replace the Kaiowa's religion, and schools teaching Portuguese instead of their native Tupi-Guarani, the suicides are a stark illustration of the Kaiowa's decline. **********''It would disintegrate any people,'' said Orlando Silvestri Zimmer, who runs the local Indigenist Missionary Council, a Roman Catholic organization that works in behalf of Indian rights. **********Mr. Zimmer complained that 28 religious groups, most of them evangelical Protestant, have flocked to the area in recent years to convert the Kaiowa. His own group, he said, does not try to convert Indians. **********Anastasio Moura, a Kaiowa who struggles to grow rice and a few crops to feed his family on a half acre, said his people felt spiritually and physically drained. ''There's nothing left to take away,'' he said. **********In an effort to build up commercial farming, the Brazilian authorities also imported the more assimilated Terena Indians from the north, who have traditionally dominated the Kaiowa, and have taken over some of the most fertile land. **********With a branch, Mrs. Moura traced a rectangle in the dirt to show the land where her parents once grew rice, manioc and potatoes. It was more than seven acres, she said. She then drew a smaller box in one corner denoting her mother's current property. After her father died, she said, the local leader and another Terena demanded three-quarters of the land. **********''They said if she didn't give it over, they would beat her up and burn her house,'' Mrs. Moura said. **********Many here complained that corruption and the power of people called captains were responsible for the loss of lands and the failure of Government aid to reach them. The captains, Indians who were historically appointed by the military as go-betweens with white society, are now elected, but their authority has subverted the influence of religious leaders and the traditions they represent. **********There are also signs that some suicides may mask murders. According to researchers at the State University of Mato Grosso do Sul, as many as six presumed suicides may have been murders, implicating local authorities in a drive to push Indians off the land. Authorities in Dourados deny the accusations. **********The Kaiowa do not themselves ascribe the suicides to specific actions by the Brazilian Government, although they do link it to living near white people. **********''They have bad thoughts,'' said Paulito Aquino, a religious chief who gave his age as 110, and who wore the traditional tambeta, a reedlike stick, through his chin. **********''They are in their houses, but they're thinking, 'Those Indians, they might as well die,' '' said Mr. Aquino.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/27/busin.snippet: Outlook for investing in Chiron Corp discussed in light of big price drop spurred by failed clinical trial of firm's new genital herpes vaccine (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/27/busin.main_headline: Some analysts see a silver lining to Chiron's cloud.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/27/busin.print_headline: Some analysts see a silver lining to Chiron's cloud.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/27/busin.body_text: **********A DAY after the Chiron Corporation's stock fell 17 percent following a failed clinical trial of a new vaccine for genital herpes, some analysts said the event was not entirely negative. At yesterday's closing price of $18.875, up 75 cents, shares in Chiron, which many consider a core biotechnology holding, are now cheap enough to consider buying, they say. **********To be sure, the failure of the herpes vaccine, which came after nearly 15 years of research and $50 million in development costs, is a blow to Chiron. A successful herpes vaccine might have produced as much as 10 percent of Chiron's future revenues. **********But while some analysts accordingly lowered their ratings of Chiron shares Monday, others pointed out that Chiron remained the most diversified of all biotechnology companies. The failure of one product candidate, while more serious for Chiron than for a Merck or a Pfizer, is not a devastating blow because the company has so many other potential drugs and diagnostics. **********''The thing to remember about Chiron is that it is virtually a biotech mutual fund,'' said Michael Murphy, publisher of the California Technology Stock Letter. ''It's in so many different technologies, let alone drugs, that unless someone was so unrealistic as to expect them all to work, the price before yesterday should have assumed that probably two-thirds of them would fail.'' **********Mr. Murphy also noted that Chiron's share price gave it a market capitalization of just over $3 billion, compared with $16 billion for the Amgen  Corporation, which is currently the largest biotech company. ''I think that someday, because Chiron has so much in development, it will have a higher market cap than Amgen,'' he said. ''The idea that Chiron is worth just 20 percent of Amgen I find ludicrous.'' **********Other analysts note that Chiron's management team had repeatedly rescued the company from previous failures. ''They'll find something; they always do, and that's why investors stay in the stock,'' said Mark Simon, an analyst with Robertson Stephens & Company. ''I would look for them sometime in the next 18 to 24 months to pull the next rabbit out of a hat,'' he said. **********Edmund Debler, an analyst with Mehta & Isaly, said Chiron shares were more interesting after the clinical failure. ''We were not active in the stock and now we will be looking at it much more aggressively,'' he said. ''I would not be surprised if it drifted down to $16, where you would have to say that you want to be in Chiron for the long term.'' **********One lingering concern from the herpes trial is that the technology Chiron used in the herpes vaccine, which proved ineffective, is also used in a number of other vaccines under development at the company. In each case, a genetically engineered portion of the virus, known as an antigen, is combined with an immune-enhancing substance of fatty particles known as an adjuvant. ''It would not be an overstatement to say that these results could have a significant impact on all of their vaccine programs,'' Mr. Debler said. **********But Edward Penhoet, Chiron's president and co-founder, said he did not believe that the failure of the herpes vaccine should be read as a failure of the approach. ''In every case the adjuvant has stimulated a better immune response, so there's a lot of evidence that the adjuvant is useful,'' he said. ''We are disappointed, and frankly surprised, by these results, but we certainly don't believe it is a death knell for our vaccine program or anything like that.'' **********Without time to adequately review the data from the trial, Chiron scientists do not know why the vaccine failed, but Dr. Penhoet said he suspected it was due to some peculiarities of the herpes virus itself. Chiron will delay tests of a vaccine for CMV retinitis, a virus that causes blindness in AIDS patients, for up to six months while it reviews the data because that virus is similar to herpes. Trials of vaccines for hepatitis C and H.I.V., both of which use the adjuvant approach, will go forward unchanged. **********Chiron recently filed an application with the Food and Drug Administration for permission to market a genetically engineered pertussis vaccine, and has received a notification of approvability in Italy for an improved flu vaccine. Its therapeutic division has three drugs pending approval in the near term: Myotrophin, in partnership with Cephalon Inc., for the treatment of Lou Gehrig's disease; Regranex, a wound-healing agent to be marketed by Johnson & Johnson, and Depocyt, a foam-based chemotherapy drug for brain cancer, developed with Depotech Inc.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/07/world.main_headline: World News Briefs;At Least 300 Are Killed In Severe China Flooding
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/07/world.print_headline: World News Briefs;At Least 300 Are Killed In Severe China Flooding
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/07/world.body_text: **********Flooding brought on by heavy rains has killed more than 300 people, severed electrical lines and knocked down buildings, and the seasonal storms headed north today through China. **********Hundreds of thousands of soldiers and reservists were called out to evacuate  more than half a million people and to repair damaged dikes in communities along the Yangtze River and its tributaries, official news reports said. **********Soldiers in southern Guizhou Province, the area hit hardest, cleared 20 tons of debris that floods and landslides had dumped across railroad lines, according to the reports. **********Since the end of June, as much as 22 inches of rain has fallen in the region, which contains some of the country's lushest farmland and poorest villages. According to Government reports, the water has destroyed 3.2 million acres of crops. **********China's Civil Affairs Ministry reported 237 people dead in four provinces as  of Friday. But reports from state-run news media, newspapers in Hong Kong and the Red Cross put the toll at 315.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/21/busin.print_headline: CYTYC STOCK SOARS ON ACCEPTANCE OF ITS PAP TEST
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/21/busin.body_text: **********Shares of the Cytyc Corporation jumped 23 percent yesterday after the company said the United Healthcare Corporation, based in Minnetonka, Minn., had accepted Cytyc's Thinprep Pap test for coverage in health insurance plans. Shares of Cytyc rose $4.4375, to $23.4375. Analysts said the decision by United Healthcare, one of the nation's largest health maintenance organizations, could mean that four million to six million of Cytyc's Pap tests would be used annually. The Thinprep test uses a thin film to analyze cervical cells and is an advance over the older Pap smear, United Healthcare said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/17/busin.snippet: Motorola to introduce line of personal computers equipped with Apple Computer Inc's Macintosh operating system, as companies bid to expand market for such machines at time when it is threatened by IBM-compatible computers running Microsoft Windows...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/17/busin.main_headline: Motorola Introducing PC's With Apple System
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/17/busin.print_headline: Motorola Introducing PC's With Apple System
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/17/busin.body_text: **********Motorola plans today to introduce a line of personal computers equipped with Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh operating system, as the companies bid to expand the market for such machines at a time when it is threatened by I.B.M.-compatible computers running Microsoft Windows software. **********The new line, called Starmax, will be priced from $1,600 to $4,000 and aimed at business customers. **********Apple has licensed its operating system software to other clone makers, notably the Power Computing Corporation of Round Rock, Tex., but these relatively small manufacturers have not sold enough computers to prevent Apple's share of the overall market from declining. Apple's licensing agreement with Motorola was announced in February. **********Though Motorola is not a big competitor in the computer business, its overall size, strong brand name and reputation for quality have heartened Apple loyalists who have been beleaguered by the company's declining sales and management turmoil in the last year or so. **********''This is a big company with big marketing clout, state-of-the-art manufacturing and tremendous legitimacy in both the corporate world and the retail market,'' said Ken Krich, president of Computerware, a large Apple retailer in Sunnyvale, Calif. At the least, Mr. Krich added, the addition of Motorola will give retailers another source to turn to when Apple, which has been plagued by poor forecasting of demand, cannot ship enough of its hottest-selling machines. **********Motorola's decision to sell Macintosh-compatible machines is defensive. Both Motorola and the International Business Machines Corporation make the Power PC chip, which acts as the electronic brain inside the most powerful Macintoshes. Motorola needs to sell more machines in order to earn back its large investment in designing and producing the Power PC chip. **********But many analysts believe that Apple waited too long to license its operating system to outside computer makers, giving Microsoft the time to match its most popular features. **********''Motorola being in the business doesn't answer the basic question why someone should buy a Mac today,'' said Richard Shaffer, president of Technologic Partners, a New York consulting firm. ''Two years ago, it might have been a different story.'' **********But Joe Gugliemi, vice president and general manager of Motorola's computer division, believes that the prices and features of the new machines, including what he called an industry-leading five-year warranty, will attract new buyers. He is planning to sell the machines throughout the world, including in China, where Motorola has a joint venture with a domestic maker, the Nanjing Panda Electronics Company. It has also sublicensed the Apple operating system to a Taiwan manufacturer, Soyo, which will make clones for the consumer market. **********''We think Mac compatibles will be a very large and successful product,'' Mr. Gugliemi said. ''And we believe that we will get a substantial share of the market.'' **********Motorola today will also introduce a new line of Power PC-equipped computers that will run the Windows NT operating system from Microsoft. The two product families, which will go on sale over the next two months, are expected to merge into one next year, when Apple, Motorola and I.B.M. begin producing machines capable of running Windows NT, Macintosh and the Unix operating systems.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/12/busin.main_headline: Cable Channel Will Carry The Big Board Ticker Live
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/12/busin.print_headline: Cable Channel Will Carry The Big Board Ticker Live
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/12/busin.body_text: **********The New York Stock Exchange ticker, which shows each trade in Big Board issues seconds after the trade is made, will now be made available to television programs on a live, rather than a delayed, basis, exchange officials said yesterday. **********The exchange has reached an agreement with one cable channel, CNNFN, to show the ticker, and CNNFN will begin doing so at the start of trading today, said Robert G. Britz, group executive vice president at the exchange. **********''We're very excited about it -- it's something that we have been discussing with the Big Board for some months,'' said Lou Dobbs, executive vice president of CNN and chief executive of CNNFN. ''Real-time, live data from the markets is critically important, and this gives our viewers better information.'' **********A number of cable channels carry the ticker, but on a 15-minute delayed basis, so trades that cross the tape at, say, 10 A.M. do not appear on the screen until 10:15 A.M. In a fast-moving, hectic market, such prices can be far from the actual prices investors would get if they placed an order to buy or sell. **********''This literally is the first time investors will be able to get live, real-time prices from their television,'' Mr. Britz said, though he declined to discuss what further steps the New York exchange planned for disseminating its information more effectively. ''It's no accident we started with television,'' he said, noting its wide availability, which should offer investors easy access to such information. **********Up-to-the-minute quotes are now available only through quote machines from a number of vendors -- services too costly for most individual investors -- or from brokerage firms, some of which provide them through Internet listings. **********But, Mr. Britz said, Internet services that allow people access to real-time quotes require the user to have a personal computer and charge fees for providing this information. **********''Clearly this market is an information-driven market,'' Mr. Britz added. ''The faster we can disseminate information, the more competitive we become and the greater we increase the depth of N.Y.S.E. market information.'' **********Big Board officials said that CNNFN -- a financial channel, owned by Time Warner Inc., that began operations last year -- would pay more for the real-time quotes than channels pay for the delayed service, but would not say how large the premium would be. They said other channels would be offered the same deal, and that some channels might soon follow CNNFN. **********Putting the ticker on the television screen will still not give viewers complete information about the market in a given stock. While the most recent trade is normally about where a stock would trade if another order were to arrive immediately, a market can move rapidly, particularly if news about a company is released. That would be reflected in the bid and asked prices -- what other investors or brokers are willing to pay or to accept -- for a stock.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/06/world.main_headline: U.S. Rights Group Asserts China Lets Thousands of Orphans Die
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/06/world.print_headline: U.S. Rights Group Asserts China Lets Thousands of Orphans Die
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/06/world.body_text: **********A New York-based human rights organization asserted today that thousands of children have died in China's state-run orphanages from deliberate starvation, medical malpractice and staff abuse. **********The group, Human Rights Watch, said it was impossible to obtain "a full accounting of the total number" and of the safety and health of China's orphan population, but based on detailed medical records smuggled out by a doctor from  a large Shanghai orphanage, and on a limited set of statistics relating to nationwide orphan mortality, there is cause for great alarm about the fate of countless abandoned infants, most of them girls. **********The brutal treatment of orphans in Shanghai, which included deliberate starvation, torture and sexual assault, continued over a period of many years and led to the unnatural deaths of well over 1,000 children between 1986 and 1992 alone," the group concluded in the report issued today. **********"This campaign of elimination could be kept secret through the complicity of  both higher- and lower-level staff," the report said, "and because the city's Bureau of Civil Affairs, responsible for the orphanage, also runs the crematoria, where starved children's corpses were disposed of with minimum oversight, often even before a death certificate had been filled out by the attending physician." **********Nationwide in China, the group said, high mortality figures indicate the strong possibility of a policy of deliberate starvation and severe abuse of orphans, especially girls and mentally and physically handicapped children. Though most of the evidence was gathered from 1988 to 1992, the organization said the policy is probably continuing, and it called on China to open its orphanages to international inspection. **********"We have to acknowledge that we can only take this investigation so far," said Robin Munro, the organization's Hong Kong director. **********Human Rights Watch based much of its report on the testimony, medical records and photographs taken out of the country by the Chinese physician, Zhang Shuyun, who fled China last year after an unsuccessful campaign to expose abuses at the  Shanghai Children's Welfare Institute. The information provided detailed medical histories and case studies on dozens of orphans who died from 1988 to 1992, showing that healthy infants admitted to the Shanghai institution often died of  severe malnutrition weeks or months later. **********"There is compelling evidence that these astonishing death rates are the result of a deliberate policy to minimize China's population of abandoned children, many of whom have been born in violation of the country's family planning regulations and are sometimes physically or mentally handicapped," the  group said in a news release today. **********The records show inappropriate changes in medication, the failure to treat severe malnutrition at its onset and blatant medical neglect of life-threatening infections and other conditions, the doctor said. **********The doctor's testimony is buttressed by that of Ai Ming, who was taken to the Shanghai orphanage as an abandoned child and spent 20 years there before leaving China last year. In 1992, he secretly photographed the emaciated bodies of dead  or dying children who were allegedly chosen for "summary resolution," or death,  by staff members seeking to minimize the orphan population. **********"The fact is that the evidence is really shocking," said Mr. Munro, who collaborated with Dr. Zhang and Jeff Rigsby, a freelance journalist, in producing the report. **********Mr. Munro said that even though the organization already had statistics showing high orphan mortality in early 1995, it was unwilling to confront Chinese officials with the evidence until it issued the report today. **********"Given that there has always been unremitting hostility in China's responses  to our organization, we didn't feel that they would engage us in any way," Mr. Munro said. "So we decided to put out our version first knowing that they would respond." **********Human Rights Watch officials said political considerations played no role in  the timing of the report, although it will have an inescapable impact on the deliberations of the United Nations Human Rights Commission in March in Geneva.  The United States and European nations have unsuccessfully sought for the past six years to have the commission approve a resolution condemning China's human rights record. **********China would like the United States to drop the annual confrontation, but human rights organizations have been pressing the White House to mount another effort this year, especially in light of the continuing harsh treatment of dissidents. **********In recent years, thousands of American and European couples have gone to Shanghai, Beijing and other Chinese cities seeking to adopt abandoned Chinese infants from the same orphanages where the abuses are said to be occurring. **********According to officials of Adoptive Family of America in Minneapolis, the national clearing house for adoptive parents, the State Department issued 1,369  visas for Chinese children in 1990-94. The group estimates that an additional 1,000 children came over for adoption since then. **********The new allegations follow earlier reports of "dying rooms" in Chinese orphanages, where unwanted or handicapped orphans were left to die of malnutrition. The Communist Party leadership has vigorously denied these allegations in each instance and has said it has a commitment to "nourish, treat and teach" orphans. **********Today, China's State Council under Prime Minister Li Peng issued a statement  saying, "The so-called accusations of 'torture and abuse of disabled children' by the Shanghai Welfare Institute are completely groundless." It said that after a "careful and thorough" investigation, "the relevant department of the Shanghai municipal government denied" the allegations. **********The State Council accused Human Rights Watch and the Chinese who collaborated in the investigation of instigating "anger," "hostility" and "political conspiracy" toward China. **********Reached by telephone in London, where she is collaborating on a television documentary about her experiences in Shanghai, Dr. Zhang said she decided to leave China with her husband because she and some of her colleagues had "exhausted all our efforts to report what we had discovered in the orphanage and get the problem corrected." **********"I had no other alternative but to turn to the human rights organizations," she said, "and now I want all the people in the world who believe that justice prevails to know about this." She said increased adoption of Chinese infants by  Western couples was saving only a "small number of children from mistreatment and from being starved to death," adding, "This alone cannot change the Communist Party's policies toward orphanages." **********Dr. Zhang's campaign to expose alleged abuses at the orphanage attracted significant support from members of the Shanghai People's Congress, a Communist  Party organization, along with several Chinese journalists and lawyers. They joined in pressing for a full investigation of conditions at the Shanghai institution, but their efforts failed in 1992 after party leaders in the city warned that a public airing of charges would open China to criticism from human  rights groups. **********One of the most vocal of the Shanghai party members who supported Dr. Zhang in 1992 was Hong Dalin, an economist at the Academy of Social Sciences in Shanghai. **********Reached by telephone today, Mr. Hong said he could not discuss the investgation because he was no longer a member of the Shanghai People's Congress. Dr. Zhang maintains that all of the local delegates who supported her  efforts were subsequently purged from jobs or party positions. **********"I hope to call the attention of the whole society to stop the Chinese Government from persecuting the orphans and witnesses who told us what they saw  and because of that have lost their jobs or been persecuted in other ways," she  said. **********The report describes abuses in Shanghai in the 1980's, during the tenure of Communist Party officials who went on to become senior leaders in Beijing, including President Jiang Zemin, who served as Mayor and Communist Party secretary of Shanghai from 1982 to 1989. **********Zhu Rongji and Wu Bangguo, now deputy prime ministers under Li Peng, both served in top municipal posts in Shanghai as the investigation unfolded within the party. **********The Human Rights Watch report singles out Mr. Wu as chiefly responsible for quashing the investigation, overseeing a campaign of persecution and banning any mention of the accusations in Shanghai's state-run news media. Mr. Wu declined requests to comment. **********Huang Jiachun, the deputy director of the Shanghai orphanage, said in a telephone interview that Dr. Zhang's allegations and evidence were "fabricated"  and that the Shanghai Supervision Bureau, an investigative arm of the Communist  Party, had proved that the charges of abuse and neglect "were wrong." Orphanage  officials have invited foreign journalists to visit the orphanage on Monday. **********Human Rights Watch said its investigation indicated a "sinister" effort by administrators to improve the outward appearance of the Shanghai orphanage since 1993, and alleged that many infant and handicapped orphans are now being transferred to a heavily guarded Shanghai orphanage and mental institution on an island in the Yangtze River. The group warned that continued abuse of orphans has been reported there. **********After spending "nearly a year gathering and analyzing documentary, testimonial and photographic evidence on the treatment of orphans and abandoned  children in state institutions," Susan Osnos, the group's communications director, said in a statement accompanying the report, "the material reveals a pattern of cruelty, abuse and malign neglect in child welfare work which now constitutes one of the country's gravest human rights problems." **********In June, when a British television network broadcast a documentary titled "The Dying Rooms," the Chinese Embassy in London issued a statement saying, "China has all along attached great importance to the healthy development of children, and is committed to the substantial protection of the rights of children, orphans in particular, by legislative, judicial and administrative means. **********"The rights of children, including those of orphans, are protected by the Constitution of the People's Republic of China. Chinese laws prohibit the abuse  of orphans and anybody who violates the relevant laws will be brought to justice."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/11/world.main_headline: World News Briefs;Burmese Refuse To Extradite Drug Lord
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/11/world.print_headline: World News Briefs;Burmese Refuse To Extradite Drug Lord
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/11/world.body_text: **********The Burmese Government has refused to extradite a reputed opium lord to the United States, where he is wanted on heroin trafficking charges. **********There is no question of extradition with any country," Foreign Minister Ohn  Gyaw said on Friday of Washington's request to hand over Khun Sa, who was indicted by a Federal grand jury in New York in December 1989 for drug dealing and who surrendered to Burmese Army forces last month. **********Mr. Ohn Gyaw's comments, at a ceremony to destroy confiscated drugs, were the first time a senior official for Myanmar, formerly Burma, publicly said the  Government had no plans to extradite Khun Sa. **********"In 1990 we received a request from an embassy to have U Khun Sa extradited," he said. "And we have called to the attention of that particular nation that there never existed any extradition treaty, and we have no intention whatsoever  of an extradition." **********Despite the absence of a treaty, Washington has sought the extradition of Khun Sa, who was indicted on 10 counts of importing or attempting to smuggle 3,500 pounds of heroin into New York from 1986 and 1988.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/17/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********I was surprised that the listed solutions to Social Security's problems did not mention the most obvious and simplest way of keeping the system solvent longer: removing the provision that makes it the most regressive tax ever invented. **********The Federal Government currently takes 6.2 percent of the first $62,500 of earned income. Up to that point, it is a flat tax, which is regressive enough. But after $62,500, the tax turns spectacularly regressive: no more tax is taken  from income. **********The very least we should do is remove the income cap. At a minimum, that will remove the troubling inequity of "the higher my income, the lower my tax rate."  And the income generated would help keep Social Security solvent longer. **********ADELE DECKINGER Jamaica, Queens, Feb. 18 **********The writer is a retired statistician.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/20/busin.body_text: **********The United States Treasury will take no disciplinary action against Lehman Brothers Holding Inc. for violations in 1994 and 1995 of laws governing Treasury auctions, the department said today. **********The Treasury said it had found no proof that the 13 violations, which took place in the six months before May 31, 1995, were intentional. Lehman officials also took steps to insure that such errors would  not occur again, the Treasury said. **********''We have found no evidence that the reporting errors reflect any intent or effort by Lehman Brothers to manipulate or control the market for the securities in question,'' said John Hawke, the Treasury's Under Secretary for domestic finance, in a letter to Lehman Brothers dated today. ''Rather, the reporting mistakes appear to have resulted from mistakes attributable to improperly trained staff and inadequate internal operating procedures.'' Lehman incorrectly reported the amount of Government securities it owned after 13 Treasury auctions, a violation of Treasury rules for those auctions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/08/news/.main_headline: Surge in Jobs Stirs Fears of an Increase In Interest Rates : Don't Brake Economy, Clinton Tells Central Bank
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/08/news/.print_headline: Surge in Jobs Stirs Fears of an Increase In Interest Rates : Don't Brake Economy, Clinton Tells Central Bank
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/08/news/.body_text: **********NEW YORK—                     The U.S. economy created double the number of jobs in May that was forecast, prompting President Bill Clinton to appeal to the Federal Reserve Board not to raise interest rates and kill the nation's economic expansion in an election year. **********The president jawboned the central bank publicly by appearing in the White House Rose Garden an hour after the Labor Department reported that 348,000 jobs were created last month, against a revised 163,000 in April. **********There was a slight upward blip in the overall unemployment rate, to 5.6 percent in May from 5.4 percent in April, as a wave of young people entered the labor force. But those young workers also helped triple the monthly number of new jobs in services, to 181,000. Manufacturing jobs increased by only 6,000 after declining for two months. **********But what was good news for Main Street was bad news for Wall Street — "a shocker," as Bruce Steinberg, a Merrill Lynch economist, told clients. **********What worries Wall Street and the Federal Reserve Board is wage pressure driving up prices. But average hourly wages rose only 0.3 percent last month, barely ahead of the inflation rate. **********In contrast with organized industrial workers, wage pressure from the new jobs is nonexistent, said Audrey Freedman, a consulting labor economist. **********"There are about 3 million young people looking for new jobs," she said, "2 million of them students working for the summer in retailing, food and recreation. They are not the ones who raise wages." **********Still, prices of Treasury securities plunged on inflation fears, raising the yield of the 30-year benchmark bond to 7.02 percent from 6.89 percent Thursday. The stock market fared better, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing up 29.92 points, at 5,697.11. (Page 10) **********Mr. Clinton spoke as congressional Democrats continued to delay approval of his two nominees for the Fed and his renomination of Alan Greenspan as chairman. The lawmakers have accused Mr. Greenspan, a Republican, of unnecessarily braking economic growth to curb inflation — but the president said there was "no evidence in this economy" of rising prices. **********"If they see that we are producing this level of job growth with no inflation," Mr. Clinton said, "I think that interest rates should stay down — not only the Fed rates but the rates that the markets set." **********In fact relief may be on the way from the markets themselves, said John Lipsky of Salomon Brothers. **********"The Fed, like most forecasters, is trying to figure out how much momentum the economy has," he said. "It was ignited in the spring by last year's lower interest rates, by the shifting of demand into the spring because of the bad winter weather and the government shutdowns and by high personal savings now being spent." **********"The ignition has been turned off on the first two," he said. "Higher long-term bond rates may slow spending and the economy along with it, and if that happens, the Fed would have to do nothing." **********Like most private economists, the Fed has been expecting the economy to slow down later this year, and Sam Kahan of A.S.K. Financial Research said that before the Federal Open Market Committee meets July 2-3 to set interest rate policy for the year, it would look very carefully at the June figures for a "flattening" out of the statistical momentum. **********He said that "marginal" signs of such a tapering had already appeared in lower unemployment claims, smaller money supply, and a slowdown in consumer spending and housing. **********In any case, he added, the policy-making committee is unlikely to change rates before Mr. Clinton's two new appointees are on board. **********If Congress can delay approval of the new members into July, he said, the Fed will not take any action until its next meeting, in August, too late to affect the economy before the November election.

In the deal announced this week, Enron Global will exchange 1.6 million newly issued shares for the pipeline stake. The Enron Corporation, based in Houston, owns 52  percent of Enron Global and the stake will be 55 percent once the transaction is completed.

The 20-state storm of March 1993, the fifth-most-costly  catastrophe, resulted in $1.75 billion of claims. [Page 1.] **********Huge Chip Growth in '95 **********The semiconductor market grew by a remarkable 40 percent in 1995, to $154.7 billion in revenue, according to a report by Dataquest, a market research firm.  The industry benefited from the enormous applications in all types of electronics, not just personal computers. Another good year is predicted. Intel  continued to lead the industry; its revenue totaled $13.8 billion in 1995. But stock market investors seized on the company's new  prominence, driving its share price up sharply. [50.] **********During the final stages of the negotiations with Loral, it appears that some options traders got word of what was going on. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [51.] **********A New Logo In South Africa  The national airline of South Africa is forming an unusual partnership to develop a revamped look for everything from the logos on the tails of the planes to the color scheme of the ticket folders. https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/31/busin.main_headline: Judge Rejects Effort to Link Implant Suits
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/31/busin.print_headline: Judge Rejects Effort to Link Implant Suits
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/31/busin.body_text: **********A Federal judge in Detroit yesterday refused to consolidate thousands of lawsuits over silicone breast implants in her court. **********The Dow Chemical Corporation, which owns 50 percent of the Dow Corning Corporation, an implant maker, had sought to combine product-liability cases against it with the bankruptcy proceedings of Dow Corning. Plaintiffs opposed the plan, preferring to bring cases in separate state and Federal courts. **********Judge Denise Page Hood of the Federal District Court in Detroit decided yesterday to abstain from hearing the implant cases, scuttling the plan. **********Dow Chemical said it would seek an "immediate review" of the decision, which  the company said would saddle the court system with "staggering costs." **********Dow Chemical is a 50 percent owner of Dow Corning along with Corning Inc. and is itself the target of thousands of implant suits. **********Dow Chemical and implant manufacturers like Baxter International Inc., the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company and the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company  want to concentrate litigation in a single court to make best use of new scientific evidence that disclaims any link between implants and disease. **********In April, the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals, in Cincinnati, ruled that all of the implant litigation was related to Dow Corning's bankruptcy and should be  concentrated in the same Federal district. **********But the ruling left Judge Hood the option of abstaining judgment, which she exercised.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/14/world.main_headline: After 21 Years, Bangladeshi Party Is Returned to Power
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/14/world.print_headline: After 21 Years, Bangladeshi Party Is Returned to Power
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/14/world.body_text: **********Nearly 21 years after it lost its leader and its grip on power in an army massacre, the Awami League, the political party that won Bangladesh its independence from Pakistan, returned from the political wilderness today as the  winner of a general election. **********The new Prime Minister is almost certain to be Sheik Hasina Wazed, 48, who was one of only two members of the immediate family to escape the attack in 1975 that killed her father, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the first Prime Minister and later President of Bangladesh. Mrs. Wazed greeted the victory today at a home in the Dhalmondi district in Dhaka, a few hundred yards from the house, now a memorial, where her father and more than a dozen other relatives died in a hail of automatic fire. **********For Mrs. Wazed the victory, which appeared to have left the Awami League only a few seats short of a majority in the 300-seat Parliament, marked the culmination of almost half a lifetime spent seeking restitution for what was lost when rebellious army officers gunned her family down. Years of exile in India, followed by a decade of struggle to rebuild the Awami League under hostile military governments, left deep scars on Mrs. Wazed, who often seemed driven by a burning zeal for revenge against her family's killers. **********But when she met reporters tonight to claim victory in the election, Mrs. Wazed struck a note of reconciliation that seemed likely to be widely welcomed across this nation of 120 million people, which has often been described as a country desperately in need of better fortune. In its brief history since the 1971 civil war, Bangladesh has been blighted by military coups and assassinations almost as much as it has been by its legacy of grinding poverty and of natural cataclysms, including cyclones and epic floods. **********"We will heal the wounds, not create new ones, unite the nation, not divide it," Mrs. Wazed said. "We will immediately initiate consultations with all the political forces in the country and begin a process of reconciliation." **********For the two countries that emerged from the 1971 war, Mrs. Wazed's victory completed an unusual political symmetry. The two politicians who more than any others drove Pakistan to dismemberment were Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, the dominant political figure in what was West Pakistan, and Sheikh Mujibur, his counterpart  in East Pakistan. Both men were later killed, Mr. Bhutto in an execution ordered by the military Government that took power in Pakistan in 1977. Now Mr. Bhutto's daughter, Benazir, is Prime Minister of Pakistan, and Sheikh Mujibur's daughter  is set to become Prime Minister of Bangladesh. **********If Mrs. Wazed succeeds in reaching out to smaller parties for the few votes she lacks for a parliamentary majority to form a new Government, she seems unlikely to produce any new political shocks of the kind Bangladeshis have endured in the past. **********The policies laid out in the election by Mrs. Wazed and her main rival, Khaleda Zia, of the Bangladesh Nationalist Party, were virtually identical on all important domestic and foreign issues, including continuation of Bangladesh's free-market economic reforms. **********But because the volatility of politics here has grown from personal enmities, it is far from certain Mrs. Wazed's victory will be accepted. **********As the results on the voting Wednesday were coming in, Mrs. Zia threatened to order her followers into the streets to contest the outcome. Aides to Mrs. Zia,  Prime Minister for the last five years , said she was planning to stage demonstrations against what they described as "election rigging" in favor of Mrs. Wazed's party. **********The losing party's assertions of unfairness contradicted at least a dozen election monitoring groups, including several from the United States and Europe, who nearly unanimously endorsed the fairness of the election. Mrs. Zia's party appeared to be positioning itself to pay Mrs. Wazed back in kind for more than two years of opposition street protests and general strikes that destabilized Mrs. Zia's Government and severely damaged what had been a highly successful program of free-enterprise economics reforms. **********Tonight, incomplete results announced by the election commission gave Mrs. Wazed's Awami League a firm count of 133 seats and a lead in 13 other seats, for a possible total of 146 of the 300 seats in the contest. Mrs. Zia's Bangladesh Nationalist Party won 104 seats and was leading in 10 others, for a possible total of 114 seats. The Jatiya Party, a group that is the personal political vehicle of the last military ruler, Gen. Hussein Muhammed Ershad, won 29 seats and was leading in 5 others, for a possible total of 34 seats. **********Three seats were won, or seemed likely to be won, by a Muslim fundamentalist  group, the Jamaat-i-Islami, which appeared to have been one of the election's big losers, down from 18 seats in the last Parliament, and the three remaining seats went to splinter groups. **********The blow to the Muslim fundamentalists was a major surprise, suggesting that  their efforts to foment opposition to successful social programs in rural areas  of this overwhelmingly Muslim country, including drives to spread literacy and birth-control programs among women, may have backfired in an election in which women voted in record numbers, as high as 80 percent of those eligible in some areas. **********The announcement of the results was complicated by the election commission's  decision to withhold formal proclamation of the winners in 29 parliamentary districts where there were reports of election malpractices or vote-counting problems. While the commission announced which parties were leading in each of the districts, no final outcome will be known until after a repeat round of voting the commission has ordered next Wednesday at some of the polling stations in 27 of the 29 districts. **********Thirty parliamentary seats that are reserved for women will be allocated between the parties in Parliament on a proportional basis. **********The likelihood of any significant change in the election's overall result was slim, since the malpractices cited by the election commission -- and the new voting it ordered -- affected only 123 of the 26,000 polling stations across the country. "I'm very positive that the election has been fair, it has been transparent, and it has been impartial," said Abu Mohammed Hena, a retired senior government official who was called in only two months ago to direct, and  overhaul, an election commission appointed by Mrs. Zia that was widely regarded  as biased. **********But the pride that many felt at having conducted a relatively unflawed election -- and having shaken off, as many Bangladeshis saw it, a reputation for chronic political immaturity -- was mixed with a wariness at what Mrs. Zia's next move might be. With most Bangladeshis exhausted by the tumult of the last two years, and apparently satisfied that the election was fair, staging demonstrations may be more difficult than it was for Mrs. Wazed. **********But Mrs. Zia, 50, has potentially powerful weapons if she chooses to continue the enmity with Mrs. Wazed, not the least of which is that she is the widow of a former military ruler, Gen. Zia ur-Rahman, and has strong backing in the army. **********One option that seemed closed to Mrs. Zia was a coalition to block Mrs. Wazed. Although the balance of power in parliament will be held by the Jatiya Party of General Ershad, who is serving a prison term in Dhaka for corruption during his nine-year rule, Mrs. Zia has accused General Ershad of complicity in  the assassination of her husband, General Zia, in 1981. **********Aides to General Ershad appeared at a news conference tonight to say they would support whichever of the two main parties met their demand for General Ershad's release, but neither the Awami League nor the Bangladesh Nationalist Party seemed in any hurry to comply. **********Mrs. Wazed may yet face uneasy days as she maneuvers to consolidate a parliamentary majority. Her anxieties tonight seemed focused on the Awami League's old nemesis, the army. In her victory statement, she concluded with what sounded like an appeal against any inclination to stage another coup. **********The statement called for "a smooth transfer of power in line with the will of the people," and said: "At this critical juncture, those heading the different institutions of the Republic must assist this process in every way. There should be no attempt to thwart the electoral will of the people."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/24/busin.main_headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Salomon's Earnings Soared In First-Quarter Rebound
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/24/busin.print_headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Salomon's Earnings Soared In First-Quarter Rebound
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/24/busin.body_text: **********Salomon Inc., recovering from a difficult 1995, said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings more than tripled, to $276 million, from $81 million in the first quarter of last year, thanks to robust securities trading and investment banking revenues. **********Salomon, the parent of one of the largest United States securities firms, Salomon Brothers, and of Phibro, a commodity trading company, reported earnings  of $2.44 a share, far exceeding both analysts' expectations for about $1 a share, as well as the 59 cents a share it reported for last year's first quarter. In the fourth quarter of 1995, Salomon reported net income of $168 million, or $1.32 a share. **********They had a pretty good first quarter," Alison A. Deans, an analyst at Smith Barney Inc., said. "Their earnings volatility is more a function of their mix of businesses," she said, adding that about half of Salomon's equity capital is devoted to trading for its own account, a notoriously volatile business. **********And, as analysts have stressed, this was a great quarter for securities firms, which reported banner earnings. "Expectations were pretty high, and as each firm reported its results, it has exceeded expectations, so the expectations kept rising. And Salomon beat even those," Raphael Soifer, an analyst at Brown Brothers Harriman, said. **********Salomon's leaders were happy, even relieved, by the company's improved performance, a change from 1995, when defections and poor results dogged the brokerage unit. **********"The first quarter's results are based on the outstanding performance of our  securities and commodities businesses," Robert E. Denham, chairman and chief executive of Salomon Inc., said. "Our balance of customer businesses and proprietary risk-taking is producing solid results." **********Deryck C. Maughan, chairman and chief executive of Salomon Brothers, called the results "excellent" and said the firm's objective "is to build underwriting  and advisory revenues and to maintain effective control of our trading risk." **********At Salomon Brothers, pretax income increased more than sixfold, to $368 million, from $60 million in last year's first quarter. The only significant blot on the report was the decline in revenues from stock sales and trading revenues, after allowing for interest expense, to $64 million, from $152 million a year earlier. In a discussion with analysts yesterday, Jerome H. Bailey, Salomon's chief financial officer, cited losses on long-term equity arbitrage positions in Japan. **********But investment banking did particularly well, with revenues rising 53 percent, to $181 million in the first quarter from a quarterly average of $118 million in 1995. **********Phibro reported pretax income of $145 million in the first quarter, compared  with $123 million in the period a year earlier, and reflecting the favorable commodity markets. **********Salomon Inc.'s return on equity jumped to 26 percent in the first quarter, compared with 7 percent a year earlier. Salomon shares, which have risen in recent weeks, climbed 50 cents to close at $41.25. **********Discussing the share price, Ms. Deans said that "near term, they may be due for a bit of a bounce, but I can't see it getting higher than the mid-40's." She said that while she was encouraged by Salomon's management of expenses, she "still wouldn't put them anywhere near the league of the Morgan Stanley's and Merrill Lynch's of the world."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/24/busin.main_headline: When On-Line Service Cannot Be Counted On
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/24/busin.print_headline: When On-Line Service Cannot Be Counted On
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/24/busin.body_text: **********Blame sunspots or planetary alignment, computer gremlins or human error. More than a million computer network users suffered interrupted or erratic Internet and on-line service connections last week because of a variety of planned and unplanned service shutdowns. **********Because of a single bad line in a computer program, Netcom On-Line Communications Inc. had to shut down its entire national system for 12 hours on Wednesday, affecting more than 400,000 Internet users, most of them businesses. **********The Microsoft Corporation shut down its entire network Sunday for as long as 10 hours as part of a long-scheduled upgrade of the system's backup power supply. But after US West, which was to install the system, said on Thursday that itwas not ready, Microsoft decided to use the scheduled shutdown to do additional system upgrades. The company will have to take its 1 million subscribers off line again in the fall. **********The electronic mail system of America Online, the largest on-line service with more than 6 million subscribers, was knocked out for an hour Wednesday afternoon when a planned system software upgrade backfired. **********Meanwhile, the AT&T Corporation, which entered the consumer Internet market earlier this year, announced that it would shut down its system for as long as 8 hours every week for maintenance, affecting more than 100,000 Internet customers. **********System failures and software bugs are hardly new for the Internet. But the scope of the problems and maintenance announcements last week surprised many observers, as well as the companies involved. **********"Can you imagine the outcry if AT&T took down the phone system for 8 hours a  week?" said Dennis Moore, vice president of marketing at the Oracle Corporation, a software data base company that provides services to banks, stock exchanges and other customers who do not like technical surprises. **********Part of the strain on the systems comes from the constant surge of new Internet and on-line service users, thought to be at least 10,000 a day in the United States alone. Part comes from the rapid pace of technological change in Internet hardware and software technologies. And part comes from the chaotic nature of the unregulated Internet itself. **********Unlike the telephone system, which has relatively few service providers and a technical infrastructure that has been tightly regulated for decades, the Internet has thousands of independent service providers, many of them in business only a few years. To compete, they change software and hardware frequently. Technical standards are in flux, whipsawed by the intense competition among companies like Microsoft, Netscape, Sun and Oracle. **********Whatever the causes, the conflict of rising consumer expectations and increasing system crashes are likely to cause a shift in the way Internet services are marketed. **********"In the next year, competition between providers is going to be based more on reliability than on price," said Tom Evslin, an AT&T vice president who heads AT&T Worldnet Services. "As users make the Internet a part of their daily lives  and businesses, it will be very important that it be available and reliable all  the time. Quality will be one of the key areas of the competition." **********Mr. Evslin said AT&T decided to announce the scheduled weekly shutdowns, which occur from 3 A.M. to 7 A.M. Eastern time on Tuesdays and Thursdays, as a way to insure reliable operations at all other times. He said the service does not always go down for the full eight hours, and he noted that as a result of the down time, the service has not had any unscheduled outages. **********AT&T's entry into the Internet service business rocked the industry. The telephone giant already has 90 million long-distance customers, and in promoting its Internet service, AT&T trumpeted its reputation of reliability in the phone  business. **********A spokeswoman for America Online said overall system reliability has improved significantly since 1994, when hordes of new users overwhelmed the service's network capacity, causing widespread shutdowns and slowdowns. The company also has periodic scheduled shutdowns for system maintenance. **********Although Mr. Moore asserted that Oracle's own internal network of 23,000 users was 100 percent reliable, others suggested that fail-safe Internet service for most consumers may not soon be ready. **********Even installing new technologies to provide improved reliability and backup capacity is a nightmare for global Internet providers like Microsoft, 40 percent of whose users are in Europe and Asia. Taking the system down after midnight in  Redmond, Wash., for example, will knock out users in London, Tokyo and Sydney. **********Sara Fitzgerald, a spokeswoman for the Interactive Services Association, whose members come from the telecommunications, on-line and Internet industries, said that rapid subscriber growth, technological upheaval, global network expansion and traditional storm-related summer power problems would likely continue to put stress on networks. **********"When computers and software and hardware are involved, these these things can happen," Ms. Fitzgerald said. "As the population of users grows to include people who are less technically oriented, there may be less understanding of the problems of keeping systems up. It will take time for everyone to learn more about what is reasonable and what is satisfactory." **********The programmer whose botched line of code caused hundreds of Netcom engineers to work all night tracing the bug is still employed. "He feels bad enough already," said David Garrison, president of Netcom in Santa Clara, Calif. "We are on the learning edge of this new technology, doing it on a scale never done  before. Part of that is trying the best you can, but recognizing that there are  going to be mistakes made."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/19/busin.snippet: New type of Internet sabotage recently reported by small New York-based service provider is spreading and has now occurred at dozen or more other World Wide Web sites around nation; attacks tie up network computers by bombarding server with more r...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/19/busin.main_headline: A New Method of Internet Sabotage Is Spreading
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/19/busin.print_headline: A New Method of Internet Sabotage Is Spreading
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/19/busin.body_text: **********A new type of Internet sabotage reported recently by a small New York-based service provider is spreading and has now occurred at least a dozen other World Wide Web sites around the nation. **********So far, the attacks, which tie up network computers so other users cannot have access to them, have created more of a nuisance than any real damage. But they have inconvenienced organizations that include the the Public Access Networks Corporation and the Internet Chess Club. **********And while the federally financed Computer Emergency Response Team at the Software Engineering Institute at Carnegie-Mellon University believes the incidents are primarily the work of unsophisticated vandals who are passing around a recipe for this type of break-in, officials concede that there is no easy defense against the attack. **********The response team is preparing a warning that will be distributed over the Internet to government, university and corporate network administrators. **********The attacks, first reported on Sept. 12 by the operators of Public Access Networks in New York actually began about six weeks ago, according to Computer Emergency Response Team officials. The identities of the victims of these earlier attacks have not yet been released. **********By bombarding an Internet server with more than a hundred requests for service each second, each coming from a randomly generated false address, the attacker is able to shut out legitimate users. **********Computer Emergency Response Team officials said they were drafting an advisory that they planned to release by the end of the day today. The warning will detail the nature of the attack and its impact on the Internet community. **********''We have no solution now,'' said Larry Rogers, a senior member of the response team's technical staff. ''But we believe that we can limit the impact.'' **********Other network security experts are less optimistic. **********''I wish there was cheery news here,'' said Eugene Spafford, director of the Computer Operating Audit Security and Technology Laboratory at Purdue University.  ''It's clear that antisocial individuals with a grudge and a PC can do tremendous damage.'' **********And Alexis Rosen, co-founder of Public Access Networks, said the number of sites attacked might be in the hundreds, based on reports from network administrators who fear being identified. Mr. Rosen said that his company had devised a shield against his particular attacker. But he said that his remedy would not necessarily work against a determined vandal using a more powerful computer. **********Internet sites reporting attacks include at least two chess server computers, which enable users to play chess electronically against remote opponents. **********Daniel Sleator, a professor of computer science at Carnegie-Mellon and an organizer of the Internet Chess Club, said that his organization's host computer had been attacked last week by the flooding program and that the attacks had continued on Monday. **********''The problems are not devastating but they are quite irritating,'' he said. ''I think this is sick, but I guess that is what these guys do.'' **********Mr. Sleator said the club had dealt with the problem by making other ports, or electronic doors, available to its members. **********He said the source of the attack had been traced back as far as Netcom On-Line Communications Services Inc., an Internet provider based in San Jose, Calif. But Netcom officials have had difficulty persuading another Internet service provider to help them trace the attacks further, Mr. Sleator said. **********Several people familiar with the investigation said that security officials were close to identifying at least some of the culprits who were  conducting the attacks. **********Recipes for conducting the attack, which has been known to Internet security experts for some time but never before seen deployed on a widespread basis, were recently published in two underground computer publications, 2600 and Phrack. **********Security officials are concerned because this type of attack exploits the basic design of the Internet itself. The software protocols, or routing instructions, on which the Internet is based were not designed to prevent this message flooding, and so the attacks are difficult to prevent or counteract. **********One partial solution is to configure each Internet service provider's routing computers so that they will not permit users to transmit messages that contain bogus addresses. But since there are now millions of computers connected to the Internet, it would be impossible to make certain that each Internet service provider adhered to this solution. **********Several makers of network server computers were working intently yesterday to develop mechanisms that might protect against the attack. One possibility is using cryptographic, or data scrambling, techniques to make certain that the computer sending a message is positively identified before the recipient computer attempts to process the message. But even if such a solution was perfected, the necessary software would have to be widely distributed before it could act as a widespread deterrent to the attacks. **********Another vexing problem is tracing the location of a malicious computer user who is transmitting false addresses over the Internet. The network was not constructed to make it easy to trace the true location of such a hidden attacker through the network.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/31/world.main_headline: World News Briefs;Peru Tribunal Denies U.S. Woman's Appeal
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/31/world.print_headline: World News Briefs;Peru Tribunal Denies U.S. Woman's Appeal
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/31/world.body_text: **********A Peruvian military tribunal today rejected the appeal by an American woman of her conviction and life sentence for helping to lead a Marxist guerrilla group, her local lawyer said. **********"I received a communique from the Supreme Council of Military Justice saying  that Lori Berenson's sentence has been confirmed and her appeal rejected," said  the lawyer, Grimaldo Achahui. **********A secret military court on Jan. 11 convicted Ms. Berenson, 26, of Manhattan, on charges that she was a member of the pro-Cuban Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement in Peru. **********The decision angered her family and lawyers, who said she had not been given  a fair trial. **********Mr. Achahui said he was "surprised" and "disappointed" by the failure of the  appeal. **********"They do not have a case in law," he said. "They have failed completely to answer the points raised by the defense." **********Ms. Berenson has already begun her life sentence at the Yanamayo maximum security prison in the Andean city of Puno.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/12/world.main_headline: Egidio Ortona, Italian Envoy to U.S., Dies at 85
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/12/world.print_headline: Egidio Ortona, Italian Envoy to U.S., Dies at 85
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/12/world.body_text: **********Egidio Ortona, a veteran diplomat who nurtured the postwar revival of Italy's close relationship with the United States and served as the Italian Ambassador to Washington, died here on Wednesday. He was 85. **********Mr. Ortona was born in Casale Monferrato in the Piedmont region of northern Italy. After obtaining a degree in law from the University of Turin in 1931, he  entered the diplomatic service, serving as consul in Egypt and South Africa. **********Mr. Ortona rose quickly through the ranks, which were still largely dominated by the Piedmontese, who led Italy's 19th-century drive for national unification. **********Mr. Ortona observed the collapse of Italy's relations with the Western Allies and Italy's entry into the war on the side of Nazi Germany from his middle-level diplomatic post in London in the late 1930's, and later served in the office of  Giuseppe Bastianini, the wartime governor of occupied Dalmatia, in Yugoslavia. **********Returning to Rome with Mr. Bastianini, Mr. Ortona witnessed the overthrow of  Mussolini's Fascist dictatorship in 1943 and the devastation of his country by the war. His experiences forged in him a belief in the need for close Italian links to the United States. **********In late 1944, Mr. Ortona was selected as a member of a delegation of bankers  and diplomats who went to Washington to obtain financial assistance from the United States for the reconstruction of Italy. The delegation's contacts laid the foundation for the close ties that later developed between Rome and Washington. **********In 1947 Mr. Ortona was posted to the Italian Embassy in Washington when the Prime Minister, Alcide De Gasperi, made a visit to the United States that secured Italy's inclusion in the Marshall Plan and its membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, which was established in 1949. **********In 1959 Mr. Ortona became Italy's delegate to the United Nations. Returning to Rome in 1961, he held several senior positions at the Foreign Ministry before returning to Washington in 1967 as Ambassador, a post in which he served until his retirement in 1975. **********"He always remained faithful to the idea of the alliance with America," said  Sergio Romano, a foreign policy expert and longtime friend. **********In the 1980's, Mr. Ortona published a three-volume memoir, "Years of America," and recollections of the war years, "The Diplomacy of War." **********He is survived by a daughter, Donatella Ferrario Ortona, and two sons, Danda  and Ludovico.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/18/busin.body_text: **********An additional 35 million bottles of Scotch whisky were sold in 1995, a trade  association said today, cheering an industry that has stumbled badly over the last decade and a half. Scotch distillers sold the equivalent of 935 million bottles last year, an increase of 3.8 percent from 1994 and approaching record sales from the peak years of 1978-79. A drop in consumption in the 1980's hit the Scotch whisky industry hard. Since 1979, the industry's employment has fallen to 14,000 people from 26,000. There are slightly fewer than 100 distilleries in business, compared with 130 in the late 1970's.
