https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/19/world.print_headline: Guatemalan Amnesty Is Approved Over Opponents' Objections
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/19/world.body_text: **********Struggling to the last moment with the legacy of hatred and brutality left by a long civil war, the Guatemalan National Assembly approved a comprehensive amnesty law today that opponents say will allow many human-rights offenders to go unpunished. **********The new law, which President Alvaro Arzu Irigoyen is certain to sign, removes the last major barrier to the signing on Dec. 29 of a final accord to put an end to 36 years of armed conflict in this Central American nation of 10.5 million people. **********The legislation was backed by both combatant groups, the Guatemalan Armed Forces and the Guatemalan National Revolutionary Unity, but has been criticized by human-rights groups here and abroad. **********At least 100,000 people have been killed, mostly by army and paramilitary forces, in the civil war here. An additional 40,000 are listed as ''disappeared,'' thousands more have been raped, tortured or illegally detained, and more than one million have been forced into exile by the violence or displaced from their homes. **********Formally, the bill approved late today is not an amnesty at all, but a ''law of National Reconciliation'' that ''extinguishes criminal responsibility'' for offenses deemed to be political. That terminology appears to have been chosen because a 1994 accord between the two sides that was brokered by the United Nations prohibits the Guatemalan Government from ''promoting'' any measures to prevent the prosecution of human-rights violations. **********With members of the public not allowed into the gallery, the final debate was witnessed only by reporters and the 80 members of Guatemala's national assembly. In a protest against what they saw as inadequacies in the legislation, deputies from the New Guatemala Democratic Front walked out of the chamber before the final vote was taken. **********Several members of that left-wing party are spouses or parents of people who were killed or forcibly abducted at the height of the conflict 15 years ago. The law was supported, on the other hand, by the ruling National Advancement Party and the rightist Guatemalan Republican Front, whose leader, Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, was the country's military ruler at that time. **********''It's a farce, starting from the name,'' said Carmen Aida Ibarra Moran of the Myrna Mack Foundation, a human-rights group named for an anthropologist killed by a military death squad in 1990. ''This is a truly disappointing result.'' **********The main area of conflict in the final debate was an article that specifies which offenses are to be excluded from the amnesty. The version approved by legislators today states, ''This law will not be applicable to the crimes of genocide, torture and forced disappearance.'' **********Human-rights groups, however, had sought to add ''extra judicial killings'' and ''illegal detention'' to the list of offenses that would still be subject to prosecution. Their version also would have specifically prohibited immunity from prosecution not only for those who took part in such activities, but also for those who ordered them or covered them up, including senior military officers and guerrilla commanders. **********Though the Government's original draft bill did not mention genocide as an offense, human-rights groups did not see the addition of that term as a significant victory. They argue that it is much easier to establish that the mass killing of the inhabitants of an Indian village took place, for example, than to prove such a massacre was motivated by racial or ethnic considerations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/21/world.snippet: Romania, where contraception and abortions were strictly forbidden during decades of Communist rule, has become what Western doctors call 'abortion culture;' has abortion rate that remains highest in Europe, as well as by far highest rate of pregn...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/21/world.body_text: **********Dorina Ciuplan, a 40-year-old mother of three teen-agers, recalled with a mixture of terror and emotion the nine self-induced abortions she endured during Communist rule under Nicolae Ceausescu. **********''I sometimes think I'm lucky to be alive,'' said Mrs. Ciuplan, her eyes watering as she described forcing miscarriages at home and then going to a hospital, where doctors and nurses tormented her with abusive words and rough treatment as they finished terminating the pregnancies rather than let her die. **********For more than two decades, contraception and abortions were strictly forbidden by Mr. Ceausescu in an attempt to build his country into a colossus through population growth. His government was overthrown in 1989, and one of its legacies was orphanages filled with unwanted and neglected children. **********Another legacy of those horrific years, for Romania's women, is abortion. Some 10,000 women are believed to have died from complications of illegal abortions, and many more were permanently maimed. **********Abortions were legalized as soon as Mr. Ceausescu was toppled, and  contraception is theoretically available through the state health system. **********But overwhelmingly, Romania remains what Western doctors call an ''abortion culture,'' with an abortion rate that remains the highest in Europe. It also has by far the highest rate of pregnancy-related mortality, the strongest indication that Romania continues to lag far behind the rest of Europe and Russia in providing reproductive health services for women. **********According to the United Nations Population Fund, Romania had 3.2 abortions for every live birth in 1990. By last year, the rate was 2.2 abortions per live birth. In 1995, the equivalent rate was 2.0 in Russia, 0.67 in the Czech Republic and Hungary and 0.2 in Germany. **********The reasons why Romanian women turn to abortion center on the reluctance of the Government to promote family-planning despite healthy doses of Western aid to help the country establish such services, Western and Romanian doctors say. Iulian Mincu, who was Minister of Health until recently and who had been a personal physician to Mr. Ceausescu, publicly stated his opposition to family planning. After a public outcry over poor conditions in the health system, Dr. Mincu was dismissed this summer by Mr. Ceausescu's successor, Ion Iliescu, in an attempt to clean up the Government's image before parliamentary and presidential elections that Mr. Iliescu lost anyway. **********The President-elect, Emil Constantinescu, made it clear during his campaign that he would make improved health services a priority, and family planning advocates said they were optimistic that the new Government would be more supportive of their efforts. **********Without guidance from the Government, many Romanian doctors have been more enthusiastic about the more lucrative work of performing abortions than about recommending birth control, said Daniela Draghica, one of the administrators of 12 pilot family-planning clinics in Romania opened in 1995 and financed by the United States Agency for International Development. **********The state pays for abortions, but as with almost all public health services women say they feel obliged to give the doctor a sizable extra payment, thus making abortions more financially rewarding. **********A 28-year-old woman who would give only a first name, Adina, was at the gynecological clinic at Giulesti Hospital in Bucharest. She said she had had six abortions. An abortion costs 3,000 lei, a little less than $1, at public hospitals, where the vast majority of Romanians get their health care. But she said she had paid an additional $7 as a ''gift'' to the doctor. **********On top of this, many doctors, repeating myths from the Ceausescu years, tell women exaggerated stories that oral contraceptives are deleterious to their health, Mrs. Draghica said. **********''Women had these myths about contraception,'' Mrs. Draghica said. ''The doctors had told them that pills were bad because they made women fat and gave them heart disease. It's a battle to get their confidence.'' **********Some women are beginning to look for other alternatives. Maria Staicu, 41, who lives in the city of Sibiu and has two children, said the pain and debasement she endured in 1991 when she had a legal abortion left her determined not to go through it again. **********''They did 20 women in a few minutes: 'Ready, go; ready, go,' '' she said, describing the atmosphere in the state hospital. In the last five years of the Ceausescu regime, she had managed to buy Hungarian-made oral contraceptives on the black market, she said. After her abortion in 1991, she was fitted with an I.U.D.. ''I would prefer anything else than an abortion,'' she said. **********Romania remains the only country in Eastern Europe not to manufacture any kind of contraceptive. Thus supplies, including condoms, must be imported and are too expensive for many women, who say they have trouble even getting food on the table in the chaotic Romanian economy. Birth control pills imported from Hungary, the Netherlands or Germany cost as much for a month's supply -- or in many cases up to two or three times as much -- as an abortion, even though Western aid helps subsidize some of the cost. **********The Western aid stems from publicity in 1990 about the plight of the unwanted Romanian children. Foreign assistance was sent to help care for the children, and for a longer-term solution, funds were offered to create family- planning services, including a $14 million World Bank loan and a $5 million grant from the United States Agency for International Development. **********In the last year, a little progress has been made, but not enough given the resources that have been made available, those who work in the program say. **********According to a report by Adriana Baban, a psychologist who counsels at one of the Romanian family-planning clinics funded by the A.I.D., and Dr. Henry P. David, director of the Transnational Family Research Institute, a nonprofit group in Washington, Romania had at least 445 deaths attributable to illegal abortion in 1989. By 1992, the number had been reduced to 120 and last year to 59. **********But despite these reductions of deaths from self-induced abortions, the pregnancy-related mortality rate remains startlingly high. The World Health Organization reported that in 1990, for every 100,000 live births in Romania, 84 women died in childbirth. By contrast, the rate in Poland was 19. Last year, the number in Romania was 48. In the United States last year, the rate was 8, according to the Population Reference Bureau.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/07/world.main_headline: Former Mexican Official, Held in U.S., Gains Partial Freedom
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/07/world.print_headline: Former Mexican Official, Held in U.S., Gains Partial Freedom
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/07/world.body_text: **********Under heavy guard and intense secrecy, a former Mexican Deputy Attorney General who spent a year in American jails was whisked out of a New Jersey jail  to partial freedom today while the Governments of Mexico and the United States struggled to find a way to send him back to Mexico to stand trial. **********Mario Ruiz Massieu left the Union County, N.J., jail before dawn this morning wearing a bullet-proof vest and an electronic identification bracelet that will  tell officials his whereabouts. He remains under house arrest in New Jersey as the United States Government continues trying to deport him. **********The 45-year-old former official, accused in Mexico of intentionally derailing the investigation of the 1994 assassination of his own brother, also had to post as bail more than $9 million he has in two Houston bank accounts frozen by the American Government. Customs officials are investigating suspicions that the money may have come from payments by drug traffickers buying protection while Mr. Ruiz Massieu headed Mexico's anti-drug efforts. **********Mr. Ruiz Massieu has applied for asylum in the United States, saying he fears for his life if he returns to Mexico. At a news conference this afternoon in his lawyer's Newark office, he said by telephone that he was innocent of all charges. His lawyers said that the $9 million in his accounts came from legal sources. **********The bizarre case has embarrassed the Mexican Government, which over the last  year bungled four attempts to extradite him. Two separate American judges rejected the petitions, charging that proof presented by Mexican officials was unconvincing or based on testimony from witnesses who were tortured. **********Mr. Ruiz Massieu's case also frustrated the United States, which considered his continued presence to have "potentially serious adverse foreign policy consequences." Secretary of State Warren Christopher tried to have him deported  but last week a Federal judge in Newark ruled that Mr. Christopher's actions were an unconstitutional denial of due process. **********The United States has appealed that decision but could not keep Mr. Ruiz Massieu from being released from jail while the appeal is heard. **********Gustavo Vega, coordinator of the United States and Canada program at the Colegio de Mexico in Mexico City, said that some Mexicans see the failure to return Mr. Ruiz Massieu as part of a conspiracy by American judges to keep him in the United States, perhaps to act as an informant. "But really it represents  a defeat for a Mexican Government that couldn't prove its case," he said. **********Mr. Ruiz Massieu was detained at Newark Airport on March 3, 1995, as he tried to board a jet for Europe because he had failed to declare over $40,000 in cash  to customs agents. **********Mr. Ruiz Massieu was considered a Mexican Elliot Ness when he first assumed control of the investigation into the assassination of his brother, Jose Francisco Ruiz Massieu, who had been secretary general of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party. **********But he quit the case after just two months, charging interference from party  leaders. Then in an incredible twist just over a year ago, the older brother of  former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari was formally charged with masterminding the killing. **********Mr. Ruiz Massieu, whose own investigation had never mentioned Raul Salinas de Gortari, was then accused of covering up the alleged participation of the ex-President's brother, perhaps on orders from the President. Within days of the arrest of Raul Salinas, Mr. Ruiz Massieu left Mexico.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/01/world.main_headline: Muslims and Croats Sign Contract to Aid Federation in Bosnia
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/01/world.print_headline: Muslims and Croats Sign Contract to Aid Federation in Bosnia
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/01/world.body_text: **********Muslim and Croatian leaders signed a contract today intended to bring the uneasy allies into a workable federation after months of conflict. **********The plan, offered by international mediators last week, sets up a new customs arrangement to raise revenues for the federation and allows for the firing of local leaders who thwart implementation of federation agreements. Municipal and  town officials have sometimes blocked the return of refugees, set up illegal customs checkpoints, and in other ways have stood in the way of attempts to bring Muslims and Croats together. **********Tensions between the two sides, which fought a bloody ten-month war ending in 1994, have threatened to undermine the alliance between the Croats and the Muslim-led Bosnian Government. The alliance is seen by the international community as a major stabilizer in the region. An international mediator, Michael Steiner, termed today's signing a breakthrough, adding that, for the first time, the federation would have a way to generate income and to put into effect a harsh disincentive for those who wish it to fail. **********"We have a motto for the month of April, which is, 'Deeds not words,' " said  Mr. Steiner, a German diplomat who is a deputy to the international community's  top civilian official in Bosnia, Carl Bildt, a former Prime Minister of Sweden.  "We have agreed to over 20 very concrete tasks, with deadlines, the first being  tomorrow and the last on April 30th." **********Even as the new agreement was concluded, a woman was killed and five children were seriously wounded in the Muslim area of the city of Mostar when an unexploded rifle grenade blew up, Reuters news service said, citing a report from the Bosnian state news agency. **********The first test of the agreement will come on Monday, when the sides are to stop charging all internal duties at the ethnic borders. The Bosnian Croats have promised to pay duties applied at the Croatian border into federation accounts.  The federation would keep two-thirds , while one-third would be funneled to the  Bosnian Government. **********Previously, such money has gone to Croat-controlled border towns and to local leaders who set up spot checkpoints along main commercial arteries. NATO peacekeepers have agreed to dismantle any illegal "customs" stops that might remain. **********The accord also sets down a schedule for other major steps for operating a working federation, such as the development of an official federation budget and banking system. **********If things go well, Mr. Steiner said, the accord will pave the way for an international summit in Petersberg, Germany, in April. At that meeting, the parties are expected to negotiate how to merge the two police forces and to decide how to cut 40,000 officers from the 60,000 now working.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/25/busin.snippet: Thompson family and their charitable foundations, seeking to recoup part of $80 million they say they lost on Oryx Energy Co stock, are suing Glenmede Trust Co, their investment advisory firm, for allegedly failing to inform them of firm's role in...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/25/busin.main_headline: A suit asks: Must advisers treat all clients exactly the same?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/25/busin.print_headline: A suit asks: Must advisers treat all clients exactly the same?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/25/busin.body_text: **********A TENNESSEE family that made a fortune in coal mining and was burned by the collapse of a stock it owned in a Texas oil company is pursuing an unusual legal strategy to recoup its losses: It has sued its investment advisory firm for not giving all clients the benefit of research conducted for the firm's largest customer. **********At the very least, the family contends, its adviser should have told the family to get guidance on the stock elsewhere. **********Lawyers say the Thompson family of Knoxville, Tenn., famous locally for its philanthropy, is trying a long shot in its effort to recoup some or all of the $80 million it says it lost. But if the Thompsons do prevail, the case could establish a precedent that would force big changes in the way investment advisers do business, the lawyers say. **********The Thompsons contend that the Glenmede Trust Company of Philadelphia breached its fiduciary duty by keeping the family in the dark about Glenmede's role in a September 1990 deal involving stock of the Oryx Energy Company. The deal was a $1 billion purchase by Oryx of 18 million of its shares at $53.75 each from the Pew Charitable Trusts. Had the Thompsons known Glenmede's opinion of the stock's value and potential, the Thompsons maintain, they could have taken action to protect their own substantial holdings. **********Glenmede executives said they did inform the Thompsons about the transaction within 48 hours of its announcement. Not only that, they add, but they offered to negotiate the sale of the family's Oryx shares and were turned down because the family's leader, B. Ray Thompson Jr., did not want to pay capital gains taxes. **********Two years later, after Oryx shares had slumped by more than half and the Thompsons had sold  more than two million shares at an average price of $25, several family members and their charitable foundations sued Glenmede in Federal District Court here, contending a loss of $80 million resulting from a Glenmede ''conspiracy.'' The suit seeks compensatory and punitive damages. **********Glenmede executives counter that they were honor-bound to respect the confidentiality of their discussions with Pew officials and add that they were under no obligation to disclose to any client the strategy devised for any other customer. **********The trial opened last week. Besides the attention generated by the connections to the Pew Charitable Trusts -- the second-most-generous philanthropy in the nation after the Ford Foundation -- the investment community is watching closely because of the potential impact on the way it does business. **********All the parties involved have ties to the Sun Company, the marketer of Sunoco gasoline. The Pew Charitable Trusts were set up by the children of the founder of Sun, Joseph N. Pew; Glenmede was chartered in 1956 to administer the trusts and began accepting other clients in 1979, and the Thompson family became a client of Glenmede  after selling its coal mining company to Sun for Sun shares. The family is Sun's second-largest shareholder after the Pews. **********In the suit, the Thompsons say Glenmede had a fiduciary duty as their investment adviser to inform them about the planned $1 billion share purchases or, failing that, at least to recommend that they get outside advice on their Oryx stock -- in effect tipping them off that something was up. **********''The Thompsons' entire fortune was at stake and they relied on Glenmede to advise them and feel the advice was not given, and, accordingly, the loss resulted,'' said James Binns, the family's attorney. **********Mr. Binns said Glenmede set itself up to get stuck between a rock and a legal hard place by trying to serve the Pew Trusts as a nonprofit venture while also dealing with paying customers whose portfolios might be affected by the Pew Trusts' holdings. ''When Glenmede changed its policy to one of going into the market and seeking other clients, it placed itself in an irreconcilable position,'' he said. **********So why didn't the Thompsons take up Glenmede's offer to sell their holdings? First, Mr. Binns said, the share price plummeted on news of the huge Pew Trusts deal, falling to levels far below a fair market price. After two years spent trying to learn more about the circumstances of Oryx's stock purchase from the Pew Trusts and after attempts to resolve the dispute privately, the Thompsons say, they filed suit. **********Experts on securities law question whether the Thompsons, or any client, can demand the same treatment for all investors from a single advisory firm. Fred Lipman, a partner at Blank, Rome, Comisky & McCauley in Philadelphia, who specializes in securities law, could think of no legal grounds for sharing arguably privileged information about one client with another client. Indeed, it is customary for investment counselors to give preferential treatment to their biggest and best-paying customers. **********A victory in court by the Thompsons could establish a precedent that changes the nature of fiduciary relationships, lawyers say. It could lead to new contract language or, potentially, cause firms to create protective ''Chinese wall'' agreements specifying that not all clients will receive the same level of service, Mr. Lipman added. **********He said Glenmede lawyers might try to show that the Oryx-Pew deal was a ''special situation'' calling for unusual privacy to avoid accusations of insider trading or other conflicts. **********''If giving priority to larger investors is viewed as a breach of fiduciary duty, that would put companies in an impossible situation,'' Mr. Lipman said. ''If there's an equal right to treatment in trust services it could definitely affect the ability to favor the larger customer. The market operates in a matter of minutes, if not seconds, so notifying everyone simultaneously would be impossible.'' **********James L. Kermes, chief executive of Glenmede, said his firm acted in accordance with established legal practices in the Oryx purchase of the Pew Trusts' shares. Within days of its announcement, he said, ''We contacted all of our clients who owned Oryx shares and explained what happened and that if they wanted to sell their shares they could and we would help them. **********''Mr. Thompson indicated he did not want to sell because of the capital gain,'' Mr. Kermes said. However, ''Two years later, with the stock down from $54 to $25, he then initiates the suit saying we should have included him in that sale.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/12/busin.body_text: **********The New York Festivals has named five grand Best of Show winners at the 38th annual international print and radio competition. **********In print, there were four winners: the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago, for the best consumer campaign, for Altoids Mints, which are marketed by a unit of the Philip Morris Companies; Euro RSCG Ball Partnership in Singapore, a unit of Euro RSCG, for the best newspaper advertising, for the Samaritans, a society dedicated to the prevention of suicide; Lewis Moberly in London, for the best design for a package, for Boots Childrens' Batteries, marketed by the Boots Company P.L.C., and Wunderman Cato Johnson in Eschborn, Germany, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., for the best direct mail, for Andersen Consulting. **********The Toronto office of Young & Rubicam won the award for the best radio campaign, for its ads for Covenant House. Ogilvy & Mather Singapore, a unit of the WPP Group, won the most radio awards over all, four gold medals, while five agencies tied for second with three awards each: Hunt Lascaris TBWA Cape in Cape Town, South Africa, which is owned by the Omnicom Group; Batey Ads in Singapore; BBDO Canada in Toronto, also owned by Omnicom; Leo Burnett, and Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/07/busin.body_text: **********Robert E. Diamond, the head of CS First Boston Inc.'s 1,200-member global fixed-income unit, resigned yesterday amid turmoil over bonuses in his department. **********Mr. Diamond, 44, becomes the second top executive in a month to leave the firm, a unit of Switzerland's CS Holding A.G. Charles Murphy, a 20-year employee of the firm and head of its equities unit, departed a month ago, also after a dispute over bonuses. **********A person close to Mr. Diamond denied he was responsible for the turmoil and  said he had offered to resign before the bonus payments. Mr. Diamond and a spokesman for the firm declined to comment. **********The firm named no replacement for Mr. Diamond.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/29/busin.snippet: Microsoft and Intel announce strategy to reduce cost of owning and using personal computers; aim is to blunt potential competition from emerging 'network computer' standard endorsed by several computer companies, referred to as NC; Microsoft-Intel...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/29/busin.main_headline: Microsoft And Intel Shift PC Strategy to Meet Network Threat
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/29/busin.print_headline: Microsoft And Intel Shift PC Strategy to Meet Network Threat
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/29/busin.body_text: **********Hoping to blunt potential competition from the emerging ''network computer'' standard endorsed by Sun Microsystems, Oracle, I.B.M. and others, the powerful PC axis of Microsoft and Intel announced a strategy today to reduce the cost of owning and using personal computers. **********The Microsoft-Intel move marks a shift for the two companies, which in the past had derided the notion of a low-cost network computer, or NC, but now seem to recognize the importance of offering an alternative to it. **********In the NC vision of the computing world, data and programs are stored on large central server computers and then downloaded over the Internet or a company's internal ''intranet,'' to run on simpler and less expensive desktop computers. **********NC's might consist of as little as a screen, keyboard, processor, memory and network connection. For businesses, giving their employees NC's, instead of more powerful and versatile PC's, could supposedly save thousands of dollars each year in operating costs per machine. **********In contrast to that approach, Microsoft and Intel executives said today that their competing design would be closer to the original PC -- though one that would not use floppy disks and could not be modified by the user. The machines would cost only slightly less than conventional PC's, the companies said, but would reduce the administrative costs for corporate networks. The companies refer to this new approach as the Net PC. **********''Think about the Net PC as the next evolution of the PC platform,'' said Pat Gelsinger, a vice president and general manager for Intel. **********The new technology is backed by most of the leading makers of PC's that are based on Intel chips and run Microsoft's Windows operating system software: Compaq Computer, Dell Computer, Digital Equipment, Gateway 2000, Hewlett-Packard, Packard Bell, NEC and Texas Instruments. But I.B.M., the second-largest PC maker, did not announce its support today, opting instead to stick with the NC standard. **********Machines based on the new Net PC standard would consist of a Pentium processor, 16 megabytes of memory, a hard disk, a network connection and a slot for reading a smart card to enable various people to each have their own user profile for that specific machine, which would be stored on a network server computer and downloaded. The first of these computers is not expected to reach the market until next year. **********Computer industry analysts said that Intel and Microsoft had been slow in reacting to the emerging threat, but that the new Net PC standard proposed today had a good chance of claiming broad support among corporate buyers. **********''If they hadn't figured out how to enter this market they were in danger of losing a huge amount of market share,'' to network computers, said Amy Wohl, a computer industry consultant. **********Microsoft also announced today what it called a ''zero administration initiative'' for its Windows software. Microsoft executives said that they would offer a set of software enhancements that would allow greater centralization of the updating, software installation and administration of PC's on a corporate network. **********According to Paul Maritz, a Microsoft group vice president, the new software capabilities will be deployed in stages in a new version of Windows due out next year, as well as in a future version of Windows NT. **********Microsoft executives said that on Wednesday the company's chairman, William H. Gates, would make a series of announcements about the company's new Internet commerce products for enabling companies to sell merchandise on line.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/08/busin.main_headline: MERGER OF GRUG GIANTS: THE SPECULATION;Value of Zeneca Soars, in Part Because It's Viewed as a Target
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/08/busin.print_headline: MERGER OF GRUG GIANTS: THE SPECULATION;Value of Zeneca Soars, in Part Because It's Viewed as a Target
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/08/busin.body_text: **********The American depository receipts for shares in Zeneca Group P.L.C. of Britain jumped 7.4 percent yesterday after two of Switzerland's three big drug makers, Sandoz A.G. and Ciba-Geigy A.G., agreed to merge. **********Traders said the merger, along with higher earnings reported by the British drug maker, raised the chance that Roche Holding A.G. or another pharmaceuticals company might offer to buy Zeneca, Britain's third-largest drug  maker. About half of Zeneca's sales come from cardiovascular drugs and a strong  franchise in cancer treatments. **********Zeneca's results were excellent and will bring back bid speculation," said  Michael Hicks, head of trading at Societe Generale Strauss Turnbull. "Takeover talk looks like it's coming to the forefront in the drug sector again." **********On the New York Stock Exchange, Zeneca A.D.R.'s rose $4.375, to $63.25, a 52-week high. Each A.D.R. counts for three shares. Earlier yesterday on the London Stock Exchange, company shares soared 96 pence, to an all-time closing high of 1,377 pence. **********Zeneca's pretax profit before special charges rose 15 percent in 1995, to L878 million, about $1.34 billion, from L763 million in 1994. After the charges, profit fell to L619 million, pretax, from L659 million. Sales were up 9 percent  at L4.9 billion. **********David Barnes, Zeneca's chief executive, said that the company intended to remain independent and focus on producing new drugs and agrochemicals to replace older ones. **********"There is not a strategic imperative for us to go out and acquire someone else or merge," he said. "If there are quality opportunities that offer enduring shareholder value to Zeneca shareholders, I hope we will be alert to take them." **********Mr. Barnes said Zeneca was not concerned that the merger of two rivals would  intensify competition in the drug and agrochemical industries. Ciba is already the world's largest agrochemical maker; Zeneca ranks fourth. **********Adam Christie, an analyst at ABN Amro Hoare Govett, said Zeneca's strongest performance was in agrochemicals, where "the operating profit was up 26 percent. That's where the biggest upside is." **********John Reeve, an analyst at Daiwa Institute of Research, said that Zeneca was "doing all the right things." He added: "It's a mix of good pharmaceutical development and good agrochemical growth. It raises confidence that management is steering the ship very well." **********Zeneca said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its specialty inks division  to the Sun Chemical Corporation for $62 million, and was in talks to sell its textile colors division. Sun Chemical, of Fort Lee, N.J., is a subsidiary of Dainippon Ink and Chemicals Inc. of Tokyo.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/26/busin.snippet: Fort Howard Corp says it will spend $160 million to expand one of its United States tissue-paper plants to meet growing demand (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/26/busin.body_text: **********The Fort Howard Corporation said today that it would spend $160 million to expand one of its United States tissue-paper plants to meet growing demand. The company, based in Green Bay, Wis., said it would upgrade either its plant in Rincon, Ga., or Muskogee, Okla. The expansion will require about 100 more workers, the company said. Until the expansion is completed, it will use bulk paper purchased from other manufacturers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/20/busin.snippet: "Animal banking" may help rebuild the economy of war-torn Bosnia-Herzegovina.The Rome-based International Fund for AgriculturalDevelopment, or IFAD, a small and unusually efficient special agency of the United Nations, is considering a plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/20/busin.main_headline: ECONOMIC SCENE : Bosnia to Get Cows, Not Cash, as Aid
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/20/busin.print_headline: ECONOMIC SCENE : Bosnia to Get Cows, Not Cash, as Aid
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/20/busin.body_text: **********"Animal banking" may help rebuild the economy of war-torn Bosnia-Herzegovina.The Rome-based International Fund for AgriculturalDevelopment, or IFAD, a small and unusually efficient special agency of the United Nations, is considering a plan to lend pregnant livestock to Bosnian farmers who will then replay their debt in live animals. **********Farmers participating in the project would make repayment in two to three years by contributing a female animal for each one they had initially received to cooperative animal banks.IFAD would then integrate the fresh livestock into the lending pool — a four-hooved form of revolving credit. **********The unusual loan arrangement is necessitated by the well-known mechanism by which banks can lend only to those able to demonstrate they do not need the money.Agencies like IFAD have had difficulty getting funds to those who need it in Bosnia because postwar conditions do not allow ordinary lending requirements to be met. **********The economy of Bosnia-Herzegovina is heavily dependent on agriculture, with a major emphasis on sheep and cattle.But war has decimated the population of meat and milk animals.The government estimates that country's livestock count has fallen by 70 percent. **********A study by an IFAD team that visited the area in central Bosnia chosen for the animal banking project said, "Cow sheds and barns have been burned down, farm houses blown up, tractors and equipment stolen or destroyed and irrigation systems vandalized." **********Mr. Theodore van der Pluijm, the IFAD officer who led the team, said damage to agricultural infrastructure, "ranges from extreme, where fields are heavily mined, to moderate but still significant damage in areas which escaped the brunt of fighting." **********IFAD has tentatively earmarked $5 million to provide about 2,200 head of cattle and 8,000 sheep to farmers in central Bosnia within the year.Agency planners count on finding another $5 million from outside donors to double those figures.The livestock would be purchased in the alpine regions of Western Europe, because of the similarities to the Bosnian climate and terrain. **********The choice of taking relatively expensive Western European livestock to Bosnia also stems from a desire to improve the bloodlines of the local animals, "and lay the basis for a real cattle-raising industry," an agency official said. **********"This part of former Yugoslavia must recover its role in providing beef to all of Western Europe," he added. "It would be short-sighted to encourage a marginal farming effort." **********Mr. van der Pluijm said the innovative project was necessary, "to alleviate the misery of the people, eliminate the need for large-scale food aid and reduce tensions which could contribute to a resumption of the war." **********Internal documents at IFAD indicate the organization has ruled out more conventional forms of aid for now because of "substantial risks caused by institutional weakness, absence of support services and the lack of marketing and infrastructure." **********The noncash loan program also complies with the desires of a Bosnian government that is wary of acquiring "insupportable" levels of foreign debt during the postwar reconstruction process. **********Jim Moody,IFAD's vice-president, said, "The plan is still subject to final approval by our board, but if we get that as expected, our animals will be able to hit the ground running late this Spring." **********The target date for the first deliveries is May. **********IFAD has been preparing for its Bosnian missionby using Albania as a training ground. **********"They are similar, both in terrain and in having a Muslim majority in their population," an agency official said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/17/busin.main_headline: Blinder Plans To Leave Post As Fed's No. 2
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/17/busin.print_headline: Blinder Plans To Leave Post As Fed's No. 2
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/17/busin.body_text: **********Alan S. Blinder has told the White House that he will leave as vice chairman  of the Federal Reserve when his term ends in two weeks, Fed officials said yesterday. **********Mr. Blinder, who was named to the Fed in June 1994, has been the chief voice  within the nation's central bank for lowering interest rates to stimulate the economy. His departure comes at a moment when the economy appears to be weakening. The Fed's control of short-term interest rates gives it powerful leverage to try to stem any such weakness, which could become an issue in this election year. **********The letter announcing Mr. Blinder's decision, sent to the White House yesterday, ended speculation that President Clinton might try to keep Mr. Blinder in place as the Administration's most influential appointee to the Federal Reserve. **********Mr. Blinder, a widely respected academic economist from Princeton University, was Mr. Clinton's first appointee to the Federal Reserve's seven-member board of governors. There was some talk at the time that Mr. Blinder, who served on the White House's Council of Economic Advisers in 1993 and early 1994, would eventually be the President's choice to replace Alan Greenspan as chairman. Mr.  Greenspan's current term ends in March. **********The Republican Congressional victory in 1994 put an end to White House hopes  that Mr. Blinder -- often regarded on Wall Street as too willing to tolerate some inflation to keep the economy growing -- could ever gain Senate approval to replace Mr. Greenspan. Recently, however, Administration officials had considered asking the Republican Senate to approve Mr. Blinder's reappointment as vice chairman as part of a package deal that would give Mr. Greenspan another term as chairman. **********Mr. Blinder is expected to announce his departure today. A White House spokeswoman would not comment, saying it was up to Mr. Blinder to make public any announcement that he is leaving the Fed at month's end. **********Wall Street, which traditionally prefers strong anti-inflationary policies from the Fed, is expected to be glad to see Mr. Blinder leave. "The constituency for easy money -- low rates -- at the Fed has just lost one of its most outspoken champions," said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. **********In his letter, Mr. Blinder, who is 50, is said to have told Mr. Clinton that  he must return to Princeton at the end of this month, when his Federal Reserve term expires. By law, he could have remained as vice chairman until Mr. Clinton  appointed and the Senate approved a replacement. But by failing to return to Princeton now, he would risk losing his tenured position as an economics professor. **********Mr. Blinder often said that he intended to return to Princeton, from which he has been on leave for three years, all of it spent working in the Clinton Administration. For a while, though, he considered giving up teaching for a career in Washington, an alternative now discarded. **********His departure leaves two unfilled seats among the seven Fed governors. John P. LaWare, who had been named by President George Bush, resigned last year, and  Mr. Clinton's attempt to appoint Alicia H. Munnell, a Treasury official, as Mr.  LaWare's replacement met a storm of protest in Congress. The White House never formally submitted her name, sending Ms. Munnell instead to the Council of Economic Advisers. **********That was more than six months ago, and the White House has made no new attempt to fill the Fed vacancy. Now Mr. Clinton will have two positions to fill, though it is not clear whether he can win Senate confirmation this year for any new member in Mr. Blinder's mold. **********Within the next few weeks, Mr. Clinton is widely expected to announce the reappointment of Mr. Greenspan, who faces little opposition in Congress, to a third term as the Fed's chairman. **********In addition to Mr. Blinder, Mr. Clinton had also placed Janet L. Yellen, an economist on leave from the University of California at Berkeley, on the Fed board. But he has never been able to tilt the balance of power toward his appointees. **********If Ms. Munnell had become a Fed governor, three Democrats might have changed  the equation, leading to greater pressure for lower interest rates than Mr. Greenspan might have preferred. The remaining governors, including Mr. Greenspan, were appointed by Mr. Bush or President Ronald Reagan, and fell readily in line with the chairman's views of what should be done. **********Not that Mr. Blinder was so far apart from Mr. Greenspan. On basic issues, such as how rapidly the economy could expand or how much the unemployment rate could fall without creating shortages that would push up inflation, the two men  did not really differ that much. More than anything, when Mr. Blinder argued at  Fed policy meetings for lower rates, as he did late last year, or resisted rate  increases, as he did in the fall of 1994, he did so because he sometimes saw less danger of inflation than Mr. Greenspan and more risk of recession. **********Whatever the differences, they were not so great that Mr. Blinder ever went so far as to vote against Mr. Greenspan in the Fed's policymaking meetings. Such a dissent would have drawn headlines and roiled the bond market. **********The Fed last cut rates, by a quarter-point, on Dec. 19. Mr. Blinder's decision to leave means that he will not participate at the Fed's Jan. 30 and 31 policy-making meeting. But with inflation low and the economy showing some signs of weakening, bond traders are betting that the Fed, with or without Mr. Blinder, will lower interest rates another half-point or so in the coming months.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/10/busin.main_headline: Dollar's Strength Has U.S. Executives Grumbling
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/10/busin.print_headline: Dollar's Strength Has U.S. Executives Grumbling
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/10/busin.body_text: **********With the dollar near its highest level against the Japanese yen in nearly two and a half years, industrial leaders in the United States are beginning to express concern that the currency's strong rebound may undermine American competitiveness against foreign rivals. **********Over the last week, the dollar rose to levels it has not enjoyed against the  yen since January 1994, although it dropped slightly in trading today. After touching 111.16 yen on Monday, the dollar sold in New York late today at 110.30  yen, 38 percent higher than its intraday low in April 1995 of 79.75 yen. **********Traders said the dollar could move even higher if the Federal Reserve increased interest rates later this summer, as some now expect. Higher rates in  the United States would make dollar-denominated assets more attractive to investors, especially in relation to investments in Japan, where interest rates  have been kept extremely low in an effort to stimulate the long-stagnant economy. **********While the complaints from American executives have worried some currency traders, the executives' concerns have not carried a great deal of weight among  economic policy makers so far. Neither the American nor Japanese Government has  expressed public concern about the dollar's strength, and both have indeed suggested that they are relatively happy with current exchange rates. **********At their meeting in Lyons, France, last month, top officials of seven leading industrial nations said the rebound of the dollar in the preceding 15 months and the general direction of exchange rates were "positive and promising." **********The dollar has also gained against other major currencies, including the German mark. The dollar was quoted at 1.5263 marks in late trading today, up slightly from 1.5261 marks. In April 1995, the dollar reached a low of 1.3675 marks. **********Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin and other Clinton Administration officials have repeatedly said that a strong dollar is good for the United States and that the currency's level should reflect economic fundamentals. **********At the moment, they said, the dollar's strength is a function of such factors as low inflation, a reduced budget deficit, steady growth, falling unemployment  and improved corporate efficiency. **********And Mr. Rubin's deputy, Lawrence H. Summers, said: "We're concentrating on strong fundamentals that are ultimately important for competition and for markets. The American economy is very strong and doesn't need currency-induced adrenaline." **********In the mid-1980's, when the dollar was worth more than 200 yen, American manufacturers would have been thrilled with an exchange rate of 110. Moreover, American industry generally has cut costs and greatly improved efficiency in the last decade, allowing many companies to absorb currency fluctuations with less strain. **********A stronger dollar makes American products more expensive in terms of foreign  currencies, and allows foreign exporters to cut prices or benefit from higher profit margins in the United States. A strong dollar can benefit American manufacturers to some degree by pushing down prices for parts they purchase abroad. **********But in industries most subject to competition from Japan, including automobiles and other heavy equipment, there have been increasingly loud complaints in recent weeks that the dollar's rise may need to be checked. **********The latest and most explicit comment came today in Tokyo from Donald V. Fites, chairman and chief executive of Caterpillar Inc., the earth-moving equipment company, whose main competitor is Japanese. **********"The recent dramatic weakness of the yen against the dollar is most worrisome and may demand attention from governments," said Mr. Fites, who is also chairman of the U.S.-Japan Business Council, at a business conference. "The yen at 111 to the dollar has the potential to erase and reverse the recent beginning of improvement in our bilateral trade balance." **********American auto makers have also made clear that they are concerned. Robert J.  Eaton, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, brought up the dollar in a meeting  with White House aides last month. The Big Three are worried that the stronger dollar will give Japanese car companies greater ability to lower their prices. **********In a statement today, the National Association of Manufacturers warned that one result of an interest-rate increase by the Federal Reserve would be to "hurt U.S. sales overseas by raising the value of the dollar." **********Paul A. Volcker, the former Fed chairman, said last month that an exchange rate of 110 yen to the dollar was reasonable, although he also suggested that this was near the high end of what the United States should consider acceptable. **********Other economists said that the current exchange rate struck a good balance between the needs of the American and Japanese economies, but that a further substantial rise could create economic and political pressure to force the dollar back down. **********"At 110, it's the level of exchange rate at which Japanese industry is making money, but one that will not produce major deterioration in the current account," said David Hale of Zurich Kemper Investments. **********A decline last year by the dollar against the yen helped narrow the trade deficit with Japan somewhat. Economists said that at the current exchange rate,  the United States would probably not see any further currency-driven improvement in its trade balance after this year, but that the trade deficit should benefit  from strengthening economies of Japan and other major trading partners. **********"I still think we're in pretty good shape and that we could see an even higher dollar and still get improved exports if the European and Japanese economies live up to their potential," said Joseph Liro, an economist at CIBC Wood Gundy. "What we have going for us now is very clear cost competitiveness vis-a-vis Japanese and German producers." **********As a result, he said, American manufacturers can weather, and policy makers in Washington would tolerate, a rise in the dollar to perhaps 115 yen. **********"If the Fed does start tightening and the dollar starts to appreciate to around 115 yen, we would start getting clear and unambiguous talk out of the Administration that that is unacceptable," Mr. Liro added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/25/world.snippet: Israelis observe first anniversary of Yitzhak Rabin's assassination according to Jewish lunar calender; they seem overwhelmed and troubled by deep division in their society exposed by slaying, which seems to have only deepened in past year; photo ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/25/world.main_headline: Year After Rabin Fell, Israel Is No Closer to Unity
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/25/world.print_headline: Year After Rabin Fell, Israel Is No Closer to Unity
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/25/world.body_text: **********At the spot where Yitzhak Rabin was assassinated last year, someone put up a homemade sign today, above the flowers and candles brought by crowds of Israelis who gathered to mark the Jewish calendar anniversary of the Prime Minister's death. **********''A year has passed and half the nation has already forgotten,'' the poster said. ''But I haven't forgotten, and I will not forget!'' **********A women sat on a curb nearby staring silently at the ebb and flow of mourners and at the circle of high school students in white shirts and jeans singing softly above the flickering memorial lights. **********''Nothing has changed,'' said the woman, who identified herself only as Ayelet. ''Things have gotten worse, people hate each other and it's only a matter of time before someone shoots again. We haven't learned a thing.'' **********As they observed the first anniversary of Mr. Rabin's assassination according to the Jewish lunar calendar, Israelis seemed overwhelmed and troubled by the deep division in their society exposed by the slaying, which seems to have only deepened in the past year. **********The killing of Mr. Rabin last Nov. 4 by Yigal Amir, a militantly nationalist religious Jew opposed to the Prime Minister's peace accords with the Palestinians, starkly defined the abyss between religious and secular Israelis and between the political left and the right. **********The slaying brought out the vastly different value systems separating religious nationalists intent on stopping the handover of territory they consider part of their biblical homeland, and liberal Israelis willing to trade the land for peace. **********The divisions have politicized Mr. Rabin's death, making its commemoration a source of contention instead of unity. **********The conservative Government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu failed to declare the anniversary a national day of mourning, setting off criticism by the opposition Labor Party, which Mr. Rabin led. **********Objections from Mr. Rabin's family prevented Mr. Netanyahu from speaking at an official graveside ceremony today. Mr. Rabin's widow, Leah, accused Mr. Netanyahu after the assassination of promoting incitement against her husband, which she said had led to the killing. **********Choirs from two nationalist and religious youth movements said today that they would not sing ''The Song for Peace'' at a memorial ceremony, asserting that the words of the Israeli peace anthem, sung by Mr. Rabin at a rally before he was killed, ran counter to their ideology. **********Looming over these differences is the threat of renewed political violence. **********Just last Tuesday, Yael Dayan, a Labor Party member of Parliament, had a glass of scalding tea tossed in her face as she visited Hebron in the West Bank. A Jewish militant convicted of killing an Arab several years ago has been arrested as a prime suspect. **********Ms. Dayan and other Labor legislators have received death threats, and even Mr. Netanyahu has reportedly been threatened by rightist militants opposed to the planned handover of Hebron to Palestinian rule. **********''How fragile and fleeting was the lesson we learned from the murder of Yitzak Rabin,'' wrote Sever Plotzker, a columnist, in the daily Yediot Ahronot after Ms. Dayan was attacked. ''A year has passed since the murder of the Prime Minister, and we still have not learned to live with one another, to talk to one another.'' **********Uzi Baram, a Labor Party leader, said the confrontation was between two communities with vastly different outlooks. ''It's foolish to think that there is a solid majority facing a lunatic fringe,'' he said. ''There's a very large public that is hurting, facing a public that is not small, which has a different value system, and sees the murder differently. It is bowing its head today until the storm passes, but it exists and can still act.'' **********Nissan Rubin, a sociologist at Bar-Ilan University, a religious institution where Mr. Amir was a student, said significant numbers of religious Israelis actually saw the assassination as a kind of divine miracle that had saved them from Mr. Rabin's policies. **********Others simply avoided soul-searching, or went on the defensive in the face of attacks on the Orthodox community by secular Israelis enraged by the killing. ''This community was pushed into a corner, and when you're under attack it's difficult to admit your mistakes -- you close ranks,'' Professor Rubin said. **********Education Minister Zevulun Hammer, the leader of the National Religious Party, defended the religious community in a television program marking the assassination. ''I don't accept that the shots are always fired from one side,'' he said. ''A tremendous effort must be made to avoid putting a whole community into a corner and saying that the whole system is distorted. There is one person who failed. If you really want to bring about a change, there should be more tolerance, more unity in order to talk and reach understanding.'' **********Mr. Netanyahu sounded a similar chord today in an address to a memorial meeting of Parliament. ''Healing the rifts in the nation is vital for achieving real peace with our neighbors,'' he said. ''Peace begins at home.'' **********But Moran Mondry, a high school senior visiting the street memorial for Mr. Rabin, said she had seen precious little reconciliation, and that peace efforts were faltering. ''After the killing I was sure everything would be different, and that there would be more unity among people,'' she said. ''But they are still the same, they are continuing to behave violently, and there's still no peace. Everything is going backward, and what was built is being destroyed.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/29/busin.main_headline: The Limited Plans a Big Buyback of Stock
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/29/busin.print_headline: The Limited Plans a Big Buyback of Stock
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/29/busin.body_text: **********The Limited Inc., the specialty- store company that operates the Limited and  Lerners chains and has a controlling interest in the company that operates Victoria's Secret, yesterday announced a $1.62 billion stock buyback apparently  intended to lift the value of its shares, which have languished. **********The company said its board had approved a tender offer to repurchase as many  as 85 million shares, or 23.7 percent of the total shares outstanding, at $19 apiece. The offer is scheduled to start on Feb. 1 and end on March 6. **********The Limited shares closed on Friday at $16.50, up 50 cents, on the New York  Stock Exchange. **********Leslie H. Wexner, the Limited's president, chairman and chief executive as well as its largest shareholder, will not sell any shares in the buyback. Instead, he will have the option of selling to the company 18.75 million, or 27.4 percent, of his 68.5 million Limited shares at $18.75 apiece for three years starting in 1998. **********If he does not exercise that option, the company, which is based in Columbus, Ohio, will have the right to buy those shares from him at $25.07 apiece for six  months starting in July 2001. **********The constraints that the board placed on Mr. Wexner's ability to benefit from the stock repurchase program might have been intended to quell the concerns of some large investors. **********Limited said last summer that as part of a revamping intended to increase shareholder value, it would partly spin off some of its businesses and distribute the proceeds to shareholders as a special tax-free dividend of about  $5.50 a share. **********Several large mutual and pension funds that owned Limited stock objected to the dividend because its biggest beneficiary would have been Mr. Wexner, who, with his mother, Bella Wexner, own 23.6 percent of the shares outstanding and would have received $463.1 million in tax-free dividends. **********"There was a sense in the investment community that he was in this just to enhance his own interests," said Jeffrey Edelman, a retail analyst at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell. **********After discussions with its shareholders, the company scrapped that plan in favor of the one announced yesterday. The company said the deal it had struck with Mr. Wexner to buy 18.75 million of his shares on his demand represented somewhat less than the number of shares he could have sold as part of the tender offer. If he opts to make the company buy those shares in two years, he will receive roughly $350 million; if the company opts to buy them from him in 2001,  he will receive about $470 million. **********Mr. Edelman estimated that the stock buyback would add as much as 40 cents to the Limited's earnings going forward. In part, the program will reduce the number of shares outstanding. But the company will also earn interest on the approximately $340 million that it will retain from the proceeds of the spinoffs. **********"Theoretically, this is an immediate step-up in shareholder value of between  $4 and $6 a share," he said. **********In a statement, Mr. Wexner gave investors a preview of the company's 1995 results, which will be issued in late February. He said the company expected to  report that last year, excluding one-time gains from the spinoffs, it earned $305 million to $320 million, or 85 to 90 cents a share -- less than analysts have been estimating. **********He said that because of severe weather in the Northeast and Midwest in January and a holiday sales season "which was clearly off-trend," the company would not make any projections for 1996. He did say, however, that the Limited's operating profits this year "should be no less than 1995, with the potential to  show significant improvement."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/12/busin.body_text: **********Short of time and facing mounting opposition, the chairman of the House Banking Committee today abandoned an ambitious election-year effort to overhaul the financial-services industry. **********The chairman, Representative Jim Leach, said he would instead content himself with providing banks with modest regulatory relief while asking the Federal Reserve to let the very biggest banks underwrite larger, but still severely limited, volumes of corporate securities. **********''The committee has become entangled in partisan and interest-group wrangling,'' said Mr. Leach, an Iowa Republican, referring to the way the banking, insurance and securities industries jockeyed for advantage as time grew short for passing legislation. Such an overhaul would effectively repeal the Glass-Steagall Act, a Depression-era law that essentially separated the banking and securities businesses. **********While the Clinton Administration supported a broad approach to lowering the barriers separating financial industries, the Treasury Department opposed Mr. Leach's bill, saying that it would roll back gains that banks had made in the courts to expand their powers. **********This latest effort to repeal Glass-Steagall foundered mainly because of hotly contested provisions involving banks' affiliation with insurers and their right to sell various kinds of insurance. **********The nation's half-million insurance agents had strongly opposed the bill, fearing that it would put them out of business. After fierce lobbying, an amendment was added that would limit banks' entry into some insurance areas. **********This afternoon, Mr. Leach threw in the towel after finding that the bill, first taken up last week, had been loaded with some 80 proposed amendments, mostly those of Democrats. But some Republicans had also said they could not support important elements of the bill and there seemed little interest on either side in antagonizing a sizable business constituency at a time of such electoral scrutiny. **********The Senate has not yet taken action on banking legislation this year and has little inclination to do so, a caucus of the House committee's Republicans learned last week just before Mr. Leach conducted the first markup session. At that session, only a handful of the amendments were considered. **********Glass-Steagall's demarcations have been gradually crumbling since the 1970's, a process that is expected to continue. But the frontal assault on it seems to have been weakened in the last year by a Supreme Court decision that gave banks the upper hand in their battle against the more numerous and politically powerful insurance brokers seeking to bar bank incursion into their businesses. **********Believing that they would continue to benefit from court decisions and action in state legislatures, the American Bankers Association voted to oppose Mr. Leach's bill. **********And smaller banks, represented by the Independent Bankers Association of America, joined insurers in opposing the measure. ''We and the insurance agents together have no use for the position that the largest commercial banks, securities firms and insurance firms should be allowed to own one another,'' Kenneth Guenther, head of the bank group, said. **********Under Representative Leach's plan, Glass-Steagall restraints would be maintained on banking-securities affiliations, as would the law's prohibitions of affiliations between banks and insurers. But he proposed to expand the financial-services activities of bank holding companies. **********Instead of being limited to operations ''closely related to banking,'' holding companies would be allowed to engage in activities considered by regulators to be ''financial in nature or incidental to such financial activities,'' a significantly broader area. **********Mr. Leach said he had written to Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, urging the Fed to increase the amount of securities underwriting that large banks would be allowed to handle. Such underwriting now may not exceed 10 percent of revenues and while Mr. Leach did not specify a higher figure, he is said to favor raising this limit to the 20 to 25 percent range. **********Some bankers said they found it interesting that Mr. Leach, who has complained when bank powers have been enlarged by the Comptroller of the Currency, should ask the Fed to do just that. **********When asked about this, David Runkel, a committee aide, explained that Mr. Leach had ''more faith'' in the central bank. **********The regulatory relief still proposed by Mr. Leach involves various disclosure and record-keeping rules but no longer includes such contentious provisions as an exemption for small banks from Community Reinvestment Act regulations or the requirement that banks calculate the annual percentage rate for a growing variety of financial products. **********''I am hopeful that as the market continues to lead toward further financial homogenization, not only will industrial consensus prove more readily obtainable but regulatory jealousies may slacken,'' Mr. Leach said in a statement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/31/world.main_headline: U.S. Brokers Peace Accord In the Aegean
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/31/world.print_headline: U.S. Brokers Peace Accord In the Aegean
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/31/world.body_text: **********Responding to the entreaties of President Clinton and other senior American officials, Greece and Turkey late this evening pulled back from a military confrontation over a tiny, uninhabited island in the Aegean. **********A State Department official said that a "mutually acceptable agreement" under which the two countries withdrew their forces and stopped unfurling flags over the 1,000-square-yard rocky outcropping came shortly before midnight. **********The official said that both sides had agreed to return to "the status quo ante" under which neither Greece nor Turkey asserted sovereignty over the island. **********"Greek and Turkish forces are withdrawing at this time," the official said, reading from a prepared statement. "The United States will monitor the withdrawal." **********The announcement brought to an end one of the more peculiar chapters in NATO  history, a moment when two members of the alliance edged close to hostilities over an utterly unstrategic piece of land. **********It began as a typical Greek-Turkish dispute over territory, and was initially treated by the Clinton Administration as a minor imbroglio. Diplomatic notes were delivered by American officials in Ankara and Athens this week urging both  sides to reconsider their stands. **********But American officials became alarmed this morning when they saw intelligence reports that the two sides were headed toward a military confrontation. A contingent of 12 Greek commandos was holding the island, and had unfurled the blue and white Greek flag above it. The Turks had plans to overrun the Greeks. Both sides had warships and airplanes poised over the tiny island, which is four miles off the Turkish coast near the city of Bodrum. **********The reports set off alarm bells across Washington. President Clinton called the Prime Ministers of both countries and the Turkish President, Suleyman Demirel. American officials said all three leaders assured Mr. Clinton that they did not want to see hostilities erupt. **********Secretary of State Warren Christopher, Secretary of Defense William Perry, Gen. John Shalikaskvili, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Anthony  Lake, the national security adviser, all worked the phones to their Greek and Turkish counterparts, urging them to back down from the ultimatums they had been trading in recent days. **********The incident over the island came at a sensitive moment for both countries.. **********In Turkey, Prime Minister Tansu Ciller heads a caretaker Government and handed in her resignation last month after an Islamic party finished first in her country's elections, defying a secular tradition that has been a cornerstone of Turkish Government for seven decades. **********In Greece, the Government has drifted for months during the illness of Prime  Minister Andreas Papandreou. This month, Mr. Papandreou was replaced by Costas Simitis, whose Government faces its first vote of confidence in the Greek Parliament this week. **********The disputed territory, called Imia by the Greeks and Karnak by the Turks, is home only to several dozen goats. **********Nonetheless, it became a flash point for tensions between the two longtime adversaries, with newspapers in both countries egging on their leaders. Over the weekend, several reporters from the Turkish daily Hurriyet rode a helicopter to  the rocks, took down the blue and white Greek flag and raised the red and white  Turkish flag. **********That prompted the Greeks to dispatch the small force of commandos and to raise their own flag again. **********The dispute arose last month when a Turkish ship ran aground on the island. According to various reports, the Turkish captain refused assistance from the Greeks. Soon, both sides were lodging protests and exchanging angry diplomatic notes. **********Sovereignty over the island has long been in question. The Turks insist that  the island is theirs; Greeks say that it was given them by the Italians in 1947. **********"All of this is obviously a function of absentee civilian leaders," said one  senior official. "You have a classic situation in which the military is disproportionately influential, and their inherent hostility toward each other just exploded." **********Ms. Ciller said on Monday in Ankara that her country was ready "to take all necessary measures" if the Greeks did not withdraw their troops from the island. Earlier, she said she would not permit the Greeks to create a "fait accompli" over the issue, and said that the issue could only be resolved through international negotiations. **********Mr. Simitis did little more to defuse tensions. "We do not accept any question on our national sovereignty," he said recently. "In defending this, we have the means and will make use of them without hesitation. Turkey should not kid itself." **********All of this was viewed as a tempest in a teapot by Washington, until the two  militaries began to spar with each other. **********A clash between Greece and Turkey could split NATO. The two countries have fought over control of the Aegean for millenia and nearly went to war over Cyprus in 1974. **********"It sounds incredible that they could go to the brink of military action -- I don't want to say war -- over a little piece of land smaller than the State Department," said Richard C. Holbrooke, the Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs. "But this is serious."

Copley, which is 51 percent owned by Hoechst Marion Roussel Inc., said it expected to lose more than 9 cents a share but less than 18 cents a share in the first quarter, which ended on March  31.
