The Paris-based company, which is facing a legal challenge to its acquisition of a Dutch rival, Nethold N.V., had sales of 8.2 billion French francs ($1.6 billion) from its wholly owned units, up from 7.4 billion francs in the period a year earlier. **********Revenue from subscriptions to Canal Plus's pay-TV channels rose 9.7 percent, to 6.65 billion francs. Canalsatellite, the company's satellite service, was helping by the start of its digital package in April and expects to count 420,000 subscribers by year-end. (Bloomberg Business News)

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/01/world.main_headline: Hong Kong, Takeover Near, In Wary Dance With Destiny
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/01/world.print_headline: Hong Kong, Takeover Near, In Wary Dance With Destiny
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/01/world.body_text: **********Tucked among the coffin makers just off Wing Lok Street, on the edge of a hankie-sized park where old men play Chinese chess, a fading photograph shows a  waterfront site, Possession Point -- the spot where the British flag was first planted, by Capt. Edward Belcher at 8:15 A.M. on Jan. 26, 1841. **********Today Possession Point -- now Hollywood Road Park -- is well inland from Hong Kong's shrinking harbor. The coffin makers lounge on low stools, smoke from their loosely fingered cigarettes drifting in the pudding-thick humidity, as they wait for their next customers and watch the last faint moments of British rule unwind. **********One year from today, at midnight's stroke on June 30, 1997, the territory's  last colonial governor will sail from Hong Kong, relinquishing Britain's final Asian outpost and its 6.2 million people to one of the world's last remaining Communist governments. It is a moment that is riveted in people's minds and emotions, a date with a destiny many fear and others exult in. **********In Beijing, where an immense digital clock flicks glowing red seconds inexorably toward zero hour, Hong Kong's return to China will be a decisive righting of historical wrongs -- the return of a piece of the motherland sundered after Britain forced China to buy its opium. The "yoke of colonialism," as Zhou Nan, China's senior official here, repeatedly puts it, is being shucked  off. **********Under that yoke, however, Hong Kong has become Asia's pre-eminent financial center, a city feverishly at work on the globe's largest civil engineering project -- involving a new airport, town, railroads, two immense bridges and two tunnels under Hong Kong's harbor. Hong Kong is the place where money is made with relish and spent with abandon, where a two-bedroom apartment can run $10,000 a month and tycoons tool around in limousines originally designed for the Japanese emperor. **********Yet even in this city of soaring financial prowess -- a place of robust debate and newly spread political wings -- pride at the ending of colonialism is stirred by a widening sense of apprehension about the future under a Communist sovereign. **********"I'm very pessimistic about the near future," said Martin C. M. Lee, the leader of Hong Kong's Democratic Party, which won the largest number of seats in last year's legislative elections. "They don't trust us, so they want to control us from Beijing." **********Indeed, after 14 years of preparing for China to retake Hong Kong, virtually  none of the major issues confronting the territory have been resolved, including most prominently who will lead the territory. A committee chosen by Beijing is nominally charged with settling these issues, but it meets only in secret, consults with carefully selected segments of Hong Kong's people behind closed doors and has banished dissenting voices from its proceedings. **********China has promised that it will leave Hong Kong unchanged and "with a high degree of autonomy" for 50 years. Yet in the past year, China has proceeded clumsily and mostly in secret as it lays its plans to resume sovereignty. **********What is clear is that Beijing has said it will abolish Hong Kong's elected legislature and replace it with handpicked lawmakers, scuttle its Bill of Rights ordinance and revive a slew of repressive laws. What is also clear is that the transition is well under way; China is already the largest investor here, with more than 1,100 mainland companies, from banks to trading houses, garment manufacturers to tour operators, doing business here. **********The Growing Signs Of China's Presence **********Already the pace of Hong Kong's absorption into China is quickening. At the Department of Government Supplies, Nigel Shipmen has taken surveys of Government buildings to determine how many of China's five-starred red flags will be needed on July 1, 1997, and how many of Hong Kong's new flag, featuring a five-petaled  bauhinia flower. **********Insignias for the police, fire department, immigration and prison officers are all being redesigned. **********Beyond the external flourishes however, China's presence and influence are already considerable here. Swire Pacific, one of the great British hongs, or trading houses, has been pressed to reduce its holdings in the airline run by Hong Kong to a minority share. The British telecommunications giant Cable and Wireless is expected to cave in to Chinese pressure and become a minority shareholder in the territory's local phone company. **********"It is natural for China to want some control of the commanding heights of the economy -- aviation, electronics, telecommunications and maybe banking -- but I am not comfortable," said Miron Mushkat, the managing director of Lehman Brothers here, at an American Chamber of Commerce conference. "It is not the Hong Kong way, and it is a form of nationalization." **********For years, companies that traditionally have done most of their business with the London-based Hongkong & Shanghai Bank have been shifting business to the Bank of China. "It just makes sense," said the director of one company. "These are the guys we have to deal with." **********But Hong Kongers themselves are not easily abandoning their sense of themselves as distinct from China's people, not merely because of social and political differences, but culturally and linguistically. **********A Sense of Identity Apart From China **********Last spring Eric K. W. Ma, a journalism professor at the Chinese University of Hong Kong, sent his students to an exhibit on Hong Kong's history, telling them to return and write about who they felt they were. **********"My purpose was to trigger them to see whether they are local Hong Kong people or are they Chinese," he said. "Most of them were born in Hong Kong and most have very remote ideas about the Chinese." **********More often than not, Hong Kong's people see themselves not as Chinese, but as Hong Kongers -- with a way of life far removed from China's mix of avariciousness born of rapid economic growth and insularity born of political repression, and with an ease with the world around them that China's people do not share. **********In an effort to lend some statistical shape to Hong Kong's amorphous sense of identity, Timothy K. Y. Wong, of the Hong Kong Institute of Asia-Pacific Studies, conducted a poll. "We found that Hong Kong people still maintain a strong indigenous identity, although this identity is declining somewhat over the years," he said. Indeed, 49 percent of those surveyed regard themselves as Hong Kongers, with only 36 percent seeing themselves as Chinese. **********One answer to the search for identity, among many, springs from the pages of  the essays Mr. Ma collected. A student who left China in 1981 described her transformation after the Tiananmen massacre of June 4, 1989, from a "Hong Kong Chinese" to a "Chinese Hong Konger." **********"The more I was influenced by Hong Kong's culture and ideas, the more I became a Hong Konger through and through," she wrote. **********Confidence, Yes, But Keep Passports **********One of the starker signs of the chasm between Beijing and Hong Kong is the refusal of Chinese officials here to speak Cantonese in public. Instead they insist on speaking Beijing-accented Mandarin, a language scarcely understood here. Yet there remains a vast range of intentions toward China's looming sovereignty. **********Six years ago, Chui Kei Kong returned to Hong Kong from Vancouver, British Columbia. "You can't earn as much in Canada as here," said Mr. Chui, an electrical engineer. He had moved to Canada 10 years ago, but the allure of business opportunity pulled him back. His wife and daughter remain in Canada. **********"I don't worry too much about 1997 because I'm a Canadian citizen," said Mr.  Chui, who now owns a factory over the border in Shenzhen. "If the situation is very bad next year, I'll go back to Canada. Even though I can earn more in Hong  Kong, I'd rather stay in a peaceful and civilized place." **********Invariably, conversations these days swing toward contingency plans, and above all that means possession of a foreign passport. There are no precise data, but the Government estimates that 600,000 Hong Kongers hold such passports. In fact, more than half the members of Beijing's hand-picked Preparatory Committee, the body that China created to chart the transition from  British to Chinese rule, carry foreign passports. **********Yet many Hong Kongers are eager to live in a Hong Kong that is a rightful part of China. Chung Lee Wai, a 22-year-old university student who said he plans to work in community development, is harshly critical of China's political system yet equally fierce in his patriotism. **********"The first step is for China to control Hong Kong," he said. "We need to go back to China. Hong Kong went to Britain because of the Opium War. I don't believe in independence for Hong Kong. I'm staying." **********Chan Siu Hong is equally adamant. "Of course things may become very harsh in  1997, but I would like to stay here to try my best to take advantage of the opportunities here," said the 26-year-old owner of a video production company. "Why should I go abroad where I'll be looked down on by foreigners?" **********Yet even some of the most ardent boosters for Chinese rule have hedged their  bets. Henry Cheng, one of the world's richest men and the managing director of the New World property conglomerate, is chairman of the Better Hong Kong Foundation, a pro-China business group that actively promotes the territory's prospects and regularly meets with China's senior leaders. **********Still, when asked recently what passport he held, he replied, "a French passport as a matter of confidence." Quickly, though, he corrected himself. "I mean as a matter of convenience." Little Understanding Of a Free Society **********Much of Hong Kong's anxiety stems not only from the opacity of the process leading to Chinese rule, but from the stream of comments from Chinese officials  that appear to threaten elements of Hong Kong's way of life, and the silence emanating from the territory's own leading citizens. Beijing's insistence on secrecy and conformity among the Hong Kongers it chooses to steer the territory  toward Chinese rule is regarded as particularly ominous. **********When Frederick Kin Kee Fung, a member of the Preparatory Committee, announced that he intended to vote against plans to abolish Hong Kong's legislature, he was aggressively lobbied by senior Chinese officials. On the day the committee voted to install a legislature picked by China, Mr. Fung cast the solitary negative vote. **********"I wanted to let them understand, through words and actions, what is Hong Kong political culture," Mr. Fung said. "At the Preparatory Committee they just  read out documents and said whoever supports it raise their hands. It's the Chinese way. I was told that if I voted no, I would be off the provisional legislature" -- the council that China will impose on July 1, 1997. **********Mr. Fung did vote no, and he has been barred from participating in any discussions over the new legislature or the chief executive. **********Many Hong Kongers, including Mr. Fung, believe that Chinese officials fundamentally do not comprehend Hong Kong. **********Hong Kong's Governor, Christopher Patten, argues that much of the blame for Beijing's ignorance of and insensitivity toward Hong Kong is a consequence of the type of advice it has sought. "I think that one of the tragedies of the last few years is this," Mr. Patten said in an interview. "It's understandable that senior Chinese officials, given their backgrounds, find it difficult understanding the nature of a free society, what makes Hong Kong tick. **********"They require a bit of assistance in learning about Hong Kong. **********"They haven't always gotten the assistance they deserve from their appointed  advisers in Hong Kong, who have believed that they should go and tell Chinese officials what they think Chinese officials want to hear. Senior Chinese officials deserve honesty, and too often they've gotten shoe shining." **********In the meantime, Hong Kong waits and watches.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/30/world.main_headline: 3 Muslims In Bosnia Die Going Home
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/30/world.print_headline: 3 Muslims In Bosnia Die Going Home
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/30/world.body_text: **********Three Muslim refugees were killed today and dozens were wounded in several angry confrontations with mobs of Serbs. The Muslims were trying to return to homes they had not seen since the war. **********It was the first time since the war ended that anyone had been killed in showdowns between Muslims seeking to go home and former Bosnian Serb enemies who do not want them to return. **********Near Sarajevo, Serbs blocked a convoy of Muslims from returning to homes and visiting cemeteries in Trnovo, 18 miles south of Sarajevo. Fifteen people were hurt as Serbs battered the buses with rocks and sticks, breaking dozens of windows. **********Bosnian television said one of those wounded, Hajrija Kazazic, died in a Sarajevo hospital tonight. **********The convoy, seven buses carrying up to 250 people, was attacked by about 100  Bosnian Serbs soon after crossing into Serbian-held territory near Sarajevo, despite an escort by French troops backed by tanks and helicopters. **********Another group of 200 Serbs stopped the convoy again just north of its destination. **********One Muslim refugee, Zineta Belko, 44, from a village near Trnovo, had boarded a bus today hoping to see her home. She ended up in the hospital after a rock hit her in the head. **********"I was very close to seeing my house, but I never got to see it," she said. "I won't try to see it again. Normal life just doesn't appear possible with the  Serbs." **********In another incident today, at a checkpoint near Doboj, a few miles southwest  of here and about 60 miles north of Sarajevo, Swedish and United States troops stood between about 300 Muslims and 25 Serbs. **********When some Muslims tried to get around the NATO troops by crossing a nearby minefield to reach their former homes, several blasts were heard and a dozen people were hurt, officials said. They later reported that two Muslims had died. **********A NATO spokesman, Maj. Jerry Rehn, said one Muslim had been killed by small-arms fire and the second presumably by a mine blast. **********Maj. Paci Karonen, a spokesman for peacekeepers in Doboj, said that seven dead or wounded people had been evacuated by helicopter but that United States Apache helicopters had spotted another five people still in the minefield. It was not clear whether any of those were dead. **********The growing number and intensity of the disputes between Muslims and Serbs have presented an important challenge to the international effort to oversee the Bosnian peace accords, which were intended to guarantee the freedom of movement  of all returnees. **********The agreement, reached in Dayton, Ohio, in November, provided no clear means  to enforce its guarantees, and the NATO-led peacekeepers here have increasingly  been drawn into trying to shield or separate the sides. **********The French troops today tried unsuccessfully to force through the convoy to Trnovo. But United States and other peacekeeping soldiers have tried to discourage the refugees from crossing the front lines to return to homes by imposing some restrictions on travel. **********Peacekeepers and NATO officials said such moves, while inhibiting freedom of  movement, were necessary to prevent violence. **********A French spokesman, Maj. Herve Gourmelon, said the heavy French military presence today had been meant mainly as a deterrent, adding that responding to attacks like those today was a task for Bosnia's police, not NATO peacekeepers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/18/busin.main_headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Several Large Banks Post Strong Results for 2d Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/18/busin.print_headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Several Large Banks Post Strong Results for 2d Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/18/busin.body_text: **********Four of the biggest American banks reported strong second-quarter earnings yesterday, in several cases shrugging off increased loan losses. **********The BankAmerica Corporation, the Bank of New York Corporation and the Wachovia Corporation relied on higher revenues from fees to offset the growth of bad loans. The Republic New York Corporation, with one of the biggest loan-loss reserves in relation to its current losses, had the strongest earnings report among large banks, as its income from lending and investments surged. **********The Corestates Financial Corporation and Fleet Financial Group Inc. both reported positive, but weaker, earnings growth as they completed acquisitions. **********Bank of New York's announcement last month that it would set aside $350 million for credit-card losses spurred concern about banks' potential loan losses. Yesterday, however, banks either reported smaller-than-expected loan losses or revenue growth and cost cuts that more than offset the bad loans. **********Corestates, still absorbing its $3.4 billion acquisition of the Meridian Bancorp in April, was a laggard, as rising loan losses and slow revenue growth hurt its results. And Fleet, with two multibillion-dollar acquisitions since December, said higher expenses had hurt its earnings. **********BankAmerica's second-quarter earnings rose 12 percent, as higher fees and lower costs offset sluggish profits from lending. The nation's third-largest bank, based in San Francisco, said net income rose to $723 million, or $1.84 a share, from $645 million, or $1.56, a year earlier. **********The earnings exceeded the average forecast of $1.79 a share in an IBES International survey of 23 investment analysts. BankAmerica's shares rose $2 yesterday, to $76.875. **********Fleet's second-quarter profits rose 9.3 percent, meeting expectations, as the impact of two big acquisitions helped the bottom line. **********The nation's 12th-largest bank, based in Providence, R.I., said net income rose to $277.7 million, or 96 cents per fully diluted share, from $254 million,  or 91 cents, in the period last year. The bank did not announce primary per-share earnings. **********Profits from lending and nonlending businesses rose as Fleet added revenue from the purchase of the Shawmut National Corporation and of the Natwest Bancorp. **********The stock was unchanged at $41.25. **********Bank of New York's second-quarter earnings rose 23 percent, above expectations. The bank's net income rose to $278 million, or $1.35 a share, from $226 million, or $1.14, in the 1995 quarter. Bank of New York stock rose 87.5 cents, to $49.875. **********Republic said second-quarter earnings beat expectations as higher revenue from loans and other investments offset lower fees. **********Net income rose more than ninefold, to $103.1 million, or $1.71 a share, from $11.1 million, or 2 cents, in last year's quarter. Last year's earnings, however, included a $78 million charge for a companywide restructuring to cut costs. **********Republic rose 75 cents, to $61.75. **********Wachovia said second-quarter earnings were $159.4 million, or 94 cents a share -- above expectations. **********While the figure was 2 percent lower than the net of $162.9 million, or 94 cents a share, the bank earned in last year's second quarter, it was 20.6 percent above its $132.2 million profit from operations in the 1995 period. The  quarter last year included a gain of $47.4 million from the sale of Wachovia's mortgage-servicing portfolio. **********Shares of the Wachovia, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., rose 75 cents, to $41.625. **********Corestates, based in Philadelphia, said its second-quarter earnings increased 9.3 percent, helped by reduced operating expenses. Its profit from operations rose to $193.4 million, or 88 cents a share, slightly below expectations, from $177.0 million, or 80 cents, a year earlier. **********Net profits, however, were nearly 50 percent lower, at $79.6 million, or 36 cents a share, compared with $158.2 million, or 71 cents a share, in the 1995 quarter. This year's net reflected merger-related charges of $123.3 million. **********The stock fell 12.5 cents, to $37.50.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/29/busin.print_headline: For Sports Investors, Dividends May Be Ringside Seats
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/29/busin.body_text: **********ONE day about 30 years ago, 11-year-old Leigh Leventis finished 16th in his age group in a national bowling tournament and thought he had found his life's calling. ''I wanted to be a pro bowler,'' he said. **********It didn't happen. ''My father made me go to law school'' instead, Mr. Leventis recalled, and now he is a lawyer with a thriving practice in Columbia, S.C. **********But Mr. Leventis has found a way back to his childhood dream: He invests in bowlers. He has advanced $45,000 each to a number of the game's professionals, and in return he  gets a sense of participation in the game and a share of the prize money. **********And he has fun. After all, who could recline in the La-Z-Boy with a beer and root for a mutual fund? **********There are a few hundred to a few thousand ''sports investors'' like Mr. Leventis, mostly in bowling, golf and tennis. Such investments are extremely risky -- often returning nothing but losses -- but for the athletes themselves the deals make sense. **********''What's unique about sports like golf and tennis is that there are no salaries,'' said Adam Lenkin, a lawyer with the Jeff Fried Company, a Washington firm that represents athletes. And the expenses can be very heavy. Professional golfers need about $75,000 a year to travel and play in tournaments; bowlers require $30,000 to $45,000. Tennis players need about $70,000 for travel,  tournament costs and outlays for coaches. **********What are these deals like? A typical one is Mr. Leventis's arrangement with Don Moser of Murrieta, Calif., who has total career winnings of $348,000 and is ranked 39th among United States bowlers this year. Mr. Moser said, ''I get $1,100 a week over the 27 tournaments we bowl, and at the end of the year he gets his money back, and we split the rest of the prizes 50-50.'' **********Mr. Leventis also receives 20 percent of the ''incentive money'' that Mr. Moser wins. This money, paid to bowlers by companies for use of their bowling equipment and apparel in televised tournaments, is linked to the bowlers' finish in the competition. ''Columbia has a new ball called the Pulse, and if you used one of their balls and wore their shirt on TV and you won you got $10,000,'' Mr. Moser said, referring to Columbia 300 Inc., a San Antonio company. **********Sports sponsors take different routes to these recreational investments. In 1980, Mr. Leventis was approached as a potential sponsor by John Douglas (Guppy) Trup, a boyhood buddy and successful professional bowler. Carl Copansky, a jewelry dealer in California who is known there for his TV commercials, is still looking for his athlete. He has wanted to sponsor a tennis player  since earlier this year, when he noticed a talented young player on a neighboring court at a private club. Finding an athlete is difficult -- there are no clearinghouses -- so Mr. Copansky is still talking to coaches and tennis officials, trying to find someone who has a line on the next Andre Agassi. **********On rare occasions, the looking pays off in potfuls. Jeff Fried of the Fried Company assembled one such deal, a syndicate of 11 sponsors who invested a total of $500,000 in a young boxer named Riddick Bowe. The fighter, of course, went on to great heavyweight success and, in the process, quadrupled his sponsors' money. **********BUT losses, or low returns, are the usual name of the game. Mr. Leventis has lost as much as $90,000 in two different years, 1986 and 1988. His best return, in 1995, was about $65,000 on $725,000 -- a 9 percent payout. **********Indeed, the only reliable return for sports sponsors is a good time. Many enjoy savoring the chance, no matter how improbable,  that they will back a champion. From this perspective, sponsorship is just a very costly way to cheer for an athlete. **********Alvin Miller, a former vice president of Giant Food, a grocery chain, was delighted to get a big return on the investment of some of his retirement money in Riddick Bowe. But Mr. Miller, of Washington, D.C., also emphasizes the behind-the-scenes access and status that his investment bought. ''It is fun having your friends ask about it, especially the caddies at the club,'' he said. ''To them, I was The Man.'' **********And Mr. Leventis explained his sponsorship as ''my way of staying in touch with bowling.'' **********Some sponsorships even yield friendships,  like that of Sal Gaudiano and Todd Berranger, a golfer. ''If he doesn't make it in golf, he's got a job with me the rest of his life,'' said Mr. Gaudiano, an executive for a coal company in Middlesboro, Ky. The two became close when the golfer found he had cancer, which is now arrested. **********''I have a daughter whom I love very much,'' Mr. Gaudiano said, ''but Todd is like a son I never had.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/16/world.main_headline: Seoul Sinks Imaginary Foe (aka Tokyo) at Islet
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/16/world.print_headline: Seoul Sinks Imaginary Foe (aka Tokyo) at Islet
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/16/world.body_text: **********In a warning to Tokyo, South Korean military forces today practiced repelling imaginary enemy vessels around disputed islets in the Sea of Japan. **********The islets are tiny clumps of rock peeking above the choppy seas about half-way between South Korea and Japan. Once inhabited only by birds, they are now occupied by a South Korean police unit. **********There are fishing grounds near the islets, and there is some talk that there may be minerals or petroleum in the area. But the main reason for the dispute is simply nationalism. **********The latest round of the dispute erupted earlier this month when Japan leaked  plans to declare a 200-mile exclusive economic zone, in accordance with the Law  of the Sea Treaty, that would encompass the islets. Seoul responded by announcing plans to build a pier on them, and Japan's subsequent protest to that set off a fury in South Korea. **********During a snowstorm this afternoon, four South Korean naval vessels, an anti-submarine helicopter and four fighter jets pounced on an imaginary foreign  ship. Seoul later announced that it had destroyed the target off what it calls Tokto Island, but is known as Takeshima in Japanese, and is sometimes called Liancourt Rocks in the West. **********It may seem a lot of fuss over barely habitable clumps of reef. But Koreans are always sensitive to national slights, particularly from the Japanese, and lately they have been burning effigies of Japanese leaders and announcing plans for a national boycott of Japanese goods. **********While Korean politicians are vying to defend national honor, the Japanese public seems unconcerned, and Japanese officials are clearly trying to soothe the Koreans. **********"We're still in the process of collecting information" about the military exercises, a Japanese Foreign Ministry spokesman said today. He declined to condemn the exercise or say whether a protest would be issued, apparently reflecting the Japanese hope that the fuss will subside. **********Even though Japan still sends patrol boats around the islets to back up its claims of ownership, Tokyo has allowed South Korean troops to occupy them since  the 1950's and it has ruled out the use of force to reclaim them. **********While most Japanese would scarcely know where to begin to look for Takeshima  on a map, Tokto is well known to Koreans and has been the subject of a Korean song, ("Tokto is our land!") and of a popular book and movie -- in which a Japanese attempt to seize the islets leads to a war that Korea wins. **********While there is little danger of a military conflict over the islets, intelligence experts are more concerned about the risk of a clash over another set of tiny islands that also would fall under Japan's 200-mile exclusive zone.  These islands, called the Diaoyu islands in Chinese and the Senkaku islands in Japanese, are uninhabited but are claimed by Japan, China and Taiwan. **********Japan now patrols the seas around these islands, and some Japanese Government officials say Tokyo might use military force against any Chinese attempt to occupy them.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/15/busin.main_headline: TRW Announces Layoffs And $233 Million Charge
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/15/busin.print_headline: TRW Announces Layoffs And $233 Million Charge
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/15/busin.body_text: **********In a move it said was taken to increase competitiveness in its automotive business, TRW Inc. said yesterday that it planned to eliminate about 2,300 jobs and close several plants. The company took an aftertax charge of $233.4 million in the third quarter to pay for the moves. **********The layoff announcement, which amounts to a little more than 3 percent of the Cleveland-based company's work force of 63,000, was contained in a third-quarter earnings report analysts said was complicated by TRW's sale last month of its credit information services business. **********On Sept. 19, TRW said it had sold the business, which last year accounted for about 6 percent of its 1995 sales, to the Thomas Lee Corporation and Bain Capital Inc. for a little over $1 billion. **********TRW said yesterday that the sale had generated an after-tax gain of $242.4 million, or $3.67 a share. On an accounting basis, the gain offset the $233.4 million charge. **********Excluding the special items and the operating results of the credit information business, TRW said third-quarter earnings rose 10 percent, to $86.2 million, or $1.31 a share, from $78.2 million, or $1.18 a share, in the comparable period a year ago. Including special items, profits were $105.2 million, or $1.60 a share, compared with $93.6 million, or $1.39. **********Revenues were $2.32 billion, up 3 percent from $2.25 billion last year.  Operating profits rose 13 percent, to $191.4 million, from $169.8 million during the comparable period in 1995. The sales and operating profit figures exclude the credit information services business, TRW said. **********Even though the results were in line with Wall Street expectations, the report did not sit particularly well with investors. TRW shares fell $1, to $92.625 a share. **********''It's confusing,'' said Eli Lustgarten, an analyst at Schroder Wertheim & Company. ''Whenever you sell a business and take a big write-off to offset it, it is hard to get your hands around what is happening. But on a division-by-division basis the numbers were in line'' with expectations, he said. **********TRW has said it will use at least some of the proceeds from the sale of the credit information service to continue its previously announced stock buyback program. Ultimately, the company said it intended to repurchase 10 to 15 percent of its shares. So far, TRW said yesterday, it has bought back 3.1 million shares, or about 5 percent of outstanding stock. **********Jay A. McCaffrey, a company spokesman, said the layoffs would come primarily from TRW's automotive group, which makes seat belts, air bags, and steering systems. After the sale of its credit business, TRW was left with its auto group and its military and space group. **********Under the plan, four plants will be closed, Mr. McCaffrey said: two in Michigan, one in Texas and one in Ontario.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/14/world.snippet: Joseph Kovago, political prisoners, Mayor of Budapest during the 1956 uprising, spokesman for Hungarians in exile, and, finally, a champion of Hungarian democracy in post-Soviet era, dies at age 83 (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/14/world.body_text: **********Joseph Kovago, political prisoner, Mayor of Budapest during the 1956 uprising, spokesman for Hungarians in exile and, finally, a champion of Hungarian democracy in the post-Soviet era, died on Tuesday at his home in Linwood, N.J. He was 83. **********The cause was cancer, his family said. **********When Mr. Kovago arrived in New York with his wife and 9-year-old daughter in January 1957, he was welcomed by Mayor Robert F. Wagner at City Hall. He pleaded his country's cause before the United Nations, held office in the Captive European Nations Assembly and remained persona non grata in his homeland for more than 30 years until the end of Communist rule. **********Hungary's freely elected post-Communist Government remembered him in 1990, inviting him to the opening of Parliament, making him an honorary citizen of Budapest and decorating him for his contributions to democracy. He is to receive a state funeral in Budapest in recognition to his having stood up to both Nazis and Communists in power. **********Trained at Hungary's military academy, Mr. Kovago also received  a master's degree and was commissioned in the Hungarian Army in 1935. During the German occupation in 1944, he helped organize the resistance and was imprisoned. **********After the war, in 1945, he was elected Mayor of Budapest and a member of Parliament and, with Western aid, started to reconstruct the war-damaged capital. When the Communists began to stifle the other parties, he resigned his political posts and went to work as an engineer. **********The Communists, backed by Soviet power, took full charge in 1948 and, in a secret trial, sentenced him to life in prison as an opponent of the Government. He spent more than six years in prison until the uprising of 1956, when he was re-elected Mayor. The  rebel Government of Imre Nagy named him to a delegation that tried to negotiate with the Soviets. **********The aim was to secure Hungary's neutrality and withdrawal from the Warsaw Pact, an effort aborted by the Soviet invasion of November 1956 that crushed the uprising. **********Mr. Kovago, secretary general of the Smallholders Party, fled and became a leader in various exile groups, a role in which he lectured widely and traveled abroad as a good-will ambassador. **********He wrote ''You Are All Alone'' (Praeger, 1959), his personal account of the Hungarian uprising. At his death he had finished a volume of memoirs. **********While in the United States, he also returned to work and became a senior research engineer for Atlantic Electric Company in Northfield, N.J. After his retirement in 1978, he lectured on world politics and energy-related subjects at Stockton State College in Pomona, N.J. **********Mr. Kovago is survived by his wife of 51 years, Ilona Varga Kovago; their daughter, Katalin Kovago of Cliffside Park, N.J.; a brother, Istvan Kuronya of Budapest, and a sister, Karoline Baranyai, of Szekesfehervar, Hungary.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/20/busin.print_headline: MOBIL IS SELLING 13 OIL AND NATURAL GAS FIELDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/20/busin.body_text: **********The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell 13 oil and natural gas producing fields in the Gulf of Mexico to Flores & Rucks Inc. for $139.3 million. Mobil, which is based in Fairfax, Va., said the fields produce the equivalent of about 10,000 barrels a day of oil. The 13 fields are in shallow waters off Louisiana's shore. The properties have low productivity and limited development potential, the company said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/14/world.main_headline: Clinton Visits Bosnia to Thank the G.I.'s
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/14/world.print_headline: Clinton Visits Bosnia to Thank the G.I.'s
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/14/world.body_text: **********With Apache attack helicopters patrolling the slate-gray skies overhead, President Clinton stood today before rows of the American soldiers he had sent to Bosnia and thanked them for being "warriors for peace." **********On a chill airfield, the nearby roads mired in thick mud, President Clinton gazed at 500 soldiers in camouflage gear and told them they represented the American ideal. **********Around the world people look to America, not just because of our size and strength but because of what we stand for and what we're willing to stand against," the President said, speaking from a makeshift wooden podium piled with sandbags. **********"We can't be everywhere, and even you can't do everything," he said. "But where we can make a difference, where our values and our interests are at stake, we must act." **********Underscoring the importance he places on peacekeeping missions, Mr. Clinton announced that he had signed an executive order creating a new campaign medal, the Armed Forces Service Medal, for troops who serve in "significant, noncombat  military missions." He said all the participants in the Bosnia operation would receive it. **********[The President returned to Washington just before midnight Saturday.] **********Before Mr. Clinton spoke at Tuzla, he visited Checkpoint Lima, a sandbag bunker on the perimeter of the airfield, and talked to the troops about their living conditions. **********Dressed in a brown leather bomber jacket and khakis, he also presided over a  brief promotion ceremony for five enlisted men. Outside the bunker, a crude cardboard sign declared the address "Sniper Street." **********It took Mr. Clinton two tries today to make it into Tuzla, the headquarters of the American forces, who will eventually number 20,000 of the 60,000 NATO peacekeepers. **********Early this morning, the C-17 military transport plane carrying Mr. Clinton, his aides and a bipartisan Congressional delegation was diverted because of fog  to the next stop on his itinerary -- an American staging base in Taszar, Hungary. Despite this delay of several hours, the President's entourage was upbeat. **********Mr. Clinton's aggressive diplomacy, which helped lead to a plan to end the four-year-old Balkan conflict, and his decision to send American troops on an unpopular mission to enforce that peace contrast with his earlier reputation for wavering on difficult foreign policy decisions. **********The deployment of troops to Bosnia and Herzegovina and success at keeping the peace could prove crucial in this election year. Mr. Clinton has acknowledged that if the mission brings substantial casualties, it could cost him re-election. **********But today his appearance among the troops in Tuzla and Taszar and at Aviano Air Base in Italy underscored his role as Commander in Chief and set him apart from his antagonists in the budget squabble. **********Senator Bob Dole, the leading contender for the Republican Presidential nomination, had wanted to visit the troops over Christmas. But he canceled his plans after Defense Secretary William J. Perry said commanders in Europe wanted  to avoid distractions as the troops arrived. **********Mr. Clinton has begun pointing to American efforts in Haiti, Northern Ireland, the Middle East and Bosnia as models of United States foreign policy in the post-cold-war world **********"We have a profound interest in seeing the United States be the world's leading source of energy for peace and freedom and democracy," he told assembly-line workers at a truck plant in Nashville on Friday just before he set off for Bosnia. **********Mr. Clinton's trip was marked by heavy security. His precise itinerary was closely held, and Secret Service sharpshooters followed him in Tuzla, where he stayed inside the grounds of the airfield, seeing nothing of the war's effects on the town. A senior official in his entourage said the President's visit had "more logistical, security and weather variables" than he had ever encountered before. **********Mr. Clinton took off from Tuzla about two and a half hours after his arrival  as fog rolled in, advised by the Secret Service to leave before dark. **********At Taszar airfield in Hungary, the forward staging area for American troops moving by land through Croatia into Bosnia, the side of the tarmac was littered  with broken-down Soviet MIG fighter planes, a reminder of the cold war. **********"Just six years ago, Hungary was still part of the Warsaw Pact, and now it's  home to the largest American military operation in Europe since World War II," the President told hundreds of men and women in combat fatigues, many with cameras, who crammed into a makeshift mess hall for his stop there this morning. **********Green tents lined an airfield that, like Tuzla, is such a sea of thick mud that Mr. Clinton described it in his radio address back home. "In Tuzla, the headquarters for our troops in Bosnia, the weather report is pretty much the same every day: mud, mud and more mud," he said. **********The soldiers greeted Mr. Clinton with applause and repeated guttural shouts of "Hoo-aa!" pep-rally style. This was in marked contrast to the early days of his Presidency, when he was heckled at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial as someone  who had avoided the military draft and who was joked about by sailors while visiting the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt. **********Many of the nearly 7,000 troops in Taszar are heading on to Bosnia, and Mr. Clinton told them, "I'd like to be able to report that when you get there, you will find deluxe accommodations." **********"I'd like to be able to do that," he said, to swelling laughter. "But even for a political leader, that's stretching the truth a little more than people dare." **********Despite the living conditions in Bosnia, some troops in Taszar expressed support for the mission and delight at seeing the President. **********"It's great, great, real great for him to help us out," said Specialist Doris Splunge, 31, who sets out to Bosnia on Monday. Another 30-year-old soldier, who  would not give his name, said: "I appreciate him coming here. Misery loves company." **********Mr. Clinton also fit in time for diplomacy. In Tuzla he assembled an unusual  delegation of religious and civic leaders of Bosnia, including Tarik Kupusovic,  the Muslim Mayor of Sarajevo, and Nedejlko Prstojevic, the Mayor of Ilidza, a Serbian suburb of Sarajevo. **********Mr. Clinton also met with President Alija Izetbegovic of Bosnia in Tuzla, before going to Zagreb for a brief stopover to meet with President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia, then flying back to Washington. **********-------------------- **********Return to Washington **********WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (By The New York Times) -- President Clinton returned to Washington just before midnight tonight from his 18-hour visit with American troops in Italy, Hungary and Bosnia. **********En route to Washington, Mr. Clinton stopped in Zagreb, where he was met at the airport by enthusiastic crowds of residents. He also held brief talks with President Tudjman. **********Treated to a red-carpet welcome in Zagreb, Mr. Clinton urged the crowds to "choose peace -- choose the future." **********He expressed optimism about peace in Bosnia despite recent violence in Sarajevo and Mostar. "Frankly I have to say I'm concerned about those incidents," he said. But he added, "Given the level of animosity which had existed, I think the signs have been quite good." **********The fighting in Mostar has been between Muslims and Croats, who are to form a federation as part of the peace accord, and the United States Embassy in Zagreb  said American mediation efforts in the city would be intensified.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/11/busin.main_headline: Blood, Money and AIDS: Hemophiliacs Are Split;Liability Cases Bogged Down in Disputes
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/11/busin.print_headline: Blood, Money and AIDS: Hemophiliacs Are Split;Liability Cases Bogged Down in Disputes
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/11/busin.body_text: **********Last December, Corey Dubin, a hemophiliac infected with the virus that causes AIDS, met for lunch at a Carrow's restaurant in Camarillo, Calif., with John Bacich, the president of a Baxter International Inc. unit that makes blood-clotting products. **********Mr. Dubin, like an estimated 6,000 to 10,000 hemophiliacs nationwide, became  infected with H.I.V. after receiving a tainted clotting substance made by Baxter and three other companies in the late 1970's and early 1980's. Hundreds of victims had sued. But statutes of limitations prevented thousands more from bringing claims. Mr. Dubin however had not come to lunch to pick a fight. Rather, dissatisfied with the way key plaintiffs' lawyers were handling the litigation, he was on a stealth mission to negotiate, for all those infected, a  settlement with the four companies without the knowledge of key plaintiffs' lawyers. **********I told him they were going to have to live with us as customers when all the high-powered litigators were gone," said Mr. Dubin, a 41-year-old former journalist from Goleta, Calif., recalling the lunchtime conversation with Mr. Bacich. "If you buy a Pinto from Ford that blows up, you can tell Ford to go to  hell. But I don't have that luxury." **********In many cases of mass litigation, corporations are able to buy themselves settlements that enrich lawyers but leave the victims -- faceless names on the cover sheets of legal documents -- with a pittance. In the hemophilia litigation, some claimants jumped off the page to try to influence the outcome of an emotionally charged dispute. **********The result of their revolt was a legal free-for-all for plaintiffs, lawyers and companies alike. United by their disease, hemophiliacs were divided between  activists seeking to squeeze the maximum settlement out of the drug makers and others willing to accept less money so that the sickest among them, dying at the rate of one a day, could get some cash. Some actors included Mr. Dubin, president of the Committee of Ten Thousand, an activist group; Jonathan Wadleigh, the committee's founder; Robert Baldwin, who gained prominence as a counselor for hemophiliacs, and David Shrager, a plaintiffs' lawyer who guided the case until the activists challenged him. **********The defendants -- Baxter; Bayer A.G. of Germany; Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc., a  unit of Rhone-Poulenc S.A. of France, and the Alpha Therapeutic Corporation, a unit of the Green Cross Corporation of Japan -- were also roiled by confusion. Today they are operating in unison. But in the past they often ignored solidarity to protect their own interests, individually discussing settlements,  withdrawing them or joining together in various combinations. **********In the end, the Committee of Ten Thousand failed to negotiate a deal alone. But its leaders insist their initiative was not in vain. At the very least, they say, they galvanized victims to press for higher compensation. And, according to Baxter documents, they came close to a settlement that could have required Baxter to pay out more than it will under industry's offer last month of $100,000 for each claimant, up to a maximum of $640 million. Hemophiliacs are expected to be polled soon on their interest in the deal. **********But some like Mr. Baldwin contend that the activists may have scuttled earlier deals that could have gotten money quickly to those who desperately needed it. "I've had mothers calling me saying that they'd be happy to get $30,000 for their son so they can buy him a new car before he dies," said Mr. Baldwin, whose brother, also a hemophiliac, died three years ago of AIDS. It is  estimated that more than 2,000 H.I.V.- infected hemophiliacs have died. **********Hemophiliacs, who suffer an inherited disorder in which the blood's clotting  ability is impaired and excessive bleeding results, occupy a unique chapter in the AIDS crisis. Their fatal infection was caused by the very clotting substances, known as Factor VIII and Factor IX, that they took to save their lives. And unlike many AIDS-afflicted homosexuals, most hemophiliacs kept a low  profile early on, fearful of exposing their conditions. **********By the early 1990's, however, activists discovered that Government regulators and industry officials had known since the early 1980's that clotting products posed an AIDS infection threat. The National Hemophilia Foundation, a research and lobbying group, also understated infection risks in the early 1980's, according to a 1995 report by the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy  of Sciences. **********The disclosures led to the creation of activist groups like the Committee of  Ten Thousand. At annual meetings of the National Hemophilia Foundation in early  1990's, activists parked hearses outside hotels, wore death masks and threw fake blood on industry representatives. And even moderates like Mr. Baldwin began pressing producers of the clotting substances to settle claims before they reached the courtroom. **********In the fall of 1993, top executives of three companies -- Baxter, Rhone-Poulenc and Alpha Therapeutic -- met with leaders of the hemophilia community to outline the terms of a $125 million offer, said Mr. Baldwin, who attended the meeting. But he said that Mr. Wadleigh and Mr. Dubin appeared anxious and insisted that any decision be put off. "I didn't know what was going on," said Mr. Baldwin, who lives in Bedford, Tex. **********He got his answer the next day: With Mr. Wadleigh as lead plaintiff, Mr. Shrager, the plaintiffs' lawyer, filed a class-action lawsuit on behalf of American hemophiliacs. Mr. Shrager, who had previously negotiated a favorable settlement on behalf of Canadian hemophiliacs, then established a panel of claimants, led by Mr. Wadleigh, to advise him and other lawyers. **********In early 1995, the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit in  Chicago decertified the lawsuit, saying it might bankrupt the industry. Soon, the partnership between Mr. Wadleigh and Mr. Shrager unraveled in a struggle over the direction of the case. **********Activists like Mr. Wadleigh and Mr. Dubin favored appealing the Seventh Circuit decision to the Supreme Court, arguing it would protect the interests of all affected hemophiliacs, not just those who had already sued. But Mr. Shrager  wanted to shift gears and pursue the separate Federal proceeding that had consolidated hundreds of individual lawsuits that had been filed against the producers. **********The clotting producers had quietly settled many claims, but individual lawsuits had failed because most states shield blood products from traditional product-liability claims. Still, damaging documents were emerging contending that the companies had collected blood from high-risk donors like homosexuals and prisoners. Soon, informal settlement negotiations intensified. **********Meanwhile tensions between Mr. Wadleigh and others on the advisory committee  and Mr. Shrager had been growing. "It was outrageous," Mr. Wadleigh said. "He said he was representing the whole community and then he'd turn around and say that he represented the individual cases." Any talk of a settlement soon took a  back seat to strife within the plaintiffs' camp. **********Finally, upset by the decision of Mr. Shrager and his colleagues not to seek  an appeal, Mr. Wadleigh and his allies asked a Federal judge to replace the current cast of lawyers. The closed-door drama played out last June in the chambers of Federal District Judge John F. Grady in Chicago, according to sealed court records. Mr. Wadleigh and Mr. Dubin accused the lawyer of selling out hemophiliacs as a group to advance the cause of his clients. Mr. Shrager denied  the allegation and argued that it was important for the individual cases to go forward to keep up pressure on the companies to settle. **********Judge Grady backed Mr. Shrager, describing the revolt by the dissidents as akin to "passengers coming up and asking to take over the controls of a DC-10,"  according to court papers. But by that time, the activists, backed by two other  plaintiffs' lawyers, Thomas Mull and Charles Kozak, were pushing ahead on a separate course. **********In November, they found a new rallying cry when the companies they were suing announced a settlement for Japanese hemophiliacs that dwarfed the numbers being  discussed in this country: $420,000 for each victim, with $235,000 coming from industry and the rest from the Japanese government. **********The next month, Mr. Dubin and his lawyers began their secret talks with the companies. And by March, they came close to reaching a deal with Baxter that might have set the framework for a more lucrative deal than the one now on the table, according to company documents. **********The documents show that in late March, Baxter considered offering $50,000 to  any plaintiff who alleged H.I.V. infection from using a company product. Even though Baxter held only 20 percent of the market, the number of hemophiliacs who qualified for that plan might have been significantly higher because users could easily switch from one company's brand to another's. If 50 percent of 6,000 affected hemophiliacs or family members applied for the plan, a separate settlement would have cost the company $150 million, not including lawyers' fees. **********That compares with Baxter's one-fifth share of the current proposal for paying each participating hemophiliac $100,000 -- up to a cost to the company of $120 million, excluding legal fees. Mary Thomas, a Baxter spokeswoman, said the company, which favored an industrywide solution, had projected that the stillborn proposal would have cost it less than its current share of the industrywide offer. But she declined to disclose the basis for that estimate. **********Along with talks to settle claims by those with cases that have not been filed, talks were also apparently under way earlier this year to settle lawsuits. Bayer, the largest company involved in the litigation with 45 percent  of the market, pressed plaintiffs' lawyers involved in individual lawsuits to reach settlements quickly, according to a lawyer familiar with Bayer's negotiating stance. Margo Barnes, a Bayer spokeswoman, denied that the company had tried to push for settlement, adding that it had rejected entreaties from plaintiffs' lawyers. **********For now, Mr. Dubin, Mr. Shrager and Mr. Baldwin have shed their differences and are taking a united stand toward the industry's settlement proposal. But the solidarity could be threatened by potential frictions between the some 500 people who have filed individual lawsuits and the thousands who would only benefit from a mass settlement. Mr. Dubin exalts about the activists' role in exacting favorable terms for the hemophiliac community. "This is the first time  that plaintiffs have taken a case into their own hands," he said. **********Mr. Shrager, though, says it was really hard-knuckled lawyering that brought  the companies around.  "Corey has done a great job of applying pressure in recent months," he said. "But giant companies don't offer to give away $640 million out of the kindness of their hearts."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/11/busin.main_headline: G.E. and Rolls Alliance Is Seen
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/11/busin.print_headline: G.E. and Rolls Alliance Is Seen
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/11/busin.body_text: **********Rolls-Royce P.L.C. and the General Electric Company are expected to announce  on Monday the formation of an alliance seeking to supply the United States military with jet engines for a new generation of strike aircraft. **********The aircraft, which are to have vertical take-off capabilities, are designed  to perform like Britain's Hawker-Siddeley Harrier "jump jets," which are powered by the Rolls-Royce Pegasus engine. **********Analysts said the United States armed forces were likely to use engines from both the G.E.-Rolls partnership and from Pratt & Whitney, a unit of the United Technologies Corporation, because more than one engine supplier would be needed  to power the 3,000 jets expected to go into service.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/20/busin.main_headline: S.E.C. Deals a Blow to First Bank's Bid for First Interstate
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/20/busin.print_headline: S.E.C. Deals a Blow to First Bank's Bid for First Interstate
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/20/busin.body_text: **********The $10 billion bid by the First Bank System of Minneapolis to buy the First  Interstate Bancorporation of Los Angeleswas dealt a possibly fatal blow yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which ruled that First Bank could not buy back its own stock for two years. **********First Bank had been counting on buying back 73 million shares -- worth $3.5 billion at today's prices -- over the next three years to make the acquisition attractive to its shareholders. Since a stock buyback eliminates shares, it increases the earnings per share outstanding. **********The S.E.C. ruling further aids a rival, Wells Fargo & Company of San Francisco, which has made a hostile attempt to win First Interstate for itself.  If completed by either side, the merger would rival the Chase Manhattan-Chemical Banking merger as the biggest in history. **********The Wells Fargo bid has been gaining momentum in recent weeks because its stock has outpaced that of First Bank, and the gap increased sharply yesterday after the accounting ruling was disclosed. **********Wells Fargo stock jumped $6.25, to $217.25, while First Bank's stock closed unchanged at $48.50 in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Both companies are offering to buy First Interstate through an exchange of stock. At yesterday's prices, Wells Fargo was offering $144.69 of its stock for  every First Interstate share. First Bank's bid is worth $126.10 a share. Stock traders appear to believe that the Wells Fargo bid will win, because First Interstate shares closed yesterday at $138.875, up $3.325, far closer to the Wells Fargo price than to the First Bank bid. **********"This means the First Bank deal is not going to happen," said David S. Berry, research director at Keefe Bruyette & Woods. "Both they and Wells predicated their deals on massive cost takeouts and massive share repurchases. Now First Bank can't buy its stock for two years." **********Mr. Berry said he estimated that First Bank's share buyback plan accounted for one-third to half of the estimated benefit from the transaction. **********Richard A. Zona, First Bank's chief financial officer, said that its deal would still increase its earnings per share by 13 percent in 1987, a far greater gain than in most bank acquisitions. Moreover, he said, the bank will take the capital it would have used for share repurchases and make other investments that will increase the bank's returns. Nonetheless, he termed the ruling yesterday, "a mistake by the S.E.C." Wells Fargo's plan to buy back stock is not affected by the S.E.C. ruling because it had chosen to use a different accounting treatment. Merger experts said that the $18.60-a-share gap between the value of the two bids and this accounting ruling increased the pressure on First Interstate's board to rethink the deal with First Bank, and possibly to find a way to sell itself to Wells Fargo instead. A First Interstate spokesman declined to comment. "I don't know how they could go to their shareholders and ask them to vote for this at this point," one top merger negotiator said. First Bank is in a difficult spot because the more the market feels that Wells Fargo will win, the higher the Wells Fargo stock price goes. Some merger specialists expect that to regain momentum, First Bank will have to raise its bid significantly. Even First Bank advisers concede that the value of its bid needs to be within $10 of the Wells Fargo bid for it to be considered. Yet if it does raise its offer, First Bank runs the risk that the market will think it is  overpaying and its share price will fall, wiping out the value of its increased  offer. First Bank may gain some benefit from the four days of hearings on the two merger proposals that the Federal Reserve will hold next week. First Interstate  has arranged for many local community and business leaders to complain that if Wells Fargo buys it, there will be huge losses of jobs and banking competition.  Wells Fargo, however, has arranged the support of several organized community groups to praise its commitment to lending to minority and low-income borrowers. First Bank will also benefit ifthe Wells Fargo proposal gets bogged down on antitrust grounds because Wells Fargo has substantial overlap in California with First Interstate. The Justice Department has already approved First Interstate's combination with First Bank, which has no California operations. But Wells Fargo has said it will sell as many branches as needed for quick approval, and regulators appear to be trying to treat both deals on a similar schedule. Regardless of the outcome for First Interstate, the S.E.C. accounting decision could put a chill on some bank mergers. The issue relates to the accounting method used by First Bank and most banking deals, known as pooling of interests. That means that when two companies merge, their financial statements are combined. The S.E.C. prefers "purchase accounting," which in theory forces the buyer to reckon with the value of its target. First Bank had argued that since it had a regular program of buying back its own stock in place before the First Interstate deal was announced, it should be permitted to continue the repurchases 90 days after the new deal closed. **********Where the company appears to have gone wrong, analysts said, is that when it  tried to sell its deal to investors, First Bank showed specific estimates of the benefit to its per-share earnings from an aggressive buyback program. This appears to have tied the stock purchases too closely to this transaction.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/15/busin.main_headline: Market Place;For Netcom, Its Fans Say Being Down Is Not Out
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/15/busin.print_headline: Market Place;For Netcom, Its Fans Say Being Down Is Not Out
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/15/busin.body_text: **********The fast-growing Internet business is often compared with the PC business a decade ago. And it is for just that reason that investors seem to be growing wary of the Internet and its wealth of too-good-to-be-true success stories. **********Consider Netcom On-Line Communication Services of San Jose, Calif., the nation's largest independent provider of Internet access, but which has yet to turn a profit. The company went public in December 1994 at $13 a share and by November of last year, the stock reached a high of $91.50 a share. The company's subscriber base has more than quadrupled, to 400,000 last week, and its revenues climbed to $52.4 million in 1995, up from $12.4 million the previous year. **********But when the market closed on Friday, the stock was trading back down at $27, up 50 cents, on Nasdaq. The market is reacting to recent announcements that bigger and better-known competitors, like AT&T, are revving up Internet access providers of their own. The day AT&T announced its intent to provide Internet access, Netcom shares fell $4.75 even though the news had been expected. Shares  of competitors like UUnet Technologies Inc. and Performance Systems International were also off. **********But even with the potentially formidable competition, many analysts feel it is still too early to nail the lid on Netcom's coffin. With the right kind of positioning, they say, independent access providers have plenty of opportunities. **********"With the market growing 100 percent a year, it's too early to call the winners and the losers," said Kevin Moore, an Internet analyst at Alex. Brown &  Sons in Baltimore, who calls the Netcom sell-off "totally unjustified." Despite the high-profile jostling for position, Mr. Moore said, "It's not a foregone conclusion that the market leaders will get wiped out." **********Still, AT&T's arrival and the expectation that just about every phone company will begin offering Internet access has forced Netcom to make some big changes in its business model, starting with lowering its prices. To counter as closely  as possible AT&T's offer of a full year free to current long-distance customers, Netcom is offering the first month for only $5 and unlimited access for only $19.95 monthly after that. **********The Netcom strategy, scheduled to be announced tomorrow, includes a repackaging of its Internet service to appeal to those familiar with the Internet rather than to neophytes. The company has shifted its marketing campaign on line, hoping to lure already heavy Internet users away from other providers and on-line services. **********The company is also attempting to solve customer service problems, which have soured a lot of current subscribers. At the core of the company's strategy, its  executives say, is giving subscribers more content, and the ability to personalize Netcom sessions by giving subscribers a daily dose of headline news  on the subjects of their choice. And the company has signed licensing deals with Netscape Communications and Microsoft to give subscribers the browser of their choice, scrapping its long-held tactic of providing Netcom subscribers with Netcruiser alone. **********As for AT&T, Mr. Moore said there could be no certainty that it would succeed in Internet access; it has already shown a certain clumsiness in several high-technology markets, starting with its high-profile failure in the PC market after acquiring the NCR Corporation. **********But not everyone is as optimistic as Mr. Moore about Netcom's longer-term prospects. "Our rating is at a hold," said Rakesh Sood, Internet analyst at Hambrecht & Quist. "The landscape on the consumer side is extremely competitive. The opportunity for improving margins and profitability are bleak." Still, Mr. Rakesh expects Netcom to report markedly improved first-quarter revenues: $23.8  million, up from $19.7 million in the fourth quarter. **********But Mr. Rakesh points to the need for Netcom to continue investing in its network to stay competitive, particularly if it hopes to attract a more technically advanced subscriber. That investment, he said, could push Netcom's time line for profitability into 1998.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/18/busin.snippet: Outlook for Keyspan Energy Corp, new holding company to be formed by Brooklyn Union Gas Co, discussed; formation would enable utility to make acquisitions abroad and much larger investments in nonutility businesses (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/18/busin.main_headline: Soon Brooklyn Union won't be just a staid utility investment.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/18/busin.print_headline: Soon Brooklyn Union won't be just a staid utility investment.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/18/busin.body_text: **********SINCE it was founded a century ago, Brooklyn Union Gas has grown steadily as it focused on serving its 1.1 million customers in Brooklyn, Staten Island and Queens. The utility has raised its dividend in each of the last 19 years. **********Thus it was a favorite stock for small, often older investors who wanted to build nest eggs for retirement and sought steady income rather than the chance at high growth. **********Hold on to your hats, shareholders, here comes  the Keyspan Energy Corporation. That's the name of Brooklyn Union's new holding company, which  the New York State Public Service Commission gave the company permission to form last week. **********The change is not merely cosmetic. If, as expected, stockholders approve the holding company at the annual meeting in February the utility will gain the freedom to make acquisitions in far-off lands and make much larger investments in businesses outside its field. **********Under the plan approved by the commission, the company could increase its investment in companies other than utilities from the current 15 percent to 50 percent of its net worth. **********Not that management plans to go wild with the new freedoms. Craig L. Matthews, the president and chief operating officer, said the goal was to have half of profits come from nonutility businesses within five years. **********The company has slowly been moving in that direction for years. It formed its Houston Exploration subsidiary in 1986 to find and produce natural gas. Houston Exploration's revenue has been soaring because of recent acquisitions. **********The company plans to build its war chest through a public offering of up to 35 percent of the subsidiary -- for about $13 to $15 a share -- to raise about $90 million. **********Brooklyn Union managers have for some time been longing to break out of the gas business,  which generates a good return but has few opportunities for expansion. **********Some growth might come from a plan to lower some service rates next year and then freeze them for five years. That could help persuade some larger customers like owners of apartment buildings and stores to switch from oil to gas. **********Management, however, has its eye on a much wider horizon. **********Vincent D. Enright, a senior vice president and the chief financial officer of Brooklyn Union, said the company was looking at possible joint ventures to build small power plants in Israel, Jordan and Greece. It has also looked at countries like Hungary that want to sell state-owned utilities. **********Robert B. Catell, the chairman and chief executive of Brooklyn Union, said of such plans, ''If we don't do this, the alternative is not to grow.'' **********''There could be more risk'' for stockholders in the new strategies, he said. ''But the alternative is even greater risk by doing nothing. The world is changing.'' **********With its core gas business being opened to more competition, Mr. Catell said, the company needed to find new ways of making a profit by drawing on its expertise in such fields as building co-generation power plants. **********The utility already has a subsidiary called Gas Energy that builds co-generation electric power plants. For decades, Brooklyn Union has been building the plants, which are efficient and require relatively small investments. The plants are placed at sites like hospitals or factories, where the waste heat from the generation of electricity can be used while the electricity produced is sold to others. **********The company also wants to expand its gas marketing in pursuit of customers of other utilities as states open up the industry to competition. **********''It's an extension of things we have learned to do fairly well,'' Mr. Enright said. **********''High growth does entail some higher risk,'' he acknowledged. He added, however, that the company planned to stay close to businesses it knows well and would continue to build from its stable base as a regulated gas utility. **********James McAuliffe, an energy analyst for Bear, Stearns, said that with the increasing emphasis on unregulated businesses there would be more risk and more volatility in earnings. **********Thus an older investor who just seeks a steady dividend might want to take a second look. Mr. McAuliffe added, however, that there could also be greater returns than in the past and that Keyspan would still have the stability of the relatively  steady earnings of its gas utility.
