https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/11/busin.snippet: True North Communications, world's seventh-largest advertising agency company, with billings estimated at $7.5 billion, says it will combine TN Technologies, a unit that specializes in interactive marketing communications, with Modem Media Adverti...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/11/busin.main_headline: True North, back in the expansion mode, plans to buy and take public an interactive marketing unit.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/11/busin.print_headline: True North, back in the expansion mode, plans to buy and take public an interactive marketing unit.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/11/busin.body_text: **********MADISON AVENUE'S march into cyberspace accelerated yesterday with a double download of digital news from True North Communications. **********True North, the world's seventh- largest agency company, with billings estimated at $7.5 billion, said it would combine TN Technologies, a unit that specializes in interactive marketing communications, with Modem Media Advertising L.P., a privately held shop in Westport, Conn., that creates marketing programs for media like CD-ROM's, the Internet and interactive television. **********Additionally, True North said, shares in the combined operations, which will retain the TN Technologies name, are to be sold in an initial public offering. **********True North, with other holdings that include Foote, Cone & Belding, will pay the three partners who head Modem Media $29 million in True North stock -- $25 million when the deal closes and $4 million upon the TN Technologies stock offering, which awaits a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. **********After the deal's closing, which is expected early next month, the partners in Modem Media will own what True North executives described as ''a substantial minority interest'' in the new TN Technologies. **********The negotiations over the transaction -- which has a fairly complex structure for tax and accounting reasons -- lasted six months, beginning after talks broke off between Modem Media and Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt in New York. Those plans were for Bozell, Jacobs to acquire Modem and combine it with a subsidiary, Poppe Tyson. Bozell, Jacobs has since filed for an initial public offering of stock in Poppe Tyson, which handles interactive accounts through a unit named Poppe.com. **********The deal between True North and Modem Media is emblematic of the acquisition binge that has been reshaping the agency industry all this year. It is also indicative of the push by agency giants into the realm of new media. **********But perhaps the larger significance of the amalgamation and the stock offering is that they are the  first big expansion moves by True North since its worldwide cooperative agreement with Publicis S.A. in Paris was terminated acrimoniously in February. **********Though True North and Publicis are still partners in a joint-venture European agency network, Publicis FCB Europe, the two are now competing furiously elsewhere. Since the agreement was rescinded, Maurice Levy, chairman and chief executive at Publicis, has announced acquisitions of controlling stakes in agencies in Brazil, Canada and Mexico. **********Bruce Mason, chairman and chief executive of True North, based in Chicago, alluded to the dispute in a statement announcing the Modem Media deal and the stock offering. **********''Throughout an exciting and challenging year with many potential distractions,'' Mr. Mason said, ''True North has been able to stay steadfastly focused.'' **********TN Technologies was opened in 1994 by True North and R/GA Media Group. It now has offices in Chicago, Hong Kong, London, New York, San Francisco and Toronto. Revenue last year, from clients like the Campbell Soup Company, S. C. Johnson & Son and Levi Strauss & Company, totaled $20 million. **********Modem Media opened in 1987 as a so-called electronic direct marketing agency. Revenue last year, from clients like Delta Air Lines, Hasbro Inc. and the J. C. Penney Company, totaled $11.5 million. Modem Media ranked No. 311 on the 1996 list of the 500 fastest-growing private American companies compiled by Inc. magazine, with revenue growth of 867 percent from 1991 to 1995. **********Modem Media and True North share clients like the AT&T Corporation and the Coors Brewing Company unit of the Adolph Coors Company. Modem Media may be best known as the creator of one of the first popular sponsored Web sites, for the Zima malt beverage sold by Coors (http:// www.zima.com). **********After the deal closes, Greg Blaine, chairman and chief executive at TN Technologies in Chicago, will continue in those posts, while two Modem Media partners will take new titles at TN Technologies. **********One is G. M. O'Connell, who was recently spotted wearing a Zima T-shirt. Mr. O'Connell, 34, who founded Modem Media with Doug Ahlers, will become president and chief operating officer at TN Technologies. Mr. Ahlers, who is 36, will become president of the Relationship Technology Group at TN Technologies. **********The third partner in Modem Media, Robert Allen, 29, will become Modem's president, also a new post.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/24/busin.main_headline: New York Brokerage Is Accused of Fraud
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/24/busin.print_headline: New York Brokerage Is Accused of Fraud
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/24/busin.body_text: **********The Securities and Exchange Commission accused a New York brokerage firm yesterday of defrauding New York University and other clients by making unauthorized stock trades and refusing to execute sales orders. **********In pressing its case against A. R. Baron & Company and two of its principals  -- its chief executive, Andrew Bressman, and a trader, Roman Okin -- the S.E.C.  is seeking a temporary cease and desist order. That order would require the firm to appoint an independent compliance officer and give the S.E.C. a sworn accounting of all money paid to the company's principals since January 1995. **********The temporary restraining measure is the first of its kind for the S.E.C. According to a rule made last July, the commission's chairman, Arthur Levitt Jr., can issue an order against a brokerage firm and its officials without taking them to court. **********"This sort of restraining measure has only recently been available to us," said Mark Kreitman, a lawyer with the commission. "But we thought it was especially appropriate for this case. Based on the kind of conduct that we've seen at A. R. Baron & Company during our investigation, we're confident this kind of fraudulent activity will continue and investors may suffer losses they may never recover." **********In response to the S.E.C.'s charges issued yesterday, Mr. Bressman, Mr. Okin  and other company officials must appear before the commission next Wednesday to  argue that the restraining order not be issued. **********Lawyers for A. R. Baron, Mr. Bressman and Mr. Okin angrily denied any wrongdoing. **********"The S.E.C. has made itself the prosecutor, judge and jury in this action," said Larry Iason, the lawyer for Mr. Bressman. "We deny these allegations, and we plan to fight them vigorously. I thoroughly expect Mr. Bressman to be vindicated." **********Martin Kaplan, a lawyer for A. R. Baron, assailed the S.E.C.'s action as unprecedented. "We're going to contest the constitutionality and legality of the whole event," he said. "We're going to protest these charges. And, in the meantime, at A. R. Baron & Company, it's business as usual." **********For the last several years, the S.E.C. has been investigating whether A. R. Baron was involved in manipulating the prices of several stocks, including Health Professionals Inc. and Cypros Pharmaceutical. The S.E.C.'s current charges, which include opening unauthorized client accounts and refusing to remit, or delaying the remittance of, proceeds from stock sales, stem from the original investigation. **********"One reason we wanted to put a stop to A. R. Baron's actions is that they were doing this under heightened regulatory scrutiny," Mr. Kreitman said. "Both  the S.E.C. and the National Association of Securities Dealers were investigating the company right when they were defrauding their clients on a large scale." **********The S.E.C. asserts that a wide array of A. R. Baron's clients were defrauded. In one instance, the New York brokerage firm refused to sell $1 million of Innovir Laboratories stock that New York University had received as a gift. The  university lost money when Innovir stock declined late last year, after A. R. Baron missed an opportunity to get out at a strong profit. **********Other clients lost money on what the S.E.C. described as illegal trades. According to commission documents, Ian Barry, the secretary of Fiduciary Management Services, a Bahamas-based investment trust, was duped several times by Baron officials, including Mr. Bressman. In August 1995, Mr. Barry instructed his broker at Baron to sell $450,000 of Time Warner bonds and remit the proceeds to him. Mr. Barry later learned that his broker used the money to buy 150,000 shares of Cypros Pharmaceuticals -- a stock Baron underwrote -- without his consent. **********In addition, the S.E.C. said, Mr. Barry could not get through to any Baron officials to complain about the purchases. After five calls, Mr. Barry finally reached Mr. Bressman, who tried to persuade him to accept the deals.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/21/busin.main_headline: Business Travel;France is going on the Internet to provide information for visitors.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/21/busin.print_headline: Business Travel;France is going on the Internet to provide information for visitors.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/21/busin.body_text: **********WITH cyberized savoir-faire befitting the 1990's, France is going on the Internet next month with a complete catalogue of just about everything you need  to know about the country to make your visit as smooth as a glass of Dom Perignon. **********For Americans occasionally baffled by France's ever-changing cornucopia of fashionable bistros, "in" inns and smash-hit trade and art shows, the Internet listings and updates -- in French and English -- should be a godsend. **********We need to help the 2.5 million Americans who visit us each year -- many of them executives -- sort out what they want to see and do," said Jean-Marc Janaillac, director general of Maison de la France, the Government tourist organization that's managing the encyclopedic web site. **********At a site (http://www.paris.org/) already on the Internet, a traveler can find a lot of information about Paris, including the city's inventory of 70,000  rooms from inexpensive to luxurious. **********The broader new service -- the site is yet to be named -- will provide names, locations, pictures and prices down to the tariff for touring the chateaus of the Loire, where to stay in Cannes during the film festival, the menu at the Michelin three-star Le Crocodile in Strasbourg or what's on at an opera festival in Aix-en-Provence. Not to mention schedules and prices for trains, planes and buses. **********"We're going to put general information about France on the Internet," Mr. Janaillac said. "But also the hours when shops like Galeries Lafayette are open. Golf and ski tour packages. Cultural events like the upcoming Corot show at the  Grand Palais updated every two weeks. **********"We'll have specific data for business travelers -- for example, meeting space in hotels and resorts. And the service will be interactive. You can ask us by E-mail, 'What can I do in Paris or Provence?' and we'll give suggestions." **********That should be good news for executives who want to combine a visit to their  Paris office with a few days of sightseeing. **********Guide to Good Living **********Also now available on the Internet is the 656-page, four-color guide to Relais et Chateaux, a group of 410 independently owned hotels and restaurants in 42 countries, from the United States to London to Singapore. Most are classy, charming and unconventional, including, for example, the Schlosshotel Kronberg in Frankfurt, the former home of Queen Victoria's eldest daughter. Relais members in the United States include: Charlie Trotter's, a favorite of expense-account travelers visiting Chicago; New York's Restaurant Daniel, and Little Palm Island, an executive getaway near Key West, Fla. **********In addition to gaining access to Relais on the Internet (http://www.calvacom.fr/relais/accueil.html), travelers can order a $10 printed  guide by fax at (800) 860-4930. **********Fare Weather **********European airlines, notorious for their high ticket prices in home territory,  are following the American lead and "liberalizing" -- they don't call it deregulation. But if lowering fares within the European Union is one of the goals, progress has been pretty slow, according to a comparison of European and  United States one-way fares compiled by American Express. **********Consider these examples, based on the lowest-priced, advance-purchase fare. Flying 100 to 199 miles -- a distance in the Brussels-to-Frankfurt range -- costs $213 in Europe but only $127 in the United States. Or fly 500 to 599 miles -- London to Milan, say -- and you pay $516 there but $296 for a similar flight  here. **********This is why the train continues to beat the plane on many routes in Europe on price and, in some cases, even total time in transit between cities. **********Mickey Mouse Institute **********Isn't a course in rock climbing (great bonding), making English tea sandwiches (corporate manners) or becoming a radio disk jockey (revenge on the media) what you need as a side order on your next business trip to Orlando? Stay at the whimsical-looking Dolphin or Swan hotels near the Epcot Center, in Disney World, and you can buzz over to the just-opened Disney Institute where learning  is fun and cheap at $49 for a day visitor's package. "Students" can phone (800)  282-9282 and sign on for one of the 80 courses -- mostly two-hour sessions -- from computer animation and garden design to relationships and healthy cooking. **********It's not quite Chautauqua, the estimable cultural center near Buffalo, which  Walt Disney's chief executive, Michael D. Eisner, once visited and liked so much he wanted one of his own. The Disney Institute looks like a cross between Edward Hopper and Norman Rockwell by way of the broom-clean streets of the Magic Kingdom. But so far it's wowing the customers. One of the main box-office draws: a one-acre sports and fitness center (including arrays of Cybex machines and a full-size gym) and a modern spa. Sprinkled among the paying guests are dozens of celebrities from the choreographer Jacques d'Amboise and the heartthrob Andy  Garcia to the architect Michael Graves and the tennis impresario Peter Burwash. **********"People on vacation don't want education," said Dan Higgins, a Disney special-events specialist. "But they like discovering they're talented." At a resort, not school, as the entertainment giant sees it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/07/busin.snippet: Michael Ovitz, president of Walt Disney Co for last year, struggles to carve out his role and define his relationship with Michael Eisner, Disney's chairman; Ovitz has found that masterful but imperious management style that worked so well when he...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/07/busin.body_text: **********The setting was a private dining room at Dreamworks on the Universal lot. At the luncheon table sat two of the most formidable power brokers in Hollywood, Michael Ovitz, president of the Walt Disney Company, and David Geffen, the billionaire mogul and a founding partner at Dreamworks. **********''I heard you've been saying bad things about me,'' Mr. Ovitz began. **********''It's because I think bad things about you,'' responded Mr. Geffen, who has tangled with the former talent agent for years. **********The recent luncheon was said by one person to have quickly deteriorated into a shouting match, becoming a failed effort by Mr. Ovitz to make peace with a long-time foe, an effort that the once most powerful agent in Hollywood has mounted in his difficult, some say, painful, transition to the Walt Disney Company. **********More than one year after Mr. Ovitz abruptly quit his job as chairman of the Creative Artists Agency to take over the No. 2 job at the Walt Disney Company, the 49-year-old executive who was once as feared as he was secretive has not only made missteps and antagonized executives in and outside of Disney but is also still struggling to carve out his role and define his relationship with Michael Eisner, the chairman. **********In doing so, people close to Disney said, Mr. Ovitz has found that the masterful but imperious management style that created the aura of intimidation at Creative Artists was inappropriate at a corporate culture like that at Disney, whose merger last year with Capital Cities/ABC created one of the largest entertainment companies in the world. **********In his short time at Disney, Mr. Ovitz's aggressive style and hubris have alienated both ABC and Disney studio executives, and have produced a torrent of private and public badmouthing. Some negative speculation comes from those he angered in his agent's role and who no longer fear him. More than any other power broker in Hollywood over the years, Mr. Ovitz managed to offend some of the most powerful people in town, from Mr. Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg, a partner in Dreamworks, to Lew R. Wasserman, the former chairman of MCA, and Ray Stark, a longtime producer. **********''Mike isn't certain of the meaning of the word friendship,'' Mr. Stark said. **********Without his agent's role and power, Mr. Ovitz now finds himself in a position of courting old enemies in Hollywood to shore up his own image -- obsessively nurtured through the years -- and to protect Disney's interests with program suppliers like Dreamworks because, as Michael Wolf, a partner and head of the media department at Booz Allen & Hamilton, said, ''This is a small industry and to be an effective executive you need to have good relationships.'' **********Even critics acknowledge that it is far too early to make definitive judgments about a power broker who has made the leap from running a talent agency with an estimated $200 million in sales to serving as president of the world's 39th-largest publicly traded company, with 1996 sales of about $20 billion. **********Over the long term, Mr. Ovitz's performance will be crucial. Today, Disney is in solid financial health. Even after paying interest on debt related to its $19 billion purchase of Capital Cities/ABC, Disney will still have more than $2 billion to invest in new businesses. **********The total value of Disney's stock has risen 22 times since 1984 when Mr. Eisner took over. But that growth took place under stable management. Now, as Mr. Eisner tries to integrate ABC -- a network whose ratings have slumped severely -- his plans to continue the growth have been shadowed by turmoil. **********In recent years Mr. Eisner has suffered a serious heart attack; his No. 2,  Frank G. Wells, died in a helicopter crash; his chief financial officer, Steven Bollenbach, quit after 18 months, and Mr. Katzenberg, the longtime chairman of Disney Studios, left in a bitter fight and is in litigation over his severance package. **********''It is essential to the company that Mr. Ovitz succeeds because to go back and restructure the senior management, where there has already been so much change, would be debilitating,'' said Emanuel Gerard, a partner at Gerard Klauer Mattison, an investment firm. **********Mr. Ovitz's new role at Disney -- still not clearly defined -- is now centered on expanding Disney abroad, especially in China, where he has sought to make inroads for distributing the company's television, film and consumer products. It is a role far more limited than that of Mr. Wells, who was deeply immersed in every major labor negotiation, budgetary issue and personnel matters. **********Mr. Eisner -- in a move many saw as a mistake -- did not name Mr. Ovitz to Mr. Wells's old post of chief operating officer, denying him a power base and specific responsibilities. People close to Mr. Eisner said he did not see Mr. Ovitz as suited to the nuts and bolts demands of that position. But one top Hollywood lawyer said: ''I don't think either Eisner or Ovitz knew how tough the situation would be. Ovitz's position is very unorthodox. He's basically a troubleshooter. Eisner tells him what problems to solve.'' **********At the same time, a sense of mystery and elusiveness still surrounds Mr. Ovitz, providing an image he enjoys. Several top Sony executives as well as rival studio chiefs are amazed that despite his job at Disney, Mr. Ovitz has apparently advised Nobuyuki Idei, the president of the Sony Corporation, who is expected to appoint John Calley, a longtime producer and studio executive, to take over the troubled Sony studios. Many believe Mr. Ovitz may even be angling for the top job there. Mr. Ovitz has told friends that his dealings with Sony are related only to joint ventures with Disney. **********Mr. Eisner, in an interview, discounted any hint of dissatisfaction with Mr. Ovitz, although three people close to Disney said Mr. Eisner was not entirely pleased with Mr. Ovitz and had bluntly said so to close associates. Mr. Eisner denied this; Mr. Ovitz declined to comment. **********''From my point of view he is a talented, strong and effective executive,'' Mr. Eisner said. ''I have been at ABC, Paramount and Disney, and I am pretty good at taking the temperature from the inside. Performance is the key. In my opinion we are performing so spectacularly and it is under the management of Michael Eisner and Michael Ovitz.'' **********But so far, Mr. Ovitz has managed to irritate a number of important colleagues over and over. **********For example, at a dinner at Mr. Ovitz's home, a top Disney business executive with overseas experience began talking to a film producer whose movie was opening in Europe. The business executive offered to assist the producer. According to one source, the Disney executive received a call at 8 the next morning from Mr. Ovitz assailing him for talking to the producer. **********''I have those relationships, you don't,'' Mr. Ovitz said. **********The executive angrily replied, ''It's good for our business.'' He added, ''Don't invite me to your house anymore because if you have interesting people I will talk to them.'' Mr. Ovitz has said he did not recall the incident. **********Seeming Unwillingness To Learn the Business **********Mr. Ovitz has also angered some because of his seeming unwillingness to learn how Disney's complex businesses work. A former senior executive at Disney recalled that Mr. Eisner had grown so uneasy about Mr. Ovitz's lack of knowledge that at one point he suggested the former agent meet regularly with Mr. Bollenbach, then Disney's highly respected chief financial officer. **********Mr. Ovitz and Mr. Bollenbach planned to hold a weekly meeting on Monday at 2 P.M. But each Monday, the executive said, Mr. Ovitz canceled the meeting at the last minute, reportedly angering Mr. Bollenbach. Mr. Ovitz has told friends that such criticism is unfair and that he met frequently with Mr. Bollenbach and other top executives at Disney. **********In his early months at Disney, Mr. Ovitz reportedly also antagonized Dennis Hightower, then chairman of Walt Disney Television and Telecommunications. Disney insiders believe that Mr. Ovitz's style may have contributed to both Mr. Bollenbach's and Mr. Hightower's departures from  the company this year. Both declined to comment. **********One senior Disney executive said Mr. Ovitz avoided and appeared to snub the managers, a sharp contrast to Mr. Wells, who knew executives at every level. Mr. Ovitz's aides said that his travels, two weeks out of every month, have limited his meetings at Disney's Burbank headquarters. **********Mr. Bollenbach, who is now chairman of the Hilton Corporation, when asked recently if Mr. Eisner would replace Mr. Ovitz, replied: ''Michael thinks he can fix everything. He thinks he can make Ovitz work out.'' **********Gordon Crawford, senior vice president of the Capital Research Group, whose fund owns about 3 percent of Disney, dismissed the speculation about Mr. Ovitz as ''Hollywood stuff.'' He said, ''People never have a nice word to say about anybody.'' **********Mr. Crawford said of Mr. Ovitz:  ''He has been very perceptive over the years about the growing importance of vertical integration. He has handled advertising, mergers and acquisitions. He understood the importance of the foreign markets.'' **********By all accounts, though, Mr. Ovitz sought to move too rapidly -- and has had to back off -- at both the studio and the network. **********Murky Episode With NBC **********One reason was a murky and, for Disney, embarrassing episode in which NBC executives accused Mr. Ovitz of making innuendoes of sexual harassment to free a former NBC executive, Jamie Tarses, from her contract at NBC so that ABC could hire her. The turmoil resulted in John F. Welch Jr., the chairman of NBC's parent company, General Electric, writing an angry letter to Mr. Eisner. (Mr. Ovitz denies that he fanned the rumors, and Ms. Tarses has said she never made accusations of sexual harassment.) **********Robert A. Iger, president of Capital Cities/ABC, was described by people at ABC as treading carefully with Mr. Ovitz. ''There is no sense of overt hostility,'' one senior ABC executive said. But the executive said Mr. Iger had what Mr. Ovitz wanted: a specific area of responsibility. ''I feel sorry for him,'' the executive said. ''How do you step in and earn a role for yourself? How do you make yourself valuable?'' Mr. Ovitz has acknowledged to friends that since Ms. Tarses has moved in, he has scaled back his involvement. **********(In fact, some Disney insiders believe that the reserved and well liked Mr. Iger, who has developed a rapport with Mr. Eisner, may one day himself ascend to the presidency.) **********Mr. Ovitz has also appeared to back off from direct involvement in the movie business after making deals with two former clients, Sean Connery and Martin Scorsese, to set up offices at Disney. Although Joe Roth, chairman of Walt Disney Studios, was reportedly less than comfortable about Mr. Ovitz's involvement, the two men have developed a relatively easy rapport. **********Mr. Ovitz has also been second- guessed elsewhere. For example, he was recently asked to approve a marketing plan for Disney's theme parks. But several days later, Mr. Eisner called the marketing executives back into his own office to re-review the plan and approve it himself. Mr. Ovitz has said privately that the move was not a slap against him but that their schedules necessitated two meetings. **********Even Spielberg Is Put Off **********Last year Mr. Ovitz even stirred the anger of Steven Spielberg, one of his top clients as an agent, as well as Edgar Bronfman Jr., the president of Seagram. Mr. Bronfman had offered Mr. Ovitz the job of running MCA, but the deal fell apart over Mr. Ovitz's demand for more money. Mr. Bronfman then struck a deal to distribute films by Dreamworks, partly owned by Mr. Spielberg, that allowed Mr. Spielberg to keep his animation division. **********After the deal was made, Mr. Ovitz called Mr. Bronfman and bluntly questioned the wisdom of giving up animation, Mr. Bronfman recalled. It was especially surprising because Mr. Ovitz had served as Mr. Spielberg's agent. Then Mr. Ovitz turned around and called Mr. Geffen and told him that he had congratulated Mr. Bronfman on the deal. When Mr. Spielberg, Mr. Geffen and Mr. Bronfman compared notes, all were angered at what they viewed as Mr. Ovitz's efforts to create suspicions about the arrangement. **********In continuing his effort to smooth relationships, Mr. Ovitz also met recently with Don Ohlmeyer, president of NBC, West Coast, who had been so furious at Mr. Ovitz over the sexual harassment issue and Ms. Tarses that he was quoted in Time as calling the Disney president ''the Antichrist.'' **********The meeting was held in Mr. Ohlmeyer's home and was not as testy as the luncheon with Mr. Geffen. But Mr. Ohlmeyer turned down Mr. Ovitz's request for a follow-up lunch at a restaurant. One person close to Mr. Ohlmeyer said he did not want to be seen with Mr. Ovitz or play any role in the Disney president's effort to revive his image.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/04/busin.body_text: **********The Union Carbide Corporation of Danbury, Conn., and Petronas, Malaysia's state-owned oil company, said yesterday that they would form a joint venture to  build a Malaysian petrochemical complex to supply Southeast Asia, the world's fastest-growing market for petrochemicals. The companies did not say how much the project would cost. The joint venture is expected to be held equally by the  two partners. The partners plan to build an ethylene and propylene plant that will make 600,000 metric tons a year. A second plant will be built to make at least 500,000 metric tons a year of ethylene glycol, an ingredient used in polyester fibers and automotive antifreeze.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/29/world.main_headline: In Burundi's Capital, Waterfront Strollers Praise Coup
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/29/world.print_headline: In Burundi's Capital, Waterfront Strollers Praise Coup
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/29/world.body_text: **********I think the coup is very good, because it will mean peace," said Janine, who was admiring the sunset from a stone breakwater that stretches into Lake Tanganyika. "Before, there were too many massacres." **********Janine, who refused to give his last name, was speaking of the coup on Tuesday by Maj. Pierre Buyoya, a Tutsi, ousting the Hutu former President, another chapter in the unceasing ethnic conflict here. Janine was one of hundreds of fashionably dressed young Tutsi strolling the beach in Bujumbura, Burundi's capital, drinking beer and flirting. **********The beach stretches from a yacht club patronized mostly by whites to the cranes of an active port, and two things about the scene stood out. First, no one had even a toe in the water, from which, despite the urban setting, hippos come out at night to feed. And the strollers seemed acutely aware that they had  one hour left to enjoy themselves before the soldiers posted every few hundred yards would sweep the street, giving anyone they caught out after the 7 P.M. curfew a night in jail and a fine of about $16. **********Janine's girlfriend, who refused to give even her first name, confirmed with  a nod that she was pleased with the coup, but refused to elaborate, saying: "I don't want to talk about politics. It's Sunday, and I want to be happy. Politics here are very sad." **********Asked if he thought a Hutu would be just as pleased, Alexis, a friend of theirs, said: "Of course. There were Hutus at the rally yesterday to celebrate it. The former President was no good. He was in the control of Hutu robbers. He  said the army did the killings. He said the army was monoethnic. It is not -- there are 15 percent Hutu in the army." **********It seemed a telling statistic -- and a telling justification -- in a country  that is 85 percent Hutu. **********Across town, living in a battered tin refugee camp near a missionary's church, are what may be the last 5,000 Hutu in the capital. They are the last remaining residents from the nearby Kamenge neighborhood. Aid workers say the area was brutally emptied this year by the army and Tutsi militias, who killed dozens of women and children while rooting out "Hutu extremists." **********In a crowd that had gathered to watch four white journalists detained under a tree for half an hour for entering a public market without police permission, only one man said he was satisfied with the new Government. Others in the crowd  pushed and swatted him, shutting him up. **********"In their democracy, they want to wipe us out so they can win in the next elections," said Berthe Barampanirama, 52. **********Many Burundians say the groundwork for this week's coup was laid three years  ago, when the country's first democratic elections were held. Hutu parties easily won the presidency. But Tutsi soldiers, angry at being governed by a Hutu, assaulted the presidential palace four months later and killed President Melchior Ndadaye. The weak Hutu-Tutsi coalition Governments that followed were finally ended by Major Buyoya's coup on Thursday. The Tutsi-dominated army appointed him as President. **********Another member of the crowd said that no Hutu were joining the Cabinet Major  Buyoya is trying to form because that would lend legitimacy to "the putsch," as  the Hutu parties refer to the takeover. **********Asked about that later at a news conference with foreign reporters, Major Buyoya said: "That's not true. Bujumbura is a city of rumors. Don't listen to them." **********A senior diplomat here commented later: "Oh, he'll find some, sure. But if they're from his own party, they don't count. Will he find them from the opposition? We'll see. Some will join for sure, out of opportunity. This is a poor country." **********At the news conference, Major Buyoya said he would reassure nervous Hutu by restoring discipline to the military, which he admitted had committed "misbehaviors," though he said they were exaggerated by Hutu propagandists. **********Prodded over whether he would offer Hutu refugees near the border with Rwanda "a cast-iron guarantee that they won't be harassed or deported," Major Buyoya sternly answered "yes" and pointed to the next questioner. **********-------------------- **********Neighbors Condemn Coup **********KAMPALA, Uganda, July 28 (Reuters) -- Two of Burundi's neighbors today condemned last week's coup but stopped short of calling for the restoration of the ousted  President. President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda and Benjamin Mkapa of Tanzania avoided a more detailed response, however, saying in a statement that the issue would be addressed on Wednesday at a summit meeting of African countries in Arusha, Tanzania. The presidents met Saturday night and Sunday morning for talks with Julius Nyerere, a former President of Tanzania, who has been leading an effort by the Organization of African Unity to end the crisis in Burundi.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/13/busin.main_headline: If Firm Lied, It Faces Penalties in America : Daimler's Puritan Problem
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/13/busin.print_headline: If Firm Lied, It Faces Penalties in America : Daimler's Puritan Problem
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/13/busin.body_text: **********When he was chairman of Daimler-Benz AG, Edzard Reuter had a handy excuse to avoid questions he did not like. **********The executive would duck questions by quipping that federal agents would swiftly arrest him the next time he set foot in the United States for breach of the strict disclosure rules of the country's securities laws. **********The long arm of U.S. law might indeed reach across the Atlantic if allegations under investigation by German prosecutors establish that Mr. Reuter and other Daimler executives willfully misled shareholders at last year's annual meeting. **********The case remains under investigation in Germany and Daimler steadfastly has denied that Mr. Reuter and other executives knew the company was careening toward a record loss and omission of the dividend when he told shareholders in May last year to expect a profit and payout. **********The investigation widened this week to include Manfred Gentz, the company's soft-spoken chief financial officer. Mr. Gentz has conceded he saw a document that forecast a 1995 loss before Mr. Reuter appeared at the annual meeting. **********As the first German company to get a listing on the New York Stock Exchange, Daimler has submitted itself since 1993 to the stringent U.S. exchange rules, which clash with Germany's more opaque regulations. **********The motor-vehicle and aerospace conglomerate has also been covered by the same anti-fraud provisions of the U.S. Securities Exchange Act, including Article 10b-5, which makes it "unlawful" to issue "any untrue statement" to investors. The article has been interpreted to apply to false statements in press releases, annual reports, filings or shareholder meetings. **********Under its usual practice, the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, the investor watchdog agency, would review the case itself and not rely solely on findings by German authorities. **********SEC officials refused to comment on the Daimler case. **********After making unprecedented efforts to lure U.S. investors and capital, a negative finding and penalty by U.S. officials would compound the embarrassment at a time when Daimler has been divesting entire divisions to move beyond its extravagant, acquisition-hungry past. **********Violation of the SEC's anti-fraud statute carries a penalty as high as $500,000 for companies and $100,000 for individuals. For the SEC, foreign companies get the same legal treatment as domestic companies. **********In Germany, charges under investigation by Stuttgart prosecutors carry a maximum penalty of three years in prison or a fine set by the court according to the person's income. **********According to past SEC practice, one thing that very likely will never happen would be for Daimler to lose its coveted listing on the Big Board, because such a move would punish current shareholders.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/12/busin.print_headline: Bonds Drop Sharply; Yield Up to 6.62%
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/12/busin.body_text: **********The prices of Treasury securities dropped sharply yesterday amid concern that the economy was not slowing fast enough and that interest rates could rise if foreign investors slow their buying. And traders kept in the backs of their minds comments last week by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, in which he questioned the high valuation of the stock market. **********The 30-year bond fell 1 15/32, to 98 13/32, and the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.62 percent from 6.49 on Tuesday. **********For bond investors, the day's losses amounted to about $14.70 for $1,000 invested. **********Traders said the market's weakness nearly matched that of last Thursday, when the dollar tumbled, eroding the attractiveness of bonds to foreign investors. One day later, Mr. Greenspan warned that the stock market might be showing ''irrational exuberance,'' further alarming bond traders, who feared that his comments might have been a signal of an increase in interest rates. **********The volume of issues traded yesterday nearly matched that of Thursday and Friday. Yesterday was the fifth day in this quarter that volume has exceeded $100 billion, considered a benchmark of heavy trading. **********Treasuries extended overseas losses in bond trading, even after a report showing that the November Producer Price Index was tame, up only four-tenths of a percent, with the core rate, excluding the volatile food and energy prices, up one-tenth of a percent. Economists had expected gains of three-tenths of a percent and two-tenths of a percent, respectively. **********Traders said that after the bond market's decline on Tuesday, United States Treasury securities fell in London and Tokyo on fears that the recent increase in purchases by large Japanese investors could slow. The fear may have been generated by an article in The Wall Street Journal that quoted Robert Hormats, the vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, as saying that Japanese buying would slow. **********Also pressuring bonds was the continued heavy issuance of corporate debt, as investors sold Treasury securities in favor of corporate paper. **********Chase Manhattan yesterday priced $997 million of asset-backed securities. These securities, rated triple-A and backed by autoloans, were offered in various classes and various average lives. A security with an average life of 0.35 of a year was priced to yield 5.489 percent, or seven-hundredths of a percentage point under the London interbank offered rate, while a security with an average life of 3.52 years was priced to yield 6.270 percent, or about 30-hundredths more than than the 5 7/8 percent Treasury note of 2000. **********Thomas F. Carpenter, chief economist and managing director at ASB Capital Management in Washington, said he thought that beyond any new information learned by the market yesterday, the primary reason for the drop was continued unease about Mr. Greenspan's comments. He said traders felt ''fear of more Federal Reserve officials talking out loud, and the thought that Greenspan & Company may be talking to the Japanese, German, and French central banks suggesting that they also talk tough to their markets in order to cool off investors.'' **********Nonetheless, some important data favor the bond market, Mr. Carpenter said. Iraqi oil is close to reaching the market again, which has had the effect of dropping oil prices about $2 a barrel, he said, implying significantly lower inflation in early 1997. **********The Treasury announced the size of next week's auction of notes, which will take place after the Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making panel of the Federal Reserve, meets on Tuesday. The Government plans to sell $18.25 billion of two-year notes on Wednesday and $12.5 billion of five-year notes on Thursday. **********In when-issued trading late yesterday, the two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.81 percent and the five-year at a price to yield 6.15 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/18/busin.main_headline: MUTUAL FUNDS;When the Manager Is a Hard Act to Follow
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/18/busin.print_headline: MUTUAL FUNDS;When the Manager Is a Hard Act to Follow
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/18/busin.body_text: **********WHEN a fund loses a star manager, chaos does not have to reign. Just look at  the smooth transition this year when John Neff passed the baton of the Vanguard  Windsor fund to his longtime co-manager. **********Not so at the Govett Smaller Companies fund, whose shareholders are experiencing whiplash after Garrett Van Wagoner left at the end of last year to strike out on his own. **********The Govett fund was among the best performers last year. In January, though, it was the absolute worst mutual fund, with a loss of 9.5 percent. Meanwhile, the spanking new Van Wagoner Emerging Growth fund trounced the market averages,  with a gain of 13.1 percent. **********Govett "is the type of fund where the star manager is key," said Don Phillips, president of Morningstar, the fund research company in Chicago, referring to Mr. Van Wagoner's eclectic investing style. **********The management changeover is one of the most turbulent in a while. In part, it is a story of unfortunate timing in a gyrating stock market. But it also raises questions about whether the fund management kept shareholders' best interests in mind and whether too much emphasis has been placed on short-term returns and big names, both of which can mean big money. **********Funds changing hands can suffer from a combination of problems: a loss of money as shareholders follow the old manager and high transaction costs as the replacement decides to reposition the portfolio. The route can be even bumpier when, as with Govett, the departing manager adheres to a quirky stock-picking style that's not likely to be duplicated. **********Mr. Van Wagoner, 40, is a gutsy manager who frenetically trades rapidly growing companies. Under his tutelage, Govett Smaller Companies had an average annualized return of 51.08 percent for the three years ended 1995, according to  Morningstar. Its return last year, of 69 percent, put it in second place among all small-company funds tracked by Morningstar. Because of differences in the way returns are calculated, it was first in the rankings produced by Lipper Analytical Services, Summit, N.J. **********Mr. Van Wagoner achieved that impressive performance in large measure by buying and flipping high-risk technology stocks that are thinly traded. **********As might be expected when a prominent manager departs, many investors redeemed their shares when Mr. Van Wagoner left at year-end. The fund shrank, because of redemptions and market losses, to $421 million in assets at the end of January from $519 million a month earlier. **********Jeffrey M. Bernstein, who had been an assistant portfolio manager on the small- and mid-cap team at Bankers Trust, found himself in an awkward position as Govett's new manager. Many of the portfolio's investments were thinly traded, and he needed to sell some of them to cash out fleeing shareholders and  to settle trades. **********"To sell holdings in an orderly fashion while rapidly deploying cash, the fund was forced to carry a higher-than-ordinary cash balance," Mr. Bernstein said. The fund's cash level reached 13 percent in mid-January -- just when the technology sector was recovering from a nasty decline earlier that month. **********In effect, Mr. Bernstein was hurt coming and going. Heavy on technology stocks, he was forced to sell in a declining market. And when the market rebounded, he was out of the technology stocks. "I really wanted to buy, but I had to sell," he said. "It was brutal and painful to watch." **********Transaction costs hurt the fund even more. Mr. Bernstein reshuffled the fund's holdings, reducing the technology stake to 37 percent from 70 percent before he took over. Health care and biotech stocks, which accounted for just 4  or 5 percent of the fund when he stepped in, rose to 47 percent. **********"In hindsight, I should have held onto the networking stocks, which bounced back," Mr. Bernstein said. "But I didn't want to get so far into the hole so early and ruin the prospects for the fund for the entire year." **********Sitting in the catbird seat was Mr. Van Wagoner. His new fund was mostly cash when the tech stocks began their decline in early January. As a result, he picked up many of his favorites at rock-bottom prices. So Van Wagoner Emerging Growth was able to show double-digit returns for the month while its peers barely broke even. **********Mr. Bernstein, who joined Mr. Van Wagoner at the end of November to begin the transition, said that Mr. Van Wagoner pushed hard in December in a quest for a top year-end ranking. Michael J. Mayer, chairman of Berkley Capital Management,  adviser to the fund, said that Mr. Van Wagoner started December not in the lead  position but did a great job of pulling ahead of his competitors by making a big bet on technology stocks. **********To score big gains, the fund could not afford to leave a lot of money in cash. By the time Mr. Van Wagoner left, the fund had 8 percent of its assets in  cash. He considered that sufficient and said he would have liked to have been fully invested but could not -- given the situation. **********Still, the fund bled $39 million in the first three weeks of January, nearly  draining the $42 million cushion at the first of the year. The 8 percent cash reserve had to be replenished and reinforced, Mr. Bernstein said. "It looks like enough, but you can't let it drop to zero, especially when redemptions are  increasing," he said. **********Mr. Mayer did not find fault with either manager. Mr. Van Wagoner made all the right moves until the end of the year, Mr. Mayer said, and "the tech downturn caught everyone by surprise." **********AS the biggest fund companies have learned, giving shareholders plenty of time to get used to a transition can help. The fund can use that time to reassure shareholders, and at the least, money may leave gradually rather than suddenly. Vanguard, for example, announced that Mr. Neff's co-manager would replace him one full year before it actually happened. **********Probably the closest thing to the Govett turmoil in recent days was the sudden departure last summer of John Wallace from Oppenheimer Main Street Income and Growth. Like Mr. Van Wagoner, Mr. Wallace is a quirky manager who sets his own course. **********His current fund, Robertson Stephens Growth and Income, has gained almost 20  percent since its July 12 inception, beating its group by four percentage points, according to Morningstar. In the period, the Oppenheimer fund rose just 15.9 percent, about average. **********Given the changes at Govett, what's a shareholder to do now? Mr. Phillips of  Morningstar recommends switching to Mr. Van Wagoner's new fund. **********"The new fund is smaller and better suited for Garrett Van Wagoner's aggressive style," Mr. Phillips said. "Then there's the incentive of his name on the fund and the fact that he's a known quantity." **********Mr. Van Wagoner's fund is sold without a sales charge, while the Govett fund  carries an upfront charge of 4.95 percent. Along with Emerging Growth, which he  said had $20 million in assets and is thus too small to appear in most fund listings, Mr. Van Wagoner manages two other funds from his new office in San Francisco (800 228-2121): Microcap with $6 million and Midcap with $5 million. **********For now, at least, his old fund and his new emerging growth fund have some striking similarities. Mr. Van Wagoner has 45 percent in health care, while Mr.  Bernstein has 47 percent in health care and biotech. Mr. Van Wagoner said he was 25 percent in technology, while his successor is 37 percent in technology. **********"I'm confident about the health care bet," Mr. Bernstein said. "The thing now is to get some zip back in the fund. I'm working hard to not be so sensitive to  how the fund does every day because the markets are so unsettled and you have to position yourself for the year." **********The fund has stabilized since mid-January in terms of outflows, Mr. Bernstein added. **********Would the fund's adviser do anything differently if it had it to do over again? No, Mr. Mayer said. "Jeff was fully apprised of the portfolio by the time Garrett left," he said. "It should have been enough time to transition the portfolio."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/20/busin.body_text: **********The Sony Corporation's president, Nobuyuki Idei, said today that a newly completed overhaul of its troubled entertainment division  could eventually lead to a public stock sale in the unit. **********Responding to a question at a news briefing here, Mr. Idei said that the company had no plans to sell Sony Pictures Entertainment, the unit which includes the Columbia and Tristar studios, but that it would consider a public offering of Sony's entertainment assets, including its music division. **********''I don't deny our intention to make the company public, but I can't tell you when it will be,'' Mr. Idei said. Sony Pictures Entertainment ''is and will be a very important part of our business,'' he added. **********Mr. Idei, 58, who took over Sony 18 months ago, and whose background was in the company's consumer-products marketing, made his comments in a conference room across the street from Sony Studios in Culver City in West Los Angeles. Mr. Idei, who smiled periodically but was generally stern and somewhat terse, brushed aside questions about the profligate spending by the company's American executives that has marked Sony's troubled voyage into Hollywood. **********He said his decision earlier this year to appoint John Calley, a respected film studio executive, to run Sony's entertainment division was the prime example of what he had learned from the company's sour experience in Hollywood. ''I have learned a lot,'' Mr. Idei said. ''I've picked John Calley.'' **********Mr. Idei confirmed a report in Daily Variety today that Sony had retained the investment bank CS First Boston as an adviser on future strategy. But he strongly denied any intention to sell any Sony divisions and said that the bank had been retained to strengthen Sony's assets before any public offering. **********''To enhance our business we need to have advice from outsiders,'' Mr. Idei said. ''Sony is a $50 billion company. It's natural to have a relationship with investment banks.'' **********Mr. Idei was flanked by his new team at the studio: Mr. Calley, 66, who was named president and chief operating officer of Sony Pictures Entertainment; Masayuki  Nozoe, 47, a Sony marketing and electronics expert and the first Japanese executive Sony has placed in a top position inside the studio; Jeff Sagansky, a former television executive who was an executive vice president at Sony's United States operations and is now co-president at the entertainment division, and Bob Wynne, executive vice president of Sony Pictures Entertainment, who oversees legal affairs. **********Mr. Calley, the former president of United Artists and a top executive at Warner Brothers in the 1970's, said that the entertainment division's problems had been exaggerated and that other studios were also mismanaged. **********''If you scan every major studio in our town there'll be anecdotal material to curl your hair,'' he said. ''The perceptual negativity of this place was misplaced. There are elements to this studio that are fantastic.'' **********But then, in a tacit acknowledgment that Sony's studios were in a mess, he said, ''I really want to get it up and running in a way that management will feel comfortable.'' **********Sony's journey into the movie business has left a trail of financial wreckage for the Japanese electronics giant. Since 1989, when it purchased Columbia Studios and later Tristar, Sony has spent at least $7 billion, perhaps $8 billion, on its Hollywood studio operations. Two years ago Sony absorbed a staggering $3.2 billion write-off because of its failures in Hollywood. Many of Sony's top executives in the United States -- including Michael P. Schulhof, the head of Sony's American operations -- have since been ousted but with huge severance packages of as much as $15 million to $20 million. **********Sony officials acknowledge that the company went wrong from the outset with its choice of managers -- a pair of high-flying producers, Jon Peters and Peter Guber, who were chosen to run the company on the advice of Walter Yetnikoff, a music executive just out of drug and alcohol rehabilitation. The Peters-Guber team not only spent lavishly on overhead -- which ran $50 million to $75 million more than any other competitor -- but also hired friends such as Mark Canton, a former Warner Brothers executive, to oversee the studio; ousted top officials, and developed a weak slate of films that included some big-budget disasters. Mr. Guber himself walked off with a rich production deal at the studio. **********Certainly Columbia and Tristar have had some successes, including ''A League of Their Own,'' ''Sleepless in Seattle,'' ''Groundhog Day,'' ''Sense and Sensibility,'' ''Philadelphia'' and ''Jumanji.'' Notably, virtually all the top executives who nurtured these films have either been dismissed or quit. The company's high-profile disasters include ''Last Action Hero,'' ''I'll Do Anything,'' ''Mary Reilly,'' ''Geronimo,'' ''Money Train'' and, most recently, ''The Fan,'' ''The Cable Guy'' and ''Multiplicity.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/14/busin.body_text: **********No one has as yet made a profit marrying multiplayer games to Prince Internet or built a business model with which to make money happily ever after. **********''There is no evidence of any single model working,'' said Steven L. Eskenazi, a new media analyst for Alex. Brown & Sons. ''But over time there will be.'' **********The dozens of businesses trying to profit from Internet games must meet their players' expectations while accepting -- or overcoming -- the restictions of slow modems and connections littered with E-mail. **********Racing in the fast lane are companies like Total Entertainment Network and Mpath Interactive. These ''channels'' deliver games with complex video components by reserving a line on the Internet for game commands. The result is that lag times between, say, the moment a shot is fired and when the opponent perceives the blow are short enough to play such ''twitch games.'' **********Moving with the flow of traffic is America Online. For AOL, games are another way to keep its broad audience on-line a little longer. But the games share the same network space as a piece of electronic mail, and the lag times restrict the type of games possible. **********'It makes a lot more sense in the short term to invest in the $(game$) software rather than trying to change the medium,'' said Lawrence Schick, general manager of AOL Games. **********With Jupiter Communications estimating that people will pump $1.6 billion into on-line games by the year 2000, the only model that might not make sense is avoiding the Internet altogether. Here are some game strategies.   KRIS GOODFELLOW

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/25/busin.snippet: Law firms taking on new partners are increasingly focusing on applicant's ability to bring in 'portable billings', that is clients who will follow him or her to new firm; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/25/busin.main_headline: Firms Look for Lawyers Who Arrive With Clients
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/25/busin.print_headline: Firms Look for Lawyers Who Arrive With Clients
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/25/busin.body_text: **********IN 1993, eight years out of law school, Douglas Skalka began to enjoy the fruits of his hard work. **********A recently minted partner in the Greenwich, Conn., office of Whitman & Ransom, Mr. Skalka was given an enviable option when his firm, which is based in New York, merged with another New York legal giant, Breed, Abbott & Morgan. He had to choose the New York or Connecticut office, and he chose Greenwich. **********Two years later, though, the partners voted to dissolve the Greenwich office. ''I went from having to make a choice to not being wanted by either office,'' Mr. Skalka said. To top it off, his wife, Susan, had recently stopped working as a marketing representative at I.B.M. to care for their infant twin daughters. **********After polishing his resume, he began a job search, but one question kept popping up: How much business -- or, as lawyers put it, ''portable billings'' -- could he bring with him? **********Mr. Skalka's reply: ''Not much.'' **********His predicament has become common in the last decade or so. Law firms once assigned the same salaries to partners at the same level, but they eliminated this lockstep compensation in the late 1970's, intending to spur new business, shed deadwood, respond to client pressures on fees and increase revenues. **********But this new order widened the gap between partners who generated much business and those who drew little, and this in turn made firms less stable. Partners with significant business became the equivalent of free agents in sports. Switching firms, once rare, became commonplace, and departments and offices sometimes moved en masse. **********''The legal marketplace became a frictionless plane with few bonds holding anybody, anywhere,'' said Joel F. Henning, a consultant at Hildebrandt Inc. in Somerville, N.J. **********Mr. Skalka was not among those who could switch easily. Though he billed a healthy 1,900 to 2,000 hours a year and was responsible for several high-profile bankruptcy cases, he worked mostly for other partners or for clients that had a long relationship with the firm. Thus he received no credit for originating business and had little possibility of taking clients with him. **********''Anybody my age and 10 years out probably was more involved in carrying someone else's bags and developing their legal rather than business-getting skills,'' Mr. Skalka, who is 36, said. ''Most firms I interviewed weren't willing to take a chance with someone who had the potential to develop business. They wanted to see numbers.'' **********After a four-month search, the New Haven firm of Neubert, Pepe & Monteith offered him a job. ''Although a large firm might have viewed his contacts as insignificant, we didn't,'' said Greg Pepe of the three-year-old, three-partner firm. ''They dovetailed nicely with our transactions and litigation practices. Doug estimated he might generate $350,000, but did $500,000.'' **********As many partners change firms, client loyalty often shifts to individual lawyers. When Bruce Meckler left Pope & John Ltd. in Chicago to form Bates Meckler Bulger & Tilson in February 1994, he took along clients like Tri-City Brokerage Inc., a commercial wholesale insurer in San Francisco. **********''Our relationship with Pope & John primarily was Bruce,'' said Dan Real, a Tri-City executive vice president. ''We had confidence in him. We also had spent time educating him and his lawyers about our practices, which isn't easy to transfer.'' **********Because of this kind of loyalty, firms have sought partners from other firms, or ''lateral'' partners, who could bring immediate business and keep their other lawyers busy, particularly as legal work slowed in the late 1980's with the recession, the real estate crash and companies taking work in-house. ''Many firms considered lateral partners the white knights who would save them,'' said David Maister, a consultant in Boston. **********Today, lawyers with significant billings are more desirable than ever. The New York firm of Morrison Cohen Singer & Weinstein eagerly hired Larry Rodman to obtain $750,000 to $1 million in securities and real estate work that he offered after practicing at Teitlebaum, Hiller, Rodman, Paden & Hibsher, also in New York. **********The same climate has, with few exceptions, made switching tougher for partners without business. And the billings threshold that is needed to change firms is soaring. ''The price of admission has gone up,'' said Tom Clay, a consultant at Altman, Weil & Pensa in Newtown Square, Pa. **********While many firms and recruiters are reluctant to cite figures, $500,000 to $750,000 in portable billings for a midsize firm (50 to 100 lawyers) and $1 million to $1.5 million for a larger firm are in the ball park, said Laura Hagen, a recruiter at the Chicago office of Major, Hagen & Africa, a legal search firm. **********The billings are linked to a lawyer's desired income. For example, if the lawyer's target income is $500,000 or more, the partner will have to have a couple of million dollars in billings, said Lynn Mestel, a New York recruiter. **********Still, a single magic number will not provide an automatic open-sesame. Firms are putting newly hired lawyers under more intense scrutiny, after being burned by some firm-switchers' overly optimistic assessments and by the high cost to service certain clients. **********''Many partners don't deliberately misrepresent what they have, but often it's based on prior years and they can't know what will follow,'' said Marty Fay Africa, a recruiter with Major, Hagen & Africa's San Francisco office. **********Many firms are structuring new partners' earnings based on incentives akin to deals for sports stars. ''We may set a lower base and if the person brings in the business, they get a bonus,'' said Lee Miller, managing partner of Chicago's Rudnick & Wolfe. **********All this is causing ripples at law firms, prompting partners to guard their clients or share work only with associates. **********''At my former firm, there were some jealous partners who didn't want you to phone their clients when you worked on a matter,'' said Mike Mueller, who switched to Much Shelist Freed Denenberg Ament Bell & Rubenstein in Chicago from the larger firm of Keck, Mahin & Cate. ''There were also ones who, when you achieved a good result, they made the congratulatory call.'' At the associate level, getting business has become another factor in whether a person becomes a partner. **********So what happens to law partners without clients? ''They can stay where they are and hope they get work from colleagues, though their situation is precarious because of younger lawyers who bill at lower rates,'' Ms. Hagen said. **********''Or, they may have to alter their goals,'' said John Challenger of Challenger, Gray & Christmas, an outplacement firm. ''We can place people, but it may not be at a comparable job.'' **********Some are lucky, as one securities partner, Mike Gamsky, was when he was hired by Much Shelist a year ago. Though he wasn't thinking of leaving his firm, Chapman & Cutler in Chicago, Mr. Gamsky listened when a headhunter called. ''It was a rare chance to move without business because the firm had the work,'' he said. **********Mr. Henning offers this caveat to managing partners: ''He who lives by the sword dies by the sword. The partner who will come to your firm for an extra $25,000 will leave your firm for another $25,000 to $30,000.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/07/world.snippet: Kashmir will hold election beginning on Sept 7 in what India hopes will be major step toward ending Pakistani-backed Muslim insurgency there; election will be held over four days; map; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/07/world.main_headline: India Counts on Vote to Blunt Kashmir Insurgency
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/07/world.print_headline: India Counts on Vote to Blunt Kashmir Insurgency
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/07/world.body_text: **********From his mansion on a hillside overlooking a lake famed for its beauty, the man who has overseen the largest Indian military operation in the 25 years since the last of India's three wars with Pakistan is preparing for what he believes will be a decisive step toward ending the Pakistani-backed Muslim insurgency here. **********This time, Krishna Rao, the Governor of the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir, is not poring over maps of  guerrilla infiltration routes from Pakistan. Instead, the 72-year-old retired general is preparing for an election, confident that five million Muslim Kashmiris under Indian rule will vote eagerly for the first elected administration since New Delhi assumed direct control of the state's affairs in 1990. **********The election is to be held over four days beginning on Sept. 7, with results in early October. **********''I have been telling you for a long time that I came here to establish peace and democracy, and I think I am now on the verge of accomplishing it,'' Mr. Rao said in an interview. **********In the Governor's mansion, a former maharajah's palace far removed from the crowded Srinagar markets and remote villages where the guerrillas strike, it is possible, for a moment, to believe that peace might not be so far off in Kashmir, where at least 30,000 people have been killed in a conflict that began six years ago. **********In addition to the killing, the war has further embittered relations between India and Pakistan, and prompted fears of a new war between the two countries, this time with the added danger that both nations have the the ability to build nuclear weapons. **********Since the partition of the subcontinent in 1947, Kashmir has been divided, with India holding about 55 percent of the old state of Kashmir, Pakistan about 30 percent, and China, after its war with India in 1962, the rest. **********Both India and Pakistan claim sovereignty over all of Kashmir, dismissing the claims of many Kashmiris, including some of the most powerful guerrilla groups, that their distinct history entitles them to independence. **********While India hopes that the election will blunt the guerrillas' appeal, there are many here who say New Delhi is chasing an illusion. **********In this view, advanced by the guerrilla leaders, the election is a ploy to install a government of ''loyal'' Muslims pliable to New Delhi's will. Because the political parties that represent the divided guerrilla movement are boycotting the election, critics say the voting, especially if it is rigged like many past elections here, may be the prelude to a stepped-up conflict. **********''We've had elections before, and the Kashmir problem was never addressed, never resolved,'' said Abdul Gani Lone, a leader of the All-Party Hurriyat Conference, an umbrella group that includes most of the guerrilla factions. ''We are interested, deeply interested, in a permanent settlement of the dispute in Jammu and Kashmir, but an election under these circumstances will not help.'' **********Still, some factors appear to be working in New Delhi's favor. Among them is a shift in American policy that has been interpreted in India as a signal that Washington now accepts that the Indian-ruled part of Kashmir is, in effect, irrevocably part of India. For years, Washington has been ambivalent, calling Kashmir a disputed territory and calling for a settlement between India and Pakistan that is acceptable to the people of Kashmir. **********A signal of Washington's approach came in a speech this summer by the American Ambassador to India, Frank G. Wisner. Addressing Pakistani military officers, he urged Pakistan to accept the Kashmir vote as ''an alternative to the conflict'' and added the sentence that heartened Indian officials. **********''No effort to end the conflict in the state will succeed until all concerned acknowledge that, after nearly 50 years, there are certain fundamental realities that will not be changed,'' Mr. Wisner said. **********New Delhi has shown flexibility of its own. The new Government of Prime Minister H. D. Deve Gowda has promised to grant ''maximum autonomy'' to Jammu and Kashmir in negotiations with the new state government. **********The formula has been left vague, but to Kashmiris it implies a return to at least a measure of the autonomy promised by India's leaders in the early 1950's, then progressively eroded until Kashmiri discontent erupted into guerrilla warfare in 1989. **********In his Pakistan speech, Mr. Wisner warned that the voting must be free of intimidation by Indian troops if it is to have any meaning. With 500,000  troops and policemen making Srinagar and other towns look as though they are under military occupation, and guerrilla groups once again threatening to kill candidates and prevent voting, this may not be easy. Already, about 20 people linked to the pro-India parties taking part in the election have been killed. **********Attention has been focused on the man expected to win the election, Farooq Abdullah, who was the state's Chief Minister until his government was dismissed in 1990. Mr. Abdullah and his National Conference party were widely discredited by allegations of corruption and election-rigging in the past, but the turnout at Mr. Abdullah's rallies has suggested that widespread exhaustion with the war among ordinary Kashmiris may be translating into a willingness to give Mr. Abdullah, who is his 60's, a second chance. **********Demoralization among the guerrillas could also weigh in India's favor. Mr. Rao, the Governor, cited Indian intelligence estimates suggesting that there may be no more than 2,000 active guerrillas, and in any case no more than than 10,000. **********Even at the higher figure, he said, the guerrilla operations were down ''50 percent'' since 1992, when Mr. Rao took office and mounted a military crackdown. It was accompanied by what human rights groups have said was a pattern of brutality, including summary executions of captured guerrillas and suspected sympathizers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/02/world.main_headline: Russia Agrees to Limit Its Forces on Borders
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/02/world.print_headline: Russia Agrees to Limit Its Forces on Borders
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/02/world.body_text: **********Russia has agreed to freeze the number of its conventional forces now deployed on its European borders and to meet its obligations under a 1990 arms reduction treaty within three years, United States and European officials said today. **********The commitment by Russia, which has been in breach of the Treaty on Conventional Forces in Europe, followed two weeks of talks here aimed at settling problems over the pact that had arisen after the breakup of the Soviet  Union. **********Lynn Davis, an Under Secretary of State for disarmament and security issues, said today that the agreement was a solution to the changes in Europe over the last few years and proved that the conventional forces treaty was flexible enough for modifications to be made. **********Russia had negotiated hard for changes in the treaty's "flank limitations" -- the number of tanks, armored personnel carriers, artillery and other arms that a treaty nation is allowed to deploy on its borders. **********The most contentious flank areas were Russia's southern region bordering the  Caucasus, where trouble has flared in Chechnya, and in the north along its borders with the Baltic states. **********Russia had been in technical violation of the treaty after acknowledging last year that it could not make the arms cuts required by the deadline of Nov. 17, 1995, because it feared its defenses would be weakened. **********Delegates to the conference allowed Russia to maintain a higher level of forces in flank areas for the next three years, in effect exempting certain zones from the treaty limits. **********Officials said all treaty nations were satisfied with the agreement, including Turkey, Norway and the Baltic states, which had been concerned that a  buildup of Russian forces in the north and south would put their security at risk.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/04/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;After a devastating hurricane, the U.S. Virgin Islands is stressing American values for tourists.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/04/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;After a devastating hurricane, the U.S. Virgin Islands is stressing American values for tourists.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/04/busin.body_text: **********FOR Todd Godwin and C. J. Waldman, it was like winning the lottery: whisked away from Manhattan to spend Labor Day weekend tooling around the United States  Virgin Islands to brainstorm, ever so lightly, a tourism ad campaign. **********The sun was high, the hilltop trade winds gentle, their island guide colorful. Mr. Godwin, a copywriter at Lowe & Partners, an agency of the Interpublic Group of Companies, and Mr. Waldman, an art director at Lowe, developed the basic campaign on the first day of their trip last year. **********Two weeks later, a hurricane struck. **********Hurricane Marilyn, by far the most destructive storm in a record hurricane season, smashed through an already battered Caribbean. Winds of more than 100 miles an hour killed nine in the Virgin Islands and damaged or destroyed more than 90 percent of the buildings on St. Thomas, the hardest hit of the three islands. The $12 million advertising campaign, set to begin at Thanksgiving, was canceled. **********Then, all of a sudden, it was on again. Lowe, best known for its Diet Coke television commercial featuring the hard-body construction worker, introduced the results of its on-again-off-again Virgin Islands campaign yesterday. **********Roy L. Schneider, a surgeon who was elected governor of the Virgin Islands the year before, had campaigned on a platform of change and decided a new approach was essential to replace the old American paradise campaign from another agency. **********Tourism accounts for 70 percent of the islands' $1.2 billion economy and keeping the old campaign would not do, especially now that worried tourists thought the Virgin Islands had been blown off the map. **********No matter that the ads would start appearing the second week of January, long after Puerto Rico and Jamaica had started advertising and well into the December-to-March tourist season. Lowe & Partners would just have to scramble. **********The campaign's slogan is: "The U.S. Virgin Islands. They're your islands." It is designed to distinguish the territory's American heritage from that of other  Caribbean resorts like Jamaica, with its British heritage, and Martinique, with  its French heritage. **********Virgin Islanders use American dollars, as do Puerto Ricans. But unlike Puerto Rico, which is a commonwealth with a more independent government, St. John, St.  Thomas and St. Croix are administered by the United States Secretary of the Interior. Also, unlike in Puerto Rico, the principal language is English, a fact that Lowe highlights in its campaign. **********What is more, a fact that is not directly mentioned in the campaign, the ads  are designed to show that the Virgin Islands have recovered. Many of the hotels  and most of the main airport have been repaired. All of the scenes in the broadcast and print campaign were taken after Hurricane Marilyn. **********All four commercials show an elegant white-bearded black man sitting in a straight-back chair near the beach. A goat is at his feet. In one, a steel guitar can be heard in the background as the Jelly Boys sing, "Never Find a Lover Like Me." A man, wearing a white hat, white shirt and white pants, and his goat turn toward the camera and he says: "You know we've been thinking. Our Virgin Islands are just like all the other Caribbean islands. With some minor exceptions. **********"You won't need passports," he continues, in a lilting Caribbean accent, "language dictionaries, foreign currency and you won't go crazy talking to non-English-speaking operators. Hey, you can even rent videos. So come to think  of it, we're nothing like those other islands." **********The camera pans to the goat with a television remote control in its mouth. "Hey," says the man, "gimme back that remote." **********Mr. Godwin and Mr. Waldman got the idea for a storyteller-guide from the example of their island guide on St. John, who also told them a fable of the islands as three brothers, which is also incorporated into the campaign. **********"You can't just laundry-list a place's virtues," said Mr. Godwin, the copywriter, "but you can tell them through a character, who is a little eccentric to help make him memorable." When, on the way down from a hilltop on St. John's, Mr. Godwin and Mr. Waldman's vehicle was blocked by a herd of stubborn goats, they got the quirk they were looking for. "We made his best friend a goat," said Mr. Waldman, the art director. **********They found Olric Carrington, who plays the storyteller, after auditions of many actors in New York, Los Angeles, Miami and the Virgin Islands. A native, Mr. Carrington is a 71-year-old retired postmaster, amateur actor and, after profiles of him appeared in the local news media, the islands' version of Brad Pitt. **********Of course, advertising can't cure everything in Hurricane Marilyn's wake. Of  the Virgin Islands' two million tourists, about 1.2 million come from cruise ships on grand tours of the Caribbean. Most, if not all, of those passengers are back. **********But the number of other visitors may be down as much as 30 percent. And only  50 percent of St. Thomas's 4,800 rooms are back in commission. Still, the Virgin Islands may have another powerful draw: rooms that usually go for $150 to $500 in the winter are going for half off at many hotels.
