https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/28/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;U.S.-Japan Pact Reached In Dispute Over Air Cargo
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/28/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;U.S.-Japan Pact Reached In Dispute Over Air Cargo
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/28/busin.body_text: **********The United States and Japan said today that they had reached an agreement on  air-cargo service, resolving one dispute that threatened to mar next month's summit meeting between President Clinton and Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto. **********The agreement will expand the routes between and beyond the two countries, which are available to two Japanese airlines and to several American companies,  particularly the United Parcel Service of America. A formal accord will be drafted in Washington next month. **********The agreement provides "significant new opportunities to carriers from both  countries," while respecting existing rights, the White House spokesman, Michael McCurry, said in a statement in Washington. **********Ryosei Akazawa, deputy director of the civil aviation bureau at Japan's Ministry of Transportation, said the agreement would correct an imbalance that favored American carriers. Japan said that the situation has existed since 1952, when the two nations signed a civil aviation treaty. "We've practically realized equality for the first time in 43 years," he said. **********President Clinton, who will visit Tokyo from April 16 to April 18, has said that he wants to see progress on four trade issues involving air-cargo routes, photographic film, semiconductors and insurance, before his trip. The air-cargo  dispute is the first to be resolved. The other three appear to be more intractable. **********The long-simmering civil aviation dispute erupted last summer. A partial agreement in July averted threatened sanctions by the United States against Japan and called for a more comprehensive cargo pact by the end of this month. **********The agreement was praised by an aviation-industry trade group in the United States that is pressing for better access to the Japanese market. **********"This is a very good agreement for the U.S., and the Administration is to be  commended," said former Gov. Gerald L. Baliles of Virginia, the head of the group, Access U.S.-Japan. "It preserves and expands on existing rights. That's a good deal and provides great momentum for talks on passenger service." **********Another dispute, on passenger service, could flare up soon. The issue was not part of the air-cargo route negotiations. Japan is threatening to take retaliatory measures if Washington does not allow passenger flights from Tokyo to Kona, Hawaii, that Japan Airlines wants to begin next Monday. **********But the accord reached today does address "beyond rights" granted to the United States in a 1952 treaty, which allow three American carriers -- United Airlines, owned by the UAL Corporation; Northwest Airlines, and the Federal Express Corporation -- to discharge and pick up passengers or cargo in Japan and continue the flight to other destinations in Asia. Japan has long objected to those treaty rights. **********The agreement, rather than cut back on those rights for the United States, expands the rights of Japan Airlines to continue cargo flights beyond American cities to Canada or Latin America, for example. **********The agreement will allow Japan Airlines to fly to eight American cities compared with five now. Nippon Cargo Airlines will be allowed to make as many as 42 flights a week between Japan and the United States, with some limited beyond  rights. It now makes 12 flights a week, although its limit is higher. **********United Parcel Service, which now makes six weekly flights to Tokyo, will be allowed an additional 12 flights to the new Kansai International Airport near Osaka, with some beyond rights. Another American carrier -- the United States Department of Transportation has not decided which one -- will be allowed to enter the market for the first time with six flights a week to a city other than Tokyo, a United States official, who insisted on anonymity said. **********United, Northwest and Federal Express will be allowed to fly to three additional cities in Japan and will now be able to begin their flights anywhere in the United States, the official said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/08/busin.snippet: Market Place: Federal regulators have brought what appears to be their first lawsuit to stop securities manipulation over Internet; Federal judge has frozen assets of Charles O Huttoe, chairman of little company called Systems of Excellence, and a...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/08/busin.main_headline: S.E.C. Acts on Stock Promotion on the Net
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/08/busin.print_headline: S.E.C. Acts on Stock Promotion on the Net
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/08/busin.body_text: **********Cynics who suspect that the real Internet ''revolution'' has been in the area of stock fraud got some ammunition yesterday, when Federal regulators brought what appears to be their first lawsuit to stop securities manipulation over the Net. **********At the request of the Securities and Exchange Commission, a Federal judge in Washington agreed to freeze the assets of the chairman of a little company called Systems of Excellence, known to its aficionados as SEXI because of its stock ticker symbol. The freeze, which the S.E.C. says is likely to go into effect today, will also apply to the proprietors of an electronic newsletter called SGA Goldstar, which was distributed over the Internet and through stock quotation services. **********Judge Gladys Kessler of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia also agreed to impose a temporary restraining order, said Erich T. Schwartz, a lawyer for the commission. A hearing is scheduled for Nov. 21; in the meantime, the commission is continuing to investigate Systems of Excellence, which  says it makes equipment for video tele-conferencing. **********The S.E.C. complains, among other things, that SGA's owners touted Systems of Excellence in return for secret, illegal shares in the company, which they dumped once the stock price skyrocketed in late May and early June. (It topped $4.75 on June 10, up from about 25 cents at the beginning of the year; now it is back below 50 cents a share.) **********Regulators have long suspected that the Internet, with its electronic linkage of computers, serves as a cheap and easy vehicle for stock promoters to reach unwary investors. But until now, the S.E.C.'s cases have involved the sale of unregistered securities, like investments in eel farms, not the manipulation of a listed stock. **********A spokesman for Systems of Excellence, Cynthia Gamer, said the company had no comment on the legal proceedings. The company's chairman, Charles O. Huttoe, could not be reached for comment; the newsletter writers, Theodore R. Melcher Jr. and Shannon B. Terry, did not return a telephone call to their office in Tennessee. **********Like an infamous stock fraud earlier this year -- involving a company called Comparator Systems -- Systems of Excellence had developed a devoted following among Internet users who posted thousands of messages about it on investing bulletin boards. **********Many of these messages cited SGA Goldstar's frequent reports on the stock, which were, as the S.E.C. complaint says, ''highly promotional, strongly urging accumulation of the stock, discouraging sales and even discouraging investors from independently verifying SGA's information.'' For example, on May 29, SGA wrote that its unnamed source ''informed us of a rumored Federal Government order so large which we do not even want to rumor the size of the order.'' **********SGA continued to tout the stock even after the S.E.C. halted trading on Oct. 7, citing concerns about the adequacy of the company's disclosures and questions about the possible sale of unregistered stock. **********What the newsletter did not disclose is that in January, according to S.E.C., Mr. Melcher had agreed to promote the stock in exchange for 300,000 shares of stock, 200,000 of which went to him personally and 100,000 to Mr. Terry through corporations they own. In June, each man received 50,000 shares of stock, the complaint says. The newsletter does print a disclaimer noting that ''personnel associated with SGA may own shares in the companies mentioned herein or may act as consultants thereto.'' **********Those shares were not registered, but were issued improperly by Mr. Huttoe, who also had millions of unregistered shares issued to accounts controlled by his wife, mother and niece, the complaint said. He was also promoting the stock himself by issuing misleading news releases, including one on May 28 that reported a $3.4 million order that did not exist. **********Meanwhile, Mr. Huttoe, Mr. Terry and Mr. Melcher were selling their shares, according to the S.E.C., which says Mr. Huttoe alone made almost $10 million from the scheme. Once the S.E.C. began investigating in September, Mr. Huttoe engaged in an elaborate effort to cover up the fraud by filing false documents with the commission, the S.E.C. says. **********As news of the S.E.C. action spread yesterday, Internet investors posted messages cursing Mr. Huttoe and SGA, considering hiring their own lawyer, and joking mournfully about writing a book about the SEXI saga. **********''The only problem with the book,'' one contributor wrote, ''is people reading it would think to themselves, 'what were the investors thinking?' ''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/01/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Bristol-Myers Shuffles Brands
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/01/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Bristol-Myers Shuffles Brands
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/01/busin.body_text: **********The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company in New York has reassigned several consumer  brands among its roster of agencies. **********"Our objective in reassigning this business is to realign our brands and key  categories by agency in order to provide marketing efficiencies in the globalization of our advertising and marketing program," said Peter J. Spengler, vice president for marketing services at Bristol-Myers. **********The Clairol's Natural Instincts hair color brand in the United States was awarded to Wells Rich Greene BDDP in New York, part of BDDP Worldwide, from the  New York office of J. Walter Thompson, a unit of the WPP Group. Those billings were estimated at $10 million. Wells Rich in New York, which already handles advertising for Bristol-Myers brands like Clairol Herbal Essences, and its sibling Paris office BDDP Worldwide, which handles the USPA analgesics brands in Europe, were also named to handle advertising for all the Clairol hair color brands in Western Europe including Britain and Ireland. That assignment was shifted from the London office of Grey Advertising, which continues to handle those brands in Eastern Europe in areas including Poland and Russia. Those billings were not disclosed. **********Thompson New York continues to handle advertising in the United States for Clairol's other hair coloring products like Nice 'n Easy, Ultress and Loving Care, with combined billings estimated at more than $50 million. **********The Mead Johnson division of Bristol-Myers, which markets brands in the United States like Boost and Sustacal adult nutrition products, will be divided  between Wells Rich and Bozell Worldwide in New York, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, from the Chicago office of J. Walter Thompson, which has been eliminated from the roster. The billings on those brands were estimated at $25 million; it has yet to be decided which agency will handle what brands. **********Bozell, which already handles brands like Excedrin, was awarded the Excedrin  PM brand from Thompson New York and the Ban deodorant brand from the Gotham Inc. unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Gotham continues to handle several Bristol-Myers brands like Bufferin, Comtrex, Keri lotion and Sea Breeze astringent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/24/busin.snippet: Prices of government securities fall sharply following report that manufacturing sector of US economy is expanding at brisk pace (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/24/busin.main_headline: Bonds Fall After Durable Goods Orders Surge
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/24/busin.print_headline: Bonds Fall After Durable Goods Orders Surge
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/24/busin.body_text: **********Probably the last thing investors wanted to see yesterday, was strong economic data showing the manufacturing sector expanding at a brisk pace, even though there were suspicions. But it happened, and prices of government securities fell sharply as a result. **********Investors sold the long maturities, moving to the short end of the market, fearing the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates sooner rather than later. **********To be sure, there were also other dynamics at work in the market -- options expirations, repositioning of portfolios by dealers ahead of Treasury auctions next week and a glut of fresh numbers late in the week. **********The 30-year bond fell 110/32  to a price of 9715/32  to yield 6.95 percent, up from 6.83 percent on Thursday and the highest since July 31, when it was 6.97 percent. **********In futures trading, which affects the cash market for current issues, traders said the September bond contract might have lost more were it not for options expirations yesterday. ''Nevertheless,'' said Robin Mesch, chief fixed-income analyst for Thomson Research of Boston, ''the September bond futures contract was moving in only one direction yesterday, and it wasn't up. The session's high price was 11016/32 , and at the close it was 10917/32 , down a full point from the previous day.'' **********Jack Regan, chief derivatives strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said the latest data would seem to indicate that the early June and July numbers that caused perceptions of a weakening economy may have been an aberration. **********''The July durable goods order today showed strength across the board,'' Mr. Regan said. ''And amidst the slow summer trade we have supply looming next week in the way of two-  and five-year notes. With many traders as well as investors on holiday, the demand may very well be on the light side.'' **********Between options expiration and dealers repositioning themselves for next week, market volume was higher than an average summer Friday, according to Govpx, a bond pricing service. ''In fact,'' said Maureen Mooney, market analyst with the firm, ''it was 18 percent higher.'' She noted that activity in the two-year when-issued note was heavy and was about 66 percent higher than normal volume on a Friday before an auction. The two-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.10 percent and the five-year note at a price to yield 6.48 percent. **********Behind much of yesterday's activity was the Commerce Department's report that durable goods orders for July were up a strong 1.6 percent from June. That leaves the Fed policy outlook uncertain at best. **********''Benign inflation has allowed the Fed to be patient in its wait for signs of an economic slowdown, and this trend should persist,'' said Kim Rupert, an economist with MMS International in San Francisco. ''Yet, the Fed may lose patience. Upcoming data from the National Association of Purchasing Management and the employment report will be crucial for the Fed,'' in deciding whether to tighten monetary policy in September, she continued, ''especially prices, vendor deliveries and wages.'' **********Yesterday's report raised fears that recent strong statistics coupled with an expected sharp rise in August payrolls could lead to another bout of selling for fear of a rate increase. **********Astrid Adolfson, an economist at MCM MoneyWatch in New York, noted that there was aggressive selling before the durables report, and said she had heard rumors of a leak. ''Over all,'' Ms. Adolfson said, ''the feeling was that durable goods cemented the view that July might have been an aberration. But now I think we have already seen weak retail sales bounce back, and housing is moderate. Now the durable goods numbers tell us that there is strength across the board.'' **********She also pointed to overseas markets getting stronger, suggesting that exports will soon add to growth. ''Jobless claims numbers continue to be low and are still at 1989 prerecession levels, showing good jobs growth,'' she added. ''But with that comes income, supporting consumer expansion.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/17/busin.print_headline: Donnelley Confirms Plans to Sell Stream
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/17/busin.body_text: **********The R. R. Donnelley & Sons Company, the nation's largest printer, confirmed today that it planned to sell Stream International, a money-losing company it formed last year as part of a  strategy to expand into software manufacturing and distribution. **********Analysts said Donnelley, which is based here, told them last week that it was considering several options for getting rid of Stream, including an initial public offering of Stream's profitable help-line business and separate sales of its manufacturing and distribution units. **********A Donnelley spokesman, William Lowe, confirmed the plan to sell the unit. The possibility of a sale was reported today in The Wall Street Journal. **********The decision to sell Stream is widely taken as an acknowledgment that the diversification strategy of Donnelley's former chief executive, John R. Walter, had failed. Mr. Walter left Donnelley six weeks ago to become president and chief operating officer of the AT&T Corporation. **********Rudolf Hokanson, an analyst at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, said, ''Stream was a big bet and it just didn't make it.'' **********Donnelley, whose printing customers include the Yellow Pages and Business Week magazine, declined to estimate how much Stream might be worth. The unit, which has annual revenue of $1.6 billion, reported an operating loss of $19 million in the first nine months this year. **********Stream is based in Westwood, Mass.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/15/busin.snippet: Profile of Lucent Technologies Inc, AT&T's high-tech spinoff; company sold 122 million shares in initial public offering in April and will distribute about 525 million more to AT&T shareholders; many of these conservative investors may be inclined...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/15/busin.main_headline: Lucent May Be AT&T's Creation, but Its Stock Is a Different Beast
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/15/busin.print_headline: Lucent May Be AT&T's Creation, but Its Stock Is a Different Beast
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/15/busin.body_text: **********ON Friday, AT&T shareholders got the chance to begin selling their shares in Lucent Technologies Inc., the phone company's high-tech spinoff, even before receiving them. **********Lucent's price fell slightly on what was a record day for the stock market, and traders and stock analysts suggested that selling pressure on the stock would pick up over the next few weeks. **********Lucent, home to the prestigious Bell Labs, is a leading manufacturer and researcher of telephone company networking systems, office phone systems and telecommunications-related computer chips and software. But it is a technology company far different from its parent. **********Some AT&T shareholders are wary of owning a technology stock and some, either by choice or by policy, avoid stocks outside the major indexes. ''The obvious concern is that there is a huge overhang of shareholders who may wish to eliminate or reduce their holdings,'' said Walter T. McCormick, a portfolio manager at Keystone Investments, who owns Lucent and considers its long-term outlook positive. **********In April, AT&T sold 122 million shares, or 18 percent, of Lucent in an initial public offering, the biggest such offering ever. About 525 million more shares will be distributed on Sept. 30 to AT&T shareholders, who will get one Lucent share for about every three shares of AT&T. On Friday, trading began in temporary shares representing those Lucent shares that are about to be issued. **********To the 3.3 million people who own AT&T stock, questions remain not only about whether Lucent can trim its bloated cost structure and remain competitive but also about whether Lucent is a good fit for their personal portfolios. As with all investment matters, it depends in part on the investor's financial goals and tax situation. **********One important factor for investors is that Lucent's stock will probably be more volatile than AT&T's. The sales cycle for telephone equipment means that more than 80 percent of Lucent's income comes in the last quarter of each year. The uneven income stream will simply be accentuated by the company's trend toward bigger and fewer contracts. So investors uncomfortable with volatility or who expect to need the proceeds soon from these shares may be tempted to bail out. **********Retirees and others investing mainly for income may consider Lucent's small payout a letdown, too. AT&T's dividend yield is about 2.4 percent, compared with an expected 0.76 percent for Lucent. AT&T says it intends to maintain its quarterly cash divided of 33 cents a share, while the new Lucent shares will pay 7.5 cents a share. **********A deterrent to selling for some people, though, will be the tax consequences. True, the Internal Revenue Service has determined that AT&T shareholders will not owe income tax just for receiving Lucent shares. But if they sell, they may realize big capital gains. After all, some people have owned AT&T stock since long before its divestiture of the Baby Bells in the early 1980's. **********The amount of the capital gain will be determined by the price of AT&T and Lucent shares on Sept. 30. Based on Friday's prices, about 77 percent of capital gains will be assessed to the AT&T shares, with the remaining 33 percent to Lucent. **********In the meantime, there are four shares trading on the Big Board: the regular AT&T and Lucent shares and two temporary stocks, one representing the Lucent shares about to be issued and another representing the AT&T shares minus their Lucent component. Assigned the ticker symbols LU WI (Lucent when issued) and T WD (AT&T when delivered), the temporary shares will stop trading with the close of the market on Sept. 30. Regular AT&T shares are now trading with coupons that are redeemable for Lucent shares on Oct. 3. **********Even though AT&T shareholders can sell Lucent shares now, it might be a mistake to rush to market. Prices might be depressed for several weeks by one-time selling. Professional investors are particularly concerned about whether Lucent will be included in the major stock indexes. Because AT&T is part of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock and the Dow Jones industrial indexes, funds that track these indexes will need to shed Lucent shares if the indexes don't add Lucent to their list. Standard & Poor's declined to comment on its plans. **********As the Dow Jones industrial average soared to a new high on Friday, Lucent's stock fell 50 cents, to $39.125; AT&T's stock gained 37.5 cents, to $55.25. **********Stock analysts expect declines in Lucent's price to be temporary. ''We are nervous about the fact that equipment company shares are not really what the AT&T shareholder base is used to,'' said Trent May, a co-manager of the Invesco Growth fund. ''But any weakness will be near term, while the shares get into the hands of people who want to own them.'' **********If Mr. May is right, investors who want to sell will benefit by waiting for the share price to bounce back. By the same token, aggressive investors might seize on a price downturn as a buying opportunity. If temporary selling pushes Lucent's stock, which went public at $27 a share earlier this year, below $35, it would be a good buy, said Lawrence Eakin, a technology investment analyst with Federated Investors, which holds Lucent in its Federated Capital Appreciation fund. **********Many stock analysts expect Lucent to outperform AT&T over the next few years. They point to rapid growth in the market for telephone equipment and systems. **********Deregulation in the United States means that phone companies of all types will increase their capital spending to compete in one another's markets. ''The deregulation of telecommunications has created a kind of free-for-all,'' said Mr. McCormick of Keystone. ''All the regional Bells can offer long distance, and AT&T might be able to offer local competitive service. Cable companies at some point may be offering telephony.'' **********United States demand for wireless equipment is growing rapidly, too, and Lucent has 40 percent of that market, about the same share as Ericsson. **********Furthermore, foreign markets will continue to open up, and many of them will need more capacity and new switching systems to handle more data. **********All told, Mr. McCormick expects the market for telecommunications equipment to grow more than 10 percent annually for several years. Even though much of the new business will go to Ericsson and Northern Telecom, Mr. McCormick says, Lucent will remain competitive. He expects Lucent's earnings to grow 15 percent a year. **********Like other financial analysts who track the company, Mr. McCormick says that much of Lucent's success depends on an ambitious cost-cutting plan. About 16,000 jobs will be gone by the end of this year -- part of the 23,000 jobs the company says it will cut by the end of 1998. That total represents about 17 percent of its 131,000 employees at the end of last year. **********Overhead now eats up about 25.5 percent of sales, compared with an industry average of 17 percent. If the company could reduce costs to that level, earnings per share would rise by 33 percent a year over the next three years, J. P. Morgan estimates. **********Even J. P. Morgan considers such cost cuts unrealistic. More likely, it says, is that Lucent will lower its costs to 22.5 percent of sales, raising earnings by 15 percent a year. **********As time-consuming as it may be to get caught up on a new stock, AT&T investors might as well get used to it. By the end of the year, AT&T will spin off another unit, NCR.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/29/world.main_headline: UNVEILED POWER: A special report.;Pakistani Leader Takes Tough New Tack
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/29/world.print_headline: UNVEILED POWER: A special report.;Pakistani Leader Takes Tough New Tack
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/29/world.body_text: **********When Benazir Bhutto returned to power in Pakistan 30 months ago, she told friends that she had learned a lesson from her first, troubled stint as Prime Minister: Not to be swayed by critics who would like Pakistan, with its history  of military coups and political violence, to be governed in the gentler traditions of Western democracies. **********"This time, I won't listen to the sloppy liberals," she said. **********The vow was a rite of passage for Ms. Bhutto. After earning degrees from Radcliffe College and Oxford, she endured first house arrest, then imprisonment  and exile, before the popular movement she led helped end a military dictatorship. In 1988, she won the country's first general election in more than a decade. **********But her first experience as Pakistan's leader was an embittering one, ending  abruptly after 20 months when holdovers from the military Government dismissed her for what they said was incompetence and corruption. After another period in  the political wilderness, harassed and prosecuted by a civilian Government close to the old military rulers, she won another election in October 1993 and set out to make sure, this time, that she remained in power. **********For Pakistan, the result has been far from the liberal traditions that Ms. Bhutto, who is 42, was exposed to in her student years abroad. **********A range of critics, including many who supported her in the past, say Ms. Bhutto's tenure this time has been marked by some of the same intolerance for opposition, the same disregard for law and civil liberties, and the same rampant corruption that contributed to the downfall of Ms. Bhutto's father, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto. He was ousted as Prime Minister in 1977, and later hanged, in the coup that brought Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq to power. **********Among other things, the Bhutto Government over the last nine months has staged a bloody crackdown on armed rivals who have conducted what has amounted to a civil war in Karachi, the country's biggest city, in which the police have  been accused of killing hundreds of opponents. In addition, critics say, Ms. Bhutto has directed a campaign of harassment against judges, reporters and officials who have angered her, ordering transfers and demotions where she could, as well as using the country's tax and criminal laws to persecute political rivals. **********Ms. Bhutto declined to be interviewed for this article, saying through her aides that her schedule was overloaded. But her supporters, and even some of her critics, say the clue to her attitudes is contained in her remark about "sloppy  liberals." What she meant, they say, was that tough and intolerant government may be unavoidable in this country, where a common Muslim faith and a shared distrust of India seem not enough to bind the 130 million people together. **********Her Record Accomplishments Vs. Liabilities **********In recent years, Pakistan has become increasingly lawless and violent in the  face of ethnic divisions, one of the world's fastest-growing populations, a deepening gulf between a wealthy minority and tens of millions who subsist on the equivalent of a dollar or less a day, and a powerful Muslim fundamentalist movement. On top of all this, the country is awash with narcotics and guns in the wake of the war in Afghanistan. **********Many of the strains have come together in Karachi, where thousands were killed in street warfare before the police crackdown began last year and the economy, accounting for 70 percent of Pakistan's tax revenues, was repeatedly paralyzed. **********Sympathizers also say there are more personal reasons why Ms. Bhutto has acted intemperately, beginning with the fact that she is still deeply wounded by the execution in 1979 of her father, condemned by a martial law court for his alleged complicity in the killing of a political rival, and unwilling to forgive anybody connected with the hanging, especially in the Pakistan Muslim League, which supported GeneralZia. **********Beyond this, these people say, is the fact that the Pakistani leader is a woman, the first to head the government of a Muslim country, and operates in a culture where women have traditionally been repressed. **********"She's ruling in a jungle, and it's not easy," said Asma Jahangir, a lawyer who is chairman of the Human Rights Commission of Pakistan, an independent body  that has criticized alleged human rights abuses by the Bhutto Government. **********Other Pakistanis say criticism of Ms. Bhutto overlooks her accomplishments, among them the fact that she almost single-handedly kept alive hopes for democracy under General Zia, and now has helped keep Pakistan a parliamentary democracy -- however flawed -- for nearly eight years. Supporters point out that this is the longest single period of democratic rule in the country's history. **********"Say what you will about the details, Benazir in Pakistan is synonomous with  democracy," one of Ms. Bhutto's aides said. **********Another achievement that many Pakistanis acknowledge is the country's turn away from a socialist economic system toward a market economy. Continuing reforms set in train when Nawaz Sharif was Prime Minister, Ms. Bhutto has sold off state-owned banks, power plants and industrial enterprises, and worked tirelessly to attract foreign investment. **********But with public opinion polls showing less than 20 percent support for the Bhutto Government, a more common view is that Ms. Bhutto herself is emblematic of the forces that have brought Pakistan to a low ebb. **********On the national holiday on Saturday celebrating the 1940 convention of the Muslim League that first voted for the establishment of Pakistan, many newspapers published special sections that were a mixture of nostalgia for the idealistic country that many Muslims of the 1940's hoped Pakistan might be and bitter lament for what it has become. **********Several newspapers questioned whether Pakistan can survive without a radical  change in the attitudes of the dominant political class -- Ms. Bhutto and the governing People's Party first of all, but also her rivals in the Muslim League. **********"Before what little is left of Pakistan disappears, we the people must disassociate ourselves from the looters and forget party labels, for whether it  is the P.P.P. or the P.M.L., they are the same leopard with different spots," a  commentary in The News, a Lahore newspaper, said, referring to the People's Party and the Muslim League. **********Her Critics Is U.S. Backing The Wrong Horse? **********Some of the harshest criticism for the Pakistani leader has come from those who backed her return to power in 1993. **********Among these were many of the country's most powerful editors, who have almost all now turned against Ms. Bhutto. Many editors have been shocked by her use of  government powers to set newsprint prices, levy discretional taxes and punish newspapers and magazines that oppose the Government. Reporters for a government-owned news agency and for the state television network have been dismissed or transferred, and replaced by Bhutto supporters. **********Before she died this month of a brain seizure, one of the country's best-known editors, Razia Bhatti, offered a stiff warning to the Pakistani leader in one of the last editorials she wrote in Newsline, a Karachi-based newsmagazine. "A clean government doesn't fear a free press," Ms. Bhatti wrote.  "Ms. Bhutto would do well to remember that her years out of power will far outnumber her years in power. Tomorrow, or many tomorrows hence, she may feel the need for a free press again." **********Some of the criticism has been directed at the United States, which downgraded relations with Pakistan in 1990, cutting off military and economic aid and banning arms sales because of Pakistan's covert nuclear weapons program. But American criticism eased up after a coalition led by the People's Party narrowly beat a coalition led by the Muslim League in the 1993 election. Relieved that the Muslim League had not returned to power, the Clinton Administration has hailed Ms. Bhutto as a champion of democracy and secularism in the Muslim world. **********Despite fresh reports that Pakistan has continued its nuclear weapons program, buying equipment from China last year that it needed to process fissionable material, the Administration recently decided to permit delivery of  $368 million worth of military hardware that Pakistan had previously paid for. Ms. Bhutto, in turn, has told Pakistani audiences that the American arms package amounts to a vote of confidence in her Government. **********But many critics say Washington is backing the wrong horse, or at least for the wrong reasons. Among these is the former Pakistan cricket captain Imran Khan, who has said he may form his own political party on a platform promising a crackdown on corruption and law-breaking. In an interview, Mr. Khan said backing the Bhutto Government in the hope that it would hold off Muslim fundamentalism here was ill-conceived. **********"It is the most naive perception, because the only reason that Islamic fundamentalism will ever gain ground in this country is corruption and injustice, and that's exactly what the Bhutto Government is all about," Mr. Khan said. **********Perhaps because he is so popular, outstripping Ms. Bhutto in public support in straw polls conducted by popular magazines, Mr. Khan has been a special object of Ms. Bhutto's ire. Recently, for instance, Bhutto loyalists in the state-owned Pakistan International Airways saw to it that a special airline calendar commemorating the 1992 world champion cricket team included photos of every team member except Mr. Khan. **********Critics say vindictiveness toward political opponents, a deeply ingrained tradition here, has exceeded even what Mr. Sharif had attempted as Prime Minister. The Bhutto Government has initiated more than 150 prosecutions -- including charges for treason, corruption, tax evasion and embezzlement -- against Mr. Sharif, now the main opposition leader as head of the Muslim League. **********As Prime Minister between Ms. Bhutto's first and second terms, Mr. Sharif used similar tactics against her, and laid corruption charges that kept Ms. Bhutto's husband, Asif Ali Zardari, in prison for two-and-a-half years. **********In addition to answering the multiple prosecutions brought against him by the Government, industrial companies owned by Mr. Sharif and his family have been ordered to repay government-owned banks the equivalent of more than $200 million in loans. Judged in default, some of the companies have been forced to shut down. The state-owned television network, which gives extensive coverage to Ms.  Bhutto's activities almost every night, has made Mr. Sharif a virtual nonperson. **********Some opposition figures have been punished still more harshly. Before the Government moved to have him released last week, Sheik Rashid, a Muslim League member of Parliament who had shocked even his own party with his vituperative and often vulgar attacks on Ms. Bhutto, served 18 months of a seven-year jail term imposed after a police search ordered by the Government uncovered an unlicensed assault rifle in his home, hardly an unusual possession here. **********Mr. Sharif, interviewed in the opposition leader's office in the National Assembly in Islamabad, said Ms. Bhutto's actions against her political opponents showed the hypocrisy with which she presented herself on more than 50 overseas trips she has made since returning to power. "She has presented herself as a campaigner for human rights, for democracy, and for the cause of the downtrodden," he said. "But she has two standards, one to present to the outside world, and one to present here." **********Some of Ms. Bhutto's supporters say her intolerance has grown under the influence of Mr. Zardari, her husband. A land-owning businessman with a love for polo and flashy cars, Mr. Zardari, who holds a parliamentary seat for the governing party, has combined business and politics in ways that have caused Ms. Bhutto's critics to accuse him of widespread corruption. He has denied the charges vehemently, and noted that all of the corruption charges laid against him by Mr. Sharif's Government were dismissed. **********Her Prospects Even Some Backers Are Disenchanted **********Some of Ms. Bhutto's critics say that her intolerance of opposition has encouraged violence by her supporters against her rivals, and that even if she knew nothing of the attacks in advance, she has done nothing to stop them. Last  week, People's Party supporters in Ms. Bhutto's home province of Sind attacked Mr. Sharif's car with wooden staves and rocks, smashing the windshield. The student wing of the People's Party has been at war with its Muslim League counterpart on college campuses across the country, with several incidents in which students and faculty members have been killed. **********But perhaps the starkest incident of its kind occurred in November when the police ransacked the home in the southern city of Hyderabad of Pervaiz Shah, a son-in-law of Pakistan's Chief Justice, Sajjad Ali Shah. A few days later, the younger Mr. Shah was dismissed without warning from his government job. At about the same time, his brother was also dismissed from his job with Pakistan International Airlines. **********The moves followed the opening of a Supreme Court hearing on a challenge to the Bhutto Government's attempts to influence court rulings by transferring and  demoting judges. **********This week, the Supreme Court, led by Mr. Shah, who was previously considered  a Bhutto supporter, stunned the Government by ordering changes in the way that judges are appointed and transferred that legal analysts said would sharply curb political manipulation. **********The move came amid signs that another Bhutto supporter, Farooq Leghari, who is Pakistan's President, is cautiously distancing himself from Ms. Bhutto. In January, Mr. Leghari chose Gen. Jehangir Karamat, then the country's second-highest-ranking general, to become the new army Chief of Staff, in preference to a junior general said to have been preferred by Ms. Bhutto. **********Some Pakistanis have seen these instances of resistance as a sign that she may have gone too far even for key members of her own camp. Some newspaper commentators have even speculated that Mr. Leghari could use a Zia-era provision of the Constitution to sack Ms. Bhutto, just as she was dismissed by another President in 1990. **********But most bets are that Ms. Bhutto will serve out her term until the next election, due in 1998 -- if only because, at least for now, she remains slightly less unpopular among Pakistanis than the man who would be likely to succeed her  if she was dismissed, Mr. Sharif.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/20/busin.print_headline: The U.S. Deficit Fell in March
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/20/busin.body_text: **********The United States budget deficit fell to $47.28 billion in March from $50.54  billion in March 1995, the Treasury Department said today. **********Halfway through the 1996 fiscal year, which ends on Sept. 30, the Government's perennial spending deficit has been improving, in part because Congress and the Clinton Administration remained deadlocked over a budget plan. **********The deficit for the first six months of the current fiscal year has fallen 12.6 percent, to $128.22 billion, from $146.65 billion in the comparable first six months of the 1995 fiscal year. **********The Government has been operating on continuing resolutions in the absence of a budget, parceling out spending authority to departments in a way that keeps a  lid on outlays. **********Total Government spending in March was $136.29 billion, down from $143.07 billion in March 1995, but up from $133.64 billion in February. **********Receipts from all sources, mostly income taxes, were down to $89.01 billion in March from $92.53 billion a year earlier and down from $89.35 billion in February. **********The Clinton Administration has forecast a deficit for the full 1996 fiscal year of $145.62 billion, down from $163.86 billion in the 1995 fiscal year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/28/busin.body_text: **********South Korea's gross domestic product rose 6.7 percent in the second quarter of 1996 from a year ago, down from 9.7 percent growth in the second quarter of last year, the Bank of Korea said yesterday. Analysts say growth is slowing as the Korean economy is hit by declining export growth and lower corporate investment. https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/12/busin.snippet: Federal Trade Commission reportedly plans to announce that it has officially approved Time Warner's $6.5 billion merger with Turner Broadcasting System; FTC approval has been expected since its staff and Time Warner signed agreement after protract...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/12/busin.main_headline: F.T.C. Is Said to Have Cleared Time Warner Deal for Turner
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/12/busin.print_headline: F.T.C. Is Said to Have Cleared Time Warner Deal for Turner
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/12/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Trade Commission plans to announce today that it has officially approved Time Warner's $6.5 billion merger with the Turner Broadcasting System, according to people familiar with the decision. **********The F.T.C.'s approval has been expected since mid-July, when the commission's staff and Time Warner signed an agreement after protracted negotiations that changed some of the original merger terms. **********The F.T.C. approved the deal yesterday by a vote of 3 to 2, people with knowledge of the deliberations said. The two commissioners who voted against the consent order -- Roscoe Starek 3d and Mary Azcuenaga -- plan to issue dissents in which they are expected to argue that the Government should not have demanded any changes in the structure of the deal, according to people familiar with the order. **********A spokeswoman for the F.T.C. declined to comment on the order, saying only, ''There will be an announcement in the morning.'' **********But people familiar with the order said that it contained virtually all the stipulations in the staff agreement with Time Warner. In that agreement, Time Warner pledged to restructure the deal to dilute the influence of Tele-Communications Inc. on the combined Time Warner-Turner. Through a 22 percent stake in Turner, Liberty Media, which Tele-Communications controls, will own roughly 9 percent of Time Warner. **********Time Warner also agreed to carry a second 24-hour news channel on its cable systems to compete with Turner's CNN. And it agreed not to discriminate in how much it charges other cable operators to carry Turner networks like CNN, TBS or the Cartoon Network. **********A spokesman for Time Warner declined to comment yesterday. The company has scheduled a shareholder meeting for Oct. 10 to vote on the merger, and it hopes to close the deal soon afterward. **********Based on their knowledge of the F.T.C. order, consumer advocates said it only partly satisfied their objections. ''However,'' said Gene Kimmelman, the co-director of Consumers' Union, ''it's encouraging that they're putting real teeth to prevent discrimination and anti-competitive practices.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/04/world.main_headline: French Agency Accuses Rwanda of Theft
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/04/world.print_headline: French Agency Accuses Rwanda of Theft
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/04/world.body_text: **********A French aid agency expelled from Rwanda last week accused Rwanda's army today of stealing the agency's vehicles, equipment and medicine. **********The group, Doctors Without Borders, said its compound in Kigali, the Rwandan  capital, had been occupied by soldiers since Dec. 24, when the army confiscated 16 vehicles, medicine and other equipment worth more than $500,000.  The group said it was making a formal protest to the Rwandan Government. **********Doctors Without Borders is one of 38 foreign agencies expelled last month by Rwanda on the grounds they had failed to register. The Government said the groups should leave behind their equipment and that it would be confiscated. **********Rwandan authorities have also cut telephone lines of agencies ordered out and have frozen their bank accounts. Diplomats said the moves were partly in response to delays in arrival of $1.2 billion of aid. **********The president of Doctors Without Borders, Philippe Biberson, said in Paris the group was expelled for reporting atrocities by Rwanda's Tutsi-led Government against Hutu living in camps there.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/22/world.main_headline: World News Briefs;Toll Rising, Japan Warns Against Eating Raw Meat
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/22/world.print_headline: World News Briefs;Toll Rising, Japan Warns Against Eating Raw Meat
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/22/world.body_text: **********The Japanese Government warned the public today not to eat raw meat as the toll grew from an epidemic of food poisoning. **********The health ministry said more than 8,000 people had been stricken since the start of summer two months ago, 6,000 of them in the last 10 days in the town of Sakai. **********A ministry spokesman said the illnesses were all linked to the O-157 colon bacteria, which cause severe vomiting, diarrhea and fever that can lead to life-threatening loss of blood pressure and dehydration. Four people have died. **********The warning about raw meat was issued after researchers for the first time pinpointed the carrier of the bacteria in a case in June. Health Ministry officials said they had established that the bacteria in raw liver was the cause of the illness in a nine-year-old boy in the town of Miura, 50 miles south of Tokyo. **********Researchers have still not been able to pinpoint the carrier of the bacteria  in Sakai, site of the main outbreak, where most of the victims were primary-school children.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/22/busin.snippet: Weather forecasts by Jon B Davis, head of Smith Barney Inc's meteorology department, are watched carefully in grain and energy markets; Davis says Smith Barney's grain futures brokers and their clients are hungry for advice on any weather that can...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/22/busin.main_headline: More Companies Are Relying On Private Weather Forecasters
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/22/busin.print_headline: More Companies Are Relying On Private Weather Forecasters
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/22/busin.body_text: **********Jon B. Davis says that every school paper he ever wrote, from second grade on, was about the weather. If it snowed at night while he was growing up just west of here in suburban Des Plaines, he stayed awake to collect hourly accumulation data. **********No wonder Mr. Davis, now 34 and head of the meteorology department at Smith Barney Inc. here, is loving 1996. **********With corn, soybean and wheat reserves so low that a poor harvest would send prices rocketing, Smith Barney's grain futures brokers and their clients have been hungry for advice on any weather that could affect crops. And with energy markets moving toward deregulation, utilities and speculators are buying, selling and swapping power on a scale unimaginable a few years ago -- and placing multimillion-dollar bets on how weather could affect demand for gas, heating oil and electricity. **********''The sensitivity to our work is unbelievable, and that makes it fun,'' Mr. Davis said on a recent morning, shortly after settling down in front of his computer at 5:30. **********Smith Barney, a unit of Travelers Group Inc., is the last major brokerage house to have its own weather department, but not because the importance of forecasters like Mr. Davis has diminished. Instead, a private weather industry with revenue approaching $200 million a year has grown up as brokerage firms join farmers, airlines, truckers, banks and dozens of other industries demanding more detailed, frequent and accurate forecasts than the National Weather Service provides. **********Companies like Accuweather Inc. of State College, Pa.; the Weatherservices Corporation of Lexington, Mass., and Weather Data Inc. of Wichita, Kan., are growing at double-digit rates. **********''The Government maintains the data collection infrastructure like it maintains highways, but about 85 percent of the weather information that reaches the public is now provided by the private sector,'' said Jeffrey Smith, executive director of the Commercial Weather Services Association, the industry's nine-year-old trade group in Washington. **********Nearly 40 percent of the industry's revenue comes from broadcasters and newspapers; Accuweather, the largest company, serves more than 700. **********Beyond the media, farmers with large operations want to know what to expect in each field over the span of a few hours to send machinery where it can do the most work. Ski resorts must know when they can efficiently make snow. Big banks rely on forecasts to decide how to transfer checks through the clearing system. **********''A regional bank like Banc One will want to know if Columbus is going to be socked in by fog, so it can drive checks to Cleveland or Cincinnati and still get them out that night,'' said Michael Leavitt, president of Weatherservices. ''They might pay a $25,000 retainer for information for all major airports for a year, but they could recoup that in a single night if they avoid losing the float on the funds they are collecting.'' **********New market niches pop up, too. Micro Forecasts Inc. of Portland, Ore., uses pagers to send forecasts for popular beaches to wind surfers. ''We can give a wind surfer enough information to reliably plan his weekend for $1 a shot,'' said the founder and president, Larry Hambrick. **********The markets served by Mr. Davis of Smith Barney, though, are among the most intense, since unexpected good weather can be nearly as disruptive as a brutal storm. **********On Feb. 23, 1994, for example, Mr. Davis forecast that no Arctic air would sweep into the United States in the next 10 days. Sandra Wilder, who manages Smith Barney's natural gas desk in Houston, recalled the reaction: a 4 percent tumble in the April natural gas futures contract. **********The contract fell 3 percent more over the next few days as Mr. Davis's prediction of milder-than-expected weather was borne out and seconded by others. **********Energy clients are now waiting anxiously for Mr. Davis's long-range forecast for this winter. Last October, after scrutinizing water temperatures in the Pacific and historic weather patterns, he told them to expect a colder-than-normal winter. The National Weather Service -- and most private companies, basing their work on its predictions -- were calling for relatively mild weather. **********''You don't see him just going along with the masses,'' said Mike Steffes, vice president for risk management at the natural gas division of Valero Energy, a San Antonio-based refiner and distributor. Valero, he said, made millions after buying call options last fall in anticipation that a cold winter would make gas prices soar by spring. **********In addition to long-range reports, Mr. Davis issues weekly updates for the grain, energy and other markets and a series of daily reports for brokers and clients. He speaks at company-sponsored investment meetings. And his reports are often faxed to investors and market researchers outside the Smith Barney network. **********''He is the single best forecaster in the business,'' said Richard Loewy, president of Agresources, a Chicago grain research firm that subscribes to Weatherservices' reports but also makes sure it keeps up with Mr. Davis's forecasts. **********Mr. Davis's day begins with what he calls ''weatherobics'': he pulls page after page of number-laden computer maps off a printer that has generated them overnight and steps on and off his chair to reach hooks from which he hangs them on the wall. Then he begins to check the differing European and National Weather Service outlooks to form his own view. **********The Government outlooks are generated from computer programs that give varying weights to winds, barometric pressure, temperatures and other factors. One arcane factor that Mr. Davis tracks, but few others bother to chart, is the wavelike patterns, over months, in air pressures at specific latitudes that help track changes in the jet stream. **********This summer, Mr. Davis said, the patterns pointed to a high probability for the heavy rains that struck northern Illinois, causing flooding in many Chicago suburbs, although the 17 inches that fell in some areas exceeded even his expectations. **********Just as important as what the maps say at the moment is how they evolved over the last 24 hours as new satellite and ground data were fed into the projections. A forecaster will not get much credit for projecting a significant chance of showers on a Tuesday morning, if several hours later he misses an opportunity to warn that they have become highly likely or all but certain. **********''Like any other weatherman, he says what the maps say and they are always changing,'' said Steven Freed, head of research at ADM Investor Services, the brokerage subsidiary of Archer Daniels Midland. As a competitor of Smith Barney, ADM has no direct access to Mr. Davis's reports, but Mr. Freed conceded that both brokers and clients routinely ask what has been heard about his views. **********Mr. Davis's command post is an open cubicle at the edge of a large floor of brokers' desks in a skyscraper across the street from the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Brokers begin calling or dropping by as early as 6:40 A.M., and he enthusiastically walks them through his expectations, explaining where the Government models diverge from each other or from his own views. **********''Real meteorology is mathematics,'' Mr. Davis said. ''Half the challenge is to talk about it in terms those with no background can understand.'' **********To make sure they understand, some companies subscribe to multiple weather services. Utilicorp United, a utility based in Kansas City, Mo., has worked with three private services. It also downloads historic National Weather Service data from the Internet to an in-house computer system designed to revise projections in light of what happened under similar conditions in the past. **********The utility's energy traders also get faxed projections and calls from brokers at Smith Barney and other firms, in essence giving them access to the wisdom of Mr. Davis and all of the outside weather firms used by Smith Barney's competitors. **********''It helps because we now monitor the whole country,'' said Keith Stamm, vice president for energy trading. ''We used to only worry about weather in Missouri and Kansas, but now, through our nonregulated Aquila Power Marketing group, we are buying and selling everywhere and not just for our own needs.'' **********The explosion in energy trading, as much as any other single factor, is making life steadily more hectic for Mr. Davis. By 9 on a recent morning, he was talking to Smith Barney's London energy group on one line while holding a second telephone receiver on which a Memphis-based broker and his client, an Arkansas cotton producer, waited to ask if enough wet weather was on the way to slow the local harvest. **********A third line rang unanswered, because Mr. Davis's assistant, Basilio Lopez Jr., had momentarily stepped away. **********In a month, Mr. Davis said later, he would be even busier. ''Right now is the transition time,'' he said. ''It's a bit peaceful because it's to the point where we don't see any frost arriving early enough to do major damage to the grains. We are putting them to bed, and just starting to look forward to the winter energy markets.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/01/busin.snippet: Peter Passell Economic Scene article on proposals to invest some of Social Security trust fund in common stocks in quest for higher yields; cites potential problems; drawing (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/01/busin.main_headline: Letting Social Security dabble in the stock market.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/01/busin.print_headline: Letting Social Security dabble in the stock market.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/01/busin.body_text: **********LOOKING for a painless way to cut the gap between what the baby boomers have been promised from Social Security and current revenue projections? Shift a big chunk of the system's trust fund to common stocks, which have enjoyed four times the return of Treasury bonds since the 1920's. **********This proposal, championed by Robert M. Ball, a former Social Security commissioner, is being offered as an alternative to the supposedly more radical departures, namely privatization. And when the Social Security advisory panel delivers it -- probably after the Presidential election -- Mr. Ball's idea is likely to get a cordial reception from politicians loath to raise payroll taxes or make the deep cuts in benefits. **********But investing in stocks is a radical idea, too, suggests Lawrence White, an economist at New York University's Stern School of Business and consultant to the Investment Company Institute, a trade association for the investment industry. At best, it constitutes socially redeeming sleight of hand that shifts risk to future taxpayers and pensioners. At worst, it is an invitation to meddle in the world's most efficient capital market. ''This would push Social Security deep into unexplored territory of public finance,'' Mr. White said. **********Social Security revenue not needed to cover current pension checks goes into a trust fund credited with interest at Treasury bond rates. But as every sophisticated investor knows, equities have proved to be a much better deal than bonds over the long haul. The real return to common stocks over the last 70 years has exceeded 7 percent, while Treasury bonds have averaged less than 2 percent. **********So why should baby boomers be deprived of the gain? Why, indeed: Mr. Ball, along with four other members of the 13-member advisory panel proposes to shovel $800 billion of the roughly $2 trillion trust fund surplus projected between 2000 and 2015 into stocks. Quadrupling the estimated return on this portion of the surplus would relieve the pressure to cut benefits or raise taxes to keep Social Security going. **********But Joseph Quinn, an economist at Boston College, wonders whether changes in economic behavior would mirror the accounting shuffle. The point of reform, he suggests, is either to increase national savings to pay for the boomers' retirement or to cut their claims on future national income. And forcing the Treasury to find other buyers for $800 billion in bonds to finance Government deficits would be self-defeating since no one would be induced to save more or consume less. **********On the other hand, if Congress cut the deficit when trust fund surpluses were unavailable to paper it over, national savings probably would rise. Were Congress so moved, though, it would not need Mr. Ball to pull up its fiscal socks. **********Not so fast. If an extra $800 billion went into private investments with four times the return of Treasuries, wouldn't the economy grow more rapidly and add to the nation's capacity to cover the cost of the boomers' retirement? **********No one is quite sure where the historical ''equity premium'' -- the extra return on common stock that apparently reflects much more than the amount needed to compensate investors for added risk -- comes from, suggests Stephen Zeldes, an economist at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business. ''If we could be sure that the premium would be sustained -- a big if -- there would be no need to use Social Security's funding problems to justify the switch,'' he said. It would pay simply to sell more Government bonds and invest the proceeds in the stock market. **********Mr. White raises a different issue. Presumably the Government would be a passive investor, buying stocks the way index mutual funds do. But would Uncle Sam limit purchases to the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index when thousands of other stocks beckoned? Would it stop at traded stocks, when millions of small businesses need capital? And what about social considerations? Would Washington invest in tobacco, or in companies that run sweatshops in Guatemala? ''Passive investing is tougher than its sounds,'' Mr. White said. **********One need not look far to understand the origins of the Ball plan. Like many Americans -- probably a majority -- Mr. Ball wants to keep a 60-year-old system on its tried-and-true path, using collective resources to provide funds for generous public pensions for all. From this perspective, circuitous means of replenishing the trust fund are justified if the public will not stand for straightforward ones like tax increases. **********But simply assuming the higher returns of stocks save the day raises the political ante. If Americans don't save more as a consequence or if economic growth does not exceed soberer expectations, the cuts needed to fix Social Security a decade or two down the road will be far greater than they are today. In short, what Americans choose not to know now could hurt later on.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/08/busin.snippet: Sun Microsystems chief executive Scott G McNealy recalls summer job as teen-ager at Roger Penske's car dealership; photos (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/08/busin.body_text: **********Almost every day during the summer of 1972, Scott G. McNealy pushed a broom around the lot of Roger Penske's Chevrolet dealership in downtown Detroit. But that simple job gave him his first taste of pressure. Because also every day, Mr. Penske would walk the lot, making sure that not one cigarette butt was left on the ground. **********''It was always a big kick for me to say, 'Ha, you didn't find anything,' '' Mr. McNealy says today. **********He worked as part of a four-man crew that unloaded new cars from delivery trucks and then washed the cars, preparing them for sale. Later, he graduated to parking cars on the lot. On weekends, he worked as part of the pit crew for Mr. Penske's racing team. **********He was initially paid $1.75 an hour. ''One of the other porters was getting $2.25 an hour and I was doing way more work than him,'' he recalls. ''I had to plead and argue and demand a 25-cent-an-hour raise to $2.'' **********Mr. McNealy started working at the dealership at 17 and loved the job so much that even after he left for Harvard a year later, he returned for the summers. His future, he figured, was in the auto industry. **********''I always thought I'd run a tool-and-die shop,'' he says. **********Mr. McNealy says his first job showed him how to run a business. And it taught him that little things count. **********''Penske was meticulous and paid attention to detail,'' Mr. McNealy recalls. ''He would pull a string across the bumpers of the cars,'' to see if they were parked straight, ''and all the bumpers would have to touch the string.'' **********''His attention to customer satisfaction and organization was fabulous,'' he says. **********For what he learned on that job, ''I'd give up all my college and business school classes,'' he says. He would even work for Mr. Penske again. **********''He could still hire me,'' Mr. McNealy says. ''He's my hero.''   SHARON R. KING
