https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/03/busin.main_headline: Economic Data Cause Selloff in Long Bonds
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/03/busin.print_headline: Economic Data Cause Selloff in Long Bonds
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/03/busin.body_text: **********Treasury prices were mixed yesterday, with the shorter maturities showing some strength, but with the longer maturities being hammered, as traders reacted uncertainly to the day's employment report. **********Traders said the short end of the market was supported by buyers anticipating more cuts in interest rates by the Federal Reserve on the heels of the overall weak economic reports. **********The long end of the market would normally stage a rally on weak numbers like yesterday's nonfarm payroll data, which showed a loss of 201,000 jobs last month. Such signs of a slowing economy are taken as indicators that inflation will be weak. The long bonds did not, however, follow the usual script yesterday as the Clinton Administration said that the job market might actually have improved last month but that the numbers failed to show that because the data were skewed by the Northeast blizzard and the partial shutdown of the Government. **********Given the vagaries of the weather, the long end of the government securities  market seemed to place more emphasis on other factors, like higher commodity prices, that might suggest a rise in inflation and on the looming supply of new  debt issues coming to market in the next week. **********The 30-year bond dropped 110/32 , to 10922/32 for a yield of 6.16 percent, up from 6.07 percent on Thursday. The two-year note held steady at 4.90 percent. **********The Treasury will be selling about $84.9 billion in new debt securities next  week, with $44.5 billion of that representing the Government's quarterly refunding, much of it in long maturities. **********Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisers Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said, "For some market participants, the weak employment report today may have been skewed by a number of factors including the blizzard on the East Coast, the strike in New York and the temporary Government shutdown." He was referring to the strike by building maintenance workers in New York City. **********He also noted as reasons for some of the market's fears, the high daily reading of commodity prices, the stronger-than-expected numbers in a Columbia University inflation index and the surge in hourly earnings. **********"Although many market participants reasoned that the loss of many jobs at the low end of the wage structure during the month may have overly boosted the average hourly earnings numbers," Mr. Chan said, "others were not as quick to discount the previous month's strength, which could not be blamed on the same factor." **********"In a market which has thrived on the expectation of future Fed easings, most market players quickly realized that if inflation were to accelerate, then bonds would decline," he said. **********Hamilton Davis, a vice president of government trading at Everen Securities Inc. in Chicago, attributed a good part of the higher bond yields to the coming  refunding, particularly given the large amount of longer maturities involved. He also said that all the weakness in the January payroll data could not be explained away by weather conditions. **********"So you have a technical condition where buyers are more comfortable buying shorter maturities believing that the Fed is on their side," Mr. Davis said. "Consequently dealers of Treasury securities view the refunding as an opportunity to make money on a setup trade." **********Mr. Davis described the weakness in bonds as dealers' positioning themselves  to buy the longer maturities next week at yields that would give them the potential for price improvement after the auctions were over. **********In when-issued trading, the three-year note to be auctioned on Tuesday was offered at a price to yield 5.02 percent. The 10-year note to be sold on Wednesday was at 5.65 percent and the 30-year bond, set for a Thursday auction,  was at 6.09 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/12/world.body_text: **********Explosives experts found a bomb today outside a naval hospital where a former military doctor in Argentina's so-called dirty war remained in critical condition after being riddled with bullets in an attack by a leftist guerrilla group last week. **********The doctor, Jorge Berges, was sentenced in 1986 to six and a half years in prison for torturing pregnant prisoners and selling their babies for adoption in the 1970's, but was later freed under an amnesty. **********On Saturday he was shot more than 20 times by two members of a leftist guerrilla group, the People's Revolutionary Organization, the latest in a series of attacks and threats coinciding with the 20th anniversary of the March 24, 1976, military coup that ushered in a military dictatorship. **********Interior Minister Carlos Corach said that today's bomb was a home-made device that was later detonated by a police bomb squad.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/26/world.snippet: Kosevo Hospital, which was at center of Serbian siege of Sarajevo, Bosnia, is showing signs of recovery; shells no longer thump down on trauma unit, and for first time in four years doctors and nurses are taking vacations; water and electricity ha...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/26/world.main_headline: Peace Brings New Kinds of Work to Sarajevo Hospital
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/26/world.print_headline: Peace Brings New Kinds of Work to Sarajevo Hospital
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/26/world.body_text: **********There are no more shells thumping down on the trauma unit at Kosevo Hospital here, and for the first time in four summers, doctors and nurses are taking vacations. Water and electricity come regularly now. **********When Biljana Jandric, a staff librarian, wants a cup of coffee, she no longer has to sneak off to the morgue, where powerful disinfectants burned better than most things for boiling a pot of water. **********''Peace for us is very nice,'' said Dr. Ismet Gavrankapetanovic, an orthopedic surgeon who for three years more or less lived inside the hospital, performing hundreds of amputations among thousands of operations as he and a small, overworked staff of doctors tended to nearly all of the people -- well over 50,000 -- wounded in the Bosnian Serbs' siege of Sarajevo. **********But the war has never really left Kosevo. And, as is true around Bosnia in almost every corner of life, peace has brought its own problems. **********In the children's ward that he oversees, Dr. Gavrankapetanovic tended to a bruised and groaning boy about 5 years old, his head stitched in several places, an arm and a leg in bandages. **********''He needs some rest,'' the doctor said. ''But he must not fall asleep.'' Another boy, Maid Bucman, 7, leaning on a pair of crutches, looked on. **********The first boy, the doctor said, was hit by a car -- something that is more and more common these days as Sarajevans career through the streets, unused to driving after nearly four years of leaving their cars in storage. And the second boy's left foot was blown off in Mostar by an anti-personnel mine. **********Mine wounds are the most common serious injuries seen at the hospital since the fighting and shelling stopped late last year. **********''In the future, I'm afraid we will have more of this,'' Dr. Gavrankapetanovic said. **********Perhaps no single place in Bosnia witnessed more of the war's horror than Kosevo Hospital, a huge complex of boxy buildings on a hill in north Sarajevo that sat in clear sight of Bosnian Serb shelling positions. **********The numbers alone are staggering. Dr. Fuad Sisic, a chief surgeon here, published a grimly illustrated book this year on the art of war medicine. **********In it, he compiled the statistics for the first three years. In 1992, for example, the hospital treated 22,549 people wounded. That works out to 1,879 people a month, 62 people a day. The worst day that year was June 8, when 332 people came in wounded. **********The numbers do not show that surgeons often worked by flashlight on floors that stayed streaked with blood because no one wanted to spend the precious commodity of water to clean it. **********Dr. Mufid Lazovic, the deputy director of the trauma ward, said one day in particular stood out. In 1992, eight people were killed and many more were wounded in a mortar attack in the old town of Sarajevo. He operated on several little girls, all terribly mangled. It turned out that he knew them all. **********''All of them were my neighbors,'' Dr. Lazovic said, speaking at first with detachment but then with rising emotion. ''I didn't recognize them. After the surgery the parents arrived and asked about their children -- then I realized who they were.'' **********Dr. Gavrankapetanovic, a big and buoyant man who is only 33, poked his head out a window and pointed out a huge hole in the building's concrete side where a Serbian shell had hit. **********''Look, that was where it hit first,'' he said. Then he opened the door to Room 123 to show the hole where the shell blasted through on its way down the corridor, wounding three people but luckily killing no one. **********But around the hospital there are slow signs of recovery. Just last week, workers installed equipment to insure a constant supply of water to all the buildings, which is still not the case around Sarajevo. **********One morgue worker remembered that on his first day of work, June 12, 1992, there were 250 bodies stacked inside, with refrigeration space for only 10. In the last week, only 13 bodies arrived to be stored there -- all people who died of natural causes. **********Ms. Jandric, the librarian, reported that she now weighs 140 pounds, up from 100 pounds at the worst time of the war. **********''We are fat now,'' she said, ''but during the war we were very thin.'' **********Doctors and nurses are finally being paid, which was not the case during much of the war. And, just as Kosevo had to shift abruptly from being a regular hospital to a war ward, it is now faces the issue of how to return, as long as peace lasts, back to a regular hospital. **********''There are a lot of changes,'' Dr. Lazovic said. ''There is not as much tension as it used to be. So we are looking at different kinds of problems. How do we organize ourselves? What kind of salaries should we have? **********''We are going from socialism to capitalism, from war to peace.'' **********The doctor stood up to go on a quick round through the ward. He stopped to talk to Ostoja Obradovic, 42, a former soldier who first came to the trauma unit in November 1994 when he lost much of a leg to a mine. But what was left of his leg began hurting again, and he required more treatment. **********Another patient, Ripet Hairic, 38, never received proper care when his hip was shattered two years ago after a grenade hit the car he was driving. Now he lay waiting for a reconstructive operation, with several pins in his side. **********The doctor stopped to talk to a woman, who is 67 but looked a decade or more older. He said her screams at night were waking up other patients. She is a Muslim refugee from Srebrenica, where perhaps 5,000 Muslims were massacred by Bosnian Serbs. And she was dreaming about her five sons, whom she never heard from, the doctor said. **********Dr. Lazovic said the war, and all the sorrows that echoed through Kosevo's halls, had worked a change on him and his colleagues. **********''You can see what in life really counts,'' he said. ''Material things are not so important. You learn how to be happy.'' **********Dr. Gavrankapetanovic said he was pleased that Sarajevo was not so cut off anymore, even if he had no success yet in finding doctors outside Bosnia to send him new medical books, which he has not been able to read for four years. ''We now have a connection with the outside world,'' he said. ''You can get in a car and go to the country. You can go to the coast.'' **********''But it's not like before the war,'' he added. ''We are old. We know so much. We still remember the things that happened here. It's lucky we have a brain so we can forget some things.'' **********A woman called Dr. Gavrankapetanovic into the hallway and gave him a small fold of bills. It was his salary, still a novel enough idea that he smiled broadly. ''Yes, yes,'' he said, sliding the money into his chest pocket. ''The coast.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/27/world.main_headline: PERES AND HIS FOE DO VERBAL BATTLE IN SOLE TV DEBATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/27/world.print_headline: PERES AND HIS FOE DO VERBAL BATTLE IN SOLE TV DEBATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/27/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Shimon Peres and Benjamin Netanyahu squared off today for their first and only direct showdown of the Israeli election campaign, a televised debate in which Mr. Peres pitted his experience, decorum and vision against his challenger's youth, television skills and aggressiveness. **********"I have no doubt in the path we are leading," Mr. Peres declared in a voice that rarely veered from a low and measured drone. He stared evenly at the moderator and invoked his long record in government, the legacy of his assassinated predecessor, Yitzhak Rabin, and the hope of a comprehensive Middle  East peace. **********The way of Mr. Peres brought neither peace to Israel nor real security," Mr. Netanyahu fired back with a stern glance at his opponent. "It brings us fear." His gestures underscored his central theme that the Labor Government had  sacrificed the safety of Israelis in a misguided search for peace. **********After 30 minutes of this, the general sense among commentators was that Mr. Netanyahu, the Likud Party leader, had confirmed his vastly superior on-camera skills but that Mr. Peres had come off as more substantive. **********But there was no immediate indication whether either candidate had made much  of a dent in the crucial cluster of undecided votes with 60 hours to go before the polling booths open on Wednesday. Takers of opinion polls said the race was  still too close to call. **********The televised debate was more a joint news conference, with the moderator, Dan Margalit, posing questions to the candidates by turns. **********In the tightly controlled campaign, it was the only time Mr. Peres and Mr. Netanyahu were seen together. Aside from this debate, Israeli rules bar the candidates from being seen on television or heard on radio for the last 21 days  of the campaign. **********Although similar debates were held in previous elections, this is the first time that Israelis are voting separately for Prime Minister and for Parliament.  As a result, it is the first race in which Israelis have focused sharply on individuals, and the debate was heavily touted as a chance for voters to take the real measure of the contenders. **********For the first time in the campaign, Mr. Margalit, a respected political commentator, challenged each candidate on his personal weak spot -- Mr. Peres, 72, on his age, and Mr. Netanyahu on an admitted extramarital affair and his three marriages. Both sides had largely refrained from personal attacks in the campaign. **********Mr. Peres came back with one of his few touches of humor: "If you had to elect a male model and not a Prime Minister, then the age would be an issue. I feel great. My ability to work is excellent. I know a lot of people who are young, but their thoughts are very old." **********Mr. Netanyahu replied to Mr. Margalit's question as he did to nearly every other one, turning it against Mr. Peres: "Concerning this matter that you bring  up now, I expressed a lot of sorrow. It hurt me. It hurt my wife. It hurt my family. It was a mistake. But the mistake that Mr. Peres made, that he is making now, that he made in the last four years, hurts the whole people of Israel. People here live in fear." **********Mr. Margalit also raised a question about whether Mr. Netanyahu's application to change his name to Ben Nitay while he was living in the United States in the  1970's meant that he thought of staying there. Mr. Netanyahu still holds American as well as Israeli citizenship. **********"Not for a single moment," Mr. Netanyahu declared. "I come from a Jewish, Zionist family, with roots here for 100 years." Then came the invariable attack  on Mr. Peres: "It is not enough, Mr. Peres, to pose with children. You have to insure their security." **********That was Mr. Netanyahu's tactic throughout the debate. When asked what he would do about Jewish settlements in the West Bank, or about civil rights, or about the economy, he virtually disregarded the questions and instead attacked Mr. Peres and his Government's peace agreements with the Palestinians. **********He described an Israel living in fear as a direct result of his opponent's policies. "Our children are afraid to get on a bus," he said. "Many of you who are watching us now are getting up in the morning and ask themselves whether the next attack will happen today. Mr. Peres, you brought our security situation to  a nadir." **********Demonstrating careful preparation, Mr. Netanyahu twice talked of moving forward "with the help of God" -- an obvious nod to the critical Orthodox vote -- and he avoided mentioning the revered Mr. Rabin, who was assassinated in November, focusing all of his attacks on Mr. Peres and the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat. **********But Mr. Peres rarely took note of Mr. Netanyahu. At the end, when each candidate got his only chance to ask the other a direct question, Mr. Peres dismissively said, "I have no question for Mr. Netanyahu." He then went on to ask one anyway, disguised as a "request." **********His approach was to emphasize his experience and the agreements reached with  Arab countries. He spoke of suddenly having to continue Mr. Rabin's work. **********"Rabin was murdered in front of my eyes," Mr. Peres said. "Otherwise it would have been he who would be sitting here in my place. The messenger was murdered,  but not the message." **********Commentators and political scientists who watched the debate generally agreed that Mr. Netanyahu had the better delivery but Mr. Peres had the better message. **********"If the question was who would get the role of Othello, there is no doubt Netanyahu would win," said Shimon Schiffer, a commentator with the daily Yediot  Ahronot. "But the Israeli voter asks himself who do I believe, who do I trust more, and I think Shimon Peres came out as the more serious candidate with a real background." **********But at this stage, the real question is whether Mr. Netanyahu swayed enough undecided voters to overcome a deficit of several points in the opinion polls. Hanoch Smith, who has conducted polls in the last several elections, said two-thirds of the undecided voters had voted for the Likud last time, and only one-third for Labor, so if Mr. Netanyahu could prevail on wavering Likud supporters to return to his fold, he would narrow the gap considerably. **********Though Israel has no previous experience with direct elections, Mr. Smith said, the power of the debate is sure to be "enormous." **********Mr. Schiffer said Mr. Netanyahu had made a credible appeal to the waverers. "If the assumption is that the floating voters are leaning to the right and asking questions about personal security," he said, "they probably heard some good answers from Netanyahu. He was very firm. He promised to continue the peace process with more caution." **********But several others said they felt that Mr. Netanyahu had failed to overcome his major handicap in the campaign: the sense that he had neither the experience nor the plan to provide the security he promised. **********"He's running a campaign of intimidation, and not projecting an alternate visition," said David Makovsky, a political reporter for the Jerusalem Post. "With Peres, you know what he's going to do. With Bibi" -- Mr. Netanyahu's nickname -- "you still don't know."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/17/world.main_headline: World News Briefs;U.S. Warns Americans Living in Saudi Arabia
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/17/world.print_headline: World News Briefs;U.S. Warns Americans Living in Saudi Arabia
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/17/world.body_text: **********The State Department, concerned about the threat of another attack on American institutions in Saudi Arabia, issued a warning today to Americans throughout the kingdom. **********The statement, issued here and in Riyadh, said the American Embassy there has received an anonymous telephone call threatening retaliation if four Saudis charged in a bombing six months ago are punished. **********The attack, at a United States-run military institution in Riyadh, killed five Americans and two Indians. Scores of others were wounded. **********In a televised statement last month, the four Saudis claimed responsibility for the bombing and said their action was inspired by militant Islamic groups in the region. **********They said they obtained the explosives from neighboring Yemen. **********The statement today said the Embassy and consulates have been sent drawings that imply bomb threats against American personnel, including the Saudi-American International School in Riyadh.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/18/world.snippet: Clinton Administration bid to find replacement for United Nations Sec Gen Boutros Boutros-Ghali before Nov Presidential election meets resistance in Security Council, where other members feel no urgency to schedule debate soon; United States handl...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/18/world.main_headline: U.S. Effort To Replace U.N. Chief Gets Nowhere
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/18/world.print_headline: U.S. Effort To Replace U.N. Chief Gets Nowhere
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/18/world.body_text: **********The Clinton Administration's plan to find a replacement for Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali before the Presidential election in November has run into a wall of resistance in the Security Council. **********When Tono Eitel, Germany's representative at the United Nations and this month's Security Council president, polled delegations in recent days, he found only one, the American, that wanted to schedule a debate on the issue any time soon. **********Diplomats from countries on the 15-member Council say the consensus among the 14 others is that there is no urgency to act, in part because a Secretary General has usually been chosen later in the year and in part because the Clinton Administration, with its record of policy shifts, may change its mind after the election. **********''The United States has made its position clear, and therefore people who think that we might change our minds are wrong,'' Madeleine K. Albright, the American representative, said this week. ''This is a big deal, electing a Secretary General of the United Nations. It can't be made in the closing hours of December.'' **********The Administration, which says Mr. Boutros-Ghali has been ineffective in reforming the United Nations, has threatened to use the American veto to block him from a second five-year term. His current term ends on Dec. 31. **********Ms. Albright, on the defensive against the widespread belief among diplomats that the Administration's campaign against Mr. Boutros-Ghali arose from the politics of the Presidential race, said the decision ''was made in the most responsible way.'' **********The American determination to replace the Secretary General was leaked to the press by Secretary of State Warren Christopher in June without first notifying other United Nations delegations. This, plus subsequent efforts by the Administration to belittle Mr. Boutros-Ghali's achievements and its warning to United Nations staff members not to use their positions to campaign for his re-election, have generated new sympathy for the Secretary General. **********The uncooperative attitude of European and other nations here also reflects unease in many capitals toward American efforts to impede commercial relations that foreign companies and citizens have with other countries -- particularly Cuba, Iran and Libya. President Clinton has signed laws that threaten to punish foreigners for trade and investment with Cuba because of its shooting down of unarmed civilian planes in February and with Iran and Libya because the United States considers them sponsors of terrorism. **********At the United Nations, delegations have not responded to American calls to help find a replacement for Mr. Boutros-Ghali, who has received formal if tepid support from African and Arab nations and from China. French diplomats say President Jacques Chirac has also been supportive. Indeed, many here ask if the United States can find a better candidate than Mr. Boutros-Ghali, an Egyptian diplomat who has presided over the largest staff and budget cuts in United Nations history. **********Ms. Albright said countries that ''insist on supporting Boutros-Ghali, rather than working to find a candidate who is somebody who will have the general confidence not only of the United States but others,'' should understand that the American decision is irrevocable. **********''One of the reasons we made the decision when we did was to allow other candidates to come forward,'' she said. ''I think that it is a little bit irresponsible not to be more active for other Council members in terms of trying to figure out how the process ought to work.'' **********Although the Secretary General and Ms. Albright have exchanged barbed comments on policy issues, they worked together reasonably well, United Nations officials say. Officials and diplomats are puzzled by the harsh language about the Secretary General that has emanated from the State Department in recent months. The United Nations spokesman's office has produced copies of effusive toasts Mr. Clinton made to Mr. Boutros-Ghali at the United Nations' 50th anniversary lunch last fall and at times before. **********''The President is in favor of a strong United Nations,'' Ms. Albright said. ''He has personal respect for Boutros-Ghali, something that he indicated at the 50th anniversary toast. After all, Boutros-Ghali was the host of the party, and the President is a very well brought-up and highly polite person. I do not think I would read too much into a toast.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/13/busin.snippet: The post-colonial future is suddenly looking rocky for Hong Kong Telecommunications Ltd. as concerns about Hong Kong's transition to Chinese rule next year and industry deregulation worldwide combine to cloud its prospects..On Wednesday, as its st...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/13/busin.body_text: **********The post-colonial future is suddenly looking rocky for Hong Kong Telecommunications Ltd. as concerns about Hong Kong's transition to Chinese rule next year and industry deregulation worldwide combine to cloud its prospects. **********On Wednesday, as its stock finished at a low for 1996, the company said it would seek compensation from the local government if it had to surrender any of the monopoly rights it had been granted on international telephone services until 2006. **********But until the company confirmed late Tuesday that talks on those rights were under way, few people knew that the terms regulating a business that contributed more than half of its 29.4 billion Hong Kong dollars ($3.8 billion) in sales last year were up for review **********The news followed the sale on Monday by one of its major shareholders, CITIC Pacific Ltd. a company controlled by China's governing State Council, of a 2 percent stake in the company for 3 billion Hong Kong dollars to an unidentified buyer. **********Although CITIC Pacific, an offshoot of an investment holding company owned by China's State Council, retains an 8 percent stake in Hong Kong Telecom, the sale — at a 6 percent discount to the stock's previous closing price — increased concerns that the company's roster of shareholders faces continued change in the months ahead. **********CITIC Pacific's stake in Hong Kong Telecom has long been viewed as the telecommunications concern's "insurance policy" against interference by Chinese officials uncomfortable with a British company dominating the local telephone market. **********On Tuesday, Hong Kong Telecom's share price fell nearly 3 percent as investors weighed CITIC Pacific's decision to reduce its stake in a business 57.5 percent owned by Britain's Cable & Wireless PLC. The shares slipped a further 1.1 percent Wednesday, closing at 13.65 dollars. **********"Hong Kong Telecom would be paid for any economic loss suffered by it resulting from any amendment to the exclusivities in the license," the company said in a statement released Wednesday about the talks on its international service monopoly. **********Analysts, however, said they doubted negotiations would turn out that simply. They cited the Hong Kong government's need to match other countries' liberalization moves in telecommunications talks at the World Trade Organization and the likelihood that such compensation payments would need China's approval.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/01/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;2 Companies Pick Campbell Mithun

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/01/busin.body_text: **********The Nabisco Biscuit Company unit of RJR Nabisco Holdings and Conagra Inc. have selected Campbell Mithun Esty in Minneapolis to introduce a line of premium-priced, low-fat cookies and bread crisps under the Healthy Choice brand  name, which Nabisco is licensing from Conagra. Billings were not disclosed, but  Brandweek reported that advertising and promotional spending would total $10 million to $15 million. **********Campbell Mithun, which is owned by top managers and the Interpublic Group of Companies, was awarded the assignment without a review; it is the lead agency for various Healthy Choice products like frozen dinners and deli meats. The new  products, aimed at the Pepperidge Farm line of baked goods marketed by the Campbell Soup Company, will come in varieties like apricot and raspberry tart and cinnamon raisin.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/18/busin.print_headline: Venture in Japan In Satellite TV
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/18/busin.body_text: **********The News Corporation of Australia and Softbank Inc. of Japan will spend 20 billion yen ($176 million) to start a satellite television service in Japan, the last big market not part of Rupert Murdoch's global network. **********The venture, the Japan Sky Broadcasting Company, with 150 channels, will compete with the satellite broadcasters PerfecTV and DirecTV to bring multichannel systems to Japanese viewers, who have had only a handful of networks to choose from. **********''For News Corporation, J Sky B becomes a key member in our family of worldwide satellite and cable broadcasting platforms,'' Mr. Murdoch, chairman of the company, said in Tokyo today. **********Mr. Murdoch was named chairman of the Japanese operation. **********The venture will be 80 percent financed by Softbank and 20 percent by the News Corporation. **********J Sky B will begin test- broadcasting 12 channels in April. J Sky B plans eventually to operate 150 channels.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/01/busin.body_text: **********Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C., the world's largest pharmaceutical company, said yesterday that growth in sales of new drugs led to a strong jump in earnings for the first six months of the year. The profit figure topped analyst forecasts, which peaked at $:1.50 billion, or $2.33 billion. Glaxo said pretax profit rose to $:1.55 billion from $:1.16 billion, despite a 16 percent drop in sales of its anti-ulcer drug, Zantac. **********The company's chief executive, Sir Richard Sykes, said growth from new products -- like the asthma drug Serevent and the anti-migraine drug Imigran -- would make up for Zantac, which faces the loss of its crucial United States patent in July 1997. https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/26/busin.print_headline: 2 Editors Quit Outdoor Life After Article Is Killed
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/26/busin.body_text: **********The two top editors of Outdoor Life magazine resigned in protest yesterday after an executive at Times Mirror, which owns the publication, pulled an article on bear baiting that was to have run in the September issue. **********Stephen W. Byers, the magazine's editor in chief, who had been at the magazine about a year, and Will Bourne, the executive editor, who had been there since February, quit, effective immediately. **********It was one of those situations where you either sucked it up and quit," Mr. Bourne said, "or you don't and are forced to live with yourself and represent something that you think is essentially gutless." **********The article in question had been critical of bear baiting, in which raw fish  or meat is set out in heavily timbered areas to attract black bears that would otherwise be difficult for hunters to see. The practice is illegal in parts of the country, and legislation to ban it will be up for a vote in states such as Michigan and Oregon in November. **********The article, called "Failure of the Spirit," was written by Tom Beck, a Colorado biologist and hunter whom some hunters view as anti-hunter. **********The editors expected the piece to elicit strong reactions from the magazine's six million readers, saying they were trying to move Outdoor Life into a more provocative direction. "I don't think people stop reading magazines because you  make them mad," Mr. Byers said. "I think the magazine desperately needs vitality." **********Mr. Bourne described Outdoor Life's category -- which includes the magazines  Field and Stream and Sports Afield -- as an "essentially defunct genre," a result largely of a reluctance to take editorial risks. "This is the sort of world where no questions have been asked for a long time," he said. "And a bunker mentality has really set in." **********The article on bear baiting was to have appeared in a new section, called "Hunter's Voice," to be introduced in the September issue. Word of the article leaked out and the magazine was besieged with faxes, E-mail notes and phone calls from hunters' rights groups. **********On Wednesday, a senior vice president, Jason Klein, killed the article. Mr. Klein declined comment. The magazine's publisher, Michael Rooney referred all calls to Mr. Klein. **********A company spokeswoman, Martha Goldstein, said the article was rejected because it did not meet the magazine's standards of "providing balanced and informed coverage of hunting ethics and practices." She said the decision was supported by several other editors at the magazine.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/22/busin.snippet: USAir Group Inc reports third-quarter earnings of $67.7 million, compared with $43.1 million year earlier; earnings chart (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/22/busin.body_text: **********USAir Group Inc. said yesterday that its earnings rose 57 percent in the third quarter, reflecting strong demand for international flights. **********The company, based in Arlington, Va., earned $67.7 million, or 69 cents a share, compared with $43.1 million, or 35 cents a share, a year earlier. The per-share results reflect payment of preferred stock dividends.  Revenue rose nearly 11 percent, to $2.07 billion from $1.87 billion. **********Wall Street expected the company to earn 61 cents a share, based on a survey of nine analysts by I.B.E.S. International Inc. **********The shares of USAir rose 25 cents yesterday, to $16.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********The quarterly results reflect a $41.1 million provision in the 1996 quarter and a $15.1 million provision in the 1995 quarter for an employee profit-sharing plan that was initiated four years ago. **********USAir's third-quarter financial performance was ''good; it's not great,'' said Susan Donofrio, an analyst with NatWest Securities in New York. ''It's good that it's profitable, but costs continue to creep up.'' **********Increases in fuel prices for the most recent quarter reduced the earnings compared with the 1995 quarter, Ms. Donofrio added. **********The average weekly cost for jet fuel during the third quarter of 1996 was 67.74 cents a gallon, up from 53.22 cents in the 1995 quarter. **********The company said its improved results were largely a result of increased demand for international flights. USAir said its international business increased 57 percent from a year earlier, mainly because of new flights to Europe from Philadelphia. **********Over all, demand for USAir flights rose 6.3 percent for the quarter. Planes were flying at 70 percent of capacity, an increase of 3 percentage points from a year earlier. **********Stephen M. Wolf, the chairman and chief executive, said airline companies continued to ''benefit from positive economic conditions.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/29/world.main_headline: Wary Britons Turning Backs on Beef
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/29/world.print_headline: Wary Britons Turning Backs on Beef
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/29/world.body_text: **********No doubt it was a scene played out in countless grocery stores across Britain over the last week: An elderly man and his wife stood looking at the mountain of packaged beef in the Waitrose store on King's Road in Chelsea. **********"But we've had roast beef every Sunday for as long as I can remember," he protested. "I'm 72 years old. What's my chances of getting it before I die?" **********It" is a new variant of Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease, a deadly brain affliction that scientists say may have been passed on to humans through beef infected with bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease. **********And despite repeated Government statements that the chances of contracting the disease from roasts and other beef products are remote, most British consumers are boycotting beef. **********"I'll never eat beef again," said Sylvia Carswell as she hurried past a McDonald's on Victoria Street around lunchtime. "I don't trust the Government an inch." **********McDonald's took out full-page advertisements in newspapers today to herald the return of Big Macs made with "non-British beef." The fast-food company, which has 660 restaurants in Britain, stopped selling beef burgers on Sunday until it could get supply lines set up to import beef. **********Nonetheless, the company said it still believed British beef was safe and would use it again "when public confidence in it has been restored." **********That may be awhile. The credibility of the Conservative Government, which is  shaky already, has been undermined by the way it has handled the issue. **********First, the Government created a panic with its sudden announcement on March 20 about a possible connection between mad cow disease and the new variant of Creutzfeldt-Jakob. Then it incited angry confusion five days later when its scientists concluded that the risk from eating beef was minute. **********"They've been twisting everything," said Joe Akonea, a janitor at Victoria Station, summing up the sentiment of a number of people interviewed today. **********Sophie Craven, a bank teller, said:"They can't seem to get their story straight, can they? I won't eat beef again for a long time, if ever again." **********The beef scare has disrupted life for many here, but not everyone. A market research group, Nielsen, reported today that sales of beef had plunged 70 percent on Thursday and Friday of last week but recovered somewhat on Saturday,  when consumers bought 25 percent less beef than they had the previous Saturday. **********Tony Nell, who sells newspapers at a stand near Victoria Station, said the scale of popular concern was "ridiculous." Although he conceded there might be a link between the diseases, he observed, "We're all going to die some day." **********The controversy has played into the hands of those who are opposed to Britain's increasing ties with Europe. The European Union ordered a ban on all exports of British beef, but the Government of Prime Minister John Major has called the ban unjustified and questioned whether the European Union was legally able to ban exports to nonmember countries, points Mr. Major promised to bring up at a weekend meeting of European leaders in Turin, Italy. **********Norman Lamont, a Tory Member of Parliament who opposes further British integration into Europe, urged Mr. Major to take no further steps until the European Union rescinds its ban on British beef. Meanwhile, the Government is weighing proposals to kill older cattle in Britain in an effort to restore consumer confidence and prod the European Union to lift the export ban. **********Whatever its political and economic ramifications, the beef scare has not been without its humor. The headline on the section devoted to British food in Time Out magazine's annual restaurant guide reads, "Innards are in, as investigators into the indigenous cuisine are discovering Britain's offal past." **********The guide then goes on to highlight a number of restaurants serving calves liver, kidneys, brains and bone marrow, including the Butlers Wharf Chop House and St. John, a trendy eatery in Covent Garden. **********"It's rather unfortunate in hindsight," said Phil Harriss, the food reviewer  who wrote the section. "Calves liver and the like were getting quite fashionable in London restaurants, but I don't think it will be fashionable for much longer." **********Christine Cort, the marketing manager for the guide, stressed that the guide  would be "fully revised" in October. "It changes every year," she said. "Completely." **********A spokesman at St. John, who refused to give his name, said the restaurant is not commenting on the national debate over beef. But he hastened to add that its famous roast bone marrow on toast comes from Dutch cattle. **********Andreas, the deputy general manager at Butlers Wharf, who uses only one name, said beef brains had only been a seasonal item on its menu and had not been served in months. **********Andreas offered assurances that the beef served in the restaurant came from a rare breed that only eats natural feeds like hay, straw and cereals and faxed over a statement from the supplier, Chesterton Farm Shop, to that effect. **********"It's also certified by the Ministry of Agriculture," he said, "although I don't suppose that matters any more." **********For his part, Mr. Harriss, the reviewer, said he has not eaten any beef, offal or otherwise, since the Government's announcement last week. "I'm reviewing curry houses right now," he said. "They don't usually use beef in curries, thank God."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/25/busin.print_headline: Stores Say Kodak Is Slow With New Camera
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/25/busin.body_text: **********The Eastman Kodak Company is falling short on delivering to retailers its new Advantix camera, part of an easy-to-use photo system that was intended to help raise sales industrywide, camera sellers said today. **********Kodak began shipping the camera last month. But camera stores are complaining that Kodak underestimated demand, leaving thousands of orders unfilled and slowing sales momentum for the new product, which was developed with several other companies. **********We're all kind of embarrassed over this entire situation," said Bob Lathrop, senior vice president and general manager of consumer products at the United States arm of the Minolta Company, one of the creators of the system. **********Minolta's version of the camera, called Vectis, was delayed one month to fix  a problem with a magnetic strip essential to developing photos taken with the camera, Mr. Lathrop said. The camera is now being shipped, he said. **********Several stores said they had received only a handful of the cameras and had thousands on back order. **********Kodak said it was shipping as many of the cameras as planned. The company began sending cameras to stores on April 22 and accepted about two million orders. Kodak officials declined to say how many cameras had been shipped but said the company planned to fill the two million orders this year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/04/busin.snippet: Some workers comment on summer employment; drawing (L)L
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/04/busin.body_text: **********Summer jobs? They're usually at the bottom, looking up -- difficult, frustrating, low-paying. But the rewards aren't to be measured in money. Who can put a value on grit and self-knowledge, hard-earned but good for a lifetime? **********''I am a fact checker at a history magazine, which basically means that I get $8 an hour to be the kind of sniveling nerd that most people avoid at parties,'' writes Dara Horn of Short Hills, N.J. ''The editors give me articles for upcoming issues, and my job is to verify every single fact in every single written sentence that goes into the magazine, noting that I've checked each word by placing a dot over it (and by placing a dot over each letter of every proper noun to show I've verified the spelling).'' **********She has checked the height of the lock gate at Gatun in the Panama Canal and is on a first-name basis with most of the reference librarians at the New York Public Library. **********She knows the number of troops (28,000) that crossed the Mississippi with Grant at Bruinsburg, a town that no longer exists; the price ($3.50) of the glow-in-the-dark dots separating the lanes on interstate highways and the truth about whether Buffalo was named after the animal (no). **********''What kind of job is this?'' she writes. ''It's inane. It's obscure. Sometimes it verges on the ridiculous.'' **********But magazine readers can rest assured, she adds, that someone like her is doing the doubting for them. **********What did Keith A. Styrcula of Westport, Conn., learn from his summer job in the late 1980's? Enough to change his aspirations  from litigation to securities law. **********After his first year of law school, he  hooked up with a professional ''pro se'' plaintiff for $400 a week. A pro se plaintiff  spends every waking hour suing everyone who has had the misfortune of crossing his path, Mr. Styrcula writes. **********With a bank loan of $30,000, he hired several law students from N.Y.U. and Columbia. ''We prepared papers for wrongful termination against his boss of eight years ago at a major oil company,'' Mr. Styrcula says, and ''sued the people who booted him out of the Southampton house he'd organized four years before for 'tortious interference with contractual relations.' We went after his landlord, his ex-wife. We were even suing the New York State Supreme Court judge who had the audacity to throw out one of his pending cases. **********''The summer ended early when the professional plaintiff ran out of money. I promptly banked my last check and drew up an agreement for the plaintiff, barring him from suing me for any reason.'' **********''On my resume, it will say that I spent this summer working in a marketing and sales internship at a popular magazine,'' writes Nina Laven of San Francisco. In fact, she spends a lot of time stamping envelopes. **********When the corporate language on her resume says she sat in on meetings, it means she made coffee and did some stenography. When it says she constructed marketing strategies, it means she did word processing and mass mailings of the boss's strategies. And when it says she was a liaison between marketing executives and their clients, it means she walked back and forth between printer, phones, fax and her supervisor. **********Not long ago she called an advertising agency in search of a more challenging internship. ''It's a great opportunity,'' the head of human resources told her. When she gave him the corporate description of what she'd been doing, he sounded impressed and put her on hold. But he punched the wrong buttons. Ms. Laven could hear him: **********''We've got a wannabe here,'' he told a co-worker. ''She's been making coffee.'' **********What has Adam Chalom of Beverly Hills, Mich., been doing in the summer between his junior and senior years at Yale? Working as a kind of ''summer assistant rabbi.'' **********''I observed my rabbi performing funerals, weddings, baby namings and counseling -- sometimes all in the same afternoon,'' he says. ''And when my rabbi went on vacation for July, I got to handle some of the problems that usually come his way.'' **********The greatest reward, he says, ''has been the realization that this summer job is what I want to be doing for the rest of my life.'' **********''And that's something to write home about.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/26/busin.snippet: New program for Japan's vilified Finance Ministry is likely to disappoint proponents of greater change; Japan's governing coalition says it will leave most of Finance Ministry intact and create independent financial inspection and supervisory comm...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/26/busin.main_headline: Politicians Take On Japan's Finance Ministry, With Caution
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/26/busin.print_headline: Politicians Take On Japan's Finance Ministry, With Caution
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/26/busin.body_text: **********Six months ago, it seemed that the public's fury at Japan's imposing Finance Ministry might result in change, as political factions were threatening to carve it up and eviscerate its power and influence. **********Such a move would have had sharp consequences not only for the Government's most powerful ministry but also for the entire country, not to mention foreign financial institutions that deal with Japan. **********But a new program for reorganization of the ministry, announced today by the parties in Japan's governing coalition, is likely to disappoint proponents of greater change. The coalition said it would leave most of the Finance Ministry intact and create an independent financial inspection and supervisory commission. **********Still, the program is the first step politicians have dared to take to chip away at the immensely influential ministry. The coalition moved against the wishes of the ministry, which is resisting any loss of control, and today's proposal could ultimately turn into a significant step. **********The ministry has attracted worldwide criticism for its handling of a string of financial crises during the last few years. It has been managing a banking industry bogged down by more than $400 billion in bad debt, and it has been plagued by a string of failures at financial institutions. **********''Government administration of financial matters requires a transformation of policy into one that follows the ground rules of the international market,'' a critical editorial said today in Asahi Shimbun, a leading national daily. **********What critics have called the ministry's negligence in inspection and surveillance activities has contributed, they say, to the ballooning debt that burdens the banks and the economy today. **********The success of the new supervisory commission hinges on how it is instituted, specifically on what kind of employees are hired and whether it will have its own budget. If it is staffed by former Finance Ministry officials, for instance, the new agency's independence and effectiveness is likely to be hampered. **********Another crucial factor is whether the commission will operate under greater public scrutiny. **********''One important role that the new commission should play is the collection of information and the publicity of it,'' said Akiyoshi Horiuchi, an economics professor at the University of Tokyo. ''It doesn't suffice to merely change the organization. It should also have authority to demand changes and reform wherever appropriate.'' **********In addition to its call for a separate investigative agency, today's plan sought the merging of the banking and securities departments and part of the international finance bureau. **********Last week, the ministry itself offered to combine the securities and banking units with some international responsibilities. The ministry's plan, which was stiffly received by many Japanese, also offered to split off some inspection functions into a new bureau, though under the control of the ministry. **********The ministry is sure to oppose the politicians' proposal, which is also sure to play a role in the campaigns for coming parliamentary elections, which are expected to be held Oct. 20. **********The Liberal Democratic Party, which heads the governing coalition, said today that the new commission's responsibilities would have to be hammered out through the political process. **********One indication of the commission's authority could be the current status of Japan's Fair Trade Commission, the antimonopoly watchdog. Many American companies, most recently Eastman Kodak, have criticized it for relying too much upon the guidance of the Government ministries and for having little influence of its own.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/24/busin.main_headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Low Inventory of Natural Gas Causes Prices to Surge by 15%
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/24/busin.print_headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Low Inventory of Natural Gas Causes Prices to Surge by 15%
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/24/busin.body_text: **********Futures prices for natural gas soared 15 percent yesterday on concerns that inventories were uncomfortably low with two months of winter demand still to come. **********In the Eastern United States, where most natural gas is consumed, inventories as of Jan. 12 were 26 percent below those of last year, according to the American Gas Association, leaving traders concerned about a possible repeat of the cold weather experienced earlier this month. **********Because the levels are so low, if by chance we get hit with more cold weather again, you are going to have a problem," said Bernard Deverin, a natural-gas trader at PVM Energy Products Group in Teaneck, N.J. "You still have all of February and all of March, and if we get hit by any more winter weather,  people are going to be scrambling." **********On other markets, crude oil fell while lumber prices rose. The Commodity Research Bureau index gained 1.10 points, to 241.98. **********On the New York Mercantile Exchange, natural gas for February delivery rose 32 cents, to $2.445 for each million British thermal units. **********Colder weather may already be on the way. The National Weather Service predicted below-normal temperatures across the northern part of the country and  as far south as Kansas in its latest 6- to 10-day forecast. **********Prices of crude oil fell for a second day after Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali of the United Nations said chances had improved that Iraq would accept an offer allowing it to sell limited amounts of oil to the world market. **********March crude oil fell 9 cents, to $18.06 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile  Exchange. **********"Even a small increase in Iraqi oil can put a lot of pressure on the crude market," said Al Lindseth, a broker at the GSC Energy Corporation in Atlanta. **********Lumber rose to its highest price in 10 months on speculation that weak demand for pulp and paper would cause mills to curtail production of both wood chips and lumber. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, March lumber rose $7.70, to $300.20 for 1,000 board feet, the highest price for an active contract since March 10, 1995.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/23/world.main_headline: Vast and Vain Hunt for 7 in Tokyo Subway Nerve-Gas Attack
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/23/world.print_headline: Vast and Vain Hunt for 7 in Tokyo Subway Nerve-Gas Attack
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/23/world.body_text: **********A face stares anxiously from posters on just about every public bulletin board in Japan these days. **********The face -- angular, alarmed and acne-scarred -- is that of Yasuo Hayashi, a  member of the Aum Shinrikyo religious cult. Mr. Hayashi is one of seven fugitives the police have been seeking for more than a year, in a vast but vain  effort to resolve the dozens of criminal cases in which the group is accused. **********The guru of the cult, Shoko Asahara, was captured a year ago and is on trial, charged with organizing the nerve-gas attack on the Tokyo subway system and other killings and kidnappings. The police seem to have wrapped up much of their investigation connected to Mr. Asahara, and now they are going all out to  find Mr. Hayashi and the six other fugitives. **********An especially intensive monthlong campaign to find them has just ended, apparently without the discovery of any clues. So far this year, the police have handed out hundreds of thousands of posters and handbills with the faces of the  fugitives -- sometimes showing them as they would appear with beards or glasses  or even dressed as women. **********In one prefecture, 60,000 cigarette lighters with the faces of the fugitives  were handed out. The police also searched vacant houses and cabins, hotels and rental villas, and even rental cars, while 400 police officers combed a mountain range near Tokyo on the chance that they might find Mr. Hayashi and his confederates camping out. **********The police decline to discuss the reason for the intensity of the manhunt. But the whispers among Government officials are that Mr. Hayashi is being sought not just for his suspected role in the poison-gas attack but also for possible involvement in one of the most mysterious episodes of last year: the shooting of the national police chief, Takaji Kunimatsu, as he left his home to go to work. **********Mr. Kunimatsu, who was shot by a gunman described as unusually tall -- as is  Mr. Hayashi -- nearly died in the attack, and he is still said to be in poor health, so much so that he may step down before long. Japan's police lost great  face by being unable to make any arrests in the case. **********The police have kept mum on the investigation, but Government officials say that dozens of police officers are working on the investigation and that it is focused on locating Mr. Hayashi. The assumption has been that he is in Japan, but investigators are also tracking down reports that he may have escaped to Thailand or Myanmar on a false passport. **********Mr. Hayashi is also charged with releasing sarin nerve gas in a subway car in March 1995 as it stopped in the Akihabara subway station in Tokyo. The train rolled on, and eight people died in and around that particular subway car before it could be evacuated. **********The overall death toll from the subway attack rose to 12 this month after a man died without ever having regained consciousness. Thousands of people were injured in the subway attack, and a few remain in serious condition. **********As the trials of Mr. Asahara and other officials of the group have progressed, prosecutors have painted a portrait of the cult as brutal to insiders as well as to outsiders. **********One follower, Toshio Tomita, was accused by the cult of being a spy and of putting mustard gas in the group's water supply. **********Prosecutors say Mr. Asahara ordered that Mr. Tomita, 27, be tortured until he confessed. Mr. Tomita did not confess and was finally strangled to death, prosecutors say.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/23/world.main_headline: America Keeps Peace, Clinton Tells Coast Guard
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/23/world.print_headline: America Keeps Peace, Clinton Tells Coast Guard
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/23/world.body_text: **********President Clinton mounted a broad defense of his foreign policy yesterday, arguing that in military deployments in Haiti and Bosnia and in his fight for free trade, he had chosen the unpopular course and left America better off for it. **********In his second foreign policy address of the week, Mr. Clinton told the graduating class of the United States Coast Guard Academy in New London, Conn., that he had trod a careful course in an era lacking the clear superpower  delineation of the cold war. **********Imagine the ongoing reign of terror and the flood of refugees to our shore  had we not backed diplomacy with force in Haiti," Mr. Clinton told the rows of white-uniformed graduates and their families. **********"Imagine the shells and the slaughter we would still be seeing in Bosnia had  we not brought our force to bear through NATO," he continued. "Imagine the chaos that might have ensued had we not used our economic power to stabilize Mexico's  economy." **********Mr. Clinton urged Americans to stay engaged in the world despite the end of the cold war. "We cannot withdraw into a fortressed America," the President said. **********Mr. Clinton also used the occasion to denounce a Republican proposal to require deployment of a national missile defense system by 2003 as wasteful, misguided and a breach of arms control agreements with Russia. **********He said the possibility of a long-range nuclear missile attack on American soil by a rogue nation was at least a decade away and that he was committed to working toward a missile defense system that could be deployed in seven years if such a threat were to materialize. **********But, without specifically mentioning the Republicans, he stepped up the Administration's attack on legislation sponsored by Senator Bob Dole, the likely Republican Presidential nominee, and Speaker of the House Newt Gingrich that would require the United States to have a national missile defense system deployed by 2003. **********The proposal, the President said, "would force us to choose now a costly missile defense system that could be obsolete tomorrow." **********House Republicans had planned to vote Thursday on their bill, which revives the national debate over the antimissile technology that is popularly known as Star Wars. **********But the Republicans abruptly postponed action when confronted by an analysis  by the Congressional Budget Office showing the project would cost between $31 billion and $60 billion by 2010. **********Mr. Dole has been sharply critical of Mr. Clinton's approach to foreign policy, accusing him in a speech this month of "weak leadership, vacillation and inconsistency." **********Republicans have suggested that a second Clinton term could leave Americans vulnerable to attack from missiles fired by countries like North Korea and Libya. **********The President, who campaigned and won the 1992 Presidential election largely  on domestic issues, has fashioned himself as an international peacemaker in this election year. **********As he has repeatedly since January, he cited his Administration's support for Russia's transition to democracy and a free market economy, as well as the American role supporting peace efforts in the Middle East and Ireland. In the past months, however, the peace efforts have looked tenuous, and Russia's presidential election could restore a revived Communist Party to power. **********Mr. Clinton specifically singled out Israel for support today, saying: "We must be with you every step of the way until there is a comprehensive, lasting peace in the Middle East. Now is not the time to turn back, and the United States must do its part." **********Later yesterday, the President flew by helicopter to the Intrepid, the floating naval and air museum in the Hudson River along Manhattan's West Side, where he emerged onto a windswept flight deck to welcome sailors celebrating Fleet Week in New York City and to receive the Intrepid's freedom award. **********Mr. Clinton was greeted by Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican Mayor, who, using a favorite line, welcomed the President to the "capital of the world." **********Last night Mr. Clinton addressed a dinner in Stamford, Conn., that raised $2.3 million for Democrats before he flew on to Milwaukee. He is scheduled to meet Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany in Wisconsin today, allowing him to showcase foreign policy once again, this time in the American heartland, in a city with a distinct German heritage. **********White House officials said the President's day of talks with Mr. Kohl would encompass issues ranging from the Russian elections, the expansion of the NATO alliance to include former Warsaw Pact nations and America's efforts to isolate  Iran. The two leaders -- who have bonded in the past over food -- also plan to sample the local bratwurst.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/01/world.print_headline: World News Briefs;Britain Takes Over Security Council Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/01/world.body_text: **********Britain will take over the presidency of the United Nations Security Council  on Monday, as five countries -- Chile, Egypt, Guinea-Bissau, Poland and South Korea -- join the 15-member body for two-year terms. **********The new members will replace Argentina, the Czech Republic, Nigeria, Oman and Rwanda, whose two-year terms on the Council officially expire at the end of 1995. **********The other five nonpermanent members, which remain on the Council through 1996, are Botswana, Germany, Honduras, Indonesia and Italy. **********The Council has five permanent members: the United States, Russia, Britain, China and France. **********The five new members were elected in November by the General Assembly after months of controversy over Libya's candidacy for a seat. **********Libya withdrew in favor of Egypt after it became clear that it would not get  the required two-thirds majority in the 185-member Assembly. The United States and Britain campaigned against Libya.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/21/world.main_headline: On the Ballot: President and Legislators
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/21/world.print_headline: On the Ballot: President and Legislators
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/21/world.body_text: **********Voters in the first Palestinian general elections are electing an 88-member legislative assembly and, in a separate ballot, a President of an executive branch. **********The assembly, officially the Palestinian Council, will be the legislature for the Palestinian self-rule areas; the President will head the Palestinian Interim Self-Government, or cabinet, which will be chosen from both inside and outside the Council. **********Both the Council and the Interim Self-Government will serve until Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization agree on the final status of the West Bank, East Jerusalem and the Gaza Strip. The target date for a final peace accord is May 1999. **********Members of the elected Palestinian Council will automatically become members  of the Palestine National Council, which has served as a kind of parliament-in-exile. **********The Council will pass laws, regulations and other acts, subject to joint review with Israel. **********It will also oversee government policy and decisions. The Council will be able to dissolve the Interim Self-Government by a no-confidence motion. It also  will vote on the Interim Self-Government's budget. **********The Council is barred from dealing with foreign policy, external security or  issues that were left for talks on the final status of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, including Jerusalem, borders, refugees and Jewish settlements. **********The Interim Self-Government administers the self-rule areas, sets policy and  conducts foreign affairs under the self-rule agreement and appoints civil servants in the various ministries. **********The President of the Interim Self-Government will be empowered to choose and  lead the cabinet, and to propose legislation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/07/busin.main_headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Renewed Interest by Industry Pushes Copper Prices Higher
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/07/busin.print_headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Renewed Interest by Industry Pushes Copper Prices Higher
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/07/busin.body_text: **********Copper prices recovered somewhat yesterday as a five-day slide in prices renewed demand from manufacturers. **********On other markets, corn prices surged as forecasts for more wet, cool weather  in the eastern Corn Belt raised concern that farmers were running out of time to plant their crops. Crude oil prices also rose. **********Copper prices bounced back, drawing buyers after falling as low as 97.5 cents a pound -- the lowest price since May 1994. **********Before this week, copper prices averaged $1.17 a pound this year even amid predictions that production costs of as little as 60 cents a pound would bring a flood of new supply. **********"We've seen really high copper prices which aren't warranted by demand, so copper is dropping like a rock," said Scott Fyffe, copper purchasing manager at  the Copper Exchange Company, a metal distributor in Fenton, Mo. **********Copper for July delivery settled 1.6 cents higher at $1.0365 a pound on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange. Even after today's small gain, copper prices are down 10 percent for the week. **********Corn prices rose after a forecast indicated that the crop regions of Indiana  and Ohio would be soaked with as much as two and a half inches of rain in two days, leaving already-wet fields too muddy to work. **********More delays could push many farmers beyond the traditional June 15 end of the corn-planting season and force them to switch to soybeans, reducing the total corn crop to less than the 81 million acres projected by the Agriculture Department. **********Corn for December delivery, representing the fall harvest, rose 7.5 cents, to $3.4825 a bushel, on the Chicago Board of Trade. **********Crude oil rose amid speculation that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting  Countries would leave its production ceiling unchanged. OPEC ministers met for more than four hours yesterday and will meet again today in Vienna. **********"The fact that the meeting went on as long as it did and that they're meeting tomorrow was seen by some as constructive," said Tom Bentz, energy services director at ING Derivatives Clearing Inc. in New York. **********July crude oil rose 33 cents, to $20.05, a barrel on the New York Mercantile  Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/20/world.snippet: Vatican and Italian Parliament praise US Supreme Court for issuing stay of execution for Joseph Roger O'Dell, inmate on Virginia's death row (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/20/world.main_headline: Italy Joins Death Row Appeal In Virginia
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/20/world.print_headline: Italy Joins Death Row Appeal In Virginia
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/20/world.body_text: **********There can't be many people left in Italy who have never heard of Joseph Roger O'Dell 3d, an inmate on Virginia's death row who, but for an eleventh-hour stay of execution issued by the Supreme Court, would have been put to death on Tuesday by lethal injection. **********The news of the Court's decision was national news here, a subject of banner headlines and the lead item on the evening television news. It was greeted with applause in the Italian Parliament and, across the Tiber, by a discreet note of ''satisfaction'' from the Vatican. The Mayor of Palermo, Sicily even offered Mr. O'Dell honorary citizenship. **********For opponents of the death penalty here, the Court's decision was interpreted as a moral victory, if only a temporary one. A few even claimed the victory for the Italian Government and Pope John Paul II -- a tandem that in this case had operated in perfect synchronization with a flurry of letters, messages and telegrams seeking clemency on behalf of Mr. O'Dell, now 54, who was convicted in 1986 of the rape and murder of Helen Schartner the preceding year. **********But with 3,050 people on the death rows of American prisons, 52 of them in Virginia, and 41 prisoners executed in the United States this year, the nagging question is how Mr. O'Dell's case was singled out for Italy's emotional embrace. In fact, another prisoner was executed in Virginia on Monday with hardly any mention in the Italian press. **********''We are also asking ourselves this question,'' said Alberto Flores d'Arcais, foreign editor at the daily La Repubblica. He attributed his own newspaper's spate of banner headlines on the O'Dell appeal to the national importance the case was given by the Parliament, Prime Minister Romano Prodi and, above all, the Pope. **********The O'Dell case was something of an overnight sensation here, according to Patrizia Spadacini, a press officer for Amnesty International's Rome office. Two weeks ago, she said, she could not get the Italian press interested. **********''I literally watched it grow,'' she said. ''Usually we don't have such a coalition -- citizens, parliamentarians, on the right and the left, the Pope and then the media. The media, that was the key.'' **********In a reported telephone interview with a correspondent for La Repubblica, Mr. O'Dell was quoted on Wednesday as saying that if he wins his freedom, he would like to come live here. ''Grazie, Italy, thank you,'' he was quoted as saying. **********But Mr. O'Dell's case is a complex one and there are no assurances that he will be freed or ultimately escape the death penalty. **********Most agree that the campaign on Mr. O'Dell's behalf, which began in the United States a year ago when he put his case on a Web site on the Internet, was able to mobilize the strong sentiments opposing the death penalty that run from Italy's far-left to a powerful network linked to the Roman Catholic Church. **********There was broad acceptance here of Mr. O'Dell's claim that DNA tests conducted three years after his conviction provided new evidence that warranted a new trial at least, and could prove his innocence. The issue of the victim, and her rape and death, have not come up in the Italian campaign. **********For the Vatican, which has intervened three times this year in death penalty cases in the United States, a key factor in the O'Dell case was a legal restriction in Virginia that bars the admission of new evidence 21 days after a conviction. **********Even before the Pope issued his own personal appeals for clemency -- one sent to Gov. George Allen of Virginia and the other to President Clinton, the Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano had criticized the American court system for its overly ''legalistic'' approach to such a morally-charged case. **********With Amnesty International and a group opposing the death penalty,  Hands Off Cain, already involved, the case was soon adopted by several small parties in the Italian Parliament. But as media interest grew following the Pope's appeal, the O'Dell affair became a national passion. On Tuesday, the day before the scheduled execution, Prime Minister Prodi appealed to Governor Allen to stop it, citing the ''great emotion among the public in my country.'' **********But the case has also stirred some uncomfortable questions, particluarly for opponents of the death penalty who worry that the complicated legal details of Mr. O'Dell's case have overwhelmed the larger issue of capital punishment itself. **********''This is the hypocritical paradox that must be disproved,'' wrote Gianni Riotta in Corriere della Sera on Wednesday. ''Everyone, even professional executioners, are against the death penalty for innocent people. That is obvious. One must have the courage to say: We are against executions even when the condemned is guilty.''
