https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/08/world.print_headline: World News Briefs;Right-Winger Concedes Defeat in Ecuador
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/08/world.body_text: **********The rightist Christian Democratic candidate, Jaime Nebot, conceded defeat tonight in Ecuador's runoff presidential election to a populist, Abdala Bucaram. **********Mr, Bucaram, of the center-left Roldosista Party, struck a sympathetic chord  with the nation's poor. **********We will be a constructive opposition to the new government," Mr. Nebot told followers in Guayaquil. **********The Opcion 96 group conducting exit polling projected Bucaram was ahead with  54.1 percent against 45.9 percent for Mr. Nebot. **********The Telered group projected that Mr. Bucaram, who twice before failed in presidential attempts, had 54 percent of the votes against 46 percent for his free-market rival. **********Official results were expected in several days.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/01/world.snippet: Yasir Arafat warns that Palestinians might have to revert to violence if peace with Israel breaks down; tells residents of refugee camp in Nablus that Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu's foot-dragging on peace talks requires them to be 'ready and prepa...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/01/world.main_headline: Arafat Warns Arab Uprising Could Return If Peace Stalls
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/01/world.print_headline: Arafat Warns Arab Uprising Could Return If Peace Stalls
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/01/world.body_text: **********Cranking up the pressure on the Israeli Government, Yasir Arafat warned today that Palestinians might have to revert to violence if the peace with Israel broke down. **********In meetings in Nablus on Friday evening and again today, Mr. Arafat invoked the ''intifada,'' the Palestinian uprising waged largely by stone-throwing youths in Gaza and the West Bank for seven years before peace was made in 1993. **********''One of our options is to return to the intifada,'' Mr. Arafat told high school students on the first day of school. ''You remember I described you as children of the stones. Keep up the spirit of resistance.'' **********On Friday Mr. Arafat told residents of the Balata refugee camp in Nablus that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's foot-dragging on peace talks required ''every one of us in these fateful days to be ready and prepared.'' **********''I don't have a magic wand, but I have the children of the uprising,'' he added. **********The tough talk was the latest volley in a campaign Mr. Arafat launched Wednesday against Israel's right-wing Government, charging that its policies on settlements and Jerusalem amounted to a declaration of war on the Palestinians. **********Mr. Arafat's weapons have included a four-hour strike by Palestinians on Thursday and a call on Palestinians to pray in Jerusalem on Friday, which prompted a heavy police cordon but a relatively light turnout. He also called on Palestinian Christians to pray in Jerusalem's Church of the Holy Sepulcher on Sunday. **********Mr. Arafat's latest sallies were made on the Jewish Sabbath, so there was no immediate reaction from Israel. But Mr. Netanyahu has warned in the past that any increase in tensions could put new obstacles in the way of a peace. **********Since his election in May, Mr. Netanyahu has repeatedly asserted that he is committed to pursuing the peace with the Palestinians and is only waiting until his aides have completed preparations. His deputies have held several meetings with Mr. Arafat's lieutenants. A Palestinian official said today that Mr. Netanyahu and Mr. Arafat would meet soon. **********But so far, Mr. Netanyahu has set no date for two steps regarded as critical for the process to resume -- an Israeli withdrawal from Hebron and a personal meeting with Mr. Arafat. At the same time, his Government has approved plans to expand Jewish settlements in the West Bank and has taken other actions in Jerusalem and in Palestinian territories that the Palestinians view as efforts to preempt issues that are supposed to be negotiated. **********With frustration rising among Palestinians, both with Israel and with Mr. Arafat's Palestinian Authority, Mr. Arafat has become increasingly assertive. **********Evidently in response, Mr. Netanyahu sent more envoys to Mr. Arafat on Thursday and suggested that a new initiative was imminent. But it is evident that any concession to the Palestinians will raise a furor among hard-line members of the Cabinet.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/01/busin.main_headline: Market Place;What Fuels Nasdaq Rise? A Handful Of Big Issues
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/01/busin.print_headline: Market Place;What Fuels Nasdaq Rise? A Handful Of Big Issues
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/01/busin.body_text: **********It looks like heaven for smaller stocks these days. But in fact it is bigger  stocks that are providing a lot of the action in the Nasdaq stock market. **********Yesterday, for the ninth trading day in a row, the Nasdaq composite index set a record closing high. With yesterday's rise of 2.38 points, to 1,190.58, the index is up 6.2 percent in those nine sessions, a much better performance than either that of the Standard & Poor's 500 or the Dow Jones industrial average. [Page D8.] **********This run is still a long way from setting a record for records. The peak string was 19 consecutive new high closes in 1979, but it is the longest in more than four years and has brought attention to the fact that many Nasdaq stocks have taken off since beginning the year with surprising weakness. **********The move reflects an improved economic outlook and better earnings for many smaller stocks. But it also reflects a surge of investment in riskier mutual funds, which have tended to put cash into some of the largest companies in the Nasdaq market. As a result, it is the big Nasdaq names, many of them involved in technology, that have paced the market. **********The latest surge in small-cap stocks began in mid-January. The Nasdaq composite index is up 20 percent since Jan. 15, vastly outperforming the Standard & Poor's 500 index of large stocks, which is up 9 percent. **********In fact, small stocks are not doing nearly as well as that would seem to indicate.  The Russell 2,000, an index of really small stocks -- ones not in the top 1,000 in market capitalization -- is up 15 percent since Jan. 15. That is good, but not nearly as exciting as the Nasdaq figure. **********About 40 percent of the rise in the Nasdaq composite -- an index that includes more than 6,000 issues -- was caused by the movement of the 100 largest Nasdaq stocks. The Nasdaq 100 is up 25 percent in the period. And a full quarter of the rise in the Nasdaq composite can be traced to just eight large stocks: Microsoft, Intel, Cisco Systems, Oracle, Sun Microsystems, Worldcom, U.S. Robotics and America Online. **********Why are the big little stocks rising so much faster than the littler stocks while the really big stocks do less well? One answer lies in the strength of the dollar, which has scared some investors regarding big international companies. The fear is that the stronger dollar will make them less competitive. **********And Claudia Mott, the head of small-cap research for Prudential Securities, says that in part because the United States economy is now growing faster than many other economies, earnings of small-cap companies as a group are growing faster than those of larger companies for the first time in a couple of years. **********But a bigger part of the answer would seem to lie where it has for much of the 1990's: in the decisions made by millions of mutual fund investors. And as a group, those investors are showing a willingness to take on more risk. **********As interest rates have risen this year, the effect has been to scare some investors away from bond funds but not away from mutual funds. Some conservative investors who once put money in bond funds are now investing in conservative stock funds. Meanwhile, some who were once conservative stock investors have moved to aggressive-growth funds. **********Such funds, the riskiest of diversified stock funds, took in $15.6 billion from investors in the first quarter, and the pace in April seems to have been greater. Not only was the quarter's performance a record -- up almost 25 percent from the previous peak, set in the third quarter of last year -- but it also amounted to more than 8 percent of assets in aggressive-growth funds, a very high figure by historical standards. **********Adding to the upward pressure on stock prices, the managers of such funds grew cautious late last year and early this year; by Jan. 31 they had $18.5 billion in cash, a relatively high 9.3 percent of total assets. Two months later, they had spent $3.5 billion of that hoard, with cash down to a relatively low 7 percent of assets. The combination of big cash inflows plus the need to put previously unspent cash to work had a big impact. **********That has also had the effect of sharply pushing up prices of computer technology stocks, which had sagged late last year after a period of stunning performance. Since Jan. 15, Microsoft is up 37 percent, Intel 26 percent and Cisco 54 percent. Some others have done much better. America Online has leaped 95 percent; U.S. Robotics, a maker of computer modems, is up 122 percent. **********How long can this last? Many on Wall Street think it will continue for most of this year. They say that valuations of smaller stocks are not excessive, at least when compared with large-cap stocks, and add that they see no signs that the money will stop flowing in. **********But there is one historic ratio that may suggest caution. That is the ratio of the Nasdaq composite to the Standard & Poor's 500. Back in the summer of 1983, the peak of small-stock popularity, and another time when technology stocks were soaring, Nasdaq became extremely popular, with the index 1.93 times  as high as the S.& P. By the fall of 1990, the reverse had occurred. Tech stocks were hated, and large stocks had zoomed in value, relative to smaller ones. The  ratio fell to 1.08. **********Now, the ratio is back to 1.82. The Nasdaq composite has recovered about 85 percent of the ground it lost, on a relative basis, from 1983 through 1990. That suggests the party is well past the halfway point.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/15/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Barings Bondholders To Sue Ex-Chairman
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/15/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Barings Bondholders To Sue Ex-Chairman
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/15/busin.body_text: **********Bondholders of the former Barings P.L.C. voted yesterday to sue Peter Baring, the former chairman, along with other officials and advisers. They seek to recover L100 million ($153 million) lost when the British merchant bank collapsed a year ago. The bondholders said they also planned to name Andrew Tuckey, the former deputy chairman; Peter Norris, former head of investment banking, and three advisers -- BZW Securities, Hoare Govett Securities and Cazenove & Company. **********The suit would come a year after Barings collapsed amid L860 million in losses on futures and options in Asia attributed to unauthorized trading by Nicholas W. Leeson, a trader based in Singapore. The Dutch banking company Internationale Nederlanden Groep took over Barings' assets.   (Bloomberg Business News)

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/02/busin.body_text: **********Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc., a Dallas investment firm that specializes in  leveraged buyouts, hired Michael Levitt today as a managing director and principal. **********Mr. Levitt, 37, was managing director and deputy head of investment banking at Smith Barney Inc. from 1993 until February, when he resigned. **********At Smith Barney, Mr. Levitt was responsible for mergers and acquisitions and leveraged transactions, as well as coverage of the media, telecommunications, retailing, lodging and financial industries. His clients included Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company. and Viacom Inc. **********He joined Smith Barney, a unit of Travelers Group Inc., from Morgan Stanley Group Inc., where he worked from 1986 to 1993. **********Mr. Levitt said he was attracted to Hicks Muse because of the firm's holdings in real estate, finance and emerging markets, as well as its expertise in leveraged buyouts. **********"The guys have marvelous momentum," he said. "They have a broader line of business than many other firms."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/22/busin.snippet: Survey of what the personal-finance magazines are offering readers in October, including Money's comparison of Pres Clinton's and Bob Dole's records as they affect the individual pocketbook; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/22/busin.main_headline: Looking at Voters' Wallets, and the Candidates' Fingers
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/22/busin.print_headline: Looking at Voters' Wallets, and the Candidates' Fingers
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/22/busin.body_text: **********IF the polls are any indication, the old saw that people vote their pocketbooks remains valid. To help such readers, the October issues of three personal-finance magazines -- Money, Worth and Mutual Funds -- have articles examining the stances of Bob Dole and President Clinton on the economy. **********The package in Money is by far the most comprehensive and rewarding. It includes an ''In Your Interest'' column by Frank Lalli, the magazine's managing editor, in which he compares the candidates' economic rhetoric with reality. **********Mr. Lalli offers some interesting conclusions: *********** The details of Mr. Dole's tax plan aren't quite as sweet as his ''I'm going to cut your taxes by 15 percent and balance the budget'' promise. *********** The President's contention that ''our targeted tax cuts are paid for'' is based on assumptions that may not pan out. *********** The line-item veto will give the next President far less power than most people have been led to believe. *********** It was Mr. Dole, not the President, who  championed (in 1982) the biggest tax increase, when adjusted for inflation, in United States history. *********** Mr. Clinton's assertion that ''we saved Medicare'' when the Republicans tried to destroy it doesn't jibe with a projection that the program's trust fund will become insolvent in 2001. **********The main article -- ''The Candidates and Your Wallet,'' by Ann Reilly Dowd, a Washington correspondent for the magazine -- includes an interview with Mr. Clinton in which some of his most interesting comments are about the need for changes in Social Security. **********Mr. Dole and Ross Perot, the candidate of the Reform Party, declined to be interviewed. **********The package, which is buttressed by the results of a Money poll, covers just about every pocketbook issue on the table and is an excellent primer for anyone trying to get beyond daily sound bites and headlines. **********The article in Worth is laudable, but not as comprehensive as those in Money. It is based on questions that the magazine submitted to Mr. Dole and Mr. Clinton. **********The article winds up with a telling point, however: ''As the election picks up steam, remember this: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's policies will have more impact on the economy, and thus on voters' pocketbooks, than a President of either party.'' **********The contribution by Mutual Funds simply presents the contrasting opinions of two fund managers. **********A WARNING SIGN? A thoughtful, and troubling, article by Jim Rogers, a finance professor at Columbia University, in Worth examines some signs that foreign investors may be pulling back from financing America's national debt by buying its Treasury bonds, notes and bills. **********The ramifications of this could be shattering for the economy, Mr. Rogers writes. He advises American investors to keep some assets out of the country, in a safe currency like German marks or Swiss francs, as an insurance policy. **********THINK SMALL The October issue of Kiplinger's Personal Finance recommends buying stocks in seven small companies whose profits are growing at least 20 percent a year and which haven't been ''discovered'' by the market. The seven dwarfs are: Avondale Industries, a shipbuilder; Consolidated Products, a restaurant chain; Friedman's, a jewelry retailer; Horizon Mental Health Management, which provides mental health services in general acute-care hospitals; Lumisys, a medical-equipment company; Nobel Education Dynamics, a for-profit operator of schools, and SEI, a financial-services concern. **********To minimize risk, it is recommended that all seven be bought as a package. **********TAKE CREDIT Smart Money's October issue examines the frustrating problem of inaccurate credit reports. Devin Leonard's ''Garbage In. Garbage Out.'' describes the workings of TRW, Equifax and Trans Union -- the Big Three in the credit-reporting business -- as well as what causes mistakes and what a consumer can do about them. **********The problem appears to be widespread. The author says that of the 2.5 million people who request copies of their credit reports each year from Trans Union, 50 percent have questions or disputes about their credit histories. TRW says it handles 360,000 complaints a month. **********YOUR POCKETBOOK Kiplinger's has a good rundown of 34 World Wide Web sites that can help consumers manage their finances, from investing to buying a car to selling a house. The magazine also recommends that it might be time to look at investing in Eastern Europe, with a list of some mutual funds that do just that. **********And in case you didn't already know it, Kiplinger's points out that the nation's banks are on a rampage of imposing fees and surcharges. Last year, the banks raked in $16 billion from such charges. **********BITS AND PIECES Worth and Kiplinger's both examine the merits of P.I.M., or personal information manager, computer programs; Smart Money gives some excellent pointers on buying an Oriental rug; Kiplinger's presents its ''stinky fish'' awards to nine mutual fund flops, and Andrew Tobias beats up on Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate and Presidential candidate, in a cover article in Worth.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/17/world.main_headline: World News Briefs;Peruvian Court Upholds American's Life Sentence
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/17/world.print_headline: World News Briefs;Peruvian Court Upholds American's Life Sentence
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/17/world.body_text: **********The Peruvian military's highest court has upheld the sentence of life in prison without parole for an American woman convicted of aiding leftist guerrillas. **********The rejection of the appeal for the woman, Lori Berenson, by the military's Supreme Council came on Friday. Her lawyer, Grimaldo Achahui, said he had not been officially notified but had heard of the decision. **********Ms. Berenson, 26, was convicted of treason on Jan. 11 for helping rebels in  a foiled plot to kidnap Peruvian congressional representatives. **********Mr. Achahui said that under Peruvian law, there is no appeal beyond the Supreme Council in cases tried in military court. **********He said he would consult with Ms. Berenson's family and might appeal to international human rights tribunals, including that of the United Nations. Although these agencies have no jurisdiction in Peru, a Peruvian law requires Peru to consider these rulings, he said. **********Ms. Berenson, a native of New York, was arrested on Nov. 30 just hours before a police raid on a guerrilla hideout in which three rebels and a police officer  were killed. She was charged with belonging to the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement, and of helping transport arms to the hideout.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/31/world.main_headline: Rising Variety of Groups Vie for Attention at U.N. Rights Forum
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/31/world.print_headline: Rising Variety of Groups Vie for Attention at U.N. Rights Forum
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/31/world.body_text: **********Fearing that they are not being heard in Africa, two members of a dwindling tribe facing eviction from a Botswana game reserve went to Geneva this week to bring their case to a human rights forum that is opening its doors wider every year to petitioners from around the world. **********"We came without any promise of getting anything done," said John Hardbattle, leader of the First Peoples of the Kalahari, whose ancestors have lived in what  is now the Central Kalahari Game Reserve for thousands of years. "We felt that if we can't get help at the U.N., then we won't get it anywhere else." **********Every spring when the forum, the United Nations Human Rights Commission, convenes in Geneva, most attention is focused on the clash of powerful nations -- in recent years on the United States and its efforts to wring a condemnation  of China out of the 51-nation body. **********But now a widening assortment of small delegations with no official backing are vying for attention. **********To his relief, Mr. Hardbattle was able to meet on Thursday with the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, Jose Ayala Lasso. He expects to address the full commission in the coming week. **********Mr. Hardbattle came to Geneva by way of the United States, where he raised money from foundations and individuals to pay for his tiny delegation. He and Roy Sesana, a Khwe leader, plan to tell the commission that 3,000 of their people are in danger of being moved out of the way of tourist development by a Government dominated by another tribe, the Tswana. **********The Khwe are getting help from Rebecca Adamson, of the First Nations Development Institute of Fredericksburg, Va., which has assisted American Indians for 15 years. International cooperation among native groups is enhancing the ability of small organizations to get attention beyond their regions. **********Diplomats at the Botswana Mission to the United Nations say the Khwe will not be forcibly relocated, but they confirm a move is being planned. The Government  cannot afford public services like schools, roads and clinics for them, the diplomats say, so the Khwe still on the reserve are being transferred to more accessible areas. The Khwe, historically called Bushmen, want a chance to counter that explanation in a public forum. **********"Going to Geneva makes sure that your case is heard," said Julie Berriault, of the Washington office of the Unrepresented Nations and Peoples Organization,  which for the last five years has been helping its 52 members get hearings. **********The organization, to which the Khwe do not belong, held workshops in Geneva this year on East Timor, the Western Sahara and Tibet. **********Another group is made up of Kashmiris battling India for independence. Last year they were able to formally present their accounts of rights abuses by Indian forces. **********This year they planned to do the same. But just days before the commmission convened, a Kashmiri human rights campaigner, Jalil Andrabi, of the Kashmir Commission of Jurists, was killed after being detained by men who his wife says  were wearing Indian military uniforms. His body was found this week in the Jhelum River in Srinagar, the capital of Kashmir. Indian officials said he was killed by militants. **********In Los Angeles Dr. Gulum Butt, president of the Kashmir American Council, said the death of Mr. Andrabi and "the liquidation of the Kashmiri intelligentsia" will now be the focus of the Geneva campaign. **********On Friday, the United States condemned the killing of Mr. Andrabi and asked the Indian Government to conduct a full investigation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/19/world.main_headline: At Least 150 Are Killed in Disco Fire in Manila
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/19/world.print_headline: At Least 150 Are Killed in Disco Fire in Manila
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/19/world.body_text: **********After a fierce fire spread through a disco packed with students early this morning, officials confirmed today that at least 150 people had been killed and  said there may be as many as 50 more bodies still in the ruins. **********Dozens more were severely injured, many with third-degree burns. Hospital officials said others had been trampled in the rush to the exits. **********When the fire began shortly after midnight, an estimated 350 people were in  the Ozone Disco Pub in suburban Quezon City, many of them taking part in high school and college graduation parties, survivors said. The school year in the Philippines ends this month. **********"It was like hell," said the disk jockey at the club, Marvin Reyes, who watched flames catch the hair and clothes of screaming victims. **********"I tried to announce there was a fire, but the microphone stopped working." **********Bodies of people who had tried unsuccessfully to escape were piled waist-deep in a narrow corridor leading from the dance floor. Others were crushed beneath a collapsed mezzanine ceiling. **********Some survivors said the fire appeared to have started in the disk jockey's booth, but radio reports said a fuel tank in the kitchen may have exploded. Fire officials are still investigating. **********The cries of people searching for their relatives added to the chaos as firefighters put out the blaze. Rescuers soon accumulated the names of more than 100 people still missing from the disco. **********"We saw smoke and tried to run outside, but were caught in a stampede," said  one survivor, who gave only her first name, Rose. "I was stepped on, but managed to force my way out." She said two of the three friends who had been there with  her were missing. **********Reny Megis, a door guard at the disco, said: "I could not do anything.  There was just a rush of people." **********Mr. Megis said his son was among those killed inside. **********Erlinda Mandap, 45, sat weeping after finding only her daughter's shoes. **********Tess Sagario, 40, said both her son and daughter had been inside. **********"I'm all alone now," she said. "What will happen to me?" **********The Fire Inspector, Warlito Daus, said the disco did not have a proper fire exit. **********The Quezon City Police Chief, Hercules Cataluna, said the death toll was the  highest for any fire in the Philippines. The death toll is among the highest in  a nightclub fire anywhere. The worst nightclub fire of all time was Nov. 28, 1942, at Cocoanut Grove in Boston, where 491 people died. A fire in 1970 in Grenoble, France, killed 147 people, and a fire in Osaka, Japan, in 1972 killed  116. The Happy Land social club fire in the Bronx in 1990 killed 87 people. **********The fire started at about 12:05 A.M. and was extinguished about two hours later, said a fire official, Moises Marcelo. **********Many victims were so badly burned that their bodies stuck to each other, said Adolfo Gutierrez of the Quezon City mayor's office.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/24/busin.main_headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Oil Prices Drop on Suggestion Iraq May Accept Export Terms
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/24/busin.print_headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Oil Prices Drop on Suggestion Iraq May Accept Export Terms
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/24/busin.body_text: **********Crude oil prices tumbled on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday after  the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, suggested that Iraq had implicitly accepted the terms of a proposal that would allow it to export oil for the first time in nearly six years. **********On other markets, soybean prices rose while gold closed below $400 an ounce for the first time in five weeks. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 17 commodities fell 1.33 points, to 248.4. **********The selloff in oil followed news that the Secretary General had told diplomats that he assumed Iraq's willingness to discuss a United Nations resolution on limited oil sales meant that the nation would accept the proposal. **********In the past, Iraq has rejected the terms of the resolution, saying provisions detailing how the revenue from the oil sales would be spent violated its sovereignty. **********Crude oil for April delivery plunged 79 cents, or 4 percent, to $19.06 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. March gasoline slipped 1.31 cents, to 58.73 cents a gallon. **********The market reacted in part to the Iraqi news and "to the idea that we could have more oil than we know what to do with during the second and third quarters" of 1996, said James Healey, general manager of oil supplies at Mapco Petroleum Inc., an oil company in Tulsa, Okla. **********Soybean prices advanced after a pair of Government reports showed strong domestic use and higher overseas demand for soybean meal. **********The Census Bureau said inventories of soybean meal and hulls, used as livestock feed, at processing plants fell 23 percent from a month ago to 302,394 tons at the end of January. **********In addition, the Agriculture Department said exporters sold 148,200 metric tons of soymeal abroad in the week ended Feb. 15, the most since the marketing year began on Oct. 1. **********May soybeans jumped 8.75 cents, to $7.44 bushel, on the Chicago Board of Trade; May soymeal climbed $4, to $235.10 a ton.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/24/world.snippet: Colombian Pres Ernesto Samper, in address to United Nations General Assembly, proposes new global campaign against drugs; Samper, who has been accused by Clinton Administration of having ties to narcotics traffickers, portrays himself as victim of...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/24/world.main_headline: War on Drugs Urged at U.N. By Colombian
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/24/world.print_headline: War on Drugs Urged at U.N. By Colombian
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/24/world.body_text: **********With the audacity that has made him the scourge of Washington, President Ernesto Samper of Colombia -- minus the American visa he lost in July because the Clinton Administration accused him of having ties to narcotics traffickers -- came to the United Nations today to propose a new global campaign against drugs. **********Portraying himself as a victim of drug lords and the leader of a country that had been ''demonized'' by outsiders, Mr. Samper struck a third-world chord and received a sustained ovation. **********In Washington, a senior official said today that Colombia needed to think less about international solutions and more on its internal mess. **********American officials say 80 percent of the world's cocaine comes from Colombia, as does 25 percent of heroin now sold on the streets of the United States. Drug money has made corruption ''endemic'' throughout Colombian society, an American official said. **********The Clinton Administration, with the public corroboration of some former senior Colombian officials, has said Mr. Samper accepted political donations from notorious traffickers in his 1994 campaign for the presidency. He has denied knowingly accepting drug money. In June, the Colombian Congress saved his presidency by dropping charges that his election campaign had been financed by the Cali drug cartel. **********Since March 1, in part because of the charges against Mr. Samper, Washington has listed Colombia along with Afghanistan, Burma, Iran, Nigeria and Syria as countries failing to cooperate in the drug war. The designation meant an end to much of Colombia's foreign aid. **********Although there have been well-publicized arrests of drug lords during the Samper administration, Washington continues to question the effectiveness of Colombia's efforts. **********Mr. Samper came to New York on a diplomatic visa and said in an interview that he was under no special restrictions. He will also attend a commemorative conference on Tuesday marking the 35th anniversary of the founding of the nonaligned movement. He holds the rotating presidency of the group. **********The Colombian President left home in a blaze of publicity after more than eight pounds of heroin were found in his official plane on Friday night, forcing him to take a chartered aircraft on Saturday. Today, the State Department announced that 11 members of the Colombian Air Force had been arrested in connection with the heroin. **********Addressing the General Assembly today, Mr. Samper proposed a six-point plan against ''narco-terrorism,'' saying drugs and terrorists were now inextricably linked and asking for economic aid for replacing illegal crops with legal ones. **********Mr. Samper, who has a graduate degree in economics from Columbia University, also asked for controls on the sale of chemicals and weapons to drug producers and traffickers, for worldwide application of a European agreement against money-laundering and for an international intelligence center for narcotics information and eventually an international tribunal for drug cases. **********Turning to the countries of high demand, he urged better programs to stop consumption. **********''One cannot place the entire burden of drug fighting on drug-producing countries, which are the weakest link,'' he said, echoing a theme that resonates in other countries where narcotics are grown or manufactured. **********American officials, who still cooperate with Colombia in crop eradication, say they have urged Colombia to impose stiffer sentences, freeze the assets of convicted drug traffickers and strengthen laws on money-laundering and extradition. **********In the interview before his speech, Mr. Samper, who survived one attack on his life, said he was still the object of death threats. Some officials here said they believed that Mr. Samper might in fact be trapped in a vicious cycle, to some extent beholden to narcotics money and unable to come down harder on Colombian traffickers, even if he wanted to, without risking his life. **********''The President of Colombia is always in danger,'' he said. **********Mr. Samper argued that the Colombian Army had been fighting a war on two fronts, against narcotics trafficking and against guerrillas who are increasingly receiving money from drug traffickers. **********He remains defiant about his relations with Washington. Taking away his tourist visa, he said, ''raised my popularity in Colombia by 15 points.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/21/busin.main_headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Crude Oil Prices Rise Sharply On Lack of Agreement With Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/21/busin.print_headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Crude Oil Prices Rise Sharply On Lack of Agreement With Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/21/busin.body_text: **********Crude oil prices posted their sharpest one-day gain since the Persian Gulf war yesterday, while gold prices tumbled. **********The surge in oil prices came after Iraqi and United Nations negotiators ended two weeks of talks on Monday without an agreement on a plan to allow Iraq limited oil sales to pay for food and medicine. The plan would have allowed Iraq to sell as much as $2 billion worth of oil over six months. **********Without the Iraqi thing hanging over our head, people are looking at how good demand is, and demand all over is up," said Jerry Samuels, managing director at ARB Oil Inc. in New York. **********On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for March delivery jumped $1.89, to $21.05 a barrel, the highest price since March 4, 1993. It was the biggest one-day gain in an active contract since Jan. 26, 1991. The market was closed Monday in observance of Washington's birthday. **********The March contract expired yesterday; the active April contract surged 87 cents, to $19.27 a barrel. **********While traders still eventually expect an oil-sale agreement between Iraq and  the United Nations, the apparent failure of the recent talks indicates that no Iraqi oil will come to market for months. **********In the meantime, demand for crude oil from refineries is strong and oil stockpiles in the Midwest, where the futures contract specifies delivery, are at their lowest since the American Petroleum Institute began measuring them in 1987. Stockpiles in the nation's refining center on the Gulf of Mexico are also  close to their lowest on record. **********Gold prices plunged. Gold had been bolstered in part by hopes that economic weakness would prompt the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates. But testimony by Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, dashed those hopes yesterday. Mr. Greenspan told Congress that weakness in the economy was "likely to be temporary." **********Mr. Greenspan's speech "was very bearish for gold," said Jim Steel, a vice president for commodities research at Refco Inc. in New York. "We have high interest rates in a low inflationary environment, and now, no prospects for further rate cuts." **********The April gold contract fell as much as $8.30 on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange before recovering to end $6.40 lower at $401.10 an  ounce, the lowest since Jan. 19. **********On other commodities markets, wheat prices plunged following forecasts that rains would soak the winter wheat crop during the coming weeks, helping ease months of dry weather. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 17 commodities fell 0.51 point yesterday, to 249.64.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/07/busin.snippet: FOR the last few years, I have been conducting secret research. The results are intriguing and illuminate something fundamental about communication design.  And like some of the best findings, this one was based largely on a chance event -- my dis...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/07/busin.main_headline: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;After Dinner, a Communication Taste Test
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/07/busin.print_headline: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;After Dinner, a Communication Taste Test
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/07/busin.body_text: **********FOR the last few years, I have been conducting secret research. The results are intriguing and illuminate something fundamental about communication design.  And like some of the best findings, this one was based largely on a chance event -- my discovery of an old set of children's blocks. **********The unwitting subjects of my study have been dinner guests over the last few  years. As any host-researcher knows, there is an odd gap between the time the table is cleared of the main course and when coffee and dessert are served. A few years ago, I noticed a set of wooden blocks on a shelf and set them on the dining table so guests could play with them to pass away this time. **********Of course, I had no idea that this little gesture would point to a basic issue in information processing. **********What I have discovered is that people fall into two categories. Not herb tea  or decaf cappuccino drinkers, but rather tower builders and maze makers. In other words, the ones who build the blocks up and up as opposed to those who build them out and out. **********I assumed at first that this was a gender issue -- men up, women out.  But that is not what the research shows. Age is not a factor, either. In fact, it has become clear frm a combination of careful observation and careless chitchat that the difference between the two groups is cognitive. **********Tower builders are linear thinkers. They process the world systematically, sequentially. I call them lineasts. They build their monuments the same way they assemble their world view, step by step. They consider each piece carefully, adjust each new placement and try to beat gravity by the sheer force  of their logic and precision. **********Their goal seems to be to create a kind of unassailable coherence, a structure both familiar and impressive -- something we can all identify with. The risk, of course, is great.  One false move, one misplaced assertion, can bring it all tumbling down. **********Maze makers are different. Let's call them optophiles because they love options, choices, parallel lines of reasoning. They tend to create dynamic patterns that may be confusing, but also draw you in by their complexity. Maze makers work differently, too. They build by constant adjustment and re-evaluation, moving and shifting. **********Maze makers are not looking for simplicity. On the contrary, their goal seems to be to create a rich interaction of forms. There is a big risk here, too, because even though it won't come tumbling down at once, their work can easily dissipate into chaos. **********After-dinner whimsy, or an insight into the human mind? I know what you're thinking. But it happens that the distinction shown by my research reflects a current conflict in the area of communication design: whether to present information in linear or interactive formats. **********LINEAR structures of information -- like novels, movies, essays, plays -- are designed so that the material unfolds a tidbit at a time. Step by step. That's their strength. Nothing can compare to the dramatic impact of a tale well told. **********In writing a novel, for example, I do something like tower building -- placing each event, each telltale moment, in a carefully constructed sequence to achieve a clear, impressive whole. In fact, to help this process, I often create plot lines, story lists, outlines and other word towers to make sure the project is coming together coherently. **********Reading a novel, or experiencing any other linear format, is a lot like climbing the tower. There is a certain neat determinism to the experience, the feeling of moving forward in one direction. Lineasts love that. **********But interactive design is more democratic. Selection buttons, hot spots, hypertext links. The information comes only through your choices as you navigate the maze of possibilities. Optophiles adore these choices and feel no anxiety about surfing a sea of data, picking and choosing nuggets. **********As an interactive designer, I work with flow charts, branching trees and other mazelike structures in shaping new software titles. Rather than control each step of your experience, I try to set out a pattern of possibilities, any one of which, if I am successful, will reward your efforts. **********What drives lineasts crazy about this is how easily they can lose track of where they are, where they were or where they are going. But it is just this freedom of choice that appeals to optophiles. **********My hunch is that most of us are a combination of the two types, and that these are tendencies rather than alternatives. And since certain kinds of information lend themselves to one form or the other, I am certain that there will always be both -- novels as well as home pages, for example. **********Linear storytelling will always be a powerful way to convey drama, giving the designer a framework in which to build a coherent sequence and manipulate you through it. An interactive "Hamlet" cannot work as well as the original because  Shakespeare already picked the best path. **********Research, however, must proceed interactively. To track down specific information, there have to be ways to navigate efficiently through vast amounts  of data. Imagine trying to look something up in a linear encyclopedia in which,  instead of the interactive device of alphabetized key words, you had to read every entry from the beginning until you reached the one you wanted. **********Knowing that each approach is distinct but equally useful, I have tried suggesting to my lineastic guests that they experiment with building out, and to the optophiles that they try building up. All are willing to do it but, it seems to me, always with a slight sense of distress, as if they were combing their hair the wrong way. **********If you want to replicate this experiment, a word of warning: Do it before dessert, not after. Before, you get the two neat groups. But after, there is only one category. Folks don't want to build anything; they just want to wrap it up and head home.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/23/your-.main_headline: Why It's Never Too Early for Tax Plans
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/23/your-.print_headline: Why It's Never Too Early for Tax Plans
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/23/your-.body_text: **********IF you require confirmation of the fact that regret is a futile emotion, ask tax lawyers. They share the job, with tax accountants, of dealing with the financial version of wisdom after the event: the unhappy legatees who only wish they had insisted that Daddy make a will before heading off on that fateful hang-gliding vacation. **********As a consequence of poor tax planning, the beneficiaries of a will may find themselves with a lot less benefit and a lot more tax to pay. **********"In general, inheritance tax or estate tax is ignored is ignored until the fatal accident occurs — and then the consequences will take full toll," warns Jack Anderson, a legal and tax partner at Ernst & Young in Paris. **********Those consequences can be dire indeed. Some of the principal issues affecting the inheritance of estates — particularly those of expatriates or married couples of different nationalities — include: **********- **********Recognition of the will. A will made in one country may not be valid under a second country's legal system. **********- **********The consequences of forced heirship. In the absence of a will, the relevant legal system will substitute its standard code to divide up assets among relatives. This can create problems if the "wrong" — i.e., the legal system which the expatriate does not consider home — applies. Children may be automatically preferred to wives and vice versa. The situation may become more perplexing still if there are children from more than one marriage. **********- **********Domicile and residency. These are key concepts in determining which tax laws apply. In general, you have to be physically present in a country to be resident there, yet you may be "domiciled" for tax purposes elsewhere. Sometimes domicile can be implied after an extended period of residence. **********- **********Tax treaties. The existence of a treaty between an expatriate's home and host country will change all tax planning considerations. **********"The top rate of U.S. income tax is 39.6 percent, whereas the top rate of estate tax is 55 percent," says Mr. Anderson. "It's remarkable how little planning gets done on estate tax when you compare those rates." **********Dominic Adams, a tax partner at U.K. attorneys S.J. Berwin & Co. in London, argues that the best time to plan is before an individual leaves one domicile for another. Using offshore companies and trusts, he says, it is possible to avoid unwanted complications of residency and domicile. **********Aside from establishing appropriate legal vehicles before taking up residence in another country, there are other basic principles of tax planning. These include: **********- **********Review the overall effectiveness of a will before leaving home. Seek professional advice as to its potential effectiveness. **********- **********Seek advice before purchasing real estate. Buying land may automatically confer domicile and bring with it unwanted tax consequences.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/08/busin.snippet: The worst bickering between Britain and China over Hong Kong's future appears to be over, reducing the chances of a business slump that could greatly complicate the transfer of sovereignty July 1, 1997..The next 12 months, a critical time for conf...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/08/busin.main_headline: ECONOMIC SCENE : Hong Kong:The Worst May Be Over
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/08/busin.print_headline: ECONOMIC SCENE : Hong Kong:The Worst May Be Over
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/08/busin.body_text: **********The worst bickering between Britain and China over Hong Kong's future appears to be over, reducing the chances of a business slump that could greatly complicate the transfer of sovereignty July 1, 1997. **********The next 12 months, a critical time for confidence, should see a continued recovery from anemic economic growth and a return of Hong Kong's fickle "feel-good" factor, just in time to persuade people worried about the future to stay put and keep most of their money with them. **********But unease about life under Chinese rule and concerns about the direction of U.S. interest rates mitigate against a boom like the one experienced here in 1992 and 1993, analysts said. **********"At the back of people's minds is the thought that in the last 12 months they should be cautious," said Ian Perkin, chief economist for the Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce. "I don't think you'll see a big sustained upturn in retail spending here for a while, especially in big-ticket items." **********Hong Kong residents are still concerned about civil liberties and Beijing's determination to abolish Hong Kong's legislature in response to Britain's unilateral move to enact electoral reforms. **********But if the depth of community disquiet about the future is accurately reflected in such indicators as the residential property market and emigration figures, then the inflow of job-seekers and a rise in real-estate transactions indicate the scent of personal gain can still override political uncertainty. **********Sales and purchase agreements for residential property in the first four months of 1996 surged 27.7 percent from the like period in 1995 as a price battle among mortgage lenders helped lessen the burden of purchasing some of the world's most expensive real estate. **********The idea that a strong economy can assuage all but the most serious political worries has not been lost on either London or Beijing, who despite their sharp differences are united in hoping the next year or so goes smoothly in Hong Kong. **********Britain's decision to build the world's most expensive airport over China's initial objections has proved wise. A $20 billion package of infrastructure projects has buoyed the economy through a relatively difficult recent stretch. **********The activity has bolstered an economy in which gross domestic product grew at an annual rate of only 3 percent in the first three months of 1996, down from 3.2 percent in the last quarter of 1995 and well below the government's target of 5 percent for 1996. **********"The government is maintaining its GDP growth forecast of 5 percent for 1996 despite the weak first-quarter growth," a recent study from Merrill Lynch & Co. said. "This implies the economy will have to grow at near 6 percent for the rest of the year — an uphill task, in our opinion." **********Beijing has suggested, unofficially, that it is prepared to pour money into the stock market to ensure that Hong Kong prospers in its first months of rule. **********China has also said it will intervene to buttress the Hong Kong dollar, the value of which is linked to the U.S. dollar, should it come under attack. **********Concrete moves by China to lower tariffs and to selectively relax restrictions on credit could help keep the Hong Kong economy on track for comfortable growth — provided that China's economy continues to recover. **********[Chinese economists said, however, that slow growth in fixed-asset investment could prove a drag on economic growth, Reuters reported from Beijing. **********[China, which has seen double-digit economic growth since 1991, has been trying to control inflation by tightening credit and imposing limits on fixed-asset investment. As a consequence, a leading state economist said, growth might not reach this year's target of 9 percent.] **********Because of the Hong Kong currency's link to the U.S. dollar, the territory's economy could also be hurt if U.S. interest rates rise. **********"The property market would be the one area most immediately affected," said Andrew Freris of Salomon Brothers. "Higher interest rates could hurt the stock market also." **********"But we don't see any changes by the Fed in the next six months," Mr. Freris said. "That should see Hong Kong safely through the year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/25/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Aerospatiale and Dassault Close to Merger Agreement
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/25/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Aerospatiale and Dassault Close to Merger Agreement
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/25/busin.body_text: **********Two French arms industry giants, the Government-owned Aerospatiale and the privately held Dassault Aviation, are close to a merger, Defense Minister Charles Millon said today. **********A merger would create a company with $12 billion in annual sales. Mr. Millon  said the final terms of the merger would be announced in a few days. But French  reports said that 27 percent of the merged company would be owned by Serge Dassault, who owned 49.9 percent of the company that was founded by his father. **********Mr. Dassault had fought to preserve his company's independence. But he lost  the battle in February, when the Government announced that it would seek to combine the companies within two years. President Jacques Chirac had said that Dassault and Aerospatiale must merge, or perish amid increasingly harsh competition. **********Mr. Dassault was unable to persuade Paris to give him the 33 percent share in the merged company necessary for veto power. **********The merged company, expected to be named Aerospatiale-Dassault, would have a  total value of more than $6 billion. Shares of a partly owned computer design subsidiary of the Dassault company, Dassault Systemes, would be offered separately on the Nasdaq and French stock markets on Friday. **********Neither company made any comment today. **********The planned merger is part of Mr. Chirac's effort to overhaul the French military and privatize state-owned industries. With the armed-forces being reduced from 500,000 to 350,000 over the next decade and the military budget being held at $37.9 billion for the second consecutive year, French arms makers  can no longer rely on Government orders. **********Mr. Chirac has urged the industry to seek cooperation agreements with other European companies, avoid duplication and slim down its work force to compete better globally. **********More changes in the French arms industry are expected to follow. Giat Industries, a largely state-owned company formed from what used to be the French Army arsenal, lost $2.4 billion last year, and the state-owned naval dockyards are expected to cut nearly a quarter of their work force of 21,000 the next three years, union officials said. **********Dassault produces the Mirage F1 and 2000 fighter planes and has a 70 percent  stake in development of the Rafale fighter-bomber. The company reported a profit of $55.4 million on sales of $1.88 billion last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/23/world.main_headline: Struggle for Peace,' Egyptian Urges Arabs
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/23/world.print_headline: Struggle for Peace,' Egyptian Urges Arabs
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/23/world.body_text: **********Twenty-one Arab leaders gathered here today in a show of alarm and an attempt at deterrence aimed at the early direction taken by Israel's conservative new Government. **********The Arab summit meeting was the first in six years, and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said he hoped that the display of unity would help to guard against attempts to stray from the path toward peace in the Middle East. **********None of us wishes to return to war and destruction, nor seek to revert to the state of no war, no peace," Mr. Mubarak said in an opening address. "We are  sincerely prepared to struggle for peace until the end. We are prepared to face  its challenges and aftermath, as long as the other party agrees on this course." **********The unmistakable target of his remarks and of the gathering itself was Benjamin Netanyahu, whose election as Israel's Prime Minister three weeks ago galvanized a divided Arab world into today's show of collective will. **********Mr. Mubarak was careful to avoid any hint of a threat, and as the Arab leaders closed the doors to their meeting to continue what will be two days of private talks, Egyptian officials said they were taking pains to insure that the unusual gathering not end on a bellicose note. **********But in what is expected to be a preview of the leaders' final communique, the Egyptian President issued a clear challenge to Israeli policy guidelines that have suggested that Mr. Netanyahu's Government will be unwilling to withdraw completely from the Golan Heights, captured from Syria in the 1967 Arab-Israeli  war, or to permit the Palestinians to establish an independent state. **********"If any party allows itself to choose what to negotiate or what not, then this means that the other parties have the same right, which thus reverts the peace process to the zero point -- or, rather, totally destroys it," Mr. Mubarak said. **********Today's gathering brought together leaders who have long been at odds, including President Hafez al-Assad of Syria and King Hussein of Jordan, and the  session recorded by television cameras today presented at least a facade of Arab solidarity not seen since the Persian Gulf war of 1991. **********Among the 22 members of the Arab League, only Iraq -- still ostracized for its invasion of Kuwait in 1990 -- was absent. Those gathered at a single table,  in business suits and traditional Arab attire, included figures as diverse as Crown Prince Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah of Kuwait and the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, who flew to Cairo in a Libyan Airlines jet in open defiance  of a United Nations ban on flights to and from Libya. **********In an earlier reunion, Mr. Mubarak even embraced President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan, whom he has blamed for an assassination attempt against him  last June. And with Mr. Mubarak as a broker, Mr. Assad and King Hussein met privately for the first time in two years in a session that included an open airing of divisive issues including Jordan's accusations about Syrian support for terrorism. **********But today's dynamics were anything but straightforward, with the participants facing pressure from Syria and Lebanon, who want Arabs to rethink their ties with Israel; from Israel and the United States, who have warned that too tough an Arab stand could prove counterproductive, and from their own rivalries. **********Prime Minister Netanyahu, who was sworn in this week, told the Israeli Parliament that peace talks between Israel and its neighbors should proceed without preconditions. His Foreign Minister, David Levy, said he would not rule  out territorial compromise on the Golan Heights in exchange for peace with Syria. **********But the policy guidelines issued by Mr. Netanyahu's Government have suggested that he will stick to campaign promises ruling out the return of the Golan Heights and the establishment of a Palestinian state -- stands that mark a sharp break from the policy of his predecessor, Shimon Peres, and which have been received by the Arabs with varying degrees of apprehension and fury. **********Trying to steer away from any appearance of confrontation or panic, Egyptian  officials have emphasized that their efforts to bridge Arab divides and convene  a full-scale summit meeting began before Mr. Netanyahu's election. Mr. Mubarak said today that the most urgent issue before Arabs was the need to close ranks. **********Yet that sense of urgency has undeniably been felt with new force since the Israeli election on May 29, a potential watershed to which Mr. Mubarak appeared  to be referring when he said, "At this present moment, we feel that we are at a  fate-determining stage." **********On Egyptian television today, 30-year-old film clips and patriotic music revived memories of President Gamal Abdel Nasser and his aspirations to pan-Arab unity. But in the rallying that began today, the main beneficiaries were intended to be Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, and President Assad of Syria, which along with Lebanon appears most likely to be isolated by the policies of the new Israeli Government. **********In his remarks, President Mubarak set a tone likely to be echoed throughout the two-day session by making repeated mention of the 1991 Middle East peace conference in Madrid and its principles of land for peace and Palestinian self-determination. **********President Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali of Tunisia, the current President of the Arab League, was the other leader to speak in the open session. He declared that Israel bore "special responsibility" for honoring those principles. **********The Arab leaders plainly hope that such high-minded invocations will add weight to their appeals for Mr. Netanyahu to rethink his views, if only indirectly by convincing public opinion and the United States that he may be embarking on a perilous course. **********Foreign Minister Amr Moussa of Egypt suggested today that the strategy might  already be bearing fruit. He described the remarks by Mr. Levy as "more reassuring" than some earlier "dangerous indications." **********But Egypt, which made its own peace with Israel 17 years ago, heard calls behind closed doors this afternoon from Syria and Lebanon for a more forceful stand than Mr. Mubarak took today, officials said. According to a transcript, President Elias Hrawi of Lebanon said in a speech that "Israel is calling on us  to talk without preconditions, and we are calling on her for a comprehensive peace." **********And while the private meeting between Mr. Assad and King Hussein was intended to prevent disputes between them from becoming a flash point in the larger gathering, it did not prevent the King from using his speech to a closed session this afternoon in part to denounce the very "cross-border terrorism" that Jordanian officials have accused Syria of promoting. **********A transcript of the King's speech provided by Jordanian officials included a  stern warning aginst those who "replace civilized brotherly dialogue by the export of nefarious attempts that kill the slightest hope of restoring Arab solidarity." **********Colonel Qaddafi, the maverick among those who attended today, supported Iraq's invasion and occupation of Kuwait in 1990-91, and he said only last month that the tiny gulf state should not remain independent if it could not defend itself. **********That was bound to make his reception by gulf leaders even more brittle than those extended to other Arabs who supported Iraq and attended the gathering today, including King Hussein, Mr. Arafat and President Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/08/busin.body_text: **********The Swiss Bank Corporation, Switzerland's third-largest bank, said yesterday that its profit growth slowed in the third quarter as world financial markets calmed. The company said that it still expected a substantially higher profit for 1996 than it recorded last year but not as high as it predicted earlier in the year. https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/08/busin.snippet: Diary of week's events in financial world; photos (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/08/busin.body_text: **********POLITICS **********Whose Economy Is It? **********O.K., so the economy's doing better, but did Bill Clinton make it happen? Come on, now: can one mere mortal truly make the difference in a vast, sprawling creature like the American economy? But that question is beside the point: in politics, it's appearances that count, and a recent poll shows that people give the President a lot of credit. Some 72 percent feel economically secure (yes, you could argue that that leaves an awful lot of insecurity), and 55 percent approve of the way Mr. Clinton is handling the economy. That approval, by the way, has shot up from 46 percent two weeks ago, suggesting that the Democrats' little gathering had an impact. And if Bob Dole thinks he'll get votes by tapping into economic anxiety, he may be barking up the wrong tax cut. **********UNEMPLOYMENT **********Young and Old at Work **********That poll was followed by a bit of good economic news: the August unemployment rate dropped to a seven-year low of 5.1 percent, from 5.4 percent in July. And there were strong gains for those often left on the fringes: people under 25 and over 54. Oddly, though, the stock market didn't act in its usually perverse way. The Dow industrials did drop 49 points the day before the jobs data came out, ostensibly because of worries that a strong report would mean higher interest rates, which would hurt stocks. But when the job numbers hit on Friday, the market took it in stride, with the Dow tktktkt tktktktting. Go figure. **********ECONOMIC POLICY **********Inflation Takes a Holiday **********Forget about whether children on welfare will go hungry, or whether anyone will ever see the tax cuts that politicians keep promising. No, here's the burning economic issue: Should policy makers go through hoops to hammer inflation, now a nice nonthreatening 3 percent or so, down closer to zero? A minor academic quibble, you say? Well, top Federal Reserve officials and economic policy makers from around the globe felt they had to trek to Jackson Hole, Wyo., a week ago to discuss it. (Of course, most people would discuss anything if they got to do it at a snazzy mountain resort.) Alan Greenspan's conclusion: ''Price stability is within reach.'' But critics say zero inflation would have a cost: higher unemployment, because employers, unable to effectively cut wages by keeping them steady, will cut people instead. A high price that would be for inflation-free perfection. **********MEGA-STORES **********Home Sweet Office **********Remember when ''offices'' were in big, ugly buildings, while ''homes'' featured easy chairs and refrigerators? Of course not. Today it is a pitiable home indeed that doesn't have three computers, two phone lines, a color printer, a fax, a copier and cabinets stocked with office supplies. No wonder, then, that stores like Staples and Office Depot -- gleefully feeding what has become a $185 billion market -- have grown like crazy. But not fast enough for them, apparently: last week, Staples agreed to buy Office Depot in a $3.4 billion stock swap. The merger will create a giant that's twice the size of its nearest rival, with more than 1,100 superstores nationwide. The company had better hope people don't get fed up with it all and convert those home offices back to dens. **********AND MORE MEGA-STORES **********Now It's Bookstore City **********It's never quite made sense. New York, the nation's biggest city, had the smallest bookstores -- storefront nooks jammed to the pressed-tin ceilings, musty basement literary lairs. But no matter, much of that is being wiped away by those book mini-cities that some people insist on calling ''stores.'' Barnes & Noble, of course, has already barreled around town with its vast superstores (dropping along the way, the slogan: ''If you paid full price, you didn't get it at . . .'' slogan; now that many of its rivals have succumbed, you may well pay full price). But suddenly it has someone its own size to pick on. Borders just opened a 38,000-square-foot store in lower Manhattan. (Complete with cappuccino? Of course.) But are people reading those books? Or are they all surfing the you-know-what? **********PUBLISHING **********Sorry: Politics, Not Sex **********And what books sell? Simple, says Harold Evans, head of Random House. ''If we didn't publish books by people who had illicit sex, we would be out of business.'' The illicit sex of the week, of course, involved Dick Morris, if the tabloids had it right, and Mr. Evans is now paying Mr. Morris $2.5 million to tell his tale. Here's the odd thing, though: Mr. Morris won't be writing about illicit sex (not his, anyway), just about being a political guru -- though the whiff of intrigue certainly didn't hurt. He already had a deal with Random House, you see (which the White House isn't at all happy about), but last week, cashing in on his new infamy, he shopped the book around before landing back at Random House -- for more money. **********BANKING **********Farewell, Chemical **********Chase gave last week, and Chase took away. Actually, it was a year ago that Chase Manhattan announced that it was merging with Chemical, a move that would take away 100 branches in the New York area. But appearances count for a lot, and it was not until last weekend that the Chemical signs actually came down, officially killing off yet another New York institution. But perhaps out of guilt, perhaps because it's saving so much with those new economies of scale, Chase gave $750,000 to Carnegie Hall to support a recital series -- ''the largest corporate sponsorship for programs'' ever, a Carnegie Hall official said. On Chase's new balance sheet, though, do numbers under $1 million even register? **********IRAQ **********Is It Principle, or Oil? **********High moral principles are routinely cited when we try to batter Saddam Hussein into submission (though of course it's other, less exalted Iraqis we're battering), but some less idealistic souls say that in the long run it's really just about oil. It's got to keep flowing, after all, so we can maneuver our mighty sport utility vehicles through those rocky, wild suburban malls. In the short run, though, oil prices and oil-company shares soared as soon as we struck -- since the attack killed any chance for 700,000 barrels a day to start flowing out of Iraq. **********AWAKENINGS **********Beyond Chicken Noodle **********Campbell Soup. That's a sleepy company if ever there was one. Chicken noodle. cream of tomato. Yawn, yawn, yawn. Last week, though, Campbell announced to the world that it was snapping to attention and reinventing itself -- to go to ''a new level,'' as its president put it. What's it all about? Among other things, a huge $2.5 billion stock buyback and more spending on advertising. And no self-respecting overhaul would be complete these days without job cuts: Campbell will dismiss 650 workers, including 11 percent of its headquarters staff. So was this just a lot of noise? Investors certainly didn't think so, with the stock leaping to a record the day of the announcement and rising even further the next.
