https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/25/busin.main_headline: Market Place;The S.E.C. chief wades into the battle over accounting rules.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/25/busin.print_headline: Market Place;The S.E.C. chief wades into the battle over accounting rules.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/25/busin.body_text: **********THE battle over accounting rules is on, and Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is demanding a bigger role than ever  in deciding who picks the people who write the rules. **********Mr. Levitt is asking that the Financial Accounting Foundation, which chooses  the members of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, have a majority of public representatives as opposed to representatives of various groups with a stake in accounting rules. And he wants the S.E.C. to have the power to approve  who is chosen for the board. **********The move comes at a time when corporate financial executives have been putting pressure on the foundation to reform the F.A.S.B. in ways that would increase the power of business to block unwanted accounting standards. **********In a talk prepared for delivery last night to the Economic Club of Chicago,  Mr. Levitt disclosed his initiative and seemed to come out against the effort to increase corporate power in the process, saying that he was trying "to strengthen and safeguard the independence of financial accounting standard-setting." **********The Financial Accounting Foundation is charged with raising the money to support the F.A.S.B. and the Government Accounting Standards Board, which sets accounting rules for government agencies, and with naming the members of those boards. And it has the authority to change the way those boards are structured. **********Currently, the foundation has 14 trustees, all but one chosen by such various constituency groups as the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, the Financial Executives Institute and the Securities Industry Association. The  sole public member, chosen by the other trustees, is Kathryn D. Wriston, a director of various organizations and the wife of Walter B. Wriston, the retired chairman of Citicorp. **********In a letter to J. Michael Cook, the foundation's president and the chairman of Deloitte & Touche, a large accounting firm, Mr. Levitt said he thought a majority of the trustees should "consist of individuals with strong public service backgrounds, who are able to represent the public interest, free of conflict." **********The F.A.S.B. has come under increasing fire over the years from corporations, which have won a series of concessions but have continued to grumble. The board  can now approve standards only by a super-majority vote -- five of its seven members, two of whom come from companies. Using political influence, including a vote of the Senate, the companies forced the board to back down when it tried to force them to report as an expense the value of stock options given to executives and other employees. **********When that happened, Mr. Levitt had little to say. But in the wake of an effort by some members of the Financial Executives Institute to force wholesale changes, he appears to have decided to step in and fight. **********In his letter to Mr. Cook, Mr. Levitt complained that the F.A.S.B. "is not being adequately reinforced by its parent organization and, thus, its public interest objectives are at risk." **********Mr. Cook, in an interview late yesterday, said the trustees would address the issues raised by Mr. Levitt at their meeting on Tuesday, and would act quickly.  He added that he hoped decisions on changing the F.A.S.B. would be made within a few months, but it is clear that Mr. Levitt wants those decisions to be made by  a reconstituted board. **********Just who those people are will be crucial. And finding people who are both disinterested and well informed will be a challenge. **********In a telephone interview last night, Kenneth Johnson, the controller of Motorola and one of the executives who has been pushing for changes at the F.A.S.B., said he had not seen Mr. Levitt's letter and could not comment on it.  But he added that the F.A.S.B. had to be changed. "They are so enamored with theoretical accounting purity that they are unable to look at the practical effects of what they are trying to do," he said. **********Mr. Cook said he wanted to make changes that would enable the board to win "higher approval ratings," although he added that any standard-setter would anger some people, and he said changes clearly were needed to make the board more productive. **********But the risk is that in winning approval from the corporate executives who are now the angriest, the eventual loser could be the investors who depend on financial statements. "If standards are drawn, or even seen to be drawn, to favor corporate interests over those of investors, faith in our markets will erode," Mr. Levitt said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/05/world.main_headline: A Hard Line In Mideast Gets Harder
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/05/world.print_headline: A Hard Line In Mideast Gets Harder
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/05/world.body_text: **********When the luncheon conversation at Syria's Presidential palace turned to the subject of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the American guest and his Syrian host could not have disagreed more sharply. **********The guest, former President George Bush, praised Mr. Gorbachev for his courage in opening the closed Soviet system to internal criticism and to accommodation with old foes. The host, President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, said Mr. Gorbachev had made a historic mistake. **********The conversation, described by people with knowledge of the meeting last week, ended on a gracious note. But it drove home an unmistakable message: As the cold war between Israel and Syria continues, nothing resembling glasnost is  on Mr. Assad's mind. **********In many ways, Syria remains on war footing, with more than two-fifths of its  budget devoted to defense and no public dissent permitted to its uncompromising  line toward peace with Israel, a stance that insists on the full return of the Golan Heights by Israel to Syria. Since Israel suspended the latest round of peace talks between the two countries after it was hit with a wave of suicide bombings, that solid front has taken on an even harder edge. **********"If anything, people have been clamming up," a Damascus-based diplomat said in describing Syrians who not long ago had begun to express hope that peace with Israel might be just around the corner. **********On Tuesday, President Assad warned that the path to an accord had "narrowed to a large extent." With Israel's attention fixed on the national elections to be held at the end of May, no one here expects the American-brokered peace talks to resume at least until early summer. **********Only groups and individuals even more critical of Israel and the United States than the Government have felt free to vary from that official line, including representatives of some of the militant Palestinian organizations. **********One group, led by Ahmad Jibril, has even used a powerful radio station that broadcasts from Syria to taunt Israelis in the aftermath of the recent bombings, which were carried out by the militant Palestinian group Hamas. "Every Zionist settler has to choose between two fates: to leave to where he came from, or become pieces of stale meat thrown on the sidewalks of Palestine," a broadcast said in late February. "He is free to choose." **********Mr. Jibril's group, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, General Command, is one of 10 organizations, including Hamas and Islamic Holy War, whose presence here is cited by the State Department as reason for listing  Syria as a sponsor of terrorism. American officials have said Mr. Assad will force them to close their offices if Syria makes peace with Israel. **********For now, however, the sanctuary that Syria provides them still serves a purpose for Mr. Assad, who has held power for 25 years and appears determined above all else that his country not show any sign of bending toward Israel. **********Institutions like the Parliament remain weak and the range of public debate is closely circumscribed. As President, Mr. Assad holds near-absolute authority, and his Government uses its power so effectively that in Syria today there is neither an organized political opposition nor visible manifestations of opposition to the Government. **********Mr. Assad remains so central to the equation of Middle East peace that Secretary of State Warren Christopher has in just over three years visited Damascus 17 times to see him. **********His most recent American visitor, Mr. Bush, who was winding up a private visit to the Middle East, spent several hours with him last Tuesday, alone but for an interpreter, to talk about the quest for peace. **********But Mr. Assad is well known for his iron will and powerfully held views. When the conversation shifted to topics ranging from mad cow disease to Mr. Gorbachev, people with knowledge of the conversation said that the Syrian leader made plain that he regarded the example set by his former Soviet counterpart as one to be avoided at all costs. **********"Everyone knew what they were talking about," one person said of a conversation that he described as a kind of allegory about Syria today. **********Mr. Bush praised Mr. Gorbachev at length for his courage and foresight in freeing the Soviet Union from a closed and stifling system. **********Perhaps not surprisingly, Mr. Assad balked. "What Assad said was basically: 'Look where it got him,' " another person said, adding that the Syrian leader had pointed out that Mr. Gorbachev's policies had also hastened his own downfall and the Soviet Union's collapse. "From that perspective, he certainly has a point."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/17/world.main_headline: British Would Yield to I.R.A. on Arms if Cease-Fire Is Revived
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/17/world.print_headline: British Would Yield to I.R.A. on Arms if Cease-Fire Is Revived
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/17/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister John Major of Britain said today that if the I.R.A. restored its cease-fire, the British and Irish Governments would not insist on the group's immediate disarmament when a conference to discuss peace and the political future of Northern Ireland started on June 10. **********Mr. Major's statement was an important concession to the I.R.A. because its political wing, Sinn Fein, has been refusing to press for a restoration of the cease-fire until the British gave assurances that the disarmament issue would not block discussion of other matters. **********The 17-month cease-fire was broken with a series of bomb attacks beginning on Feb. 9 in London. In recent weeks, Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, has said that a new cease-fire was unlikely without assurances from Mr. Major that the talks would not focus on disarmament. **********Today, in a first-person article in The Irish Times of Dublin, the Prime Minister wrote that disarmament, called decommissioning here, would have to be considered at the start of the June talks, but that "recommendations on decomissioning can be taken forward without blocking the negotiations." The article also was published in The Belfast Telegraph, an afternoon paper. **********Officials and analysts said Mr. Major chose The Irish Times partly because the Irish Government had been privately urging him to reassure the I.R.A. on the disarmament issue. **********Before Mr. Major's statement, Sinn Fein feared that political issues would not be discussed at the June talks until actual I.R.A. disarmament had begun. **********Britain and Ireland say the I.R.A. must restore the cease-fire if Sinn Fein is to be allowed to take part in these talks, which would make them the first negotiations with all parties represented. **********It is widely acknowledged that a peace conference without I.R.A. representatives would be virtually useless and could lead to a full resumption of violence, which has been restricted to London since the end of the cease-fire. **********Mr. Adams said he welcomed the "positive elements" of Mr. Major's statement.  "But he hasn't told us how it's going to be accomplished," he added. "Let's see  if we can build on what he's said." **********Mr. Adams said he would not appeal for a new cease-fire until he had heard more from the British and Irish Governments on how disarmament would be dealt with at the June conference, which is to be made up of delegates chosen at a special election on May 30. Irish and British officials are considering handling the issue by appointing former Senator George J. Mitchell to head a separate disarmament committee at the June talks. **********In January a disarmament commission led by Mr. Mitchell recommended that the  talks proceed with simultaneous consideration of disarmament and political negotiations. Mr. Mitchell is known to be ready to accept a role in the June negotiations. **********Prime Minister John Bruton of Ireland welcomed Mr. Major's statement and urged the I.R.A. to restore its cease-fire "straightaway," so Sinn Fein could be admitted to the June talks. **********David Trimble, the leader of the largest Protestant political group, the Ulster Unionist Party, said he favored simultaneous discussion of disarmament and political issues. He has also indicated he approves of the appointment of Mr. Mitchell. **********But the Rev. Ian Paisley, the evangelist leader of the smaller Democratic Unionist Party, called Mr. Major's statement "surrender to the I.R.A."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/19/busin.snippet: Bay Networks says it has acquired Netics for about $99 million (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/19/busin.main_headline: BAY NETWORKS BUYS NETICS IN CASH AND STOCK DEAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/19/busin.print_headline: BAY NETWORKS BUYS NETICS IN CASH AND STOCK DEAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/19/busin.body_text: **********Bay Networks, based in Billerica, Mass., said yesterday that it had acquired Netics, a privately held maker of computer networking equipment, for about $99 million -- $55 million of its stock and as much as $44 million in cash. Bay expects to take an unspecified charge in the current quarter for the purchase of Netics research and development. Netics makes switches that help move information between computers. The switches are based on a technology called 100Base-T and will be used in new Bay products. The market for the switches is expected to grow to more than $2.5 billion in 2000 from more than $700 million in 1996, the market researcher International Data Corporation said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/14/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Trade Threats? Say Ho-Hum;Chinese in a Boomtown Busy Making Money
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/14/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Trade Threats? Say Ho-Hum;Chinese in a Boomtown Busy Making Money
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/14/busin.body_text: **********To Wu Bangdong, a garment manufacturer in this booming coastal city, the danger that the United States and China will impose trade sanctions on each other seems a distant worry. **********A ubiquitous make-money-any-way-you-can mentality drives nimble garment companies like Mr. Wu's to make decisions with speed and flexibility, shifting products and markets with little hesitation. Lately, domestic sales in China have grown more rapidly than any export market. **********We don't really care about sanctions," said Mr. Wu, who at 33 is general manager of the fast-growing George Garment Group. The company sold $30 million in suits, shirts and neckties last year and plans to sell $40 million this year. "Demand is growing so much faster within China," he said, where city dwellers have taken a fancy to dressing up for work and for Sunday strolls. "We have already decided to concentrate on the domestic market." **********Facing a June 17 deadline, trade negotiators in Beijing and Washington are in a final round of brinkmanship over China's inability to control the piracy of American software, movies and musical recordings. If they fail to agree, $2 billion in sanctions will be imposed in each direction. But the indifference of  factory managers like Mr. Wu, many of whose garments are in categories that America has threatened with sanctions, is a measure of how economically irrelevant, and arguably misconceived, such measures can be. **********Despite solemn warnings from Washington that its $2 billion in new tariffs, the largest in United States history, will take a nasty bite out of China's economic growth, higher tariffs will actually affect just a small part of China's $48.5 billion in exports to the United States, let alone the nation's tens of billions in additional exports worldwide. **********"In terms of the overall economy, the effect would be minimal," said Nicholas Kwan, senior economist at Merrill Lynch in Hong Kong. "Sanctions would hardly affect 1.5 percent of China's trade. That's really nothing dramatic." **********Arguing that China has been lax in enforcing a landmark agreement on intellectual property rights reached in February 1995, the United States trade representative's office announced last month that it would increase tariffs on textiles, garments like those stitched together by Mr. Wu's factory, electrical  goods like telephones and sporting goods like water skis and surfboards. **********The sanctions are intended as a political stick to encourage Chinese leaders  to get serious about the widespread piracy of American music, movies and software, since there is virtually no way to punish the pirates directly. **********[Charlene Barshefsky, the acting United States trade representative, flew to  Beijing on Thursday amid indications that a Chinese crackdown on pirate software factories might prompt the United States to drop its sanction threat. "We hope the U.S. side will take note that the Chinese side has made tremendous effort,"  a spokesman for the Chinese Foreign Ministry said in Beijing.] **********In laying out the proposed sanctions, Ms. Barshefsky had said the list of items selected was designed to minimize the impact on American consumers. Popular merchandise from China, like footwear -- $6.1 billion worth was imported last year -- was omitted. **********Textiles and garments were also chosen, United States officials said, because most of those factories are in southern China, where compact disk pirates operate, as if taxing one group would somehow increase pressure on the other. **********A number of exporters of textiles and garments and electrical goods will obviously be hurt, and some possibly put out of business by the new tariffs. Economists in the Chinese Government have even warned that 500,000 textile industry jobs could be lost, though no one really knows. **********Of course, trade sanctions can also create unintended results. Winston Lord,  Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, complained that Japanese and European companies were taking advantage of an anti-American mood in Beijing to win contracts that might go to American companies. Such cases are  actually quite rare, though United States and Chinese officials often have their own political reasons for talking about them. **********Yet here on the coast of southern China, in a city of three million where hundreds of garment factories have sprung up in old wheat fields, the consensus  among many Chinese business leaders is that the threatened sanctions would have  a minimal overall impact. **********Some businessmen go further, saying that United States trade policy is arrogant and muddled, if Washington thinks it can hurt China's economy without damaging the benefits it derives from the $60 billion trade relationship between the two nations. **********"Trade goes in two directions," said Chen Qingsheng, chairman of Lianyi Touring Goods, which shipped $1.5 million of sporting goods, or one-fourth of its total sales, to the United States last year. "These sanctions only stop a small part. It's not like they're revoking most-favored-nation status," referring to the preferential trade relationship that China now enjoys with the  United States. **********To Mr. Chen, and perhaps to anyone as far outside the Beltway as China, the rationale behind the Clinton Administration's trade action looks a bit murky. **********Most-favored-nation status, originally designed to encourage Communist governments to allow freer emigration, is likely to be renewed for China -- a country that still restricts travel overseas -- principally because a significant jump in tariffs would be unacceptable to American businesses and consumers used to buying competitively priced garments, footwear, toys and electrical goods from China. **********Yet at the same time, lesser trade sanctions are being threatened because of  China's widespread piracy of intellectual property rights, an area the Chinese Government says it is actively working to control, if only with mixed results so far. **********"I don't really understand the American Government," said Mr. Chen, whose conversation was continually interrupted by calls on the two telephones on his office desk and the mobile phone in his lap. "This approach doesn't make any sense. China and America need each other in the long run." **********Despite his own reliance on exports to the United States, Mr. Chen said he was not worried because he expected a resolution to emerge from the Beijing trade talks. **********Like many Chinese businessmen, he sees the negotiations over piracy as little more than a colorful charade, following the same script as in previous years, with accusations and counteraccusations by officials on each side who finally smile and shake hands when a last-minute agreement is struck. **********Pressed about how he would cope with sanctions, Mr. Chen said that he would go through a few months of adjustment, shifting some production to nonsanctioned items and channeling merchandise to other foreign countries. **********Many American companies with operations in China have objected to the threat  of sanctions, worried about damage to the overall business climate. More specific concerns are voiced by American importers who already have contracts to buy items on the sanction list, like buyers for large department store chains. Such companies have paid for orders months in advance and will have to pay the new duties if sanctions are enacted. **********"Nobody expects these sanctions to be long term, so we are carrying the new cost, while Chinese exporters aren't affected at all," said Jeffrey J. Macho, managing director in North Asia for Sears, Roebuck & Company, which buys millions of dollars of garments in China. "It's the reverse of what's intended." **********Some American importers have already stopped orders for Chinese goods, United States officials have said, for fear that shipments in early June could be hit with new duties when they arrive in an American port after June 17, if there is  no accord by then. **********Other American companies would feel the blow of the $2 billion in retaliatory sanctions -- mainly on food products -- that China threatened after the United States trade representative's office formally published its list in Washington on May 15. The Chinese Government also warned that going ahead with sanctions would limit the access of American companies to China's market. **********Although no exporter will say so publicly, one solution to higher American tariffs is to ship sanctioned items through a third country. Chinese garment makers who have contended for years with American quotas have already learned how to send almost completed trousers to Hong Kong or Latin America or even Mongolia, for example, where they get a final button or zipper stitched on before being shipped off to the United States. In that way, China is not listed  as the country of export. **********Here in Wenzhou, for decades an impoverished area, there is a self-reliance that makes for a robust economy. Ma Jinlong, vice director of the Wenzhou Economic Reseach Center, said that Wenzhou's annual growth rate averaged 27.1 percent over the last four years. The city has attracted nearly 800,000 laborers from the surrounding countryside during its tremendous expansion. **********"With that kind of growth, sanctions would not be much of a shock here," said Mr. Ma, sipping tea in a noisy downtown restuarant. "A few sectors will be affected, though even they will find other markets. But it seems like there are  a lot of American consumers enjoying Chinese-made goods. They lose, too, if sanctions come." **********As for businessmen, they seem more eager to talk about investments than sanctions. "Do you know any American investors who would like to come to Wenzhou?" asked Chen Min, the general manager of the Jindingzhen Clothing Company, a $30-million-a-year manufacturer, who wants to expand rapidly so he can open stores in every major Chinese city. "We need extra capital." **********Mr. Chen says he has no reservations about cooperating with American businesses. "I like Americans," Mr. Chen said. "They have lots of money."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/26/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;For more than a quarter of the advertisers, it'll be Super Bowl I.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/26/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;For more than a quarter of the advertisers, it'll be Super Bowl I.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/26/busin.body_text: **********THE Dallas Cowboys have played in the Super Bowl before. So too have the Pittsburgh Steelers. But when they meet Sunday in Super Bowl XXX, it will be Super Bowl I for more than a quarter of the advertisers buying commercials in the NBC broadcast of the game. **********The Super Bowl rookies range from marketing giants like General Mills Inc. and Mastercard International to smaller, less well-known companies like Kinko's  Inc. and Mail Boxes Etc. Even the halftime show sponsor, Oscar Mayer, is a Super Bowl newcomer. **********Those advertisers will join Super Bowl mainstays that are making return appearances like the Cowboys and Steelers. Among them are the Anheuser-Busch Companies, the McDonald's Corporation, Nike Inc. and the Frito-Lay and Pepsi-Cola units of Pepsico Inc. **********Tyro or veteran, the more than two dozen advertisers that will run spots nationally during the game are spending an average of $1.2 million for the fifty-eight 30-second units of commercial time. That's a record for any television broadcast, easily surpassing one set last year when each 30-second Super Bowl commercial cost about $1 million. **********Why would a marketer sign up for the Super Bowl just when the price reaches a historic high of $40,000 a second? It's not unlike someone watching the Dow Jones industrial average set a record Wednesday, then rushing out to buy his or  her first shares of stock. **********Executives acknowledge how expensive a Super Bowl spot is and that several first-time advertisers in Super Bowl XXIX won't be back. But they assert there are compelling business reasons to finally advertise, from the game's status as  an unofficial national midwinter holiday to the demographic desirability of the  large viewing audience. **********"We knew right up front it was pricey," said Bob Starr, national communications manager for the Yamaha Motor Corporation USA in Cypress, Calif.,  which will run a 30-second commercial by the Saatchi & Saatchi Pacific unit of Cordiant P.L.C. in Torrance, Calif. **********"But we also knew we had to make the investment," he added, because Yamaha was seeking "a very broad-reach, impactful" way to introduce the Royal Star, its entry into the so-called supercruiser segment of the motorcycle market, and "nothing is more broad reach and impactful." **********Karen Sophiea, vice president for marketing at Kinko's in Ventura, Calif., said it required a "deep swallow" to "step up to the Super Bowl." **********"When I first talked about it," she said, recalling a presentation to other Kinko's executives, "they looked at me and laughed. **********"But then the chairman said, 'I'm glad to see you be so bold and audacious,'  " she added. "It's the prestigious platform we need." So Kinko's will run a commercial by Hal Riney & Partners/Heartland in Chicago that will introduce "The new way to office" as the Kinko's theme. **********"It's a big chunk of change," said William Lange, vice president for marketing at Mail Boxes Etc. in San Diego. His company's spot, created by Kenneth C. Smith Advertising in San Diego, will devour about 8 percent of its annual advertising budget of $15 million. **********"But it seemed like an opportunity we couldn't pass up," Mr. Lange said, because of the serendipity of Oscar Mayer's sponsorship of the halftime show: by coincidence, Oscar Mayer is the focus of the Mail Boxes Etc. commercial. Chad Gretzema, a driver of an Oscar Mayer Wienermobile, describes how Mail Boxes Etc. serves as his "office on the road." **********Bob Eckert, president of Oscar Mayer Foods in Madison, Wis., a unit of the Philip Morris Companies, said the company's sponsorship of the halftime show grew out of a 13-year relationship with the National Football League. But until  now, he added, Oscar Mayer's efforts had primarily centered on "a lot of local promotions during the football season." **********"We've seen our business grow as a result of what we've done with the N.F.L.," Mr. Eckert said. "So we think it's time to take the next step." **********Eyebrows rose when another first-timer, Mastercard, announced its plans because rival Visa International is an N.F.L. sponsor and Mastercard is not. **********But "this is not about an ambushing opportunity," said Joan Bogin, vice president for advertising for the United States region at Mastercard in Purchase, N.Y. "Rather, it reflects a new strategy to heighten our brand awareness, and nothing says you're here like the Super Bowl does." Mastercard will run two spots by the Ammirati & Puris/Lintas unit of the Interpublic Group  of Companies in New York; Visa will also run two commercials, which were created by the BBDO New York unit of the Omnicom Group. **********One Super Bowl advertiser, the United States unit of the Nissan Motor Company, is not a first-timer but will return for the first time since 1990, running a "teaser" spot promoting the new Pathfinder sport-utility vehicle. **********"Upward of 60 percent of our target audience of adults 25 to 54 will be watching," said Pam Keehn, Nissan account director at the TBWA Chiat/ Day unit of Omnicom in Venice, Calif. "It's our best opportunity to reach them in one fell swoop." **********While some first-time advertisers from Super Bowl XXIX will return Sunday, like the National Pork Producers Council, others will not. **********"We'll be back as we grow bigger and stronger and our pockets become deeper," said Michael B. Moore, vice president for marketing at No Fear Inc., the sports  apparel marketer in Carlsbad, Calif. "But this year we've made a strategic decision to allocate dollars to other media that give us a better bang for the buck." **********One pitfall to being a first-time advertiser is that longtime sponsors can reserve commercial time during the first half. The conventional wisdom decrees second-half slots less desirable because several recent Super Bowls have been routs. **********"I don't think that's true," said Martin F. Puris, chairman, chief executive  and chief creative officer of Lintas Worldwide, which landed third- and fourth-quarter time slots for the Mastercard spots. **********"Being on the game," he added, "is being in the game."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/16/busin.main_headline: COMPANY NEWS;A FOR-PROFIT SPINOFF OF INTELSAT IS PROPOSED
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/16/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;A FOR-PROFIT SPINOFF OF INTELSAT IS PROPOSED
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/16/busin.body_text: **********The Comsat Corporation and the Federal Government yesterday proposed to revamp Intelsat, the global satellite consortium, by spinning off a publicly traded, for-profit affiliate from it. The plan is subject to approval by the members of Intelsat, a consortium backed by 136 governments. The group, which is based in Washington, owns and operates the world's most extensive global communications satellite system. Comsat is the largest owner. Under the plan, Intelsat's roughly $3 billion in assets -- made up largely of more than 20 satellites -- would be split about evenly between the new affiliate and the current owners. Initially, the existing Intelsat would own all the new company's stock. The proposal calls for 60 percent of the stock to be sold to outside investors within a year. Intelsat lost a satellite Wednesday when a Chinese rocket carrying one exploded and crashed seconds after takeoff in southwestern Sichuan province.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/28/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Another Revamping At True North
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/28/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Another Revamping At True North
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/28/busin.body_text: **********True North Communications Inc., which owns agencies including Foote, Cone & Belding, announced yesterday another revamping of top management that included two executives being stripped of their responsibilities, two promotions and a formation of a committee to focus on resolving a fractious dispute with Publicis S.A. over a joint-venture European agency network. **********Jack Balousek, who only three months ago was named chairman and chief executive of TN Technologies, the digital and interactive marketing services unit of True North, will be replaced in those roles by Gregory W. Blaine, 47, executive vice president and global operating systems director. Mr. Balousek, 52, will continue at True North, but has not yet been assigned new duties. **********Also losing executive duties was Craig R. Wiggins, 51, vice chairman, who had been responsible for mergers and acquisitions. Those duties will now be overseen by a new committee of six independent outside directors on the True North board. **********That committee has also been given full responsibility to reach agreement with Publicis on the two-year dispute over Publicis FCB Europe, the joint-venture network. Disagreements over operational and management issues led  Publicis and True North, which is based in Chicago, to declare that while the network, with estimated billings of $1.9 billion, would remain intact, they would end an alliance agreement binding them to cooperate worldwide. **********The other executive besides Mr. Blaine being promoted was Mitchell T. Engell, 44, executive vice president and corporate operations director. He takes a new post, president of the Associated Communications Companies, supervising the agencies separate from Foote, Cone like Tierney & Partners in Philadelphia and TN Media in New York.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/06/busin.snippet: Prices of US Treasury securities rise sharply; benchmark 30-year bond surges 31/32, to price of 102 6/32, to yield 6.58 percent, down from 6.66 percent on Nov 4; graph (L)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/06/busin.body_text: **********Weak economic data and a strong dollar, combined with expectations in the stock and bond markets that the post-election political landscape will not change, sent bond prices sharply higher yesterday. **********The benchmark 30-year bond surged 31/32 , to a price of 1026/32  to yield 6.58 percent, down from 6.66 percent on Monday and the lowest since March 26, when it was 6.57 percent. A bond's yield moves in the opposite direction of its price. **********Investors yesterday saw yet another sign of slowing economic growth, as September home completions fell 5.8 percent, to 1.358 million units, from a a revised 1.442 million units in August. **********The downturn in completions further removed concerns that the Fed might raise interest rates at its coming Federal Open Market Committee meeting on next Wednesday, or at the final meeting for this year on Dec. 17. The first meeting for 1997 will be Feb. 4. **********Foreign demand for Treasury securities caused by the rising dollar also pushed prices higher. Weak retail sales reports also contributed to the rally. **********Analysts said the bullish tone in trading yesterday also eased fears about the market's ability to absorb the large amount of Treasury paper coming to market this week. **********The market reacted to early exit polls that showed President Clinton leading the Republican challenger, Bob Dole, but the Democrats failing to make headway in their effort to regain control of one or both houses of Congress. The market had feared that if Democrats were successful, there would be less incentive to cut the budget deficit. **********Jack Regan, chief derivative strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross,  said the optimistic view on the election this week, was for a Democratic President with a Republican Congress. ''Expectations among Wall Street traders and investors are that we will continue having the two parties work toward a solution in reducing the budget deficit, pretty much the way they have for the past few years,'' Mr. Regan said. **********Mr. Regan said that yesterday's three-year note auction, the first part of the Government's quarterly refunding, was a ''fair auction'' and came in as advertised. He noted that noncompetitive bidding was a little less than expected, with the bid-to-cover ratio, or the number of bids compared with size of the total auction, a little on the light side. The bid to cover at yesterday's auction was 2.28 to 1, compared with an average of 2.49 to 1 over the last four auctions. **********The yield came in at 5.889 percent, in line with expectations. **********Mr. Regan said the retail sales reports helped alleviate inflation fears. **********''The weekly retail reports released yesterday were a little lighter than they had been in the prior week,'' he said. Today the Treasury will auction 10-year notes, but with the yield in the 10-year and 30-year maturities lower than they have been since last March, Mr. Regan said, ''it may prove to be more formidable to auction the 10-year, considering that we still don't know the full effects of the election at the present time.'' **********Doug Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston, said that while a resurgence of foreign demand helped propel the market along to lower yields, ''the Street fought it the whole way, believing that it is dangerous to press the market higher during a refunding auction.'' **********In when-issued trading ahead of today's and tomorrow's auctions, the 10-year note was being offered at a price to yield 6.27 percent, down 7 basis points from the previous day, while the 30-year bond was offered at a price to yield 6.54 percent, down 8 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three-year notes: **********(000 omitted in dollar figures) **********Average Price   99.989       Average Yield   5.879%       Low Price   99.962       High Yield   5.889%       High Price   100.008       Low Yield   5.872%       Accepted at low price   10%       Total applied for   $42,194,660       Accepted   $18,501,060       Noncompetitive   $564,000       Interest set at   5 7/8% **********The 3-year notes mature Nov. 15, 1999.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/22/busin.main_headline: 4 Archer-Daniels Executives To Leave Board for Outsiders
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/22/busin.print_headline: 4 Archer-Daniels Executives To Leave Board for Outsiders
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/22/busin.body_text: **********Four managers of the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, the agricultural giant,  will step down from its board of directors, the company announced yesterday. **********In a letter to shareholders, Dwayne O. Andreas, the company's chairman and chief executive, attributed the move to a January report by the corporate governance committee. The report recommended that a majority of the board and its committees be composed of outside directors. **********In the letter, Mr. Andreas said that his son, Michael D. Andreas, the executive vice president, and James R. Randall, the company president, would not stand for re-election. Also stepping down will be H. D. Hale, the president of ADM Milling, and the chairman's nephew, Martin L. Andreas, the company's senior  vice president. Dwayne Andreas plans to continue on the board. **********"The board of directors of A.D.M. should be made up of qualified individuals  who are not members of the A.D.M. management, with the single exception being the chairman and chief executive," Mr. Andreas wrote in the letter. **********The announcement was far from surprising. Archer-Daniels had adopted the governance committee's report as policy in January, and its terms could not be met without the resignation of the management directors. **********But even with this step, the board would still have many directors with close connections to Mr. Andreas, the chief executive, or the company. Many of the remaining executives are former company executives, or are related to Mr. Andreas. **********"This is a good first step, but it is only a first step, and they have a ways to go to become a fully independent board," said Richard Koppes, general counsel for the California Public Employees Retirement System, or Calpers, which has criticized Archer-Daniel's directors. Still, Mr. Koppes said that he was "very encouraged.". **********Shares of Archer-Daniels were unchanged at $18.625 yesterday. **********The move came in response to pressure by institutional investors to end insider domination of the board. The critics said that the directors were failing to treat a Federal criminal investigation of the company's business practices seriously, in large part because of their ties to management. **********Three grand juries are investigating accusations that senior Archer-Daniels officers engineered a conspiracy with competitors to fix prices for several additives to food and animal feed, including lysine, high-fructose corn syrup and citric acid. The investigation was sparked by Mark E. Whitacre, a former senior executive at Archer-Daniels, who worked for several years as a secret informant for Government prosecutors. **********At least two other executives are expected to resign, because of a new rule that board members not be allowed to run for re-election once they reach the age of 70. Under that rule, Ray A. Goldberg, a professor of business at Harvard University who helped lead the governance committee, and Happy Rockefeller, a longtime friend of Mr. Andreas and the widow of Nelson A. Rockefeller, would have to step down this year.

Terms of the sale were not disclosed. In December, James River said it intended to sell its CZ Inks division and its plastic packaging business to focus on its more profitable tissue-paper and consumer products business. Combined, the inks division and the plastic packaging business had about $540 million in 1995 sales, the company said. James River's CZ Ink's division employs 200 people at seven plants. James River said it would use proceeds from the sale to reduce its long-term debt.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/21/busin.main_headline: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;Slicing the Last of the Regulated Monopolies
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/21/busin.print_headline: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;Slicing the Last of the Regulated Monopolies
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/21/busin.body_text: **********MERGERS, restructuring, alliances: We've become used to these headline-making events in the telephone industry. It is still unsettling, however, when such news involves electric utilities. **********Well, customers and investors, get ready. The current takeover battle over a  utility in Kansas, the recent merger of electric and gas companies in Texas and  nontraditional alliances -- like the one including Ameritech and Wisconsin Electric to provide interactive energy information -- are only early indications of the revolutionary changes about to occur in the last remaining regulated monopoly. **********Since 1978, when a Federal law opened power generation to private companies, the market has become more competitive. Today, marketers -- both utility affiliates and independents -- offer to supply power at about 40 percent below the costs that utilities are passing along to customers. Including the transmission and distribution of the electricity, these prices are still 15 percent lower, on average. **********Evidence from other industries, like telecommunications and natural gas, and  from other countries shows that customers who gain the right to choose their electricity supplier will exercise that right. Almost half the large customers in Britain, for example, have switched suppliers since they were given this choice five years ago. **********In this country, it is not surprising that Federal regulation has accommodated these market forces by providing wholesale customers like municipalities with access to the transmission system. And pilot experiments, allowing consumers to choose their electricity suppliers, much as they do their  long-distance telephone companies, are under way. Soon all customers in California will have the option, and Massachusetts and New York are likely to follow suit. Federal legislation introduced this month would provide for customer choice nationally. **********The results of all this will be the end of the electric utility industry as we know it. In its place, three distinct, but linked, businesses are emerging: power generation, wires and energy services. **********Power generation will be a highly competitive commodity business. Power producers -- utilities as well as independents -- will be fighting it out in regional markets defined primarily by constraints in the transmission network. Price transparency, aided by the proliferation of spot markets and futures contracts like those recently initiated by the New York Mercantile Exchange, will stimulate even more competition. **********The transition will be painful for many of today's generators. Costs that customers will no longer cover for expensive plants and contracts -- "stranded costs" in industry jargon -- could require the eventual write-off of about $135  billion, about equal to the equity of American utilities. **********Successful generators will have low costs and will be astute in playing regional power markets. Many of today's players won't cut it, and a huge consolidation of generating plants by efficient producers is inevitable. **********THE wires business -- the transmission and distribution of electricity -- will remain regulated but will be operated by utilities or third parties, with access to the wires open to all. **********Operators of distribution wires will seek regulation that encourages efficiency. Regulators are expected to go along, provided that the savings are shared with customers. Some competitors will seek economies of scale by consolidating assets and activities with neighboring electric and other utilities, including providers of natural gas, water and possibly telephone and  cable service. The recent merger of the Texas Utilities Company, a power company, with the Enserch Corporation, a gas utility, and the acquisition of a British water company by its local electric distributor are early moves toward "wires and pipes" companies. **********The energy services business, which involves the packaging of different types of energy and other services, is just getting started. The leading edge of this  business is the marketing of power -- generated by low-cost providers and moved  for a fee across the wires of intervening utilities -- to wholesale customers. Since it was first allowed in 1992, more than 200 companies have entered this business. The early leaders have been natural-gas marketers and financial traders who have had a decade to perfect their game. But the big contest is still ahead. **********Consider, for instance, the service businesses born of telecommunications deregulation. Cellular phones, paging, conference calling and a host of other services now account for about 25 percent of telecommunications revenue. Several companies are looking for the energy equivalent of these services by offering packaged natural gas, electricity and related services to grocery, fast-food and hotel chains; residential customers are next. **********What will the electric power industry look like in about a decade? There will probably be a small number of national-scale generators -- perhaps a dozen or so --, supplemented by regional and niche players. Many of today's electric utilities will be little more than regulated wires companies, but some will have grown by acquiring neighboring wires and other operations. Many companies -- maybe banks, retailers or other service companies -- will offer electricity, usually bundled with other products and services. **********Although electric mergers have become more frequent, the industry's future probably holds more horizontal than vertical consolidation. Companies that aspire to be regional or national generators will seek only generating assets, not the forever-regulated wires attached to today's integrated utilities. Others will shun the competitive generation business but may be interested in acquiring distribution assets to consolidate wires-only or wires-and-pipes businesses. **********Tough choices are ahead. Investors, who have seen electric utilities underperform the market in recent years, have the difficult task of picking winners. Policy makers must sort through the competing interests to balance demands for lower rates with the need to establish rules for effective long-term competition. Perhaps the toughest decisions are faced by the utilities as they try to remake themselves. Customers should benefit from lower prices and more options, but how much they do so will depend on how astute their choices are.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/27/world.snippet: Arabs in Bethlehem, who nine months ago celebrated withdrawal of Israeli soldiers, now speak bitterly in their rock-strewn battleground of dashed hopes for peace and anger that erupted into deadly fighting; photos; Palestinians point to work and t...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/27/world.main_headline: Among Arabs, Dashed Hope Brought Resentment to a Boil
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/27/world.print_headline: Among Arabs, Dashed Hope Brought Resentment to a Boil
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/27/world.body_text: **********Just nine months ago, this city was swept up in joyous celebration as Israeli occupation forces withdrew days before Christmas, handing over the traditional birthplace of Jesus to Palestinian rule. **********But as their town became a rock-strewn battleground today, Palestinians here spoke bitterly of their dashed hopes for peace and the frustrations that have welled up to produce one of the deadliest days of fighting in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. **********Like the Palestinian uprising that broke out in 1987 against a backdrop of grinding economic hardship and political stagnation, the current unrest is rooted in unrealized expectations, raised in this case by the Israeli-Palestinian peace accords. **********The anger here and across the self-rule territories did not seem to be directed today at Yasir Arafat, the onetime guerrilla who led Palestinians to the 1993 peace agreement and is now president of the Palestinian Authority. **********Instead, people here said, it was aimed at the remaining bonds of Israeli occupation. **********Work and travel restrictions, economic blockades and a new Israeli Government that has failed to carry out significant parts of the accords have left many Palestinians wondering whether there was anything to be gained by the pact they made. **********Israel's opening of an entrance to an archeological tunnel this week near Muslim holy sites in Jerusalem's Old City, Palestinians asserted, was only a final provocation that turned long-simmering resentment into rage. **********In Bethlehem today, people slipped back into old patterns of confrontation and hopelessness, fighting in the streets with Israeli soldiers and making grim predictions of a new uprising in which Palestinians would show Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel that he could no longer ignore their needs. **********''We're going backwards,'' said a man as screaming ambulances ferried wounded from the front line of fighting between hundreds of stone-throwing youths and Israeli soldiers. **********Clouds of tear gas and bursts of rubber bullets filled the air near an Israeli-controlled enclave at Rachel's Tomb, the traditional burial place of a wife of the biblical patriarch Jacob. **********Palestinian police officers and Israeli soldiers fired at one another as similar gun battles raged all across the Palestinian self-rule zones, filling hospitals with dead and wounded. **********''The Palestinian problem is in the freezer, and only God has the key,'' said an elderly man, in a typical show of despair. **********A teacher, Yahya Yahya, described the increasing disappointment in the months since Mr. Netanyahu took office. ''After the peace accord we had hoped for a change,'' he said, ''but we see that in the last three months things are getting worse and we are losing what we achieved. **********''They are expanding settlements, confiscating more land, building bypass roads for settlers that isolate Palestinian cities, and they haven't withdrawn from Hebron. The pressure on people was stronger than they could bear.'' **********But perhaps the most powerful strain has been economic. Israeli border closings imposed after suicide bombings in Israel have added to already high unemployment, barring many young Palestinians from reaching jobs. **********''People are feeling squeezed because they can't find work and can't earn a living,'' said Ibrahim Atallah as he watched waves of youths surge toward the Israeli soldiers. **********Nidal Juneidi, visiting from Hebron, asserted that there had been little improvement in daily life since the accords, and that border closings keeping Muslim worshipers from Jerusalem were particularly painful. **********''We had big hopes for peace, prosperity, our own country, our own nationality and freedom,'' he said. ''We've seen nothing of it. If we can't even reach Jerusalem, what kind of peace are they talking about?'' **********''People just want to live, nothing else,'' Mr. Juneidi continued. ''They want peace, a country of their own and work. If they lose hope, no one can guess what is going to happen. These are demonstrations for the peace accords. We want them to be kept.'' **********Nabil Kukali, who runs a Palestinian public opinion research center in the neighboring town of Beit Sahour, said he had recently found increasing resistance among Palestinians to pursuing peace talks as long as Mr. Netanyahu and his Government failed to meet Israeli commitments under the self-rule agreements. **********''They cannot take us back to the past,'' Mr. Kukali said. ''They should look to the future. We don't need an uprising anymore. We need to live with dignity.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/12/world.main_headline: Colombian Faults Pilots in the Fatal Air Crash
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/12/world.print_headline: Colombian Faults Pilots in the Fatal Air Crash
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/12/world.body_text: **********A Colombian aviation official said today that readings by investigators of navigational and recording data on an American Airlines flight that crashed near Cali on Dec. 20 indicated that it was pilot error rather than a failing by air traffic controllers that caused the crash. **********The official, Col. Jorge Parga, the Deputy Director of Colombia's Civil Aviation Administration, whose agency oversees pilots and air traffic controllers, said that although final results of the investigation are still pending, he saw "no reason at all to blame the air traffic controllers" because  "it was the responsibility of the pilot." The plane hit a mountain, killing 160  people; 4 survived. **********United States and Colombian officials investigating the crash have ruled out sabotage and mechanical difficulties. Airline pilots and newspapers have reported that the Cali airport's air traffic controllers could have been partly  responsible. **********They said the controllers could have realized that the pilot of the Boeing 757 was lost and that they should not have insisted that the crew navigate via a radio beacon to approach the airport for a landing. Instead, they said, the pilot should have been allowed to make a landing from his off-course position. They added that it was the air traffic controllers' insistence that may have contributed to the plane's veering toward the mountains. **********Colonel Parga said, however, that because there is no radar for the Cali airport, it was up to the pilot to inform the controllers where he was. "The controllers have no way to know where the pilot is if he does not tell them," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/09/world.main_headline: Clinton Approves Plan for Sanctions Against China Over Piracy
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/09/world.print_headline: Clinton Approves Plan for Sanctions Against China Over Piracy
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/09/world.body_text: **********President Clinton, meeting with his top foreign policy and economic advisers  about rising tensions with China, approved a plan today to go ahead with sanctions on Chinese exports to the United States if Beijing fails to stop producing pirated American software, movies and music, the White House said. **********Mr. Clinton told the acting United States Trade Representative, Charlene Barshefsky, to proceed next week with the publication of a list of goods totaling about $3 billion annually that could be subject to 100 percent tariffs  on June 15 unless China complies with an accord it signed with the United States a year ago. **********Before the sanctions are imposed, the list is likely to be winnowed to about $2 billion, roughly equivalent to the damage that the Administration estimates is being done to American software producers and entertainment companies by pirates each year. That would represent only about 5 percent of China's annual exports to the United States. **********"The President reaffirmed that if we don't get satisfaction, we have no choice but to go ahead with the sanctions," David Johnson, a White House spokesman, said this evening. **********While the session focused on the dispute over China's failure to protect intellectual property, White House officials said that far more was at stake. The meeting also discussed a growing concern that relations with Beijing are slipping further, with no clear strategy for ending the cycle of threats and counterthreats. **********As a result, nearly all top Cabinet members took part in the meeting: Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who is considering separate sanctions against China for its shipment of nuclear materials to Pakistan; Defense Secretary William Perry; Gen. John Shalikashvili, the chairman of the joint chiefs of staff; Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, and Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor. **********But participants said there was little discussion of a grander plan for dealing with China. Instead, the meeting discussed how to design the sanctions list so that it is likely to have the maximum impact on Chinese companies, especially those close to the Government and the military, while causing the least disruption to American retailers and others who might protest the action. **********Administration officials said that the list will be sent to Lee Sands, a trade negotiator who is to be in Beijing on Monday and Tuesday, just before the  May 15 deadline that Washington set for action by China on a plan to carry out last year's accords. Presumably Mr. Sands will brief Chinese leaders on the contents in the hope of extracting a last-minute settlement. **********But even if, the Chinese made some accommodation that prevented the list from being published, China will still have 30 days to act before the Customs Service begins applying the 100 percent duties. **********"We expect they'll take this to the wire," one senior Administration official said today. **********The negotiations will coincide with a bitter, annual Congressional debate over whether to extend the so-called most-favored-nation trade privileges to China that has already divided both the Democratic and Republican parties. **********The Administration has said that it would be self-destructive to cancel the trading privileges, which give China the benefit of low tariffs in the United States. Senator Bob Dole, the Republican frontrunner for the Presidential nomination, is expected to address the issue on Thursday morning in his first major policy speech about Asia, and is expected to support renewing the trade benefits with some conditions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/05/busin.main_headline: EARNING IT;When Americans See Bias and the Boss Is Foreign
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/05/busin.print_headline: EARNING IT;When Americans See Bias and the Boss Is Foreign
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/05/busin.body_text: **********FOR Beth Goodman, equality in her workplace came down to more than her suspicions that she was not being offered the same perks as the Japanese employees at the United States subsidiary of Tokai Bank. **********And despite her promotion to vice president, equality, she felt, was about responsibility and an adequate salary, both of which Ms. Goodman said she was denied because she was a woman and was not Japanese. **********Ms. Goodman said the Japanese men at the bank got the money and the important jobs. Twice, she contended, the company tried to replace her with a man. **********So in June 1994, after five years at the New York subsidiary, she filed a discrimination complaint with the United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. Five months later, she was dismissed from her job. **********Some employee-rights lawyers say discrimination cases against foreign subsidiaries are increasingly common as foreign companies continue to set up operations in the United States and as Federal oversight over discrimination wanes. **********And in many discrimination cases, the companies have invoked bilateral treaties that they say protect them from civil rights complaints when they bring an executive from overseas to fill a key position instead of promoting an American employee. **********Just last month, the American subsidiary of the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation was accused by the E.E.O.C. of allowing sexual harassment at its auto plant in Illinois. And on Monday, Astra, the Swedish pharmaceuticals company, announced that it had suspended the president and chief executive of it United States operations because of employee accusations of sexual harassment at the company. **********Lewis M. Steel, a civil rights lawyer in Manhattan who is handling Ms. Goodman's case, says companies become emboldened "each time the E.E.O.C. shrinks its budget -- which keeps happening." **********Mr. Steel said he knew of about 50 such discrimination complaints over the last three years. He said he was handling about 10 cases that involve Japanese subsidiaries, and four that involve units of French, German or Spanish companies. **********Ellen Vargyas, a lawyer for the E.E.O.C., said her agency did not track how many discrimination cases involved foreign companies. **********"Frankly, we hear enough about discrimination from American companies," she said. She noted that the agency handled about 100,000 discrimination complaints  a year. "We're just trying to keep our heads above water." She said the agency had not had a significant budget increase since 1979. **********Complaints against foreign companies do not always concern sex discrimination. Two years ago, the E.E.O.C. district office in New York helped settle an age discrimination case involving a man who had worked for the American unit of a Hong Kong bank and a national-origin case concerning an employee of a bank based in Venezuela. **********Ms. Goodman's accusations against Tokai have been supported by four men who used to work for the bank in the United States. The men have signed affidavits that have been submitted to the E.E.O.C. The affidavits described situations in  which American employees, but no Japanese employees, lost their jobs when business departments were downsized or eliminated. The affidavits also contended that American traders were dismissed when they suffered trading losses, while Japanese traders would simply be given other assignments. **********Tokai Bank says Ms. Goodman's accusations are without merit. "And we're fully cooperating with the E.E.O.C. in this investigation," said Carolyn Chave, a senior vice president and human resources manager for the bank. About the perks  that Ms. Goodman felt she was being denied, Ms. Chave said, "Every global company makes allowances for home staff employees who are on short-term assignments overseas to compensate them for the burden of being away from home." **********A United States Supreme Court ruling in 1982 specifically warned subsidiaries of foreign companies against violating the civil rights of American employees. Before the ruling, such subsidiaries argued that they were exempt from American  civil rights law because of friendship treaties that gave them and United States companies the right to assign key personnel abroad. The United States has such treaties with most of its trading partners. **********In the 1982 case, which involved Americans working for Sumitomo Shoji America, a subsidiary of the Japanese trading company, the Supreme Court ruled that the treaty did not exempt foreign subsidiaries from civil rights laws, although the court implied that subsidiaries might still have the right to bring over top-tier managers who were vital to the company's operations without violating those laws. **********Two appellate courts have since ruled that American subsidiaries of foreign companies can be protected by the friendship treaties when a parent company, rather than a subsidiary, asserts its treaty rights to send managers to the United States. **********Peter van Schaick, an employee rights lawyer in Glen Ridge, N.J., said he had noticed that foreign companies were regularly invoking the friendship treaty. **********"I've had more than a half-dozen cases prevented from going to court because  of the friendship treaty," he said. "It's become a license to discriminate." **********Amy Chen, a Chinese-American who works for the United States subsidiary of the Nomura Trading Company, filed a complaint against the company with the E.E.O.C. in November 1994, accusing Nomura of discrimination on the basis of sex and national origin. **********Ms. Chen said that Nomura hired her as a traffic coordinator for its chemicals and machinery department in 1991, but that she was unofficially made an assistant manager in September 1994 when the company needed her skills during a business trip. Ms. Chen said that both before and after the trip, she helped the company's president pursue new business in the United States and abroad. But she said she never received a salary increase or the benefits to which she was entitled as an assistant manager. **********Ms. Chen sent a letter in October 1994 to the president of Nomura's American  unit. In his response, he said management positions at Nomura's subsidiary were filled on a temporary, rotating basis by Japanese employees from the parent company. **********By the following spring, after she had filed her complaint with the E.E.O.C., Ms. Chen said she had been stripped of her managerial duties. She said that many of those duties were then assigned to a younger Japanese man whom she was expected to train, and that she was given secretarial tasks like typing invoices. She said she was also told that if she wanted to stay with the company, she could apply to become the Japanese man's assistant. **********The promotion "was a paper tiger deal," Ms. Chen said. **********Nomura did not respond to requests for comment last week. **********Mr. Steel, who is Ms. Chen's lawyer, said her experiences were typical of what American employees faced. "These companies are arguing that, despite the Sumitomo decision, they can bring in their own employees at any level," he said. "They're also arguing that they can define what constitutes a management job." **********He added: "It's difficult for the private bar to comes to terms with the problem because these companies are large and show resistance. That's why the Federal Government needs to show some leadership here."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/05/busin.snippet: Digital technology that makes designing typefaces, or fonts, easier has brought more competition, lower prices and more design theft to profession; over 100 small foundries and independent designers are moving into territory once occupied by few l...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/05/busin.main_headline: Creating a New Generation of Vivid Typefaces
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/05/busin.print_headline: Creating a New Generation of Vivid Typefaces
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/05/busin.body_text: **********It had to be sulky and sultry, just like Marlene Dietrich. **********With those sparse instructions from the client, a style magazine, David A. Berlow, a font designer, created Belucian, a curvaceous, low-hanging typeface that sashays across the page just as the husky-voiced ice queen herself might traverse a movie set. **********Mr. Berlow, who is also the president of the Font Bureau Inc. in Boston, is part of a new generation of designers of typefaces, or fonts, that has emerged since the birth of the Apple Macintosh and desktop publishing in 1984. **********But the digital technology that made designing type simpler has made the profession more difficult. More designers mean more competition and lower prices. And the technology that makes type easier to design has also made it easier to steal. **********There are about 500 designers worldwide these days who ponder the curves of an ''S'' or try to create a more beautiful or shocking letter ''B,'' and half of those are in the United States, according to Frank Romano, a professor at the Rochester Institute of Technology and a historian of type design. That compares with about 20 in the days of metal type, which lasted through the 1960's, and about 50 during the subsequent reign of phototype. **********The profession was exclusive because designing type was both expensive and time consuming. Only a handful of foundries owned the machines needed to produce new fonts in metal type or phototype. Today, anyone armed with a personal computer and software like Fontographer or Ikarus can design fonts. **********''The secret is out,'' said Edward Benguiat (pronounced ben-GAT), one of the giants in typeface design who has created more than 600 fonts. ''Type has been liberated.'' **********The great emancipator, of course, is digital technology. From the 15th- century days of Johann Gutenberg, who is credited with inventing movable type, to the time of William Caslon of Britain in the 18th century through the lifetime of the American Frederic W. Goudy early this century, it took years to develop a font, Mr. Romano said. **********Nowadays, with the right software, it can take just 45 seconds to produce a font, Mr. Berlow said. **********Today more than 100 small foundries and independent designers are moving into territory once occupied by a few large companies, like Monotype Typography Inc. and the Linotype-Hell Company. **********In addition to Monotype and Linotype, large companies with more than a thousand fonts to their credit include Adobe Systems Inc. of Mountain View, Calif.; the Agfa EPS Division of the Bayer Group of Germany and the International Typeface Corporation of New York. But also elbowing their way into the market are smaller font houses like Emigre Inc. in Sacramento, Calif., and Garagefonts in Del Mar, Calif. People in the industry estimate that 50,000 to 60,000 fonts are now in use. **********Some of the older companies have adjusted. Some have not. Monotype, founded in 1897 as a hot-metal type company, began to focus on the computer font market in 1990, said Steve Kuhlman, vice president for sales and marketing. But the American Type Founders Company in Elizabeth, N.J., once the largest type foundry in this country, went out of business in 1993. **********Many designers say that the boom in the font trade does not improve the product. For some, the painstaking design process has not changed much since the days of Gutenberg. **********For example, it took Mr. Berlow three months to research, conceptualize and refine all the characters of Belucian, which, intended for headlines, had to be easy to read but was also obliged to whisper subliminal messages of va-va-voom. **********''It's like a harmonica,'' said the 70-year-old Mr. Benguiat, whose clients have included the AT&T Corporation and the Barcelona Olympics. ''You can blow on it and make a lot of noise, but it won't be anything. You can't just give a person a computer and have that person design a typeface.'' **********A good typeface, Mr. Benguiat said, ''has a rhythm -- it flows.'' **********In essence, the new technology has made good designers better, but having an expensive Macintosh filled with software does not make someone a designer. **********Erfert Norton, author of ''The Macintosh Font Book'' sees a divergence in the popular font styles. There are grunge fonts and bizarre designs with illegible letters, but at the same time, there is a revival of fonts that ''hit a classical chord.'' Caslon, named after the 18th-century designer, remains a favorite. **********The typeface business, after all, is a fashion business. The hottest fonts right now are ''retro,'' Mr. Benguiat said, ''like platform shoes.'' **********While the number of people who design fonts seriously is believed to be in the hundreds, thousands dabble in the craft. **********Todd Dever, who works in video production in Long Beach, Calif., began designing fonts last year, when he could not find the typeface he wanted to produce a music video for Mike Keneally, a former guitar player for Frank Zappa. So Mr. Dever created Freak, a jittery, nervous alphabet full of curlicues. Then he made Smash, a ''grunge font'' inspired by the Seattle music scene that looked dirty and scratched up. **********After designing a few more fonts in his spare time, Mr. Dever put them up for sale, $5 for each complete alphabet, at his World Wide Web site, Cool Fonts Online. **********With competition like that, font prices have been in a free fall. **********At the high end of the market, a typeface that is commissioned -- usually for newspapers, advertising or corporate logos -- can still fetch tens of thousands of dollars. But the rest of the industry has suffered a meltdown in profit margins. **********Royalties, the one-time fees collected every time a font is sold, are the essence of the business. For commercial customers, licensing fees increase proportionally with the company's use of the font. A licensee can require a fee each time a font is sold, as Monotype did when it licensed its Times New Roman font to the Microsoft Corporation for use in its word processing software. **********Decades ago, a single font cost hundreds of dollars. Today, many fancy fonts from professional designers sell for less than $50. And hundreds can be downloaded, at no charge, from the Internet. **********To survive, foundries and independent designers have been banding together to market their ware. **********International Type Founders Inc., founded by Steve Jackaman, is a distribution network that represents 30 small font companies and independent designers in a CD-ROM catalogue of nearly 4,000 fonts. For $75, buyers get 25 fonts free and then can pay fees to ''unlock'' additional ones. **********There are also distributors that offer fonts in megapacks of thousands for $19.95, much to the dismay of some designers, who belittle the quality of bargain typefaces. **********''It's a hard business,'' said Mr. Jackaman, echoing the view of many in the profession. ''There's no one getting rich in our business. Most people in type designing do other things,'' like graphic design. **********Another serious issue is piracy. In the United States, fonts are protected by intellectual property laws; the computer code for a font can be copyrighted and the name trademarked. But the design -- the dimensions and contours of characters and the spacing between letters -- cannot be copyrighted. Pirates have sometimes copied the software, changed a few lines of code then renamed and resold the typeface. **********Almost everyone in the industry, from giants like Adobe to casual designers like Mr. Dever, has been victimized by font thieves. ''It's the single biggest threat to the type business,'' said Brian Heuckroth, senior product marketing manager for typefaces for Adobe. **********Last year, Adobe, Emigre and three other co-plaintiff font companies settled a lawsuit against SWFTE International Ltd., a font distributor, for copyright infringement, Mr. Heuckroth said. **********Mr. Dever, too, has found his own fonts in unexpected places. Not long ago, he was surfing the Internet when he stumbled across a grungy and banged-up alphabet that looked awfully familiar. **********''Hey, there's Smash,'' he said. **********Someone had posted the font on the Internet to be freely downloaded by anyone. But he has no plans to sue anyone. ''I'm not into arm-twisting,'' he said.
