https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/15/busin.main_headline: King World Said to Be in Talks Over Acquisition by New World
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/15/busin.print_headline: King World Said to Be in Talks Over Acquisition by New World
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/15/busin.body_text: **********Like a long-running soap opera, the question of the future ownership of King  World Productions continued yesterday with reports that it was discussing a sale to New World Communications for $1.5 billion. **********One person familiar with the talks confirmed there had been some but was leery of predicting a deal between New World, which owns television stations and produces programs, and King World, which distributes "The Oprah Winfrey Show," "Wheel of Fortune" and "Jeopardy." **********Variety, the entertainment trade newspaper, first reported yesterday that Ronald O. Perelman, the chairman of New World, was in talks on paying $1.5 billion in stock for King World, which was been for sale for several years. Neither company would comment, and Wall Street barely reacted to the news. King  World stock closed up 25 cents at $39.875 and New World shares were unchanged at $16. **********Behind Wall Street's skepticism is the question of whether Mr. Perelman really wants to build New World or whether he is simply trying to provoke the News Corporation, which owns 20 percent of New World, into acquiring the balance. Some experts believe that Mr. Perelman is trying to press Rupert Murdoch, the chairman of the News Corporation, to agree to a deal before New World makes an acquisition that makes it too big and diversified to fit easily into the News Corporation. **********According to one person with knowledge of the talks, Mr. Murdoch and Mr. Perelman have been in discussions for several months, but Mr. Perelman wants more for New World than the News Corporation is willing to spend. Mr. Murdoch reportedly struck a deal to pay $25 a share for New World, but the deal was apparently derailed when Mr. Perelman decided he wanted $28 a share and Mr. Murdoch balked. **********This person noted that New World had not been enormously successful in programming and that this helped explain why Mr. Perelman was willing to sell the company. That impression was strengthened when the company recently sold two television stations to NBC for $425 million. **********There is already one tie between New World and the News Corporation. New World's 10 television stations are affiliates of the Fox Network, which the News Corporation owns. **********But an alliance with King World would help counter New World's programming problems by giving it a stream of successful shows. Mr. Perelman has moved to develop the company's programming. He hired Brandon Tartikoff, who helped rebuild NBC, to create programming, and New World spent $30 million to acquire the producer Steven J. Cannell's company. But New World has yet to make a splash with new series. **********At King World, the concern is that the company is not vertically integrated because it owns programs but no television stations that can guarantee that the shows will get on the air. Though that is a bigger problem for companies when they start new shows, even the future of longtime hits like "The Oprah Winfrey Show" could become an issue as larger companies consolidate. **********King World's shows are carried on ABC stations. In the wake of the Walt Disney Company's purchase of ABC, the question is whether Disney will ultimately bump outsiders off the air to put its own shows on its stations. **********Jessica Reif, who follows King World for Merrill Lynch, said that a merger with New World would assure that there would be a solid outlet for King World's  shows. She added that it would also strengthen New World's balance sheet, because that company could look to King World, which has plenty of cash, to help pay off its roughly $500 million in debt. **********But King World's founders, Roger and Michael King, have been trying to sell the company for several years and were reportedly close to a $1.8 billion sale to Turner Broadcasting System last year. Those talks were said to have broken off in part because the Turner board believed that the price was too high. **********Previously, there had been reports that King World would be sold to a number  of companies, including MCA Inc., the parent company of Universal Pictures and Universal Television. But the company has been on the market for several years,  and in that period it has failed to generate new hits, raising the question of its growth potential. As a result, analysts said it was unlikely to command much of a premium in any deal. **********While King World has been profitable recently, New World has been losing money. **********For its fiscal second quarter, which ended on Feb. 29, King World reported net income of $35.2 million, up from $29.9 million a year earlier. Revenue rose  to $176.8 million from $143.7 million. **********For its fiscal first quarter, which ended on March 31, New World reported a loss of $14.5 million, almost twice the loss of $7.5 million in the comparable period a year earlier. Revenue rose to $161.8 million from $114.8 million. **********In the current talks, First Boston is said to be representing New World, while Wasserstein Perella is the banker for King World. Bankers at both firms did not not return telephone calls yesterday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/27/busin.snippet: Outlook for investing in firms that make software and peripherals used in troubled Apple Computer's products discussed; table; graph (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/27/busin.main_headline: Linked to Apple but Trying to Branch Out
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/27/busin.print_headline: Linked to Apple but Trying to Branch Out
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/27/busin.body_text: **********WHILE scores of analysts mull over the fate of troubled Apple Computer, some investors are taking a look instead at companies that are related to Apple. They want to see if those enterprises are as endangered as Wall Street may think. **********Of course, as Apple's troubles have grown, many companies that make software and other peripherals used in Apple's Macintosh computers have seen their sales plummet. And Apple's problems, including product recalls and delays, are clearly huge. Revenue for the quarter ended Sept. 30, for instance, was off 23 percent from the comparable period a year earlier. **********Yet, even though all these companies could be further hurt if Apple's efforts to improve turn sour, some  have much brighter prospects than others. Some of them have strong, resourceful managers. Some may have stock prices that are too low. And some are succeeding at something that all of them are trying: to diversify into non-Apple products, like ones geared to Microsoft's Windows computer system. **********For investors willing to take a chance -- and their numbers may have grown with Apple's recent $25 million profit, the first after a string of losing quarters -- these companies may hold promise. **********Many Apple-linked companies  make software for computer graphics and editorial work, two fields in which Apple has long been strong.  Three of these enterprises -- Adobe Systems, Macromedia and Metatools -- not only have strong reputations for superior software, but also have made good progress at developing  non-Apple products. **********''All three of these companies have been really dependent on Macintosh,'' Christopher Galvin, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist, said. ''But each has come out with major products for the Windows platform.'' **********And because of Apple's troubles, the stock prices of two of them, Adobe and Macromedia, are hovering around their 52-week lows and look attractively cheap, some analysts say. The stock of Adobe, which makes the Postscript computer language, is trading at 19 times estimated earnings for its current fiscal year, while Macromedia's multiple is 23. Both figures are much lower than those of many other high-tech concerns. **********Adobe's stock has fallen for reasons other than Apple's woes, like the loss of a big contract with Hewlett-Packard. But Gerard Hallaren, a portfolio manager at Invesco's Strategic Technology fund, says he believes Adobe is overcoming these difficulties. Also, the company is now  releasing new versions of Photoshop, Pagemaker and other popular programs. Sales typically slow at such times, as customers hold off buying in anticipation of the new software. **********Many customers, however, are wondering these days whether to stay with Apple systems or to convert to Windows. Analysts say this uncertainty -- Macromedia is similarly affected -- may hurt sales at both of these software companies for an unknown time. **********''The transition period may be more protracted than we think,'' Mr. Galvin said. **********NEVERTHELESS, many analysts remain bullish. ''The world has not moved away from these products,'' Mr. Galvin said. In the long term, he added, ''both Adobe and Macromedia are well positioned.'' **********Metatools presents a closer question for the investor. Although it has done a good job of diversifying -- only 30 percent of revenues come from Apple-related products -- its  stock is not cheap, trading at 57 times estimated earnings. **********And in contrast to Adobe and Macromedia, Metatools' new products, like a line of Internet games, are largely untested in the market. **********Like Metatools, Micro Warehouse, a mail-order computer seller, has been diversifying well. But while its Windows-based products are selling briskly, the declines in Apple-linked sales are sharp. Indeed, the company's stock dropped 25 percent in June, after it warned that its earnings would be below expectations. **********The decline, however, may have created a bargain. Micro Warehouse shares are trading at 16 times estimated earnings. According to Dale Dutile, an analyst with Massachusetts Financial Services, ''Mail-order catalogue companies that have computer exposure have multiples three times as high.'' **********Mr. Dutile also notes that Micro Warehouse focuses on the high end of  Apple products, where margins are greater. And he and others agree with John Force, lead manager of the PBHG Technology and Communications fund, that the company is ''extraordinarily well-managed.'' But these advantages may mean little if Micro Warehouse cannot perform its  basic task: continuing to grow non-Apple revenues. **********AT first glance, Insignia Solutions, which makes software  that allows Windows-based programs to run on Apple computers, seems to be distancing itself from Apple nicely. In the quarter ended Sept. 30, its Apple-related revenue dropped to just 23 percent of  overall revenue. The low percentage, however, mostly reflects markedly lower income from Apple-based  products. **********And while the company is getting some growing sales from a new  product, that product is geared to work with Windows NT, Microsoft's latest operating system for offices. Such reliance can be risky. **********''Insignia is a value play,'' said Alan Lowenstein, an assistant portfolio manager for the John Hancock  Global Technology fund, which holds stock in Insignia. ''But you also buy it because you believe in Windows NT.'' **********One company that is still tightly tethered to Apple is Global Village  Communications, a maker of modems and communications software. **********Global Village has distanced itself a bit from Apple with Focal Point, a Windows product that merges E-mail, voice mail and faxes in one desktop application. More such products are in the pipeline, analysts say. **********But 80 to 85 percent of the company's sales are Apple-linked. And its stock price shows it, having fallen 61 percent since mid-1995. Without more diversification -- and Global Village is in a competitive sector -- the company may be hit hard if Apple fails to improve. **********Of course, the true Apple fan has no doubt that Apple will thrive. And in that case, all these companies, diversified or not, should shine.

Kipp A. Bedard, vice president for corporate affairs, said the company, which makes semiconductors, had no timetable for such spinoffs but would consider them if the units were able to bring products to market profitably. https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/10/busin.print_headline: Japan's Trade Surplus Fell 28.9% in August
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/10/busin.body_text: **********Japan's huge surplus in its current account, the broadest measure of trade in goods and services, shrank in August as the flow of foreign goods into the country continued to increase. The current account surplus dropped 28.9 percent, to 460.60 billion yen, or $4.14 billion, from a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said yesterday. The surplus in merchandise trade alone decreased 27.8 percent, to 566.70 billion yen, or $5.10 billion, from a year earlier. **********Japan's current account surplus has been on a downward trend since September 1995, and August was the 21st consecutive month in which the merchandise trade surplus had fallen when compared with the year-earlier number.   (Reuters)

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/21/world.print_headline: World News Briefs;Bosnian Serbs Pick Karadzic for President
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/21/world.body_text: **********In a direct violation of the Dayton peace accord, a local party board in the  Serbian part of Bosnia today nominated Radovan Karadzic, an indicted war criminal, as their candidate for president, Serbian news organizations reported. The local board of the Serb Democratic Party in Pale, the Bosnian Serb headquarters during the war, unanimously agreed to the nomination, the news agency SRNA said. **********But it remained unclear whether the full party leadership, which has said it will announce its presidential candidate next Thursday, would support the nomination. **********The move is in direct violation of the Dayton peace accord, which forbids indicted war criminals from taking part in the elections. As the Bosnian Serb' political leader, Dr. Karadzic is the most prominent person to be indicted by the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague, along with the Bosnian Serb  military commander, Gen. Ratko Mladic.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/11/busin.main_headline: MCI and British Telecom to Join Networks for Internet Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/11/busin.print_headline: MCI and British Telecom to Join Networks for Internet Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/11/busin.body_text: **********Projecting that the volume of computer-based communications traffic will soon surpass voice communications, the MCI Communications Corporation and its partner, British Telecommunications P.L.C., said yesterday that they planned to  merge their international high-speed data networks and expand their capacity significantly. **********By joining their data networks and managing them as a single entity, the two  companies said they could offer their corporate customers a faster and more reliable international network. MCI and British Telecom hope that such a merger  will allow them to compete more effectively against larger rivals like AT&T and  Sprint, which are also expanding their international data traffic capacity in the hope of winning larger shares of a global Internet market. **********MCI also said it would announce today an alliance with the Intel Corporation that involves Intel's Internet products. Both companies declined to provide details yesterday. **********MCI and British Telecom will together spend about $100 million this year to establish at least eight new regional Internet hubs in the United States, Britain, Germany, the Netherlands, Japan and Australia, said Gerald H. Taylor, president of MCI. **********Eventually, 20 of these "super hubs" will be installed around the world, Mr.  Taylor said, reducing the heavy load on the more established network infrastructure in the United States, through which most international Internet traffic is routed. **********Mr. Taylor said he expected the new high-speed services to appeal primarily to multinational businesses as an alternative to more expensive, private data networks. Using high-speed data lines, each capable of transporting more than 45 million bits of information -- or a copy of Tolstoy's "War and Peace" -- a second between countries, the two companies hope to foster the growth of multimedia communications services among businesses, including electronic commerce, voice mail, electronic mail, document sharing, facsimile services and  World Wide Web publishing. **********The joint venture's so-called backbone connections between some of the new Internet hubs in the United States will be even faster, carrying 155 million bits a second, he said. **********The newly expanded and beefed-up networks will be operated by the joint venture that MCI and British Telecom formed three years ago called Concert. While it will handle global customer service and billing for the network, Concert will also try to sell the new network capacity to Internet service providers who would in turn resell the capacity to businesses and individuals. **********Vinton Cerf, the chief Internet strategist for MCI, said Concert would offer  both standard and premium Internet services to its customers, allowing Internet service providers to offer higher-priced services to businesses that demand peak performance at all times. When international Internet traffic is heavy and standard performance slows down -- an increasingly common phenomenon as millions of new users pile onto the network -- Concert's computers will route the premium customer's traffic to a separate, less-crowded network. **********"It's like first-class service on an airline," Mr. Cerf said. "There's the same square footage, but there are fewer passengers and better food." **********MCI and British Telecom said yesterday that the NTT Data Corporation, a company that is 60 percent owned by the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, had signed on as the newest international customer of Concert. Growth of the Japanese Internet market is expected to outpace that of the United States over the next year, analysts said. **********Mr. Cerf of MCI said that although the initial expansion of the Concert network would be in Europe, Japan and the United States, eventually it would extend to Canada, Mexico, South America and elsewhere. **********"In the long run, there is a tremendous demand for transoceanic Internet capacity," Mr. Cerf said. "Demand from customers is as ambitious and aggressive internationally as it is on the domestic front. The numbers are not as big in absolute terms, but they'll get there." **********Ullas Naik, vice president and Internet analyst at First Albany Technology Research in Boston, said the Concert expansion would help spur the growth of the Internet overseas, but that it was too soon to know if the expansion would help  MCI in its quest to increase its share of the market in the United States. **********"I don't see from a competitive standpoint how it changes the landscape," Mr. Naik said. "However, the international front is still very much uncharted territory, so this will certainly have some impact." **********British Telecom owns 20 percent of MCI. Mr. Taylor of MCI said British Telecom had no plans to increase its stake in MCI as a result of the deal disclosed yesterday. **********Both British Telecom and MCI left no doubt, however, of the importance they place on the joint venture. **********"We are anticipating that at the turn of the century and into the next millennium, the totality of Internet traffic for us could be surpassing voice traffic, if you look at the current rates of growth," said Rupert Gavin, British Telecom's director of multimedia services. "Certainly we at BT consider this to  be extremely substantial for our future."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/06/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Trade Surplus Shrinks in Japan
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/06/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Trade Surplus Shrinks in Japan
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/06/busin.body_text: **********Japan's merchandise trade surplus for the first 20 days of February shrank 80.9 percent from the comparable period in 1995, to $1.232 billion, the Finance  Ministry said today. **********Economists said the sharp contraction was largely a result of the jump in exports last February, after the Kobe earthquake blocked exports in January. **********The exaggerated decline in the surplus will probably also appear in the figures for all of February, to be released in about 10 days, said Tetsuro Sawano, an economist at Nikko Research Center. **********Exports during the 20-day period fell 11.3 percent, to $20.599 billion, while imports rose 15.6 percent, to $19.367 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/26/world.main_headline: Harold Trobe Is Dead at 82; Helped Resettle War Refugees
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/26/world.print_headline: Harold Trobe Is Dead at 82; Helped Resettle War Refugees
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/26/world.body_text: **********Harold Trobe, a key figure in efforts to rescue and resettle hundreds of thousands of Jewish refugees from war-ravaged Europe, died on Monday at his home in Gainesville, Fla., where he had retired in 1980. He was 82. **********The cause was cancer, his family said. **********Mr. Trobe spent 36 years overseas for the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee and the Hebrew Immigration Aid Society, starting in 1944. His assignments as a country director for the committee took him to places with great concentrations of human suffering. **********He was in charge of the agency's commitments to finance the movement of refugees, feed, shelter and clothe them and provide medical attention. He also traveled in the United States to lecture and raise money. **********Born in Beaver Falls, Pa., the son of a rabbi, Mr. Trobe graduated from the University of Pittsburgh and earned an master's degree in 1937 from what is now  the Columbia University Graduate School of Social Work. German immigration to the United States was on the rise at the time, and he found work in Pittsburgh to retrain and find jobs for the new arrivals and care for their children. **********He turned to fund-raising and was increasingly engrossed in the plight of European Jews. In 1944 he joined the Joint Distribution Committee, which appointed him its overseas field representative and sent him to Lisbon, its European headquarters. **********Portugal was then a way station for refugees from German-occupied Europe, many of them Jews. Largely because of his efforts, two shiploads of refugees were able to sail for Palestine in the face of diplomatic opposition. **********The end of World War II in 1945 left an immense mass of displaced people all  over Europe. Mr. Trobe was sent to Czechoslovakia, an early focal point for displaced people. **********As the situation stabilized there in 1946, he went on to Milan as the committee's director for northern Italy. With long gaps between the arrival and  departure of displaced people, Mr. Trobe and his assistants cared for the well-being of many of them. **********After a stint in Vienna, he returned to Italy in 1952 as countrywide Joint Distribution Committee director. He remained there for five years, focusing on the flight of Jews from North Africa. **********He then served as the director general of the Hebrew Immigration Aid Society  for Europe and North Africa for five years, and four more in Rio de Janeiro in the same position for all of Latin America. From 1966 until his retirement, he worked for Joint Distribution Committee in Israel. **********In an interview with The Jerusalem Post in 1969 he remembered local authorities' complaints of illegal entry by refugees. "How they get across the border is not my business," he said he told them, "but the minute they come across, they are. If they come across illegally, that's also not my concern. **********"I'm not the police. I feed them." **********Mr. Trobe is survived by his wife of 58 years, Ruth Weiner Trobe; two sons, Jonathan D. of Ann Arbor, Mich., and Dr. Thomas O. of Zurich; a daughter, Susan  T. Goldbard of Millbrae, Calif.; a brother, Jacob L. of Haverford, Pa., and six  grandchildren.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/04/world.main_headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Hungary to Compensate Jews for Wartime Losses
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/04/world.print_headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Hungary to Compensate Jews for Wartime Losses
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/04/world.body_text: **********The Government has agreed to compensate the Jewish community for property seized during World War II, a Jewish leader said today. **********"This is a landmark agreement, a big step forward," said Gusztav Zoltai, head of the Hungarian Jewish Communities. **********More than 600,000 of the million Jews who lived in Hungary before World War  II were killed in the Holocaust. Today, there are about 100,000 Jews in Hungary, including about 20,000 Holocaust survivors. **********Hungary was obligated under the 1947 Treaty of Paris to make restitution of Jewish property, but the Communists ignored the accord. **********The agreement establishes a Hungarian Jewish Heritage Foundation to manage the assets that belonged to Jews, plus $26 million contributed by the Government. Establishment of the foundation is subject to confirmation by Parliament, which reconvenes in September.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/19/busin.snippet: Walt Disney Co promotes Richard W Cook, its domestic distribution and worldwide marketing chief, to chairman of its motion picture group (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/19/busin.main_headline: Disney Names New Chairman of Movie Group
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/19/busin.print_headline: Disney Names New Chairman of Movie Group
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/19/busin.body_text: **********The Walt Disney Company has promoted Richard W. Cook, its domestic distribution and worldwide marketing chief, to chairman of its motion picture group, as part of a reorganization that will cut film production in half. **********Mr. Cook will report to the former studio chief, Joe Roth, who was promoted to chairman of Disney Studios four months ago, Disney said on Saturday. Mr. Roth now oversees Disney's film, TV and video businesses. **********A 25-year veteran at Disney, Mr. Cook began as a ride operator at Disneyland, advancing to become sales manager at the theme park. He later managed Disney's pay television business, helped plan its Disney Channel and headed movie distribution and marketing. **********Mr. Cook will oversee Donald DeLine, president of Touchstone Pictures, and David Vogel, president of Walt Disney Pictures, Disney's other two film studios. **********Analysts expect more executive shuffling as Mr. Roth cuts film production to about 20 to 25 films and scales back its Hollywood Pictures studio. **********Christopher P. Dixon, a Paine Webber analyst, estimated that the production cuts would save Disney between $300 million and $400 million. **********The revamping ''is an appropriate response given the high cost of production, the oversupply of product in the marketplace and the underperformance of Disney films over the last year,'' Mr. Dixon said. **********The president of Hollywood Pictures, Michael Lynton, left recently to become chairman of Pearson P.L.C.'s Penguin Group book publisher. **********Chris McGurk, president of the motion picture group under Mr. Roth, will give up his post at the studio to become a consultant, The Los Angeles Times reported.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/28/busin.main_headline: Stocks in Sharp Retreat, With Dow Falling 43.72
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/28/busin.print_headline: Stocks in Sharp Retreat, With Dow Falling 43.72
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/28/busin.body_text: **********Stocks fell sharply yesterday, following a slump in the bond market.  But technology issues bucked the selloff. **********The Dow Jones industrial average, fell 43.72 points, to 5,626.88. The broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks dropped 4.06 points, to 648.91. But the Nasdaq composite index, which is rich in technology issues, rose 5.53 points, to 1,093.88. **********The stock market was tied to what occured in the bond market," said Richard Cripps, chief market strategist of Legg Mason. **********Bond prices tumbled after comments by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, and a report on durable-goods orders suggested that interest rates would not be cut in the coming months. **********The price of the bellweather 30-year Treasury bond fell 1 8/32, and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, surged to 6.68 percent, from 6.57  percent on Tuesday. Higher bond yields increase borrowing costs for corporations and consumers. **********"Today marks the eighth time so far this year the D.J.I.A. has declined more  than 40 points," said Jerry Hegarty, equity market analyst of Thomson Research.  "This clearly indicates that the straight-up bullish phase that marked 1995 has  ended." **********Declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange exceeded advancers by 1,278 to 1,049. Big Board turnover was down to 403 million shares, from 404.3 million  shares Tuesday. **********Oil stocks, which had been quite strong recently, fell on a drop in crude oil prices. Exxon dropped 1 7/8, to 84 1/8; Texaco gave up 7/8, to 87 1/2, and Royal Dutch declined 1 1/4, to 141 1/4. **********Drug issues, which surged in the previous session, slipped on profit taking and rumors that corporate pricing policies were under investigation by the Federal Trade Commission. Merck closed at 63 1/8, down 1; Eli Lilly closed at 65 3/8, down 1 5/8, and Schering-Plough closed at 58 1/2, down 1. **********Food companies were also lower as analysts voiced some concern over the effect of higher grain prices. CPC International fell 1 1/4, to 69 1/2; Campbell Soup declined 1 1/4, to 62 5/8, and Kellogg dropped 1 3/8, to 76 3/4. **********However, high-tech issues turned in a relatively good performance amid optimism that sales will rise due to new price cuts. I.B.M. rose 1/2, to 111 1/4; Hewlett-Packard increased 1/4, to 93 7/8, and Seagate Technology added 1 1/2, to 52 7/8. Even Apple Computer advanced 1 3/8, to 25 1/4, despite saying that it expects a fiscal second-quarter loss. The Morgan Stanley high-tech index climbed 4.62 points, to 313.89. **********Some communications equipment stocks bounced back from their recent lows. Cisco Systems closed at 44 15/16, up 2, and Bay Networks closed at 30, up 1 1/2. **********Penske Motorsports soared 7 3/4, to 31 3/4, on its first day of public trading. CompUSA tacked on 3 1/8, to 53, after reporting a 29 percent sales gain in its fiscal third quarter and announcing a 2-for-1 stock split. And Burlington Resources advanced 2, to 38 1/4, following an upgrade by Paine Webber. **********In contrast Health Care and Retirement, which was downgraded by Merrill Lynch, fell 2 1/2, to 37 1/2. Dun & Bradstreet, whose Moody's unit was said to be under investigation by the Justice Department, dropped 1 1/8, to 60 3/4. And  Northstar Health Services, whose auditors resigned on Monday after questioning certain company practices, plunged 1 5/8, to 3.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/22/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Canal Plus May End Bertelsmann TV Link
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/22/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Canal Plus May End Bertelsmann TV Link
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/22/busin.body_text: **********Canal Plus S.A. of France, Europe's biggest pay-television company, is talking with Bertelsmann A.G. of Germany on whether to end a two-year-old joint  accord to develop digital pay-TV in Europe. Executives at Canal Plus and its main shareholder, Havas S.A., said they were reconsidering the link in the wake  of Bertelsmann's alliance with Compagnie Luxembourgeoise de Telediffusion -- a Canal Plus rival. **********Canal Plus said that while it had not decided to terminate the Bertelsmann accord, "it would be a logical consequence, since Bertelsmann has de facto broken the agreement by negotiating with CLT without us," said Sylvie Ruggieri,  a spokeswoman for the French company.   (Bloomberg Business News)

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/04/busin.main_headline: Warner Music Plans to Shift Key Executives
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/04/busin.print_headline: Warner Music Plans to Shift Key Executives
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/04/busin.body_text: **********In a move aimed at consolidating their control over the Warner Music Group, the co-chairmen, Bob Daly and Terry Semel, are relocating several crucial executives to Los Angeles, where Mr. Daly and Mr. Semel are based. **********As part of the shift, Warner Music executives, who insisted on anonymity, acknowledged yesterday that about 20 members of the corporate staff of about 70  people would either be laid off, moved to Los Angeles or moved within the company. **********Mr. Daly and Mr. Semel, who also head Warner Brothers, another unit of Time  Warner Inc., took control of the music group from the former chairman, Michael J. Fuchs, in a power struggle last November. Previously, Mr. Fuchs had been seen as the potential heir apparent to Time Warner's chairman, Gerald M. Levin. **********At the time, the dismissal of Mr. Fuchs was widely seen as a concession by Mr. Levin to Mr. Daly and Mr. Semel, who wanted to expand their authority to include films and music. The move made the pair by far the most dominant force in the company, after Mr. Levin. **********Among those expected to move to the California headquarters are the general counsel, Fred Wistow, and the chief financial officer, Gerry Gold, as well as James Noonan, head of corporate communications. Mr. Noonan said yesterday that several executives would remain in New York. He said there would be no change in location for the individual labels in the music group. **********Mr. Daly said yesterday that in 1977, when he ran CBS Entertainment, which is now owned by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, and moved from New York to Los Angeles, he took his key executives with him.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/11/world.main_headline: 211 Bosnians Free After 8 Months. Why So Long?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/11/world.print_headline: 211 Bosnians Free After 8 Months. Why So Long?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/11/world.body_text: **********The smile did not leave her face, but her eyes began to fill with tears as she led her husband down the path to the house where his two young children awaited him. **********"At times the whole family would go crazy waiting for him, not knowing if he  would ever come back to us," said Shura Rizvic, 34. Dressed as well as a refugee mother could be, in a blue suit and freshly shined brown pumps, she said, "We kept asking ourselves, 'Why are they holding him so long?' " **********Her husband, Sakib, was released today after being detained in Yugoslavia along with 210 other Bosnian Muslims. **********They escaped Bosnian Serb forces by fleeing to Yugoslavia, where they were taken prisoner and held for more than eight months. They were the largest group  of prisoners from the war known to remain in captivity so long after the peace accords. But the question of why the release came so late brought so many conflicting answers that the truth was lost. **********The captivity that ended today in the slowly warming Balkan spring began last July in the panic that followed the fall of the United Nations "safe area" of Zepa to the Bosnian Serbs. The people there knew about the massacres of the men  of Srebrenica, another designated safe area that was overrun two weeks earlier. **********So to avoid the Bosnian Serb forces to their west, about 800 of the men and boys of Zepa fled east. They crossed the Drina River to Yugoslavia, where they were split between two detention camps. **********An official with the International Committee of the Red Cross in Yugoslavia said, "We did not forget about them, but there was a war going on and everything is complicated in a war." **********The complications were such that for two months all 800 men were in camps where conditions were "horrible and shameful," one Red Cross worker said. Many of the men said today that they had tried to return to Bosnia but that United Nations officials had refused their requests. **********Their case was the responsibility of the Belgrade office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. The head of that office, Margaret O'Keeffe, said today that the initial intention was to get other countries to take the men because most were afraid to go home. **********She said that because they had fled Bosnia, they would be seen as traitors if they returned. "Because of their anxiety, the possibility of going to Bosnia did not arise," she said. **********But those returning to Bosnia today disputed that. "We had defended our homes, and had to go to Yugoslavia to save our lives," said Nadjed Cesko. "Why should we be afraid?" **********Ismet Sehic recalled, "The U.N. said: 'Don't even mention Bosnia. There's no  way to get you to Bosnia.' " **********In September the first men were released to other countries. The United States and other countries eventually took more than 500. But this was complicated too, a refugee official said, because the countries would often promise to take some men, then be slow to actually accept them. **********"We worked and worked to get them a place to go, but you know how these diplomatic things are easily sidetracked," the official said. **********In December, the Dayton agreement was signed and the war stopped. Subsequently, prisoners were slowly being released by all sides. Hundreds of the men who had gone to other countries had left there and returned to Bosnia, but the men released today were still prisoners. **********Their families, driven out of Zepa, had become refugees within their own country. Relief agencies tracked the families to their new addresses, and prisoners like Mr. Rizvic were reunited with their families in houses that had never been their homes. **********"Ask the Serbs why the men were not freed," said Amir Hadziomeragic, the Bosnian Minister for Relations with the United Nations. "They kept them to pressure us, to get us to give them something in return." **********He also suggested that the United Nations efforts had been slowed by fighting between refugee officials in Belgrade and Sarajevo. **********A United Nations refugee official based in Sarajevo said the Bosnian Government had moved unreasonably slowly. "They didn't even send a real delegation to Yugoslavia until last month,"he said. **********After the Bosnian Government passed an amnesty law three months ago, United Nations officials considered it safe for the men to return. **********But, Mrs. O'Keeffe said, it was difficult to find a way to get them home. The officials decided not to move the men by air because they considered the Sarajevo airport dangerous, though it is used daily by NATO planes. **********They tried to get permission to take the men by bus via Croatia, but Croatia  refused. Then Hungary would not give them visas. **********Each request took time, Mrs. O'Keeffe said. "The Serbs were not delaying things," she said. But getting the men home "was a process of many long steps." **********Finally, after three months, the United Nations just sent buses to the camp and brought the men straight to Bosnia, about a four-hour drive. **********There were two further complications. First, the Yugoslav police kept 13 of the men, saying that after eight months the authorities needed additional time to investigate them in connection with war crimes. **********Then, just before the men were to transfer from Yugoslav to Bosnian buses that would take them to their new homes, they came across a new bridge they could not cross. It was built last week by Hungarian soldiers under the supervision of the United States Army, but its incline was too sharp for the buses. **********The men had to get off and walk the last mile of their journey.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/12/world.snippet: Pres Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina forces three top military officers to step down; they have been slow to embrace his military reforms and have embarrassed the government in recent months with authoritarian statements (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/12/world.main_headline: Argentina's Military Reshuffle Makes It Clear President Is Boss
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/12/world.print_headline: Argentina's Military Reshuffle Makes It Clear President Is Boss
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/12/world.body_text: **********If there were any doubts about who controls the armed forces in Argentina, which has a long history of military dictatorships, President Carlos Saul Menem laid them to rest today when he forced three of the country's four top military officers to step down. **********Defense Minister Jorge Dominguez said the Government had accepted the resignations of the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Mario Candido Diaz; the head of the Navy, Adm. Enrique Molina Pico, and the head of the Air Force, Brig. Juan Paulik. The leader of the Army, Gen. Martin Balza, who is highly regarded, was not asked to resign. **********The three cashiered officers were slow to embrace the President's military reforms and made authoritarian statements in recent months that  embarrassed the Government. **********No one has suggested that the three were planning a coup, but their quick and sudden removal underscored the radical shift in power that has taken place in Argentina. **********The men will be replaced by officers with close ties to Mr. Menem and views more in tune with his. **********Mr. Dominguez played down the significance of the turnover, calling it ''nothing more than a changing of the guard.'' **********Mr. Menem, since his election in 1989, has undertaken a broad restructuring of Argentina's military, which relinquished power in 1983 after losing a brief war to Britain over the Falkland Islands. **********During the military dictatorship from 1977 to 1983, at least 10,000 people were killed at the hands of the armed forces or disappeared without a trace. **********Although Mr. Menem granted pardons to military officers on trial for human rights abuses, he has virtually eliminated the threat of future military coups. Military spending has been cut in half, mandatory service has been abolished in favor of a professional force and the number of troops has been sharply reduced. **********For decades, the military ruled Latin America with impunity, but with the end of the cold war and consolidation of democracy in the region, governments are seeking to bring their armed forces under tighter civilian control. The Argentine military, which committed some of the worst rights abuses in the region during its reign, is now viewed as the most subordinate to democratic rule in all Latin America. **********''It's important to note who's staying rather than who's going,'' said Andres Fontana, a military expert. ''Balza is staying because he's been a leading symbolic figure in saying that the military has to adapt to a new world.'' **********General Balza, a hero of the Falkland war who was a prisoner of the British forces, was the first Argentine military leader to acknowledge that the armed forces had committed crimes during their rule. The general has long preached strict adherence to the Constitution and civil authorities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/16/world.body_text: **********Nohle Mohapi's husband had been in detention -- she didn't know where -- when someone came to her workplace to deliver two letters he smuggled from jail. They were written on toilet paper and said "the situation was bad" but that her politically active young husband, Mapetla, was all right. The letters said she must take care of the children until they would all be together again. **********It was only a few days later, in 1976, that the police told Mrs. Mohapi that  her husband had hanged himself in his cell with a pair of blue jeans. **********One of the officers laughed at her, Mrs. Mohapi recalled today, unable to keep the outrage from her voice. "I still remember this," she said. "He said: 'They call themselves leaders, but they cannot take the pressure.' " **********In the ornate Victorian city hall here, South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission began its work today, inviting a half dozen victims of apartheid's brutality to come forward and tell their stories. Most were widows like Mrs. Mohapi, whose husbands disappeared in police custody. They told of their ever more frantic searches and in some cases, their own detention. One woman was falsely told that her youngest child had died, and that if she confessed, she could attend the funeral. **********The women, graying now, arrived dressed in their Sunday best. Although tissues were passed around before the start of the proceedings, it was not particularly a day of tears, but a day to take aim at "official stories" and to  ask the commission to find out once and for all what had really happened to their husbands. **********Mrs. Mohapi seemed to step down from the witness chair just a bit taller than before. "I feel much excitement today," she told reporters afterward. "Before, I had anger, but that anger has changed to excitement because something good has happened in my life. The truth will come out now." **********The commission was established as a way for South Africans to put their past  to rest. It has three mandates -- to collect and investigate victims' accounts,  to consider amnesty for those who confess their part in atrocities and to make recommendations on reparations for the victims. **********But since its inception it has been controversial. Before today's hearings began, three suits were filed to shut the commission down. Two come from victims' groups who feel the committee is usurping their right to seek prosecutions and civil damages. One is from people who will probably be identified at the hearings as having committed atrocities. Arguing that they have been convicted of nothing, they want the commission barred from disclosing  their names. **********The first hearings are being held here because this small Indian Ocean port city was a hotbed of political activity and repression in the late 1970's and 1980's. Later, the commission, headed by Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu, the Anglican primate of Southern Africa, intends to tour the country. It is supposed to finish its work in 18 months. **********No one knows what it will accomplish in so little time. It has 60 investigators, but there are thousands of crimes, victims and perpetrators. What it may produce is a national catharsis about the sins of the past, a chance to forgive, if not to forget. **********The commissioners seemed reluctant today to ask the witnesses many questions, except about what sort of reparations they hoped for. **********Mrs. Mohapi said that she wanted a memorial to those who died in the struggle, someplace her children could visit. "I would like to see a place where all these fallen heroes can be remembered, a place where when you feel down you  can go read the name and put a wreath there." **********Mrs. Galela and Monica Godolozi, whose husbands disappeared together, asked for their bodies. **********"Please bring my husband's remains so I can bury him in a very dignified manner," Mrs. Godolozi said. **********Before the day was over, the commission had illustrated its intent to avoid being partisan by hearing a white witness who was probably the victim of a black terrorist. **********In 1991, Karl Andrew Webber, an inspector for the local Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, was having a drink in a hotel bar when it was  sprayed with automatic-weapon fire by a lone gunman, leaving five people dead and seven wounded. Mr. Webber, 38, lost his left arm below the elbow and 60 percent of the use of his right arm. He now lives on disability payments of about $100 a month. **********"My life was changed overnight, being a disabled person," he said. "It's taken some time, but I have accepted it and I have to get on with my life." He too asked the commission for financial aid.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/16/world.snippet: Nancy Macdonald, well-born anarchist who helped radicalize her husband, Dwight Macdonald, in 1930's, managed his magazine Politics in the 1940's, and then struck out on her own in 1950's to aid refugees of Spanish civil war, dies at age 86 (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/16/world.main_headline: Nancy Macdonald Dies at 86; Aided Spain's Loyalist Exiles
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/16/world.print_headline: Nancy Macdonald Dies at 86; Aided Spain's Loyalist Exiles
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/16/world.body_text: **********Nancy Macdonald, the well-born anarchist who helped radicalize her husband, Dwight Macdonald, in the 1930's, managed his magazine Politics in the 1940's, and then struck out on her own in the 1950's to aid refugees of the Spanish civil war, died last Monday at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 86 and had lived on East 10th Street for more than half a century. **********Her son Nicholas said the cause was emphysema. **********The darlings of New York's radicals in the 1930's were the half million Spanish loyalists who fought in vain against the forces of Francisco Franco, then made their way across the Pyrenees to refuge in southwestern France. **********The loyalists got a lot of attention at the beginning, and those who had been Communists continued to receive support, but by the 1950's, with Franco's fascist dictatorship well established, the others had become what Mrs. Macdonald called ''the legion of the forgotten,'' languishing in poverty, unable and unwilling to return to their homeland. **********It was then that Mrs. Macdonald decided to remind the world of their plight. In 1953 she founded Spanish Refugee Aid to provide help to the non-Communist exiles. **********From her office on Union Square, Mrs. Macdonald attracted money and support from intellectual friends like Hannah Arendt, James T. Farrell, Alfred Kazin and Barbara Tuchman, while Pablo Casals and Francine Faure, the wife of Albert Camus, distributed the aid in France. **********And her home, which had been a literary and political social center in the 1930's, was hopping once again. Where T. S. Eliot had once been among the lionized guests, Alexander Calder mingled with refugees. **********There was, to be sure, one change on East 10th Street. Mr. Macdonald, who had helped establish the aid organization, was no longer around as the marriage had dissolved. **********On paper, at least, the union between Dwight Macdonald and Nancy Gardiner Rodman seemed made in establishment heaven. He was Yale, she was Vassar, and both were descended from prominent families, he from the Dwights of old New England, she from the Gardiners of colonial New York. **********When her brother, Selden Rodman, a poet and prominent art collector, introduced them at a party, she, the daughter of a New York architect, was fresh out of college, and he was a writer for Fortune magazine. **********For all their social and establishment credentials, both had left-wing views. In his years as a founding editor of Partisan Review in the 1930's, as the founder of Politics in the 1940's and later as a social critic for The New Yorker, Mr. Macdonald acknowledged that his wife had prodded him ever leftward. **********It was also her family money that enabled him to leave Fortune for The Partisan Review, where she worked as business manager. And it was her administrative skills as managing editor that helped keep Politics going  after the couple established it in their apartment in 1943. **********While her husband was securing his reputation as a major critic, Mrs. Macdonald was becoming known for her intellectual fervor and for what Mr. Kazin recalled as her abiding kindness and concern for others. **********Mrs. Macdonald, who peppered The New York Times and other publications with letters and articles describing the plight of the refugees, even after the death of Franco in 1974, continued to direct Spanish Refugee Aid until retiring in 1983, then summed up her work with a book in 1987 based on taped interviews, ''Homage to the Spanish Exiles: Voices from the Spanish Civil War.'' **********With the time and the restoration of democracy in Spain, the number of exiles has declined, but there are still 125 aging loyalists receiving help from the charity. According to the director, Margaret Childress, because of Mrs. Macdonald's financial efforts, the help will continue. **********Mr. Macdonald died in 1982. In addition to her son Nicholas, of Brooklyn, and her brother of Oakland, N.J., Mrs. Macdonald is survived by another son, Michael of Manhattan, two grandchildren and one great grandchild.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/07/world.main_headline: U.S. Finds China Guilty of Wide Rights Abuses
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/07/world.print_headline: U.S. Finds China Guilty of Wide Rights Abuses
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/07/world.body_text: **********The Clinton Administration issued its annual human rights report today, declaring China guilty of "widespread and well-documented human rights abuses,"  and announced that the United States would again co-sponsor a critical resolution on China at the coming meeting of the United Nations Human Rights Commission in Geneva. **********The State Department had held out the possibility that better Chinese behavior would be rewarded at the Geneva meeting, which convenes on March 18. But China's human rights record has worsened rather than improved, the Administration said today, making public its annual report on human rights in 194 countries around the world. **********China has been guilty of human rights abuses including torture, arbitrary detention, coercive family-planning practices and organ transplants from executed prisoners, the report said. Toward the end of 1995, it said, "almost all public dissent against the central authorities was silenced." **********In its overview, the report implicitly challenged the Clinton Administration's strategy, supported by many business interests, of strengthening economic ties with China regardless of Beijing's human rights record. **********"The experience of China in the past few years demonstrates that while economic growth, trade and social mobility create an improved standard of living, they cannot by themselves bring about greater respect for human rights in the absence of a willingness by political authorities to abide by the fundamental international norms," the report said. **********Senior officials were concerned about the release of this sensitive report, delayed because of the Government shutdown over the budget, as they try to improve a difficult relationship with Beijing. In recent months the United States has accused China of violating agreements on the spread of nuclear and missile weapons, of trying to intimidate Taiwanese voters who are electing a President on March 23 and of breaking its pledge to crack down on the flagrant pirating of American music, videos and computer software. **********A senior Chinese Foreign Ministry official, Liu Huaqiu, is now in Washington  for talks with Secretary of State Warren Christopher, the national security adviser, Anthony Lake, and other officials charged with finding a consistent policy toward China. **********Despite the strong language in today's report, human rights advocates remain  critical of Administration policy. Mike Jendrzejczyk, Washington director of Human Rights Watch Asia, said: "Overall it is an accurate, hard-hitting report,  and probably more critical than last year." **********"But it underlines the glaring disparity between the Administration's analysis and its policy," he added, calling the overall approach too soft on China. **********Although the United States will co-sponsor the human rights resolution in Geneva, Mr. Jendrzejczyk said, the Chinese are pushing Washington not to lobby hard for the resolution, which could lead to its easy defeat when a vote comes in late April. Even John Shattuck, the Assistant Secretary of State for Democracy, Human Rights and Labor who is in charge of compiling these reports, said today the American vote in Geneva would depend on Chinese behavior at the time. **********While saying little that American officials have not regularly discussed, these annual human rights reports carry the weight of an American political judgment that many countries, especially in Asia, reject as hypocritical. **********In the report Russia was criticized for abuses of human rights in its effort  to put down an armed revolt in Chechnya. **********The Administration said abuses had decreased in Turkey and in Israel, where the redeployment of most Israeli troops from large areas of the West Bank and Gaza Strip had reduced the incidents of abuse. In Turkey, however, the improvement came against "a continuing pattern" of abuses, including restrictions on expression, torture and excessive use of force against the Kurdish population in the battle against terrorism. Similarly, Egypt was criticized for excessive force, including torture and extrajudicial killings, in its campaign against Islamic militants. **********There were "familiar patterns of abuse" in countries like Mexico, Saudi Arabia, Colombia, Indonesia and countries in crisis, like North Korea and the Sudan, the department said. **********Over the last 20 years, Mr. Christopher said, the reports also "tell a vivid  story of how much the world has changed." **********Latin America, he noted, had greatly improved, with a strong movement toward  democratization throughout the hemisphere. But displaying how the reports are used for current political purposes, Mr. Christopher sharply criticized Cuba for stifling dissent and shooting down civilian airplanes. He also touched on other  countries that he called "rogue states that possess the greatest threat to America's security -- states like Iran, Iraq and Libya -- that are among the greatest violators of human rights." And he mentioned Nigeria and Burma as abusers of human rights as well as protectors of the drug trade. **********As the State Department focused today on human rights, Mr. Lake, the national security adviser, gave a speech at George Washington University about America's security challenges in a post-cold war world. **********While listing the promotion and defense of democracy, "which enhances our security and the spread of our values," Mr. Lake spent little of his speech discussing human rights. Instead, following the new tone of a Clinton Administration encouraged by its relatively successful use of the American military in Haiti and Bosnia, Mr. Lake concentrated on "the use of force" and "the example of our power," in addition to "the power of our example." **********"Until human nature changes," Mr. Lake said, "power and force will remain at  the heart of international relations."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/16/busin.snippet: Group of shareholders of former Rockefeller Center Properties Inc files lawsuit charging that David Rockefeler, Goldman, Sachs and others committed securities fraud in their $1.2 billion purchase of company earlier this year; case discussed (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/16/busin.main_headline: SUIT FILED OVER ROCKEFELLER CENTER SALE
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/16/busin.print_headline: SUIT FILED OVER ROCKEFELLER CENTER SALE
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/16/busin.body_text: **********A group of shareholders of the former Rockefeller Center Properties Inc. has filed a lawsuit charging that David Rockefeller, Goldman, Sachs and others committed securities fraud in their $1.2 billion purchase of the company earlier this year. The suit contends that Mr. Rockefeller, Goldman, Sachs and the company's management knew but did not tell shareholders that the buyers were in talks to sell to the General Electric Company's NBC unit the space the broadcaster leases in the New York landmark, Rockefeller Center, for $440 million. As a result, shareholders were forced to sell their stakes at an artificially low price, the suit says. The sale of the company was approved by shareholders before the Rockefeller-Goldman group reached the agreement with NBC. The defendants called the suit meritless. The suit, filed yesterday in Federal court in Delaware, seeks unspecified damages or rescission of the sale.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/21/busin.main_headline: Sweetened Bid From Utilicorp In Kansas City Takeover Fight
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/21/busin.print_headline: Sweetened Bid From Utilicorp In Kansas City Takeover Fight
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/21/busin.body_text: **********Faced with losing a shareholder vote on its original offer to merge with the  Kansas City Power and Light Company, Utilicorp United Inc. has sweetened its bid. **********People familiar with the proposed deal said Utilicorp's original offer, which is competing with a bid from Western Resources Inc., would not have won the necessary approval of two-thirds of Kansas City Power's shareholders, who were scheduled to vote on it tomorrow at the company's annual meeting. **********The revised merger proposal will not only increase the value of Utilicorp's  offer but it will also reduce -- to a plurality of shareholders who vote -- the  level of approval needed to effect a combination. **********"In order to facilitate this merger, we have chosen another tack to insure the delivery of benefits and value to our key constituents," Richard C. Green Jr., chairman and chief executive of Utilicorp, said last night. **********Under the terms of the amended proposal, Utilicorp's shareholders would receive one share in the merged company for every share they currently own, rather than the 1.096 shares they would have received under the original offer. **********In essence, that increases the value of the offer for Kansas City Power shareholders by reducing the number of total shares outstanding. Kansas City Power shareholders would receive one share of the new company for every share they currently hold, unchanged from the original offer, but their stake in the new company would increase by 9 percent, compared with the orginal offer. At yesterday's closing price of Utilicorp shares, the amended offer is worth $27.25 a share. **********The revised offer is an effort to roughly match the value that Western Resources has proposed to offer Kansas City Power's shareholders. **********Utilicorp has been locked in a bitter battle with Western Resources, which made a competing bid for Kansas City Power in April that many analysts and shareholders regard as the better offer -- even though it has technically not yet been made. **********Utilicorp's revised proposal also makes use of a complex structure called a reverse triangular merger that effectively circumvents the need for the approval of two-thirds of Kansas City Power's shareholders. That requirement, part of the company's bylaws, presented a high hurdle to the merger because, typically, 10 to 20 percent of shareholders do not vote in corporate elections. **********"We think they had at least a plurality of the votes and probably a majority, but two-thirds was going to be impossible," a person involved in the proposed deal said. **********The dividend of the combined company would be $1.85 a year, the same as the original offer. **********Western Resources, which has proposed a stock-for-stock transaction valued by some analysts at $28 a share, has promised a $2.01 dividend. **********Pam Levetzow, a spokeswoman for Kansas City Power, said the annual meeting would go ahead as planned. "We have a number of other matters to discuss," she said. **********Utilicorp will also hold its annual meeting tomorrow. **********Shareholder votes on the proposed Utilicorp-Kansas City Power merger will be  postponed until the summer, although the companies said the regulatory approval  process would stay on track. **********Western Resources still requires approval from the Securities and Exchange Commission, its board and its shareholders before it can make a formal offer to  Kansas City Power shareholders. **********Utilicorp has hinted that its rival bidder may be more interested in derailing a deal that would put it at a competitive disadvantage than in actually consummating a combination. **********Indeed, there is no love lost between Kansas City Power and Western Resources, which was formed in 1992 as a means of blocking a hostile takeover of Kansas Gas and Electric by none other than Kansas City Power. Kansas Gas and Electric merged with Kansas Power and Light and became Western Resources as a way of fending off Kansas City Power's advances. **********Western Resources said again yesterday that it expected to complete the approval process and make a formal bid for Kansas City Power in June. **********Last week, Institutional Shareholder Services, an independent investor advisory firm, recommended that Kansas City Power shareholders vote against a merger with Utilicorp, saying that Western Resources' proposed bid was better. The firm said Western Resources' proposal offered shareholders a higher value and richer dividends.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/27/your-.main_headline: Emerging Economies Favor Free-for-All Trade Policy
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/27/your-.print_headline: Emerging Economies Favor Free-for-All Trade Policy
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/27/your-.body_text: **********MUCH of the success of emerging economies is accounted for by the expansion of trade as governments worldwide reduce tariffs and import quotas. It is a given among economists that if manufacturers in countries on the way up are free to take advantage of their lower production costs and sell goods in countries that are already up, their economies will become ever more prosperous. **********A world of absolutely free trade would be a richer place for all, the argument goes, because producers would be driven to become as efficient as they could and make only those things they were best at making, and consumers would have as wide a choice of products and services to buy as possible. **********"The whole reason for producing in a location other than the domestic market is that the cost of getting goods to market is lowered, primarily because of lower wages," said Stuart Parkinson, senior economist at Morgan Grenfell, the investment bank and fund management company. **********"So in the long run, the whole point is that free trade is good for everybody," Mr. Parkinson said. "Economists disagree about most things, but the fact that free trade is good for everybody, you won't find much disagreement on." **********If total trade liberalization suddenly erupted tomorrow, it might be good for all, but not for each. **********Some businesses would not be able to succeed without the official protection they have enjoyed for years and some countries, the ones protecting their industries, would likely grow poorer. **********"Opening trade exposes inefficiency, so if you have a case where domestic producers are inefficient, then they struggle," Mr. Parkinson said. "One reason for lowering barriers is to make them more competitive, to change or else." **********Emerging economies generally stand to benefit more from open markets than wealthy countries not only because they are cheaper producers but also because trade comprises a bigger portion of their gross domestic product. **********If Michael Hope-Lewis, head of global research at the investment bank ING Barings, had to pick a region to bet on based on the trading prowess of its businesses, it would be "unhesitatingly Asia-Pacific because of the work ethic, because of the capacity to undercut and provide comparable quality at competitive price." **********Mr. Hope-Lewis stressed that open trade is not a panacea. It must be accompanied by openness in other forms: "An un-deregulated economy is one that's not going to compete effectively. You can bring down trade barriers around the world, but without sovereign deregulation, it won't bring any advantage."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/11/busin.main_headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Price of Gold Surpasses $400 First Time in Nearly 2 1/2 Years
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/11/busin.print_headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Price of Gold Surpasses $400 First Time in Nearly 2 1/2 Years
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/11/busin.body_text: **********The price of gold rose above $400 an ounce for the first time in nearly two and a half years yesterday, pushed higher in part by speculative demand from investors fleeing, at least temporarily, the stock and bond markets. **********Analyst said technical and fundamental factors, including supply problems and lower interest rates, also contributed to gold's rise. **********In heavy trading on the Commodity Exchange in New York, the February gold futures contract settled at $400.20 an ounce, up $3.30 from Tuesday's close. Earlier in the session, the contract had risen as high as $403. **********In London yesterday, gold was fixed at $400 an ounce, the first time it has reached that level since Aug. 3, 1993, when it was fixed at $402.65. **********Yesterday's price action was a continuation of a surge that began at the start of the year. **********Since the beginning of the new year, spot gold prices, which averaged just above $384 for all of last year, have risen nearly $15 an ounce. **********Analysts said some of the metal's recent rise, particularly the final push through $400, was attributable to the recent weakness in stocks and bonds. **********"I think you have a degree of sectoral rotation by professional investment pools coming out of things like technology stocks and into gold and gold instruments," said John Brimelow, director of international equities at BV Capital Markets in New York. **********But Mr. Brimelow and others said much of the run-up had to do with an increasing realization that producers, which have been big suppliers into the market in the last few years, are currently in no position to meet the demand for gold. **********Moreover, even though gold is viewed as an inflation hedge by many, it tends  to do best in a world of low and declining real rates of interest. **********"Gold has a causal relationship with real interest rates," said Fred Kalkstein, a vice president at Janney Montgomery Scott, the brokerage house. "When you have some combination of inflation and nominal interest rates that cause real interest rates to come down, that causes gold prices to go up." **********Lower real interest rates not only reduce the cost of holding gold, but also  pare returns on interest-bearing assets, forcing investors in search of better returns to look to other investments, like gold. **********In Mr. Kalkstein's view, the reduction in a key German interest rate yesterday, as well as comments by officials at the Bundesbank, played as much a  role in gold's rise yesterday as the steep slide in the stock market. **********After the meeting at which they approved the German rate cut, the officials noted that real interest rates in Germany were still quite high, suggesting further easing in monetary policy. **********"Right now the Bundesbank is a very key central bank, and this kind of talk is the stuff that gold feeds on," Mr. Kalkstein said. "It nurtures demand for gold as a monetary asset." **********Still, while predicting that gold would trade in a somewhat higher price range than the last few years, few were willing to forecast that gold would continue its recent strong advance. **********"At $400, I don't think we will see continued demand," said a precious-metals analyst at a European bank, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "The speculators are long gold already, and I question how much longer they can get.  I don't think we can sustain these prices until we find out where the new underlying demand is coming from." **********William O'Neill, senior futures strategist at Merrill Lynch & Company, said,  "You should be careful about becoming too bullish, because the global economic outlook is not a positive for precious metals." **********"What we are seeing now is a market moving to a somewhat higher trading range of around $380 to $420 an ounce," he said, "as opposed to the $365 to $395 range that has existed since 1993. **********On other commodity markets, gasoline prices continued their retreat, as this  week's storm in the Northeast continued to make driving difficult, thus reducing demand for fuel. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 17 commodities fell 1.05 point, to 245.23. **********February unleaded gasoline fell 0.46 cent, to 58.19 cents a gallon, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. **********Gasoline's decline weighed on other energy contracts. February crude oil fell 28 cents, to $19.67 a barrel. February heating oil fell 0.84 cent, to 59.59 cents a gallon, and February natural gas fell 1.19 cents, to $2.809 for 1,000 cubic feet.
