Its detractors see it as the latest way of trying to fool investors that the weak really is the strong..But, love it or hate i...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/13/your-.main_headline: Controversy Builds Around a New Analytical Tool
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/13/your-.print_headline: Controversy Builds Around a New Analytical Tool
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/13/your-.body_text: **********ITS advocates hail it as a theoretical and practical tool of analysis that helps differentiate the weak from the strong. Its detractors see it as the latest way of trying to fool investors that the weak really is the strong. **********But, love it or hate it, style analysis is flavor of the month in today's mutual fund industry. **********Style analysis is another way of describing the investment process or style by which a fund manager aims to match or exceed the relevant benchmark. Instead of using a fund's portfolio to determine the manager's investment approach, style analysts use actual performance results. **********Barra, a California-based investment technology company, provides a quantitative style-analysis service to consultants, advisers and private investors. Using fund data supplied by Micropal, the London-based fund research group, Barra compares a fund's month-by-month returns over the past three years with the returns of 15 standard asset classes or indexes, from Treasury bills to large-company value stocks to small-company growth stocks. It then produces an asset allocation table based on how the portfolio acted over this time period. **********A fund manager's success within a particular investment style is alsomeasured by comparing the fund's performance with the results that could have been achieved by a passive investment strategy using the same style. Fund managers are allocated a specialist investment benchmark andare assessed according to how well, or how badly, they did against that indicator. **********Style analysis is formidably complex. But the basic premise presupposes a manager's personal style of investing as the principal factor determining performance. **********The only interest to investors, of course, is whether or not this latest "technique" is a gimmick or a realistic means of improving investment returns. **********William Sharpe, a professor of finance at Stanford University, has been credited with developing the technique for determining a fund's style empirically. Mr. Sharpe maintains that the description of a fund manager's style in a typical investment prospectus is opaque and of limited value to investors, and that style analysis provides more detailed and consistent information about a manager's investment approach and performance. **********"Investment labels cover a multitude of sins," " Mr. Sharpe says."One can find several funds described as aggressive growth that act in a completely different manner from one another. Some might not even act like growth funds at all. One can also find funds with different stated styles that act in the same, or a similar manner. Style analysis will enable investors to spot these inconsistencies." **********As well as characterizing the style of a manager, style analysis is sold on the strength of its ability to measure performance. **********"One of the problems with measuring performance is that growth funds will look good in some years and bad in other years," Mr. Sharpe said. "The investor may want to know which manager picks above-average growth stocks or above-average value stocks. **********"Style analysis will provide each manager with a relevant benchmark to their specific style," he said."Investors can compare funds of a similar style on the strength of their performance against the benchmark." **********Richard Bernstein, director of quantitative analysis at Merrill Lynch in New York, is a firm believer in the benefits of style analysis, which he says Merrill Lynch has been using since the late 1980s. **********"Style analysis can provide investors with a critical insight into what actually drives the market," he said."This insight can help investors predict, with some degree of certainty, how afund will perform in the future." **********Not everyone in the industry likes style analysis, however. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services Inc. in New York, wonders what all the fuss is about. He argues that style analysis is a very simplistic and one-dimensional way of looking at the investment process. **********"Style analysts are making judgments about a fund manager's style without understanding the actual contents of a portfolio and the manager's reasons for choosing these investments," Mr. Lipper said."It is like employing someone on the basis of their height and shoe size. These figures say absolutely nothing about the individual's skill. Style analysis is another example of statisticians attempting to use science to explain an art form." **********Anne McMeehan, managing director of Framlington, a fund management group in London, agrees with Mr. Lipper that style analysis is probably too simplistic a technique to rely on exclusively.But she believes it is useful for understanding how a fund management group aims to add value. **********Ms. McMeehan maintains that while it is important to have a disciplined approach to investing, managers need also to be able to respond to changing market conditions and not be beholden to a particular label. **********Mr. Sharpe acknowledges that style analysis has its limitations. "Itwill not help investors pick next year's winning fund. Nor will it enable investors predict whether growth or value is going to do best in the next 24 months. Style analysis may even be misleading in situations where a fund manager abruptly changes investment style," he said. **********But then style analysis is not intended to be a cure-all. At best, it can provide information about how funds and their managers behave and how funds perform relative to their specialist benchmarks. At worst, it is a number-crunching exercise that leaves the vast majority of investors nonplussed and none the wiser.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/27/busin.snippet: United Automobile Workers union is leaning toward negotiating with new national labor contract first at General Motors Corp and Ford Motor Co, and leaving Chrysler Corp for later (L)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/27/busin.main_headline: U.A.W. Said to Prefer Talks With G.M. and Ford First, Chrysler Later
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/27/busin.print_headline: U.A.W. Said to Prefer Talks With G.M. and Ford First, Chrysler Later
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/27/busin.body_text: **********The United Automobile Workers union is leaning toward negotiating a new national labor contract first at the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, and leaving the Chrysler Corporation for later, people close to the union said today. **********While Stephen P. Yokich, the U.A.W.'s president, could change his mind, the current consensus at the union is that negotiations should proceed simultaneously with Ford and G.M., people familiar with the union's decision-making said. The three-year labor contracts between the U.A.W. and each of the Big Three auto makers expire at midnight on Sept. 14. **********Although Mr. Yokich and Richard Shoemaker, the U.A.W.'s vice president for G.M. issues, are delegates to the Democratic National Convention in Chicago, both men stayed here today to hammer out strategy, people close to the union said. Another delegate, Ernest Lofton, the U.A.W.'s vice president for Ford issues, abruptly flew back here from Chicago this afternoon to join them. **********But a fourth delegate, Jack Laskowski, the vice president and head of Chrysler issues, remained in Chicago, a sign that Chrysler is unlikely to be included in the U.A.W.'s first round of negotiations. **********Chrysler had expressed strong interest last spring in going first, and many industry analysts expected it to do so. The U.A.W. has traditionally confronted the most prosperous company first, on the theory that it would be the most willing to settle to prevent a strike disrupting its production. In the United States auto industry, Chrysler has the highest profit margins for each of its vehicles. **********But the U.A.W.'s leaders began having second thoughts this summer, worrying that if Chrysler made generous concessions, G.M. might refuse to sign the same deal. The most pressing issues for the U.A.W. are at G.M., which is trying to buy more parts from outside suppliers and which accounts for half the U.A.W.'s employment in the industry. **********Mr. Yokich said last Thursday that it was important for the domestic auto makers to pay like wages and benefits, although he pointedly did not say that the rest of each auto maker's labor contract had to have identical language. **********All three auto makers have said they would have liked to go first so as to negotiate contracts that suit their needs. But the talks this summer have gone slowly, with all the auto makers taking a hard line. **********The developing consensus at the U.A.W. in favor of including Ford in the first round of negotiations reflects Mr. Yokich's close friendship with top Ford executives and Ford's tradition of coming up with innovative solutions to complex labor problems, people close to the union said. U.A.W. and Ford officials said on June 10, at the opening of labor talks, that the next national labor contract might last for longer than the traditional three years. **********If the U.A.W. pursues talks with G.M. and Ford simultaneously, it would be unusual, but it would have precedents. The union negotiated with G.M. and Chrysler in 1990, and with G.M. and Ford in 1970. **********In both cases, the U.A.W. ended up narrowing its focus to G.M. in the final days before its national contracts expired. The 1990 negotiations ended peacefully, while the talks in 1970 produced a two-month-long national strike at G.M. that contributed to a nationwide recession that year. G.M. is the nation's biggest company in terms of sales and employees. **********If the U.A.W. chooses G.M. and Ford, it will put the Canadian Auto Workers, a separate union, in a difficult position. Basil E. Hargrove, the Canadian union's president, who is known as Buzz, said in an interview earlier this summer that he would start negotiations with a different company than the one the U.A.W. was negotiating with. If both unions negotiated with the same auto maker at the same time, the smaller Canadian union might be ignored. **********If the U.A.W. chooses Ford and G.M., that would appear to leave Mr. Hargrove with only Chrysler, with which the Canadian union has few quarrels. Chrysler is the only auto maker not to have backed tough new labor laws being drafted by Ontario's provincial government. **********In a telephone interview this afternoon, Mr. Hargrove refused to discuss the U.A.W.'s decision-making. But he acknowledged a reluctance to confront Chrysler first. **********''There is some hesitancy on my part because of the relationship with Chrysler, because they have been very good on the issues here,'' Mr. Hargrove said. **********He added that he planned to choose his negotiating target on Wednesday morning in any case. ''The companies are waiting now for us to identify a target,'' Mr. Hargrove said. ''People have really staked out their ground as far as the issues.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/26/world.snippet: French truck drivers striking for higher pay and right to early retirement at full pay blockade highways, ports and airports; Prime Min Alain Juppe appeals to new Government-appointed mediator to resolve dispute, which could mushroom into national...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/26/world.main_headline: Strike by French Truck Drivers Slows Commerce to Snail's Pace
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/26/world.print_headline: Strike by French Truck Drivers Slows Commerce to Snail's Pace
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/26/world.body_text: **********French truck drivers striking for higher pay and the right to early retirement at full pay blockaded highways, ports and airports all around the country today as a dispute with private employers went into its second week. **********After a week of blockades around oil refineries in southern France, gasoline supplies were running out in Bordeaux, the most heavily affected city. Prime Minister Alain Juppe, who is also Mayor of Bordeaux, appealed to a new Government-appointed mediator to get the two sides to find a solution quickly after an all-night negotiating session failed to produce results. **********''The Government has done everything to get these talks under way,''  Mr. Juppe said. ''They must now resume and finish.'' The talks resumed at 5 P.M. today. **********The dispute had the greatest potential of any this year to mushroom into a paralyzing national protest like the rail and mass transit strike that brought the French economy to a standstill a year ago. Like the railroad workers then, the truck drivers now have the support of 74 percent of the public, according to a poll for France 2 Television, because many people identify with the truckers' grievances. **********The main one is their claim that the trucking industry has not lived up to the terms of an agreement, which ended a strike two years ago, to pay drivers for the time they spend loading or waiting to start their journeys. **********The truck drivers, supported by all the main labor unions, also want the right to retire at full pay at age 55 instead of 60 at present. **********To back those demands, they reinforced 100 roadblocks throughout France today after the fruitless 14-hour session Sunday night, the first presided over by the mediator, Robert Cros, a civil servant who played a similar role two years ago. **********''Operation Escargot,'' as the action was called, also had trucks crawling at a snail's pace along some superhighways, causing huge traffic jams behind them. The main highway to Spain was blocked in both directions north of Bordeaux; north of Paris, trucks blocked all but one lane into Charles de Gaulle Airport. **********Along the English Channel, truck drivers kept all but private passenger cars from using ferries, adding to transportation woes caused by the fire that put the Channel Tunnel substantially out of operation a week ago. Some of the 1,000 British truck drivers caught up in the dispute have asked French union leaders to let them go back to England. **********Store shelves in Paris began emptying after drivers cut off much of the wholesale market south of the capital. In Alsace, trailer trucks blocked the main highways in and out of Germany, and five rail unions called on their members to support the truckers. **********Marc Blondel, who led last year's movement, met with Transport Minister Bernard Pons today, but he said he would await the result of the mediator's talks before deciding whether to call for a broader strike.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/14/busin.body_text: **********THE STOCK MARKET What Goes Up Goes Where? It was the battle of the cliches last week on Wall Street: "What goes up must come down" vs. "You can't miss with stocks." The "can't miss" theory got a resounding vote on word that we keep pouring staggering sums into mutual funds.  Watch the superlatives pile up: the first quarter's $80 billion take shattered the previous record, with the $72 billion that went into stock funds exceeding the total for 1995's first seven months. Still, come down the market did, relentlessly -- with no big next-day bouncebacks, like soothing hot chocolate, to make it all better. What's happening? "Inflation!" cried the doomsayers, while optimists pointed, yet again, at the aging-baby-boomer savings juggernaut. Irresistible force, meet immovable object. **********SUBSISTENCE A 'Living Wage,' Locally It's called the "minimum" wage -- a name that's more appropriate by the day. Inflation so eroded this base wage in the 80's that even if the Clinton team manages to cajole it up to $5.15 an hour from $4.25, it'll buy less than it did  in the 70's. But now this battle has gone local, to cities like Baltimore, and has a new name, the "living wage" movement. Baltimore now demands that companies with city contracts pay at least $6.10 -- it goes to $6.60 in July -- and more than 30 other cities are also looking for ways to do at the local level what Congress has not seen fit to do nationwide. Baltimore's rule affects few workers, though, so living-wage advocates are calling for broader local action. **********THE TOBACCO WARS Smoking Documents? The Great Tobacco Wars are marked by a lot of facts, a lot of haze. Here's a fact: the F.B.I. just got some documents. After that, the haze descends. Some lawyers say they are Philip Morris documents, the executive who'd squirreled them away begs to differ, and Philip Morris calls their release a "bizarre stunt." If they're the real thing, they just might provide a -- pardon the expression -- smoking gun on one smoldering issue: whether tobacco companies manipulated nicotine levels. A lawyer said one note read: "determine minimum nicotine drop to keep normal smokers hooked." It was, he said, dated Feb. 1, 1965 -- soon after the landmark Surgeon General's report, as Philip Morris was trying to design low-tar cigarettes. **********On other fronts, a Mayo Clinic study suggested that when alcoholics smoke, it's  the cigarettes that are more likely to kill them. Marlboro will be named to the  Marketing Hall of Fame, the first tobacco product to get that honor. And R.J. Reynolds is gambling on a nearly smokeless cigarette. **********FOLLOW THE FORTUNE Duke, Father and Daughter Speaking of tobacco, James Buchanan Duke and his daughter are both in the news.  The daughter you know all about: Doris Duke, whose $1.2 billion estate has been  a battleground since her death in 1993. Last week came a tentative settlement in which Bernard Lafferty, the butler-come-lately who'd been living in her mansions and jetting about in her plane, would get millions but no longer rule the roost. And her father, "Buck" Duke? Well, he's the one who made that fortune, as the turn-of-the-century founder of American Tobacco, the colossus that dominated the industry until the trust-busters got at it in 1911. His rough-and-tumble story is told in detail in "Ashes to Ashes," by Richard Kluger, a history of the tobacco wars just out from Alfred A. Knopf. **********THE AGE OF PLASTIC Farewell, Loose Change? Watch out. They're trying to make our lives easier again. Who's "they"? Well, this time it's Citibank, Chase, Mastercard and Visa, which last week offered to  let the world try cash that's been computer-imbedded in a plastic card. Just swipe it through some machine, you're $1.78 poorer, and the store is $1.78 richer. Why? Faster sales, more sales to those not endowed with exact change, fewer bank tellers -- the list goes on. But think of small rituals lost: the math lessons for schoolchildren in figuring change, the triumph of pointing out  that you've been shortchanged, the moral dilemma -- keep it, or give it back? -- when you get too much. And as one citizen, echoing the lament of the plastic-carrying masses, put it, "Why do I need another card?" **********ROARING FOR DOLLARS Numbers, Hollywood Style The numbers boggle the mind -- but it is Hollywood, after all. When Jeffrey Katzenberg left Disney in 1994, it seems, he expected 2 percent of the profits from all those money machines like "Beauty and the Beast" and "The Lion King." Hollywood heavyweights normally work these things out in whispers, but there is  apparently such bad blood between Mr. Katzenberg and Michael Eisner, Disney's boss, that they couldn't. So Mr. Katzenberg sued last week, saying those profits now exceed $12.5 billion -- which puts his 2 percent at, yes, $250 million. A lion's ransom indeed. **********DEVELOPER PLUS Building for Real People A socially conscious real estate developer. Hmmm. Sounds like an oxymoron. But then there's James W. Rouse, who died last week at 81. He "did more to revitalize American cities than anyone this century," said Donna Shalala, Health and Human Services Secretary. How? For one thing, he created Columbia, Md., a city designed to carve some order out of the chaos of postwar sprawl. And he invented the idea of inner-city "festival marketplaces" by creating Boston's Faneuil Hall, which counts South Street Seaport among its numerous offspring. But he was proudest of his late-in-life efforts to offer affordable housing, with his Enterprise Foundation building more than 40,000 units. Through it all,  he had one passion: he watched people walk, talk and shop; he wanted real people to live in places he built. What a quaint idea. **********FUEL EFFICIENCY Some Guzzle, Some Don't The fuel-efficiency news was all over the map last week. At one extreme, the Energy Department said it expected gasoline demand to set records this summer. One culprit is Americans' bizarre infatuation with gas-guzzling sport utility vehicles. (Do ads picture them in odd, wild places because they're searching desperately for gas stations?). Another is higher speed limits (because faster driving erodes efficiency). At the far side of the map, Honda introduced a new electric vehicle, to appear in California in the spring of '97 -- the first to use nickel-metal hydride batteries. It says this advanced technology greatly improves range, though the Honda EV still goes just 125 miles on a charge. The price, a big sticking point as electrics yearn for actual buyers, was not disclosed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/09/world.main_headline: Pro-Chechen Hijacker of Turkish Jet Surrenders in Germany
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/09/world.print_headline: Pro-Chechen Hijacker of Turkish Jet Surrenders in Germany
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/09/world.body_text: **********A pro-Chechen gunman hijacked a Turkish Cypriot airliner to Munich late Friday, but released the 109 hostages early today. A Munich airport spokesman, Hans-Joachim Bues, said the 101 passengers and 8 crew members were safe. **********The hijacker was arrested. Chechens have been at war with Russia for more than a year in an effort to win independence for their republic, in the Caucasus. **********The hijacker's only reported demand was to speak to speak to a human rights  lawyer and to the news media; neither demand was met. **********Before the surrender, the hijacker had released eight hostages from the Boeing 727, including the pilot and a flight attendant. **********The plane was hijacked soon after leaving northern Cyprus for Istanbul. It stopped first in Sofia, Bulgaria, where the hijacker got fuel to fly to Germany. **********The freed hostages said the hijacker was armed with at least one automatic weapon and a bomb, a police investigator, Winfried Bischler, said this morning. **********Throughout the drama, officials had said there were four hijackers. There were conflicting reports on their nationality, variously given as Azerbaijani, Russian and Chechen. **********A Bulgarian security official and the Turkish Ambassador to Bulgaria had said there were several hijackers, and identified them as supporters of rebels fighting for independence for Chechnya. The deputy head of Bulgaria's national security service, Vladimir Markov, said that the hijackers were Chechens and that they were armed with pistols. **********The passengers included 47 Turks, 33 Turkish Cypriots, 2 Russians and at least 5 Belgians. Anatolia identified one American on board as James Richard Walton; his hometown was not immediately available. **********On Jan. 16, nine pro-Chechen gunmen protesting Moscow's attempt to crush the  separatists hijacked a Turkish ferry in the Black Sea and kept more than 200 people hostage for three days. **********The hijackers, six Turks and three Russians, diverted the ship toward Istanbul, but Turkish authorities refused to allow the ferry into the Bosporus Strait and negotiated a peaceful end, capturing the hijackers. **********Turks have ethnic ties to the Caucasus, and many in Turkey sympathize with the Chechen secessionists. **********-------------------- **********Fighting Continues in Grozny **********GROZNY, Russia, March 8 (AP) -- The roar of gunfire and exploding shells shook Grozny for a third day today as Russian troops fought to drive Chechen rebels out of the capital of their separatist republic. **********The fiercest fighting was on the southern outskirts, where 200 Russian troops were reportedly pinned down. Moscow's reinforcements were unable to break through, Russian news reports said. **********Casualty reports have been conflicting and fragmentary. The Russian television reported today that about 100 Government troops and 150 to 300 rebels had been killed in the three-day battle. The health ministry in Grozny said 70 civilians had been killed today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/13/busin.main_headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Prices Post Sharp Drop
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/13/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Prices Post Sharp Drop
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/13/busin.body_text: **********Treasury prices ended sharply lower yesterday despite a report that showed inflation remaining moderate. **********The report said consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in May, providing little evidence of inflationary pressures. But the numbers only matched the market's expectations and were not weak enough to shake fears that inflation could still begin to accelerate. **********Indeed, the nervousness and uncertainty has made the market vulnerable to rumors about selling by large funds and about the Federal Reserve's next move. **********Bond prices bounced off morning lows, but ended the session down lower as buyers position themselves ahead of the next important economic report, today's  data on retail sales. **********"Thursday's retail sales data should set the tone in the bond market for the  next couple of days," said Doug Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data of Boston. **********"The Street presumes that consumers came out of their cave in May and spent furiously," he said. If this assumption is true, the bearish tone that pervaded  the market for the past several months will find a new set of fans." **********The price of the 30-year bond ended down 24/32 , to 8515/32 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the bond's prices, rose to 7.19 percent, from 7.12 percent on Tuesday. The yield is currently at its highest level since May 3, 1995, when it was 7.24 percent. **********Shorter-term maturities fared a little better, with the yield on the two-year note rising to 6.39 percent from 6.36 percent and the yield on the 10-year note  rising to 7.06 percent from 6.98 percent. **********Yesterday's report on consumer prices confirmed indications that inflation remains contained. Excluding the volatile categories of food and energy, the so-called core rate of the Consumer Price Index edged up only two-tenths of 1 percent, with a year-to-year gain of 2.7 percent. **********The two price reports are consistent with a view -- albeit a minority opinion in the market -- that the Federal Reserve will leave short-term interest rates unchanged when Fed policy makers meet on July 2 and 3, said Bruce Steinberg, an  econmist with Merrill Lynch & Company. **********"Many worry that even though inflation is currently subdued the economy is currently growing too fast, which will lead to inflation problems down the road," Mr. Steinberg said. "That concern is understandable, but there are two reasons we believe it will not materialize. First we think that the economy's growth potential is higher than the pathetic 2.2 percent that many believe it to be. **********"Second, interest rate developments so far this year are likely to slow the economy sharply during the next six months, short-circuiting any budding inflation problem." **********But the market was busy yesterday pricing in a strong retail sales number expected today. Still, additional signs of strength will likely lead to more selling and a retesting of the market's lows. **********The May report is expected to show a gain of 1 percent, and excluding autos,  a gain of nine-tenths of 1 percent. **********In the corporate market, Chase Manhattan Bank sold $2 billion in asset-backed securities in two parts through a Chase Manhattan Credit Card Trust. **********The banking company joins companies like Chrysler, Advanta and the Providian  Corporation that have repackaged about $65 billion of credit card, auto, home equity and other loans and sold them as bonds so far this year. **********The Chase securities, which are backed by credit card receiveables, are equally divided between an expected maturity date of 1999, that is priced to yield 6.831 percent, or about 28-hundredths of a percentage point more than a comparable Treasury issue, and one with an expected maturity date of 2001 that is priced to yield 7.147 percent, or about 37-hundredths of a percentage point more than a comparable Treasury.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/25/busin.snippet: Procter & Gamble Co reports net income rose 9.3 percent profit in fiscal first quarter ended Sept 30 to record $979 million, up from $896 million in year-earlier period; table (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/25/busin.body_text: **********The Procter & Gamble Company reported a 9.3 percent profit increase yesterday, to a record $979 million, in the latest quarter despite a decline in worldwide sales. **********The giant consumer products company said net income for the three months ended Sept. 30 rose to $979 million, or $1.39 a share, from $896 million, or $1.27 a share. **********The per-share earnings for the company's fiscal first quarter were 2 cents better than Wall Street estimates of $1.37, according to First Call, which tracks analysts' estimates. **********Still, investors sent the Cincinnati-based company's stock reeling. P.& G. fell $2.25, to $94, on the New York Stock Exchange, where it was one of the most active issues. **********Procter & Gamble said despite record unit sales volume worldwide, its sales for the quarter slipped to $8.9 billion from $9.03 billion, primarily because of the strong dollar compared with other currencies. **********Excluding the effect of unfavorable exchange rates, particularly in Japan and Germany, sales increased consistent with unit volume growth, the company said. **********The company, whose brands include Tide detergent, Pampers diapers and Hawaiian Punch drinks, said its North American shipments, led by the laundry and cleaning products, expanded by 2 percent to a record as dollar sales rose 1 percent. **********P.& G. said sales and volume increased despite capacity constraints on some fast-growing categories, like tissues and towels. **********The company said unit sales volume in Europe, the Middle East and Africa grew 5 percent to a record, but unit volumes were down 9 percent in Asia and 6 percent in Latin America. (Reuters)

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/03/world.main_headline: THE BOSNIA ACCORD: IN SARAJEVO;Across a Balkan Bridge, the Barriers of Hate and Suspicion Linger
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/03/world.print_headline: THE BOSNIA ACCORD: IN SARAJEVO;Across a Balkan Bridge, the Barriers of Hate and Suspicion Linger
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/03/world.body_text: **********Guarding his post on the Brotherhood and Unity bridge, Sinisa Jovic, a Bosnian Serb policeman, had a message for his best friend, a Muslim in the part  of the city the Bosnian Serbs had shelled and besieged. **********"Go tell him that if he comes here I will guarantee that no one will touch one hair on his head," said the 31-year-old former soldier. "And ask him if it will be safe for me to come there, so we can again drink coffee together and talk about the old times that were. He is my friend and I have no other." **********Where once armed Serbs sat stony-faced, 60 feet from their enemies in the Bosnian capital, they now drink toasts to the end of the war and daydream about  the cosmopolitan city they fled. **********It is a reflection of the change they see across the Miljacka River, in the Government-controlled center of town. From their perches over the last two months, they have watched Sarajevo come alive with the bustle of people and the  rush of trams. They have heard the distant thumping of discos and have seen empty buildings turned into shiny coffee bars. **********Their neighborhood, Grbavica, sits in stark contrast to this economic regeneration. On the southern edge of the city, it remains a chilly grouping of  damaged high-rises and former sniper nests, where all streets are marked by rows of protective shields. Under the terms of the Dayton peace agreement, even this  dismal sanctuary will soon be lost, formally coming under Government control next month. **********The peace accord guarantees the rights and property of Serbs who remain in Grbavica, but few say they will risk staying. Where to go remains a problem. **********Most of the Bosnian Serb republic is composed of villages, where foreign languages and university education are not prized, where the main export is wood, not art, music or education. And for the men on the bridge -- like many residents of Sarajevo's suburbs, well educated and accustomed to urban society -- a sadness has crept from the peace, a longing for the eclectic trappings of the city they tried to kill. **********"Before the war, I had a country," said another Bosnian Serb policeman, 28-year-old Risto Bebarovic. "Now I have nothing. Over there, they have cars, apartments, culture and a country. I have the Bosnian Serb republic but I have no heart for this place. **********"During New Year's Eve, I could see the tram moving in the night picking up people in what was once my neighborhood and I began to cry. Sometimes I regret crossing the bridge." **********Mr. Bebarovic grew up in Sarajevo, learned English, became an electrical engineer, and fell in love with a young Muslim girl. He never planned on leaving. But in 1992, as war broke out, he and his Serbian friends said they were pushed to chose sides. **********Some Bosnian Serbs took up arms and sowed terror in their own city. Others just left, overcome by worry that they might become victims of Muslims. They now have a wasteland to ponder. **********Shaking his head at his dismal prospects, Mr. Bebarovic recalled the day he slipped away across the bridge into Grbavica. **********"I had gone down to the coffee bar, 20 feet from my home," he said clenching  his jaw. "But when I asked for a brandy, the waiter told me he had none. I tried to get a beer, then a coffee. He had none for Serbs. After that I stayed awake all night, worried that they would come for me. Finally, by the morning, I had crossed to the other side and lost everything." **********Mr. Jovic and Mr. Bebarovic are now trying to rekindle their connections in the city, hoping that old friends will guide them back into the lives they once  had. But their return is fraught with difficulties. The Bosnian Government has yet to offer amnesty to its former enemies. It also keeps records on all Serbs who left Sarajevo and has put together lists of complaints against those who might have committed crimes. **********The war has left old friendships tattered and vague, more things of suspicion than cherished memories. And there is plenty of hate to go around. **********Mr. Jovic's friend, 31-year-old Mevludin Kaljanac, now sits in the Dayton Cafe, covered with scars and hobbling to the cash register on an artificial leg, a replacement for the leg he lost in a battle for a hill near Sarajevo. Tapping  his prosthetic limb under the dim fluorescent light, Mr. Kaljanac said he was once a soccer player and judo expert, sports he played with Mr. Jovic as a boy.  But now, he said, people who left the city and then fired on its people are no longer welcome. **********"I am not the President, so I can't decide who comes into the city," he said. "He can come if he wants. But I think it's better if he just stays away." **********Where Mr. Jovic grew up, less than a mile from his post on the bridge, houses sit largely vacant due to shells and sniping from Grbavica, and his neighbors while away hours talking about close calls and the young dead. They recall Mr. Jovic as a good youth who one day abandoned them. They wonder if over the years  he fired some of those deadly shots into their midst or committed crimes in Grbavica. If he didn't, they know his compatriots did. **********"I have lost a lot in this war," Mr. Kaljanac said. "Look at me, I don't even have my leg. Sinisa was my best friend but I can't remember the good friendship  anymore. All things are different now." **********-------------------- **********Windows for Sarajevo **********GENEVA, Feb. 2 (Reuters) -- The United Nations refugee agency announced plans today to replace many of the window panes of Sarajevo and said it was increasingly hopeful that thousands of Serbs would choose to remain in their homes in the city. **********A spokesman for the group said it would replace about 70 percent of the windows smashed in more than three years of shelling and sniper fire. **********The agency will also be buying large amounts of concrete, timber and roofing  tiles to help displaced people elsewhere in Bosnia reclaim and repair their homes. **********The cost of the operation is put at $5 million, part of a $30 million emergency shelter program that the agency will present to donor governments in the coming days. **********When possible, the materials will be bought in Bosnia itself to help kick-start local industries, but the agency said the glass for Sarajevo will have to come from abroad. **********The vast majority of windows in Sarajevo have been replaced by plastic sheeting during 43 months of war. **********A spokesman for the agency, Ron Redmond, said the group welcomed the opening  to unrestricted foot traffic opened on Thursday of Sarajevo's Brotherhood and Unity Bridge, linking central Sarajevo with the Serb-held suburb of Grbavica. The bridge was a hotly contested passage during the war. **********The United Nations estimates that 12,000 Serbs have already packed up and left Sarajevo suburbs, which are due to come under the control of the Muslim-led Government by mid-March.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/21/world.main_headline: Charles Kades, 90, Architect Of Japan's Postwar Charter
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/21/world.print_headline: Charles Kades, 90, Architect Of Japan's Postwar Charter
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/21/world.body_text: **********Charles L. Kades, a lawyer who supervised the drafting of Japan's postwar Constitution, died on Tuesday in a hospital in Greenfield, Mass. He was 90 and had lived in Heath, Mass., since his retirement from law practice in New York in 1976. **********In a long and varied career, Mr. Kades, a native of Newburgh, N.Y., who graduated from Cornell and received his law degree from Harvard, tackled many complex problems. **********As a Government lawyer in Washington during the New Deal in the 1930's he worked as a counsel for the Public Works Administration, the Treasury and the Internal Revenue Service. In private practice in New York in the 1950's, 60's and 70's, he specialized in tax, bond, banking, corporate and estate matters; became a senior partner of the firm of Hawkins, Delafield and Wood, and advised  Gov. Hugh L. Carey on the creation and operation of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, the agency that supervised New York City's recovery from financial  crisis. **********Yet none of the cases he worked on and none of the deals he made had the impact of one whirlwind, a 10-day effort in February 1946 when Mr. Kades supervised the transformation of Japan from a monarchy into a modern democracy with full guarantees of equality. **********Under pressure from the occupying Allies, the Japanese Government had begun the process of revising the Meiji Constitution of 1881 late in 1945, but when details of the drafting committee's work leaked out on Feb. 1, 1946, and were seen to be no more than a light reworking of the old Constitution, there was an  immediate outcry. **********Although an American directive allowed him to order reforms "only as a last resort," with the first postwar general election just two months away and with an 11-nation commission due to take over the issue of a constitution, Gen. Douglas MacArthur, the Supreme Allied Commander, intervened. **********He ordered his own 24-member Government Section staff to draft a constitution, and on Feb. 4, his aide, Brig. Gen. Courtney Whitney, convened a meeting and declared: "Ladies and gentlemen, this is a historic occasion. I now  proclaim you a constitutional assembly." **********Lieut. Col. Charles Kades, who had been in Japan since a week before Japan's  formal surrender the previous summer after taking part in the invasion of France in 1944 and serving on the War Department's General Staff, was put in charge of  the steering committee and told to produce a constitution by Feb. 12. **********Colonel Kades, a gentle leader who resolved a myriad of debates, worked night and day to accomplish his mission. **********The resulting document effectively stripped the Emperor of authority, established an elected government and guaranteed a range of civil rights, including full equality for women. **********On March 4, Colonel Kades presided over the negotiations with Japanese authorities that led to the adoption of the American draft, including the famous renunciation of war that Colonel Kades had composed himself from General MacArthur's notes. **********The Constitution took effect on May 3, 1947, and proved so popular and so effective in laying the groundwork for Japan's postwar re-emergence as an economic power that Mr. Kades, who was decorated by the Army for his work, also  became a lionized figure in Japan. **********Mr. Kades is survived by his third wife, Phyllis; a daughter from a previous  marriage, Caroline Foster-Bunch of Avalon, Australia; three stepchilren, Jewelle Bickford and William C. Wooten, both of New York, and James H. Wooten of Orlando, Fla.; and nine grandchildren.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/30/busin.snippet: Commerce Department reports growth in total output of goods and sevices for April-June period was calculated at annual rate of 4.8, six-tenths of a percentage point above estimate published at beginning of month and strongest since spring of 1994;...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/30/busin.main_headline: Economy's Pace Gained Speed In 2d Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/30/busin.print_headline: Economy's Pace Gained Speed In 2d Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/30/busin.body_text: **********The Commerce Department reported today that the economy sprinted to an even bigger gain in the spring quarter than it had earlier estimated. The report, along with other data released today, suggested that an expected slowing of activity was eluding policy makers, rekindling financial markets' fears of higher interest rates. **********Growth in total output of goods and services for the April-June period was calculated at at an annual rate of 4.8, six-tenths of a percentage point above the estimate published at the beginning of the month and the strongest since the spring of 1994. Moreover, the upward revision showed less production going into inventories and more of it to meet demand. **********In a second report, the Government said sales of new single-family homes surged 7.8 percent in July, the most robust showing since February. This advance came despite mortgage rates that remain above 8 percent and, like the output figures, also surprised analysts, most of whom had expected a small decline in home sales. **********''The economy still has a good deal of momentum,'' said Brian M. Jones, an economist at Salomon Brothers. **********The unexpected strength rattled the bond market. Bond prices tumbled on revived fears that the Federal Reserve would not be able to avoid a decision to tighten monetary policy to prevent a flare-up of inflation. The next scheduled meeting of the Fed's main policy body is Sept. 24; minutes of its July meeting published last Friday showed it had decided to lean in the direction of raising short-term rates. **********The slump in prices drove up the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond -- a benchmark for mortgages and other consumer and corporate interest rates -- to 7.03 percent, from 6.98 percent on Wednesday. Bond prices and their yields move in opposite directions. **********Stocks followed bond prices lowers on fears that higher rates would raise borrowing costs and cut into profits. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 64.73 points, or 1.13 percent, to 5,647.65, while the Nasdaq composite index fell 8.85 points, or nearly eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,145.03. **********A third report, covering last week, showed today that first-time claims for unemployment insurance edged up 4,000, to a total of 331,000. This continued a recent pattern of job-market strength but closely matched expectations. Some analysts are predicting that the Labor Department's monthly gleaning of labor-market data, to be published Sept. 6, will show that the nation's unemployment fell in August to 5.2 percent, which would be the lowest in more than six years. **********The Clinton Administration, facing a Presidential challenge from Bob Dole, who has centered his campaign on calls for faster economic growth, was quick to hail the surprising, though not unusually large, upward revision in gross domestic product. **********Joseph E. Stiglitz, the President's chief economic adviser, declared the G.D.P. report ''strengthens our view that the United States economy is achieving the kind of strong economic growth that can raise America's living standards.'' He added that the downward revision of inventories combined with upward revisions for final sales and business investment in plant and equipment ''provide additional signs that the prospects for further strong economic growth in the future are excellent.'' **********By this he was pointing out that when shelves and warehouses are thinly stocked -- and much of the second-quarter increase was concentrated in motor vehicles -- demand is quickly transmitted to new production. **********The biggest single factor in the revision was international trade, which was less of a drag because import growth was lower than initially assumed. **********But the slowing of imports, as Merrill Lynch analysts noted today, is not a sign of economic strength. Nor is inventory buildup, however moderate. And the second-quarter growth rate also benefited, by about a percentage point, from the way the Government chose to account for last winter's partial shutdown of the Government, for which its workers were paid. **********For these and other reasons analysts seemed to be sticking today with forecasts for marked slowing in the third quarter, with Merrill Lynch holding to a 2 to 2 1/2 percent rate of increase. This is in line with assessments, including the Federal Reserve's, that the economy can grow that much without accelerating inflation. **********Still, after a string of figures pointing to a cooling off, perhaps partly because the Olympic Games kept many shoppers at home, some of the most recent figures cast doubt on this hope. One was last week's report of very strong orders for long-lived factory goods in July. Another was today's report from the Departments of Commerce and Housing and Urban Development that builders sold single-family homes at an annual rate of 783,000 last month, up from 726,000 in June. **********''The housing market is stubbornly strong,'' said Alan D. Levenson, an economist at UBS Securities in New York. He nevertheless predicted that the economy would throttle down to a 2 percent pace in the current quarter and that the Fed would not need to move rates higher. **********The rise in home sales included sizable gains in all four regions of the country other than the Northeast, where activity remained at the best level of the year while showing no further rise. **********At month's end, builders had 365,000 unsold houses, 2,000 more than in June but only a 5.8-month  supply at the latest selling rate instead of 6.1 months. **********Sales have now surpassed 700,000 for seven consecutive months, the first time this has happened in 10 years, said Ed Yardeni, economist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell/C. J. Lawrence. Sales for April, May and June, however, were revised downward by a combined 70,000, the report also showed. **********The median sales price of new houses sold last month was $143,000, up from $140,000 in June and up from $131,000 in July 1995. **********The G.D.P. report disclosed that inflation, as gauged by the price index for gross domestic purchases, ran at a 2.1 percent pace in the spring quarter, one-tenth of a point higher than previously estimated. **********Corporate profits, estimated by the department for the first time, slackened during the quarter. Profits from current production advanced 1.3 percent following a 5.4 percent first-quarter increase, while current-production cash flow rose 1.1 percent, compared with a 2.5 percent advance in the winter quarter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/27/world.main_headline: Bomb Kills 5 in Albania; 2 Ex-Officers Arrested
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/27/world.print_headline: Bomb Kills 5 in Albania; 2 Ex-Officers Arrested
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/27/world.body_text: **********A car bomb exploded outside a supermarket today, killing 5 people and wounding 30. Two members of the disbanded Communist secret police were charged with the crime. **********The car bomb, thought to contain 110 pounds of TNT, was parked six feet from  a store in Tirana, the capital. The blast, which gouged a small crater in the road, threw the car 30 feet and set the store on fire. Flying shards of glass wounded passers-by. **********The explosion killed two men and a woman who was believed to be pregnant. The body of another person, charred beyond recognition, has yet to be identified, the police said. Another man, a retiree, died later in a hospital. **********The explosion appeared to be the first act of political violence in Albania since the fall of Communism in 1990. **********"This is a fascist act organized by the forces of the former secret police,"  President Sali Berisha told Albanian radio after the attack. "There is no doubt  that this was a political act." **********Later in the day, the police arrested two former Communist secret police officials in connection with the blast. The Albanian news agency A.T.A. quoted the police as saying one of the officials had connections with the former Soviet secret police, the KGB. **********The police were also believed to be hunting for a man with long hair who was  seen leaving the car that later exploded. **********After the bombing, Mr. Berisha called an emergency meeting with top Government officials and security directors. The Cabinet offered the equivalent  of $50,000 for information leading to the arrest of the bombers. **********The President said that "the murderers had intended to kill as many people as possible" and wanted the explosion to create maximum destruction. **********Mr. Berisha's governing Democratic Party has often accused former agents of the Communist Sigurimi secret police of trying to raise tension in Albania. **********The country is scheduled to hold its third free general election by the end of May. **********The Sigurimi was disbanded in 1990 after a popular uprising toppled 40 years  of hard-line Stalinist rule, but the Government fears that some agents are still active, operating under cover to try to undermine democracy. **********Albania's main opposition Socialist Party, heirs to the former Communists, condemned the bomb blast. **********"The Albanian Socialist Party utterly condemns this unprecedented terrorist act in our country, and we support the Government's measure to hunt down and punish those responsible," the party said in a statement. The manager of a hotel near the site of the explosion said the blast had sent car debris hurtling into his rooms. Debris from the supermarket lay scattered across the street. **********A spokesman for the Vefa company, which owns the market, said no warning had  been received before the bomb went off. **********Vefa is one the biggest trading and investment companies in Albania, with a turnover of hundreds of millions of dollars. **********The spokesman dismissed suggestions of an attack by rival companies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/10/world.main_headline: Key Russian Legislator Accuses Leading Military Officers of Graft
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/10/world.print_headline: Key Russian Legislator Accuses Leading Military Officers of Graft
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/10/world.body_text: **********In an early test of President Boris N. Yeltsin's promise to root out corruption if re-elected, the retired general who heads Parliament's defense committee has accused some of Russia's highest-ranking generals of enriching themselves from the military budget. **********The charges, which have become the talk of Moscow, have rocked the military establishment. **********They are also shaping, and perhaps are being shaped by, the struggle to succeed the ousted Defense Minister, Gen. Pavel S. Grachev, who has himself been implicated in the scandal. **********"While soldiers are on a hunger ration, while officers wait to get a flat for more than 10 years and get no salaries for months, those close to the Defense Minister are literally living it up," said Lev Rokhlin, the defense committee chairman. **********Corruption is hardly a new phenomenon within the top ranks of the military. There have been persistent reports of opulent dachas, secret bank accounts and the sale of weapons for private gain, even as Russia's military budget has shrunk and its conscript army has been deprived of basic provisions. **********The problem of corruption, as well as the considerable risks in uncovering it, were brought into stark relief two years ago when Dmitri Kholodov, a 27-year-old reporter for the daily Moskovsky Komsomolets, was blown up by a booby-trapped suitcase. **********Mr. Kholodov had been investigating graft when Russian troops were stationed  in East Germany and asserted that two Mercedes sedans were purchased for General Grachev by selling army equipment. **********The newspaper took to calling the Defense Minister "Pasha Mercedes." Nevertheless, during his years as Defense Minister, General Grachev and many of  his top aides were immune from serious legal challenges. **********But now that Mr. Yeltsin has dismissed General Grachev and appointed Aleksander I. Lebed, a retired general, as his national security adviser, General Grachev has suddenly become more vulnerable. **********The allegations are coming from Mr. Rokhlin, a political ally of Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin and also a retired general, who is well regarded within the Russian military. **********Mr. Rokhlin charged on Friday that General Grachev, his key aides and other high-ranking officers are "mired in corruption." **********No sooner were the charges made than Parliament voted 301 to 0 to demand a legal investigation. **********The charges have also created a sensation in the Russian mass media, which originally disclosed some of the most damning allegations. **********Tonight, the independent television network NTV broadcast a report in which a camera crew and investigators from the prosecutor's office descended on a dacha  settlement. The broadcast showed army trucks carrying concrete and soldiers building the dachas, which the network said were for high-ranking officers from  the Strategic Rocket Forces and the Air Defense Forces. **********Mr. Rokhlin's report was far more specific. **********In a litany of charges was the accusation that Gen. Konstantin Kobets, a chief military inspector who is among the candidates to replace General Grachev, was part of a plot in which the military gave away a Government building to a construction company in exchange for officers' apartments that were never delivered. **********Mr. Rokhlin asserted that General Kobets's son was involved in the company, and charged that the general also urged the transfer of $12 million worth of aircraft engines to the company. **********At a news conference today, General Kobets denied that his son had any connection to the company and said that Mr. Rokhlin's charges were a politically motivated attempt to influence the selection of the new Defense Minister. **********But much of General Kobets's account of the tangled transactions appeared to  raise as many questions as they answered. **********In another charge, Mr. Rokhlin asserted that Col. Gen. Dmitri Kharchenko, whose daughter is married to General Grachev's son, pocketed the interest from a $5 million bank deposit of government funds. **********In the new Russia, many ousted officials tend to retain their privileges and  perks. But the allegations raise the possibility that former ranking officials may be prosecuted. **********And since corruption is believed to be widespread within the military and the Government, many are asking how far the anti-corruption drive will go. **********In Russia's conspiracy-minded capital, the timing of Mr. Rokhlin's report produced no shortage of speculation. **********General Grachev, who has protested his innocence, insisted that Mr. Rokhlin was nothing more than a stalking horse for Mr. Lebed. **********"There is a simple reason for this," General Grachev told the newspaper Nezavisimaya Gazeta. "Lebed's supporters worked on him." **********Mr. Rokhlin has denied that he working on Mr. Lebed's behalf. But he has endorsed Mr. Lebed's candidate for Defense Minister, Gen. Igor Rodionov, and has acknowledged that he wants to bar the door to corrupt candidates. **********For all the storm and fury, some members of Parliament say more sweeping steps must be taken to fight corruption. **********Aleksei Arbatov, a military expert and member of the parliamentary delegation led by the liberal reformer Grigory Yavlinsky, said that the Yeltsin Government  needed to appoint honest officials and to press the Defense Ministry to disclose more information about its finances. **********"That there is unprecedented corruption is not news," Mr. Arbatov said. "The  system is not transparent. It is most secretive, and changing it is one of the conditions for fighting corruption."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/18/busin.main_headline: Stocks Are Mixed as Dow Posts a Slight Gain
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/18/busin.print_headline: Stocks Are Mixed as Dow Posts a Slight Gain
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/18/busin.body_text: **********Stocks were mixed yesterday as a rally in bonds failed to shake investor concern that profits would fall short of expectations later this year. **********The Dow Jones industrial average rose 3.33 points, to 5,652.78, ending five straight days of losses. The broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell  0.69 point, to 665.16, while the Nasdaq composite index slipped 5.54 points, to  1,207.64. **********In the bond market, expectations of slowing growth, coupled with optimism that the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates next month to quell inflation pressures, helped drive the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond lower for a third session. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction of a bond's price, fell two-hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.06 percent. **********Lower rates, and the prospect of lower borrowing costs, pushed the Dow industrials up more than 28 points at one point late in the day, but fears about corporate earnings pared the gain. **********"We're very concerned about the profit outlook," said Kip Wright, portfolio manager at Kirr, Marbach & Company in Indianapolis, which oversees $800 million  in investment assets. "We're hearing that business is O.K., not booming. A lot of companies are leery about being too optimistic about the next six months." **********The Philip Morris Companies led decliners in the Dow industrials, falling 1,  to 104 3/8, after the prosecuting attorney in a Mississippi anti-tobacco lawsuit said six new industry insiders had come forward to assist the state's case. **********Semiconductors slid for a third day. Cyrix fell 2 1/16, to 23 1/2, after an analyst at the Southcoast Corporation who recently took over coverage of Cyrix cut the former earnings estimate for the current quarter by more than half. **********Intel shed 1, to 72. **********Brooktrout Technology Inc. and Smith Micro Software Inc., two small computer  software publishers, slid amid concern about the current quarter's earnings estimates, analysts said. Brooktrout fell 5 3/4, to 32 3/4, and Smith Micro retreated 1 7/8, to 11 1/2. **********Aptar Group Inc., a maker of aerosols and pumps for fragrance and health care manufacturers, said its second-quarter earnings would not meet expectations because of weak perfume and cosmetic sales in Europe. Aptar fell 3 3/8, to 36 3/8. **********Oil shares gained, following crude prices higher. A standoff between United Nations inspectors and Iraq led to speculation that the recent agreement allowing Iraq to sell oil might be delayed or shelved, tightening supplies. Exxon rose 1, to 84 1/2; Texaco rose 5/8, to 84 1/8, and Chevron advanced 3/8, to 60. **********Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C.'s American depository receipts gained after analysts said the company would report promising results in the development of a new AIDS treatment at a conference next month. Shares of the British drug maker, the world's largest producer of AIDS medications, rose 7/8, to 27 3/8. **********I.B.M. rose 7/8, to 102 1/2, after saying it would begin selling laser printers designed for computer networks, in competition with the market leader,  Hewlett-Packard, whose shares fell 5/8, to 99. **********Beverage companies, whose profits can grow regardless of the economy's performance, gained amid expectations of less frenetic growth. Coca-Cola rose 3/8, to 46 1/8, and Pepsico added 1/8, to 33 1/4. **********First Union rose 1/2, to 60 1/2, after it said it would buy two smaller East  Coast banks, Center Financial of Waterbury, Conn., and Home Financial of Hollywood, Fla., for a total of about $715 million in stock. **********Center Financial shares rose 1 1/4, to 24 1/8, while Home Financial fell 9/16, to 13 1/16 on the offer. **********Kansas City Power and Light rose 1 1/2, to 27 3/8, after Western Resources said it had sweetened its bid for the utility to $31, a share from $28. **********Syquest Technology rose 1 7/8, to 11 1/4, after the company said it met qualifications for listing on the Nasdaq stock market, after raising $20 million from investors by selling preferred shares.
