https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/24/busin.print_headline: MOOG TO ACQUIRE UNIT FROM MOTION CONTROL
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/24/busin.body_text: **********Moog Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Moog Controls Inc. from closely held International Motion Control for $48.6 million in cash. All of Moog Controls' 240 employees will be offered jobs, a company spokesman said. Moog Controls, a maker of industrial controls primarily for United States markets, was spun off by Moog Inc. in 1988 in exchange for stock held by Bill Moog, the company's founder. Moog Inc., based in East Aurora, N.Y., makes controls used in commercial, industrial, aerospace and military applications with sales in the United States and overseas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/21/world.main_headline: ACCORD REACHED BY IRAQ AND U.N. FOR OIL EXPORTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/21/world.print_headline: ACCORD REACHED BY IRAQ AND U.N. FOR OIL EXPORTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/21/world.body_text: **********Iraq and the United Nations signed an agreement today allowing the Iraqis to  sell oil for the first time since their 1990 invasion of Kuwait in order to pay  for the urgent needs of a civilian population suffering from six years of tight  international sanctions. **********The agreement permits Iraq to sell up to $1 billion worth of oil every 90 days, under tight United Nations supervision, with most of the money to buy food and medicine. **********The deal sets aside one-third of money for a compensation fund for victims of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August 1990. In addition, $130 million to $150 million of the relief goods will be reserved for Kurds in northern Iraq, a  minority abused in the past by Baghdad. **********Oil industry experts say the sudden infusion of Iraqi oil into the world market could mean a drop in oil prices of $2 to $3 a barrel. [Page A8.] **********That could translate into something of a political windfall for the Clinton Administration, which is under pressure to stem the rise in gasoline prices. **********The deal today became possible when negotiators for President Saddam Hussein  of Iraq dropped demands that Baghdad choose the bank to manage the oil money, that it and not the United Nations deliver relief to the Kurds, and that United  Nations inspectors have limited authority to check compliance. **********Oil is not expected to begin flowing for a number of weeks, perhaps months, because some operational details remain to be worked out. But diplomats and United Nations officials say they believe that the Iraqis mean business now, unlike the situation four years ago, when a similar plan collapsed. Since the earlier deal broke down, hundreds of thousands of Iraqis have become malnourished or ill, with many dying from lack of medication, United Nations agencies estimate. **********"This resolution is based on one of the most important objectives of the United Nations, which is to alleviate the problem of poverty -- and the poorest  of the poor were suffering in Iraq," Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali said after announcing the agreement to the Security Council, which adopted the plan in April 1995 and has been waiting a year for an Iraqi response. **********Reuters reported that news of the agreement, broadcast on state radio and television, set off street celebrations in Baghdad. Iraqis embraced each other and fired volleys of shots into the air. **********Food vendors cut prices for eggs, sugar, rice, tea and cooking oils in anticipation that supplies would soon increase, the agency reported. **********The new agreement does not change the broad sanctions still in place against  Iraq. In order to have those lifted, and be free to sell oil in unrestricted quantities for purposes of its own choosing, Iraq will have to prove that its weapons of mass destruction have been eliminated, and it will also have to return looted Kuwaiti property and account for 600 Kuwaitis still missing after  the 1990 invasion and the 1991 war in the Persian Gulf. **********The United States has accused the Iraqi leader of building palaces and indulging in other luxuries while letting his population suffer as a way of generating international sympathy for an end to sanctions. **********"The whole point here is that Saddam Hussein has been using his people as pawns in order to try to get a change in the sanctions regime," said Madeleine K. Albright, the chief United States delegate. This resolution would "remove that blackmail," she said. "The sanctions will stay in place until he abides by  all the resolutions." **********Under the plan, accepted by President Hussein after several months of off-and-on negotiations here, Iraq may sell up to $2 billion in oil during a six-month period, renewable if Baghdad meets all the conditions of the agreement, which will be monitored by the United Nations. Compliance with the accord will be checked by the Security Council every 90 days. Its Iraqi sanctions committee will be involved in all phases of the operation. **********The agreement would add about 700,000 barrels a day of Iraqi oil to world supplies at current prices. Before the 1990 embargo, Iraq supplied about 3 million barrels daily, or about 4 percent of world supplies. **********Iraq has the world's second-largest oil reserves after Saudi Arabia. Officially, reserves stand at more than 100 billion barrels, more than a tenth of the world's untapped oil. But analysts say the supply may be twice that amount. **********The plan outlined today requires that Iraqi oil must pass through pipelines the West regards as relatively easy to monitor -- the Kirkuk-Yumurtalik pipeline across Turkey to the Mediterranean, or through Iraq's oil terminal at Mina al-Bakr on the Persian Gulf. The new accord, in the form of a memorandum of understanding signed by Iraq's negotiator, Abdul Amir al-Anbari, and the United  Nations legal counsel, Under Secretary General Hans Corell of Sweden, leaves a few procedures still to be worked out, including how foods, medicines and other  goods will be distributed. **********During the last two weeks, prodded by objections from the United States and Britain, negotiators turned down an Iraqi request for greater authority over how supplies get to Kurds in the north of Iraq. Today's deal provides for United Nations agencies to deliver the aid. **********Iraq also lost a bid to choose the bank to be used for an escrow account to be handled by the United Nations. The bank will now be chosen by officials here, who will control the account so that Iraq cannot divert money or obtain credit for other purposes beyond humanitarian relief. **********The agreement also promises that United Nations inspectors will have freedom  to visit any site in Iraq to see if the goods imported are reaching the most needy. **********"The United States intends to hold Iraq's feet to the fire to assure that this agreement is not violated," an American diplomat said today. Although some  countries, notably Russia and France, had argued for some relaxation of sanctions more than a year ago, Iraq lost most of its support after disclosures  last summer about the extent to which the Iraqis had been lying about their nuclear, biological and chemical weapons programs. **********But there was always a sense that something had to be done to relieve the sufferings of Iraqis, said Emilio J. Cardenas, the Argentine envoy who helped draft the United Nations resolution on selling oil for humanitarian needs. "The  general feeling by last year was that this was pretty much overdue," he said. "The reports we were operating with indicated that there was a lot of suffering  in Baghdad and a number of other Iraqi cities. There was a prevailing mood all last year and this year that something had to be done." **********Under the sanctions resolutions enacted following the Persian Gulf war, Iraq  has been permitted to import medicines, food and other necessities. But increasing shortages of hard currency have made that very difficult. American officials say that what money is available has not gone to repairing or restocking hospitals or other urgently needed civilian projects. **********Some Iraqi oil has been smuggled out of the country in recent years. President Clinton recently reported to Congressional committees watching sanctions that some small shipments of oil had been intercepted. A senior United States official said today that the plan accepted by Iraq this morning would make it easier to keep sanctions in place indefinitely, a goal shared by Britain. Britain and the United States have at times been isolated on the Security Council, where other members say that the aim of Washington and London is not to punish the Iraqi leader but to topple him. **********"This agreement is the best way to lock in a coalition in favor of maintaining sanctions against those who are squishy on Iraq," the senior American official said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/15/your-.snippet: SKEPTICS would call it fashion. Cynics would see it as envy. Whatever the reason for its popularity may be, the world in generalwith the exception of a few insignificant, notionally Communist autocracies — has bought the idea of market capitalism
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/15/your-.main_headline: FIRST COLUMN : Accepting Lessons of Capitalism
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/15/your-.print_headline: FIRST COLUMN : Accepting Lessons of Capitalism
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/15/your-.body_text: **********SKEPTICS would call it fashion. Cynics would see it as envy. Whatever the reason for its popularity may be, the world in generalwith the exception of a few insignificant, notionally Communist autocracies — has bought the idea of market capitalism in a big way. **********But buying something is very different from understanding it and getting the best out of it, as many parents who have given their offspring computers would agree. As we near the end of the millennium the worldwide dominance of capitalism is clear. Its suitability for all the countries that have adopted it is less certain. **********Take Russia, under the international microscope ahead of Sunday's elections. Observers cite two problems that impede the healthy rooting of capitalism. **********The first is the notion that an agreed price and a handshake constitute a firm deal. Major Western corporations have faced tremendous difficulties in negotiating with Russian businessesThe thinking goes that a deal that is fair when made is voidable if economic or other conditions change to make it hard — or unfair — on one of the parties. The message that certainty of bargain is fundamental to the business ethic does not quite seem to have gotten through. **********The second problem is a straight hangover from the old regimes of Eastern and Central Europe. Under communism, people were taught that all profit was bad. Now the opposite is understood to be true. From there it has been a short step to the kind of gangster capitalism that is part of everyday life in so many formerly Communist countries. **********From a long-term perspective, an investment in emerging Europe should be in most investors' portfolios. But they should be aware that the much talked-of structural problems apply not just to industry and the legal system, but to the structure of people's thinking too.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/01/world.main_headline: THE ISRAELI VOTE: IN THE WEST BANK;Settlers Rejoice, Arabs Are Uneasy
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/01/world.print_headline: THE ISRAELI VOTE: IN THE WEST BANK;Settlers Rejoice, Arabs Are Uneasy
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/01/world.body_text: **********Beaming through his thick beard, Yossi Leibowitz sat in his kitchen here today in the heart of a Jewish settler enclave as the words he had longed to hear came over the radio. **********"The decision is clear," the announcer said. "Benjamin Netanyahu is the next  Prime Minister of the State of Israel." **********Mr. Leibowitz was ecstatic. **********"The people of Israel have a future," he said with a grin. "We're going to be a free people, and we'll be able to breathe here again like human beings. It's absolutely clear to us that the army will not pull out of Hebron. It was all God's plan." **********Down the street and across Israeli Army barriers, Nidal Abu Hadi sat in his father's grocery store and heard the news on his radio. "If the Israelis won't withdraw, we'll go back here to the intifada," he warned, using the Arabic name  for the Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation. **********A tinderbox town in which about 450 heavily protected Jewish settlers are wedged in among about 120,000 Arabs, Hebron is the last West Bank city still under Israeli control. It is likely to become an early test case of Mr. Netanyahu's readiness to honor commitments made under the self-rule accords signed by Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization. **********The agreements say Israeli soldiers should withdraw from most of Hebron, remaining to guard the Jewish enclaves and the Tomb of the Patriarchs, a shrine  holy to both Jews and Muslims where a settler massacred 29 Arabs at prayer in February 1994. **********But the pullout, originally scheduled for March, was delayed by Prime Minister Shimon Peres after four Palestinian suicide bombers killed 59 people in Israel in attacks in February and March. Security concerns and fears of a damaging confrontation with settlers on the eve of elections led Mr. Peres to postpone the pullout again until after the May 29 vote. **********Now, the next move in Hebron is up to Mr. Netanyahu. He was vague about his plans during the election campaign, suggesting at one point that he preferred postponing the withdrawal until talks on a final peace settlement. But he was careful to dissociate himself today from statements by members of his Likud party ruling out any pullback. **********Ariel Sharon, a Likud leader expected to join Mr. Netanyahu's Cabinet, said in a radio interview that the agreements on Hebron would be reviewed and that there would be no withdrawal. Mr. Peres, meanwhile, decided after a meeting with his security chiefs not to go ahead with the pullout in his remaining weeks in office. Mayor Mustafa Natsheh of Hebron had urged Mr. Peres to order the troops  out before stepping down. **********In the Jewish enclaves of Hebron today, there was a collective sigh of relief at Mr. Netanyahu's victory, and hopes for renewed Government financing for building and expansion. The departing Labor Government had effectively frozen development of the Jewish neighborhoods in Hebron when it cut state financing for settlements throughout the West Bank soon after it took office. **********"The next Government will give first priority to the needs of the people of Israel, not the people of Ishmael," Mr. Leibowitz said, using a reference to Arabs common among the settlers. **********Miriam Levinger, who with her husband, Rabbi Moshe Levinger, founded the settlement in Hebron in 1968, was in high spirits today. **********"This is a victory of the Jewish people who did not abandon their roots and remained faithful to their heritage," she said of the election results. "The Messiah hasn't arrived yet, but I felt that the Jewish people have made a 180-degree turn. This is the beginning of a new era." **********Shopping in Hebron's vegetable market not far from Mrs. Levinger's home, Ahmad Abu Turki had a gloomier vision of the future. He said he was worried that there would be violence if the Israeli soldiers did not withdraw. "People will despair, there will be more trouble and the situation will deteriorate," he said. **********"If President Clinton wants the peace process to continue, he has to press the Likud to redeploy the army in Hebron. We had hoped Mr. Peres would do it after the election, but when we heard the results, we lost hope. This is a retreat from peace, and the Likud will be harder on us." **********Other people in Hebron also pinned their hopes on American intervention, arguing that neither Likud nor Labor could stand in the way of the United States. **********"The peace accords are not only a matter between the Likud and Yasir Arafat," said Adnan Abu Halaf, a taxi driver. "They were signed before other nations, and Israel cannot stand up to the whole world. The train is moving. Whoever tries to stop it will be run over."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/13/world.snippet: World Health Organization says South Africa has worst known tuberculosis problem in world with estimated 350 cases per 100,000 people and rising incidence of multi-drug-resistant tuberculosis; doctors and WHO officials say country has health emerg...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/13/world.main_headline: South Africa Slow to Battle Spread of Tuberculosis
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/13/world.print_headline: South Africa Slow to Battle Spread of Tuberculosis
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/13/world.body_text: **********Collin Rass, a 27-year-old house painter, has tuberculosis that is resistant to drugs. If he were in a New York City hospital he would be isolated, breathing filtered air under ultraviolet lights. **********But here he shares a room in Reitfontein Hospital with 63 other men -- half of whom do not have his especially dangerous and nearly incurable form of the disease. And every night, despite the nurses' efforts, the patients shut all of the windows and turn up the heat. The coughing starts. The tin-roofed ward becomes an incubator for TB bacteria. **********Benedict Philomen, 37, in the bed two feet away, says he has ''regular tuberculosis,'' and he worries every night. ''There are worse patients in here than me,'' he said. ''Who says I won't grab their germs?'' **********The Government, he said, is dragging its feet on tuberculosis. ''There's no doctor in this whole hospital at night,'' he complained. ''There's not enough nurses capable about TB. If I gave you some water in my glass right now, no one will say, 'Stop, you're spreading the disease.' '' **********Just three months ago, the World Health Organization announced that South Africa had the worst known tuberculosis problem in the world. It has the highest documented infection rate -- about 350 cases per 100,000 people -- and a rising incidence of multi-drug-resistant tuberculosis, which kills 54 percent of those here who develop it. **********Mr. Philomen is not alone in his frustration over South Africa's response to the problem. Everyone from the doctors at Reitfontein up to the World Health Organization in Geneva thinks that the country -- in the midst of a wrenching transition to a non-racial democracy -- has a health emergency on its hands and is nearly paralyzed in the face of it. **********Government officials say they are tackling the problem. But experts say movement has been slow, and they fear that the consequences of the political transition -- health administrators new to their jobs, tight budgets and a calculated shift of power from Pretoria to the provinces -- are letting the disease proceed unchecked. **********A problem that existed under the former white-minority Government has grown steadily worse, in part because of a rise in drug use and the spread of H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. The incidence of drug use and H.I.V. infection, which both depress the immune system and can increase vulnerability to tuberculosis, has risen as South Africa has renewed international contacts after the lifting of the sanctions imposed on the apartheid Government. **********''My big fear is that we're building up to an epidemic of virtually untreatable TB,'' said Dr. Theodore Collins, 72, a consultant to the South African National Tuberculosis Association who has spent 42 years fighting the disease. ''Right now, we probably have the worst TB control program in the world.'' **********Publicly, health officials have committed themselves to training hundreds of nurses to adopt the latest treatment method, set up a national case register and build 200 mini-laboratories to speed diagnoses. **********But experts say the plan is meeting resistance because provincial health officials are moving lethargically, the big private agency that treats TB victims is paid only for hospitalizing patients and the national health department is enmeshed in a scandal about its financing of an anti-AIDS musical, ''Sarafina 2,'' that is consuming officials' time. **********Officials of the World Health Organization, a United Nations agency, think President Nelson Mandela should declare a national health emergency to draw attention to the problem, and should talk about his own bout with tuberculosis when he was in prison. **********Other prominent South Africans  have had the disease, which in this country strikes hardest at the poor in rural as well as urban areas. **********Rates are high among miners and those who live in crowded urban slums, but the highest incidence is among the people of mixed race in the townships north of Cape Town. **********No one is sure why, but mixed-race people there, known as ''Cape coloreds,'' have high rates of drug abuse and of alcoholism -- the Cape vineyards used to pay workers in cheap wine -- both of which lower resistance to the disease and make patients forgetful about taking their daily pills. **********No one is quite sure why TB is so common, but there are many theories. Families packed 10 to a room, commuters packed 15 to a minibus and miners packed 60 to an elevator -- all features of South African life -- help spread the disease. Fear of being dismissed from jobs and a belief among rural Africans that the disease is spread by witchcraft keep sufferers away from treatment. **********The latest treatment, used everywhere from New York to Tanzania, is called directly observed therapy, short-course. Patients take their medicine under the eyes of a guardian every day for six months and are given regular sputum tests to see if the pills are working. **********The guardian may be a nurse or family member, but far from clinics it is sometimes a minister, a shopkeeper or even a sangoma -- an herbal healer. **********Thus monitored, a patient can usually be cured with about $12 worth of drugs a month, said Robert J. Davidow, chief pharmacist at Reitfontein. But someone who stops taking the pills after a few weeks, when the coughing and night sweats fade, will probably be back a year later with a drug-resistant strain of the bacteria that has a 50 percent chance of killing him or her and will cost about $60 a day to treat. **********The South African health system, never good at serving poor black patients and long isolated by apartheid, now spends about 20 percent of its tuberculosis budget on hospitalizing the 2 percent of patients with drug-resistant TB. Very few clinics have the resources or inclination to follow up patients who stop taking their medicine. **********South Africa realized how bad the problem was in June, when the World Health Organization completed its study. ''There was a real sense of urgency then,'' said Dr. Jacob Kumaresan, a specialist with the agency. But it has faded. **********Two administrators who run what are often cited as model tuberculosis control programs, Lyndon J. Barends in Cape Town and Dr. Elsa Balt in Mpumalanga Province, expressed frustration with the lack of urgency. **********Treatment succeeds, Dr. Balt said, only if there is a tuberculosis control officer in every province, dozens of districts and hundreds of clinics, each reporting upward so that every case in the country can be tracked. **********As of today, there is one tuberculosis control officer in Pretoria and four in the country's nine provinces. **********The TB chief in Pretoria, Dr. Harry Hausler, a Canadian newly hired from the World Health Organization, disagrees that progress is slow. But when he is pressed it becomes clear that most of the progress consists of promises made in meetings. **********Also, each clinic must have enough workers to hunt down missing patients. **********One obstacle is the health department's contract with the National Tuberculosis Association, a private charity that runs 22 hospitals. The association is reimbursed only for patients in beds, a disincentive for switching to outpatient therapy. **********Some of the association's 4,000 volunteers do outpatient work, said Jacqui van Rensburg, a spokeswoman. But many are retired health workers and set in their ways. One chapter, for example, refuses to stop using chest X-rays, which are expensive and inaccurate. On top of that, she said, the association's nurses distrust the volunteers and resist giving them pills to hand out. **********Dr. Hausler's boss, the director general of health, Dr. Olive Shishana, said she would end that inertia. The department is in upheaval, she said, as it tries to change its focus to providing primary care to poor black people, and simultaneously to lose hundreds of staff members through budget cutting. **********She expressed surprise that the World Health Organization and local TB experts were so unhappy, and she promised to visit places like Reitfontein soon. Shortly after she made that promise, the pharmacy budget at Reitfontein was increased. She also said she would find enough money to build 200 laboratories, rewrite the contract with the tuberculosis association and maybe even call President Mandela to ask him to talk about his TB. **********''The commitment from us is there,'' she said. ''I'll work on it personally.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/11/world.snippet: Turkey declines to attend dinner with European Union heads of state in Ireland because it has not been offered fuller role in summit; Government of Prime Min Necmettin Erbakan complains that European Union seems not to recognize Turkey's strategic...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/11/world.main_headline: Empty Seat Signals Turkey's Sensitivity Over Role in Europe
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/11/world.print_headline: Empty Seat Signals Turkey's Sensitivity Over Role in Europe
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/11/world.body_text: **********Although many European countries are knocking loudly on the door of the European Union, seeking admission to a club that they believe will bring them prosperity and political stability, one prominent guest who was invited to dinner at the European Union summit meeting in Ireland  this weekend has declined. **********The Turkish Prime Minister, Necmettin Erbakan, said he would not attend a dinner with European Union  heads of state and government because Turkey, which is not a member of the union, had not been offered a fuller role at the summit meeting. **********''We do not see this as a correct attitude,'' Mr. Erbakan told Turkish reporters. ''Turkey is a powerful country at the center of the world.  The European countries have to review their policies on world affairs and on Islam. That is why we are warning them.'' **********Mr. Erbakan complained that the European Union does not recognize Turkey's strategic importance and stabilizing role in a turbulent region, and focuses instead ''only on human rights and the Kurdish issue.'' **********''The mechanism is working against us,'' he asserted. ''Things done to no other country are done to us. Obstacles are created for us.'' **********Turkey turned down a chance to join the European Union in 1977, when it was known as the European Community, but 10 years later reversed its position and filed an application for membership. It has faced resistance based in part on its economic underdevelopment and its human rights record. **********Successive Turkish leaders have  asserted that the true reasons for the European Union's reluctance include pressure from Greece, Turkey's historic rival, which accepted the 1977 offer of membership made to both nations, and fear of admitting an Islamic nation. **********Mr. Erbakan announced that instead of accepting the European Union's invitation for dinner this weekend, he will send Foreign Minister Tansu Ciller to bring his message. Mrs. Ciller is perceived as pro-European, but she has complained that the European Union is discriminating against Turkey by considering other applicants for membership more favorably. **********''I support Prime Minister Erbakan's view on this,'' she said this week. ''We are very disappointed with the E.U.'s attitude toward Turkey. Trying to exclude our country, which has been part of Europe for years, is unacceptable.'' **********While Mrs. Ciller's irritation is evidently based on a legitimate desire to bring Turkey into the European Union, Mr. Erbakan may have another motive. He and other leaders of the pro-Islamic Welfare party have for years criticized the European Union and asserted that Turkey should seek to strengthen its ties with other Muslim countries rather than concentrate on moving closer to Europe. **********By refusing to accept what he says is a second-class invitation to this weekend's summit meeting, Mr. Erbakan is portraying himself as a defender of the Turkey's dignity. He may also be chipping away at the support most Turks feel for closer ties to Europe. **********''He is mining a vein of nationalist feeling that is strong here, even among people who want Turkey to join the E.U.,'' said a foreign diplomat in Ankara. ''A large majority of Turks support what he did. They see it as a matter of national pride.'' **********In his five and a half months in power, Mr. Erbakan has not sought to change Turkish policy radically, either in foreign or domestic affairs.  But when he finds opportunities, as in the European Union invitation, he has made clear that he does not agree with a reflexive embrace of secular and pro-Western policies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/26/busin.body_text: **********Asserting that the boundaries of free speech in the 21st century are at stake, more than 20 corporate and trade organizations have initiated a major legal challenge to the new Communications Decency Act. **********Their civil suit, organized by the American Library Association, America Online and the Center for Democracy and Technology, is expected to be filed today in United States District Court in Philadelphia. There, it will be consolidated with an earlier suit against the law filed by the American Civil Liberties Union and a dozen other civil rights groups. **********The law, part of the Telecommunications Act of 1996, makes it a felony to knowingly transmit indecent or patently offensive sexual material over communications networks where children may see it. It was passed overwhelmingly  by Congress and signed by President Clinton. **********United States District Judge Ronald L. Buckwalter, one of three Federal judges who will hear arguments in the consolidated lawsuits beginning March 21,  has already ruled that the provision in the new law barring indecent material was unconstitutionally vague. **********He declined to strike down other parts of the law, which imposed more restrictive standards of speech on the Internet and other computer-based communications networks than those for books, newspapers or other printed material. The Government is expected to argue that speech on the Internet and on-line information services should be regulated just as the content of radio and television broadcasts is regulated. **********The Justice Department, which is the respondent in both suits, has agreed not to investigate or prosecute anyone for suspected violation of the law until the  three-judge panel issues its ruling, some time after Government lawyers present  their case on April 11 and 12. **********The new plaintiffs include the four largest consumer on-line information networks -- America Online; Compuserve, a unit of H & R Block; Prodigy, jointly  owned by I.B.M. and Sears, Roebuck, and MSN, the Microsoft network. Netcom On-Line Communications Services, one of the country's largest Internet access providers, and the Microsoft Corporation are also plaintiffs. **********Others joining the suit include the American Booksellers Association, the American Society of Newspaper Editors, the Association of American Publishers, the Recording Industry Association of America, the Interactive Services Association, the Society of Professional Journalists and the Citizens' Internet  Empowerment Coalition, a diverse group whose members include Americans for Tax Reform and People for the American Way. **********"The Internet is the communications medium for the 21st century, and the most important thing that has happened to communications since the printing press," said Judith F. Krug, director of the American Library Association's Office for Intellectual Freedom. "Our main argument is that you cannot limit ideas and information to the lowest common denominator, which is what this law does. It is unconstitutional to force adults to limit the information they can see to a level suitable for children." **********The library association represents more than 80,000 public libraries, which are increasingly making books and other information available on line. More than a third of the libraries provide citizen access to computers connected to the Internet. **********Supporters of the law contend that the Government has an obligation to protect children from pornography and objectionable forms of information that can be obtained over the Internet, a global network that links millions of computers and tens of millions of people, most of them outside the United States. **********Jerry Berman, executive director of the Center for Democracy and Technology,  said the focus of the new lawsuit would be to explain the technologies that made the Internet fundamentally different from broadcasting and more like publishing. **********"The thrust is to focus the court's attention on what policies should be applied to new media," Mr. Berman said. "Congress passed this law without ever once holding a hearing. If the judges don't understand the Internet, they may pick the wrong paradigm, and this case of first impression will decide the limits of free speech for the 21st century."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/01/busin.body_text: **********The Cigna Corporation said first-quarter operating earnings rose 50 percent,  exceeding expectations, because of improved profit in its property and casualty  division. **********The Philadelphia-based insurer said profit, excluding gains from investment sales, rose to $219 million, or $2.85 a share, from $146 million, or $2.02, in the comparable quarter a year earlier. **********The results surpassed Wall Street estimates of $2.60 a share, based on a survey of 11 analysts by Zacks Investment Research. **********But first-quarter net income fell to $238 million, or $3.10 a share, from $290 million, or $4 a share. Revenue in the first quarter fell to $4.6 billion from $4.8 billion. **********The earnings were released after the close of trading. Shares of Cigna rose $4.50, to $113.375. **********"Cigna is benefiting from taking steps to turn around their property and casualty unit," Ira Zuckerman, an analyst for Nutmeg Securities Ltd., said. **********In February, the insurer received regulatory approval to split its United States property and casualty business into two units. One segment kept the most  profitable policies, while the other plans to wind down coverage that produces Cigna's largest claims. **********Earnings from the property and casualty unit rebounded to $42 million from a  loss of $19 million, largely because of fewer costs from claims from businesses  forced to clean up tainted soil and asbestos. The company took a $686 million charge in the third quarter to pay for environmental cleanups.   (Bloomberg Business News)
