https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/03/busin.body_text: **********Monaco is encircled by France, but its phone system is stepping out. On June 21, the principality will get its own country code, 377, and it has plans to get into the international telecommunications business in a way that belies its status as the smallest sovereign state in Europe at about 1.9 square kilometers (465 acres) of real estate. **********Although it is now part of France Telecom's network, Monaco has its own phone company, the Office Monégasque des Téléphones, which is a state agency. It therefore is part of the European phone cartel, whose members have access to international satellite and cable links at prices far below what consumers pay for calls. **********As a result of deregulation, the cartel's days are numbered, the office's director, Antoine Veran, said, but while it remains, Monaco can use it to establish a beachhead in the international communications industry. It has teamed up with Global TeleSystems Group Inc., a privately held American company in which the peripatetic investor George Soros owns a stake, to form GTS Monaco Access. The venture plans to operate as a "carrier's carrier," offering services targeted at new phone companies, Internet providers and poor countries with limited international access. **********These kinds of services are typically purchased from the state or recently privatized carriers in various countries, but that means that new phone companies are essentially buying from their established competitors. GTS Monaco, Mr. Veran said, would be nonaligned. **********Global TeleSystems, however, already operates telecom service companies in Russia, Hungary, the Czech Republic, China and India, and it is a partner in Hermes Europe Railtel, a venture with 11 railroads that is building a fiber-optic network along their rights of way. **********A British report said GTS Monaco would price its services at about 20 percent below current market rates, but Mr. Veran said the charges had not yet been decided.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/13/world.snippet: Turkish Prime Min Necmettin Erbakan signs $23-billion, 23-year agreement to purchase natural gas from Iran, raising awkward possibility of American sanctions against NATO ally; White House expresses disappointment; deal could provoke variety of US...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/13/world.main_headline: Turkey-Iran Gas Deal: A Test of U.S. Law on Terror?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/13/world.print_headline: Turkey-Iran Gas Deal: A Test of U.S. Law on Terror?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/13/world.body_text: **********Turkey's new Prime Minister signed a $23-billion, 23-year agreement today to purchase natural gas from Iran, raising the awkward possibility of the United States' invoking sanctions against a NATO ally. **********''We're disappointed that Turkey is pushing toward a broader and more active relationship with Iran,'' a White House official said today. ''Iran's use of terror to try to erode support for the Mideast peace process is well known and documented. And we find it perplexing that Turkey, which has itself been a victim of terror, has taken these steps.'' **********The deal could provoke a variety of American sanctions against the state-owned Turkish oil and gas company under the Iran-Libya Sanctions Act, which gives the President the power to penalize foreign companies that invest $40 million or more a year in the oil and natural-gas sectors of either country. President Clinton signed the measure last week, over the objections of European allies. **********Contracts already in effect were exempted, but possible sanctions for the new deal could include denial of loans from the Export-Import Bank,  denial of licenses for exports to the United States, a prohibition on loans or credits from American financial institutions and a ban on imports from the United States. **********American officials were reluctant to say today whether the agreement, the text of which they have not seen, violates the new American law, for which operating regulations have not yet been written. They noted that pipelines needed to be built and that gas would not flow until at least 1999, and they suggested that given Iran's economic problems, those grand plans may prove overly optimistic. **********Retaliation would create sharp new strains between Washington and a vital NATO ally that bridges Europe and Central Asia, the Balkans and the Middle East. Washington is already alarmed over the installation last month of Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan, head of the pro-Islamic Welfare Party, who has called for closer Turkish ties to Iran, Iraq and Syria, and a reorientation of Turkey away from the West. **********''Turkey remains a very important NATO ally in an extremely tough neighborhood, and it's on that basis that we've continued to consult with the Turkish Government on this issue,'' the White House official said. ''Whether or not it is a violation of U.S. law, it is certainly bad policy.'' **********With Mr. Clinton on vacation in Wyoming and Secretary of State Warren Christopher traveling, Under Secretary of State Peter Tarnoff telephoned his Turkish counterpart today to express American concerns about the gas deal, officials said. **********Turkish officials argued that the  agreement did not break American law, because it is a trade agreement to purchase gas, not an investment in Iran, and each country will be responsible for its own infrastructure. **********''The sanctions ban investments in Iran,'' a Turkish Cabinet minister, Abdullah Gul, said today in Teheran, where Mr. Erbakan signed the contract with the Iranian First Vice President, Hassan Habibi. ''We're not going to invest in Iran. This is only a trade agreement. The two countries will build their own sides of the gas pipeline.'' **********But the Iranian President, Hashemi Rafsanjani, hailed the agreement as a major triumph over American efforts to choke Iran's economy. And Mustafa Murathan, the director of the Turkish company, said Turkey might help cash-poor Iran build its part of the pipeline, from Tabriz to the border town of Teba, under a barter agreement. **********Mr. Erbakan chose to go to Iran on his first official trip abroad as Prime Minister. He was met on Saturday with full state honors and told Turkish television in an interview, before leaving for Pakistan, ''Turkey will not permit any third country to interfere in the growing trend of cooperation between Turkey and Iran.'' **********Iraq and Libya are subject to United Nations sanctions, but the American effort to isolate Iran and Cuba has been sharply criticized by the European Union and other countries, like China, as an effort to apply ''secondary boycotts'' and bring foreign companies under American law. When Arab states tried to apply such secondary boycotts against American and other companies that did business with Israel, the United States objected, but now is applying the same principle to others, European diplomats argue. **********Some nations, like Canada, have instructed their companies to ignore  a separate law, the Helms-Burton Act, that punishes companies investing in formerly American-owned properties in Cuba. **********In a public response, Glyn Davies, the State Department's deputy spokesman, said, ''Our general reaction is that we believe that this deal's conclusion sends the wrong message to Iran.'' But the details of the contract will have to be studied before the United States can decide if sanctions should be applied, he said. **********Top Turkish officials have told Washington that ''this isn't an investment but a purchase of gas,'' Mr. Davies said, ''and we'll see.'' **********But he emphasized the strong relationship between the United States and Turkey and said, ''We certainly don't expect that this will cause a major rift in our relationship.'' **********Turkey plays a vital role in various American policies to broaden the ''circle of peace'' in the Middle East, to train and equip the Muslim-led Bosnian Army, to help the newly independent Muslim states of the Caucasus and Central Asia and to serve as a restraining buffer to Iran, Iraq and Syria. **********Mr. Erbakan, while constrained by his coalition partner, the conservative former Prime Minister Tansu Ciller, could undermine those policies if he tries to reorient Turkey in a serious fashion, as opposed to making merely symbolic gestures to his Islamist constituency, American officials say. It could also lead to a coup by the Turkish military, an embarrassing step away from democracy in a NATO that is looking to expand. **********New strains between Turkey and Greece, first over tiny islands in the Aegean and now over last weekend's rioting on Cyprus between Greek and Turkish Cypriots, could be worsened by the nationalist Mr. Erbakan and lead to a new cycle of reaction and overreaction in Athens, the officials say. **********So they are being careful to stress the longstanding ties between Turkey and the United States, while also indicating sharp displeasure at Turkey's new turn. **********Under the agreement signed today, Iran will start supplying Turkey with 105 billion cubic feet of natural gas a year beginning in 1999, rising to 350 billion cubic feet in 2005. **********--------------------        Turkish Aides Visit Iraq **********BAGHDAD, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Turkish Cabinet officials visited Baghdad  today, seeking to improve connections with Iraq, another adversary of the United States, so as to complete  plans to reopen a pipeline to carry Iraqi oil through Turkey. **********Justice Minister Sevket Kazan and Education Minister Mehmet Saglam drove across the desert from Jordan for talks, scheduled to begin Tuesday, about ''everything concerning our relations with Iraq,'' Mr. Kazan said. **********The pipeline is part of an agreement struck with the United Nations Security Council to allow Iraq to sell some oil, despite sanctions against the country. **********Turkey has been seeking United States and United Nations agreement to buy 200,000 barrels of Iraqi oil a day above the $2 billion Baghdad can sell every six months under a United Nations agreement that allows it to sell the oil to buy food and medicine for its people.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/28/busin.main_headline: INVESTING IT;Company's Systems Know the Way to San Jose
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/28/busin.print_headline: INVESTING IT;Company's Systems Know the Way to San Jose
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/28/busin.body_text: **********IN centuries past, navigators used the stars and magnetized needles dangling  from strings to find their way. It's not that way anymore. **********Now, 24 satellites tended by the Defense Department circle the globe and use  radio signals and atomic clocks to pinpoint objects on earth within one centimeter. This network, the Global Positioning System, was created for military purposes, but increasingly serves civilian needs, too. Motorists whose  cars have devices that connect with the positioning system use the system to navigate streets. Surveyors use it for map-making. Pilots guide their flights with it. There are similar uses in areas from mining to agriculture to toll-taking. **********Furthermore, the biggest concern -- doubts about whether the Defense Department would allow the industry regular access to the positioning system signals -- vanished in early April, when the Clinton Administration committed the Government to free public access. On the strength of that commitment, sector analysts expect that the positioning system industry, which had revenues of $1.25 billion last year, will expand to $8.4 billion by 2000. **********How can one invest in this market? The possibilities are as simple as the Global Positioning System is complex. Only one publicly traded company focuses solely on producing the equipment: Trimble Navigation Ltd. All the other big players are either private companies, like Ashtech, or giant multinationals like Sony or Pioneer, which make only a small part of their earnings from system products. **********From many angles, Trimble looks like a good investment. It is the industry's  worldwide leader, with 20 percent of the market.  With sales in more than 60 countries, the company gets about half its revenues from overseas, where the Administration's April announcement is expected to spur large growth. Trimble also controls about 60 percent of the most profitable part of the market, surveying and mapping equipment. **********Based in Sunnyvale, Calif., Trimble is in the lead in product development as  well. It holds more positioning system technology patents than anyone, including the United States Government. During each of the last three years, the company has plowed back 13 to 15 percent of its revenues into research, making it the biggest such spender in amounts as well as percentage in the field. **********Trimble has also played the mating game well, which is important as new applications . cut across industries and as technology is integrated into products that can perform many tasks. **********Take the lucrative possibilities in aviation. Positioning system navigation allows pilots to choose their own routes. With it, they can fly around turbulence or choose a path that saves fuel. **********The technology also helps pilots avoid crashes in areas where ground-based navigation is inefficient. To gain a foothold in this market, Trimble has joined with Honeywell in an alliance that has helped it to secure new clients like American Airlines and American Trans Air. **********Or consider the car market, where technology enables drivers to punch in a destination and then follow voice directions. "I remember years ago, one of the  big questions when you bought a car was whether it had F.M. radio," said Arthur  Calavritinos, who manages John Hancock's High Yield Bond Fund and owns shares of Trimble. "Now you take it for granted. I think it will be the same for G.P.S." **********In autos, Trimble has teamed up with Germany's Philips Car Systems and Xanavi, itself an alliance between Nissan and Hitachi, to supply equipment for BMW and Nissan cars. These and other partnerships, such as with Pioneer and Delco Electronics, should help Trimble expand its 30 percent share of the car-navigation market. **********Companies in this high-tech area have much to do, though, before they can pull in profits. That means investors must assume the risk that things may not go as planned, or as quickly as anticipated. **********For the car-navigation devices to sell well in the United States, prices must fall markedly. The systems, currently on offer in a few General Motors models and some rental cars, cost about $2,000. "Most people believe they have to go under $1,000 and that they will start to be more popular at $700, which is where we expect the price to be in three years," said Charles Trimble, the company's chief executive. **********Another obstacle, also from the auto market, is the availability of the digitized road maps drivers will need to use the navigation. While mapping is widespread in countries like Germany and Japan, only 11 states in the United States are mapped. **********As for positioning system products not yet in existence, like those that could be used to track children and others, there are many unknowns and their potential remains unclear. And the satellites on which the whole system depends  are subject to the risks of outer space. If they are damaged, the disruption could be costly for the industry. **********Competition is another threat. Many of Trimble's rivals, like Sony and Toshiba in the car-navigation market, are larger and richer. In the military sector, Trimble's alliances with firms like Honeywell and Lockheed Martin will help, but the company must still work hard to compete with heavyweights like Rockwell International, Texas Instruments and Magnavox. **********Quickening competition can mean price wars. In the lucrative market for surveying equipment, Leica P.L.C. and Ashtech have aggressively cut prices. **********"In terms of quality, Trimble is still well respected," said John Calamos Jr., chief executive of Calamos Asset Management and portfolio manager of the Calamos Growth Fund. "But there is a lot of competition in the field, and the profit margins are narrowing. They just can't command the same high price for their product." **********Mr. Trimble said his company was fighting back by introducing lower-cost products and controlling expenses. Gross margins, which were on steadily down in 1995, were back up in the first quarter of this year. **********Trimble has also missed its earnings estimates for the last three quarters. The explanations do not suggest big flaws in the company as an investment. Last  fall there was a shortage of parts, and a customer's big order was delayed because of problems the customer had that were not connected with the equipment. But in any event, these earnings problems have continued. In this year's first quarter, the company had a net loss of $1.14 million, even though revenues were  up 14 percent. **********Like many technology stocks, Trimble Navigation is volatile. After it missed  the analysts' earnings estimates last fall, Trimble stock plunged to about $17 from $35 in a matter of weeks. Likewise, the stock gained about 25 percent a month ago when President Clinton announced the new positioning system policy. **********"I still believe the company is a long-term buy," said Darren von Behren, an  analyst with Comvest Partners in Dallas. But in the near term, he said he thought that Trimble's volatility might continue. "There is some choppiness you  have to be able to weather as an investor," he said. Trimble closed Friday at $23.50 on Nasdaq. **********In a sense, that is good news. If an investor who likes the company is watchful, the price dips can become buying opportunities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/24/world.main_headline: Little Buffalo Journal;In a Poisoned Forest, A Tribe Canada Forgot
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/24/world.print_headline: Little Buffalo Journal;In a Poisoned Forest, A Tribe Canada Forgot
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/24/world.body_text: **********He shot and killed a fat bull moose last spring, his first moose in more than two years. Its antlers crown the tawny roof of the log cabin that Joel Laboucan  built in happier days, before hundreds of oil jacks, a sour gas processing plant with the smell of rotten eggs and clear-cut logging scarred the land and scared off the wildlife. **********Mr. Laboucan, 62, is a hunter and trapper who has lived all his adult life in this small, isolated Lubicon Cree community 350 miles north of Edmonton. **********After years of industrial exploitation and what Lubicon leaders consider a history of broken federal and provincial promises, this community now seems more part of the third world than a rich province in one of the world's richest countries. **********"Nobody likes to live this way," Mr. Laboucan said, angrily flicking ashes from his cigarette. "The struggle has been for so long. Sometimes you just want  to give up. If we could only go back to the way we were." **********Roads are dirt with potholes that could swallow a bear. Two and three families live together in ramshackle housing that would be condemned elsewhere in Canada. No one has running water. The outhouse stands 100 feet from Mr. Laboucan's kitchen.  Mr. Laboucan's wife, Alma, and daughter, Rema, do laundry in a bathtub. Some families have 40-year-old washing machines, but everyone has  to cart water from a pump a mile away. In the winter, drinking water is melted snow. In the summer, it comes from the nearest clean-water lake, Lake Haig, an hour's drive north. **********Such living conditions have taken their toll. "There's a lot of alcohol-related domestic violence," said Jyoti Vasudev, the community health nurse. "Usually the police don't get involved. It's soft violence: punch, kick and that sort of thing. But soft violence is detrimental to the children, to the families." **********Suicide attempts among the young are almost a common occurrence, as in other  communities of indigenous people. Mr. Vasudev counted a dozen here in the last four years. Three succeeded. **********Yet the children are eager students in the Little Buffalo public school, where 110 students are enrolled. **********"I think they're happy to come to an environment that is cheerful, warm and safe," said a teacher, Joyce Willows, who is not Indian and has just completed her first year at the school. **********Another non-Indian teacher, Leanne Rein, added, "There are times when it'll be 45 below, as it was this winter, and you'll have the kids try to walk to school because it's so cold the school bus won't start, and still they want to come." **********The Lubicons are a symbol of Canada's struggle to settle claims of indigenous people -- and the fearsome difficulties and human tragedies that are rising from that struggle. **********Indigenous people make up 3 percent of the population but claim more than a third of the land area. Polls show attitudes of Canadians hardening toward them. One recent survey by a polling concern called Insight Canada found that more than 40 percent of Canadians believe that indigenous people have only themselves to blame for their troubles. **********The plight of the people at Little Buffalo has at times embarrassed the Canadian Government, which is proud of its international reputation. **********In 1984 the World Council of Churches warned of "genocidal consequences" as a result of the oil and timber development in the Lubicon tribal lands -- hundreds of thousands of acres around Lubicon Lake in northern Alberta. To date some $8 billion of resources have been extracted, while the Indians themselves live in poverty. **********With money from the World Council of Churches, the small and diminishing tribe, now numbering probably little more than 300, appealed to the United Nations Human Rights Committee. In a judgment in 1990, that committee cited Canada for breaking international covenants on civil and political rights. **********Although Ottawa had no comment on the ruling and ostensibly paid little attention to it, the new Liberal Government of Jean Chretien is actively trying  for a settlement. **********Harold Millican, an Alberta construction company executive appointed by Indian Affairs Minister Ron Irwin as principal negotiator with the Lubicons, acknowledges that the story of the tribe is "a blight on Canadian society." **********"There's no question the Government of Canada wants this thing settled as soon as possible," he said in an interview. **********The story goes back to the end of the last century, when the Lubicons were overlooked by federal treaty commissioners because they were not living along one of the major waterways. So the Government never signed a land treaty with them, as it did with hundreds of other tribes. **********In 1939 Lubicons were promised reserve land. But after 57 years of bureaucratic deception and delays, the promise has yet to be kept. **********To try to prevent economic development of their tribal lands until their claim had been settled, the Lubicons turned to the justice system.  They were turned down by provincial and appeals courts. The Supreme Court of Canada refused to hear the case. **********The Lubicons are fighting for a land rights settlement that would give them a reserve area of about 95 square miles around Lubicon Lake, a few miles from the  present community at Little Buffalo, but also a few miles and downwind of a Unocal sour gas plant that removes lethal hydrogen sulfide from natural gas. **********The Lubicons have been offered housing, water, sewage and other basic services, but are seeking additional money to make the community economically viable -- for instance, help in learning trades and money for agricultural and small-business start-ups. **********One of the big issues is the number of Lubicons left. One splinter group, known as the Woodland Cree, accepted the Government terms and settled their claim in 1991. They live in a neighboring community a few miles toward Peace River. **********The Lubicon chief, Bernard Ominayak, declines to release the rolls. Published reports have suggested there could be even fewer than 300, which could reduce the amount of any settlement. **********"It seems to be the hope and objective of both the provincial and federal government that there be no Lubicon people left," Mr. Ominayak said. "We've looked up the definition of genocide in the dictionary, and at this point I would say that's what we're going through."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/22/busin.main_headline: Taking In the Sites;But What About Ring Around the Collar?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/22/busin.print_headline: Taking In the Sites;But What About Ring Around the Collar?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/22/busin.body_text: **********Your house is haunted. The boisterous toasts of parties past, the carefree tracings of children long gone, even the faithful dogs that once slept by the fire have all left their ghosts behind. And in these weeks between the holidays  and spring cleaning, you stare at the ghosts and wonder: "Will seltzer take that out?" **********Stains not only mar carpets and tablecloths, but they also haunt their victims by tugging at dimmed memories. You know there was some hint from Heloise that involved some improbable cleaning combination, but you can't remember whether the key ingredient was baking soda or hair spray. **********Fortunately, the collected stain-removing wisdom of day-to-day washing experience and the efforts of advanced chemical research is available on the Internet. **********To some, stains are not a blight, they are a marketing opportunity. Products  that are often the target of stains, like carpets, offer remedies, but are quick to point out replacement options. Du Pont Antron's home page, for example, has stain removal tips, but also features the latest styles and the mills that make  them. And Shihadeh, an Oriental rug dealer in Ardmore, Pa., provides a stain-removal table by perpetrator and by carpet fiber (mustard on acrylic; beer on wool). They will also teach you the difference between a Tabriz and a Tafrish rug and how you can buy one of each from them. **********As the halls of higher education are hotbeds of stain activities, it makes sense that both Mississippi State University and the University of Illinois have stain-removal sites. These sites are good for general household questions, and take a studied approach to stains. The Mississippi site, for example, differentiates between black coffee (flush with cool water, rub stain with detergent then launder with color-safe bleach) and coffee with cream (sponge stain with dry-cleaning solvent, let air dry, then rub in detergent and wash with color-safe bleach in the hottest water appropriate for the type of fabric). **********The fabric lovers on the World Wide Quilting page provide happy chat with their cleaning guides.  While at this site, don't miss the "winner" of the Worst Quilt in the World contest. **********Even the stainers do penance through cleanup suggestions. Crayola Inc. offers procedures for removing itself from all types of surfaces. And Crayola fans can  read more on this year's celebration of their 100 billionth Crayola crayon. **********This profusion of stain-removal sites means that you can get different advice for the same stain. **********To put a series of remedies to the test (and to be forearmed against some art-loving nieces), red Crayola-brand crayon was generously scribbled on swatches of old sheet. Different methods of stain removal were applied: **********Crayola method: Place the stained surface on a pad of paper towels, spray with WD-40 lubricant (!), let stand a few minutes. Turn fabric over and spray the other side. Apply liquid detergent and work into the stained area with paper towel, replacing the towels as they pick up the stain. Wash fabric in hot water  with laundry detergent and powdered bleach for 12 minutes, or the heavy soiled cycle; rinse in warm water. **********Mississippi State University method: Rub dampened stain with bar soap. Launder with hottest water safe for that fabric. **********Both methods worked. The bar soap wins the "easiest" division, but the WD-40  will look much more impressive at the laundromat.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/16/world.main_headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Kurd in Washington Said to Be Rebel Leader
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/16/world.print_headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Kurd in Washington Said to Be Rebel Leader
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/16/world.body_text: **********The head of the Kurdish Information Office has been arrested for passport fraud, and American authorities said they believe he is a leader of the rebel Kurdistan Workers' Party, which the State Department lists as a terrorist group. **********The arrested man, Kani Xulam, was being held pending a hearing in Federal court on Wednesday. He was arrested on Friday after a two-month investigation by the State Department found he had obtained a passport by claiming the identity of a child killed in a car crash more than 30 years ago. **********Officials said Mr. Xulam was not an American citizen and may have entered the United States after living in Canada as a student. They said the case was brought to their attention by the Government of Turkey, where Mr. Xulam could eventually be deported for prosecution. **********State Department investigators said Mr. Xulam originally obtained a passport  under the name Steven Barry Citron, the name of an 18-month-old baby killed in a car crash in Louisiana in 1963.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/27/world.main_headline: London Journal;England's Toffs and Yobs: Sports Draws the Line
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/27/world.print_headline: London Journal;England's Toffs and Yobs: Sports Draws the Line
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/27/world.body_text: **********It has come down to this, the yobs against the toffs. **********The toffs (derivation obscure; thought to come from the tassels or tufts worn by aristocratic students) dress in white trousers and blue blazers. They consume two tons of strawberries and 11,000 pints of fresh cream daily while watching a ball the size of an orange travel at speeds up to 120 miles an hour.  They applaud demurely and register surprise with a sudden intake of breath. **********The yobs (orig. East End; c. 1859; from "boy" spelled backward) wrap themselves in Union Jacks, paint their faces into red and white crosses of St. George and devote themselves to a ball the size of a large melon. When not filling the country's biggest stadiums, yobs frequent sidewalks outside pubs, clutching cans of warm lager, and late into the night their chant periodically arises, a long lugubrious sound that mixes danger and yearning like the mating wail of a pubescent carnivore: "Ing-ga-land! Ing-ga-land!" **********An explorer blundering into southern England this week to peer at the natives would find that they have divided themselves into two tribes, each in the throes of wild passions and bizarre rites. **********One tribe hangs out at Wimbledon, the other at Wembley. **********Rarely have the stars aligned themselves in such a way that the national tennis championship, the centerpiece of the upper-class socializing that goes by the grandiosely reductive name of "the Season," coincides with the European soccer championship, Euro96, which is being held in England this year. **********This evening, England was knocked out of the semifinals by Germany in a close game that ended after extra time in a 1-1 tie and was decided by penalty kick competition. Germany will play the Czech Republic for the championship on Sunday. **********The soccer and the tennis are only the brightest lights in a sports firmament that has suddenly descended upon England. In the space of two weeks, there are toff events including a major cricket tournament with India, the races at Ascot, the rowing regatta at Henley and the Queen's Cup in polo. **********It would not take our intrepid explorer long to discover the cause of the schism at the heart of English sports fanaticism. **********"Class," said Rogan Taylor, director of the soccer research unit at Liverpool University. "Class provides the intense dynamic of sports in England. That's why there's this enormous gulf. It's chalk and cheese." **********Codified soccer, which began in England in 1863, came out of Eton, Harrow and Marlborough and was at first aristocratic, Mr. Taylor noted. Then within 15 years it "got mugged" by the Lancashire working class. **********"It became the sport of all the rural people sucked into the mills and towns  of the north from the 1870's to the 1890's," Mr. Taylor said. "The football clubs provided them with a second identity." **********He paused to reflect on how the class divide sometimes escapes those caught up in it. **********"English people go abroad and they're always surprised to find football grounds in the center of town," he said. "They have swimming pools and tennis courts around them. And they say: why did it never develop like that at home? If you think people who play tennis in England would have anything to do with people who play football, you're in cloud-cuckoo-land." **********A 22-year-old man named Eddie from Manchester, whose face was painted pale white with red stripes and who did as a consequence have a chalk-like appearance, was asked why he was waving a giant Union Jack at the base of Lord Nelson's column in Trafalgar Square with such pugnacious abandon. "It's me country," he explained. **********Nearby, as some 50 compatriots sang a ditty that went "If you hate Germans, clap your hands," and a bottle flew through the air, a knot of German fans clustered around Tony Langa, a 25-year-old from Dusseldorf wearing a Monchengladbach shirt. He was negotiating politely with a bobby. **********"Officer, if we lose, we can come here?" he asked. The policeman gravely shook his head. "No, no, no," he explained. **********The soccer fever sweeping England has inspired anti-German tabloid headlines  heavy with words like "Kraut," "Fritz," and "Jerry." The nadir was reached by The Mirror, which on Monday printed an "Achtung! Surrender" cover, complete with a declaration of war written as an echo of Neville Chamberlain's speech to the nation in 1939. The Mirror editor, Piers Morgan, was forced to apologize. As an  editor of a rival tabloid explained, he had stepped over the line from jingoism  to xenophobia. **********Such sentiments are not expressed at Wimbledon, where British players did well in men's singles on the opening day, seven of them moving to the second round. The announcers maintained a nationality-neutral hushed tone, and the crowd was largely silent during the thwak, thwak, thwak of the matches as the evening shadow crept across the court. Only the upset defeat of the American seeded third, Andre Agassi, brought exclamations of emotion -- in this case, disbelief. **********It doesn't do to register reactions. And besides, many of the Season's sporting events involve more than sport, explained Skodina Kenny, a resident of  London's exclusive Belgravia, on her way to Ladies Day at Ascot. **********"I go because it's a show," she said. "I've been going for 25 years and I see people I don't see all year. It's fun to wear your flower hat. It's fun to meet  in the bar and have a Pimms and to bet on horses whether you win or not. This is the social event of the year."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/12/world.main_headline: U.S. Enlists Rich Nations in Move to End Business Bribes
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/12/world.print_headline: U.S. Enlists Rich Nations in Move to End Business Bribes
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/12/world.body_text: **********Under intense pressure from the United States, the world's richest nations today took an important step to fight corruption in international business dealings by agreeing that bribes paid to foreign officials, often listed as commissions or fees, should no longer be tax deductible. **********The United States, which is the only major nation that has laws barring its companies from paying bribes abroad, has long argued that Americans are often at a disadvantage in bidding for major contracts around the world. **********But rather than weaken its own rules, a move some American business executives wanted, Washington has enlisted its main rivals and others to join an anti-bribery campaign. **********Today's decision by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a club of industrial countries, commits its 26 members to rewrite tax rules that have effectively encouraged the bribery of foreign officials by making such payoffs tax deductible. **********"This is a sea change, a very important step in breaking the international chain of corruption," said David Aaron, the American representative at the organization. "It takes governments out of the business of subsidizing corruption by giving tax breaks for bribery. **********"It may sound ludicrous to declare a bribe as a tax deduction, but that is simply a measure of how ingrained this habit was." **********While all the O.E.C.D. countries have laws against domestic corruption, most  of these rules do not apply to what their executives do abroad. **********On the contrary, most industrialized countries allow businesses to deduct payoffs and kickbacks, commonly described as commissions or fees or promotional  costs, from their taxable income as a legitimate expense. **********Business executives and diplomats from several European countries said they believed that in countries with strong tax systems, the proposed changes should  have an effect on business practices because large payments to officials will not be deductible. **********But some said that given the stiff competition for what are often multibillion-dollar contracts in construction, armaments, telecommunications and pharmaceuticals, entrepreneurs may try to find loopholes. **********They noted that some American companies, barred from paying graft, have hired middlemen to handle such matters, and that some regularly woo prospective clients by inviting them on junkets to the United States that include gambling stops at Las Vegas or Atlantic City or visits to Disney World. **********A number of American companies do not need to disclose foreign payments if they are involved in "national security" work. **********In most cases -- but not in the United States, Britain and Canada -- payments to foreign officials have been tax deductible as long as the recipient is identified by name. Laws are most lax in Belgium, Luxembourg and Greece, which have not even required the recipient's name. **********In each country, Governments are expected to propose legislation tightening tax laws, which will be subject to parliamentary approval. **********The group gave the member countries no deadline for revising their tax codes, but it ordered a watchdog committee to monitor the changes with instructions to  report back within a year. **********The O.E.C.D. does not have the power to make its agreements legally binding;  it works through peer pressure, and its decisions amount to strong commitments by the members. **********American diplomats said they hoped the next step would be to make payoffs to  foreign officials a crime, as they are under the United States Foreign Corrupt Practises Act of 1977. **********The Council for International Business in New York, one of many American groups that has lobbied against bribery as an unfair business practice, applauded the move. **********"We are very pleased that the O.E.C.D. has gone much further and much faster  than we anticipated," said Sheila O'Neil, a council official, noting that when talks began in 1994 "there wasn't much of a consensus." **********Insiders said negotiations had been difficult, with countries with powerful ministries in charge of commerce or exports, like Germany, Japan and France, at  first arguing that they could not put obstacles in the way of exporters. But they said the issue gained momentum in recent months as big bribery scandals have come to light affecting many governments. "We think everyone has begun to see the huge social and economic and political consequences of bribery," Ms. O'Neil said. **********American diplomats who have worked on the anti-bribery issue said they felt vindicated as the 26 Governments approved today's anti-bribery move by consensus. **********"We were considered naive Americans for pushing this issue," Mr. Aaron said.  "Now many others recognize there is a serious problem." **********Since 1977 several dozen American companies have been charged with violating  the anti-bribery law, but no chief executive has been convicted. **********Today's decision is part of a broad crusade by the Clinton Administration, which has said that bribery used by America's rivals represents a real if invisible form of trade barrier. It has said bribery inhibits American exports and cost Americans jobs, all the more so in the present rush toward the globalization of business, with opportunities growing rapidly in Eastern Europe  and Asia. Large American companies, including General Electric and Boeing, have  openly complained that they have difficulty competing for contracts with European rivals who are free to use bribes. **********In March the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, calling bribery an unfair tariff, said, "Last year, from April 1994 to May 1995, the U.S. Government learned of almost 100 cases in which foreign bribes undercut U.S. firms' ability to win contracts valued at $45 billion." **********He added that the Administration's goal was "to level the playing field and make the rules fair by eliminating his pernicious practice." **********The Clinton Administration is not alone. Several West European governments have said that they are in favor of addressing the issues of bribes and extortion in future loan and aid agreements and have begun debating at the O.E.C.D. the question of how to police development aid. **********Two weeks ago the International Chamber of Commerce, based in Paris and with  members from more than 130 countries, published new rules on how to handle extortion and bribery. **********"We are definitely noticing a change in attitude," said Karen Hussmann, an official of Transparency International, a Berlin-based group that fights corruption. "Many governments and companies are becoming sensitized to the devastating impact of corruption." **********On March 29 the United States was successful in its campaign to have the Organization of American States adopt an Inter-American Convention Against Corruption. **********Next, the Clinton Administration has said, it wants to put corporate bribery  on the agenda of the ministerial meeting of the World Trade Organization in Singapore later this year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/02/busin.snippet: The United States pledged Wednesday to support the Asian Development Bank despite Washington's embarrassing failure to honor its earlier commitments to the bank's program of soft loans to poor governments in the region..But in numerous private con...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/02/busin.main_headline: U.S. Warns ADB Development Aid Will Face a 'Strain'
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/02/busin.print_headline: U.S. Warns ADB Development Aid Will Face a 'Strain'
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/02/busin.body_text: **********The United States pledged Wednesday to support the Asian Development Bank despite Washington's embarrassing failure to honor its earlier commitments to the bank's program of soft loans to poor governments in the region. **********But in numerous private conversations at the bank's 29th annual meeting, the undersecretary of the Treasury, Jeffrey Shafer, and other U.S. officials warned their counterparts that, as far as Washington is concerned at least, a new, leaner era for development banks has dawned. **********The stance by the United States, which after Japan is the bank's leading shareholder, worries countries now receiving development assistance. The comments, which were softly echoed by the officials of several other governments, have the potential to deeply divide the world's wealthiest nations as they chart the future of multilateral aid organizations. **********The United States will seek to maintain its influential role in the multilateral banks of which it is now a large or leading shareholder, such as the Asian Development Bank and the World Bank, Mr. Shafer said in an interview. **********But, citing budget constraints at home and changing global political and economic trends, Washington is arguing in forums such as the Asian Development Bank that less money will have to be spent — and spent more wisely — in future international development efforts. **********"We are facing the need to cut our deficit, and that has put a strain on all our spending, including funds for the multilateral banks," Mr. Shafer said. "There are other countries in Europe who have yet to face up to this. **********"Aid that was once seen as a way of competing with the Soviet Union for friends around the world is no longer appropriate. Money once spent without question has to be justified. We are going to have to think now about a world more focused on quality than quantity." **********Under steady pressure from the United States and some other donor countries, the development bank has been steered away from directly financing large infrastructure projects and other programs now increasingly backed by private foreign investors. **********Instead, the bank is seeking to use its resources as a catalyst for private-sector investment and to emphasize social and environmental considerations in future projects, a transformation lauded by Mr. Shafer in his address to the board of governors Wednesday. **********Now, the United States is leading an effort to require the bank to better use its ongoing earnings to buoy its Asian Development Fund, the chief source of financing for so-called concessional lending, loans made on favorable terms to countries in need of development help. The bank is seeking $5.3 billion to replenish its Asian Development Fund, the seventh in its series of fund-raising exercises to benefit the region's poorest countries. **********"We realize that under a new environment, concessional funds have become more scarce," said the bank's treasurer, Tadahiro Asami, who is directing a re-examination of the way the bank allocates its revenue, resources and risks. "We have to carry out the ADF-7 negotiations against this backdrop of change." **********The United States is not alone in telling the bank that its hopes for the fund may be too high unless it gets larger contributions from East Asian members that have shown impressive economic growth lately. "Many donors face severe budgetary constraints which seriously limit their capacity to provide the same level of support as in the past," said New Zealand's chief representative to the bank, Lockwood Smith, urging newly wealthy Asian members to shoulder an increased portion of the development burden. **********Washington's ability to lead the debate has been hampered by its failure to pay $337 million of the $680 million it pledged for the development fund in 1991. **********The United States is the only one of 24 donor countries to be in arrears, a situation that elicits both sympathy and keen concern from its peers about Washington's future actions toward this and other development banks. **********"We are extremely disappointed with the lack of leadership by the United States," said Mats Karlsson, state secretary of Sweden's Foreign Ministry, echoing sentiments expressed by several other European delegations. **********"We have talked about being more efficient for 10 years, and we are making great progress here," he added. "Should talk of less support now be the response? There is no logic to this." **********The unpopularity of foreign aid in a U.S. Congress dominated by conservative Republicans has caused Washington to fall behind in its commitments to the World Bank's soft-loan arm as well. The failure to clear up those arrears while working on a new fund-raising effort prompted other donors to the International Development Association countries to negotiate a provisional solution without the United States. **********The interim program penalizes the United States by preventing U.S. companies from participating in any of the development association's contracts until Washington comes up with the funds it has agreed to contribute. **********But excluding U.S. companies from contracts only makes it more difficult for the government to ask Congress for funds, Mr. Shafer said. **********"The people who think an IDA-type solution would lead the U.S. Congress to act to redress the problem should listen closely to the questions I have to answer," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/10/busin.main_headline: AT THE GATE;Getting a Grip on the Value Of a Glamorous New Act
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/10/busin.print_headline: AT THE GATE;Getting a Grip on the Value Of a Glamorous New Act
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/10/busin.body_text: **********WHEN Planet Hollywood International makes its appearance as an initial public offering this spring, it is likely to be one of the year's hottest performers. Crowds always gather when the company opens a new restaurant, and investors are  expected to come for the same reason the crowds assemble: celebrity glitz. **********"Obviously, it's going to be a deal that gets a lot of press attention and publicity," said George Novello, the portfolio manager of the Smith Barney Special Equities Fund who plans to invest in the stock. That buzz, he believes,  will translate into profits for those who buy the new issue. **********While Planet Hollywood has not yet revealed the price or volume of shares it will offer, it's not too early for investors to make rough estimates of the company's worth -- and try to avoid overpaying for the sought-after stock. As such, investors will be doing just what the company and its underwriters will do when they try to fix a range of possible prices for the issue, with which they hope to raise as much as $190.5 million. The money will mostly be used to pay off debts, but also to expand the chain. **********In valuing a soon-to-be-public company, the first job is to find those public companies most similar to it. With Planet Hollywood, that's not simple. **********While there are several publicly traded restaurant stocks, like McDonald's and Applebee's, Planet Hollywood, which is based in Orlando, Fla., bills itself  as a theme restaurant that mixes entertainment -- loud music, videos and displays of Hollywood memorabilia -- with standard fare like pizza, hamburgers and pasta. Much of the restaurants' appeal depends on convincing stars -- they double as big Planet Hollywood stockholders -- like Bruce Willis and Whoopi Goldberg to show up at the openings of new restaurants and to appear occasionally at existing ones. **********Unlike a typical restaurant chain, Planet Hollywood also sells a lot of related merchandise, from a $3.50 pin to a $325 leather jacket. Almost 40 percent of its sales are from such products. **********Theme restaurants are risky: today's hot theme can be passe tomorrow. But because of profitable merchandise sales, their stocks command higher prices than a typical restaurant chain, said Linda Killian, an analyst for Renaissance Capital, a research firm. **********However, the only other publicly held theme restaurants, Rainforest Cafe and  Dave & Buster's, are much smaller than Planet Hollywood. The only similarly sized public company that comes close to a theme approach is the Starbucks Corporation, the chain that is "not only selling coffee but also cachet" in the  form of T-shirts and coffee mugs, as Ms. Killian says. **********Starbucks has a current market value of about $1.4 billion, or roughly three  times its trailing annual sales of $519 million. By the same measure, Planet Hollywood, which had 1995 sales of $270.6 million, could command a market value  of around $800 million. **********But that calculation is just one way to get a hint of Planet Hollywood's value. A second looks at speed of company growth. Because of its tiny size, for  instance, Rainforest Cafe is expected to be able to double its earnings annually, said Andrew Zarnett, an analyst with Ladenburg Thalmann. Thus, the market values Rainforest stock at a market value that is equivalent to 11 times  the company's 1995 revenues of $13.5 million. **********But such a rate is unduly optimistic for Planet Hollywood, whose market value would be about $3 billion under it. While the company does expect to add 17 restaurants this year, and to develop restaurants with themes tied to athletes and Marvel comic book characters, its growth rate will still probably be much less than Rainforest's. **********Then comes the "I.P.O. discount," which analysts use to factor in the inexperience and modest size typical of new public companies. When the enterprise sells a large amount of stock and when it is far less seasoned than its peers, this discount can rise to as much as 20 percent, said Brian P. Hehir, managing director for equity capital markets for Merrill Lynch, which is not involved in Planet Hollywood's deal. **********But Planet Hollywood scores fairly high by this measure. While Rainforest Cafe had just one restaurant, with less than a year under its belt, when it went public last year, Planet Hollywood has been in business for more than five years and operates 28 restaurants worldwide. "This is a real company with real earnings and with real global expansion," said David Menlow, president of IPO Financial Network, a research firm. **********But despite its five years of revenue, Planet Hollywood did not turn a profit until 1995. And the company's four largest restaurants accounted for more than 40 percent of last year's total sales. Such concentrated revenues would make it  very vulnerable to a problem at one of the locations. **********And there are questions about how many more restaurants the company can build. It acknowledges that few, if any, cities can support more than one Planet Hollywood, and only so many places can support even one. An Orlando or a Las Vegas can attract enough tourists and locals, according to Ron Paul, the president of Technomic Inc., a restaurant consulting firm in Chicago. But with 28 outlets, the chain may soon have to head into smaller, less lucrative markets. **********Even so, there is no arguing that Planet Hollywood stock will be hip. The underwriters can probably count on a lot of buyers desperate to own the same stock as Demi Moore and Don Johnson. Ms. Killian, the analyst, would put Planet  Hollywood's market value at $1 billion, at least, in part because of this celebrity premium. **********Nevertheless, Planet Hollywood is not without risk of losing its appeal. People who flock to the restaurants today may suddenly find the experience -- music that some might call overbearing and food that some would describe as mediocre -- a bore. **********And celebrity connections are no proof against disaster. Wilt Chamberlain had to cancel plans to take his restaurant public, for instance. There have been plenty of casualties among other "hot concept" restaurants, too, Mr. Paul said.  Victoria Station, which had a railroad theme, also ran off the track. **********It may also be that the celebrities will desert Planet Hollywood, not vice versa. **********To be sure, Planet Hollywood is working hard to keep the stars that are so crucial to its success -- so hard that shareholders may object to the company's generosity. The company has given the stars and industry executives roughly 12.8 million shares. That's 16 percent of the company's outstanding private shares, and it doesn't even count options to buy another 2.25 million shares at $7.88 apiece. **********As is often the case, the stars can cash in some of their shares in the not-too-distant future. And -- only in Hollywood -- they can sell their shares to the company if a "high profile senior executive officer is convicted of a felony, or for use of illegal drugs, or of a crime of moral turpitude" and the company is harmed as a result. But the celebrities must hold the shares for at least six months after the offering, and keep at least half their stake for three years. **********If the stars eventually bail out, they will have much less reason to make restaurant appearances. Even with substantial stock ownership by the stars, the  company may have difficulty luring the stars to the smaller cities where new outlets will be unveiled.  Bruce and Demi may have been willing to go to Aspen,  but what about Scranton, Pa.? **********If Planet Hollywood loses its glitz -- and this may explain the company's stock deals with its stars -- then investors may decide the company is no more entertaining than a typical restaurant chain, like Outback Steakhouse. That stock sells for just 31 times trailing earnings. At that valuation, Planet Hollywood would have a market value of just $600 million. **********There may also be trouble from another direction: growing competition in the  booming field of theme restaurants. There's Hard Rock Cafe, which pioneered the  concept, as well as Brooklyn Diner, Motown Cafe and others. RKO Pictures plans to build a $35 million, five-restaurant complex in Times Square, with each restaurant featuring a distinct theme with live music -- like Western movies and country tunes. "If it goes as well as we think it will, it can be a new kind of  entry into this whole field," said Ted Hartley, the chairman of RKO Pictures. **********All these factors will influence investors, underwriters and executives as they seek a fair value for Planet Hollywood. But more general factors will also  have an impact. **********In the weeks ahead, for example, the underwriters will keep a close watch on  the gyrations of the overall stock market and the popularity of restaurant stocks in particular. "In the course of three weeks, you can have a severe change," Mr. Hehir said.  Then comes a practical, pocketbook limit: Underwriters are unlikely to ask for more than $20 a share, said Ms. Killian, because they don't want to alienate small investors, who are expected to be eager buyers. **********Among all this information, the most valuable may be this: Beware glamour. Such stocks "come to market with sizzle," warned John E. Fitzgibbon, the editor  of the IPO Aftermarket, a publication of the Securities Data Company. "But when  it's all over, all you're looking at is some dead cow."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/06/busin.main_headline: Exxon to Add To Surge in Oil From North Sea
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/06/busin.print_headline: Exxon to Add To Surge in Oil From North Sea
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/06/busin.body_text: **********The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it would spend $800 million to develop a big oilfield in the Norwegian part of the North Sea, adding to the area's surging output. **********A surprisingly strong flow from the wells of Norway and Britain has checked the ability of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to push up prices at a time when world demand has grown. **********The Exxon project, which the company said would begin production in early 1997 and plateau at 75,000 barrels a day, will add to the growth and put pressure on OPEC's sales of about 25.9 million barrels a day. **********William L. Randol, the oil analyst for Lehman Brothers, said the surge in production from outside OPEC would exceed the growth in world demand this year,  cutting into OPEC's sales and prices. **********Iraq is expected to begin talks at the United Nations this week about being permitted to sell a limited amount of oil. Those sales could lower world prices, too. **********The attraction of the North Sea area for the major oil companies is that it is politically stable and the oil companies have driven down the cost of development. The time needed to bring a field into production has been greatly shortened, which also saves money. **********Exxon said the Balder field, which lies 110 miles off Stavanger, would be brought into production. The company estimates that reserves at Balder total about 170 million barrels. The field will be brought into production by the Exxon affiliate Esso Norge A.S., using undersea wells tied to a floating vessel that will store oil and load tankers. **********K. C. Williams, the vice president of production for Exxon International, said in an interview that the company would be able to bring the field into production quickly since the vessel was already under construction in Singapore. He added that the cost of producing the oil would be competitive at about $4 a barrel. **********Exxon said last week that Esso Norge had been awarded a stake in three licenses to explore in an area of about 1.1 million acres off Norway. The company said the area had significant potential.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/28/busin.main_headline: AT&T Chief, Who Cut Jobs, Defends Pay
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/28/busin.print_headline: AT&T Chief, Who Cut Jobs, Defends Pay
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/28/busin.body_text: **********Robert E. Allen, AT&T's chairman and chief executive and the man who ordered  40,000 people cut from the company's payroll, received stock options last year that increased his total pay package to $16 million from $6.7 million. **********Executives of the AT&T Corporation say Mr. Allen's actual pay is much less, because he and other top executives cannot cash in their options for at least four years. Mr. Allen, in a long and testy message to all company employees on Monday, said he had actually taken a 20 percent cut in cash compensation and was "in line with C.E.O.'s of comparable companies." **********But Mr. Allen's pay package, which is included in a proxy statement that AT&T sent to shareholders on Monday, is likely to antagonize many workers and increase bad publicity that has already infuriated the usually unflappable chief executive. **********In the last several weeks, AT&T and its layoffs have come under a torrent of  hostile coverage on television, newspapers and news magazines that have highlighted the company's cutbacks as a sign of deeper troubles in the American  workplace. AT&T has also come under repeated attack by Patrick J. Buchanan, the  Republican Presidential contender, who has cited the company as an example of how big corporations shirk their responsibilities to ordinary workers. **********Mr. Allen, in a message to all of AT&T's 303,000 employees, lashed out against what he called "relentless" and "inaccurate" news coverage and defended  his business judgment, his salary and his empathy for the "painful results" of AT&T's job cuts. **********"Restructuring to get to a strong future does unfortunately require force reductions," he said. "I'm not immune to the emotions they engender. I'm deeply  saddened by the pain and loss this is causing some of our people and their families. But in the end, concern isn't enough." **********AT&T's core long-distance telephone and equipment manufacturing businesses were fairly healthy last year, generating $79 billion in revenues. With intense  new competition on the horizon, however, Mr. Allen embarked on a corporate revamping last month that included taking more than $6 billion in write-offs and announcing plans to cut 40,000 workers. **********Despite the huge write-offs, as well as the confession that AT&T's $7.5 billion purchase in 1990 of the big NCR computer company had been a complete failure, Mr. Allen's compensation got a substantial lift last year. **********His cash compensation, in salary and bonuses, did in fact decrease about 20 percent from 1994 to $2.67 million. But Mr. Allen also got 750,000 stock options to buy AT&T stock at $63.50; the stock closed today at $64, down $1 on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Mr. Allen cannot exercise those options for at least four years, and company  executives said that 75 percent of those options could not be exercised until AT&T stock had increased from 10 to 30 percent above $63.50. **********"We want to retain these guys in the business," said Dick Gray, head of investor relations for AT&T.  "These options are designed to operate for the long-term good of the company." **********But Graef S. Crystal, an expert in corporate compensation packages, said Mr.  Allen had gotten generous treatment in light of AT&T's difficulties. **********"Why do you want to retain him -- he's an average performer," Mr. Crystal said. "He's not even a face card, he's a seven in the deck." **********Mr. Allen conceded in his message that he had been paid "a lot of money," but he said the stock options would be worthless if he and others failed to shepherd AT&T to greater success. **********"Without extraordinary business growth, the options have practically no value," he wrote. "This growth-oriented plan is consistent with the interests of all of AT&T's stakeholders." **********But at least some AT&T employees were quick to disagree, though privately, asserting that at least part of AT&T's problems stemmed from calamitous misjudgments in buying NCR and fumbling a long litany of attempts to introduce innovative new consumer electronic products. **********"The question is, at a time when AT&T is going through this wrenching transition, is this fair?" said one AT&T executive, who spoke on the condition he not be identified. "He's comparing himself with other C.E.O.'s, but the question for corporate America is whether you can get loyalty out of men down the line with that kind of logic."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/06/busin.main_headline: COMPANY NEWS;FIRST NATIONWIDE RAISES BID FOR LOMAS FINANCIAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/06/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;FIRST NATIONWIDE RAISES BID FOR LOMAS FINANCIAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/06/busin.body_text: **********First Nationwide Bank has increased its offer for assets of the Lomas Financial Corporation by $7.75 million, or 5.2 percent, to $157.75 million. Lomas disclosed the higher offer in a filing in United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., where the Dallas-based mortgage-servicing company filed for Chapter 11 protection on Oct. 10. First Nationwide is offering more money for less of Lomas Financial. The original bid was for the entire company. Now First Nationwide is not bidding for Lomas's insurance business. Last month, Judge Peter Walsh sided with Lomas's creditors and allowed them to seek bidders  other than First Nationwide.
