https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/02/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;French Concern Selling Turkish Bank Interest
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/02/busin.body_text: **********Turkiye Garanti Bankasi has agreed to pay $245 million for Osmanli Bankasi A.S., which once served as the central bank of the Ottoman Empire. The seller is Compagnie Financiere Ottomane, which is 49.9 percent-owned by the French banking and industrial concern Compagnie Financiere de Paribas S.A. **********Clover Investments, a company held by Turkiye Garanti, will actually acquire the retail bank, which has 61 branches and 1,400 employees. Osmanli Bankasi, Turkey's oldest bank, was founded in 1863 by order of Sultan Abdul Aziz.   (Bloomberg Business News)

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/28/busin.main_headline: Market Place;The Stratosphere in Las Vegas comes down out of the clouds.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/28/busin.print_headline: Market Place;The Stratosphere in Las Vegas comes down out of the clouds.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/28/busin.body_text: **********TRATOSPHERE, eh? **********In the Las Vegas meat grinder, it is often said, a casino has to have a gimmick to avoid being turned into sausage. And that is exactly what the Stratosphere Tower, Casino and Hotel seemed to have. **********Let the other casinos have their volcanoes, pyramids, huge guitars and shark tanks. At the cost of a mere $550 million, the Stratosphere Corporation conjured up a 1,149-foot-high hotel, gambling and retail spire, the tallest building west of the Mississippi. Its pinnacle was wrapped with a roller coaster and then topped with a heart-stopping slingshot of a ride called the Big Shot. **********The Stratosphere -- which is about 43 percent owned by Grand Casinos, Inc. -- was the toast of the town when it opened on April 30. And Wall Street liked the  stock, sending its price to a peak of nearly $14 just before the opening, up from about $8 at the end of last year. The market had generally been good to the gambling stocks for months, and particularly liked any company that talked up an expensive new casino project. **********That was then. **********Shares of Stratosphere have since tumbled, to $5.8125, off 43.75 cents, yesterday in Nasdaq trading and gambling revenues have been deeply disappointing -- $7.7 million after the first five weeks. **********"What I think is happening is that the people who are attracted to a facility like that are not necessarily the people who are going to sit down and do some serious gaming," said Scott Renner, an analyst with Salomon Brothers, which has  lowered earnings estimates just two months after the tower's opening. Salomon is now predicting earnings of 5 cents a share this year, compared with an earlier forecast of 20 cents a share. **********Dennis I. Forst, an analyst at Hancock Institutional Equity Services, said: "The hype moved the stock more than it should have. Frankly, it says more about  the securities business than the gaming business. I see further downside risk in the stock." **********But there are several lessons in the Stratosphere's problems that are already having big implications for the industry. One is that while the casino business  is about entertainment, it ultimately has to be about the entertaining qualities of gambling. **********Several other Las Vegas casinos have spent huge sums learning this lesson. The MGM Grand built a splashy amusement park on some 30 acres of prime land and  Circus Circus constructed its Grand Slam Canyon amusement complex. Both have done poorly and MGM Grand has announced that it is going to cut the space at its park roughly in half. **********But what is important is that the idea of building an attraction has been refined, not dropped, by the industry. Take yesterday's announcement by ITT that its Caesars Palace subsidiary is planning to construct two big casinos with the  Planet Hollywood themed restaurant chain, one in Las Vegas and the other in Atlantic City. **********In this venture, the amusement part of the business will be integrated with the gaming hall, trying to make gambling itself more fun. That is the real trend in gambling, not human slingshots. The Hilton in Las Vegas is constructing a big Star Trek themed casino and amusement area and the musically themed Hard Rock Hotel and Casino has been packed since its opening last year. **********The point is that at some point, entertainment can become a mere distraction, not an enhancement of the experience for a gambler. **********Another major lesson is that location counts more than gimmicks. The Stratosphere is at the north end of the legendary Las Vegas Strip, almost a mile from the nearest giant resort. The casino companies accept now that gamblers are going to stroll from one casino to the next in the never-ending search for Lady  Luck, and that having other attractive properties nearby is a competitive advantage. **********"It's difficult to overcome the fact that it's not in a great location," Mr.  Renner of Salomon Brothers said of the Stratosphere. (The new ITT-Planet Hollywood casinos will be in prime locations.) **********Yet another problem is that the Stratosphere, whose opening was delayed by various problems, may still have opened too soon. Its retail complex is not yet  completed, and an additional 1,000 hotel rooms, on top of the existing 1,500, will not open until next year. **********"The biggest mistake a company can make is to open too soon," said Jason Ader, an analyst with Bear, Stearns & Company. "First impressions can last a long time." **********He added: "Most of the problems are fixable. But these are the growing pains  of a young company learning about the business."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/28/world.main_headline: Serbs in Pragmatic Pullout from Albanian Region
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/28/world.print_headline: Serbs in Pragmatic Pullout from Albanian Region
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/28/world.body_text: **********In 1989 the Serbian strongman, Slobodan Milosevic, swooped down in a helicopter onto the field where 600 years earlier the Turks had defeated the Serbs at the Battle of Kosovo. In a fervent speech before a million Serbs, he galvanized the nationalist passions that two years later fueled the Balkan conflict. **********Now, in this bedraggled southern province of Kosovo, a predominantly Albanian Muslim region where President Milosevic promised a glorious future for the minority Serbs, the Balkan conflict appears to be playing out a subdued denouement. **********More than 90 percent of Kosovo's two million people are Albanians, and their resentment of Serbia's assertion of dominance has long made Kosovo a tinderbox that has threatened to entangle Macedonia, Albania, Greece and Turkey in a wider Balkan conflict. **********But instead of seeing Kosovo reinforced as a Serbian stronghold with the resettlement of Serbs from the former Yugoslavia, as Mr. Milosevic promised, the last Serbs of Kosovo are fleeing, embittered that their leader appears to be deserting them. **********"Many Serbs are leaving right now," said Momcilo Tradkovic, a former Serbian  Governor of Kosovo. "More than 50 percent of the Serbs in Kosovo have already built houses in Serbia. If this continues, the bulk of the Serbs will leave in the next five years, and after that it won't matter." **********The idea that Mr. Milosevic might allow Kosovo, the cradle of Serb history and mythology, to drift away would have been preposterous at the height of the Balkan war. **********But boxed in by the Dayton peace agreement, which requires Serbia to safeguard the rights of ethnic Albanians in Kosovo or forgo access to international credits, Mr. Milosevic appears to be undecided about what to do, Western diplomats say. **********The United States, in an attempt to demonstrate its seriousness about enforcing the accord, opened an information center here on July 20 -- the first  office of a foreign power in Kosovo's capital. And in another effort to keep Mr. Milosevic on better behavior, the Clinton Administration has said it will not send an ambassador to Belgrade while Serbian authorities continue to abuse Albanians' human rights. **********The possibility that Mr. Milosevic may be preparing to soften his stance on Kosovo was further signaled in a recent paper by a member of the Serbian Academy of Science and Arts, who argued that the Albanians and Serbs should share power  in Kosovo or divide the province into two ethnic enclaves. In the past, Mr. Milosevic has often used the academy as a harbinger of policy shifts. **********And in a move that was interpreted by the Serbs of Kosovo as another betrayal by the leader they increasingly distrust, Mr. Milosevic signed an agreement with the German Government this month that calls for the return to Kosovo of 120,000  Albanian refugees now in Germany. **********The tensions over Kosovo intensified in 1990 when Mr. Milosevic infuriated the Albanian majority by revoking Kosovo's autonomy and incorporating it into Serbia. He then strengthened the hand of the heavily armed Serbian police who, human rights monitors say, have made life miserable for the Albanians. About 120,000 Albanians have been dismissed from jobs in state-run plants in the last  five years, the monitors say, and Albanians have been subject to arbitrary arrests, beatings and shakedowns. **********In 1993 Zeljko Raznjatovic, the paramilitary leader known as Arkan, who did much of the "ethnic cleansing" of Bosnia for Mr. Milosevic, turned up in Kosovo  to warn the Albanians what might be in store for them. **********Human-rights abuses persist, said Fred Abraham, a monitor from Human Rights Watch in New York, who recently spent a month in Kosovo. **********"The most severe problem is police violence and torture," he said, adding that Albanians were frequently stopped in their cars by the police and beaten. Detention and sometimes torture in prison were particularly directed to politically active Albanians, he said. **********Ibrahim Rugova, a former Albanian Communist leader during Tito's rule, has been leading a campaign for Albanian independence. Some more moderate Albanian leaders say they would accept a halfway step of autonomy, leading to eventual independence. To underline this goal, Mr. Rugova has formed a shadow government  and established separate Albanian schools, medical facilities and local councils, much of it with funds from Albanians abroad. **********Mr. Rugova's nonviolent civil disobedience and his support from Albanian exiles in Switzerland, Germany and the United States have resulted in a parallel society. Satellite dishes directed toward Tirana, the capital of Albania, enhance even the poorest Albanian dwelling here, suggesting that while Albanians physically live in Serbian-ruled territory, mentally they are elsewhere. **********The inability of the financially strapped Mr. Milosevic to prevent the economic free fall in Kosovo is also propelling the steady Serb exodus, Serbs say. **********"There is no life for us here," said Milica Borzos, a Serbian pensioner whose ancestry in Kosovo goes back centuries and who has seen the once prosperous zinc mining town of Zvecan, where she lives, sink into despair. **********With most industry shuttered and agriculture moribund, Kosovo is kept afloat  largely from the proceeds of Albanian drug-running to Europe and remittances from Albanian expatriates. **********With the help of the drug money that filters down into Albanian villages from the couriers who drive their flashy cars from Kosovo to Switzerland, many Albanians are able to build a future that some Serbs, Mr. Tradkovic asserted, are beginning to envy. **********In Veliki Trnovac, a strategically located Serbian village that borders Kosovo, a handful of tightly knit Albanian families are reported by Western drug enforcement agencies to control the traffic of heroin as it passes from Turkey to Germany and Switzerland. **********Expensive European cars with Swiss license plates and tinted windows parked on the village's narrow streets are the only outward signs of the courier system that is reportedly run out of the village. But a cafe owner gave a sense of the importance of the European connections. **********"There are 25-year-old men who linger in the street who have never worked in  their lives," said the owner, who would give his name only as Ibrahim. "They are just waiting for money to come from Switzerland." **********To help pay the $300-a-month rent for his cafe, Ibrahim said, he received money from three brothers in Switzerland. **********Fehmi Agani, a sociology professor and vice president of the main Albanian party, the Democratic Alliance of Kosovo, acknowledged that Albanians were involved in drug trafficking. But he said that the Albanians were not "in charge" of the drug trade and served only as couriers. "People have no other way to survive," he said. **********And when Kosovo Albanians end up in Swiss jails on charges of drug trafficking -- about 3,000 are currently being held -- life is not so bad, he said. **********"A large number of people live better in jail in Switzerland than here in freedom," said Mr. Agani, who gets by with the help of $150 his son sends each month from Germany. **********The ability of the Albanians to survive economically, by legal or other means, rankles many Serbs, particularly those who arrived in Kosovo last year as refugees from Croatia. **********In the basement of an ostentatious sports hall here built by Tito to celebrate the brotherhood of Yugoslavia's Serbs and Albanians languish about 500 ethnic Serbs who fled the Krajina region of Croatia last year as Croatian troops advanced and Mr. Milosevic failed to come to the Serbs' defense. **********Instead of finding refuge in the heart of Serbdom, they now feel abandoned at the end of the world. **********About 15,000 of the estimated 150,000 Krajina Serbs were sent by the Belgrade authorities to Kosovo. And like many of their Kosovo brethren, they are desperate to leave. **********Mladenka Rajlic, the mother of two children, has visited all the shrines of Kosovo: ornate Orthodox churches, monasteries and the medieval battlefield where Mr. Milosevic proclaimed his vision of a new Serbia. **********But history left her unimpressed. **********"God forbid I should stay here; this place is 300 years behind civilization," Mrs. Rajlic shuddered as she sat in a makeshift room with no running water. "I'm only 36 and I'd rather die than remain in Kosovo."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/18/world.main_headline: Clinton Urges Broad Global Role for Japan
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/18/world.print_headline: Clinton Urges Broad Global Role for Japan
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/18/world.body_text: **********Bringing a state visit to an end, President Clinton today urged Japan to forge an alliance with the United States for the next century, with a growing commitment to free trade and to an expanding international leadership role that  "flows from its place as a great nation." **********In an address to Parliament this morning, Mr. Clinton also said the American  people "profoundly regret" the rape of a Okinawan schoolgirl by three American servicemen last September, an attack that shook the security alliance by provoking an anti-American backlash. **********But he strongly defended the American presence in Asia, which was ratified in the joint declaration he signed on Wednesday with Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto. **********"Consider what might happen if the United States were to withdraw entirely from this region," Mr. Clinton said. "It could spark a costly arms race that could destabilize northeast Asia. It could hinder our ability to work with you to maintain security in a part of the world that has suffered enough in the 20th century through world war and regional conflicts and that is now in the midst of profound change." **********Mr. Clinton discreetly avoided any reference to China, whose military exercises in the Taiwan Strait recently sent tremors through Asia. But he noted  that a United States withdrawal from Asia "would weaken our power to deter states like North Korea that may still threaten peace." **********Much of the President's speech was devoted to urging Japan to end its economic protectionism and hesitation about a role in world affairs. Noting that Japan had sent peacekeepers to Cambodia and minesweepers to the Persian Gulf, and had committed $500 million in reconstruction aid to Bosnia, he said, "We are all better off for your commitment to this kind of leadership." **********"Today, to a great Japanese people whose pride in the past is now matched by  your focus on the future, I say, stay true to that commitment to lead," Mr. Clinton said. "Make it even stronger. We have come so far in the last 50 years.  Think about it: from the waste of war to the wealth of peace, from conflict to cooperation and competition, from mistrust to partnership." **********Mr. Clinton acknowledged that American-Japanese trade relations were "not entirely free of friction." But as he has throughout his visit here, he played down the many areas of specific disagreement. Instead, he argued that open markets and American exports would benefit both nations. **********"For Americans those exports mean more jobs at better pay," he said. "For the people of Japan, allowing these American goods and services to compete for the favors of the Japanese consumer means greater choice at lower prices." **********Mr. Clinton was only the second American President to address Japan's Parliament; Ronald Reagan spoke here 1983. He received a standing ovation when he finished his speech and another one as he and his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, stood at the front of the chamber of the House of Representatives bowing their heads slightly in a Japanese-style gesture of courtesy. **********Mr. Clinton's visit to Japan came midway through a weeklong tour that will now take him to Moscow, where he is to attend a nine-nation summit meeting on nuclear security and meet with President Boris N. Yeltsin, who is in an election struggle. **********The crucial centerpiece of Mr. Clinton's visit to Japan came on Wednesday when he and Mr. Hashimoto signed a joint declaration endorsing the American military presence in the Asia-Pacific region as "essential for preserving peace  and stability" in an area rattled by North Korea's incursions into the demilitarized zone separating it from South Korea and China's military maneuvers in the Taiwan Strait. **********The security declaration affirmed that the United States would maintain its troop strength in the region at 100,000, the same number it maintains in Europe. The declaration also incorporated a plan for the American military to return an air base, two communications centers, a port and other military properties on Okinawa, where the rape of the girl set off anti-American protests. **********The leaders also signed a separate document setting forth areas of cooperation between the two nations on regional disputes and in the United Nations. **********On Wednesday afternoon, Mr. Clinton visited an aircraft carrier that had recently been deployed in the Taiwan Strait in order to thank the American forces serving in Japan. **********On the carrier deck of the Independence, the oldest active ship in the service, under the banner "Don't Tread on Me," Mr. Clinton told the sailors and  marines that their presence in the strait during China's military exercises "reassured nations all around the Pacific." **********The President also saluted the crew of the Japanese cruiser Myoko, who had joined the ceremonies at the Yokosuka Naval Base outside Tokyo. **********"Fifty years ago no one would have believed that an American carrier and a Japanese cruiser could be berthed side by side, that our forces would work shoulder to shoulder, day in and day out," Mr. Clinton said. **********On Wednesday night the President and his wife were welcomed by Emperor Akihito at a white-tie state dinner in the Imperial Palace. Toasting the Emperor and his wife, Mr. Clinton remarked on how far the alliance had come since Japan's defeat in World War II. **********"History offers very few examples of two peoples who have forged such a powerful relationship in the short period of half a century," he said. "We have  indeed traveled far together. We have created in modern times a great democratic tradition." **********At a similar official dinner in 1992, President Bush fell ill, his discomfort recorded by a television camera. This time, according to an American official familiar with the arrangements, the Japanese required that television cameras be turned off after an official photo session and pointed away from the tables.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/07/busin.main_headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Prices Rise As Auction Is Success
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/07/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Prices Rise As Auction Is Success
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/07/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday as the Government's quarterly refunding began with a successful auction of Treasury notes. **********The 30-year bond rose 13/32, to a price of 110 6/32 to yield 6.12 percent, down from 6.15 percent on Monday. **********The Government sold $18.5 billion in three-year notes with an average yield  of 5.043 percent, but analysts said yesterday's auction was the easy part of the refunding. The remaining $26 billion of securities is expected to be harder to sell, with $14 billion of 10-year notes scheduled today and $12 billion of 30-year bonds set for Thursday. **********"The remaining two are usually harder auctions to complete successfully," said Gerald A. Guild, senior vice president of the taxable fixed-income department at Advest Inc. "But we still won't know if this refunding is successful; that will depend on whether the price of these securities at settlement on Feb. 15 will be at or above the average price at auction." **********Mr. Guild said investors were worried about the heavy supply. There is a chance, he said, that the yield on today's 10-year note could be below the 25-year low of 5.69 reached in November 1993, and the 30-year bond below the more-than-20-year low of 6.33 percent in August 1993. **********"The economic fundamentals, low inflation and the slowdown in economic growth are positives," Mr. Guild said, "while the big negative remains the impasse between Congress and the President on budget and debt ceiling. I personally do not believe the market will do well until the issues are resolved, which may not be until after the election. As a result short rates likely will decline more than long rates." **********Traders said investors bid strongly for the three-year notes because they believed that the Federal Reserve would continue to lower interest rates to help the economy. The average yield on the three-year notes was down from 5.549 percent in November and the lowest since 4.83 percent on Feb. 8, 1994. **********In when-issued trading, the 10-year notes in today's auction were being offered at a price to yield 5.65 percent, and Thursday's 30-year bond, 6.06 percent. **********Last week the Fed lowered short-term rates for the third time in eight months, cutting the Federal funds rate a quarter-point, to 5.25 percent. **********David Ader, managing analyst with Technical Data in Boston, termed yesterday  an uneventful day, with buying interest at the note auction seen coming from central banks and retail investors. "Although today's auction went off without a hitch, the 10- and 30-year auctions will not be as easy," he said. **********"The market is currently trading in the middle of a range," Mr. Ader added, "and players don't know if they want to buy or sell. I expect, though, that the  market is setting itself up for a buy." **********The economic reports issued yesterday were the Mitsubishi Bank/ Schroder Wertheim report on retail sales, which showed salesdown three-tenths of a percent for the week ended Saturday, and the Johnson Redbook report, which put retail sales for the first week in February up seven-tenths of a percent. **********Elsewhere in the fixed-income market, Argentina plans to sell $1 billion in five-year bonds within the next several weeks, said an official at Merrill Lynch & Company, which will co-manage the sale with CS First Boston. **********Argentina had planned to sell $750 million worth of bonds in January, with those bonds expected to be priced to yield about 425 basis points more than comparable United States Treasury securities. According to traders, Argentine bonds have rallied in recent months as investors bet that the country would emerge from a recession in 1996 and more money would flow into emerging markets. **********Bloomberg Business News said the Argentine 8 3/8 percent global bond due in 2003 was trading around 89 1/2, up from 72 on Nov. 15, dropping the yield to 10.35 percent, 485 basis points more than comparable United States Treasury securities. **********Slim pickings in higher corporate-grade issues brought investors out for yesterday's junk-bond sale by the El Paso Electric Company, which is emerging from bankruptcy. **********Underwriters led by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette priced six maturities running from 3 to 15 years, with the longest maturity priced to yield 8.9 percent. **********The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three-year notes: **********(000 omitted in dollar figures) **********Average Price . . . 99.882 Average Yield . . . 5.043% Low Price . . . 99.873 High Yield . . . 5.046% High Price . . . 99.898 Low Yield . . . 5.037% Accepted at low price . . . 51% Total applied for . . . $49,440,971 Accepted . . . $18,505,941 Noncompetitive . . . $857,000 Interest set at . . . 5% **********The three-year notes mature on Feb. 15, 1999.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/07/busin.snippet: The tensions underlying the European Union's drive toward a single currency were exposed Wednesday by two official reports, one that criticized national governments for running excessive budget deficits and one that predicted 12 of the 15 EU count...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/07/busin.body_text: **********The tensions underlying the European Union's drive toward a single currency were exposed Wednesday by two official reports, one that criticized national governments for running excessive budget deficits and one that predicted 12 of the 15 EU countries would get their financial books in order by next year. **********The reports from the European Commission and the European Monetary Institute illustrated the conflicting agendas of EU governments and their central banks. The commission's report reflected the view of governments, which have resorted in recent weeks to accounting moves and rosy economic scenarios to present 1997 budgets that meet the requirements for a single currency. **********Meanwhile, the EMI echoed the views of central banks, led by the Bundesbank, which insist on strict compliance with the Maastricht treaty's criteria to guarantee the stability of the Euro. **********But both reports were in line with expectations and did little to alter the view in financial markets that Europe is more likely than not to launch the single currency in 1999 — primarily for political reasons rather than economic ones. **********"The bottom line is that the markets remain fairly positive," said Thomas Mayer, chief economist at Goldman. Sachs & Co. in Frankfurt. **********The monetary institute, the forerunner of a future European central bank, said in its annual report on compliance with the single-currency rules that progress in reducing deficits "has generally been too slow." The report also adopted the tough language used by senior Bundesbank officials in recent months: It cited the need for sustainable compliance with the economic criteria and delivered an unmistakable criticism of France's bid to meet the deficit target with a pre-privatization payment of 37.5 billion francs ($7.32 billion) from France Telecom to the French treasury. **********"The improvement of the deficit by measures with a one-off effect does not ensure sustainable consolidation, and great attention will have to be paid to the substance and not only to the accounting methods used in measuring both deficits and debt," the report said. **********Italy, Spain and Portugal have unveiled ambitious deficit-reduction programs for 1997 in recent weeks in a bid to qualify for monetary union from the outset. But Bundesbank officials, led by President Hans Tietmeyer, have increasingly insisted that countries meet the criteria on a lasting basis rather than with a last-minute rush. **********The commission, meanwhile, predicted that all EU countries except Italy, Greece and Britain would get their deficits down to or below the single-currency ceiling of 3 percent of gross domestic product in 1997, compared with an EU average of 4.4 percent this year. **********The progress in part reflects an upturn in growth, which the commission forecast would rise to an average of 2.3 percent in 1997 from 1.6 percent this year. **********The commission assumed that national governments would deliver on the deficit-cutting promises made in recent weeks, a view not shared by many private forecasters. For example, the commission's forecast of a 2.9 percent deficit for Germany next year is much more optimistic than the 3.5 percent forecast issued by the top six German economic institutes just last week. **********Meanwhile, financial markets regard the commission forecasts as a "nice statement of objectives" rather than a serious forecast, said Alison Cottrell, economist at PaineWebber in London. **********By forecasting a French deficit of 3 percent next year, the commission endorsed the government's use of the France Telecom payment, a move criticized by Germany. But in an unexpected warning to Paris, Yves-Thibault de Silguy, the commissioner for monetary affairs, said countries would be judged in early 1998 on the "durable character" of their budget reforms. **********"We will not be content with one-shot measures," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/03/world.main_headline: Surveys Rate Nigeria as Most Corrupt Nation for Business
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/03/world.print_headline: Surveys Rate Nigeria as Most Corrupt Nation for Business
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/03/world.body_text: **********Nigeria tops the list of countries that international business people consider the most corrupt, according to a ranking published yesterday by a Berlin-based independent organization, Transparency International. **********Fifty-four countries involved in international business are ranked by Transparency International in its second annual corruption index. The rankings are based on results from 10 surveys made by management and risk-analysis organizations as well as on information volunteered by representatives of international companies through the Internet. **********After Nigeria, business people ranked Pakistan, Kenya, Bangladesh, China, Cameroon, Venezuela, Russia, India and Indonesia as the most corrupt countries. **********The 10 least corrupt countries this year were New Zealand, Denmark, Sweden, Finland, Canada, Norway, Singapore, Switzerland, the Netherlands and Australia. **********The United States was judged the 15th-least-corrupt place, with a slightly worse reputation than Israel but better than Austria. **********The findings, stored and analyzed at Gottingen University in Germany, report  perceptions of people in international business, mostly from industrialized nations, who deal regularly with foreign companies and governments.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/23/busin.main_headline: EARNING IT;From 'Working Rich' To Endangered Clan
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/23/busin.print_headline: EARNING IT;From 'Working Rich' To Endangered Clan
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/23/busin.body_text: **********DUDLEY BRAND'S father was a carpenter, and the words he chose to guide his son into a blue-collar career were hammered home like galvanized nails driven deep into a plank of fresh-cut timber: "Get a toolbox and you can always get a day's work." **********That was 30 years ago, but the words still ring in the ears of Mr. Brand, now 44. Like many working-class boys of his generation in eastern Connecticut, he had entered Windham Regional Vocational-Technical School to learn a trade and follow in his father's footsteps. **********Last month, Mr. Brand was among some 200 alumni who attended a reunion dinner-dance at Tech, as they call the school, entering from bright sunshine into a building many had not visited since graduation. **********Members of classes spanning five decades gathered in small groups on the gymnasium floor, beneath bunches of blue and white balloons and yards of bunting, to exhume adolescent memories of shop routines and classroom pranks. As late afternoon slipped into evening, they also examined their working lives and  whether the maxims they learned about jobs and security still held true for their sons and daughters. **********"We are the lucky ones, the last of the working rich," said Dave Meikle of the class of 1959, a modest man with a quick smile who has worked 32 years as an electronics technician at the Pratt & Whitney aircraft engine plant in East Hartford. "We still hold good-paying industrial jobs we were trained to do." **********But Mr. Meikle, 55, says he will accept an incentive package to leave his job by the end of summer, a program he says is intended to eliminate senior workers  at his wage level of $20 an hour. Similarly, Ronald Drouin, 54, a classmate of Mr. Meikle, hopes to get a buyout at the Electric Boat submarine division of General Dynamics in Groton before his job is eliminated in a new round of 2,000  layoffs this summer. He has worked at Electric Boat as a draftsman for 33 years. **********"Electric Boat and Pratt were companies a guy who came out of Tech could always find work," said Mr. Meikle, who studied television and radio repair at Tech and then went into the Navy, where he was trained in electronics. "When I started at Pratt in 1964, we had 20,000 hourly workers at the East Hartford plant. Now we're down to 2,500." **********For earlier generations, the mainstay of employment was the American Thread Company, a mill that opened in 1854 on the banks of the Willimantic River, a swift-running ribbon of turbulent water that bisects this community of 22,000. At one time, the mill had 2,500 workers tending 30,000 spindles, which turned out everything from Aunt Lydia's carpet and button thread to material used in the making of fire hoses, seat belts and baseballs. The city's identity was so interwoven with the mill that the centerpiece of emblems on police cars was a thread spool. **********In 1985, American Thread shut down the Willimantic operation and moved to North Carolina. The abandoned mill still stands like a haunted relic of past economic glory, a chain of sturdy stone and brick buildings dominated by a smokestack with a handsome mosaic design on its blunt tip 175 feet above the ground. **********Textiles were already seen as a dead-end industry by the time the new vo-tech school opened in 1956 on the north brow of the shallow valley overlooking the mill. Mr. Meikle and Mr. Drouin enrolled that fall as eager sophomores and signed up for shops intended to feed the growing demand for workers in military-related industries and the home construction trades. **********The school they came back to this year again reflects a changing marketplace. Service industry jobs are replacing those based in manufacturing; culinary arts  and health care courses have far more students than tool-and-die making. **********"There are still small machine shops around, but we have a tough time encouraging kids to go into that line of work," said Paul Manzone, a guidance counselor at Tech for 24 years. "You don't hear them say anymore, 'Dad is going  to get me a job in the union and I'll lead the good life.' **********"Now you hear them say, 'My parents are divorced and my father is working in  Florida and I'm headed south as soon as I get out of school.' " **********If they stay around, he continued, many take state jobs; the three largest employers in the area are the University of Connecticut in Storrs, Eastern Connecticut State University in Windham, and a nearby state prison. Otherwise, he said, unless a local contractor is hiring, the only opening may be at Home Depot for $9 an hour. **********Many in the gymnasium said the shifting economy had forced them to switch jobs. Mr. Brand quit carpentry to teach at another vo-tech school, a choice he did not regret as the home building boom of the 1980's collapsed in this decade. Horace Geer, 54, used his fingers to pick off the number of jobs he has held since leaving Tech in 1960; he stopped when he got to 10. **********"Next week I start work as a janitor at Foxwoods Casino, run by the Indians," he said with a husky voice as "A Teen-Ager in Love" by Dion and the Belmonts drifted through the gymnasium, part of a taped stream of reunion nostalgia. "I don't know how long that will last, but they have good health benefits, which you can hardly get anymore." **********Steve LeBel, class of '79, expressed impatience when he heard the older men lament the loss of industrial jobs. **********"Trouble is, they've been ruined by industry," said Mr. LeBel, who manages a  small machine shop. "They're afraid of the new machines. A lot have been spoiled by union jobs. They didn't have to work hard and got lots of overtime and benefits. **********"This guy from Pratt & Whitney comes by my shop looking for a job but he's not versatile and has a lot of holes in his skills. I tell him, 'I'll start you  off at 11 bucks an hour and see how it works out. Medical covers you but not your family and there's no pension.' **********"He looks at me like I insulted him and walks out," Mr. LeBel said, a quizzical look on his goateed face. **********Dave Meikle took issue with that assessment. "I believe we earned our high wages and benefits at Pratt," he said as he prepared to sit down for dinner in the cafeteria. "The trouble is, those jobs are not there for the next generation because the work is being placed with vendors who are either out of the country  or don't pay union wages or benefits. **********"Like I said, my class from the 50's was the lucky one. We knew what we wanted and it was there for us. It's just not that easy anymore," said the electronics technician, whose daughter, the youngest of his five children, graduated this spring from Yale with a degree in fine arts. **********By now, the sun rimmed the western skyline and lengthening shadows chased through the Willimantic valley. The turbulent ribbon of water rushed by the shuttered mill, which had once been a symbol of so much in this New England town, tossing spray in bursts of energy no longer yoked and converted to man's will. **********Only the mosaic-tipped brick chimney continued to catch the receding light creeping up its shaft, and in a few minutes that, too, blinked out.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/23/busin.snippet: Surging current-account deficits in several Southeast Asian countries, caused largely by a rapid rise in imports, are prompting government and monetary authorities to rethink free-trade policies..Economists estimate that spending by Indonesia, Mal...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/23/busin.main_headline: ECONOMIC SCENE : Rising Asian Deficits Threaten Trade
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/23/busin.print_headline: ECONOMIC SCENE : Rising Asian Deficits Threaten Trade
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/23/busin.body_text: **********Surging current-account deficits in several Southeast Asian countries, caused largely by a rapid rise in imports, are prompting government and monetary authorities to rethink free-trade policies. **********Economists estimate that spending by Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand on imports of goods and services in 1996 is likely to exceed their export and other earnings by more than $30 billion **********While taking some measures to tighten credit and slow growth to more sustainable levels, Indonesia and Malaysia are also applying import-substitution programs. Thailand is considering selective curbs on foreign investment. **********Although foreign investment in the three countries is helping to finance their deficits, repatriation of profits and imports of equipment and goods for foreign investment projects are a major cause of the spiraling imbalances. **********Like other Asian nations, Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand have been liberalizing their economies in recent years to make them more efficient and competitive. **********Officials said the recent steps in response to the growing deficits did not mean that market-opening was being put into reverse gear, but analysts said it was certainly a setback. **********But a Western business executive whose company has established manufacturing operations in Southeast Asia said the moves "send the wrong signals to investors who were banking on the region becoming a genuine free-trade area" by early next century. **********The Malaysian government, for instance, has directed all state entities and the private sector to make an audit of the local content of their projects and increase it wherever possible to cut the current-account deficit. **********"Of course, this may result in some people complaining that we are imposing quotas on imports," said Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad of Malaysia. "But if we don't impose quotas, we have a deficit, and they complain that we are not managing our economy properly." **********Official figures due out soon are expected to show that Indonesia's deficit reached almost $8 billion in 1995, more than double the level in 1994, while Malaysia's nearly doubled to just over $7 billion **********The Bank of Thailand announced recently that the country's current-account deficit last year was nearly $12 billion, up 65 percent on 1994. **********The central bank proposed that the government take several steps, including restriction of foreign investment in manufacturing to large operations. **********President Suharto of Indonesia earlier this month set up an official group to scrutinize imports for government and state-owned company projects, saying it should direct the procurement of goods and services to domestic suppliers as much as possible. **********The government has also agreed to hefty protection for a national car project and a giant petrochemical complex, both of which are partly owned by companies controlled by sons of Mr. Suharto. **********Japan has protested that the national car program runs counter to World Trade Organization rules and the spirit of the Bogor Declaration on free trade adopted by a meeting of leaders of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, in Indonesia in 1994. **********Japan currently has a share of over 90 percent of the Indonesian automobile market through joint venture assembly plants set up with local companies. **********Tunky Ariwibowo, Indonesia's trade and industry minister, said that the government was determined to reduce the annual current-account deficit by expanding exports and bringing down the growth rate of imports in 1996 to 11 percent from 30 percent in 1995. **********He said that imports would be slowed by a government strategy to develop Indonesian-based industries and services that could "substitute for imports." **********Foreign business executives and bankers are critical of the moves toward greater self-sufficiency in Thailand, Indonesia and Malaysia, saying they will scare off overseas investment that is helping to build stronger exports.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/11/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;As on-line stock trading heats up, can bigger and better campaigns for cyberfirms be far behind?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/11/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;As on-line stock trading heats up, can bigger and better campaigns for cyberfirms be far behind?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/11/busin.body_text: **********PC FINANCIAL NETWORK, one of the pioneering on-line discount brokers, is counting on a humorous ad campaign to increase its share of the hotly competitive electronic investment market. **********In the last six months, on-line investing has grown rapidly, with the introduction of e.Schwab, Charles Schwab & Company's computerized trading service, and Internet trading by E*trade Securities and Lombard Institutional Brokerage. The time seems ripe for this financial-services niche market to try to entice computer-savvy investors to experiment with on-line trading. **********The new campaign represents a change in marketing for PC Financial Network,  a Jersey City unit of the Equitable Companies' Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities division. For the first time since its start-up in 1988, the discount broker is advertising in traditional print and electronic media; previously, it  advertised only on Prodigy and America Online. **********Unlike its on-line ads and current advertising by many of its rivals, the new campaign by the network features clever, tongue-in-cheek humor. And unlike most  ads for on-line investing, PCFN's advertising does not feature commission charts and pictures of computer screens. **********Created by Goldsmith/Jeffrey -- which has also done award-winning work for J. P. Morgan Private Banking -- the black-and-white campaign has a tag line that says "PCFN, you'll get attached to it." **********Each ad shows a single object, such as a piece of burnt toast. In that ad, the copy, a memo to a hypothetical investor, says PCFN knows how much the investor likes the convenience of trading on line, but reminds him or her that the toast is ready. The basic message: users become so engrossed in on-line trading they forget the demands of daily life. **********"Traditional financial services advertising has talking heads discussing commissions and how much you can save," explained Stephen Killeen, PCFN's director of marketing.  "Our goal is to say you can save, but also look at all the stuff you can do, on your own schedule." **********The new campaign -- costing an estimated $4 million to $5 million, less than  half of the network's annual marketing budget -- began last month. Print ads run through mid-summer in the financial and computer publications Barron's, Investor's Business Daily, Worth, Wired, Home PC and Individual Investor. Cable- TV advertising is running nationally on CNN, CNNfn and CNBC, in some cases through December. **********In addition, the campaign will run in the specific markets of New York, Seattle and San Diego, with ads in The New York Times, The Seattle Times and The San Diego Union Tribune and on A & E, Discovery and ESPN. **********Those areas, Mr. Killeen said, "are pockets where there is high penetration of electronically enabled consumers." **********Goldsmith/Jeffrey is also preparing a direct-mail campaign for PC Financial Network, which is continuing its on-line advertising as well. **********The network's rivals, meanwhile, are themselves paying increasing sums to advertise their services. According to Competitive Media Reporting, Charles Schwab spent a hefty $654,000 just in January to advertise e.Schwab, which was introduced that month; people close to the account say that monthly media buys for the rest of the year will probably not match this level. **********Lombard, a division of Thomas F. White & Company, a San Francisco brokerage firm, is about to start a $2.4 million print and cable TV campaign by Tracy/Ryan & Partners of San Francisco; E*Trade, of Palo Alto, Calif., is estimated to be spending more than $300,000 a month on print, radio and on-line ads, quadrupling what it bought monthly in 1995's fourth quarter. **********The e.Schwab campaign is utterly straightforward, while Lombard and E*Trade inject some levity into their advertising. Both e.Schwab and E*Trade ads contain charts comparing commission structures for electronic trading among various firms. Typically, commissions charged by electronic brokers are smaller than those for conventional trading. **********Bill Bluestein, group director of new media research for Forrester Research of Cambridge, Mass., said all electronic discount brokers have to get their advertising strategies in order because on-line investing "is about to take a huge jump forward." **********"Between 50 percent and 60 percent of mutual fund and discount broker clients have personal computers, but only a tiny percentage currently invest on line," he said. **********Mr. Bluestein found e.Schwab's advertising thrust appropriate for the "hard-core, active trader," but predicted that PCFN's campaign could be more effective in the long term. **********"The hard-core, active trader represents a minority of investors who use on-line services like AOL or Compuserve," he said. "PCFN has developed a message that can span this frequent trader as well as the less active trader. PCFN's strategy is to stand out from the pack; its campaign has a broader reach. In that sense, its advertising is very powerful."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/12/busin.main_headline: Rivals of American and British Air Quickly Assail New Alliance as Anticompetitive
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/12/busin.print_headline: Rivals of American and British Air Quickly Assail New Alliance as Anticompetitive
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/12/busin.body_text: **********American Airlines and British Airways formally announced their plans yesterday for a broad marketing alliance, setting off sharp criticism from competitors and raising questions about the likelihood of their partnership winning approval from Government regulators in both countries. **********In addition, their announcement left unanswered the question of what would become of British Airways' current marketing link with USAir, which would be eclipsed by the new alliance with American. **********Officials of American and British Airways indicated yesterday that they planned to begin joint marketing of their flights in April 1997, creating, they said, more choices for consumers to travel more conveniently over the route networks of two airlines. **********To carry out their plan -- which includes selling seats on each other's flights and sharing the profit from some $3.5 billion in revenue from their combined service over the Atlantic -- they would require antitrust immunity from the United States Department of Transportation, but not from the British, whose laws are less restrictive on antitrust issues. **********The airlines' plan would also require the United States and British Governments to renegotiate and loosen their long-restrictive aviation agreement, replacing it with a so-called open-skies accord. **********The United States has struck such an agreement with 11 other European countries, but Britain has remained a holdout. Executives at both airlines said yesterday they were confident that they would win the required approvals for their alliance by November. **********But their proposal has already generated controversy because of the combined market power of American and British Airways, two large and profitable airlines whose combined route networks, including alliances with carriers like Qantas, would reach most continents. **********The two airlines currently provide 58 percent of the flights between the United States and Britain. By comparison, United Airlines, a unit of the UAL Corporation, and Lufthansa already have a similar alliance that accounts for 39 percent of flights between the United States and Germany. **********American is also only one of two United States carriers -- United is the other -- that is formally authorized to fly into London's Heathrow Airport, the world's busiest international hub, under an aviation agreement signed by Washington and London 50 years ago. **********Although an open-skies agreement would allow others to fly to Heathrow, using their own aircraft, the airport is at full capacity. That makes it unlikely for this deal to satisfy the concerns of all airlines and governments in each country. **********Delta Air Lines, for example, described as ''frightening'' the market dominance of an allied American Airlines and British Airways. A company spokesman said that Delta would need ''meaningful access'' to Heathrow before it went along with the plan. **********Delta and others are expected to file their concerns with the Justice Department, whose ruling on the proposed alliance would carry the weight of a recommendation to the Department of Transportation. The Transportation Department., which will rule on whether the proposal is anticompetitive, has said that it will require additional and ''commercially viable'' access to Heathrow for other United States carriers. **********But Robert L. Crandall, chairman of the AMR Corporation, American Airlines' parent company, said that any slots for takeoffs and landings would not come from American or British Airways, and that slots at Heathrow would be a make-or-break issue for the proposed alliance. **********''If we are expected to give up slots, this deal will not happen,'' he said. **********Jon F. Ash, a managing director at Global Aviation Associates, a Washington consulting firm, said yesterday that if Mr. Crandall was unwavering in his stance, ''this is going to be a tough battle.'' **********An American-British Airways partnership would be the latest major airline alliance between United States and European companies. Other deals include those between Northwest and KLM, United and Lufthansa, and Delta's alliances with Virgin Atlantic, Sabena, Swissair and Austrian Airlines. **********British Airways' alliance with USAir has been in place for several years, with the British carrier owning 24.6 percent of its smaller partner. **********American and British Airways officials said that their plan did not affect the USAir alliance, and that a new role for USAir might evolve in coming months. **********USAir said that yesterday's proposal ''has the potential to provide USAir with the ability to pursue new and positive opportunities.'' It did not elaborate, adding only that it would act in the best interests of its shareholders, employees and customers. **********USAir executives have said that one of their strategies is to expand the airline's international network. Industry analysts predicted yesterday that USAir would use the announcement as a reason to dissolve its marketing alliance with British Airways and to fly more international routes on its own. **********''The British Airways-American Airlines alliance probably severs the connection permanently,'' said Mark Ray, who manages a transportation bond portfolio for John Hancock Financial Services. **********Industry analysts have said that the relationship with USAir has grown lopsided as it evolved. Some analysts have suggested that British Airways has benefited more from USAir's vast domestic network than USAir has gained from British Airways' international routes, generating an additional $300 million in revenue for British Airways and a fraction of that for USAir.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/21/world.snippet: US Labor Department reports fewer children appear to be working overseas to make apparel sold in US as companies facing adverse publicity adopt standards barring such practices by subsidiaries and suppliers; says American companies have failed to ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/21/world.main_headline: Clothing Makers Taking Steps To Limit Child Labor Abroad
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/21/world.print_headline: Clothing Makers Taking Steps To Limit Child Labor Abroad
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/21/world.body_text: **********Fewer children appear to be working overseas to make apparel sold in the United States, as companies facing adverse publicity adopt standards barring such labor in their subsidiaries and suppliers, the Labor Department has found. **********But the department has also found that American companies did not adequately enforce their own standards, often known as ''codes of conduct,'' and that child labor remained pervasive in smaller factories and even in homes in some countries, particularly in Asia. **********In a report to be released on Monday, the department concluded that the codes of conduct had become increasingly common among the largest American retailers and manufacturers. With stricter enforcement, the report says, they could reduce the number of children working in foreign factories, often in dismal working conditions at substandard wages. **********''Codes of conduct are not a panacea,'' the report said. ''Child labor remains a serious problem -- with hundreds of millions of children working around the world.'' **********The survey was completed two years after two reports by the department concluded that children were involved in the production of garments for export to the United States -- often working long hours and receiving less than minimum wages and in some cases working in shops with armed guards blocking the exits. **********''This is a major change from just a few years ago, when importers were more inclined to avoid any responsibility on this matter,'' the report said. **********While the new report suggested that fewer children were working in these industries in some countries since those reports were released, it said it remained unclear that ''a downward trend in the use of child labor in garment production is a universal phenomenon.'' A cable from the American Embassy in Cambodia just last month, for example, reported children working in a garment factory there. **********Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said the latest report was the first comprehensive survey of efforts by American companies to address the problem. ''Although our laws don't reach to other nations, we can at the very least alert American consumers, the media and the major retailers and manufacturers to the extent of the problem with child labor,'' Mr. Reich said in a telephone interview on Friday. **********As imports of apparel have steadily climbed, working conditions in overseas factories have become a growing concern. The department noted that more than half of the $178 billion worth of garments sold in the United States in 1995 were imported, compared with 30 percent in 1980. **********In recent years, several companies have found themselves embarrassed by those conditions -- the most recent and most publicized example being the controversy last spring involving a line of clothing bearing Kathie Lee Gifford's name manufactured in Honduras. **********The department's new survey found that 36 of 42 of the largest apparel companies had adopted formal standards prohibiting child labor, as well as other labor violations like the use of forced labor. Many have done so only in the last couple of years. **********The department examined the companies' codes and visited six countries with significant imports to the United States -- the Dominican Republic, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, India and the Philippines -- to assess the effects the codes were having. **********The report concluded that child labor is ''not now prevalent'' in the Latin American countries surveyed, although there was anecdotal evidence that it had been common in the past. Only four of the companies that took part -- the Gap, Levi Strauss, Phillips-Van Heusen and Sears -- reported that they had themselves encountered cases of child labor. **********But the department also reported evidence that dates of birth documents had been falsified, suggesting efforts to evade the prohibitions, and that children continued to work for small subcontractors, including in the San Pedro de Sacatepequez region of Guatemala, an area with a substantial garment industry. **********And the department concluded that child labor remained a greater problem in Asia, with children in India and the Philippines working for small subcontractors or for their parents at home. **********The report recommends that all American retailers, manufacturers and buyers adopt stronger, more explicit and uniform standards and that they make a greater effort to enforce them.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/04/world.main_headline: World News Briefs;Nigerian Publisher Wounded by Gunmen
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/04/world.print_headline: World News Briefs;Nigerian Publisher Wounded by Gunmen
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/04/world.body_text: **********The publisher of Nigeria's leading independent newspaper, The Guardian, has been shot and seriously wounded, the newspaper said today. **********Guardian executives said Alex Ibru, 61, was shot by unknown assailants here on Friday night while on his way from work. **********They said that the motive of the attack was not clear but that nothing was stolen from Mr. Ibru, a former Interior Minister in Gen. Sani Abacha's military  Government. **********Nigeria has been in a political and economic crisis since the annulment in 1993 of a presidential election that would have ended military rule. **********In December, an arson attack gutted a small section of The Guardian's building. The newspaper was closed for more than a year by the Government and allowed to reopen in October only after Mr. Ibru apologized to the authorities for any offensive reports it may have carried.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/29/busin.main_headline: Cray to Accuse NEC Of Trade Violations
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/29/busin.print_headline: Cray to Accuse NEC Of Trade Violations
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/29/busin.body_text: **********Cray Research Inc. said yesterday that it plans to outline today what it says are trade law violations by the NEC Corporation. **********Cray would not say whether it planned to file dumping charges, but there were reports in Asia that the company would do so. **********We will detail violations of U.S. trade laws by NEC," a spokesman for Cray, a unit of Silicon Graphics Inc. of Mountain View, Calif., said. He declined to be more specific. **********A report by the Japanese news agency Jiji said the complaint arose from a contract NEC received to sell a supercomputer to the National Science Foundation. The billings were not disclosed. **********Collagen has selected the agency to handle advertising for its Collagen Replacement Therapy SM treatment, which had previously been handled by Grey Advertising in San Francisco. Becky Stirn, vice president for marketing strategy at Collagen in Palo Alto, Calif., said Jerry & Ketchum was awarded the  account after a three-month review that had narrowed the choice to that agency and three other finalists, all based in California: Esprit Communications in Corona del Mar, Forsythe Marcelli Johnson in Newport Beach and Mullaly Communications in San Ramon. **********And Block Drug in Jersey City named Jerry & Ketchum to assess what was described as "marketing and positioning opportunities" for its newly acquired Carpet Fresh brand of carpet deodorizer. That account had been inactive under the brand's previous owner, Reckitt & Colman P.L.C. Jerry & Ketchum was awarded  the Carpet Fresh assignment without a review. **********Jerry & Ketchum is 51 percent owned by top managers including Jerry Della Femina and 49 percent owned by Ketchum Communications, which agreed last week to be acquired by the Omnicom Group. The agency plans to continue operations as the managers discuss buying the 49 percent interest from Omnicom, which avoids owning minority stakes in North American agencies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/05/world.snippet: Japanese police, in move that could bolster support for Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto's reforms, arrest former Deputy Health Minister Nobuharu Okamitsu, who is suspected of taking about $530,000 in bribes (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/05/world.main_headline: Japanese Ex-Aide Is Accused Of Taking $530,000 in Bribes
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/05/world.print_headline: Japanese Ex-Aide Is Accused Of Taking $530,000 in Bribes
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/05/world.body_text: **********In a move that could bolster support for Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto's reforms, the police today arrested a former Deputy Health Minister suspected of taking about $530,000 in bribes. **********It was the first arrest of a top ministry official in seven years, and a big embarrassment for Japan's bureaucrats, who are currently under fire for wielding too much power. **********The former official, Nobuharu Okamitsu, 57, who resigned two weeks ago from the top bureaucratic post at the Ministry of Health and Welfare, received the money in a room of the ministry, the police said, according to Kyodo News Service. **********The police said Mr. Okamitsu in turn granted special access and privileges to Hiroshi Koyama, the head of a welfare organization who was arrested on Nov. 18. **********Mr. Okamitsu was shown on national television today with his eyes closed, his face without expression, as he was taken into a car by the police. Police officials were shown carrying cardboard boxes of materials from both his Government-provided home and a condominium he bought in 1994, reportedly with money he received as bribes. **********Before his arrest, Mr. Okamitsu, who played a pivotal role in developing a 10-year welfare program for the elderly, admitted receiving two cars from Mr. Koyama. In return, he reportedly helped Mr. Koyama's organization win large subsidies to build nursing homes for the elderly. Mr. Okamitsu has denied taking any money. **********''I can only say it's extremely regrettable,'' said Junichiro Koizumi, the new Health Minister, who on Tuesday demoted another senior official for accepting nearly $9,000 in cash. The official, Masaru Wada, said he had returned the money. **********Mr. Okamitsu had risen to the pinnacle of his career, with his appointment earlier this year to Deputy Health Minister. The last time such a senior bureaucrat was arrested in disgrace was in 1989, when the Deputy Ministers for Education and Labor were taken into custody for bestowing benefits in exchange for shares from a company called Recruit. **********The arrest today could help Prime Minister Hashimoto fulfill his promise to the public of reforming the bureaucracy and cutting the number of officials. In recent polls, Mr. Hashimoto has had favorable ratings of 56 percent, and the single most popular issue has been his plan to reform the administration. **********''I hope that a strict investigation will be conducted, so that we will get a result that is acceptable to the Japanese people,'' Mr. Hashimoto was quoted as saying by the Tokyo Broadcasting System. **********Bureaucrats have traditionally held enormous prestige. But a number of recent scandals, including the mismanagement of the nation's banking crisis and the promotion more than a decade ago of blood tainted with the AIDS virus, have tarnished the image of bureaucrats.
