https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/15/busin.main_headline: Limiting a Medium Without Boundaries;How Do You Let the Good Fish Through the Net While Blocking the Bad?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/15/busin.print_headline: Limiting a Medium Without Boundaries;How Do You Let the Good Fish Through the Net While Blocking the Bad?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/15/busin.body_text: **********All over the world, a growing number of governments, schools, special interest groups and families are struggling to find acceptable ways of tapping into the riches of the Internet without also hitting the darker veins of the global computer network. **********But with its ability to carry all kinds of information across borders and oceans in a flash, the Internet has evolved faster than the laws and technical structures of the countries it touches. Although communities have struggled for  centuries to preserve local laws and standards when they come into conflict with the outside world, the Internet and on-line information networks are presenting  them with new problems that defy old solutions. **********For example, German officials last month persuaded Ohio-based Compuserve to  cut off access to some 200 sex-related news forums worldwide. Chinese officials  said last week that they wanted to stop "detrimental information" from entering  the country via the Internet. And the United States Congress, in legislation still stalled by disagreement over other issues, has voted to halt the flow of "indecent" computer files through this country, even if the offensive material is created and maintained on computers halfway around the world. **********Even as pressure is intensifying to restrict the flow of pornography, hate speech and other offensive material in electronic form, Internet technologists say that ultimately there is no completely effective way to block the relatively small number of "bad bits" out of the torrents of data available to tens of millions of people in more than 150 countries. **********But there are some partial solutions. A growing industry has emerged in the last two years to offer individuals, schools and businesses a variety of tools,  ranging from complex computer barriers known as firewalls to simple software programs, to screen certain bits while allowing others to pass. Most of these tools are effective in stopping some unwanted data traffic, but none guarantees  100 percent effectiveness. **********"Nothing we can do will be a perfect solution, for two important reasons," said Brian R. Ek, spokesman for an industry group trying to create the equivalent of a motion picture ratings system on the Internet. "First, no matter what technologies we come up with, somewhere, somehow, someone is going to figure out a way to circumvent them. That's the nature of programming." **********"Second," Mr. Ek continued, "there is an ocean of Web pages and news groups already out there, and being able to rate them all, with several hundred new ones coming on line every day, is an impossibility." **********Even so, Mr. Ek and others say, new software and hardware tools hold the promise -- or the threat, depending on one's point of view -- of allowing people to filter out certain kinds of information while allowing other kinds to be viewed on a personal computer screen. "Yes, with the right software tools you can selectively block access for some people," said Paul Resnick, an AT&T Bell Labs researcher who is co-chairman of the technical committee for PICS, the Platform for Internet Content Selection, the group trying to develop a ratings technology. "The key is to have selective  rules rather than blanket rules." **********There is disagreement over whether it is technically possible to impose blanket control over incoming information, as Germany is seeking in the Compuserve case, without resorting to Draconian measures that most democratic countries find distasteful, like limiting access to telephone lines or employing vast squads of censors to monitor all data traffic. **********The biggest obstacle seems to be the basic design of the Internet itself, which was created during the cold war to allow uninterrupted routing of data traffic even in the event of a nuclear war. At that time, the Internet comprised only a handful of computers, and if one computer failed, the data packets would  automatically detour around it. **********Today the Internet is composed of millions of "host" computers, all but a few of them privately maintained. Tens of millions of personal computer users tap into this vast ocean of data on any given day. It is as easy to retrieve data files from halfway around the world as it is to get a file from the computer on  the next desk, and the data path may snake through dozens of cities and countries along the way. **********Trying to keep certain types of information from entering a jurisdiction is as difficult as keeping certain kinds of molecules from entering a country's air space, or certain kinds of fish from swimming in its waters. **********"The nature of the Internet, if not contemporary telecommunication and transportation technologies in general, make this intrinsically impossible to achieve," said Anthony M. Rutkowski, an engineer and lawyer who until recently was head of the Internet Society, an international association of Internet access companies. **********"One can regard the Internet in some of the same ways as radio waves with respect to the abilities of the medium to transparently flow across national boundaries," Mr. Rutkowski said. **********For decades, some countries, like the Soviet Union and what were once its East European satellites, did try jamming radio and television signals, with limited success. **********"This century has seen numerous energetic efforts to control information that comes via the airwaves, as well as to stop publications from being smuggled across borders," said Mitchell Stephens, a fellow at the Freedom Forum Media Studies Center and a journalism professor at New York University. **********"Some countries have never quite accepted the idea that information goes wherever it damn well pleases, and they try to extend their walls to reach up into the air. It is not surprising that such efforts would be made with computer technology now, especially in light of the incredible potential power inherent in the Internet." **********"I suspect we're just seeing the start of this," Professor Stephens said, "because the major authoritarian countries that remain are typically poorer countries, where most of the population does not have access to computers or televisions or other information sources. When that changes, it will be a huge issue." **********If access to information on a computer is blocked by one route, a moderately  skilled computer user can simply tap into another computer by an alternative route. Or one can easily disguise a flurry of bad bits, either by data encryption, which renders them unreadable except by the intended recipient, or simply by changing the file name to something that will pass through most filtering mechanisms. **********An Internet axiom credited to John Gilmore, an engineer at a Silicon Valley networking company, puts it succinctly. "The Internet interprets censorship as damage and routes around it," he said. **********Disputes over international broadcasting have been common since 1928, when international delegates gathered in Vienna to discuss cross-border transmissions. **********In 1948, at the dawn of television, the United Nations General Assembly adopted Article 19 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which said: "Everyone has the right to freedom of opinion and expression; this right includes freedom to hold opinions without interference and to seek, receive and  impart information and ideas through any media and regardless of frontiers." But some governments' efforts to control information have often meant those words constituted little more than an unfulfilled hope. And with each new and more powerful communications medium, attempts to restrict the flow of information across borders increase. **********Recent technical advances suggest that it is easier to block the sending of certain forms of information to a specific country or a specific computer than to keep people in that country from reaching across the border to get the information. **********"From a technical-feasibility point of view, we could segment content country by country," said George Meng, a manager for the Microsoft Network, which offers Internet connections in 50 countries. "The question is whether that is something we want to do." **********But a more intractable problem, he said, arises when an MSN subscriber goes through the system to gain access to the Internet and the World Wide Web. "If they know the URL of a site," he said, "they can enter the Web directly via our  Internet Explorer. If we don't maintain the server, my guess is that we could not control the content." **********If Internet companies cannot control millions of servers, at least the individual user can control his or her own machine. A small industry has grown up in the United States to produce filtering software, which a parent, teacher or boss can install to keep other users from straying into forbidden areas of the network. **********Programs like Surf Watch and Net Nanny typically work by comparing a user's request for information against a list of prohibited sites. Each program's list  is compiled from well-known sources of sex-related discussions or pictures, and  is updated periodically, either by computer programs that scan the data stream for key words, or by teams of people employed to find objectionable material on  the Net. **********There are many drawbacks to the filtering approach. First, new data sites are created every day, so even with frequent upgrades the software is always at least partly out of date. Also, content within a site can change at any time, compromising the reliability of any rating system, and a skilled and determined  teen-age programmer can generally find his or her way to any filtered site. **********But the programs can be effective in stopping casual users from gaining access to the better-known sources of pornography or sex-related discussions. **********One promising attempt to filter information is the PICS proposal, which is defining voluntary technical standards to enable individuals, groups, or even government agencies to establish ratings for Internet, Usenet and World Wide Web files. **********A ratings tool would be encoded into the browser software used to gain access to Internet data sites, for example. Parents could choose a browser endorsed by  the Christian Coalition, for example, or by the local school board or the on-line service provider itself. "We want individual families to set their own selection rules," Mr. Resnick said. "You could have different rules for different countries, too. Of course, we don't get to set the rules for China."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/30/busin.main_headline: U.S. Defeated In Its Appeal Of Trade Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/30/busin.print_headline: U.S. Defeated In Its Appeal Of Trade Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/30/busin.body_text: **********The United States lost its final appeal today in the first major case brought before the newly created World Trade Organization. A three-judge panel ruled that regulations issued under the Clean Air Act discriminated against foreign oil refiners. **********The practical effect of the ruling is that the Environmental Protection Agency will almost certainly be forced to rewrite some of the rules concerning the environmental standards for imported gasoline or face trade sanctions from the countries that filed the complaint, Venezuela and Brazil. Imported gasoline  accounts for only about 5 percent of gasoline sold in the United States, but about 20 percent of gas sold in the New York area. **********The changes seem unlikely to have a major effect on the environment. But the political significance of the decision may be far larger. Senator Bob Dole, the  presumptive Republican nominee for President, has long argued that the trade accord that created the trade organization in late 1994 as an international arbiter, runs the risk of surrendering sovereignty over American laws to foreign judges. **********Today's rulings bolster his argument that the international organization can  effectively force the United States to rewrite its rules. Mr. Dole's office said today that it was still reviewing the decision and had no comment on its contents. **********The judges -- from the Philippines, Japan and New Zealand -- concluded that standards set by the Environmental Protection Agency constituted "unjustifiable discrimination" because they set different rules for foreign producers than for domestic refiners. They found that the rules were a "disguised restriction on international trade." **********In a brief statement today, the acting United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, said that she was "disappointed that the practical result of this case remains unchanged," but "gratified" that the appellate panel ruled  for the United States on a number of technical points. Administration officials  noted that the panel acknowledged that countries had the right to control air pollution or take other steps to protect the environment -- as long as the rules applied equally to domestic and foreign companies. **********The United States faces another potential conflict after the World Trade Organization threatened to scuttle talks over a global telecommunications agreement that faces a deadline of midnight on Tuesday. American negotiators in  Geneva said they were not yet satisfied with market-opening offers from Asian nations. The accord among 53 nations would regulate the $500 billion global telecommunications services and equipment industry. **********Jeffrey Lang, the deputy United States trade representative and top American  negotiator at the talks, said that after American officials made their objections clear, they had not received improved offers from other nations. **********Today's decision on gasoline regulations, announced at the World Trade Organization's headquarters in Geneva, was the first ever handed down by the organization's recently appointed Appellate Body, which is essentially the Supreme Court of international trade. It is charged with reviewing decisions issued by panels that hear trade complaints brought by any of the 120 nations that have signed the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. **********The trade organization's judicial authority has long been a main sticking point for economic nationalists who opposed America's entry into the worldwide trade accord. Opposition has created a disparate group of critics, including consumer advocates like Ralph Nader, trade hawks like Ross Perot and Patrick J.  Buchanan and conservatives like Senators Jesse Helms of North Carolina and Strom Thurmond of South Carolina. They argue that environmental protections, laws against the purchase of goods made by child labor and even steps taken to cut down on drug imports can be challenged as trade barriers. **********The Administration has argued that those concerns are overblown: The world organization does not have the power to strike down laws, only to impose trade penalties. **********After weeks of haggling with Administration officials over that issue in 1994, Mr. Dole reached an agreement with Mr. Clinton to support the trade accord -- thus assuring its passage -- as long as a commission was appointed to review  all decisions that go against the United States. If the commission concludes that three such decisions are capricious, Congress will automatically be asked to vote on whether to pull the United States out of the trade group. **********But more than a year and a half later, the commission has yet to be established. The legislation creating it was held up by Senator Robert C. Byrd,  the West Virginia Democrat and an opponent of the trade accord, who said that the appeals commission was not powerful enough. **********At the time he struck the deal with Mr. Clinton -- and announced it in a ceremony in the Rose Garden -- Mr. Dole was criticized by the conservative wing  of his party, which said he sold out to major corporate donors to his campaign,  all supporters of the international accord. Indeed, he will have a hard time blaming Mr. Clinton for agreeing to American participation in the organization.  In the end, it was his vote and the votes he brought with him that won the trade accord's passage in the Senate. **********The dispute that led to today's decision began three years ago, when Venezuela asked the United States for permission to ship gasoline to the Northeast that probably produced more smog-emitting chemicals than American refiners were permitted to sell. **********Under the Clean Air Act, domestic producers are required to meet standards based on the emissions of gasoline they produced in 1990. But many foreign producers did not keep equivalent records of their production then. So a different standard was created: They could ship only gasoline that met an average quality standard in the United States. **********The foreign companies argued, successfully, that the rule effectively required them to meet a higher standard than some American concerns were required to meet, putting them at a disadvantage.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/22/your-.print_headline: IRS Adds Layer of Red Tape For the Foreign Investor
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/22/your-.body_text: **********WASHINGTON is adding to the red tape it imposes on foreign investors, requiring anybody who deals with the Internal Revenue Service to provide it with their passport and home-country tax paper numbers. The rule will add to the difficulties of people who would rather not let their home countries know they have U.S. investments. **********Although the IRS will not penalize people who do not comply, they stand to lose the chance to get refunds if they do not, according to Richard Andersen, an international tax lawyer withJones, Day, Reavis & Pogue in New York. **********Mr. Anderson said most foreign investors would find the new requirement to be just be one more adventure in red tape. But he added thatit could cause problems for foreigners who are not anxious to have their connections to the United States disclosed. **********He noted that the IRS has an interest through tax treaties and other agreements in sharing taxpayer information with other countries as a tool for combating international tax evasion. But to foreign investors this information-sharing raises concerns that go beyond avoiding taxes. **********Mr. Anderson said that, for some investors, local politics could make any connection with the United States damaging and even dangerous if it became known. He added that in some political climates investors could face confiscation or expropriation of assets. **********While many foreign investors already have U.S. taxpayer identificationnumbers, the new rules require them for anyone who fills out a U.S. tax return. This includesspouses filing joint returns with American taxpayers.It also includes people filing to obtain a refund of American taxes, including those who have had tax withheld on dividends and interest. **********Theinformation will be required in a new form —W-7,the application for an alien taxpayer identification number. **********Mr.Andersen,said "it is a fair inference" that the only consequences for failing to fill out the W-7 will be the loss of tax benefits, such as refunds or special tax treatment, since the IRS will not acceptcommunications lacking a taxpayer identification number. **********Mr. Andersen suggested that those investors review their investments to determine how they can comply with the new requirements and still maintain confidentiality. This could be done by "interposing investment vehicles"— such as offshore trusts — to break the link between themselves and their investments. **********An IRS spokesman said that the new forms should be available at embassies and consulates by mid-July. The form already can be obtained from the IRS homepage on the World Wide Web section of the inter net. The address is http://www.irs.ustreas.gov/. **********For those who do not have access to computer, the form can be obtained by "fax on demand". The taxpayer must use the voice unit of your fax to dial this service at 703-487-4160 and request the form by return fax. **********For further information taxpayers can call their nearest IRS overseas office or teh IRS International Tax Assistance office in Washington D.C. at 202-874-1460.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/07/busin.main_headline: SPENDING IT;Dr. Fad's Advice on Buying Art: Keep It Simple
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/07/busin.print_headline: SPENDING IT;Dr. Fad's Advice on Buying Art: Keep It Simple
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/07/busin.body_text: **********AFTER a while, being Dr. Fad just wasn't enough for Ken Hakuta. The 45-year-old Harvard M.B.A. earned $20 million -- and his nickname -- marketing the Wacky Wallwalker, a sticky plastic octopus that was the Pet Rock of the mid-80's. And, he has made millions more manufacturing the tiny toys found in cereal boxes. **********But by 1990, he was looking for a different challenge, and he couldn't have taken more of a left turn. For about $1 million, he bought over several years one of the world's best assemblages of Shaker furniture, the Mount Lebanon Collection, dedicating much of his energy to preserving the cultural legacy of the millennialist Christian sect, whose heyday was before the Civil War and which largely died off by the 1940's. **********With the money I had to spend, I could either buy a third-rate Picasso or this entire collection, which represents one of America's most important contributions to the arts," Mr. Hakuta said in the ringing tones of the zealot.  "It's been a lot more work than just hanging a picture on my wall, but it's also been a lot more rewarding." **********The story of how Mr. Hakuta acquired his collection is a complex tale of chance encounters, mystical experiences with the dead, the difficulties of reaching Bill Cosby on the phone and hardball business negotiations. It is also  about how a thoroughly modern mogul added meaning to his life through a group whose motto is: hands to work; hearts to God. **********The story begins in 1774 when Mother Ann Lee and eight companions came to America to escape religious persecution in England. At their central site in Mount Lebanon, N.Y., near Albany, they practiced communal ownership of property, equality of the sexes and, perhaps because four of Mrs. Lee's children had died  young, celibacy. (This helped lead to their eventual demise because they could only increase their ranks through recruitment.) By 1850 more than 6,000 members  lived in 19 established communities from Maine to Kentucky. **********The Shakers shunned the outside world to pursue plain and simple living. They developed a stripped-down esthetic, which held that beauty rests on utility. Symmetry and simplicity were the hallmarks of this style, which informed their many practical inventions, including clothespins and the functional cupboards, desks and bureaus that are masterpieces of Shaker design. **********When the Mount Lebanon community withered away, the Shakers sold their buildings, furniture and land in 1930 to a small coed boarding school, the Darrow School, which still operates on the site. Few people then attached much value to the furniture, so Darrow used the 2,500 pieces in its dormitories and offices. **********Darrow parted with some minor pieces as interest in Shaker design developed in the 1970's, but it wasn't until 1988 when, faced with financial problems, it  sold one of its prize possessions, a circa 1820 cupboard, to Bill Cosby for $200,000. **********During the next two years, the school sold four pieces to Mr. Hakuta, who had long been interested in American folk art. He paid half a million dollars for the pieces, which included a tall clock made in 1806. **********As the school's finances continued to weaken, Darrow called Mr. Hakuta in the summer of 1990, offering to sell him everything. Sotheby's had told Darrow the lot might fetch $1.3 million at auction, but the school hoped to find a single buyer who would agree to leave it on site. **********"They wanted to sell it to Cosby," Mr. Hakuta said, with a hint of skepticism. "But they told me they couldn't reach him. I guess he doesn't give his private number out." **********When Mr. Hakuta and his wife, Marilou, visited the school, he had two transforming experiences. While at an old Shaker graveyard one night with two curators, "we saw this light, an intense white light that suddenly came up," he  recounted. "And it became so noisy up there, an internal sound, inside your head. We had to yell. Later, we decided that the Shakers were not at peace there." **********One of the curators, Andy Vadnai, said, "I didn't see any white light, but there was an eerie sound about and strange electricity in the air. I think Ken was more affected than we were, but there was definitely something spiritually powerful going on there." **********The next night, rummaging through an old attic, "I kicked something and there was the rusting grave marker of a 4-year-old girl, Elida Barbour," Mr. Hakuta said. "Maybe because I have three sons but no daughters, this discarded object made me think, 'I've got to save this.' " **********Through tough negotiations, Mr. Hakuta bargained Darrow down to $600,000 for  the entire lot. Under the agreement, the collection would remain in Mount Lebanon and a local foundation, now called the Mount Lebanon Shaker Village, would have the right to repurchase it for an undetermined price for display in a new museum. **********"They wanted my money and the collection, and I was happy to oblige because we were keeping everything together," Mr. Hakuta said. "But then I became a fanatic. I wanted to care for my babies, as I call them." **********Within a year, foundation members told him they would not be able to build the planned museum, and Mr. Hakuta became increasingly prickly about the school's use of the furniture. "One faculty member was keeping his socks in a $200,000 cupboard; another was using a magnificent piece as a home entertainment center for his stereo and VCR," he said. "They hadn't changed the way they were  using the furniture, but now it was mine." To the school's consternation Mr. Hakuta exercised his rights under the contract in the summer of 1991 and removed the collection. **********"He snookered us," said Earl D. Samson 3d, chairman of Darrow's board, who agreed that the school was ill-equipped to care for the collection. "We sold at  a low price because Hakuta gave us verbal assurances he would not remove the collection. When he decided to take it, we were facing bankruptcy and didn't have the time or money to fight him." **********Mr. Hakuta says he made no such assurances and that making a profit was never his goal. "Only about 60 percent was of real monetary value, but I took everything, including rusty old pieces of pipe from their aqueduct system," he said. "When we removed an old stove, I kept the ashes because they were Shaker ashes. I know it's a little crazy, but I wanted to preserve everything these people had left behind." **********He moved lock, stock and aqueduct to a warehouse near his toy factory in Laurel, Md. He says he has since spent $500,000 and much time restoring, photographing, insuring and caring for the collection, which was recently appraised for $2.5 million. **********"Ken Hakuta saved the collection," said Tim Rieman, a board member of Mount Lebanon Shaker Village and author of "The Complete Book of Shaker Furniture" (Abrams, 1994). "It is finally getting the care and attention it deserves." **********Now Mr. Hakuta wants to "show the world the Shakers' wonderful legacy." After a recent exhibit in Hartford, the collection has traveled to Lincoln, Neb., as a part of a United States tour that will wind up at the Smithsonian Institution in 1999. **********He would like to find a permanent home for the collection, but, he said, a museum will only accept the furniture as a gift if he includes perhaps $10 million to cover the costs of storage and display. **********"I'm still not sure how I got into this," he said. "And I have no idea how it will end. But the fact that Dr. Fad and the Wacky Wallwalker could save a piece  of American history, that's reward enough."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/20/busin.main_headline: Fight Over Picking Up Tab For S.&L. Bailout Renewed
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/20/busin.print_headline: Fight Over Picking Up Tab For S.&L. Bailout Renewed
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/20/busin.body_text: **********The savings-and-loan crisis may have passed, but the fight over who picks up  the bill rages on. **********Six and a half years after Congress passed sweeping legislation to clean up $150 billion in losses from a decade of mismanagement and fraud at the nation's savings and loans, savings institutions and their commercial bank competitors are arguing anew over how much responsibility each industry has to make up a share of the losses. **********At stake is not just the cost to financial institutions, but the growing possibility of default on $8.2 billion of bonds issued by the Financing Corporation, an arm of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, which was established in 1987 to help pay for an early bailout package. And in the long run, Federal regulators including Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned in testimony to the House Banking committee today, the hard-won stability of the savings-and-loan industry and of its deposit-insurance fund could be undermined. **********The survivors of the financial carnage in the savings industry are now very healthy, and though regulators said another recession could create some problems, no one is worried about systemic failures. **********Rather, regulators said, the main problem now is that savings institutions are forced under terms of the bailout package to pay hefty premiums into the industry's depleted deposit-insurance fund, while banks pay little or nothing into their industry's fund. As a result, healthy savings institutions are moving deposits into affiliates that qualify as banks. **********Because the bank insurance fund is fully capitalized, healthy banks now pay only a token $2,000 a year into their fund. **********Savings institutions, by contrast, pay 23 cents for each $100 of deposits into their deposit-insurance fund. That means an institution with $100 million in deposits -- relatively small by industry standards -- would pay $230,000 a year. **********As the amount of deposits covered by the savings industry's insurance fund declines, so does the total of premiums the fund takes in. The remaining savings institutions will probably tend to be those with a higher risk of financial problems, the regulators said, potentially putting more strain on the fund. **********In total, the savings industry's fund is required to have $1.25 on hand for every $100 of deposits held by the industry, but at the end of last year had only 47 cents for every $100. **********Indeed, the fund has only $3.4 billion in it. That's a little more than a third of the reserves it is supposed to have -- and a level that the Treasury said could be wiped out by the failure of a single large savings institution or  several medium-sized ones. **********Not only is the fund left badly undercapitalized, but because nearly half of  the premium income is used to pay holders of the Financing Corporation bonds, regulators said that the risk of the fund defaulting on the bonds was also increasing. **********"We're looking at a deteriorating process where as healthy institutions leave, then the burden falls on, by definition, less healthy institutions," Mr.  Greenspan said. "It's a cumulative downward spiral which seems to me inevitable  in the long run, although the time frame is difficult to judge." **********Asked at the hearing by Representative Bill McCollum, a Florida Republican, whether time was of the essence in dealing with the problem, Mr. Greenspan replied, "Unquestionably." **********A measure passed last year with support from both parties and the White House was meant to solve the problem. But the measure was attached to the vetoed balanced-budget bill, making the savings-industry legislation the victim of a bigger and more politically charged dispute. **********The measure would have charged savings institutions a one-time assessment of  $6 billion to lift the insurance fund to its required level. It would also have  spread responsibility for paying interest on the bonds across both the banking and savings industries -- a step that commercial banks said would cost them $12  billion in the next 25 years. **********With the issue now reopened, banks are lobbying hard against it and their pressure has stalled if not killed efforts to revive last year's legislation. **********Citing heavy opposition from banks around the country, James M. Culberson Jr., the president of the American Bankers Association, told the committee: "Bankers are extremely upset with the prospect that having rebuilt their fund at no cost to taxpayers they may be asked to pay approximately $12 billion to help  relieve an obligation of one of their principal competitors." **********The savings industry's survivors said they were happy to shoulder the heaviest share of recapitalizing their insurance fund and paying interest on the bonds. But they said they should not be held solely responsible, especially since as survivors they constitute the savings industry's most conservatively run institutions. **********James F. Montgomery, the chairman of America's Community Bankers, the savings industry's trade group, urged the committee to try again to pass the legislation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/25/busin.body_text: **********The Bankers Trust Company has agreed to pay $67 million to Air Products and Chemicals Inc. to settle a dispute over money-losing derivatives contracts, the  companies announced yesterday. **********The settlement is by far the largest so far in disputes involving the New York bank holding company and its clients over the highly complex, volatile securities, which in 1994 generated huge losses at some of the nation's best-known and biggest companies. **********Experts said the settlement, and an accompanying conciliatory statement from Bankers Trust, indicated that the bank might now be willing to settle remaining  lawsuits. In the past it has sent out strong signals that it intended to defend  its actions in court. **********Of the other derivative-related actions brought against Bankers Trust and yet to be settled, by far the largest is a lawsuit by Procter & Gamble, which is seeking $130 million, plus unspecified punitive damages. **********In a statement, Thomas Parisi, a Bankers Trust spokesman, said the financial  effects of the settlement were reflected in the bank's fourth- quarter earnings  results, which were announced last week. The settlement is expected to be covered by the bank's reserves for potential credit losses, which are just under $1 billion. **********"As we said at the time of the earnings announcement, management believes that the expected potential impact of all outstanding issues related to leveraged derivative transactions are now covered by existing reserves," Mr. Parisi said. "We are pleased to be able to put these past difficulties behind us, and are especially pleased to conclude this matter with Air Products, a valued client with whom we continue to enjoy a constructive relationship." **********Harry T. C. Hu, a law professor at the University of Texas in Austin, said: "The fact that Bankers Trust settled this thing and is saying kind words about Air Products seems to signal they care about customer relationships right now, and are perhaps more willing to settle cases now than they were under the Sanford regime." **********Mr. Hu was referring to Charles S. Sanford Jr., the chairman and former chief executive of Bankers Trust. Mr. Sanford surprised banking analysts last year when he announced he intended to retire. He plans to step aside as chairman in April. **********Also last year, Eugene B. Shanks Jr., the bank's president and the executive  who oversaw the derivatives business, resigned when the Bankers Trust board passed him over as Mr. Sanford's successor as chairman and chief executive, and  chose Frank N. Newman instead. **********"The overall sense of these proceedings is that rational minds are sitting down and sorting this out in a very calm fashion," said Robert Albertson, a banking analyst at Goldman, Sachs. **********Air Products and Chemicals, based in Allentown, Pa., said it lost more than $107 million in its 1994 fiscal year on contracts it entered with Bankers Trust  between October and December 1993. **********The contracts involved interest rate swaps, a derivative in which the value of the transaction fluctuates with changes in interest rates. **********As interest rates rose sharply in 1994, the value of the contracts dissolved, and the losses mounted. **********Air Products and Chemicals contended that the contracts violated its corporate policy against risky investments. **********Although a potential settlement with Procter & Gamble could well exceed what  Bankers Trust is paying to Air Products, the $67 million payment is well above the $14 million the bank paid to Gibson Greetings Inc. and the $12 million it paid to the Federal Paper Board Company to settle previous derivatives disputes. **********"They are telling us pretty emphatically they are fully reserved" against future derivatives costs, said Lawrence Cohn, an analyst at Paine Webber. "But I'm not sure I believe them. All through last year they said they were fully reserved, and then they added an additional $51 million in the fourth quarter." **********Still, Mr. Cohn said he was recommending Bankers Trust stock, which yesterday fell by 50 cents a share, to $62.125. **********"Their capital position is as strong as J. P. Morgan's, and their dividend is secure," he said. "People who look at the company and fear they will cut the dividend are not looking at Bankers Trust's balance sheet."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/01/busin.body_text: **********The Vanguard Group mailed incorrect tax-preparation materials to its more than five million fund shareholders that could result in people having to amend  their tax returns to the Internal Revenue Service, Vanguard said today. **********"We did make a mistake," said Brian Mattes, vice president of Vanguard, based in Valley Forge, Pa. "The error we created involved our telling investors to use the 'ordinary income' box when we should have told them to pick the 'gross income' box." **********Mr. Mattes said gross income included long-term capital gains, while ordinary income excluded the gains. **********Vanguard's error came to light in an article today in The Boston Globe. The Globe said Vanguard's error would cause customers to pay more in taxes, while Vanguard contends they will pay less.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/23/world.body_text: **********Charges of abandonment against the Canadian Indian parents of five children who died in a fire have been dropped, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation reported this evening. The case brought national attention to the plight of Indians. **********The couple, Gregory and Agathe Rich, members of the Innu Indian band of Davis Inlet in northern Labrador, had been charged with abandonment for leaving their five children and a nephew alone in a wooden house on a February night in 1992 while they went out drinking with friends. The authorities believe an electric hot plate caused a curtain to catch fire, killing the children. **********A judge in Labrador decided to suspend the charges, ruling that too much time had elapsed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/14/busin.body_text: **********Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc. agreed today to pay $595 million in cash for the Coca-Cola Company's French and Belgian bottling operations. **********The purchase gives Coca-Cola Enterprises, the world's largest Coke bottler, better access to markets where it has greater potential to increase sales. The French drink an average of 71 eight-ounce servings of Coke products a year and the Belgians consume 220 -- far less than the 310 drinks consumed on average in  the United States, the company's largest market by far. **********We've got a lot of growth opportunities there," said Laura Asman, a spokeswoman for Coca-Cola Enterprises. **********In addition to the cash, Coca-Cola Enterprises will assume $320 million in debt for Coca-Cola Beverages S.A., which is wholly owned by Coke, and Coca-Cola  Production S.A. in France and N.V. Coca-Cola Beverages Belgium S.A. **********Coke founded Coca-Cola Enterprises in 1986 and sold a majority stake to the public. It still owns about 44 percent of the stock. **********Coca-Cola Enterprises distributes about 57 percent of Coke's bottle and can volume in the United States and is the sole licensed bottler for Coca-Cola products in the Netherlands. **********The company, which will generate more than 15 percent of unit case sales outside the United States after the purchase, is following Coke's lead in building distribution muscle in the more lucrative, faster-growing markets outside the United States. The move sets the company up to become Coca-Cola's main, or "anchor," bottler in the region. **********Ms. Asman said Coca-Cola Enterprises would consider making more purchases in  Europe, especially in neighboring regions. **********The purchase will add about $1.2 billion to Coca-Cola Enterprises' $6.77 billion in annual sales. The company said the transaction would not affect 1996  earnings. **********The transaction price is slightly more than analysts had expected but still at a lower multiple to pretax earnings than Coca-Cola Enterprises' stock now trades at, Ms. Asman said. **********Shares of Coca-Cola Enterprises rose 62.5 cents today, to $29, on the New York Stock Exchange; shares of Coke rose $1, to $43, adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split on Friday. **********Coca-Cola Enterprises said it would raise money through new debt sales to pay for the bottlers. The company was already heavily leveraged before the purchase, with $4.47 billion in debt.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/18/busin.main_headline: Utility in Settlement With Chase Group

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/18/busin.body_text: **********The Bonneville Power Administration said today that it had reached a $115 million settlement of a lawsuit filed by the Chase Manhattan Bank over the agency's decision last year to cancel its 20-year contract to buy electricity from a half-built power plant in Frederickson, Wash. **********Chase was the lead lender on the 250-megawatt plant, that was being developed by Tenaska Washington Partners 2 of Omaha. Chase sued Bonneville in August in Federal court in Washington, D.C., on behalf of 18 international banks that made construction loans. The settlement represents the amount the Chase consortium had lent to Tenaska for construction plus accrued interest and related expenses. **********The Tenaska group has filed a $1.05 billion claim against Bonneville in the  same court. That dispute is scheduled for arbitration in the fall. Tenaska is a  partnership comprising affiliates of Tenaska Inc., the Montana Power Company, the Illinova Corporation and the KU Energy Corporation. **********The payment will not affect Bonneville's 13 percent rate reduction announced  today because money had been set aside for a settlement, said Dulcy Mahar, a Bonneville spokeswoman. She said the $115 million would be deducted from any future settlement with Tenaska.

For example, when Microsoft Corp.'s 52 percent increase in profits...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/10/your-.body_text: **********NO REVIEW of the American stock market's performance in recent weeks would be complete without a look at the role of high technology stocks in its heart-stopping leaps and plunges. For example, when Microsoft Corp.'s 52 percent increase in profits for its fourth quarter failed to soothe jittery investors, they bailed out in droves, contributing to a fall of 32 points, or almost 3 percent, in the Nasdaq composite index on July 23. **********On the other hand, when the Dow-Jones industrial average leaped 67 points on July 25, roughly half that advance was driven by hectic buying of IBM Corp., as investors rushed into a perceived buying opportunity. **********How is it that high-tech companies have come to wield such a disproportionate effect on the overall performance of the U.S. stock market? **********The answers are both substantive and psychological, say market observers. One reason that high tech carries so much clout, according to David Bostian, chief economist for Herzog, Heine, Geduld, a New York brokerage, is that it has become a driving force in the U.S. economy. "Investors realize that it creates job growth, and growth in the gross domestic product, both in the U.S. and internationally, so they monitor high-tech companies very closely," he said. "When they do well, it makes them feel that everything is OK, but if they come down, that implies a downturn for the overall economy. So when tech stocks got hit in July, that cast a pall over the entire market." **********Fred Hickey, editor of the High Tech Strategist, a New Hampshire-based newsletter, notes that both neophyte investors seeking fast profits in Internet stocks and professional money managers under pressure to produce high returns have made several high-tech names into market leaders. Companies like Microsoft and Intel Corp. "absolutely dominate the trading volume now on Nasdaq," said Mr. Hickey. He added that Micron Technology Inc., a chip maker, often leads IBM on the New York Stock Exchange. **********But both these analysts see trouble ahead. Mr. Bostian noted that prices of Hewlett-Packard Co., the computer maker, and Motorola Inc., the electronics company, fell sharply after recent earnings disappointments reflected slower global demand. **********Mr. Hickey said that growth in personal computer sales in the U.S. has slowed markedly, to 12 percent in the second quarter from 25 percent previously. Though investors are still buying high-tech stocks on each downturn, he said, "each time the decline is deeper and the bullish consensus gets hit a bit harder."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/10/busin.snippet: Funds Watch column on consolidations in mutual fund industry; list (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/10/busin.body_text: **********Give them an inch and they will, of course, want a mile. **********Now that mutual fund managers can use prospectuses to promote their previous track records when they join other companies or set up their own shops, there is a push to  permit adding those records to their advertising, too. **********In mid-August, the Securities and Exchange Commission permitted Elizabeth R. Bramwell, former manager of the Gabelli Growth fund, to continue to use her Gabelli record in the prospectus for her Bramwell Growth fund, which she started when she struck out on her own in 1994. In effect, the S.E.C. was dropping the one-year limit it previously placed on any mention of past performance in a prospectus. **********The National Association of Securities Dealers then weighed in to make sure its members understood that past-performance data could appear only in a fund's prospectus and not in ads. The N.A.S.D. did not issue a formal ruling because Ms. Bramwell's firm is not registered with the agency. But it made clear that portable track records were not to appear in fund advertising. **********Its decision was grounded in previous policy, said R. Clark Hooper, senior vice president of the Office of Disclosure and Investor Protection of  N.A.S.D. Regulation. In several instances, the agency has looked at putting past performance into supplemental sales literature but has been stymied on ''how to make clear to investors what the performance means and, more important, what it doesn't mean,'' Ms. Hooper said. **********As a result, it was relegated to the prospectus, where the accompanying disclosure put the data in context.  The Investment Company Institute, the fund trade group in Washington, gave the arrangement its blessing. **********The pressure, however, appears to be building as more managers switch firms and want to promote their previous records. **********As of the end of October, the N.A.S.D. had received two formal submissions and several informal inquiries about the policy, although it would not identify from whom. In light of this interest, Ms. Hooper said, the agency will reconsider its policy at its next committee meeting, which has not yet been scheduled. **********Likewise, the S.E.C. has been petitioned to take up the matter. **********''Historically, the investment company division staff has taken the position that performance data of other accounts shouldn't be included in stand-alone mutual fund advertising,'' said Jack W. Murphy, associate director and chief counsel in the S.E.C.'s division of investment management. ''However, in the wake of the Bramwell letter, we have been asked to reconsider the issue.'' **********Dividing the Pie **********New England Star Small Cap is the third fund in a series sponsored by New England Funds to be jointly managed by successful managers at several companies outside the firm.  The fund will invest mainly in companies with market capitalizations below $1 billion, as well as in overseas companies and fixed-income securities. Overseas issues are limited to one-quarter of the assets. **********Management responsibilities are divided among four subadvisers, each of whom will receive 25 percent of new cash; redemptions will also be allocated equally. Spreading the money among the four managers, each with a somewhat different investing style, is intended to help reduce risk in small-stock investing. **********The managers are John Wallace of Robertson Stephens; Michael Carmen of Montgomery Asset Management; Steven Reid of Harris Associates, and Christopher Ely, David Smith and Phil Fine of Loomis Sayles. The fund levies a 5.75 percent sales charge. **********The two New England funds that are already being jointly managed are Star Advisers and Star Worldwide. **********New Funds **********The Montgomery Emerging Asia fund is intended to capitalize on long-term economic growth predicted for China, Hong Kong, Singapore, Thailand, India and other Asian markets.  It will not invest in Japan. **********Pioneer First, managed by a Russian subsidiary of the Pioneer Group, in Boston, is the first mutual fund approved for Russians by the regulatory agency there under a pilot program established in November. **********New Manager **********Tim Keefe, former manager of  Federated American Leaders and Capital Appreciation funds, has joined the John Hancock fund group.  He takes over John Hancock Growth and Income from Ben Hock, who now heads equity research for the firm. Mr. Keefe will also lead the team managing John Hancock Special Value. **********New Identities **********Twentieth Century International Emerging Growth has been renamed Twentieth Century International Discovery. In developed markets, it can now own companies with market capitalizations of up to $1 billion, up from $800 million. A cap of $1 billion has been added for companies in  emerging markets. **********Keystone Strategic Development was renamed Keystone Global Resources and Development and will own mostly stocks of companies involved in natural resources and energy. Keystone Fund of the Americas retains its name but will invest at least 65 percent of its assets in Latin American securities and at least 20 percent in securities issued in Canada and the United States. **********In Brief **********The Vanguard Primecap fund reopened to investors on Oct. 31 after closing to new accounts in March 1995. **********The minimum investment in the Benham funds has been increased to $2,500 from $1,000.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/28/world.main_headline: Near Sarajevo, a Quest To Heal War's Hatred
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/28/world.print_headline: Near Sarajevo, a Quest To Heal War's Hatred
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/28/world.body_text: **********Every evening, after walking his beat in this suburb newly transferred from rebel Serbian control, Radovan Zidovic, a police officer for the Bosnian-Croat Federation, drives to a hospital in Sarajevo. He weeps at the bedsides of his daughter and father, who were gravely injured by a Bosnian Serb grenade, and wonders why he spends his days cheerfully greeting his former enemies, offering them his hand and the reassurance that they should stay in their homes. **********"That is what I do, but sometimes I think that I really want them to leave because of what they have done to my family, what they have done to my country," said Mr. Zidovic, scratching at his mustache and pointing to some of the few apartments still occupied by Serbian residents. **********I feel for the old people who are left here and have nothing," he said. "And I know they are innocent of the crimes that have been perpetrated over the  last four years. But my heart still bleeds for my own." **********He added: "It is especially hard for me. I am a Serb. I am here to be a symbol that the Federation wants them to stay." **********Convincing the thousand or so elderly Serbs stuck in Vogosca that they will not be killed in their sleep or harassed during the day has become one of the main tasks for the Federation police officers now making their rounds here. It is a difficult job, because many of the officers find it hard to offer condolences. **********Many of them have watched loved ones killed during their country's 43-month war. Nearly all have lost friends or seen the deadly aftermath of a hit by a Serbian shell. And as they walk among their former enemies, it is sometimes a challenge to hold back from swinging a billy club out of anger or uttering words of retribution. **********"At first I wondered if I had the nerves to do this job," said a fellow officer, Bojan Marjanovic, who is also a Serb, one of the minority who remained  on the Government side during the war. **********"We just have to keep in mind that these are people too," he said. "These are not the war criminals who tried to destroy us." **********Mr. Marjanovic added that he is looking forward to the "liberation" of the suburban town of Grbavica, his former home and where his mother lives. The last  of the five Sarajevo towns scheduled for transfer under the Dayton peace agreement, Grbavica is to come under Federation control on March 19. **********So far, the Federation officers patrolling Vogosca have offered forgiveness and taught the necessity of inclusion. And they have done their job with a professionalism that has surprised not only the foreign journalists who watch their every move, but also the few Serbs who found themselves trapped in the town. **********"When I found out that the Federation was coming on Friday, I started to shake with fear," said Dragan Knezevic, 72, a Serb who immediately began packing up his small apartment into neatly arranged boxes. "But no one would help me move without money and I figured that I could only go if I left all my things. I was on my last box when I decided to stay and give this new time a try." **********He added: "I am not afraid of the Federation anymore. Some of these officers  came to my home yesterday and gave me bread. Then they asked that I stay and this freed my mind." **********Eighty-five Federation policemen, including 30 Serbs and 8 Croats, now patrol the town. All of the officers have at least eight years previous experience, were screened and are monitored by the International Police Task Force. **********Though the new officers were culled from the Bosnian police force and a Bosnian flag hangs outside the new police station, they are called Federation officers in preparation for the new Muslim-Croat republic envisioned in the Dayton accord. **********The shaky alliance between the two groups was preceded by their own bitter 10-month war that ended in February 1994 and has so far been put to little practice. **********The town is populated mainly by former residents making day trips from Sarajevo to gawk at the scenery or see if their old homes are still standing. **********The officers admonish the visitors to watch out for booby-traps and mines, though none have been found. **********Often, they have little work other than directing traffic. **********"Really the cold is the only problem here," Mr. Marjanovic said.  "And of course there are no coffee shops. We cops really like to sit and drink coffee." **********Nearby, a fellow officer ran through a book of traffic signs. "Just brushing  up while I've got the time," he said. **********They expected much worse. Upon arriving last Friday, they clustered around the police building, fingering their pistols and darting their eyes suspiciously over the few Serbs turning up for bus service to Pale, the Bosnian Serb regional headquarters. At first, they made only token efforts at patrols, preferring instead to set up checkpoints in front of the police station. It was  all a no-man's land, mysterious ruins that could hold snipers and mines. And no  one wanted to be killed on the first day on the job. **********"For me it was like I had just joined the force," said Sakilo Omeragic, Mr. Zidovic's Muslim partner. "I was so excited, I couldn't sleep. I don't know what I expected, but I thought it would be more damaged and dangerous." **********He added: "Now that we're here, its great. You don't know what it's like to return to a place like this after four years of war. This is the happiest day of our lives."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/15/busin.snippet: By agreeing to set up a new system of exchange-rate limits and to reinforce discipline against budget deficits, the European Union's top finance officials have taken the most concrete steps yet toward economic and monetary union..The agreement amo...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/15/busin.main_headline: EU Agrees to Form New Currency Grid And Cements EMU
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/15/busin.print_headline: EU Agrees to Form New Currency Grid And Cements EMU
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/15/busin.body_text: **********By agreeing to set up a new system of exchange-rate limits and to reinforce discipline against budget deficits, the European Union's top finance officials have taken the most concrete steps yet toward economic and monetary union. **********The agreement among finance ministers and central bankers at a weekend meeting in Verona, Italy, also represented a clearacknowledgement that a single European currency will significantly curtail the autonomy of the 15 EU governments in handling their economic affairs. **********While many details remain to be worked out in coming months, the officials agreed to grant decisive power over future exchange-rate realignments to the independent head of the planned European central bank. **********They also committed their governments to bringing budget deficits well below the single-currency ceiling of 3 percent of gross domestic product and to seek ways to make that commitment binding. **********By ensuring greater exchange-rate stability and encouraging all 15 governments to stick to the path of low inflation and low deficits, the measures aim to prevent a single currency from dividing the EU between a minority of states entering monetary union in the first wave and those remaining outside. **********"For the general interest, we must create a system that has rights, obligations and advantages for those that are in and those that are out," said Prime Minister Lamberto Dini of Italy, who was the chairman of the meeting Saturday. **********But none of the mechanics discussed at Verona directly addressed the problems of sluggish growth, rising unemployment and high budget deficits that are the main obstacles to a single currency. **********Hans Tietmeyer, president of theBundesbank,acknowledged as much when he said Germany and France needed to fulfill the Maastricht treaty's criteriato launch a single currency on schedule in 1999. **********But Mr. Tietmeyer expressed confidence that growth would lead to recovery in the second half because of low interest rates and the recent fall of EU currencies against the dollar, which makes European goods more competitive. **********Meanwhile, Finance Minister Theo Waigel of Germany, said Germany would not accept any softening of the requirement on budget deficits. "As far as the 3 percent goes, that means three-point-zero percent, there's no question," he said. **********Senior officials of Bonn's ruling coalition met Sunday evening to seek ways to cut public spending by at least 50 billion Deutsche marks ($33.33 billion) in 1997, the year in which countries must hit the single-currency targets. **********Still, the Verona agreement was significant because the potential for a split between participants in monetary union and those outside had loomed as one of the biggest political risks to a single currency. **********The agreement was particularly sweet for French officials, who were criticized for seeking to erect protectionist barriers within the EU last year when they first pressed for a revived currency grid. **********"Six months ago, we were the only ones calling for a new exchange-rate mechanism," Finance Minister Jean Arthuis said. "Now only the British and Swedish are opposed." **********Finance Minister Philippe Maystadt of Belgium said a new mechanism "would send a strong message to financial markets about the willingness to preserve exchange-rate stability in Europe and to extend monetary union as quickly as possible to all EU countries that want to join.'. **********The new mechanism, which EU countries would be encouraged but not obliged to join, would maintain current broad fluctuation bands of plus or minus 15 percent to avoid setting easy targets for currency speculators, officials said. **********But it would allow countries to peg their currencies more closely to the Euro if they keep inflation and deficits under strict control. **********There would be limits to the European central bank's intervention in defense of exchange-rate limits, and the central bank president would have the power to initiate negotiations to realign currencies. **********Those features, advocated strongly by the Bundesbank, are designed to prevent a repeat of the collapse of Europe's old currency grid in 1992, when Britain and Italy held out against a realignment until their currency reserves were exhausted. **********Even Britain's differences with its partners over the mechanism were less than they appeared. **********Chancellor of the Exchequer Kenneth Clarke saidBritain would not participate in the mechanism even though it intended to keep its options open on joining monetary union. **********While most EU officials stressed that two-years' participation in the mechanism was a key Maastricht treaty requirement for joining monetary union, Eddie George, the governor of the Bank of England, dismissedthe idea that Britain would be denied entry if it met the Maastricht budget and inflation criteria and kept the pound steady. **********Many EU officials agreed, saying Britain's commitment to a stable pound was more important that its refusal to re-enter an EU currency grid. **********Finance ministers and central bankers also agreed to strengthen budgetary discipline. Although they stopped short of Mr. Waigel's demand for swift, automatic sanctions for any country exceeding the 3 percent limit, they agreed to explore ways to speed up the penalties spelled out in the Maastricht treaty and to seek a medium-term budget target of "near balance." **********Ministers instructed the European Monetary Institute and the EU monetary committee to present detailed reports on the exchange-rate and budget regimes to EU leaders at their summit meeting June 21-22 in Florence. **********They hope to reach final accords by December. **********"If you believe that monetary union is a gradual process and not a big bang, then Verona is a big step forward," said Mario Draghi, the director-general of the Italian Treasury.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/09/busin.main_headline: Ann Taylor To Buy Rest of Joint Venture
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/09/busin.print_headline: Ann Taylor To Buy Rest of Joint Venture
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/09/busin.body_text: **********In an effort to salvage its ailing principal supplier, Ann Taylor Stores said yesterday that it would buy 100 percent of a joint venture it now shares with Cygne Design Inc., as well as another unit of that company. **********The retailer will buy Cygne's 60 percent interest in the venture, known as CAT, which provided Ann Taylor with about 38 percent of its merchandise last year, and Cygne's Ann Taylor Woven division, a merchandise sourcing unit. **********Ann Taylor said it would pay for the acquisitions with about $36 million worth of its common stock, plus a cash payment to be determined. The cash payment will be equal to the book value of the woven division's inventory and fixed assets. In addition, the retailer will assume some liabilities for both units. **********The purchase will enable Ann Taylor to better micromanage the fashion choices made for its 308 stores. Sales lagged last year as a result of poor merchandise  decisions. Cygne, which has been hurting for quite some time, gets a new lease on life. **********Cygne Design, a private-label and brand-name apparel vendor in New York, has  reported three consecutive quarters of losses, and its trade credit agreement was suspended in November after it failed to make payments. **********Its dealings with Ann Taylor accounted for 54 percent of the company's estimated sales of $431 million for the year ended Feb. 3, and also contributed  to its losses as Ann Taylor's fortunes faltered much of last year. Cygne's shares closed yesterday at $2.375, up 37.5 cents, in Nasdaq trading. **********"Ann Taylor had to buy this company," said Walter Loeb, a retail consultant in New York. "They had to keep their source of supplies intact." **********Sally Frame Kasaks, Ann Taylor's chief executive officer, said in a statement, "The acquisition of CAT and the Ann Taylor Woven division of Cygne is an important step in furthering our strategy of improving our merchandise offerings by more closely integrating the processes of design, planning, merchandising and sourcing." **********Ann Taylor also said yesterday that it would attempt to raise $75 million in  a private placement of convertible preferred securities that would be used to pay down debt. **********Some investors seemed pleased by the plans, which they said gave them comfort about the future of Ann Taylor' supplier, as well as the retailer's liquidity. **********"It makes good business sense," said John Johnson, a co-manager of the Crabbe Huson Special Fund in Portland, Ore., which holds about two million Ann Taylor shares. "It will bring in the value investor who will get paid to wait. I can see in fiscal 1997 this consolidation adding modestly to their earnings." The company's shares closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $17.875, up 87.5 cents.
