https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/03/busin.main_headline: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;Wrapping a Gift? Remember the String
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/03/busin.print_headline: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;Wrapping a Gift? Remember the String
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/03/busin.body_text: **********Q. How can grandparents setting up Uniform Gift to Minors Act accounts for their grandchildren's education make sure the money won't be squandered by divorcing parents? **********A. First of all, thank goodness for all those grandparents without whose generosity thousands of high school seniors would not be going to college next fall. My paternal grandfather was fond of saying that the second best thing about getting old was being able to help the next generation. (The best thing, he felt, was Polident, which enabled him to sing while brushing his teeth.) **********The Uniform Gifts to Minors Act, or UGMA, allows grandparents, parents and others to give a child money, which is usually held in a bank, mutual fund or brokerage firm. The account is in the child's name and carries his or her Social Security number, but is supervised by an adult, known as the custodian. When the child comes of age -- between 18 and 21, depending on the state, although in California it can be delayed to 25 -- he or she gets the goods. **********Generosity isn't necessarily the only motivation for these gifts. Many wealthy parents and grandparents use these accounts to give up to $10,000 each to children every year; the donors pay no taxes on the gifts and, at the same time, they winnow their estates and thus shrink the potential inheritance taxes. Parents often like these accounts because the earnings are often taxed at a lower rate than their own. **********Nevertheless, parents may be doing themselves a disservice by stashing money  in a child's name. When schools determine a student's eligibility for financial  assistance, they consider 35 percent of the holdings in an UGMA to be usable for tuition. For assets held by parents, the figure is 5.6 percent. **********Another caveat: don't put money in an UGMA account if you may need it yourself.  Once the money has been deposited, it cannot be taken back, even to be returned later. **********Which may answer your question. It would be illegal for a parent to use custodial powers to appropriate assets of the account.  If this happens, a donor should hire a lawyer immediately to protect the child's interest and to replace  the custodian. **********This brings up a good point. The custodian doesn't have to be a parent. You can name a lawyer, a financial adviser or a friend. **********A bigger problem with these accounts, however, is the possible immaturity of  the recipients. Many 18-year-olds are not up to handling the windfall. Nor are some 25-year-olds. Yet there are no restrictions once the children come of age,  and UGMA checks can make for a big birthday blast. **********Estate lawyers have many stories of young recipients who put college on hold  while they join a rock band or ride a motorcycle across Asia. One father received a certified letter from a lawyer representing a commune where his daughter had fled; the lawyer demanded that her UGMA funds be transferred there. With $50,000, you can fertilize a lot of organic kohlrabi. **********For such reasons, donors should consider alternatives to these accounts, said Michael Hartz, a partner in the Chicago law firm of Katten, Muchin & Zavis. **********For example, grandparents can hold onto the money and pay the tuition directly to the school, said Terry Savage, author of "New Money Strategies for the 90's" (Harper Business, $14, 1995). The grandparents avoid the gift tax, keep control of the money and can look forward to being fussed over on their birthdays by the grandchildren. If the grandparents are worried that they won't  be around to receive the bills, they can stipulate in their will that a trust fund be set up for the grandchildren, though it may be subject to a generation-skipping tax. **********Other ways to deter untoward use of such gifts include long-term investments  in Treasuries, certificates of deposit or zero-coupon bonds in the child's name. Why? Because early withdrawal can be costly for all of these investments. And under the Uniform Transfers to Minors Act, a broader version of UGMA, you can leave them real estate and works of art -- assets that you cannot put into an UGMA account and are not easily converted into cash. **********Another alternative is a Crummey trust (named for the taxpayer, not the adjective). According to Mr. Hartz, this is the logical choice for a donor who wants to qualify for the $10,000 annual gift-tax exclusion but also desires to keep control over how or when the money is used. The trust donor is not limited  to making the money available at a certain age and can specify the use of the money. **********But Crummey trusts involve some legal time to set up: be prepared to spend $500 to $1,500, depending on how many bells and whistles you want. **********For those planning a more modest gift, say $500, there is another way to delay all or part of it past the commune years: buy into a no-load mutual fund that allows you to set up an irrevocable trust account for the child.  For example, Twentieth Century Giftrust Investors (800 345-2021) invests for long-term growth and requires only that the gift remain in the fund for at least 10 years or until the child reaches the age of majority, whichever is longer. Unlike Crummey trusts, these trusts do not confer control over how money is spent. **********Donors should note that the Twentieth Century fund has different tax consequences than UGMA's. Contributions count against the $600,000 available for the gift and estate tax exemption, and the fund pays taxes annually and at maturity. But the contributions don't count toward the annual $10,000 gift limit, leaving you free to make a separate gift to your grandchild. **********For those who already have UGMA's and worry about their children running amok, Ms. Savage recommends a strategy of "don't ask and don't tell all." Children kept in the dark about the pot of gold awaiting them at the end of the  high-school rainbow are not likely to blab about their good fortunes to friends  or Porsche salesmen. **********"Instead," Ms. Savage advised, "start another, separate account at your local brokerage firm and throw in shares of a mutual fund or whatever so your kids can learn about investing and watch their money grow." **********Envious of all these potentially wealthy college students, I called my mother and asked why she hadn't set up some sort of tuition fund for me. Her side of the family, I was informed, firmly believes that the way I spent my weekends as a child -- trying to win money for college at the Fort Erie, Ontario, race track, close to our home in Buffalo -- best prepares one for the real world. A place where, Mom said, "the odds are always against you and success is the ultimate long shot." **********Questions about investing, careers and personal finance can be sent to Minding Your Business, c/o Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d  Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to yourmind@nytimes.com. Questions can be answered only in the column, not by mail, E-mail or telephone.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/31/busin.main_headline: COMPANY NEWS;DURACELL TO BUY A SOUTH KOREAN BATTERY BRAND
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/31/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;DURACELL TO BUY A SOUTH KOREAN BATTERY BRAND
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/31/busin.body_text: **********Duracell International Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the assets and operations of Sunpower, a South Korean alkaline battery brand, for $115 million. Duracell plans to buy Sunpower's brand-related trademarks and sales and distribution operations from the STC Corporation, a maker of batteries, tape and film products. STC would retain its manufacturing operations and continue to make the batteries, but the batteries would be marketed by Duracell under a multiyear supply agreement. Duracell, which is based in Bethel, Conn., would continue to sell Duracell-brand batteries in Korea.   (Dow Jones)

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/24/busin.main_headline: A Forum on the Tax Deductions for Corporations
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/24/busin.print_headline: A Forum on the Tax Deductions for Corporations
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/24/busin.body_text: **********Tax Reformers, Take Your Mark" (Feb. 11), Reed Abelson's article on the tax  deductions available to corporations that have made expensive mistakes, drew many responses from readers. In general, the letters defended these deductions,  and for a variety of reasons. Some said the breaks were justified because a business cannot be expected to succeed in every project it undertakes. Others said no business would deliberately lose a huge amount of money just to save part of it in taxes. And others contended that the corporate deductions were not different from those available to individual taxpayers. **********To the Editor: **********Obviously, the I.R.S. gets its share of corporate profits, and if a division  of a company has losses, the net income to be taxed is simply lessened. Does anyone really expect a business to hit a home run every time it goes up to bat? **********Risk capital means just that. No business has a franchise in perpetuity; companies must be creative and innovative in order to stay ahead in the fiercely competitive battle. As we all know, nothing ventured, nothing gained. **********If a business never makes a mistake, it may be an indication of overly extreme caution, which could be a death knell to its future. A business must be  judged by its long-term performance, and some of the companies singled out in the article, like McDonald's and Coca-Cola, have enjoyed fabulous records, contributing heavily to tax revenues as well as rewarding their stockholders. **********HAROLD A. SEGALL Manhattan, Feb. 14 **********The writer is senior counsel at Gilbert, Segall & Young.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/22/busin.snippet: Advertising account changes involving companies owned by Viacom Inc noted (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/22/busin.body_text: **********There was account activity yesterday involving companies owned and partly owned by Viacom Inc. **********Paramount Pictures, owned by Viacom, moved responsibilities for buying all national television advertising in the broadcast, cable and syndication media for Paramount film and home-video releases to Televest Inc. in New York, the media services division of the D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles unit of MacManus Group. Those duties had been handled by Ogilvy & Mather New York, owned by WPP Group. Competitive Media Reporting, which tracks advertising spending, reported that Paramount spent $62 million in those media last year. **********Jeff Baskin, a spokesman for Paramount in Los Angeles, confirmed a report of the change in the Daily Fax edition of Advertising Age. Other duties like the creative portion of the account continue in-house. **********And the Sci-Fi Channel, a cable network partly owned by Viacom, began a review on its account, which had been handled on a project basis by Butler, Shine & Stern in Sausalito, Calif., since April 1995. Billings were estimated at $4 million. **********Lisa Galeano, a spokeswoman for the Sci-Fi Channel in New York, said that Richard Roth Associates, a consulting company in Chappaqua, N.Y., had been hired to manage the review, which is in the preliminary stages. A decision is expected in early February, Ms. Galeano said. The Sci-Fi Channel is part of USA Networks, a joint venture of Viacom and MCA Inc., which is controlled by the Seagram Company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/16/busin.main_headline: Viacom in Swap for New York FM Outlet
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/16/busin.print_headline: Viacom in Swap for New York FM Outlet
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/16/busin.body_text: **********Viacom Inc. will become one of New York's largest radio station owners after  it swaps its three Seattle stations for WAXQ-FM in New York in a transaction valued at $90 million. **********Under the agreement announced yesterday, the closely held GAF Corporation will sell the New York station to closely held Entertainment Communications Inc. for $90 million, which in turn will swap it for Viacom's three Seattle stations. **********The transaction gives Viacom, which now owns 12 stations, a second station in one of the most lucrative radio markets. WAXQ is Q-104, which plays "modern rock." The station was formerly WNCN, which played classical music. **********"It's a very savvy deal for Viacom," said Gary Stevens, a radio broker in New Canaan, Conn. **********Viacom is getting a station worth $90 million for three stations that have combined cash flow of around $6 million, Mr. Stevens said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/03/busin.main_headline: INVESTING IT;The Talk of Cyberspace: Is Iomega Losing Its Zip?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/03/busin.print_headline: INVESTING IT;The Talk of Cyberspace: Is Iomega Losing Its Zip?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/03/busin.body_text: **********EVERY investor dreams of getting in on the meteoric rise of a hot stock like  that of the Iomega Corporation, a maker of high-capacity disk drives for computers. The stock could be picked up for about $1 a share early last year, and last week, it traded as high as $20. **********Recently, though, Iomega has wound up with more detractors than perhaps any other company listed on the Nasdaq stock market. Last week, Nasdaq reported that as of mid-February more than 18.1 million shares of Iomega stock had been sold short, a bet that a stock will decline. The huge short position is equivalent to 30 percent of the company's shares. **********Iomega, whose market value is more than $1 billion, is certainly facing its  share of problems. It is having trouble getting enough parts to build its drives and still doesn't have patents on the disk technology, leaving the door open to  competitors. Wall Street is confused about its earnings; more ominously, the company is facing a cash crunch, which a planned debt offering would ease only until the summer. Much of the debate over Iomega's future has taken place not in Wall Street trading rooms, but, according to a prospectus Iomega filed last week with the Securities and Exchange Commission, on "electronic bulletin board postings on America Online and other similar services." **********The debate has gone beyond the normal tug-of-war between buyers and sellers,  to the point where two weeks ago the company postponed an offering of 5.25 million shares of common stock, which could have raised up to $100 million in much-needed cash, because of "confusion and misinformation in the marketplace" regarding the company and the offering. **********Last week, Iomega announced a plan to raise $40 million in an offering of convertible notes -- a plan Iomega apparently hopes will fill its short-term cash needs and quiet some of the debate. **********The remarkable surge in Iomega's share price was sparked by one of the technology industry's most impressive turnarounds. For about a decade, Iomega has been best known for its popular Bernoulli disk drives. Bernoulli boxes, as they are known, overcame the relatively small storage capacity of early personal computers. **********But with leaps in data storage technology, Bernoulli boxes became all but obsolete. Only recently, as data-intensive multimedia programs have gained popularity, have computer users again found their PC storage capacity stretched  to the limit. **********Once again, Iomega has a niche, this time with a new but anthropologically similar line of disk and tape drives, which go by the brand names Zip, Jaz and Ditto. **********Introduced a year ago, the products quickly bolstered Iomega's sales, to $148 million in the fourth quarter of last year from $40 million in the first. The company earned 14 cents a share last year, its first year in the black since 1992. **********Joseph E. Besecker, an analyst for the Emerald Investment Companies, a money  management firm based in Lancaster, Pa., now estimates that Iomega will earn more than $1 a share this year. **********That estimate might be a bit rich. In a prospectus for the debt offering filed last week with the S.E.C., Iomega notes that initial sales of the Zip drive "may be attributable in large part to the novelty of the product and the initial publicity surrounding the introduction of the Zip, and may not be indicative of the long-term demand for the product." **********Also, Iomega has no patent protection for the disk drives or the disks, which can be removed from the computer and carried to other sites, although it has applied for some. That leaves the company wide open to potential competition. **********Mr. Besecker's estimate is nearly double what Hambrecht & Quist estimated earlier this year as it prepared to underwrite Iomega's proposed stock offering, according to people familiar with the estimates. When those estimates  began circulating on Wall Street, short-sellers stepped up their attacks on Iomega's stock. Officials at Hambrecht declined to comment. **********Iomega officials also declined to be interviewed because, according to S.E.C. rules, the company cannot promote itself while preparing for a public offering.  The latest offering is critical to Iomega. Because of sharp increases in accounts receivable and inventories, the $40 million in expected proceeds will be enough to finance Iomega's operations only through June 30; thereafter, "the  company expects to require additional funds to finance its operations," the prospectus states. **********Some of its cash needs might be satisfied by sales growth. Just last week the company announced that Hewlett-Packard will offer Zip drives as an option in its Pavilion line of personal computers later this year. **********But Iomega has a key problem. Industrywide shortages of the integrated circuits that are critical to construction of its drives could limit Iomega's ability to meet demand this year. **********In its prospectus, the company also warns that "investors should not assume fourth quarter of 1995 revenues are necessarily indicative of the revenues to be expected in any future quarter." **********It looks as though some investors are expecting just that. Even assuming that Iomega can replicate the fourth quarter's sales in every quarter of 1996, the company's shares are being valued at more than two times total revenue. At its recent price of $17.125, the stock trades at more than 16 times this year's expected earnings. **********By contrast, when Seagate Technology recently bought Conner Peripherals to create the country's single largest disk drive company, Seagate paid about 0.72  times Conner's sales. Iomega's competitors in the disk drive industry trade at about 12 times this year's expected earnings. **********By those standards, Iomega shares appear due for a pause.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/31/world.main_headline: World News Briefs;Indian Forces Destroy Kashmiri Muslim Shrine
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/31/world.print_headline: World News Briefs;Indian Forces Destroy Kashmiri Muslim Shrine
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/31/world.body_text: **********Indian troops firing grenades and mortars today destroyed the headquarters of the separatist group that had occupied Kashmir's holiest mosque. **********The police in Srinagar said 21 militants were killed, but a spokesman for the state Government in Jammu put the death toll at 16. **********Two adjacent buildings were set on fire outside the compound of the Hazratbal shrine in Srinagar, the center of the Muslim separatist insurrection in Jammu and Kashmir state. A separatist leader, Shabir Siddiqui, was reportedly among the dead. **********The violence broke out after troops demanded that the militants surrender. Six adults and three children walked out of the building before the others opened fire, a police officer in Srinagar said. **********Troops pounded the building with grenades and mortars and raked it with machine guns until it collapsed. **********Indian forces reported no casualties. **********Muslim militants have been fighting for six years to separate Jammu-Kashmir,  India's only Muslim-majority state, from the rest of the predominantly Hindu country. More than 12,000 people have died in the fighting.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/25/world.main_headline: Okinawa Journal;Angry Islanders Dig In For a Battle Over Bases
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/25/world.print_headline: Okinawa Journal;Angry Islanders Dig In For a Battle Over Bases
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/25/world.body_text: **********This verdant little seaside town seems a better site for a beach party than for a battlefield, but local officials are warning that they may have to fight it out with the United States armed forces. **********"In Japanese history, peasants were normally very docile but sometimes they rebelled when they were oppressed and discriminated against too much," said Tokushin Yamauchi, the Mayor of Yomitan, on the southern Japanese island of Okinawa. **********They decided that they just could not put up with their suffering any longer. Well, people in Yomitan are normally very patient, but if the Japanese and American Governments insist on putting a new military facility here, we'll have to rise up in rebellion." **********Just so that no one thinks he is using hyperbole, Mr. Yamauchi says citizens  would first use lawsuits and procedural delays to harass those planning to put in an American military heliport. "But if the Governments insist," he added, "we would have to consider physical resistance." **********Neither American nor Japanese generals seem to be trembling at the prospect.  But Mr. Yamauchi's threat underscores the difficulties facing the American and Japanese Governments as they try to adjust the American military presence in Okinawa. **********Last month Washington and Tokyo observed President Clinton's visit to Japan by announcing a landmark package that would sharply scale back the annoyance level of the American bases in Okinawa, more than almost anybody had imagined they would. One-fifth of the land taken up by the bases would be returned to Japan. **********But the return of some bases was conditioned on their functions being moved to existing bases elsewhere. The heliport, for example, may be moved near Yomitan, and so Mr. Yamauchi and the other citizens of towns like Yomitan are doing their best to block the deal. **********While here in sun-drenched Okinawa many people are less than delighted with the package, the deal seems to have had its intended effect on the Japanese-American relationship as a whole. Polls show rising support for the military partnership between the two countries, and many Japanese seem to have concluded that America made a good-faith effort to resolve the problems on Okinawa and that not much more needs to be done. **********That is a striking turnaround from the mood last fall, after the rape of a sixth-grade Okinawan girl by three American servicemen. At that time, as Ambassador Walter F. Mondale noted recently, "the whole security relationship was in question." **********"The rape triggered a long overdue debate in Japan about whether the alliance was necessary following the end of the cold war," Mr. Mondale said. "As the debate went on, the answer came in the affirmative, stronger than ever. So I believe there's some greater depth underpinning this alliance as a result of that debate." **********The agreement to return some American bases has also strengthened the position of Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, in that he has been given credit for demanding that Americans pay attention to the Okinawans. But in fact officials say the crucial figure in pushing for a less intrusive Japanese presence was not Mr. Hashimoto but Defense Secretary William J. Perry. **********As a young serviceman, Mr. Perry traveled throughout Okinawa to survey the island. Throughout the negotiations over the bases, he reportedly showed great sympathy -- sometimes more than Japanese counterparts from Tokyo -- for islanders who have to live with the noise and inconvenience of bases next door. **********Japanese officials agree with Mr. Mondale that the summit meeting last month, plus recent Chinese and North Korean military moves that worried some Japanese, nurtured a new consensus in Japan about the need for American bases. Kiichi Miyazawa, a former Prime Minister, said the base-reduction package "showed the American Government's sincerity." **********Yet while the American announcement about base reductions has helped defuse a crisis over the security alliance, it is not clear that the plans will really be put into effect.  The problem is that nearly all the cutbacks on bases were conditioned on functions being moved elsewhere -- and no other place wants to accept them. **********The centerpiece of the package was the return of Futenma, an air base in the  middle of the city of Ginowan. The United States said it would return Futenma in five to seven years, after its functions had been moved elsewhere in Okinawa. **********The informal plans are for the heliport now at Futenma to be moved to the Yomitan area and for other functions to be moved to Kadena, on the site of an existing base. But now, with Mr. Yamauchi in Yomitan threatening an insurrection and many local citizens outraged, the return of Futenma is looking more doubtful. **********Faced with much opposition, it might be in the interests of the Japanese and  American Governments to let the timetable slip and stick with the existing bases rather than move troops to towns that refuse to have them. The opposition to the bases, though aggravated by the rape last year, goes much deeper. **********In the town of Kadena, where 83 percent of the city's land is taken up by a huge air base, residents compare their own cramped quarters with the American military's spacious green lawns and golf course -- and then their irritation grows when their windows rattle each time a jet flies low over their home for a  landing or takeoff. **********"The residents of Kadena have suffered from this air base for 50 years," Tokujitsu Miyagi, the Mayor of Kadena, said in his office (with double-glazed windows) as helicopters roared over the base a few hundred yards away. **********"So we can't tolerate any extra activities at this base," he added, "and we can't compromise on that."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/19/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;The country's biggest brewer renews its defense of that position.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/19/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;The country's biggest brewer renews its defense of that position.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/19/busin.body_text: **********ANHEUSER-BUSCH is seeking to regain momentum in the beer wars by undertaking  several marketing initiatives. **********For one thing, Anheuser-Busch, the beer marketing unit of the Anheuser-Busch  Companies, is returning to Times Square with an oversized neon sign promoting its flagship Budweiser brand. And the company has expanded its relationship with Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco by designating that agency  to produce two unconventional corporate and product campaigns. **********There is also speculation about further changes on the agency front. The Leap Partnership in Chicago, which until recently worked for the Miller Brewing  Company -- Anheuser-Busch's principal rival -- has hired a former Anheuser-Busch marketing executive. **********The steps come as Anheuser-Busch continues to hold a commanding lead in the American beer market of 44.1 percent, according to the Beer Marketer's Insights  newsletter, compared with 22.6 percent for No. 2 Miller, which is owned by the Philip Morris Companies. **********But Miller has lately been the busier of the two brewers, introducing a premium-priced brand bearing the Miller name, which is meant to battle Budweiser, as well as sponsoring its first image campaign for the Plank Road Brewery, which markets smaller specialty Miller brands like Red Dog and Icehouse. **********"Anheuser-Busch's plans for 1996 seem extremely ambitious," said Benj Steinman, president of Beer Marketer's Insights in West Nyack, N.Y. "And they're throwing a lot of money into it, too." Anheuser-Busch will spend an estimated $600 million on advertising this year, as its parent rededicates itself to core operatons like brewing after leaving fields like snacks and baked goods. **********In Times Square, Anheuser-Busch has signed a multiyear contract for the Budweiser sign, of a type known in the outdoor advertising industry as spectaculars for their gaudy displays. Terms were not disclosed; typical leases  run from $350,000 to $1.5 million annually in addition to construction costs that can total $1 million or more. **********The Budweiser sign, 40 feet wide by 70 feet high, is scheduled to appear by the fall on the north face of One Times Square -- the building that plays host to the annual ball-drop on New Year's Eve -- directly above the Sony Jumbotron screen. **********"We've tried to use outdoor advertising more impactfully," Tony Ponturo, president of the Busch Media Group in St. Louis, the Anheuser-Busch unit that handles media planning and buying, said yesterday. "Times Square is a place where you can make a dramatic statement." **********Tom Turner, vice president at Van Wagner Communications in New York, the advertising representative for One Times Square, said: "This is a great marketing opportunity. Our basic emphasis was, 'You're the king of beers and it's time to have you in the most royal of settings.' " **********Old photographs of Times Square show Budweiser signs on various sites from the 1930's through the 1950's. One photo depicts a sign above 1482-90 Broadway at 43d Street -- where Calvin Klein billboards appear today and across from the  site of the new spectacular. **********Anheuser-Busch is consulting with the Budweiser agency, DDB Needham Chicago,  on designs for the sign, Mr. Ponturo said, adding that a temporary sign in vinyl would fill the space beginning in April. **********Turning to the campaigns being created by Goodby, Silverstein, which like DDB Needham Chicago is owned by the Omnicom Group, they are expected to begin in the next month, said August Busch 4th, vice president for brand management at Anheuser-Busch. Billings are not being disclosed. **********One is a humorous campaign, carrying the theme "It'd be weird without beer,"  that promotes beer as a beverage for good times. Rather than pitching specific brands, it is billed as "brought to you by the brewmasters at Anheuser-Busch." **********Anheuser-Busch had sought to involve Miller in the campaign, Mr. Busch said,  under an industry sponsorship. Miller "was very interested," he added, but a joint venture could not be worked out. **********Gina Shaffer, a spokeswoman for Miller in Milwaukee, said: "Anheuser-Busch did come to us and we did seriously consider the opportunity. We definitely support their efforts but unfortunately our time-lines didn't coincide, so we couldn't do it this time around." **********Mr. Busch said the other campaign by Goodby, Silverstein would introduce "an  eccentric delivery-driver-salesman named Gus" who discusses beer quality; in August, the ads will segue into promoting new freshness dating on cans and bottles of Budweiser, Bud Light and Bud Ice beers. **********Goodby, Silverstein has worked for Anheuser-Busch since August on Bud Ice. Mr. Busch praised the agency's offbeat commercials, which feature a mysterious penguin; one ran during Super Bowl XXX and two more began appearing last week. **********The speculation about Leap was fueled by word that Thomas R. Sharbaugh, who in 16 years at Anheuser-Busch held posts like vice president for brand management, is joining the agency as president. Mr. Sharbaugh, 51, comes to Leap from Sears, Roebuck & Company in Chicago, where he held advertising and marketing positions; he succeeds Frederick Smith, 41, a partner who was named to the new post of chief operating officer. **********Leap was formed in 1993 by executives who had worked at DDB Needham Chicago on Anheuser-Busch brands like Bud Light. The next year, Miller hired Leap to handle projects and later awarded the agency the Lite Ice account. When Leap unexpectedly resigned its Miller assignments in December, billings were estimated at $30 million. **********Beth Heitzman, a creative partner at Leap, said Mr. Sharbaugh's hiring was not an effort to land Anheuser-Busch as a client. The Delaney Report newsletter  reported last week that Leap had resigned Miller to work for Anheuser-Busch.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/18/world.main_headline: Serb Stands Firm in Face of U.S. Effort to Oust Karadzic
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/18/world.print_headline: Serb Stands Firm in Face of U.S. Effort to Oust Karadzic
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/18/world.body_text: **********A round of high-profile American talks to persuade President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia to remove the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, from power in Bosnia ended without progress today, the special United States envoy to the Balkans, Richard C. Holbrooke, said. **********After four hours of talks with Mr. Milosevic, the man whom Mr. Holbrooke persuaded to sign the Dayton peace accords last fall, the envoy left for Zagreb  to meet with the Croatian President, Franjo Tudjman, and said he would return here on Thursday. **********Diplomats said Mr. Holbrooke had threatened to reimpose sanctions on the battered Serbian economy if Mr. Milosevic did not bring about the removal of Dr. Karadzic as head of the biggest political party in the Serbian portion of Bosnia, and his immediate departure from Bosnia. **********Under the Dayton accord, Dr. Karadzic, who is under international indictment  for war crimes, is supposed to be arrested and handed to the tribunal in the Hague. But American officials are now eager, at a minimum, to remove Dr. Karadzic from power in Bosnia well before the national elections are held there  on Sept. 14. **********Mr. Holbrooke appears to be facing an informal Friday deadline for Dr. Karadzic's resignation from his post as party chief, at least. On Monday, Western officials delayed the official start of campaigning for the Bosnian elections until Friday to allow time for his removal, and said they would not allow Dr. Karadzic's powerful party to take part if he remains in office. **********Unwilling to risk provoking retaliation by using NATO troops to arrest Dr. Karadzic, Western countries have threatened renewed economic sanctions against Belgrade, which is believed to have the ability to force Dr. Karadzic out. This  threat may be Mr. Holbrooke's strongest lever as he negotiates with Mr. Milosevic here. **********But diplomats and economic analysts wondered how seriously Mr. Milosevic would take the threat. **********A Western diplomat here said Mr. Milosevic held a "healthy skepticism" about  whether the major powers, who are divided over the question, would quickly organize effective sanctions like a ban on trade. **********Economists also questioned whether Mr. Milosevic, a skilled political poker player, would be influenced by the economic threats or rewards Mr. Holbrooke can offer. **********United Nations sanctions against Serbia were suspended after the Dayton accord but can be reimposed for noncompliance with the treaty.  On the positive  side, Mr. Holbrooke can offer to formally end the sanctions, lifting the cloud of uncertainty that might deter international investors. **********Since the suspension of sanctions last December, there has been little improvement in the Serbian economy, largely because of the determination of Mr.  Milosevic, a former Communist, to keep state controls and his refusal to allow privatization. **********But daily life has regained a modicum of normality. Families no longer hoard  oil, sugar and other foodstuffs and gasoline, previously sold on the roadside by black marketeers, is more easily available. **********Thus, initially, the reimposition of sanctions would mainly have a negative psychological impact on the country, economists said. **********"If we have sanctions again, we will have a really bad situation," said Tomislav Popovic, director of the Institute of Economic Sciences in Belgrade, and a critic of the government's policies. "But we have developed survival mechanisms and the possibility to live under many limitations." **********In the longer term, however, new sanctions would be "catastrophic," Mr. Popovic said. The once healthy but now decrepit industrial base -- 70 percent of factory machinery is useless because of the effect of three years of sanctions -- would decay further, he said. **********Western diplomats said that one of Mr. Holbrooke's strongest positive incentives would be allowing Serbia to re-enter international organizations, including the International Monetary Fund, the World Trade Organization and the  United Nations.  But a Serbian economist at the Vienna Institute for Comparative Economic Studies, Vladimir Gligorov, said that because state monopolies were enriching Mr. Milosevic's political cronies, membership in the I.M.F. and the World Bank would not be that attractive at the moment. **********"They are not in a great hurry about that because they are not ready to accept the conditions the I.M.F. would put on Serbia," Mr. Gligorov said. **********To gain I.M.F. support Mr. Milosevic would have to agree to politically unpalatable policies, like reducing the deficit, now estimated at between 10 and 20 percent of gross domestic product, and slashing subsidies to industry. **********Politically, Mr. Milosevic seems to have little to lose by ousting Dr. Karadzic and may even gain. With Dr. Karadzic out of the way, for example, Mr. Milosevic's Socialist Party would have a better chance of winning seats in the Bosnian elections. **********"We are actually asking Milosevic to do something that will help him in the election but Milosevic has set it up so cleverly we have to grease his palm to get him to do it," one diplomat said. **********Should he choose to act, Mr. Milosevic has plenty of economic and political leverage over Dr. Karadzic, said Serbian economists who described the Serbian-held region of Bosnia as a virtual colony of Belgrade. **********The Bosnian Serb police are heavily infiltrated by people loyal to the Serbian leader, they said. Almost all of Serbian-held Bosnia's food and industrial products come from Serbia and the Bosnian Serb military is completely dependant on the Yugoslav national army, run by Mr. Milosevic. **********Further, Mr. Milosevic could, if he wanted to, choke off the profitable smuggling businesses that many Bosnian Serb leaders run through Serbia. **********White House officials in Washington, mindful that President Clinton faces election in November, sent Mr. Holbrooke on his mission in the hope that the Bosnian elections can proceed smoothly, avoiding a collapse of the Dayton peace  effort. However, they say they feel little domestic political pressure to take military risks to arrest Dr. Karadzic. **********The expected Republican nominee, Bob Dole, attacked the President's approach  this week in response to questions. **********Referring to the continued power of Dr. Karadzic and the Bosnian Serb military leader General Ratko Mladic, who is also under indictment for war crimes, Mr. Dole said: **********"All we've heard from the Administration are empty threats, not even the minimal action of reimposing sanctions."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/13/busin.snippet: Labor Department report shows inflation fundamentally remained in check in August, even though hefty increases for food and energy drove producer prices up three-tenths of 1 percent, second-biggest rise this year; Labor Department says first-time ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/13/busin.main_headline: August Producer Price Report Shows Inflation in Check
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/13/busin.print_headline: August Producer Price Report Shows Inflation in Check
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/13/busin.body_text: **********Inflation fundamentally remained in check last month, even though hefty increases for food and energy drove producer prices up three-tenths of 1 percent in August, the second-biggest rise this year, a Labor Department report showed today. **********Economists and the securities markets largely disregarded these two erratic sectors and dwelled instead on a decline in the rest of the Producer Price Index for finished goods. That, they said, provided fresh reassurance that inflation was not a threat. **********''The core P.P.I. numbers look fabulous,'' said Michael L. Penzer, a senior economist at the Bank of America. **********The markets also welcomed the department's report this morning that first-time claims for unemployment benefits climbed 21,000 in the week ended Sept. 7, more than offsetting the preceding week's decline. **********Bond prices gained across the board, and the stock market posted a moderate advance as operators braced for publication on Friday of figures on consumer prices and retail sales for August. **********If today's figures did anything to shift the odds about whether Federal Reserve policy makers would decide to push up interest rates at their meeting the week after next, it was probably in the direction of standing fast, analysts said. But most appeared to hold a belief that the Fed would raise short-term interest rates by a minimal amount to try to keep an economy that has been expanding too rapidly from generating faster inflation. **********''We still expect the Fed to tighten policy by 25 basis points at the Sept. 24th Federal Open Market Committee meeting,'' Bruce Steinberg and Cheryl Katz of Merrill Lynch told clients today. ''However, that is an extremely close call, and the P.P.I. report certainly supplies a rationale to hold policy steady.'' **********Although the core finished-goods index eased just one-tenth of 1 percent, the consensus forecast had been for a slight rise. Moreover, prices of the goods at the intermediate and crude stages of production were also well behaved -- each up two-tenths of 1 percent over all and up one-tenth of 1 percent excluding the volatile food and energy components over which Federal Reserve influence, in any event, is scant. **********''There is simply no inflation in the pipeline,'' declared analysts at Macroeconomic Advisers, a St. Louis consultant, pointing to actual deflation in the core intermediate and crude indexes since late last year. **********On the other hand, while core finished-goods inflation was being halved, to 1.4 percent, over the latest 12 months, the finished goods index as a whole was rising nearly a point, to a 3 percent year-over-year rate in August. **********''Unfortunately, the run-ups in food and energy prices coincided and will likely show up in broader measures of inflation about the same time the increase in the minimum wage does,'' Macroeconomic Advisers said. The Federal minimum rises 50 cents an hour, to $4.75, on Oct. 1. **********Prices of finished foods advanced 1 percent in August, with pork prices leaping 8.7 percent. Fresh fruits and melons, eggs for fresh use and shortening and cooking oils also turned up after July declines. Fresh and dry vegetables, however, dropped 11.9 percent, and fish and young chickens also turned down. **********Prices obtained by energy producers climbed seven-tenths of 1 percent after a modestly larger July decline, with gasoline a major contributor. Residential electric power and lubricants also moved up. Residential natural gas and heating oil rose less than in July. **********Elsewhere, price increases for paper products, alcoholic beverages, tires, floor coverings, sporting goods and newspaper circulation were offset by declines for prescription drugs, passenger cars, books, apparel and light trucks, the department reported. Producers of capital equipment saw prices they receive edge down one-tenth of 1 percent. **********Among intermediate goods, durable items like aluminum mill shapes used in manufacturing fell six-tenths of 1 percent following a nine-tenths of 1 percent decline in July. Nondurables like organic chemicals used in factories posted a three-tenths of 1 percent increase in August, reversing a larger July decline. **********The index for all domestic manufacturing, including petroleum refining, advanced two-tenths of 1 percent after showing no change in July. **********The department's report on jobless claims, which analysts viewed with more than the usual caution because of the difficulty of adjusting for the Labor Day holiday, found 338,000 workers applying for new benefits. This compared with an exceptionally low 317,000 for the week ended Aug. 31 and lifted the four-week moving average to 327,750, a rise of 4,250.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/01/busin.snippet: Pres Clinton will permit American computer companies to export more powerful data-scrambling software, but only if they establish system that will enable keys to code to be obtained by law enforcement officials with a court warrant; American compu...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/01/busin.main_headline: Accord Near On Computer Secruity Codes
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/01/busin.print_headline: Accord Near On Computer Secruity Codes
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/01/busin.body_text: **********After several years of debate between the computer industry and American intelligence agencies, President Clinton has decided to permit American computer companies to export more powerful data-scrambling software but only if they establish a system that will enable keys to the code to be obtained by law enforcement officials with a court warrant. **********Administration officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said Mr. Clinton reached his decision late last week and that Vice President Al Gore would announce it on Wednesday or Thursday. **********Several big computer companies, led by the I.B.M., have agreed to the new system, but many others, which have opposed past proposals by the Administration for data-scrambling policies, are likely to object. **********Many American computer and software executives have long argued that United States export controls on the most sophisticated data-privacy technology put American industry at a disadvantage versus products sold by their foreign competitors. **********But the Clinton White House, like previous Administrations, citing national security issues and fears of foreign terrorists or criminals, is loath to permit the export of some of the most powerful data-scrambling software. The reason has chiefly been that intelligence agencies feared such equipment would be used by foreign terrorists, drug cartels and other criminals to hide transactions and communications. **********Now, in a compromise, according to two senior officials in the Administration who have been deeply involved in the new policy, American companies will be permitted on Jan. 1 to export software that encrypts, or scrambles, data using ''keys'' -- lengthy numeric codes -- that are up to 56 bits long. Until now, companies have been prohibited from selling products abroad that have keys longer than 40 bits. **********Mr. Clinton has also decided to move the authority for exporting the encryption software from the State Department, which has had export-licensing authority because the technology has been classified as munitions, to the Commerce Department, which controls the export of products that have both commercial and military use. Industry officials have long urged that change, betting the Commerce Department would be more inclined to give a higher priority to American competitive interests. **********But starting in two years, American companies choosing to export  the more sophisticated software would have to set up what the industry is calling a ''key recovery'' system. That system would enable intelligence officials and law enforcement agents, armed with court warrants, to go through a lengthy multistep process that would give them the mathematical key to decoding  scrambled communications. **********The approach replaces the Administration's earlier proposed ''key escrow'' system in which the Government would have been the repository of the numeric keys -- leading to fears of potential Government abuse, or a reluctance by legitimate foreign users to buy the software. **********Under the new plan, the keys may be held by third-party companies. And large institutions, like banks, may be allowed to hold their keys in escrow -- assuming they pass some kind of Government certification. **********Still, the success of the system will depend on large part on the Administration's efforts to persuade other countries to adopt the same ''key recovery'' system, allowing their intelligence agencies and justice systems to cooperate in trailing criminals across national borders. But Mr. Clinton's aides acknowledged today that this process has just begun, and so far only England and France have expressed much enthusiasm. **********''It is going to take a while to persuade people that their data is safe under this system, that it protects privacy, and yet that we can use the system to trace terrorists or drug dealers,'' one senior Administration official said. **********Officials at I.B.M., which is expected to announce on Wednesday the creation of an industry consortium to aid in establishing the ''key recovery'' system, said today that no single entity would hold the entire key. **********Instead, it will be divided up across several companies that would handle any given message, much the way the launching officials in nuclear missile silos each had only part of the key instructions needed to begin a nuclear attack. **********If the C.I.A., for example, obtained a court order to decode a message, it would have to go to several groups with its warrant to piece together the key. **********''We believe that this solves the biggest weak point in the previous plans, where one entity held the key,'' said an I.B.M. official familiar with the company's announcement. **********But these steps are not likely to silence all the critics. **********''There is still a perception that the U.S. is trying to extend its intelligence capability by setting standards around the world,'' said Marc Rotenberg, director of the Electronic Privacy Information Center. **********There are other potential holes in the system. Customers in the United States will be free to buy encryption software of any complexity -- as they can today -- with keys that are much longer than 56 bits and are nearly impossible to break. That means terrorist groups or drug dealers could still buy such software and sneak it out of the country, or even transmit it over computer networks. **********''There is nothing we can do about bright students or Joe Terrorist who use sophisticated encryption systems to communicate with each other,'' one senior administration official said. ''But when they brush up against legitimate groups, especially banks,'' the official said, ''then they are more likely to be dealing with a system'' where law enforcement could use the key recovery system to decode the communications. **********On Capitol Hill, several bills had been pending that would lift all export controls on encryption software, but the legislation did not move as the current session of Congress wound down. In Congressional testimony last week, Jamie S. Gorelick, Deputy Attorney General, said lifting all export controls would ''undermine our leadership role in fighting international crime and damage our own national security insterests.''

The account, with billings estimated at $20 million,  has been handled by J. Walter Thompson New York for the last eight years. **********"We're at a point where it's appropriate for us to evaluate our marketing approaches," Simon J. Rothon, executive vice president at Van den Bergh in Trumbull, Conn., said in confirming a report this week in Adweek. Trade publications speculated last year that Thompson New York's hold on the account might be loosening. **********Mr. Rothon said Thompson New York, which is owned by the WPP Group, would participate in the review along with two other Unilever roster shops, both based in New York: Ammirati & Puris/Lintas, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, and Ogilvy & Mather, also owned by WPP. The Chicken Tonight line of simmer sauces at Thompson New York, and the Five Brothers line of pasta sauces at Ogilvy New York, will be excluded from the review, Mr. Rothon said, adding that a decision was expected in a month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/02/news/.main_headline: American Topics : 3-D Images, Without Funny Glasses
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/02/news/.print_headline: American Topics : 3-D Images, Without Funny Glasses
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/02/news/.body_text: **********A researcher at Stanford University has developed a system that will allow people to view three-dimensional color images without the cardboard glasses that were a fad in the 1950s. **********The system was developed by Elizabeth Downing, a graduate student who spent eight years using donated lasers and borrowed lab space in pursuit of what she called "a crazy idea." The technique has potential uses ranging from air traffic control displays to medical diagnostic viewers for surgeons. **********Ms. Downing uses two computer-controlled infrared lasers to project 3-D pictures in a cube of laminated glass, reports the Los Angeles Times. The energy generated where the invisible beams intersect makes a point of the glass glow. By varying the chemistry of the glass, designers can generate lights of different colors. **********Guy Marlor, a physicist who has seen a prototype, said, "You can walk around the darn thing and see a true 3-D image." That, he added, is "the stuff of 'star wars.' "

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/14/busin.main_headline: MUTUAL FUNDS;Buy Britain! Sell Sweden! Hold Hong Kong!
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/14/busin.print_headline: MUTUAL FUNDS;Buy Britain! Sell Sweden! Hold Hong Kong!
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/14/busin.body_text: **********WANT to bet on a recovering economy in another country? Think Germany will soon cut interest rates and drive up that country's stock market? Some new investments make it particularly easy to speculate on just such matters. **********The American and the New York stock exchanges recently introduced stock index products for several countries. The issues, which trade like stocks, let investors buy the bulk of a foreign market in one fell swoop, in much the same way as a Standard & Poor's 500 index fund allows one to own most of the United States market. **********This is the simplest and most convenient way for most Americans to invest abroad," said Jim Rogers, the author of "Investment Biker" and a financial adviser. "You can tell your broker, 'Instead of buying me I.B.M., buy me Germany or Australia.' " **********Not that it was impossible to buy a fund specializing in these areas before.  But the choices were mostly closed-end funds, which issue a fixed number of shares and often trade at a discount or a premium to their underlying stock prices. Most closed-end country funds do not track an index but are actively managed, meaning they are run by stock pickers who aim to do better than the broad market. **********Along with closed-end funds, some open-end mutual funds specialize in specific countries, but most of those are also actively managed. Open-end funds  are priced once a day and can be bought or sold at their net asset values. Among the biggest managers of these funds is Wright Investors' Service, in Bridgeport, Conn., which has nine actively managed open-end country funds. "Our objective is to outperform," said Peter Donovan, chairman of Wright, adding that investors will choose based on performance. "If the index outperforms, they'll buy that."  Index funds aim to replicate the performance of the broad market by buying all the shares in a stock index and then keeping their expenses low. Only a few foreign funds, including the Vanguard International Equity Index European, now use indexing. Given how Americans have flocked to the concept of index investing at home, the new country index investments -- really a cross between open-end and closed-end funds -- are likely to attract a fair share of fans. World Equity Benchmark Shares, or WEBS, made their debut in March on the American Stock Exchange, and come in 17 varieties, each based on a different Morgan Stanley Capital International index. Country Baskets Index Funds, listed  on the New York Stock Exchange, come in nine versions, including one for the United States, and are based on Financial Times/Standard & Poor's AWI indexes. Most of the countries covered have relatively large, stable stock markets. You won't find Turkey or Israel in either group -- at least not yet. **********"This is the first time you can easily buy an index fund for most of these countries," said Gregg Wolper, who specializes in closed-end funds at Morningstar Inc., the fund tracking firm in Chicago. "Whether that's good or not remains to be seen. It's very possible you could do just as good or better with  a closed-end fund." **********The biggest impact could well be on the closed-end fund market, which has been in the doldrums, with only a handful of new issues in the last year. **********"Since the WEBS and country baskets started, discounts on some closed-end funds have widened," said Thomas Herzfeld, who specializes in closed-end fund investing and is president of an advisory firm bearing his name in Miami. The discount on the Germany Fund has increased to 18 percent from 11 percent in January, he said, and the discount on the Scudder New Europe Fund, which has holdings in France, Germany and the Netherlands, has grown to 20 percent from 10 percent at the beginning of the year. "The result is that closed-end funds are currently cheap," Mr. Herzfeld said, "compared to WEBS and country baskets." Investors could reap a nice profit if the price of the closed-end funds moved closer to their underlying values and perhaps a windfall if the funds ever decided to convert to open-end status, issuing new shares. **********As an example, look at the Germany fund, a closed-end fund, and the new indexed Germany products. The portfolios are similar. "If the discount narrows,  you'll make a lot more money buying the closed-end Germany Fund," said Mr. Wolper of Morningstar. There is no guarantee, however, that a discount will disappear over time. **********Some investors have long treated closed-end country funds as something akin to a broad market basket. That's not always the case. Even portfolios with similar holdings may have weighted the stocks differently. At the end of January, the Mexico index for WEBS consisted of 41 stocks, with Telefonos de Mexico at 28.2 percent. The Wright-Equifund Mexico, by contrast, had just 5.5 percent in Telmex at the end of March. **********The choice between actively managed funds and index funds is a basic one for  investors. Index funds have proved particularly useful for buying large-company  stocks in the very efficient stock market in the United States. The markets overseas may not be as efficient because of different accounting rules and difficulties in getting access to information. **********For these reasons and others -- like a desire to buy a fund that hedges against currency risk or one that moves into cash in times of political uncertainty -- many investors are willing to pay more for actively managed funds. Average annual expenses on international stock funds are 1.8 percent of assets, versus about 1 percent for WEBS and country baskets. Other costs to consider are brokerage commissions, which apply to WEBS, country baskets and closed-end funds, and sales charges, levied on many international mutual funds. **********"The indexes are a low-cost alternative," said George Murnaghan, vice president of Rowe-Price Fleming International, which runs $23 billion in actively managed international funds for T. Rowe Price. "But an investor may not want to have exposure to certain things in an index. They may want to skew their portfolio away from certain companies, like banks in Japan." **********Financial advisers generally urge small investors to start with a foreign fund that invests in many nations. **********"The single worst investment you can make is in a single-country fund, especially in emerging markets, which are highly volatile and high risk," said Frank A. Fernandez, chief executive of Global Emerging Market Advisors L.P., of  New York, a specialist in diversified funds. "And the toughest investment decision to make is 'top down' by country. It's easier to pick individual stocks in individual markets than to follow the political, economic and cultural events that can affect a single-country market." **********STILL, some people want to speculate -- at least with a small part of a portfolio -- with a single-country fund. **********And large investors may find the products particularly appealing. Money managers and fund companies may buy the country baskets and WEBS for their mutual fund portfolios. One appeal for anyone investing at least $450,000 is the possibility of getting out of WEBS or country baskets by taking the underlying stocks instead of cash. Such redemptions, granted at the issuer's discretion, allow investors to time their gains and losses on specific stocks. **********Sophisticated investors many also use the index products for arbitrage, taking advantage of temporary discrepancies in markets. For example, they could  sell the index fund short -- a bet that its price will fall -- during New York trading hours and then buy the underlying shares abroad when that market opens if the price indeed falls. They would pocket the difference as a profit. Country baskets can already be sold short when the price is going down; WEBS are seeking authorization to do so. Shorting is rarely possible with funds. **********"I think the new indexes will make the markets more efficient," said Gary Evans, senior strategist for fixed income in emerging markets at Lehman Brothers. **********Investors in foreign countries may clamor for the new products as well. "You  can't buy index funds in most countries of the world," said Mr. Rogers, the investment adviser, "so I suspect these funds also will be a way for foreigners  to invest in their own markets."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/12/world.main_headline: Japanese Try to Reach 20 Trapped in a Road Tunnel
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/12/world.print_headline: Japanese Try to Reach 20 Trapped in a Road Tunnel
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/12/world.body_text: **********Rescue workers blasted the side of a mountain with dynamite today in an unsuccessful attempt to reach some 20 people trapped in a collapsed highway tunnel. They said they would try again. **********A giant slab of rock, about the size of a 20-story office building, had peeled off the mountain and crashed through the tunnel roof early Saturday, apparently crushing a bus carrying people, including a group of teen-agers, to nearby Sapporo for an annual snow festival. **********Hopes were fading that anyone would be found alive. In addition to the bus,  officials said, it is believed that one car was trapped under the collapsed tunnel, about 550 miles north of Tokyo on Japan's northern island of Hokkaido. **********A second blasting attempt planned for Monday was delayed while engineers rearranged the charges. **********Rescuers had reached as far as the front bumper of the mangled bus early today, but there were no signs of life. Officials say they believe that 19 people were on board, including the driver, and that one person was in the car. **********In an attempt to clear away the bulk of the large oblong boulder, officials planted 550 pounds of dynamite in 21 places on it, hoping that the topmost part  of the slab would topple into the sea. **********The boulder is about 70 yards tall and 40 yards wide, and officials estimate  that it weighs about 50,000 tons. **********But the blasts only crumpled the lower part of the rock into dust, leaving the rest of it slightly lower but still upright. The rock appeared to be directly on top of the bus. **********More than half of those aboard the bus were from this fishing village, which  has a population under 5,000. **********Anguished family members kept a vigil as snow swirled around the opening of the tunnel and the temperature dropped to 23 degrees. **********"They haven't told us anything," said Tetsuo Honma, whose son, 17, was among  the teen-agers in the bus and who spent the night near the mouth of the tunnel waiting for news. **********Fearing that any survivors would die from cold, several family members grew angry at the pace of rescue efforts and shouted at at police to hurry. **********Rescuers had milled around the site for almost 11 hours after the accident while officials discussed how to get through the rubble without setting off another collapse. **********Takako Watanabe gradually has lost hope there will be any survivors. Her lifelong friend Nobuko Hattori was on the bus accompanying her grandmother to the next town for a visit to the doctor. **********"I've cried and cried while watching this unfold, until I just don't have any more tears," she said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/04/busin.main_headline: OFF THE SHELF;Feathering Retirement Nests, With Home Recipes and All
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/04/busin.print_headline: OFF THE SHELF;Feathering Retirement Nests, With Home Recipes and All
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/04/busin.body_text: **********THE "elderly" person I knew best in the world was my father's cousin Sophie,  a retired New York City schoolteacher who lived frugally on her pension and her  savings and who always gave me her grasshopper-and-ant lecture when we got together. "I certainly hope you're putting something away for later," she would  begin for the millionth time, as I obliged her with affirmative nodding. **********To Sophie, saving for old age meant passbook accounts -- six of them -- and Government bonds. Investing in the stock market? That was for "swank" people, an activity to be mentioned only mockingly ("I guess you must have shares in Consolidated Edison") if, say, a visitor insisted on lighting a few living-room  lamps when it got dark. **********These days, as some recent books on pensions tell it, the outlook for retirement is both better and worse than it was for Sophie (who ran out of life, at the age of 100, before she ran out of money). **********Better, because do-it-yourself pension plans like 401(k)'s offer employees a  chance to amass some real retirement money by diverting part of their salaries to tax-deferred investment funds. Worse, because many workers cannot afford or are not allowed to put money in a save-it-yourself plan, at a time when company-paid retirement programs are in retreat and Social Security benefits, as always, give retirees just a taste of the money they used to make. **********Among the optimists are the 15 members of the now-famous Beardstown Ladies' Investment Club, who, with Robin Dellabough, are the authors of "The Beardstown  Ladies' Stitch-in-Time Guide to Growing Your Nest Egg" (Hyperion, $19.95), which became a business best seller this month. The authors -- eight of whom are retired -- acknowledge that "traditional pensions have been getting scarcer," but they interpret this as a trend to "put  more responsibility back onto the employee" for retirement. **********The goal for pensioners, they say, should be to capture 75 to 80 percent of their preretirement income. Aggressive investing within a tax-deferred employee-savings plan is at the heart of their strategy, of course, but that comes later. **********First, readers are advised to assess their net assets (work sheets are included) and figure their potential income from these and other sources -- including Social Security, which the authors believe will be with us for a while. **********They recommend, however, that people check in regularly with the agency before they retire to head off any accounting mistakes and to learn what their future benefits will be (telephone numbers, addresses and instructions are handily provided). **********The "Stitch-in-Time Guide" also gives tidy, coherent explanations of each pension category -- from traditional employer-paid plans to 401(k)'s, I.R.A.'s,  Keoghs and a little-known option called an S.E.P., or simplified employee pension. It also gets into real estate investments and "reverse" mortgages (which turn home equity into cash). And it includes a handy pension resource list. **********This Beardstown book is at its best where its authors are happiest: in the chapters on the joys of stocks -- in this case, within a 401(k) or other tax-sheltered plan. But as a sequel of sorts to the "Beardstown Ladies' Common-Sense Investment Guide," it disappoints. The 30 pages of author profiles  and recipes feel like padding this time. There's also a forced folksiness afoot, with adages ("put the horse before the cart") appearing in every chapter and investment charts bearing labels like "Homemade Apple Pie." And, ladies, I'm going to have to mention the mixed metaphor in the title. If you want more on 401(k)'s, take a look at "Building Your Nest Egg With Your 401(k)," by Lynn Brenner (Investors Press, $14.95) or "The 401(k) Book," by Richard Sasanow (Henry Holt, $9.95). Both are useful and readable (and, in the case of Sasanow, relentlessly upbeat).    THIS brings us to "Pensions in Crisis," by Karen Ferguson and Kate Blackwell  (Arcade Publishing, $22.95), a comprehensive and sobering look at America's pension policies. **********The crisis, the authors say, is that for many people, the theoretical triad of pension sources -- Social Security benefits, traditional company plans and individual savings -- doesn't add up to much protection. Only about a third of private-sector workers are in employer-paid plans, they assert. And half of the  retirees receiving these benefits get less than $4,500 a year. Some private pensions are "integrated" with a retiree's Social Security benefit, meaning that the company's monthly payments are reduced by part or all of that amount. **********Meanwhile, the authors say, half of all Americans rely solely on Social Security -- with average benefits of less than $8,400 a year. Women, especially  widows, do most poorly. **********As for the rush into 401(k)'s, the authors say, "those who will profit from these new savings plans are people wealthy enough to save without tax incentives." **********Ms. Ferguson, director of the Pension Rights Center in Washington, and Ms. Blackwell, a co-author with Ralph Nader of "You and Your Pension," contend that  companies have embraced these new plans because they are cheaper than old-style  pension funds. Do-it-yourself plans typically cost a company 1 to 2 percent of its total payroll, they say, compared with about 7 percent for the traditional employer-paid pension plans. **********"Pensions in Crisis" calls for a national pension policy based on these traditional, voluntary, private-sector plans -- all in the context of a Pension  Bill of Rights that would, among other things, shorten vesting times and give all employees access to retirement benefits. (Today, companies can exclude some  workers from both traditional and tax-deferred plans.) **********But the book is also a practical primer for employees, one that deftly delineates the pension choices and dispenses advice about what workers can do to protect an underfinanced or overfinanced plan (the latter being ripe for raiding by the company) or to persuade an employer to start a pension plan. There's even a section on getting the most out of that 401(k).
