https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/13/world.snippet: Pentagon dispatches second aircraft carrier to Middle East, expanding American fire power in the region as the United States prepares for new attack on Iraq; Pres Clinton vows to do 'whatever it takes' to keep Saddam Hussein from threatening his n...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/13/world.main_headline: U.S. Sends Another Carrier To Bolster Mideast Forces
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/13/world.print_headline: U.S. Sends Another Carrier To Bolster Mideast Forces
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/13/world.body_text: **********The Pentagon dispatched a second aircraft carrier to the Middle East today, expanding American firepower in the region as the United States prepared for a new attack on Iraq. **********Defense Department officials said that the carrier Enterprise, which is now in the Adriatic Sea, has been ordered to the Suez Canal and from there to pass this weekend into the Red Sea, where its jet fighters would be in range for attacks on Iraq. **********The American aircraft carrier Carl Vinson is already in the Persian Gulf and was involved in last week's cruise-missile strikes on Iraq, which were intended to punish Iraq for  sending tens of thousands of troops into northern Iraq in recent weeks in support of a Kurdish faction in its conflict with Iranian-backed rivals. **********Despite the American action, the Iraqis have continued their attacks, with the Pentagon reporting that  three surface-to-air missiles were fired today from sites in southern Iraq, apparently in hopes of hitting American jets patrolling the ''no-flight'' zone there. **********Defense Departments officials said no American fighters were in the vicinity at the time of the firings. ''They just fired the missiles into nothingness,'' said Kenneth Bacon, the Defense Department's chief spokesman. **********The Enterprise received its new deployment orders as the Pentagon toughened its warnings to Iraq, telling Baghdad that a new threat today to Kuwait was ''rash'' and ''unacceptable'' and that any military action there would be met with ''all necessary and appropriate actions.'' **********The warning came after Tariq Aziz, Iraq's Foreign Minister, accused Kuwait today of an ''act of war'' for having agreed to allow the United States to send F-117 stealth fighters to Kuwait. **********In a commentary carried by the Iraqi News Agency, Mr. Aziz likened the recent turmoil in the Persian Gulf to the period six years ago before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, and he accused Kuwait's rulers of ''evil collaboration with America in conspiring against Iraq's people.'' **********''Those kinds of rash statements are totally unacceptable,'' Defense Secretary William J. Perry said. **********In a campaign appearance in Rancho Cucamonga, Calif., President Clinton said that ''I don't want to get in a word war with Saddam Hussein, but we're going to do whatever it takes to keep him from threatening his neighbors, threatening our pilots.'' He added, ''We cannot allow anybody anywhere to believe they are not bound by the rules of civilized behavior.'' **********With its 75 planes, the Enterprise would add significant muscle to the American military presence in the Middle East. But Pentagon officials said they had not yet received permission from Saudi Arabia for the Enterprise's fighters to cross Saudi Arabia en route to Iraq. Without such permission the next most direct route would be to cross Israeli and Jordanian airspace, or the carrier would have to reach the Persian Gulf, sometime next week, to bring its planes within range without mid-air refueling. **********The Israel-Jordan route would seem less likely, given the aversion of America's Arab allies to any Israeli involvement in an attack on another Arab nation. **********Mr. Bacon acknowledged today that while the United States was ''satisfied with the cooperation we're getting'' from American allies in the Persian Gulf, saying ''it's no secret that this is a touchy business for our allies in the Gulf.'' **********As the Clinton Administration sent the aircraft carrier to the Red Sea, ,  Republicans heaped criticism on the Administration. **********Testifying before the Senate Armed Services Committee, James A. Baker 3d, President Bush's Secretary of State during the 1991 Persian Gulf war, accused the Clinton Administration of a ''failure of leadership.'' **********''I don't think that our response was strong enough,'' Mr. Baker said of last week's attacks on Iraq with 44 cruise missiles. ''Iraq, under Saddam Hussein, only understands force. And more to the point, it only seems to understand overwhelming force.'' **********Partisan wrangling over the Administration's handling of the gulf crisis broke out in the House when Democrats tried to bring up a non-binding resolution of support for the American troops in the Middle East. **********Representative Dick Armey, Republican of Texas, the majority leader, said it was inappropriate for the House to approve any resolution until the Administration had briefed legislators on its policy goals toward Iraq. He and other Republicans said that the White House had not fully consulted lawmakers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/04/busin.main_headline: Bell Atlantic Agrees to Open Network
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/04/busin.print_headline: Bell Atlantic Agrees to Open Network
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/04/busin.body_text: **********The Bell Atlantic Corporation, hoping to demonstrate that it can play according to the new open-competition telecommunications rules, announced an agreement yesterday to let the cable television company Jones Intercable Inc. connect to its telephone network in Virginia. **********Although the companies filed their plan with state regulators in Virginia, the agreement is seen as part of the Bell company's broader effort to win Federal approval to enter the long-distance market by opening its own local networks to competitors. Such give-and-take is provided for in the sweeping Federal telecommunications law that went into effect earlier this year. **********While the deal is the first such agreement between a regional Bell company and a cable operator, it is by no means the first or broadest open-network deal  between a Baby Bell and a would-be competitor. Late last month, the Ameritech Corporation, the Bell company serving five Great Lakes states, agreed to open its local networks to the MFS Communications Company, a provider of telecommunications services to business customers. **********Still, the Jones-Bell Atlantic agreement is significant. And it came on the same day that the Federal Communications Commission introduced new rules for letting large telephone companies offer cable-like video services over their phone wires. These F.C.C. rules, mandated by the new telecommunications law, would require phone companies to reserve much of their video-network capacity to outside programmers in return for being able to offer their own video programming -- with few of the regulations currently borne by cable companies. **********James Cullen, vice chairman of Bell Atlantic, described the Jones deal in a statement as "indisputable proof that Bell Atlantic is absolutely serious about opening its markets to competition as soon as possible." **********Bell Atlantic will connect Jones to its network this summer. The alliance will let Jones offer telephone service to businesses and residents quicker than  if it had to upgrade its network of cables. The agreement covers only Virginia,  not any of Bell Atlantic's other five Middle Atlantic states or the District of  Columbia. **********The agreement remains subject to the approval of Virginia regulators. Bell Atlantic has 2.5 million customers in Virginia, while Jones provides cable television service to 300,000 people in the state. **********Under the new telecommunications law, the regional Bell companies must meet a 14-point list of requirements before they can provide long-distance telephone service. One of the 14 points is letting competitors connect to the Bells' local networks. **********In New York, the Nynex Corporation, has had an interconnection agreement with the Cablevision Systems Corporation since February 1995. However, that alliance  does not meet the 14 requirements set down in the telecommunications law, according to Bob Varettoni, a Nynex spokesman.

"There is interest in Fokker from international companies," said a spokesman, Luuc van Zijp. https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/20/world.snippet: Interview with United Nations Sec Gen Boutros Boutros-Ghali, who is bucking American efforts to deny him second term; says his fight with US is not just for himself, but for entire third world; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/20/world.body_text: **********When Boutros Boutros-Ghali visits Japan, he inevitably makes a quiet pilgrimage to an obscure shrine in what an aide calls ''some godawful far-reaching corner of Tokyo.'' There, with incense drifting around him, the Secretary General pauses alone for a moment or two and bows. **********The shrine is a monument to Adm. Heihachiro Togo, the Japanese naval commander who defeated Russian fleets at Port Arthur and the Tsushima Strait in 1904 and 1905 -- the first great victories of an emerging nation over an imperial European power. **********Today, as Mr. Boutros-Ghali stood his ground against an American veto, the first of as many as it will take to deny him a second term as Secretary General, this proud descendant of Egyptian aristocracy could draw from a complex personal history: part radical anti-colonialist, part French-educated intellectual and scholar, part diplomat sharpened and deromanticized by the politics of the Middle East and Africa. **********Today's vote in the Security Council was 14 to 1 in his favor, but the American no vote sets the stage for a prolonged battle over his future, and opens the way for new compromise candidates. **********It is a matter of principle, he insists as he carries on his almost certainly futile confrontation with the last superpower, that he fight not only for himself but also for the third world. The less developed countries do indeed still support him, though not always with the enthusiasm he might expect given his long association with nonalignment and other policies unpopular in most Western capitals. But Mr. Boutros-Ghali, 74, knows the odds, he said with a hint of resignation in an interview Sunday at his Sutton Place home. **********In the other corner in Washington is a 50-year-old American President from Arkansas with little experience in foreign affairs but a good political instinct for distancing himself from a man viewed with suspicion by many American conservatives.  President Clinton's aides say they never considered the United Nations Secretary General important enough to warrant a private meeting with their chief. **********''Friends come to me and say, 'Don't be passive,' '' Mr. Boutros-Ghali said. ''You are in America; they like fighters. You look like a lame duck. You have to act. But how can I fight Goliath? Come on! Who am I to fight a superpower? I cannot.'' **********He said that when he asked Secretary of State Warren Christopher to make his case with Mr. Clinton, Mr. Christopher told him, ''I'm the lawyer of the President; I'm not your lawyer.'' **********Mr. Boutros-Ghali's style, he said, is tete-a-tete, and it helped him build ''good chemistry'' with Presidents Carter and Bush. Now he finds himself frozen out of the White House. **********''Do I represent a danger to the security of the United States?'' he said, with the edge that can intimidate those who work for him. ''No. Did I smuggle something? Am I Noriega or Saddam Hussein?'' **********Boutros Boutros-Ghali is the great-grandson of a Coptic Christian courtier who managed the vast holdings of a royal prince in a 19th-century Egyptian caliphate and the grandson of a former Prime Minister who was assassinated in 1904. **********He said he was an active opponent of Muslim fundamentalism from his student days and a fervent anti-colonialist by the time he arrived in Paris in 1946 (the year President Clinton was born) to study at the Sorbonne, where he received a doctorate in international law. He has written books on Islamic thought. **********He likes to draw historical analogies. The United States, he suggested, has developed an attitude not unlike that of the Roman Empire.  ''Like in Roman times, they have no diplomacy,'' he said of Washington in its current mode. ''You don't need diplomacy if you are so powerful.'' **********Mr. Boutros-Ghali is an elegant man of wry wit whose understated tailored suits never crease or his polished shoes scuff, even in the African bush or battlefields in Bosnia. He has never sought to cut a figure in New York society. His visibility is so low that Americans who poke fun at his name probably do not really know who he is or what he does for a living. **********Barbara Walters, who has known Mr. Boutros-Ghali and his wife, Leia, since she was first assigned to interviews with President Anwar el-Sadat in Egypt in the 1970's, is one of the few people who have been able to draw him out socially. Ms. Walters says that the Secretary General prefers small dinners at home to big social events. **********But she does not think, as others do, that this has hurt him much in celebrity-conscious New York. ''In Washington, maybe, that would matter, but not in New York,'' she said. Still, Mr. Boutros-Ghali may not feel totally at home here. He muses about a future life writing in Europe. **********An American diplomat took a slightly different view of the importance of media appeal. The next Secretary General, he told reporters recently, needed to be a bit more media-friendly if not exactly social. Mr. Boutros-Ghali, Administration officials are fond of saying, had such a negative, arrogant image that he had become ''radioactive'' in Washington. **********Under his tenure, the United Nations has made steep staff cuts and held its budget level for the first time. **********But American critics say the organization needs more aggressive streamlining and Administration officials say that if he continues in office it will be impossible to persuade Congress to begin paying off the large American arrears at the United Nations. **********Warm and indulgent he is not, say many at the United Nations who have worked for him -- or been dismissed by him -- during his first term, which ends on Dec. 31. Stories are told of days off to attend family events denied; vacations barely tolerated. He does not see himself that way. He just does not like people to be somewhere else when he needs them, he says. **********Mr. Boutros-Ghali, who for many years was Egypt's chief foreign affairs minister, had built a good working relationship with succeeding American administrations through his work on Middle East peace efforts, including his visit to Jerusalem with President Sadat in 1977. As a Christian in the Middle East he had often been seen as a betrayer. **********He has remained close to a number of American officials, including Cyrus R. Vance and Lawrence S. Eagleburger, two former Secretaries of State. **********His relationship with Madeleine K. Albright and others in the Clinton Administration was not so bad until very recently, he added, when he got tangled up in an American Presidential campaign. **********''I had cooperated with the Americans in so many ways'' he said. ''My relations were good -- I would not say excellent. But politics is politics.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/24/busin.snippet: St Jude Medical Inc says its Pacesetter subsidiary will acquire Ventritex Inc in stock swap valued at $505 million (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/24/busin.main_headline: $505 Million St. Jude Deal For Maker of Defibrillators
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/24/busin.print_headline: $505 Million St. Jude Deal For Maker of Defibrillators
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/24/busin.body_text: **********St. Jude Medical Inc. said yesterday that its Pacesetter subsidiary would acquire Ventritex Inc. in a stock swap valued at $505 million. Ventritex, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., is a leading maker of implantable heart defibrillators, which are small devices that deliver a jolt of electricity to stabilize a racing heart. **********The deal would give St. Jude, a leading manufacturer of pacemakers, an entry in the defibrillator market, which is growing more rapidly. **********In a related move, St. Jude, based in St. Paul, Minn., said it would acquire the cardiac-rhythm-management assets of Telectronics Pacing Systems Inc. from the Australian consumer and industrial product concern Pacific Dunlop Ltd. for $170 million (Australian), or $135 million (United States). Included in the deal is the acquisition is Medtel, a medical-products distribution business. **********According to the terms of the Ventritex deal, shareholders will receive 0.6 share of St. Jude Medical for each of their shares. The ratio is not dependent on St. Jude's stock price. In addition, Ventritex will purchase up to 200,000 of its own shares before the merger closes, which is expected by  early 1997. Frank Fischer, Ventritex's president and chief executive, will remain with the company. **********St. Jude also said it would pay $25 million in cash to acquire certain intellectual property rights from Intermedics Inc., a Freeport, Tex. unit of Sulzer Medica Inc. and settle disputes between Intermedics and Ventritex Inc. **********St. Jude shares closed at $37.325, down $1.25, while Ventritex shares closed at $21.563, up 93.8 cents. Analysts said the relatively modest prices for Ventritex and Telectronics  reflected the fact that both companies were weakened. **********Ventritex, having gained an early lead in the market for implantable defibrillators, failed to keep up with larger competitors like Medtronic Inc. and the Guidant Corporation. Telecronics, based in Englewood, Colo., has had losses since early 1995, when the company was forced by the  Food and Drug Administration to temporarily cease manufacturing heart pacemaker products for the American market. That ruling followed the deaths of several patients fitted with faulty heart pacemaker leads -- the wires that deliver the electrical current from the device to the heart -- made by Telectronics. **********''St. Jude has once again shown their savvy as buyers,'' said Kurt Kruger, an analyst with Montgomery Securities. ''They are paying a modest premium for Ventritex to gain a turn-key operation in the fastest-growing market,'' in the cardiology device business, he said. **********St. Jude executives said the deals would allow them to offer a complete line of heart rhythm regulating devices. ''Since St. Jude entered the cardiac rhythm management market with the Pacesetter acquisition, we have been committed to offer our customers a full line of products'' said Ronald A. Matricaria, the chief executive of St. Jude. ''Today's announcements will allow us to fulfill that commitment.'' **********Michael Weinstein, an analyst with J. P. Morgan, said the Ventritex deal would reduce earnings per share in the short term, but would bolster revenue and earnings growth for St. Jude. ''This combination has made strategic sense for a while,'' he said. ''It raises the growth profile.'' He estimated that St. Jude's annual revenue growth could accelerate from about 9 percent to 12 percent and that earnings growth could go from 16 percent to 20 percent. **********Defibrillators are small devices that monitor the heart for signs that  it has gone into an unstable rapid beat. They deliver a measured dose of electrical current to shock the heart back to normal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/14/busin.snippet: IMAGINE yourself the manager of a team of five engineers. The team is experienced, well-knit and highly effective. The team members have paid their dues and know their subject area better than anyone else on earth. Their project is on track. And n...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/14/busin.body_text: **********IMAGINE yourself the manager of a team of five engineers. The team is experienced, well-knit and highly effective. The team members have paid their dues and know their subject area better than anyone else on earth. Their project is on track. And now, to your dismay, one of the five announces that she will be leaving at the end of the month. What a disaster. You call Personnel. "Louise is leaving on the 31st," you tell them. "Send me another Louise." **********But experienced team members like Louise are, sadly, out of stock. "How about a Ralph?" they suggest. The deal is done: Louise out on the 31st, Ralph in on the 1st. **********In an accounting sense, nothing has changed. Ralph makes about the same salary and has about the same workload as did Louise. Input (cost) is the same,  and output (effort) is the same. If the project was on track last month, it should still be O.K. this month. Why are you complaining? **********To understand the problem, consider Ralph's meaningful production on his first day on the job. How much does he chip away at the remaining project work?  Not at all, of course. He is trying to figure out who's who, how to find the gents' room and where to get those yellow legal pads. Mostly, however, he is poring over the notes Louise left about her work, notes that Louise would have no need to consult (and probably wouldn't even have written if she hadn't been about to leave). **********Every now and then Ralph has a question, so he looks for another team member  for help. Ralph's productivity on the first day is not even zero; it is negative. He is keeping other people from working at full capacity.  On the second day, he may be a bit less of a burden, and still less on the third. **********Eventually he comes up to speed, producing at the same level as his predecessor.  In picture form, it looks like the graphic below. The shaded area  is the lost production attributed to the sudden loss of an experienced worker, Louise. Put another way, it is the investment that the company is forced to make in the new worker, Ralph. The extent of the investment is a function of how long it takes new people to become as effective as the ones they replace. **********Depending on the type of work, the investment can be substantial. One of my clients, a network protocol group at Hewlett-Packard, figures that it takes 25 months to bring a new engineer up to speed. In simple terms, the shaded area in  such a case would be a bit more than one work year, including all the costs, salary and overhead. Each time a new engineer is hired, $150,000 has to be invested in that person before the investment begins to pay off. **********For reasons best understood to bean counters and tax authorities, modern companies do not capitalize their investment in people. Their rules make us pretend that people are a pure expense. Of course, that might have made sense for the unskilled workers of 100 years ago. But today's knowledge workers are different. They represent an enormous hidden investment, the company's human capital, shielded from the eye by let's-pretend bookkeeping. **********We often evaluate companies as if human capital doesn't matter. And so a company like AT&T; can lay off 40,000 knowledge workers, and the market will respond positively because expenses are trimmed. If corporations booked their investments in workers as capital assets, as I believe they should, AT&T; would not have been able to eliminate those jobs without writing down $4 billion to $8 billion of assets. Then the market response would be different. Instead of applauding the company's executives, we'd be looking to give them the boot.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/09/busin.body_text: **********The shares of the Tandy Corporation tumbled yesterday after the company said  it expected second-quarter earnings to decline as much as 30 percent because of  weak same-store sales and higher interest costs. Tandy shares fell $4.625, to $40.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. Before charges, the company expected to earn 40 cents a share, said the chief financial officer, Dwayne Hughes. A charge of $25.5 million, or 26 cents, to close two stores would reduce net income by about 15 cents a share, he said. Tandy, which operates the Radio Shack and Computer City electronics chains, was expected to earn 51 cents a share, according to the average estimate of 14 analysts polled by Zacks Investment Research. A year earlier, the company earned 55 cents a share.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/13/world.main_headline: Canada and Mexico Join to Oppose U.S. Law on Cuba
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/13/world.print_headline: Canada and Mexico Join to Oppose U.S. Law on Cuba
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/13/world.body_text: **********In a united and increasingly defiant stance against their common ally, Canada and Mexico are stepping up their opposition to what they consider an unlawful United States effort to penalize foreign companies that trade with Cuba. **********During meetings here and in other Canadian cities this week Jean Chretien, Canada's Prime Minister, and Ernesto Zedillo, Mexico's President, strongly criticized the United States for its attempts to impose the Helms-Burton Act. The American law requires foreign companies to report any property they have in  Cuba that was confiscated from American owners by the Communist Government of President Fidel Castro. It also opens the way for those companies to be sued in  American courts for compensation. **********The law could have a damaging impact on companies like Grupo Domos, a Mexican company that bought half of the Cuban telephone company in 1994 for $750 million. ITT, the New York-based communications company, ran the Cuban phone system before Mr. Castro took over. **********Canada, which has no restrictions on trade with Cuba, has passed a law blocking local companies from complying with the reporting provisions of the American law and also forbids Canadian businesses from paying any fines that might be levied by an American court. Mr. Chretien said this morning that even tougher measures are being considered. **********Mexico, which has more money invested in Cuba than any other country, is considering adopting a law similar to that of the Canadians and perhaps imposing retributive tariffs. **********"Mexico and Canada consider inadmissible every measure that, rather than promote liberty, obstructs freedom, that instead of dropping barriers, erects them to the detriment of international investment and business," Mr. Zedillo said at a joint session of the Canadian Parliament on Tuesday. **********The Helms-Burton Act is the central theme of the first state visit to Canada  by Mr. Zedillo, who took office in December 1994. His visit to Canada began on Monday in Ottawa and ends on Friday in Vancouver. **********American officials say they are not surprised by the complaints by Canada and Mexico, which have also been voiced by European and other Latin American countries. Last week Washington was handed a stinging setback as the Organization of American States, a hemispheric organization normally dominated by the United States, condemned laws that reach beyond the country where they are adopted. **********But the Americans warned against pushing too far. **********"A lot of people on Capitol Hill are very irritated about this," said a White House official who spoke on condition of anonymity. The official called some recent comments by officials from neighboring countries "gratuitous U.S.-bashing." **********Canada, Mexico and the United States joined in the North American Free Trade  Agreement in January 1994, forming the largest trading bloc in the world. The three trading partners have already met several times to determine whether Nafta regulations supersede the provisions of the Helms-Burton Act. Nothing has been resolved. **********The law was hastily passed last March after Cuban fighters shot down two unarmed civilian planes flown by anti-Castro Cuban-Americans from Miami. Four men died in the incident. **********The most controversial aspects of the law, permitting lawsuits against foreign companies and their executives doing business in Cuba, do not become effective until Aug. 1. Some officials from Canada and Mexico believe there is still a chance that President Clinton, who initially opposed the legislation, will not allow it to be enforced. **********Cemex, a large Mexican cement company, announced two weeks ago that it was pulling out of Cuba to avoid trouble with American laws. But other Mexican businessmen have taken a defiant stand. **********"If someone starts a legal action against us in the United States, we're ready to defend ourselves," said Bernardo Dominguez, president of the Mexican construction and hotel company Grupo DSC. **********Canada also has large investments in Cuba, including several hotels and Sherritt International's sprawling nickel mine. **********Both Domos and Sherritt were among the first companies to receive warnings from the United States State Department last month that they may be operating in Cuba in violation of the Helms-Burton law. **********Miguel Angel Gonzalez Felix, legal counsel to the Mexican Foreign Relations Ministry, said Mexico had focused on the date July 15 to decide how to respond to the United States initiative. Under the Helms-Burton law, Mr. Clinton must decide no later than 15 days before the implementation date whether he will allow the law to take effect. **********"Right now everyone in the world is focusing on that date to see what the Americans will do," said Mr. Gonzalez Felix. **********But the White House insists the law will be enforced and preparations have already been made for a Mexican counter law based on the Canadian model. **********Canada has what is called a "blocking statute" that would prohibit Canadian businesses from complying with the Helms-Burton law. Canada toughened the blocking statute in January. There is also a "claw-back" provision that allows Canadian companies to countersue to be compensated for judgments made against them in the United States. **********"In trying to isolate Cuba, they're hurting their largest trading partners,"  said Roy MacDonald, a Liberal Party Member of Parliament, referring to the United States. "In our view, that's not how you treat your friends." **********Despite the polemics, Canada and Mexico seem to understand the limits of what they can do. **********"I do not want to lie to Mexican businessmen and promise them legislation that will make them totally invulnerable to the Helms-Burton law," Mr. Zedillo said at a news conference this morning. "That is not possible."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/11/busin.main_headline: Ford Places Top Designer On the Leadership Track
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/11/busin.print_headline: Ford Places Top Designer On the Leadership Track
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/11/busin.body_text: **********The Ford Motor Company today named Jacques A. Nasser, 48, to head its North American and European automotive operations, clearing the way for the urbane car designer to become the auto maker's top operating officer someday. **********Mr. Nasser, who had been a group vice president in charge of vehicle development, will take the rank of executive vice president when his promotion takes effect on Nov. 1. **********His rise through the ranks partly reflects Ford's growing emphasis on international experience. Born in a remote mountain village in Lebanon and raised in Australia, Mr. Nasser speaks several languages fluently and is a former chairman of Ford's European subsidiary and a former president of its Australian unit. **********While the current president of Ford's automotive operations, Edward E. Hagenlocker, has worked from an office at the company's headquarters here, Mr. Nasser will remain at Ford's sprawling vehicle development campus several miles away. Some senior marketing executives and other managers will also move there, a further indication of the powerful role that Mr. Nasser will now play at the No. 2 auto maker. **********Ford also announced today that it was separating its many auto parts businesses from the core automotive operations that Mr. Nasser will oversee. The new automotive products operations division has annual sales of $14.3 billion and 75,000 employees; its profitability was not disclosed. **********Mr. Hagenlocker, a 56-year-old executive vice president, was named a vice chairman today with responsibility for overseeing the new auto parts division. **********Alex Trotman, Ford's 63-year-old chairman and chief executive, said at a news conference today at Ford's headquarters here that Mr. Hagenlocker would conduct a broad review of whether to sell or otherwise overhaul existing businesses and whether to invest in new auto parts operations, possibly through joint ventures. **********In a telephone interview this afternoon, Mr. Trotman said that Mr. Hagenlocker and Mr. Nasser would both have a lot of responsibility in the coming years and declined to discuss who might eventually replace him. Auto analysts said that today's management move, while expected, gave Mr. Nasser the inside track to become the top operating officer at Ford. **********William Clay Ford Jr., 39, the chairman of the Ford board's finance committee, is considered the front-runner to be the next chairman, partly because the Ford family still controls 40 percent of the voting power at the company. **********Today's reshuffling of senior management ''does not necessarily determine who will be the next chairman, it identifies the next No. 1 operating person at Ford, Jacques Nasser,'' said Maryann N. Keller, an auto analyst with Furman Selz. ''The job is his to lose right now.'' **********Mr. Nasser, a favorite of the Ford family, has long been expected to go farther than Mr. Hagenlocker, a  physicist who does not seem as comfortable as Mr. Nasser at making speeches and other public appearances. While Mr. Hagenlocker has received some of the credit for the highly successful redesign last winter of the F-series pickup trucks, the nation's best-selling vehicle, he has also taken some of the blame for the less successful redesign last year of the Ford Taurus sedan. **********Mr. Trotman hinted today that he would be interested in staying on as chairman of Ford beyond his 65th birthday if the board will let him. ''You'd like to live to be 100 years old and work in the auto business, it's just not realistic,'' he said. **********If the automotive operations run into trouble, Mr. Nasser could easily run into competition for the top job. **********John M. Devine, the 52-year-old chief financial officer and a favorite of Wall Street because of his consistent candor, was also picked today to become an executive vice president. He gave up his responsibility over land development to Mr. Hagenlocker but kept his position as chief financial officer. **********W. Wayne Booker, the 62-year-old executive vice president who oversees Ford's operations in emerging markets, was also chosen today to become a vice chairman. But neither Mr. Hagenlocker nor Mr. Booker will become members of the board. All of the management moves are scheduled to take effect on Nov. 1. **********Mr. Trotman said that part of Mr. Hagenlocker's job would involve figuring out how to make use of Ford's new labor contract with the United Automobile Workers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/17/busin.main_headline: Dollar Rises Against the Mark As German Rate Cut Is Seen
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/17/busin.print_headline: Dollar Rises Against the Mark As German Rate Cut Is Seen
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/17/busin.body_text: **********The dollar rose against the German mark yesterday, bolstered by growing speculation that Germany's central bank will reduce interest rates when its policy council meets on Thursday. **********''People are thinking a Bundesbank rate cut is a done deal next week,'' said Steve Koenig, manager of currency sales at Bank Brussels Lambert. ''That's why we're seeing the mark fall.'' **********Lower short-term rates in Germany reduce the appeal of bank deposits there, and often weigh on the mark. **********The market was full of speculation yesterday that reports on the German money supply would show that its growth slowed last month, giving the central bank room to reduce rates. Some Bundesbank officials have said such a slowdown is a prerequisite for a rate cut. The central bank is expected to release money supply figures early next week. **********In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.4918 marks,  from 1.4854 marks on Thursday and the highest level since July 18. The dollar slipped to 107.70 Japanese yen from 108.10 yen. The British pound fell to $1.5481 from $1.5510. **********Hopes for a German rate cut have been building for several days, encouraged by comments from Bundesbank officials. **********''The Germans are trying to make it fairly clear that their economy is not in the greatest shape, and they're concerned about the mark's strength,'' said Bob Gruber, senior currency salesman at Chase Manhattan Bank. ''What better way to keep it under control than to cut rates?'' **********The mark also suffered from talk that a survey to be published next week by a German economic research institute would show that the economy was still sputtering. **********Many analysts predict that on Thursday the central bank will lower its 14-day repurchase rate, which it charges on short-term loans to financial institutions in exchange for government securities. **********''The rumor mill is starting up again regarding a Bundesbank rate cut next week,'' said Ben Strauss, currency trader at Bank Julius Baer. **********But the Bundesbank surprised many traders by leaving rates unchanged at its last meeting on July 25, prompting a rebound in the mark. The central bank has held the repo rate at 3.3 percent since February.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/09/busin.main_headline: Network Computers: For Now, Only for Business
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/09/busin.print_headline: Network Computers: For Now, Only for Business
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/09/busin.body_text: **********It was only 14 months ago that the concept of the network computer was introduced to the public by Lawrence Ellison, chairman of Oracle Corp. In the following months, many of the big names in the computer industry — including International Business Machines Corp. and Sun Microsystems Inc. — lined up behind Oracle's idea. **********The first machines are now being produced, and some were on display last month at Comdex, the computer-industry trade show in Las Vegas. **********But the vision has changed: It is companies, not consumers, who are expected to buy them. **********Mr. Ellison's idea was that, for most consumers, personal computers are too difficult to use and too expensive to buy and maintain. Rather than buy a personal computer costing $2,000 to $3,000, he said, people could pay as little as $500 for a device with a microprocessor and good picture and sound capabilities but little memory. Such a machine would connect to big server computers where programs and data would be stored. People could view movies or do home banking and shopping without having to learn complicated programs or configure peripheral devices. **********But that is not how things seem to be working out. **********"Basically, the network computer as it is being brought out by IBM, LG Electronics, WYSE and others is really targeted at the business marketplace," said Bruce Stephen, a vice president at the research company International Data Corp. **********Phil Hester, an IBM vice president, said network computers would eventually end up in homes as well as offices, but only after telecommunications improved and programs were developed that made them compelling to consumers. **********Meanwhile, Oracle, Sun, IBM and their allies are hoping to use the so-called NCs to wrest control of the computer industry from Intel Corp. and Microsoft Corp., whose microprocessors and software set the standards for most users. **********When Mr. Ellison first raised the concept, Intel and Microsoft largely dismissed the idea, but in recent months they have softened their opposition. **********Mr. Stephen said companies were looking for lower-cost computing, and that this was creating changes in the computer industry. **********Philippe Kahn, chairman of Starfish Software Corp., a small company that makes network software, said that Intel and Microsoft had started to talk about the cost of ownership and inexpensive designs for PCs. **********But both companies have been reluctant to embrace the network computer because, according to Mr. Kahn, "They want to sell big processors that let them take advantage of all the investments they have made in those factories that have cost billions and billions of dollars to put up and use, and they are committed to those factories." **********But Bill Gates, Microsoft's chairman, thinks that many proponents of the network computer are just trying to increase their own sales. "We've also had various attempts to recentralize computing, to go back to the time sharing days," he said. Development had to do with "people who want to sell expensive servers," he said. **********Such companies as IBM and Sun want to sell server computers. **********Andrew Grove, the chairman of Intel, said this year at Comdex that the consumer market was going to be his company's focus for growth in coming years. **********Network computers are unlikely to be useful in the home market for many years, he and executives of other companies said, because public communications systems are too slow to allow programs and multimedia data to flow to peoples' homes. **********But private corporate networks known as "Intranets," do not have this problem, and so the computer industry is focusing on them. **********Ed Caldwell, vice president of Digital Semiconductor, a unit of Digital Equipment Corp., has an idea for the network computer: "What if you had one of these in every hotel room?" **********Instead of carrying around a personal computer, he said, executives could use a wallet-size card to access their personal information, which would be held on a server computer connected to the hotel by high-speed telecommunications lines. **********"It's easier to wire up hotels than it is homes," he said. **********Digital has developed and produces the microprocessor that will be at the heart of the network computers to be made by LG Electronics Inc. and others. The chips cost $30 to $40, Mr. Caldwell said, less than a third the price of Intel's processors. **********Digital is also working closely with Oracle. **********LG Electronics has developed an network computer which aimed at business users. The machines will go on sale in March for about $650. **********Internet address: Cyberscape@iht.com

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/03/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;J. Walter Thompson Gets Zantac Account
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/03/busin.body_text: **********The Warner-Lambert Company said yesterday that it had named J. Walter Thompson New York to handle advertising for an over-the-counter version of Warner-Lambert's Zantac prescription antacid. **********Robert Casale, vice president for gastrointestinal marketing at Warner-Lambert in Morris Plains, N.J., confirmed a report of the assignment this week in Adweek. He declined to discuss billings, but Adweek estimated that the introductory advertising and promotional spending could reach $100 million. Thompson New York, which is a unit of the WPP Group, was awarded the assignment  without a review, Mr. Casale said; the agency already handles Warner-Lambert brands like Listerine mouthwash, e.p.t. pregnancy tests and Lubriderm lotions. **********In being sold over the counter, Zantac will enter a competitive category that includes several products introduced in 1995, like Pepcid AC and Tagamet HB. The Whitehall-Robins Healthcare division of the American Home Products Corporation plans to introduce its own product, Axid. **********Adweek reported that at least three New York agencies working for Whitehall-Robins were competing for the Axid assignment; it identified them as Lowe & Partners/ SMS, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies; Partners & Shevack, which is owned by Mickelberry Communications Inc., and Young & Rubicam  Inc. Carol Dornbush, a spokeswoman at Whitehall-Robins in Madison, N.J., declined to comment. **********The entry also referred incorrectly to the companies marketing Zantac 75 and Zantac. Zantac 75 will be marketed by Warner Wellcome Consumer Healthcare, not the Warner-Lambert Company. Zantac is marketed by Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C., not Warner-Lambert.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/21/busin.main_headline: Digital Says It Won't Meet Forecasts, and a Sector Slumps
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/21/busin.print_headline: Digital Says It Won't Meet Forecasts, and a Sector Slumps
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/21/busin.body_text: **********Blaming slow sales of its personal computers, the Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that this quarter's earnings would fall below analyst expectations. The news sent Digital's shares tumbling nearly 17 percent, dragging down other computer issues and, in turn, the broader market. **********The question for investors in Digital and other technology issues is whether  the slowing sales of personal computers is a temporary or protracted trend. **********In making the case that the slump is a passing phase, many analysts have cited the slow corporate adoption of the Microsoft Corporation's Windows 95 operating system. In this view, sales will pick up in the second half of the year, after large companies complete their evaluations of Windows 95 and begin to buy the more powerful PC's that the system requires. **********But Digital's warning for the third quarter, ending March 31, comes amid other recent signs of softness in the personal-computer market, including plunging prices for memory chips and less optimistic forecasts from the Compaq Computer Corporation and I.B.M. Earlier this week, Dataquest, a market research  firm, released a report that concluded the home market for PC's is rapidly maturing; Dataquest forecast just 8 percent growth in 1996, down from 22 percent in 1995 and 42 percent in 1994. **********Digital's shares dropped $11.25, to close at $56, on the New York Stock Exchange. Shares in the Hewlett-Packard Company dropped $3.625 to $97.625; those of I.B.M. fell $4.75, to $117; Compaq fell $2, to $38.125, and the Dell Computer Corporation fell $1.125 a share, to $32.50. **********Related stocks also took a hit, with declines at the Intel Corporation, Micron Technology Inc. and Microsoft. The Dow Jones industrial average fell as much as 52 points in the session before rebounding to close at 5,655.42, down 14.09 points. **********John Jones, an analyst with Salomon Brothers in San Francisco, recommended caution about the entire information-science sector, citing a broad shift in economic factors that does not bode well. **********"We've had the wind at our back in this group for two years," he said. "We've seen now collectively, enough indications -- softness in certain markets, the PC market getting ugly, currency shifts, memory prices under pressure -- and yet the stocks until a few days ago were trading at two-year highs." **********Mr. Jones has downgraded Digital, I.B.M., Hewlett-Packard and several smaller companies, and sees no hurry to begin buying the stocks again. "Is this a long-term downturn or a speed bump in the road? I think it's a speed bump," he said. "The fundamentals of these companies are better than in years, but it doesn't mean their earnings aren't going to get hit. It's going to take a couple of quarters to settle out, so we think it's better to be cautious for a while." **********Other analysts argued that while sales of personal computers had clearly slowed, there was little indication that work stations, servers and larger systems had followed suit. Driving down the share price of a diversified technology company like Hewlett-Packard or I.B.M. because of weakness in PC sales, they said, has created an opportunity. **********"We're saying buy I.B.M. and H-P,"said Steven Milunovich, an analyst with Morgan Stanley. But even he downgraded Digital Equipment to neutral. "I would return to the stock, but right now I don't think it's going to go anywhere," he  explained. **********Digital's problem is that PC's account for nearly 20 percent of the company's revenue; while sales of servers based on the company's Alpha chip are strong, they are not enough to compensate for such a big hit, Mr. Milunovich said. "My guess is the PC slowdown will cost them 25 to 30 cents a share and they just can't offset that with other business," he said. **********But Stephen Smith, an analyst with Paine Webber, said the rest of Digital's businesses were performing well enough that investors should stay with the stock. "Everything else at D.E.C. is above plan; to get bitten in the leg by the PC business like this is a real tragedy," he said. "I think it's a major overreaction." He said Paine Webber has had a buy on Digital shares since they were at $18, and it was keeping that recommendation. **********A positive indicator for Digital today was a Microsoft report that sales of its more powerful operating system, Windows NT, have accelerated. "Windows NT is really beginning to kick into high gear, and D.E.C. is aggressively serving that market," Mr. Smith said. **********On the other hand, he said, Digital's advisory that price cuts have not stimulated corporate PC sales is worrisome -- and not just for Digital. "I'm concerned about I.B.M.'s exposure, Hewlett's exposure," he said. "It does not look to me like a D.E.C.-specific problem." **********One reason for the divergence of views is that some indicators can be read in many ways. The steep drop in memory prices is widely believed to reflect excess  inventories at PC manufacturers, created by the drop in demand. But cheaper memory lowers the manufacturing cost for computers, which should lead to lower prices, higher margins or both. **********"Demand may be slowing on the PC side, but we can't see that there's any slowing on the work station side," said Doug van Dorsten, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist. "The upshot of all this is the tea leaves are a mess right now."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/04/busin.main_headline: Why a Strong Yen Could Hurt European Bonds
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/04/busin.print_headline: Why a Strong Yen Could Hurt European Bonds
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/04/busin.body_text: **********Transition is never easy, and usually it is painful. So a stretch of discomfort probably is in store as financial markets prepare to move away from an extended period of yen weakness — which, in turn, could have far-reaching effects on European bond markets. **********What makes the change especially charged is the uncertainty about the upcoming dominant trend: Will it be dollar strength, giving the yen room to fall a bit more, or dollar weakness? **********Analysts are cautious about identifying the next big trend, but they agree that, because of trade concerns in Tokyo and Washington, the leading role of the yen is just about over. "We're nearing the end of the yen's decline," said Brendan Brown at Tokyo-Mitsubishi International. "Further weakness of the yen makes no sense," said Jim O'Neill at Goldman, Sachs & Co. **********The end of the yen's weakness undoubtedly will spill over onto other currencies — just as the yen's weakness, which pushed the dollar up in Japan, contributed to pushing up the dollar against the Deutsche mark. Over the past three months the dollar has risen 5.8 percent against the yen and 2.5 percent against the mark. **********In turn, the weak performance of the mark, aided by German interest rate cuts, greatly reduced strains within Europe's fixed exchange-rate system and fueled optimism that the planned monetary union would occur as scheduled in 1999 — possibly with a larger number of participants than initially thought. This, in turn, fueled a massive rally in European bond markets, pulling long-term bond yields close to levels in the benchmark German market. **********If the mark were to strengthen on the basis of a stronger-than-expected economic upturn, and if the Bundesbank were obliged to raise interest rates before recovery in the rest of Europe could support such a move, convergence toward monetary union could be blown apart. **********Alternatively, expansion in the United States could force Federal Reserve Board policymakers to raise rates and add to the dollar's attractiveness for international investors. Unfortunately for this theory, the latest U.S. economic data do not warrant expectations of a move by the Fed. **********J.P. Morgan & Co., which has been the most insistent on the need for an interest rate increase, now puts a low probability on such a move before early February. Salomon Brothers Inc., which is also bearish on the rate outlook, thinks the latest economic data put a Fed policy shift "off the table for the next few months," said John Lipsky, a Salomon analyst. **********Mr. Brown is putting his money on a strong fourth-quarter bounce in the U.S. economy, leading to an early increase by the Fed and a rising dollar. **********Mr. O'Neill of Goldman is looking to the Dublin summit of European leaders in December to produce agreement on a so-called "stability pact" to adhere to sound budget policies. That, in turn, would open the way for Germany to reduce interest rates further. By that scenario, DM weakness could replace the current yen weakness, supporting the dollar and enhancing the outlook for monetary union. **********For Mr. O'Neill, the recent tough talk on the German rate outlook from various members of the Bundesbank is a "scare tactic" to assure agreement on the stability pact. **********John Llewellyn at Lehman Brothers agreed that German rates probably were not headed down, unless economic activity is much stronger than now forecast. "But given that fiscal policy is tightening — a combination of spending cuts and tax hikes — and inflation is no worry, there certainly won't be any increase in interest rates, and more likely rates will be cut further."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/29/world.main_headline: 3 Britons Believed Killed by Bosnia Mine
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/29/world.print_headline: 3 Britons Believed Killed by Bosnia Mine
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/29/world.body_text: **********Three British soldiers on a routine patrol in western Bosnia were presumed dead today after their vehicle was blown up in an unmarked minefield, and a 28-year-old American officer was shot in the neck and slightly wounded in the Serb-held Sarajevo suburb of Ilidza.    NATO spokesmen said the American officer, Second Lieut. Shawn H. Watts, 28, of Greenwood, Miss., was back on duty after being grazed by a sniper at 6 A.M. today. **********The bullet struck him as he walked in the hotel complex used by NATO as its  ground force headquarters in Bosnia. Soldiers did not return fire. **********Lieutenant Watts, a member of the 66th Military Intelligence Group based at Augsburg, Germany, is the first American soldier in Bosnia to be wounded under fire. **********Sniping incidents are by no means rare in the Serb-held suburbs around Sarajevo. French troops there reported being fired on twice on Saturday during routine patrols, and an Italian soldier was wounded in a similar shooting this month. **********Ilidza, which under the Dayton peace accord is to come under Muslim and Croatian rule in March, has been the site of several protests by residents angered that they must give up Serb-held land around the Bosnian capital. **********"Unfortunately, this shooting is not an isolated incident," said a NATO spokesman, Lieut. Col. Brien Hoey. "In a city like this it would be difficult to establish trends, but this is one of a series of recent incidents that have put  soldiers at risk." **********Another NATO spokesman, Lieut. Chuck Merlo, said: "At this point we don't know whether this was a ricochet, an accident or direct fire. But the investigation is under way." **********The compound where Lieutenant Watts was hit is ringed by razor wire, and all  troops on duty must wear Kevlar helmets and flack jackets. **********Later in the day, a vehicle carrying three British soldiers hit an unmarked minefield west of Mrkonjic Grad, in the fourth mine accident to befall the 10,000-member British contingent. Bad weather and more mines have prevented rescue crews from learning the condition of the soldiers, who were on patrol in  central Bosnia. **********There are an estimated three million mines in the former Yugoslavia, with the rival factions submitting plans that account for 1,500 in the area now under British control. Under to the terms of the Dayton agreement, all sides were required to provide maps of minefields by Jan. 19. But a NATO spokesman, Maj. Steven Kilpatrick, said his troops, "were not given any records of any minefield in the area of this incident." **********He added that it would be difficult to place blame for the uncharted minefield because the area changed hands repeatedly over the course of Bosnia's  nearly four years of war. The stretch of land -- now under the control of the Muslim-Croatian federation -- is to be handed back to the Bosnian Serbs in March. **********In a separate accident, one Swedish soldier was killed and another injured when their armored personnel carrier ran off a road and landed in a river northwest of Tuzla. As in the case of the British soldiers, their names have not been released by NATO pending notification of their families.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/20/busin.main_headline: Small Travel Agencies Face Hard Times Under Fee Cap
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/20/busin.print_headline: Small Travel Agencies Face Hard Times Under Fee Cap
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/20/busin.body_text: **********Mary Hogan, the owner of a tiny three-person travel agency in Cambridge, Mass., thought she was ready for anything in the notoriously fickle travel business. "I survived the gulf war," she said, "when not a soul was traveling anywhere." **********But she did not survive the decision made a year ago by the airline industry  to limit the normal 10 percent commissions on domestic travel to no more than $50 a ticket. She closed up shop last April, shortly after the cap went into effect. **********When my income went down and my overhead didn't, I had the business sense to know to get out," Ms. Hogan said. "As we speak today I know five other people who are closing their agencies. The small, independent agency is an endangered species." **********That may be an exaggeration, but clearly something is amiss. Last year, even  though overall travel revenues were up and the number of agents grew, 1,550 full-service travel agencies went out of business. That is 53 percent more than  in 1994, according to figures compiled by the Airlines Reporting Corporation, the clearinghouse for funds between airlines and travel agencies. Many of those  were replaced by new agencies springing up elsewhere, for a total of 33,600. But single-office locations -- most of them the traditional mom-and-pop shops that have long been the mainstay of the industry -- fell by 1.3 percent. **********Moreover, the longer the cap has been in effect, the more agencies are going  out of business. Travel Weekly magazine reported 484 full-service agency closings in the fourth quarter of last year, compared with 407 such closings in  the third quarter of 1995 and 340 in the second quarter. There were only 290 closings during the fourth quarter of 1994. **********"Many small agencies struggled all year to hang on," said Lauraday Kelley, president of the Association of Retail Travel Agents. "When you'll really see closings and mergers is later this year, when leases and contracts with customers expire." **********Others echoed that view. "Lots of people in the industry think we'll see a drastic number of people calling it quits in the next few months," said Paul Rudin, senior vice president of industry affairs for the American Society of Travel Agents. **********The majority of agencies do less than $2 million in business annually. Most of them see themselves as under siege from almost every side: from the imminent  opening of a prototype Wal-Mart Travel agency in Roanoke, Va., to the spread of  travel and reservation services onto the Internet. And with the savings airlines already achieved last year by capping domestic flights -- commissions fell 3 percent to $3.69 billion -- carriers are now talking about whether they can get  away with capping commissions on international flights as well. **********No wonder, travel agents say, that so many smaller agencies have decided to call it quits. **********Stephen and Ruthie Dukkony of Annapolis, Md., were travel agents for 17 years before recently concluding there was little future as an independent agency for  their Annapolis Travel. Three months ago, they sold it to Travelogue, a small chain based in Washington, although they continue to run the agency. **********"In the past we used the 10 percent commission we made on fares over $500 to  offset the money we lost writing low-priced fares," Mr. Dukkony said. The caps "pushed us over the edge." **********Although about one-third of agencies charge service fees or say they plan to  do so, small agencies fear that fees will drive away customers. Even giant American Express withdrew its $20 fee on airline tickets priced less than $300. **********When Delta Air Lines began the stampede by airlines to cap agency commissions last February, the driving force was clearly economics. Delta, in its bid to cut a total of $2 billion in operating costs in little more than two years, argued it had little choice but to seek savings from commissions, its third-biggest expense after salaries and fuel. Delta's commissions to travel agents fell $157 million last year, or 12.5 percent, to $1.1 billion. During the fourth quarter of last year, Delta's commission payments plummeted 17 percent compared  with the comparable period a year earlier. **********The only hope for the agencies of lifting the cap is to win a class-action lawsuit against AMR's American Airlines, Continental Airlines, Delta, Northwest  Airlines, UAL's United Airlines and USAir. The suit contends that the carriers conspired to impose the caps. The jury trial -- from which Trans World Airlines  was dropped as a defendant last spring when it restored the full 10 percent commission -- is tentatively scheduled for the fall in the United States District Court in Minneapolis. **********"Because it's in litigation, we don't have any comment on the cap," said Jackie Pate, a Delta spokeswoman. **********To blunt the impact of commission caps, many agents have diversified into specialty markets and into booking more tours, hotels, rental cars and cruises.  Results appear mixed. **********Hotel commissions more than doubled last year, to $74 million. But only about 300 agencies out of an estimated 10,000 responded to an offer by Carnival Cruises to increase commissions for bookings from those who had not done business with the cruise line before. That was "far fewer than we expected," said Tim Gallagher, a Carnival spokesman. **********Still, many surviving travel agencies are optimistic. Northwestern Travel Service, a large Minneapolis agency, spent a good part of last year renegotiating contracts with its commercial accounts, at a cost to its bottom line. "But our clients are now paying more attention to what services we offer them, and finding them worth the price," said Arthur I. Dahl, Northwestern's president. **********While acknowledging that the commission caps hurt, Mark Mancini, an industry  consultant in Los Angeles, also sees vast opportunities for travel agents as opinion brokers. **********"You can access the best fare from New York to Paris, but try finding how far it is to Monet's gardens at Giverny," he said. "What travel agents can do best is tell you what planes have more legroom and what airline has better food." **********Meanwhile, newcomers are still coming into the business, although at a slower pace than before. **********Faye DiGirolamo opened Paradise Travel Ltd. in Kansas City, Mo., after having worked as an independent agent for a dozen years. "Even with all the drawbacks,  I love the business," he said, "I never intend to be in another one the rest of  my life."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/10/world.snippet: Interview with Colombian musician Jairo Varela, leader of Niche, one of world's hottest salsa bands who recently served prison sentence on charges related to alleged business dealings with drug cartel in Cali, Colombia; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/10/world.main_headline: Salsa Star Sings Less Carefree Song After Jail Stay
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/10/world.print_headline: Salsa Star Sings Less Carefree Song After Jail Stay
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/10/world.body_text: **********When his cell door opened at the end of November after 11 months and 18 days, Jairo Varela could not walk out a free man. He took a few steps outside the prison gate, but fans who had been anticipating his release swarmed around him. **********The leader of Niche -- one of the world's hottest salsa bands -- and the suspected songster of drug traffickers ducked back inside the prison walls. **********He tried again, calling for his white Lexus to be brought to him. This time the parade of admirers followed Mr. Varela in cars, scooters and bicycles to his studio in the southern part of town. His mother was waiting there for him. **********So was his recording equipment, including the ''Rolls-Royce of recording consoles,'' as he called it, which had helped to get him into so much trouble in the first place. **********Along with Mr. Varela's large investments in a discotheque and a modeling agency, it was this $250,000, 48-track British-made Solid State Logic recording console -- one of only two in South America -- that made the Colombian authorities wonder whether all his money was coming from his music. **********Mr. Varela, 47, returned to Colombia from Miami last December to face charges of illicit enrichment, conspiracy and money laundering. **********The charges stemmed from business dealings that Mr. Varela was alleged to have had with Helmer Herrera Buitrago, a confessed drug trafficker, and Jose Santacruz Londono, another major drug trafficker, who was killed in a storm of gunfire a month after he escaped from prison in January. **********Mr. Varela was released on a technicality. The investigating magistrate in Cali improperly ignored statements from his Miami bank, where Sony, the group's record company, deposited royalties and other payments, Mr. Varelas said. **********But he was released on a $50,000 bond, with orders that he not leave the country without permission. The investigation continues. **********''I've been working in music for 17 years,'' Mr. Varela said in an interview here the day after his release, while his band was on tour in the United States without him. ''We're the best-paid salsa band in the world. They're saying I can't show where my money comes from.'' **********He denied having any ties with drug traffickers and said it was a coincidence that a song he wrote some years back happened to be an anagram of Jose Santacruz Londono's name. **********''I wrote the song at the request of a mother for her child who had the same name,'' Mr. Varela said. Besides, he said, he wrote the song in 1986, when Mr. Santacruz ''was still recognized as someone worthy of respect.'' **********He insisted that Niche never performed at the private parties the drug cartel leaders threw, and he said the group had not realized that drug dealers had paid for a public concert the group once gave. **********He also contended that Colombian prosecutors were willing to believe that his income was ill-gotten because he is black in a country where few black residents have that kind of income. In the complicated lexicon of race in Colombia, the band's name, Niche, describes the darkest-skinned black people. **********In Cali, his fans bristled at his imprisonment, contending that many entertainers had performed at the drug cartel leaders' private bashes without being charged with anything. **********''His popularity hasn't suffered,'' said Jorge Valencia, who invited Mr. Varela to appear on his live television program, where former members of his band performed boleros in Mr. Varela's honor. The show, ''Noche de Luna,'' is broadcast on Spanish-language stations from Peru to Canada. ''People are absolutely convinced of his innocence,'' Mr. Valencia said. **********Like most salsa bands, Niche sings of the trials of love and beauty and bruised hearts. Umberto Valverde, editor of a cultural newspaper here called The Word and the author of a book about the Cuban salsa star Celia Cruz, said Niche was the first salsa group to gain a wide international following. **********Mr. Varela ''took the salsa tradition of Puerto Rico, Cuba and New York and mixed in his own musical history'' from his Chocuano region of Colombia and his experiences in Cali,'' Mr. Valverde said. **********Before Mr. Varela's legal trouble began, Mr. Valverde, a musicologist, had been faulting him for not being daring enough artistically, sticking to a commercially successful formula of a salsa that was lively, yet suave. In a 1992 interview, Mr. Varela had promised that his next record would include pachanga, a salsa from Cuba that uses instruments not traditionally associated with salsa music like flute, saxophone and piano. **********And in his recording studio after his release, the composer said he had been thinking in new directions while he was in jail. **********Though as a jailhouse celebrity, Mr. Varela enjoyed a private cell and the latitude to manage his band, the isolation and public opprobrium affected him deeply. It started him thinking about justice and racism -- subjects that had never preoccupied him before, he said. **********In addition to losing a year of freedom, he has lost his $2 million discotheque, which the authorities shut down. **********In prison, he worried about his family, his band, his finances and his fate. He wrote some 30 songs, about a rebellious black slave, prison and justice. His next album is provisionally titled ''Trial by Fire.'' **********He said he supported the chief prosecutor, Alfonso Valdivieso, who has been trying to search out the tentacles of the drug trade. **********''They simply made a mistake in my case,'' Mr. Varela said. **********He sat before his recording console, with its dizzying array of dials, switches, slides and meters, adjusting a recording that Niche made of his song ''The Jail.'' **********It was not the first time the songwriter was hearing it performed -- he had advised on the recording by cellular telephone from jail -- but taking over the control panel once again was something else. ''I could spend the rest of my life here,'' he said, his eyes filling with tears. **********From speakers as tall as a man, surrounding him, sang the chorus: ''Freedom, freedom is a treasure whose value you don't know until you've lost it.''
