https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/22/busin.main_headline: U.S. Panel Approves Use of Artificial Skin
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/22/busin.print_headline: U.S. Panel Approves Use of Artificial Skin
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/22/busin.body_text: **********A United States Food and Drug Administration panel has recommended that Advanced Tissue Sciences Inc.'s artificial skin product be approved for treating severe burns. **********The company's Dermagraft-TC is genetically engineered human tissue used to cover a burn wound to protect body fluids and prevent infection while allowing the wound to heal enough for a permanent skin graft. **********By 5 to 3, the advisory committee voted on Tuesday to recommend approval on the condition that the company monitor infections among patients who use it. The agency usually follows the advice of its advisory panels, but not always. **********The meeting was closely watched by investors eager for a sense of of what could come when the agency considers another use for Dermagraft -- treating the ulcers that appear on the feet of many diabetics. Approval for that use could open a $1 billion market for Dermagraft, the company estimates. About 13,000 Americans each year require skin grafts for treatment of burns.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/29/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Chip Makers In Japan Post Strong Gains
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/29/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Chip Makers In Japan Post Strong Gains
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/29/busin.body_text: **********Four of Japan's biggest electronics companies said today that group earnings  rose in the double digits during the latest fiscal year, aided by strong sales of semiconductors. But with chip prices now falling, they said they expected profit growth to slow, and in one case decline, this year. **********Semiconductor demand rose sharply last year as computer sales surged worldwide. But it has tailed off, leaving stockpiles of chips that have pushed down prices by more than 50 percent. **********Chip prices fell faster than we expected and for a longer period than we expected," said Atsumi Uchiyama, a vice president at the Toshiba Corporation. "I believe prices will bottom out around June." **********The three other companies reporting earnings today were Hitachi Ltd., Fujitsu Ltd. and the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation. **********Hitachi said net profit rose 25 percent in the latest fiscal year, which ended March 31, to 141.77 billion yen, or $1.3 billion, from 113.91 billion yen  in the year earlier. Sales increased 7 percent, to 8.124 trillion yen from 7.592 trillion yen. **********Toshiba's net profit doubled, to 90.39 billion yen, or $832 million, from 44.69 billion yen. Sales rose 7 percent, to 5.120 trillion yen from 4.791 trillion yen. **********Fujitsu, Japan's largest computer maker, said net profit rose 40 percent, to  63.11 billion yen, or $581 million, from 45.02 billion yen. Sales increased 16 percent, to 3.761 trillion yen from 3.258 trillion yen. **********Mitsubishi Electric's net profit rose 41 percent, to 59.21 billion yen, or $545 million, from 42.10 billion yen. Sales gained 8 percent, to 3.511 trillion  yen from 3.251 trillion yen. **********In the current fiscal year, Toshiba expects group net income to grow 11 percent. Fujitsu expects a gain of 3 percent and Mitsubishi an increase of 1.3 percent. Hitachi expects net profit to fall 4.8 percent. **********Together with the NEC Corporation and the Oki Electric Industry Company, which each posted a profit gain earlier this month but predicted weaker results  for the current fiscal year, the four companies are among the world's top 20 makers of dynamic random access memory, or D-RAM, chips, which are used in computers, mobile telephones and other electronic devices. **********Worldwide semiconductor sales grew 44 percent last year, to $147 billion, according to IDC Japan Ltd., a unit of the International Data Corporation of the United States. Demand was fueled by surging sales of computers and telecommunications devices. **********However, sales growth slowed at the end of last year. Chip users found themselves with stockpiles of unused chips, and chip makers faced falling prices just as they had increased investment in manufacturing capacity. **********The Semiconductor Industry Association, an industry group in the United States, expects the world chip market to grow only 6.7 percent this year, with sales of D-RAM's declining 2.3 percent. **********The Japanese will thus be looking to other products. "We are too dependent on memory chips, but rather than cut down, we should increase output of more profitable logic chips," said Mitsubishi's managing director, Masatoshi Umeda.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/02/busin.snippet: Anthem Inc, big insurance company based in Indiana, confirms it plans to add Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Connecticut to its Anthem East unit; says Anthem and Blue Cross will merge, subject to approval by Anthem board and insurance commissioners ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/02/busin.main_headline: Deal Confirmed for Blue Cross of Connecticut
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/02/busin.print_headline: Deal Confirmed for Blue Cross of Connecticut
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/02/busin.body_text: **********In the latest salvo in the battle for the growing New York-area health care market, Anthem Inc., a big insurance holding company based in the Midwest, confirmed yesterday that it planned to add Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Connecticut to its Anthem East unit. **********Anthem and the Blue Cross plan said yesterday they had agreed in principle to merge, subject to approval by the Anthem board at a meeting this week and by insurance commissioners in Connecticut and Indiana, Anthem's home state. Since the partners are mutual insurance companies, the deal is also subject to approval by their policyholders. **********The deal, in which no cash changes hands, will unite Anthem, a growing and thriving company based in Indianapolis, with a Blue Cross and Blue Shield plan which is rich in customers, if not in profits. **********The Anthem East unit, based in Newark, would also include Blue Cross and Blue Shield in New Jersey and Delaware, plans that Anthem is in the process of acquiring. The unit would have at least three million enrollees. **********Health care experts said that Anthem would eventually compete head-on in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut with Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, the New York giant, which last week said it planned to become a for-profit enterprise. **********''They've got New York surrounded,'' said Richard Sinni, a health-benefits analyst in Secaucus, N.J., with Buck Consultants. ''The next step may be an acquisition in New York itself.'' **********Assuming that all its planned mergers are approved, Anthem said, it would have $11.5 billion in consolidated annual revenue, assets exceeding $7.5 billion and policyholders' equity of more than $1.8 billion, making it one of the nation's five biggest health care management companies. **********Empire has more than four million enrollees, of whom 523,000 are in managed care, and people familiar with the New Jersey market said that Empire had taken steps to do business there as part of a plan to expand into Connecticut as well. **********The moves by Anthem and Empire should provide new strength for Blue Cross plans in the three-state region as they struggle against managed-care companies like Aetna, which recently combined with U.S. Healthcare for a subscriber base of about 1.4 million people in New York area networks, and Oxford Health Plans, which has close to one million. **********Employers welcomed the announcement, which could mean better buys and improved products. ''Anything that will increase the efficiency and effectiveness of the Blue Cross operations is a big plus,'' said Helen Darling, an executive at the Xerox Corporation who is active in national employer groups dealing with managed-care companies. **********Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield already covers four million people in Indiana, Ohio and Kentucky. Anthem also runs health care networks in California and Florida. **********John F. Croweak, chairman and chief executive of Connecticut Blue Cross, will be chairman of Anthem East. William Marino, president of New Jersey Blue Cross, will be president and chief executive of Anthem East. **********''The proposed merger will have little impact on Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Connecticut members, customers, providers and employees at this time,'' the companies said. The Connecticut insurer, based in North Haven, has 2,300 employees. **********Kenneth S. Abramowitz, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, said that the wave of Blue Cross mergers was 10 years late but ''still welcome.'' He noted that health care was often bought on a regional basis, but that Blue Cross plans until recently were organized on a state-by-state basis. **********Connecticut Blue Cross and Blue Shield, which reported an operating loss of $24.2 million in 1995 on revenue of $1.48 billion, has been expanding its managed-care business and reported a $2.3 million profit in the second quarter, reversing a $3.8 million loss a year earlier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/08/busin.snippet: When President Bill Clinton arrived in Jakarta on his most recent swing through Asia, his hotel was mobbed. Hordes of admiring women clamored for a glimpse — not of Mr. Clinton but of another visiting celebrity who glamorously upstaged him, stirri...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/08/busin.body_text: **********When President Bill Clinton arrived in Jakarta on his most recent swing through Asia, his hotel was mobbed. Hordes of admiring women clamored for a glimpse — not of Mr. Clinton but of another visiting celebrity who glamorously upstaged him, stirring passions more than politics. **********Coraima Torres, the fiery heroine of "Kassandra," a telenovela produced in Venezuela, regularly emptied the streets of Indonesia's capital and disrupted production schedules as shopkeepers, factory workers and bureaucrats took prolonged lunch breaks to catch the latest midday episodes. Telenovelas are soap operas, except that they have a definite beginning and end, typically portraying 120 hours of stormy deceit and thwarted love. **********Now, much like the spurned bride of a soap opera, Latin American television itself is plotting a comeback. After languishing last year in the doldrums of the "tequila effect," the regional economic slowdown brought on by the devaluation of the Mexican peso, Latin America is once again a hot media market — both for importing and for exporting TV programs. **********From Amman to Beijing and Warsaw, Latin American telenovelas have captured hundreds of millions of devoted fans. The global telenovela industry is worth more than $1 billion, according to industry figures. **********U.S. and other foreign operators, meanwhile, are poised for an invasion going the other way. Although about 83 million households in Latin America have television, fewer than 10 percent currently subscribe to some form of pay television. Like latter-day conquistadors, global media companies are moving in to exploit the wide-open market. **********Warner Brothers International Television, Sony Television Entertainment, Turner Broadcasting System Inc. and Viacom Inc. are among the international program producers that have recently increased their Latin American operations. Rival consortiums led by Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. and the satellite communications operator Hughes Electronics Corp. are vying for the emerging regional market for television delivered by direct-to-home satellites. **********Discovery Communications Inc., the cable documentary network, has doubled its subscribers in two years, to 5 million households across 23 countries, and Walt Disney Co.'s cable sports network ESPN reaches 6.8 million viewers with service in English, Spanish and Portuguese. **********Growth in Viacom's MTV has been so rapid in the region that the music network is spinning off a third channel alongside its MTV Latin America and MTV Brasil services. Turner's Cable News Network International recently launched a Spanish-language service based in Argentina. **********"The conventional wisdom used to be that Asia would be the next boom television market and Latin America would follow, but now it appears that Asia will follow Latin America," said Piper Parry, a spokeswoman for Nickelodeon networks, a Viacom subsidiary. The children's network is conducting research in the region before entering an already crowded children's programming market. **********Ms. Parry joined 10,500 television executives gathered here last week for an international television market that drew a large contingent of buyers and sellers from Latin America. **********Shaky currencies still cripple the region's media industry. Investors in Venezuela and Mexico in particular continue to encounter difficulties withdrawing profits. But U.S. investors remain optimistic. **********"Once the effects of devaluation have run their course, Mexico and other Latin American countries will turn into an exceptionally strong market," said Charlotte Leonard, general manager for Turner's TNT and Cartoon Network Latin America. **********Piracy has also proven to be a major stumbling block to opening up the region. In Colombia, where there are no effective laws against program piracy, ersatz neighborhood broadcasters pull television signals from a satellite, unscramble them with a cheap decoder and beam them back out to subscribers, who are typically charged $25 a month to receive the pirated programs. **********In contrast to France, where American television programming faces stiff quotas and continues to be branded as a cultural invasion, producers in Latin America see little threat from such U.S. standards as "Baywatch" and "Beavis and Butthead." **********"Local production continues to dominate the schedules across the region, particularly in Brazil, Mexico, Argentina and the larger countries," said Alberto Peceguiero, chief executive of the Brazilian network Globosat Programadora Ltda. "So far, it doesn't look like exposure to international programs harms local production. Instituting quotas would be a grave mistake." **********Mr. Peceguiero said the principal drawback to the proliferation of new U.S. networks in the region was the threat that major U.S. studios would hold back films and series from local broadcasters to reserve them for their own networks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/19/busin.body_text: **********It isn't the jet-black hair, the silky pink dress or her endearing effervescence that win her fans, but at 60 years old, Mariko Mukai is still a siren in Japan. For millions of ordinary Japanese, who for two decades watched American movies on Japanese television, she is the sweet and syrupy falsetto of  Marilyn Monroe. **********Marilyn Monroe with a high-pitched voice? **********That's what happens when movie stars are brought to TV screens in Japan, where thousands of American movies have been dubbed into Japanese for years. Feminine allure, manly courage and the glamour of film idols take on an entirely new timbre in Japan, as Japanese directors and agents try to match American heroes and heroines with Japanese voices that will most appeal to audiences here. **********In Japanese theaters, as in American ones, foreign films tend to use subtitles. But for television -- where most Japanese see foreign films -- dubbing is considered essential, and must be accomplished with a fine ear for society's unspoken expectations. **********"We have our own Japanese image of Marilyn Monroe, which fits exactly with Mukai -- Mukai's soft, cute voice," said Takashi Fujii, Mrs. Mukai's agent. "When Japanese people think of Marilyn, we think of Mukai's voice. It's almost as if Japanese audiences have been brainwashed." **********Whitney Houston, Lauren Bacall and other movie actresses also get sky-high voice lifts by female Japanese dubbers, who are aiming for wide audiences with the traditional pitch of feminine charm. **********Such personal touches sometimes give dubbed movies an edge over subtitled films, which are common in the theaters (with the exception of popular dubbed cartoons). At least three Oscar-nominated films have been dubbed for video rentals. **********There are about 1,000 professional dubbers, but only about 300 are used for the voices of major movie roles. So famous American actors begin literally to sound alike. **********The results are sometimes surprising to an American ear. The lines of Kevin Costner, Robert Redford and even Danny DeVito, for example, are all rendered in  the rich, booming baritone voice of 52-year-old Masane Tsukayama. **********In the corner of a tiny basement room, crowded on a recent day with more than a dozen other dubbers sitting on metal chairs, Mr. Tsukayama held his helmet-like earphones with one hand as he bellowed his lines into a microphone. **********In gray tweed trousers, a white shirt and glasses, Mr. Tsukayama looked more  like a professor, with his eyes flitting back and forth between a script and a small TV screen, than the football coach he was portraying as the voice of James Caan in "The Program." **********In Japan, however, Mr. Tsukayama is well known as the voice of Mr. Costner, whose lines he has spoken in such movies as "Dances with Wolves," "Bodyguard," "Robin Hood" and "JFK." He says he is generally comfortable with Mr. Costner's acting style -- except when Mr. Costner laughs and sings. **********"Kevin is not a great singer and sometimes he misses notes," Mr. Tsukayama said. "I had to miss notes, too. It's hard to miss notes." **********Still, Mr. Costner is generally easier to dub than Robert DeNiro was as Frankenstein's monster, who curled his tongue and distorted his mouth when he spoke. Aside from trying to incorporate the sounds of those contortions into his lines, he had to accommodate the reality that a strict translation of English comes out about twice as long in Japanese. **********Thus, when Frankenstein's monster said "I LOVE YOU" in three slow, monster-like syllables, Mr. Tsukayama had to deftly work in eight syllables in a monstrous drawl. **********Some Japanese directors and agents say they try to match both the looks and the voice of actor and dubber. "For example, overweight people have overweight voices because the vocal chords are different, while skinny people have skinny voices, which tend not to be so deep," said Satoshi Kato, head director of the movie production division at Tohoku Shinsha, a production company in Tokyo. **********"It's hard to find a person to fit Schwarzenegger," Mr. Kato said. "The dubber must have a voice that is strong, manly and wild." **********Looks and attitude seemed to have helped Mrs. Mukai get her first Marilyn Monroe role. When she started dubbing 30 years ago, her manager told her that she would not get very far in her career unless she could act sexy. **********But Japan was a prudish society back then and even kissing scenes in American movies were faded-out, so there were no movies to learn from. **********When Mrs. Mukai's manager landed her a role as Monroe in "How to Marry a Millionaire," even though she had never dubbed before, Mrs. Mukai decided she had to determine what sounds were sexy on her own.  One quiet night, she heard her neighbor's baby crying and thought it sounded sexy, and she recorded it. Then a puppy whined, and she recorded that, too. **********She ended up imitating the sounds, inserting coos and whines in between her lines for Monroe. **********"The director told me I didn't have to really pay attention to Marilyn's original voice, but to just copy Marilyn's heart," Mrs. Mukai said. "So I created my own Marilyn Monroe voice." **********"I whispered a lot, almost half my lines," she said. "People expected the atmosphere of a soft, tender-like marshmallow, so I exhaled a lot."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/25/busin.body_text: **********Fed Leaves Rates Steady, Cheering Administration **********After weeks of speculation that the Federal Reserve would take a pre-emptive strike against inflation, its monetary policy officials decided not to raise interest rates, apparently believing the economy is cooling enough. **********The inaction cheered the Clinton Administration, which had feared that a rate rise just weeks before the election could undercut the Administration's claim of success in handling the economy, creating record employment. $(Page A1.$) **********Treasury prices moved higher. Traders were relieved by the inaction, and the yield on the 30-year bond fell below 7 percent. $(D16.$) **********Stocks were mixed, with blue chips dragged down by AT&T's slide. Mr. Espy, who resigned under pressure in December 1994, was not charged. $(A17.$) **********Loewen Rejects $3.1 Billion Bid **********The Loewen Group, striving to remain an independent competitor, rejected a $3.1 billion stock offer from the Service Corporation, the world's largest chain of funeral homes. Fuller Company of St. Paul, a leading adhesive manufacturer, was dismissed by a Federal judge in St. Paul, who said it should be tried in Guatemala. The suit was filed by the family of a Guatemalan teen-ager who died in 1993 from the effects of sniffing glue. $(D5.$) **********Investment Advisers Watch Suit **********If the Thompson family of Knoxville, Tenn., succeeds in an unusual lawsuit against Glenmede Trust of Philadelphia, lawyers say big changes could ensue in the way investment advisers do business. Market Place. $(D6.$) **********Pro-Bono Campaigns to Fight AIDS **********Peter Rogers, creator of the Blackglama mink campaign, is producing a series of celebrity-filled print ads for Gay Men's Health Crisis. More than 20 magazines have agreed to donate more than $1 million worth of space. Also, a print campaign, created pro bono by Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York will promote the Race to Deliver, a four-mile footrace through Central Park on Sunday to raise funds for God's Love We Deliver, which feeds homebound AIDS patients. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. $(D5.$) **********Pan Am Flies Again **********Pan American World Airways, which is to be restarted today with daily nonstops between New York and Miami and New York and Los Angeles, is offering a generous frequent-flier plan. https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/13/world.main_headline: Once Again, No Safety In Lebanon
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/13/world.print_headline: Once Again, No Safety In Lebanon
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/13/world.body_text: **********Before Israeli rockets fell on Beirut today, reproducing the familiar black smoke spirals and sirens of 14 years ago, Mohammed Nasur stood in the deserted streets of his neighborhood in the southern suburbs and peered into the overcast sky. **********"Listen, there they are -- those are the Israeli planes," said Mr. Nasur, 75, who left his village in the south of Lebanon a decade ago to flee Israeli occupiers for the relative safety of Beirut. **********Before they knew that Israel had warned civilians in southern Lebanon to evacuate, many Muslims in Beirut were talking of heading south for safety. **********But today, while many people had already fled this neighborhood controlled by the Iranian-backed Party of God, leaving it unusually quiet and empty on what would normally have been a busy day of prayer, Mr. Nasur remained. **********"Where can we go?" he said. "The whole country is in danger. These people will go to the south and then what?" **********Once the word was out about today's attacks, hundreds of cars and trucks full of villagers from the south drove bumper-to-bumper northward along the coastal road toward Tyre, Sidon and even Beirut, the only safe haven, such as it is, for Muslims who would not be welcome in the Christian-dominated areas north of the city. **********One Lebanese journalist, referring to the Party of God by its name in Arabic, said, "By hitting Beirut, the Israelis are trying to make Hezbollah understand that there is no safe place they can go." **********The exodus is posing a serious economic and relief problem for the Syrian-backed Government in Beirut. **********"The problem is bound to increase the pressure on the cash-strapped Government to house and feed this new wave of refugees," said Khalil Younis, a Lebanese economist and financial consultant. **********"It could also diminish popular sympathy and support for Hezbollah," he said. **********Party of God leaders remained nervously entrenched in their southern Beirut headquarters today, with tense gunmen patrolling empty streets where Israeli rockets struck today and on Thursday. They said they interpreted Israel's actions as raising the stakes of the conflict. **********"They have changed their tactics," said a high official within the Party of God. "We have ways to change ours. We will retaliate at the same level. If they're going to shell Beirut and kill civilians, we will hit them somewhere else." **********He added: "They have brought the war to Beirut. We don't like it, but we will fight them. This is a war, this is a military battlefield." **********Nothing seemed further from the case seven miles away in the Christian sector of the city, where a popular cafe was packed with fashionable Lebanese of all ages eating and laughing. Since the country's 15-year civil war ended in 1990, Beirut has been slowly rebuilding itself. **********In the last few years, war-weary Lebanese here had begun looking forward to a new era of civility and peace in Beirut. **********"We have had enough of the Katyusha," wrote Elias Dairri in his column Thursday in the Beirut newspaper An Nahar. "It's enough, we want to live." **********In the last few years, Beirut has seen a growing number of European tourists, new construction and foreign-funded business. Although the attacks did not cause major physical damage or noticeably interrupt daily life in most of the city today, the missiles have undoubtedly cast a pall over Beirut's perceived bright  future. **********And while Beirut residents are typically blase about the shelling, they admit concern for their future plans. **********"I thought the crisis was over. I could see things were improving," said Munah Dabaghi, from the noisy center of his new restaurant. Mr. Dabaghi, who lived in Beirut for 50 years, opened the City Cafe six months ago. He said he hopes Beirut will not become a battleground, but is confident that the city can  survive. **********"We can live through anything," he said. "Life goes on here in any circumstances. We just thought that they were getting better."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/13/busin.main_headline: SHARES OF ALLERGAN CLIMB 7% ON TAKEOVER SPECULATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/13/busin.print_headline: SHARES OF ALLERGAN CLIMB 7% ON TAKEOVER SPECULATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/13/busin.body_text: **********The shares of Allergan Inc. rose 7 percent on speculation the company may be acquired and optimism about new products in development. Allergan's shares rose $2.375, to $35.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts said speculation that Allergan, which is based in Irvine, Calif., could be acquired was renewed after Hoechst A.G. said this week that it would pay $3.5 billion to buy the shares in the French drug maker Roussel Uclaf that it does not already own. Allergan is often the subject of takeover speculation because its market value of about $2.3 billion is relatively small for a pharmaceutical company. In addition, Allergan said its new treatment for psoriasis and acne, Zorac, had been approved for sale in Germany. Zorac is expected to be a major product for Allergan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/05/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Unlikely Credits for a Korean Movie Mogul
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/05/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Unlikely Credits for a Korean Movie Mogul
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/05/busin.body_text: **********Miky Lee sees nothing odd in her family company jumping from making sugar, shampoo and swine feed to making movies with Steven Spielberg. **********"We're pleasing their mouths and their bodies," she said of consumers. "And now they want to be pleased with their eyes and ears." **********Thin as that rationale may be, Ms. Lee, with almost no corporate experience, has at 38 become South Korea's first Hollywood mogul. **********Miky Lee (pronounced Mickey and derived from her Korean name, Mie Kyung) arranged for Cheil Foods and Chemicals Inc., the stodgy sugar and flour maker controlled by her family, to invest $300 million for 11 percent of Dreamworks SKG, the entertainment company established last year by Mr. Spielberg, Jeffrey Katzenberg and David Geffen. **********Cheil is the second-largest outside investor in Dreamworks, behind Paul G. Allen, a co-founder of the Microsoft Corporation, and has exclusive rights to distribute its films in Asia, outside of Japan. **********Now Ms. Lee, a rare example of a successful businesswoman in Korea's male-oriented business world, hopes to turn the company, recently renamed the Cheil Jedang Corporation, into a major producer and distributor of movies in South Korea and the rest of the booming Asian market. **********The Dreamworks investment shocked people on both sides of the Pacific, with many predictions that Cheil would face the same losses and embarrassing culture  clashes suffered by Sony and Matsushita in Hollywood. **********"They've decided to diversify into an area in which they have no experience," said Jonathan Dutton, an analyst with SBC Warburg Securities in Seoul. Cheil wanted to diversify out of the low-margin food business, but doing so by investing in a Hollywood company, he said, is "a risky business." **********But Ms. Lee is confident, saying, "We don't have any doubt that we will get the money back." **********And while Sony and Matsushita bought existing studios, she noted, Cheil and Dreamworks have been partners from the beginning. "We believe in each other," she said, adding that Mr. Spielberg "has the innocence of a child." **********She said Cheil wants to learn from Dreamworks, not tell it what to do. She speaks on the phone with Mr. Katzenberg often, and she and her brother, Jay, will be attending Dreamworks board meetings four times a year. **********"I understand Hollywood culture to the extent I need to understand," she said in an interview in her office, where "Entertainment Industry Economics," a book  by Hal Vogel, a Wall Street analyst, lay on the coffee table. **********While Cheil's move was the most dramatic, other Korean companies are also courting Hollywood. Earlier this year, the Samsung Group paid $60 million for 7.4 percent of New Regency Productions of Burbank, Calif., an independent company that made "JFK" and "Pretty Woman." **********The Hyundai Group's Diamond Ad Ltd. unit recently formed an alliance with Canal Plus of France involving joint film production. Kolon Industries says it is negotiating with the Walt Disney Company in the areas of cartoons and character licensing. And Daewoo is making a big push into movie-making and theaters. **********The companies are, among other things, seeking films and other material to distribute in the theaters, video stores and cable systems that are sprouting in South Korea now that people here can finally afford more leisure. **********Multiplexes are going up throughout Asia, which should mean growing markets for the movies made by Dreamworks and distributed by Cheil. Pay television, home video and movie revenues rose 7 percent in Korea and 27 percent in Asia as  a whole last year, according to the Motion Picture Association of America. **********Korea's family-owned conglomerates, known as chaebol, have no qualms about diversifying, and perhaps Ms. Lee's daring is in her genes. **********Her grandfather, Lee Byung Chull, a commodities trader, set up Cheil, a sugar refinery, in 1953. He kept on diversifying, building today's Samsung Group, South Korea's largest chaebol, with revenues of more than $80 billion and businesses ranging from ship building to semiconductors. **********Ms. Lee's father, Lee Maeng Hee, the founder's eldest son, was expected to inherit control, but he was passed over in favor of his younger brother, Lee Kun Hee. Ms. Lee's branch of the family was given control of Cheil, once the core of the empire but until recently an unglamorous outpost. Ms. Lee's younger brother, Lee Jai Hyun, 36, called Jay, effectively runs the company. **********Cheil had revenues of $1.8 billion in 1995 but recurring profits of only $12.5 million. Its real wealth, which allowed it to borrow to invest in Dreamworks, is its more than $2 billion in assets, much of it in stock it owns in other Samsung companies. **********Relations between the branches of the family are said to be strained, and Cheil has been trying to break free of Samsung, but disagreements with Samsung have slowed the divorce process. **********Hence the latest investment was all the more satisfying: Samsung itself had the first shot at Dreamworks, but its deal fell apart. **********Ms. Lee grew up in Korea watching Disney shows on television in black and white. In 1983, after getting her undergraduate degree from a university in Seoul, she earned a master's degree in East Asian languages at Harvard. From there she went to Taiwan and then Hong Kong, where she worked on a doctoral thesis. **********"I always wanted to be a professor," she said. "I really didn't even imagine  that I would be working in the company." **********But Ms. Lee never quite finished her Ph.D., in 1994 going to work for a Samsung subsidiary in America. She helped set up the Samsung Art and Design Institute in Korea, a joint venture with the Parsons School of Design in New York. Then one day an American lawyer friend called to ask if Samsung would be interested in investing in Dreamworks. **********A $900 million investment was discussed at a dinner at Mr. Spielberg's house. But Samsung officials, led by the president, Lee Kun Hee, spent a bit too much time talking about semiconductors to please the Dreamworks founders. "I kept on  saying to them," Mr. Geffen recalled, that "if we were only interested in making money we'd also build semiconductor plants." **********Dreamworks' founders were also uncomfortable with Samsung's insistence that it be the only outside investor and have effective control. **********For whatever reason, the two groups parted ways. Then Paul Allen invested $500 million, reducing the amount Dreamworks needed. Ms. Lee asked her brother,  and the two won the deal for Cheil. **********"They were enthusiastic about what we were doing," Mr. Geffen said. "Their determination was particularly impressive to Steven, who responds well to enthusiasm." **********But enthusiasm can go only so far. **********The Cheil multimedia division, headed by Ms. Lee, consists of 33 people, 23 of them recruited from within Cheil. **********Ms. Lee, diminutive but energetic, runs things informally. "She is not like Korean men, giving orders and expecting them to be followed," said Steven J. Searle, Ms. Lee's high school English teacher, who now works for the multimedia  division. "To do anything creative, you have to have a soft touch." **********To get help in distribution, Cheil turned to Raymond Chow, the founder of Hong Kong's Golden Harvest Entertainment Ltd., a big movie producer and distributor known for bringing the world Bruce Lee and Jackie Chan, not to mention the Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles. **********Cheil and Golden Harvest have a joint venture to distribute movies throughout Asia, and another venture, with an Australian company, to build multiplexes in Korea. **********Cheil has also set up a division to make movies in partnership with the director Kim Jong Hak and the screenwriter Song Ji Na, who collaborated on a searing television drama about the 1980 massacre of pro-democracy demonstrators  in the Korean city of Kwangju. **********In making movies, Cheil is supposed to get help from Dreamworks. Miky Lee organized a field trip to watch Dreamworks work on "The Prince of Egypt," its first animated film. And Cheil hopes to send interns to work in California. **********But Mr. Kim said the gap between Cheil and Dreamworks was so huge that it might be difficult for Cheil to apply what it learned. "It's like talking about  a relationship between a kindergarten child and a university student," he said.  "We don't know what we need, and they don't know what to give." **********Mr. Kim said Mr. Spielberg would have been frustrated trying to make movies in Korea. At a reception, Mr. Kim once shocked Mr. Spielberg by telling him: "If you had been born in Korea, you would have ended up in a mental hospital." **********But Ms. Lee said Cheil's work would help Korea's poorly developed movie industry. "Our investment in Dreamworks is not a destination," she said. "It's the departing point."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/15/world.main_headline: U.N. Survey Finds World Rich-Poor Gap Widening
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/15/world.print_headline: U.N. Survey Finds World Rich-Poor Gap Widening
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/15/world.body_text: **********In the wake of reports that gaps between rich and poor in the United States are wider than they have been in half a century, a United Nations survey to be published on Wednesday finds that the phenomenon is worldwide, and that the wealthiest and poorest people -- both within and among countries -- are living in increasingly separate worlds. **********Moreover, the United States is slipping into a category of countries -- among them Brazil, Britain and Guatemala -- where economic stratification is most pronounced, with the national per capita income four times or more higher than the average income of the poor, according to the survey, the Human Development Report 1996, compiled by the United Nations Development Program. **********The ratio of the top 20 percent of American incomes to the poorest 20 percent is now 9 to 1, the study shows. **********"An emerging global elite, mostly urban-based and interconnected in a variety of ways, is amassing great wealth and power, while more than half of humanity is left out," said James Gustave Speth, an American who is administrator of the Development Program. **********"We still have more than half the people on the planet with incomes of less than $2 a day -- more than 3 billion people," Mr. Speth said in an interview on  Thursday. "For poor people in this two-class world, it is a breeding ground for  hopelessness, for anger, for frustration." **********The Human Development report will be released officially in Tokyo on Wednesday by Richard Jolly, its principal author. **********A nation's total wealth is not an adequate guide to how its people live, the  survey says. In nations as diverse as the Netherlands, Japan, Bangladesh and Nepal, the gap between average incomes and those of the poorest 20 percent of the population is half that of the United States. **********The distribution of private economic assets, in property and investments, widen American differences even more. **********Many of the most equitable societies are now in East and Southeast Asia, where economic growth has been fastest but where at the same time the division of national wealth has been the fairest, the report says. **********The annual Human Development Report was first published in 1990 as a new way  to measure countries' progress by going beyond gross national product to factor  in life expectancy, education and adjusted real incomes. The report's Human Development Index ranks countries by health, sanitation, the treatment of women  and other aspects of life that give what the authors believe is a truer picture  of day-to-day existence. **********This year, Canada leads the index with the most advanced overall human development, followed by the United States, Japan, the Netherlands and Norway. On a list of 174 countries, Russia ranks 57th, China 108th and India 135th. Africa south of the Sahara dominates the bottom. **********When the list is adjusted to reflect the status of women, the United States drops to fourth place among 137 countries, behind Sweden, Canada and Norway. Japan drops to 12th place, while China rises to 79th. **********The 1996 report introduces another new measure of national growth -- or lack  of it. Called a "capability poverty measure," this index tries to find hidden or potential poverty by looking at factors like the percentage of children under 5  who are underweight, the proportion of unattended births, the number of children in school and rate of female illiteracy. In other words, is a nation programming poverty and disadvantage into coming generations? **********For example, in South Asia -- India and its neighbors, except Sri Lanka -- 29 percent of the people are living in severe poverty when income alone is measured, but more than 62 percent are living in conditions that can negatively  affect their futures. **********John Sewell, president of the Overseas Development Council, a private policy  research organization in Washington, said in an interview that social indicators can no longer be overlooked by any country focused on national economic growth. The era of choosing between a welfare state or a bigger G.N.P.  is over; social and economic factors work together, he said. **********"It is clear by now in the developing world that the prime responsibility for progress has to fall to those governments and societies themselves," he said. "Nothing much is going to change until countries take the steps to invest in people, educate women and create a health care system that works while also adopting policies that are going to lead to economic growth." **********In Asia, as in the Scandinavian countries a generation or more ago, a number  of countries -- among them Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore -- have spent significant sums on health, education, the advancement of women and the provision of credit to low-income families and small-scale entrepreneurs. But they also focused simultaneously on national economic growth, and this two-track policy led to "the most sustained and widespread development miracle of the 20th century, perhaps all history," the report says. **********At the independent Cato Institute in Washington, Ian Vasquez, director of the Project on Global Economic Liberty, is skeptical about more foreign aid and about reports by agencies with an interest in continuing or expanding assistance programs. **********"The evidence over the past 30 to 40 years shows quite clearly that economic  reforms, especially of the market-oriented type, help raise the standards of living dramatically more than traditional programs supported by foreign aid agencies like the U.N.D.P.," Mr. Vasquez said in an interview. **********"The real story is that the conditions of people around the world have vastly improved over the last 50 or so years," he said. Progress rests with liberalizing economic policies, not outside support, he added. **********Among the 1996 Human Development report's other findings are these: ***********Worldwide, 358 billionaires control assets greater than the combined annual  incomes of countries with 45 percent of the world's people. ***********Eighty-nine countries are worse off economically than they were a decade or  more ago. In 70 developing countries, incomes are lower than they were in the 1960's or 1970's. In 19 countries, including Ghana, Haiti, Liberia, Nicaragua, Rwanda and Venezuela, per capita income is below the 1960 level. **********The Human Development Report 1996 is published by Oxford University Press at  $18.95 in paperback and $29.95 in hard cover.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/20/busin.main_headline: G.M. to Merge GMC Division With Pontiac
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/20/busin.print_headline: G.M. to Merge GMC Division With Pontiac
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/20/busin.body_text: **********The General Motors Corporation plans to announce on Tuesday the merger of its Pontiac and GMC divisions, a sign that G.M. management is moving to consolidate  the conflicting brands and corporate fiefs that have hampered the auto maker for decades. **********General Motors will announce that it is combining the staffs and dealer networks of the two divisions into a single marketing unit headed by Roy S. Roberts, now the general manager of the highly successful GMC truck division, company officials said today. **********The division will sell a full range of Pontiac cars and GMC sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks. General Motors's marketers will try to give the combined division a brand image projecting physical power and outdoor activity,  all aimed at attracting youthful middle-income buyers. **********John G. Middlebrook, the general manager of Pontiac, will become the general  manager of the Chevrolet division, while Jimmy C. Perkins, the general manager of Chevrolet who is close to retirement, will be put on special assignment, according to the G.M. officials, who spoke on the condition that they not be identified. The details of Mr. Perkins's new assignment were not clear tonight.  Nor was it clear what would become of lower-level managers with duplicative responsibilities. **********A spokesman for General Motors declined to comment on the company officials'  disclosure. **********The combination of GMC and Pontiac represents a bureaucratic victory for Ronald L. Zarrella, the vice president for North American marketing at General Motors. Unlike most General Motors executives, Mr. Zarrella is a newcomer to the auto industry, having been brought into the company 15 months ago after serving  as president of Bausch & Lomb Inc., the Rochester-based maker of contact lenses  and sunglasses. **********Mr. Zarrella is a specialist in managing brands, and has already taken an active role in designing the marketing campaigns for the midsize sedans that Chevrolet, Pontiac, Buick and Oldsmobile plan to introduce over the next two years. The new cars, which were displayed at the North American International Auto Show here last month, resemble each other in many ways. But General Motors  plans to promote separate brand images for each of them. **********Mr. Zarrella is the protege of John G. Smale, an outside director of General  Motors who took over as chairman from 1992 until the end of last year. Mr. Smale is a former chairman of the Procter & Gamble Company and a consumer goods marketing specialist like Mr. Zarrella. **********David L. Lewis, a professor of business history at the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor, said a merger of Pontiac and GMC would represent the first time since the creation of General Motors in 1908 that the company has reduced the number of its car divisions. While the Cadillac division dropped its LaSalle line on the eve of World War II, and the Buick division dropped its Marquette line a few years earlier, the divisions themselves have been remarkably durable, he said. **********Within months of being formed in 1908, General Motors acquired the Rapid Motor Vehicle Company and renamed it the General Motors Truck Company, the corporate ancestor of the GMC division today. The current Pontiac division is the direct descendant of General Motors' Oakland division, which the company acquired in 1909. **********The company's Chevrolet, Pontiac, Oldsmobile, Buick and Cadillac divisions were shaped by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., the legendary marketer and chairman of General Motors, to each pursue customers of a different income range. Buyers were expected to start with a Chevrolet and work up to a Cadillac as they became more prosperous. **********Mr. Sloan's slogan was, "A car for every purse and purpose." But over the years, the lines between the brands became blurred, as each division began pursuing a broad range of customers and competing ever more directly with other General Motors divisions. **********Combining the Pontiac and GMC units is the easiest step for General Motors to take in consolidating divisions because they have the least overlap. Pontiac mostly produces fairly sporty cars and GMC mostly produces sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks. **********Opposition from car dealers, as well as corporate resistance within General Motors, has slowed past efforts to consolidate brands. But while General Motors  has separate Buick, Oldsmobile and Chevrolet dealers in some towns, all competing bitterly with each other, about two-thirds of its Pontiac and GMC dealers sell vehicles from both divisions. **********Jim Bradley, owner of a Cadillac, Pontiac and GMC dealership in Ann Arbor, Mich., said tonight that he favored the combination. **********"I can see some significant savings for G.M.," Mr. Bradley said. "You don't need to have two different people from two different organizations calling on" each dealership.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/14/world.main_headline: Two Attacks On Foreigners Raise Tension In Bosnia
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/14/world.print_headline: Two Attacks On Foreigners Raise Tension In Bosnia
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/14/world.body_text: **********Two attacks on foreigners, including the shooting of an American working for  the United States Embassy, have heightened tensions in Bosnia and may also increase concerns that any attempt by NATO forces to arrest Bosnian Serb leaders for war crimes could result in retaliation against foreigners. **********The American, a woman whose name was not released, was shot in the back late  Friday night while she and her husband were driving between Kiseljak and Sarajevo. She was reported in stable condition after undergoing surgery at a NATO military hospital. **********American Embassy officials said that the circumstances surrounding the shooting were not clear and that it was possible the assailant did not know the  victim's nationality. **********But the second attack, two hours later, was clearly directed against foreigners. An explosive charge was set off under a truck parked in front of the office of United Nations police monitors in this Bosnian Serb-controlled town in northeastern Bosnia. **********The explosion demolished the truck and damaged the building, which also contained the living quarters of three monitors -- one Senegalese and two Nepalese. Two of the monitors were slightly wounded. **********One monitor said the attack was clearly an attempt by "local extremists" to intimidate them. "They want to scare us, to terrorize us," he said. **********The headquarters of the Bosnian Serb military commander, Gen. Ratko Mladic, is about six miles away. He and the Bosnian Serb political leader, Radovan Karadzic, have been indicted on war crimes charges, and on Thursday the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague issued arrest warrants for them. **********The warrants, along with increasingly strong statements by foreign diplomats  in Bosnia that the two men must be removed from power if free elections set for  September are to be held, have heightened concerns among senior officers in the  NATO-led peacekeeping force about retaliatory attacks on their soldiers or on other foreigners. **********One officer said today that there was already a strong feeling among his colleagues that the consequences of having NATO forces arrest the two men could  be so severe that the arrests would jeopardize the peace rather than strengthen  it. **********American military officers have predicted that Bosnian Serb forces might begin testing NATO's resolve with small incidents. One said that although NATO forces were prepared to enforce military aspects of the Bosnia peace agreement,  they would have trouble containing acts of random violence. **********Aside from the fact that the two attacks occurred on the same evening, American military officers said they could see no connection. **********The shooting of the American woman took place in an area under Muslim and Croatian control. **********Some of the United Nations police monitors who work in Vlasenica said the explosion there might also have been a response to war crimes investigations by  the United Nations. **********The United Nations monitors' station is near the area where investigators from the war crimes tribunal are exhuming the bodies of Muslim men thought to have been massacred by Serbs after they seized the town of Srebrenica one year ago. **********Serbian officials insist that there were no such mass murders of men from Srebrenica and say United Nations efforts to prove there were are part of an international conspiracy against the Serbian people.

He was 89. **********Mr. Trimble began his career as a vice consul in Seville, Spain, in 1931 and  finished it in 1968 as Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs.  In 1958, he became United States Ambassador to Cambodia, where he remained until 1962. **********Mr. Trimble is survived by his wife of 62 years, Nancy Gordon Carroll Trimble; a daughter, Carroll L. Cabot of Manchester, Mass.; two sons, T. Ridgeway and William C. Jr., both of Baltimore; a brother, the Rev. Canon David  C. Trimble of Boonsboro, Md.; five grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/19/world.snippet: Manuel Antonio National Park, jungle paradise in Quepos, Costa Rica, is imperiled by large numbers of tourists who upset natural balance; sign now warns that monkeys have become aggressive and dangerous as result of being fed; other problems of de...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/19/world.main_headline: Today's Garden of Eden, Fouled by Adam and Eve
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/19/world.print_headline: Today's Garden of Eden, Fouled by Adam and Eve
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/19/world.body_text: **********Over the last decade, more than a million people have visited Manuel Antonio National Park here, attracted by the capuchin monkeys, two-toed sloths, poisonous dart frogs, the long-tailed coatimundi and scarlet macaws that roam its lush rain forest. **********But the sign that now greets visitors is somewhat less than welcoming, and suggests that the boom in ecotourism may be too much of a good thing for this jungle paradise. **********''Because of people feeding the monkeys, they are now aggressive and dangerous,'' warns the sign in English at the main entrance to the 1,700-acre park, which can be reached only by fording a small stream. ''Three children have been attacked in the last three months.'' **********Nurtured by the Costa Rican Government and foreign conservationists as an ecologically pristine alternative to mass tourism destinations, this Pacific Coast reserve appears to have become a victim of its own success. **********Camping within the park has been prohibited because too many animals were eating human waste and falling ill, and the hotels built to cash in on the area's renown are now dumping their sewage into the sea. **********''Five or six years ago, I was extremely outspoken against runaway development in Manuel Antonio and places like it,'' said Michael Kaye, an American who operates a company specializing in ecotourism, Costa Rica Expeditions, in the capital, San Jose. ''But that damage has been done, so the thing we have to do now is mitigate its effects.'' **********The continued well-being of Manuel Antonio and 27 other parks and reserves is of vital interest to this Central American country of 3.5 million people. Thanks largely to Costa Rica's reputation as a haven for the environmentally aware, tourism now surpasses bananas as the main source of foreign exchange, drawing more than 800,000 foreign visitors each year, earning $700 million and providing jobs to thousands. **********''There have been some errors committed, but we know we have a moral duty to protect these riches, and we are doing our best to carry it out,'' said Carlos Roesch Carranza, the Minister of Tourism. ''Those in the tourism business have to understand that the only guarantee for the investment that they have made is to act logically and responsibly, or else our national parks will lose their attractiveness and they will be the losers.'' **********Without exception, international conservation groups give the Costa Rican Government high marks.  Nearly one-quarter of the country has been set aside for national parks, biosphere reserves or other protected areas, and Costa Rica has also led the way in innovative experiments like carbon offset agreements, which relax emission requirements for utilities that agree to protect tropical forests. **********''What they have done in Costa Rica is just great,'' said James Nations, a Latin America specialist at Conservation International, a Washington-based environmental group. ''As conservationists, we want to send the message that tourism can be a great ecological tool, and Costa Rica has done that and prospered by protecting so much of its natural ecosystems.'' **********But the experience of Manuel Antonio National Park suggests that ecologically oriented tourism can create its own problems. Established a quarter of a century ago, after the land was expropriated from a retired American Navy officer who planned to build beach-front condominiums, the park began to boom in the mid-1980's, when word of its unspoiled beauty spread among nature lovers in North America and Western Europe. **********By the early 1990's, the park was being visited by 200,000 people a year, far beyond its capacity to absorb. To dampen the appeal, park officials have limited visitors to 600 a day, raised the entrance fee tenfold to nearly $15, and now close the park altogether on Mondays. By last year, the measures resulted in a decrease in the number of visitors of nearly 50 percent, to 110,000. **********''We have gained some relief for the park with that decline,'' said Jose  Antonio Salazar, a park service official who supervises Manuel Antonio and other Pacific Coast reserves. ''But the whole tourist infrastructure has suffered as a result, and all the hotel and restaurant owners are complaining now, with some having to sell their businesses.'' **********Outside the park there are more than 100 hotels, ranging from small bed-and-breakfast establishments to the inevitable Hotel California. To build one luxury, Dutch-owned hotel called El Parador, rangers at the national park said, a hillside on a peninsula overlooking the sea was flattened with dynamite, which so frightened monkeys and other animals that some jumped onto power lines and were electrocuted. **********Along with the many restaurants, bars and nightclubs that have also sprung up, the hotels produce large amounts of waste. But the area still lacks a sewage system, so the refuse is dumped directly into the sea. **********''That is something we have needed from the time Quepos first exploded as a tourist destination a decade ago,'' said Carlos Munoz Vazquez, the municipal administrator here. ''But sewers are an extremely expensive investment that the municipality cannot confront, costing perhaps $10 million, so we have been reduced to taking palliative measures.'' **********Manuel Antonio National Park also has a 212-square-mile maritime component, which has been so successful in attracting marine life that schools of tuna, sailfish, dorado, wahoo and roosterfish now flourish in the surrounding unprotected waters. As a result, the area just outside the park's boundaries has become a favorite place for sport fishermen from around the world, who pay up to $800 a day to charter boats. **********But the fishermen do not seem quite as enthusiastic as ecotourists about spending their free time hiking the jungle trails or attending nature discussion groups. So three small casinos have recently opened here, where visitors with big bankrolls can gamble to their hearts' content. That, in turn, appears to have attracted a few prostitutes. **********''The backpackers aren't the kind of people who spend a lot of money,'' the owner of one casino, who spoke on condition he not be identified, said with some disdain. ''We much prefer the fishermen, and we hope that more of them will be coming.'' **********Mr. Kaye, whose company operates three hotels here that have turned to alternative sources of energy like solar power for half their electricity, argues that ''the situation is definitely salvageable.'' But he also said that he has begun ''looking to Panama'' as an alternative destination for clients. **********''Ecotourists want to feel like they are in an area that is pristine, and as an area gets too much attention, they will go looking for other places they feel are still pristine,'' Mr. Nations said. ''So we need to extend the benefits of ecotourism to areas that are receiving no visitors and in that way defuse the dangers to places that are being overused.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/01/world.main_headline: World News Briefs;De Klerk's Party Wins Voting in Cape Town
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/01/world.print_headline: World News Briefs;De Klerk's Party Wins Voting in Cape Town
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/01/world.body_text: **********Defying speculation that South Africa's white-led National Party would quickly pass from the national scene, it has romped to victory in local elections in the Cape Town area. **********With most of the votes counted after elections on Wednesday, it was clear that the National Party had won in almost all the rural areas at stake and at least four of six metropolitan areas. **********The African National Congress, the party of President Nelson Mandela, did make some gains, but party officials said they were disappointed. **********National Party leaders, trying to remold their image in the new South Africa, were jubilant about the results. The party has said that it wants to rebuild itself around promoting "core values," not racial segregation. **********Most of the country and large parts of Western Cape province, which contains  Cape Town, had already held nonracial elections for local government last November. But a dispute over boundaries delayed the vote in the Cape Town area,  a National Party stronghold in the 1994 election, until Wednesday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/08/busin.snippet: Market Place column: Wall Street bankers say weakness in shares of telephone companies could stanch flood of mergers that has transformed these industries in recent months; they cite Worldcom's takeover of MFS Communications, worth $14 billion whe...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/08/busin.main_headline: As Shares Slip, So Do Phone Deals' Worth
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/08/busin.print_headline: As Shares Slip, So Do Phone Deals' Worth
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/08/busin.body_text: **********''Cash is king,'' Robert Maxwell used to say. And although the late British media mogul did not heed his own words in making deals, his motto is timely for today's frenzied deal-makers. **********In the media and telecommunications industries, where much of this year's merger activity has taken place, slumping stock prices have recently eroded the value of several landmark deals. **********Worldcom's takeover of MFS Communications, which was worth $14 billion when it was announced on Aug. 26, is now worth only $11.8 billion. That is because Worldcom's shares have dropped 15 percent on fears that the long-distance carrier paid too much for MFS. **********U S West and Continental Cablevision, which announced a $10.8 billion merger in February, said yesterday they had agreed to a reduced price for the U S West stock that is being used to acquire Continental. **********Shares of the U S West Media Group, which tracks the performance of the phone company's cable properties and which is being used to finance the deal, has fallen 20 percent since it was announced -- a decline so precipitous that it threatened to derail the merger. But Continental agreed yesterday to value U S West Media Group's shares at $21, a 16 percent premium to their market price at yesterday's close, which will let the two companies finish the deal by the end of November. **********The MFS-Worldcom deal also seems likely to go through, analysts said. Still, several Wall Street bankers said the weakness in the shares of telephone companies could stanch -- at least temporarily -- the flood of deals that has transformed these industries in recent months. **********''Worldcom has spooked people about making these bold-stroke deals,'' said one leading banker, who spoke on condition of anonymity. **********In addition, phone companies are still struggling to make sense of the profound regulatory changes unleashed by the Telecommunications Act of 1996. Until the new rules are set, analysts said, even deal-minded executives may hold back. **********''It's almost like you've just run a marathon, and you need a couple of days off before you can run it again,'' said Daniel Reingold, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company. **********With telephone companies' reliable earnings and cash flow, their shares are a ready currency for huge acquisitions. This year alone, Bell Atlantic agreed to merge with Nynex in a stock deal worth $22.1 billion, while SBC Communications agreed to acquire Pacific Telesis for $16 billion in stock. **********But those deals involved companies in similar businesses and with similar stock market values. So after initial deal-related swings, the declines in shares of the acquiring companies have been mirrored by declines in the prices of the companies being bought, reflecting general sentiment about the industry. The troubles have arisen in deals involving dissimilar companies with divergent stock market values. **********In the case of U S West and Continental, for example, the regional Bell is acquiring the nation's third-largest cable operator. Complicating matters, U S West Media Group shares track the performance of the company's other cable assets, which include, among other things, a 25 percent stake in Time Warner Cable. **********Like other major cable operators, the U S West Media Group has seen its shares languish in recent months. But as a tracking stock issued by a phone company, analysts said, U S West Media Group carries two extra burdens: the regulatory uncertainty of the phone industry and Wall Street's traditional ambivalence for these so-called letter stocks because of their hybrid quality. **********Executives at U S West and Continental sought to put the best face on matters in a telephone conference call yesterday. **********''We are solidly committed to this deal,'' said Amos B. Hostetter, the chairman and founder of Continental, ''We'll survive any short-term ups and downs in the stock market.'' **********U S West executives noted that the deal contained a mix of stock and cash -- and that they had the discretion to pay anywhere from $1 billion to $1.5 billion in cash, and to issue anywhere from $2.8 billion to $3.3 billion in Continental stock. **********But people familiar with Continental said that Mr. Hostetter felt pressured to accept a fixed -- and relatively low -- per-share price for U S West stock, because the deal was structured so that U S West could have scuttled it. Given the weakness of the cable industry, Mr. Hostetter may not have wanted to start peddling his company from scratch. **********In the case of Worldcom, the nation's fourth-largest long-distance carrier acquired MFS, a provider of alternative local phone access. While analysts applauded the strategic advantages of the combination, they questioned why Worldcom, based in Jackson, Miss., agreed to pay a 37 percent premium for MFS, which had negative net earnings in 1995. **********Worldcom shareholders were doubly surprised because the deal will dilute the company's per-share earnings for three years. Bernard J. Ebbers, the company's president and chief executive, had promised he would not do a dilutive deal. **********Executives at Worldcom acknowledged that Mr. Ebbers caught his shareholders off guard, but they defended the deal itself. **********''The reaction to the announcement was more dramatic than it probably should have been,'' said Charles Cannada, senior vice president of corporate development. ''This is a transaction that creates shareholder value over the long term.'' Mr. Cannada added that he believed that Worldcom's share price had ''bottomed out.'' **********Despite these troubled deals, some investment bankers said that telephone companies' appetite for blockbuster deals was far from slaked. The industry's deregulation, they said, was simply too strong a force to be stymied by oscillating share prices. **********Some bankers even predicted a fresh round of deals, involving long-distance carriers like AT&T and MCI, and alternative local-access providers like the Teleport Communications Group. **********''I think all the factors that are causing people to combine are still there,'' said Jack Roberts, an investment banker at Bear, Stearns & Company, who advised Nynex on its merger with Bell Atlantic. ''This is being driven by strategic necessity, not by price.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/26/busin.main_headline: Giscard Seeks EMU With French Accent
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/26/busin.print_headline: Giscard Seeks EMU With French Accent
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/26/busin.body_text: **********Rejecting the idea that Germany was in a position to dictate the terms of European monetary union, former President Valéry Giscard d'Estaing of France said Thursday that it was time for Paris to exert more influence over the project and demand some easing of its tough economic conditions. **********"The Germans have expressed themselves," Mr. Giscard d'Estaing said, referring to Bonn's high-pressure campaign in recent months for strict budget discipline before and after monetary union. "It's normal that the French speak, too." **********The French will need to do plenty of speaking in the weeks ahead. Mr. Giscard d'Estaing's call for a softening of the economic criteria in order to guarantee the 1999 date for a single currency, made in a Brussels speech Wednesday, has highlighted a fundamental Franco-German rift that is fueling doubts about monetary union. **********German officials have insistedthe criteria must take precedence over the timetable to assure its citizens and the markets that the Euro will be as stable as the Deutsche mark. The Foreign Ministry in Bonn issued a statement Thursday formally rejecting Mr. Giscard d'Estaing's proposal. **********Speaking in Paris, the former president defended his idea and argued that it suited Germany's interests as well. **********The current economic slump is a stark change from the strong growth Europe was experiencing when the Maastricht treaty on European integration was written in 1991, Mr. Giscard d'Estaing noted. **********If European governments seek to fulfill the letter of Maastricht and cut their budget deficits to below 3 percent of gross domestic product by 1997, he said, they risk worsening the slowdown and further alienating a public that already blames Maastricht for recession and unemployment. **********Instead, he said, political leaders need to remember that the treaty does permit deficits above 3 percent if they have fallen close to that level, or if the overshoot is "exceptional or temporary." The real aim, he contended, is a convergence of performance among European economies rather than the achievement of arbitrary deficit and debt ratios. **********"We can be in a situation of convergence without pursuing a deflationary policy," he said. **********Such a flexible interpretation of the Maastricht criteria would avoid the risk of delaying the 1999 deadline, which many French officials believe would be tantamount to abandoning the project. That would be a huge national setback because the single currency for two decades has been held out as a vehicle for weakening Bundesbank leverage over monetary policy. **********"For us, the essential point is the date," Mr. Giscard d'Estaing said. "We must respect the date of January 1, 1999." **********The key to bridging the Franco-German differences over the criteria and timetable lies in Finance Minister Theo Waigel's plan for a stability pact on public spending, Mr. Giscard d'Estaing said. Firm commitments to long-term budget discipline should persuade Germans that the Euro will be solid money, he said. **********For now, Bonn is determined not to fudge therules. **********"It will require a lot of political leadership to resist populist tendencies," one senior German official said. "The point is whether the recipes offered, either reducing the time pressure or weakening the criteria, will help increase competitiveness or jobs. The answer is flatly no." **********But others said Mr.Giscard d'Estaing had helped to clear any remaining taboos about the single currency plan.

London office for British advertising; at that time, the Umbro billings worldwide were estimated at $30 million. However, D.M.B.& B. resigned the account in the United States this month, citing contractual problems. **********Barry Breede, vice president for marketing at Umbro North America, said Goodby, Silverstein would "help us establish a worldwide brand position from which D.M.B.& B. in London will execute advertising to run in Europe." **********And Kohl's Department Stores in Menomonee Falls, Wis., named J. Walter Thompson Detroit to handle the creative and media parts of its broadcast advertising account, which had been handled by William Eisner & Associates in Hales Corners, Wis., for the last nine years.
