https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/24/busin.snippet: Ford Motor Co advertising drive uses old-fashioned snob appeal in outdoorsy setting to sell firm's Expedition sports utility vehicle; ads, like vehicle itself, are oversized and bold (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/24/busin.main_headline: In the campaign for its new sports utility vehicle, Ford its traveling the young and haughty road.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/24/busin.print_headline: In the campaign for its new sports utility vehicle, Ford its traveling the young and haughty road.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/24/busin.body_text: **********THE Ford Motor Company is using old-fashioned snob appeal in an outdoorsy setting to sell its all-new Expedition, a big brother to its popular Ford Explorer model. **********Ford is scheduled to begin its fall advertising blitz for 1997 models on Sunday. The centerpiece of a slew of new television spots will be ads for the Expedition, a giant sport utility vehicle. All ads are by J. Walter Thompson Detroit, a unit of WPP Group and Ford's longtime advertising agency. **********Ford's most important ad campaign this fall takes aim at sporty yuppies who are willing to pay at least $28,000 to impress their friends while driving a sport utility vehicle that seats up to nine people. **********Like the Expedition itself, the ads are oversized and bold. **********One TV spot begins with a helicopter hovering low over a snow-covered mountain. It drops off two skiers who have come to schuss down the untouched powder. The skiers are surprised to come across a Ford Expedition, which carries a 30-something couple dressed in expensive ski gear. **********The couple are disgusted by the idea that they don't have the mountain entirely to themselves. ''It is getting so crowded around here,'' the man says impatiently. ''We're outta here,'' the woman replies. They toss their skis in the back of the Expedition and drive on to commune more privately with the great outdoors. **********Another ad opens with two men who look to be in their early 40's riding on a small pontoon plane as it flies over beautiful summertime mountain scenery. As they get ready to land on a remote lake, near where they are to spend a week fishing, they gossip about their friend Peter, who did not join them because he is afraid of flying. ''Peter's a wimp,'' one of his friends says. **********Meanwhile, music reminiscent of that found in the Indiana Jones movies begins to play, and we see the rugged-looking Peter driving his Ford Expedition over seemingly impassable dirt roads. The Expedition makes it to the lake's edge just before the plane lands, to the amazement of those flying in, who had thought their fishing spot accessible only by air. **********''The new Ford Expedition. The only way to get there,'' is the tag line for both ads. **********Gerry L. Donnelly, national advertising manager for Ford vehicles,  said his division was trying to avoid selling Expeditions mostly to owners of its popular Explorer. The ads are designed to woo buyers trading in luxury cars or large sport utility vehicles made by the General Motors Corporation -- the Chevrolet Suburban and Tahoe or GMC Yukon. **********The upscale tone of the ads is designed to ''separate Expedition from the Explorer,'' said Mr. Donnelly, who added that Ford hoped to sell about 150,000 Expeditions each year. ''We obviously want to sell those and maintain our Explorer sales,'' he said. **********Expedition ads are aimed at 40-  to 50-year-old professionals with median incomes above $82,000, he said. **********Ford is expected to spend far more advertising the Expedition than the $74 million it spent last year advertising the Explorer. For its entire 1997 lineup, it has bolstered ad spending 8 percent above last year's levels, Mr. Donnelly said. **********Ford spent $470 million last year advertising its various Ford models and another $258 million on its Lincoln and Mercury brands, according to Competitive Media Reporting, which tracks advertising spending. Ford spent $251 million the first six months of this year on its Ford models and spent another $167 million on its Lincoln and Mercury models, according to Competitive Media. **********While Ford has the most riding on its Expedition ads, ads for other 1997 models will begin showing Sunday. One of the latest Explorer ads shows parents insisting their young children turn off the Bullwinkle cartoons so the family can go for a drive together through a nearby wilderness. The two children whine until the Explorer comes across a real moose grazing, then they are thrilled. **********Other ads in the campaign include some tired customer testimonials for  Ford's 1997 Taurus. They emphasize the car's safety features and roominess, as well as the starting price of $18,545. **********But perhaps the most notable spot this fall is a fresh Mustang ad likely to appeal to the MTV generation because of its fast-paced music and its off-center images of urban scenes. It is designed to woo women as well as men, and has shots of a woman running and another practicing her boxing, along with the tag line ''It's your race,'' which recalls the successful ''Just do it'' campaign for Nike shoes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/10/busin.main_headline: MARKET WATCH;Anybody Want To Buy A Bond?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/10/busin.print_headline: MARKET WATCH;Anybody Want To Buy A Bond?
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/10/busin.body_text: **********Sometimes, it matters who has been doing the buying. **********Never has that been more important than in the Treasury bond market, circa 1996. The buyers of late have been foreign central banks and a bunch of international speculators who have been seeking a sure thing through a clever trade involving Japanese yen. (More on that later.) **********Notably absent from the mix have been genuine investors. Mutual funds that invest primarily in Treasuries have not seen net cash inflows since late 1993, notwithstanding last year's rally in bond prices. **********It was after the markets closed on Thursday that the Federal Reserve provided the evidence of just how big that swing had been. It said foreign central banks  had purchased a record $17.7 billion in Treasuries in the week ended Wednesday.  That brought their holdings to $547 billion, also a record. **********Then on Friday came the worst day for the bond market in at least 10 years, after a report showing that more people were working than had been expected. In  the upside-down world of bonds, that was bad news because it reduces the probability that the Fed will push down short-term rates. But that hardly explains the brutality of the bond plunge, which drove the yield on 30-year Treasuries up a quarter of a percentage point in a single day, to above 6.7 percent. **********"This is what happens when the lenders of last resort and the speculators get long the same thing," observed Mike Rouzee, a money manager at the Friends Vilas Fischer Trust Company. **********The central bank buying, says James Grant, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, has largely been a case of the Bank of Japan buying bucks to keep the yen from rising. It then invests the dollars in Treasury securities. **********The Japanese central bank has been trying to keep the yen from rising to avoid injuring Japanese exporters.  It has also tried to jump-start the ailing economy by keeping short-term rates very low, at about one-half of 1 percent. **********That is where the speculators came in. They borrowed billions of yen, paying  that low rate, and put the money into Treasuries. It was a sure thing, so long as the yen did not rise or Treasuries crash. **********At the Chicago Board of Trade, where they have been trading bond futures for  almost 20 years, Friday was the worst day ever. Prices fell so far that the exchange wouldn't let trading go on. It will resume tonight, and it will be interesting to see if buying materializes. Mutual fund investors have a history  of buying stock funds on weakness, but of selling bond funds when they plunge. And highly leveraged speculators may have to sell Treasuries, putting more pressure on prices. **********There is no good reason for the bond market's woes to have clipped 171 points off the Dow Jones industrial average. A strong economy is not bad for corporate  profits, which is what stock prices are supposed to be about. But it would be   easier to be confident if stock prices were not so high, and valuations so extended. **********In 1987, mutual fund investors ran for the hills after the first-ever 100-point down day for the Dow, on Friday, Oct. 16. Fidelity Investments dumped  American shares in London Monday morning, and the rout was on. That selling was  not the only reason the Dow fell 508 points that day, but it helped. **********But since 1987, mutual fund investors have regarded every 100-point down day  as a buying opportunity, and the market has quickly rebounded. Tomorrow morning, a lot of traders will be watching to see what Fidelity is doing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/15/busin.snippet: Diary of week's events in financial and economic worlds; photos (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/15/busin.body_text: **********WELFARE PROTEST **********Goodbye, Mr. Clinton **********The welfare bill that the President signed a few weeks ago hasn't been too popular at the Department of Health and Human Services. But reactions have varied. Donna E. Shalala, the department's Secretary, has joined those who seem to be saying that Bill Clinton needs to be re-elected to undo the welfare damage done by Bill Clinton. ''This bill will be changed,'' she vowed, ''until we get it right.'' Others at the agency, though, are not buying this Mobius-strip logic. Last week two top welfare officials -- Mary Jo Bane and Peter B. Edelman -- resigned in protest. For Mr. Clinton, the departure of Mr. Edelman had to sting. He and his wife, Marian Wright Edelman of the Children's Defense Fund, had started as staunch members of the Friends-of-Bill club, but as Mr. Clinton was washed to the right by the conservative tide, the Edelmans receded in the liberal distance. Last week Mr. Edelman was simply waving goodbye. **********WALL STREET **********What Goes Up Must Go Up **********In July the party seemed to be over on Wall Street, as the Dow industrials took some scary drops. But the resounding message last week was: Never mind. The Dow piled gain on top of gain, soaring to a new record of tktktktk. Does it make any sense? Not really. After that summer scare, money is flowing back into mutual funds -- the market's lifeblood -- but it isn't the flood it was earlier in the year. And higher interest rates -- the market's mortal enemy -- seem highly possible when the Federal Reserve next tinkers with them in a week or so. The explanation seems to be that investors have it fixed in their minds that this is a bull market that won't die. By that logic, a market dip means ''buy.'' Period. **********TERRORISM **********Can Air Travel Be Perfect? **********If everyone at an airport, whether traveler or employee, faced the scrutiny accorded, say, a Supreme Court nominee, you can bet there would be no terrorism. But perhaps three or four people would fly a day, having each spent a week at the airport. So what's needed is the right balance between reward (everyone flies) and risk (getting blown up). Some would say that balance had been found, considering how vastly safer it is to fly than to drive or do a lot of other things. But the bottomless mystery of the T.W.A. crash created a vacuum that demanded to be filled by action (especially -- dare one say it? -- in an election year). Last week, sure enough, President Clinton proposed sweeping changes, from criminal background checks on workers to searching the luggage of ''suspicious'' passengers (is that you, Big Brother?). Airlines and airport operators, though, raising the specter of three-hour airport check-ins, quickly questioned whether such steps were practical. **********IMAGE INSURANCE **********Bad News, Spin Away **********It doesn't matter what you do, Henry Higgins said, as long as you pronounce it properly. What a sadly outdated notion. For one thing, E-mail means never having to pronounce anything. Now it doesn't matter what you do; it's how it looks. Image is all. Say a corporation gets bad news, be it a defective product or a defecting executive. Given the speed of communications today, that news will hit the streets in no time. You need spin control, fast. Miss a beat and the egg gets imbedded on your face. Enter National Union Fire Insurance, the first insurer to cover the hiring, if the need arises, of a public-relations firm for ''crisis management.'' Spin the bad news fast enough, the theory goes, and it will just fly away. **********SECOND THOUGHTS **********Tax-Cut Memories **********It was 1981. Ronald Reagan was smiling, taxes were falling, all was Republican with the world. To Bob Dole, it was the good old days, and now he wants to revive that tax-cut crusade. A survivor of those good old days, though, has distinct second thoughts. Murray Weidenbaum, who as Mr. Reagan's chief economic adviser applauded the 1981 cuts, warned last week against copying them. It is easy to cut taxes, he said at a gathering of business economists, but far harder to cut spending -- a lesson he ''learned the hard way.'' Simply cutting taxes, he said, is like pumping air into a flat tire without patching up the holes first. Easy for him to say. He isn't running for office. **********TAKEOVERS **********Smiling at Duracell **********It was hard to tell whether it was a lovefest or a merger announcement. Analysts and executives fell all over themselves in applauding Gillette's deal last week to buy Duracell for $7 billion in stock. A perfect fit, they all cried. Few acquisitions ''could be better for Gillette.'' ''Duracell absolutely fits their core competencies.'' But as often happens, the big winner is not Duracell or Gillette, but a deal maker in the wings. Kohlberg Kravis Roberts -- sound familiar in these billion-dollar windfalls? -- put up just $350 million to buy Duracell in 1988, and now stands to make billions on its controlling stake. But do those billions emerge from thin air, or come out of someone's pocket? An enduring capitalist mystery. **********HEALTH INSURANCE **********The Mighty A.A.R.P. **********If the A.A.R.P. speaks, the elderly listen. So it's clearly a big deal when the group bestows its seal of approval on a health insurer -- roughly a $4 billion deal. That's the amount of business Prudential will lose yearly after the A.A.R.P. switched its blessing last week to United Healthcare. There is not much of a profit margin in this business as it stands, of course -- the lure for United Healthcare will be the shot it will get at persuading elderly policyholders to switch to H.M.O.'s. That's where it can make some money. And though 3,500 jobs will be lost at Prudential, United Healthcare has committed itself to hiring many of them. **********SOCIAL POLICY **********Depressed? Build a Prison **********Whenever America has a bad day, it seems, it cheers itself up by building a few prisons. Keep locking people up, we say, and our problems will evaporate. The trouble is, it costs such vast sums to build and run prisons that there is less left for society's other needs. Usually that trade-off is hard to see up close, obscured in the shifting billions in Government checkbooks. But in Los Angeles last week the choice was stark: whether to take $19 million away from poverty relief so a new high-tech prison could open. An advocate for the homeless estimated that it would cost the same to support 10 people on relief as to support one prisoner. And another predicted that crime would rise by a third if relief was cut. This time, Los Angeles stuck with poverty relief. But the prison industry keeps booming. **********TRADE POLITICS **********Too Many Best Friends **********Imagine calling everyone you know, wife-beater and model citizen alike, your dearest friend. Sounds silly, doesn't it? Yet the United States has done exactly that, using the gushy phrase ''most-favored nation'' for, well, any country we trade with. This relic of some long-forgotten tariff wars is not just linguistic nonsense, though, that can be easily ignored. Every time the topic of, say, China comes up, indignation erupts. How can we give special treatment to such a nation? Take heart. An elegant solution is at hand: Since we obviously can't change China, we'll just change the words. The Senate voted last week to scrap ''most-favored'' and make it ''normal'' trade relations. ''It's a victory for clarity,'' said Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a co-sponsor of the bill. True, China still won't be a model world citizen -- but is anyone really?

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/10/news/.main_headline: Multinational Producers Stumble Over Bureaucratic Roadblocks : The Long March to Chinese Stores
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/10/news/.print_headline: Multinational Producers Stumble Over Bureaucratic Roadblocks : The Long March to Chinese Stores
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/10/news/.body_text: **********BEIJING—                     Su Zhen, a computer science student, seemed an unlikely person to be promoting Mars chocolate products in a Beijing department store. "Some classmates told me about this job," she said, arranging the chocolate bars and candies on her special display stand. "It's an easy way to earn extra money." **********Dressed in her promotional cap and apron, Ms. Su was a typical example of how multinational food manufacturers will try anything to get their products to ordinary Chinese customers. Yet for major players like Mars, Coca-Cola and Nabisco, getting goods to the shops is an even bigger struggle than persuading the public to buy them. Time and again, the ambitious sales plans of such producers has been thwarted by China's antiquated, bureaucratic retail distribution network. **********Just how serious the problem is now regarded by consumer goods manufacturers was revealed by an Economist Intelligence Unit survey earlier this year. Asked what they would do if given the chance to relaunch their least successful brand, almost 60 percent of respondents said they would invest more in distribution. A majority also identified distribution problems as the most important brake on further expansion in China. **********At one level, the difficulty of shifting goods around China is simply a function of the country's dilapidated, overstretched transport system. At Cadbury-Schweppes, which operates a confectionery plant in Beijing, the preferred distribution channel is by rail. **********On average, however, freight space needs to be booked at least six weeks in advance, and even then there is insufficient capacity. As a result, Cadbury's — like its competitors — is forced to use trucks, which are much slower and far more expensive, especially once myriad illegal "toll fees" and provincial "customs duties" have been paid. **********That illustrates the second obstacle; intrusive, avaricious bureaucrats, who are determined to keep control of retail distribution channels, which they use to raise dubious "tax" revenues. **********In practice, however, the old state-controlled system is breaking down, under the weight of its own inefficiency and the rapidly growing demands of both Chinese and overseas manufacturers. An increasing number of producers are now bending the rules, as they seek ever more ingenious means to get their goods to the customer. **********A recent report by the Australian Trade Commission identified some of these channels. For exporters of goods into China, who areforbidden from operating their own distribution network, a favored route in recent years has been through trading companies in Hong Kong. These Hong Kong middlemen sell on the shipment to importers in the Special Economic Zones across the border, who — by claiming the goods are really Chinese — can use the many informal transport networks favored by mainland producers. **********According to the Australian Trade Commission, about 80 percent of all imported foods are now distributed on the mainland through the Hong Kong-South China connection. The main drawback is that the subterfuge, though tolerated, is strictly illegal: no major food exporter to China will admit to using the connection, for fear of penalties from Beijing. **********In addition, products entering China through the Special Economic Zones may be handled by as many as 10 different distributors before they reach theirdestination. That raises handling costs and puts a premium on secure, durable packaging, with the extra price passed on to the customer. **********For international food companies with production bases in China, it is also a case of testing the possibilities of a half-reformed distribution system. The good news is that the China National Council of Light Industry, which regulates the food and beverages industry, appears to have tacitly accepted that the old, state-dominated system is no longer viable. **********Since foreign-invested enterprises, unlike foreign exporters, are theoretically allowed to participate in their own distribution networks, there is now greater leeway to find do-it-yourself solutions. **********In Beijing, for example, the British Unilever Walls company, which opened an ice cream plant in 1994, is widely regarded as having one of the most effective delivery systems. At the outset, Walls recruited its own effective distributors, trained them, and then provided a fleet of trucks to transport ice cream from the Beijing factory's cold storage plant to six distribution points around the city. From there, the ice cream is shifted to more than 2,500 shops and street vendors,the latter provided, under a licensing arrangement, with Walls's name-brand refrigerators. **********One minor problem for Walls in Beijing has been the public's slightly shaky brand awareness. "Walls? That's an American ice cream," said one, nonetheless satisfied, customer, who reported that she kept cool during the summer with her favorite Magnum bars. **********A more serious difficulty, encountered by all bigfood producers, is that local arrangements, by definition, do not travel. When Walls moved into Shanghai last year, the company found a new set of obstacles, including the city's much narrower streets — making distribution by van more problematic — and the hostility of Shanghai ice cream producers, who had heard about the British company's success in Beijing. As a result, Walls has had to build a second distribution network in Shanghai from scratch. **********In such an environment, even the biggest players have yet to develop the food and drink manufacturers' dream — a dedicated, national distribution network capable of delivering goods to retailers from Harbin in the northeast to Ghangzou in the south. Nestle, the Swiss confectionery giant, has its eyes on this goal, having just opened a major manufacturing plant in the coastal city of Tianjin. "The whole [of China] distribution system is not developed enough for the needs of a modern sales and distribution network," said Helmut Maucher, the chairman of Nestle, at a Beijing press launch in October. **********Mr. Maucher reported that his company was tackling the problem head-on via Nestle China Investment Services (NCIS), a liaison company with branches in 13 Chinese cities and a staff of 500. **********The function of the company is to ensure efficient local sales and distribution for Nestle products, leading ultimately to an interconnecting network as the company's target market expands across the country. Whether Nestle achieves this goal will be the subject of much attention from its chief competitors in China, Mars and Cadbury's, both of which have concentrated on less ambitious local distribution schemes. **********As for the cost, Nestle's strategy is certainly an expensive one. On the other hand, if NCIS eventually delivers the national distribution network that Mr. Maucher wants it will be a small price to pay for a company that expects sales in China and Hong Kong this year to reach $370 million

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/04/busin.main_headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Prices End Up Slightly
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/04/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Prices End Up Slightly
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/04/busin.body_text: **********Treasury prices ended slightly higher yesterday on relief that Federal Reserve policy makers had left interest rates unchanged. **********While the decision by the Fed was expected, recent strong economic reports had raised doubts among some market participants. Investors have now turned their attention to tomorrow's June employment data, which are expected to help determine the Fed's next move on interest rates. **********The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 2/32 , to 8812/32 , leaving its  yield unchanged from Tuesday at 6.93 percent. **********Prices were weaker before the Fed's policy-making group, the Federal Open Market Committee, ended a two day meeting without raising short-term interest rates. **********Bond prices bounced off their lows on news of the Fed's inaction. **********Gary Thayer, senior economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis, said that by not raising rates the Fed was telling the market that the economy was fine and that it was willing to wait and see if growth would begin to accelerate inflation. Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said the Fed's decision not to raise rates gave the board another seven weeks to analyze  more data. "But unless the upcoming data shows a significant weakening of the economy, the Fed is very likely to tighten by Aug. 20," he said. **********"The market will now focus on the Friday employment data, which is simply the first of many important pieces of information that the Fed will receive by the next F.O.M.C. meeting." **********The employment numbers, if they come in stronger than expected, could have a  volatile impact on the market because trading is expected to be thin tomorrow. The Treasury market is closed today in observance of the Fourth of July and will close early tomorrow, at 2 P.M., on the recommendation of the Public Securities  Association, a trade group. **********Mr. Thayer of A. G. Edwards said he did not expect that the employment numbers would be a surprise. **********"But traders are reluctant to risk being surprised nonetheless," he said. "We're hearing a gain of 150,000, which is far less than 348,000 gained reported last month." Employment reports earlier this year have shown unexpected strength, roiling the bond and stock markets. **********Before the end of the Federal Reserve policy-making meeting yesterday, few investors were willing to do much trading. As a result, the economic reports released in the morning had only a mild impact on prices. May factory orders rose 1.9 percent, driven by a 3.4 percent increase in durables, previously reported up 3.3 percent, and from a one-tenth of 1 percent gain in nondurables. The weekly initial claims for unemployment for the period ended last Saturday fell by 4,000, to 351,000, lower than the expected 355,000. It brought the four-week moving average down slightly to 356,000, keeping the trend intact. **********In another move expected by the market, the Treasury announced plans to to sell $10 billion of 10-year notes Tuesday. In when-issued trading yesterday, the notes were being offered to yield 6.77 percent. **********Hamilton Davis, a vice president of government trading at Everen Securities Inc., in Chicago, said the bond market was relieved, with the yield spread between the two-year and long-dated paper increasing as some of the fear of a Fed move has been removed. He added: "However, there are some market participants who feel a move on Friday, while out of the normal pattern of Fed action, is not impossible. If for instance the nonfarm growth was above a 200,000 increase, the talk of Fed tightening would be back on the front burner." He said that looking at the previous data, and given National Association of Purchasing Managementemployment statistics on Monday, it raised that possibility. **********"In the last seven years, when the employment component of the N.A.P.M. survey is above 49, nonfarm payroll gains have always been above 199,000," Mr. Thayer said. "The latest N.A.P.M. on Monday had the employment component at 49.2." The market he says, has another hoop it must jump through on Friday. It jumped through one yesterday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/10/busin.print_headline: Pearson to Buy a Publisher From News Corp.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/10/busin.body_text: **********Moving to expand its educational publishing operations in the United States,  the British-based media company Pearson P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire HarperCollins Educational Publishing Inc. from Rupert Murdoch's News  Corporation for $580 million. **********Pearson, whose holdings include The Financial Times and Penguin books, said it would merge the HarperCollins operation with its existing Addison-Wesley Longman educational publishing division, which it bought in 1988 for $283 million. **********The combined entity will rank fourth among American schoolbook publishers, with approximately 11 percent of the market, Pearson said, and third in the American market for sales of college textbooks, with about 13 percent of the market. Analysts said those two markets generated about $5 billion in sales each year. **********"This is a big step forward for our education division," Lord Blakenham, Pearson's chairman, said in a prepared statement. "It opens up a host of opportunities for us, both within the domestic U.S. market and also in English-language markets around the world, which should allow us to derive substantial benefits for Pearson shareholders." **********The sale stirred little reaction among investors on either side of the Atlantic. In London, Pearson shares closed at 690 pence, up 5 pence. In New York, News Corporation's American depository receipts slipped 37.5 cents, to $21.25. **********The News Corporation said in November that it intended to sell the educational publishing division, which consists primarily of Scott Foresman, an  Illinois-based publisher of textbooks for elementary and high schools, and HarperCollins College, a New York-based publisher of college texts. **********In a statement announcing the acquisition, Pearson said that last year the two units had operating profits of $51 million on combined sales of $316 million. **********Analysts said the move out of the market was purely strategic. **********"Educational publishing doesn't fit News Corp.'s image as a global distributor of information," John Reidy, an analyst at Smith Barney, said. "Rupert has a lot of different objectives, and this is not one of them." **********Edward Hatch, an analyst at UBS Securities, said: "Educational book publishing is not part of their overall strategy for broadcast, satellite and cable distribution, and News Corp. was a long way from being among among the top players in the business. They just didn't have the critical mass." **********Even with the expansion, analysts said Pearson would still trail The McGraw-Hill Companies, Macmillan, a unit of National Amusements Inc., and Harcourt Brace & Company, a unit of Harcourt General Inc., in the ranks of education publishers. **********The News Corporation entered the publishing business in the United States in  1987, when it acquired Harper & Row. Two years later the company bought Scott Foresman from Time Warner Inc., and in 1990 merged Harper & Row with William Collins & Sons, the British publisher, forming HarperCollins. Terms of the purchases were never disclosed. **********HarperCollins will retain its adult and children's book divisions, as well as Zondervan Publishing, its religious books publishing operation. **********The HarperCollins sale is the third transaction involving an education-related publisher in the last three weeks. **********In late January, the Tribune Company said it had agreed to buy the privately  held Educational Publishing Company for $200 million. **********And on Monday the Tribune Company said it had agreed to buy the NTC Publishing Group, a closely held company, for $82 million in cash. **********"The educational book business, particularly the elementary/high school segment, is entering into a new growth cycle," Mr. Hatch, the UBS analyst, said. "For the next several years, purchases of new schoolbooks by states and municipalities should grow by 15 percent to 17 percent at an annual rate. That is fast."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/12/world.body_text: **********With China test-firing missiles into the seas around Taiwan's main ports and  American warships patrolling the Taiwan Straits in response, the United States remains deliberately vague about the depth of its commitment to defend Taiwan from attack. **********That ambiguous approach has long been viewed by Republicans and Democrats alike as a prudent one. But now, as some Congressional Republicans call for more pointed guarantees by Washington to defend Taiwan, the traditional consensus is  under threat. **********While some Republicans still favor what the policy makers call "strategic ambiguity," a swelling chorus of China critics are pushing for a more explicit commitment. Even Senator Bob Dole, the Majority Leader and front-runner for the  Republican presidential nomination, has edged from his usual bipartisan caution  on foreign policy toward a more explicit embrace of Taiwan. **********The United States' defense treaty with Taiwan was abrogated in the years after President Nixon's visit to Communist China in 1972. The visit led to recognition of Beijing, accepting its argument that it, not Taiwan, was the Government of a single China. **********But in return, the United States received promises that reunification with Taiwan would happen peacefully and at some vague time in the future. And in the Taiwan Relations Act of 1979, the United States set forth the intentionally  vague commitment that now applies. **********The law asserted Washington's right to help Taiwan defend itself and declared Taiwan to be within the American sphere of interests. And it said the United States would consider "any effort to determine the future of Taiwan by other than peaceful means, including by boycotts or embargoes, a threat to the peace and security of the Western Pacific area and of grave concern to the United States." It said the United States would "maintain its capacity to resist" any act that jeopardized the security or the social and economic system of Taiwan. **********But the act does not require any particular response. **********"The act is an important framework whereby China knows that the use of force  will have consequences," a senior Administration official said. "Without pre-committing or allowing Taiwan to dictate our China policy, it's very important that China knows it cannot act with impunity, and that we have options and can use them." **********[Speaking to reporters in Chile, Defense Secretary William J. Perry declined  to say if Washington was planning for any eventual Chinese attack on Taiwan, Reuters reported.  But Assistant Secretary of State Winston Lord said tonight on "The News Hour with Jim Lehrer" that the naval build-up was meant to "reassure our friends in the area that we have a big stake in the stability and peace of that region." **********["At the same time," he added, "we are not on the brink of war."] **********By sending more American ships to patrol near Taiwan, officials say, the United States is insuring that China does not underestimate American resolve, while stopping short of an explicit challenge that could lead to a confrontation. **********"We want to make clear, against indications of some in Beijing who are thinking of using force, that we are committed to a one-China policy, but in the context of peaceful unification," one official said. **********But the Administration is also trying, by this ambiguous show of force, to head off more drastic measures in an election-minded Congress. Some proposals now alive in Congress could infuriate China: providing more advanced arms to Taiwan, supporting United Nations membership for Taiwan or issuing invitations to high-ranking Taiwan officials to visit the United States after Taiwan's presidential elections March 23. **********"What the Administration has done in the last two or three days has been a measured, prudent but necessary step," Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, said in an interview. "But by emphasizing only one side and emphasizing military force, China is making it harder for the United States to maintain bipartisan support for the policy," Mr. Nunn said. **********Senator Dole has been circumspect on China, criticizing the Administration for being weak on Chinese violations of human rights and arms accords and calling for more American forces to be sent to back up Taiwan, but stopping short of a promise to go to war over the island. **********The United States should make it clear to China that Washington has strong ties to Taiwan and "if necessary, we would protect them" from any Chinese military action, Mr. Dole said over the weekend, without saying how. He suggested China was testing Mr. Clinton because of a wavering foreign policy. **********Senior Administration officials accuse Mr. Dole of playing politics and say a Dole Administration policy would be no different. **********"It's a campaign year, and they will very likely play for any advantage they  can get," one official said -- including using Mr. Clinton's 1992 campaign promises to get tough on China against him. **********Mr. Nunn said: "The unfortunate thing about presidential candidates in both parties is that they focus so much on getting elected they don't focus on what foreign policy commitments they've made. Dole will have a lot of pressure on him not to be responsible about China." **********Stanley O. Roth, of the United States Institute of Peace, says that while it  is vital that China understand that Washington would react, "if it becomes a formal defense commitment, we may rue the day it is made." **********To defend Taiwan against unprovoked aggression is one thing, he says, but if  Taiwan should declare independence, "it's quite another thing if you're really intervening in a 50-year-old Chinese civil war." **********"That's why the ambiguity makes sense," Mr. Roth added. **********Too strong a confrontational policy, he said, frightens American allies in Asia, while too soft a reaction undermines American credibility as Asia's "great balancer." **********A senior Asian diplomat applauds Washington's show of force but says: "If you get into a direct confrontation with China, you'll probably be alone," given China's importance to the region. "No one expects a war, but everyone is worried that given the political, domestic dynamic in America, Taiwan and China, it could somehow get out of hand." **********But there is pressure in Con,ress to alter the terms of the Taiwan Relations  Act to recognize that while Taiwan has moved toward democracy since 1979, China  remains Communist and is not respecting its commitments, says Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California. **********"I Taiwan is now a democracy, and that makes all the difference in the world." **********Many in Congress "want to see Taiwan's rights respected," she added, including free elections. **********"It could mean peaceful reunification or self-determination," she said. "Fundamentally, there's a commitment to one China, but now there are two economic and political systems, and it increases the challenge." **********The article also misstated the change that took place when President Nixon visited China in 1972. He did not recognize Beijing as the government of a single China; rather he began the process of establishing diplomatic relations with the mainland and left open the question of which government was the rightful ruler of a single China.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/16/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene;Central Europe is unsettled by a currency union for West Europe.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/16/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene;Central Europe is unsettled by a currency union for West Europe.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/16/busin.body_text: **********THE 200 politicians, business executives and assorted policy wonks attending  the first congress of the New Atlantic Initiative -- a tony pep rally here for trans-Atlantic harmony -- got the good show they no doubt expected. **********They heard President Vaclav Havel of the Czech Republic warn: "Unless democrats proceed with greater vigor to build a European order, others will start to do so -- and we know who the others are." The group was also treated to a star turn by Margaret Thatcher, the former British Prime Minister. After agreeing with Hobbes that "covenants without the sword are but words," she called for the merger of the North American free trade area of the United States, Canada and Mexico with the European Union. **********But those who stayed for the panels organized by the conservative American Enterprise Institute, Center for the New Europe and National Review Institute were exposed to one distinctly downbeat theme: The drive to create an economic superstate in Western Europe, specifically the plan for monetary union beginning in 1999, could unhinge the Atlantic alliance and leave Central Europe out in the cold. **********"If a monetary union is launched on schedule," predicted Jan Krzysztof Bielecki, the former Prime Minister of Poland, "it will touch off a chain reaction that will halt integration." **********This is not an entirely new thought, but it is particularly relevant as the deadline for locking together at least a handful of Europe's currencies nears. Economists of varying ideological stripe have long worried that the transition to monetary union may trap some less-advanced nations into chronic recession, much the way single currencies handcuffed efforts to develop Canada's Maritime Provinces and Italy's poor southern region. **********A common currency makes it impossible to adjust currency rates to reflect differences in productivity within the currency zone. That is eased for those born in Newfoundland and Calabria, though, because they are free to migrate within their countries. **********But multilingual, multinational Europe is an entirely different matter. How many Europeans would be comfortable with tens of millions of jobless citizens crossing national borders to find work? Certainly no more than the number of western Germans who welcomed eastern Germans heading for Munich and Stuttgart after reunification -- and probably a lot fewer. **********What does all this have to do with Central Europe, particularly the leading candidates for future membership in the European Union -- Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic? Back up for a minute. The primary barrier today to their admission to the 15-nation European Union is the costly subsidy policy now used  to help bind the economies of Western Europe. **********Brian Hindley of the London School of Economics notes that the European Union's payments to the less affluent members -- Portugal, Spain and Greece -- along with price supports for virtually all farmers, already cost more than $60  billion a year. Most of the cash comes out of the coffers of Germany, Britain, Belgium, Luxembourg and the Netherlands. Mr. Hindley estimates that adding Central Europe would raise the bill by an additional $50 billion. **********But there is a way out of this quandary, Mr. Hindley argues. If farm subsidies were converted from price supports to income supplements unrelated to  production -- and new entrants to the European Union were declared ineligible -- the cost of integrating the three new countries would be modest. Indeed, Mr. Hindley sees the incorporation of Central Europe as an opportunity to deep-six a scandalously wasteful farm policy that now generates enormous agricultural surpluses. **********Whatever the outcome of that debate, all bets are off, Mr. Bielecki says, if  plans go forward for monetary union before the end of the decade. For one thing, he points out, that would distract political energies from what is bound to be a traumatic transition for the union's weaker economies. **********For that and other reasons, Mr. Bielecki expects that Western Europe -- preoccupied with its own situation -- will postpone formal integration with Central Europe for many years. That may or may not be a disaster. Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic are all recovering from the collapse of central planning and beginning to grow again. But both Poland and Hungary have found the going so hard that their voters have turned to governments of former Communists, whose commitments to completing the transition to free markets would probably not survive a serious recession. **********Most of those assembled in the glitter of the Hapsburg Palace in Prague probably do not agree with Lady Thatcher that European monetary union is "in truth a nightmare." But as 1999 approaches, they are finding it ever harder to ignore the risks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/10/busin.snippet: Arbitrager Guy P Wyser-Pratte, seeking to press Rexene Corp to consider being sold, has joined with Spear, Leeds & Kellogg to nominate four candidates to Rexene's board; nominees, in marked departure from typical dissident slate, were recruited by...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/10/busin.main_headline: A new proxy strategy: Upgrading the dissident slate.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/10/busin.print_headline: A new proxy strategy: Upgrading the dissident slate.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/10/busin.body_text: **********GUY P. WYSER-PRATTE, the New York arbitrager best known for his willingness to wage proxy fights against what he considers recalcitrant managements and boards, has another company in his sights: the Rexene Corporation, which recently rebuffed several takeover bids from the Huntsman Corporation. **********In an unusual strategy to try to force Rexene to consider being sold, Mr. Wyser-Pratte and Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, a New York-based investment firm, have nominated four candidates for Rexene's board -- all recruited by an executive search firm. Mr. Wyser-Pratte's firm and Spear Leeds, which together own about 10 percent of Rexene's shares outstanding, are pushing for a special shareholders' meeting to consider the nominees. **********The nominees represent a marked departure from the typical slate of dissident directors, who are often friends or colleagues of the shareholders seeking change. Three have extensive business experience and the fourth is a law professor. **********The idea, Mr. Wyser-Pratte said, is to find ''Grade A directors'' who make large investors feel comfortable. Their priority would be to consider the sale of Rexene, Mr. Wyser-Pratte said, but they are also capable of running the company. **********A strategy of creating this kind of interim board could make takeover players like Mr. Wyser-Pratte more successful, said John Coffee, a securities law professor at Columbia University. By nominating directors who can take their time in negotiating for the best deal, these shareholders may be able to put more pressure on corporations to consider unsolicited offers. ''If it works, I would predict it would be emulated,'' Mr. Coffee said. **********Without such a strategy, large investors are frequently reluctant to vote for a dissident slate. When Mr. Wyser-Pratte tried to force Wallace Computer Services to drop its ''just say no'' defense last month, for example, the three board nominees -- Mr. Wyser-Pratte and two lawyers he has worked with -- received the least shareholder support of all his proposals. **********Finding executives comfortable in the role of dissident director remains a challenge. Many executives still see the director's job as defending management, said Steven A. Seiden, the president of the New York firm of Seiden Krieger Associates, which conducted the search. One executive he approached, Mr. Seiden said, called dissident directors ''disloyal to corporate America.'' **********For Rexene's shareholders, however, the question is why Rexene, a Dallas-based manufacturer of resins and petrochemicals, rejected the takeover bid from Huntsman, a privately held chemical producer in Salt Lake City. Huntsman offered $16 a share, or about $300 million, in October and agreed to assume some $175 million in debt. Before Huntsman made its first bid in July, the stock had been trading around $9. It closed yesterday at $13.875, down 12.5 cents. **********''Based on our recent experiences with Rexene and its advisers, we believe that Rexene does not have a sincere and serious intent to sell the company and maximize shareholder value,'' said Jon M. Huntsman, the chairman and chief executive of Huntsman, in a recent statement. Rexene, on the other hand, contends that it had serious objections to the deal's structure and that Huntsman refused to modify it. **********Mr. Wyser-Pratte said that only a board in which his four nominees were a majority could accomplish a sale. ''It is our impression that these directors, if they can, will scuttle any deal that comes along,'' he said of the Rexene board. **********And as impressive as Mr. Wyser-Pratte's slate may be, shareholders must still decide on whose vision -- Rexene's or Mr. Wyser-Pratte's -- is most compelling. ''Unless the company's going to be sold, it's not in the best interest to support a dissident board,'' said one shareholder, Steven Stokes, a manager of the Kemper-Dremen Small Cap Value Fund. **********David Drake of Institutional Shareholder Services, a firm that advises large investors, agreed. ''You can put together a squeaky clean, top-notch board of directors,'' he said, ''but if the shareholders are not supportive of the underlying action, it isn't going to make much of a difference.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/02/busin.main_headline: HFS Will Acquire Employee-Controlled Avis for $800 Million in Cash andStock
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/02/busin.print_headline: HFS Will Acquire Employee-Controlled Avis for $800 Million in Cash andStock
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/02/busin.body_text: **********HFS Inc. said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire Avis Inc., the world's second-biggest car rental company, for about $800 million -- approximately $500 million in cash and $300 million in HFS common stock. **********If approved by Avis employees, who own 71 percent of the company's 24 million shares, it will be by far the biggest acquisition ever of a company controlled by its employees. HFS is expected to pay about a 50 percent premium on the current share vale of Avis. **********Henry R. Silverman, the chairman and chief executive of HFS, said that the company was considering buying additional rental car companies. **********"We see an opportunity to follow our typical consolidation strategy" by buying a second or maybe even a third rent-a-car company, he said in an interview. "Then the synergies are quite dramatic." **********HFS, which is based in Parsippany, N.J., is the nation's biggest hotel franchiser, with more than 5,000 properties under eight brand names, including Days Inn, Howard Johnson and Ramada Inn. Almost a year ago it bought Century 21  Real Estate for $200 million in cash and stock, and recently purchased the Coldwell Banker Corporation, the real estate brokerage company, for $740 million. Together with ERA, the real estate brands of HFS have more than 11,000  franchised offices worldwide and about 160,000 brokers. **********In setting his sights on Avis, with its 13,500 employees, 1,200 locations nationwide and annual revenues of about $2 billion, Mr. Silverman intends to pursue a familiar strategy: HFS will spin off Avis Rent a Car to HFS shareholders, while Avis Inc., will become a subsidiary of HFS and license its name to Avis Rent a Car. **********HFS stock closed yesterday at $69.50, down 50 cents a share. **********"Investors probably expected all cash, and the $300 million in stock makes it a little less additive to earning per share, although I expect the transaction to be highly additive next year," said Mark Mutkoski, an analyst with BT Securities. He added that by receiving HFS stock, Avis stockholders would be able to benefit from the value that HFS was likely to create as it continued to  build the business. **********Mr. Silverman said the synergies from the Avis acquisition included renting hotel guests Avis cars, renting Avis cars to Coldwell Banker and Century 21 agents who typically buy new cars every three years, and renting cars to relocated executives. **********"We are the largest company in the corporate relocation business," Mr. Silverman said, speaking of Coldwell Banker and Century 21. "We relocate 50,000  executives a year, who when they get to L.A. or wherever they're going typically have to wait for their cars to arrive. Now we could offer them a rental car." **********Michael Keeling, the president of the ESOP Association in Washington, a nonprofit association for employee-owned companies, said the proposed acquisition would "dwarf all previous purchases" of employee-owned companies. Even though his association will lose an important member, he added, "From what  I know of the deal the employees can expect a good return." **********David Johanson, a lawyer in San Francisco with a practice that deals mostly with employee stock-ownership plans, said he was disappointed that Avis decided  to sell after putting together a successful employee buyout, and paying off the  purchase price, of $785 million. **********"I admit that from the employee perspective, it's great," Mr. Johanson said.  "But it's inconsistent and disappointing, after they made it work so well." **********Joseph V. Vittoria, chief executive of Avis, said he was also "a little sad"  about selling the company. "But when somebody comes along and offers a very attractive deal, it's hard to pass it up," he said. **********Avis stock does not trade publicly, but under the rules of an employee-owned  company, a value is placed on its shares each year. Mr. Vittoria said Avis stock fell from $22.21 in 1990 to $9.04 in 1994, "because manufacturers changed the deals with all rental car companies." The stock ended 1995 at $12.51, the most recent valuation. While the deal with HFS is not complete, Mr. Vittoria said, Avis stockholders would probably get about $25 a share. **********Bill Patterson, corporate affairs director of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which represents some 3,200 Avis corporate stockholders, said that while the proposed deal "looks like a good starting price," the sticking point is what will happen to 14 million unallocated shares. **********"Our position is that this money belongs to the employees," he said. "So we're going to make sure the ESOP trustee serves the shareholder, not just enriches management." **********Mr. Vittoria said, "The trustee is looking out only for the interest of employees, and on price per share they'll come out better than management will." **********The trustee is U.S. Trust, which recently replaced Nationsbank. U.S. Trust and General Motors -- which holds nonvoting preferred stock in Avis that is convertible at any time into common stock equal to a 29 percent stake -- control a majority of shares. **********Toni Simonetti, a spokeswoman for G.M., said that the auto maker had signed a letter of intent to sell its stake in Avis because G.M., which paid $135 million for its stake in 1989, now relies less on fleet sales and because it is focusing on its core businesses. "There's really no strategic value in owning a rental company," she said. "It hasn't been a problem, but on the other hand, it hasn't  been a strategic asset." **********The car maker, which sold the National Car Rental System to a group of investors last year, is likely to continue supplying vehicles to Avis, Ms. Simonetti said. "We are in the process of negotiating a fleet agreement and we expect to continue to have one." **********Auto industry analysts said that G.M. had made the right decision to retreat  from the auto rental industry. The sale of its stake in Avis is very unlikely to have a material effect on the world's largest auto maker, said Scott Sprinzen, an auto analyst with Standard & Poor's Ratings Group. **********G.M.'s expected share of the proceeds from the sale, about $230 million, is equal to half a day of sales at the world's biggest auto maker.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/26/world.snippet: Mexico rejects US request to allow American drug agents to carry sidearms for their own protection inside Mexico and to have full diplomatic immunity; insists on same privilege for its anti-drug agents in the US; some 18 agents for Drug Enforcemen...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/26/world.main_headline: Mexico Rejects U.S. Request On Sidearms for Drug Agents
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/26/world.print_headline: Mexico Rejects U.S. Request On Sidearms for Drug Agents
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/26/world.body_text: **********Mexico has rebuffed a request by the United States to allow American drug agents to carry sidearms for their own protection inside Mexico and to have full diplomatic immunity, United States and Mexican officials say. **********Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, head of the Clinton Administration's anti-drug effort, raised the issue most recently in a meeting here in mid-December. Mexican officials refused to approve the request, but indicated they would engage in further talks on the issue. **********''We can't authorize it,'' said the Mexican Attorney General, Jorge Madrazo Cuellar. He said having armed agents of the United States Drug Enforcement Administration in Mexico would be ''a complete break'' with the 1992 agreement that governs the role of the agents. **********Mexico said it would allow D.E.A. agents to carry arms in Mexico only if Mexican anti-drug police are given the same privilege in the United States, a Mexican official said. **********Since General McCaffrey took charge of drug policy in early 1996 he has gone out of his way to applaud Mexico for its enforcement efforts, generating unusually warm relations between the countries on drug issues. Because of improved cooperation, Mexico eradicated large areas of heroin poppies and marijuana crops and reduced flights of large cargo jets carrying drugs over Mexico. **********But the two sides have made no progress on the status of D.E.A. agents. **********The issue is delicate for Mexico, which is reluctant to make concessions to the United States that seem to compromise its sovereignty. The American request is especially sensitive for President Ernesto Zedillo because of elections scheduled for July 1997 in which his party will battle for control of the national Congress with opposition groups who have criticized him for yielding too much to the United States. **********But American officials feel strongly as well. Although the search for better protection dates back years, the United States' concern increased after a joint task force was created in 1995 to coordinate anti-drug operations along the border. **********Some 18 American agents from the Drug Enforcement Administration, Customs and the Federal Bureau of Investigation are based in the United States but move frequently across the border to work with counterparts in Mexico. They go unarmed and are not officially shielded by standard diplomatic immunities from local arrest and prosecution. **********In the last eight months, death threats against Mexican and American drug agents in the border area have increased to the point of alarm, an American official said. Six Mexican agents from Tijuana, the city just south of the border from San Diego, were killed in 1996.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/28/busin.snippet: Peter Passell Economic Scene article on Environmental Protection Agency plan to tighten air quality standards for ozone and particles in dust and soot; cites concern EPA uses strong case for curbing particulates to mask relatively weak case agains...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/28/busin.main_headline: The E.P.A.'s tough standards: cost isn't a consideration.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/28/busin.print_headline: The E.P.A.'s tough standards: cost isn't a consideration.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/28/busin.body_text: **********AFTER years of hinting, the Environmental Protection Agency now wants to tighten air quality standards for ozone and the tiny particles in dust and soot. **********That's good, right? After all, the new rules are designed to meet the letter and spirit of the Clean Air Act, which requires the agency to ''protect public health with an ample margin of safety.'' But they are raising eyebrows among economists inclined to look much more critically at the costs of regulation as well as the benefits. **********Lumping together standards for the two pollutants, these economists say, uses the strong case for reducing particulates to mask the relatively weak case against ozone. More important, the tighter standard for ozone pushes regulation into little-explored territory where the costs of pollution control are large and obvious, while the likely benefits are ephemeral. **********So how will the Government reconcile the stern dictates of the law with the cool realities of economics and politics? Good question. ''Los Angeles never had a prayer of meeting the old ozone standard,'' Lester Lave, an economist at Carnegie-Mellon University, said, ''let alone the new one.'' **********The good news here is that the E.P.A. is updating particulate standards to mesh with scientific findings that very small particles (2.5 microns, or millionths of a meter, in diameter) are as damaging to health as larger ones. It is still not clear, however, that all new particles being regulated are equally dangerous. Exposure to nitrogen compounds (from car exhausts and power plants) may be less risky than contact with sulfur compounds (mostly from burning coal). **********Even less clear is the logic in linking the regulation of soot and ozone. Killer smog, still a phenomenon in the third world, is typically loaded with both particulates and ozone. And reducing emissions of one often reduces emissions of the other. But those rationalizations mask big differences. **********The epidemiological case against ozone is weak. For example, a study of the horrific air pollution in Mexico City by the widely respected Health Effects Institute found that particulates rather than ozone did most of the medical damage. And while researchers have been looking for the smoking gun on ozone for decades, Paul Portney, president of the economically aware environmental group Resources for the Future, says that ''all they've been able to prove is that exposure causes short-term reversible effects,'' like bronchial irritation and watery eyes. **********Above all, what the E.P.A. ruling will do is raise the bar for meeting air pollution standards to a qualitatively higher level. Under the old ozone standard of 120 parts per billion, some 70 urban areas fail to make the cut. But only Houston, New York, Philadelphia and a few cities in California were under pressure to make radical changes in order to meet the standard. And only Los Angeles was hopelessly out of compliance. **********By ratcheting down to 80 parts per billion, Los Angeles will have plenty of company in the E.P.A.'s dog house. Mr. Lave expects that ''much of the Eastern Seaboard'' will fall into this category. **********In a society that could cope rationally with these issues, Robert Hahn, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, suggests, the appropriate response would be to change the law. Rather than an absolute Federal health standard, Congress may create a test in which the value of lives lengthened (along with other benefits) are weighed against the cost of compliance. Cities that want to pay for cleaner air -- resorts, say, or places catering to retirees -- ought to be allowed to find ''local solutions for local problems,'' he argues. But no one is going to force Cleveland or Baltimore to abandon the internal combustion engine. **********That is not how Washington works, of course. It has dealt with the Los Angeles compliance problem in the past, for example, through a process of endless delay. That has led to significant progress but has also allowed everyone involved to avoid confronting the serious trade-offs involved. The region has repeatedly been given more time to comply as long as it was making a good faith effort -- electric cars, reformulated charcoal lighting fluid and the like. **********In the end, though, the only way around the impossible is to fudge the health standards. Today, noncompliance means the failure to keep the average ozone level below 120 parts per billion for more than one hour on more than one day a year. Raising the averaging period to a full day, along with allowing four or five noncompliance days a year, would effectively double the permissible level of ozone. **********This approach is untidy and a bit cynical. But, then, democracy has always been untidy. And unless you can imagine members of Congress publicly debating whether asthmatics should be asked to stay indoors on heavy smog days, cynicism is probably the order of the day.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/31/busin.main_headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Bonds Slip on Housing Data, Then Recover

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/31/busin.body_text: **********After faltering in the wake of a strong housing report yesterday, Treasury bonds rallied from session lows to end mixed. Contributing to the rebound was the Government's sale of five-year notes, which was surprisingly robust despite  recent comments by Fed officials that have suggested an upsurge in inflation. **********The price of the 30-year issue rose 7/32 , to 8813/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, dropped to 6.92 percent, from 6.94 percent on Wednesday. **********Government bond prices had been weighed down early as dealers tried to get ready for the Treasury's auction of $12.5 billion in notes, amid investor apprehension about the economy and its implications for Fed monetary policy. **********Market participants first had to deal with a Commerce Department report that  sales of new homes leaped 6.7 percent in April, far more than expected; additionally, it revised its estimate of home sales for each of the preceding three months. **********In addition to the new-home sales report, data were issued yesterday on weekly jobless claims, and the first-quarter gross domestic product was revised  downward to a 2.3 percent growth rate from the previously estimated rate of 2.8  percent. **********Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, noted that a sharp drop in business inventories accounted for the entire G.D.P. revision; all other major components showed slight pickups in their first-quarter rates of growth. **********"Indeed, this bodes well for second-quarter G.D.P. growth," Mr. Fine said, "as these inventories are in the process of being replenished. But despite the implication for strong second-quarter production, the bond market reacted favorably to the G.D.P. data." **********This proved to be rather temporary, he added, as the reported surge in new-home sales immediately raised concerns about inflation. "While many expect the housing sector to slow as the year progresses because of the recent lift in  bond yields," he said, "it is clear from the data that this has not happened yet." **********Among the main indicators the bond market will consider in the next week, Mr. Fine said, will be the May National Association of Purchasing Management index scheduled to be released on Monday, automoile sales statistics to be released on both Monday and Tuesday and labor-market data due next Friday. **********Yesterday Fed officials continued to issue warning flags about rates, making  it difficult for the market to regain its balance. At the University of Maine, the Boston Federal Reserve president, Cathy E. Minehan, was reported to have said that inflation pressures could be building, signalling the need to maintain a cautious interest-rate policy. She tied the price pressures to the volatile food and energy components. **********Ms. Minehan's comments echoed those of the Richmond Fed president, Alfred Broaddus Jr., and Fed governor Susan Phillips on Wednesday. Some analysts saw the comments as preparing the market for a tightening. **********At the Treasury's note auction yesterday, participants were mildly surprised  at the aggressive bid, even from the noncompetitive side. Traders said a number  of central banks were believed to be solid buyers. **********The five-year note auction was awarded at the yield of 6.565 percent, better  than the 6.59 percent that had been expected. The yield in when-issued trading ahead of the auction had risen 10 basis points from the previous day's low, a move dealers hoped would entice bargain hunters. **********Today, the Treasury plans to sell $7 billion of 7-day cash management bills and $23 billion of 10-day bills through auction to cover the Government's short-term cash needs outside the regular borrowing schedule. **********The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new five-year notes: **********(000 omitted in dollar figures) **********High Price . . .                           99.727 High Yield . . .                           6.565% Low Yield . . .                             6.50% Median Yield . . .                         6.540% Accepted at low price . . .                   22% Total applied for . . .               $32,527,250 Accepted . . .                        $12,500,550 Noncompetitive . . .                     $559,000 Interest set at . . .                       6.50% **********The five-year notes mature May 31, 2001.
