https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/22/busin.main_headline: A Financial Showdown Looms in Bond Markets
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/22/busin.print_headline: A Financial Showdown Looms in Bond Markets
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/22/busin.body_text: **********These are turbulent times in world finance,and nowhere more so than on American bond markets, where the populists and the hard money are slugging it out with the same intensity as the U.S. presidential candidates. **********Add the international deals by billion-dollar hedge funds during the past half-year, and you have a recipe for uncertainty, volatility and contradictory signals that far exceeds the ability of Delphic utterances by Alan Greenspan to unnerve investors. **********Two days of Congressional testimony by the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board caused the Dow Jones industrial average to swing down 44.79 points on Tuesday and back up by 57.44 points on Wednesday as Wall Street appeared to decide that "the end of the world isn't coming, and we overreacted," as James Weiss, a money manager at State Research and Management, said to Bloomberg Business News. **********What is happening in the bond markets is of much longer duration.According to Pravin Banker, who runs his own consulting firm, it began in Japan in August when money was available to international financiers at virtually no cost.Borrowing yen at annual interest rates of as little as 0.5 percent, they bought U.S. Treasury securities with yields that ran up to 6.8 percent. **********The unwinding of these positions started in the streets of Paris late last year, moved to the unemployment lines in Germany, and then to the Republican primary campaign, where it is becoming politically profitable to bid for working class votes with the classic demagoguery of the right blaming foreigners for stealing the jobs of American voters. **********Now, said William Gross, who manages bonds in mutual funds at Pacific Investment Management Co.,investors fear that their money may be devalued by government interest in reflation and "think it is time to bail out." **********The yield on the benchmark 30-year issue fell to 6.37 percent Wednesday from 6.41 percent Tuesday, when bond prices plunged. **********"For some years now, governments and central banks have not only been listening to the bond market vigilantes but following their every move," Mr. Gross said."Now there has been a populist counterattack, which you saw first in Europe and now you see here with Pat Buchanan. The Republicans now are talking about growth and not deficits. This has unnerved the bond market." **********Although such swings in sentiment are part of all bond markets, Mr. Banker explained that they have been greatly exaggerated by changes during the past decade.Insurance companies and pension funds, which used to buy up to 90 percent of all bonds and keep them for years until they matured, now represent only about a quarter of the market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/15/news/.main_headline: U.K. Probes Huge Losses By Japan Copper Trader
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/15/news/.print_headline: U.K. Probes Huge Losses By Japan Copper Trader
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/15/news/.body_text: **********LONDON—                     Britain's Serious Fraud Office announced Friday that it had opened an investigation into $1.8 billion in losses that the Sumitomo Corp. said it had suffered as a result of unauthorized trades by its chief copper trader in Tokyo. **********A spokeswoman said that following discussions with the Securities and Investments Board, Britain's top markets regulator, the Serious Fraud Office and the City of London police "have taken on an investigation into the affairs of, and surrounding" Yasuo Hamanaka, a former employee of Sumitomo. **********She said the City of London police were involved because the allegations fell within their jurisdiction. She added that it could be months before the investigation yielded any results. **********The revelations Thursday of Sumitomo's losses over a 10-year span were the third in 16 months in which markets have been rocked by news of traders punching holes in their company's accounts. It comes just eight months after another Japanese giant, Daiwa Bank, admitted that a senior trader in its New York office had caused $1.1 billion in losses over an 11-year period through unauthorized trades in the bond markets. **********What sets the Sumitomo case apart from either that of Daiwa Bank, or the $1.4 billion in losses run up by Nicholas Leeson at Barings Plc last year, is both the size of the losses and the profile of the man who has now acknowledged doing the unauthorized trading. **********By all accounts, Mr. Hamanaka, the ousted chief copper trader, had long ranked not only as the pivotal player in the huge world copper market, but also as one of its most controversial figures. In 1993, for instance, Mr. Hamanaka denied that he had been involved in price manipulations that had claimed numerous victims. Among those was Codelco, a Chilean company that is the world's biggest copper producer. It reported losses of $170 million in the episode. **********Traders say that Mr. Hamanaka, as the biggest fish in the pond, used Sumitomo's size to maximum advantage, periodically punishing those who had sold the metal short by buying up copper and sending its price higher. Many in the market, for instance, saw Mr. Hamanaka's hand in just such a squeeze put on several big investment funds this March, which produced large losses for them. **********In spite of Mr. Hamanaka's tactics, few traders ever doubted his worth to Sumitomo. "The general feeling was always that Hamanaka was a successful trader who sometimes lost his shirt but on balance did well for Sumitomo," said a London copper analyst. **********What nonetheless struck many as odd about Mr. Hamanaka was the contrast between his huge trading volumes and the fact that Sumitomo's own rules prohibit the company from speculating in the market. Questioned about that over the years, both the company and its head copper trader insisted that their activities in the markets were necessary to ensure a steady supply of metal to their customers, who bought as much as a total of 750,000 tons from Sumitomo a year. **********For regulators, this latest financial scandal holds at least some consolation. For once, the regulators did bark and bark together, although admittedly tardily. **********A senior British regulator said early this year that both the Securities and Investments Board as well as the London Metals Exchange, the world's dominant copper market, had begun an investigation into copper trading. "What was going on just didn't make sense," he said, recalling that in contrast to the established norm, the price of copper had soared well above its price for future delivery. **********Not surprisingly, given Sumitomo's leading role in the market, regulators quickly turned their attention in its direction. Working with the U.S. regulator, the Commodities Futures Trading Corporation, they ultimately passed news of their concern to Sumitomo. Finally, on June 5, Mr. Hamanaka reportedly confessed to years of unauthorized off-the-books trading. **********It was three weeks earlier, though, that the market had gotten its first hints that something was amiss. Rumors that Mr. Hamanaka, copper's leading bull, had been dismissed from his post at Sumitomo were widely blamed for a 15 percent fall in the metal's price in just four days in mid-May. On May 17, the company denied the dismissal but admitted that Mr. Hamanaka had been reassigned. **********According to Sumitomo, their first indication of serious problems came in early May, when the company received notice of a $200,000 bank credit in its copper trading activities that it could not account for. Company officials then transferred Mr. Hamanaka away from trading and began a full investigation. **********What made Mr. Hamanaka's fate especially important to the markets was that in recent months traders had become increasingly convinced that a long-running undersupply of copper had been reversed at last. With new mines coming into production in Chile, Australia and New Zealand, many traders had become convinced that the only thing standing between the price of copper and the floor was Mr. Hamanaka and his conviction that prices need not fall. **********What surprised many observers was that in spite of Sumitomo's announced losses, the metal's price proved remarkably stable on Friday. Following a steep overnight selloff, copper regained much of its lost ground in trading Friday. **********Some attributed the performance to pledges from Sumitomo that it would not sell off its huge positions and thus do further damage to copper prices, which have now lost 30 percent of their value since early May. Others suggested that Sumitomo had already sold off many of its positions, a move they say may account for the huge volatility in copper prices over a 10 day period.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/09/world.main_headline: A Gathering By Burmese Defies Junta
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/09/world.print_headline: A Gathering By Burmese Defies Junta
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/09/world.body_text: **********Defying Burmese Government threats of harsh punishment, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the leader of a pro-democracy campaign, addressed more than 5,000 supporters who gathered in front of her house today. **********The gathering lasted an hour, and there was no interference from the authorities. **********The crowd cheered and shouted "Long live Aung San Suu Kyi!" and "Let the cause for democracy be successful!" when she appeared at the gate to her compound. **********Myanmar's military Government announced a new law on Friday that calls for prison sentences of 5 to 20 years for anyone who acts to undermine the stability of the state. **********The law's immediate target appeared to be Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, winner of the 1991 Nobel Peace Prize for her efforts to bring democracy to Myanmar. She has met with her supporters every Saturday since being freed from six years of house arrest last July. **********Her speech today was much milder than usual, containing no remarks critical of the Government. It was not clear whether she would be subject to legal action. **********The law was imposed in reaction to recent challenges by dissidents to the authority of the military, which has ruled Myanmar, formerly Burma, since 1962. **********Besides prison sentences, the law mandates fines and confiscation of property, and decrees that any organization found in violation will be suspended, disbanded or outlawed. **********The law was imposed a day after the Government informed Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's party that it was banning the Saturday meetings. The meetings were already prohibited under a law that forbids gatherings of more than 50 people, but that  law had not been enforced. Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi said then that the meetings would continue. **********The new law, signed by the chairman of the country's junta, also makes unauthorized writing of a constitution subject to the same penalties. **********Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy announced last month after a party congress that it was doing just that, rejecting a constitution being drafted by a Government-organized convention that has met for three years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/11/busin.body_text: **********Shares of Integrated Device Technology Inc. fell 8 percent yesterday after the company disclosed that its fiscal first-quarter earnings would come in below Wall Street's expectations because of declining demand for its integrated circuits. **********Integrated Device's stock fell 1 1/64, to 11, in heavy Nasdaq trading. **********Integrated Device, a Santa Clara, Calif., maker of large-scale integrated circuits, said on Friday that it expected earnings of 11 cents to 15 cents a share in its quarter ending June 30, on revenue of about $145 million to $150 million. That is below the average estimate of 20 cents a share from six analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research. **********In the quarter a year earlier, the company had net income of $28.8 million, or 36 cents a share, on revenues of $152.2 million. **********Integrated Device also said it would cut costs by instituting an unpaid holiday for the first week of July. The company, which employs 3,830 workers, said this would be the first time it needed to shut down in the summer. Integrated Device has previously shut down during the Christmas season. **********The company said a softness in demand for products that serve the personal computer market would hurt its profit. In addition, until the company completes  a new wafer fabrication factory it is building, it cannot meet the strong demand for microprocessors that serve the communications market. **********The plant is expected to be completed later this summer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/04/world.main_headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Stone of Scone to Return To Scots After 700 Years
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/04/world.print_headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Stone of Scone to Return To Scots After 700 Years
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/04/world.body_text: **********The Stone of Scone, the ancient coronation seat of the kings of Scotland, is  going home, 700 years after it was carried away to London by King Edward I, Prime Minister John Major announced today. **********Mr. Major told the House of Commons that the stone, kept beneath the coronation chair at Westminster Abbey, will be returned once a new home is selected. The stone was captured in 1296 and has been used in every coronation since 1308. **********I believe that on this, the 700th anniversary of its removal from Scotland, it is appropriate to return it to its historic homeland," Mr. Major said, adding that the stone would be brought back to London for coronation ceremonies. **********In 1950 the stone was stolen from Westminster Abbey by four young Scottish nationalists, but it was returned in time for the coronation of Queen Elizabeth  II in 1953. **********The announcement by the Conservative Prime Minister followed a proposal last  week by Labor Party leaders that, after an election victory, their party would hold referendums on shifting more power to Scotland and Wales.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/12/world.snippet: UN officials and aid workers, 10 days after leaving Zairian town of Goma because of siege by Tutsi rebels, make tentative attempt to return; cross nearby border from Rwanda with shipment of medicine and food in hope of reaching hundreds of thousan...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/12/world.main_headline: AID TEAMS RETURN TO ZAIRE BUT FIND ARMIES IN THE WAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/12/world.print_headline: AID TEAMS RETURN TO ZAIRE BUT FIND ARMIES IN THE WAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/12/world.body_text: **********Ten days after pulling out of the Zairian town of Goma because of a siege by rebels, United Nations officials and aid workers made a tentative attempt to return today, crossing the nearby border from Rwanda with a shipment of medicine and food in the hope of reaching hundreds of thousands of needy refugees. **********United Nations officials contacted the main leader of the rebels holding the looted town, who had invited them to bring aid, and took in a modest amount of food, medicine and blankets for the beleaguered residents by truck, officials said. **********But the team made almost no progress in negotiating safe passage through a war zone to the largest camp for Rwandan refugees, known as Mugunga, officials said. **********Hundreds of thousands of the refugees are believed to be in Mugunga or scattered in the countryside to the west of the camp. They are believed to be running short of food and clean water. **********Aid officials fear a calamity from epidemics and famine if medicine, food and clean water do not arrive soon, and they were hoping that the United Nations and the countries that are debating whether to take part in a relief force to aid the refugees will reach a decision quickly. **********The United Nations officials who entered Goma today were acting in defiance of the Zairian Government, which has insisted that all aid to the refugees go through Kinshasa, the capital, which is 900 miles away. United Nations officials said the decision to go ahead with the mission had been made by Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali. **********Mugunga, a sprawling tent city, lies about nine miles west of Goma. The rebels hold the town, but only up to a checkpoint about a half-mile from the camp. Beyond that, most of the territory is still under the control of Rwandan Hutu militias, who have joined the Zairian Army in fighting the rebels. **********These Hutu armed forces fled Rwanda in 1994 along with more than a million refugees as Tutsi-led forces won control of the country. **********The Hutu forces have been rearming. Many fled Rwanda to escape reprisals for mass killings of Tutsi civilians. They have fought hard to keep the mass of innocent Hutu refugees from going home, using them as a human shield and a bargaining chip in negotiations with the United Nations and aid agencies, United Nations officials said. The militias are known as the interhamwe, which means ''those who fight together'' in the Rwandan language. **********Thousands of the Rwandan refugees in the camps around Goma have been cut off from sources of food and other aid in recent weeks as a rebel alliance of Tutsi and other ethnic groups opposed to Zaire's Government has captured three major eastern Zairian cities, including Goma. **********''The big hole in all of this is that no one is talking to the other guys with the guns,'' said one aid official, speaking on condition of anonymity. ''We can make any agreement we want with all these parties in Goma, but there is one party missing.'' **********After meeting with the rebel leader in Goma, Laurent Desire Kabila, United Nations officials said it had become clear that the rebels alone could not open a path to the vast majority of refugees. Either an agreement with the Hutu guerrillas or military intervention of some kind would be needed, they said. **********''We can't get to the majority of the affected population from Goma,'' said Paul Stromberg, a United Nations spokesman. **********For his part, Mr. Kabila said today that he could guarantee the aid agencies' safe passage only as far as the camp's edge, not beyond. **********He said at a news conference that the Hutu forces in the Mugunga camp had shelled the town indiscriminately in recent days, killing at least two people. He said he was willing to allow United Nations food supplies to flow through his territory to the refugees, but he warned that if the shelling continued, he would be forced to attack the camp. **********''We must stop the killing of innocent people on our side by any means,'' Mr. Kabila said. ''We hope that before it is too late the international community can do something to stop this problem.'' **********He suggested, though, that the United Nations or ''other regional countries'' should ''send troops through us to go and neutralize the camp.'' **********''If we attack the refugee camp to push out these killers, the international community will start crying again,'' he said. **********The United Nations officials who accompanied the shipment to Goma not only met with Mr. Kabila, but also surveyed the damage to their organization's buildings and equipment after 10 days of looting by local Zairians. **********A similar United Nations team went into Bukavu, a rebel-held town about 150 miles to the south, in an area where about a half-million refugees from the fighting are believed to be sprinkled in the hills. ''They went over to make contact with the rebels, look at the offices, make an assessment how quickly we could get back in and get our offices up again,'' said Ray Wilkinson, a spokesman for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. **********The aid shipment today by the World Food Program and the United Nations refugee agency included about seven tons of high-protein biscuits and eight tons of beans and corn, enough to feed 2,500 people for a week, along with kits containing basic medical supplies, enough for about 10,000 people for a month. **********Catherine Bertini, executive director of the World Food Program, told The Associated Press that 15 more trucks were waiting to cross the border if the situation stayed calm. ''We have two months' worth of food pre-positioned all around Zaire,'' she was quoted as saying. ''It's just a question of how we will be able to get it in.'' **********In addition to the United Nations, a number of nonprofit aid agencies crossed the border in all-terrain vehicles, taking in small amounts of food and medical supplies, along with about 100 bales of blankets. Among the agencies are the United Nations Children's Fund; Concern; Save the Children; Doctors Without Borders; Merlin, a British medical relief organization, and Trocaire, an Irish aid group. **********It was not easy. The aid workers were delayed for nearly four hours at the border by Rwandan health officials. After crossing, the aid workers spent most of the afternoon gathered in a sports stadium, waiting for their representatives to gain permission from Mr. Kabila and other rebel leaders to distribute their goods. **********Some aid workers said they hoped to re-establish their operations in Goma right away and thus shame the United Nations into moving more quickly to supply the refugees out in the countryside. **********Peter Sinclair, a worker for Trocaire, told National Public Radio, ''If we are here supplying very small quantities of food, then it would put pressure on the international community to say, 'Listen, what is the U.N. doing about this?' '' **********There is a consensus among many aid workers that refugees are already dying of thirst and disease while proposals for military intervention have become bogged down at the United Nations Security Council in disputes over whose troops would constitute the force and what its mission would be. **********Nicholas Burns, the State Department spokesman, said today: ''The United States believes there will be a need for a humanitarian force to go into Zaire. Given the level of fighting, there is a need for a security force.'' **********But Mr. Burns, speaking to reporters traveling to Cairo with Secretary of State Warren Christopher, repeated that the shape, purpose and size of such a force remained unclear. ''You can't go rushing in with troops without knowing what the mission is, the scope of responsibility and who's going to pay for it,'' he said. **********Several conflicting plans are being considered, he said. ''The United States is not trying to block that force,'' Mr. Burns said. ''We are trying to help that force take shape.'' **********In Washington, Gen. John Shalikashvili, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told CNN television that ''we should not exclude that possibility'' of sending American troops. But ''it is not so clear that throwing troops in'' is the solution, he said, adding, ''I would feel much more comfortable if it were confined to humanitarian assistance.'' **********--------------------        Strike Paralyzes Kinshasa **********KINSHASA, Zaire, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Zaire's capital was paralyzed today as shop owners and public transportation workers honored a strike called by university students demanding the Prime Minister's resignation. **********The students lined the main road to the airport, seized cars and trucks and blocked many roads into the capital by setting tires on fire. **********Soldiers lobbed tear gas at young men who threw rocks at the motorcade of a departing European Union delegation. Other forces patrolled the streets and guarded gas stations to prevent the students from taking vehicles and looting gasoline. **********Prime Minister Leon Kengo wa Dondo has been the focal point of anger because his mother is Rwandan Tutsi. Tutsi rebels have recently seized towns in eastern Zaire with the support of Rwanda's Tutsi-led Government.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/28/world.snippet: Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto dissolves Parliament, setting stage for new national elections on Oct 20 that may reconfigure Japanese politics (M)û
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/28/world.main_headline: Japan's Premier Calls Elections for October
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/28/world.print_headline: Japan's Premier Calls Elections for October
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/28/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto dissolved Parliament today, setting the stage for new national elections that may reconfigure Japanese politics. **********Mr. Hashimoto's party is expected to do well in the elections, which will be held on Oct. 20, and most bets are that he will remain Prime Minister. But his party may not win a majority, meaning that he would have to form a new coalition that could help set off a political realignment. **********These elections are regarded as particularly important because they will be the first under a new voting system that is expected to mean the extinction of some small parties and a reduction in the importance of conservative rural voters. Under the new system, for the first time since 1924 Japanese will elect a single legislator from each district, as in the United States. **********''The time has come to ask for the people's support in determining how to guide Japan into the future,'' Mr. Hashimoto declared. **********''The battle is at hand,'' he added, ''and I want to give our every effort to win.'' **********Mr. Hashimoto could have waited until next summer to call an election, but the opposition is now in disarray and his Liberal Democratic Party is doing relatively well in the polls. It is benefiting from a slowly reviving economy and a sense that Mr. Hashimoto has moved to resolve problems with American bases in Okinawa. **********To be sure, Mr. Hashimoto has not lived up to the enthusiasm that greeted him when he took office in January, seeming young and dynamic by the standards of Japanese politics. But if voter attitudes toward the 59-year-old Mr. Hashimoto are lukewarm, they are positively cool to the main opposition leader, Ichiro Ozawa, head of the New Frontier Party. **********''This is an election on which we are staking the very existence of the New Frontier Party,'' Mr. Ozawa told party members today. ''More important, this is also an election on which we are staking the possibility of securing Japan's future and public happiness for the new generation.'' **********A recent poll by the Nihon Keizai newspaper found 22 percent support for the Liberal Democrats and only 7 percent for New Frontier. A full 49 percent were undecided, and a surprising 8 percent said they would support a new party, the Democrats. **********The Democratic Party, which is to be formally introduced on Saturday, is trying to emerge as the leading force for change in Japan, appealing to voters who are weary of corrupt and tired politicians who seem to be manipulated by the bureaucracy. It is led by Yukio Hatoyama, the scion of a wealthy political family who is sometimes compared to President Kennedy, and Naoto Kan, the energetic Health Minister and perhaps the most popular politician in Japan. **********Because it is so new, the Democratic Party is a wild card in the election, and it could emerge with the balance of power in a coalition. It is conceivable, though unlikely, that it could win enough seats to insist on the prime minister's job in a coalition with the Liberal Democrats. **********Politicians say that the new electoral system makes the outcome difficult to forecast, but that the most likely outcome is that the Liberal Democrats will dominate a coalition.  This would probably mean policies similar to the present ones. **********''I think it's going to be a coalition very much along the lines of what we have now,'' said John F. Neuffer, a specialist on Japanese politics at Mitsui Marine Research Institute in Tokyo. In any case, he noted, there are few major differences among the political parties. **********''Basically, everybody agrees on all of the issues,'' he said. ''This is a largely issue-less campaign.'' **********The one topic that has aroused some interest is whether the national sales tax should be raised as scheduled in April from 3 percent to 5 percent. Voters are opposed to the tax increase, and so the opposition is trying to make an issue of it. **********The opposition is also calling for major administrative reform, including a dramatic reduction in the number of government ministries. But since all the major parties are calling for this, even the governing Liberal Democrats, voters seem skeptical of all the proposals. **********In the old electoral system, Japanese elected several legislators from each district. But now 300 legislators will be chosen in single-seat constituencies, with just one member of Parliament for each district. An additional 200 legislators will be chosen by proportional representation based on votes for each party. **********The combination of the new system and the surly voter mood is expected to be nearly fatal for the Social Democratic Party, which recently changed its name from the Socialist Party in a desperate attempt to broaden its appeal. The Socialists were the main opposition party for most of postwar Japanese history, but they seem to be fragmenting and may not survive much longer. **********''Our identity as an independent party has not become clear, and we have provoked criticism and distrust,'' the Social Democrats' leader, Tomiichi Murayama, said today. ''But we've had some calls of support just now, and we've got to win in this election at all cost.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/06/busin.main_headline: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar Soars in Thin Trading As Higher U.S. Rates Are Seen
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/06/busin.print_headline: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar Soars in Thin Trading As Higher U.S. Rates Are Seen
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/06/busin.body_text: **********The dollar surged in thin, volatile trading yesterday, as a surprisingly strong United States employment report buoyed hopes for higher United States interest rates. **********The dollar initially fell in New York trading, dragged down by tumbles in the United States bond and stock markets, after the Labor Department reported that 239,000 jobs were added to the nation's payrolls last month. But the same interpretation of the data that drove down stocks and bonds -- that robust economic growth would compel the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates -- eventually bolstered the dollar. **********This news strengthens the view that the Fed will tighten, probably in August," said Marc Chandler, a trader at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell. "It keeps the dollar going higher." **********A rise in interest rates typically helps the dollar by making bank deposits in the United States more attractive. **********The dollar climbed as high as 111.0 Japanese yen, its highest since Jan. 26,  1994. In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 110.85 yen, up from 110.40 yen on Thursday. The dollar traded at 1.5298 German marks, up from 1.5206. The British pound fell to $1.5525 from $1.5625. **********Trading was light, however, with many traders in the United States on a long  holiday weekend. American financial markets were closed on Thursday for the Fourth of July. **********The dollar's rise yesterday was tempered by the sharp declines in stocks and  bonds. When foreign investors sell American assets, they are converting the proceeds into other currencies. **********"There's a tug-of-war for the dollar," said John McCarthy, foreign- exchange  manager at ING Capital Markets. "Certainly from a yield standpoint this is positive for the dollar. But falling asset prices are not." **********John Rothfield, currency strategist at Nationsbanc-CRT in Chicago, predicted  that the strong economy would help push the dollar to 1.60 marks and 115 yen in  the next three months. **********"Over all we think the data will be good for the dollar," he said. "A continuation of the dollar's rise is dependent on a firm response from the Fed,  and we do expect a rate hike in August."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/02/world.snippet: Air Marshal Sir Arthur McDonald, career Royal Air Force officer, dies of July 26 at age 93 (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/02/world.main_headline: Sir Arthur McDonald, 93; Set Up Radar to Thwart Blitz
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/02/world.print_headline: Sir Arthur McDonald, 93; Set Up Radar to Thwart Blitz
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/02/world.body_text: **********Air Marshal Sir Arthur McDonald, a career Royal Air Force officer who conducted a secret rehearsal of the Battle of Britain three years before the Luftwaffe flew into a well-prepared hornet's nest that handed Hitler his first defeat and changed the course of World War II, died on July 26. He was 93. **********A longtime senior officer whose posts included the last British command of the Pakistani Air Force, Sir Arthur, who retired in 1961, was also a noted amateur sailor who represented England in the 1948 Olympics and won his last race at the age of 92. **********London newspapers that reported his death gave no details. **********It was in June 1937 that a civilian airliner took off from the Netherlands and flew across the North Sea on a flight of such uneventful routine that when the plane landed safely in London, the Dutch pilot had no idea that he had unwittingly become a footnote to military history or that Squadron Leader Arthur McDonald had tracked him all the way. **********For although there had been earlier tests with cooperating R.A.F. target planes, the Dutch airliner was the first foreign plane in history to be detected and tracked by a new system based on reflected radio waves. **********It was called R.D.F., for radio detection finding, but in a gesture of noblesse oblige after sharing the technology with the United States, whose scientists called it radio aid for directionfinding and ranging, once the Battle of Britain had been won, the British adopted the American terminology and called it radar. **********It was Robert Watson-Watt, the British scientist who discovered and developed radar, who tipped the technological scales in favor of Britain in the air battles of World War II. **********But it was Sir Arthur who led the effort to adopt the technology for military use. **********The son of a British Army doctor who had served in the Boer War, Sir Arthur, who was born in South Africa and grew up on St. Kitts and Antigua, where his family had lived for generations, was the logical choice. **********After graduating from Epsom College in England and joining the air force in 1924, he had studied engineering at Cambridge, becoming one of the first R.A.F. officers to receive advanced technical training. **********It was to come in handy in 1936 when he was summoned back from his post in Singapore to take command of a secret experiental project to incorporate radar into the air force structure. **********Although it had been known since 1930 that reflected radio waves could theoretically be used to detect the position of distant planes, the technology was so rudimentary that German scientists who spent the 1930's working on it, were stunned in 1940 when they learned how rapidly and how well the British had perfected the system and incorporated it into their air defense. **********The British, of course, had the advantage of desperation. With no place in the country more than 20 minutes by air from the nearest coastal point, they knew that without an advance detection system it would take thousands and thousands of planes and antiaircraft guns scattered all over the country to mount more than a token defense against a mighty German Air Force that could pick the time and point of attack at will. **********And the British didn't have thousands of planes. They had only 650 Hurricanes and Spitfires, and were outnumbered by more than three to one by a German force of 900 German Messerschmitt fighters and 1,300 bombers. **********But by the time the air assault began as a prelude to a German invasion, the British also had chain of radar beacons and the techniques Sir Arthur had designed to use them for the rapid, accurate and efficient deployment of defending planes. **********For while it was Watson-Watt, who had been working with radar since 1919, who won the technological race, it was Sir Arthur who gave it its military sting, and not, coincidentally, created the familiar icons of countless movies about the Battle of Britain. **********It was he who designed the familiar war rooms with airmen pushing contrasting symbols of attacking and defending aircraft across a map table and it was he who invented the cryptic radio jargon of angels and bandits. **********He is survived by his wife, Mary; two sons and two daughters.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/17/busin.body_text: **********The Compaq Computer Corporation reported strong gains yesterday in revenues, earnings and profit margins, which it attributed to successful new products, cost-saving efforts and an increase in its share of the personal computer market. **********Compaq's earnings comfortably exceeded Wall Street analysts' estimates for the quarter, and the announcement was taken by many as another sign of the industry's renewed vigor. **********But like the Intel Corporation's earnings report, which beat analysts' estimates on Monday, the good fortune of Compaq owes much to the company's dominant position in the industry. As the world's leading supplier of PC's, Compaq benefits from any broad pickup in demand, but also reaps proportionately greater savings from a higher volume of components purchases. **********Shares of Compaq fell $1.125, to $73.625. Analysts said some investors were selling on Compaq's good news, taking advantage of the increase in the stock, which has risen 12 percent in the last week and on Tuesday had reached a high of $74.75. **********''This was a very good quarter,'' Todd Bakar, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist, said. ''The overall industry health is good, but for those companies gaining share it's extremely good,'' he said, naming Compaq, Gateway 2000 Inc., the Dell Computer Corporation and the personal computer division of the Hewlett-Packard Company. For companies losing market share, such as AST Research Inc., these have been tough times. **********The stock market has also been ruthless to companies it perceived as underperforming or facing future troubles. Despite strong earnings, shares of Sun Microsystems Inc. fell nearly 10 percent yesterday, to $63.125, on fears that other companies including Compaq are entering the work station market that is dominated by Sun. **********For the third quarter, Compaq reported earnings of $350 million, or $1.26 a share, a 43 percent gain from $245 million, or 89 cents a share, in the comparable period last year. Revenues grew 25 percent, to $4.5 billion, compared with $3.6 billion reported in the third quarter of 1995. **********Wall Street analysts had expected earnings of $1.07 a share, according to First Call. **********Compaq's sales growth of 25 percent indicated the company was taking market share from competitors, Earl L. Mason, Compaq's senior vice president and chief financial officer, said in a telephone interview. Gross profit margin improvement ''was fueled not only by good products, but by cost reduction activities in our main business,'' he said. ''We have people focused on trying to move raw materials to finished products as fast as possible,'' he said. Compaq reduced inventory and increased its cash, he said. **********Eckhard Pfeiffer, Compaq's president and chief executive, said in a statement: ''Our outlook continues to call for a strong second half. We're confident that Compaq's business model enables us to gain market share and improve profitability.'' **********But one longtime industry consultant said Compaq's third-quarter gains could be fleeting. Seymour Merrin of Merrin Information Services in Mountain View, Calif., said that the entry of the Sony Corporation and the Toshiba Corporation into the desktop computer business, coupled with strong new products from I.B.M., would challenge Compaq. **********''Compared to Toshiba and I.B.M., their product design is not as enticing and their merchandising, especially packaging, has really gone back a number of steps, and will probably cost them share,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/16/busin.body_text: **********Milio Azcarraga Milmo usually travels with an entourage befitting the most powerful media mogul in Mexico. With his baronial bearing and distinctive appearance -- a stripe of white hair bisects his jet-black mane -- Mr. Azcarraga lives up to his nickname, "El Tigre." **********On a bright, cold morning in January, however, Mr. Azcarraga turned up alone  at the home of Mary Anselmo in Greenwich, Conn. And on that day at least, the tiger acted more like a tabby. **********Mr. Azcarraga had known Mrs. Anselmo and her late husband, Rene V. Anselmo,  over four turbulent decades. Through his company, Grupo Televisa S.A., he had backed Mr. Anselmo's bold effort to break into the satellite business. Now, though, Mr. Azcarraga wanted Mrs. Anselmo to sell her husband's creation, PanAmSat, which had become the world's largest private satellite network, so he  could liquidate his investment. **********After a brief, subdued conversation in front of a crackling fireplace, Mrs. Anselmo acquiesced. She has been in agony ever since. **********"I'm not sure Rene would have approved," Mrs. Amselmo said in an interview at her home, an elegant chateau modeled on the Petit Trianon at Versailles. "I think he would have thought this was precipitate." **********Indeed, the 66-year-old widow's reluctant decision has set off an emotionally charged drama involving her family, Mr. Azcarraga and PanAmSat's 188 employees.  Behind everything hovers her late husband, a charismatic but combative man who seemed to spy an enemy behind every satellite dish. Though Mr. Anselmo died of heart failure in September at 69, his tangled legacy looms large over the family and the family business. **********So great were his passions and so fierce his feuds that Mr. Anselmo still seems to be pulling strings from the peaceful grotto behind his home where he is buried. **********"Rene was a fighter and a scrapper," said Mark Fowler, who, as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission under President Ronald Reagan, helped Mr.  Anselmo pierce the monopoly in satellites. "He was crazy like a fox." **********Mrs. Anselmo has retained Morgan, Stanley & Company to solicit offers for PanAmSat. People familiar with the process said Morgan had already attracted a blue-chip list of potential buyers: Hughes Electronics, General Electric, Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, Loral, Lockheed Martin, and SES, a European satellite company. Morgan hopes to present a menu of options to the family in mid-July. **********With its necklace of four satellites that float in stationary orbit 22,300 miles above the equator and beam channels like CNN, HBO, and MTV to more than 100 countries, PanAmSat is a crown jewel in the rarefied world of global satellite networks. It now has a market capitalization of $2.9 billion, and several investment bankers estimate that it could command a price between $3 billion and $4 billion. **********Mrs. Anselmo, however, frets that a new owner may sunder the close-knit team  of sales executives and engineers that her husband gathered around him in the 12 tumultuous years that he built PanAmSat from a far-fetched concept into a public company that trades at a gravity-defying multiple of 25 times 1995 revenues. **********Prominent among these executives is Frederick A. Landman, president and chief executive, who began working for Mr. Anselmo fresh out of college in 1973 and married his only daughter, Pier, four years later. Mr. Landman, 48, and Pier Anselmo were recently divorced, but he retains close ties to Mary Anselmo. The couple have two daughters, Rissa and Chloe. **********"My husband was very paternalistic, and I've inherited that," said Mrs. Anselmo, whose sad eyes and weary tone bespeak a woman struggling with the pressures of settling her husband's estate. "It makes this really tough." **********If Mrs. Anselmo does not receive an attractive offer for PanAmSat, she has the option of doing a secondary stock offering instead. Under the company's shareholder structure, she is all but guaranteed to have the final say on any deal. And if Televisa tries to sell its stake without her consent, the stock would lose its special PanAmSat voting rights. **********But a stock offering would raise less money than an outright sale. That may not suit Televisa, which needs to fix a balance sheet battered by the collapse of the Mexican peso in 1995. Televisa's $200 million investment in PanAmSat now  has a market value of $1.17 billion. **********Although Televisa recently raised $700 million through a private debt placement, the company has not wavered from its desire to cash out of PanAmSat.  "The refinancing does not in any way change our position," said Guillermo Caneda White, chief financial officer of Televisa and Mr. Azcarraga's principal representative on the PanAmSat board. **********Though Mrs. Anselmo says she, too, wants a premium price for PanAmSat, an attractive offer clearly means more than cold cash. She said she would also like to honor the memory of her husband. **********And that's where things get sticky. Mr. Anselmo, the son of a Massachusetts postal superintendent of Italian descent, served as a young Marine tail-gunner in World War II. Throughout his life, he relished a good fight and nursed old grudges -- against competitors, suppliers, partners, even his neighbors in Greenwich. "When I get mad, I just never give up," he said in a 1990 interview. **********Now, the battles Mr. Anselmo fought during his life could ensnare the sale of PanAmSat after his death. **********For example, Hughes is perhaps the most logical buyer. The company is starting a direct-to-home satellite service in Latin America that could be folded into a rival Latin American service being started by PanAmSat, Televisa and several media companies. Hughes is also no stranger to PanAmSat; it built three of its satellites. **********The catch? Hughes deeply offended Mr. Anselmo when it opted to go head-to-head with PanAmSat and Televisa in Latin America. He told Hughes executives he would never buy another satellite from them and promptly switched  his contract to Loral. **********The bitterness persists. Shortly after her husband's death, Mrs. Anselmo got  a condolence letter from C. Michael Armstrong, the chairman of Hughes. After expressing his regrets, however, Mr. Armstrong segued into business -- offering  to buy the company if Mrs. Anselmo put it up for sale. "It was a clumsy move," she said. **********Reverge C. Anselmo, her 33-year-old son, who used to work for PanAmSat and is now one of its five directors, is more frank. "We don't like Hughes," he said. "They betrayed my dad, and they betrayed Azcarraga." **********A spokesman for Hughes declined to comment on Mr. Armstrong's letter or on whether Hughes planned to bid for PanAmSat. One top Hughes executive, who declined to be identified, acknowledged that "it makes for a strained relationship when your satellite manufacturer is also competing with you as an operator." But he added that Mr. Anselmo's past clashes with the company would not influence its decision to bid. **********NOTHING dramatizes the late Mr. Anselmo's mix of vision and vitriol more than his roller-coaster relationship with Mr. Azcarraga. **********The two men met in Mexico in 1954, where Mr. Anselmo settled after graduating from the Great Books program at the University of Chicago in 1951. Mr. Anselmo was directing theatrical productions while Mr. Azcarraga was dabbling as a theatrical financier. Mrs. Anselmo, who married Mr. Anselmo soon after he moved  to Mexico, remembers the young Mr. Azcarraga as a "playboy," though she said he worked hard and had the drive of a locomotive. **********Mr. Azcarraga prodded his father to recruit Mr. Anselmo to build a television network that would cater to the mushrooming Hispanic population in the United States. The company he created, Spanish International Network, eventually strung together more than 300 affiliates. Together, Mr. Azcarraga and Mr. Anselmo also  acquired five stations. **********In 1985, though, the F.C.C. refused to renew the station licenses after ruling that their foreign parent company, Televisa, exercised too much control over them. Over Mr. Anselmo's strident objections, the younger Mr. Azcarraga agreed to sell the stations and the network. Mr. Anselmo pocketed $80 million, but he broke off relations with the younger Mr. Azcarraga. **********From broadcasting, it was a small leap for Mr. Anselmo to satellites. His debut as a satellite executive has already passed into lore -- as celebrated in  this tight-knit industry as Ted Turner's risky foray into round-the-clock news is among cable programmers. **********In 1988, Mr. Anselmo gambled the bulk of his fortune, more than $60 million,  to buy a used satellite and launch it with inadequate insurance and no clients on an unproven Ariane rocket. A three-pack-a-day smoker, Mr. Anselmo missed the  launching in French Guiana because he was in Greenwich recovering from quintuple bypass surgery. **********While Mr. Anselmo scrambled to sign up clients -- his first coup was a contract to transmit CNN to Latin America -- he waged an epic and victorious battle against Intelsat, a consortium owned by more than 100 governments that dominated the global satellite business. **********President Reagan had declared in 1984 that private operators ought to be allowed to compete with Intelsat in global satellite communications. But Intelsat lobbied long and furiously, both at home and abroad, to keep PanAmSat out of the business. Mr. Anselmo retaliated with a blizzard of letters to F.C.C. officials and lawmakers that lampooned Intelsat's monopoly with humor that sometimes bordered on the scatological. **********"We were all amused to read those letters," said Mr. Fowler. "They were either the product of a very clever mind or a very demented one." **********Alfred C. Sikes, one of Mr. Fowler's successors as F.C.C. chairman, said there was a method to the madness. "Discussing satellite policy is like watching paint dry. He took it out of the abstract." **********In Congressional testimony, Mr. Anselmo played to the hilt the role of scrappy underdog. Bernard L. Schwartz, the chairman of Loral, recalls sitting next to Mr. Anselmo at a 1994 House hearing. Asked what he thought of a treaty restricting overseas satellite transmission, Mr. Anselmo ripped up a piece of paper with a flourish. **********Mr. Anselmo created a cartoon dog named Spot as a mascot for his crusade. Spot was usually pictured lifting his hind leg -- a less-than-subtle metaphor for Mr. Anselmo's contempt for monopolies. Spot showed up in letters, newspaper  advertisements, even emblazoned on the nose cone of the Ariane rockets that carried PanAmSat's satellites aloft. Even today, the company's stock trades on Nasdaq under the symbol SPOT. **********Emboldened by his early success, Mr. Anselmo agreed to pay $721 million in 1991 to build, insure, and launch three more satellites. After a fruitless search for investors, Mr. Anselmo went back to Mr. Azcarraga with an offer to sell Televisa 50 percent of PanAmSat for $200 million. Despite the six-year rupture in their friendship, Mr. Azcarraga agreed. **********With Mr. Azcarraga's money in his pocket, Mr. Anselmo set off on a wild ride  to turn PanAmSat, which then had one satellite, into a global network able to sign up a wide array of clients and beam their programming virtually anywhere in the world. Over the next three years, Mr. Anselmo kept expanding despite a failed satellite launching, an initial public offering that was pulled at the last minute and ever-worsening health problems that led to another major operation in 1994. **********By the time of Mr. Anselmo's death -- the day before the company's shares began trading on Nasdaq -- PanAmSat had become a genuinely global player. The company had expanded beyond its core clientele of American cable networks to sign up foreign broadcasters like China Central Television, Doordarshan of India, and NHK of Japan. **********"They came at a time when there was no good alternative," said Robert M. Zitter, the senior vice president of technology operations at HBO. "And they developed a system that meets the needs of the television market." HBO leases capacity on three PanAmSat satellites to beam its channel to Latin America, Asia, and, soon, India. **********In 1995, PanAmSat's revenue rose to $116.1 million, almost twice the $63.7 million it recorded in 1994. More than half of last year's revenue, $66.1 million, is operating cash flow -- money the company can theoretically reinvest  in the business. In the first quarter of 1996, PanAmSat's results continued to soar: revenues hit $50.4 million, while cash flow jumped to $36.6 million. **********PanAmSat's horizon is not completely cloud-free. With the explosion of satellite communications, private companies are sprouting here and abroad to challenge its cozy franchise. And Mr. Anselmo's pell-mell expansion saddled the  company with $575 million in long-term debt. **********But Andrew Hornick, a media and communications analyst at Citicorp Securities Inc., said the debt load was manageable because the company would generate a reliable flow of revenue from long-term contracts worth a total of $3.2 billion. Once airborne, he pointed out, satellites are inexpensive to maintain. **********These unusual economics -- large starting costs offset by low operating expenses and lofty margins -- have made PanAmSat's stock buoyant.  After going public in September at $17, the company's shares slipped briefly and then rose to a high of $33.25 in April. Since then, they have settled in the high 20's; on Friday, the company's stock closed at $29. **********PanAmSat's four satellites already reach 98 percent of the world's population. But Mr. Landman, the chief executive, said PanAmSat intends to launch two more satellites next year and a third by 1998 to expand its capacity  to carry TV programming, plus some telephone and data traffic. When finished, PanAmSat will have eight satellites aloft -- four over the Atlantic and two each over the Pacific and Indian oceans. **********WHILE Mr. Landman talks excitedly about these plans, his mood darkens when the conversation switches to a potential sale. Like other senior executives, Mr. Landman owes his career to Mr. Anselmo. While Mr. Landman's seven million shares are worth $203 million, there is no other job he wants aside from running his former father-in-law's company. **********"This has been a very emotional time for me," he said, "Rene Anselmo was my mentor in every sense of the word." **********For Mrs. Anselmo, the potential payoff from a sale is even greater. But so, too, is the emotional strain of worrying about employees like Mr. Landman. The Anselmo family together controls a 40.5 percent stake in PanAmSat, which is worth $1.17 billion, and elects three of the company's five directors. Although  Televisa also owns 40.5 percent, it elects only two directors. And in the event of a split among the Anselmos, Mrs. Anselmo alone gets to cast the tie-breaking vote. **********Two of Mrs. Anselmo's three children -- Pier and Rayce, a son who has worked  in television and lives in California -- profess not to be interested in the business. But Reverge Anselmo, who attended the decisive meeting with Mr. Azcarraga in Greenwich, is keen on diversifying his family's holdings. **********"My family has a lot of talent, and there are a lot of other things we could  do," Reverge Anselmo said in an interview from his home in Capitan, N.M. "Let's  get our noses out of the solar panels for a while." **********Reverge Anselmo worked as a sales executive for PanAmSat in Miami for several years, and Mrs. Anselmo said her husband harbored hopes that he would make a career in the family business. But Mr. Anselmo quit abruptly 18 months ago, after clashing with Mr. Landman, then his brother-in-law. Though Mrs. Anselmo said her husband was chagrined, he was not willing to side with his son over Mr. Landman. **********"It was a case of the heir apparent coming up against the heir," said Mrs. Anselmo with palpable regret. **********Mr. Anselmo is now completing a novel that grew out of his experience as a Marine in Beirut during the 1982 terrorist bombing. **********Edward J. Landau, Mrs. Anselmo's lawyer, is also gently prodding her to consider a sale. "No matter how good a company is, to have 95 percent of your net worth in one stock is not a good thing," he said. **********People familiar with the process said that at least one company, Loral, had made a preliminary offer for PanAmSat and had indicated it might negotiate. As Mrs. Anselmo watches the players maneuver, she is doing her best to soothe the fears of PanAmSat's employees. After saying she would consider a sale, Mrs. Anselmo reassured employees in a conference call that she would try to take care of them. **********In a rare break from her husband's practices, she threw a companywide Christmas party last December at her home, which employees jokingly refer to as  the "big house." (Rene Anselmo always hated Christmas parties, according to employees.) **********"A lot of us viewed Rene as a father figure," said Lourdes Saralegui, a 34-year-old executive vice president, who joined PanAmSat only 12 years ago as a temporary secretary. "Now, Mary is taking on the role of a maternal figure." **********That's no easy task. Just as Katharine Graham struggled to take the reins of  the Washington Post and Loida Lewis grappled with the job of running TLC Beatrice International after the deaths of their husbands, Mary Anselmo has found it daunting to step into the breach. "My mother has never had anything other than being Mrs. Anselmo," Reverge Anselmo said. **********Smoking one cigarette after another just as her husband had done, Mrs. Anselmo said the other day that she had rarely been involved in her husband's business and that she knows precious little about satellites. Asked how she was  handling all the pressure, she responded, "Not too well, obviously." **********For example, she expressed surprise in the interview that Morgan Stanley, PanAmSat's financial adviser, was also playing a big role in Televisa's efforts  to raise some quick cash. Given her ambivalence about a sale, some of Morgan Stanley's rivals say the bank may be wearing too many hats. **********Yet Mr. Landman said Mrs. Anselmo was being too modest. They said she kept well-informed about the financial mechanics. "Don't let her fool you with the I-don't-know-anything-about-business line," he said. And Mrs. Anselmo has continued her vocation: the upkeep of her chateau in suburbia. The Anselmos bought the house in 1967, and she and her husband supervised a never-ending series of landscaping and construction projects dreamed up by Mr. Anselmo. **********MR. ANSELMO'S drive to beautify his surroundings extended beyond his front gates. For years, he paid to plant thousands of daffodils and tulips along North Street, where his house is located. In 1990, he was arrested for spray painting  over a neighbor's "For Sale" sign that he contended was unsightly. The town later dropped the charges. **********Soft-spoken and gracious, Mrs. Anselmo would not use such ham-handed tactics. But she is starting to put her own imprint on the house that Rene built. Mrs. Anselmo just bought the six acres adjoining her 12-acre lot to prevent anyone from building a house there. She said she would like to build a pond and a pavilion on her expanded grounds. **********It's the skies -- and the satellites that rove silently through them -- that  Mary Anselmo may not have as much control over.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/04/busin.print_headline: Microsoft has failed to apply its own success formula to interactive media.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/04/busin.body_text: **********OF the Microsoft Corporation's grip on the software industry is roughly equivalent to the Kremlin's control over the former Soviet Union -- so great that the world scrambles to decode every ceremonial hiccup -- then the industry's Kremlinologists should take note of the subtext in the revamping that the company announced last week. **********That subtext concerned Microsoft's huge investments in interactive media, a growing genre of products, viewed on a PC, that includes video games, CD-ROM's and World Wide Web sites. What grabbed most of the headlines was the announcement that Patty Stonesifer, senior vice president of the interactive media division and Microsoft's only top-ranking female executive, was leaving the company. **********But the organizational shift also moved Nathan Myhrvold, one of the company's best-known technical visionaries, out of his role as group vice president of Microsoft's ''applications and content'' business. As the  executive in charge of ''content,'' Mr. Myhrvold approved most of Microsoft's media projects. But he has now been pulled back into research as  chief technology officer. **********Perhaps most noteworthy is that the company, for the first time, has broken out interactive media into its own business group -- and tapped a highly regarded Microsoft executive, Pete Higgins, to run it. **********Sharing management duties in the applications and content group with Mr. Myhrvold, Mr. Higgins ran the company's cash-cow software applications business, which includes the company's flagship Word and Excel products. Now, under his leadership, the interactive media business will have its own entry on Microsoft's balance sheet. Until last week, its finances were never public because they were reported as part of the applications and content group. **********These are radical moves that speak volumes about the strategic importance Microsoft is now placing on the interactive media market. **********Because it already dominates the PC software industry, Microsoft cannot grow much more simply by increasing market share. Instead, the company measures its growth by increasing ''dollars spent per PC,'' as Ms. Stonesifer once said. Once customers have bought word processors, spreadsheets and data bases, most of what they continue to buy are inexpensive upgrades. **********But media is an addictive, hit-driven business. Unlike buying a spreadsheet and using it for years, buying one video game is likely to inspire the buying of another. The media opportunities are not only in software titles: PC users, on average, now spend between $10 and $200 a month for on-line services and Internet connections. **********And if consumers buy lots of Microsoft Windows-based interactive media, they are increasingly bonded to the Windows PC platform itself -- meaning, in theory, that they will continue to spend more and more dollars per PC. **********Industry watchers estimate Microsoft's media investments are now between $800 million and $1.5 billion, embracing everything from giant reference works on CD-ROM to television's MSNBC cable channel (on which this writer appears as a commentator). The company has ensconced more than 2,000 workers in a new Redmond, Wash., campus for its interactive media division. In addition to MSNBC, its joint venture with NBC News, Microsoft has partnership deals with Dreamworks SKG, Paramount Television, Black Entertainment Television and others. **********Earlier this month, moreover, the company transformed its Microsoft Network, known as MSN, from a proprietary on-line service to a giant Web site of information and entertainment ''channels,'' much of which is created by independent producers financed by Microsoft. **********In fact, one on-line developer said Microsoft is courting these producers so intensely that ''no one in the New York interactive media world has bought themselves dinner in more than a month.'' **********But as any company can tell you, making deals and spending money does not insure success. And even though both businesses involve PC's, the process of creating and selling PC software, Microsoft-style, could not be more different than creating  and selling interactive media. **********Hit media properties, especially in entertainment, are the result of a winnowing of thousands of creative visions made manifest in the market. If the public does not like one vision, it will simply go somewhere else. **********But Microsoft is not known for creative vision. Instead, it is legendary for taking the visions of others, pushing its own version into the market, and reiterating it until the company  gets it right. **********The difference between software applications and media properties is so fundamental that many people believe Microsoft cannot be successful in interactive media until it puts someone in charge of the division who knows and understands both media and creative vision. **********Ms. Stonesifer's move out of the company was under way for a year, and Mr. Higgins had been attending meetings with her for more than eight months, according to people familiar with the situation. During this transition, the company presumably had the opportunity to find someone with vision and the skills to make it a reality. It chose not to. **********Why not remains a mystery. Any analysis of Microsoft's success focuses on the acumen of its chairman, Bill Gates, whose intimate knowledge of software is inextricably linked to his business skills, making him a formidable competitor. **********Mr. Gates said Mr. Higgins was right for his new job because of his success with applications, as well as his considerable management skills. **********But that represents only half of the equation that Mr. Gates has long brought to the making and marketing of software. What is missing in this case is a fundamental understanding of interactive media. **********With such sizable investments on the line, Microsoft's failure to apply its own success formula to interactive media is an apparent lapse in logic -- from a company where logic is a stock in trade.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/17/busin.body_text: **********The European Union hopes to establish a broad partnership on trade and investment with Asia to gain a bigger share of the region's explosive growth and strike a fresh blow against U.S. trade unilateralism, officials said. **********The economic partnership will be the centerpiece of discussions when EU leaders hold their first summit meeting with the heads of 10 Asian governments in Bangkok on March 1 and 2. **********One primary aim of the partnership is to bolster the World Trade Organization as an effective arbiter of global trade rules and to hammer out common positions on extending those rules to new areas such as telecommunications, EU and Asian officials said. **********That goal amounts to an implicit criticism of Americantrade policy, which many European and Asian officials believe seeks to gain an unfair advantage by threatening to impose unilateral trade sanctions. **********It also underlines the improvement in relations between the EU and Asia since the two sides made common cause against Washington in trade disputes over cars and financial services last year, officials said. **********The meeting "should make a strong pledge for multilateralism and open regionalism," said an EU position paper adopted by the European Commission on Tuesday. EU and Asian officials also hope that the meeting will stimulate greater trade and investment between the two regions. **********Although the European Union conducted 23.2 percent of its trade with Asia in 1994 compared with 17.4 percent with the United States, the EU sent just 1 percent of its direct foreign investment to the region. **********"They have a lot of room to improve," said Somkiati Ariyapruchya, Thailand's ambassador to the Union. **********With Asia's needs for roads, power plants and other infrastructure estimated at as much as $150 billion a year, the region represents an opportunity that can enhance Europe's growth rather thanpose a threat to its jobs, he said. **********EU and Asian officials said the trade initiatives should not be interpreted as anattack against the United States, and U.S. officials noted that the trans-Atlantic initiative signed in December committed Washington to cooperating with Europe at the World Trade Organization. **********Mary Seet-Cheng, Singapore's ambassador to the Union, said the overall goal of the Bangkok meeting was to "close the triangle" in global relations by elevating links between Europe and Asia to the same level that each region now enjoys with the United States.

He will continue as vice chairman until April 4 and then be a director and consultant. Brian Jones, executive vice president of the cellular unit's Los Angeles market, will succeed Mr. Cox as chief executive of Airtouch Cellular. **********CAMPBELL SOUP CO., Camden, N.J., said Frank Weise, senior vice president, had resigned. He headed Campbell's bakery and confectionery division, which includes Pepperidge Farm cookies and Godiva chocolates.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/04/world.body_text: **********An outspoken Palestinian critic of human rights violations by the Palestinian Authority was detained for 24 hours and then released late tonight by Palestinian security forces in the West Bank town of Ramallah. **********The Palestinian, Bassem Eid, lives in Jerusalem and works as an investigator  for the Israeli human rights group, B'Tselem. He is also a representative of the Paris-based media group, Reporters Without Borders. **********His arrest followed a pattern of similar detentions in recent months of several Palestinian journalists and human rights advocates, and it raised concerns that the authority was trying to intimidate critics before planned Palestinian elections. **********Mr. Eid was freed after a flurry of contacts throughout the day in which the  authority came under pressure from Israeli Cabinet ministers, foreign diplomats  and human rights groups at home and abroad. **********Shortly after he was freed, Mr. Eid said he had spent the day in a room near  the offices of one of the branches of the Palestinian security force. He was neither questioned nor told why he was there, he said. **********Mr. Eid was released to Dr. Ahmad Tibi, an Israeli Arab adviser to Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization. **********Mr. Eid had been arrested on Tuesday night after he left his house in the Shuafat refugee camp on the outskirts of Jerusalem, apparently to help resolve a dispute between neighbors. **********As he was driving home, Mr. Eid said, he was stopped by a Palestinian officer who told him to follow him to Ramallah, a city under Palestinian rule about eight miles north of Jerusalem. **********Throughout the day, Palestinian officials denied that Mr. Eid was in their hands. **********"We don't have him," said Col. Yunis al-Asi, the commander of Palestinian security forces in the Ramallah area. "There is no warrant for the arrest of Bassem Eid." **********Nabil Abu Rdeineh, Mr. Arafat's spokesman, said: "The President does not know anything about this, and he has nothing to do with this case. If there is a security problem, this has nothing to do with the President." **********But Yizhar Beer, director of B'Tselem, said Mr. Eid had been targeted because of his harsh criticism of the authority's human rights record. **********Mr. Eid researched a B'Tselem report published last year that documented torture, abduction and other abuses by the Palestinian Protective Security Service, based in the self-rule enclave of Jericho. The head of the service, Jibril Rajoub, subsequently accused Mr. Eid of being a "cheap informer" for Israel, a charge Mr. Eid said endangered his life. **********Last week, Mr. Eid investigated and publicized the six-day detention of a Palestinian editor who failed to print a story flattering to Mr. Arafat on the front page of his newspaper. Speaking on Palestinian radio this week, Mr. Eid said broadcasts had failed to provide equal time to independent and opposition candidates in the Palestinian elections. **********Mr. Beer said the detention of Mr. Eid, who holds an Israeli identification card because he lives in Israeli-ruled East Jerusalem, violated the accord on Palestinian self-rule.
