https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/12/busin.main_headline: AT&T's Cards Caught in Shift To Deregulation
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/12/busin.print_headline: AT&T's Cards Caught in Shift To Deregulation
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/12/busin.body_text: **********Deregulating the telephone industry may usher in lower prices and a wealth of new services, as Government officials and telephone executives promise. But for people who own telephone calling cards from AT&T, this new era is starting not with a bang, but a busy signal. **********Over the last three months, thousands of cardholders from New York City to Oklahoma City have been unable to place local or toll calls using their AT&T calling cards. The reason: The AT&T Corporation has been dissolving agreements with the regional Bell operating companies and the GTE Corporation that provided for these companies to carry some of AT&T's calls over their local networks. **********Now, if you place a call from Manhattan to Westchester County using an AT&T card, you are referred to a Nynex operator who informs you that ''AT&T no longer allows its cardholders to use the Nynex network.'' To complete the call, you must dial an 11-digit prefix, 1-800-CALL-ATT, which transfers the call from the Nynex Corporation's wires to AT&T's wires. **********It is all part of the untrammeled competition introduced by the Telecommunications Act of 1996. Under the old rules, AT&T was not permitted to carry local or toll calls. So it agreed to transfer those calls to the Baby Bells and GTE. Now AT&T can compete for these calls -- if cardholders dial the magic 11-digit access code. **********Such fine distinctions may not matter to the harried businessman who suddenly finds he can no longer call home from a distant airport. Industry executives admit that the chaos over calling cards illustrates the dark side of what was supposed to be a consumer-friendly law. **********''This just makes life more confusing in a world that's confusing enough,'' Eric Rabe, a spokesman for the Bell Atlantic Corporation, said. **********Even officials at the Federal Communications Commission, which has championed telephone competition, acknowledged the problem. ''There's going to be a lot of confusion over things like this,'' Mary Beth Richards, the deputy chief of the F.C.C.'s Common Carrier Bureau, said. ''But the benefits of competition outweigh the confusion.'' **********As in most telephone skirmishes, this battle pits the seven Baby Bells and GTE against their familiar nemesis, AT&T. Mr. Rabe and executives at other Baby Bells said that AT&T asked them to block local calls and short-haul long-distance, or toll, calls made by AT&T cardholders. **********AT&T's rationale was logical: Why should it pay the Baby Bells for calls that it could legally carry itself? The trouble, according to the Bells, occurred when AT&T allowed its customers to believe that the Bells had blocked the calls. **********In the days after AT&T's ''mutual card-honoring'' agreement with Nynex expired in April, AT&T even ran commercials implying that Nynex was blocking the calls of AT&T cardholders, according to Gary Scarano, the product director of Nynex's calling-card division. **********That prompted Nynex to file a complaint with the F.C.C., in which it coined a new word to describe AT&T's action: jamming. Mr. Scarano said that ''jamming'' was a variation on ''slamming,'' the industry's slang for the illegal practice in which a long-distance carrier switches a customer's service without his knowledge or consent. **********''Jamming means they block the call, then blame us, and then blur the line about who was carrying the call,'' Mr. Scarano said. **********For its part, AT&T denied that it had misled customers. ''At no time were we trying to imply, or did we imply, that the Baby Bells made the decision,'' Kelly Statmore, a spokeswoman for AT&T, said. **********Ms. Statmore said AT&T's advertising merely educated customers about the benefits of the access code -- namely, that the cardholder's call would travel exclusively on AT&T's reliable network. This reduces the danger of a call being routed to another long-distance carrier -- which could charge higher rates -- without the caller's knowledge. **********Ms. Statmore said this situation often occurred when an AT&T cardholder made a call from a pay phone leased by another long-distance carrier. **********AT&T, which has issued about 80 million corporate and consumer cards, has been introducing its new card policy in a wave across the United States. Starting with Nynex in April, it has dissolved agreements with Bell Atlantic, GTE, the Ameritech Corporation, and last Friday, with SBC Communications Inc. In November, AT&T plans to cancel its agreement with the BellSouth Corporation. And it expects to complete the process with the Pacific Telesis Group early next year. **********Though AT&T's policy has provoked testy responses from the Baby Bells -- which are, after all, losing a stream of revenue -- the companies have responded with various marketing strategies. **********Ameritech, which serves five states in the Great Lakes region, has told its customers that its card was easier to use than AT&T's. To place a local, toll, or long-distance call with Ameritech's card, one has only to dial ''0'' plus the number. **********''It's not good customer service to make life harder for your customers,'' Thomas Hester, the general counsel of Ameritech, said. **********Ameritech is not simply being altruistic. Under the new telecommunications law, the Baby Bells cannot carry long-distance calls until the long-distance carriers begin competing in the local market. So Ameritech and most of the Bells still must use AT&T or another carrier for long-distance calls by their cardholders. **********But Nynex has added a twist. The company recently came up with its own 11-digit access code. Now, a Nynex cardholder can either dial ''0'' plus the number, or 1-800-54-NYNEX. Dialing the access code insures that a cardholder's long-distance call will be carried over the Sprint Corporation's network, rather than AT&T's. **********Nynex has been promoting the access code in radio ads with the tag line ''Card 54,'' a none-too-subtle play on the vintage television series, ''Car 54, Where Are You?'' Like AT&T, Nynex has been trying to reassure cardholders who feared that their long-distance calls might be routed to an unauthorized carrier. **********Calling-card fraud and 11-digit prefixes are not the only complications that flow from open competition. AT&T also recently stopped tucking its monthly service bills into the same envelopes that carry the local phone bills. AT&T promised its new bills will be more informative, but for customers, it just means more paper. **********Given all this, Ms. Richards of the F.C.C. conceded that some people may yearn for the days of regulation. But she contended that prices for calling-card services will drop as the competition escalates. **********Bradley Stillman, the director of telecommunications policy at the Consumer Federation of America, puts it another way: ''Choice is more difficult than monopoly, but the benefits are greater.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/22/busin.snippet: British Petroleum Co and Shanghai Petrochemical Co agree to form $2.5 billion joint venture to build ethylene plant in Shanghai (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/22/busin.body_text: **********The British Petroleum Company  and the Shanghai Petrochemical Company have agreed to form a $2.5 billion joint venture to build an ethylene plant in Shanghai, the companies said yesterday. Each partner will hold a 50 percent stake in the venture, with B.P. providing cash and technology and Shanghai Petrochemical contributing some existing plants. The project will have a capacity of 637,000 tons of ethylene annually, B.P. said. **********The two companies said the investment would be B.P.'s largest in China and also the largest joint venture undertaken by Shanghai Petrochemical.   (Dow Jones)

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/20/world.main_headline: Income Gap in Mexico Grows, and So Do Protests
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/20/world.print_headline: Income Gap in Mexico Grows, and So Do Protests
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/20/world.body_text: **********One simmering Sunday in May, a hundred peasant farmers stormed a luxurious hillside mansion here and, in a scene out of an old newsreel of the 1910 Revolution, pounded on the gates with machetes and their clenched fists until the wealthy owners abandoned their brunch and fled. **********Peasants now stand guard at the exclusive grounds about 35 miles south of Mexico City. They have painted "House of the People" on the imposing wooden doors, but they still find themselves ogling such luxuries as the artificial lake just inside the gates and the mounted bison head on the warehouse wall. **********The only thing that one can feel is embittered," said Guillermo Noriega Garcia, 56, a farmer who took part in the assault on the 20-acre estate that stands in the middle of parched subsistence farms. "How can it be that one man has everything and others don't even have water?" **********The episode is just one sign of how the current economic crisis has deepened  already serious divisions in Mexico. It has exaggerated the gap not only between rich and poor, but also between the industrialized north and the rural south, between Spanish-speaking Mexicans and the 10 million who are Indians and between those whose lives are increasingly tied to the United States economy and those who are entirely dependent on the fortunes of Mexico. **********The degree of income disparity in Mexico is among the worst in the world and  is steadily growing more extreme. Excluding African countries, Mexico has the largest gap between rich and poor of all but six nations in the world, United Nations and World Bank figures show. **********Today the richest 10 percent of Mexicans earn 41 percent of the country's income, while the bottom half of the population receives only 16 percent of all  national income. The Government admits that the number of Mexicans living in extreme poverty has grown to 22 million, an increase over the last 15 months of  5 million people. **********The growing gap has given rise to many clashes and to startling contrasts throughout Mexico. On the outskirts of the wealthy northern city of Monterrey, residents of a shantytown recently stopped a freight train in the dead of night. Officials say the train was disabled when it slowed down to go through the area. When word got out that the train carried tons of corn, whole families rushed out to fill pots and sacks full of grain. **********On the other hand, as the Mexican market for bargain-priced Volkswagen Beetles dried up in 1995, Mercedes-Benz sales actually rose. This year, as the worst economic crisis in 60 years continues, the car maker is on target to sell  50 percent more cars in Mexico than last year. **********A few large Mexican companies benefited handsomely when Mexico entered the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1994 and when the devaluation of the peso in December of that year made Mexican exports cheaper. But business leaders say 17,000 companies have folded since the crisis began. While a second Gucci boutique recently opened in the swank Polanco section of Mexico City, a United Nations report said the number of children who live and work on the streets of the capital has doubled in three years. **********The polarization between classes in Mexico is a "historic problem that is always present but never resolved," the historian Lorenzo Meyer wrote. Mexico now faces severe political and economic problems, but the most serious crisis, he wrote, "is the enormous distance and antagonism between the classes and groups that form the Mexican social fabric." **********One factor aggravating the tensions is the insistence by the Government of President Ernesto Zedillo, like the Governments of his two predecessors, on pursuing an economic policy of privatizations, free markets and integration into the global economy. Such a policy is endorsed by the United States and the International Monetary Fund, but it has failed to raise the standard of living for most Mexicans. **********Big gains in real wages and economic growth from 1963 to 1984 were wiped out  as the previous two presidents religiously followed their open-market policies.  Real wages today are below what they were in 1981. The debacle of Mr. Zedillo's first 18 months in office only worsens that record. **********Criticism of the economic model is widespread. "An absolute and total disaster," said Vicente Fox, an opposition-party Governor from the central state of Guanajuato. Even Mr. Zedillo has called for a public debate about Mexico's economic direction. **********But alternatives are scarce. Beyond some technical tinkering, the only consensus so far has been that the economic modernization of Mexico should be more humane -- which in most cases means more direct Government intervention to  help small- and medium-sized manufacturers stand up to the competition. **********Although the class gap in Mexico has deepened, the political scientist Jorge  G. Castaneda believes that there is little danger of social conflict. The reason is the substantial and growing number of Mexicans whose lives are tied to the United States economy. **********Those Mexicans, Mr. Castaneda says, include both rich exporters and the poor  farmhands who cross the border and send home their earnings. What they have in common is dependence on the American economy, which buffers the shocks of Mexico's economic problems. **********"A nationwide social explosion, such as the Revolution of 1910, is virtually  impossible while such a large, regionally well-distributed, broadly based segment of the population is thriving," Mr. Castaneda wrote recently in Foreign  Affairs magazine. **********Others believe that the danger of a spark to set off social revolt is actually much greater. Manuel Camacho Solis, the former Mayor of Mexico City who broke ranks with the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party and is now part of a developing alternative political force, said in an interview that recent polls showed 22 percent of the capital's residents believe that violence is justified to correct social imbalances -- a figure far higher than at any time in the last decade. Recently, public schoolteachers demanding a living wage paralyzed the city with demonstrations that at times turned violent. **********"It doesn't take 50 percent of the population to make the country ungovernable," Mr. Camacho said. "If just 5 percent take to the streets, that could be enough." **********It was a comparatively small band of guerrillas in Chiapas who in January 1994 shocked Mexico with an insurrection that is still not resolved. And in June, as few as 50 masked men, and perhaps a few women, declared themselves another revolutionary army. That was enough to send shivers down the spines of many Government officials. **********Recent incidents have worried many in Mexico because they seem to reflect a loss of respect for the rule of law and a frightening lack of Government control. The train robbery near Monterrey was reminiscent of the 1910 Revolution, when peasants routinely assaulted trains. **********But in the modern version, the attackers included children and housewives like Argelia Espinosa, who was almost arrested for trying to bring home a bushel of corn. "We would have milled the corn and used it to make tamales and tortillas," said the 37-year-old woman, whose husband, Alberto, was arrested with a sack full of corn on his shoulder. "It wouldn't have gone to waste." **********For the Rev. Rodolfo Reyes, a local priest, the assault was a manifestation of Mexico's smoldering economic and social crisis. "I see it as a sign that says 'Hey, be careful,' " he said. **********In June, in a similar episode, a train full of wheat was sacked in the state  of Durango. **********The assault on the Tepoztlan mansion roused fears that have haunted wealthy Mexicans since the Revolution, when peasants banged on the doors of big haciendas demanding the return of the land to the people. **********The mansion, called La Quinta Piedra, is owned by Guillermo de Jesus Occelli, the brother-in-law of former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari. Mr. Occelli says he bought the 20 acres legitimately. But for the last five years, local people have insisted that the transactions were fraudulent and that the land, like much of the land in Mexico since the Revolution, belongs to the community. **********This is an old battle here, where Emiliano Zapata began his struggle for liberty and land at the beginning of this century. **********The peasants here finally decided this year that they had had enough. After meeting in a general assembly on May 12, they made their way to the huge front gate of the Occelli estate, peasant leaders said. Inside, the family was enjoying a Sunday brunch. Some peasants banged on the door with machetes. One may even have tried to start a fire, a newspaper account said. **********The gates eventually lumbered open, and the family and guests rushed off, peasant leaders said. For the first time, local peasants passed through the great doors and gawked at the splendor they had until then only imagined. People who lived four or six to a room wandered wide-eyed through the house and past a  dining room table large enough to accommodate a dozen people. Peasants who rely  on water from a tanker truck during the dry season stared at the hotel-sized pool and the fountains that seemed capriciously to splash water everywhere. **********The peasants say they now have a list of other property holders in the area who, they contend, also bought land illegally. What happened at La Quinta Piedra ought to be taken as a warning, they say. What started as a land dispute has turned into an open struggle between rich and poor. **********"We tried to talk to the rich people, but they never paid attention to us," said Nicanor Demesa Ortiz, who took part in the takeover. "But what we did here  was to show that no one, no matter how powerful or influential, is immune to the power of the people or to what is right."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/21/world.main_headline: Russia Says 170 Chechens Died in Attack on Main Rebel Town
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/21/world.print_headline: Russia Says 170 Chechens Died in Attack on Main Rebel Town
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/21/world.body_text: **********In a move that raised new questions about President Boris N. Yeltsin's campaign promise to end the war in Chechnya, the Russian military has attacked the main rebel stronghold in the secessionist republic. **********Gen. Vyacheslav Tikhomirov, the Russian commander in Chechnya, asserted today that as many as 170 rebels had been killed in the attack on Novogroznensky. **********The Russians say that as many as 1,000 Chechen fighters had taken up defensive positions in the fortified town. Thirty Russian soldiers also died in  the fight, the general said. **********Late tonight Russian military officials said that the operation to seize the  town was virtually complete and that the rebels had fled. **********But the Russian Army has generally proved better at leveling buildings than breaking the will of the Chechen fighters. And according to initial Russian press reports, only a small number of rebel bodies have been found so far in the town. **********The stepped-up fighting comes less than a week after Mr. Yeltsin announced his intention to seek re-election and promised to arrive at an early solution to the widely unpopular war. **********With its grinding toll, the conflict in Chechnya has taken on all the features of a military quagmire. It has also become an increasing financial burden, spurring resentment from coal miners and other disgruntled workers, who  have seen their wages delayed for months. **********Just last month, for example, Mr. Yeltsin promised to spend $3.4 billion to rebuild the battle-damaged region. Along with other costly pre-election promises, that pledge has cast doubt on the Government's commitment to economic  discipline. **********Reflecting the budget squeeze, the financially pressed Government is now seeking a $12 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund, according to Sergei Dubinin, the head of the Central Bank. That is $3 billion more than the loan now under negotiation. The managing director of the fund, Michael Camdessus, is scheduled to begin a series of top-level meetings here on Wednesday. **********Acknowledging that a resolution of the conflict is vital to his chances for re-election in June, Mr. Yeltsin has assigned his loyal Prime Minister, Viktor Chernomyrdin, and an adviser, Emil Pain, to head separate commissions to produce a peace plan. But the President has ruled out the speedy and unconditional withdrawal of Russian troops. **********Mr. Yeltsin could announce the plan as early as Friday, when he delivers a "state of the nation" address. But it is not clear if Mr. Yeltsin has a combined military and political strategy to achieve peace. **********The attack on Novogroznensky could be part of an effort by Mr. Yeltsin to weaken the Chechens and strike a tough pose for nationalists at home before seeking new talks. Or it could simply be an effort to deliver a few blows before political campaign pressures prompt the Kremlin to tone down the fighting. It is also possible that the assault is just another brutal chapter in a tragic war. **********Novogroznensky, one of the best-known centers of resistance, has become a symbol of rebel determination and Russian impotence. **********Aslan Maskhadov, the Chechen military commander, and other rebel leaders have used the fortified town as a headquarters, directing operations on a mobile phone and giving interviews to journalists. Just two weeks ago Mr. Maskhadov boasted that the Russian forces knew where he was but lacked the will to go after him. **********The assault, which had been intensifying for several days, was carried out by the heavily equipped Russian Army, not Interior Ministry troops, Russian television reported.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/10/world.snippet: Clinton Administration's plans to evacuate second group of Iraqi relief workers from Kurdish region of northern Iraq is delayed amid concerns that some of workers may pose security risks to US (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/10/world.main_headline: U.S., Fearing Security Risks, Delays Evacuation of Kurds
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/10/world.print_headline: U.S., Fearing Security Risks, Delays Evacuation of Kurds
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/10/world.body_text: **********The Clinton Administration's plans to evacuate a second group of Iraqi relief workers from the Kurdish region of northern Iraq has been delayed amid concerns that some of the workers may pose security risks to the United States, officials said today. **********Two weeks after announcing its plans, the State Department has yet to identify the workers it hopes to help flee Iraq or to screen out those who may have connections to terrorist groups or Iraq's secret security forces, the officials said. **********The department's spokesman, Nicholas Burns, said today that while the Administration was still considering plans to evacuate the workers, no final decision had been made. **********The delay has prompted criticism from relief organizations and some members of Congress, who say the workers, most of them Kurds who worked with private relief organizations in northern Iraq, remain targets for retaliation by President Saddam Hussein's security forces. **********''These people are living in daily fear that they will be arrested,'' said Lionel A. Rosenblatt, the president of Refugees International, an advocacy organization based in Washington. **********In the weeks after Iraqi troops stormed into the Kurdish enclave on Aug. 30, helping to rout a Kurdish faction that controlled the city of Erbil, the Administration evacuated 2,100 people who had been employed by the United States as part of its military and relief efforts in Iraq  after the Persian Gulf war in 1991. **********The United States helped those refugees, most of them Kurds, cross into Turkey and flew them to an Air Force base on Guam. They are undergoing medical tests and screening by the Immigration and Naturalization Service for permission to resettle in the United States. **********A State Department official said the evacuation of the second group --  3,000 to 7,000 workers and their families -- has proved more complicated because the workers did not work directly for the United States Government, but rather for private relief groups that received American funds. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that while those in the first evacuation made ''a nice little package,'' the second group was less well known to the United States, raising numerous security concerns. **********The workers were employed by a variety of relief organizations, many of them based in the United States. They include groups like Kurdish Human Rights Watch. **********The Kurdistan Democratic Party, the faction that invited Iraq to intervene in its struggle with the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan, has pledged to protect relief workers. But Mr. Hussein greatly extended his influence over the enclave by leaving behind security forces after pulling out the bulk of Iraq's troops. **********Secretary of State Warren Christopher discussed a second evacuation with Turkey's Foreign Minister, Tansu Ciller, at the United Nations two weeks ago. But today Mr. Burns said basic details remained unclear.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/25/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Ciba-Geigy Says Sales Fell but Sees Profit
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/25/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Ciba-Geigy Says Sales Fell but Sees Profit
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/25/busin.body_text: **********Ciba-Geigy A.G. said yesterday that its sales declined 6 percent in 1995, damped by the strong Swiss franc. But it said nevertheless that it would report  earnings "considerably higher" than those of 1994. Profits are scheduled to be reported on March 26. The big chemical and pharmaceutical company had sales of 20.69 billion Swiss francs -- about $17.4 billion -- last year, down from 22.05  billion francs a year earlier. **********Ciba-Geigy said the effects of the strong Swiss franc, which make the company's products expensive to foreign buyers, were offset by sales progress and productivity improvements. Excluding the transfer of its diagnostics business to the Chiron Corporation, the company said its 1995 sales declined 3 percent, to 21.44 billion francs, but rose 6 percent in local currencies.   (Dow Jones)

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/25/world.main_headline: Hong Kong Journal;Remnants of Chiang's Army Are Routed Again
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/25/world.print_headline: Hong Kong Journal;Remnants of Chiang's Army Are Routed Again
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/25/world.body_text: **********Along the pathway that tumbles down the hill between banyan and red pine trees, metal door after wood plank door is pasted with white notices in a tidy bureaucratic prose that heralds the death of one of Hong Kong's oldest distinct  communities. **********"I hereby give you notice to quit and deliver up possession of the premises known as Cottage No. 23, Section 2, Tiu Keng Leng Cottage Area," a typewritten notice reads. **********In 1949 and 1950, soldiers of Chiang Kai-shek's shattered Kuomintang army and their families fled in panic from a China taken over by the Communist armies of Mao Zedong, a China in a caldron of poverty, repression and corruption. And while most of Chiang's troops descended on Taiwan, some 20,000 soldiers and refugees straggled across the frontier into Hong Kong. **********These Nationalists were an unwelcome presence here in those years, endangering the British colony's neutrality and stature. So, in crisp, colonial  fashion, the Nationalists, their few possessions and their red, blue and white flags were shipped off to a barren hillside overlooking Junk Bay, a glittering inlet where the failed flour magnate A. H. Rennie drowned himself in 1906. The place became known as Rennie's Mill. **********"There were never any people here," said Hsia Chiang-yun, a cramped twig of a man whose 79 years have gnarled his limbs but not his memory. "When we came here, we just had tents. Nobody gave us anything, not the Kuomintang, not the government." **********Slouched in a rickety lawn chair balanced on a narrow stoop outside the cement blockhouse of his home, Mr. Hsia is one of the dwindling population of Rennie's Mill, the once thriving Kuomintang village that was home to more than 30,000 Nationalist refugees, all of whom will be gone when Hong Kong comes under Chinese rule next year. **********From the hills here, the people of Rennie's Mill built a buoyant village, a community of schools, churches and shops, sprinkling the shoreline and slopes with clumps of houses woven together by cement pathways and flights of steps. **********In 1961, worried that they would someday be forced from their land, the people of Rennie's Mill wrested a promise from the government that they would be permitted to remain "indefinitely." **********But eight years ago the Hong Kong government scrapped its commitment and began an effort to empty Rennie's Mill, asserting that the village and its hillsides overlooking Junk Bay were needed for urban redevelopment. From carefully tended houses and little neighborhoods, the people of Rennie's Mill were being pushed into anonymous Lego-like apartment complexes. **********Mr. Hsia, and now just a handful of others, insist they will remain until the bitter end. He has never believed that destroying Rennie's Mill is simply one phase of a greater housing redevelopment program. **********"They want to clear out this anti-Communist encampment," he said. "When they  force me to move, they will put me in a little apartment. Now they've cut off my water and electricity." **********For Mr. Hsia, who was a communications officer in the Nationalist Army, worse than eviction from Rennie's Mill is the shift of Hong Kong's sovereignty to Beijing. **********"I've always opposed the Communists," he declared, his Chinese thickly spread with the accent of his native Hunan. "I'm going to fight them until I die. Do you know how many people died in China? They even take out the bones of the dead and insult them." **********Last month, in desperation, the remaining residents of Rennie's Mill, amounting to only several hundred, mostly aged people, petitioned Hong Kong's High Court for compensation, asserting that the government had acted illegally.  Raymond Sears, a British judge in the High Court, heard their case. After some lyrical recounting of history, he lashed out at the government. **********"They were loaded onto wooden boats and taken to a remote part of Hong Kong which was at that time a barren piece of land," the judge recounted. "It was a remote inhospitable part of Hong Kong with no electricity or water. Some 20,000  or more people were taken there. **********"What happened, however, was that these people turned this barren piece of wasteland into their own village. They built roads and schools and they dug wells. They governed themselves. There was no police there. The government appeared to have abandoned them." **********Abandoned, that is, until the government decided that the land was ripe for the picking. And this, Judge Sears determined, was intolerable. **********"In my judgment, the conduct of the Housing Authority by serving notices to quit, in breach of the clear promises of 1961, amounts to an abuse of power," he found. "The government have acted unfairly to the residents of this village and  this amounts in law to an abuse of power." **********But Hong Kong being Hong Kong, where development rages like a California brush fire, Judge Sears determined that the vast building projects already under way, the filling in of huge parts of Junk Bay and the gobbling up of Rennie's Mill could not be stopped; only the degree of compensation remained to be determined. **********Of course, the idea of preserving an area that was "like a part of Nationalist Taiwan in Hong Kong," he observed, "would be highly embarrassing for mainland China." **********Along the main path of Rennie's Mill, the doors of many houses are already welded shut. A striped barber pole stands frozen. But everywhere, both new and sunbleached flags of Taiwan, a 12-point white sun in a field of blue on a red banner, snap in the early winds of the typhoon season. **********An old man who would give his name only as Ch'en sat in the shell of what was once his small eatery, the Small Shanghai Restaurant. "We regular people don't know if the government is bad or good," he said quietly. "But it's done now. There aren't many people left. The problem is our new house will be so small, just two rooms." **********He showed a visitor around, pointing to a stack of bamboo dumpling steamers on a table. "I won't need these anymore," he said. "I really won't need anything here anymore."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/17/busin.snippet: Advertising column on growing efforts by some marketers to link themselves with celebrity endorsers who have rational, as well as emotional, connections with the products they peddle (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/17/busin.main_headline: A new campaign for Hanes hosiery features the singer Tina Turner and her famous legs.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/17/busin.print_headline: A new campaign for Hanes hosiery features the singer Tina Turner and her famous legs.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/17/busin.body_text: **********THE owner of what may well be the most glamorous gams since Betty Grable's is the star of an elaborate cross-marketing effort to promote Hanes hosiery. **********The campaign, with a budget estimated at $20 million, is centered on the singer Tina Turner, who has been signed to serve for at least two years as the spokeswoman for Hanes hosiery lines like Resilience, Smooth Illusions and Silk Reflections. In addition to conventional elements like television commercials and print advertisements, the campaign, created by the Arnell Group in New York, also features tie-ins between Hanes and the Virgin Records label of the EMI Group. **********Those tie-ins, timed to coincide with the release of Ms. Turner's album ''Wildest Dreams,'' include offering hosiery to buyers of the album and albums to buyers of the hosiery. **********Hanes will also sponsor the American leg (as it were) of Ms. Turner's concert tour in support of ''Wildest Dreams,'' which made its debut last week on the charts at No. 61. About the only step not being taken is asking Ms. Turner to re-record one of her biggest hits as ''What's Legs Got to Do With It.'' **********''It's synergies, synergies, synergies,'' said Peter Arnell, chairman at the Arnell Group, which was awarded the Hanes account in November, ''leveraging all toward one big strategic objective.'' **********''Advertising today has a role to be entertainment,'' he added. ''If we're selling hosiery, it should be fun. And music is a great way to express the beat, the mood, the tempo of what's going on.'' Indeed, the commercials, which begin running this week, take place as Ms. Turner shoots a music video clip for ''Missing You,'' the first single from ''Wildest Dreams.'' **********The Hanes hosiery campaign is indicative of efforts by some marketers to link themselves with celebrity endorsers who have rational, as well as emotional, connections with the products they peddle. Mr. Arnell, in fact, said the goal was a pitch ''not unlike Michael Jordan's for Nike.'' **********Another example is Sears, Roebuck & Company's hiring of Bob Vila, the home-repair specialist, to promote brands like Craftsman tools. And the M&M/Mars unit of Mars Inc. began a campaign for Snickers candy featuring Ken Caminiti, the popular third baseman for the San Diego Padres, only after he ate a Snickers bar before a game against the New York Mets last month -- and then hit two home runs. **********''It's not just going out to get a celebrity; this one makes sense,'' said Cathy Volker, president and chief executive at Sara Lee Hosiery in Winston-Salem, N.C., who was also recently named a vice president of the hosiery unit's parent, the Sara Lee Corporation. **********''We had done a survey asking women and men to tell us who they think of when they think of legs,'' she added, ''and the No. 1 response was Tina Turner. And when we spoke about getting Tina Turner as a spokeswoman, every single person said, 'Of course; why didn't anyone do this before?' It made us feel stupid for not doing it sooner.'' **********Ms. Volker called Ms. Turner ''a woman who epitomizes strength and beauty, and appeals to my 19-year-old niece as well as my 70-year-old mother. That's pretty cool.'' **********''We've been viewed possibly as a little stuffy,'' Ms. Volker said, referring to the Hanes brand image. ''It's fascinating we've been able to get a 56-year-old spokesperson who contemporizes us.'' **********Another task Ms. Turner is to tackle is to help ''bring together all the hosiery brands under the Hanes umbrella,'' Ms. Volker said, which are sold in department and specialty stores; their lower-priced siblings, bearing the L'Eggs name, are sold in discount stores and drugstores. **********''The Hanes brands had become somewhat fragmented into a group of subbrands,'' Ms. Volker said. ''Tina Turner is a superstar with the stature to handle the whole umbrella campaign.'' (Coincidentally, L'eggs has also introduced a spokeswoman, the actress Jamie Lee Curtis, in a broadcast and print campaign by the Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising unit of Cordiant P.L.C. in New York.) **********Ms. Turner's appeal has led to a decision to run the print part of the campaign in magazines that do not usually carry Hanes hosiery ads, Ms. Volker said, like Entertainment Weekly, Interview, Premiere and Rolling Stone, as well as in traditional titles like Elle, Harper's Bazaar and Vogue. The commercials will appear on broadcast, cable and syndicated series like ''Baywatch,'' ''Best of 'American Bandstand,' '' ''Inside Edition,'' ''Murphy Brown,'' ''Seinfeld'' and ''Silk Stalkings.'' **********Though Ms. Volker declined to discuss Ms. Turner's fee other than describing it as ''significant,'' she said there were ''options to extend the contract'' beyond its initial two-year term. **********Since signing Ms. Turner, she added, ''we've been getting calls from managers of other celebrities telling us they'd be interested in a similar campaign.'' Ms. Volker would identify the other celebrities only as ''big names.'' **********Actually, there may be only one star who stands as tall as Ms. Turner and on legs as stunningly shown off. But Dennis Rodman is busy promoting his new book.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/11/world.snippet: China announces ban on imports of selected goods from US, stepping up trade dispute with Clinton Administration and sending blunt signal that it will not easily succumb to pressure; says decision is in response to unilateral cut by US in import qu...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/11/world.main_headline: China Announces Trade Penalty as Reply to Similar U.S. Move
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/11/world.print_headline: China Announces Trade Penalty as Reply to Similar U.S. Move
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/11/world.body_text: **********China announced a ban on imports of selected goods from the United States today, stepping up a trade dispute with the Clinton Administration and sending a blunt signal that it will not easily succumb to pressure. **********With Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher to visit here in less than two weeks, the promise to further restrict China's market from American exporters seemed timed to draw maximum attention. Mr. Christopher plans to leave office soon, and his successor appears likely to face a growing number of trade disputes with China. **********American textiles, farm goods and alcoholic drinks will be affected by the ban, effective Dec. 10, according to an announcement by China's Foreign Trade Ministry and customs office. **********A specific list of the affected items will be drawn up by then, said the trade authorities, who did not estimate how much trade would be affected or say how long the ban would last. ''The decision was made in response to the U.S. unilateral cut of import quotas of Chinese textiles,'' said the announcement, carried by the New China News Agency, referring to a move by Washington in September. **********Washington and Beijing have battled for years over how to count Chinese textile exports to the United States, but the problem has grown stickier in recent months as China has emerged as the country with the biggest trading surplus in American markets, expected to exceed $30 billion by the end of the year. **********On Sept. 6, Washington levied a $19 million penalty on China, saying Beijing had tried to evade textile quotas by transshipping goods through third countries, where garments are sometimes labeled to disguise their origin. American officials said they had detected repeated violations of a 1994 United States-China trade accord. **********Today, Chinese trade officials accused Washington of acting before it had fully consulted them and of acting without clear evidence, itself a violation of the bilateral textile agreement. **********''We wish to urge the United States to handle trade disputes in the spirit of advancing bilateral trade and refrain from taking any actions harmful to bilateral trade in the future,'' the announcement said. It added that China ''opposes any practice intended to impose the will of one side on others in trade dealings.'' **********Beijing and Washington narrowly avoided a trade war in June, when a dispute over how to enforce copyright protection of American music, computer software and movies threatened to provoke sanctions in each direction that would have totaled $2 billion. **********The dispute over textiles looks minor and symbolic in comparison, with China expected to target American imports worth about the same as the $19 million worth of goods excluded by Washington. Yet an American official said there was a danger that China's reaction would provoke retaliation from Washington. **********''We're probably going to have to respond with something else,'' said the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. ''You're never sure where it will lead.'' **********The official said the trade dispute would certainly be on Mr. Christopher's agenda when he visited Beijing and Shanghai this month. **********China's exports are increasing sharply, as it produces toys and footwear and clothing that American consumers want, and are expected to push up China's trade surplus with the United States by more than 10 percent this year. **********On top of political differences over Taiwan and human rights, trade disputes make China a popular target in Congress.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/12/busin.snippet: Federal Reserve Board reports wages are rising as economy across most of nation continues to grow at moderate pace; sees little evidence yet of inflation taking root; report, based on survey of businesses by 12 regional Federal Reserve Banks, is l...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/12/busin.main_headline: Fed Report Finds Growth Still Modest
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/12/busin.print_headline: Fed Report Finds Growth Still Modest
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/12/busin.body_text: **********Wages are rising as the economy across most of the nation continues to grow at a moderate pace, but there is little evidence yet of inflation taking root, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. **********The report, based on a survey of businesses by the 12 regional Federal Reserve Banks, was the latest to suggest that the economy remained finely balanced between a sustainable expansion and the onset of inflation. **********Although many economists still believe the Federal Reserve will nudge up interest rates when its policy-making body meets on Sept. 24, they said today's report did not provide the Fed with the unambiguous case for tightening monetary policy that it would like to have before raising rates, especially in the midst of a Presidential campaign. **********Signs of inflation ''were varied and generally inconclusive, although there appears to be greater upward pressure on wages than on prices,'' the Fed report said. ''Business activity in most districts is reported to be good and expanding moderately.'' **********Fed officials have indicated over the last week that while they are on heightened inflation alert, they are still uncertain whether the economy is slowing fast enough from its torrid pace in the first half to avert a destabilizing wage-price spiral. **********Both inside and outside the Fed, those economists who think the economy will keep growing at a strong pace see a substantial risk of inflation. Those who see the economy slowing, view inflation as less of a threat despite the low 5.1 percent unemployment rate and upward pressure on wages. **********After falling early in the day on fears that the Fed report, known as the beige book, would show rising inflationary pressures, the bond market bounced back when the report was made public, with the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond ending the day about unchanged, at 7.11 percent. **********The Fed's stance since July has been to lean toward a tightening, and inflation hawks on the Fed's policy-making body have been agitating for a rate increase for several months, arguing that the time to move is before inflation infects the economy. Many economists think the Fed is likely to raise its Federal funds target rate by a quarter-point this month, to 5.5 percent. A rate increase would reverse a series of three cuts that began 14 months ago. The Fed's last move was to cut the Federal funds rate by a quarter-point on Jan. 31. **********''We continue to pick up early-warning signs on the inflation front coming through loud and clear in labor market conditions and rising wages,'' said Stephen S. Roach, the chief economist at Morgan Stanley, who forecasts a continued strong growth rate of 3 percent for the second half. ''A failure to move at this juncture, with the unemployment rate as low as it is, and with the economy growing well in excess of the inflation-stable growth rate, would really be irresponsible on the Fed's part.'' **********The beige book is based on anecdotal reports from businesses replying to inquiries from researchers at the Federal Reserve Banks. **********''Reports of substantial price increases were notably absent'' from many areas of the country, the Fed said. In the regions around New York, Boston, Cleveland and Kansas City, consumer prices were reported to be stable or increasing only slightly. There were some price increases in industrial commodities, but they tended to be restricted to a few markets, the report said. Lumber prices, for example, were higher in the regions around Boston, Richmond, Dallas and Chicago. **********''Wage gains have tended to outstrip price increases, however,'' the report said. In Boston, wage and salary increases were running at 2 to 4 percent, while in Cleveland the increase was 2 to 3 percent. **********Companies normally try to pass on the cost of wage increases to consumers of their products through price increases. But intense competition has made it hard for companies to raise prices, forcing them to absorb higher wage rates by improving productivity or biting into their profits. The Clinton Administration's economists have been arguing that since corporate profits are robust, companies have plenty of leeway to absorb rising wages without spurring inflation. A number of outside economists dispute that contention. **********The report showed few signs that the economy was cooling off as rapidly as the Fed had expected in July when it forecast a growth rate for the full year of 2.6 percent. The economy grew at a 3.4 percent rate in the first half, and would have to slow to a rate of 1.8 percent in the second half to match the Fed's forecast. **********Today's report said the economy was expanding ''moderately'' in most places, with two exceptions being California and the Far West, where growth was characterized as strong, and in the St. Louis region, where it ''continued to moderate slightly.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/05/busin.body_text: **********They were like father and son. **********For the past 11 years, Carlo De Benedetti, the chairman and co-chief executive of Olivetti SpA, was inseparable from his top aide and alter ego, Corrado Passera, the company's other co-chief executive. **********In the glitzy world of Italian capitalism, Mr. De Benedetti, 61, and his youthful, American-trained deputy, were always side-by-side, whatever the corporate adventure. **********While Mr. De Benedetti, one of Europe's most renowned business tycoons, plotted strategy, Mr. Passera carried it out. **********In the 1980s, they fought and beat Fiat SpA in a hotly contested bank takeover. Later, they gained control of the Mondadori publishing empire, then lost it to Silvio Berlusconi in a corporate and court battle. Since 1992, the pair have been entrenched in the painful process of trying to transform Olivetti from a loss-making personal computer company into a telecommunications business. **********But the two men officially parted company Thursday when the board of Olivetti accepted the resignation of Mr. Passera, 41, as co-chief executive and head of the personal computer division. **********Mr. Passera, a former McKinsey & Co. management consultant and banking expert with a master's degree from the Wharton School of Finance in Pennsylvania, apparently had a better offer. He will soon become chief executive of Banco Ambrosiano Veneto SpA, the largest private-sector bank in Italy. **********At the same time, Mr. De Benedetti fed speculation that he was quietly disengaging from Olivetti, which he controls with a 15 percent equity stake. He gave up his own title as co-chief executive, surrendering day-to-day involvement with the company, while retaining his role as chairman. He also made a point in an interview of denying rumors of a clash with Mr. Passera. **********Although some friends have said that Mr. De Benedetti is gradually retreating from the business world to enjoy his personal life more, he vigorously rejected the idea that he was really stepping back from Olivetti. **********"After nearly 20 years of work here, I have the right to be just chairman and to let a 38-year-old run the company," Mr. De Benedetti said. "I want to have more time to dedicate myself to forming alliances and to keeping in touch with the political authorities in Rome and in Brussels, because the next two years will be crucial as we move toward the liberalization of telecoms in Europe." **********Then, displaying resentment at reports that have suggested he is withdrawing from the business world, Mr. De Benedetti said: "If I become the chairman only, they say I am stepping back. Well, Gianni Agnelli was only the Fiat chairman for 30 years, and nobody said he had stepped back." **********The parting of Mr. De Benedetti and Mr. Passera comes just as Olivetti claims it is poised to emerge this year from losses that have cost more than $2 billion over the past five years. Mr. De Benedetti bought into Olivetti in 1978 and rapidly transformed it from a loss-making typewriter company into a successful European computer business. But the sharp drop in personal computer prices in the early 1990s started the losses that resulted in a massive restructuring of the whole company. Olivetti has slashed its work force to 28,000 from nearly 60,000 in the late 1980s. **********Mr. De Benedetti said his top priority was "to accelerate the transformation of Olivetti into a telecommunications company." **********He stressed that this aim was also implicit in the choice of Francesco Caio, another former McKinsey consultant, as the new chief executive. Mr. Caio has run Olivetti's new cellular phone unit, Omnitel. **********The PC division will be taken over by Bernhard Auer, a German-born veteran of Compaq Computer Corp. and Digital Equipment Corp. **********Mr. Passera's reasons for leaving, although not announced, appear to be a mixture of professional and personal factors. In taking over Banco Ambrosiano Veneto, he will return to his first love — banking — with prospects of playing a part in reshaping the Italian financial system. He will also be closer to his family in Milan, rather than having to live in the remote Piedmont town of Ivrea, where Olivetti has its headquarters. **********The move to Ambrosiano is not without irony. An Italian appeals court in June upheld Mr. De Benedetti's conviction in connection with the fraudulent bankruptcy of Banco Ambrosiano, where he was briefly vice chairman in 1982. Mr. Passera will be running an institution built upon the ashes of that bank. **********The soft-spoken Mr. Passera had promised Mr. De Benedetti that he would remain at Olivetti until its personal computer unit returned to profit, which company sources say it did in the quarter ended June. **********Analysts remain unsure whether Olivetti will sell or merge the PC units, its office equipment division or its systems and services operations. Some are not sure Olivetti will break even this year. **********The only thing certain is that Mr. De Benedetti wants to change the company's identity one last time. **********He predicted Thursday that the Omnitel unit — which is 41.5 percent owned by Olivetti, with the rest held by partners Bell Atlantic Corp. and Airtouch Communications of the United States, Mannesmann AG of Germany and Telia AB of Sweden — would be profitable by 1997, one year ahead of schedule. **********The company signed up more than 300,000 subscribers in its first six months of operations, against a full-year target of 360,000. **********Mr. De Benedetti said Olivetti's future also lay in fixed-line telephone services.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/29/world.main_headline: India Separatists Say They Killed 15 on Bus
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/29/world.print_headline: India Separatists Say They Killed 15 on Bus
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/29/world.body_text: **********Two separatist groups from the violence-torn areas of Kashmir and Punjab took responsibility today for an election-day bus bombing that killed 15 people. **********Throughout the country, at least 20 people died in violence related to monthlong national elections that began on Saturday, but officials said the disturbances were less widespread than in previous elections. **********The bombing tore the roof off the bus in the town of Modinagar, in Uttar Pradesh, about 30 miles north of New Delhi, the police said. The two separatist  groups issued a statement saying they targeted the bus because the passengers included politicians. Voting in Uttar Pradesh will be held next week. **********Voting took place on Saturday in nine states, two territories and two island  chains -- about a third of the country. Officials said new elections will have to be held at 45 polling places in three states. **********Armed guards stood watch today over tens of thousands of sealed ballot boxes. They will be guarded in government-run schools and offices until counting begins in May. **********Preliminary results are not expected until May 8. Voting is being staggered over several weeks to give police and paramilitary troops adequate time to prevent election violence. The election ends on May 30.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/28/busin.snippet: Dow Jones industrial average rises 17.38 points, to 5,711.27, on New York Stock Exchange trading volume of 310.5 million shares; table (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/28/busin.body_text: **********Stocks rose yesterday as prospects for higher dividends and stronger-than-expected corporate earnings outweighed concerns that interest rates would rise. **********Philip Morris rose 1 1/2, to 91 7/8, to lead the Dow Jones industrial average up 17.38 points, to 5,711.27, its first gain in three days. The company rose a second consecutive day after an Indiana jury sided with the tobacco industry and against a former smoker late Friday in a liability lawsuit. **********The stock was also bolstered by speculation that its board would raise its dividend by as much as 20 percent and split its shares today. **********Dividend speculation overshadowed a Conference Board survey that found that consumer confidence was higher than it had been for more than six years. **********Bond prices initially fell after the report on concern that the Federal Reserve would need to push interest rates higher, but they recovered to end slightly higher. **********''If you get the stronger growth, and it's coupled with higher inflation and a Fed tightening, earnings will likely be better,'' said John Trammell, portfolio manager at A. Gary Shilling & Company in Springfield, N.J. **********Broader market indexes were also higher yesterday. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.52 points, to 666.40. The Nasdaq composite index jumped 9.80 points, to 1,149.02. **********Trading of 310.5 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange was up from Monday's session. **********The hint of economic strength seen in some recent economic reports has been good for manufacturing stocks. The Morgan Stanley cyclical index, which includes stocks like Caterpillar Inc. and International Paper, is up 5.09 percent this month, compared with a 4.11 percent rise in the recession-resistant Morgan Stanley consumer goods index. **********Among the gainers yesterday, shares of Boeing rose  7/8, to 91 1/8. The aircraft maker said it would start building seven of its 777 twin-engine jets a month in July 1997, up from five now, and increase its hiring plan by 5,000 workers. **********ADC Telecommunications Inc. added 5, to 53 1/4, after the company's 36 cents in profit for the fiscal third quarter beat the average estimate of analysts by 2 cents a share, according to Zacks Investment Research. **********HBO & Company rose as much as 2 3/4, to 57 1/2, after Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette raised its rating on the health care information manager to ''outperform'' from ''market perform.'' **********Worldcom Inc. continued to suffer after its announcement it would buy MFS Communications for about $12 billion in stock. Shares in the long-distance telephone company dropped 1 3/4, to 21, after falling 3 5/8 on Monday. MFS fell 3 1/2, to 41 5/16. **********Consolidated Freightways Inc. rose 1 3/4, after the trucker said it would spin off its largest subsidiary, CF Motorfreight, to avoid competition between its regional and long-haul units. **********Pepsico Inc. slid  5/8, to 31, after Merrill Lynch & Company cut its estimate of the company's earnings for 1996 by 5 cents, to $1.40 a share, and its long-term growth outlook by 1 percent, to 14 percent annually. **********3Com . rose 2 1/4, to 46, after the company said that it had consolidated its sales and marketing of certain products into two divisions, one aimed at small networks and others at large far-flung corporations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/22/world.main_headline: Populist's Victory in Ecuador Worries the Elite
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/22/world.print_headline: Populist's Victory in Ecuador Worries the Elite
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/22/world.body_text: **********Six years ago, as Abdala Bucaram waited out charges of corruption by fleeing  to Panama, it was Jaime Nebot, a political rival and leader of the Social Christians, who pushed for Mr. Bucaram's pardon, confident that the one-time Mayor of this city would wither at the polls. **********A court pardoned Mr. Bucaram in 1990, and two weeks ago, he became Ecuador's  new President. The loser in the election? Jaime Nebot. **********Mr. Bucaram, a flamboyant populist known as El Loco, the Crazy One, has made a career of being underestimated. His election surprised pollsters and voters and galvanized the poor, who make up 70 percent of this small Andean nation of 12 million people. **********Mr. Bucaram's victory exploded conventional political wisdom. His triumph, some here say, represents an unexpected backlash by the poor against the strict  monetary policies and fiscal restraint that are being embraced across South America, and that in many countries have done little to improve the lives of the masses. **********"The people believed in the ability and in the work of Bucaram," the President-elect said in an interview at his mansion here. "It was also a condemnation of the system, which was corrupt, racist and repressive, which strengthened monopolies and excluded large sectors of society from managing the  country." **********The new President, a charismatic communicator of Lebanese Christian descent,  built his campaign on ferocious attacks against the "oligarchy," with backup music by an Uruguayan rock band that traveled with him to campaign stops. **********Rejecting foreign advisers, Mr. Bucaram directed, wrote and even sang in his  long commercials. At rallies, he would ask supporters, "Do you want me to sing or talk?" He carried 20 of 21 provinces, a record in Ecuador, where unemployment is running at 14 percent. **********And his victory came despite the fact that Mr. Nebot carried Quito and Guayaquil, the traditional centers of power here. **********"It's a vote against the people of good families and against the political parties," said Jaime Duran, a poll taker based in Quito. **********Mr. Bucaram, who was once quoted as saying "Mein Kampf" was one of his favorite books and who has a tight little mustache reminiscent of Hitler's, has  people fretting over just how crazy he might be. **********When he was police commissioner here in the early 1980's, crime was less of a problem than it is now, and many supported his morality crusade that banned liquor sales on Sunday. **********But he also chased down women wearing miniskirts, jumping off his motor scooter and ripping out hems to make their skirts longer. **********As Mayor of Guayaquil in 1984 and 1985, he was known for demanding payments from businesses and for harassing the owners when they refused. Mr. Bucaram called the payments donations; the business people and the municipal council called them extortion. **********"If his intelligence prevails over his temperament, we can have a great President," Mr. Duran said. "If his temperament overtakes his intelligence, we can have a disaster." **********Mr. Bucaram, 44, says he has matured, and upon his election, he seemed intent on becoming a statesman. **********He says his mustache does not reflect an admiration of Hitler, but rather his ineptitude at shaving. He says now that his heroes are Christ, Gandhi, John F. Kennedy and Martin Luther King. **********"I don't like Hitler," he said. "Hitler was a fascist with deep complexes. He killed five million Jews and started a world war." **********His post-victory speech was conciliatory, and for all his railing against politics as usual, he reappointed the Foreign Minister and the head of Ecuador's Central Bank in a bid for continuity. He proposed the outgoing President, Sixto  Duran-Ballen, to become Ecuador's next Ambassador to Washington. **********"The previous Government has done some good things, and we have to move forward in these areas," he said. **********He also appointed three bankers who had supported his campaign to form an advisory economic council. Last week he announced plans to visit New York a week before his Aug. 10 inauguration to court foreign investors, whose cash he will need if he is to deliver on campaign promises to build 200,000 homes for the poor. Ecuador now faces a shortage of 1.2 million houses, Mr. Bucaram said. **********"When the poor of a country have never been listened to, sometimes all they expect is a little love and nothing else," he said. "Nevertheless, they need more: a basic breakfast, security, education, preventive medical care. It cannot be logical that in the 20th century people should be dying of diarrhea, parasites, cholera." **********He said there was no excuse for the thousands of street children when building shelters was so simple. "These are the moral obligations of a society," he said. **********For the moment, Mr. Bucaram's moderation has somewhat relieved the jittery middle and upper classes, while the poor are accepting his emphasis on continuity. But he has worried business leaders and others with some of his appointments and recent actions. **********The weekend after his election, Mr. Bucaram was photographed in Panama hugging his sister Elsa, another former Mayor of Guayaquil who fled under charges that she stole millions before resigning in 1991. **********And on Wednesday, Mr. Bucaram's closest aide, Alfredo Adum, intervened forcibly to pry the President-elect's brother, Gustavo, free from a police station here, where he had been detained after being found in a stolen jeep outside the United States Consulate. The jeep had been used in the presidential  campaign. **********The President-elect said his brother did not know it had been stolen because  a friend had lent it to him. He said Mr. Adum's intervention did not signal that the law would not apply to the President and his entourage, because there had been no formal order for his brother's arrest. **********But in these days of intense scrutiny, business leaders are worried. Because  Ecuador lacks a strong, independent judiciary, Mr. Adum's move suggested that contacts could count for more than law over the next four years. That, they added, would scare away investors, particularly foreigners. **********Lacking political experience outside Guayaquil, the President-elect has filled his Cabinet with supporters, family and friends from this Pacific coast city. He appointed another brother, Adolfo, as Minister of Social Welfare. **********Some of his closest associates, like Mr. Adum, made their fortunes in La Bahia, a marketplace that avoids taxes by importing goods from Panama's Free Trade Zone. Other businesses complain that because of the tax break, sellers at  La Bahia can undercut them with low prices. **********Mr. Bucaram named Mr. Adum to the crucial post of Minister of Energy and Mining, responsible for privatizing Ecuador's petroleum industry.  The appointment was not taken well in business circles. **********For Ricardo Noboa, who ran against Mr. Bucaram, the candidate's triumph on his third run for the presidency reflected the desperation of a neglected populace rather than hope. **********Mr. Noboa, who had investigated Mr. Bucaram for the Congress, concluded that  he was the power behind his sister's notoriously corrupt administration. He quit the Social Christian Party in disgust when it ignored the evidence he uncovered  and made the latest of several political deals with Mr. Bucaram in 1994. **********"Bucaram has surprised the entire country," he said. "He's given us a real jab."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/19/world.main_headline: Gerry Adams Says He Asks For a Truce From I.R.A.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/19/world.print_headline: Gerry Adams Says He Asks For a Truce From I.R.A.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/19/world.body_text: **********Gerry Adams, the head of the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, indicated today that he was trying to persuade the I.R.A. to restore its cease-fire after the bomb blast that wounded more than 200 people in Manchester, England, on Saturday. **********"The question of what the I.R.A. can do or should do is one which obviously I'm working on," Mr. Adams said on the Irish radio. Mr. Adams's influence and prestige were severely shaken by the I.R.A.'s admitted killing of a policeman in the Irish Republic 12 days ago and by the bombing in Manchester, which the British police say was the work of the I.R.A., but which the I.R.A. has not acknowledged. **********Speaking in their separate Parliaments today, Prime Ministers John Bruton of Ireland and John Major of Britain continued to castigate the I.R.A. But they did not rule out the inclusion of Sinn Fein, the I.R.A.'s political wing, in the new broad-based peace talks that began in Belfast last week. Both Governments, however, insist that there must first be a new cease-fire. **********Both Prime Ministers have said the talks will go ahead with or without Sinn Fein, but few officials seem to believe that a permanent peace agreement can be  achieved without the I.R.A.'s representatives at the negotiating table. Mr. Major said that "an unequivocal cease-fire" was still necessary for Sinn Fein to be admitted to the talks. **********Mr. Bruton called the bombing in Manchester and the killing of the Irish policeman "unpatriotic, contrary to a true sense of Irishness, anti-Irish." But the Irish Cabinet decided today not to cut off all contacts with Sinn Fein,  but to remain open to discuss "matters of substance," which officials said means a new cease-fire. **********Despite the Manchester attack, officials and political experts said, a new cease-fire was still possible. The widespread speculatlion that the I.R.A. was severely split between hawks and doves, they said, was interesting but unconfirmed. Some experts suggested that the latest attack might have been a face-saving show of strength, which the I.R.A. has made in the past before making concessions. **********Others disagreed, saying that trying to anticipate the I.R.A. is futile. Mr.  Adams clearly sought to give the impression that a new cease-fire was still possible, paving the way for Sinn Fein to enter the broad-based peace talks in Belfast. **********"Despite the setbacks, despite the difficulties, it is still my conviction that we will have a peace settlement," he said. "It is my conviction that it will grow from inclusive dialogue and that Sinn Fein will be part of that inclusive dialogue. I may fail. All politics, I'm told, ends in tragedy. But it  won't be through any lack of trying." **********He suggested that Mr. Bruton's aides were disingenuous for publicly demanding to know whether he had asked the I.R.A. to restore a cease-fire. Irish officials are "fully aware," Mr. Adams said, of his efforts to persuade the I.R.A. to resume the 17-month cease-fire they broke in February. The extent of Mr. Adams's influence on the I.R.A.'s military command, however, is questionable. **********Mr. Adams declined to answer for reporters the Irish Government's question as to whether he now condemned the I.R.A. for the violence it calls "the armed struggle." **********"Sinn Fein wants to see an end to the armed struggle," he said. "We're not involved in it. We do not advocate it. We are a party which has suffered as a result of the armed action of others." He added, however, "We understand how in  certain conditions armed actions are seen as legitimate."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/16/busin.main_headline: Computer Security Concern Agrees to Be Sold for Stock
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/16/busin.print_headline: Computer Security Concern Agrees to Be Sold for Stock
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/16/busin.body_text: **********RSA Data Security Inc., which makes cryptography software that is a key component of secure transactions on the Internet and corporate computer networks, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Security Dynamics  Technologies Inc. for four million shares of stock. **********Investors, sensing that Security Dynamics got a bargain in the midst of Wall  Street's feeding frenzy for Internet stocks, sent the company's shares up sharply yesterday and, as a result, increased the potential value of the deal. Shares of Security Dynamics, which closed last week at $49.625, rose $13.125 yesterday to close at $62.75, making the deal worth $251 million. **********If approved by Security Dynamics shareholders, the acquisition would give the company control of RSA's portfolio of data encryption and authentication technologies, which are licensed to virtually all of the major companies involved in electronic commerce, including the Netscape Communications Corporation, the Microsoft Corporation, I.B.M., Sun Microsystems Inc., Motorola  Inc., Mastercard International and Visa International. **********RSA's three largest shareholders: Addison Fischer, a Florida investor; D. James Bidzos, the president and chief executive; and Leonard M. Adleman, one of  the inventor's of RSA's technology, who together own 70 percent of the company,  have agreed to the deal. **********Security Dynamics, of Cambridge, Mass., makes a variety of products used by corporations to verify the identity of computer network users. The company specializes in so-called smart tokens, electronic packets that verify a network  user's identity and grant access to specific network computers and services. **********The tentative $251 million purchase price appears to be a windfall for investors and employees of RSA, of Redwood City, Calif., which reported profits  of less than $1 million last year on revenue of $11.6 million. However, the company also owns interests in other Internet companies, including Netscape, Cybercash Inc. and Verifone Inc. **********RSA's decision to sell out to Security Dynamics, rather than test its luck in the hot market for Internet public offerings, raised some eyebrows among analysts. Internet companies with even smaller revenues have garnered hundreds of millions of dollars from investors. **********"If we go public, we get a lot of money," said Mr. Bidzos. "But if we do it this way, we get a lot of synergy. We think there is a real market opportunity for enterprise security solutions." **********"The union of RSA and Security Dynamics is a very positive one," agreed Paul  L. Merenbloom, vice president for technology research at Piper Jaffray Inc. in Minneapolis. "It would be a very logical move for the folks at Security Dynamics to extend their installed base into other cryptographic products." **********In addition, Mr. Merenbloom and others suggested that the appeal of RSA on Wall Street might be tempered by its potential liability in several legal disputes with a rival company, the Cylink Corporation, arising from a failed joint venture called Public Key Partners. The lawsuits, which challenge the validity of the patents on which RSA's technology is based, are expected to go to trial this summer.
