https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/18/busin.main_headline: From Russia, New Level of Risk
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/18/busin.print_headline: From Russia, New Level of Risk
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/18/busin.body_text: **********At what point does an appetite for risk turn to folly? **********It's a question worth pondering as Russia enters the international bond market. The issue, expected to be officially launched this week, will be for as much as $500 million with a likely maturity of five years, offering investors a return of about 300 basis points, or three percentage points, more than comparably dated U.S. government paper. That suggests a coupon of around 9.5 percent. **********At this point, the lead managers, J.P. Morgan & Co. and SBC Warburg, refuse to be more specific, insisting that the details will be made public after a series of "road shows" in major financial centers ends at midweek in New York. These presentations to prospective investors have been closed to reporters at the insistence of the Russians. But participants have said the deal that is already substantially oversubscribed and that the maturity might be longer than the three to five years initially suggested. **********All this comes as the International Monetary Fund is withholding additional lending to Moscow because of its inability to meet its budget-deficit target. Russia also has yet to reschedule with international banks $25.5 billion of debts inherited from the Soviet Union or to settle with French holders of Russian imperial debt that was repudiated after the 1917 revolution, even though a settlement has been promised. **********Nonetheless, investor response to the proposed sale is enthusiastic, and the terms at which the paper will be sold are likely to widely exceed the expectations of even the Russians, who have been quoted as anticipating a coupon of between 10 percent and 11 percent. **********Most important, the deal serves as a metaphor for the bubble engulfing the bond market. **********The true nature of the excesses in asset markets — stocks as well as bonds — has been easy to overlook because the cover story has been so convincing: inflation tamed, corporate earnings on the rise — not least due to downsizing — and moderate growth. **********But there is no escaping the fact that the massive easing of monetary policy — starting in 1991 in the United States to recapitalize the injured banking system and fueled by the decade's unprecedented 88 percent growth in (mostly Asian) central bank foreign-exchange reserves and the subsequent injections of liquidity by Japan, Germany and Switzerland to stave off currency appreciation and spur domestic growth — has unleashed an inflation in asset prices that has yet to show up in wholesale or consumer price indexes. **********The fact that price indexes are well behaved — just as they were while the damaging bubble was building in Japan at the end of the 1980s — does not alter the fact that inflation is infecting financial asset markets. Too much money there chasing too few assets is driving prices to levels that appear unsustainable. **********For bond markets, there has been a double whammy: High-quality supply is declining. The major industrialized countries (excluding Japan) have been cutting budget deficits, and therefore borrowing less, while companies have been selling equity, using retained earnings or investing less as they too have cut borrowing. **********For example, net issuance in the international bond market in the first half of 1996 was up 53 percent from a year earlier. But net issuance by governments of developed countries was unchanged, while net corporate issuance was down 30 percent. In the major domestic markets, net bond sales this year are running 12 percent behind the year-ago pace. **********Faced with nearly record low yields on 10-year bonds of 2.7 percent in Japan, 5.8 percent in Germany and 6.18 percent in the United States, it is no wonder that investors seeking quality as well as income have stormed into what were once high-yielding peripheral markets in Europe, driving prices up and yields down. **********Those gains, in turn, are dwarfed by the performance of Brady bonds — restructured paper that enabled what were then called developing countries to walk away from the debt crisis of the 1980s. **********Although partly collateralized, these are high-risk, high-yielding instruments. Morgan's Brady bond index is up 3.5 percent this month and has gained almost 36 percent since January. **********Such massive growth has compressed the risk premium on these countries' noncollateralized debt, which has become the favored vehicle for those interested only in maximizing potential income. **********Which brings us back to Russia, whose credit rating places it between Mexico and Argentina. **********The yield on five-year Mexican paper ended the week at 287 basis points over U.S. government paper, down from a spread of 315 basis points at the start of the month. The spread on Argentine debt, 389 basis points at the end of last month, is 333 basis points. **********With five-year U.S. paper yielding 5.95 percent, Russia can expect to sell five-year notes with a coupon easily below 10 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/17/busin.body_text: **********The Best Products Company said yesterday that Ocean Reef Management had withdrawn its unsolicited offer to buy the company for $2 a share, or a total of $63.2 million. Best Products said that Ocean Reef had concluded the takeover would require greater resources than originally thought. But it said that Ocean Reef wanted to continue talks in the hopes of reaching an alternative proposal. Best Products' stock plummeted more than 58 percent on the news, falling 62.5 cents a share to close at 43.75 cents in Nasdaq trading. Best Products, a catalogue retailer based in Richmond, emerged from bankruptcy-court protection in 1994. Ocean Reef is a closely held investment concern based in Miami.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/23/busin.main_headline: Oil Firms Get Blamed for High Prices
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/23/busin.print_headline: Oil Firms Get Blamed for High Prices
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/23/busin.body_text: **********The ministers who will gather at the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' annual meeting on Monday in Vienna have much to be thankful for. **********The average price of crude oil has soared by more than 25 percent in the last year, and better yet, nobody is blaming OPEC. Instead, as the airlines push for fare increases because of the soaring price of jet fuel, and as economists ponder the impact that high oil prices could have on global inflation, the blame for the explosion in oil prices has shifted increasingly to the major oil companies. **********Faced with the paradox of plentiful oil supplies and the absence of war in the Middle East on one hand, and the steepest oil price increase in years on the other, many industry analysts have begun to look at the behavior of the oil companies for answers. Specifically, their attention has been focused on a little-noticed decision taken last year by several oil companies to cut their stockpiles of refined petroleum products, such as heating oil. **********To many observers, that move set the stage for the subsequent explosion in oil prices that began late last winter. Leo Drollas, deputy director of the Center for Global Energy Studies in London, calls the decision to move to lower stocks "crucial" in explaining this year's increase in prices — a rise that for some grades of crude has reached nearly 50 percent over the past 12 months. By the beginning of this year, oil stocks, which are the cushion between the oil companies' ability to serve their customers and the vicissitudes of demand, stood at their lowest levels in 20 years. In the industrialized countries in January 1995 the oil companies had a 62-day supply of petroleum. One year later, those stocks had fallen to an average of 57 days, with stocks in the United States falling to slightly more than 50 days. **********Analysts say that an oil market already precariously off balance was then tipped into a panic by an unexpectedly cold winter in Europe and the United States. As demand for heating oil shot up, prices for the relatively thin supplies of refined products available soared. Then, as refiners scrambled to buy more crude oil to increase production in their refineries, pressure suddenly shifted to the crude market, driving up prices there. **********The oil companies themselves are reluctant to talk about the charges. Ian Stewart, a spokesman for British Petroleum Co. said that information about his company's oil inventories was "commercially sensitive." **********In Washington, meanwhile, a spokesman for the American Petroleum Institute, an industry trade group, conceded that the industry had cut its inventories, but denied the move had increased prices. **********"The cushion is not as large as it was historically, but experience has shown that we can get by with less," said Joseph Lastelic, the institute's spokesman. Instead, he attributed the higher petroleum prices to global "prosperity," which, in turn, lifted oil demand. **********For the oil companies, particularly those involved in exploration and production — the so-called upstream end of the business — this year has shown that not only can they get by with less, but that less is more. "It has been a great year for oil companies and particularly for the upstream operators," an analyst said. "They have got their costs down to where they can live comfortably" with oil at $18 a barrel, "and now they are getting $24 for it.' **********Most observers agree that the oil companies themselves were surprised by the volatility of petroleum prices this year. Low inventories may have laid the groundwork for those market conditions, but the companies' aim was not to squeeze more cash out of their customers but simply to attack their own costs. **********Faced with intense pressure on the profit margins of their downstream operations — refining and marketing — they decided to do what many other industries have done — cut costs, including their huge bills for holding unsold inventory. **********Even now oil companies in the United States still have 118 million barrels of petroleum distillate — heating oil and diesel fuel — on hand, down 15 million barrels from a year ago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/04/world.main_headline: Rebels' New Cause: A Book for Yankee Bashing
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/04/world.print_headline: Rebels' New Cause: A Book for Yankee Bashing
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/04/world.body_text: **********To describe his feelings toward America, Zhang Xiaobo, 32, a poet, author and onetime pro-democracy rebel, told a reporter from a state-run press agency recently: ''I admire some things American. When we were students, we yearned for American novels and movies.'' **********He was explaining why he and four of his comrades have written a book called ''The China That Can Say No,'' an almost instant best seller this summer that sailed through Chinese censors and has won expressions of admiration from Communist Party officials all the way up to President Jiang Zemin. **********''But today,'' Mr. Zhang was saying, winding up for one of the uppercuts he delivered through this friendly interview, ''we find that country rather disgusting. The Chinese people should have a sense of their own identity.'' **********This is the season in which China is saying no to the United States -- over improving China's human rights record, trade issues and global agreements to stanch the flow of high technology and sophisticated weapons to rogue states. **********So Communist Party leaders seem to be celebrating the appearance of the book that Mr. Zhang and his colleagues wrote in just three weeks to popularize -- or cash in on -- a wave of anti-Western nationalism. **********The book's five authors admit to a certain lack of knowledge about the issues. Their book is not so much political analysis as a handbook for  anti-American and anti-British slogans, conspiracy theories and satire. **********''Some people abroad said we did this book because we are manipulated by the Government, or for commercial purpose, or that we are terrorists,'' Mr. Zhang said, seated this weekend in a small Beijing hotel convenient to his fruit stands -- his main source of income before he turned social commentator. **********''This is very unjust,'' Mr. Zhang continued. ''Our views may be radical, but they are from the heart.'' **********''What is important,'' interjected Song Qiang, one of the co-authors, ''is not that the book is being used by the Government, but what lesson the United States could draw from the public mood of China.'' **********What lesson? he was asked. **********''Don't think that the Chinese youth appreciate the sanctions by the United States against China,'' Mr. Song replied. ''You cannot divorce the individual from the state and when you hurt the Chinese Government, you hurt the Chinese people.'' **********At a time when drinking Coke, smoking Marlboros and eating at McDonald's is high fashion among Chinese youth, many now also have an ''attitude'' toward the United States. Seven years after the 1989 Tiananmen massacre, Chinese young people may still be unhappy with their own Government, but with no available outlet for political expression, they are channeling their energy, and their frustrations, in other directions. **********Sports has become a national obsession. Sports and pride in China's athletes have unified the Chinese, despite deep political wounds that otherwise divide Chinese society. **********Su Shaozhi, one of the leading democratic thinkers within the Communist Party in the 1980's, who now lives in exile in the United States, observed, ''In mainland China and other leading post-Communist socialist countries, Marxism-Leninism has become a sham ideology causing a crisis of faith.'' Thus, he added, ''it is a common phenomenon that nationalists are taking advantage of this weak spot.'' **********Writing a review of the book in the dissident newsletter China Focus, Mr. Su said: ''Though sales of this book have been considerable, it has not really caused a stir among intellectuals. Rather, I would say that this book became popular overseas because foreign leaders paid more attention to it.'' **********In the book, Western countries are portrayed as stifling China's emergence as a great power, interfering in China's internal affairs over Taiwan and Tibet and practicing a repugnant brand of moral superiority in human rights. **********In one example, they assert that the Central Intelligence Agency, in contravention to the White House, is supporting pro-independence ''separatists'' on Taiwan to provoke a military confrontation with China. The goal, they say, is ''to make any action by China condemned by the world as a threat to regional and world peace.'' **********''When I read that book, it makes me feel good,'' said a young Chinese office worker named Wang Yanhong, through she conceded that she found much of the logic ''a little confusing.'' She still has plans to seek admission to an American university. **********The book idea may have been borrowed from a Japanese assault on the United States a few years ago titled ''The Japan That Can Say No,'' written by the former chairman of Sony Corporation, Akio Morita, and Shintaro Ishihara, a legislator. Both books could be called ''grievance literature,'' tapping a layer of Asian xenophobia, nationalism and, in China's case, a deep youthful patriotism. **********Mr. Zhang took part as a 22-year-old in the pro-democracy demonstrations that briefly broke out in 1986. Now he has concluded that China's democracy movements were ''a blind alley,'' and he has become ''ambivalent'' about the United States. **********When he recently found himself face to face with the British journalist Jasper Becker, who asked in an interview why it was wrong for foreign governments to put pressure on China to make it comply with international standards, Mr. Zhang fired back: ''Britain sold opium to China and waged the Opium Wars against China. That was a great infringement on Chinese human rights. Yet I have never heard of any apologies being made by your Government.'' **********The book complements the strategy of today's Communist Party leaders. To shore up their own legitimacy, they travel the country, expressing deep concern for the welfare of the people. **********Justified or not, America is blamed for things like International Olympic Committee's decision to reject Beijing's bid to be host to the 2000 Olympic Games and the World Trade Organization's insistence that China take down its market barriers as a condition for admission. **********In the political season that is opening as Deng Xiaoping, the paramount leader, fades from the scene, party stalwarts would like Western leaders to ease their demands for concessions, which they fear would open them to the charge that they are ''appeasing'' foreigners. **********Stoking youthful nationalism has become a refuge for these leaders, a place from which to warn foreigners that pressure will backfire by offending the patriotic sensibilities of China's youth.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/04/busin.main_headline: Goodbye Corner Office, Hello Virtual Suite : Workplace on Demand
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/04/busin.print_headline: Goodbye Corner Office, Hello Virtual Suite : Workplace on Demand
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/04/busin.body_text: **********Every morning, Flore Millet-Cassin, armed with her microchip-encapsulated identification card, checks into a small computer that looks like an automated banking machine. **********The 'Check-in-Station' at Andersen Consulting here tells the manager where she will be working that day and updates her on events and meetings that have been scheduled. When she leaves the building or is in a meeting, the central computer will automatically transfer calls and take messages. **********Welcome to the virtual office: it exists only when the employee needs it and is transformed into space for others when the worker is out. Andersen Consulting, along with Digital Equipment Corp., Microsoft Corp., International Business Machines Corp. and others, believes there is money to be saved and efficiency to be increased by eliminating individually assigned office space. **********Andersen's new Paris offices, unveiled in January, created work spaces available to employees through advance reservation, eliminating the traditional territorial element. David Andrews, managing partner for Andersen Consulting Western Europe, estimates that the system will save the Paris office about $1 million annually **********"What we want to try to do is shift the emphasis from space costs to technology and infrastructure," Mr. Andrews said. **********Andersen has assigned about 40 full-time staff members to managing reservations and office space. Many of these logistics employees were new hires, but others were reassigned from other duties, so the overall number of jobs has not changed. **********The company spent about $4 million to renovate the 7,000-square-meter (22,967-square-foot) 1930s-era building. While Andersen has 1,150 Paris-based employees, the new virtual offices can accommodate only 600 at any given time. The space is organized to provide small cubical-like working areas for each manager, conference areas and open offices for visiting managers. **********The change required all of Andersen's managers to take the draconian step of destroying all but the most important documents — which amounted to about 150 tons of paper. **********Now, each Paris-based manager has a small filing cabinet with current files, which is moved into their reserved working space before they arrive. They each carry a portable computer, which connects to the company network from wherever they are working. **********Jean-Pierre Mercier, the director of communications for Andersen's Paris office, summed up the change as a move to a building structured for communication inside and out. "It is a new vision of space and time," he said. **********For Ms. Millet-Cassin, the change has proven to be positive. 'The greatest advantage is that the virtual office environment permits a high level internal communication," she said. "Mangers are working in close proximity and are able to communicate with an ease that the traditional office environment was not necessarily adapted to." **********But there are drawbacks. "It gets noisy and one must sometimes seek out closed office spaces for privacy," she said. **********Mr. Andrews said the company realized that employees might have trouble giving up their personalized space. But he said the change was lead by management, which made the transition smooth. **********"What we are hoping to put across is that we have a more egalitarian approach," he said. **********The Chadwick Group, which designed the space for Andersen, sees the development of the virtual office as "a cumulating of all the business engineering projects going on everywhere which are about reducing head count, increasing efficiency, lowering responsibility through the levels of management and encouraging people to work in teams," said Andrew Chadwick, managing director of the company. **********Mr. Chadwick, who started experimenting with these ideas in 1990, said the concept was modeled on a university campus. **********"In university work, you are encouraged to be independent, and it is the results that count," he said. "In the traditional work force you go back to primary school being told what to do, where to do it and how to do it. What is really interesting is that by adopting the university structure you are also adopting the university moiré — you have to be more independent and manage your time efficiently." **********The London-based company has a staff of 40 and sets up its own virtual offices when needed. **********While Andersen plans to expand the virtual-office concept to all of its offices in Western Europe by the end of 1997, the company is not the first to use technology to save space. **********Digital Equipment's Swedish unit eliminated territorial office space in January 1992. The Swedish office experimented by creating common working spaces for some consultants so they could work in an environment best suited to the job at hand. **********In the first six months, efficiency increased 68 percent. The company's lighting bills fell 70 percent, air conditioning costs dropped 60 percent and the cleaning bill was halved. **********The experiment worked so well that Digital Sweden was quickly mimicked by Digital in Britain and Finland. Indeed, Digital Sweden now works with 40 other companies to analyze their organizational needs. **********IBM has been experimenting with just-in-time offices for the past two years. The company's Beijing branch functions much like Andersen's Paris office, where telephone and mail messages follow employees to their assigned work cubicles. **********"IBM finds that the open-work environment is very good for people that are mobile, such as the marketing staff that spends most of their time out with customers," said Fred McNeese, the company's director of international public relations. **********At Microsoft, personal offices have not been eliminated, but laptop computers serve as a virtual office for many employees on the road. **********"Just about everyone has a laptop computer and has access to a remote access site, which allows anyone to plug their computer in anywhere and have total access to their files and the company's network," said Andrea Tevlin, manager of manager development. **********She said Microsoft saw an advantage to what Andersen was doing. "It is great that a company can identify existing technology and then structures itself around it." **********Mr. Andrews of Andersen Consulting agreed. "Historically business strategy has always driven technology," he said. "What we are finding is that now you see technology driving and enabling business strategy, and that is a fascinating new trend."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/02/busin.main_headline: COMMUNICATIONS RESHAPED: THE OVERHAUL;CONGRESS VOTES TO RESHAPE COMMUNICATIONS INDUSTRY, ENDING A 4-YEAR STRUGGLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/02/busin.print_headline: COMMUNICATIONS RESHAPED: THE OVERHAUL;CONGRESS VOTES TO RESHAPE COMMUNICATIONS INDUSTRY, ENDING A 4-YEAR STRUGGLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/02/busin.body_text: **********After four years of struggle and gridlock, Congress rewrote the nation's communications laws today, passing a bill that would transform television, telephones and the emerging frontiers of cyberspace. **********Voting within two hours of each other, both the House and Senate approved a final version of a bill that is broadly intended to promote a free-for-all rivalry between local telephone companies, long-distance carriers, cable television operators and even electric utilities. **********The House approved the bill first, by a vote of 414 to 16; the Senate's vote was 91 to 5. The bill now moves directly to President Clinton, who strongly supports it and has said he will sign it. **********"Today, we have broken up two of the biggest government monopolies left: the  monopolies in local telephone service and in cable television," said the bill's  primary author in the House, Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr., Republican of  Virginia, the chairman of the Commerce Committee. "For the first time ever, Americans will be given choices. Besides lower rates and better service, the result will be innovative new products and services that will create thousands of new American jobs." **********Whether or not the bill lives up to the superlatives heaped on it today by its supporters, few dispute the sweeping impact of the new legislation, which leaves no corner of the industry unchanged. **********It would replace the historic antitrust consent decree that broke up the Bell telephone system in 1984, freeing the seven regional Baby Bell companies to offer long-distance services while forcing them to open the local telephone business to new rivals. **********The bill lets cable television and telephone companies attack each other's markets, as each industry races to offer a full menu of telephone, video and high-speed data communications. The bill also relaxes ownership restrictions in  broadcasting, allowing companies to greatly increase the number of radio and television stations a single company can own. **********And it contains provisions that make it a crime to transmit indecent sexual material over computer networks, and require television manufacturers to begin including the so-called V-chip to allow parents to block undesirable programming. **********Today's vote came after Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, dropped his objections to a provision that he attacked as a multibillion-dollar  giveaway for television broadcasters. That provision essentially reserves a segment of the nation's airwaves, estimated to be worth as much as $70 billion,  for television broadcasters to start new digital television services. **********Mr. Dole effectively blocked the bill several weeks ago, arguing that the provision amounted to corporate welfare for media companies at a time when Congress was cutting funds for social welfare programs. **********But today he let the bill proceed unchanged -- though not without being blasted by numerous Democrats for capitulating -- after he obtained assurances from Republicans and from the Federal Communications Commission that no licenses would be given until after Congress revisits the issue in a separate bill. **********Over all, however, today's votes drew a chorus of praise from almost every segment of the communications industry. But consumer groups complained that the  measure would lead to higher prices for telephone and cable customers, and civil liberties groups were furious about provisions aimed at blocking sexual material on computer networks. **********In industry, the biggest winners today were the seven regional Bell companies that have been prohibited from entering the $70 billion long-distance market since the companies were created 12 years ago. **********It remains unclear how quickly this will take place, but executives at AT&T predicted today that head-to-head rivalry from the Bells could arrive within two years. Under the new law, the Bell companies must open their local networks  to competition by satisfying a detailed checklist of requirements that aspiring  rivals have said are essential for entering the local phone business. **********"This bill is a blueprint for the 21st century," said Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts. "It breaks down all the old models of one  cable company and one telephone company. It is not perfect, but it is the best overall blueprint that any country in the world has ever come up with." **********Vice President Al Gore, who has spearheaded the Clinton Administration's efforts on communication issues, effusively praised today's votes. **********"It's a bipartisan victory, a textbook example of how the White House and Congress can work together," he said tonight. "Creativity that has been bottled  up for decades will be let out in a very constructive way." **********Today's votes mark the end of a four-year legislative struggle worthy of the  Perils of Pauline. Lobbying by the regional Bell companies helped kill a similar measure drafted by Democrats in 1994, with Bell companies complaining that the measure would not let them into the long-distance industry quickly enough. **********This year, with Republicans pushing a stronger deregulatory bill, AT&T and other long-distance carriers waged a lobbying campaign to defeat provisions that would free the Bells more quickly. They lost that battle last summer in both the House and Senate, but declared victory after winning a few modest concessions in December during a House-Senate conference committee. **********But that was hardly the end. Within hours after top Republicans and Democrats on the conference committee reached agreement on a final bill, rank-and-file House Republicans complained that their own leaders had made too many concessions to Democrats. Many Republicans were furious when Mr. Gore quickly declared his delight with the agreement, and their anger delayed passage for another six weeks. **********Mr. Dole then confounded almost every other lawmaker who had worked on the bill by attacking it as a "giveaway" to broadcasters. That issue only became resolved after Mr. Dole and the House Speaker, Newt Gingrich, agreed to a compromise on Wednesday morning. **********Despite the turmoil, virtually every segment of the communications industry has been pleading with Congressional leaders for weeks to simply pass the bill and be done with it. **********Gerald M. Levin, chairman and chief executive of Time Warner Inc., phoned Republican lawmakers to beg for an end to the bickering. Time Warner, the nation's second-largest cable television operator, will benefit from both cable  price deregulation and from rules to ease its entry into the telephone business. Cable companies were so eager for the bill that they agreed to delay full price  deregulation for three more years -- a retreat from the bills passed last summer. **********Consumer advocates continued to criticize the bill, particularly provisions that would immediately end most cable television price regulations in small markets and permit cable television and telephone companies to merge in markets  with fewer than 50,000 people. **********"Cable rates are going to go up in small towns immediately and could rise significantly in three years across the country," said Gene Kimmelman, co-director of the Consumers Union's Washington office. **********Civil liberties groups quickly vowed a court battle over provisions that would block the transmission of smut over computer networks. "The Internet has been give second-class speech rights, and we are going to take them to court over it," said Jerry Berman, director of the Center for Democracy and Technology, a nonprofit group in Washington focused on Internet issues. **********Numerous Democratic lawmakers took potshots over the provision that would reserve part of the airwaves for digital television. "It is a huge charitable corporate gift," thundered Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan. **********But Mr. Dole, citing assurances from the F.C.C. that it would take no action  until Congress revisits the issue in a separate bill, said broadcasters would not get the valuable television frequencies without a fight in the months ahead. **********"I am determined to turn the F.C.C.'s commitment to us into a victory for the American taxpayer," he said in a statement today. "For those who think this is an idle threat, guess again."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/08/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;Pep Boys hires Cliff Freeman to enliven its image and sales.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/08/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;Pep Boys hires Cliff Freeman to enliven its image and sales.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/08/busin.body_text: **********THE agency that brought pizazz to peddling pizza and made buying office supplies seem like fun is facing perhaps its most challenging retail assignment: convincing consumers that shopping for automotive parts and repairs can be less  painful than a root canal without anesthesia or a double feature of "Waterworld" and "Showgirls." **********Cliff Freeman & Partners, the New York shop known for campaigns that sell with a smile for the Little Caesars pizzerias and the Staples office-supply chain, is introducing television commercials for the Pep Boys -- Manny, Moe & Jack, the automotive parts and service retailer with 510 stores in 33 states and Puerto Rico. The campaign, which begins Monday, is the first from Freeman since  being named in December to handle the creative portion of the Pep Boys account,  with billings estimated at $25 million to $30 million. **********The commercials are Freemanesque in their deft blend of humor with hard-hitting, competitive claims. For instance, in one spot disparaging local garages that compete against Pep Boys, a woman confronts a mechanic who appears  to have wandered off the set of "Deliverance." **********In another commercial, a gruff garage owner who has kept a man's car for five days without fixing it seeks to reassure him by declaring, "I have three of my best guys on it right now." Indeed they are -- draped on it, eating. **********The campaign carries the theme "Everything but gas," which is meant to play up the selection at Pep Boys superstores. Each averages 23,000 square feet, stocks 26,000 items and has 12 service bays. **********Pep Boys appeals to "all automotive aftermarket customers, whether they are the 'do it for me's' who make no repairs on their cars or the 'do-it-yourselfers,' " said Richard Hammill, vice president for advertising at Pep Boys in Philadelphia. **********"We needed an agency to talk to each segment," he added. "Others came up with cute scenarios, but you could have put the name of any company at the end of the spots. Freeman was head and shoulders above the others in how it wove in the Pep Boys advantages." **********Executives at Pep Boys hope the campaign will help reinvigorate sales, which  have been sluggish. "A lot of retailers are glad 1995 is behind us," Mr. Hammill said. **********"We're very enthused about 1996," he added, in part because of the weather. "We had a very good winter is how I would put it. If it's miserable outside, we  do well." **********Peter Minnium, senior vice president and group account director at Freeman, which is owned by Cordiant P.L.C., said the campaign was based on data that included "two forms of proprietary research we use with our sister agency, Saatchi & Saatchi, that involve sending clinical psychologists and anthropologists to observe our target markets in their natural habitat, if you will." **********"It confirmed for us that because a consumer has such an emotional attachment to the car," he added, "repairs and maintenance are hugely important." **********So in developing "the strategic mosaic" for Pep Boys, Mr. Minnium said, Freeman created "a campaign that would accomplish two things: dramatizing in a highly emotional manner how Pep Boys will meet your needs, and conveying that Pep Boys will be able to meet those needs across a broad spectrum, whether it's  a horn relay for a 1989 Ford Taurus or a repair." **********Cliff Freeman, chairman and chief executive at the agency, said the humor provided a way to deliver a tough message, that "people have had a lot of unsatisfactory experiences with this industry," suffering "year after year of being ripped off and pandered to." **********The tone of two commercials is somewhat earthier than typical Freeman fare and marks a departure for Pep Boys. Mr. Hammill characterized the company's previous campaign, by N. W. Ayer & Partners in New York, as "warm and fuzzy -- kids and that type of thing." **********In one of the two commercials, a gang of ninja-like thieves strips a man's truck while he is behind a tree answering a call of nature. In the other, a man  who paid "too much for auto supplies" compares himself to the back end of a horse. **********"Is it a little bit more liberal for us?" Mr. Hammill asked. "Absolutely. But we felt it was memorable and it's targeted toward a male 25 to 49." Mr. Freeman  estimated that 70 percent of Pep Boys' customers are men, adding, "There's a different mind-set in this category." **********The commercials will run on national cable networks like CNN and ESPN and on  local stations affiliated with the four broadcast networks. **********One aspect of the campaign is vintage Freeman: a sight-and-sound-bite at the  end of each commercial to reinforce the sales message. For Little Caesars, a toga-clad gnome barks "Pizza! Pizza!" For Staples, a stapler noisily races across the screen. **********For Pep Boys, it is an aerial view of a superstore as the roof slams shut with a loud thunk, not unlike the sound made by a car hood closing. The traditional characters of Manny, Moe and Jack, the Pep Boys founders, are not in the commercials but are to appear in print.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/23/busin.main_headline: With Gasoline Prices Steady, Some Foresee Slide
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/23/busin.print_headline: With Gasoline Prices Steady, Some Foresee Slide
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/23/busin.body_text: **********With Americans preparing to hit the road for the Memorial Day weekend, it appears that gasoline prices are stabilizing and the prospect for lower prices is improving as suppliers begin to rebuild their very low inventories. **********"Retail prices have leveled off," said John H. Lichtblau, director of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, an industry consulting group. **********After rising by more than 20 cents a gallon from early February to mid-May,  the average price of regular gasoline has steadied, even dipping slightly from a peak of nearly $1.29 last Friday to just over $1.28 a gallon this week, according to a daily survey of retail gasoline prices around the country conducted by the Department of Energy. **********Some analysts predicted that gasoline prices could begin to retreat soon, but they warned that another increase at the pump was possible this summer if demand rose at the unexpectedly strong pace of the last couple of years. **********Frederick P. Leuffer, an oil analyst for Bear, Stearns, said that the recent  buildup of gasoline inventories was a sign that oil refiners were beginning to catch up with consumption, contributing to the fall in wholesale prices by roughly a dime since their peak in mid-April. Another factor helping to hold down wholesale prices has been an increase in gasoline imports, mostly from Europe to the East Coast. **********Pushing in the other direction, however, was the expectation that motorists this summer were likely to drive farther and faster in less fuel-efficient vehicles, sustaining demand at such high levels that many refiners will be straining to keep up. **********Given these competing forces, Mr. Leuffer said, "It's hard to say what will happen at the pump." **********The partial lifting this week of the oil embargo against Iraq, allowing it to bring about 700,000 barrels of crude oil a day onto the world market, is not expected to have any near-term effect on retail prices. But Mr. Lichtblau predicted that gasoline prices could fall significantly two to three months from now as those additional barrels begin to work through the supply pipeline. **********One of the factors that helped to drive up prices earlier this year was the sharp squeeze at refineries that were unable to switch as much output to gasoline because they were forced by the cold weather to produce heating oil longer than normal. That drove gasoline inventories to very low levels. **********While still low compared with previous years, that squeeze on supplies appears to be easing, according to new figures released this week by the American Petroleum Institute, the industry's trade group. Gasoline supplies rose by 1.85 million barrels, or about 1 percent, to 204.9 million barrels for the week ending May 17. Energy Department statistics, while slightly different, point in the same direction. **********While the increase is small, the timing is critical because it comes at the start of the heavy summer driving season, which traditionally starts this weekend. **********"We're in a stage where supplies are in excess of what is being consumed," said Edward H. Murphy, the director of finance, accounting and statistics at the petroleum institute. "That inventories are now building up suggests that there could be downward pressure on prices." **********There was concern among some analysts that refineries would not be able to keep up with the surge in demand that typically begins at this time of year. **********For the moment, though, gasoline demand is running lower than many analysts had feared. The Energy Department predicted about a month ago that demand would  rise by more than 2 percent this summer because of faster speeds and a decline in gas mileage caused by the popularity of mini-vans and sport utility vehicles. **********But so far this year, Mr. Murphy said, gasoline demand is only about 1 percent above what it was during the corresponding period last year. That could  be due in part to the impact of higher prices on the driving habits of American  motorists.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/01/busin.main_headline: Governments Have Taken Control Back From Markets : Beating Currency Speculators
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/01/busin.print_headline: Governments Have Taken Control Back From Markets : Beating Currency Speculators
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/01/busin.body_text: **********After years of having their best-laid economic plans torn asunder by currency speculators, the leaders of the Group of Seven countries have ample reason for smugness. **********But at the end of their annual meeting Friday in Lyon, they refrained from gloating, contenting themselves with a communiqué that simply said, "Exchange-market interventions can be effective and even decisive." **********Many hedge funds, brokerage houses and banks have learned that lesson the hard way. **********After having built massive operations to bet on the currency markets in recent years, many of them now acknowledge that profits in that game may never again rival those of its lucrative past. "The days of massed ranks of spot currency traders all making pots of money are over," said Michael Burke, senior currency economist at Citibank in London. "For most, margins on the business no longer cover their costs." **********Currency traders make their money from volatility — from sharp swings in the values of the currencies they buy and sell — and volatility has been in short supply for the better part of a year. Along the way, leadership in determining the value of currencies has shifted decisively toward central banks and governments. **********The results speak for themselves. "Now, there seems to be no major currency whose value is wildly different from where the authorities would like it to be," said Kit Juckes, currency strategist at NatWest Capital Markets Ltd. **********Governments' success in taking control of their currencies from the markets has come not only from intervention, but more importantly, from the fact that for once, policymakers are singing from the same hymnal. All agree on the dangers of inflation, of high budget deficits, and crucially, of misvalued currencies. **********The calm that has now descended over trading in European currencies is reassuring to governments. Through an extraordinary exercise of political will, the 15 European Union economies have now converged as rarely before. **********Their progress has been so impressive that even in the currency markets, the hotbed of doubts over EU plans for a single currency by 1999, true believers in monetary union now probably hold the majority. "It has gained enormous credibility in the markets where people feel that even if all the economic conditions for union are not met the project will go ahead anyway," Mr. Burke said. **********Market participants must now contemplate whether this new agreement on economic objectives among the industrial world's policymakers marks the end of an era. Most analysts are optimistic that volatility will rise again, despite their own predictions of placid markets extending until at least the end of the year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/14/busin.main_headline: HIGH COURT SAYS LIQUOR PRICE ADS CAN'T BE BANNED
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/14/busin.print_headline: HIGH COURT SAYS LIQUOR PRICE ADS CAN'T BE BANNED
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/14/busin.body_text: **********In a ruling that strengthens free-speech protection for advertisers and casts doubt on the Clinton Administration's proposed restrictions on cigarette promotions, the Supreme Court struck down today a Rhode Island ban on advertising liquor prices. **********All nine Justices agreed that the ban violated the First Amendment's guarantee of free speech. The ban, part of a 40-year-old state law, is similar to bans on liquor-price advertising in Connecticut, Pennsylvania and eight other states. **********There was, however, no majority opinion on a rationale, indicating that the  Court's approach to commercial speech remains in flux 20 years after the Court first extended First Amendment protection to truthful, nonmisleading advertising of lawful products. But for the most part, the four separate opinions expressed  nuances of difference rather than the deep fissures that characterize other areas of constitutional doctrine in which the Justices have yet to find common ground. **********"When the day is done and you add up all these crazy fragments, you come away with a strengthened test" for First Amendment protection of commercial speech, one specialist in this area, P. Cameron DeVore of the Seattle law firm Davis Wright Tremaine, said today in an interview. **********In invalidating the Rhode Island law, the Court overturned a 1994 ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, in Boston, which found "inherent merit" in the state's argument that the advertising ban, by discouraging bargain-hunting, kept liquor prices high and thus served the state's goal of discouraging liquor consumption. **********The state had not demonstrated a close enough fit between means and ends, Justice John Paul Stevens said in the Court's principal opinion. "The First Amendment directs us to be especially skeptical of regulations that seek to keep people in the dark for what the Government perceives to be their own good," Justice Stevens said in a portion of the opinion that Justices Anthony M. Kennedy and Ruth Bader Ginsburg also signed. **********The case has been watched closely for clues to the Court's eventual response  to restrictions that the Food and Drug Administration is now considering on the  advertising and promotion of cigarettes. There were no definitive answers, but it is apparent that the Court will subject any new regulations to a searching examination. **********Among the proposed restrictions are a ban on outdoor displays of cigarette advertising within 1,000 yards of a school or playground, a ban on the use of color advertising in media likely to be seen by young people and restrictions on the use of cigarette brand names and logos on caps and other items. **********The proposed cigarette regulations focus on sales to minors, which are against Federal law; Rhode Island made no effort to defend its advertising ban as a way of restricting young people's access to liquor. It is unclear from today's opinions whether the explicit reference to young people in the anti-smoking regulations might be more persuasive to the Court than the broad-brush defense by Rhode Island of its advertising ban. **********One advertising executive said today that the decision offered useful ammunition against the Federal cigarette proposals. "Alcohol is also a product that is off-limits to teen-agers," Wally Snyder, president and chief executive of the American Advertising Federation, said in an interview. "This decision transfers the focus back to speech and the First Amendment and away from the product." **********In his opinion, Justice Stevens said one serious flaw in the Rhode Island law was that the state's goal of discouraging drinking could have been accomplished  by other means that did not restrict speech, like direct price regulation, higher taxes, limitations on purchases and education campaigns. **********Justices Kennedy and Ginsburg along with Justice David H. Souter joined this  portion of the opinion, which could have a fairly direct application to the cigarette situation. However, the question remains whether there would be a different outcome regarding cigarettes since the proposed regulations aim directly at illegal purchases by young people. **********A separate concurring opinion by Justice Clarence Thomas suggested that the difference might indeed be significant. While offering a strong First Amendment  analysis, in some respects more sweeping than that of Justice Stevens, he qualified his analysis by suggesting that it would be limited to products that are legally sold to their intended customers. A governmental interest in keeping "legal users of a product or service ignorant in order to manipulate their choices in the marketplace" can never be legitimate, Justice Thomas said. **********The Court may soon give a clue to its further thinking on these issues when it acts on two related cases it has been holding since early in the term while awaiting the outcome in the Rhode Island case. Both cases challenge restrictions imposed by the City of Baltimore on outdoor advertising of cigarettes and beer.  The restrictions were upheld by a Federal appeals court. The cigarette advertising restriction, adopted by the city in 1994, has the explicit purpose of discouraging smoking by teen-agers. **********The Rhode Island case, 44 Liquormart v. Rhode Island, No. 94-1140, began in 1991 when competitors complained about a liquor store's newspaper advertisement  that did not actually list prices, but showed pictures of liquor bottles with the word "Wow" in big letters. The Rhode Island Liquor Control Administrator imposed a $400 fine on the store, 44 Liquormart, which paid the fine and then challenged the law in Federal District Court in Providence, R.I. The store won at that level before losing in the appeals court. **********The Court's opinions today -- there were opinions by Justice Antonin Scalia and Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, as well as by Justices Stevens and Thomas -- contained discussions of the Court's numerous precedents in the area of commercial speech that were at times distinct and at times overlapping. **********It was clear from the opinions that a majority of the Court is no longer satisfied with several of these precedents but is uncertain how to replace them. **********Justices Stevens, Kennedy, Thomas and Ginsburg called for overruling a 1986 case, Posadas de Puerto Rico v. Tourism Company, which upheld a Puerto Rico law  that banned the advertising of casino gambling on the theory that if the activity itself could be prohibited, speech about it could be prohibited as well. Justice O'Connor's opinion, which was also signed by Justice Souter, Justice Stephen G. Breyer and Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, did not advocate overruling that decision, but stated that subsequent decisions had, properly, ignored it. **********Justice Stevens did command a clear majority for a portion of his opinion holding that the 21st Amendment, which repealed Prohibition while leaving the states much leeway to regulate alcohol, could not outweigh the First Amendment and, therefore, could not save the Rhode Island law from the conclusion that it  violated the constitutional guarantee of free speech.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/14/busin.main_headline: Senate Clears Way for Vote On Third Term For Greenspan
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/14/busin.print_headline: Senate Clears Way for Vote On Third Term For Greenspan
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/14/busin.body_text: **********Senate leaders broke the logjam holding up the confirmation of the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, to a third term today, with Republicans agreeing to Democratic requests for an extended debate on monetary policy over several days before the confirmation vote next Thursday. **********Within hours of the agreement, Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, the Democrat whose demands for a debate have held up Mr. Greenspan's confirmation, began making his case on the Senate floor that an excessive focus by Mr. Greenspan on reducing inflation was keeping the economy from growing to its full potential. **********But even as the Senate undertook its most extensive arguments to date over the Fed chairman's record, both Republican and Democratic leaders said they expected Mr. Greenspan to win easy confirmation. **********President Clinton renominated Mr. Greenspan to the job in February, and the Administration has remained firmly behind the nomination despite opposition from a few Democrats, led by Mr. Harkin. The Fed chairman's term expired in March, and he has been serving in an acting capacity since then. His new four-year term begins when he is confirmed. **********The agreement also unfreezes the nominations of two other appointees to the seven-member Fed Board of Governors -- Alice M. Rivlin, the White House budget chief, whom Mr. Clinton named to be the central bank's vice chairman, and Laurence H. Meyer, a St. Louis economist. Both are expected to win confirmation, although some Republicans have criticized Ms. Rivlin in recent days for what they said were misleading statements to Congress about Mr. Clinton's proposed budget. **********Senator Christopher S. Bond, a Republican of Missouri, said he wanted to ask  Ms. Rivlin how the Administration could make public proposed long-term cuts in spending programs even as it "quietly tells political interest groups we're not  going to make the cuts." **********Responding to Mr. Bond, a White House official said that while President Clinton might shift spending between programs in future years, he would retain his commitment to reaching a balanced budget by 2002, and that the budget fight  should not affect Ms. Rivlin's nomination to the Fed. **********"We are confident that the Senate will confirm all the President's three nominees for the Federal Reserve, and we will work with Congress to answer any questions they may have," the official said. **********The agreement to proceed with the debate and separate recorded votes for each of the nominees was worked out early today between the new Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, and the Senate minority leader, Thomas A. Daschle of South Dakota. The Republicans had previously been unwilling to grant  Mr. Harkin's demand for three days of debate, and were happy to have the Democrats fighting among themselves over the nominations. But there was increasing concern within the Administration and in the Senate that further delay could unsettle the financial markets, leading to higher interest rates. **********"I hope we can have a good back and forth among those who believe we ought to have a much more aggressive monetary policy than we do," Senator Daschle said. "Once the Greenspan nomination is gone, we may not have that chance again for some time." **********Mr. Harkin's argument that the Fed under Mr. Greenspan has taken its war against inflation too far has little support among economists. But it has been welcomed by some industrialists, who feel that high interest rates are cramping  growth rates and that Mr. Greenspan does not appreciate how few upward pressures on prices the economy faces in an era of global competition. **********"This debate about Chairman Greenspan's policies and their impact on the economy, about how we can get our economy to grow faster, about how we can create jobs and raise incomes, zeroes in on the most important issues we face,"  Mr. Harkin said. **********Mr. Harkin said that Mr. Greenspan's "almost obsessive" concern with inflation had led him to misread the state of the economy and had "stifled economic growth and the income of average Americans." **********Mr. Harkin said there was still some risk of inflation. But he said that unless the Fed was willing to "take a chance" on higher growth rates, the nation would never get a chance to see how fast the economy can expand without igniting inflation. **********Defending Mr. Greenspan, Senator Charles Grassley of Iowa, a Republican, said the Fed chairman "has been pretty good at bringing confidence" to the financial  system, and that the real economic debate should not be over monetary policy, but over balancing the budget. **********"We ought to be putting our energy in this body not so much in fighting the reappointment of Chairman Greenspan, but in being more fiscally responsible," he said. **********Mr. Greenspan was in Sweden today giving a speech on banking regulation. He has long defended his focus on reducing inflation as the best way to give the economy a stable foundation for growth. Mr. Greenspan has always said that he has no preconceived notion of how fast the economy can grow, and that he tries to stamp out inflation before it takes root by watching carefully for early warning signals of rising wages and prices. **********With the economy growing at a robust pace this quarter and unemployment low,  many economists expect Mr. Greenspan to push the Fed to raise interest rates in  July or August. Mr. Clinton, clearly concerned that a rate increase could slow the economy heading into the Presidential election, said last week that the Fed  should not raise rates if there is an absence of any signs of inflation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/30/busin.snippet: Prices of US Treasury securities tumble; 30-year bond drops 22/32, to price of 96 15/32; yield rises to 7.03 percent, from 6.98 percent; graph (L)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/30/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury securities tumbled yesterday on the unexpected strength of the latest economic statistics, which heightened investor fears that inflation would accelerate, forcing the Fed to tighten monetary policy soon. **********The 30-year bond dropped 22/32 , to a price of 9615/32  ; the yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, rose to 7.03 percent, from 6.98 percent on Wednesday. What perhaps bothered the bulls most yesterday were signs that the expected slowdown for the third quarter may not materialize. **********The Commerce Department revised the second quarter's gross domestic product gain sharply upward, to 4.8 percent from 4.2 percent. Moreover, surprisingly strong housing sales in July, up 7.9 percent, to an annualized rate of 783,000 units, almost certainly shocked market participants who were looking for signs of moderation in the wake of the strong G.D.P. revision. **********Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said that ''the economic statistics released today reaffirmed the economy's bouyancy.'' He added, ''Initial claims for unemployment insurance are still relatively low despite recent modest increases in both the weekly numbers and the four-week averages, second-quarter G.D.P. growth proved to be even stronger than initially reported, and new-home sales noticeably exceeded even the highest expectations.'' **********Mr. Fine said that ''the downward revision to business inventories increases the chances that third-quarter G.D.P. growth, while more moderate than the April-to-June period, will also exceed the Federal Reserve's trend rate of maximum, noninflationary growth, which implies a continued bias toward tightening on the part of both the Federal Open Market Committee and the bond market.'' **********The open market committee, the Fed panel that sets interest rate policy, last met on Aug. 20 and chose not to raise rates. But its next meeting is set for Sept. 24, and it is possible, though highly unlikely, that the committee could opt to shift rates even before then if other data are strong enough to alarm the central bank. **********According to Maureen Mooney, a market analyst with Gov Px, a bond pricing service, activity was average after deducting the volume of trading in 14-day cash management bills that were auctioned yesterday. **********The Government was selling $30 billion of the short-term bills to bridge a brief shortfall in cash flow expected in September. Dealers said the average rate at auction was 5.24 percent and the bid-to-cover ratio, a low 2 to 1, which reflected the weakness in the market generated by fears that the Fed would raise rates soon. **********Selling did quicken in the afternoon, but some traders suspect that investors who held long positions took advantage of some index-fund buying by portfolio managers to get out on an uptick after the recent price declines in the market. And because of the thinness in volume, price movements were exaggerated. **********Today, the Treasury market will have an abbreviated session and close early. Thus, with a shortened session and long weekend ahead of next week's employment report, few traders yesterday were willing to be buyers. **********Mr. Fine said that perhaps the bigger surprise was the jump in July new-home sales, which nearly matches the high for the year that was seen in February. **********The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of 14-day cash management bills: **********(000 omitted in dollar figures) **********Average Price . . .   99.796       Discounted Rate . . .   5.24%       Coupon Yield . . .   5.33%       High Price . . .   99.797       Discounted Rate . . .   5.21%       Coupon Yield . . .   5.30%       Low Price . . .   99.795       Discounted Rate . . .   5.26%       Coupon Yield . . .   5.36%       Accepted at low price . . .   32%       Total applied for . . .   $60,065,000       Accepted . . .   $30,010,400       Noncompetitive . . .   $1,000,000 **********The 14-day cash management bills mature Sept. 17, 1996.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/07/busin.main_headline: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;Globe-Trotting? Check Your Exchange Rate
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/07/busin.print_headline: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;Globe-Trotting? Check Your Exchange Rate
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/07/busin.body_text: **********WITH stocks at lofty levels, the economy in the mature stages of expansion and an election ahead, many American investors think this might be a profitable  time to look abroad. **********But despite handsome -- and in some cases fabulous -- returns in recent years, success with international funds can be elusive, even when you pick the right companies. This is because buying foreign securities means converting your investment dollars into another currency, a process that very likely will magnify or nullify your gains or losses. **********The challenge is to pick not just a winning portfolio, but also to do so in  countries whose currencies are climbing against the dollar, increasing the value of an American investor's profits, or are at least holding their own so those profits will not be reduced. This seems a particularly formidable task now because the dollar, which like most currencies tends to benefit from rising interest rates, is looking fairly muscular. **********"My own view is that the dollar is more likely to be flat or up than down over the next five years," said Jonathan H. Francis, chief global strategist for Putnam Investments in Boston. **********How, then, does the mutual fund investor -- and funds are seen as the best way for most people to operate in overseas markets -- appraise the currency factor, one of the main determinants of total return? **********First, specialists say, realize that the news isn't all bad if the dollar rises against, say, the yen. While an investor in a Japanese-oriented fund would probably suffer from this, at least in the short term, a declining yen means that Japanese companies that export to the United States would find their  products relatively cheaper. So the drag from unfavorable currency translation will tend to be offset by the enhanced competitiveness of Japanese business. **********"A lot of countries are export-led economies, and currency devaluation can thus greatly help corporate earnings" there, said William F. Wendler 2d of Rowe  Price-Fleming International in Baltimore. **********But while this implicit hedge is a welcome offset in a stock fund, an investor in a foreign bond fund, which generally requires more hedging than a stock fund, would probably see any such benefit as trivial. **********Ideally, of course, investors would like their funds to achieve double-barreled profits by being on the right side of both the stock and currency markets. And except for a sharp upward spike in the first half of the 1980's, the dollar has been in a gradual downward trend for the last 20 years or more, adding a percentage point or two each year to the typical international portfolio. **********Against the mark, the dollar has dropped some 55 percent from its peak in early 1985, producing an extra gain of that amount for American investors in Germany. **********But even if you can count on such long-term wind at your back, the short run  can be unpleasant if you remain highly exposed to the swings of foreign currency, especially if your fund concentrates on a particular part of the world. **********As a result, most international and global funds -- the latter can invest in  the United States as well as abroad -- hedge their currency risk with forward or options contracts, though very few seek to eliminate all currency exposure. **********Although some risks, like those in Latin America, can be too costly or virtually impossible to hedge, most managers aim to do enough hedging to keep currency swings from spoiling returns but without trying to enhance them, either. **********"I use hedging as an insurance policy to protect the underlying stock from a  potential devaluation," said Helen Young Hayes, portfolio manager for the Janus  Worldwide and Janus Overseas funds, based in Denver. Both have posted gains of about 20 percent so far this year. **********"I do not speculate in currencies," she added. "I am a stock picker, not a currency trader." **********About 70 percent of Ms. Hayes's yen exposure is currently hedged back to the  dollar compared with 40 percent to 50 percent for her European holdings. **********Although fund prospectuses mention their approaches to currency risk, the discussions tend to be fairly vague, typically on the order of, "Hedging techniques are used from time to time." It is a good idea to inquire further. **********Investors probably would be wise to avoid funds that are fully hedged and those, like index funds, that never hedge, said Richard C. Pell, chief investment officer at Bank Julius Baer in New York, sponsor of the BJB International Equity fund, up about 12 percent this year. **********An especially bad idea, added Denise Downey, a portfolio strategist for Julius Baer's individual clients, is for an American to buy into a foreign money-market fund. "A short-term fund denominated in a nondollar currency is really nothing more than a foreign-exchange trading vehicle," Ms. Downey said. **********She also cautioned against what she called the widespread belief that there is no currency risk in buying American depository receipts, which represent foreign shares trading in this country and are found in various equity fund portfolios. **********She and other specialists also said investors should avoid the psychological  trap of thinking that the currencies of major European countries or Japan, for which trading markets are highly liquid, do not require much attention. **********"People get wooed into situations like Germany and France, thinking they're safe," Ms. Downey said. "But they can still lose money."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/16/busin.body_text: **********Bayer A.G. and Roche Holding Ltd. are forming a joint venture in the United States to sell Roche's Aleve analgesic and several other nonprescription drugs, people with knowledge of the deal said last night. **********The arrangement gives Roche, which assumed full ownership of Aleve from the Procter & Gamble Company in June, access to Bayer's powerful sales force and customer relationships in the struggle for shelf space in drugstores, supermarkets, mass merchandisers and convenience stores. **********Though neither side had released United States over-the-counter sales figures before the announcement expected today, drug industry analysts said that the Roche and Bayer products involved had about $800 million in combined sales last year. **********P.& G. spent about $200 million promoting Aleve, which was introduced in June 1994. Aleve sales in the United States were about $200 million last year, analysts said. **********Viren Mehta of Mehta & Isaly, a pharmaceutical and health-care research group in New York, said that Roche bought P.& G.'s Aleve stake so it could take responsibility for a global marketing campaign. While terms of the sale were not disclosed at the time, P.& G. said it would report $120 million in after-tax profits from the sale. P.& G. entered into the Aleve venture in 1988 with Syntex Laboratories, which Roche bought in 1994. **********Based on 1995 sales, Bayer, of Germany, is one of the top five marketers of nonprescription drugs in the United States behind Johnson & Johnson; American Home Products; Warner-Lambert's partnership with Wellcome, and P.& G., Mr. Mehta said. Novartis, the drug maker formed by the merger of Ciba-Geigy and Sandoz, will also challenge for a top-five ranking, he said. **********Roche, based in Switzerland, ranks high in over-the-counter drugs in Europe and Latin America. **********Bayer will contribute Actron, Midol and Vanquish analgesics; Roche will add Femstat 3, a vaginal-yeast treatment it also bought from P.& G.
