https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/15/busin.body_text: **********Laws -- the theoretical variety, not those made by governments -- have been part of science since before Sir Isaac Newton, his apple and what became known as Newton's Law of Gravitation. But the practice among physicists of observing a phenomenon, creating a testable hypothesis, then sometimes elevating that hypothesis to a named law has become a popular hobby in other fields. For example, the laws of motion in physics have been joined by the laws of markets in economics. **********And as information technology and computer science have risen to prominence  in the economy, they have given rise to a few laws of their own. These lie somewhere between the laws of physics, which are not all exactly true, and the laws of economics, which are not all exactly false. Einstein showed that Newton's laws were false, except for practical purposes. As for the various laws of economics, we can expect one to prove true any day now, but don't hold your breath. **********In this day and age, one way to judge the importance of laws is by counting  references to them on the Internet's World Wide Web. (O.K., there are other ways, but we are talking about computer-related laws here.) The last time I checked, Grosch's Law, discredited for a decade now, is mentioned on today's Internet 58 times. There are 67 references to something I once said -- now known as Metcalfe's Law and some 500 references to Moore's Law. Brooks's Law gets 28 mentions; Wirth's Law, none. This probably means he never said it, not uncommon  in the laws business. **********By comparison, there are 700 references to Newton's Law and 2,000 references to Murphy's Law: if anything can go wrong, it will. Got to hand it to Murphy. You may be wondering about what law of computing comes next; I certainly am. I suspect the next big law will be something about commerce on the Web or parallelism or biological computing. Who knows, perhaps the next law of computing will be named after you. It won't be named after Microsoft's chief executive, the multibillionaire William H. Gates, who in computing is seen as a  law unto himself. **********But while you are waiting, here is a quick look at some computing laws; one  obsolete, one in its prime, one on the rise and three that are elegant expressions of pique computing's equivalent of Murphy's Law. **********GROSCH'S LAW Bigger Computers Are Better **********Grosch's Law was one of the first laws of computing. The computing pioneer Herbert R.J. Grosch first observed in 1953 that the cost of a computer grows only as the square root of its speed -- bigger computers are better. Mr. Grosch  says he was dismissed twice from I.B.M., which might have thought at the time that he was underpricing their larger mainframes. Mr. Grosch had the temerity to name his own law after himself. **********MOORE'S LAW Smaller Computers Are Better **********Moore's Law overthrew Grosch's Law. Gordon E. Moore, founder and now chairman of the Intel Corporation, projected in 1965 that the logic density of silicon integrated circuits -- their raw computing power -- would grow exponentially each year. With an annually compounded doubling of chip densities  since 1965, it has turned out that bigger computers are not better, smaller computers are. (Goodbye, mainframes. Hello, PC's.) This also means that if you can afford to put it off until next year, don't buy a computer this year. Moore's Law will reign in Silicon Valley until he retires. **********METCALFE'S LAW Connected Computers Are Better **********Metcalfe's Law is named after me, but not by me. In 1980, I promoted computer networking standards, like the Internet, by arguing that the value of a network can be measured by the square of its number of users. More simply: Connected computers are better. Having the only telephone in the world would be of zero value, but this value increases for each new telphone it can call. **********The author George Gilder elevated my arguments to the status of a law in a preview of his forthcoming book, "Telecosm." Mr. Gilder says that Metcalfe's Law compounds Moore's and so Microsoft had better pay more attention to the Internet. **********GROVE'S LAW Monopolies Generally Slow Things Down **********Andrew S. Grove is Mr. Moore's longtime partner, now chief executive of Intel. Grove's Law, according to Mr. Moore, holds that the telecommunications bandwidth doubles every hundred years. This has become Mr. Grove's way of complaining about the underperformance of the telephone monopolies over the last 50 years as compared with the performance of the highly competitive computer industry. **********BROOKS'S LAW The More Workers, The Later It's Done **********Software is difficult to develop. In his classic book on the process, "The Mythical Man-Month," Frederick P. Brooks, a former I.B.M. software developer and now a professor of computer science at the University of North Carolina, introduced what has come to be called Brooks's Law: Adding manpower to a late software project make it later. Mr. Brooks saw his law operating at I.B.M. in the 1960's, when the joke was that if I. B. M. asked its programmers to jump a 100-foot gorge, a hundred of them would each jump one foot. **********WIRTH'S LAW Machines May Leap, But Programs Creep **********Software consistently fails to make good use of the latest hardware. According to a law sometimes attributed to a software pioneer, Nicklaus Wirth, a professor at the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich, software gets  slower faster than hardware gets faster. Wirth's Law can be traced all the way back to Mr. Grosch and is often paraphrased today with the names of the chief executives of Intel and Microsoft: "Grove giveth and Gates taketh away."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/16/busin.main_headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Shift by Company Will Bring in More Outsiders
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/16/busin.print_headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Shift by Company Will Bring in More Outsiders
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/16/busin.body_text: **********Responding to widespread criticism of insider domination of the company's board, the directors of the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company yesterday unanimously approved a series of proposals that would turn majority control of the board over to a group of outside directors, according to company officers and a member of the board. **********Under the proposals, several of the 17 current directors would not be able to stand for re-election at the next annual meeting of Archer-Daniels in the fall. **********But some large investors said that such changes did not go far enough in addressing the problems at Archer-Daniels, the agribusiness giant. As a result,  at least one influential institutional investor said it would begin preparing its own proposals on revamping the board and seek a shareholder vote. **********The recommendations were presented in a report by a corporate governance committee formed at the last annual meeting in October. **********"The board has accepted the report unanimously, and approved every proposal without exception," said Ray A. Goldberg, a professor of business at Harvard University who helped lead the governance committee. "This makes A.D.M. consistent with the best governance procedures of all the major corporations in  the United States." **********Still, little change is expected anytime soon at the company, which is based  in Decatur, Ill. At yesterday's meeting, some current outside directors were named to board committees. But the composition of the full board is not expected to change until at least the October meeting. **********The governance committee was formed as Archer-Daniels faced a revolt by big investors that resulted in as much as 20 percent of the shares being voted against the company's slate of directors at the meeting last October. **********The investors said that the directors were failing to treat a Federal criminal investigation of the company's business practices seriously, in large part because of their close ties to management. The investigation concerns accusations that senior Archer-Daniels officers engineered a widespread price-fixing conspiracy with competitors. **********Three grand juries are investigating whether Archer-Daniels conspired to fix  prices for several food additives and animal feed, including lysine, high-fructose corn syrup and citric acid. The investigation was sparked by Mark  Whitacre, a former senior executive at Archer-Daniels who worked for several years as a secret informant for Government prosecutors. **********Despite the intended changes, some critics of the company remained unimpressed. **********"What you have got here is a very minimal response," said Edward Durkin, director of special projects for the United Brotherhood of Carpenters, which owns about 775,000 shares of Archer-Daniels. "And it's hard to tell at this point whether the response means anything." **********Mr. Durkin said the union had sent proposals to the committee a few weeks ago, including suggestions that all board committees be composed of independent  directors and that directors be held personally liable in instances of gross negligence. But the union received no response. As a result, Mr. Durkin said the union would bring its proposals before the shareholders at the next annual meeting. **********Still, some analysts praised Archer-Daniels for agreeing to any change, given its history under its strong-willed chairman, Dwayne O. Andreas. **********"The fact that Dwayne Andreas and the board were willing to announce that they would do this was a surprise to some," said Leonard Teitelbaum, an analyst  at Merrill Lynch & Company. "Clearly, the board has heard the message that was delivered at the last annual meeting." **********In the report, the governance committee recommends that the board be reduced  from its current size of 17 to a minimum of 9 members and a maximum of 15. And regardless of the board's size, the report says, most of the directors should have no other affiliations with the company. **********The report defines outside director as someone who is not a current or former Archer-Daniels executive, has no material business or professional relationship  with the company, has no close family relationship with the company's management and is not receiving compensation from the company other than as a director. **********On the board now, 10 directors are current or former Archer-Daniels executives, or are related to such executives. Several others have been criticized for what some shareholders contend are outside financial relationships with the company or its officers. **********Under the proposals, board members who are now younger than 70 would not be permitted to run for re-election once they reach that age. According to Mr. Goldberg, that means that at least two current directors would be forced to step down this year. They are Mr. Goldberg himself and Happy Rockefeller, a longtime  friend of Mr. Andreas and the widow of Nelson A. Rockefeller. **********While a number of other directors will also have to step aside under the proposals, Mr. Goldberg indicated that no decision had yet been made by anyone. **********"Over the next few months, there will have to be a number of people who will  rethink what their appropriate role is on the board, and whether they should be  on the board," he said. "It will be for each individual member, together with the nominating committee, to figure out what's best for the company and its shareholders." **********The report also suggested that the compensation of directors be reviewed to insure that it is in line with that of other large companies. It said that health and retirement benefits should not be provided to any nonmanagement directors. To tie the interests of the directors to those of the shareholders, the report recommends that half the compensation of directors be in some form of company stock. **********Despite what apparently was the unanimous acceptance of the proposals, the company was skittish about disclosing any action. In a statement yesterday, Mr.  Andreas said that the report had his "strong support" and that he had requested  that the recommendations "be seriously reviewed and considered as the framework  for future implementation."He also said that the board would accept having more  outside directors. **********Also yesterday, Archer-Daniels said that its net income for the second quarter, which ended on Dec. 31, had risen 2.7 percent, to $226 million, or 43 cents a share. That compares with $220.1 million, or 41 cents a share, in the second quarter of last year. **********The company, which operates under a great deal of secrecy because many of its rivals are privately held, does not announce its revenue figures, but discloses  them later in filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. **********Analysts were impressed by the financial performance. "The numbers were surprisingly good," Mr. Teitelbaum of Merrill Lynch said. "The company is proving that it can run a business even in the most difficult environment."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/30/world.main_headline: Kohl Is an Iron Man, but the Price Is High
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/30/world.print_headline: Kohl Is an Iron Man, but the Price Is High
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/30/world.body_text: **********Helmut Kohl, who presided triumphantly over Germany's reunification in 1990, is about to become his country's longest serving Chancellor since Bismarck, who first fused the land 125 years ago. **********On Oct. 31, Mr. Kohl is to set the record as postwar Germany's most durable leader, surpassing Konrad Adenauer's 14 years from 1949 to 1963, when Germany was rebuilt from the ruins of war into a European powerhouse. But even at this moment of tribute, his longevity is beginning to exact a price. **********A central gamble of Mr. Kohl's 14 years in office -- his decision to cushion the pain of reunification with unparalleled financial largess -- has produced at best mixed results from the staggering $600 billion in subsidies, incentives and aid that has poured into the former East Germany in the last six years. **********The spending proved politically expedient for Mr. Kohl's electoral fortunes, but many economic analysts now say it was half-baked, tying Bonn to years of taxes and budget commitments that conflict increasingly with his defining vision of European unity forged in fiscal restraint. **********Mr. Kohl himself disarmingly acknowledged at his Christian Democratic party congress in Hanover this month that adding up the sums is not his strongest suit. But in a speech earlier to mark the sixth anniversary of reunification, even he finally admitted that fusing the two Germanys would take much longer than the five years in which, he once predicted, eastern Germany would become a place of ''blossoming landscapes.'' **********''The picture that Mr. Kohl painted in 1990 was too colorful, and was not based on facts and figures,'' said Christian Jacke, Leipzig's Economics Director. ''The five years have gone, and people are asking: where are these beautiful landscapes?'' **********The approach of the 66-year-old Mr. Kohl's record-setting anniversary has inspired much musing about precisely how a provincial politician beloved of solid food, labored jollity and postponed decisions took his place among Germany's titans. **********Mr. Kohl has not publicly discussed his political longevity in great detail, and he declined to be interviewed for this article. Those who chart his success, including even his adversaries in eastern Germany, point to his political prowess, a weak opposition and Germans' general satisfaction with the stability that has followed the fall of Communism. **********''There's a conservative way of thinking,'' said Lothar Tippach, the leader in Leipzig of the Democratic Socialist Party, the successor to the East German Communists. ''So the people say: We want stability, peace, no huge changes. We've had enough huge changes here already.'' **********But when they contemplate the fruits of reunification, many Germans still find it hard to look beyond a curtain of increasing bitterness between easterners, who tend to see westerners as exploiters, and westerners, who regard the east as an unworthy sinkhole for their tax money. **********Up to 35 percent of eastern Germans in towns like Dessau, 40 miles north of here, are without real work. Eastern German productivity is only half of the western level. Most worrying of all, a culture has taken root that puts subsidies from Bonn at the center of political and economic life. **********''Without subsidies and incentives, there'd be no investment at all,'' said Hans-George Otto, the Mayor of Dessau. **********In 1990, Mr. Kohl acted with uncharacteristic boldness to reunify his country, welding the two uneven sides of Germany with his decision to swap worthless East German marks for rock-solid Deutsche marks at a rate of one to one. **********Overnight, eastern Germans living for three generations under dictatorship -- first Hitler's, then the Communists' -- were propelled into a competitive western society that few could absorb. **********Politically, the decision was seen as inevitable and adroit. Indeed, such was the eastern German clamor for the coveted currency that Mr. Kohl saw no other options. But economists shuddered at the implications of long-term commitment to an eastern economy distorted by huge injections of money that it could not earn. **********For all the advances that have been made in roads, telephones, wages and prosperity in eastern Germany, a visitor's primary impression is of landscapes blossoming with construction cranes -- emblems of a building industry that has peaked -- and of contradictions. **********True, wage levels in the east have risen to 75 percent of those in the west. And eastern Germans are slowly beginning to produce and buy their own goods instead of importing virtually everything from the west. **********But as Government leaders in Bonn have begun to acknowledge, Government spending in the east will continue for years to come in business subsidies, early retirement pensions and unemployment benefits -- precisely the outlays that Mr. Kohl wants to reduce in preparation for a single European currency, a major step toward his all-consuming dream of European unity. **********And for the foreseeable future, the German taxpayer will continue to foot an unwelcome bill. Just this month the Bonn Government faced the embarrassment of postponing yet again a promised reduction in the hated 7.5 percent income tax surcharge that finances eastern development -- the exact opposite of the painless transition that Mr. Kohl once promised. **********Some specialists make a telling comparison with those Central European economies with which East Germany was once inextricably linked in the Comecon trade bloc. **********There, in countries like Poland and the Czech Republic, Mr. Jacke said, ''they have lower living standards, lower labor costs, lower standards of social services.'' **********''But they have built step by step and they have built by themselves,'' he added, ''which is not something that's happened in eastern Germany.'' **********''We have to ask whether the way we did things makes people move forward,'' he said, referring to the huge amounts of Government support. ''That's really the question: why should people move?'' **********Between them, Jorg Hofmann and Ursula Finke provide some answers to that question. **********For many years in East Germany, they were colleagues in the research section of Leuchtenbau Leipzig, a state-owned lighting company that employed 1,100 people and shipped street lamps and other products to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe under market-defying rules that blended barter with distorted exchange rates to balance Comecon's books. **********He was the boss of the department; she was a draftswoman. ''It wasn't good pay, it wasn't bad,'' said Mrs. Finke, 40. But it was steady. **********Then came the collapse of Communism and with it the instant crumbling of the controlled Comecon marketplace on which East Germany was totally dependent. **********Companies like Leuchtenbau Leipzig, and untold others in eastern Germany, were left with huge wage bills in a currency they did not have and could not earn, no new orders and a product line that could not compete against the corporate raiders from what Germans call the pushy ''elbow society'' of the west. **********''The competition was completely uneven,'' Mr. Jacke said. Not only that, Mayor Otto of Dessau said, the whole process of selling off bankrupt and run-down eastern German companies to private buyers wrote another dark and resentful chapter. **********In his own town, for instance, he said, a western company bought the local brewery for knock-down prices, sold off its assets, moved the production center to Munich, in western Germany, and flooded the market with its own brands. Faced with this invasion of capital and expertise and an overwhelming urge to crush potential challengers, he said, the local brewery simply died. **********These days Dessau's unemployment is 20.1 percent, twice the national level. But if other elements are factored in -- people sent into early retirement, on re-retraining courses and in Government-sponsored job programs -- the true figure is 35 percent: one in three people without real work. **********At Leuchtenbau Leipzig, the story was different because Mr. Hofmann got there first -- with a little help from friends. **********By 1993 only 130 of the Communist-era work force of 1,100 remained. The company had run up $20 million of debt. It went bankrupt. And that is when Mr. Hofmann and Mrs. Finke went their different ways -- he to join the fledgling ranks of small-business men, she to the unemployment lines, a destination she shared (and still shares) with many other women and older men. **********But Mr. Hofmann secured $400,000 in seed money from the local state government to buy equipment from Leuchtenbau Leipzig and set up his own company, Leipziger Leuchten. Modeling himself a little on the ''elbow society'' of the west, he quickly learned to pull political strings to secure orders and to play the game of securing government subsidies. **********''No one tells you how to do it, but you find out,'' he said. **********This year Mr. Hofmann, 49, turned what he called a ''very good'' profit on a turnover of $3.3 million -- respectable productivity ratings for a staff of 16 full-time employees -- and won the ''Golden Saxon'' award from the state authorities for his spirit of enterprise. **********Mrs. Finke, his colleague, has different memories. **********''It was a dark moment,'' she said. ''Nineteen years, and the people you were working with, your friends, all had to go.'' She went, too: first to the unemployment lines, then to a Government-financed job training program to qualify as a saleswoman for office equipment. **********Materially, the suffering was not too bad: her husband still had a job, and she was drawing unemployment pay. But to this day she has not found another job. **********Across the landscape of eastern Germany, it is people like Mr. Hofmann, not Mrs. Finke, who provide what Chancellor Kohl sees as the hope of the future -- just as it is small-  to medium-sized businesses that provide the backbone of the western German economy. **********But the Hofmanns and Finkes are a minority: surveying a rain-swept industrial park on Leipzig's outskirts, where his modest factory is located, Mr. Hofmann reckoned that he could count on one hand the number of home-grown eastern businesses there. **********Anywhere else, such stories of stuttering progress and future perils might spell political ruin for their author. **********But at their congress this month, Chancellor Kohl's Christian Democrats gave him a standing ovation for an uneventful speech and re-elected him as their leader with 95 percent of the vote -- in effect endorsing him for the 1998 national election and thus an opportunity for a fifth four-year term, outstripping even Bismarck's 19 years from 1871 to 1890 in Germany's political longevity stakes.

Under the aegis of Trade Representative Mickey Kantor, Wa...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/13/busin.main_headline: Thinking Ahead/Commentary : America Needs a Cure for Kantoritis
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/13/busin.print_headline: Thinking Ahead/Commentary : America Needs a Cure for Kantoritis
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/13/busin.body_text: **********U.S. trade policy is suffering from a bad case of Kantoritis — a debilitating disease whose symptoms include aggression, narrow-mindedness and an inability to see the forest for the trees. **********Under the aegis of Trade Representative Mickey Kantor, Washington's policy — particularly toward Japan — has been progressively reduced to a blunt assertion of the special interests of American business. Broader U.S. economic and strategic considerations have fallen from view. **********Mr. Kantor himself unabashedly discounts the need for any vision in his job. He sees his mandate as being to soldier on from one dispute to another, brandishing threats of retaliation and demands for reciprocity, in the hope of cracking open specific markets for American exporters. **********As Henry R. Nau writes in a new book, "Trade and Security," published by the American Enterprise Institute, "trade policy has been increasingly isolated from other U.S. foreign-policy interests in a single-minded pursuit to capture exports and high-wage jobs for the American economy." **********As a result, Mr. Nau says, "the standard of trade-policy success becomes a cellular-telephone agreement with Japan that benefits one American company (the 1993 agreement giving Motorola Inc. access to the Nagoya-Tokyo market), rather than a new post-Uruguay trade round that commits the United States, Japan and Europe to early integration with reforming countries in the former Communist and developing worlds." **********Instead of alienating its allies, Mr. Nau argues, Washington should make trade policy just one ingredient of a strategy to deal with potential threats to America's national security around the world and advance its overall political and economic interests. **********Mr. Nau ends up going too far with this. He suggests, for example, that the United States should allow China to join the World Trade Organization, as Japan and other Asian nations want, in exchange for Japanese and South Korean backing for efforts to rid North Korea of nuclear weapons. **********That loses sight of the main aim of the operation — to get China to accept the rules of the game in international trade — which has to be negotiated with China, not Japan. **********But Mr. Nau puts his finger on one key cause of Kantoritis. **********That is the widespread misconception that, with the Cold War over, the United States is at loggerheads with its industrial allies for a share of world trade and economic wealth, just as it was previously in military competition with the Soviet Union. **********That belief lies behind the "strategic trade" theories, so popular with President Bill Clinton's administration, which call for managed trade to carve up international markets, combined with interventionist domestic policies to protect and subsidize high-wage, advanced-technology industries, often patterned on the so-called Asian model. **********Although a conflicting, more free-trade-oriented strand of thinking led Mr. Clinton to support the North American Free Trade Agreement and the setting up of the World Trade Organization, that vision is increasingly losing out to special interests, Mr. Nau says. **********But trade rivalry among friends is not the same as military warfare. **********In an important sense, Mr. Nau writes, "the industrial nations already constitute a single democratic civil society or community in which major political or geopolitical conflicts do not exist." **********The interventionist approach ignores the dramatic improvement in U.S. competitiveness since the 1980s, which was due to free trade, competition and flexible labor and capital markets, not to "strategic trade" weaponry. **********"The American-British model of deregulation is at least a decade ahead of the Asian-German model of industrial policy in moving jobs and capital into the information economy," Mr. Nau writes. **********Rather than mimic the authoritarian Asian model, America should work with its allies to continue to liberalize world trade and bring more countries into the democratic, open-market fold. That also should help cure Kantoritis.

Slawomir Gorzkiewicz, who headed the invesitgation, said at a news conference. **********The investigation into the allegations caused Mr. Oleksy to resign in January. But after three months, Colonel Gorzkiewicz, the prosecutor, said he could establish "no direct proof" against Mr. Oleksy. **********The 49-year-old Mr. Oleksy, who has all along asserted his innocence, was not immediately available for comment. **********The espionage allegations first were leveled in Parliament in December after  President Lech Walesa lost his reelection bid to Aleksander Kwasniewski, a close friend of Mr. Oleksy and a party ally.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/08/news/.body_text: **********WIMBLEDON—                     In the roles of Boris Becker and Arthur Ashe were a Dutch son of Czech immigrants and a 27-year old African-American with four tournament victories in his life. **********They were augmented by the naked lady who, so far as Richard Krajicek was concerned, made the difference. **********Their final Sunday was the first in 110 years at Wimbledon between two unseeded men, and when Krajicek beat MaliVai Washington in 6-3, 6-4, 6-3, after three rain delays, he wasn't quite sure if he was right to be sliding to his knees in triumph. **********"For a split-second I thought, 'Is the match over? Am I making a fool out of myself?"' said Krajicek, 24, the first Dutchman to win a Grand Slam title. "But nobody was laughing so I knew it was all right." **********Later, while posing for photographers, Krajicek was trying to hold the trophy as if it were a baby when the lid fell off. Meanwhile Washington was pretending to toss his runners-up plate like a Frisbee and flashing his chest like the streaker who four hours earlier had helped start their match on the right foot. **********Krajicek's parents had him registered with the Dutch tennis federation by the time he was 6. Between them, Krajicek and Washington had 13 career titles — one-third as many as Pete Sampras, the three-time defending champion knocked out by Krajicek last week — and neither had any prospects of winning when the world's greatest tennis tournament began two weeks ago. **********Krajicek joined Becker, who was 17 when he won in 1985, as the only unseeded Wimbledon titlists. Though Krajicek was ranked 13th in the world — and will move into the Top 10 this week — he was not seeded among the top 16 because he had lost his opening match at Wimbledon each of the last two years. **********Washington, who had lost six of his nine Wimbledon matches before this year, was the first African-American finalist at Wimbledon since Ashe beat Jimmy Connors in 1975. **********"It's great when you can come into a tournament when everyone's there, all of the great players, and you're still standing at the end," said Washington, ranked 20th in the world when the tournament began. "For the fortnight, I was the second-best player in the world." **********It took the 6-foot-5-inch (1.96-meter) Krajicek 93 minutes to apply the same formula he had used against the 1991 champion Michael Stich and Sampras in earlier rounds. Krajicek has always had a big serve, averaging 118 miles an hour (189 kilometers an hour) in the final with 14 aces, but recently he added a strong return and the patience to pass from the baseline. He earned 11 break points, while conceding just 17 points on serve overall to Washington. **********They had never played each other, had never contested a Grand Slam final and between them had won just one tournament this year. **********Washington had his debut on Center Court just two days before. A little self-consciously they appeared Sunday behind a short man in a long white coat carrying their bags. The players had the look of two contest winners trying not to gawk at their five-star hotel. **********THEY WERE standing at the net for photographers, awkwardly trying to recreate the casual poses of more famous players, when a naked woman came streaking along the length of the grass floor and turned them from cardboard cut-outs into two men with the giggles. **********She was the first streaker ever to play Center Court, and Krajicek, among others, was happy to see her. He opened with one big serve after another as if he had never wondered whether he could make it this far. **********"I was a little bit tight," Krajicek said. "Then she comes out, and at least for me she put a smile on my face. For me it broke the tension." **********Krajicek ran up a 3-0 lead on big serves, forehands and overheads. But Washington admitted nothing. His service improved steadily, until by the start of the second set he was holding without deuce, largely because he was playing his second serve to Krajicek's weaker backhand. Krajicek was seven inches (16 centimeters) taller, but in pace and rhythm Washington might have been holding down Krajicek by the shoulders as the first interruption of rain came early in the second set. **********By then Washington's play at the net seemed to be withstanding the Dutch cannons. Born in New York, he was raised and coached in Michigan by his father, William Washington. The crowd revealed its support for him every time Washington punched an overhead or a forehand back at the bigger man. **********But it was all he could do to stay even with Krajicek. Over the next 77 minutes, only five were spent playing. If Krajicek had seemed nervous early in the second set, Washington thereafter lost the laser focus he needed. He fought off two break points in the ninth game of the second set before conceding serve to a trio of Krajicek forehands. **********Play was suspended for the third time after the opening game of the third set. Then Krajicek pounced, conceding one point in the next four games. **********Washington recovered one of the breaks, and for a moment he was reminding everyone of his semifinal comeback the day before, from 5-1 down in the fifth set to fellow American Todd Martin, the No. 13 and last surviving seed. **********Washington may have been expressing the sameresilience and poise, but the opponent was completely different. Martin had double-faulted three times while helping Washington to draw level on his way to the decisive set in 10-8. Krajicek was of no such mind. **********When Washington threw him a scare with a terrific backhand pass that wove its way inside the line, Krajicek responded with an attribute borrowed from Sampras. He came up with a pair of timely serves to bring him within four points of the title. Krajicek converted his second match point against Washington's serve with a deep forehand that Washington swept into the net.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/27/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;TBWA Chiat/Day Shifts Top Managers
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/27/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;TBWA Chiat/Day Shifts Top Managers
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/27/busin.body_text: **********The TBWA Chiat/Day unit of TBWA International, formed last year by the merger of Chiat/Day and TBWA Advertising, is shifting top managers as another step in efforts to integrate the two agencies. **********Ira Matathia, who had been president of the New York office of TBWA Chiat/Day, was named to the new position of chairman at TBWA Milan in Italy. Mr. Matathia, 46, who had headed the New York office of Chiat/ Day before the merger, will report to Alasdair Ritchie, president of TBWA Europe in London. **********Mary Maroun, 40, an account director at the New York office of TBWA Chiat/Day, was promoted to the new position of managing director there; no one will assume Mr. Matathia's position as president. Ms. Maroun will join with Marty Cooke, the creative director, to oversee to day-to-day management; they will report to Richard Costello, president and chief executive of TBWA Chiat/ Day East. Trade publications attributed Mr. Matathia's move to problems stemming from the overlapping of his responsibilities with Mr. Costello's, but both executives yesterday dismissed those reports. They said Mr. Matathia's new position represented new responsibilities for the executive.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/14/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********Times have not changed all that much in regard to early graduation. While an  undergraduate at the University of Pennsylvania from 1972 to 1976, I saw most of my friends graduate in fewer than four years, in part for the reasons described  by Amy Wu. Education was expensive then, too, and accelerated graduation, along  with part-time work and scholarship or loan assistance, was a reasonable option  for mitigating cost. There were also other reasons for early graduation, like the desire to begin a career or graduate study as soon as possible. **********The difference seems to be that those of us who chose to accelerate our educations by a semester or a year did so as a positive choice. As I recall, we  still had plenty of opportunities to go to parties, make lifelong friendships and discuss philosophy on the lawn. **********As I approach my 20th reunion this year, I certainly see my greatest achievement of college as far more than saving money. **********LINDA F. WILLING Lyons, Colo., March 7

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/22/busin.snippet: As more and more companies offer stock plans to their workers, Wall Stree firms are vying for piece of booming business; led by Merrill Lynch and Smith Barney, brokerage firms are negotiating exclusive contracts--sometimes known as captive-broker ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/22/busin.main_headline: Buy Your Company's Stock Plan And Get a 'Captive Broker,' Too
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/22/busin.print_headline: Buy Your Company's Stock Plan And Get a 'Captive Broker,' Too
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/22/busin.body_text: **********WHEN an employee buys stock as part of a company plan these days, he is likely to get something else -- a new stockbroker. **********As more and more companies offer stock plans to their workers, Wall Street firms are vying for a piece of the booming business. Led by Merrill Lynch and Smith Barney, the brokerage firms are negotiating exclusive contracts -- sometimes known as captive-broker arrangements -- with companies to handle the stock-plan transactions for employees. In the process, they hope to become the employees' broker of choice. **********The practice has been embraced by a number of companies, including GTE, Corning and Delta Air Lines. In many cases, the companies save time and money by having the brokerage firms take over much of the plans' administrative work. Whether the arrangements prove to be good deals for workers, though, depends in large part on the terms each company strikes with the brokerage firm. **********The most common type of plan is an employee stock purchase plan, which encourages workers to buy company stock, often with discounts of up to 15 percent off the market price. Employees decide what percentage of their salaries to invest in the plan, and the money is withheld from their paychecks. Traditionally, employers have mailed stock certificates to employees who have put them into safe-deposit boxes or sent them to the stockbrokers of their choice. According to Merrill Lynch, 43 percent of public companies offered stock purchase plans in 1995 -- up from 32 percent in the late 1980's. **********Stock option plans, once reserved for the upper echelons of corporate America, are now available to more and more workers. Just last week, Chase Manhattan Bank said it would make stock options available to all its 67,000 employees. **********Such programs give employees the right, say for a 10-year period, to buy a set number of shares at a specified price. If the stock rises, employees profit by exercising the option to buy it at the preset price and then reselling it at the higher market price. Participants usually receive a rule book on exercising options, then find a broker to execute the transaction. **********Brokerage firms offer to simplify the process. With stock purchase plans, employers funnel shares directly into brokerage accounts at the captive firm instead of mailing stock certificates to employees. With stock option plans, employers tell employees to get in touch with the captive firm, which then helps them exercise their options. As part of an exclusive arrangement, the broker usually lowers its commissions. **********For companies, the practice may eliminate a number of headaches. ''It's an administrative nightmare to try to operate a program where every employee could choose their own brokers,'' said Claude Johnston, managing director of Pearl Meyer & Partners, a New York consulting firm on compensation. **********Along with time and money saved by shifting the record-keeping to a brokerage firm, companies may get a tax benefit. Under current tax law, companies generally can deduct as a compensation expense the discount an employee gets on company stock, provided that he sells the stock within a year of purchase or within two years of becoming eligible to buy it. So if an employee pays $1,000 for stock with a market value of $3,000, and then sells it within a year for $3,000 or more, the company can deduct $2,000 as an expense. **********''If a company issues certificates to employees, it's very difficult for the company to track when people sell,'' said Paul Allen, director of equity plan services at Smith Barney in New York. ''Because we hold the shares and people have to call us to sell them, we can report that activity back to the company.'' **********The commissions that captive brokers charge to sell company stock can be much lower than those they charge ordinary customers. So, many employees may get a better deal than they would if they walked into a full-service brokerage firm to execute the transactions. **********BUT savvy investors may do even better by transferring their stock to a broker outside the system, especially with stock purchase plans. ''As with any other stock investment,'' said Martin Nissenbaum, a partner at Ernst & Young in New York, ''you want to minimize your costs and shop around.'' **********Captive brokers' rates tend to be most competitive in exercising stock options. While the fees vary, they often rival those of the deep-discount brokerage firms. Employees with many options and shares, though, may still be able to arrange better deals elsewhere. **********The captive brokers may be less competitive when it comes to a regular stock purchase plan. Employees at Cisco Systems, the high-technology company in San Jose, Calif., have reason to smile about their plan. They pay a flat administrative fee of $4 and no commission when they sell shares through their captive broker, Smith Barney. But employees of Earthgrains, a baking goods company in St. Louis, pay commissions to the plan's broker, Merrill Lynch, that are only about 20 percent lower than the firm's retail rates, according to the company's director of human resources. Transferring shares to a deep-discount brokerage firm, like Jack White or E*trade, and then selling them might be less expensive for its workers. **********THERE is almost always a way to transfer shares to another broker. But in some plans administered by Smith Barney, at least, transfers are discouraged. In those plans, Smith Barney requires employees to request stock certificates, perhaps at a $15 fee. This fee could wipe out the financial benefit of switching to another broker; moreover, losing one to four weeks for such a transaction could cause an employee to miss a market upturn. **********''It's not the $15 that irritates many people,'' said Peter Van Ness, president of Stock Plan Inc., a stock-benefits-plan management company based in Santa Clara, Calif. ''It's the idea that you have the hassle of making the transfer, and to add insult to injury you have to pay for it.'' **********To be sure, many employees are happy with the arrangement. ''Now employees can exercise their options or sell their shares with a single phone call,'' said Robert Salwen, a principal at the Executive Compensation Corporation, a management consulting firm in White Plains. **********Convenience and simplicity are  important for companies like Chase, Bank America and GTE that are starting option programs for lower-level employees -- many of whom are inexperienced investors. **********Some industry experts say employees' negative reactions to captive-broker arrangements have been similar to their reactions to managed health care. Roger Mastako, managing director of Options Link, a San Francisco firm that manages stock plans, said, ''Employees get grumpy when their choices are taken away from them.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/06/busin.main_headline: Ford to Offer Cheaper Cars As Sales Sag
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/06/busin.print_headline: Ford to Offer Cheaper Cars As Sales Sag
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/06/busin.body_text: **********The Ford Motor Company said today that it would begin selling a lower-cost version of its redesigned Taurus sedan as it reported that its sales of cars and light trucks dropped in January, pushing the pace of total industry sales into negative territory, compared with levels a year ago. **********The cheaper Taurus -- which will be $605, or some 3 percent, less than the starting point for a Taurus now -- will be a new car called the Taurus G. It represents the latest retreat by Ford from its strategy of building ever-fancier cars and trucks and charging premium prices for them. Last month, as Taurus sales got off to a disappointing start for the year, Ford announced a $600 rebate through April 2. **********Ford has poured billions of dollars into developing sophisticated engines, transmissions and suspensions that are costly to manufacture, only to find that  it is introducing them when consumers are especially price sensitive. **********With sales of Taurus and its sibling, the Mercury Sable, down last month, Ford said that its total sales of cars and light trucks fell 3.4 percent in January from a year earlier. That follows a report on Friday by the Toyota Motor Corporation that its January sales plummeted 17.3 percent from a year earlier. Toyota attributed the decline to a decision to offer fewer discounts this year. **********But total-vehicle sales do seem to be holding up at the Chrysler Corporation  and, to a lesser extent, the General Motors Corporation. Indeed, G.M. provided another sign of its continuing recovery today as its board voted to increase the quarterly dividend on common stock to 40 cents a share from 30 cents, effective Feb. 15. [Page D9.] **********For the entire industry, the negative reports from Ford and Toyota mean that  the overall sales rate fell 1.6 percent in January from a year earlier. Percentage calculations are based on a daily selling rate because showrooms were open one more day last month than in January 1995. **********The latest data were a contrast to January reports from a dozen other auto makers last Thursday that showed a slight sales gain from a year earlier. Those  reports had prompted Wall Street analysts to declare that sales seemed to be relatively resilient despite signs of weakness in the economy. **********At Ford, the new Taurus G is scheduled for introduction on April 3, the day after the rebates are set to expire, and will have a base price of $18,545, including destination charges. That compares with $19,150 for the cheapest version of the Taurus GL, the best-selling car in the United States. Ford will also offer a less expensive version of the Mercury Sable, which is quite similar to the Taurus. **********Even in the G version, the Taurus will remain more expensive than a Chevrolet Lumina sedan, but less expensive than the Toyota Camry or the Honda Accord. G.M. officials quickly pointed out today that the Lumina price starts at $16,895, which is $1,650 less than the Taurus G. The Lumina is "priced correctly for the marketplace," said William J. O'Neill Jr., a Chevrolet spokesman. **********Many car shoppers have said that the new, bubble-shaped Taurus, which went on sale in September, feels smaller inside than its predecessor although Ford engineers insist that the vehicle has slightly more room. **********Ford officials have scrambled in the last two months to come up with the Taurus G, which will be available only in white, red, gray, silver and green for the exterior, while all of the interiors will be gray, the most popular color. The mirrors and side moldings will be black only, instead of matching the paint  color as they do in other Taurus models. **********Some popular options will not be offered on the Taurus G, as a way to limit the number of buyers who choose the less expensive vehicle. Standard equipment will include an AM-FM stereo radio, air-conditioning, dual air bags and a 3.0 liter V-6 engine with automatic transmission. **********Robert Rewey, Ford's group vice president for marketing and sales, predicted  that the G version will account for only 5 to 10 percent of all Taurus cars sold. He said that the company had not overpriced the original vehicle but that  public reaction had produced considerable concern among Ford dealers. **********"We're responding to a lot of coverage in the press and elsewhere about where the Taurus is positioned," he said in an interview today. Ford's overall pricing strategy remains in place, he said, adding that the decision to offer the Taurus G and the decision last month to offer discounts on half of Ford's product line  represented isolated responses to market needs. **********The daily rate of Taurus sales fell by 3.5 percent in January from the previous year, still a better showing than that of many other Ford models. But Christopher W. Cedergren, a consultant at AutoPacific Group, in Santa Ana, Calif., said the Taurus sales were unimpressive in light of the incentives being offered. **********"Given the $600 rebate, they probably should have done more," he said. **********Mr. Rewey said that small-car sales were the weakest last month, while the F-150 pickup truck, the Ford Explorer sport-utility vehicle and the Ford Contour sedan all sold well, as did the large Ford, Lincoln and Mercury cars. **********Ford dealers today played down the importance of the weak sales. January sales were "maybe a little softer than we normally have," said Larry V. Sexton,  a dealer in St. Roberts, Mo. "It's not like the bottom fell out."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/19/news/.main_headline: Genetic Screening: An Unsettling Battle Is Joined
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/19/news/.print_headline: Genetic Screening: An Unsettling Battle Is Joined
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/19/news/.body_text: **********LONDON—                     Five years ago, Jamie Stephenson, a New Hampshire writer and her husband, Jonathan, a dentist, got a nasty shock. Their new health insurer suddenly dropped them after re-examining their file. **********"They told us that they would not write health insurance for anyone who has a positive genetic test," said Mrs. Stephenson. Three years earlier, the Stephensons' 2-year-old son, David, had tested positive for "fragile X" syndrome, an inherited form of mental retardation. Never mind that David's three siblings and his parents had no known genetic problems, and that David's condition had no impact on his physical health. Never mind also that a family of six might actually need health insurance. **********The Stephensons had been stigmatized as untouchable bya positive genetic test. **********Inspired by the case of the Stephensons and others, in 1995, New Hampshire barred employers and health insurers from discriminating on the basis of genetic information. A dozen other American states have now followed suit. **********Yet even gene rights activists admit that such moves mark little more than isolated victories in what now looms as a long and fierce war over the control and use of genetic information. **********At issue are the individual's rights to genetic privacy, or at the very least the right to prevent others from using the secrets of one's genetic makeup to deny equal access to everything from a job to a mortgage. Insurers around the world are now fiercely contesting that right by increasingly demanding nothing less than full and open access to genetic information. **********Fueling the battle are the almost daily leaps in the understanding of scientists of the roles specific genes play in diseases along and the fact that obtaining genetic information can be as simple as analyzing a strand of human hair or a mouth swab. **********After four years of wrangling, a committee of the International Bar Association will examine this legal and ethical morass beginning Monday. After three days of meetings in Berlin's International Congress Center, the lawyers hope to emerge with the bare bones of a draft international treaty setting out minimum legal standards for the use of genetic information. And drafting meaningful legislation has proven devilishly difficult. "After four years we do not agree on everything," said Martine Rothblatt, the Washington lawyer who chairs the International Bar's Bioethics Subcommittee. "But we agree on a lot more than nothing." **********Broad agreement exists that genetic information sould enjoy the same legal protections as our sexual orientation or racial identity. In other words, that regardless of what their genes say, individuals should have an equal right to a job, a vote and health care coverage. **********But the consensus ends when it comes to the issue of life insurance. **********"It is one of the points we do not agree on," said Ms. Rothblatt. **********Life insurance executives such as Robert Pakorski, a vice president for medical research at Swiss Re in Connecticut, are adamant that anything less than full access to genetic tests would be "devastating" for the industry. **********If, for instance, genetic tests reveal, as they now can, that a perfectly healthy young woman has an 80 percent chance of contracting breast cancer, she now has a right to keep her health insurance in many American states. But what about her life insurance? Can she keep what she has? Can she cushion the financial blow her premature death would cause her family by taking out a huge life policy and taking advantage of information her insurance company does not have? Or does her insurer have a right to see that information? **********Take the example of a 30 year-old male with no known health risks. Mr. Pakorski notes that a $100,000 life insurance policy would carry a premium of around $125 a month. If that person knew from genetic tests that he would only live another five to ten years, that policy would represent a tremendous risk to the insurer. **********Mr. Pakorski calculates that just to break even on the policy after ten years, the insurer would need to charge an annual premium of $5,704 a year. The insurer would have to charge three times as much, or $14,891 a year, if it knew their policy holder would die after five years. It is a danger insurers call "adverse selection" — a process whereby otherwise healthy people load up on life insurance after genetic tests tell them they face shortened lives. **********In Europe, where health costs are borne not by private insurers but by national entitlement plans, the debate over genetic discrimination has focused almost exclusively on life insurance. **********Unlike Americans, Europeans seem more willing, for the time being anyway, to strike a compromise. **********A prime example of this trend is the Netherlands. In 1990, Dutch life insurers agreed to a moratorium under which they excluded genetic information from their premium calculations for policies up to 200,000 guilders ($115,000). **********That compromise addresses both insurers' fears of being taken to the cleaners by their genetically tested policy holders, and growing government concerns over the adverse effects the discrimination controversy could have on public health. **********"Governments fear that unless there is a workable compromise people will be put off from getting tests that could improve their health," said David Shapiro, executive secretary of the Nuffield Council on Bioethics in London. **********Individuals found to have a genetic predisposition to heart disease, for instance, could take that early warning, exercise more, eat less fatty foods, and thereby greatly extend their life expectancy. If on the other hand they worried that a bad genetic test result could cost them their life insurance, or possibly even their job, they might just skip the test. **********That may be an increasingly rare luxury, however. Some experts forecast that genetic tests will become as common as tests analyzing cholesterol levels are today. Already, donors at many in vitro fertilization clinics are routinely screened not just for human immuno-deficiency virus and venereal diseases, but for genetic conditions such as those leading to cystic fibrosis. **********"It is up to the clinic to tell the donors the results and to offer counseling if necessary," said Barry Mellars, an executive with University Diagnostics, a London-based genetic testing firm that charges £65 for its tests and uses a sample of mouthwash sloshed around a patient's mouth as raw material. **********In recent years, insurance companies have balked at asking would-be policy holders to have their genes screened, in large part because of the high cost and limited usefulness of such tests. Cheaper, more accurate tests may cause them to reassess that decision. **********Still, said Paul Smee, head of life insurance at the Association of British Insurers, "It is tomorrow's problem not today's." But the speed with which tomorrow is now hurtling toward us all is frightening to many. **********"Most disease has a genetic component," said Dr. Neil Holtzman a professor at Johns Hopkins Medical School in Baltimore, and the chairman of a high level U.S. government task force on genetic testing. "The big question is how powerful are those genetic factors."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/18/world.snippet: UN General Assembly begins 51st session without ceremony, in financial crisis and with uncertainty over who Secertary General will be when session ends on Dec 23 (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/18/world.main_headline: With Little Fanfare and Facing Crisis, U.N. Starts a New Year
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/18/world.print_headline: With Little Fanfare and Facing Crisis, U.N. Starts a New Year
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/18/world.body_text: **********Its difficult 50th birthday party over, the United Nations opened the 51st session of the General Assembly today without ceremony, in financial crisis and with no idea who its Secretary General will be when this session ends on Dec. 23. **********''The United Nations General Assembly begins its 51st session without celebration but amidst criticism of the U.N.'s inability to respond adequately to international crises,'' the Assembly's new president, Razali Ismail of Malaysia, said in his opening speech. Mr. Razali, an outspoken diplomat who has represented Malaysia here for eight years, said that in this environment, he hoped that the ''business as usual'' syndrome would go. **********''Delays and long lunches which lead to more delays, at enormous cost, are over,'' he said. ''So too, I trust, the torture of long, unfocused speeches.'' **********A high point of this annual meeting of leaders of 185 nations will come next Tuesday, when President Clinton plans to be the first to sign a treaty banning all nuclear test explosions. The Clinton Administration has been pressing for the treaty, which was approved by 158 countries  a week ago, for the last three years. **********Otherwise, it is not such a good time to be an American diplomat or official at the United Nations this year. Washington is responsible for more than half the $2.8 billion debt owed to the organization. Congress has attached conditions to American participation in peacekeeping and other international activities. Republicans and Democrats alike are demanding that Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali step down or be ousted by an American veto. **********''It is great to be back from vacation,'' Mr. Boutros-Ghali said, darkly satirizing his critics at a lunch today. ''Frankly, I get bored on vacation. It's much more fun to be at work here blocking reform, flying my black helicopters, imposing global taxes, demoralizing my staff.'' **********When the 50th General Assembly opened a year ago, there were high hopes that the anniversary would spur reform. Working groups representing a range of member states were set up to look at changes in the organization's component parts and how to improve its financial status. **********In recent days, however, committee after committee has reported no real progress because of disagreements among member countries. Only the Secretariat, the permanent civil service, has taken steps to cut back on its size and spending. **********Changes in the Security Council seem a dead or dying issue because most nations rejected the proposal backed by the Clinton Administration to add Germany and Japan to the Council as permanent members and make room for some major developing nations without the same privileges. **********There are no substantive plans for overhauling the General Assembly, now a plodding agglomeration of special interests grown to three times the size it was when the United Nations was founded in 1945. Much of the spending and duplication of efforts for which the United Nations is criticized originates in Assembly resolutions. **********''Member states have announced they would reform the organization, but now they must deliver,'' said Diogo Freitas do Amaral, the Portuguese law professor and political leader who was president of the 50th Assembly. ''The world expects this. The issues cannot just be endlessly debated. There must be action. And there must be action soon.'' **********Mr. Razali, the new Assembly president, picked up the theme, saying the ''reform process must begin with finding a political consensus on what the U.N. should be and what it can do.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/17/busin.main_headline: F.C.C. Sells Wireless Licenses for $905 Million
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/17/busin.print_headline: F.C.C. Sells Wireless Licenses for $905 Million
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/17/busin.body_text: **********A Federal auction ended today with seven companies pledging $905 million for  licenses to provide the next generation of mobile telephone and data services. **********The Federal Communications Commission put the 18 licenses on the auction block after two companies defaulted on license payments. The licenses fetched $30 million more in the second auction than the first, the F.C.C. said. **********This auction proves that our reruns get the same reviews as our first-run shows," Reed E. Hundt, the F.C.C. chairman, said. The F.C.C. has raised more than $20 billion in the last two years through auctions for wireless services including personal communications services, also known as P.C.S.; wireless cable TV, and other dispatching services. **********Today's top bidder was Nextwave Personal Communications Inc. of San Diego, which put up $542.5 million for seven licenses in Seattle, Bellingham, Olympia and Longview, Wash.; Portland, Ore.; Denver, and Minneapolis. **********Alan Salmasi, Nextwave's chairman and chief executive, said the new licenses  put the company "in a position to offer P.C.S. to customers in all four corners  of the country." **********Bidding ended after 25 rounds. The auction began July 3. **********The original winners, a Questcom Inc. subsidiary, BDPCS Inc., and National Telecom PCS Inc., lost the licenses after failing to pay required down payments  on their $874 million bids.    CH PCS was the second-highest bidder, offering $214 million for a license in  Phoenix. Magnacom Wireless L.L.C. followed with $109 million for licenses in Eugene and Salem, Ore.; Tucson, Ariz., and Albuquerque and Santa Fe, N.M. **********Mountain Solutions pledged $24 million for licenses in Colorado Springs and Fort Collins, Colo.; Cook Inlet Western Wireless offered $9.2 million for a license in Bremerton, Wash.; the Redwood Wireless Corporation pledged $7 million for the license covering St. Cloud, Minn., and Westel won the license for American Samoa with $170,250. **********The auction was open only to small businesses. **********Licenses are for personal communications operations that include a new phone  service, which is supposed to be more mobile and less expensive than existing cellular services. It also includes two-way paging and messaging.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/22/world.main_headline: Afrikaners Try to Stand in the Schoolhouse Door
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/22/world.print_headline: Afrikaners Try to Stand in the Schoolhouse Door
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/22/world.body_text: **********Surrounded by television cameras and reporters, Meiki Kekana wasn't trying to hide her sense of triumph today as she walked her 7-year-old son through the doors of the all-white public elementary school here and enrolled him for classes. **********The school's reception area, with its lace curtains and trophy cases, was filled with other black parents doing the same thing. And senior Government officials were on hand to make sure the white principal came out of his office to personally process the paperwork. **********This is a very good day," said Mrs. Kekana, looking around at the school. "My son will have the best education now." **********Only an hour before, the police had had to remove dozens of white Afrikaner families who had stood at the school's entrances trying to prevent the black families from entering. And, as the blacks mingled inside, the whites gathered again outside, saying they would continue their fight. **********In the 20 months since South Africa held its first democratic elections, sweeping a black President into office and adopting an interim constitution that prohibits racial discrimination, many of the country's schools have been integrated without difficulty. **********But in hundreds of small towns like Potgietersrus, dominated by conservative  Afrikaners, little progress has been made. **********Last month, Afrikaner parents forced away three young black children who had  arrived for their first day of classes here, in an incident that has outraged Government officials and highlighted the depths of the Afrikaner resistance to change. The Government promptly took the school to court charging racial discrimination, but the Afrikaners have filed a counterclaim arguing that, as members of a minority group, they have the right to protect their culture. **********For the black families, access to the school represents their right to share  in South Africa's wealth. The Potgietersrus elementary school is a cozy-looking  two-story building with computers, sports fields and a pool, a far cry from the  rundown barracks the country's former apartheid Government provided for blacks.  A few miles away, the classrooms in the former black township are so crowded that teachers barely have room to walk between the blackboard and the front row  of desks. **********But for many Afrikaners, the forced integration of their schools is one more  assault on the way of life they have cherished and now see crumbling. No longer  in control of the Government, they are forced to face the fact that they represent a mere 3 percent of the population. **********Parents of schoolchildren say they are worried about being overwhelmed and unable to maintain the Afrikaner way of life, which includes the use of the Afrikaans language and a deep belief in Christianity. **********"This is where it counts," said Koos Nel, a car dealer who is the head of the school's parents committee. "These are our children. I know to the outside world we look horrible -- a big school of 700 not letting in 3 blacks. But we are looking at this long term. To us this is just the edge of the wedge." **********So far the Afrikaner parents have lost two court rulings, the latest one announced today. They intend to take the case to the country's highest court, but meanwhile Government officials insisted that some black children be enrolled immediately and begin classes as early as Thursday. **********[At least 18 black children attended the school on Thursday, Reuters reported.] **********"We took the legal route because we felt it was needed to show the utmost respect for the law," said Ngoako Ramathlodi, the premier of the Northern Province, which includes Potgietersrus. "We were prepared to wait for a certain  time but now they must wait for the rest of the process." **********Mr. Ramathlodi said the Government would provide police protection for the children coming into the schoolyard and that there would be monitors in the school at all times to make sure that they were being properly treated. "We are  going to flex our muscle here," Mr. Ramathlodi said. **********The struggle over the school in Potgietersrus began subtly enough -- black parents who came to apply were simply told there wasn't any room. But then, last month, the school's principal agreed to enroll the children of Alson Matukane, without first notifying the school's parents committee. **********However, when Mr. Matukane arrived with the children the next morning the white parents had found out about their enrollment and were waiting for them, blocking their way. Mr. Matukane said one man grabbed his arm, put his own next  to it and pointed out the difference in their colors. **********"God made us differently" the man said. "We do not belong together." Others in the crowd simply shouted insults until Mr. Matukane retreated. **********A few days later, Mr. Matukane found that the house he had been preparing to  move into in the white section of town was covered with threatening graffiti. For this reason, he is still living in a hotel. He says his children have told him that they no longer want to attend the Potgietersrus elementary school and he is not sure he will send them. **********"They will always be pointed at as the kids who caused all this havoc," Mr. Matukane said. "That is a problem for them." **********But other black parents who registered today said they could not pass up the  opportunity. Mrs. Kekana said her son, Karabo, had also not wanted to come to this school, but she told him about the pool and particularly the music classes. **********"I think in a month everything will be all right," Mrs. Kekana said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/28/busin.snippet: Prudential Corp of Britain is selling its Mercantile & General reinsurance unit to Swiss Reinsurance Co for 1.75 billion pounds ($2.7 billion)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/28/busin.main_headline: Prudential of Britain Sells Reinsurance Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/28/busin.print_headline: Prudential of Britain Sells Reinsurance Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/28/busin.body_text: **********The big British insurer the Prudential Corporation said today that it was selling its reinsurance subsidiary, Mercantile and General, to the Swiss Reinsurance Company for $:1.75 billion ($2.7 billion), making the Swiss company the world's largest life and health reinsurer. **********''That's a very high price,'' said Eamonn Flanagan, an analyst at Charterhouse Tilney Securities, adding that it is a ''superb business,'' particularly in life reinsurance. **********The move comes amid global consolidation in reinsurance as the growth of the biggest reinsurers squeezes out smaller businesses. In total reinsurance premium income, Swiss Re is second only to Munich Re, which solidified its global lead on Aug. 14 with the $4 billion purchase of the American Re Corporation. **********Swiss Re shares rose 2.6 percent, or 33 Swiss francs, to 1,303 ($1,094) in Switzerland. Shares of Prudential, which is not related to the Prudential Insurance Company of America,  rose as much as 8.5 pence, to $:4.455 ($6.87). The shares have climbed 5.6 percent in the last week on speculation that Prudential would decide to sell the unit. **********In recent years, Swiss Re has tried to cut its exposure to catastrophe losses and increase its business in life and health reinsurance.
