https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/09/busin.body_text: **********Stocks continued to rise yesterday, pushing stock indexes to record highs for the fourth consecutive session, even as the market confounded professional investors who have been baffled by its recent gains. **********The Dow Jones industrial average moved above the 5,500-point level for the first time, finishing ahead 47.33 at 5,539.45. Records were also set by the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which closed at 656.07, up 6.14, and by the Nasdaq composite index, which was up 8.29, to 1,093.17. **********Following a recent trading pattern, prices yesterday weakened in the morning, stabilized in the early afternoon and then surged -- especially in the  larger, blue-chip stocks -- just before the close. **********"What is interesting is that the focus changes every day," said E. Wayne Nordberg, equity partner at Lord, Abbett & Company in New York. "It's extremely  volatile on a day-to-day basis. There is no real leadership that has emerged in  the advance this year." **********Mr. Nordberg credited lower interest rates and a sluggish economy with creating a large pool of cash with little place to go but the financial markets. As consumers pay their debts and companies sell off inventories of goods, the money is flowing into stocks, a situation he does not see changing until the economy begins to pick up perhaps later this year. **********"This is a classic liquidity-driven market," he said. **********Advancing stocks outpaced decliners on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, 1,330 to 953. Issues reaching new highs totaled 230, while only 14 set new lows. **********The New York Stock Exchange Index was up 2.83 points, to 349.15. The American Stock Exchange composite index closed at 564.66, up 2.07. **********The market's strength so far this year -- the Dow is up 8.3 percent since Jan. 1 -- has wreaked havoc on the full-year forecasts of several of Wall Street's most well-known strategists. Many had predicted that share prices, which soared in 1995, would level off this year as corporate earnings growth declined. **********"The amateurs are outdoing the professional so far this year," said Robert H. Stovall, president of Stovall/21st Advisers in New York. **********With interest rates declining, shares of banking companies were strong. Wells Fargo rose 5, to 258 1/4, and Nationsbank, added 3, to 73 1/2. **********Investors also favored consumer goods companies like Coca-Cola, which closed  at a record 80 1/4, up 2 1/4. Gillette rose 1, to 56 1/4, while Kellogg gained 2 to close at 78 7/8. **********Oil companies were also among the big winners yesterday. Exxon gained 1 7/8,  to 82 5/8, while Chevron was up 11/64 , to 53. **********Normally when energy companies gain, industrial stocks slide. But some of the biggest industrials were up yesterday, including Caterpillar, which gained 1 1/4, to 65 1/8, and Allied Signal, which was up 1 1/8, to 54 5/8. **********Telephone companies, which were among the big gainers in Wednesday's trading, slipped back yesterday. Nynex was off 3 3/8, to 55 7/8, on reports that it was joining Bell Atlantic to offer long-distance service. Bell Atlantic lost 1/2 to  close at 71 7/8. **********Technology stocks, which also had a big rise earlier in the week, were down for the second consecutive day. Micron Technology, which was the day's most active issue, fell 1 1/2, to 39 7/8; Intel was down 3/8, to 57 7/8 in Nasdaq trading, while Motorola, which makes both semiconductors and cellular phones, fell 5/8, to 57. **********Not all technology issues stumbled. I.B.M., which has seen a strong rise since its fourth-quarter results were announced in mid-January, rose again yesterday, closing at 113 1/2, up 7/8.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/08/world.main_headline: Election Fraud Charges Filed Against Mexico's Ruling Party
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/08/world.print_headline: Election Fraud Charges Filed Against Mexico's Ruling Party
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/08/world.body_text: **********Prosecutors here say they have determined that the governing party spent $38.8 million -- more than 30 times the legal amount -- to win a 1994 election in Tabasco, a crucial oil state where the opposition has been pressing accusations of electoral fraud. **********The Attorney General filed criminal charges late Thursday against ruling party and Government officials in Tabasco for fiscal fraud. At issue is some of  the money spent on the campaign of Roberto Madrazo Pintado, who is now Governor  of the Gulf state. **********Mr. Madrazo, with an overwhelming blitz of advertisements, giveaways and patronage favors to voters, won the election over a leftist opponent. **********The sum invested by the Party of the Institutional Revolution, known as the PRI, was almost 33 times the legal spending limit and $37 million more than the  campaign declared. **********The case is haunting President Ernesto Zedillo, also of the ruling party, who is trying to persuade Mexicans that the party, which has governed for six decades, can reform itself and is willing to stand in clean and democratic elections. **********But what happened in Tabasco is a nagging reminder to voters of how far the ruling party has gone and how much money it can mobilize to control the polls. **********Governor Madrazo, a longtime ruling party militant, has openly defied President Zedillo's reform efforts by suing him to block federal authorities from investigating the case. The Supreme Court threw out Governor Madrazo's suit in March. **********The attorney general's action left considerable doubt about whether the case  will ever be fully prosecuted. Prosecutors decided to entrust to state justice officials in Tabasco the inquiry into the origin of most of the funds. And most  of the state justice officials are associates and appointees of Mr. Madrazo. **********The attorney general's investigation began with an especially strange episode in the long history of accusations of fraud against the governing party. **********An anonymous whistle-blower deposited 21 boxes of financial records from the  Tabasco campaign in the main square of Mexico City during a rally by the Party of the Democratic Revolution, a leftist opposition group, in June 1995. **********Using these documents, investigators found that virtually all of the nearly $40 million spent on the campaign was cash in the form of pesos. They were not able to determine whether any of the money came from public coffers, as the opposition has charged. **********Despite the rich petroleum industry centered in Tabasco, an average worker there doesn't make more than a few thousand dollars in a year. **********Fewer than 500,000 people voted in the election. **********The investigation uncovered a direct link between Mr. Madrazo's campaign and  the biggest bank fraud currently before Mexican financial authorities. **********The investigators discovered that $4.5 million was illegally funneled through a trust in Mr. Madrazo's name held in a bank that belonged to financier Carlos Cabal Peniche. **********Mr. Cabal, a Tabasco native, is accused in Mexico of stealing $700 million from his own banks through insider loans and has been an international fugitive  since 1994. **********Opposition leaders today renewed their calls for Mr. Madrazo to resign as governor. Since 1994 the leftist opposition has led a series of rowdy civil disobedience campaigns in Tabasco to force Mr. Madrazo out. **********Today Felipe Calderon, leader of the right-of-center opposition party, added  his voice, saying that Mr. Madrazo "has lost all moral authority" to govern. **********The Governor rejected the federal charges as "calumny."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/23/your-.main_headline: Investing $7,500: When a Small Stake Presents a Big Choice of Options
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/23/your-.print_headline: Investing $7,500: When a Small Stake Presents a Big Choice of Options
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/23/your-.body_text: **********YOUR rich aunt just died, but she did not like you very much and left you only $7,500. The amount may be small, but the number of choices for what to do with it is not. **********Financial advisers say the best place to keep such a relative pittance is in one of the many thousands of investment funds, which provide the sort of diversification that would be too expensive and otherwise impractical if buying individual shares or bonds. **********"With that amount of money, you want to go to a single fund that is internationally diversified and can meet your particular objective," said Graham Wainer, executive director for fund management at the Private Bank & Trust Co. in London. "There is a whole range of vehicles designed to give you international coverage." **********What type of fund is bought depends on present and future financial needs and tolerance for risk. Investors who need a steady income stream should opt for a global bond fund, a balanced fund or one that holds convertible securities, Mr. Wainer said. Some good ones, in his opinion, are the Lazard International Bond Fund, the Warburg World Bond Fund and the GT Global Bond Fund. **********Investors should avoid the tendency in countries, such as Britain, where stocks carry high dividend yields to go with an equity fund, he said. The income generated is usually much less than that of a bond fund, and the volatility can be much greater. **********Stocks are fine, though, for those seeking capital growth. Mr. Wainer recommends global equity funds, more so than funds targeting only one's home country. Some that he thinks highly of are Gan Worldwide, Templeton Global Growth and Guinness Flight Global Equity. **********Anyone out for pure speculation — maybe you figured your aunt wouldn't leave you a penny, and easy come, easy go — can try a global emerging-markets fund, perhaps Pictet Emerging or Genesis Emerging, or else a fund that offers leverage: a warrant fund, say, or a hedge fund. **********He noted that hedge funds tend to be open only to those with a lot of money to play with, although with $7,500 a speculator might be able to buy a single share in Leveraged Capital Holding, a fund run by the Rothschild organization in Switzerland that invests in hedge funds such as George Soros's renowned Quantum. **********The universe of funds is so expansive that picking one can be a complicated undertaking. "You're spoiled for choice because there are literally hundreds around," Mr. Wainer said. **********To whittle that number down, he advised, "go to a publication that gives rankings and tables and come up with one that meets your objectives." **********Consulting an investment adviser is another option. But for such a meager amount, an investor can expect only about half an hour of an adviser's time, for which he will expect to take part of the fund's front-end load, perhaps 1.5 percent or 2 percent, an amount that is "probably money well spent if you don't feel comfortable picking a fund on your own." **********Laurie Laner, a certified financial planner with Financial Designs Inc. in Minnesota, said that before she recommended any investments to the recipient of a tiny windfall, she would take stock of his financial situation to make sure the money could not be put to better use outside the markets. **********"The first assumption would be that this person doesn't have significant debt and has enough cash in the bank so that he can afford to invest," she said. Someone paying 14 percent interest on a credit-card balance, for instance, would be better off paying down the debt than risking the money in a stock or bond fund. **********If investing the money proves suitable and income is desired, Ms. Laner's first choice for an American would be a bond fund that is as diversified as possible, buying high-grade corporate paper as well as lower-quality, high-yield debt. Ideally, the fund would hold bonds with a range of maturities and perhaps some foreign bonds, too. **********For capital growth, Ms. Laner would recommend a global equity fund that invests in large companies, for these have been proven "more consistent performers over time" than smaller companies. **********As for speculation, she was hesitant to suggest anything truly offbeat, and many such investments — some hedge funds, for instance — are forbidden to retail investors under U.S. regulations. **********"I don't do any super-high-risk stuff, but when I meet an aggressive-growth investor, I put him in a U.S. aggressive-growth fund," typically one that buys shares in smaller companies, she said. Ms. Laner might also counsel buying an emerging-markets fund, especially one that invests in the Pacific, a region she described as "a really good buy." **********Tom Buck, a financial consultant with Merrill Lynch, has the same warm regard for Asia, which he called "clearly the fastest-growing segment of the world's economy. There is risk there, but you could put in a dollar and in 10 years have the potential for it to be worth $10.' **********The advantage of an Asia-Pacific fund is that "you can put money in and not have to worry about managing it," he explained. Other speculative investments, such as technology shares, precious metals and natural resources, must be watched carefully for fear of missing a market turn. **********For those interested in capital growth, Mr. Buck would seek out a stock fund whose manager is aiming for "consistency of performance, rather than trying to make a return of the highest magnitude in any given year." **********He favors value-oriented portfolios, in which price-earnings ratios are below the market average and below the companies' earnings growth rates. He would prefer below-average price-to-book ratios, as well, and above-average dividends. By limiting the search to funds that meet those criteria, "the universe of several thousand funds can be narrowed down to a handful," he said. **********For income, the key is to find a fund with a low expense ratio that buys only government or investment-grade corporate bonds and does not use derivatives to boost yield. A low expense ratio is especially important, he said, because "a difference of a couple of tenths of a percent can have an enormous impact on yield over time." **********Even better than buying a fund, he said, is buying an individual bond. "I know exactly when the bond comes due, when the [interest] comes due and how much I'm going to get," he said. **********The diversification that a fund can offer to equity investors makes it safer than shares in a single company, few of which can be deemed completely secure. With bonds, however, some individual issues are as safe as any investment imaginable. Their prices may fluctuate with interest rates, but at maturity there is every reason to believe that the debt of the best companies will be repaid in full. **********"Bond money is safe money," Mr. Buck said. "I'd rather be more cautious and know what I have than take greater risks and not know what I have."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/23/world.main_headline: Protest Leader In Indonesia Is Relieved Of Party Role
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/23/world.print_headline: Protest Leader In Indonesia Is Relieved Of Party Role
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/23/world.body_text: **********Indonesia's most prominent political opposition figure, Megawati Sukarnoputri, was ousted today from her party's leadership by rival members, leaving her supporters uncertain over their next move. **********With the blessing of the Indonesian Government, the rival members reinstated  Ms. Megawati's predecessor as party chairman at a meeting in the western city of Medan, setting the stage for a possible confrontation with her supporters, who continued to occupy the party headquarters in Jakarta. **********Ms. Megawati, the daughter of Indonesia's late President Sukarno, denounced  the rival meeting as unconstitutional and said, "I will continue to fight for democracy and uphold the people's sovereignty." **********But without the position of party leader, Ms. Megawati would not have legal standing to run for President in elections scheduled for 1998, and her supporters said her political options were limited. **********The reinstated party chairman, Suryadi, said he hoped to keep Ms. Megawati in a prominent position in the party, but her supporters said she would not accept  a compromise. **********In recent weeks, Ms. Megawati, 49, has raised an increasingly vocal challenge to the leadership of President Suharto, who has ruled Indonesia since taking power from Mr. Sukarno in 1966. **********In six presidential elections, he has been the only candidate of all three Government-sanctioned parties, including that of Ms. Megawati, the Indonesia Democratic Party. **********True opposition parties are not allowed in Indonesia, and Mr. Suryadi, who like many Indonesians uses one name, said today that he did not want his party to become "the enemy of the Government." **********Ms. Megawati had been leading the party in that direction, threatening last week to mobilize her supporters and saying that if she chose, she could paralyze the country by bringing millions of people into the streets. **********But on Thursday, when 5,000 of her supporters demonstrated in central Jakarta to protest the rival party meeting, soldiers with batons choked off the demonstration, sending dozens of people to the hospital and sobering their leaders. **********"It was a shock," Laksamana Sukardi, the party's treasurer and a Megawati loyalist, said on Friday. "We need to pause and save some logistics and energy.  We don't have anything. We don't have money. We don't have access to the media.  We don't have tanks. We don't have barbed wire." **********He said Ms. Megawati's choices were now limited. "I think there are two options now: to gracefully withdraw or to face them head on," Mr. Laksamana said. **********He said a head-on confrontation might be quixotic. "The force that we are challenging is too huge," he said. "I don't see a chance to succeed at this time." **********But he said he did not expect Ms. Megawati simply to accept defeat.  "A graceful withdrawal would make a lot of grass-roots supporters disappointed and  they might have to wait for a generation or two for true democracy." **********President Suharto, who is 75, has not said whether he intends to run again, and Ms. Megawati's challenge comes in the context of growing speculation about his plans and about his possible choice of a successor. **********"After 30 years of relatively stable rule, no one is sure that the transition is going to be accomplished with stability," said Jeffrey A. Winters, an associate professor at Northwestern University who is an expert on Indonesia. **********"There is no institutionalization for change, which is what makes investors nervous." **********Though he has brought increasing prosperity to this nation of 190 million people, President Suharto has maintained tight control over its press and political system. **********His monopoly on power has fueled opposition and created an opening for an opposition figure like Ms. Megawati, who has attracted a following primarily because of her family name.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/11/busin.body_text: **********The dollar slipped against the Japanese yen yesterday, hurt by a continued slump in United States bonds that raised concern that foreign investors might pare their American holdings. **********''The bond market selloff signaled foreign exchange traders to sell dollars,'' said Charles Spence, director of foreign exchange at the Standard Chartered Bank. **********The dollar also suffered against the yen as Japanese investors, who have supported the currency of late, were absent from the market because of a national holiday, Health Sports Day. **********In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 111.15 yen, down from 111.55 yen on Wednesday. The British pound edged up to $1.5665  from $1.5650. But the dollar rose to 1.5382 German marks from 1.5287. **********The dollar erased an early drop against the mark after a Bundesbank official denied there was a rift between the central bank and Finance Minister Theo Waigel over European monetary union. **********The denial followed a report yesterday in the German weekly magazine Die Zeit that Bundesbank officials feared a ''crisis of confidence'' for the union, unless European Union officials went further toward adopting German proposals for tough penalties on countries that slide from the economic requirements of the union. **********''The denial helped push the dollar back up,'' said Vicki Schmelzer Alicea, a currency trader at Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale. **********The plans for monetary union include the introduction of a single currency, the Euro, on Jan. 1, 1999. Signs of progress toward union hurt the mark because the Euro will replace it as Europe's benchmark currency. **********The mark also suffered from continued speculation that President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia might have died. While Russian officials denied such talk yesterday, speculation persisted among traders. **********''People are still wondering what's going on with Yeltsin,'' said Seth Garrett, director of foreign exchange at CS First Boston. **********Political turmoil in Russia hurts the mark because Germany is Russia's largest creditor and trading partner. The Swiss franc also benefited from the speculation, because the currency is treated as a safe haven in times of international turmoil.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/13/news/.body_text: **********PARIS—                     Silvio Berlusconi and Bettino Craxi, two former prime ministers who have dominated Italian politics in recent years but who now face multiple corruption investigations, were indicted Friday and ordered to stand trial together on fraud and illegal party financing charges. **********The two men, together with nine of their former aides, will be tried in November on specific allegations that Mr. Berlusconi's media group put more than $6 million in payoffs into a Swiss bank account that benefited Mr. Craxi. **********For Mr. Berlusconi, 59, whose political power has seeped away since his center-right coalition lost Italy's general election in April, this is the second high-profile criminal indictment. He is already on trial in a separate case, charged with having authorized the bribing of tax officials who were inspecting his media group, Fininvest. **********Mr. Craxi, 62, was once the strongman of Italian politics and served as Socialist prime minister from 1983 to 1987. Today he is the quintessential symbol of Italy's discredited former political class. **********Having been convicted in other corruption trials in Milan, he is now living in luxurious self-imposed exile at his villa in the Tunisian seaside town of Hammamet. Mr. Craxi, whose brother Antonio Craxi was among those indicted Friday and charged with receiving some of the Fininvest money, has been sentenced in absentia to jail terms totaling more than 25 years in other trials. **********The indictments handed down Friday, although not a complete surprise, nonetheless rank as being among the most spectacular set of criminal charges filed since the graft-busting Milan judges began their wide-ranging investigations of leading Italian businessmen and politicians in 1992. Judge Maurizio Grigo, who made the ruling at a closed-door committal hearing in Milan, set the start of the trial for Nov. 21. **********On Friday night, Mr. Berlusconi dismissed the indictment as "a trial that evidently has a political aim, and namely to eliminate me as the leader of the opposition." He described the money transfers as "a normal commercial operation" and said the payments were made to a Tunisian film producer named Tarak ben Amar. **********Word first leaked some months ago that prosecutors were looking into allegations of an elaborate transfer of Fininvest funds to Mr. Craxi though a network of offshore banks and companies. On Friday, the indictment made it clear that Mr. Berlusconi is accused of permitting payments by Fininvest of 10 billion lire ($6.5 million), channeled to Mr. Craxi in 1991 through a Fininvest-linked offshore company, All-Iberian, and by way of accounts held at Swiss Bank Corp. in Lugano and the Trade Development Bank in Geneva. **********Over the years, the self-made media tycoon and billionaire has repeatedly denied allegations by political opponents that in exchange for payments to Mr. Craxi's Socialist Party, the Fininvest group obtained a raft of special favors, including important legislation allowing him to build and maintain a television empire that today controls half of the national market. **********The allegations of a link between Mr. Berlusconi and his close friend Mr. Craxi had become so public and widespread in Italy that when word of the inquiry leaked, the august Corriere della Sera newspaper began an article with the word "Bingo!" **********Mr. Berlusconi is virtually the only politician on the Italian scene who still defends the discredited Mr. Craxi. The former Socialist prime minister was best man at the media mogul's second marriage, and in the 1980s the two men and their families spent New Year's Eves partying at Mr. Berlusconi's villa near Milan. Recently, Mr. Berlusconi denied claims that Bettino Craxi served as his secret adviser and helped him plan to found Forza Italia, the political party and vehicle staffed with Fininvest executives that catapulted him into the prime minister's office for seven tumultuous months in 1994. **********Since 1992, Mr. Berlusconi's Fininvest group, another member of his family and a handful of his top executives, have faced a total of 27 arrests, 26 indictments and 3 convictions. The charges have ranged from fraud to an alleged attempt by Mr. Berlusconi's brother Paolo to blackmail Judge Antonio Di Pietro, the former prosecutor who first investigated the Berlusconi group. **********The charges filed Friday — of fraudulent accounting practices and illegal political contributions — come just ahead of the expected start of trading on Monday in the shares of Mediaset SpA, Mr. Berlusconi's television company. Among those who will be tried for corruption is Ubaldo Livolsi, the chief executive of Mediaset. Despite the success of Mediaset's international stock offering, critics have derided Mr. Berlusconi's recent assertion that the share offer had resolved his conflict-of-interest between politics and business.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/20/world.snippet: European diplomats and military officials say Yugoslavia has destroyed 240 of its tanks in wake of arms control treaty that was signed in June; say Clinton Administration, which promised Yugoslavia $2 million to help with demolition program, is de...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/20/world.main_headline: Who's Beating Swords Into Plowshares in Balkans: A Score Card
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/20/world.print_headline: Who's Beating Swords Into Plowshares in Balkans: A Score Card
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/20/world.body_text: **********In the course of the Bosnia war, it became axiomatic that the various governments in the region made promises on which they quickly reneged. **********So, when Yugoslavia, in the course of negotiating an arms control treaty that was signed in June, promised to destroy 80 tanks before the end of this year, few expected it to happen. **********But it turns out that Yugoslavia has gone beyond its promise, destroying 240 of its tanks, according to European diplomats and military officials who reviewed compliance with the treaty this week. **********At the same time, these officials said, the Clinton Administration, which promised Yugoslavia $2 million to help with the demolition program, is delaying the payments. Based on what Belgrade has done to date, the officials said, Washington owes Yugoslavia about $1 million. **********The reluctance of the United States to make good on its offer -- issued when the treaty was being negotiated -- is understood by European diplomats to arise out Washington's unhappiness with President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia. Mr. Milosevic's harsh reaction to protests against his decision to annul the results of elections last month has been condemned by Washington. **********The American mission to the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, which oversees the treaty, declined to comment on the failure of the United States to make the payments to Yugoslavia. **********While Yugoslavia has more than met its obligations under the arms control accords, the Bosnian Serbs have not, diplomats and military officers said. **********Officials said the Bosnian Serbs are trying to keep twice the number of tanks and 50 percent more heavy artillery pieces than they are permitted under the accord. Altogether, the Bosnian Serbs are trying to protect some 1,200 tanks and artillery pieces from destruction. **********As well as tanks and artillery, the treaty places ceilings on the number of armored combat vehicles, combat aircraft and attack helicopters that may be possessed by Yugoslavia, Croatia, the Muslim-Croat Federation in Bosnia and the Bosnian Serb republic. **********Each Government was required to report the number of weapons it had at the time and to begin destroying its excess. They were, for example, to have destroyed 40 percent of the artillery and 20 percent of the tanks above what the treaty allowed by the end of this month. **********The Muslim-Croat Federation is behind in meeting its obligations because of a dispute between the Muslims and Croats over which of their armies has to turn over the weapons to be destroyed. **********The greatest concern, however, is focused on the Bosnian Serbs. **********To begin with, they underreported the number of weapons in their arsenal when the war ended. The Bosnian Serbs said, for example, they had 1,348 pieces of heavy artillery, according to a report prepared by the security organization. But NATO intelligence concluded they had between 2,200 and 2,950. **********More troubling to the officials monitoring the treaty is the manner in which the Bosnian Serbs have interpreted treaty provisions that allow the parties to exempt from destruction those weapons that are intended for export, are used in research and development, or will be placed in museums. **********The Bosnian Serbs assert that 338 of their tanks and 800 of their heavy artillery fall within those exemptions. If allowed to stand, that would leave the Bosnian Serbs with 475 tanks, instead of the 137 ceiling set by the treaty.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/30/busin.snippet: Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, whom General Motors Corp has accused of stealing thousands of secret company documents when he left GM to join Volkswagen in 1993, resigns as president of Volkswagen; his lawyers say Lopez wants 'to concentrate on ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/30/busin.main_headline: President Out As VW Seeks G.M. Truce
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/30/busin.print_headline: President Out As VW Seeks G.M. Truce
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/30/busin.body_text: **********Thomas Andersson had already been unnerved once by his two roommates, when he walked in to find they had moved in paper-shredders and were busily destroying documents in the house they shared in Wiesbaden, about 20 miles from here. **********When he later discovered four cartons of what seemed to be confidential documents from General Motors in his living room, he decided to call the police. That call, on June 21, 1993, may well have been the beginning of the end of Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua's career as a top executive at Volkswagen A.G. **********Mr. Lopez, whom General Motors has accused of stealing thousands of secret company documents when he left G.M. to join Volkswagen in 1993, resigned as president of Volkswagen today. His lawyers said Mr. Lopez wanted ''to concentrate on expected legal proceedings'' -- a civil suit brought by General Motors in the United States as well as criminal charges that are expected to be filed soon by German prosecutors. **********It remains to be seen whether Mr. Lopez, who is 55, will be found guilty of industrial espionage, as General Motors has contended. But the cartons found in the Wiesbaden house have now led prosecutors and General Motors to evidence of widespread secret shipments of G.M. documents, late-night shredding parties and at least one big effort to transfer material from G.M. floppy disks and paper documents into Volkswagen computers. **********Volkswagen executives are now showing signs of panic about the prospects of a court trial in the United States, and are scrambling to reach an out-of-court settlement with G.M. **********A person close to VW's board, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said the company was horrified by the prospect of VW's chairman, Ferdinand Piech, being forced to defend himself in an American court on accusations of racketeering and industrial spying. The same person expressed the hope that General Motors would be equally concerned about damaging its own image in Europe. **********''This is very frightening both to G.M. and to us,'' the person close to the board said. ''We fear that unless there is a settlement, this could really develop into economic warfare. If the discovery process and the trial goes on, there is no question that this could lead to a very, very bad situation.'' **********At a minimum, the Lopez case  threatens to severely wound Volkswagen's public image, just when the German car maker is showing strong growth in profits and sales after years of poor performance. **********Volkswagen's shares gained 2.3 marks today in trading on the Frankfurt exchange, closing at 615.6 marks. **********The chairman of VW's supervisory board, Klaus Liesen, met with the General Motors chairman, John G. Smale, and a board member, Thomas H. Wyman, in September, although the talks evidently made no progress. VW board members are continuing to make informal contacts with G.M. on a frequent basis, hoping that the departure of Mr. Lopez will open the path to some sort of agreement. **********For General Motors, the Lopez case has become a campaign for corporate revenge. Before he quit, Mr. Lopez had been one of General Motors' most visible and treasured stars, the man credited with sharply cutting the auto maker's costs and revolutionizing the way it bought its parts. Since losing Mr. Lopez to its German rival, General Motors has spared little effort to investigate, litigate and publicize what it describes as a brazen act of corporate back-stabbing. **********Today, General Motors offered little sign of being willing to let bygones be bygones. **********''The resignation of Lopez, which has been overdue for more than three years, cannot compensate for the substantial damages,'' said a statement issued by the company's Adam Opel subsidiary in Germany today. The statement accused VW's top management of a ''systematic cover-up'' for three years. **********If General Motors wins its suit in Detroit, Volkswagen could be forced to pay billions of dollars in compensation. That prospect grew more realistic on Tuesday, when a Federal judge in Detroit ruled that General Motors could sue VW under racketeering laws and claim triple the amount awarded by a jury. **********In 1993, when the police responded to Mr. Andersson's call, they found a cache of documents in the Wiesbaden apartment that included internal G.M. studies, cost information and a report entitled ''Strategic Business Plan Global Outsourcing.'' That soon led to a sweeping search of Volkswagen headquarters, Mr. Lopez's  home in Germany and VW's guesthouse, where Mr. Lopez had set up copying machines, shredders and a small staff to sort through papers. **********Volkswagen, which originally denied that it had obtained any information from General Motors, now admits that it received some of that material. But the company asserts that it had nothing to do with Mr. Lopez's efforts, that the information did not reach VW executives outside Mr. Lopez's group and that VW never used the information. **********However the case develops, VW will have a hard time disentangling itself from the activities of Mr. Lopez. G.M.'s lawsuit against Volkswagen contains a long chronology of Mr. Lopez's activities before and after he jumped over to the German car company. **********The documents found in the Wiesbaden apartment came directly from General Motors, but they were only the beginning. Once German police found the cartons, they searched Volkswagen headquarters, its computers, its offices and the homes of Mr. Lopez and his associates. According to G.M.'s complaint, Mr. Lopez had set up an elaborate document-processing operation at one of Volkswagen's more remote offices in Germany and installed a mainframe computer, 15 computer work stations and other equipment to transfer data from G.M. disks and documents to Volkswagen computers. **********The complaint also recounts the discovery of 20 cartons of General Motors documents, which the company says Mr. Lopez had shipped from Detroit to Spain at the time of his job switch. Those cartons were shipped on an airplane owned by Volkswagen, according to the complaint. **********G.M. also retraced Mr. Lopez's movements on an almost daily basis between February 1993, when he started negotiating with Volkswagen, and the time he quit General Motors on March 10. Based largely on interviews with scores of General Motors employees, many of whom helped prepare documents for shipping to Europe, the complaint draws a vivid portrait of Mr. Lopez collecting information voraciously at G.M. at the time he was in deep negotiations with VW over a new job. **********Mr. Lopez, the complaint says, demanded vast quantities of information about G.M.'s purchasing structure, its feasibility study for a revolutionary new factory that was code- named Plant X and even pictures of new automobile designs. **********At one point, the complaint says, Mr. Lopez ordered G.M. employees to translate large volumes of documents into German and then arranged to have those documents shipped to Europe. **********Volkswagen denies that its top management conspired with Mr. Lopez, but the company cannot deny that it adamantly supported the executive at every turn in the three-year conflict with General Motors, and that it refused to back down even after it became clear that Mr. Lopez and his followers had retained control of a big collection of G.M. documents. **********Not only did Volkswagen defend Mr. Lopez, but it also used a battery of lawyers to keep G.M. from taking legal action at every available opportunity. VW unsuccessfully tried to prevent G.M. from pursuing its lawsuit in Detroit. It also went to court in Germany, again unsuccessfully, to block G.M. from talking about its allegations here. And most recently, it sought -- again unsuccessfully -- to prevent German prosecutors from sharing their information with the United States Federal Bureau of Investigation. **********Even today, Volkswagen officials refrained from even hinting at any criticism of Mr. Lopez or acknowledging any improprieties. What G.M. wants, perhaps as badly as financial compensation, is an apology.

BWAY said Milton Can's shareholders would receive about $30 million in about equal portions of cash and BWAY stock, and BWAY would assume existing Milton Can debt. Milton Can, which has operations in  New Jersey and Massachusetts, had sales of about $60 million last year, while BWAY had sales of about $250 million, it said. BWAY makes steel containers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/17/your-.body_text: **********MODERN portfolio theory is clever stuff, the rocket science of financial services. But is it good for the smaller mutual fund investor? **********Cynics say that modern portfolio theory has helped the insidious culture of victimhood to spread into the mutual fund industry. One of its tenetsis that fund managers should not be expected to consistently outperform the market, which is seen as an entity that prices assets efficiently and therefore is very difficult to beat. **********The general acceptance of this argument can be seen in the emergence of phrases such as "stock picking" to describe fund management styles. In most other professions this would be an absurd redundancy. If you go to the doctor, you do not have to ask whether the physician is a "curer," or one who passively waits for an illness to take its course. But if you buy a mutual fund you need to know whether the manager actively selects stocks or simply sits back and buys the hard-to-beat index. **********Nice theory.Great job.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/19/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;KEYSTONE TO CUT JOBS AND GET RID OF SOME ASSETS
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/19/busin.body_text: **********Keystone International Inc. said yesterday that it would cut about 260 jobs,  or about 6 percent of its work force, as part of a restructuring intended to streamline operations and divest itself of underperforming assets. Keystone, a maker of flow-control products, also said its fourth-quarter earnings, before one-time expenses associated with the restructuring, should be about the same as last year's results, which would put them below Wall Street estimates. The company, which is based in Houston, will divest itself of certain assets, including several small businesses and one product line, which total about $13 million in annual sales.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/05/busin.body_text: **********A Federal judge today threw out an agreement by 15 drug makers to pay $408.9  million to settle a class-action lawsuit that contends they conspired to fix prices charged to retail pharmacies. **********The judge, Charles P. Kocoras of the Federal District Court here, also ruled  that the retailers had presented enough evidence to warrant a trial of the drug  makers, as well as seven others that did not join the settlement. The trial is scheduled to begin May 7. **********The dispute centers on the sharp discounts given by pharmaceutical companies to health maintenance organizations, mail-order drug sellers and hospitals that  are not available to retail pharmacies. The retailers contend that the price discrimination is costing them $30 billion annually and will drive many out of business if it continues. **********"We wanted to see this evidence go to a jury and now it will," said John Rector, general counsel for the National Association of Retail Druggists in Alexandria, Va., which represents 24,000 independent drug retailers. **********The settlement agreement had been bitterly criticized by many retailers who felt that it paid them too little, restricted their ability to pursue other complaints against the manufacturers and, worst of all, did nothing to halt the  pricing practices. Still, many lawyers were surprised when Judge Kocoras threw out the settlement, reversing a preliminary approval he gave in February. **********In asking Judge Kocoras to summarily dismiss the case before trial, drug makers had argued that they had done nothing more than respond to the pressures  of a competitive marketplace. Judge Kocoras concluded today that drug makers were entitled to give discounts to managed care companies and others that could  demonstrate the market power to influence which drugs consumers use. **********But, he said, that did not give them the right to refuse the same discounts to retailers or retail buying groups if they could show similar market influence. Evidence that such discrimination had occurred was a basis for going  to trial, he ruled, and the lack of any promise to end it was his main reason for rejecting the settlement. **********"No commitment exists on the part of the settling defendants to bring about the fairness in opportunity which we believe the law requires," Judge Kocoras said in his opinion on the settlement. **********In a separate ruling, the judge granted a motion to dismiss six drug wholesalers from the suit. **********A fair shot at discounts is far short of what many retailers want -- one price for all. Indeed, it is very much in doubt whether many of the thousands of drug retailers that are having trouble competing as the health industry concentrates will ever achieve the influence over consumers needed to get the discounts. Still, groups that opposed the settlement were elated. **********"It's a whole new ballgame in which manufacturers now have to demonstrate in  court that they don't have unfair, anticompetitive pricing practices," said Phillip Schneider, a spokesman for the National Association of Chain Drug Stores, a group also based in Alexandria that represents 135 chains owning 30,000 pharmacies. **********Drug companies said they had not yet had a chance to study the judge's ruling, but denied any conspiracy in setting prices. "We have done nothing wrong, and we aren't part of any alleged conspiracy," Brian McGlynn, a spokesman for Pfizer Inc., told Bloomberg Business News. Judge Kocoras's ruling was a setback for Michael Freed and Perry Goldberg, well-known class-action lawyers who had negotiated the agreement with the drug makers. They had argued that the settlement was a good one because the payout -- a modest $10,000 for each class member after legal fees -- still added up to the biggest total by far in an antitrust case that had not been based on prior Government action. They also said that Judge Kocoras did not have the power to order the changes in pricing practices many retailers wanted. **********Neither Mr. Freed nor Mr. Goldberg returned calls seeking comment today. **********Fay Clayton, a Chicago lawyer who represented retailers in the case, said that some defense lawyers, whom she declined to identify, had already contacted  her suggesting negotiatons for a new settlement. **********"I'm confident we can work this out," Ms. Clayton said. "We are not looking for a ton of money. All my clients want is a level playing field." **********Those that had tried to settle the charges included many industry giants like Merck, Pfizer, Eli Lilly, Glaxo Wellcome and Bristol-Myers Squibb. Marion Merrell Dow Inc. and Johnson & Johnson were among the larger companies that had  declined to settle. **********"This is pretty much of a non-event for investors," said Paul A. Brooke, who  follows the industry for Morgan Stanley & Company. He said that many companies had already set aside money to cover the expected costs of settling the litigation. **********He also said that the trial of the complex pricing issues would have taken place in any case because so many plaintiffs had already chosen to sue separately, and that the conflict might take years to resolve. **********The pharmaceutical industry also faces a Federal Trade Commission investigation of its pricing, begun after the settlement had first been reached, and separate suits by large drugstore chains, grocery-store pharmacies, and about 3,500 independent pharmacies that had chosen to stay out of the class action. Some suits have broader antitrust claims than those filed by the independent retailers that would have been covered by the settlement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/06/busin.body_text: **********Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing reported a loss yesterday of $97 million for the fourth quarter as a result of charges for job cuts and write-downs. **********The company, which makes Post-it notes and Scotch adhesive tapes, took charges of $414 million as part of a plan to close its audiotape and videotape businesses and spin off several others. In the comparable quarter a year earlier, the company earned $332 million, or 79 cents a share. **********But earnings from continuing operations were higher in the latest quarter, rising to $318 million, or 75 cents a share, from $294 million, or 70 cents a share. Sales from continuing operations rose 7 percent, to $3.3 billion from $3.09 billion. The company did not disclose total sales. The results were in line with Wall Street estimates. **********Minnesota Mining, based in St. Paul, had said on Jan. 17 that it expected fourth-quarter earnings to fall because of weak December sales. The company said demand in the United States was weakest in the automotive, furniture and textile industries, although its consumer products, office supplies and roofing materials did well. European sales were also weak in December, the company said, in part because of a monthlong transportation strike in France. **********For the quarter, sales in the United States rose 4 percent and international  sales gained 10 percent, the company said.   (Bloomberg Business News)

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/28/world.main_headline: Serbs Evicted From Apartments in Sarajevo
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/28/world.print_headline: Serbs Evicted From Apartments in Sarajevo
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/28/world.body_text: **********The Bosnian police have evicted dozens of people, mainly Serbs, from apartments that once belonged to the Yugoslav Army, United Nations officials said today. Most of the apartments are in parts of Sarajevo that reverted to Bosnian Government control under the 1995 Dayton peace treaty. **********Kris Janowski, a spokesman in Bosnia for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, said people were being evicted even though they had valid papers from the Yugoslav army in the late 1980's. The army built the apartments when Bosnia was a member of the Yugoslav federation; it seceded in 1992. **********Hundreds of people, again mostly Serbs, have also been moved out of former army housing in Croatia, another former Yugoslav republic. **********A diplomat in Sarajevo said the Government seemed anxious to fill the apartments with trusted soldiers to forge a front for urban warfare if fighting  erupts in Sarajevo again.

Revasc is intended for treatment  of acute coronary syndrome, which is life threatening to some patients.   (Reuters)

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/26/busin.body_text: **********Daimler-Benz A.G. said yesterday that it expected operating profit of 6 billion marks ($4 billion) in 1998, compared with a loss of 5.7 billion marks in 1995. Sales at Germany's largest company are expected to be 132 billion marks in 1998, Daimler said, a 21 percent rise from 1995. The company made the forecasts  in a statement on merging the remaining parts of AEG A.G. with the parent, Daimler. **********The company was required to estimate sales and profit to value the two companies. Daimler cautioned that the estimates could prove wrong if "if there are changes in the worldwide business climate and other factors which affect Daimler-Benz activities -- especially the U.S. dollar." Earlier this month, Daimler said it expected to return to profitability in 1996.   (Bloomberg Business News)
