https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/16/your-.body_text: **********WE are sitting on the edge of an abyss. The dangers facing modern capitalism, and the industrialized democratic societies that house such economic systems, have never been more acute. The risk of catastrophe has never been greater. Good: Now is the time to spread our picnic blanket on the utmost border of the precipice, settle down and enjoy the view. **********The above is very much the perspective of the investor — as opposed to the politician or soldier, who must strive to ensure that political tension does not mushroom into wholesale war. Yes, the last few months in the Middle East have been particularly bloody and horrible. Yet, chillingly enough, for the investor little has changed. Because sitting on the edge of the precipice is just a metaphor for the controlled fear that is long-term risk management. And despite the moral horror of the recent assassinations, the bombings and the violence in the Middle East, the long-term investment outlook remains little changed. **********In the aftermath of tragedy, that analysis may sound arid to the point of soullessness. Yet what else should investors take into account? If violence had an importance beyond political risk in investment calculations, why are banks in Lebanon — the site of numberless atrocities just a decade ago — numbered in the hundreds? Why is the Beirut stock exchange up and running again? **********The simple answer is that capitalism and its business methods have won an important ideological war. Short of actual, materially destructive war, regions like the Middle East offer vast investment upside. Whether investors can live with the risk, or the moral resonance of making money in a climate of political volatility, is a personal choice.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/28/busin.main_headline: Market Place;A New Way to Measure an Exhausted Bull
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/28/busin.print_headline: Market Place;A New Way to Measure an Exhausted Bull
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/28/busin.body_text: **********Is the Q ratio signaling that the end is near for this great bull market? **********The what? **********If you're an economist, you didn't ask the second question. The Q ratio, devised by James Tobin, the Yale economist who won a Nobel prize for his work, is a ratio of the total market value of stocks and bonds compared with what it would cost to replace the assets of America's corporations. **********There are good data on this since World War II, when the Federal Reserve began calculating the numbers on an annual basis. On average, stocks and bonds sold for about a 30 percent discount to what it would cost to replace the companies' assets. **********But now those financial securities sell for at least 70 percent more than the replacement cost. That level has never been seen before, and to some analysts, it is a warning of excessive overvaluation. **********Andrew Smithers, a British economist and proprietor of Smithers & Company, a  pension consulting firm, is sounding the loudest alarm. "Professor Tobin received a Nobel prize for his work, and the U.S. stock market may thus be said  to be making a bet of approximately $3 trillion that he should return his laurels," Mr. Smithers said in a report to clients. "I expect him to be justified in keeping them." **********But Mr. Smithers, in an interview, conceded that there was no way to know just when the bubble might burst. The Q ratio, he said, was a good valuation measure, not a way to time the stock market. **********Barton Biggs, the chief strategist for Morgan Stanley & Company, agrees. "It  is an indication that stocks are very risky, because they are very expensively priced," he said. **********Mr. Biggs said he had studied the numbers, and the only thing he could come up with to possibly modify them is that they do not take into account the value  of franchises and brand names, which perhaps are worth more now than before. Certainly, one could duplicate every asset of the Coca-Cola Company, from bottling plants to office desks, without creating a company as valuable as Coca-Cola if one did not get the right to use the name as well. **********Mr. Tobin's work showed that the profits on invested capital, measured by its current value, should return to normal levels eventually, simply because figures well away from normal will produce an investment boom. Eventually, all that investment will create competition, eroding whatever was producing high rates of return. **********And what does Mr. Tobin think about all this? He said that he had not seen Mr. Smithers' work but that the current Q ratio did seem to imply that stock prices are higher than they ought to be. **********"Another implication is that it ought to generate an investment boom," he said. "You don't have to sell much of your firm to get the money you need for an investment project." **********It is conceivable that the current figures are exaggerated because the replacement costs are underestimated. And it is also true that while a lot of companies are selling stock to the public, as would be expected if prices really are ridiculously high, some are also buying stock back and making acquisitions for cash. Neither would seem reasonable if valuations were that extreme. **********The figures for the Q ratio are computed annually by the Federal Reserve, with the 1995 figure due out soon. Morgan Stanley estimates it will be about 1.71, and adds that if a figure were to be computed now, taking into account just how much the stock market has risen, it would be around 1.8. That is, assets now sell on Wall Street for about 80 percent more than it costs to make them. **********If one assumes that the stock market will eventually fall back to the norm of about 70 percent of replacement value -- or a ratio of 0.70 -- that implies a stock market drop of about 60 percent. That would leave the Dow Jones industrial average at less than 2,500 points. **********Mr. Smithers said he had estimated Q values back to the 1920's and had concluded that the stock market was considerably more overvalued now than it was in 1929. **********To Mr. Biggs, the Q ratio is a good reason to cut back on American stocks, and substitute foreign ones. To Mr. Smithers, even foreign stocks may not be immune to the consequences of what he thinks will be a huge crash. **********A major reason stocks have gone up, of course, is that American investors have done well in stocks and do not see other investments as offering high returns. Real estate has not boomed recently, and interest rates on bonds and bank deposits are far less than where they have been. **********That logic, it turns out, has been compelling even to one who might be expected to be especially impressed by Mr. Tobin's Q ratio. What, Mr. Tobin was  asked, had he done with his own money? **********"I haven't taken it out of the market, if that's what you're asking," he replied, adding that he thought investor psychology was an important consideration. And anyway, he added, "the alternatives don't look all that attractive."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/12/world.main_headline: Chaos in Burundi Could Sow Misery Next Door
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/12/world.print_headline: Chaos in Burundi Could Sow Misery Next Door
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/12/world.body_text: **********When Burundi's divided Government recently asked neighboring countries to send troops to help quell ethnic violence, it represented the first breakthrough in a deadly three-year stalemate between Hutu and Tutsi political leaders. **********In response to Burundi's call, six heads of state met last month and agreed to create a security force from neighboring countries to protect officials, civil servants, public institutions and communications centers in the country, which is led by a Tutsi Prime Minister and a Hutu President. **********But the solution is likely to unravel unless moderates can find a way to make the idea of foreign peacekeepers acceptable to Tutsi hard-liners. **********For centuries the Tutsi have been the ruling class here, and their leaders see any intervention as a threat to their wealth and power. The current round of Hutu guerrilla raids and attacks by the Tutsi-led army, which have killed 150,000 people, were ignited when a Hutu became the country's first elected President in October 1993, and Tutsi soldiers kidnapped and killed him. **********More is riding on the peace plan than just Burundi's future, diplomats say. If Burundi slips further into chaos, it could spill into Rwanda, its neighbor to the north, which has the same ethnic mix and has still not recovered from the massacres that took 500,000 lives. **********The danger is that an ethnic war between Hutu and Tutsi in Burundi and Rwanda could engulf the region, sending hundreds of thousands more refugees into Tanzania and Zaire, where 1.7 million Hutu are now living in camps along the borders. **********That fear is apparently lost on some Tutsi politicians in Burundi who have decided to draft their own plan to present to the African officials for approval, a fact that has slowed the process. And each day that passes without agreement on the peace plan has given Tutsi leaders in Burundi more time to establish opposition. **********For instance, thousands of Tutsi civil servants recently marched in the streets calling President Sylvestre Ntibantunganya a traitor for agreeing to a foreign force and demanding his resignation. **********In the center of the controversy is Prime Minister Antoine Nduwayo, a Tutsi who once adamantly opposed foreign peacekeepers, but has since changed his stance. Leaders of his Tutsi-dominated Uprona Party then accused him of treachery, and so the Prime Minister has tried to distance himself from the plan, insisting that any foreign force be under the command of the Burundian military. He has also portrayed the plan as a way to help the army defeat the rebellion. **********"The way I see things, this assistance will just be here to fill in the deficit we have in protecting the population, and not to replace the national army," he said. "The rebels, instead of fighting the national army, have decided to massacre people, and because the population is so spread out, the army has not been able to protect every family." **********But from the perspective of Hutu political leaders, the Tutsi-led army is as  guilty of massacres as Hutu rebels are. The Hutu are unlikely to accept any plan that does not give peacekeepers the power to halt atrocities by Government soldiers. **********Even with all the obstacles, there are some reasons for hope, Western aid officials say. To begin with, there is the change in position by Mr. Nduwayo and the Defense Minister, Fermin Sinzayiheba, who has come to support the agreement. **********Why the change of heart? One reason is the shattered economy. After three years of guerrilla war, the Burundi treasury is in such poor shape that 40 percent of its revenues come from taxes on locally brewed beer. It has only about $60 million in reserve, about enough to last until December. Indeed, the only people making money in Burundi are arms, gold and heroin smugglers, who would probably like to see the hostilities continue. **********At the same time, American and European aid, which had represented a quarter  of Burundi's gross domestic product, was cut off two months ago after visits from high-ranking officials. **********"There have been clear statements over the last few months that Western donor countries were able to help, but were unable to do this unless there is very quickly a minimum of stability and security," said one relief official, speaking on the condition of anonymity. **********European and American diplomats here have also made it clear that they will not recognize a Tutsi government that takes power through a coup. The West has also made it known it will not allow Burundi to turn into another Rwanda. The implicit message has been that a Damocles sword of military intervention is hanging over the Burundi Government's head, so it may prefer to invite foreign troops in before it is forced to accept them. **********Prime Minister Nduwayo said as much. "We preferred this kind of formula to military intervention from an international force because we know that the neighboring countries know much better the problems here and also because we believe in regional cooperation," he said. **********Some Tutsi leaders are also recognizing they cannot win the war. Despite having a 20,000-strong army, the Tutsi have been unable to curb Hutu guerrillas  based in Zaire from gaining control of northern provinces. Neither have they been able to keep the rebels from sowing terror in other parts of the country. **********Furthermore, demographics are against the Tutsi. They are outnumbered four to one, and the anti-Tutsi sentiment in the country has only grown with each reprisal carried out by the army against Hutu villages. **********Similar attempts by foreign troops turned into disasters in Liberia and Somalia, where the peacekeepers became drawn into the fighting. **********The danger of the same thing happening in Burundi is high, and some army officials are already saying they will fight any foreign force not under their command. **********Even the main rebel group has said it will consider the peacekeepers as enemies. The rebel leader, Leonard Nyangoma, a former Interior Minister, may think he has more to gain in a fight than peace talks. **********"If this intervention force is imposed on the Government or if it is a foreign force coming to replace the army, I have doubts about the capacity of such a force to bring the country back to peace," former President Pierre Buyoya said. "Unless this force has the full support of the national leadership, you can be sure that it will be no solution at all. This is likely to bring about more confusion."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/24/busin.main_headline: General Magic Is Planning to Introduce New Products for the Internet
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/24/busin.print_headline: General Magic Is Planning to Introduce New Products for the Internet
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/24/busin.body_text: **********General Magic Inc., which intended to reinvent computing but missed out on the rise of the Internet, plans to introduce several products on Tuesday that will refocus the company on the global computer network. **********General Magic, whose investors include the AT&T Corporation, Motorola Inc., Apple Computer Inc., the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation and the Sony Corporation, set out when it was founded in 1990 to develop an operating system  and a telecommunications language. **********The original vision was to create a new generation of hand-held "personal intelligent communicators" and a digital telecommunications system that would permit personal software "agents" to perform tasks for mobile computer users. **********But General Magic executives now acknowledge that by focusing on the company's own proprietary vision of the future, they failed to capitalize on the rise of the Internet. **********"We've concluded we have to redirect our technology there," said Robert Kelsch, the president and chief operating officer of General Magic. "We still believe that we can add value to the Internet." **********The company plans to announce that it has developed a version of its Telescript language for use on World Wide Web server computers. General Magic plans also to sell software development kits, called Tabriz Agentware and Tabriz Agent Tools, for programmers who use the language. Those products are intended to make it possible for programmers to create applications for users of personal computers with World Wide Web browsing software. **********"Their agent concept makes a lot of sense, particularly now for the Internet," said Tim Bajarin, president of Creative Strategies, a consulting firm in San Jose, Calif. **********"But they are very late and there are a number of other companies now pursuing agent technologies on the Net," he added. **********General Magic plans to announce that it has added Internet capabilities to its Magic Cap operating system for hand-held communicators. **********Despite its stumbles, General Magic has remarkably deep pockets. As a result  of its public stock offering in February 1995, the company has $97 million in cash and is spending about $3 million a month. **********But it has yet to see significant revenue from licensing of its technology and sales of its software. In the most recent quarter, which ended last month, it had revenue of $2.8 million and a loss of $7 million. And though General Magic went public at $14 a share and rose to $32 the first day of trading, its shares closed at $5.375 Friday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/13/busin.snippet: Handelsbanken, in one of the biggest takeover battles ever in Sweden, offers almost 23 billion kronor ($3.37 billion) to buy Sweden's largest mortgage provider, Stadshypotek AB (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/13/busin.body_text: **********In one of the biggest takeover battles ever in Sweden, Handelsbanken offered almost 23 billion kronor ($3.37 billion) yesterday to buy Sweden's largest mortgage provider, Stadshypotek A.B. The combined company would be the Nordic region's largest financial company,  with assets of 869 billion kronor. **********The Swedish Government, which owns a controlling 34 percent stake in Stadshypotek, said it would accept Handelsbanken's offer if no higher bids appeared. The Government had begun a controlled auction for its stake. Last month, the insurance company Skandia A.B. offered to buy Stadshypotek for 24 billion kronor in newly issued stock, but the Government said it would prefer a cash deal. Handelsbank offers a choice of cash or stock. (AP)

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/11/busin.main_headline: Kmart to Test Its Own Label Credit Card
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/11/busin.print_headline: Kmart to Test Its Own Label Credit Card
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/11/busin.body_text: **********In its latest effort to lure customers into its discounted aisles, the Kmart  Corporation will issue a private-label credit card. **********The card will be rolled out late next week in 11 test markets, and by August  will be available for use in the rest of its stores, Kmart said. **********The deal was put together through Beneficial National Bank, a unit of the Beneficial Corporation. **********"The benefits for Kmart are, of course, increased sales," said Floyd Hall, chief executive of the retailer, based in Troy, Mich., in a telephone interview. "With increased buying power, we think customers will visit stores more often and we will build more customer loyalty. This is just another step in trying to  improve customer relations." **********The card, which will provide rebates as high as 6 percent for cumulative purchases throughout the year, will get the company up to speed with other discount retailers that have tried a similar approach. **********"Some retailers make more money on their credit operations at their stores,"  said Henry D. Jackson of the investment firm Peter J. Solomon. "They will be providing a valuable service to credit-strained customers." **********The card could give the company a chance to get smart about its customers, a  skill in which it has been weak. "By having a private-label card, they will be able to monitor customer-purchase trends," said Wayne L. Hood, retail analyst with Prudential Securities in Atlanta. "Sears was the pioneer in providing credit, and over the decades they have built a proprietary base that is unmatched."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/20/busin.snippet: Four major broadcast television networks--ABC, CBS, NBC and Fox--along with newcomers UPN and WB are spending $400 million to $500 million as each tries to create distinctive identity through advertising effort known as branding; branding is short...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/20/busin.main_headline: Networks Are Fine-Tuning The Art of Self-Promotion
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/20/busin.print_headline: Networks Are Fine-Tuning The Art of Self-Promotion
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/20/busin.body_text: **********A marketing blitz to promote fall television programming, estimated at a record $400 million to $500 million, has been inundating America with a barrage of branding. **********Branding is a shorthand term along Madison Avenue for attempts to create or burnish an identity or image, just as Coca-Cola seeks to distinguish itself from Pepsi-Cola. For the 1996-97 prime-time broadcast television season, which officially began this week, viewers have been swamped by the torrent of teasing practically since the 1995-96 season ended in May. **********Behind those efforts is the most ambitious push ever by the broadcast networks to brand themselves and many of the blocks of programming they offer -- a marked departure from the past, when they would promote only specific shows. **********''The perception was that people watched shows, not networks,'' said Bob Bibb, who with Lewis Goldstein jointly heads marketing for WB, a fledgling network owned by Time Warner Inc. and based in Burbank, Calif. **********''But that was when there were only three networks, three choices,'' Mr. Bibb added, ''and it was easy to find the shows you liked.'' **********WB has been presenting a sassy singing cartoon character named Michigan J. Frog as its ''spokesphibian,'' personifying the entire lineup of the ''Dubba-dubba-WB'' -- as he insists upon calling the network. **********''It's not a frog, it's an attitude,'' Mr. Bibb said, ''a consistency from show to show.'' **********In TV, an intrinsic part of branding is selecting shows that seem related and might appeal to a certain audience segment. It means ''developing an overall packaging of the network to build a relationship with viewers, so they will come to expect certain things from us,'' said Alan Cohen, executive vice president for the ABC-TV unit of the Walt Disney Company in New York. **********That, he said, means defining the network so that ''when you're watching ABC, you'll know you're watching ABC'' -- and to accomplish it in a way that appeals to the primary ABC audience of youngish urbanites and families with children. **********For the most part, the network branding binge is aimed at capturing the attention of that most demographically desirable audience so coveted by advertisers, consumers ages 18 to 49. **********But there are some variations: CBS is trying to lure back older viewers; NBC is trying to portray itself as more urban and single-friendly (think of ''Friends''); the two newest networks, WB and UPN, hope to gain favor with a younger, often black, audience in big cities, where their affiliates are concentrated, and Fox is trying to broaden its appeal beyond its trademark young brash image by playing up new programming like the Super Bowl. **********To push those brand identities, the six networks have all assembled a slew of slogans and elaborate promotional campaigns. Fox promises a ''Super season''; CBS bids a fervent ''Welcome home'' to its traditional audience after a disastrous season spent courting younger viewers who avoided flops like ''Central Park West,'' and NBC keeps asserting the merits of ''Must see TV.'' **********The broadcast networks are also trying to forge brand images for certain nights with thematically similar programs. NBC, a unit of the General Electric Company, is peddling a Saturday night of three melodramas about the paranormal meant to appeal to sophisticated urbanites. ABC is rejuvenating ''T.G.I.F.,'' four Friday sitcoms aimed at children and families. UPN has two separate nights of ''Back to Back'' comedies and dramas. And CBS is selling ''America's night of television,'' three schmaltzy Saturday shows. **********The ardor with which branding is being embraced underscores just how high the stakes are for the networks as they grow anxious to lure eyeballs back to the set. **********The four largest networks -- ABC, CBS, NBC and Fox -- have suffered ratings erosion, losing viewers precipitously to cable channels and, to a lesser degree, UPN and WB. The four networks' share of the prime-time audience in 1995-96 fell to 61 percent, a record low, compared with 65 percent in 1994-95. **********That loss is especially perilous because the networks have taken advantage of the robust demand for commercial time among consumer marketers by aggressively raising ad rates. The networks' decoupling of ad rates to market share has not gone unnoticed by cable television executives, who are intensifying their pitches to Madison Avenue. **********Indeed, cable advertising revenue has been growing strongly; for the first six months of this year, the national cable networks took in $2.1 billion in ad revenue, up 25.7 percent from $1.7 billion in the corresponding period a year ago. **********Not everyone is a fan of branding. Critics point to the difficulty of linking disparate programs on a single network. Take ABC: it wants viewers for edgy dramas like ''N.Y.P.D. Blue''; slick sitcoms like ''Spin City,'' a new series starring Michael J. Fox, and fluffy favorites like ''America's Funniest Home Videos.'' **********The networks ''are overdoing it,'' said Walter Staab, chairman and president at the SFM Media Corporation, a New York agency that buys commercial time for advertisers. He said that the promotional spots the networks are running are ''detracting somewhat from the impact of our clients' commercials.'' **********Gene DeWitt, president at DeWitt Media, another New York media agency, agreed that ''a lot of the money branding networks is wasted.'' But he called brand-identification campaigns for specific nights ''a great idea because they give people a hook that they might remember.'' **********Yet network branding has met with some success, especially among the broadcasters' cable rivals. Networks like CNN, ESPN and MTV have drawn viewers almost as much for their catchy branding promotions as for their focused programming. **********Branding made its mark on broadcast TV in the late 1980's as Fox, a unit of the News Corporation, began developing an in-your-face image with promotional ploys that celebrated raucous sitcoms and flashy nighttime soap operas. **********''When people look at schedules, they say, 'That's a Fox-like show,' '' said Stacey Marks-Bronner, executive vice president for marketing at Fox in Beverly Hills, Calif. The strategy worked, drawing viewers 18 to 34 and 18 to 49. **********NBC followed earlier this decade, aiming at a similar audience, though perhaps more urbane. NBC shrewdly branded several popular sitcoms -- and by extension, the network's entire schedule -- as ''Must see TV'' with playful promotions that mix humor and celebrities with a nostalgic comeback for the NBC peacock. **********''We have tried to give our network an attitude of being a little bit smarter, a little bit riskier, a little bit funnier,'' said Vince Manze, senior vice president for advertising and promotion at the NBC unit of the General Electric Company in Burbank, Calif. **********''Everyone is doing it now,'' he added. NBC, which won the ratings race for the 1995-96 season, was the only large network to have increased viewership from the 1994-95 season. **********To try to duplicate that feat this year, the NBC promotional juggernaut is in overdrive. More than twice as many NBC commercials ran during the Summer Olympics as for the next largest advertiser, Coca-Cola. **********''We feel it's important to 'produce' the network,'' said John Miller, executive vice president for advertising and promotion and event programming at NBC. ''We want to give viewers a sense of place throughout each night.'' That is why ''Must see TV,'' which originally described a sitcom block on Thursdays, has been expanded to cover Tuesdays and Wednesdays, too. **********UPN is touting a ''Back to back'' block of comedies, many featuring black casts, on Mondays and part of Tuesdays. The theme is echoed for a block of dramas on Wednesdays. **********''Branding is extraordinarily important because the landscape from a competitive standpoint is so much more complex,'' said Joe Passarella, senior vice president for marketing and advertising at UPN, a joint venture of Chris-Craft Industries and Viacom Inc. in Los Angeles. **********CBS is so busily branding that the network has been the object of pointed jokes on two of its own shows. On ''Late Show With David Letterman'' Wednesday, Mr. Letterman mocked the ''Big comedy Monday'' slogan being used to peddle a block of four sitcoms starting with ''Cosby.'' Mr. Letterman claimed CBS was also hawking ''Really big comedy Wednesday'' and a Friday of ''Del comedia muy, muy hilarioso.'' **********And on the season premiere Monday of ''Murphy Brown,'' Murphy and her colleagues caught Stan Lansing, the fictitious head of CBS, watching a cartoon on WB. **********''It's funny and their network has that cute little singing frog,'' he said. ''Maybe we should spice up our mascot. But it's an eye.'' **********Suddenly, he had an idea. ''Wait!,'' he cried. ''We could call it Blinky . . . Blinky, the tap-dancing eye!'' **********CBS's ratings fell the most last season as the network, which is owned by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, lost 13 percent of its audience in a futile effort to appeal to younger viewers than its primary audience of 25-  to 54-year-olds. **********''Our objectives were noble,'' said James A. Warner, who, as president of the CBS Television Network in New York, is its real head. ''But we way overshot the target. So this year, our message is 'Welcome home,' to the CBS tradition of outstanding television, to a warm, trustworthy place, to the stars you know and like.'' **********Those stars include Bill Cosby, who won an unprecedented two-season, $50 million commitment from CBS for ''Cosby.'' The initial ratings were favorable: the debut episode, against less-than-strong competition, dominated its Monday time slot and helped CBS win the night. **********''Cosby'' is perhaps the season's most-promoted series and is being featured on display trucks that cruise Los Angeles and Manhattan, with promotional posters that change every five seconds; on free videocassettes offering a ''sneak peek'' of the season, and in a sweepstakes offering prizes of MCI long-distance phone calls. **********Those promotions show how willing the networks have become, as they court viewers, to experiment beyond traditional tactics like TV spots and ''tune-in'' advertisements. **********There is advertising in movie theaters, fast-food restaurants and on the Internet, as well as on cable and radio networks. There are mailings, posters, billboards, brochures and buses painted with the faces of series stars. There are tie-in promotions with big advertisers and contests with prizes like Pontiacs and walk-on roles in popular series. **********About the only come-on that's missing, it seems, is an offer of a job branding a network for next year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/21/busin.main_headline: Bias Suits Against Wall St. Firms
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/21/busin.print_headline: Bias Suits Against Wall St. Firms
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/21/busin.body_text: **********When the Rev. Jesse Jackson called on Texaco Inc. last week to urge the oil company to address racial discrimination, he arrived in the glare of television lights. But three years ago, a similar visit to Smith Barney Inc. received scant publicity. His workplace concern then: allegations of not only racial, but also sexual, discrimination made by a politically connected investment banker at one of Wall Street's biggest brokerage firms. **********Not long after, Smith Barney dealt with the issue by quietly paying $1.35 million to settle claims by Marianne Camille Spraggins that she had been humiliated and discriminated against because she was black and a woman. Ms. Spraggins, a high-profile managing partner at the firm, had been a fund-raiser for David N. Dinkins, the former New York mayor. **********The expensive settlement, however, did not end discrimination complaints at Smith Barney. And now they are no longer being made behind closed doors: in May, three female employees sued Smith Barney in Federal District Court in Manhattan, and by last month 22 more current and former employees from across the country had joined that action or a second lawsuit filed in California. **********Along with claims that the company -- a unit of Travelers Group Inc. -- had denied them promotions, the women accused male brokers of routinely subjecting them to abuse and unwanted sexual advances. When they complained of harassment, some of the women said, executives often ignored them; when the firm did investigate, it disclosed their identities prematurely, exposing them to retaliation. **********Smith Barney will not comment on the specific allegations, but rejects any suggestion that it tolerated sexual harassment or discrimination, a spokesman, Bob Connor, said. He said the company investigated all complaints and took appropriate action, but company officials said they could not disclose the number of complaints they had received or actions they had taken. **********''Our goal is to create an environment that is as free of discrimination and harassment as possible,'' Mr. Connor said, adding that there were high-ranking women in all levels of the firm's operations. **********Every so often a discrimination case takes on larger-than-life dimensions because of a smoking gun like the tapes on which Texaco executives discussed destroying documents requested for a racial discrimination case. But the kind of charges now surrounding Smith Barney, slowly unfolding for years amid competing claims and counterclaims, are more typical. **********Piercing to the factual heart of such claims is particularly difficult on Wall Street, where discrimination cases are heard not in the open forum of a courthouse, but in the closed-door proceedings of security-industry arbitration panels. Only those cases in which decisions are reached become public -- and few, it appears, make it through the process before being settled. **********While they wait for a Federal judge to decide whether to grant class-action status to their claims, however, the women at Smith Barney are opening Wall Street's doors by speaking out. **********In an interview this month, for example, Lisa Mays said her problems at Smith Barney began soon after she started work in 1989, as a wire operator at a branch in Walnut Creek, Calif. Starting work at 5:30 A.M., she typically found herself alone in the office with one broker. **********One day, Ms. Mays said, the broker suddenly cornered her, slammed her against a wall and tried to rip off her skirt while he unbuttoned his pants. The attack was halted by the arrival of a co-worker, Stanette Goepel. **********''I was really out of it for a long time,'' Ms. Mays said. ''I couldn't talk to anyone about anything. I wouldn't eat my lunch. I won't get up to go to the bathroom; I just did my work.'' **********When she finally told the branch manager about the incident months later, he said she was ''taking it wrong'' and that the broker ''would not have gone all the way,'' according to court papers filed by Ms. Mays and other plaintiffs. **********Her problems did not end there. Last year she transferred to a Smith Barney office in Larkspur, Calif., as an operations manager. According to her complaint, the office's manager referred to women as ''bitches,'' suggested that they had ''cyclical'' moods and told Ms. Mays to ''lay down and take it'' when brokers complained to her about office matters. **********Mr. Connor said Smith Barney would not comment on Ms. Mays's claims; the broker declined to comment and the office manager referred questions to Mr. Connor. **********Securities industry records show that cases have been filed against nearly every major brokerage firm. But while the aggressive world of Wall Street is often said to be rife with male harassment of women, there are few statistics to support the perception. **********Among the arbitration cases that were resolved and became public in the last two years, for example, there were only 26 discrimination complaints by women, most of them decided against the complainant, according to Richard Ryder, editor of the Securities Arbitration Commentator, an industry newsletter in Maplewood, N.J. **********That figure barely indicates the scope of the problem, according to several plaintiffs' lawyers active in discrimination and harassment lawsuits. ''About 90 percent of complaints we handle are settled before they are submitted for arbitration,'' said Judith Vladeck, a lawyer in New York. ''The problem is endemic.'' **********In 1994 the National Association of Securities Dealers studied the arbitration system and found it basically sound, said Linda Fienberg, the N.A.S.D.'s executive vice president and chief hearing officer for arbitrations. The process, she added, is also far less costly than litigation. **********But a 1994 study by the General Accounting Office, the research arm of Congress, found that the arbitrators assigned to discrimination cases did not appear to have any legal expertise in the area. In addition, 80 percent of arbitrators were white men, with women making up only 11 percent. **********At Smith Barney, the allegations range from officewide harassment, as claimed at a branch on Long Island, where female employees say they were groped and humiliated in a clubhouse-like ''Boom Boom Room,'' to individual cases accusing not only brokers but also a high-ranking investment banker. **********Following the company's investigation of the Long Island case, the branch manager was relieved of his duties and subsequently retired. **********According to the California suit, Ms. May wasn't the only woman to have problems in the Walnut Creek branch. **********Ms. Goepel, who started working as a receptionist at the office in 1990, contended that the same broker who reportedly attacked Ms. May frequently asked her about her favorite sexual position and would call her seeking ''phone sex.'' **********Ms. Goepel said in court papers that she repeatedly complained about the broker to her superiors, including two divisional managers, but no action was taken to investigate the matter. **********Ms. Goepel said she quit Smith Barney in 1994 and was now working at a brokerage firm where the atmosphere was less hostile toward women. ''I was just a single parent, trying to keep my act together and not be harassed,'' she said. **********Besides brokers, one leading investment banker at Smith Barney has been accused of harassment. **********In case filed last year in Federal District Court in Manhattan, Alicia DeGaetano charged that her boss, Frederick Hessler, a managing partner, made frequent sexual advances and suggested that her job advancement was tied to her response. **********Over a period of several months, court papers state, Mr. Hessler asked her out and tried to entice her to take out-of-town trips with him, court papers indicate. **********Finally, Ms. DeGaetano complained about Mr. Hessler to Smith Barney's legal department. She was subsequently told that company had found no evidence to support her allegations. **********''We found that her claims were without merit,'' Mr. Connor said. Mr. Hessler referred questions about the case to Mr. Connor. **********As with most harassment and discrimination claims involving Wall Street, the facts surrounding Ms. DeGaetano's claims may never be known. After she sued, a judge ordered the case removed from court and sent to a securities-industry panel for arbitration, where it remains.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/10/busin.main_headline: Bond Market Holds Stocks Back From Good-News Rally
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/10/busin.print_headline: Bond Market Holds Stocks Back From Good-News Rally
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/10/busin.body_text: **********The bond vigilantes have taken control of Wall Street, setting financial markets up for a wild ride whenever they spy the threat of inflation hiding behind an innocent statistic. Realistic inflation watchers discount them, but markets cannot. **********Although bond prices rose Tuesday, the stock market remained in **********the doldrums, and two stock plunges in two months after reports of healthy job growth in February and March raise a question: **********Why should the stock market go down at every sign of economic revival? **********The answer lies in the Treasury bond market. It now focuses almost exclusively on inflation, and to bond traders growth equals inflation, and inflation reduces the purchasing power of the principal and interest payments received on bond investments. This, in turn, reduces demand for bonds and lowers the prices people are willing to pay for them. **********Short-term traders therefore dump bonds at the first signs of rising prices for commodities, weakened government resolve to cut deficits or a mere hands-off signal by the Federal Reserve Board that it might not cut short-term interest rates. **********Their next marker will come with the producer price index on Thursday. A rise of 0.4 percent will be taken as a signal to sell bonds again at even lower prices. **********Since the start of the year, as prices of Treasury securities have fallen steadily, the yield on the benchmark 30-year issue has risen almost one full percentage point. Although the yield slipped to 6.83 percent Tuesday from 6.87 percent Monday, many analysts have predicted it would reach 7 percent soon. **********No wonder stocks are taking a beating. With average dividends on the Standard & Poor's 500 stocks at record-low yields of about 2 percent, bond returns look more attractive every day. Especially when the Dow's gain of 1,875 points since the start of 1994 is equal to the gain of the past eight years, said Stephen Langan of Nichols, Santina & Lerner, who last month predicted the Dow would drop a whopping 500 points in April because "this can't last." **********But the short-term bond traders have forgotten that their actions may become a self-fulfilling prophecy and automatically slow the economy, warned Geoffrey Bell, a New York investment adviser and executive secretary of the Group of 30, a bankers' study group. **********"The bond market now is doing what the Fed used to do and has become its advance guard," he said. "As interest rates go up, demand for housing, autos, and other interest-sensitive goods will go down. It is a self-correcting process for the economy. We continue to be in a disinflationary environment." **********He also warned that Europe could be dragged deeply into the economic doldrums if it stood aside and permitted rising U.S. rates to permeate global markets instead of actively fighting back by lowering rates, starting with the Bundesbank. **********Wall Street nevertheless sees strong inflation warnings in rising prices of oil, wheat, corn, and gold. "Very premature," snapped Anir Van Banerji, senior economist at Columbia University's Center for International Business Cycle Research, whose leading inflation index rose 0.4 percent in February from March. **********The index expresses direction of inflation rather than its strength, and throughout 1995 it had been going down. All that is happening, he said, is "a dissipation of disinflationary pressures." In other words, after a full year, air has finally stopped hissing out of the economic balloon and nothing more. **********Wall Street follows the Commodity Research Bureau index 17 commodities because it tracks futures prices, and agricultural futures have pushed it up nearly 5 percent this year. Columbia uses the Journal of Commerce's index, which is heavily weighted with industrial materials and has remained fairly steady. **********Moreover, said Michael Aronstein of West Course Capital, none of these indexes take account the shift in business practice in which "everyone becomes a hero by holding no inventory." Sudden demand for crude oil has pushed up prices for immediate delivery by nearly $5 a barrel this year, but that can evaporate in days, he warned. Oil bought on six-month contract can be bought for far less and those prices do not show up in the index. **********Aside from highly volatile food and energy prices, said Rosanne Cahn, CS First Boston equity economist, "nothing's going up." Moreover, she said, even if interest rates are going up, "it made hardly any difference to the stock market when it last happened in 1994." **********During that year, short-term rates doubled, but stock prices declined only 4 percent as measured by monthly averages. By contrast, in past soft economic landings like this one, rising interest rates bought a 15 percent decline in stock prices. The difference is the underlying shift toward higher rewards in the capital markets than the labor market, she said, and that is not going to change soon.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/15/busin.main_headline: Behind the Scenes;Computer Critters: Way Beyong Mr. Ed.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/15/busin.print_headline: Behind the Scenes;Computer Critters: Way Beyong Mr. Ed.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/15/busin.body_text: **********It takes several years of training to teach a lion to not bite the trainer's  head off while it is in the animal's mouth. During the filming of a movie, most  animals can memorize only one to two tricks at a time. **********When the producers of "Jumanji" leafed through the script, they knew that they could not make the movie at reasonable cost using live animals. **********With the help of Joe Johnston, the director, and Industrial Light and Magic, the chair-and-whip routine was replaced by a team of animators who worked for a  little more than a year to bring the film's digital creatures to life. Doug Smythe, the computer graphics sequence supervisor for the film, said that additional work was done with computer puppets, much like the frogs in the Budweiser beer commerical. **********The whole digital animal tradition may have started with the MCA/Universal film "Babe," which featured talking barnyeard animals and the work of the Thythm and Hues computer effects house. They improved upon the nylon bit that Cult TV,  a book by John Gavna, said was used to make Mr. Ed look discursive in the 1960's sitcom about a talking horse. **********The efficiency of using the digital creatures has increased as the computer-effects houses have become more familiar with adopting the techonology  to specific animals. The lion in "Jumanji" took seven months to develop. And no  trainers were scratched in the process.   TY AHMAD--TAYLOR **********INVERSE KINEMATICS **********Some companies use a technique called inverse kinematics to define a skeleton underneath the animated figure. Once sketched in digitally, the skeleton defines the way each figure moves. It is programmed with instructions that determine how the joints work together. Different companies set different attributes, so their figures move in a unique fashion. **********Using I.K. also saves time: to move an arm, for example, the animator need only tug at the hand. Without I.K., he would need to move the hand, then the wrist, then the arm, and so on. **********INDUSTRIAL LIGHT AND MAGIC'S DIGITAL LION **********The largest of the special-effects houses had the most digital animals to generate when it started work on Tri-Star's "Jumanji." The work done for "Jurassic Park" was a starting point, but that work focused on the relatively easy plastic-like skin of dinosaurs. Creating animals with hair and human-like abilities (monkeys drive a motorcycle in one scene) was a leap forward from that older technology. **********THE MANE **********The mane was especially hard to do in the computer realm because its intricate detail is difficult to draw in 3-D. Each hair could be calculated as a cluster of two-dimensional polygons. I.L.M. cheated the process by using texture maps, a process used in video games. **********TEXTURE MAPS **********ROUGH RENDER **********The Designer can make the basic form, or wireframe, as detailed or simple as she wants to. The version at right is called "rough render" because it does not have much detail. **********More complex figures take more time to render because the computer spends more time doing calculations. **********TEXTURE MAP **********A designer can create a rough render, shown at 1, and then apply a texture map,  or muscles in this case. The computer applies the digital skin to the rough frame, and then can draw the entrie body faster than if it had to render each muscle. **********Digital Animals at Other Special-Effects Houses **********DIGITAL DOMAIN

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/22/busin.main_headline: Taking In the Sites;Government Regulations, In Their Electronic Form
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/22/busin.print_headline: Taking In the Sites;Government Regulations, In Their Electronic Form
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/22/busin.body_text: **********The newly hired chief executive at the Acme Widget Company, Betty Boss, wants to make sure that her business is in compliance with Federal regulations. Acme,  a mythical manufacturing company with 432 employees that makes widgets, is subject to rules and regulations on safety, environmental practices, labor laws  and trade. So, Ms. Boss turns to the World Wide Web to start her research. **********Some Federal regulations can be obtained directly from the Web pages of regulatory agencies. For example, the 1970 Occupational Safety and Health Act is available on the home page of the Labor Department's Occupational Safety and  Health Administration. There is also a searching mechanism for regulations and standards, which contains the detailed rules used to enforce the act. **********A search for "lighting and manufacturing" yields information on inspections, equipment requirements, electrical standards and penalties. For instance, standard number 1926.56 lists minimum illumination requirements (in foot-candles) for construction areas, and standard number 1926.405 (a)(2)(ii)(B) directs: "Conductors shall be run as multiconductor cord or cable assemblies or  open conductors, or shall be run in raceways." Obviously, the lawyers at Acme Widget are going to have to read through some of these regulations. **********Other Federal agencies, like the Environmental Protection Agency and the Food and Drug Administration, allow computer users to search for laws or the regulations and guidelines and items published in the Federal Register. **********There are also two major sites to find related studies and reports published  by the Federal Government.  Fedworld is a home page set up by the National Technical Information Service, an agency that is part of the Technology Administration of the Department of Commerce. The agency, which sells its information, is a source for business, scientific and technical reports, surveys and data bases. Once a product is found, it can be ordered by telephone, mail, fax or over the Internet. **********The second site is the Government Information Locator Service, which bills itself as an on-line catalogue of information resources. A search on this page yields the name of the Federal agency that gathered the information, a description of the document, and how to get it. **********Finally, there is the Government Printing Office page. The page has a searching mechanism for the monthly catalogue of United States Government publications. When a document is chosen, the researcher can find the nearest Federal depository library through which it can be obtained. The site also provides the catalogue information for a publication and the closest Government  Printing Office bookstore. **********Many of these Federal Web sources are linked. But, if Betty Boss wants sites  that offer a broader look at the Government, many universities and public-policy research institutes offer excellent pages. **********Among these are the Federal Web Locator, which is run by the Villanova Center for Information Law and Policy, and the United States Government information page of the Joseph Bartunek 3d Law Library of Cleveland State University.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/04/busin.body_text: **********Continuing an industry effort to create a mass market for digital cameras, the Eastman Kodak Company introduced a product yesterday that the company expects to sell for less than $350. **********That price would be half the previous lowest for Kodak's digital cameras, and far below the models selling for up to $10,000 that Kodak produces for professional photographers. **********Instead of using photographic film, digital cameras capture an image as a digital file that can be stored, edited and transmitted by computers. **********Electronic cameras have gone into wide use in journalism and industrial photography because the images are instant and can be transmitted quickly over telephone lines. **********But they have made hardly a ripple in the consumer market, if only because even the most basic cameras have been priced above $500 until recently. **********Earlier this year, Epson and Casio each introduced digital cameras with a suggested price of $499, and the Casio model, the QV-10, is being advertised by  some stores in New York at $399.95. **********Kodak introduced its $350 camera, the DS-20, yesterday at the Comdex computer show in Chicago. The device, small enough to fit in a shirt pocket, can store 8  to 16 color pictures, depending on the image resolution selected, and transfer them to a Macintosh or Windows-based computer. **********The camera comes with a software program, Kai's Power Goo from Meta Tools Inc., that allows the user to manipulate the image on the computer in various ways. Pictures can be stretched and squeezed and distorted in any direction, as  long as the information is already contained in the image. **********The software also enables users to insert photos into greeting cards or into  digital "picture postcards" that can be sent via E-mail. **********Adding Power Goo as one of the camera's accessories is a way of attracting people to the creative possibilities of electronic photography, Kodak officials  say. **********"The bottom line is fun," said Nick Billow, the company's digital camera product manager. "You show kids how to use it and they go crazy. Adults tend to  say it is silly, but they use it anyway."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/16/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;After $5 billion is bet, marketers are racing to be noticed amid the clutter at  the Summer Games.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/16/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;After $5 billion is bet, marketers are racing to be noticed amid the clutter at  the Summer Games.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/16/busin.body_text: **********IF commercialization and ambushing were Olympic sports, the Summer Games, which start on Friday, could be called off before they began, because the United States would have already won more gold medals than Atlanta has grits. **********The Centennial Olympiad, which continues through Aug. 4, will be the biggest, and most lavishly sponsored, ever. The trade publication Advertising Age even declares it "the marketing event of the century," as advertisers spend an estimated $5 billion worldwide on Olympic-related campaigns, promotions and events. That includes the $675 million worth of commercial time -- 20 hours of spots -- that NBC has sold during 171.5 hours of Summer Games coverage. **********As a result, the 250 or so marketers that have agreed to be sponsors, licensees or suppliers of the 1996 Games are in a mad scramble to find ways to stand out amid that advertising overload. And they must also figure out how to fend off the pesky efforts of so-called ambush marketers that exploit Olympic and athletic imagery to create perceptions among consumers of official ties that do not actually exist. **********"The clutter will be so enormous, I'm not sure the public walks away with any distinctive view of you," said David F. D'Alessandro, senior executive vice president of the John Hancock Life Insurance Company in Boston. Hancock paid $40 million to be a worldwide Olympic sponsor. **********Even though "we find that extraordinarily beneficial," Mr. D'Alessandro said, "I'm to a point where I no longer believe a sponsor should buy any time on the games." **********Rather, he added, marketers probably ought to concentrate their Olympic-themed campaigns before and after the actual event. So while Hancock will run regular commercials during the Olympics, a special 90-second spot produced in-house -- a paean to American athletes set to the Judy Collins version of "Amazing Grace" -- will appear one time only, during the opening ceremonies. **********The Coca-Cola Company, the largest single Olympic advertiser, is spending an  estimated $250 million on activities before, during and after the Games. That includes $62 million worth of commercial time on NBC to run an unprecedented barrage of 100 different spots, created by more than a dozen agencies, for brands like Coca-Cola Classic, Diet Coke and Sprite as well as celebrations of the opening and closing ceremonies. **********"We're trying to be unique in the approach we take to make sure we don't just become one more sponsor," said Sergio Zyman, senior vice president and chief marketing officer of Coca-Cola. He attributed a 17 percent increase in second-quarter net income from the corresponding quarter last year, which Coca-Cola announced yesterday, to an extensive pre-Olympic campaign. **********During the Games, the Coca-Cola blitz will feature what Mr. Zyman called "just-in-time advertising": 17 commercials created fresh daily, presenting highlights of events and promoting themed pitches like "world sports" and "sounds of refreshment." The company is also blanketing Atlanta, its headquarters city, with everything from vending machines to "cooling zones" that will spritz sweaty fans with water. **********Yet even mighty Coca-Cola has been ambushed in its hometown, Mr. Zyman said,  as "Gatorade is sampling product on the streets." That sports drink, marketed by the Quaker Oats Company, competes against Powerade, the Coca-Cola brand that is  the official Olympic sports drink. **********Quaker is only one marketer without official ties to the Summer Olympics that is pursuing an ambitious ambush agenda, despite attempts by Olympic officials to end what they describe as parasite marketing. The Blockbuster Entertainment unit of Viacom Inc. is promoting a "Games of summer sweepstakes" -- video games, that is. And a print ad for Gucci watches uses five colored rings evocative of the Olympic symbol, though Swatch watches are the official Olympic timekeepers. **********The most relentless Atlanta ambusher is Nike Inc., which in a campaign by Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., has appropriated almost every Olympic element except the weird-looking mascot Izzy. Reebok International Ltd. is the official Olympic licensee and supplier. **********A Nike magazine insert asserts, "If you can't stand the heat, get out of Atlanta." A television commercial declares: "You don't win silver. You lose gold." The campaign even dares to mock the concept of official sponsorship by proclaiming: "We don't sell dreams. We sell shoes." **********"We feel strongly we haven't misappropriated anything," said Keith Peters, a  spokesman for Nike. "We're not an Olympic sponsor and we're not trying to create an impression we are. **********Dave Fogelson, a spokesman for Reebok, said: "It's a nonissue as far as we're concerned. It's a given the major shoe companies all have an involvement." **********"There are benefits to being involved officially," he added, such as Reebok's role in the giant Coca-Cola Olympic City exhibit, open from Memorial Day through Labor Day, and "a very nice retail presence" at the Centennial Olympic Park. The main focus of Reebok's program is the outfitting of athletes of more than 50 national Olympic committees. **********One marketer known as an Olympic ambusher, the American Express Company, is quiet -- so far. **********If Visa International, an Olympic sponsor, does not "use the Olympics to bash a competitor," said John Hayes, executive vice president for global advertising  at American Express in New York, Amex will forgo such ploys as a campaign that appeared during the 1992 Summer Games in Barcelona. Those ads ended, "And remember, to visit Spain, you don't need a visa."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/17/busin.main_headline: The Next Thing to Go Global Will Be Toll-Free Numbers
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/17/busin.print_headline: The Next Thing to Go Global Will Be Toll-Free Numbers
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/17/busin.body_text: **********Toll-free telephone numbers are one of those things -- like country music and automobile cup-holders -- that flourish here but have never really caught on overseas. **********Now, though, the United Nations agency that sets telecommunications policy has approved a global standard for toll-free calls. By enabling callers to make  these calls across borders, the International Telecommunication Union hopes to rouse this business overseas. **********Dozens of countries allow consumers to dial toll-free and pass the charges along to the recipient of the call. But the numbers generally only work domestically. If you are in Brussels, for example, and you want to buy a plane ticket to New York on Delta Air Lines, using its toll-free line, you would have  to know its toll-free number for Belgium. Until recently, you would also have had to dial Belgium's toll-free prefix. **********To eliminate this jumble of numbers and prefixes, the International Telecommunication Union has opted to use the American "800" prefix worldwide and to assign companies one toll-free number that works anywhere. So a caller in Brussels would need only to dial 800, plus an eight-digit number. The organization adopted an eight-digit system because the United States has already used up every possible seven-digit number with an "800" prefix. On March 1, AT&T and other carriers began assigning new toll-free numbers with an "888" prefix. **********"I think this will generate increased demand for international toll-free numbers," said Susan G. Mirbach, the president of Belgacom North America, a unit of Belgium's state telephone service. **********Toll-free service has grown into a vast and lucrative business in the United  States since it started in 1967. AT&T estimates that "800" numbers account for 40 percent of the traffic on its network, or 80 million calls a day. The telephone companies collect about $10 billion in revenue from this business every year. **********The plan is not without its pitfalls, Ms. Mirbach said. The agency, which is  based in Geneva, plans to assign "800" numbers on a first-come, first-serve basis, starting in February. Because American companies are well-versed with the "800" system, she said some foreign companies were afraid the Americans would "monopolize the good numbers." **********The uniform toll-free number will also enable American telemarketing companies to expand abroad: 1-800-FLOWERS, the floral delivery service, plans to begin marketing throughout Europe. **********One thing 1-800-FLOWERS will not be able to do is use its vanity telephone number abroad. The buttons on the key pads of most foreign telephones have no letters.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/15/busin.snippet: Number of prestigious private boarding schools, dismayed by paucity of middle-income students, are offering financial aid to students; officials of Phillips Academy, Philips Exeter and Choate Rosemary Hall comment; photos of students (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/15/busin.main_headline: Choate on the Cheap: Prep Schools Woo the Middle Class
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/15/busin.print_headline: Choate on the Cheap: Prep Schools Woo the Middle Class
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/15/busin.body_text: **********GWEN HALEY teaches at a public high school in Stratford, Conn. Her husband, Ted, is a drug rehabilitation counselor. Together they make a decent income, but not enough to simply say yes when their younger son, Ben, announced he wanted to go to Choate Rosemary Hall, a  boarding school with a blue-chip reputation and a price tag of more than $22,000 a year. **********So they applied for financial aid, and received an award that covered half of Ben's costs for his freshman year. The following years, his aid was increased to meet three-fourths of the cost because by then Ben's older brother had entered a private college. **********''I would say to anybody who wants to go to a school like that, just go for it,'' said Mrs. Haley, whose son graduated last year and now attends Amherst College. **********During the last few years, sending your child to boarding school -- that fabled realm of quaint buildings around a picturesque green; steam tables loaded with mysterious, clotted entrees, and well-weathered teachers wielding big academic sticks -- has become surprisingly attainable for people like the Haleys. Dismayed by the paucity of middle-income students on their campuses, the nation's boarding schools are widening the array of financial-aid options for people who know they are not rich enough to pay outright and have long presumed they were too rich to receive help. **********The eligibility rules vary from school to school, but many families with substantial salaries are receiving help. At Phillips Exeter Academy in Exeter, N.H., for example, middle income now refers to people earning  between $60,000 and $120,000 a year. This year, 70 of the 331 financial-aid awards went to students whose families fell into that category. The Emma Willard School in Troy, N.Y., gave aid to 46.7 percent of its 270 students. Nearly all the families who received that aid reported incomes of more than $75,000. **********At Concord Academy, a coeducational school in Concord, Mass., 23 students whose parents earned $60,000 or more received awards that averaged $12,000 apiece. At St. George's School in Newport, R.I., someone whose parents earned $145,000 still got a break on the cost this year. **********''There's no income cutoff because there are so many variables,'' said Jay Doolittle, director of admissions and financial aid at St. George's. ''If you make $100,000 and you have three or four children at tuition-paying schools, you could easily qualify for aid.'' **********High fees, now as high as those at many colleges, and attributed to unavoidables like salaries, heating bills, technology and deferred maintenance, are one reason that  boarding schools are offering a more generous helping hand. The median annual cost, including tuition, room and board, has risen  from $10,195 in the 1985-86 school year to $19,850 in the 1995-96 year, according to the National Association of Independent Schools in Washington. That is a 94.7 percent increase in dollars, and a 37.1 percent increase after inflation is taken into account. **********Particularly in the 1990's, these numbers can unnerve a group that admissions directors call ''the emotional middle class.'' **********These people earn far more than the Government's definition of middle income. Children in families earning $35,000 a year would receive automatic free rides at a typical boarding school. But while many middle-class families could and did send their children to boarding school through the 1970's, these days many more of them balk. They worry about an insecure job market, another four years of tuition at college and the specter of a penny-pinching  retirement as traditional pensions vanish. **********Boarding schools are worried, too --  about losing their socioeconomic diversity. In some institutions, enrollments have started to resemble barbells, with the wealthy clustered at one end and the woefully deprived at the other. Over the last decade, the same concern has propelled many colleges to award merit scholarships to even out their enrollments. **********At Choate Rosemary Hall, ''we definitely want to avoid having just the haves and the have-nots,'' said Charlotte Murphy, the school's communications director. ''It's an issue that all the schools are hearing and are concerned about.'' **********At Exeter, trustees were hearing complaints at alumni cocktail parties that tuition had spiraled beyond many people's means. A comparison of middle-class enrollment in the 1950's and in the 1990's found a definite discrepancy, said Rick Mahoney, the director of financial aid at the school. ''We still had a spread, but we felt the middle-income group was less well represented here than they were 40 years ago.'' **********Thomas Hassan, Exeter's admissions director, said: ''It's part of our charter that this place shall ever be open to youth from every quarter. We want to get all kinds of kids. It's just healthier.'' **********THE schools, eager for the best students, know they face tough competition. ''Our biggest competitors are the public high schools, for which the price tag is zero,'' said Trudy Hanmer, Emma Willard's director of admissions and associate head of school. Moreover, ''it is not an expectation that middle-income families are going to pay for high school,'' she said, and when they do they ''typically pay for education out of discretionary income, not out of trust funds.'' **********For all these reasons, boarding schools have set aside more money in the last few years for the middle class. In 1994, for instance, Exeter began offering more aid to families with incomes of $60,000 to $120,000, Mr. Hassan said. **********Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., with a $6.7 million aid budget, recently increased its middle-class support too. In the 1992-93 school year, 52 families with incomes greater than $80,000 received aid from the school; this fall, 140 such families will. **********The schools, which generate their financial-aid money from endowment earnings or annual campaigns, can often be generous with both the size and number of awards. After all, they are making them for just three or four years, not 14 as with schools that run from prekindergarten through grade 12. Choate, for example, gave an average award of $14,000 to middle-class students this year, while at St. George's the average was $11,900. (But never say ''scholarship'' in talking about the new largess. The somewhat cumbersome ''need-based financial aid'' is preferred.) **********One beneficiary is Amanda Cohen, an Exeter senior from Sacramento, Calif. The school covers about three-quarters of the  $20,000 tuition. ''Let's put it this way,'' said her father, Ned, a deputy counsel for the California Legislature. ''I don't make enough to send Amanda to Exeter. But we made the decision that we would afford it, and that she would go.'' **********His daughter, he added, has flourished. ''They work them to death,'' he said, approvingly. ''I think she's gone through four years of sleep deprivation.'' **********Besides outright grants like Amanda's, monthly payment plans are offered by most schools to help those without ready chunks of cash. For a $70 annual fee, Concord Academy will deduct a monthly payment directly from parents' checking accounts, said Rachel Countryman, the school's director of financial aid. **********Schools can also steer families to low-interest loans. Knight College Resource Group, which administers many monthly payment plans, offers through many schools  a low-interest, variable-rate loan pegged to the 13-week Treasury-bill rate. **********For many families, aid ends up being a combination of grants, loans and payment plans. ''In general, we will meet about 80 percent of a family's need,'' said James F. Ventre, financial aid director of Phillips Academy. ''And then we will help them come up with the other 20 percent.'' **********Nevertheless, many middle-class parents are too embarrassed to acknowledge that they cannot afford boarding school. Many also believe that to check the box next to the question ''Are you applying for financial aid?'' is to deal a death blow to their child's chances for admission. **********Charles Pittman, an advertising manager from Charlotte, N.C., battled those anxieties when he applied for aid to send his son, Tony, to Andover in 1989. ''I thought at this stage of my life I should have been better prepared,'' he said. ''But I don't think you can prepare for this unless you make tons of money.'' **********Since then, he has sent his two daughters there, too. His youngest, Mauresa, is a senior who manages the football team. She said that once she enrolled, she felt no different from anyone else on campus. ''Nobody asked, and nobody brought it up,'' she said. **********PARENTS might be surprised at how many boarding-school students receive aid. At Deerfield Academy in Deerfield, Mass., for instance, only about two-thirds of the families pay full tuition and ''most of them were born into it,'' said Bill Cumming, the admissions director. The remainder receive financial aid or use monthly payment plans. **********Parents need to squelch their reluctance  and check the box when they apply, Mr. Cumming said. After all, what is more painful: a little honesty now or a huge humiliation later? **********''I don't want to get blindsided in the middle of someone's junior year by a phone call from the father, saying 'I've tapped everything I have, I can't come up with the money, and he won't be coming back,' '' Mr. Cumming said. ''It's not the best thing for the child.'' **********Some schools have revised the aid process to help eliminate embarrassment and worry. At Concord, all parents receive information about financing options along with the application packet. **********Concord also handles all aid requests on a sheet of paper apart from the rest of the application. ''We've started not to have a box per se,'' Ms. Countryman said. ''We were concerned about keeping the two processes separate.'' At many schools, just who is getting help is a closely held secret as well. Gone are the days when scholarship students had to help out in the dining hall. **********Despite all this concern and generosity, however, there is no guarantee that asking means you will receive. Only a handful of schools -- Deerfield is one -- call their admissions need-blind, and even they acknowledge that their resources are not so bottomless that they never turn down someone who needs help with tuition. **********''There are a lot of families who may well qualify for financial aid but won't get it because the school doesn't have a big enough financial-aid budget,'' said Meade B. Thayer, director of financial aid services for the National Association of Independent Schools. The approach may differ: a Concord applicant may be accepted and not receive aid, while Deerfield tries not to accept someone who needs aid unless the money is available. But the point is that there is not enough cash to go around. **********Parents should not conceal assets, however, because while the schools may be more supportive, they are often vigilant in checking the truth of applications. **********''Some people think it's a hiding game, but these days it's real easy for us to find out about other information,'' said Mr. Ventre, of Phillips Academy. ''They do have to provide tax returns, and we have C.P.A.'s here who are trained to look things over.'' **********While aid is clearly welcome, it hardly means easy street for the middle class. **********''We haven't been on a real vacation in a long time,'' Mrs. Haley said, ''and we drive old cars.'' **********Mr. Pittman said, ''It's the sacrifice we've opted to make, to give our children the best education possible.'' With financial aid, he added, the boarding-school experience becomes manageable. **********''It stretches you,'' he said, ''but at the same time, it doesn't bankrupt you.''
