https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/05/busin.body_text: **********Osram Sylvania Inc. in Danvers, Mass., a unit of Osram G.m.b.h. of Germany, said yesterday that it had named Mullen Advertising in Wenham, Mass., to handle  advertising for its consumer specialty lamp and industrial commercial lighting divisions. The billings were estimated at $7 million. Mullen was awarded the account after a three-month review that was narrowed to that agency and the two  incumbents: Poppe Tyson in New York, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, which handled the specialty and industrial commercial division, and Leonard/ Monahan in Providence, which handled the consumer division.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/27/busin.body_text: **********A partnership that includes a development company owned by the basketball star Magic Johnson has agreed to buy a Los Angeles shopping center for $20.1 million. The purchase is among the first by the partnership, California Urban Investment Partners, which was formed in March with $51.5 million to invest in retail properties in California cities. The firm is buying the 184,684-square-foot Ladera shopping center in southwest Los Angeles with Burnham Pacific Properties Inc., a San Diego real estate company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/02/busin.main_headline: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTINGWhat Now?; Even if '74 Rings a Bell, Avoiding The Market Remains a Risk, Too
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/02/busin.print_headline: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTINGWhat Now?; Even if '74 Rings a Bell, Avoiding The Market Remains a Risk, Too
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/02/busin.body_text: **********THE reason so few professionals on Wall Street remember the last real bear market -- 1973, when stock values fell 15 percent, and 1974, when they fell 26 percent -- is that most of the unlucky ones who suffered through it have made so much money in the last 20 years that they could retire. **********About the only people still around to rekindle the memories of those dark days, and to warn that the good times will not last, are financial journalists.  And many of them have been wrong about stocks for nearly a decade. **********Simply put, the biggest risk to individual investors in recent times has come from not being invested in the market. **********An investor in a mutual fund that matched the performance of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, among the most watched market indicators, would not have suffered an annual loss of more than 5 percent in any year since 1977. Seven times in those 18 years, the annual return on the S.& P. 500 exceeded 20 percent, assuming all dividends were reinvested. **********Four times, there were back-to-back gains exceeding 15 percent, and in three  of those four, the second year was better than the first. **********In all but two of the 18 years -- 1981 and 1990 -- investments gauged by the  S.& P. 500 made money. Even in 1987, when stocks took a frantic tumble, falling  22 percent in one day, the S.& P. index finished the year with a gain of 5 percent. **********None of which means that investors are assured of double-digit returns in 1996, or even single-digit returns. But the outlook for stocks for the rest of the decade -- a decade in which inflation has all but died, interest rates have  been tame and the economy has continued to chug along -- appears sound at this point. **********So it should be of little surprise that more money than ever poured into mutual funds that invest in American stocks in 1995. So good was the year that the previous record, set in '93, was broken in November, with a full month to be reported. **********Over the next five years, the chances are that those investors will make money. In the shorter term, however, "investors could be disappointed if they jumped in for the first time in the last quarter of 1995," said John C. Bogle, chairman of the Vanguard Group, the country's second-largest mutual fund company after the Fidelity group. "Investors certainly have been informed about the rewards of investing," he said. "I wonder if they have been well enough informed about the risks." **********One of the greatest risks the market faces this year is likely to be that all those individuals who plunged into the market recently will flee if results in the first half do not measure up to their expectations. **********"I'm concerned about the growing illiquidity in the marketplace," said A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services, which tracks mutual fund performance. "The capital of the big Wall Street firms is not growing at the same rate as the capital invested by institutional investors," including mutual funds. **********That means that Wall Street, which often has been able to absorb selling pressure when investors might be inclined to panic, might not be as much of a cushion during sharp declines, Mr. Lipper said. **********Wall Street is not the only place where liquidity has been drying up. "Household liquidity is down considerably over the last several years," said Byron R. Wien, portfolio strategist for Morgan Stanley & Company. "Individuals do not have the money to keep up the pace of mutual fund investments they have over the last few years." **********In addition, Mr. Wien warned, "debt burdens have hampered consumers' willingness to spend," which could prove to be a bigger drag on the economy than some people anticipate. "That was one of the reasons that Christmas retail sales were so disappointing," he said. **********BUT far from Wall Street, where the horizons are broader and individuals pay  less attention to wrangling in Washington and the nuances of economic pronouncements, many investors remain positive about prospects for growth from the big engines of the economy -- capital goods and machinery makers. **********"I think the environment of low interest rates and inflation that propelled the market over the last year should continue in the first half of '96," said Alan B. Lancz, an investment adviser in Toledo, Ohio, who also writes a stock-picking and economic newsletter. **********Mr. Lancz, who last year included the media giants CBS, Time Warner and Times Mirror among his favorite stocks, this year sees the greatest potential in several companies engaged in more basic industries, which should benefit from lower interest rates around the globe. **********Among them, Mr. Lancz said, are Imperial Chemical Industries and Hanson P.L.C., two British conglomerates; the Lubrizol Corporation, a producer of engine oils and fluids, and two Canadian energy concerns, TransCanada Pipelines  and Westcoast Energy. **********In the second half of the year, the Presidential and Congressional elections  are likely to drive economic and financial concerns and to have unpredictable effects on certain stock sectors. In January 1992, few on Wall Street would have predicted that Bill Clinton would be elected President, much less anticipated the wringer that stocks of health care companies would be put through in concern over the President-to-be's proposals for medical care. **********So while the outlook is positive for people who truly are long-term investors, with expectations of staying around for five years or so, the only certainty in the short term is that past performance is no guarantee of future results. Investors hoping for another year of better-than-30-percent gains in stock prices are likely to be disappointed. But fearful investors who stay on the sidelines will probably be worse off.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/14/busin.body_text: **********Liggett Breaks Ranks, Settling Tobacco Suit The Liggett Group, the smallest of the nation's five major cigarette companies,  broke industry ranks, agreeing to settle a huge class-action lawsuit. Lawyers representing millions of smokers agreed to drop the company from the suit in return for payments to a national quit-smoking campaign and Liggett's promise to withdraw from the fight against new tobacco regulations from the F.D.A. **********Liggett and the plaintiffs' lawyers were scrambling to broaden the settlement to another battleground: lawsuits brought by states to recover billions of Medicaid dollars that have been spent to treat illnesses attributed to tobacco.  [Page A1.] **********Legal experts predicted the settlement could lead to an onslaught of lawsuits against others in the tobacco industry. [D6.] **********LeBow 'Got a Great Deal'  Bennett S. LeBow, in agreeing to settle a class-action suit against his Liggett  Group, "got a great deal, and gave up nothing," one analyst said. He limited Liggett's liability and won leverage in his battle to force the RJR Nabisco Holdings Company to spin off its food unit from its tobacco business. Market Place. [D7.] **********Mr. LeBow has a reputation for clever financial dealings that can raise eyebrows -- as well as ire -- on Wall Street. [D7.] **********Product Liability Limits  Congressional negotiators reached final agreement on a compromise measure to limit suits involving faulty products. It would set limits on money awarded for injuries from products as diverse as food blenders, prescription drugs, heart valves and automobiles. But bipartisan support for the bill in the Senate  is fragile. [B12.] **********G.O.P. Leaders Soften Debt Stand  Speaker Newt Gingrich and Senator Bob Dole softened their stance on legislation  to extend the Government's borrowing authority, turning to a plan that both conservative Republicans and President Clinton are likely to find acceptable. [B11.] **********Dow Slides; Most Stocks Rise  Stocks generally rose, but the blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average, weighted  down by a slide in tobacco stocks, declined 15.17 points, to 5,568.72. The broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks gained 1.46 points, to 638.55, and the Nasdaq composite index, helped by gains in technology issues, jumped 15.59 points -- or almost 1 1/2 percent -- to 1,088.64. [D8.] **********Prices of Treasury securities slipped with the 30-year bond falling 5/32 of a percentage point, to 91 9/32 ; its yield rose to 6.68 percent. [D18.] **********Compuserve Plans Family Service  Even as other commercial on-line providers move toward fewer proprietary offerings, Compuserve plans a service, called Wow! featuring materials aimed at  families and children. Wow! will also provide access to the World Wide Web and will equip parents with controls to limit children's access to Internet sites. [D2.] **********Successful Well in Gulf of Mexico  Phillips Petroleum and Anadarko Petroleum drilled another successful well in the Gulf of Mexico. The discovery significantly increased the prospect of tapping large reserves of oil and natural gas below layers of salt that cover sizable parts of existing fields. [D5.] **********Toys "R" Us Earnings Slide  Toys "R" Us reported a 77.3 percent slide in fourth-quarter earnings, which it attributed largely to a $270 million charge to close stores and consolidate distribution centers. The company, the world's largest specialty toy retailer, earned $93 million, or 34 cents a share. [D4.] **********Calvin Klein Promoting Khakis  Calvin Klein is promoting a new line of khaki shirts, slacks, shorts and outerwear for men and women, with narrow-hipped models displaying equal measures of attitude and skin. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D4.]

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/18/world.main_headline: Guatemala's Uneasy Time: No War but No Peace Pact
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/18/world.print_headline: Guatemala's Uneasy Time: No War but No Peace Pact
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/18/world.body_text: **********For the first time in 35 years, Guatemala is no longer racked by civil war. But a definitive peace agreement formalizing the end of hostilities between the armed forces and leftist guerrillas has yet to be concluded, leaving the country uneasy and impatient. **********The Government and the rebel leaders have been negotiating sporadically for five years in an effort to bring an end to a conflict that has killed more than 100,000 people since it erupted in 1961. **********The talks were stalled until this spring, when the rebels declared a cease-fire and the new President, Alvaro Arzu Irigoyen, responded by ordering the armed forces to halt all offensive operations. **********''We are in an intermediate situation,'' Rolando Moran, a rebel commander, said in an interview in El Salvador in late July. ''The war has not ended, but we have proclaimed the political struggle as the means to revolution, because we recognize that armed struggle is no longer feasible.'' **********Mr. Moran praised Mr. Arzu, saying he had put into effect ''changes that are very important and significant,'' most notably ''changes that herald a reconversion and modernization of the armed forces.'' **********The situation now, Mr. Moran added, should not be called a truce, but rather ''a suspension of hostilities'' with the prospect of a final peace agreement ''in just a few months.'' **********In the meantime, the two sides continue testing their adversaries and accusing each other of shifting forces in an effort to take advantage of the de facto cease-fire. **********Just recently, guerrillas briefly took over a market a few blocks from the Presidential Palace, distributing leaflets, forcing vendors to listen to a tape-recorded speech of their program and drawing complaints from a military spokesman of a ''provocation.'' **********At the same time, there has been a surge of kidnappings and other violent crimes, which many Guatemalans blame on the armed forces as well as the rebels. With the guerrillas having stopped collecting the ''war taxes'' that they imposed on businesses, and the army being pushed out of sidelines like drug and timber smuggling, both groups are said to be eager to reap one last bonanza before a peace agreement is signed. **********Before that can happen, several points must be resolved. Among them are the size of the armed forces, now with more than 40,000 men, in a postwar Guatemala and what the army will do once its ''counterinsurgency'' function disappears. **********The question of granting amnesty to those accused of killings and other human rights abuses in the civil war is proving even thornier, Guatemalan officials and foreign diplomats say. The military has been responsible for most of the deaths, but rebel leaders must be exempted from sedition and treason charges if they are to take part in politics. **********Many human rights groups oppose any amnesty for the military, and several prominent human rights campaigners, including Rigoberta Menchu, the Nobel Peace Prize winner, have formed a group called Alliance Against Impunity. In addition, mass graves are now being uncovered, fueling public demands that former and present members of the armed forces high command be held accountable. **********Since taking office in January, Mr. Arzu has taken several steps to weaken the power of the military, which after relinquishing formal control of the country a little over a decade ago had dominated three civilian Presidents. He has purged several generals, made more than 250 changes in local command postings, withheld promotions of other senior officers and ''in general greatly advanced the principle of civilian supremacy,'' one diplomat here said. **********Most recently, Mr. Arzu, a conservative businessman, approved legislation depriving military personnel of the right to be tried by special military tribunals when they are charged with common crimes. As a result of that June measure, nearly 350 cases in which soldiers face charges are being transferred to civilian courts. **********But problems in that area remain. In late May, for instance, a judge was criticized by human rights groups here and abroad after he ordered the release of 8 soldiers charged with the massacre last October of 11 peasants who had settled, with United Nations support, in the village of Xaman after returning from years of exile in Mexico. **********Nevertheless, Guatemalan and foreign analysts maintain that a last-minute collapse of the peace talks is extremely unlikely. For one thing, expectations are now so high, and Guatemalans so tired of war, that a breakdown would be a political disaster for Mr. Arzu and the guerrillas, leading to ''a plague on both your houses'' attitude among the people.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/09/world.snippet: Last-ditch effort by Kenya Wildlife Service to save hirola antelope from extinction by transportion them by air from scrubby desert region of Garissa near Somali border to Tsavo National Park runs into opposition from local political leaders, as w...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/09/world.main_headline: It's Moving Day, and the Antelope Are Up in the Air
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/09/world.print_headline: It's Moving Day, and the Antelope Are Up in the Air
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/09/world.body_text: **********The airplane dropped out of the twilit sky above the savanna just in time, only minutes before darkness enveloped the dirt airstrip. It taxied quickly to a flatbed truck huddled in the gloom at the runway's end. A side-door sprang open. **********A moment later, Dr. Richard Kock climbed out of the single-engine Cessna Caravan, cradling in his arms a baby hirola antelope. Drugged and masked, the little animal looked fragile and lost in his arms. It was one of the last of its kind. **********''We made it!'' yelled Dr. Kock, a veterinarian. ''This is it. That's the last of them.'' **********Rangers from the Kenya Wildlife Service lugged two more adult female antelopes out of the plane, loaded the animals onto the flatbed and ferried them to a nearby corral, where they would sleep off the sedative before being released. **********In a last-ditch attempt to save the hirola from extinction, Dr. Kock and rangers airlifted 33 of the rare, sand-colored antelope in August from the scrubby desert region of Garissa near the Somali border to this national park. **********It was not an easy operation. The rangers struggled with the logistics of catching and transporting the antelope, and local political leaders, Kenyan citizens who are ethnic Somalis, filed a lawsuit that halted the project twice. **********In court, politicians led by Abdikadir Sheik Hassan, the Garissa council chairman, accused the wildlife service of stealing a precious natural resource. The animal, they said, was ''a good omen and a gift from nature.'' **********''Its translocation to another far-off land will bring disaster to the people and their livestock,'' the lawsuit said. **********On the last day of the airlift, a judge in Nairobi, Justice Gideon Mbito, agreed. He banned the wildlife service from taking any more animals from the Arawale Natural Reserve, a park managed by the local council. **********The ruling did not stop the project, since many of the antelope were being caught outside the reserve, but it could doom future attempts to save endangered species in Kenya if it stands up on appeal, wildlife officials said. **********Among other things, the judge ruled that the wildlife service does not own the wildlife, nor does it have the final authority over its management. The ruling added that the people who use the land are entitled to its flora and fauna. **********Kenya has lost 60 percent of its wildlife in the last 10 years because of poaching and the encroachment of people on the wild lands. The only animals increasing in numbers are those species the wildlife service has relocated to national parks and aggressively protected, like the rhinoceros and the elephant. **********''If the ruling stands, then I'm afraid that's the end of the game,'' said Dr. Kock, who is chief veterinarian adviser to the wildlife service and chairman of the task force to save the hirola. **********But Ahmed Isaak Hassan, a lawyer representing the Garissa council, said the council's aim was only to force the wildlife service to protect the animal where it now lives. ''What we are arguing is that they should first try to conserve the animal it its natural habitat,'' he said. ''It is a very sacred animal among the Somali community.'' **********By last count, only 306 of the hirola were living in their natural habitat between the Tana River and the Somali border. Another 57 were barely surviving in the Tsavo Park. They are the descendants of a dozen animals that were brought to the park in 1963 as part of an earlier attempt to save them. **********But the gene pool of the Tsavo group is too small to allow it to survive over the long run, researchers say. The only way to save the species is to bring new members to the Tsavo herds before poachers destroy the remaining hirola in Garissa.  ''Our aim is to inject some new blood,'' said Wilbur Ottichilo, the deputy director for biodiversity. **********One reason the antelope has declined is the general lawlessness of the Garissa region. Since civil war broke out in Somalia in 1990, armed gangs have terrorized the area, stealing from herders and poaching wildlife. The scientists and rangers on the project had to travel under heavy guard. **********The rangers also had to contend with the anger of some local villagers, who were convinced by their leaders that the removal of the hirola was a bad omen. On one occasion, the rangers were stoned and assaulted in the village of Bura Bura. **********''These people are criminal in my opinion,'' Dr. Kock said of the local politicians. **********Beyond the political troubles, wildlife officials were faced with the logistical nightmare of trying to capture and transport wild animals nearly 200 miles. A helicopter was used to drive the wild antelope into nets. Then the animals were sedated, blindfolded and taken by truck to a small plane. **********Scientists say the hirola is an evolutionary relic that first appeared about 15 million years ago and is believed to be a progenitor of some more modern antelope, like the hartebeest and the topi. According to fossil evidence, it once roamed as far south as the Cape of Good Hope and as far north as Somalia. **********Also known as the hunter's antelope, the hirola has long curved horns like the Impala, a sandy hide, and pronounced scent glands under the eyes. Its anatomy is suited to harsh conditions, and it can live on very little water for weeks. **********In 1976, there were 14,000 of the hirola in Kenya, living mostly along the Tana River and in the Garissa region, scientists said. The first blow to the population came in the early 1980's, when poachers killed off most of the elephants, which used to clear the land of thorn bushes and make room for grazers. **********Then, between 1983 and 1985, a rinderpest epidemic brought in by cattle herders killed off more than half the antelope in the region. Finally, the civil war and upheaval in Somalia in the early 1990's took its toll. As a flood of refugees and fleeing troops crossed the border into Kenya, thousands of the antelope were killed for food. **********By 1993, 2,000 hirola remained. Two years later, a census found only 306 left in Garissa. They were scattered in small groups of six or seven over 45,000 square miles of bush. Unless the animals are moved, they will be extinct within two or three years, wildlife officials said. ''Each of these pockets will gradually disappear, like bubbles,'' Dr. Kock said. **********The morning after the last flight, researchers finished putting radio collars on a few of the animals to track them, opened up the gate of the corral and chased seven antelope out. For a few minutes, the hirolas stood still in the vast Tsavo morning, as if stunned to find themselves in such a grassy place. **********Their noses worked the wind coming down over the grassy flat lands dotted with Acacia trees, performing the calculus of scent and survival.  Behind them, Dr. Kock clapped and whooped, encouraging them to go into their new world. **********The antelope loped off. They moved tentatively at first, then picked up speed. Their tails bobbed away into the flat lands that were the same tawny color they were. Soon, the bush swallowed them up, as if they were not creatures of flesh and blood at all, but spirits belonging to the land itself.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/08/busin.snippet: Charitable remainder trusts, which allow donors to generate a steady stream of income by making a charitable donation, are growing in popularity (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/08/busin.body_text: **********When giving to charity, you can often get something in return besides a tax deduction. Some charities invite you to black-tie dinners, give you a book bag or tickets to an event. There is also a way to make money by giving. **********That is the logic behind charitable remainder trusts, which let you generate a steady stream of income by making a charitable donation. **********It works like this: You create the trust either through a lawyer or an institution like a bank, brokerage firm or charity. The trust is financed with cash or something that can be turned into cash, like stocks, bonds or property. Those assets are sold, and because the trust does not have to pay capital gains tax on the appreciation of the assets, the trust receives the full value and reinvests the money, usually in something that produces a high rate of income. Who gets that income? You do, often for the rest of your life. After you die, a charity you designated will receive all the money left in the trust. **********The benefits are many. Although you give up a sizable asset, you get a charitable tax deduction and a steady income for years from the full value of the asset. Your heirs avoid estate taxes on the money. And you benefit the charity. **********Charitable remainder trusts have been growing in popularity. Robert F. Sharpe Jr., president of an endowment development consulting firm in Memphis, estimated that the number of these trusts have doubled in the last five years, to 50,000, and that they contain at least $20 billion in assets. **********But the trusts are not necessarily straightforward to set up or administer, and the ways some trusts are used has caught the attention of the I.R.S. **********Here are some of the rules: The trusts are allowed to generate income either for a period of up to 20 years, or for the life span of its beneficiary, usually yourself. You still have to pay taxes on income distributions from the trust, and the tax amount depends on whether the distribution comes from ordinary trust income (usually interest and dividends), capital gains or the trust's principal, in which case the income is tax-free. **********Most charitable remainder trusts come in two flavors. **********One type provides annual income at a fixed rate that is set either as a percentage (no less than 5 percent) of the initial fair market value of the assets in the trust or as a fixed amount, say $5,000. Another type provides distributions that are recalculated each year based on a trust's annual value on a certain date. With these trusts, investors cannot change the percentage of their distribution, but they have the potential to increase their income if the value of the trust has risen. **********There are variations on these two types of charitable remainder trusts that are technically legal, but whose charitable intent the Internal Revenue Service has been questioning. For example, in 1994, the agency issued a warning that it wasn't keen on accelerated charitable remainder trusts, which some taxpayers have set up to pay annual distributions that are often as high as 80 percent. **********To meet these payments, these trusts almost always have to dip into principal, which gives the beneficiary tax-free income, since distributions of principal are not taxed. And because the principal is being drained, there is often little money left for the charity. **********The I.R.S is also looking into charitable remainder trusts that are set up to defer the income distributions to later years, such as when a beneficiary retires and his or her income tax rate is lower. **********John H. Gardner, director of estate planning at KPMG Peat Marwick's national tax office in Washington, said the I.R.S. might be getting ready to issue regulations concerning accelerated trusts as well as those that defer income. A spokesman for the agency said it was continuing to study the issue. **********''Basically,'' Mr. Gardner said, ''the I.R.S.'s position is that the assets of these trusts are being manipulated to benefit the income beneficiaries, and the trustee really should be benefiting the charity beneficiary.''   SANA SIWOLOP

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/31/busin.snippet: New York Stock Exchange says that Sanjoy Hazarika, former trader at Oppenheimer & Co, has been barred from securities industry for one year for concealing trading losses that cost firm $878,000; he incurred losses trading mortgage-backed bonds for...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/31/busin.body_text: **********The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it had punished a former trader at Oppenheimer & Company for concealing trading losses that cost the firm almost $900,000. **********The Big Board censured Sanjay Hazarika, 32, and barred him from the securities industry for one year for covering up losses he incurred trading mortgage-backed bonds for Oppenheimer from October to December in 1994. **********Mr. Hazarika, who has not worked in the securities industry since he was dismissed by Oppenheimer in January 1995, did not return calls seeking comment. **********John Ryan, a spokesman for Oppenheimer, declined to comment. **********The firm, based in New York, does not report its profits to the public. Its revenue for the 1996 fiscal year, which ended last April, was $925 million, Mr. Ryan said. **********Mr. Hazarika traded adjustable-rate mortgages, which are bonds backed by variable-rate residential mortgages. The value of Oppenheimer's holdings of such mortgages was about $18.6 million in October 1994, the N.Y.S.E. said. **********The firm took a loss of about $878,000 when it sold the securities two months later. **********The losses were discovered by another Oppenheimer trader while Mr. Hazarika was away on vacation in December 1994.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/24/world.main_headline: Islamic Rule Is Reaffirmed By Sudan Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/24/world.print_headline: Islamic Rule Is Reaffirmed By Sudan Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/24/world.body_text: **********Hundreds of Sudanese poured into the streets of Khartoum today to hear their  newly elected President, Lieut. Gen. Omar al-Bashir, vow to keep the country ruled by "Islamic law and dignity," with no return to party politics. **********General Bashir, who appointed himself President in 1989 after overthrowing a  democratically elected Government in a military coup, told the crowd after his widely expected landslide victory in the presidential elections, "We have fully  returned power in full to the people." **********The 52-year-old leader defeated 40 little-known candidates in the voting earlier this month. **********Leaders of the Sudan's main opposition parties, disbanded when General Bashir took power, boycotted the presidential and parliamentary elections. The ousted Prime Minister, Sadeq el-Mahdi, called the elections a cheap attempt by the Government to buy legitimacy. **********General Bashir's promise to maintain the rule of the sharia, or Islamic law,  came against a background of 13 years of civil war, with rebels from the mainly  Christian and animist south battling domination by the Muslim north. **********General Bashir is to serve a five-year term, after which he will be allowed to run once more. He is unlikely to face dissent from the newly elected Parliament, which is packed with supporters of his Islamist Government. The power behind his Government is widely believed to be the militant Muslim cleric Hassan Turabi, who was elected to a seat in Parliament in Khartoum. **********Pro-Government committees known as national congresses appointed 125 people last January to the 400-member house. At least 12 clerics were elected for four  years. **********General Bashir faces considerable problems during his coming five-year term.  Besides the costly war in the south, the Sudan is facing possible United Nations sanctions if it fails to extradite to Ethiopia three gunmen accused of trying to kill President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt in Addis Ababa last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/11/busin.main_headline: Airline Pact Could Mean 'Open Skies' For Heathrow
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/11/busin.print_headline: Airline Pact Could Mean 'Open Skies' For Heathrow
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/11/busin.body_text: **********A planned marketing alliance between American Airlines and British Airways may seem at first to be simply the latest in a series of partnerships between airlines. But the alliance is also expected to lead to an aviation accord between Britain and the United States to replace one that American officials have been dissatisfied with since it was signed 50 years ago. **********An important aspect of the alliance, which is expected to be announced today, will revolve around Heathrow International Airport, the world's busiest hub for  international traffic and a linchpin in the strategy of the United States to bring American-style "open skies" to the more restrictive world of European air  travel. **********For decades, the United States has lobbied Britain for a freer aviation policy to allow more carriers to fly into Heathrow than the two that have been allowed -- Pan Am and T.W.A., later replaced by United and American. But an alliance between American Airlines and British Airways, which would not be announced if the airlines did not think they had some support of their respective governments, suggests that Britain and the United States are more likely to loosen historic restrictions on flying to and beyond Heathrow. **********"The U.K. is our largest aviation partner," said Patrick V. Murphy, the Deputy Assistant Secretary for Aviation and International Affairs at the Transportation Department. "An agreement with them would represent the most profound breakthrough we've achieved on open skies internationally." **********Such an agreement, however, will not be reached smoothly. Other United States airlines will most likely criticize the American Airlines-British Airways accord, arguing that their combined share of almost 60 percent of the flights between the two countries will hurt competition. **********That lobbying effort has begun. Trans World Airlines filed a request yesterday in Washington with the Transportation Department for three daily round-trip flights between Kennedy and Heathrow. **********"The traveling public in this market is ill served by the concentration of market power in the hands of a very limited number of competitors," said Jeffrey H. Erickson, president of T.W.A. **********Nor is an agreement likely to be reached quickly. Delta Air Lines waited about a year to receive its recent tentative approval for antitrust immunity for its alliances with Sabena, Swissair and Austrian Airlines. Those countries already had open-skies agreements with the United States. **********American Airlines and British Airways officials declined to comment yesterday. **********People familiar with details of the two airlines' plans, however, said they would announce an alliance in which they would market and sell seats on each other's flights, pool revenues on trans-Atlantic traffic and link frequent-flier programs. **********The goal of the alliance is to create more choices for consumers, so that travelers will be able to call American, for example, to book a flight to a far-flung destination, even though a portion or all that trip might be flown on  British Airways. With a network that extends to many continents, the airlines hope to draw passengers away from competitors. **********And those competitors have become increasingly powerful as they have entered  into alliances of their own, like those linking United and Lufthansa, and Northwest and KLM. **********There is also much at stake for the United States and British Governments. For the British, an open-skies agreement would give the nation's domestic airlines more access to United States markets. **********For the United States Government, an open-skies agreement with Britain would  cap a strategy it has pursued for many years to export the notion of deregulated skies to Europe. In recent years, for example, it has signed open-skies agreement with 11 European countries. Holdouts have included France, Greece, Italy, Spain, Portugal and Britain. **********With Heathrow as their crown jewel -- a gateway for 54 million travelers last year -- British officials have had considerable leverage in talks with American  negotiators. **********But as other United States and European airlines form alliances, they have made airports in Frankfurt and Amsterdam and in other cities popular alternatives, threatening Heathrow's lock on much of the international traffic.  The British Airways-American Airlines announcement will give both sides a way to revisit a thorny issue. **********"It offers a significant opportunity for the U.S. Government to obtain a long-sought goal," said Daniel M. Kasper, an aviation consultant with Coopers &  Lybrand, "and for the British Government to put an amicable end to what has been an increasingly sore point in the U.S.-U.K. relationship."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/12/busin.body_text: **********In an unusually swift cooperative action, Federal prosecutors and securities  and commodity market regulators charged a New Jersey man yesterday with misappropriating at least $1.5 million from commodity pool accounts he managed for more than 100 investors. **********Civil and criminal charges were filed in Federal District Court in Camden, N.J., against Michael Tropiano of Haddonfield, who has conducted business as Ardmore Financial Services since 1990. The filing by Federal prosecutors, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission  came just three weeks after problems with the accounts first came to light. The  teamwork was remarkable because the public relationship among the prosecutors and regulators has often been marked by squabbling and turf battles. **********Mr. Tropiano could not be reached for comment yesterday, and his attorney, Michael Pinsky, did not respond to messages left at his office. **********Faith S. Hochberg, the United States Attorney for New Jersey, explained in a  letter sent yesterday to investors that the case against Mr. Tropiano began when Mr. Pinsky told her staff that Mr. Tropiano "had committed a massive fraud, wanted to turn himself in to the authorities and was willing have all his personal assets liquidated" to make restitution. **********As a result, Federal prosecutors filed a criminal complaint yesterday that accused Mr. Tropiano of mail fraud. Mr. Tropiano was released on bail of $350,000, said Howard Wiener, an assistant United States attorney in Camden. **********Working together, the S.E.C. and the commodity market regulators filed civil  charges accusing Mr. Tropiano of misappropriating funds from investors in a commodities trading scheme that began in 1993. **********In an affidavit filed in Federal court, James Yacone, a special agent with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, reported that Mr. Tropiano told prosecutors on Dec. 28 that he had experienced substantial losses in January 1993 in his pooled commodity trading accounts. **********Mr. Tropiano told prosecutors that after the losses, he "decided to stop making actual trades," Mr. Yacone said, but continued to send false trading statements to his investors that showed $6 million in principal and accrued profits in the accounts. **********The authorities charged yesterday that Mr. Tropiano had nearly depleted the pool accounts by drawing a salary from them and by transferring about $1.5 million to personal bank accounts he used to buy and renovate an expensive home, and to buy cars and other luxury goods. **********Mr. Tropiano's assets have been frozen and will be sold to raise money for investors, but regulators said full restitution was unlikely. Investors have been sent information explaining the Government plans to maximize the amount that can be returned to them, Mr. Wiener said. **********According to the S.E.C., a preliminary injunction -- which Mr. Tropiano was not contesting -- has been issued barring him from future securities law violations and requiring him to account for his use of investors' money.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/06/world.snippet: New surge of outrage sweeps Britain after woman who is 16 weeks pregnant and her gynecologist agree to abort one of two healthy twin fetuses because she says she is too poor to raise twins; experts say abortion would be first known case in Britain...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/06/world.main_headline: Planned Abortion of One Twin Stirs Furor in Britain
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/06/world.print_headline: Planned Abortion of One Twin Stirs Furor in Britain
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/06/world.body_text: **********A new surge of outrage swept Britain today after a woman who is 16 weeks pregnant and her gynecologist agreed to abort one of two healthy twin fetuses because she says she is too poor to raise twins. **********Experts said the abortion would be the first known case in Britain in which a healthy fetus in a naturally conceived multiple pregnancy was aborted. Such a procedure in a multiple pregnancy, known as selective termination, is not unusual when a fetus is discovered to be unhealthy or abnormal. **********The woman in this case was not identified, but it is known that she is a 28-year-old single mother who already has one child. No other details about her were disclosed. **********There was an outcry from anti-abortion groups last week when the Government ordered the destruction of 3,000 unclaimed human embryos in fertility clinics in keeping with a law stipulating that frozen embryos cannot be kept for more than five years without specific requests from the parents. **********The doctor who agreed to carry out the abortion and others who supported it asserted that the decision was ''no different from any other abortion,'' in the words of Dr. Vivienne Nathanson, the head of the board of ethics at the British Medical Association. **********But anti-abortion groups here and in Italy, where there was much shock last week over the frozen embryo case, have offered money to the woman to give birth to both twins and give one up for adoption. **********The decision was first reported over the weekend by The Sunday Express in a front-page interview with the woman's gynecologist, Dr. Phillip Bennett of Queen Charlotte's Hospital in London. He said the abortion of one fetus was the solution he had proposed to the woman when she told him she could not continue the pregnancy if it meant having two children. **********After the report appeared, other British dailies and television gave the story prominent coverage. A wide range of commentators expressed revulsion, with some calling the decision ''uncivilized,'' ''horrific'' and ''abhorrent.'' **********A spokeswoman at Queen Charlotte's Hospital said that Dr. Bennett had not been in the hospital today and that there would be no comment on the case, which she called ''a private matter between the doctor and his patient.'' **********The spokeswoman, Nuala O'Brian, declined to say whether the abortion had been carried out, but other knowledgeable people said it had not. **********Dr. Bennett told The Sunday Express that he had performed 3,000 abortions in the last 10 years and as many deliveries. Having suggested that he knew the sex of the babies, he said, ''Killing one healthy twin sounds unethical, but my colleagues and I concluded this week that it would be better to terminate one pregnancy as soon as possible and leave one alive than to lose two babies.'' **********The doctor faced a deluge of requests for interviews today but was not available for further comment. **********Ms. O'Brian would not say whether the woman had been informed of offers of financial aid to carry the pregnancy to term, saying such information would have to be communicated by the doctor to his patient. **********The technique of abortion in this case would involve piercing the selected fetus with a needle, Dr. Bennett said in the interview with The Sunday Express. That fetus is then carried for the full term of the pregnancy, ''although it shrivels and mummifies'' in the womb, Dr. Bennett said. **********Among of the unanswered questions in the case are how the doctor selects the fetus to be aborted and whether the woman is told the sex of that fetus. **********British law permits the termination of a pregnancy up to the 24th week. The law allows wide latitude on the reason for terminating a pregnancy, considering that a woman's request motivated by a psychological rejection of childbearing is acceptable ground for abortion even if there would be no health risks to the mother or child. **********After 24 weeks, the law permits an abortion if there is a physical abnormality. **********''Although technically it meets the criterion under which abortion is legal in this country, it is so close to abortion on demand,'' Harry Coen, acting editor of The Catholic Herald newspaper, said in an interview. ''At this stage, in this case particularly, it sounds to me like selective murder. I mean, we know they have aborted healthy babies before, but to leave one and kill the other is abhorrent.'' **********Some anti-abortion activists and charity groups have offered money and adoption as incentives to the woman to give birth to both twins. **********Life, a British national charity with 35,000 dues-paying members and 135 offices around the country, said it was deluged with offers of help and could immediately offer the woman upward of $16,000 from donors who had called today. An Italian anti-abortion group said it would offer monthly stipends and adopt one of the babies after birth. **********''A lot of people who have been taking things for granted and leaving such matter to the state are suddenly shocked about it and beginning to question the ethical and spiritual void that creates such dreadful developments,'' said Nuala Scarisbrick, a trustee of the group, which was founded in 1970. **********''We are not trying to bribe the woman, just save the twins,'' Ms. Scarisbrick said in a telephone interview. ''We have made the offer to Bennett but have received no response.'' **********The Roman Catholic Church, which deplored the destruction of frozen embryos last week, said the case of selective abortion might again set off a national debate over the whole issue of terminating pregnancies. **********''What it seems to have done is brought to the public a short, sharp shock,'' said Nicholas Coote, assistant secretary of the Catholic Bishops Conference of England and Wales. **********''In this country basically what happens is if you go to a doctor and say, 'I don't want to take this pregnancy to term because I can't cope,' the doctor can make the decision to terminate it, even if it is a perfectly healthy fetus,'' Mr. Coote said. ''Until now it was easy to look away, but this case has brought the full implications of such an act to people's attention.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/22/busin.snippet: Treasury Sec Robert E Rubin's is being credited with making the economy Pres Clinton's strongest argument for re-election; his influence has been felt in everything from tax policy to the budget to economic foreign policy and he has succeeded in h...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/22/busin.main_headline: An Old Wall Street Pro's Voice in the Campaign
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/22/busin.print_headline: An Old Wall Street Pro's Voice in the Campaign
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/22/busin.body_text: **********A FEW years ago President Clinton's political advisers were fuming about Robert E. Rubin's relentless focus on satisfying America's bond markets, fearing that his insistence on cutting the Federal deficit would prove politically disastrous for his boss. But history gets rewritten quickly in Washington. And now some of those same advisers, rejoicing in the latest poll results, argue that the bond markets were in fact a proxy for a majority of American voters, who seem to have decided, in the last weeks of the campaign, that Bill Clinton deserves credit for his handling of the economy. **********Whether the markets and the voters are truly in sync won't be clear for 44 more days. But there is little question that the 58-year-old Treasury Secretary, once viewed as a political novice from Wall Street, is regarded in Washington these days as a man who, with a mix of cunning and luck, has worked some quiet economic magic for President Clinton. **********When the Democratic candidate declares at every campaign stop that he will endorse only ''targeted tax cuts that are fully paid for'' by budget cuts -- an effort to cast Bob Dole's call for a 15 percent reduction in every American's taxes in the most unfavorable light -- the words have a familiar ring. Mr. Rubin has been using a similar phraseology for two years. **********Working out of the limelight, Mr. Rubin's Treasury has also generated a host of Mr. Clinton's campaign-year mini-initiatives that create big headlines but cost relatively little -- including, most recently, the proposal to end the capital-gains tax on all but the biggest profits from selling a home. **********Perhaps just as important, Mr. Rubin, the former co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company,  has time and again sidestepped land mines that could have blown up Mr. Clinton's best case for re-election: his handling of the economy. After the Administration got off to a rocky start with the Federal Reserve, he developed a close relationship with its chairman, Alan Greenspan, over private breakfasts every Thursday morning. And three times in the last 20 months, he has headed off potential political disasters. **********He was the engineer of a risky bailout of Mexico that, while wildly unpopular at the time, appears to have worked, with three-quarters of America's $12 billion in loans already paid back, ahead of time and ahead of the election. With a mix of stealth and good fortune, he helped guide the dollar back from the dead before it could send interest rates surging. And, in the heat of the budget battles last winter, he outmaneuvered Republicans in Congress who were trying to force the White House to accede to their budget demands by cutting off the Treasury's borrowing authority. Stepping up the pressure day by day, Mr. Rubin portrayed them as zealots who were threatening to put the United States into default. They surrendered. **********''I'm working on the supposition that good economics can also be good politics,'' Mr. Rubin said recently in his office at the Treasury, tipping back his chair under the portrait of a more fiery predecessor, Alexander Hamilton, the first Treasury Secretary. Flashing something between a grimace and a smile, Mr. Rubin added, ''I'll admit that not everyone believes that.'' **********He says that he has mostly been playing defense for the President. ''The last two years have been more of a balance of preventing bad things from happening,'' he said. ''We've had to focus a lot of resources on stopping untoward things. It's not exactly what I imagined.'' **********Mr. Rubin has been skirmishing with more than just Republicans. He frequently found himself at odds with Dick Morris, a fellow longtime resident of the Jefferson Hotel in Washington, who as Mr. Clinton's image maker sought far bigger, flashier tax cuts in case Mr. Dole's appeal took off. Mr. Morris resigned last month and moved out of the Jefferson after a supermarket tabloid photographed him on the hotel's balcony with a prostitute. (Mr. Rubin's staff joked that their boss is so focused on his work that they believe him when he says he was oblivious to the late-night happenings across the courtyard.) **********For the most part, Mr. Rubin has sought to control the debate within the Administration by gently controlling the process. **********Before the Democratic National Convention,  Mr. Rubin helped to torpedo one of Mr. Morris's ideas -- a deep cut in capital gains taxes on investments in inner cities -- arguing that it would create ''minimal economic activity.'' Instead, he used the National Economic Council, which he once directed, to come up with a series of less costly urban initiatives. Among them was a tax credit for employers to hire longtime welfare recipients, as well as tax incentives for private investment in community development banks and for venture funds that back projects in low-income communities. The measures sound good in a campaign speech, and their cost would be only $430 million. **********And Mr. Clinton's proposal to allow homeowners to pocket up to $500,000 in capital gains on the sale of their homes tax-free began as a $4 billion program; by the time it emerged from the bowels of the Treasury, the price had come down to $1.4 billion. **********In fact, while it is difficult to overstate Mr. Rubin's influence on everything from tax policy to the budget to economic foreign policy, he has hardly won every argument. This summer, he advised President Clinton not to sign the welfare bill; he was overruled. A month earlier he was clearly uneasy with the Administration's imposition of sanctions against foreign companies that do business with Cuba, arguing that it was an extraterritorial use of American law that would undercut efforts to win cooperation with key economic allies and trading partners, including Canada, Mexico and Britain. Mr. Clinton went ahead, though with watered-down sanctions that will not go into effect until next year, if ever. **********And Mr. Rubin is certainly not without his critics in this capital -- especially those who contend that his low-key, self-deprecating manner masks a sharply political use of the Treasury. **********In the spring, Republicans became so outraged by his maneuvers to keep paying the Government's bills despite Congress's refusal to raise the national debt limit that they talked briefly about impeaching him. (Mr. Rubin responded by suggesting that his wife, Judy -- who makes no secret of her disdain for Washington life and spends most weeks at their Park Avenue apartment in Manhattan or at their estate in Westchester County -- would happily testify on the Republicans' behalf.) **********But Republican hopes of arguing that Mr. Rubin was raiding Government pension funds and juggling the books were dashed a few weeks ago when a study they ordered from the General Accounting Office concluded that Mr. Rubin's manipulations were legal. **********Last week John B. Taylor, a chief economist of the Dole campaign, took a different tack, arguing that Mr. Rubin's description of the Clinton tax proposals as ''fully paid for'' is ''ridiculous.'' **********He said the Clinton tax cuts would last only a few years and would be revoked if Government revenues were insufficient. **********But even Mr. Rubin's harshest public critics often concede in private that it is difficult to make attacks on the Treasury Secretary stick. Over time he has developed a reputation for bringing a focus and a force of logical argument to the White House. And after the Administration's failure in its first two years to develop a working relationship with Republicans in Congress -- a lapse that Mr. Rubin counts among his biggest political mistakes -- he has been more successful than almost anyone else in the Cabinet at massaging the Republican majority and turning their divisions to his political advantage. **********These days, Republican leaders act as though they suspect they will be dealing with Mr. Rubin for some time. That was particularly evident last Tuesday, as Mr. Rubin got out of a Secret Service limousine and entered the Capitol for a brief meeting with a committee that controls the Treasury's budget. **********The Republican chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Bill Archer of Texas, who last winter accused Mr. Rubin of courting ''a constitutional and legal crisis'' over the debt ceiling, caught sight of the Treasury Secretary from afar. **********''Bob!'' Mr. Archer yelled, trotting up to greet him. ''I don't think this election is over yet, but if Clinton is re-elected.  . . . '' Standing in the hallway, the two men proceeded to talk about ideas for next year, as if it were just about over. **********A Special Credibility **********It is sunrise along the New Jersey Turnpike and Bob Rubin is racing to a breakfast meeting with real estate developers, Wall Street investors and local entrepreneurs near Newark Airport. He is bleary eyed from six trips back and forth between New York and Washington in the last 48 hours. The final leg, at midnight after a hastily called meeting in the Oval Office about the Cuban sanctions, was aboard a private Cessna jet he leased at his own expense -- a luxury he indulges in often to save time. (''It's one of the only moments when you realize this guy not only signs dollar bills, he has $100 million of them in the bank,'' a Treasury official who works with him quipped.) **********To prepare for his talk he is flipping through the papers, reading about Bob Dole's summertime embrace of big tax cuts and supply-side economics. Mr. Rubin has taken pains not to publicly attack the Republican candidate -- he carefully edits himself, saying that there ''is a tradition of keeping Treasury secretaries one step away'' from politics -- but he has made it abundantly clear to many that he doesn't think Mr. Dole believes in his own tax plan. **********He comes as close as he ever does to a direct political attack after an introduction at a Newark hotel by Representative Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey, the Democratic candidate who is in a tight Senate race. Mr. Rubin starts into his familiar patter that every tax cut ''must be fully paid for, with no gimmicks.'' **********''There's no magic to this,'' he says. ''Do you really want to explode the deficit, and put America back where we were when we inherited this mess?'' Even a few Republicans in the audience applaud. **********The entire White House economic team employs this remember-the-Reagan-era argument, but Mr. Rubin brings a special credibility to it with business audiences. He was a deficit cutter before it was fashionable in the Clinton White House. And his 26 years at Goldman, Sachs lend an authority to his pitch. Often, in the presence of Republican business leaders, he doesn't try to win new votes so much as neutralize the opposition. **********''Let's face it, many of these people will never vote for a Democratic President, no matter what I say,'' Mr. Rubin said on the way to one recent fund-raiser. ''But even if they don't support the President because they are Republicans, if they have the confidence we are handling the fundamentals right, they won't energize against us.'' **********The strategy is working. Not only do polls show that many more Americans are giving the Administration credit for its handling of the economy -- a recent New York Times/ CBS News poll showed the figure at 55 percent, up from the 30's a few years ago -- but many business executives who would reflexively vote Republican seem to be sitting on the sidelines. **********In public speeches, Mr. Rubin appears far more comfortable than when he first arrived in Washington. But he never seems entirely happy at the podium or on television. His mind often races ahead of his sentences, and a result can be long asides that water down otherwise pungent insights. By his own admission, he has never learned his boss's skill in spinning anecdotes. (Reached at his home the day a plane crashed with Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown on board, Mr. Rubin, who worked with Mr. Brown for years, could not think of any incidents that gave insight into the man. ''Call Mickey,'' he said, referring to Mickey Kantor, who a few weeks later became Mr. Brown's successor. ''He's good at that.'') **********So as the campaign enters the final stretch, other members of the economic team, from Mr. Kantor to Laura D'Andrea Tyson, are taking the economic message to the Rotary Clubs and local radio stations. As Mr. Rubin's successor in running the National Economic Council and his most frequent ally in the White House, Ms. Tyson, a University of California at Berkeley economist, is particularly adept at reducing economic complexity to simple sentences. The White House, for obvious reasons, never misses an opportunity to put her in front of women's groups and university audiences. In some ways, she has become the more visible of the two. Mr. Rubin seems perfectly happy with the arrangement. **********''What's remarkable about him is that he's got so little ego, and that's not something you see often in Washington,'' said W. Bowman Cutter, who worked closely with Mr. Rubin for three years until he left the Administration to return to investment banking. **********Mr. Rubin's style -- working the inside, minding the office -- stands in sharp contrast to the approach taken by predecessors like Lloyd M. Bentsen and James A. Baker 3d. Both viewed the Treasury as a place for high diplomacy and savored the constant world travel and the pomp and ceremony. **********Mr. Rubin dislikes all of that. His aides know that 24 hours before most foreign trips, he will question whether he could accomplish the same results on the phone. As Treasury Secretary, he has yet to visit Tokyo, the world's next-biggest financial center; apart from obligatory foreign summit meetings, he has limited his travel to a one-week tour through Indonesia and India and a weekend in South America. ''I guess I see the job a bit differently,'' he said recently. ''My job is to stay in Washington and run the Treasury.'' **********So it is not uncommon to see Mr. Rubin on the third floor of the Treasury, his sleeves rolled up and his tie at half-mast, startling some deputy assistant secretaries by showing up in their offices with friendly but penetrating questions. His focus is so tight that others in the Administration often laugh at how he can filter out other pleasures in life. Ms. Tyson remembers walking through the White House one day with Mr. Rubin and hearing Aretha Franklin practicing for a concert that night for the President. Ms. Tyson wanted to linger and listen. Mr. Rubin asked: ''Who's Aretha Franklin?'' **********As a result of his single-mindedness, Mr. Rubin has immersed himself in parts of the Treasury his predecessors rarely touched, especially the law-enforcement agencies: the Customs Service, the Secret Service and the troubled Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. With little publicity -- and limited success so far -- he has used money-laundering laws to put more heat on Colombian and Mexican drug dealers. **********Recently, following a longtime interest in urban issues, he pushed the Treasury into the nation's ghettos in hopes of bringing some market rationale to the crazy quilt of Federal housing and development projects. In July, he showed up in a section of Los Angeles where investment bankers rarely tread: A burned-out lot, surrounded by warehouses, where businesses are still trying to rebuild from the Los Angeles riots in 1992. He was pressing an Administration proposal to use tax incentives to draw manufacturing back into ''brownfields'' -- abandoned, polluted inner-city lots. **********On the same trip, he started talking about a Treasury effort to package public and private loans for low-income housing and small businesses, and sell them as securities on the secondary market in a way that would get the cost off Washington's books. ''These are experiments in using the markets to recycle scarce resources, so that what little money we have left in the budget for these kinds of projects can go further,'' he said. **********The Mexico Gamble **********Robert Edward Rubin may be low key, but he is filled with restless energy. He was eager to get out of his hometown, Miami Beach, where his father was a successful real estate investor and lawyer. At Harvard College he majored in economics and tried to convince himself he wanted to be a lawyer. But after a week or so at Harvard Law School he quit, left Cambridge, Mass., and headed off to the London School of Economics. He returned to law school at Yale, and on graduation went to practice corporate law at Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton in New York. It wasn't for him. **********Two years later he mailed out resumes to investment houses and soon jumped to Goldman, Sachs. By the 1970's, a Democrat in a sea of Republicans, he began raising money for Democratic Presidential candidates, while despairing that the party's old, big-government ideology could steer it off the rails. **********At Goldman he was fascinated by every detail of every deal; a colleague remembers getting called with questions during Thanksgiving dinner and during the second half of the Super Bowl. Mr. Rubin's mentor was Goldman's chief, Gus Levy, whose photograph occupies the center of a wall of pictures in his office, surrounded by the usual Bill-and-Hillary shots. He learned the brutal arbitrage business, and still occasionally tells stories of deals that went bad. All of this prepared him for the riskiest international investment of his life: Mexico. **********The outlines of the Mexican bailout are now familiar: When the newly Republican Congress refused to go along with an Administration plan to keep America's southern neighbor from default, Mr. Rubin urged the President to go it alone, using funds under the control of the Fed and the Treasury. If Mexico collapsed, Mr. Rubin feared, it could trigger a run on emerging markets around the world, from Brazil to Hong Kong. But the move cast the United States into a dangerous new role, that of the world's financial peacekeeper, its emergency lender. **********So to discourage other countries from depending on Washington, Mr. Rubin set extraordinarily tough standards for Mexico to get its house in order -- so tough, his critics contend, that it threw millions of Mexicans into unemployment. Today, Mr. Rubin admits that he spent months tortured by the fear that even with the tough requirements, private investors might not return to Mexico. Quietly, he stationed a Treasury agent there to make sure the government was really sticking to its austerity plan. **********Mexico is hardly out of the woods yet. But Mr. Rubin is. Private investors crept back in. And by this summer the Mexican Government -- partly to save money and partly to pay back a President it owed so much -- refinanced its debt by issuing bonds to private investors -- unthinkable a year ago -- and repaid the Treasury three-quarters of the borrowed money. Republican critics who had lambasted the bailout were silenced. **********''Can you imagine what would have happened if this had failed?'' Rubin said one day at the Treasury, putting his hands over his eyes. ''We would have spent the whole fall at hearings,'' answering questions about how billions of American dollars were lost. **********Taming Currency Traders **********Mexico was still boiling when Mr. Rubin faced his second potential political disaster: the fall of the dollar to below 80 yen. **********For Mr. Rubin, this was more familiar territory: he had supervised the currency traders at Goldman, and he knew both the fiscal and political risks. ''These kinds of occurrences are not without consequences,'' Mr. Rubin said. A declining dollar tends to drive investors out of American stocks, bonds and Treasury debt, putting pressure on the Federal Government to raise interest rates. ''It would take a while to show up, but I'm certain it would have happened,'' he said. **********Mr. Rubin did not add the obvious: high interest rates would have reversed the Federal Reserve's loosening of credit over the last year and undermined the President's argument that life has become easier for consumers because rates have fallen. Moreover, Mr. Rubin was haunted by the memory that in the Carter Administration, a weak dollar came to symbolize a weak America. ''I knew we couldn't let that happen again,'' he said. **********Wherever any Treasury Secretary goes, the dollar lurks over him. His airplane, President John F. Kennedy's old Air Force One, is equipped with encrypted communications equipment so the Treasury chief can order currency interventions -- the nuclear strikes of the 1990's -- from 30,000 feet. A flying wedge of wire-service reporters trails his every move, seeking the stray comment that could affect billions in transactions. **********Sometimes these reporters get lucky. Early in the Clinton Administration, Mr. Bentsen flipped off a casual remark that the United States was not as concerned about a weak dollar as it was about a stronger yen. Within seconds, the markets became convinced that the Clinton Administration would not defend the dollar, the yen soared, and Mr. Bentsen never again opened his mouth without a script. **********Mr. Rubin knew that getting the dollar back up would require discipline, patience, considerable stealth and luck. **********His first move was to impose an ironclad rule that he would be the only one in the Administration ever to talk about the dollar, the loquacious President included. Then he repeated, mantralike, that ''a strong dollar is in the interest of the United States.'' He mouthed this so often for so long that even his colleagues began to tease him about it. Mike McCurry, the Presidential press secretary, couldn't help himself during the Group of Seven summit meeting in Lyons, France, this summer. Stopping by the Treasury's early-morning staff meeting he smiled and said, ''Bob, let me make sure I have this right: a strong dollar is in the interest of the United States, right?'' **********''No, no, no,'' Mr. Rubin said, playing along. ''Repeat after me: It's in the interest of the United States that the dollar remain strong. There's a difference. Now, next week I'll teach you about 'stronger.' '' **********''Oh, no,'' Mr. McCurry responded, retreating from the room. ''I can't handle that.'' **********But words alone don't do the trick. Mr. Rubin's first, tentative efforts to bolster the dollar with the coordinated help of Japan and Germany failed; the intervention was washed away by investors who knew that the governments did not have the resources to outbid them. So he and his deputy, Lawrence H. Summers, a former Harvard economist who has become a considerable power in his own right in the Administration, retreated for months. Then, when the dollar had fallen off the front pages and the market's attention was elsewhere, they ambushed the currency speculators, ordering the Treasury to buy dollars. The idea was to sow so much uncertainty about the Treasury's tactics that no big speculators or hedge funds would risk being caught with a huge position in yen that could cost them millions if the Treasury intervened. **********''You can't outgun them,'' one of Mr. Rubin's close colleagues said. ''But you can teach them to fear you.'' Mr. Rubin smiled, Cheshire cat-like. ''Yeah, I've heard some people say that,'' was all he would say about it. By this summer, the dollar was back to 110 yen -- and Detroit was complaining it was so high that it was hurting car exports. **********The 'Tensest Moment' **********Mr. Rubin had a free hand in fighting the dollar war; the President almost never got involved. It could not have been more different from the battle that truly tested him, an enormous game of chicken over the budget. This was less familiar ground for the former Wall Street trader, and on more than one occasion, aides say, his cool veneer cracked. **********His mission was to protect the President from a classic Washington political ploy. Drawing from the Democratic playbook of the 1980's, House Speaker Newt Gingrich and his fellow Republicans warned that if President Clinton refused to sign the Republican budget, Congress would refuse to raise the Federal debt limit, the restriction on the Treasury's ability to borrow. That meant dallying with default: if the Treasury could not borrow, it could not pay Social Security and Medicare benefits, as well as billions in Treasury bonds that were coming due. **********Mr. Rubin's task was to convince Republicans that they would bear the election-year blame for default -- and the risk to America's rating as the world's safest investment -- while simultaneously assuring the markets he would never allow a default to happen. **********Making both arguments required a good deal of footwork -- and, in Republican eyes, considerable duplicity. In public, Mr. Rubin declared, ''It is unthinkable that the United States would default for the first time in its history.'' In private he, Mr. Summers and the Treasury's general counsel, Edward S. Knight, designed a series of moves to liquidate Government pension funds that hold Treasury bills. Once those funds were turned into cash or cash equivalents, they no longer counted against the Government's borrowing limit. But the law was murky on how far he could go, and Mr. Rubin had to keep up the juggling act for months, pushing the law to its limit. **********Eventually, Mr. Rubin effectively threw the steering wheel out the window: He declared that he had run out of financial tactics, and that if Congress wanted to bear the blame for default, that was Mr. Gingrich's problem. Mr. Gingrich's troops had to decide whether he was bluffing. Already stung by the public reaction to shutting down the Government during the winter, they backed off. Mr. Clinton never had to choose between signing a budget he didn't want and threatening the fiscal credibility of the United States. **********''This was Bob's tensest moment,'' Ms. Tyson said. And in the end, he helped Mr. Clinton appear to be taming the Republican Congress's excesses -- just the image on which the President is campaigning. **********A Bond for the Middle Class **********But between now and Nov. 5, Mr. Rubin will be busy using the power of the Treasury to improve his boss's prospects. On Wednesday, in Pittsburgh, he and the President will introduce a new kind of Treasury bond, the first to carry yields that are adjusted for inflation. The bonds are designed for middle-class savers who fear that inflation could eat into their savings, and will be cast as part of the Clinton Administration's effort to make it easier for Americans to plan for their children's college educations and their own retirement. **********In effect, the bonds are a kind of marriage of family values and Economics 101. If inflation stays low, the innovation could save the Treasury hundreds of millions of dollars in interest payments. But inside the White House, they aren't known as Clinton bonds; they are called Rubin bonds.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/25/world.main_headline: U.N. Says That Serbs Renewed Expulsions
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/25/world.print_headline: U.N. Says That Serbs Renewed Expulsions
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/25/world.body_text: **********The United Nations refugee agency accused Serbs today of resuming expulsions  of Muslims, while NATO's commander in Bosnia criticized all parties for violations of peace accords. **********Serbs forced about 30 Muslims out of their homes over the weekend near the Serbian-held city of Banja Luka, said Kris Janowski, spokesman for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. Serbs beat some of the Muslims, he said. **********Tens of thousands of non-Serbs were forced out of Banja Luka during three and a half years of war in Bosnia. **********Mr. Janowski said the weekend expulsions were the most extensive since the Dayton accord was signed in December. **********Adm. Leighton Smith, commander of the NATO-led peacekeeping force in Bosnia,  said he was distressed by obstacles to free movement of civilians throughout the region. **********"I expressed my dissatisfaction with the way all of the citizens of this country are being treated with respect to restriction of movement," Admiral Smith said after meeting with a Serbian leader, Momcilo Krajisnik. **********Fewer than 10,000 of Bosnia's 2 million refugees have crossed former front lines and returned to their prewar homes since December. Most of those have been Muslims settling in Croat-dominated areas and vice versa, rather than refugees returning to Serbian-held areas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/22/busin.main_headline: WARNER-LAMBERT SHARES JUMP AFTER INVESTOR MEETING
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/22/busin.print_headline: WARNER-LAMBERT SHARES JUMP AFTER INVESTOR MEETING
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/22/busin.body_text: **********The shares of the Warner-Lambert Company hit a record high yesterday amid speculation that Roche Holdings A.G. of Switzerland would make a bid for the company. Shares of Warner-Lambert, which makes Halls cough drops and Cognex, a drug treatment for Alzheimer's disease, rose $2.875, to close at $62.75, on the New York Stock Exchange after trading as high as $63.375. Warner-Lambert, based in Morris Plains, N.J., is often mentioned as a takeover candidate. Still, some analysts discounted the latest speculation, saying the price jump was partly caused by renewed interest in Warner-Lambert's new drug pipeline after a Boston meeting between the company and investors on Tuesday. Roche and Warner-Lambert declined to comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/29/busin.body_text: **********The Anglo American Corporation of South Africa Ltd. said yesterday that it would sell a 20 percent stake in the Johnnies Industrial Corporation to the National Empowerment Consortium, a group representing black business people and trade unions. Anglo first announced its intention two years ago to sell a stake in the company to increase blacks' participation in the economy. **********Anglo and its De Beers unit together hold 47.4 percent of Johnnies Industrial, or Johnnic, a holding company whose businesses include real estate development and equity stakes in some of South Africa's largest comanies. The National Empowerment will buy an initial 30.35 million shares in Johnnic at 50 rand, or more than $335 million.   (Bloomberg Business News)

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/26/busin.body_text: **********The Topps Company in New York, which markets trading cards, comic books, gum  and candy, has narrowed the review on its account to five agencies from 12. The  account, with billings now estimated at $7 million to $10 million, had been handled by Grey Advertising in New York for two and a half years until that agency resigned in April. **********Alan Krinsky, a partner at Advice and Advisors in New York, a consulting company managing the review, identified the finalists as North Castle Partners in Stamford, Conn., and four New York shops: Avrett, Free & Ginsberg; Compton Partners Saatchi & Saatchi, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C.; Griffin Bacal, a unit of  the Omnicom Group, and Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners. A decision is expected in early August.
