https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/01/world.body_text: **********The European Union said today it was taking the first step toward involving a World Trade Organization panel in a dispute over a new American law that strengthens trade sanctions against Cuba. **********The European Commission, which represents the 15-nation European Union in trade matters, said the bloc was calling for formal World Trade Organization consultations with the United States over the law. **********Under the legislation, American citizens could take foreign companies to court if the firms made profits from property identified as having been expropriated from individuals by the Cuban Government after the country's revolution. Cuba has been encouraging investment by foreign firms to aid its economy, which was damaged by the loss of its ties to the former Soviet Union. **********Consultations are the first phase for solving disputes under world trading rules. They can lead to setting up a formal panel to hear and rule on a complaint.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/14/busin.main_headline: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;For an AT&T Brat, the Anguish of Letting Go
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/14/busin.print_headline: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;For an AT&T Brat, the Anguish of Letting Go
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/14/busin.body_text: **********YESTERDAY, in exchange for a sum of money that will help me get started on a  new career, I was taken off payroll at AT&T. As one of 72,000 managers offered the company's buyout, I chose to accept it, but it was a hard decision: I spent  nearly 10 years as an AT&T employee, but far longer as part of the Bell System.  I am, you see, an unheralded, fading demographic -- an AT&T brat. **********As longtime AT&T employees, both my parents paved the way for my career. My two sisters also did stints with the company years ago; my older sister even met her husband in the cafeteria -- he's now a salesman for AT&T in Manhattan. There was a time when most of us even worked in the same building. If you were a financial adviser, you might say my family has consistently lacked diversity in  its employment portfolio. This point was driven home when my mother, brother-in-law and I received the voluntary severance package offered to managers early in December, thus beginning a month of agonizing. **********Our long history provides the context for that anguish. The first to join the company was my father, who started at Bell Laboratories in Murray Hill, N.J., in 1965, when he was 25 and I was 2. As a college recruiter for the company, he was always inviting people home for dinner, so I met many of his smiling recent hires as I grew up. His closest friends were also employees -- we spent two weeks at a lake each summer with another AT&T family (two of the children also became employees). My younger sister's godparents came from the company, too. **********My father spent the majority of his working life at Bell Labs, where he marveled at the freedom and creativity of that unique technical environment, in  which the bearded gurus wandering the hallways got much more respect than staff. Become an engineer, he said again and again. The techies have it made. **********Dad rose to become a human resources manager advising top-level technical management. When I was in high school, his executive friends would pull me aside during their visits and ask what I was going to do with my life. Be an engineer, I said, knowing it was what they wanted to hear. I painted their houses, even caddied for them on the golf course, and let them help my father groom me for a  technical job at AT&T. **********Indeed, I started college at the University of Delaware as a would-be engineer. And I nodded my head when one of my father's colleagues offered me a temporary job working with computers during a winter break. But that bleak month was so boring that I spent it in the Bell Labs library reading Kurt Vonnegut books (notably "Player Piano," about what happens to society when everything is  automated). I later ditched electrical engineering for the liberal arts. **********And so I was happily writing papers on Joyce and Dostoyevsky as my parents struggled through the aftermath of AT&T's breakup in the early 1980's. But come  graduation, I was out on the street, wondering what I could do. After many disenchanting and frustrating interviews on Wall Street, I let my father help me get a temporary job in an AT&T software testing lab. **********Six months later, I landed a full-time job at the labs as a technical assistant in network planning. This followed a tip from my mother, who had joined the company years before to help pay for tuition bills. **********Despite my best intentions, I found myself exactly where I swore to my parents I would never be -- working for AT&T as a full-fledged employee. I was even promoted and sent to get my master's degree in computer science, and I soon found myself a software designer in the most prestigious technical organization  in the world. **********Even so, every few years I would tell my father I was ready to leave. Whatever excuse I gave him -- a Ph.D. program or a possible job in Europe -- Dad's response was as reliable as the dial tone. I should stay, he said, because AT&T is a good place: it offers great benefits and a good salary, and the company needed people like me. I'd make a great executive, he said. To him, the  company wasn't a job; it was a way of life. His way of life. How could I reject  that? **********I didn't. I stayed and exciting things did happen for me. I became a project  manager. And I gained confidence traveling and giving presentations to corporate vice presidents, foreign delegations and even Congressional staff members.    MEANWHILE, I closely watched my father's career. In the 80's, he had become an integral part of an organization embracing the latest quality principles. He  would come home thrilled by a talk by Deming or a team-building exercise in the  woods. But three years ago, after years of restructuring, cutbacks and growth, his job function was eliminated. A surplus employee, he moved to another part of the company, but by then his enthusiasm had waned. **********After 30 years at AT&T, my father retired early last year. Even before I rejected an opportunity to go into a management training program, I knew I wanted to avoid what I had observed firsthand: the feeling of obsolescence that  my father and his friends experienced after a lifetime of power. The loss of identity was painful and real. **********It was troubling for me to see a man who had personally hired, nurtured, and  promoted a hundred people -- and whose contributions were honored at a wedding-reception-size retirement dinner -- have so few contacts outside the company. It shaped my decision to go part-time -- four days a week -- two years  ago. With the extra time, I taught technology courses to teen-agers and teachers, did some freelance writing and wrote a novel and a technical book. It  was a thrill to meet so many people who did not wear the AT&T badge. **********And the company has been hugely supportive of my extracurricular endeavors. The idea of a career path, in the old Bell System sense, has long been obsolete. In recent years, inside and outside the company, the message has been strong: You must take your career into your own hands. **********But no matter how excited I was about the outside opportunities, I felt my stomach sink last September when I watched Robert E. Allen, the chairman, announce AT&T's "trivestiture" -- its breakup into separate companies dedicated  to communications services, computers and networking products. Three hundred of  us were crammed in the atrium of our offices in Middletown, N.J., watching the announcement on the video monitor, making nervous jokes. We knew it would change our lives irrevocably. **********When the voluntary severance packages finally arrived at the beginning of December, my family equilibrium was broken by the stress. My mother, brother-in-law and I went off on an emotional roller coaster that made the approach to the holidays sleep-deprived and surreal. **********My brother-in-law never got close to applying -- he was in the middle of a large sales deal whose commission made even thinking about leaving impractical.  But my mother and I were both teetering throughout the extremely short, ill-timed decision period. Some days it seemed we would both take it, other days not a chance. But most of the time we were somewhere in between, discussing the  pros and cons in our daily phone calls. **********It was painful to see my mother's emotional strain. On good days, she would get excited by the possibility of using her lump sum -- about six months' pay -- to pursue her avocation as an artist; and she would be glad to avoid the uncertainty that would be sure to come after the buyout and layoffs. But on bad  days, she would worry about giving up her paycheck and, even more, about leaving a position as a personnel administrator, where she was well-respected and productive. She kept asking me what she should do. There aren't many opportunities, she feared, for someone her age. **********As Christmas approached, she knew she wouldn't be able to prepare for the holidays under the strain of deliberation, so she effectively deferred her decision until the last minute. Smiling calmly shortly before the Dec. 29 deadline, she told me she had decided to stay and see what the new year would bring. **********It turned out that the timing of the severance package was much more auspicious for me, given the surge of interest in the Internet, my technical expertise. Even so, the possibility of accepting the buyout didn't seem real until I asked for my father's advice. I expected to hear the same litany of reasons why the company needed people like me, but instead he told me it might be time to move on to other challenges. **********IT was a defining moment in our relationship. Over the years we had argued about the issue of corporate loyalty. I would ask why anyone should be loyal to  a legal entity. You have to be, my father would answer, frustrated with my irreverence to his lifelong ideal. Now, though he acknowledges that the AT&T of  religiously loyal lifetime employees is gone, he still struggles with what's next. To him, a corporation based on anything but long-term, personal loyalty doesn't make sense. **********Unlike my father, I tend not to personalize the restructuring effected by corporate management. I have no doubt the new companies will succeed, that the lean-and-mean AT&T triplets will capitalize on new information-age opportunities, and I am envious of my colleagues who will lead the way. **********Even so, with my father's blessing, I chose to take the buyout. My colleagues were shocked at first, but then they realized that I had been preparing for my departure all along. They were the ones, after all, who had been telling me that I should pursue my writing or that I would make a good entrepreneur. **********In fact, I have been greeted with so much support and good will that it has increased the painful feeling that I am leaving home. The corporation of my parents did, after all, pay for my education and help me become a successful adult. At times, I wish I could stay in the secure arms of Ma Bell, but she no longer exists. So now it is time for me to make my own way in the world.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/07/busin.snippet: Excerpt from speech by Federal Reserve Chmn Alan Greenspan (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/07/busin.main_headline: Excerpt From the Speech by Greenspan
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/07/busin.print_headline: Excerpt From the Speech by Greenspan
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/07/busin.body_text: **********Following is an excerpt from a speech by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, given at a dinner in Washington sponsored by the American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research on Thursday night: **********But where do we draw the line on what prices matter? Certainly prices of goods and services now being produced -- our basic measure of inflation -- matter. But what about futures prices or more importantly prices of claims on future goods and services, like equities, real estate or other earning assets? Are stability of these prices essential to the stability of the economy? **********Clearly, sustained low inflation implies less uncertainty about the future, and lower risk premiums imply higher prices of stocks and other earning assets. We can see that in the inverse relationship exhibited by price-earnings ratios and the rate of inflation on the past. But how do we know when irrational exuberance has unduly escalated asset values, which then become subject to unexpected and prolonged contractions as they have in Japan over the past decade? And how do we factor that assessment into monetary policy? We as central bankers need not be concerned if a collapsing financial asset bubble does not threaten to impair the real economy, its production, jobs and price stability. Indeed, the sharp stock market break of 1987 had few negative consequences for the economy. But we should not underestimate or become complacent about the complexity of the interactions of asset markets and the economy. Thus, evaluating shifts in balance sheets generally, and in asset prices particularly, must be an integral part of the development of monetary policy. **********The public examination of Federal Reserve actions extends well beyond our stewardship of monetary policy. Our overall management of the Federal Reserve System should, and does, come under considerable scrutiny by the Congress.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/30/news/.main_headline: Cups, Pots and Rituals:Hong Kong Museum Traces All the Tea in China
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/30/news/.print_headline: Cups, Pots and Rituals:Hong Kong Museum Traces All the Tea in China
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/30/news/.body_text: **********HONG KONG—                     Whatever differences exist between the British and the Chinese, one belief has never been challenged by either: a cup of tea is more than just a cup of tea. **********Little wonder, then, that Hong Kong is home to the Flagstaff House Museum of Tea Ware and that collecting teapots is a favorite pastime of a select and wealthy fraternity. **********The core of the exhibit — more than600 pieces of teaware dating from the Western Zhou times (11th century B.C. to 771 B.C.) until the 20th century — was donated by Dr. K.S. Lo and it is located in Hong Kong Park, which was recently expanded. **********These works of art are displayed along with explanations of different tea-making techniques in what was formerly the office and residence of the commander of the British forces in Hong Kong.This attractive building, constructed between 1844 and 1846, has been restored; new wings of the museum were built to match what is the oldest domestic building in Greek Revival style in Hong Kong. **********The museum is dedicated to the arts associated with Chinese tea.Through the study of the exhibitions, the viewer can start to learn how to decipher old tea rituals, which encompass aesthetics, medicine and philosophy. **********The reason that philosophy also plays a role, explains the museum's assistant curator, Grace Kwok, is that "many potters were under the patronage of literary scholars."Pottery would feature inscriptions of a favored verse by the scholar-patron, for example, or at least the names of great thinkers of the time. **********Traditional tea emporia in Hong Kong still boast of their ties to ancient rituals.The Chan Chun Lan Tea Merchants' emporium, for example, dating from 1855, was renowned as a gathering place for the colony's literati.Along with the fancy tea available, there was also mah-jongg and opium. **********In Flagstaff House, there are works of extreme delicacy and beauty with each object dedicated to the tea leaf.Taking pride of place is a fine set of "month cups," a set of 12 small bowls with flared sides. Experts debate whether these cups were in fact used more often for wine than for tea. **********Each is decorated with the flowers relevant to each month, while on the back is a finely painted verse extolling the beauty of the bloom and its season. **********Examples of such sets of cups have been sold to collectors in recent years. Pola Antebi, a specialist in Chinese ceramics at Christie's in Hong Kong, says prices for similar sets of month cups have been rising. **********In 1985, a set sold in New York for $143,000.Three years later, another setfetched $464,550, and in March 1991, Christie's Hong Kong sold a set for 6.16 million Hong Kong dollars (about $800,000) **********"It is very rare to get a complete set," said Ms. Antebi. "But even the singles are highly collectible. They are very finely potted, they are exquisite." **********Before the Tang Dynasty in China, (618-907), tea was regarded as a medicine rather than a daily drink.The leaves would be put in any old cooking pot, perhaps mixed with ginger or leeks, and brought to a boil. **********But then the connoisseur Lu Yu(circa 760-800)wrote "Chajing," or "Classic of Tea," in whichhe expounded on the methods of making powdered tea, a mixture of dried and ground leaves added to salted boiling water and ladled into bowls. **********By the time of the Sung Dynasty (960 to 1279), tea-making was further refined into the whipped tea method.Boiling water was poured onto tea powder and beaten with a bamboo whisk with the intent of making as much froth as possible. **********By the time of the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644), the practice of steeping tea had developed. **********The significance of the new tea-making methods was that each new stage required additional utensils. From the use of normal cooking vessels, tea-making progressed into a ritual requiring a large variety of bowls and teapots. **********In the Ching Dynasty (1644 to 1911), for example, a new refinement to the drinking process was developed in which lids and stands were added to little tea cups.The result was a small dish to hold the cup, which had a narrow base to steep the tea and a wide mouth for ease of drinking, topped by a lid. **********The lid kept the tea warm, but also helped hold off errant tea leaves that would otherwise be swallowed along with the tea. **********The value of itemssuch as the month cups at Flagstaff House, which date from the Kangxi period (1662-1722) of the Ching Dynasty, rests in the delicate painting and workmanship rather than in the material used. **********The highly popular Purple Clay wares from Yixing, the pottery capital of China, are an exception.The material used is the primary attraction.The clay is often of fine grain, is highly malleable and has a high iron content. **********These qualities give it a remarkable plasticity but prevent it from being thrown on a pottery wheel. So Yixing wares have to be handmade. To highlight the clay itself, Yixing wares are usually not decorated with verse or painting.As a result, the focus is on originality of shape. **********Many examples of Yixing pottery can be seen at the museum. A potter named Gongshun pioneered the treatment of the special clay and his seal is found on an interesting six-lobed teapot from 1513. **********The key criteria of value for teaware are the age of the pot, its rarity, and the presence of the potter's name or seal. Even then, says Ms. Antebi, the variations in price can be immense and sometimes puzzling. **********In 1988, one variety of teapot sold for about $13,000.By 1992, its price had surged to about $21,500.In 1993, subtle variations in the pot for sale led to a slip in price to about $15,000.In 1994, another sold for about $4,500 **********On the other hand, there is a man who unfurls a small rug on a central Hong Kong pavement in the evenings, selling small Yixing teapots. They are not hundreds of years old, but they feature the clay and forms for which the wares are famous.His pots go for about 50 Hong Kong dollars. **********- **********VAUDINE ENGLAND is a journalist based in Hong Kong.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/02/world.snippet: Left-wing rebels in Colombia mount one of deadliest offensives in decades, killing at least 80 soldiers and policemen in separate attacks across country; 54 soldiers are killed as rebels overrun army base in southwest; map; authorities blame FARC ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/02/world.main_headline: Rebels Kill 80 in Strongest Attacks in Colombia in Decades
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/02/world.print_headline: Rebels Kill 80 in Strongest Attacks in Colombia in Decades
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/02/world.body_text: **********Left-wing rebels mounted one of their deadliest offensives in decades over the weekend, killing at least 80 soldiers and policemen in separate incidents throughout the country. **********In the worst attack, which occurred on Friday night, 54 soldiers were killed and 17 were wounded when 500 rebels overran Las Delicias army base, in the southwestern Putumayo region along the Caqueta River, Defense Ministry spokesmen said. Another 26 soldiers were missing and believed to have been kidnapped by the rebels. **********Military spokesmen said it was the greatest loss of life by the army in a single rebel attack since the guerrillas began battling the Government nearly 40 years ago. Because it occurred in an isolated, densely-forested area, news of the attack did not reach the rest of the country until Saturday afternoon. **********Military spokesmen said the guerrillas used rockets and grenades in that attack as well as in other strikes in 10 different locations, where the rebels targeted police and army installations in small towns and destroyed public buildings and banks. **********The authorities attributed the attacks to members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, known by the Spanish acronym FARC. The group, one of the oldest guerrilla factions in Latin America, was once a pro-Cuban Marxist movement. But Cuba's support for FARC waned in the mid-1980's, and it has been years since the group has stated its exact goals, aside from opposing the Government. **********In the last decade, the group has stepped up its kidnappings for ransom and has become involved in Colombia's drug trade by extorting money from coca growers and drug traffickers to protect their crops and routes from the authorities and by operating its own drug-processing laboratories. Both of those lucrative businesses have allowed FARC to grow considerably in recent years. **********The attacks come at a time when the Government of President Ernesto Samper faces generalized unrest. Thousands of peasants, farmers and workers have been clamoring for greater economic investment and social programs that Mr. Samper promised during his 1994 campaign but, they say, has yet to deliver. Since mid-July, about 130,000 people have been involved in demonstrations around the country. **********The unrest is widely attributed to Mr. Samper's weakness and loss of credibility after being exonerated last June of charges of drug-related corruption by a Congress that faces similar accusations. Polls show that most Colombians distrusted the congressional decision and that Mr. Samper and his aides have lost the leverage needed to keep the country under control. **********In what is seen as an effort to placate the United States, Mr. Samper has embarked on an ambitious coca eradication program that seeks to wipe out more than 67,000 acres of illegal crops this year. The plan has met its fiercest resistance in regions like Putumayo. **********A week ago a Government commission met with peasant leaders in Putumayo and signed an agreement in which the Government pledged to increase social programs and investment in the area in return for an end to the protests. While spokesmen for the peasants said the accord guaranteed that coca crops would not be forcefully eradicated, Government officials denied that their eradication program had been compromised. **********In the ensuing confusion, analysts worried that the Government was making hasty promises in an attempt to buy time and stave off further trouble. ''All this makes one conclude that the agreement in Putumayo, rather than deactivating a time bomb, has temporarily put off an explosion,'' wrote Semana, a Bogota weekly. **********Indeed, the scenes witnessed in Putumayo echo what happened in December 1994, when the Government first announced its eradication program. Violent protests ended only after the Government agreed to make investments worth $1 million  in the region. **********''The credibility of those agreements inspires doubts,'' wrote Enrique Santos Caldera An, a columnist for El Tiempo newspaper, at the time. He add that if the Government did not honor its commitments soon, ''it would not be surprising if in six months these areas are again up in arms.'' **********Military leaders have said the protesters are being manipulated by guerrilla leaders who want to protect one of their main sources of livelihood. Yet demonstrations have also included thousands of farmers who grow legal crops, as well as transportation workers in Bogota who are asking for pay raises. **********The attacks this weekend appear to have ended any immediate chances of peace negotiations with guerrilla groups. Besides the FARC, two other left-wing guerrilla groups, the National Liberation Army and the Popular Liberation Army, are active in Colombia.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/16/busin.body_text: **********The Sprint Corporation said yesterday that it had passed the last hurdle to spinning off its cellular-telephone business by getting approval from the Internal Revenue Service to make the spinoff tax-free for shareholders. The company plans to spin off the cellular unit, called the 360degrees Communications Company, in the first quarter to comply with a Federal law that prohibits the overlap of Sprint's cellular business with its new operations in so-called personal communications services. Sprint shareholders will get one share of 360degrees Communications for every three Sprint shares they own.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/19/world.snippet: Sole threat facing many American troops stationed in Vlasencia, Bosnia, is high cost of long-distance telephone service, coupled with constant temptation to call home; many report telephone bills of $500 or more each month; long-distance service i...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/19/world.main_headline: Calls Home From Bosnia Can Shell a G.I.'s Wallet
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/19/world.print_headline: Calls Home From Bosnia Can Shell a G.I.'s Wallet
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/19/world.body_text: **********Pfc. Eddie Waiters had been wooing the same woman since the ninth grade and, on a recent leave from Bosnia back home in Chicago, he finally won her heart. Like any good boyfriend, he calls often. But being here in Bosnia presents a problem that became evident the other day after he had chatted with her, happily, for about two hours. **********The problem? ''About, ah, $160?'' said Private Waiters, 21, straining to guess what his most recent call cost. **********But in all he is doing well compared with what he was spending  when he first arrived in Bosnia in January: He managed to get his last bill down to $650 -- not bad considering that the first month here, he paid $1,300 of the $2,000 he earns each month to AT&T. **********''You just get lonely out here,'' he said. ''You need someone to talk to. It gets you through the days, sometimes.'' **********There are only so many games of dominoes to play, James Bond films to watch or romance novels to browse through -- yes, there are stacks of them here -- on a peacekeeping mission during which 15,000 American troops are kept cooped away from the potentially dangerous distractions of local towns and cities. **********And with the peril from the former warring factions mercifully low so far, many soldiers see only one threat they have difficulty defending themselves against: the high cost, and constant temptation, of calling home. **********After a half-hour call to a girlfriend in Germany from this hilltop camp in Serb-controlled territory, Specialist William J. Hunt 4th, 26, of Wilmington, Mass., said he worried more about AT&T than about the Serbs or Muslims. ''AT&T is winning the war,'' he said. **********At another American camp several miles to the northwest, where the sign on the AT&T tent once read, ''House of Debt,'' Sgt. Ralph Middlebrooks Jr., of Dayton, Ohio, gave an irritated look when the subject of the phone company was raised. **********''I walk by that AT&T tent every morning, and just keep walking by,'' Sergeant Middlebrooks said, adding grouchily that he reaches out to touch his family via daily letters. ''They aren't getting my money.'' **********This is an issue of some touchiness for AT&T, which has an exclusive contract to provide telephone services for the troops in Bosnia and under no circumstances wants to seem like it is gouging the men and women who risk their lives so far away from their families. **********As it has done in other places where American troops are stationed, like Korea or the Persian Gulf, the company rolled early into Bosnia to set up satellite dishes and phones at every United States post of any size. That cost money, said Kelly Sratmore, a spokeswoman for AT&T in New Jersey, as does what she said is exceptionally high-quality service: Each call, whether it is aimed at Paramus, N.J., or Berlin, is beamed back to the United States, to English-speaking operators, over lines remarkably free of static or interference. **********There are cheaper but far more cumbersome alternatives. Many soldiers say they try to call home on  military phones, which provide a free connection to the military base closest to the person called, but have a lot of static and often require a long wait in line. The call can then be channeled from the base to a private long-distance carrier for a fee. **********Ms. Statmore declined to elaborate on the financial aspects of AT&T's operation, but said ''There are a lot of factors wrapped into the service we are providing and it is very much in line with costs.'' **********She added that the rates are discounted, and have actually gone down for soldiers since March. But it is still easy to see how soldiers run up bills quickly and why one lieutenant colonel ordered signs put up next to the phones. ''WARNING!'' the signs read. ''Manage your money: Indebtedness is punishable under Article 134, U.C.M.J.,'' the Uniform Code of Military Justice. The sign goes on to note that the penalties for reneging on one's debts can include a bad-conduct discharge and six months in jail, although military officials here said they were not aware of any problems that severe. **********In scores of interviews with soldiers, many reported bills of $500 or more a month, and there was much undocumented talk of bills as high as $2,000. **********The cheapest approach is to enroll in a special AT&T savings plan for the military, at a cost of $5 a month, and to call home only on Saturdays or Sundays. That costs 99 cents a minute. On weekdays, the cost is $1.14. Using a regular AT&T card costs $1.75 for the first minute, $1.50 for each additional minute, plus a $2.50 surcharge, on any day of the week. **********But those rates apply only to calls to the United States. The home bases of most American soldiers in Bosnia are in Germany, and to call families there, the price rises to $1.49 a minute on weekends with the military discount and $1.64 on weekdays. With a regular AT&T card, the cost is $3 for the first minute, $2.75 for each additional minute and the same $2.50 surcharge. **********To call collect to the United States, as Pfc. Nathan Cox, 20, learned recently when he reversed the charges to his parents in Davenport, Iowa, for an hour, is a painful $7 a minute. **********Many commanders here recommend that their soldiers buy pre-paid calling cards from AT&T, which come in denominations of $20, $40 or $60. The rates are uniform all week long -- $1.06 a minute to the United States, and $1.80 to Germany -- and help keep soldiers on budget because they cannot talk indefinitely. **********Every camp with AT&T phones has an on-site technician, and the one at the camp here in Vlasenica, Matt Barbani, 65, tries to impart a little grandfatherly advice. He said he tells the troops to use only pre-paid cards, or to have an operator cut in after a set number of minutes. **********But he said the young soldiers, especially, have trouble budgeting their time and money, and he has seen many bills mount up because of arguments or a troubled marriage. **********''I found a receiver broken in half one day,'' Mr. Barbani said. ''I imagine he was upset. It upset me too because these guys have guns.'' **********Mr. Barbani, by the way, has to pay the same rates as anyone else when he calls his wife in Vienna, Va., at least two times a week. **********''I try to keep it to 10 minutes,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/09/world.main_headline: Israel's Parties Open the Election Campaign, With Slick Ads and a  Focus on Security
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/09/world.print_headline: Israel's Parties Open the Election Campaign, With Slick Ads and a  Focus on Security
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/09/world.body_text: **********The Israeli political race burst into Israeli homes today as the major parties opened their television campaigns with a slick cascade of doves, babies, jingles and slogans, all focused on a single issue -- security. **********The images were not particularly subtle, and the endless variations on "peace" and "security" often sounded much alike, but nobody needed to be told that the choice they offered was one of the most crucial that Israelis have been asked to make in many years. **********Prime Minister Shimon Peres, 72, assumed the role of national father-figure  in the Labor Party spots, mingling happily with hundreds of bright-eyed adolescents who listened spellbound to his tales of peacemaking and broke into song. "We're all with you with tears and happiness," they sang. "Peres, we're all with you." **********Mr. Peres's predecessor, Yitzhak Rabin, the general-turned-peacemaker who has become a national icon since his assassination six months ago at the hand of a young religious nationalist, appeared often in the snappily edited spots, establishing a connection that is expected to figure prominently in the Labor Party's campaign. **********Benjamin Netanyahu, the 47-year-old Likud challenger, took a more sedate tack, standing in a dark suit in an oak-paneled study as he laid out his basic line of attack. **********"Peres tried it his way, putting security in the hands of Yasir Arafat," he intoned, building steadily up to his campaign jingle: "Netanyahu: making a secure peace." **********Unlike Mr. Peres, whose spots never mentioned Likud or Mr. Netanyahu, the Likud's ads repeatedly attacked the Prime Minister as a dove who would divide Jerusalem, barter away the Golan Heights and compromise Israel's security. **********Smaller parties also unveiled their television spots, joining in what will be a nightly ritual through the election on May 29. Under Israeli election law, television campaigning is limited to the last three weeks before the election, during which time the Central Election Commission parcels out time every evening among the competing parties, according to their size. **********On opening night today, Labor and Likud each had four spots, while the liberal Meretz had two, and two religious parties had one spot each. **********The same election laws also bar all the candidates, including Mr. Peres, from appearing on regular television programming from now through the election. They  can be shown only if they appear at official events, but not speaking or being interviewed. **********While these procedures have been around for several elections, this one is the first in which Israelis will vote directly for the Prime Minister, rather than only for a party, as in the past. That has focused the campaign largely on  the personalities of Mr. Netanyahu and Mr. Peres. If the first day's ads were not too rough, both parties made clear that things would get much tougher as the election drew near. **********Also in contrast to the past, when the debate was over the basic ideology of  the Israeli state, the peace agreements reached with the Palestinians and with Jordan over the last four years fundamentally changed the debate, dividing the nation into those who want to continue down Labor's road and those who are afraid that it would only undermine their security further. **********That has made this race a virtual referendum on how to proceed with the peace negotiations, throwing supporters as diverse as the Clinton Administration and Mr. Arafat behind Mr. Peres, and prompting Islamic militants opposed to peace to seek his ouster. Other issues have been pushed to the distant background. **********With the country split roughly half and half, the outcome is expected to hinge on about 100,000 undecided voters in the center. It is after them that both Mr. Peres and Mr. Netanyahu have gone, with the dovish Mr. Peres seeking to toughen his image, and the hawkish Mr. Netanyahu insisting that he is for peace, albeit on tougher terms than Labor. **********Polls show the candidates only about four percentage points apart now. That promised a close race, and one that could be swayed if new security crises erupted in the final three weeks. **********Though the race has been officially under way now since Mr. Peres moved the elections up from October to May three months ago, a series of crises -- first a spate of bus bombings, then the incursion into Lebanon -- have kept campaigning  muted. But every move by the Prime Minister, from his stern response to the bombings to his decision to stage the operation against Hezbollah guerrillas in  Lebanon, has been scrutinized by the press, the opposition and the electorate through the prism of the campaign. **********That the Lebanese operation has brought international reproach on Israel has  mattered far less in public opinion than what it showed about Mr. Peres's readiness to be tough with the Arabs in the name of security. **********Against this backdrop, the television spots represented the initial tactic of each party on how best to secure the wavering mass at the center. **********Mr. Peres's approach was to draw his links to the slain Mr. Rabin, to President Clinton, to King Hussein and to his long experience and, most important, to suggest that future generations will live in a better Israel through his peace. **********Accordingly, the Labor ads were full of mothers hugging children and youths flocking to Mr. Peres. In one scene, an infant stares at his sad-faced mother, while the child's thoughts are narrated: "Mom, why are you sad? Do you imagine me as a soldier one day?" The child then turns to his father and continues, "Tell her when I grow up, there won't be wars; tell her on May 29 to vote for the person who makes peace." **********The spot then concludes with dazzling snatches of prosperous, modern Israelis in convertibles, on tractors, in nightclubs, while youths sing the campaign song, "We feel strong with Peres, strong and healthy." **********The Likud's ads were geared to a more nationalistic message, all of them opening with an athlete running with an Israeli flag, from which darts a white dove. Most of them continued with assaults on Mr. Peres. **********The most captivating sequence showed a pane of glass breaking. "Who said whether the Israelis want it or not, Jerusalem is the capital of Palestine?" the narrator asks, and a piece of glass falls out to reveal uniformed legs. **********"Who promised to fight terrorism?" it continues, and the rest of Mr. Arafat is shown. **********"Who is cut off from reality and relies on him?" goes the final question, and the rest of the glass falls out to reveal a smiling Mr. Peres walking alongside  Mr. Arafat. **********Along with the spots, Mr. Netanyahu also released the Likud party's long-awaited position on peace and security issues. The statement declared that  a Likud government would honor existing agreements and would continue negotiations toward a peace agreement, but it also said it would allow the expansion of Jewish settlements in the West Bank, oppose the establishment of a  Palestinian state and give the Israeli Army "complete freedom of action" to fight against terror. **********That formulation, and in particular the intention to lift the freeze on settlements, marked a fundamental change in the understandings on which the Israeli-Palestinian negotiations have taken place so far, and it is not likely that the Palestinians would agree. **********For his part, Mr. Peres has sought to demonstrate that Mr. Arafat has cracked down on extremists and has lived up to his obligations, among other things by changing the Palestinian charter to excise articles calling for the destruction  of the Jewish state. At the same time, Mr. Peres has tried to delay sensitive actions, for instance by suspending Israeli withdrawal from Hebron until after the election. **********Mr. Peres has also had to soothe Israeli Arab voters who have threatened to boycott the election in protest against the Lebanese operation and restrictive measures against Palestinians. **********To restore their critical votes, the Prime Minister announced that he would appoint an Arab minister to his Cabinet, and that he would probably release Sheik Ahmed Yassin, the spiritual leader of the militant Hamas group, who has been held in Israeli prisons for seven years and who has lately called for an end to terror. But only after the election.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/27/your-.body_text: **********DESPITE the frequently uttered caveats about the legal, fiscal and administrative difficulties of building your own retirement fund, some analysts say doing it yourself is the best way to secure value. **********"The whole business is much simpler than people say," says Bob Young, a pensions specialist at British stock broker Christows Ltd. **********"Investors want to see their savings grow over a given period in order to provide a good income at a certain date," he says."They are as well equipped to do that for themselves as they are for any other type of investment." **********"What puts people off is that pensions evoke an emotional rather than a practical response from many investors," he adds."Because they may eventually be entirely dependent on their pension for income in retirement, investors feel it needs specialized care." **********Instead, he says, pension investors should take a more proactive role in organizing their retirement income, enabling them to tailor a portfolio to their specific needs and maybe even producing a better return than a dedicated pension manager can. **********Broadly speaking, there are two ways investors can be involved in the daily management of their pensions, both of which offer differing degrees of control. **********They can either go the whole way and build their own portfolio, or they can opt for partial self-invested plans — sometimes known as hybrids.The advantage with a hybrid is that the investor can tap into the benefits of having a professional manager but still have a good deal of leeway to play around with at least a portion of the fund. **********The manager will be aware of what investments are allowed according to local pension rules and can keep the investor up to date with any taxation changes.The manager will also carry the often considerable administration burden that comes with pension investment. **********Self-invested pensions are growing in popularity, says Peter Jordan, pensions marketing manager with Skandia Life in Britain. He says that since private pension plans were made widely available in Britain in the late 1980s, investors have become more enthusiastic about deciding how their pension money is invested. **********"The market here is more advanced and more diverse than in other European countries, mainly because other European equity markets are less developed than in Britain," he says. **********But he warns that pension investors running their own portfolios need to be certain of their reasons for doing so."It's a tempting idea to have freedom and control over your investments," he says. "But dealing costs can be high and diversification low. Running a relatively small portfolio could be self-defeating." **********At the other end of the scale are investors who prefer to build their pension portfolios from scratch. These are usually either high-net-worth investors or people who have already amassed a large fund for their retirement. **********Few choose to manage their own investments purely for fun, says Mr. Young.Usually they are looking for a strategy that traditional pension fund managers are unable to provide. **********"Take pension funds in Britain for example," he says. "Almost all of them are invested 90 percent in British stocks.But to get real growth you ought to invest internationally.If you're getting 8 percent growth in China, what's the point of sticking with 3 percent in Britain?" **********He dismisses the argument by some fund managers that keeping assets and liabilities in the same currency is preferable to risking adverse shifts in currency values: **********"It depends on what country you plan retiring to, but it certainly doesn't wash in Britain.The chances of sterling soaring in value are extremely remote.In the meantime, people invested in some emerging markets are getting the benefits of high growth plus currency appreciation." **********Building a private pension portfolio also allows investors to consider a broader range of investments.Private client advisers say they are frequently asked to include collectibles and other valuable assets, such as yachts andracehorses, as part of their clients' pension arrangements.However, tax rules usually exclude anything other than traditional equity and debt instruments as tax-qualifying pension investments.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/06/news/.print_headline: Communists Are Up to No Good, Russian Warns
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/06/news/.body_text: **********DAVOS, Switzerland—                     Russia's resurgent Communist Party will suppress civil liberties, devastate the economy and trigger widespread bloodshed if it is allowed to prevail in presidential elections this June, a leading Russian economic reformer warned the West on Monday. **********Anatoli B. Chubais, former deputy prime minister, issued his warning here at a gathering of business and political leaders, some of whom he accused of letting themselves be seduced by the Russian Communist Party leader Gennadi A. Zyuganov. Russian opinion polls show Mr. Zyuganov as the leading candidate in the June elections. **********If the Communists are brought back to power, Mr. Chubais said, "the first move will be to forbid the free press," and then Mr. Zyuganov will "put in prison allhis political enemies." **********"Those policies will inevitably lead to big blood in Russia," he said. **********The comments were the first detailed remarks Mr. Chubais has made abroad since he was dismissed last month as deputy prime minister by President Boris N. Yeltsin. Mr. Chubais said that whereas 75 percent of Russia's economic activity is now generated in the private sector, "Zyuganov's idea is to create the opposite situation, where at least 75 percent of property will be renationalized or confiscated." **********Mr. Chubais said he had witnessed "international businessmen, some my friends, dancing around Zyuganov here in Davos." This Swiss alpine resort is where the World Economic Forum holds its annual meetings, which have become a business mating-dance for a thousand of the world's capitalist and governmental elite leavened with a sprinkling of cultural figures. **********Mr. Chubais read out what he said were policy statements of Mr. Zyuganov's Communist Party that called for reversing privatization and nationalizing such sectors as energy and banking. **********Mr. Zyuganov, during his own presentation here Sunday, rejected suggestions that he would renationalize and promised to defend private property rights, improve the climate for investment, and fight escalating crime and corruption. In an interview with the International Herald Tribune, he held out an olive branch to the leading democracy candidate, Grigori A. Yavlinsky. **********On Monday, however, Mr. Chubais portrayed the Communist leader as a wolf in sheep's clothing, saying: "There's a Zyuganov a for foreign use and a Zyuganov for domestic consumption." **********Mr. Yeltsin, who has come under increasing political pressure from the left as well as the right for the government's economic policies and has seen his popularity plummet, chose the manager of the state-owned Lada vehicle factory, to succeed Mr. Chubais. **********Despite his dismissal, and fears that Mr. Yeltsin will end the program of economic reforms and privatization long championedby Mr. Chubais, hesaid he hoped the International Monetary Fund would not hold back on$9 billion in planned loans.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/07/busin.snippet: Users of World Wide Web are often frustrated by interminable delays in retrieving software and graphics; Marimba Inc will introduce new software, called Castanet, for distributing information much more quickly over Internet; analysts say Castanet ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/07/busin.main_headline: New Software Seeks End To Long Waits on Internet
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/07/busin.print_headline: New Software Seeks End To Long Waits on Internet
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/07/busin.body_text: **********Marimba Inc., an eight-month-old company, will formally introduce new software today for distributing information much more quickly over the Internet. **********The new software, called Castanet, tries to solve one of the major remaining obstacles to the Internet's future commercial growth: reducing the interminable delays in retrieving software and graphics that can make the experience of using the World Wide Web a frustrating one. **********Castanet, which consists of several programs, provides for a system of  ''channels'' by which only selected, or updated, information and graphics are sent down from Internet servers to individual computers on a ''time release'' basis. Whereas users who currently want to view information must wait while entire images, sets of data or applications are retrieved, Castanet users need only  retrieve the entire set of data once, updating as needed. **********Initially, Castanet will work only with programs written for Sun Microsystems' Java language, but it is eventually expected to support other programming languages. **********''There's a lot of waiting, and a lot of repeat traffic on the Internet,'' said Marimba's president, Kim Polese, who founded the company with several colleagues from the original team that created Java at Sun. ''We're working on how to take Java to the next level.'' **********Other companies are also developing systems for gathering information over the Internet. Pointcast Inc., for example, automatically retrieves such information as stock quotes, news and sports scores, but these come from specific sources like Reuters. But Marimba's Castanet appears to have broader applications than such programs. **********Many new-media companies are already working with early versions of Castanet to create programs they say they would not have tried before. MGM Interactive, for example, a division of MGM United Artists, said it was using Castanet to start a series of entertainment Web sites that involve a continually changing story  line. AT&T New Services Strategies has said it is already using Castanet to help it design new communications devices that interact with the Internet. **********But while Castanet could significantly improve the performance of  software on the Internet's World Wide Web, the software may have an  even bigger impact on the way software is managed on private corporate networks, some analysts say. **********Distributing and tracking software throughout large corporations is an expensive and time-consuming problem for computer systems departments, and one that only promises to become more complex. Castanet helps automate the process by providing an efficient way for computers on a network to retrieve and distribute new versions of software, mostly during off hours. **********''Probably their largest opportunity is focusing on the most immediate  and difficult issue: software distribution to corporate users,'' said Hubert Delany, director of Internet research at the Gartner Group, a market research company in Stamford, Conn. ''It's a huge problem.'' **********Yet while the young start-up has enjoyed significant attention, its success is by no means insured, Mr. Delany said. Particularly in the corporate market for software management, Marimba could face considerable competition, he said. **********Based in Mountain View, Calif., Marimba was created with a $4 million investment from the JavaFund, a $100 million venture capital fund.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/02/busin.body_text: **********The General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers union announced an agreement early this morning on a new three-year labor contract, averting a national strike against the world's largest auto maker and likely bringing to an end the greatest labor unrest in the American automobile industry since 1970. **********Negotiators did not settle a three-day strike by two local unions, but a resolution of those walkouts seems likely very soon. **********The deal, which is subject to a ratification vote by 215,000 G.M. workers, bears a strong resemblance to contracts that the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation have already signed with the U.A.W. The contracts are intended to make the Detroit auto makers' stop the long shrinkage of their work forces while still letting them reduce their labor costs and compete more effectively with non-union factories that Japanese and European auto makers have built in the South. **********Each auto maker agreed to keep overall employment close to current levels, although with a few escape clauses, such as in case of recession. The employment guarantees slightly reduce the incentive for auto makers to rely on outside suppliers, since they will have to pay their workers anyway. **********The union even gave the auto makers an incentive to hire more workers, by allowing them to pay somewhat lower wages in any auto parts industries they may enter. Ford has already begun a broad review of what parts can now be manufactured in-house to make use of the lower wages. **********But the auto makers, notably G.M. and Ford, gained a little more flexibility this autumn to sell a handful of unprofitable auto parts factories. And while the union won wage increases that will exceed the inflation rate by a couple percentage points a year, it was not as aggressive in demanding pay increases as it has been in some previous labor contracts negotiated during prosperous times in the auto industry. **********Stephen P. Yokich, the U.A.W.'s president, announced the new labor contract at about 2 A.M., saying: ''We have it. We're happy about it.'' **********The Canadian Automobile Workers, a separate union, has already reached deals with Chrysler and G.M. and is trying to reach an agreement with Ford by next Monday. A short strike there cannot be ruled out, but few industry experts expect a prolonged walkout. **********So while there may still be a few isolated walkouts at G.M. factories in the months' ahead, today's agreement seems likely to end months of conflict that pitted a more militant American labor movement against the nation's biggest companies in a struggle over corporate downsizing and outsourcing. G.M. is the nation's biggest company in terms of sales, while Ford is the second largest and Chrysler is the ninth largest. **********G.M.'s sprawling empire of assembly plants and auto parts factories, which produce a little over 1 percent of the nation's economic output, has suffered three massive strikes this year. A 17-day strike last March at two brake factories in Dayton, Ohio, forced G.M. to close most of its North American assembly plants and temporarily lay off 177,000 workers. **********A three-week strike by G.M.'s Canadian workers that ended on Oct. 23 also produced heavy layoffs, as severe shortages of auto parts idled many American factories. G.M. said today that 19,000 of its American workers still have not been able to return to their jobs because of the lingering effects of that strike. **********The latest strike, and potentially the most costly of all, began on Tuesday evening when 7,500 U.A.W. workers walked out at G.M.'s most profitable assembly plant and at one of its most important truck parts factory. Because G.M.'s truck factories have been running at full speed and have scant supplies of spare parts, the latest strike quickly affected other operations. G.M. closed four highly profitable assembly plants that make pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles, and idled another 11,000 workers. Outside companies that make parts for G.M. also began temporarily laying off thousands of workers. **********Auto analysts put G.M. combined losses from these strikes at about $1.3 billion in foregone after-tax profits. By comparison, only 46 publicly traded American companies earned more than $1.3 billion in all of 1995, a year of record corporate profits. The strikes have also cost the Federal Government as much as $600 million in taxes that G.M. would have paid on these profits. **********G.M. may recoup half its losses by asking workers to put in a lot of overtime in the months ahead, Wall Street experts said. **********Tonight's settlement came after Labor Secretary Robert E. Reich had publicly urged both sides today to strike an agreement. Mr. Reich said that Labor Department officials had tried to ''make sure that all parties know that there is a national interest at stake, that we hope and encourage them to reach a settlement.'' **********But it was unclear that Mr. Reich's efforts had affected the timing of tonight's deal. Labor Department officials also told union leaders and company executives that Federal mediators were available if needed. But both sides' negotiators declined the offer, following an auto industry tradition in which union and company officials have prefered for decades to deal with each other with no outsiders present.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/17/busin.print_headline: Incoming OECD Chief Charts an Activist Role
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/17/busin.body_text: **********Pledging to turn the world's leading economic think tank into an activist force, the incoming chief of the OECD has said he wants to raise the organization's profile and forge close ties with the World Trade Organization. **********"We are going to have to start playing a much more aggressive role, and that means we will do a lot more than just deliver reports and studies and analyses to governments," said Donald Johnston, the Canadian politician who will take over as head of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development on June 1. **********Mr. Johnston, 60, said he wanted to see the Paris-based economic research institute provide support to the WTO. "We must be committed to helping the WTO to move the trade agenda forward," he said this week from Montreal. "The OECD can keep momentum going on trade in some of the most critical areas." **********Mr. Johnston stressed that trade would be a priority under his leadership "because everything flows from trade and investment." Meanwhile, officials from member governments said they wanted to see the OECD transformed from something of a bureaucratic backwater into a visible instrument of economic-policy formation for the world's leading industrial nations. **********Mr. Johnston, a lawyer and former Canadian finance minister who was president of Canada's Liberal Party until 1994, said he did not wish to criticize Jean-Claude Paye, who will leave the OECD top job on May 31. **********Mr. Paye, a former French official who has been criticized for providing solid but uninspiring leadership, narrowly survived attempts by the United States, Japan and other countries to oust him in 1994. Although Mr. Paye had been in office for 10 years, France threatened to veto Mr. Johnston unless Mr. Paye was allowed to hang on to the job for an additional 18 months. **********Mr. Johnston said the OECD must take "a more activist and advocacy role to sell the benefits of the free-trade agenda." He added, "It will be central to my mandate to move the OECD to a different level of communication." **********Mr. Johnston's remarks won enthusiastic responses from the United States and Japan. "This is the kind of energy that we were seeking in a new secretary-general," said Ambassador David Aaron, U.S. representative at the OECD here. He said all of the new trade issues that would be addressed at the first WTO trade ministers' meeting in Singapore in December had been "incubated" at the OECD. Among these are trade and the environment, competition policy, labor standards and investment. **********In Tokyo, Kazuo Ogura, Japan's deputy minister of foreign affairs, said, "We most certainly welcome Mr. Johnston's comments that the OECD should be reinvigorated and more aggressive because we consider it to be one of the most important organizations for economic policy formation." **********In Geneva, Renato Ruggiero, director-general of the WTO, said, "These are very intelligent comments, and I wish Johnston all the best." He added, " I am convinced that a close and strong relationship between our two organizations will be an important element for making progress in the international trading system." **********Not everyone is pleased to see the OECD taking a more activist role. Some developing countries have complained the organization's work on cross-border investment flows means they risk being excluded from the process. **********Addressing this concern, Mr. Johnston said he understood, but he also said that pressing ahead with work on trade and investment were "fundamental" because they held "the key to the evolution of the developing world."
