https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/17/busin.body_text: **********A new breed of stock exchange that specializes in small companies is springing up in Europe. **********The aim of these bourses is to channel money from risk-embracing investors to enterprises that may become tomorrow's blue chips, but do not yet meet the stringent conditions for listing on big markets in London, Paris, Milan or Frankfurt. **********The latest of these boursettes calls itself Easdaq and boasts that it intends to be Europe's answer to Nasdaq, which helped design it and retains a small equity stake. **********Officially started on Sept. 30, Easdaq now has 30 registered traders and is attracting new members at the rate of about seven a week. Although trading is due to start later this month, only a few companies have so far announced intentions to list their shares. They include Artwork Systems, a Belgian software company, and Innogenetics, a Belgian biotechnology concern. **********However, Jonathan Freeman, an Easdaq official, says he hopes there will soon be more stocks in what will be an all-electronic market with its headquarters in Brussels, its computer system in London and with settlements taking place in Zurich. **********Mr. Freeman says Easdaq is not meant only for small-capitalization stocks. He hopes it will become ''a European Nasdaq where quite important companies will be traded.'' **********Like the other new European markets, Easdaq is intended to provide easy entry for small enterprises. To be listed, Easdaq companies need have no more than $2.5 million in assets, but they must provide quarterly reporting in accordance with international generally accepted accounting standards. In the Nasdaq Small Capitalization market, by comparison, a company must have $4 million in assets. **********The London Stock Exchange also has a new market: the Alternative Investment Market, or AIM. Set up in June 1995, it has proved a powerful magnet for small, fast-growing companies, with 224 listed so far. **********AIM's performance has been lackluster this year, with an average price increase of just 1 percent, compared with a 13 percent gain on the main London market. But AIM's total capitalization is $7 billion, and it  has raised $1.2 billion in new capital for its companies. **********Across the channel, Paris has followed hard on London's heels, creating its version, Le Nouveau Marche, last February. It trades 15 stocks, with total capitalization of just under $1 billion; the companies have raised $260 million of new capital. **********Small-cap markets are also on the drawing board elsewhere. Frankfurt's stock exchange has said it will set up an easy-to-enter small-cap market, the Neuer Markt, in the first quarter of 1997. Brussels also plans such a market next year, to be called the New Market (an English title because Belgium's linguistic tensions preclude a French or Flemish name). Amsterdam is expected to start one, too. **********Once these markets are running,  they and the Nouveau Marche have agreed to link themselves in a single Europe-wide electronic market, much like Easdaq. The market, with a single set of listing standards, will be called the Euro NM. **********''Euro NM will provide investors with access to a much wider market and companies with access to a bigger circle of investors,'' said Herve de Laitre, a spokesman for Nouveau Marche. **********Many market observers expect Easdaq and Europe's other new  markets to grow appreciably, much as Nasdaq has done in the United States. ''Trends in Europe seem to be fostering more small-cap companies,'' said Tom Troy, a trader with Merrill Lynch in London, noting the move toward economic unification and a lessening of regulations. **********And if the bourses expand, American investors in mutual funds may soon be participating in them. The new markets will give international funds more choice in their investments, said Tracy Stouffer, who manages the Federated International Small Company fund. **********But will the spread of these small bourses mean that European companies will issue fewer American depository receipts, thus depriving American investors of an easy way to diversify into foreign stocks? **********For the moment, that possibility seems slim. ''A.D.R.'s come from much bigger companies than we are seeing on these new markets,'' Ms. Stouffer said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/22/world.body_text: **********Christopher Robin Milne, immortalized as the young friend of Winnie-the-Pooh  in the children's stories of his father, A. A. Milne, has died, The Times of London reported today. He was 75. **********The newspaper said he died on Saturday, but it did not say where he died or give the cause of death. **********Mr. Milne was born in London in 1920 and was known as an adult to resent the melding of his real childhood and the fictional one in his father's tales. **********In 1924, Alan Alexander Milne, already well-known for his light hand at literature and fiction, published a book of verse inspired by his 4-year-old son, "When We Were Very Young." **********His son's affection for a bear named Winnie at the London zoo became the model of hugely successful children's books -- "Winnie-the-Pooh" (1926), "Now We are Six" (1927), and "The House at Pooh Corner" (1928). The stories were later brought to film by Disney. **********In photographs, it was clear how closely A. A. Milne had modeled the fictional Christopher Robin on his son: the same wide, inquisitive brown eyes, the same carefully cropped mop top, the same gingham smock. **********But the grown Christopher Milne displayed a tendency to counter his father's  wishes. He dropped out of Cambridge in 1939 to enlist in the army, and was wounded in Italy during World War II. **********He married a cousin, Lesley de Selincourt, in 1949 -- again, not his father's preference -- and became a bookseller, settling in Stoke Fleming on England's southwestern coast. Together they had a daughter. **********He endured countless parents pressing Pooh books into his hands and asking for an autograph; in return he asked for a donation for his favorite charity, Save the Children. **********His father died in 1956, and Mr. Milne remained silent about the effect of the series' immense popularity on his life until 1974, when he published "The Enchanted Places." It was followed by "The Path Through the Trees" in 1979 and "The Hollow on the Hill" in 1982. **********Mr. Milne described his father as a man who used his small son's youth to stave off his own middle age. **********"When I was three, my father was three," he wrote. "When I was six, he was six," adding "he needed me to escape from being 50." **********He said his father kept his only child at a distance: "His heart remained buttoned up all through his life." **********He also resented the confusing of his childhood with popular legend, and he himself could not remember whether it was the real or fictional Christopher Robin who invented the game of "Pooh sticks," dropping sticks from a wooden bridge into a flowing stream. **********Nonetheless, he was not averse to invoking his own name when he found a cause was worthy, like his efforts to protect Ashdown Forest, which was used as the setting of some of his father's stories. **********He is survived by his wife and daughter. Funeral arrangements were not immediately known.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/30/busin.main_headline: U.S. PC Makers Don't Gain Any Market Share in Japan
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/30/busin.print_headline: U.S. PC Makers Don't Gain Any Market Share in Japan
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/30/busin.body_text: **********Makers of American personal computers stopped gaining market share in Japan last year, having brought about ferocious price competition by their Japanese competitors, a market research firm reported today. **********The NEC Corporation of Japan kept its No. 1 position, and vaulting to second  place was Fujitsu Ltd., which more than tripled its shipments of personal computers in 1995 to 1.05 million, and doubled its market share, to 18.3 percent, the market research firm Dataquest Japan said. **********Apple Computer Inc., which was the second-largest vendor in the market in 1994, dropped to third place in 1995, its market share falling to 14.2 percent from 15.4 percent, according to Dataquest. I.B.M. dropped to fourth from third rank, with its market share holding steady at 10.1 percent. **********Toshiba Ltd. was fifth, and the Compaq Computer Corporation came in sixth place. While Compaq rose from seventh place last year, its market share climbed  only a tad to 3.8 percent from 3.7 percent, Dataquest said. **********Until a couple of years ago, the Japanese personal computer market was a backwater. Prices were high, technological advance was slow and personal computers were not catching on as they were in the United States and Europe. Each vendor had an original design, fragmenting the market. **********But in the last couple of years, the second-largest PC market in the world has undergone a vast transformation. All vendors except NEC and Apple have coalesced around the so-called I.B.M.-compatible standard used in the rest of the world. Prices have plummeted and sales have soared. **********Dataquest, which is based in San Jose, Calif., said PC shipments rocketed 71  percent last year to 5.7 million machines, a number that might be a bit higher than estimates by other market researchers and companies. In monetary terms, the market grew 46 percent, to 1.3 trillion yen, or about $13 billion. **********The event that caused the change was the "Compaq Shock," when Compaq entered  the market in 1992 with machines selling for half the price of equivalent Japanese models. The Dell Computer Corporation quickly followed with similarly aggressive pricing. **********But that shock awoke the sleeping giants of Japan, who reacted by trimming down and slashing their prices. Most aggressive was Fujitsu, which basically bought market share by selling machines at a loss. Fujitsu was in a position to  do that because it was making big profits in computer memory chips. **********NEC, which long held more than 50 percent of the Japanese market, saw its share drop to 40 percent in 1995, despite a 46 percent gain in shipments to 2.28 million units. NEC disputes Dataquest's figures and maintains that it still holds half the market. **********The new vigor of the Japanese vendors has made it hard for the Americans to gain market share, although the American shipments have been rising healthily because of the growth of the overall market. **********Apple, which has a significantly higher market share here than in the United  States, saw its shipments in Japan rise 58 percent, to 810,000 machines in 1995, Dataquest said. However, the severe price competition has knocked the profits out of Apple Japan, contributing to the recent financial difficulties of its parent company. **********Despite the tougher going, newcomers like Gateway 2000, Packard-Bell and Hewlett-Packard are now mounting efforts to sell PC's in Japan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/03/busin.snippet: Jake Petrosino article backs California referendum that would remove legal barriers to class-action suits in cases involving stock fraud and would hold corporate directors and officers personally liable when juries award damages; drawing (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/03/busin.main_headline: California's Proposition 211: Vital Protection for Investors
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/03/busin.print_headline: California's Proposition 211: Vital Protection for Investors
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/03/busin.body_text: **********THE trustees of five large California pension plans have endorsed a referendum on Tuesday's state ballot that would remove prohibitive legal barriers to class-action lawsuits in cases involving stock fraud and would hold corporate directors and officers personally liable when juries award damages. **********It was right for these trustees to support the measure, known as Proposition 211. It was right not only because they have the responsibility to preserve and protect the retirement assets of employees of Los Angeles, San Bernardino, Fresno, Alameda and San Mateo counties, but also because it will help millions of individual investors protect their retirement assets. **********Anyone with responsibility for protecting and preserving retirement assets, be it a huge pension fund or your 401(k) program, has an obligation to endorse the principles of Proposition 211. Securities fraud costs Americans $40 billion a year, according to the Justice Department. No investor -- institutional or individual, large or small, sophisticated or naive -- is immune. **********Indeed, William McLucas, the director of the enforcement arm of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has testified before Congress that securities class-action lawsuits are ''essential'' to maintain protection for investors. **********Meanwhile, the fight over Proposition 211 has evolved into a battle between investors, who need strong protections, and corporate interests that want lower standards of liability for wrongdoing. **********Corporations chant false battle cries for the media. The measure, they say, would encourage frivolous lawsuits or predatory-strike suits whenever a company's stock drops. **********They blow their charging bugles, sounding the notes of factual misstatements: Companies will leave California, they say. Directors and officers will resign, they add.  And the flow of information between corporate management and securities analysts will dry up because corporations will be afraid that their own projections about performance will come back to haunt them. **********Opponents go so far as to contend that Proposition 211 would reduce the number of initial public offerings by high-technology companies, which would fear being exposed to a greater degree of liability. **********Of course, it's all balderdash of mythic proportions; it just isn't true. **********A study by the University of California at Berkeley business school of all listed shares that declined 20 percent or more in price over five-day periods from 1988 through 1990 found that in the 589 cases only 20, or 3.4 percent, resulted in lawsuits against the companies. **********And over the last 20 years, the courts have deemed only one securities class action to be frivolous. If filing meritless cases has become the new national pastime, why haven't we heard of thousands of cases? **********The facts are that the number of securities class actions has averaged only 300 a year for more than 20 years. The administrative office of the Federal courts recorded 305 securities class-action lawsuits filed nationwide in 1974 and 290 filed in 1994. The statistics also show that suits are filed against approximately 120 companies annually, out of more than 14,000 public corporations reporting to the S.E.C. **********In fact, Proposition 211 seeks to discourage frivolous lawsuits even further by establishing the highest preventive standard for any state court system in the United States: the proposal mandates that California courts require the plaintiff in a lawsuit that is found to have no merit to pay the defendant's full expenses. **********And Proposition 211 allows corporations to buy insurance for any liability. Directors' and officers' liability policies already cover them for exposure not indemnified by the corporation. The S.E.C., however, has declared that indemnification for liabilities arising under the securities laws is against public policy. The courts already uphold this position. **********The quantity of information flowing from management to the public and to securities analysts will not be stanched under Proposition 211, but the quality is likely to improve. The measure simply requires that forward-looking statements be made on a reasonable basis of fact and good faith. Is there anyone who would condone statements made on an unreasonable basis and in bad faith? **********As for companies that might be reluctant to go public because it might reduce their ability to get away with wrongdoing, perhaps they should remain privately held. **********Consider the statements Charles Valdes, the chairman of the investment committee of the California Public Employee Retirement System. Although Calpers, the nation's largest pension fund with $100 billion invested on behalf of a million Californians, has remained officially neutral on Proposition 211, a number of its trustees have criticized the campaign against the referendum. **********''The opponents of Proposition 211 behave in the same way a corporation behaves when it deceives investors,'' Mr. Valdes said at a news conference last month. ''They commit a fraud on the public, just as a company commits a fraud on the market.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/19/busin.main_headline: COMPANY REPORTS;General Electric Reports Increase in Earnings
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/19/busin.print_headline: COMPANY REPORTS;General Electric Reports Increase in Earnings
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/19/busin.body_text: **********Led by its NBC broadcasting network and its finance and plastics divisions, the General Electric Company yesterday reported stronger earnings for the fourth quarter. **********Net income rose to $1.865 billion, or $1.12 a share, from $768 million, or 45 cents a share, in the 1994 quarter. Earnings then were held down by the sale of General Electric's Kidder, Peabody brokerage operations -- for which it took  a charge of $868 million -- and another smaller charge. **********The latest net income was 39 percent above the company's operating earnings  of $1.685 billion, or 99 cents a share, in the 1994 quarter. **********For the year, sales increased 17 percent, to $70 billion. Earnings increased  11 percent in 1995 to $6.57 billion, or $3.90 a share. **********Both the quarterly and yearly earnings were in line with the consensus expectations of financial analysts. The shares of General Electric rose $1.125 yesterday to $72.50 on the New York Stock Exchange. **********In a statement, the company said 11 of its 12 business units reported increased earnings. Six of them, including NBC and the plastic and aircraft-engine businesses, reported double-digit increases. The company's electric-power-generation equipment unit was the only one reporting a decline in earnings. **********Russell L. Leavitt, an analyst with Salomon Brothers, described the results as "impressive" particularly because of the "severe collapse" in generating-equipment earnings. **********The company said much of its increase in sales during the year came from international operations. General Electric said its overall operating margin --  or profit -- rose to a record 14.4 percent of sales, from 13.6 percent in 1994. **********"The broad strength of our businesses coupled with our continued emphasis on  globalization, productivity and effective asset-management delivered top-line growth, increased margins and strong cash generation," said the company's chairman, John F. Welch Jr., in a statement. **********Earnings at the company's finance subsidiary, GE Capital Services, increased  16 percent, to $2.41 billion. The company said its specialty insurance and equipment management and two other divisions of GE Capital had double-digit increases in earnings. **********Mr. Welch said the company had expanded aggressively during 1995. He noted that NBC had secured the United States television rights to five of the next six Olympic Games and that its new, high-powered GE90 aircraft engine had been certified for use on the new Boeing 777 airplane.    GE Capital, he said, had made acquisitions in France, Germany, Australia and  Hong Kong and General Electric was expanding its plastics production capacity to include a new plant in Spain to produce products known as polycarbonates. **********Mr. Welch said he expected the company to post another earnings record in 1996. Mr. Leavitt of Salomon Brothers predicted that General Electric's earnings would increase almost 13 percent, to $4.40 a share, for this year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/23/your-.snippet: PROFESSIONAL gamblers sometimes take a portion of their chips off the table when their winnings pile up during a hot streak.That might also be good advice for investors in gaming stocks, given the peaks and valleys in their prices..Trump Hotels
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/23/your-.body_text: **********PROFESSIONAL gamblers sometimes take a portion of their chips off the table when their winnings pile up during a hot streak.That might also be good advice for investors in gaming stocks, given the peaks and valleys in their prices. **********Trump Hotels & Casino Resorts Inc. shares rocketed to $34 from $13.75 last spring and have since tumbled to around $15.Anchor Gaming, one of last year's hottest stocks, is trading around $43, about a third off its 12-month high of $71, and recently plunged $8 in a day on news that it would not expand one of its casinos. **********Analysts point to a number of reasons why gambling stocks are volatile. First, there are seasonal factors: Gambling stocks traditionally do well in the first half of the year as casinos book profits from year-end holiday gambling sprees.Then they underperform in the second half, when casino operators typically announce expansion plans, which might affect earnings. **********Casino stocks also swing wildly on rumors of mergers and acquisitions, such as this year's mergers of Hilton Hotels Corp. with Bally Entertainment Corp. and of Sun International Hotels Ltd. with Griffin Gaming & Entertainment Inc. **********So far this year, the industry has run true to form. The Chicago Board Options Exchange index of 15 big casino operators surged from 217.95 at the end of 1995 to 302.31 at mid-year, but as of Nov. 15, it had relapsed to 231.33. **********All of this means that it may be time to do some bargain-hunting, some analysts say. **********At Deutsche Morgan Grenfell in New York, Maria Vallejo recommended ITT Corp., which owns properties like Caesars Palace in Las Vegas."Its stock has been beat up in the last two months because the casino lost money at the tables," she said. But she is betting that the casino's earnings will improve, noting that more hotel rooms would bring in gamblers and that the company's hotel and information businesses were doing well. **********Other analysts, like William Schmitt of Gerard Klauer Mattison in New York, think a safer way to invest in gaming stocks is with a company like GTech Holdings Corp., which makes, owns and services machines that print out lottery tickets for 65 percent of all U.S. state lotteries.GTech also is part-owner of Camelot Group PLC, operator of Britain's national lottery. **********A different play on casino gambling is shaping up in Australia, where the gaming industry is still in its infancy but expected to grow quickly now that state governments have licensed casinos in their capital cities.In 1993, Australia had only two casinos generating 304 million Australian dollars ($242.4 million), according to Andrew Nichols of Deutsche Morgan Grenfell in Melbourne.By last year, that had grown to five casinos with revenues of 1.6 billion dollars, and he expects that figure to reach 2.5 billion dollars by 2000. **********Mr. Nichols's two top picks are the dominant casino operators in the country's two big Eastern cities, Sydney Harbour Casinos Holding Ltd. and Crown Ltd. in Melbourne. **********"We like Sydney Harbour because it's in Australia's richest city with a 7 percent Asian population that loves gambling, and has the most international tourist arrivals," he said.He favors Crown for its solid management and strong local market in Melbourne, and its plans to expand there.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/24/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;COOPER INDUSTRIES TO SELL STAKE IN COOPER CAMERON
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/24/busin.body_text: **********Cooper Industries said yesterday that it would sell its 14.4 percent stake in the Cooper Cameron Corporation and use the proceeds to reduce debt and finance possible acquisitions. Cooper Cameron shares rose 50 cents yesterday, to $45.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. At that price, the more than 3.6 million shares  owned by Cooper Industries would be worth more than $164 million. Cooper Industries retained the stock when it spun off Cooper Cameron last year. Cooper Industries has filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the stock sale. The filing gives it until June 30, 2000, to sell the shares. Cooper Cameron makes and services equipment used in oil and  gas wells and in power generators.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/11/world.main_headline: Bosnian Mine Is Thought to Hold Evidence of Mass Killings
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/11/world.print_headline: Bosnian Mine Is Thought to Hold Evidence of Mass Killings
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/11/world.body_text: **********The vast open-pit iron mine, the hulks of ore-processing machinery and the bulldozers lie blanketed in snow, but the scene is not abandoned. Outside the gates of the complex, closed for four years, heavily armed soldiers patrol and the dirt roads leading to the heart of the mine are blocked with land mines. **********This mining complex is believed by residents here and Western officials to be the central collection point and hiding place for thousands of corpses that remain from the Bosnian Serbs' campaign of "ethnic cleansing" in northwestern Bosnia. **********The Bosnian Serbs, according to non-Serb miners in the town, are exhuming the remains of victims from numerous mass graves in the area and transferring the bodies to this mine, where they are often mangled in old mining equipment, doused with chemicals and reburied under tons of debris in the open pits. **********The effort to collect the bodies in one central location began late last year, but has picked up as NATO troops move into the area, the townspeople say.  Two American reporters who passed through the gate of the mine and attempted to  make their way by foot toward one pit were arrested by the Bosnian Serb police on Saturday, held for the day, then expelled from the territory. **********Senior British commanders, stationed in the mining town with the NATO force,  say British patrols sometimes find corpses, usually badly decomposed, only to have the bodies whisked away by the Bosnian Serbs, often within hours. They speculate that some of these bodies are from executions carried out last fall by paramilitary forces led by Zeljko Raznatovic, known as Arkan. Others, they say, may date back four years to one of the earliest waves of ethnic killing in  the Bosnian conflict. **********"Everyone seems to be in a hurry to cover their killings," said one senior British commander, who asked to remain unidentified. "There are bodies all over  this place. We go in to houses and find floorboards ripped up and holes in the basement. They are working very hard." **********The Ljubija mine is seen by human rights officials abroad as one of the keys  to documenting the killings in this part of northern Bosnia. Investigators believe the mine, along with a group of suspected mass graves near the Serb-conquered town of Srebrenica, will help prove whether the Bosnian Serbs carried out a deliberate, well-planned policy of genocide against Muslims and Croats living in this region. **********"There was a lot of killing in Ljubija," said Ivan Zvonimir Cicak, the head of the Croatian Helsinki Committee for Human Rights. "We think there may be as many as 8,000 bodies in the mine. We have eyewitness testimony from people who saw the bodies. On top of the bodies they dumped lime. This is probably the largest mass grave in Serb-held Bosnia. **********"We look at the mine as the key to saving Bosnia. We must show that there was a systematic campaign of genocide, and to do this we must get to Ljubija and Srebrenica." **********NATO forces so far show no inclincation to approach the mine or interfere with the Bosnian Serb soldiers there. **********"Our job is to separate forces, not look for mass graves," said Lieut. Col. Benjamin Barry, the commander of the British forces, whose headquarters are a mile from a pit that is said to hold thousands of bodies. "I don't have the resources to go looking for them. It would be a diversion of soldiers from our main goal." **********Those who live in the area, all of whom insisted that they not be identified, said the main pit used to bury bodies is near Stara Rijeka, about five miles south of Ljubija. **********While the exact location of the mass grave site remains unconfirmed, there is much circumstantial evidence that such a grave site exists in the mine area. **********Residents in the town report that during the summer of 1992, busloads of Muslims and Croats, including women and children, went through the gates of the  mine. **********But unlike the Muslims and Croats delivered to the three main concentration camps in the area -- Omarska, the Keraterm tile factory and the railway station  in Trnopolje -- no one ever returned from the Ljubija mine. The mine, townspeople said, was never used as a detention camp, but only as an execution and burial site. **********"The buses would go in day and night," said one resident of the town. "They were filled with people. They always came back from the mine empty. We heard shooting day and night. At first we heard single shots, then we began to hear lots of automatic fire. This went on for over two months." **********Croats who live near the St. Ana Chapel, about 300 yards from the suspected burial pit, said that for several weeks in 1993, they were not permitted by the  Bosnian Serbs to leave their homes or even peer out the windows. **********"Even the Serbs were not permitted to graze their goats in the area," said a  66-year-old retired Croatian miner. "We heard the sounds of many heavy trucks on the road to the pit. When we were finally allowed back outside, the pit looked different. It was full of dirt. There were earthen barricades around the  pit." **********Another Croat who lives near the site said she saw dozens of pairs of sports  shoes on a road near the pit. **********"These were the kinds of shoes our young men wore," she said. **********In the fall of 1992, after news reports about the camps, the Bosnian Serbs disbanded the detention centers. But last fall, as the war began to turn against them, townspeople say, the Bosnian Serbs moved to begin to collect bodies from other grave sites and dump them in a central pit in the Ljubija mine. Residents  say bodies were also collected from various pits in the mine and transferred to  one central location. **********Some who live near the mine said that it was sealed off for a month last fall and that large numbers of Bosnian Serb troops and local miners were used to transfer the bodies to one central pit. **********None of townspeople interviewed admitted to taking part in this, but many residents told identical stories they said they had heard from neighbors and friends who worked in the mines. According to these reports, the bodies were often mangled by machinery used to crush iron ore and were further disfigured by chemicals. And late last year detonations resounded through the town that local  residents say sent tons of earth over the stacks of remains. **********"If you go near the site you are killed," said one resident. "It is strictly  off-limits. There are guards around the pit day and night. There are lots of land mines there." **********The Government offensive this fall was halted just a few miles from the Ljubija mine. Government officials said they had hoped to push their forces into the mining town to capture the mine site. They said much of their reluctance to  halt their offensive was due to their failure to take this objective. **********Despite the presence of NATO troops in the mining town, investigators from The Hague say they are still being refused permission to enter the area around Prijedor. Ljubija is 12 miles south of Prijedor. **********"There were certainly thousands killed at various camps around the Prijedor area," Graham Blewitt, the deputy prosecutor for war crimes at The Hague, said in a telephone interview. "We have never had access to the area. We are hoping we will have access to the area to identify the mass graves, wherever they may be, including any mines."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/27/world.main_headline: U.S. Officials Confident That Mad Cow Disease of Britain Has NotOccurred Here
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/27/world.print_headline: U.S. Officials Confident That Mad Cow Disease of Britain Has NotOccurred Here
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/27/world.body_text: **********Federal officials are confident that the mad cow disease found in Britain has not occurred in the United States and that existing policies are adequate to protect the beef supply. A meeting of 70 animal and public health experts convened by the United States Department of Agriculture reviewed current policies last week and concluded without recommending any further safeguards. **********Nonetheless, the department said it would increase the number of cattle brains routinely tested for mad cow disease. **********The chief reasons for confidence, Agriculture officials say, are that mad cow disease has never been identified in the United States and the incidence of  Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, as the human version of mad cow disease is known, has remained unchanged since 1979. **********This contrasts with the situation in Britain, where there has been an epidemic of mad cow disease that has stricken some 162,000 animals since 1986. Cases of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease in Britain have risen to 55 in 1994 from 28 in 1985, including a cluster of patients more youthful than had previously been  known. Even more striking to British experts than the rising numbers was the change in the microscopic appearance of the diseased nerve cells, a clue that there may be a new variant of the disease. **********British scientists announced last week there was evidence for only a tentative link between mad cow disease and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. But the announcement, coming after years of government denials of any possibility of a link, is likely to focus new attention on this mysterious and previously obscure group of diseases. **********In Britain the disease is believed to have started in sheep, which it afflicts in a form known as scrapie. Until the practice was banned in 1989, British farmers fed rendered sheep parts to cows as a protein supplement, and the disease is believed to have infected cows only through improperly treated sheep parts in this food. **********In sheep, cows and humans, the disease takes the form of slowly attacking the brain, giving it a sponge-like consistency as nerve cells are destroyed. Because the human form of the disease can take many years or even decades to develop, it is possible that many more cases will materialize in Britain than those so far apparent. The scientists who advised the British Government are concerned that the handful of cases identified so far could be the beginning of a larger epidemic. **********Since 1986, when the outbreak of mad cow disease was detected in Britain, many countries have set up monitoring systems to detect it.American officials say that outside Britain, mad cow disease has turned up only in the 10 countries to which Britain exported cattle in the 1980's. In six of those countries, including Canada, the disease did not spread from imported cattle to ones already living in the countries. **********For surveillance, the United States Department of Agriculture is relying on standard techniques used by British health officials. From 1990 through 1995, the department tested 2,660 cattle brains and found evidence of mad cow disease  in none, said Dr. William D. Hueston, a leading expert on the disease at the department. **********The Department of Agriculture has kept careful watch on the 499 cattle imported from Britain before the 1989 ban but has found no cases of mad cow disease. The 116 surviving cattle are still being monitored. **********But at least one expert does not share Dr. Hueston's confidence. He is Dr. Richard F. Marsh of the University of Wisconsin in Madison, who has done research on a disease of mink that resembles mad cow disease. Dr. Marsh notes that scrapie exists among sheep in America, and that sheep offal is sometimes fed to cows here. He would like to see more sophisticated and systematic testing of cows to be sure that mad cow disease is not present. **********"The fact that we have no reported cases of bovine spongiform encephalopathy  in this country is a false sense of security because it is not based on sufficient testing," Dr. Marsh said, referring to the scientific name for the disease. "If the United States ever gets mad cow disease, we will have the same kind of reaction that occurred in Britain." **********The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention does not actively monitor for  Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, which is difficult to diagnose in any case. Epidemiologists say at least a small rise in cases could occur without being noticed. **********Concerns about sheep-to-cow transmission have also risen in the Federal Food  and Drug Administration, which regulates animal feed. In 1994 the agency proposed banning the use of certain sheep offal, a move that was opposed by large segments of the agricultural industry. The agency took no action after risk-assessment studies indicated "that having such a rule will not provide any  value," said Dr. Stephen F. Sundlof, an agency official. But the proposal is now being re-examined in light of the British Government's finding, Dr. Sundlof said, and he expects a decision soon. **********Major sheep producers have voluntarily agreed not to render adult sheep and sell the rendered products for feed in ruminants and cattle. But Federal officials said it was "very difficult" to verify compliance. Dr. Sundlof noted that even if a ban was carried out, there would be no absolute assurance that farmers were complying, in part because there is no way to test a rendered product for sheep parts. **********Dr. Hueston said the Department of Agriculture has carefully studied the sheep-to-cow transmission possibility but has been unable to verify it in the United States, either in theory or practice. Scrapie-infected tissue collected from sheep in this country has been injected into the brains of cattle without causing the damage typical of mad cow disease, suggesting the scrapie agent that infects American sheep may differ from that of British sheep. **********"With all the work we have done in the United States so far, we have not been able to recreate a disease that fits the bovine spongiform encephalopathy picture," Dr. Hueston said. **********The Agriculture Department thus sees no reason for alarm or no threat to the  $36 billion American beef industry. **********There is no evidence from any country that scrapie can be transmitted directly to people who eat lamb or mutton. **********Besides animal feed, another concern of the Food and Drug Administration is the medical products derived from cattle tissue and organs.  The human version of the disease was shown in 1968 to be transmissible through injections and transplants of infected tissue, like corneas or growth hormone, then obtained from the pituitary glands of cadavers. Some three dozen marketed drugs are derived from cattle tissue and organs, and hundreds more contain fractions of cow blood. Gelatin, derived from cow hooves, is an ingredient of many drugs and  is used to make capsules. **********To prevent risk of infection by the mad cow disease agent, the Food and Drug  Administration prohibits the use of bovine material from countries afflicted with mad cow disease. In addition, Dr. Carol Vincent, a Federal Drug Administration official, said the agency did not consider gelatin to be a problem because "the manufacturing process would reduce or eliminate the agent,  if it is present." Dr. Vincent said "it is terribly unlikely that gelatin is going to be a source for" mad cow disease. **********The British scientific committee concluded that gelatin could safely be used  in pharmaceuticals, medical devices and food. **********Nevertheless, the World Health Organization urged last year that a meeting of specialists be held to develop guidelines to minimize the risk of transmitting the agents causing spongiform brain diseases through drugs and medical devices. The meeting is being planned for next fall, but no date has been set. **********Scrapie, mad cow and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease are maladies of unknown cause. The infectious agent seems too small and hardy to be a virus. A leading theory is that abnormal variants of a certain protein cause the diseases. These theoretical variants, known as prions, are thought to convert their normal counterpart proteins into the abnormal form. Since the normal proteins are conjectured to form part of the surface of nerve cells, prion infections show up as brain degenerative diseases. Prions, however, are still conjectural entities. **********Worldwide, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease affects about 1 person in a million, on  average, each year. Doctors know little about how it is spread. While it usually affects older people, a striking factor in the cluster of 10 recent cases in Britain is that the victims were younger than 42, and some were in their teens. **********The British scientific committee that advised the Government said a previously unrecognized and consistent disease pattern had come to light, although one that fell short of clear proof of a link between the cow and human  diseases. **********"In the absence of any credible alternative, the most likely explanation" of  how the Britons contracted Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is that they were exposed to mad cow disease before the British government's ban on feeding sheep offal in 1989, the committee said. It added that though the number of cases was small, they were a "cause for great concern." **********The British Government believes that the chain of transmission of the disease from sheep to cows has now been broken. It is now thought that an important sanitary step in the preparation of sheep parts was omitted during the 1980's. The epidemic of mad cow disease, which peaked in the early 1990's, presumably arose largely from cattle that were infected up until the 1989 ban. Some cows may have been infected since then through lack of compliance with the ban, but the government's position is that younger cows are now essentially free of the disease. **********In humans, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease can resemble Alzheimer's. It produces progressive apathy, irritability, dementia, balance problems and severe muscle spasms. **********Humans and scrapie-infected sheep have co-existed for centuries and there is  no evidence that scrapie is directly transmissible to humans from eating lamb or mutton or that Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease could be a manifestation of scrapie  in humans.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/16/busin.snippet: Hanson PLC says its profits almost tripled to $1.1 billion in its third quarter, and sales were up 11 percent, to $4.6 billion (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/16/busin.body_text: **********The British conglomerate Hanson P.L.C. said yesterday that its profits had almost tripled to more than $1 billion in its third quarter, helped by the sale of several of its businesses.  The company, in the midst of a four-way breakup, said profits for the three months ended June 30 soared to $:713 million ($1.1 billion) from $:252 million. The company said sales for the third quarter were up 11 percent, to $:3 billion ($4.6 billion). **********Hanson said the results included $:608 million ($942.2 billion) in one-time gains from the sale of several units, including Cavenham, Suburban Propane, Ever Ready South Africa and Seven Seas. The company said total proceeds from divestitures now exceeded its target of $:2 billion ($3.1 billion).   (Reuters)

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/30/busin.main_headline: COMPANY NEWS;DUN & BRADSTREET FINDS BUYER FOR CREDIT INSURANCE UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/30/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;DUN & BRADSTREET FINDS BUYER FOR CREDIT INSURANCE UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/30/busin.body_text: **********The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its American Credit Indemnity unit, a credit insurance company. Terms were not disclosed. Dun & Bradstreet, based in Wilton, Conn., said in January that it would sell the business as part of its plan to split into three separate companies. The unit is being sold to ACI Holding Inc., a Baltimore-based concern owned by Compagnie Financiere SFAC of France, a credit insurer, and the investment firm Securitas Capital L.L.C. SFAC acquired a 5 percent stake in American Credit Indemnity in 1992.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/18/busin.main_headline: Steady Rate Policy Is Seen At Fed's Tuesday Meeting
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/18/busin.print_headline: Steady Rate Policy Is Seen At Fed's Tuesday Meeting
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/18/busin.body_text: **********With inflation under control despite low unemployment and a revival in economic growth, the Federal Reserve is almost certain to leave short-term interest rates at current levels when its policy-making body meets on Tuesday, economists say. **********The lack of upward pressure on prices and wages could also persuade the Fed to leave rates unchanged at its subsequent policy meeting in July, the economists say, despite forecasts that growth in the second quarter is likely to accelerate from the unexpectedly robust 2.8 percent annual rate in the first three months of the year. **********The Fed is generally reluctant to stray far from the Main Street view of the economy," said David C. Munro, the chief domestic economist at High Frequency Economics, a consulting firm. That view, he said, is of an economy that is "prosperous but not booming, with remarkably little in the way of price  pressures." **********Salomon Brothers told its clients today that the Fed would probably hold rates steady next week, "reflecting relative contentment with the present economic and inflation backdrop." **********But the outlook for the rest of the year remains extremely unsettled, analysts said. While the current debate is whether the Fed will have to raise rates at some point, there is also the possibility that an expected economic slowdown this fall might provide an opening for the arguments of those business  executives, economists and politicians who contend that Fed policy is too tight. A rate cut, these people say, would bring stronger growth with little risk of inflation. **********The last time the Fed acted -- it reduced the Federal funds rate by a quarter-point, to 5.25 percent, in late January -- the central bankers apparently failed to anticipate the strength of the first-quarter rebound in growth. Those signs of strength produced a sharp run-up in long-term interest rates this year and rekindled fears, so far unfulfilled, of greater inflation. **********The Fed's actions will come under even greater scrutiny than usual in coming  months. Not only will the Presidential campaign leave the Fed open to being second-guessed in an intensely partisan atmosphere, but the renomination of Alan Greenspan as Fed chairman is being held up by Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, a Democrat. **********Mr. Harkin, who contends that Mr. Greenspan is sacrificing economic growth to an overemphasis on stamping out inflation, is holding out for an agreement by the Republican leadership to allow a full Senate debate on monetary policy and a recorded vote, rather than the planned voice vote, on a third four-year term for Mr. Greenspan. Mr. Greenspan's nomination is expected to be approved by a wide margin once it comes to a vote, and he continues to serve in an acting capacity until then. **********The holdup has also frozen the nomination by President Clinton of two new Fed members: Alice M. Rivlin, currently the Administration's budget chief, and Laurence H. Meyer, an economic forecaster. They will not take office until confirmed. **********Amid the debate over the Fed's role, there are also growing pleas from the business community for the Fed to consider that growth may not be as robust as it seems. **********In a survey by the Business Council, a group of chief executives from 100 of  the nation's largest corporations, nearly half the respondents said it was harder to raise prices in their industry than it was six months ago, and only 9  percent said it was easier. Many said their own sales figures did not reflect any significant economic quickening. **********Almost half the respondents urged the Fed to stimulate the economy by cutting rates. "There is absolutely no inflation," said John F. Welch Jr., the chairman  of the General Electric Company. **********"We don't see industrial prices or labor pressures" driving inflation upward, Mr. Welch said. **********Edgar S. Woolard Jr., the chairman of the Du Pont Company, said the Fed should hold rates steady at its meeting next week, but that it should then "err  on the side of testing inflation" later in the year. **********Fed officials have been indicating that they see no strong case for a change  in short-term interest rates, barring some new evidence of overheating. **********"I don't see any driving forces at this time that would take growth on a greatly accelerated path from the trend growth picture that we have been looking for for some time," a Fed governor, Edward W. Kelly Jr., said last week. **********But Fed officials said they were keeping a close eye on wages, which could start rising faster if the current 5.4 percent unemployment rate dips further. They said they were also watching energy prices, which have jumped sharply in recent months but have now started leveling off, and food prices, which could be driven up by rising grain prices. **********While Fed officials said they were not altering their views on inflation, they also gave some indications that they were looking into whether the economy  currently has a greater capacity for noninflationary growth than the statistics  may indicate. For one thing, widespread fears of job insecurity have contributed to an easing of wage demands. **********"I don't think we have the same kind of inflationary psychology that we used  to have," said Susan M. Phillips, a Fed governor.

Walter Thompson Company, owned by the WPP Group.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/15/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Liz Claiborne gets set to pitch a curve to the youth market and hopes it will throw a strike.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/15/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Liz Claiborne gets set to pitch a curve to the youth market and hopes it will throw a strike.
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/15/busin.body_text: **********LIZ CLAIBORNE wants to throw consumers a curve, but they may well be knocked  for a loop. **********The Liz Claiborne Cosmetics division of Liz Claiborne Inc., which has been a  solid if unspectacular performer in the competitive fragrance industry, will begin pursuing the lucrative yet fickle youth market with a line of scents and other products for men and women, to be sold under the brand name Curve. A $5 million advertising and promotional campaign, featuring the first television commercials for any Claiborne fragrance, is imbued with symbols and imagery intended to attract consumers in their 20's. **********You have young men and women who see life as very unpredictable -- the curves -- but they roll with the punches," said Neil J. Katz, the president of Claiborne Cosmetics in New York. "They look forward to what's beyond the curves." **********That attitude is underscored by the theme of the campaign, which was created  by Arnold Communications in Boston: "Curve. See where it takes you." The campaign -- scheduled to begin Sept. 1 and to continue through the holiday shopping season -- will also include a World Wide Web site, campus sampling programs, posters, scent strips and a sweepstakes offering 20 Chrysler Sebring convertibles as prizes. **********Until now, 20-somethings have meant hardly anything to Claiborne Cosmetics, which for the last decade has concentrated on selling fragrances like Vivid, Realities by Liz Claiborne and Claiborne for Men to older consumers. But "when we started to do our research, we found it was important to appeal to what you might call a hipper audience," Mr. Katz said. **********Even so, the scents, body lotions, massage oil sprays and other items to be sold under the Curve brand will also carry the Liz Claiborne or Claiborne names. That poses a problem: Younger consumers might perceive such products in the same way that they might see a line of grungewear bearing the Bill Blass label or those Chrysler Sebrings if they sported DeSoto nameplates. **********Jack Trout, president at Trout & Partners, a marketing consulting company in  Greenwich, Conn., had this advice for Claiborne Cosmetics: "Don't do it. It doesn't sound to me like it's going to be a winner." **********"It's a Liz too far," he added. "To give it any chance, I'd leave the 'Claiborne' off." **********Allan G. Mottus, a consultant in New York who publishes The Informationist, which reports on beauty and health care, echoed Mr. Trout. **********"Unless Curve is in sync with the whole Claiborne imagery," Mr. Mottus said,  "it'll stand out like a sore thumb." He did, however, praise Claiborne Cosmetics for "going where the competition has been," referring to youth-oriented scents like CK One, marketed by the Calvin Klein Cosmetics Company, a unit of Unilever, and the Tommy fragrance, marketed by the Tommy Hilfiger Toiletries Company, a unit of the Estee Lauder Companies. **********Mr. Katz, needless to say, defends flying the Claiborne colors. **********"The brand name is Curve, but Liz Claiborne is an invitation to try," he said. Citing the results achieved by Claiborne clothing, he added: "When you're  selling 60 million garments a year, 40 percent of the apparel business in department stores, it says what's being bought is of high quality and value." **********Kathy Kiely, executive vice president and creative director at Arnold in Boston, agreed. **********"Liz Claiborne is never going to be Calvin Klein," she said, "so we didn't try to do that." She added that while "we didn't completely walk away from the essence of who we are," the idea was to present Curve as "a younger, hipper Liz  Claiborne." **********The campaign is the first work from Arnold since it became the Claiborne Cosmetics agency in November. To signal how different the brand is supposed to be, the television commercials and print ads will appear on cable networks like  MTV and VH1 and in magazines like Car and Driver, Details, George, Spin, Swing and Us. **********The ads are centered on attractive couples indulging in the behavior characteristic of youthful models in contemporary campaigns: standing up backward in moving cars, wearing tank tops to show off their toned bodies and spritzing fragrance into the camera. **********"It's free-spirited, adventurous," Ms. Kiely said. "You're cruising along and suddenly life throws you a curve. And things get very exciting." To "add to that energy," she added, the TV commercials are fast-paced; one has 39 cuts in 30 seconds. **********Asked to contrast the older consumer with the potential Curve buyer, Ms. Kiely said, laughing: "You decide you've had enough of curves. You go into soft-shoulder mode." **********The Curve products, like Claiborne clothing and the other Claiborne Cosmetics lines, will be sold in department stores. Unlike CK One, which has achieved surprising success as a fragrance that comes in the same version for both sexes, Curve will come in separate versions for men and women. **********Packages of Curve for Women are colored what the company describes as periwinkle blue, while Curve for Men will be found in a yellowish hue called citrine. **********In one sense, the use of the name Curve, Claiborne Cosmetics is, well, behind the curve. In January, Deneuve, a magazine for lesbians owned by Outspoken Enterprises, was renamed Curve.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/03/world.main_headline: Walesa Back at Shipyard to Work, or Get a Pension
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/03/world.print_headline: Walesa Back at Shipyard to Work, or Get a Pension
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/03/world.body_text: **********Chauffeured in a black Mercedes and wearing a suit, former President Lech Walesa turned up at the shipyard here today, ostensibly to reclaim his old job as an electrician. **********But as his mode of arrival suggested, Mr. Walesa did not appear very serious  about work. Not even a brand new set of eight red-handled screwdrivers brought by his favorite Roman Catholic priest, the Rev. Henryk Jankowski, persuaded Mr.  Walesa to don overalls and pick up tools. **********Instead, he chatted with the management of the financially troubled shipyard for which the Government has just announced it is seeking a buyer. And he held a news conference, saying he was not sure whether his political obligations would  meld with the daily grind at the yard. **********"If I can't couple the two things I will ask for another year of leave," said Mr. Walesa. **********In fact, Mr. Walesa, who as an electrician started the Solidarity movement that brought down the Communists and propelled him into the presidency, came back to the shipyard as a way of forcing the Government to settle the question of his pension. **********Mr. Walesa lost his attempt at re-election last November to a former Communist, Aleksander Kwasniewski. Since then, he has established a research center in Warsaw to help him mold center and right-of-center political parties into a viable opposition. He leaves next week for a fund-raising lecture tour in the United States. **********Mr. Walesa said today that if Parliament approves a bill to provide him a $2,260 monthly pension as an ex-President, he would not work at the shipyard, where his salary would be $350. **********President Kwasniewski said last week that he expected Parliament to pass the  bill shortly and that he would sign it immediately. **********Mr. Walesa's return to the yard was not widely welcomed at a time when other  matters are much on the employees' minds. The unions have agreed to the layoffs  of 2,000 of the yard's 7,300 employees and the Government placed newspaper advertisements today seeking international buyers for its 60 percent share in the yard. There were no greeters as Mr. Walesa sped through the gates. **********Others expressed embarrassment over Mr. Walesa's return. "It's a stupid thing," Roman Hebel, 55, a technician, said as he arrived for the 6 A.M. shift,  half an hour before Mr. Walesa showed up. "In what democratic country does a president come back to a job like this? He just wants to prove something about his pension." **********But some in the shipyard did their best to make Mr. Walesa feel at home. Marian Zolciak, who is in charge of clothing for workers, specially ordered a new pair of overalls, flannel shirt, cap and shoes, all to Mr. Walesa's measurements. **********Mr. Walesa was assigned his old locker -- the fourth one in the second row from the window -- and the grime and bits of dirty snow were scraped away from his work area. Even his old tool shelf had been repainted, awaiting the ex-electrician.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/22/busin.main_headline: When Fraud Truly Stings: Smaller Bank as Target
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/22/busin.print_headline: When Fraud Truly Stings: Smaller Bank as Target
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/22/busin.body_text: **********For a banker, what could be worse than discovering that you may have lent to  a fraud? **********Answer: When that money represents the biggest loan on the books. **********The Signet Banking Corporation's $81 million in loans, in connection with what seems like a scheme worthy of a detective novel, represents the largest exposure on the books of the midsize bank based in Richmond. And the loan was well in excess of the bank's $50 million internal limit, Gordon Layfield 3d, Signet's senior executive vice president, said yesterday. **********Signet had intended to sell the $31 million of the loan in excess of its limit to other banks, Mr. Layfield said. And it now expects to get back a significant part of the loan from funds that have been recovered. **********Still, banking experts say, Signet's experience underscores the importance of traditional discipline at a time that competitive pressure is tempting banks to  stretch ever further in search of profit. **********"This always happens," said Thomas K. Brown, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "People who make loans out of policy learn that those loans come back to bite them." **********The $81 million was only part of more than $300 million in loans that the F.B.I. says a former employee of the Philip Morris Companies, Edward J. Reiners, obtained fraudulently over two years from eight banks. On Tuesday, the F.B.I. arrested Mr. Reiners, charging him with weaving a complex tale of a secret Philip Morris project that required the money to lease computers to develop an alternative to cigarettes. **********Of course, it is impossible to completely prevent fraud or other unexpected losses. But the other banks involved in the apparent scheme, like Nationsbank, the Bank of Montreal and Corestates Financial, are far larger and better able to withstand a financial shock than Signet. **********The bank, with assets of $11 billion, does not number among the nation's 50 largest. And the $81 million loan represents 9.4 percent of its equity. The legal lending limit is 15 percent of equity, or $128 million in Signet's case -- although most banks seek to keep loans far below their legal limit. Put another  way, $81 million represents 38 percent of Signet's pretax profit last year. **********Signet officials said that the size of the loan appeared to be justified by the stability of Philip Morris, with which they believed they were doing business. "We are dealing with what we thought was a Fortune 100 company with an outstanding rating," Mr. Layfield said. **********Yet in this case, the deal may well have been too good to be true. Companies  as big as Philip Morris rarely borrow from any bank, let alone one as small as Signet, typically choosing to instead go to Wall Street, where they can tap investment banks' and brokerage houses' substantial bond and commercial-paper offerings. When they do borrow from commercial banks, companies of this size pay rates so low that the banks often make loans at a loss to try to get other, more profitable business from those companies. **********So it would have been unusual for Signet to get any business from Philip Morris, especially so much that Signet had to arrange a syndicate of other lenders. And this sort of syndication activity was highly unusual for Signet, which, analysts say, should have perhaps been another warning sign. **********"That loan should have had more scrutiny, especially for something of that size," said Livia S. Asher, an analyst with Merrill Lynch. "The big question is  what is going on with their internal controls." **********Mr. Layfield flatly rejected the suggestion that there was any flaw in Signet's controls. "I don't think there is any evidence that the system broke down," he said. "When you are involved in a fraudulent transaction of this nature, with this degree of sophistication, I'm not sure any bank has the systems that could always protect you." Mr. Layfield added that there was no evidence that any Signet employees were involved in the apparent fraud. **********In retrospect, there were some relatively simple acts in the oversight process here that might have uncovered fraud. The scheme unraveled last week when an executive at the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, another lender involved, contacted Philip Morris to verify a document that purported to authorize the loans and was told that the signature was a forgery and the documents were not valid, the F.B.I. says. **********Banking experts say that no matter how complex the financial world becomes, the basic rules of banking still apply, such as "know your borrower." **********"For any kind of big credit exposure, it's very important for the lender to go out and personally check the tires," said Rodgers L. Harper, a corporate-loan expert with the First Manhattan Consulting Group. "You want to meet the guy in his office to have a sense he's on the up-and-up, and if it's a big deal, you want to meet several people." **********Standard & Poor's, the debt-rating agency, said yesterday that it was considering lowering Signet's bond rating -- already just BBB-, one rung above junk-bond status. **********"The ultimate financial costs to Signet include not only direct credit losses, but also legal expenditures and collection-related costs, which are also unquantified," S.& P. said in a statement "Additionally, issues related to Signet's risk-management process need to be clarified." **********And other analysts said the incident underlined uncertainty about a move by Signet into uncharted territory with a consumer product known as Loan-By-Check.  Signet is mailing bank checks for $7,500 to consumers nationwide; by endorsing and cashing the check, the consumer agrees to an installment loan. **********Still, Signet is widely considered to have some of the most advanced computer technology for evaluating and making consumer loans, and some investment brokers, including Goldman, Sachs and J. P. Morgan, have reiterated their buy recommendations on the company's stock despite the fraud case. **********The case comes at a time government regulators and banking leaders have begun to worry that lending standards have become too lax. Last week, Tom Ripke, chairman of Robert Morris Associates, a trade group for commercial lenders, called for tighter standards. **********"Trading lower underwriting standards for improved loan growth can lead to serious problems in future quarters and years," he wrote to 3,000 banks. Among the issues Mr. Ripke raised was whether banks were making more exceptions to their own policies. **********"Experienced bank credit officers are concerned," he said in a statement released with the letter. "We have a feeling, an intuition, that C.E.O.'s need to be extra vigilant, especially in these good times, to insure sound credit quality standards are maintained." **********The bankers' graveyard is filled with institutions that did not ask enough questions in the face of what seemed to be lucrative opportunities, banking experts say. Most notably, fraudulent oil-patch loans distributed by the Penn Square bank in Oklahoma ultimately forced a Government bailout of Continental Illinois. **********The Penn Square case raised another issue that may emerge for Signet: the role of banks that buy into loans originated by other banks. The contracts in such deals are clear that each bank is responsible for conducting its own due-diligence investigation and credit analysis of a borrower. **********But, in practice, bankers often make decisions quickly to take part in syndicated loans, especially for companies like Philip Morris that are household names, and they often depend on the lead bank to conduct most of the investigation.

The discount and Lombard rates were each lowered a half-percentage point on April 18, to 2.5 percent and 4.5 percent, respectively. The Lombard rate is the rate at which banks borrow emergency overnight funds from the central bank. The discount rate is the cheapest form of central bank refinancing.   (AP)
