https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/25/busin.body_text: **********Olivetti shares dropped yesterday after the Italian computer and office products company late on Tuesday forecast a wider-than-expected loss for 1995. The company said it expected to lose 1.55 trillion lire ($1 billion) in 1995, as costs to reorganize its computer unit and dismiss workers surpassed expectations. The company had a pretax loss from operations of 500 billion lire  and one-time charges of 1.05 trillion. **********Olivetti shares fell 66 lire, to 993, bucking the broader market's rally. The price fell below 1,000 lire for the first time since last month.   (Bloomberg Business News)

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/28/busin.main_headline: MUTUAL FUNDS;INVESTING WITH: Christopher H. Wiles
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/28/busin.print_headline: MUTUAL FUNDS;INVESTING WITH: Christopher H. Wiles
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/28/busin.body_text: **********THE current stock market, dipping and swaying as it is, "is our kind of market," says Christopher H. Wiles, manager of the Federated Equity-Income fund. "It's like shopping in a nice jewelry store and all of a sudden they've got a blue-light special on Rolex watches." **********But that doesn't mean Mr. Wiles is taking undue risk. In fact, equity income  is the most conservative style of stock investing, and Mr. Wiles considers it his job to keep as much risk out of the Federated Equity-Income fund as he can. **********There are three principal risks in managing an equity portfolio, and I avoid two of them," Mr. Wiles said. He characterized the first as market timing, which he shuns by typically holding a minimal 2 percent or 3 percent of the $508.2 million portfolio as cash. The second, he said, is "trying to forecast what sectors are going to be the hottest." Since that's impossible, he asserts,  his portfolio is sector neutral, matching the industry weightings of his benchmark, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. **********"The third risk is company risk, or picking individual securities, and that's the risk I'm willing to assume," he said. "I try to ignore the market's noise and focus on the best securities." **********That approach has rewarded shareholders of the fund, which has been run since its inception in 1986 by Federated Investors of Pittsburgh but carried the Liberty name until April. Before Mr. Wiles took it over in 1991, the portfolio consistently lagged behind its peers, by an average of a quarter percentage point a year. Over the last three years, through Thursday, the class A shares performed 1.2 percentage points better than the fund's peers, according to Morningstar, the fund researchers. And in the five years through June 30 since Mr. Wiles became manager, the class A shares have topped their rivals by an average of three points annually, said Matthew Muehlbauer, research manager of the Value Line Mutual Fund Survey. **********"He tends to hold 60 issues so he can keep up his intensive research," Mr. Muehlbauer said, referring to the relatively few holdings. **********Mr. Wiles says he picks stocks based on four qualities: good corporate management, high return on equity, attractive valuation and what he called "some secular growth characteristics." He likes stainless steel at the moment, he said, because the demand for it is growing more rapidly than for ordinary steel. **********He also looks for relatively high, and growing, dividends. Equity-income funds generally offer higher yields than other stock portfolios. The Federated fund typically holds 30 to 35 percent of the portfolio in convertible securities, which yield more than common but can be exchanged for it later. **********He noted a convertible issued by Sun America Life Insurance, a leader in the  annuity business. The convertible is yielding 4.2 percent, more than four times  the common stock's 1 percent. If Sun America's common rises 25 percent, the convertible will rise 24 percent, Mr. Wiles said, but if the common falls that amount, the convertible will probably drop only about 10 percent. So on a move of this size, "you get almost all of the upside potential of the stock and less  than half of the downside," he said. **********Taking advantage of the buying opportunities in the current market gyrations, Mr. Wiles has reduced cash to 1.5 percent of assets, adding to positions in beaten-down companies like AT&T, and creating new ones for other battered securities, like MFS Communications, a long-distance reseller, and SCI Systems,  a maker of electronic components. **********A Stake in Steel **********One of Mr. Wiles's biggest positions is in Allegheny Ludlum, the industry leader in stainless steel. Because stainless does not rust, it has a longer life expectancy than ordinary steel, and its use is increasing in high-consumption industries like automobiles and construction. "Their earnings have been growing  around 15 percent a year," he said of Allegheny Ludlum, "and I expect growth over the next five years to average 13 percent to 14 percent." **********Allegheny Ludlum is acquiring Teledyne, an even larger producer of high-end specialty metals, predominantly for the aerospace industry. Although the deal is for stock, Mr. Wiles said it would not be dilutive but would instead add substantial earnings per share. **********The steelmaker also buys back shares periodically. At the current price of $18.50 , the stock is yielding 3.5 percent. **********A Toy Story Another of Mr. Wiles's top picks is Tyco Toys, a distant and out-of-favor competitor to Hasbro and Mattel. While the shares of those two companies trade at 1 and 2 times, respectively, their annual sales per share, Tyco's share price is just 25 percent of sales. The stock closed Friday at $4.875 a share. **********Tyco is a potential turnaround, Mr. Wiles said, and new management took over  earlier this year. Tyco is a leader in two toy types, remote-controlled cars and the small model cars it sells under the Matchbox name. The new management is seeking stock-car racing tie-ins for these lines. **********"If they're successful with the turnaround, the stock should trade into the $8 or $9 range," Mr. Wiles said. "If they're not, we feel it would be a very attractive acquisition candidate, again around the $8 level." **********The manager sees relatively little risk in Tyco stock, in part because the company sold almost $100 million of convertible preferred stock last month, using the proceeds to pay down debt and bolster its balance sheet. Indeed, the Federated fund bought Tyco in the form of that convertible, which is now trading at $5.50 a share and has a coupon of 8.25 percent until it matures in 2000, when it must be exchanged for the common. **********Mr. Wiles said the strong link to the common meant his investment reflected his basic outlook for the company. **********When the Smoke Rises **********The Federated fund's No. 1 holding, at 2.8 percent of assets, is Philip Morris, now at the center of the national debate over tobacco. "If I told you about this company's numbers," he said, "and didn't talk about what it does for  a living, you would say, 'Wow! That sounds really good.' " **********Philip Morris, which owns Miller Brewing and Kraft Foods as well as cigarette brands, "is No. 1 or No. 2 in every market they serve," Mr. Wiles said. "Their expected earnings growth for the next five years is 16 percent," he added, but their current price-earnings ratio, based on 1996 estimated earnings, is 13. Coca-Cola, which has the same kind of brand-name power in its markets, trades at a multiple of 30 times 1996 estimated earnings, he noted. **********"Absent the controversy, this would be a $250 stock," he said of Philip Morris, which closed Friday at $102.125 . "It won't get that kind of value, considering the risks, but I think it will get to the $130 to $140 area." **********The risks, of course, are that a court might find Philip Morris and other cigarette makers liable for the cancer deaths of their customers. Mr. Wiles noted that Philip Morris had never lost such a lawsuit. **********Philip Morris has been buying back shares and has raised its dividend an average of 18 percent in each of the last five years, to a current yield of nearly 4 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/07/world.snippet: European Union extracts agreement from defiant Bosnian Croat politicians to honor local election results, thus allowing European reconstruction efforts to continue in battered and divided city of Mostar; map (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/07/world.main_headline: Divided Bosnia City's Croats Agree to Honor Vote Results
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/07/world.print_headline: Divided Bosnia City's Croats Agree to Honor Vote Results
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/07/world.body_text: **********After weeks of intense haggling, the European Union extracted an agreement today from defiant Bosnian Croat politicians to honor local election results, thus allowing European reconstruction efforts to continue in this battered and partitioned city. **********The deal was greeted with relief among State Department officials. They worried that the repudiation of municipal polling results -- in this case favoring Bosnian Muslims over Bosnian Croats -- would set an unacceptable precedent for the nationwide elections scheduled for next month. **********But European officials who have been administering Mostar for two years acknowledge that the agreement was partly a face-saving mechanism. **********The heavy lobbying needed to resolve a seemingly minor issue included a White House lecture from President Clinton to the President of Croatia, Franjo Tudjman, to push the stray Bosnian Croats into line. That does not bode well for the future of the larger Bosnian-Croat Federation, officials here said. **********Mostar, a traditional exemplar of Bosnian tolerance, was riven by ''ethnic cleansing'' during the war between Bosnia's Muslims and Croats. The city was supposed to come together during the European Union's tenure here. **********A reunited city, it was hoped, would be the paragon for the federation, which is intended under the Dayton peace accords to be the counterweight to the Bosnian Serbs' self-styled republic, in a multi-ethnic Bosnia. **********But with Mostar split along ethnic lines and virtually none of the refugees who were uprooted by the fighting here returning to their homes, the city looks like anything but an uplifting model. **********The European Union threatened to pull out of Mostar if the Croats did not agree to ratify the election results. But the European Union is at the end of its work here anyway. **********In its remaining five months, the union is set to spend about $25 million, completing projects but not starting new ones, said the spokesman in Mostar, Dragan Gasic. Already, senior officials like engineers and economists are leaving, he said. **********When the union officials leave in December they say they will hand over all responsibilities to the joint municipal council that the Croats have tried to make inoperable. **********The European Union has poured more than $200 million into Mostar, rebuilding war-shattered schools, hospitals, water systems and traffic lights. At the peak of activity, more than 350 Europeans worked here, including 180 European police officers supervising trial inter-ethnic police patrols. **********Nestled in a mountainous canyon, with the jade-green Neretva River flowing through it, Mostar has about 60,000 residents about evenly divided between Muslims and Croats. The internationally admired 400-year-old stone Mostar bridge, which spans the river at its narrowest point, was pummeled by Bosnian Croat artillery and remains at the bottom of the river. **********A thin, swaying walkway put up by the European Union, perhaps a symbol of the frayed state of affairs here, replaces it. **********In the western side of the city, controlled by the Bosnian Croat politicians, some 7,000 Muslims remain, although demobilized Croatian soldiers continue to throw Muslim families out of their homes, Western officials say. **********On the eastern side of the city the inhabitants are virtually all Muslim, many of them evicted from their homes on the west side during the 1993 war. The European officials, who have been struggling to persuade Bosnian Croats to agree to joint city projects with the Muslims, say the most difficult task has been psychological healing. It mostly has not been accomplished. **********''When it comes to tangible projects -- bridges, schools -- obstacles are rare,'' said Howard Fox, a British adviser to the inter-ethnic police force. ''When you demand spiritual unification like a police force or a city council, the will to unify disappears. The idea of recreating the old Mostar is an idea of nostalgia.'' **********Many Muslims and Croats agree with this outsider view. They say that in many ways the two cultures are springing away from each other, intent on preserving separate identities. Both sides are becoming self-sufficient -- with working telephones, their own police forces, separate schools, different license plates and distinctive currency. So there appears to be less and less need for people to cross into each other's territory. **********Election day on June 30, when many uprooted Muslim residents now living on the east side of the river returned to their old polling places on the west side, was the first time there was significant movement of people across the boundaries. **********But it was only because of a security blanket provided by NATO-led troops that there was so much traveling and virtually no incidents of violence, election monitors said. **********And the reception in old neighborhoods was often frigid. A young woman who was one of the few pedestrians walking across the city's dividing line today said she had returned for the first time since the war to her old address for the election. **********''When I came to vote, the people who pushed me out were in the polling place,'' she said, refusing to give her name. ''They knew what they had done, and when they saw me they were not pleased.'' **********She said she visited the west side to organize business for her store almost daily but made her meetings there as brief as possible. ''After the elections I thought I would feel safer,'' she said. ''But I am afraid. I don't think I would get any help if I were attacked.'' **********After 18 months of trying, the European Union gave up on the idea of inter-ethnic schools. The two sides now have separate schools with separate curriculums in social studies, history and music. On the west side, the courses are taught in Croatian; on the east side in a language being forged as Bosnian. **********''I've always said that if people want to have their own nation and language, they should have it,'' said Jure Musa, the minister of education, sports and culture in West Mostar. ''And that's what we are doing here.'' **********The situation in the city was summed up well by the Mostar Arts Festival last month. **********Akis Brkic, 60, a sculptor who has lived in the city all his life, was showing his wood and stone works in a gallery on the east side of the city today. More than 100 visitors came to the opening day of his exhibit, he said. **********''I live for the day when the city won't be divided,'' Mr. Brkic said. ''We had hoped for Croatian artists to participate in the festival -- just like it used to be. But they didn't come.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/01/busin.main_headline: Sorting Out Ups and Downs of the Nasdaq
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/01/busin.print_headline: Sorting Out Ups and Downs of the Nasdaq
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/01/busin.body_text: **********Has the summer technology slump returned to Wall Street? **********The slide in the Nasdaq composite index earlier this month convinced many analysts that the annual selloff -- conspicuous by its absence last year -- was  back. **********But then technology stocks rallied on Thursday and Friday, sending the index back up nearly 3 percent since Wednesday's close. That is still down more than 5 percent, however, from the Nasdaq index's record-high close on June 5. **********"We've seen this dance before," said Laura Conigliaro, a computer hardware and software analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York. "People get fed up and say, 'I never want to see these stocks again' and a lot of good stocks get thrown out with the bath water. Then it all comes back. Sometimes it gets as bad as people throwing out a stock one week and then buying it back the next." Some of that bounce may have been at work late last week, when the stocks of several technology companies, including Hewlett-Packard, Digital Equipment and Storage Technology, largely recovered after falling steeply earlier in the week. For most of the 1980's and into the early 90's, many investors would sell off their technology holdings in the late spring, when corporate spending on computers and other equipment slowed, and would begin buying again in the fall,  when capital spending picked up. The striking exception came last summer, when anticipation of Microsoft's Windows 95 software operating system and the expectation of record Christmas-season sales of personal computers lifted the entire sector to new heights. At that time, many analysts talked about a new level of sustained demand for key components like semiconductors, ending that industry's painful boom-and-bust cycles. But almost as soon as those words were uttered last fall the bottom fell out of the chip market. And yet, by early June, investor infatuation with technology stocks in general had helped send the Nasdaq index to new heights. Then came what looked suspiciously like a return of the summer slump. **********For 8 of 10 trading sessions in mid- and late June, the Nasdaq Composite fell and other high-technology stock indexes plunged with it. Analysts attribute the  selloff mainly to investors who had believed predictions that a weak first quarter for technology companies, like computer and disk drive makers, would be  followed by a strong recovery but who had finally abandoned that hope. Some analysts argue that if the high-tech slump is back this year it is for reasons that have little to do with the technology industry's old pattern of seasonality. Rather than a summer slump, they say, the recent downturn may be largely a result of an inventory glut that is the hangover from last year's technology binge. According to this version of events, the story began in 1994, when surprisingly  strong sales caused many personal computer companies to run out of vital components. Fearing a repeat in 1995, and whipped up by the hype surrounding the August introduction of Windows 95, PC makers began double- and triple-ordering components in the spring of 1995. That led to record sales for many suppliers, setting off a big round of investment in new plants to meet the heavy demand. But when sales of computers turned out to be merely strong, not spectacular, many companies were left with large inventories of components. "We had hoarding mentality last year because the lead time on chips was 15 to 20 weeks compared to 4 to 6 weeks in normal times," said Tom Kurlak, a semiconductor analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company in New York. Executives at semiconductor and disk drive makers who thought the excess inventory would be used up by the end of the first quarter have been unpleasantly surprised. While sales of personal computers have remained strong,  sales of components have stayed weak, indicating that there was a lot more excess inventory than many people believed. "The scale of the inventory problem was quite a bit larger than people thought," said Drew Peck, an analyst with Cowen & Company in Boston. "You can find excess  inventory in every nook and cranny of the PC business throughout the world." Over the last few weeks, several technology companies, including the chip makers Advanced Micro Devices and Cyrix and the disk drive maker Quantum, have issued statements warning that they will not be meeting Wall Street's earnings estimates for the quarter that just ended. Other companies, especially memory chip makers like Samsung, Hyundai and Texas Instruments, have announced that they are suspending expansion plans or cutting production. At the same time, analysts have cut estimates for the more established technology stocks, like I.B.M., Hewlett-Packard, and Digital Equipment, in advance of their second-quarter earnings because of reportedly weak sales in Europe. In addition, a strong dollar, which contributes to weak overseas sales,  also makes overall earnings appear weaker because they are calculated in dollar  terms. The resulting decline in technology stocks began to pick up its own momentum earlier this month as fund managers moved to bail out of the stocks before the end of the month so that the quarterly snapshot of their holdings seen by investors would not include a heavy exposure to the declining technology sector. But now that such window dressing has come to an end, will technology stocks begin to pick up again? If the Nasdaq closes of last Thursday and Friday are any indication, the recovery may have already begun. But many analysts think that the next quarter will also be weak. Still, they are optimistic that the business will start to recover toward the end of the year and will be strong in 1997. "This is the final give-up phase in this down cycle," Mr. Kurlak of Merrill Lynch said. "This summer should represent the bottom. Inventory liquidation has  gone as low as it can go." However, the only company he is recommending is the Intel Corporation, the maker of more than 80 percent of the microprocessors that form the heart of personal computers. Mr. Kurlak said that Intel was six months ahead of schedule reaching mass production of its new Pentium Pro chip, which he predicted would help drive a new round of computer sales to corporate buyers starting next year. That, in turn, should lift personal computer makers like Compaq Computer, I.B.M. and Dell Computer. **********Other analysts agree, but they warn that a recovery for the memory chip industry, which is plagued by overcapacity, may be a long time in coming. That should help makers of personal computers and cellular telephones, who use many of the chips, pull out of the current slump later this year. "The memory chip business will suffer for a quite a while," said Mr. Peck, the Cowen & Company analyst, added, "but my sense is that the rest of the technology industry will return to normalcy."

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/21/busin.snippet: National Semiconductor Corp, struggling with falling computer chip sales, to cut 170 more jobs, mostly in California; will take $280 million to $320 million charge against earnings in current quarter (S)

https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/21/busin.print_headline: NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR TO CUT 170 ADDITIONAL JOBS
https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/21/busin.body_text: **********The National Semiconductor Corporation said yesterday that it would cut 170 jobs, mostly in California, as it struggles with falling sales of its computer chips. The cuts are the third in three months, bringing the number of jobs to be eliminated to 590. The company has 20,000 employees. The company also expects to take a charge of $280 million to $320 million against earnings in its current quarter. National Semiconductor is based in Santa Clara, Calif.
